0	"Rose Garden
5:35 P.M. EDT
MR. BARDEN: Hello. My name is Mark Barden. Just four months ago
column2: my wife Jackie and I lost our son
column3: and our children
column4: James and Natalie
column5: they lost their little brother Daniel. Daniel was a first-grader at Sandy Hook Elementary School. Our sweet
column6: 7-year-old Daniel was one of 20 children
column7: six adults lost on December 14th. I have to say it feels like it was just yesterday.

column1: In our deepest grief
column2: we were supported by the love of our families and comforted by the love and prayers we received from millions of America
column3: from every corner of the country.

column1: What happened in Newtown can happen anywhere. In any instant
column2: any dad in America could be in my shoes. No one should feel the pain. No one should feel our pain or the pain felt by the tens of thousands of people whoÃ¢ÂÂve lost loved ones to senseless gun violence.

column1: And that's why we're here. Two weeks ago
column2: 12 of us from Newtown came to meet with U.S. senators and have a conversation about how to bring common-sense solutions to the issues of gun violence. We came with a sense of hope
column3: optimistic that real conversation could begin that would ultimately save the lives of so many Americans. We met with dozens of Democrats and Republicans and shared with them pictures of our children
column4: our spouses
column5: our parents who lost their lives on December 14th.

column1: Expanded background checks wouldn't have saved our loved ones
column2: but still we came to support the bipartisan proposal from two senators
column3: both with Ã¢ÂÂAÃ¢ÂÂ ratings from the NRA -- a common-sense proposal supported by 90 percent of Americans. ItÃ¢ÂÂs a proposal that will save lives without interfering with the rights of responsible
column4: law-abiding gun owners.

column1: We'll return home now
column2: disappointed but not defeated. We return home with the determination that change will happen -- maybe not today
column3: but it will happen. It will happen soon. We've always known this would be a long road
column4: and we don't have the luxury of turning back. We will keep moving forward and build public support for common-sense solutions in the areas of mental health
column5: school safety
column6: and gun safety.

column1: We take strength from the children and loved ones that we lost
column2: and we carry a great faith in the American people.

column1: On behalf of the Sandy Hook Promise
column2: I would like to thank President Obama
column3: Vice President Biden for their leadership and for standing strong and continuing to fight for a safer America. I would like to thank Senators Toomey
column4: Manchin
column5: Schumer and Kirk on coming together to seek common ground on legislation that would keep guns out of the hands of criminals and save lives.

column1: And I would like to thank ConnecticutÃ¢ÂÂs Senators Blumenthal and Murphy. TheyÃ¢ÂÂve been right with us. They stood by us right from the very beginning. From the first few hours after this tragedy they were with us.
We will not be defeated. We are not defeated
column2: and we will not be defeated. We are here now; we will always be here because we have no other choice. We are not going away. And every day
column3: as more people are killed in this country because of gun violence
column4: our determination grows stronger.

column1: We leave Washington hoping that others
column2: both here and across the country
column3: will join us in making the Sandy Hook Promise
column4: a pledge that we'd had great hope that more U.S. senators would take literally. I'd like to end by repeating the words with which the Sandy Hook Promise begins: Our hearts are broken. Our spirit is not.

column1: Thank you. It is now my great pleasure to introduce the President of the United States of America
column2: Barack Obama.

column1: THE PRESIDENT: A few months ago
column2: in response to too many tragedies -- including the shootings of a United States Congresswoman
column3: Gabby Giffords
column4: whoÃ¢ÂÂs here today
column5: and the murder of 20 innocent schoolchildren and their teachers Ã¢ÂÂ- this country took up the cause of protecting more of our people from gun violence.

column1: Families that know unspeakable grief summoned the courage to petition their elected leaders Ã¢ÂÂ- not just to honor the memory of their children
column2: but to protect the lives of all our children. And a few minutes ago
column3: a minority in the United States Senate decided it wasnÃ¢ÂÂt worth it. They blocked common-sense gun reforms even while these families looked on from the Senate gallery.

column1: By now
column2: itÃ¢ÂÂs well known that 90 percent of the American people support universal background checks that make it harder for a dangerous person to buy a gun. WeÃ¢ÂÂre talking about convicted felons
column3: people convicted of domestic violence
column4: people with a severe mental illness. Ninety percent of Americans support that idea. Most Americans think that's already the law.

column1: And a few minutes ago
column2: 90 percent of Democrats in the Senate just voted for that idea. But itÃ¢ÂÂs not going to happen because 90 percent of Republicans in the Senate just voted against that idea.

column1: A majority of senators voted Ã¢ÂÂyesÃ¢ÂÂ to protecting more of our citizens with smarter background checks. But by this continuing distortion of Senate rules
column2: a minority was able to block it from moving forward.

column1: IÃ¢ÂÂm going to speak plainly and honestly about whatÃ¢ÂÂs happened here because the American people are trying to figure out how can something have 90 percent support and yet not happen. We had a Democrat and a Republican -Ã¢ÂÂ both gun owners
column2: both fierce defenders of our Second Amendment
column3: with Ã¢ÂÂAÃ¢ÂÂ grades from the NRA -- come together and worked together to write a common-sense compromise on background checks. And I want to thank Joe Manchin and Pat Toomey for their courage in doing that. That was not easy given their traditional strong support for Second Amendment rights.

column1: As they said
column2: nobody could honestly claim that the package they put together infringed on our Second Amendment rights. All it did was extend the same background check rules that already apply to guns purchased from a dealer to guns purchased at gun shows or over the Internet. So 60 percent of guns are already purchased through a background check system; this would have covered a lot of the guns that are currently outside that system.

column1: Their legislation showed respect for gun owners
column2: and it showed respect for the victims of gun violence. And Gabby Giffords
column3: by the way
column4: is both -- sheÃ¢ÂÂs a gun owner and a victim of gun violence. She is a Westerner and a moderate. And she supports these background checks.

column1: In fact
column2: even the NRA used to support expanded background checks. The current leader of the NRA used to support these background checks. So while this compromise didnÃ¢ÂÂt contain everything I wanted or everything that these families wanted
column3: it did represent progress. It represented moderation and common sense. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs why 90 percent of the American people supported it.

column1: But instead of supporting this compromise
column2: the gun lobby and its allies willfully lied about the bill. They claimed that it would create some sort of Ã¢ÂÂbig brotherÃ¢ÂÂ gun registry
column3: even though the bill did the opposite. This legislation
column4: in fact
column5: outlawed any registry. Plain and simple
column6: right there in the text. But that didnÃ¢ÂÂt matter.

column1: And unfortunately
column2: this pattern of spreading untruths about this legislation served a purpose
column3: because those lies upset an intense minority of gun owners
column4: and that in turn intimidated a lot of senators. And I talked to several of these senators over the past few weeks
column5: and theyÃ¢ÂÂre all good people. I know all of them were shocked by tragedies like Newtown. And I also understand that they come from states that are strongly pro-gun. And I have consistently said that there are regional differences when it comes to guns
column6: and that both sides have to listen to each other.

column1: But the fact is most of these senators could not offer any good reason why we wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt want to make it harder for criminals and those with severe mental illnesses to buy a gun. There were no coherent arguments as to why we wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt do this. It came down to politics -- the worry that that vocal minority of gun owners would come after them in future elections. They worried that the gun lobby would spend a lot of money and paint them as anti-Second Amendment.
And obviously
column2: a lot of Republicans had that fear
column3: but Democrats had that fear
column4: too. And so they caved to the pressure
column5: and they started looking for an excuse -- any excuse -- to vote Ã¢ÂÂno.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: One common argument I heard was that this legislation wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt prevent all future massacres. And thatÃ¢ÂÂs true. As I said from the start
column2: no single piece of legislation can stop every act of violence and evil. We learned that tragically just two days ago. But if action by Congress could have saved one person
column3: one child
column4: a few hundred
column5: a few thousand -- if it could have prevented those people from losing their lives to gun violence in the future while preserving our Second Amendment rights
column6: we had an obligation to try.

column1: And this legislation met that test. And too many senators failed theirs.
I've heard some say that blocking this step would be a victory. And my question is
column2: a victory for who? A victory for what? All that happened today was the preservation of the loophole that lets dangerous criminals buy guns without a background check. That didnÃ¢ÂÂt make our kids safer. Victory for not doing something that 90 percent of Americans
column3: 80 percent of Republicans
column4: the vast majority of your constituents wanted to get done? It begs the question
column5: who are we here to represent?

column1: I've heard folks say that having the families of victims lobby for this legislation was somehow misplaced. ""A prop
column2: somebody called them. Ã¢ÂÂEmotional blackmail
column3: Ã¢ÂÂ some outlet said. Are they serious? Do we really think that thousands of families whose lives have been shattered by gun violence donÃ¢ÂÂt have a right to weigh in on this issue? Do we think their emotions
column4: their loss is not relevant to this debate?

column1: So all in all
column2: this was a pretty shameful day for Washington.

column1: But this effort is not over. I want to make it clear to the American people we can still bring about meaningful changes that reduce gun violence
column2: so long as the American people donÃ¢ÂÂt give up on it. Even without Congress
column3: my administration will keep doing everything it can to protect more of our communities. WeÃ¢ÂÂre going to address the barriers that prevent states from participating in the existing background check system. WeÃ¢ÂÂre going to give law enforcement more information about lost and stolen guns so it can do its job. WeÃ¢ÂÂre going to help to put in place emergency plans to protect our children in their schools.

column1: But we can do more if Congress gets its act together. And if this Congress refuses to listen to the American people and pass common-sense gun legislation
column2: then the real impact is going to have to come from the voters.

column1: To all the people who supported this legislation -- law enforcement and responsible gun owners
column2: Democrats and Republicans
column3: urban moms
column4: rural hunters
column5: whoever you are -- you need to let your representatives in Congress know that you are disappointed
column6: and that if they donÃ¢ÂÂt act this time
column7: you will remember come election time.

column1: To the wide majority of NRA households who supported this legislation
column2: you need to let your leadership and lobbyists in Washington know they didnÃ¢ÂÂt represent your views on this one.

column1: The point is those who care deeply about preventing more and more gun violence will have to be as passionate
column2: and as organized
column3: and as vocal as those who blocked these common-sense steps to help keep our kids safe. Ultimately
column4: you outnumber those who argued the other way. But they're better organized. They're better financed. TheyÃ¢ÂÂve been at it longer. And they make sure to stay focused on this one issue during election time. And that's the reason why you can have something that 90 percent of Americans support and you can't get it through the Senate or the House of Representatives.

column1: So to change Washington
column2: you
column3: the American people
column4: are going to have to sustain some passion about this. And when necessary
column5: youÃ¢ÂÂve got to send the right people to Washington. And that requires strength
column6: and it requires persistence.

column1: And that's the one thing that these families should have inspired in all of us. I still don't know how they have been able to muster up the strength to do what theyÃ¢ÂÂve doing over the last several weeks
column2: last several months.

column1: And I see this as just round one. When Newtown happened
column2: I met with these families and I spoke to the community
column3: and I said
column4: something must be different right now. WeÃ¢ÂÂre going to have to change. That's what the whole country said. Everybody talked about how we were going to change something to make sure this didn't happen again
column5: just like everybody talked about how we needed to do something after Aurora. Everybody talked about we needed change something after Tucson.

column1: And IÃ¢ÂÂm assuming that the emotions that weÃ¢ÂÂve all felt since Newtown
column2: the emotions that weÃ¢ÂÂve all felt since Tucson and Aurora and Chicago -- the pain we share with these families and families all across the country whoÃ¢ÂÂve lost a loved one to gun violence -- IÃ¢ÂÂm assuming that's not a temporary thing. IÃ¢ÂÂm assuming our expressions of grief and our commitment to do something different to prevent these things from happening are not empty words.

column1: I believe weÃ¢ÂÂre going to be able to get this done. Sooner or later
column2: we are going to get this right. The memories of these children demand it. And so do the American people.

column1: Thank you very much
column2: everybody.

1	"Money woes in the most populous US state have given birth to an impromptu trading market for the newest of American financial instruments Ã¢ÂÂ the California IOU.
Encumbered by a $26bn (ÃÂ£16bn) budget shortfall and a seemingly intractable political stalemate
column2: California's state government is issuing IOUs to businesses
column3: health clinics
column4: college students and taxpayers who are owed money by the state.

column1: The green documents look like any ordinary cheque except for the words ""registered warrant"" stamped in the corner. They carry a 3.75% interest rate and can be cashed in October
column2: by which time California's governor
column3: Arnold Schwarzenegger
column4: is hoping that he will have some money.

column1: Entrepreneurs have been quick to leap on the phenomenon
column2: with Craigslist and eBay cluttered with offers. A website
column3: BuyMyIOU.com
column4: aims to match sellers of the warrants with buyers eager to snap up the above-market interest rate.

column1: The market's at an early stage Ã¢ÂÂ we're really in the infancy of it right now
column2: said Mark Granger
column3: president of Pacific West Managers
column4: a finance company offering to buy IOUs. ""It's a little unusual to see the state of California resorting to paying its bills like this.""

column1: California is the world's eighth largest economy but its financial situation is grave. The once booming property market has been hit catastrophically by foreclosures and its wealthy elite have seen their income wiped out by stockmarket woes. Usually 1% of the population contribute 50% of income tax revenue
column2: but the capital gains of these rich individuals have evaporated.

column1: Dismal relations between Democrats and Republicans have all but frozen business in the state capital
column2: Sacramento. A two-thirds majority is required to pass any budget
column3: but Republicans
column4: with just over a third of the legislature
column5: are refusing to countenance tax rises while the Democrats are balking at spending cuts.

column1: Schwarzenegger has proposed deep cuts to social programmes
column2: including aid for the elderly
column3: disabled and impoverished
column4: plus cuts to schools
column5: healthcare and universities. Larry Gerston
column6: a professor of political science at San JosÃÂ© State University
column7: says this will accentuate an already yawning gap between the rich and poor: ""The state is quickly becoming an hourglass economy. The middle class is all but evaporating Ã¢ÂÂ people are either moving further to the top or sinking to the bottom.""

column1: The initial victims of the standoff are California's creditors
column2: who had received 91
column3: 000 IOUs worth $354m as of the end of Thursday. High-street banks
column4: including Bank of America
column5: Wells Fargo and JP Morgan Chase
column6: agreed to cash them for a few days but announced that they would not accept them beyond the end of the week.

column1: There's a sentiment inside the banks that the longer they accept the warrants
column2: the longer the budget impasse will go on
column3: said Beth Mills
column4: a spokeswoman for the Californian Bankers Association.

column1: That leaves IOU holders with limited options. Certain local credit unions are still taking the notes at face value. Beyond that
column2: holders face a choice of either waiting until October to receive their money or selling them at a discount on a rapidly developing informal market.

column1: Many online offers for the IOUs propose dubious rates. On eBay
column2: one buyer was willing to pay $140 in return for $170 worth of IOUs. Granger
column3: whose firm sees the debt crisis as a potentially lucrative opportunity
column4: said a market rate was emerging of between 80 and 95 cents on the dollar. ""Because they're cumbersome and troublesome to deal with
column5: a lot of the big investment houses are not going to deal with them
column6: he said. ""And some people will just put them in their piggy banks.""

column1: Last week
column2: the credit agency Fitch cut its rating on California's debt by two notches from ""A minus"" to BBB - just two levels above ""junk"" status. Analysts fear that there could be weeks of IOUs to come.

column1: Gerston says a confrontational culture of extreme left-wing and right-wing politics has contributed to the morass
column2: as has a reluctance to wake up to problems: ""Californians are known as laidback for a reason they've earned that reputation. Most people just don't believe what's in front of them. They just don't buy it."""	0

A 1995 federal court ruling out of Pennsylvania may offer some clues to Clinton supporters as to possible legal authority for removing an elected official from office and replacing them with their erstwhile opponent.
In light of late-breaking reports Friday evening that Russians interfered with the 2016 presidential election to assist Donald TrumpÃ¢ÂÂs victory

column1: At 10:45 p.m. Friday evening

column1: The development has Clinton supporters and other concerned Americans confused and hot in pursuit of potential remedies. No clear constitutional remedy exists to halt the certification of the outcome. Article II of the U.S. Constitution vests Congress with the power to determine the date by which the Electoral College will cast their votes

column1: 5	"""All Legislative Powers herein granted shall be vested in a Congress of the United States
column2: which shall consist of a Senate and House of Representatives.""

column1: (Article I
column2: Section 1
column3: of the United States Constitution)

column1: How Are Laws Made?
Laws begin as ideas. First
column2: a representative sponsors a bill. The bill is then assigned to a committee for study. If released by the committee
column3: the bill is put on a calendar to be voted on
column4: debated or amended. If the bill passes by simple majority (218 of 435)
column5: the bill moves to the Senate. In the Senate
column6: the bill is assigned to another committee and
column7: if released
column8: debated and voted on. Again
column9: a simple majority (51 of 100) passes the bill. Finally
column10: a conference committee made of House and Senate members works out any differences between the House and Senate versions of the bill. The resulting bill returns to the House and Senate for final approval. The Government Printing Office prints the revised bill in a process called enrolling. The President has 10 days to sign or veto the enrolled bill."	1

Donald Trump
column2: Sen. Ted Cruz
column3: Sen. Marco Rubio and Gov. John Kasich debated Thursday night in Miami
column4: five days before the winner-take-all GOP primary in Florida. The complete transcript is posted below. Washington Post reporters and readers using Genius have annotated it
column5: and will continue to do so following the debate.

column1: To see an annotation
column2: click or tap the highlighted part of the transcript; if you would like to leave your own annotations
column3: make sure you have a Genius account. Post staff annotations will appear by default; others are in a menu that you can see in the upper right when you click or tap on an annotation.

column1: Jake Tapper introduced the candidates and the debate began.
TAPPER: Governor Kasich
column2: we will start with you.

column1: KASICH: Well
column2: thank you. You know
column3: I look in the faces of people all across this country
column4: and I know they want to be hopeful. And many are hopeful. Look
column5: I can take conservative policies to the White House
column6: to Washington
column7: to restore the strength of our economy. But I also want to transfer power
column8: money and influence to where you live
column9: because I believe the strength in this country rests in the neighborhoods
column10: the families
column11: the communities and our states.

column1: Advertisement
And I believe it's a new partnership -- a partnership that can allow us to restore the spirit of America and strengthen America for the best century we've ever had.
Thank you.
(APPLAUSE)
TAPPER: Senator Rubio?

RUBIO: Every election is important. I believe this is the most important election in a generation. Because what's at stake in this election is not simply what party is going to be in charge or which candidate wins. What's at stake is our identity as a nation and as a people.
RUBIO: For over two centuries
column2: America has been an exceptional nation. And now the time has come for this generation to do what it must do to keep it that way. If we make the right choice in this election
column3: our children are going to be the freest and most prosperous Americans that have ever lived. And the 21st century is going to be a new American century.

column1: Advertisement
(APPLAUSE)
TAPPER: Senator Cruz?
CRUZ: Fifty-nine years ago
column2: Florida welcomed my father to America as he stepped off the ferry boat from Cuba onto Key West. He was 18. He was filled with hopes and dreams
column3: and yet he was in the freest land on the face of the earth.

column1: This election
column2: this debate is not about insults. It's not about attacks. It's not about any of the individuals on this stage. This election is about you and your children. It's about the freedom America has always had and making sure that that freedom is there for the next generation
column3: that we stop Washington from standing in the way of the hard-working taxpayers of America.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
TAPPER: Mr. Trump?

TRUMP: One of the biggest political events anywhere in the world is happening right now with the Republican Party. Millions and millions of people are going out to the polls and they're voting. They're voting out of enthusiasm. They're voting out of love. Some of these people
column2: frankly
column3: have never voted before -- 50 years old
column4: 60 years old
column5: 70 years old -- never voted before.

column1: Advertisement
We're taking people from the Democrat Party. We're taking people as independents
column2: and they're all coming out and the whole world is talking about it. It's very exciting. I think
column3: frankly
column4: the Republican establishment
column5: or whatever you want to call it
column6: should embrace what's happening.

column1: We're having millions of extra people join. We are going to beat the Democrats. We are going to beat Hillary or whoever it may be. And we're going to beat them soundly.
(APPLAUSE)
TAPPER: Thank you. Thank you.
Let's begin with jobs and the economy
column2: which Republican voters say is the most important issue to them in this election. There have been some real differences expressed in -- on this stage on whether trade deals have been good for the American workers. One of Mr. Trump's
column3: the front runner's
column4: signature issues is ending what he calls ""disastrous trade deals"" in order to bring jobs back to America.

column1: Advertisement
Governor Kasich
column2: I'd like to start with you. You've been a strong advocate for these trade deals over the years. Critics say these deals are great for corporate America's bottom line
column3: but have cost the U.S. at least 1 million jobs. How do you respond to the criticism that you've been catering to board rooms at the expense of the American middle class?

column1: KASICH: Well
column2: Jake
column3: I grew up in a blue collar family. And the simple fact of the matter is that of course we're sensitive about trade. One out of five Americans works in a job connected to trade; 38 million Americans are connected to it.

column1: But my position has always been we want to have free trade
column2: but fair trade. And I've been arguing all along that it is absolutely critical that when other countries break those agreements
column3: we don't turn the process over to some international bureaucrat who comes back a couple years later and says
column4: ""Oh
column5: America was right
column6: and people are out of work.

column1: Advertisement
The fact of the matter is we have to have an expedited process. When people cheat
column2: when countries cheat and they take advantage of us
column3: we need to blow the whistle. And as president of the United States
column4: I absolutely will blow the whistle and begin to stand up for the American worker.

column1: But we don't want to lock the doors and pull down the blinds and leave the world. Because frankly
column2: if we do that
column3: prices will go up. People will buy less. Other people will be out of work. And we don't want to see that happen.

column1: Trade
column2: though
column3: has to be balanced and we have to make sure that when we see a violation
column4: like some country dumping their products into this country
column5: believe me as president
column6: I will stand up and I will shut down those imports because they're a violation of the agreement we have and the American worker expects us to stand up.

column1: Advertisement
And Jake
column2: my family worked in the steel industry
column3: not with a white collar. I understand their plight.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
TAPPER: Mr. Trump
column2: your critics say your campaign platform is inconsistent with how you run your businesses
column3: noting that you've brought in foreign workers instead of hiring Americans
column4: and your companies manufacture clothing in China and Mexico.

column1: Why should voters trust that you will run the country differently from how you run your businesses? TRUMP: Because nobody knows the system better than me. I know the H1B. I know the H2B. Nobody knows it better than me. I'm a businessman. These are laws. These are regulations. These are rules. We're allowed to do it. And frankly
column2: because of the devaluations that other countries -- the monetary devaluations that other countries are constantly doing and brilliantly doing against us
column3: it's very
column4: very hard for our companies in this country
column5: in our country
column6: to compete.

column1: Advertisement
So I will take advantage of it; they're the laws. But I'm the one that knows how to change it. Nobody else on this dais knows how to change it like I do
column2: believe me.

column1: TAPPER: Senator Rubio
column2: last October
column3: you said that you're
column4: quote
column5: ""generally very much in favor of free trade."" More recently
column6: you backed a away from your support of some trade deals. If elected
column7: will you support free trade deals even if it means the inevitable loss of U.S. jobs?

column1: RUBIO: No
column2: I support free trade deals that are good for America. We're 5 percent of the world's population. If all we do is sell things to each other
column3: we can only sell to 5 percent of the people on earth. We have to have access to the hundreds of millions of people in the world today who can afford to buy things.

column1: The problem is we're a low-tariff country. To import something into the United States is not very expensive
column2: but many of these countries we can't export to because their tariffs are too high. And so I am in favor of deals that allow us to bring down those tariffs so that America can sell things to all these people around the world.

column1: Advertisement
There are good trade deals and there are bad ones. So for example
column2: here in Florida
column3: we have benefited from the free trade deal with Colombia. It's allowed flower exporters to come into the United States but it's created jobs for hundreds of people who are now delivering those flowers and working in that industry. We have a surplus with Colombia.

column1: On the other hand
column2: you've seen trade deals like in Mexico that have been less than promising in some aspects
column3: better in others. Bottom line is I believe that America
column4: if given access to foreign markets
column5: our workers are the most productive in the world
column6: our people are the most innovative on this planet. If it is a free and fair trade deal
column7: we can compete against anyone in the world
column8: and we need to in the 21st century.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
TAPPER: Senator Cruz
column2: you were a supporter of the Pacific trade deal
column3: but after taking some heat from conservatives
column4: you changed your position. Why should these voters who don't like these trade deals trust that you will fight for them all the time and not just in election years?

column1: CRUZ: Actually that's incorrect. There are two different agreements. There's TPA and TPP. I opposed TPP and have always opposed TPP
column2: which is what you asked about. And when it comes to trade
column3: look
column4: free trade
column5: when we open up foreign markets
column6: helps Americans. But we're getting killed in international trade right now. And we're getting killed because we have an administration that's doesn't look out for American workers and jobs are going overseas. We're driving jobs overseas.

column1: And the people who are losing out are in manufacturing jobs
column2: or the steel industry or the auto industry. But I'll tell you who else is going to be losing out
column3: which is the service industry. This Obama administration is negotiating the Trade in Services Agreement which is another treaty to allow services to come in and take jobs from Americans as well.

column1: And you've got to understand. Trade and immigration are interwoven
column2: and they are hurting the working men and women of this country. So the question is
column3: what's the solution? It's easy to talk about the problems. But do you have a solution to fix it? And I think the solution is several things.

column1: Number one
column2: we need to negotiate trade deals protecting American workers first
column3: not the corporate board room. Number two
column4: we need to lift the regulations on American businesses here so we see jobs coming back. And number three
column5: we need a tax plan like the tax plan I've introduced that will not tax exports and that will tax imports
column6: and that will bring millions of high-paying jobs back to America.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
TAPPER: Let's talk more about how American jobs are impacted by foreign workers. Let's go to Stephen Dinan of the Washington Times. Stephen.
DINAN: Senator Rubio in late 2014
column2: Disney laid off 250 tech workers in Orlando
column3: replacing many of them with foreign workers. Some of the Americans even had to train their own replacements. You support increasing the H-1B visa program that made it possible to bring in these foreign workers. Doesn't this program take jobs away from Americans?

column1: RUBIO: If it's being abused the way Disney did. Understand that program
column2: it is illegal now under that program to use it to replace American workers. Under that program
column3: you have to prove not only that you're not replacing Americans
column4: but that you've tried to hire Americans. And if a company is caught abusing that process
column5: they should never be allowed to use it again.

column1: The second problem with the current structure of the program that people perhaps don't understand is a lot of these companies are not directly hiring employees from abroad. They are hiring a consulting company like Tata
column2: for example
column3: out of India. That company then hoards up all of these visas. They hire workers. You hire -- Disney or some other company hires this company.

column1: What they're basically doing is they are insourcing and outsourcing. They are bringing in workers from abroad that are not direct employees of a Disney or someone else
column2: they're employees of this consulting business. And what I argue is that no consulting business such as that should be allowed to hoard up all of these visas
column3: that the visas should only be available for companies to use to directly hire workers and that we should be stricter in how he enforce it.

column1: It is illegal now
column2: it is a violation of the law now to use that program to replace Americans. And if a company is caught doing that
column3: whether it be Disney or anyone else
column4: they should be barred from using the program in the future.

column1: DINAN: Senator Rubio
column2: real quick follow-up on this.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
You've -- in the -- in the context of illegal immigration
column2: you've called for basically putting off any legalization process until we get the border secured.

column1: RUBIO: Correct.
DINAN: Why not call for a pause on H1Bs until those abuses you've talked about are solved.
RUBIO: Well first
column2: I think -- well
column3: I'd be open to it if it takes a pause. But I don't think it takes a pause to enforce the law. What they are doing is they are in fact using that program to replace an American.

column1: If there's an American working at Disney and they bring someone from another country using H1B to replace their direct job
column2: that's in violation of the law. And what I'm explaining to you is
column3: what they are doing now is they are not -- what they are doing is they are eliminating the job.

column1: They are outsourcing the entire tech division to a consulting company. They are making the argument that we didn't replace you. We just replaced the whole unit by hiring a company to do it instead. And that company that they're hiring is bringing their workers from abroad. It's a loophole they've figured out that we need to close so they can no longer continue to do it that way.
(APPLAUSE)
DINAN: Governor Kasich
column2: I want to come to you next. Mr. Trump says that legal immigration is producing quote
column3: ""lower wages and higher unemployment for U.S. workers"". He's calling for a pause on green cards issued to foreign workers. Wouldn't that help workers in the U.S.?

column1: KAISCH: Well look
column2: I believe in immigration
column3: but it has to be controlled. The simple fact of the matter is I wouldn't be standing here. I'd be maybe running for president of Croatia if we didn't have immigration.

column1: Immigration is something that brings youth and vibrance and energy to our country. But we clearly have to control our borders. We can't have people just walking in. Look
column2: we lock our doors at night in our homes. The country has to be able to lock its doors as well. So
column3: we -- I have a comprehensive plan to deal with this problem of immigration.

column1: I would say we have to absolutely finish the wall and guard the border. And if anybody were to come in after that
column2: they are going to have to go back. No excuses because we can't continue this problem. I think we ought to have a guest worker program
column3: where people come in
column4: work and go home.

column1: And I think at the same time
column2: for the 11 and a half million who are here
column3: then in my view if they have not committed a crime since they've been here
column4: they get a path to legalization. Not to citizenship. I believe that program can pass the Congress in the first 100 days.

column1: But let's not lose sight of the fact that the whole key to the future of America is strong economic growth with common sense regulation
column2: lower taxes and a balanced budget.

column1: We can have a rising tide that lifts all the workers in America
column2: all the people who are citizens of America
column3: if we'll just follow the formula that works
column4: that I used in Washington. And guess what
column5: I've used it in Ohio to grow over 400 private sector jobs since I've been governor

column1: DINAN: Mr. Trump
column2: I do want to come to you. Will you also in your answer
column3: address how long you think that pause would be and what that pause would look like.

column1: TRUMP: I will. First of all
column2: I think and I know the H1B very well. And it's something that I frankly use and I shouldn't be allowed to use it. We shouldn't have it. Very
column3: very bad for workers. And second of all
column4: I think it's very important to say
column5: well
column6: I'm a businessman and I have to do what I have to do.

column1: When it's sitting there waiting for you
column2: but it's very bad. It's very bad for business in terms of -- and it's very bad for our workers and it's unfair for our workers. And we should end it. Very importantly
column3: the Disney workers endorsed me
column4: as you probably read.

column1: And I got a full endorsement because they are the ones that said
column2: and they had a news conference
column3: and they said
column4: he's the only one that's going to be able to fix it. Because it is a mess. I think for a period of a year to two years we have to look back and we have to see
column5: just to answer the second part of your question
column6: where we are
column7: where we stand
column8: what's going on.

column1: We have to sort of take a strong
column2: good
column3: hard look and come up with plans that work. And we're rushing into things
column4: and we're just -- we're leading with the chin.

column1: (BELL RINGS)
We're leading with people that don't know what they are doing in terms of our leadership. I'd say a minimum of one year
column2: maybe two years.

column1: DINAN: Senator Cruz
column2: I want to bring you in very quickly on this.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
DINAN: The United States averages about a million new permanent legal immigrants a year and hundreds of thousands more guest workers. What should the right level be?
CRUZ: Well
column2: we need to redefine our legal immigration system so that it meets the needs of the American economy. Right now
column3: we're bringing in far too many low skilled workers. What that is doing is driving down the wages of hard-working Americans. Our system isn't working. And then on top of that
column4: we've got a system that's allowing in millions of people to be here illegally.

column1: And the answer to that
column2: I've laid out a very
column3: very detailed immigration plan on my website. We're going to build a wall
column4: triple the border patrol. We're going to end sanctuary cities. And let me tell you how we're going to do that.

column1: We're going to cut off federal taxpayer funds to any city that defies federal immigration laws.
(APPLAUSE)
CRUZ: We're going to end welfare benefits for anyone who is here illegally. And the thing to understand
column2: Stephen
column3: we can solve these problems. It's not that we don't know how to do it. It's that we're lacking the political will. Neither of the parties in Washington wants to do this.

column1: The Democrats support illegal immigration because they view those illegal immigrants as potential voters and far too many of the Republicans are doing the bidding of Wall Street and the special interest and they view it as cheap labor.
CRUZ: We need instead leadership that works for the working men and women of this country. We need an immigration system that takes care of the jobs of the working men and women of this country.
(APPLAUSE)
TAPPER: Senator Rubio
column2: did you want to weigh in?

column1: RUBIO: Well
column2: I would add when you talk about the millions of green cards that are coming in
column3: those aren't actually workers at all. They are just coming in primarily based on family connection. And ;let me tell you
column4: when my parents came in 1956
column5: I acknowledge that my parents came to the U.S. on a family-based system.

column1: The problem is nothing looks like it did 60 years ago. The 21st Century economy simply is not creating enough jobs for people that don't have skills. When my parents came
column2: they had a very limited education. My father stopped going to school when he was 9 years old because his mother died and he had to work. And he would work the next 70 years of his life and never go back to school. And I'm grateful every day that America welcomed them.

column1: But today in the 21st Century
column2: 60 years later
column3: finding jobs when you don't have skills is very difficult. We need to move to a merit- based system of immigration
column4: not just on H-1B
column5: particularly on green cards. The primary criteria for bringing someone from abroad in the 21st Century should be
column6: what skills do you have? What business are you going to open? What investment are you going to make? What job are you going to be able to do when you arrive in the United States?

column1: (APPLAUSE)

TAPPER: Education obviously plays a large role when it comes to jobs and the economy. The United States has long been falling behind others in the industrialized world. American students currently rank 27th out of 34 countries in math and 17th in reading.
Mr. Trump
column2: you've called the education standards known as Common Core a disaster. What are your specific objections to Common Core?

column1: TRUMP: Education through Washington
column2: D.C. I don't want that. I want local education. I want the parents
column3: and I want all of the teachers
column4: and I want everybody to get together around a school and to make education great.

column1: And it was very interesting
column2: I was with Dr. Ben Carson today
column3: who is endorsing me
column4: by the way
column5: tomorrow morning
column6: and he is...

column1: (APPLAUSE)
TRUMP: We were talking. We spoke for over an hour on education. And he has such a great handle on it. He wants competitive schools. He wants a lot of different things that are terrific
column2: including charter schools
column3: by the way
column4: that the unions are fighting like crazy. But charter schools work and they work very well.

column1: So there are a lot of things. But I'm going to have Ben very involved with education
column2: something that's an expertise of his.

column1: TAPPER: OK. But just to clarify
column2: the Common Core standards were developed by the states
column3: states and localities voluntarily adopt them
column4: and they come up with their own curricula to meet those standards. So when you say ""education by Washington
column5: D.C.
column6: what do you mean?

column1: TRUMP: You're right
column2: Jake. But it has been taken over by the federal government. It was originally supposed to be that way. And certainly sounds better that way. But it has all been taken over now by the bureaucrats in Washington
column3: and they are not interested in what's happening in Miami or in Florida
column4: in many cases.

column1: Now in some cases they would be. But in many cases they are more interested in their paycheck and the big bureaucracy than they are taking care of the children.
(APPLAUSE)
TAPPER: Governor Kasich
column2: you have called opposition to Common Core hysteria. What is your response to grassroots conservatives who do not agree with you?

column1: KASICH: Well
column2: look
column3: all I'm in favor of in Ohio is high standards. First of all
column4: let me tell you
column5: I would take 125 federal education programs
column6: put them in four buckets
column7: and send them back to the states. OK
column8: I've been working on this for many
column9: many years.

column1: Secondly
column2: Jake
column3: in our state
column4: the state school board sets the standards. And we want high standards because we have not always had high standards
column5: unfortunately. They set the standards and the local school boards develop the curriculum.

column1: Not only did we have that in the law
column2: we reasserted it in the law. And we also want parental advisers in the local school district so that
column3: in fact
column4: you know
column5: frankly
column6: education has to be run at the school board level with a little guidance from the state.

column1: Now on top of that
column2: you want to talk about the 21st Century and what we need to do with our kids? We need to start connecting them to the real world. We need to be training them for the jobs of the 21st Century
column3: not the jobs of 20 years ago.

column1: We need vocational education starting in the seventh grade where kids can get that kind of education that can take them to college
column2: but all the way through their K through 12 they ought to be connected with real-world jobs.

column1: Frankly
column2: what ought to happen is we ought to get them to pursue their God-given talents and connect them with the things that give them passion. And that's exactly what we're doing in Ohio
column3: combined with mentoring programs to talk to kids about what their future can be.

column1: So let me be clear
column2: local control
column3: obviously
column4: high state standards. That's what it is in the state of Ohio.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
TAPPER: So
column2: Senator Cruz
column3: let me bring you in. You object to Common Core. Governor Kasich says it's local school boards developing local curriculum to meet higher standards. What's wrong with that?

column1: CRUZ: Common Core is a disaster. And if I am elected president
column2: in the first days as president
column3: I will direct the Department of Education that Common Core ends that day.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
CRUZ: Now
column2: let me tell you why you can do that
column3: because it's easy to talk about the problem
column4: but you have to understand the solutions. The Obama administration has abused executive power in forcing common core on the states. It has used race-to-the-top funds to effectively blackmail and force the states to adopt common core.

column1: Now
column2: the one silver lining of Obama abusing executive power is that everything done with executive power can be undone with executive power
column3: and I intend to do that.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
Beyond that
column2: though
column3: Jake
column4: I intend to work to abolish the federal Department of Education and send education back to the states and back to the local governments.

column1: And let me say finally
column2: the most important reform we can do in education after getting the federal government out of it
column3: is expand school choice; expand charter schools and home schools and private schools and vouchers
column4: and scholarships. And give every child -- African American
column5: Hispanic -- every child in need an opportunity to access to a quality education.

column1: (APPLAUSE)

TAPPER: Let's move on to another topic of particular interest here in Florida. Florida has the highest percentage of seniors in the country. There are 3.1 million senior citizens here who receive Social Security benefits
column2: and they're very interested in hearing what you candidates intend to do to keep Social Security going for future generations.

column1: Let me turn now to my colleague Dana Bash.
BASH: Senator Rubio
column2: you argue Americans your age must have an honest conversation about making Social Security sustainable. For people under 55
column3: you want to raise the retirement age and also reduce benefits for wealthier Americans. So
column4: what should the new retirement age be? And how much will those benefits be cut?

column1: RUBIO: Well
column2: first of all
column3: let me say that you're right
column4: there are about 3 million seniors in Florida with Social Security and Medicare. One of them is my mother
column5: who happens to be here today. I'm against any changes to Social Security that are bad for my mother. And we don't have to make any changes for them. But anyone who tells you that Social Security can stay the way it is is lying. Any politician that goes around saying
column6: ""We don't have to anything; all we have to do is raise a few taxes or just leave it the way it is
column7: they're not being honest with you.

column1: Social Security will go bankrupt and it will bankrupt the country with it. So what it will require is people younger
column2: like myself
column3: people that are 30 years away from retirement
column4: to accept that our Social Security is going to work differently than it did for my parents.

column1: For example
column2: instead of retiring at 67 the way I'm supposed to retire
column3: I'd have to retire at 68. If I were still in the Senate
column4: I'd be one of the youngest people there.

column1: (LAUGHTER)
If I've made a lot of money
column2: my Social Security benefit will not grow as fast as someone who made less money. And by the way
column3: Medicare could very well become the option of using my Medicare benefit to buy a private plan that I like better. Medicare Advantage does that now.

column1: These are not unreasonable changes to ask of someone like myself who is 25 or 30 years away from retirement
column2: in exchange for leaving the program undisturbed for the people that are on it now or about to retire
column3: and ensuring that we do not bankrupt our country and that this program still exists when my children retire
column4: when my grandchildren retire
column5: when I retire.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BASH: Senator
column2: the question was specific though. You made your plan very clear about generally what you want to do
column3: but how high would the retirement age go and how much would you cut those benefits?

column1: RUBIO: Well
column2: I'm sorry I didn't answer that part. So the thing is that my -- my generation
column3: someone my age would retire at 68. We would continue to allow it to increase the retirement age for future generations until it hit 70. And so my children would retire at 70. I would retire at 68. It would be a graduating scale over a period of time.

column1: But again I'm talking about people like myself and Ted who are 45 years old. We're years away from retirement. For people that are on it now
column2: we don't have to change it at all. If we don't do anything
column3: we will have a debt crisis. It's not a question of if. It is a question of when. In less than five years
column4: only 17 percent of our budget will remain discretionary; 83 percent of the federal budget in less than five years will all be spent on Medicare
column5: Medicaid
column6: the interest on the debt.

column1: That's -- all of it will be eaten up by that. That's a debt crisis. And it will be debilitating to our economy and our children deserve better than to inherit a debt crisis.
(APPLAUSE)
BASH: Mr. Trump
column2: you don't want to raise the retirement age
column3: and you also don't want to cut benefits even for wealthier Americans. But according to the Social Security Administration
column4: unless adjustments are made
column5: Social Security is projected to run out of money within 20 years. So specifically
column6: what would you do to stop that from happening?

column1: TRUMP: Well
column2: first of all
column3: I want you to understand that the Democrats
column4: and I've watched them very intensely
column5: even though it's a very
column6: very boring thing to watch
column7: that the Democrats are doing nothing with Social Security. They're leaving it the way it is. In fact
column8: they want to increase it. They want to actually give more.

column1: And that's what we're up against. And whether we like it or not
column2: that is what we're up against.

column1: I will do everything within my power not to touch Social Security
column2: to leave it the way it is; to make this country rich again; to bring back our jobs; to get rid of deficits; to get rid of waste
column3: fraud and abuse
column4: which is rampant in this country
column5: rampant
column6: totally rampant.

column1: TRUMP: And it's my absolute intention to leave Social Security the way it is. Not increase the age and to leave it as is.
You have 22 years
column2: you have a long time to go. It's not long in terms of what we're talking about
column3: but it's still a long time to go
column4: and I want to leave Social Security as is
column5: I want to make our country rich again so we can afford it. I want to bring back our jobs
column6: I want to do things that will make us
column7: that will bring back GDP...

column1: I mean
column2: as an example
column3: GDP was zero essentially for the last two quarters. If that ever happened in China. you would have had a depression like nobody's ever seen before. They go down to 7 percent
column4: 8 percent
column5: and it's a -- it's a national tragedy. We're at zero
column6: we're not doing anything.

column1: We've lost our jobs. We've lost everything. We're losing everything. Our jobs are gone
column2: our businesses are being taken out of the country. I want to make America great again and I want to leave Social Security as is. We're going to get rid of waste
column3: fraud
column4: abuse and bring back business.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BASH: Senator Rubio
column2: I know you want to get in. Hang on one second
column3: I just want to follow up with Mr. Trump. You're talking about waste
column4: fraud and abuse
column5: but an independent bipartisan organization
column6: the Committee For a Responsible Federal Budget
column7: says improper payments like you're talking about
column8: that would only save about $3 billion
column9: but it would take $150 billion to make Social Security solvent. So how would you find that other $147 million?

column1: TRUMP: Because they don't cover most of the subjects. We're the policemen of the world. We take care of the entire world. We're going to have a stronger military
column2: much stronger. Our military is depleted. But we take care of Germany
column3: we take care of Saudi Arabia
column4: we take care of Japan
column5: we take care of South Korea. We take -- every time this maniac from North Korea does anything
column6: we immediately send our ships. We get virtually nothing.

column1: We have 28
column2: 000 soldiers on the line
column3: on the border between North and South Korea. We have so many places. Saudi Arabia was making a billion dollars a day
column4: and we were getting virtually nothing to protect them. We are going to be in a different world. We're going to negotiate real deals now
column5: and we're going to bring the wealth back to our country. We owe $19 trillion. We're going to bring wealth back to our country. (APPLAUSE)

column1: BASH: Senator Rubio
column2: will that be enough to save Social Security?

column1: RUBIO: No. And I -- and I think you've outlined why. The numbers don't add up. You know
column2: when I ran for the Senate in 2010
column3: I came out and said we're going to have to make changes to Social Security
column4: and everyone said that's the end of your campaign. In Florida
column5: you can't talk about that
column6: but people know that it's the truth her"	0

column1: 12	"In his press conference on March 11
column3: President Barack Obama talked up U.S. oil production against a backdrop of rising prices at the pump.

column1: We need to continue to boost domestic production of oil and gas
column2: he said. ""Last year
column3: American oil production reached its highest level since 2003. Let me repeat that. Our oil production reached its highest level in seven years. Oil production from federal waters in the Gulf of Mexico reached an all-time high. For the first time in more than a decade
column4: imports accounted for less than half of what we consumed. So any notion that my administration has shut down oil production might make for a good political sound bite
column5: but it doesnÃ¢ÂÂt match up with reality

column1: In this item
column2: weÃ¢ÂÂll check the first piece of evidence to support his contention that his administration hasnÃ¢ÂÂt ""shut down"" oil production -- that ""last year
column3: American oil production reached its highest level since 2003.""

column1: We turned to the Energy Information Administration
column2: the federal governmentÃ¢ÂÂs official office for energy statistics. Since Obama said ""oil production
column3: we will only look at oil removed from U.S. territory
column4: rather than natural gas or other petroleum products.

column1: Here are the annual totals
column2: in barrels produced
column3: going back to 2003:

column1: So
column2: 2010 is definitely the highest since 2003. But weÃ¢ÂÂll note a couple of caveats.

column1: First
column2: production levels actually have been quite stable over the eight-year period. Comparing 2009 and 2010 statistics
column3: petroleum production only rose about 3 percent. And the level for 2010 is only 11 percent higher than for the lowest year in that eight-year period. So the increase the president is referring to is not particularly dramatic.

column1: The second caveat is that the Energy Information Administration projects that production totals are poised to fall from their current levels over the next two years.
Domestic crude oil production
column2: the agency says
column3: is projected to decline by 110
column4: 000 barrels a day in 2011 and by an additional 130
column5: 000 barrels per day in 2012. The agency makes that projection based on expected production declines in Alaska due to maturing oil fields. Production in the Gulf of Mexico is also projected to decline. Both are partially offset by projected increases in the Lower 48 states
column6: but on balance
column7: EIA sees the numbers falling.

column1: So Obama is right that American oil production is at its highest level since 2003
column2: but weÃ¢ÂÂre taking the statement down a notch on our rating scale because the amount is projected to fall during each of the next two years
column3: making it somewhat problematic to use the number as evidence that domestic oil production is on a healthy trendline. On balance
column4: we rate the statement Mostly True."	0
