THE LEAD WITH JAKE TAPPER
Interview With Chicago Mayor Rahm Emanuel; Guns in Schools; Interview with Randi Weingarten of American Federation of Teachers; The Plot to Rig the Race; What's Behind Auto Industry's Comeback?
Aired April 2
THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.
JAKE TAPPER
column2: CNN ANCHOR: Chicago Mayor Rahm Emanuel is with us this afternoon
column3: but I assure you
column4: parents
column5: there will be no cursing.

column1: I'm Jake Tapper
column2: and this is THE LEAD.

column1: The national lead. An NRA task force lays out ideas to put a good guy with a gun in every school. I will ask Mayor Emanuel how that is going to apply in Chicago
column2: which buries hundreds of people from gun violence every year.

column1: Also in national news
column2: cheating on standardized tests
column3: but not by students
column4: by the school officials responsible for administering them. Now they're getting the ultimate detention in a jail cell.

column1: And the money lead. If there was a traffic sign that represented the auto industry just a few years ago
column2: it would be rough road ahead. Did it take a little Italian carmaker to help turn -- Chrysler turn the corner?

column1: The national lead. It is an idea that could lead to kindergarten teachers carrying Glocks
column2: principals spending their extracurricular time at target ranges.

column1: Today
column2: a task force commission by the National Rifle Association unveiled a report with recommendations to make schools safer. The most controversial idea would put more guns in our nation's schools. The task force backed off the notion of putting armed volunteers in schools
column3: but it wants to see more teachers and administrators trained and armed.

column1: Former Republican Congressman Asa Hutchinson is leading the task force and urging action on its recommendations.
(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
ASA HUTCHINSON
column2: FORMER UNDERSECRETARY FOR HOMELAND SECURITY: If you are interested in making our schools safer and to save children's lives
column3: look at these recommendations seriously.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)

TAPPER: We have seen so many Newtown parents advocating for gun control after 20 children were killed in a senseless massacre in December. But today we saw a Newtown parent standing with the NRA's task force.
(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
MARK MATTIOLI
column2: FATHER OF NEWTOWN VICTIM: I think politics need to sort of be set aside here. And I hope this doesn't lead to name calling
column3: but rather this is recommendations for solutions
column4: real solutions that will make our kids safer.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
TAPPER: If there is a city that sees the toll of gun violence every single day
column2: it's Chicago
column3: more than 500 homicides last year and almost 90 percent of them were gun-related. And yet Chicago has some of the most strict gun control laws in the nation.

column1: And Chicago Mayor Rahm Emanuel joins me now.
Mr. Mayor
column2: thanks for joining us.

column1: One of the recommendations issued today was that more individuals
column2: more adults in schools become proficient in guns. I'm wondering your reaction to that.

column1: RAHM EMANUEL (D)
column2: MAYOR OF CHICAGO: No
column3: look
column4: I think that is not what schools are for and that's not where you want the time and training for principals and teachers. You want that on the education of our children. There's a whole host of things to do different as it relates to safety in schools
column5: but training principals and teachers on use of handguns is not one of them.

column1: TAPPER: A lot of people look to the city of Chicago and they say
column2: here's a city with some of the strictest gun control laws in the country. And although crime and homicide has gone down this year
column3: it still has a staggeringly high homicide rate.

column1: How do you reconcile that?
EMANUEL: Well
column2: Jake
column3: first of all
column4: as you know
column5: March
column6: our homicides dropped nearly 70 percent; in February
column7: it dropped 50 percent. And in the first three months are down a total of 50 homicides
column8: 42 percent. So it's a very significant drop and one of the most -- March was one of the biggest one-month drops in the history of the city of Chicago.

column1: Second is
column2: it's
column3: you know
column4: people in the city of Chicago
column5: there are gun purchases done in Indiana
column6: brought over. So you need a uniform policy on gun control. As I've always said
column7: it comes down to the four P's.

column1: And it's not one of them; it's all of them: policing
column2: and so being strategic about your police resources where you apply them; smart prevention
column3: like after school programs and summer jobs to make sure kids have a positive thing to do and are out of harm's way; stiffer penalties
column4: like a three-year minimum for gun crimes
column5: first prevent people from getting guns -- criminals
column6: second if the criminals commit the crimes there's swift punishment; and fourth P is sound parenting
column7: teaching kids right from wrong.

column1: And all four of those P's have to work. Now there cannot be over-focus on gun control. But you can't also wipe it off the table as if it's not part of it. And you can't rely only on policing and forget parenting. And you can't also not participate and have a comprehensive after school program to keep your kids when the school bell goes off.
All four P's
column2: policing
column3: prevention
column4: penalties and parenting have to work together. Gun control matters. And what happens across the border in either Indiana or Wisconsin affects the Chicago area. We take more guns off the streets than New York or L.A.

column1: Yes
column2: we have good and strong gun laws. But we're as good and comprehensive working with our policing and our parenting and our prevention programs as the actual background checks are that apply to Indiana where a lot of purchases are made before the gun ends up in the city of Chicago. So you have to be smart about it.

column1: You have to -- you have to have stiff gun control laws. And I believe firmly in preventing criminals getting access to them. But you have to focus on every one of those aspects that
column2: in my view
column3: have a policy that makes sure that you have police on the street
column4: getting kids
column5: guns and drugs off the streets.

column1: And all of those have to work
column2: not one of them
column3: and not one of them have -- be allowed to take off the table as if it's not part of the overall solution to safety and security of our streets.

column1: TAPPER: The president is hitting the road tomorrow to start campaigning further for greater gun restrictions. Do you regret
column2: when you were White House chief of staff
column3: that the White House in the first term under President Obama
column4: did not do more on this issue?

column1: EMANUEL: Well
column2: look
column3: you know
column4: as chief of staff -- and you remember
column5: Jake
column6: because you were there; you were covering it.

column1: You were covering the decision to make -- to take the auto industry that was on its knees
column2: to close to collapse
column3: and make sure that those jobs were created and made sure that the auto industry came back to the point it is today
column4: that it's adding more jobs than it was when the president was there.

column1: That was a crisis he inherited; it was one that took a lot of time and painstaking work to fix in the same way that the economy was headed -- going head over heels towards what is now known as the great recession. And it took a lot on that aspect in the financial sector. And to govern
column2: as President Kennedy said
column3: is to make a set of choices.

column1: And the president made a set of choices to put in place the things that were necessary
column2: given the financial
column3: economic and auto manufacturing crises that he faced
column4: not one of them
column5: not two of them
column6: all three of them simultaneously.

column1: And for people to then kind of look back and said
column2: you know
column3: in the middle of either the financial or the auto scandal
column4: he should have done X
column5: there are choices you make. And he has properly given post- Newtown and part other things that have happened in America making sure that Washington now gets in place the gun control laws that are necessary to prevent criminals' access to guns.

column1: But the notion that somehow in retrospect you should have pushed the auto industry crisis to the side
column2: or the financial crisis to the side
column3: you were there covering it; and you know that -- what the state of mind and where we were at that time.

column1: So this is where he is now in the second term and taking control of this situation
column2: making sure that we have
column3: for the first time since when I was in the White House under President Clinton
column4: I was a point person for passing both the Brady bill and the assault weapon ban that we have the opportunity actually to make progress on getting sound
column5: comprehensive gun control legislation that works with policing
column6: prevention programs and encouraging strong parenting.

column1: TAPPER: Lastly
column2: Mr. Mayor
column3: I'd be remiss if I didn't ask you
column4: former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton is speaking this evening and it's garnering a lot of media attention and buzz. She is the power player if she decides to run for president.

column1: Do you think she is beatable if she runs for the Democratic nomination? Could anyone beat her?
EMANUEL: Well
column2: I -- look
column3: I think that's way ahead of yourself
column4: Jake. But that would not be the first time anybody and me got way ahead of themselves.

column1: (LAUGHTER)
EMANUEL: So
column2: look
column3: she'll speak; there will be a lot of excitement. She has
column4: as you no doubt -- and you know how close I am to the Clintons and that she has a lot to offer if she decides to do that. And there's no doubt
column5: both on her record as former first lady
column6: secretary of state
column7: senator from the state of New York
column8: she has a lot to offer.

column1: TAPPER: So you're not going to -- you're not even going to touch it
column2: whether or not anybody could beat her?

column1: EMANUEL: Well
column2: we can go back and talk about the 69 percent drop in homicides in Chicago.

column1: TAPPER: All right. Mayor Rahm Emanuel
column2: thank you so much for joining us today.

column1: EMANUEL: Thanks
column2: Jake.

column1: TAPPER: Ever wonder why so few folks responsible for the financial crisis seem to have been punished in any way?
Well
column2: some say those in charge of regulation and enforcement did not do their jobs with the vigor and aggressiveness necessary. Now
column3: why would that be? Today
column4: we learned the former head of the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission Mary Schapiro is joining the consulting firm Promontory Financial Group
column5: which advises
column6: you guessed it
column7: financial firms.

column1: The mission of the SEC -- and I quote -- ""is to protect investors and maintain fair
column2: orderly
column3: and efficient markets."" Schapiro took the helm at the embattled SEC in January of 2009
column4: and while many praise her for restoring the all-but-nonexistent reputation of that agency at that time
column5: she's also been criticized for never fully holding Wall Street accountable for the worst misdeeds that caused the financial crisis.

column1: Her announcement comes just days after we learned that Lanny Breuer
column2: the assistant attorney general in charge of the Criminal Division of the Justice Department
column3: has left the Justice Department and rejoined the law firm of Covington & Burling as vice chairman. Covington & Burling represents a long list of big bank clients tied to the financial crisis.

column1: Breuer was criticized for not pursuing prosecutions against big bank malfeasance while at the Justice Department. Neither Schapiro nor Breuer responded to our requests for comment.

It was hailed as an epic turnaround. Atlanta schools went from bad to good in a matter of years. Now teachers are accused of cheating in order to line their own pockets. But is the federal government partly to blame?
Plus
column2: how much does city hall go for these days? A New York mayoral candidate is accused of trying to bribe his way on to the ticket. Our national news continues next.

column1: (COMMERCIAL BREAK)
TAPPER: In other national news
column2: charges of racketeering
column3: theft and corruption in two states
column4: but we're not talking about the mob.

column1: We begin with Atlanta's public school system
column2: 35 teachers and school administrators
column3: indicted for filling in the right answers on their students' standardized tests starting all the way back in one 2001. Why? To make it look like their kids were improving faster than they really were. Those teachers now have until midnight tonight to turn themselves in. Several have already done so.

column1: Joining me now
column2: Randi Weingarten
column3: president of the American Federation of Teachers.

column1: Ms. Weingarten
column2: you issued a statement about this scandal
column3: saying it -- quote -- ""crystallizes the unintended consequences of our test- crazed policies.""

column1: What did you mean by that?
RANDI WEINGARTEN
column2: PRESIDENT
column3: AMERICAN FEDERATION OF TEACHERS: Well
column4: first
column5: Jake
column6: let me just also say that in that statement and throughout this period of time
column7: we have to say at the outset that cheating cannot be condoned
column8: and this is a very sad day for Atlanta.

column1: And
column2: frankly
column3: our union
column4: our local back in 2005
column5: when they saw the irregularities
column6: whistle-blew the situation and was ignored. So
column7: the bottom line is we can't condone cheating. And the vast number of teachers do an extraordinary job and do not succumb to cheating.

column1: But
column2: at the same time
column3: we have seen in city after city and state after state an environment and a climate that says that the tests are more important than anything else for kids
column4: for teachers
column5: and for schools
column6: more important than teaching and learning
column7: more important than critical thinking
column8: more important than problem solving
column9: more important than integrity.

column1: TAPPER: You say that
column2: but most of the teachers and administrators in this system seem to have had no problem operating within the confines of the law.

column1: The NATE scores
column2: the state testing scores
column3: have gone up
column4: not just with these specific teachers and administrators
column5: but across the state. So why do you think this is related to teaching to the test
column6: as opposed to just teachers trying to get ahead? We know that the administrator got big bonuses based on these improvements.

column1: WEINGARTEN: Well
column2: you know
column3: what -- if you talk to teachers about getting paid based upon test scores
column4: they will universally recoil from it and get very insulted by it. But at the same time
column5: what we've seen is in 37 or 38 different places
column6: we've seen this huge emphasis on testing and testing has narrowed the curriculum and has done -- and
column7: worse
column8: a lot of the tests that we have right now are not even correlated to what kids really need in a knowledge economy.

column1: But you are right. Most people did not succumb to cheating. Most people in Atlanta did the right thing. But what we're seeing throughout the United States is that much more time is focused on testing as opposed to teaching and learning.
Let's take Florida. In Florida
column2: you have almost 80 days a year where some testing is going on in any particular school district. In New York state
column3: where I served on the Cuomo commission
column4: we saw from some superintendents in Rochester
column5: Monroe County
column6: they told us in the first four weeks over 20
column7: 000 pretests were being given to kids to 4
column8: 000 kids in that district.

column1: TAPPER: All right. Thank you so much. We'll have you on again to talk more about education reform.
WEINGARTEN: Thank you. Thanks. Good luck with the gig.
TAPPER: Thank you so much.
From Atlanta to New York City
column2: where in the race to replace Mayor Bloomberg comes a case prosecutors are calling an unappetizing smorgasbord of graft and greed. It reads like a sleazy dime store novel from yesteryear. A Democratic state senator who wanted to be the next mayor of New York City -- good luck with that now -- figured his best chance was to run as a Republican. So he allegedly bribed GOP county leaders to back him with money he got from a real estate tycoon. Too bad the guy bankrolling him was actually an undercover FBI agent. For today's installment of ""Explain This to Me
column3: we turn to host of New York 1's ""Road to City Hall
column4: Errol Louis.

column1: Errol
column2: explain this to me
column3: who is this guy?

column1: ERROL LOUIS
column2: CNN CONTRIBUTOR: Who is this guy? Well
column3: Malcolm Smith used to be the top Democrat in the New York State Senate
column4: so he actually had quite a lot of power back in 2009. His colleagues unfortunately dumped him after about six months. So
column5: his star was not exactly on the rise. Then he just decided that maybe he could run for mayor.

column1: What everyone is mesmerized by
column2: Jake
column3: is the fact that there are so few Republicans in New York City that if you can round up even less than 50
column4: 000 votes you can be the nominee and if you get a stroke of luck as Mayor Bloomberg did or Rudy Giuliani did
column5: it's tantalizing. People think maybe they can become mayor.

column1: TAPPER: Fascinating.
And
column2: Errol
column3: lastly
column4: cash changing hands
column5: parking lots
column6: hushed conversations in restaurants
column7: is this just how business is done in New York City?

column1: LOUIS: Well
column2: you know
column3: one of the people arrested said that but I can name you dozens if not hundreds of others who really sort of play it straight. The characters who were arrested are far from the A-team -- very undistinguished
column4: sort of a freshman city council member. Malcolm Smith I just described. These are guys who weren't necessarily going to light up the sky any other way.

column1: And I haven't heard anybody yet say
column2: Jake
column3: that they're terribly surprised that this happened.

column1: TAPPER: All right. Errol Louis
column2: thank you so much.

column1: LOUIS: Thank you.
TAPPER: Hash tag
column2: you're it. Help out the New York tabloids. Send us your best headlines for the New York City bribery scandal. Tweet your ideas to @TheLeadCNN. Use the #headlinehelp. We'll read the best ones on air at the end of the show.

column1: Thinking of buying a new car? You and everyone else. The U.S. auto industry is on the comeback trail and it has the recession to thank for its turnaround. Our ""Money Lead"" is next.
(COMMERCIAL BREAK)
TAPPER: ""The Money Lead"": It looks like Motor City has found its mojo. Detroit's big three saw a surge in auto sales last month
column2: the biggest in almost six years. But
column3: surprise
column4: surprise
column5: it's not the economy or even the better business model fueling the come back.

column1: CNN Money correspondent Zain Asher is live in New York to explain this all to us. Zain
column2: what's really behind these numbers? ZAIN ASHER
column3: CNN MONEY CORRESPONDENT: Hey
column4: Jake. Well
column5: you know
column6: it's a number of things.

column1: First
column2: we've got the record low interest rates. That's making car financing attractive. Right now
column3: you're looking at just under 2.5 percent for a car loan compared to more than 4 percent in 2006. So
column4: things are very cheap right now.

column1: Also want to talk about pent-up demand. OK. So
column2: the average American car right now is pretty old. It's roughly around 11 years old. The oldest
column3: in fact
column4: believe it or not
column5: that's ever been. People are now ready to switch over to new and head to the showrooms again.

column1: Plus
column2: home sales
column3: construction
column4: and renovation activity
column5: as that increases
column6: you're going to see a big boost in pickup sales because that's what independent contractors tend to drive. Definitely good news for American car manufacturers -- Jake.

column1: TAPPER: How do these numbers compare to the sales of foreign cars here in the U.S.?
ASHER: Well
column2: it's a little all over the map. So
column3: the big three American car companies
column4: GM
column5: Ford
column6: and Chrysler
column7: were all up between 5 percent and 6 percent. Some foreign car companies like Honda saw an even bigger increase
column8: whereas Toyota and Nissan both had slightly slower months
column9: only roughly around 1 percent.

column1: It's been big a big turn-around for American car companies. They tend to focus more on pickup trucks than SUVs. They were hurt very badly during the financial crisis partly because these vehicles tend to gobble for more gas. Also
column2: a lot of the businesses that buy pickup trucks were closing down. Now
column3: we're seeing things slowly start to turn around.

column1: U.S. car companies also want to mention they're trying desperately to compete with Asian cars
column2: adding more bells and whistles. So
column3: Ford's got the Sync system
column4: Chevy has got a MyLink entertainment system working with smartphones to integrate music into the driving experience.

column1: So
column2: they're trying to compete with the Asian counterparts as well -- Jake.

column1: TAPPER: And
column2: Zain
column3: how does the future look?

column1: ASHER: Well
column2: experts predict that 15 million cars will be sold this year. Right before the financial crisis
column3: 16.5 million cars were sold. So
column4: not really that far off.

column1: Also
column2: as the housing market improves
column3: we're going to see a big boost in car sales especially with pickup trucks.

column1: One problem
column2: though
column3: I want to mention
column4: might be urbanization. More people moving to cities to find work that might have a slightly negative impact on car sales. Overall
column5: though
column6: there's a lot working in the car manufacturers' favor right now. So
column7: the upward trend should continue -- Jake.

column1: TAPPER: Do you have a car
column2: Zain? Do you drive a car? Or are you one of these New Yorkers who just takes the subway everywhere?

column1: ASHER: I used to drive a car when I was in L.A. But now
column2: I take the subway.

column1: TAPPER: All right.
Will she or won't she? I don't even know what I'm having for breakfast tomorrow
column2: but everybody already expects Hillary Clinton to know what she's planning for 2016. I will ask my political panel what their five-year plan is and what they think Clinton is up to
column3: in our 'Politics Lead."" That's coming up.

column1: (COMMERCIAL BREAK)
TAPPER: Welcome back to THE LEAD. I'm Jake Tapper.
The Politics Lead"": Nothing to see here. Just private citizen Hillary Clinton. She leaps back into the spotlight today. With the money already lining up
column2: here come the questions about 2016.

column1: The World Lead"": The North Korea crisis heating up as in heating up an old nuclear reactor and the U.S. answers with a massive missile destroyer. Is the Pentagon making all the right moves?
The Pop Lead"": I can picture it now. Clint Eastwood turning to an empty chair and asking
column2: who the heck is Lady Gaga? Details of the RNC's big money plan to get her to perform at the convention and how they got rejected.

column1: The World Lead"": The situation in North Korea seems to be careening increasingly out of control by the day. The U.S. military now says that it has a second destroyer in the region after the North announced it is restarting a nuclear reactor and leaving no doubt that it plans to use that reactor to try to make nuclear weapons. The reactor is in Yongbyon. North Korea shut it down five years ago under an agreement reached in six-party talks
column2: which included the U.S.

column1: The country made a big show of imploding one of the cooling towers at the facility in 1998. Now
column2: North Korea is turning it on again
column3: giving the usual line about how it will use the facility to generate electricity
column4: but also saying for the first time it will be used to make nuclear weapons
column5: too.

column1: North Korea is relaunching a number of other facilities
column2: including ones who enrich uranium
column3: which could also be used for nukes. This comes just a day after the U.S. decided to park a destroyer that can shoot down missiles near the Korean peninsula.

column1: Today
column2: the Pentagon announced that a second destroyer is now in the region.

column1: But the White House says it is hardly shocked by the North's latest provocation. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
JAY CARNEY
column2: WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: North Korea's announcement it will reopen or restart its nuclear facilities at Yongbyon is another indication of its
column3: you know
column4: pattern of contradicting its own commitments and its pattern of violating its international obligation.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
TAPPER: The head of the United Nations sounded a lot more alarmed by the North Korea's announcement. Secretary General Ban Ki- moon
column2: who is South Korean
column3: says the rhetoric is already away over the line.

14	John McCain's Acceptance Speech
By John McCain
September 5
column2: 2008 Thank you all very much. Tonight
column3: I have a privilege given few Americans -- the privilege of accepting our party's nomination for President of the United States. And I accept it with gratitude
column4: humility and confidence.

column1: In my life
column2: no success has come without a good fight
column3: and this nomination wasn't any different. That's a tribute to the candidates who opposed me and their supporters. They're leaders of great ability
column4: who love our country
column5: and wished to lead it to better days. Their support is an honor I won't forget.

column1: I'm grateful to the President for leading us in those dark days following the worst attack on American soil in our history
column2: and keeping us safe from another attack many thought was inevitable; and to the First Lady
column3: Laura Bush
column4: a model of grace and kindness in public and in private. And I'm grateful to the 41st President and his bride of 63 years
column5: and for their outstanding example of honorable service to our country.

column1: As always
column2: I'm indebted to my wife
column3: Cindy
column4: and my seven children. The pleasures of family life can seem like a brief holiday from the crowded calendar of our nation's business. But I have treasured them all the more
column5: and can't imagine a life without the happiness you give me. Cindy said a lot of nice things about me tonight. But
column6: in truth
column7: she's more my inspiration than I am hers. Her concern for those less blessed than we are -- victims of land mines
column8: children born in poverty and with birth defects -- shows the measure of her humanity. I know she will make a great First Lady.

column1: When I was growing up
column2: my father was often at sea
column3: and the job of raising my brother
column4: sister and me would fall to my mother alone. Roberta McCain gave us her love of life
column5: her deep interest in the world
column6: her strength
column7: and her belief we are all meant to use our opportunities to make ourselves useful to our country. I wouldn't be here tonight but for the strength of her character.

column1: My heartfelt thanks to all of you
column2: who helped me win this nomination
column3: and stood by me when the odds were long. I won't let you down. To Americans who have yet to decide who to vote for
column4: thank you for your consideration and the opportunity to win your trust. I intend to earn it.

column1: Finally
column2: a word to Senator Obama and his supporters. We'll go at it over the next two months. That's the nature of these contests
column3: and there are big differences between us. But you have my respect and admiration. Despite our differences
column4: much more unites us than divides us. We are fellow Americans
column5: an association that means more to me than any other. We're dedicated to the proposition that all people are created equal and endowed by our Creator with inalienable rights. No country ever had a greater cause than that. And I wouldn't be an American worthy of the name if I didn't honor Senator Obama and his supporters for their achievement.

column1: But let there be no doubt
column2: my friends
column3: we're going to win this election. And after we've won
column4: we're going to reach out our hand to any willing patriot
column5: make this government start working for you again
column6: and get this country back on the road to prosperity and peace.

column1: These are tough times for many of you. You're worried about keeping your job or finding a new one
column2: and are struggling to put food on the table and stay in your home. All you ever asked of government is to stand on your side
column3: not in your way. And that's just what I intend to do: stand on your side and fight for your future.

column1: And I've found just the right partner to help me shake up Washington
column2: Governor Sarah Palin of Alaska. She has executive experience and a real record of accomplishment. She's tackled tough problems like energy independence and corruption. She's balanced a budget
column3: cut taxes
column4: and taken on the special interests. She's reached across the aisle and asked Republicans
column5: Democrats and Independents to serve in her administration. She's the mother of five children. She's helped run a small business
column6: worked with her hands and knows what it's like to worry about mortgage payments and health care and the cost of gasoline and groceries.

column1: She knows where she comes from and she knows who she works for. She stands up for what's right
column2: and she doesn't let anyone tell her to sit down. I'm very proud to have introduced our next Vice President to the country. But I can't wait until I introduce her to Washington. And let me offer an advance warning to the old
column3: big spending
column4: do nothing
column5: me first
column6: country second Washington crowd: change is coming.

column1: I'm not in the habit of breaking promises to my country and neither is Governor Palin. And when we tell you we're going to change Washington
column2: and stop leaving our country's problems for some unluckier generation to fix
column3: you can count on it. We've got a record of doing just that
column4: and the strength
column5: experience
column6: judgment and backbone to keep our word to you.

column1: You know
column2: I've been called a maverick; someone who marches to the beat of his own drum. Sometimes it's meant as a compliment and sometimes it's not. What it really means is I understand who I work for. I don't work for a party. I don't work for a special interest. I don't work for myself. I work for you.

column1: I've fought corruption
column2: and it didn't matter if the culprits were Democrats or Republicans. They violated their public trust
column3: and had to be held accountable. I've fought big spenders in both parties
column4: who waste your money on things you neither need nor want
column5: while you struggle to buy groceries
column6: fill your gas tank and make your mortgage payment. I've fought to get million dollar checks out of our elections. I've fought lobbyists who stole from Indian tribes. I fought crooked deals in the Pentagon. I fought tobacco companies and trial lawyers
column7: drug companies and union bosses.

column1: I fought for the right strategy and more troops in Iraq
column2: when it wasn't a popular thing to do. And when the pundits said my campaign was finished
column3: I said I'd rather lose an election than see my country lose a war.

column1: Thanks to the leadership of a brilliant general
column2: David Petreaus
column3: and the brave men and women he has the honor to command
column4: that strategy succeeded and rescued us from a defeat that would have demoralized our military
column5: risked a wider war and threatened the security of all Americans.

column1: I don't mind a good fight. For reasons known only to God
column2: I've had quite a few tough ones in my life. But I learned an important lesson along the way. In the end
column3: it matters less that you can fight. What you fight for is the real test.

column1: I fight for Americans. I fight for you. I fight for Bill and Sue Nebe from Farmington Hills
column2: Michigan
column3: who lost their real estate investments in the bad housing market. Bill got a temporary job after he was out of work for seven months. Sue works three jobs to help pay the bills.

column1: I fight for Jake and Toni Wimmer of Franklin County
column2: Pennsylvania. Jake works on a loading dock; coaches Little League
column3: and raises money for the mentally and physically disabled. Toni is a schoolteacher
column4: working toward her Master's Degree. They have two sons
column5: the youngest
column6: Luke
column7: has been diagnosed with autism. Their lives should matter to the people they elect to office. They matter to me.

column1: I fight for the family of Matthew Stanley of Wolfboro
column2: New Hampshire
column3: who died serving our country in Iraq. I wear his bracelet and think of him every day. I intend to honor their sacrifice by making sure the country their son loved so well and never returned to
column4: remains safe from its enemies.

column1: I fight to restore the pride and principles of our party. We were elected to change Washington
column2: and we let Washington change us. We lost the trust of the American people when some Republicans gave in to the temptations of corruption. We lost their trust when rather than reform government
column3: both parties made it bigger. We lost their trust when instead of freeing ourselves from a dangerous dependence on foreign oil
column4: both parties and Senator Obama passed another corporate welfare bill for oil companies. We lost their trust
column5: when we valued our power over our principles.

column1: We're going to change that. We're going to recover the people's trust by standing up again for the values Americans admire. The party of Lincoln
column2: Roosevelt and Reagan is going to get back to basics.

column1: We believe everyone has something to contribute and deserves the opportunity to reach their God-given potential from the boy whose descendents arrived on the Mayflower to the Latina daughter of migrant workers. We're all God's children and we're all Americans.
We believe in low taxes; spending discipline
column2: and open markets. We believe in rewarding hard work and risk takers and letting people keep the fruits of their labor.

column1: We believe in a strong defense
column2: work
column3: faith
column4: service
column5: a culture of life
column6: personal responsibility
column7: the rule of law
column8: and judges who dispense justice impartially and don't legislate from the bench. We believe in the values of families
column9: neighborhoods and communities.

column1: We believe in a government that unleashes the creativity and initiative of Americans. Government that doesn't make your choices for you
column2: but works to make sure you have more choices to make for yourself.

column1: I will keep taxes low and cut them where I can. My opponent will raise them. I will open new markets to our goods and services. My opponent will close them. I will cut government spending. He will increase it.

My tax cuts will create jobs. His tax increases will eliminate them. My health care plan will make it easier for more Americans to find and keep good health care insurance. His plan will force small businesses to cut jobs
column2: reduce wages
column3: and force families into a government run health care system where a bureaucrat stands between you and your doctor.

column1: Keeping taxes low helps small businesses grow and create new jobs. Cutting the second highest business tax rate in the world will help American companies compete and keep jobs from moving overseas. Doubling the child tax exemption from $3500 to $7000 will improve the lives of millions of American families. Reducing government spending and getting rid of failed programs will let you keep more of your own money to save
column2: spend and invest as you see fit. Opening new markets and preparing workers to compete in the world economy is essential to our future prosperity.

column1: I know some of you have been left behind in the changing economy and it often seems your government hasn't even noticed. Government assistance for unemployed workers was designed for the economy of the 1950s. That's going to change on my watch. My opponent promises to bring back old jobs by wishing away the global economy. We're going to help workers who've lost a job that won't come back
column2: find a new one that won't go away.

column1: We will prepare them for the jobs of today. We will use our community colleges to help train people for new opportunities in their communities. For workers in industries that have been hard hit
column2: we'll help make up part of the difference in wages between their old job and a temporary
column3: lower paid one while they receive retraining that will help them find secure new employment at a decent wage.

column1: Education is the civil rights issue of this century. Equal access to public education has been gained. But what is the value of access to a failing school? We need to shake up failed school bureaucracies with competition
column2: empower parents with choice
column3: remove barriers to qualified instructors
column4: attract and reward good teachers
column5: and help bad teachers find another line of work.

column1: When a public school fails to meet its obligations to students
column2: parents deserve a choice in the education of their children. And I intend to give it to them. Some may choose a better public school. Some may choose a private one. Many will choose a charter school. But they will have that choice and their children will have that opportunity.

column1: Senator Obama wants our schools to answer to unions and entrenched bureaucracies. I want schools to answer to parents and students. And when I'm President
column2: they will.

column1: My fellow Americans
column2: when I'm President
column3: we're going to embark on the most ambitious national project in decades. We are going to stop sending $700 billion a year to countries that don't like us very much. We will attack the problem on every front. We will produce more energy at home. We will drill new wells offshore
column4: and we'll drill them now. We will build more nuclear power plants. We will develop clean coal technology. We will increase the use of wind
column5: tide
column6: solar and natural gas. We will encourage the development and use of flex fuel
column7: hybrid and electric automobiles.

column1: Senator Obama thinks we can achieve energy independence without more drilling and without more nuclear power. But Americans know better than that. We must use all resources and develop all technologies necessary to rescue our economy from the damage caused by rising oil prices and to restore the health of our planet. It's an ambitious plan
column2: but Americans are ambitious by nature
column3: and we have faced greater challenges. It's time for us to show the world again how Americans lead.

column1: This great national cause will create millions of new jobs
column2: many in industries that will be the engine of our future prosperity; jobs that will be there when your children enter the workforce.

column1: Today
column2: the prospect of a better world remains within our reach. But we must see the threats to peace and liberty in our time clearly and face them
column3: as Americans before us did
column4: with confidence
column5: wisdom and resolve.

column1: We have dealt a serious blow to al Qaeda in recent years. But they are not defeated
column2: and they'll strike us again if they can. Iran remains the chief state sponsor of terrorism and on the path to acquiring nuclear weapons. Russia's leaders
column3: rich with oil wealth and corrupt with power
column4: have rejected democratic ideals and the obligations of a responsible power. They invaded a small
column5: democratic neighbor to gain more control over the world's oil supply
column6: intimidate other neighbors
column7: and further their ambitions of reassembling the Russian empire. And the brave people of Georgia need our solidarity and prayers. As President I will work to establish good relations with Russia so we need not fear a return of the Cold War. But we can't turn a blind eye to aggression and international lawlessness that threatens the peace and stability of the world and the security of the American people.

column1: We face many threats in this dangerous world
column2: but I'm not afraid of them. I'm prepared for them. I know how the military works
column3: what it can do
column4: what it can do better
column5: and what it should not do. I know how the world works. I know the good and the evil in it. I know how to work with leaders who share our dreams of a freer
column6: safer and more prosperous world
column7: and how to stand up to those who don't. I know how to secure the peace.

column1: When I was five years old
column2: a car pulled up in front of our house. A Navy officer rolled down the window
column3: and shouted at my father that the Japanese had bombed Pearl Harbor. I rarely saw my father again for four years. My grandfather came home from that same war exhausted from the burdens he had borne
column4: and died the next day. In Vietnam
column5: where I formed the closest friendships of my life
column6: some of those friends never came home with me. I hate war. It is terrible beyond imagination.

column1: I'm running for President to keep the country I love safe
column2: and prevent other families from risking their loved ones in war as my family has. I will draw on all my experience with the world and its leaders
column3: and all the tools at our disposal -- diplomatic
column4: economic
column5: military and the power of our ideals -- to build the foundations for a stable and enduring peace.

column1: In America
column2: we change things that need to be changed. Each generation makes its contribution to our greatness. The work that is ours to do is plainly before us. We don't need to search for it.

column1: We need to change the way government does almost everything: from the way we protect our security to the way we compete in the world economy; from the way we respond to disasters to the way we fuel our transportation network; from the way we train our workers to the way we educate our children. All these functions of government were designed before the rise of the global economy
column2: the information technology revolution and the end of the Cold War. We have to catch up to history
column3: and we have to change the way we do business in Washington.

column1: The constant partisan rancor that stops us from solving these problems isn't a cause
column2: it's a symptom. It's what happens when people go to Washington to work for themselves and not you.

column1: Again and again
column2: I've worked with members of both parties to fix problems that need to be fixed. That's how I will govern as President. I will reach out my hand to anyone to help me get this country moving again. I have that record and the scars to prove it. Senator Obama does not.

column1: Instead of rejecting good ideas because we didn't think of them first
column2: let's use the best ideas from both sides. Instead of fighting over who gets the credit
column3: let's try sharing it. This amazing country can do anything we put our minds to. I will ask Democrats and Independents to serve with me. And my administration will set a new standard for transparency and accountability.

column1: We're going to finally start getting things done for the people who are counting on us
column2: and I won't care who gets the credit.

column1: I've been an imperfect servant of my country for many years. But I have been her servant first
column2: last and always. And I've never lived a day
column3: in good times or bad
column4: that I didn't thank God for the privilege.

column1: Long ago
column2: something unusual happened to me that taught me the most valuable lesson of my life. I was blessed by misfortune. I mean that sincerely. I was blessed because I served in the company of heroes
column3: and I witnessed a thousand acts of courage
column4: compassion and love.

column1: On an October morning
column2: in the Gulf of Tonkin
column3: I prepared for my 23rd mission over North Vietnam. I hadn't any worry I wouldn't come back safe and sound. I thought I was tougher than anyone. I was pretty independent then
column4: too. I liked to bend a few rules
column5: and pick a few fights for the fun of it. But I did it for my own pleasure; my own pride. I didn't think there was a cause more important than me.

column1: Then I found myself falling toward the middle of a small lake in the city of Hanoi
column2: with two broken arms
column3: a broken leg
column4: and an angry crowd waiting to greet me. I was dumped in a dark cell
column5: and left to die. I didn't feel so tough anymore. When they discovered my father was an admiral
column6: they took me to a hospital. They couldn't set my bones properly
column7: so they just slapped a cast on me. When I didn't get better
column8: and was down to about a hundred pounds
column9: they put me in a cell with two other Americans. I couldn't do anything. I couldn't even feed myself. They did it for me. I was beginning to learn the limits of my selfish independence. Those men saved my life.

column1: I was in solitary confinement when my captors offered to release me. I knew why. If I went home
column2: they would use it as propaganda to demoralize my fellow prisoners. Our Code said we could only go home in the order of our capture
column3: and there were men who had been shot down before me. I thought about it
column4: though. I wasn't in great shape
column5: and I missed everything about America. But I turned it down.

column1: A lot of prisoners had it worse than I did. I'd been mistreated before
column2: but not as badly as others. I always liked to strut a little after I'd been roughed up to show the other guys I was tough enough to take it. But after I turned down their offer
column3: they worked me over harder than they ever had before. For a long time. And they broke me.

column1: When they brought me back to my cell
column2: I was hurt and ashamed
column3: and I didn't know how I could face my fellow prisoners. The good man in the cell next door
column4: my friend
column5: Bob Craner
column6: saved me. Through taps on a wall he told me I had fought as hard as I could. No man can always stand alone. And then he told me to get back up and fight again for our country and for the men I had the honor to serve with. Because every day they fought for me.

column1: I fell in love with my country when I was a prisoner in someone else's. I loved it not just for the many comforts of life here. I loved it for its decency; for its faith in the wisdom
column2: justice and goodness of its people. I loved it because it was not just a place
column3: but an idea
column4: a cause worth fighting for. I was never the same again. I wasn't my own man anymore. I was my country's.

column1: I'm not running for president because I think I'm blessed with such personal greatness that history has anointed me to save our country in its hour of need. My country saved me. My country saved me
column2: and I cannot forget it. And I will fight for her for as long as I draw breath
column3: so help me God.

column1: If you find faults with our country
column2: make it a better one. If you're disappointed with the mistakes of government
column3: join its ranks and work to correct them. Enlist in our Armed Forces. Become a teacher. Enter the ministry. Run for public office. Feed a hungry child. Teach an illiterate adult to read. Comfort the afflicted. Defend the rights of the oppressed. Our country will be the better
column4: and you will be the happier. Because nothing brings greater happiness in life than to serve a cause greater than yourself.

column1: I'm going to fight for my cause every day as your President. I'm going to fight to make sure every American has every reason to thank God
column2: as I thank Him: that I'm an American
column3: a proud citizen of the greatest country on earth
column4: and with hard work
column5: strong faith and a little courage
column6: great things are always within our reach. Fight with me. Fight with me.

column1: Fight for what's right for our country.
Fight for the ideals and character of a free people.
Fight for our children's future.
Fight for justice and opportunity for all.
Stand up to defend our country from its enemies.
Stand up for each other; for beautiful
column2: blessed
column3: bountiful America.

column1: Stand up
column2: stand up
column3: stand up and fight. Nothing is inevitable here. We're Americans
column4: and we never give up. We never quit. We never hide from history. We make history.

column1: Thank you
column2: and God Bless you."	0

column2: ""My son is dead. My son is dead.""

column1: BOETTCHER: Now he is recovering at a U.S. military hospital. The lives of the American officer and the Afghan boy intersected on this stretch of highway in Khost province

column1: (on-screen): The American convoy was traveling this direction. The other way
column2: civilian vehicles. They slowed down when the convoy passed. So did a suicide bomber. And inside his car

column1: (voice-over): The soldiers were not hurt

column2: that's right
column3: Joe. I really do believe there is a little bit of symmetry here between the issue of PAYGO and the energy legislation that Republicans are going to be introducing today. What the Democrats have and are planning to bring to the floor this month is essentially a national energy tax. This so-called ""cap and trade bill"" is a means of paying for all of the runaway federal spending that we've seen under the last Administration and redoubled and increased.

column1: SCARBOROUGH: Can you explain that because we hear about cap in trade. Break it down for us as simply as you can. What does that mean for americans and their energy problem?

REP. PENCE: What it means all in the name of climate change this new regime of limiting carbon emissions from all different sources of energy production in this country but i don't think you need to look any further than the President himself
column2: Joe
column3: who literally said his cap and trade proposals were to pass
column4: that utility rates
column5: his words now
column6: would
column7: ""necessarily skyrocket"". John Dingle of Michigan and the Commerce Committee said people don't realize this is a tax and a
column8: ""great big one."" Republicans today are going to unveil a plan that takes us in the direction of energy independence.

column1: SCARBOROUGH: Trying to break this down. So where people would mainly feel it is in their power bills every week?
REP. PENCE: Places like Indiana where I'm from would see a potential doubling of their utility rates but also
column2: remember; the cost of energy goes into virtually every product we consume. This national energy tax according to some estimates could mean additional energy costs across the board of some $3
column3: 000 or more per year per household. We have a better way. We have a better solution. We're going to unveil it this morning. I'm glad to do so exclusively here on Morning Joe. The Republicans' all-of-the-above strategy
column4: we're going to say yes to giving the American people more access to American oil
column5: more domestic exploration for natural gas and coal
column6: yes to renewables like wind and solar and we're going to say a deafening yes to nuclear energy. We're going to commit this country or call on this country to build 100 new nuclear power plants in the next 20 years.

column1: SCARBOROUGH: Your alternative energy source
column2: obviously we're not there yet. The federal government may need to step in and get involved in helping the private sector.

column1: REP. PENCE: It really does
column2: Joe. We want to capture some of the revenues from offshore drilling and put it into a renewable trust fund that will be available in the development of alternative and renewable sources of energy. We just don't need to pass legislation like cap in trade that will amount to a national energy tax
column3: harm our economy at a time
column4: quite frankly
column5: when every American small business is struggling to make ends meet. There's a better way. Republicans will outline that today and I have a feeling - I just have a gut feeling there's a lot of concern even among many Democrats on capitol hill about the national energy tax looking for a better solution and I believe the American Energy Act we introduce today will be part of that.

column1: SCARBOROUGH: I think you're exactly right. A lot of Democrats are concerned. a lot of Republicans I know are concerned about the way we use energy in this country. I mean
column2: do you agree with me and a lot of conservatives that there's nothing conservative about a country that has 4% of the world's population spending 25% of the world's energy?

column1: REP. PENCE: Percentages I don't get as concerned about as the notion that appears. Joe
column2: you served on the house floor with great distinction. Remember the quote up on the wall by Daniel Webster that speaks about the resources of this country
column3: the natural resources of this country
column4: the genius of this country. He said let us call forth this nation's power. Part of that power is innovation. Part of that power is finding alternative sources of energy like wind
column5: energy and solar. Oil and coal
column6: natural gas and clean coal technologies. We just don't need to pass the Democrat cap in trade plan
column7: to answer with innovation and alternatives. That's the Republican solution.

column1: SCARBOROUGH: Teddy Roosevelt
column2: of course
column3: also talked a lot about conservation.

column1: REP. PENCE: That's right.
SCARBOROUGH: That's something we can do right now.
REP. PENCE: That's right.
SCARBOROUGH: Is that part of your package
column2: too?

column1: REP. PENCE: That's exactly right. You're one of my favorite Teddy Roosevelt Republicans
column2: Joe
column3: and we're going to make a real commitment to conservation in this legislation but
column4: remember
column5: the national energy tax is all about paying for all this spending. People should see it as no other way. They want to pass a national energy tax so you pay and they go on spending. That's the real PAYGO. Republicans have a better solution and we're looking forward to showing it to the American people.

column1: SCARBOROUGH: Thank you for coming here and talking to us about it first

column1: Frankly
column2: I think that the system was broken before the last administration got their hands on it. I started my company 21 years ago
column3: and I had a vision of wanting to provide 100 percent full family healthcare for as long as I had a company
column4: because I really felt in my heart that it was the right thing to do. I was one of the last holdouts. But
column5: sadly
column6: after about 15 years
column7: I really had a choice of either having a company or being able to provide my employees that level of healthcare. And that's sad. I tell my wife all the time -- you can have anything you want
column8: we just can't everything we want. We have the best healthcare system in the world -- we do -- but it needs to be fixed -- whether it's small business owners
column9: like myself -- I'm a manufacturer
column10: I'm on several boards in the Midwest in manufacturing.

column1: What we'd like to see is not a government-operated market
column2: but a free market. I sell (inaudible) equipment for a living. We have a trade show every year
column3: and there's hundreds and hundreds of people selling competitive products. If we had a healthcare show in my town
column4: there would be three or four people under that roof. And as a businessman yourself
column5: you know what that does to driving down costs or the lack thereof. So we would like to see more of a free-market solution
column6: going back to what made this country great -- entrepreneurialism instead of empowerments; work ethics instead of welfare. And that's what we'd like to ask you for. And I'd like to say thank you very much.

column1: THE PRESIDENT: As you know
column2: that's what we're doing largely
column3: but we also have to take care of people that can't afford to be in a position like you are. So we're going to do that. Largely
column4: I think beyond everything
column5: if you look at what's going to happen -- the competitive bidding -- every element of what we're doing is competitive bidding
column6: but we have to take care of people who need the help. And there are a lot of people like that.

column1: MR. KNOX: There's always been a safety net in the United States

column10: not free handouts for (inaudible).

column1: The groups sought to convince the public they had a right to opioids. TennesseeÃ¢ÂÂs legislature was pushed by one of those advocacy groups to pass a law requiring doctors to prescribe opioids if a patient insisted.
Purdue also used fake advocacy literature
column2: such as pamphlets
column3: videos
column4: and social media
column5: to convince the public that long-term use of opioids led to a higher Ã¢ÂÂquality of life.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: The firm sent doctors fake literature with similar claims but added material on how Oxycontin Ã¢ÂÂ PurdueÃ¢ÂÂs financial rainmaker Ã¢ÂÂ was better for patients than other opioids on the market.Ã¢ÂÂ
