column1: By: Lexy
On Twitter? Follow me:
@PoliticallyRYT
Have Information? Message me!" 1
24	"Transcript: NPR's Full Interview With Sen. Marco Rubio
Sen. Marco Rubio
column2: R-Fla.
column3: is running for president and spoke with NPR's Steve Inskeep on Monday ahead of his big announcement.

column1: Rubio talked about how he hopes to stand out in the 2016 presidential field
column2: Indiana's religious freedom law
column3: the president's deal with Iran
column4: immigration policy
column5: and America's warming relationship with Cuba.

column1: STEVE INSKEEP: In all the years I've been interviewing people
column2: I don't think I've spoken with somebody on the day of an announcement like this. And I was thinking that if it were me
column3: there might be a moment the night before where I was lying awake wondering if I was really ready for this. Did you have a moment of wondering if you were really ready for this?

column1: SEN. MARCO RUBIO: Not last night
column2: but
column3: I mean
column4: if you reach the point where you're wondering it the night before you announce
column5: then you probably shouldn't run. I think anyone who's thinking about the highest office in the most powerful nation on earth has to spend some time analyzing whether they're prepared for the job. And look
column6: I think the job is perhaps the most difficult job in politics anywhere in the world. You're the leader of the most powerful military on the planet. You make decisions that have global implications. And it's happening at a time when the country's going through an extraordinary economic transformation that is leaving many people insecure. But from all that and given both my experience at the local
column7: state and federal level
column8: and especially the lessons learned over the last five years as I've been engaged in federal policy making
column9: I'm very confident that I have the judgment and the knowledge that I need to do a very good job as president of the United States. And clearly
column10: as you see the history of the presidency
column11: people who go into that office grow
column12: the office helps you grow as well as you go through it and that's
column13: having the ability to learn is a big part of the office as well. But I'm certainly capable from day 1. I'm very confident that I have the capability from day no. 1 to lead this country.

column1: Are you also affirming that you are not giving up your Ã¢ÂÂ are you also affirming that you are not running for Senate?
I am not. And the reason I think strongly about that is
column2: if you've decided that you want to serve this country as its president
column3: that's what you should be running for. And I find myself in a situation where my Senate seat comes up for re-election at the exact same time as the presidency. And by Florida law
column4: you can't run for both
column5: anyway. But to even be thinking about a Plan B in case this doesn't work
column6: I think diminishes your ability to succeed on the campaign because your mind will always be on
column7: if this doesn't work
column8: then I can do something else. And the truth is that
column9: you know
column10: I don't want to be in politics my entire life. And I'm prepared to serve this country now in its highest office and I'm excited about this opportunity.

column1: You'll be in a crowded Republican field. How do you expect to distinguish yourself from your opponents on the Republican side?
Well
column2: I expect that I'm going to go out and tell people my vision for the future of this country. I'm going to be very specific and detailed about our plans and how we're going to get there. In fact
column3: I've done that already. We have a very detailed policy position that we've outlined on numerous issues over the last two years
column4: culminating in my book that just came out earlier this year
column5: American Dreams. And I think from that
column6: voters are going to analyze the different position of the candidates
column7: their capabilities
column8: their history
column9: but more importantly their view of the future and their plans to get us there and I'm very confident that that will lead to success.

column1: Is there a sentence that people can have in their heads? Marco Rubio is different from the others because...
He has the clear view of how the 21st century can also be an American century.
We're in a moment where you have put out plans proposing to reshape the way the federal government deals with federal assistance to the poor.
Yes.
We're in a moment where Jeb Bush
column2: who may also run
column3: has a superPAC called Right to Rise. And this week
column4: of course
column5: Hillary Clinton declared her campaign for the presidency talking about helping everyday people. What's going on there?

column1: Well
column2: that's a good thing for our country because equality of opportunity has always defined us as a people and as a nation. And the fact that there are millions of people now in America that are starting to have significant doubts about whether we're still that kind of country should be deeply concerning to us. Our identity is at stake. Every country in the world has rich people. What makes America different is
column3: we've had millions and millions of people who through hard work and perseverance are able to achieve happiness and upward mobility. And the fact that that's in danger and in question is deeply concerning
column4: and should be. It threatens our identity. So I'm glad that people are talking about it. Ultimately
column5: talking about it won't be enough. You have to have plans that work to help us address it. And for me it begins by embracing and acknowledging the reality that we are living through a massive transformation into this post-industrial 21st century economy that is both disruptive but also exciting. It comes not just with challenges
column6: but also with opportunities. But we can only embrace those opportunities if we move forward on thinking about the changes we're going to have to make in order to fully enter the 21st century.

column1: What's one way that your approach would be different from Jeb Bush's or Hillary Clinton's?
Well
column2: as far as the Republican field is concerned
column3: there will be plenty of time for comparison shopping. The truth is
column4: for voters
column5: the truth is that at this moment most of my opponents in the field beyond talking about upward mobility have not clearly outlined what they would do. We have a clear policy outline on each of these issues that people can read about. And if
column6: you know
column7: all of my opponents and other candidates in the Republican field choose to adopt some of those ideas
column8: I'll consider that a victory as well as flattery. But on the Democratic side
column9: I think
column10: you know
column11: Hillary Clinton is someone who's deeply wedded to the institutions of the 20th century. Her plans are to spend more money on the existing higher education system. That system doesn't work any more. It doesn't work any more because we don't graduate enough young people from high school ready to work. We need to do more of that Ã¢ÂÂ ready to work in trades as mechanics
column12: airplane technicians and plumbers and engineers. These are good Ã¢ÂÂ welders. These are good 21st century jobs and we are capable of teaching people how to do that so at 18
column13: 19 years of age
column14: they can be employed. We also need to have more flexible
column15: more flexibility in higher education for working Americans who can't afford to drop everything and go to school full-time for four years. We need to have programs that allow someone who works full time to learn at their own pace
column16: on their own time
column17: so that a receptionist can become a paralegal
column18: so that the home-health aide making $10 an hour can become a dental hygienist making $55
column19: 000 a year. And then we have to have more quality measures in higher education. For example
column20: before you take out a student loan--

column1: Mhmm
I have a bill that says every student
column2: before you take out a student loan
column3: needs to be told how much you can expect to make when you graduate from that school with the degree you're pursuing so you can make an informed decision about whether or not it's worth it to borrow a bunch of money for that degree.

column1: A Florida political reporter noticed that you spent a plane ride sitting beside Jeb Bush
column2: more than two hours
column3: coming back from an NRA convention. Did you guys talk about the presidential campaign at all?

column1: Not in great detail. Jeb and I are friends
column2: we'll always be friends. And I have tremendous admiration for him as a person
column3: what he did as governor
column4: and personal affection. And that's not going to change. I don't view
column5: I'm not running against Jeb Bush and I'm not running against anybody in this field. I'm running because I strongly believe that I have something to offer this country that no one else in the field does at this moment in our history. And I'm going to go out there and do the best job that I can and Ã¢ÂÂ but
column6: I mean
column7: that's not going to impact our relationship in any way that's going to change how we feel about one another and it was great to see him and spend quality time just talking about good times and everything going on ...

column1: You didn't talk politics very much at all?
... and everything in between. Sure
column2: I mean we had observations about Ã¢ÂÂ we joked with a lot of the passengers who saw us sitting next to each other and we took some pictures with people and we told them
column3: we warned them how historic a picture like that may be one day. And
column4: um
column5: but you know
column6: we talked about the Masters
column7: we talked about the Paleo diet
column8: we talked about the Miami Dolphins. I mean it
column9: we talked about
column10: reminisced about old war stories from our time in the legislature
column11: when I was in the legislature and he was governor. It was just a host of things.

column1: Sooner or later if you go forward and he goes forward
column2: there's going to be a moment where you're going to have to say
column3: ""Here's why it should be me and not him.""

column1: I don't know. I mean
column2: I think this year's going to be quite different in that regard. We have a quality field of candidates who are going to be well financed and experienced
column3: who are going to be running. And I think that'll change the nature of the race. There'll certainly be moments when others will try to draw distinctions. But in my mind
column4: I'm going to talk about who I am and what I want to do. And I'll let voters make the decision about who they think is best capable at this moment of leading our country.

column1: You scheduled an announcement at Miami's Freedom Tower
column2: which has historic significance because Cubans who fled Fidel Castro's regime in the 60s and 70s received federal aid there. This brings to mind that you have strongly criticized President Obama's restoration of relations with Cuba. If you're elected
column3: would you reverse that policy?

column1: Absolutely
column2: and I think the reason why is because I'm interested in
column3: my interest in Cuba is freedom and democracy. I think the Cuban people
column4: they are free
column5: have the right to choose any economic model they want to follow. I don't believe these changes will actually further democracy. In fact
column6: I think they will make it harder to achieve. The goal of the Castro regime is to create the impression and the reality that their form of government is a legitimate form of government and set it in concrete. They know they have a generational challenge. Most of their top leaders are in their 80s. The actuarial tables tell you they don't have much longer. And they want to leave in place global recognition for this form of government so that it can continue in perpetuity. And that means the Cuban people will never have the chance to experience what the people in the Dominican Republic and Haiti have
column7: what the people in Mexico have
column8: what the people in Peru have
column9: what the people in Colombia have
column10: which is free and fair elections. And that's all I want for the people in Cuba. And I think U.S. policy towards Cuba is a major leverage point that we can use to help the Cuban people achieve freedom for themselves.

column1: But help me think through this. The president made this announcement
column2: they're working on getting an embassy going at some point in the future. He went to Summit of the Americas where other countries in Latin America very much welcomed the restoration of relations. You're saying that if you're elected
column3: you would close that embassy
column4: you would break diplomatic ties
column5: you would go back to the way things were?

column1: We have an interest section in Cuba and it will continue to operate
column2: but an embassy
column3: I'm not
column4: I don't believe this country should be diplomatically recognizing a nation of the nature of Cuba. Obviously there are other dictatorships in the world that we have relations with by geopolitical reality. You know
column5: China's the largest country in the world
column6: the second largest economy
column7: the second largest military force. There are geopolitical realities there. Cuba is a brutal
column8: tyrannical dictatorship 90 miles from the shore of our country. It is a nation that helps North Korea evade U.N. weapon sanctions. It is a country that harbors fugitives from American justice
column9: including Medicare fraudsters and someone who killed a police officer in the United States. And I just think that we should have continued with the policy and perhaps looked for new ways of Ã¢ÂÂ continue with the policy of not recognizing that regime and not allowing them access to economic growth that would allow them to perpetuate themselves in power
column10: and continue to search for ways to provide the Cuban people with more information about the reality of the world so they would be empowered to eventually create for themselves a democratic society.

column1: You've also said that you would reverse the president's deal with Iran
column2: assuming that that is finalized. You said you would absolutely do that. What would that look like on day one?

column1: Well
column2: I would not adhere Ã¢ÂÂ well
column3: we have to understand the deal
column4: basically
column5: can be what it is on paper. What the president is banking on is that he's going to use a national security waiver to lift the sanctions on Iran
column6: the economic sanctions that now exist. And we would simply re-impose the sanctions. And I still have tremendous questions about whether this deal's even viable. The Iranians are now saying that what we're saying the deal is and what they understand it to be are two different things. This issue of them asking for immediate relief of sanctions the minute the deal is signed is going to be a deal breaker. I hope it would be a deal break for this administration. And at the end of the day
column7: we need to recognize that what Iran is trying to do here
column8: and this is clear to anyone who has inside knowledge into this or has followed it closely
column9: Iran is trying to maintain all the infrastructure they need to be nuclear capable without agreeing to any irreversible concessions. And that seems to be what they have achieved
column10: if in fact this moves forward. So in my mind
column11: we would just reinstitute the sanctions.

column1: But I'm just thinking this through. The deal is made. It's made not just with the United States
column2: but with the European allies. Would you move forward with re-imposing sanctions even if the Europeans don't go along with it?

column1: Yes
column2: it wouldn't be as effective
column3: obviously. We would
column4: ultimately
column5: I think
column6: the Europeans are going to have a test anyway because the Iranians are going to violate the sanctions at some point. They're going to evade it either by trying to take advantage of loopholes in the deal
column7: or they'll just flat out evade it because they've always had a secret component to their
column8: to their program. And at that point
column9: they're going to have a huge test on their hands
column10: which is
column11: are they willing to live by the agreement that they even signed on to? But from the United States' perspective
column12: while we want our allies to join us in this endeavor
column13: and certainly sanctions against Iran would be more effective were they in conjunction with our allies around the world
column14: we have to look out for our own national security concerns. And in my mind
column15: if the president wanted this to be a permanent deal that survived his presidency
column16: he would have brought it to Congress.

column1: I'm just thinking through further
column2: though
column3: as part of this deal
column4: assuming it's finalized
column5: the Iranians get rid of a vast amount of enriched uranium
column6: almost all they have. They limit the amount of enrichment that they will have. They limit the number of centrifuges they will operate and they will allow inspections for decades
column7: actually. So you would say
column8: all that
column9: forget about it
column10: it's done.

column1: They would retain all the infrastructure
column2: first of all
column3: they ...

column1: They retain infrastructure
column2: sure.

column1: They retain not only just infrastructure
column2: they retain centrifuges
column3: too. They may not be spinning them
column4: but they will retain them in their possession. They continue to develop their long range missile capabilities
column5: which are unstopped. There's no prohibition on them acquiring a weapon design as they probably
column6: may even already have. They continue to sponsor terrorism all over the world. In fact
column7: now they'll have more funding to pay for it
column8: in places they already control
column9: places like Beirut. They're increasingly active in Yemen. Their hand and their role's clear in Bahrain and in a growing number of places around the world. And they continue to be run by a radical Shia cleric who has apocalyptic views of the future and of their role in it. So none of these things change. Their infrastructure will remain in place and at some point
column10: they could follow the North Korean model very easily
column11: which is they can cook up an excuse for why they need to have a weapon program and move forward on it.

column1: Is war inevitable then?

I hope not. My hope is that we can delay a program long enough and you would hope that there would be some sort of change in leadership in Iran that would at least allow them to decide that they would rather have an economy than have a weapon. You can't guarantee it. But at the end of the day no one wants war
column2: but I actually think that this deal could advance the prospects of war. I think this deal and the fact that Iran will retain nuclear infrastructure increases the likelihood that one of their neighbors may take action against them
column3: whether it's Israel or the Saudis or someone else. It also increases the likelihood now
column4: that Iran becomes even more aggressive in its proxy wars that it's conducting all over the world. It also increases the likelihood that they'll increase their conventional capabilities threatening our U.S. presence in the region. And ultimately I think it almost guarantees an arms race in the region
column5: because the Saudis have made very clear
column6: and others
column7: the Egyptians as well
column8: that whatever Iran has
column9: they'll get as well. So if Iran is allowed to enrich to a certain level
column10: they will begin doing the same
column11: requiring a capability to do the same.

column1: Let me ask about a domestic issue. In recent weeks
column2: the state of Indiana passed a Religious Freedom law
column3: which was interpreted by many as discrimination
column4: by others
column5: as protection for people who don't want to take part in gay marriage. You defended the law and spoke about the hypothetical example of a florist who was asked to participate in a gay marriage and wanted to refuse. You said that person should have the right to follow their religious beliefs. Indiana
column6: though
column7: has since changed the law. Do you still support that concept?

column1: Well
column2: to be fair
column3: I haven't read the change in detail to give you an opinion on it specifically
column4: but I'll tell you where I stand. I don't believe you can discriminate against people. So I don't believe it's right for a florist to say
column5: I'm not going to provide you flowers because you're gay. I think there's a difference between not providing services to a person because of their identity
column6: who they are or who they love
column7: and saying
column8: I'm not going to participate in an event
column9: a same-sex wedding
column10: because that violates my religious beliefs. There's a distinction between those two things. So
column11: certainly
column12: you can't not Ã¢ÂÂ it's immoral and wrong to say
column13: I'm not going to allow someone who's gay or lesbian to use my restaurant
column14: stay in my hotel
column15: or provide photography service to them because they're gay. The difference here is
column16: we're not talking about discriminating against a person because of who they are
column17: we're talking about someone who's saying Ã¢ÂÂ what I'm talking about
column19: is someone who's saying
column20: I just don't want to participate as a vendor for an event
column21: a specific event that violates the tenets of my faith.

column1: What if two gay people get married and then they go that night to a hotel. Can the hotelkeeper refuse service to them?
That's not part of an event. Again
column2: I mean
column3: that's
column4: there's a difference between saying
column5: we're not going to allow you to stay in our hotel
column6: common lodging establishment where people have a right to shelter
column7: food
column8: medical care
column9: and saying we're not going to
column10: what we're not going to do is provide services to an event
column11: to an actual event
column12: which is the wedding itself. And I think that's the distinction point that people have been pointing to
column13: and
column14: because mainstream Christianity teaches that marriage is between one man and one woman. People feel very strongly about that. And to ask someone to individually provide services to something of that nature
column15: I think violates their religious liberty.

column1: There's a big question lurking here
column2: which is that most Americans
column3: according to surveys
column4: now support gay marriage. A large minority of Americans still oppose gay marriage. The question is
column5: that people seem to be wrestling with
column6: is
column7: what ground do opponents of gay marriage have left to stand on? What ground should they have to stand on?

column1: First of all
column2: if the majority of Americans support gay marriage
column3: then you'll see it reflected in changes in state law
column4: which has always regulated marriage. And so at the end of the day
column5: if a majority of people in any given state in this country petition their legislature to change the definition of marriage to include the marriage of two people of the same sex
column6: that'll be the law of the land. And that is what it is. Separate from that
column7: there's a constitutional protection of religious liberty that allows people to live by the tenets of their faith both in their public and in private life. That doesn't mean that you're allowed to go in and disrupt a gay wedding. But by the same token
column8: it doesn't mean that someone's allowed to come to you and force you to be a participant in a ceremony that violates the tenets of your faith. And to be honest
column9: in the real world
column10: 99.9% of the time
column11: a same-sex couple doesn't want a florist or a photographer at their wedding that doesn't agree with the choice that they've made. So we're really talking about an issue that in large part is really not going to manifest itself in daily life
column12: but in the instances that it does
column13: there are individuals that don't want to be compelled by force of law to participate in an event that puts them in the position of violating their religious faith. There's a difference between that and discriminating against an individual because of who they are.

column1: Are there are other specific situations on your mind where you feel that people who are opposed to gay marriage would need some kind of protection from
column2: from it?

column1: Well
column2: I mean
column3: that's the one that's in the news today. Again
column4: I don't
column5: we can always sit here and engage in hypotheticals
column6: this
column7: that
column8: and the other
column9: but at the end of the day
column10: I mean
column11: that's the one that's emerged because there's real cases behind people being fined for not providing services to a
column12: to a ceremony as opposed to individuals.

column1: When we spoke last year
column2: we talked about immigration
column3: an issue on which you worked for a time on an immigration reform bill. You said
column4: first
column5: the reason to do that is not political
column6: it's substantive. But
column7: second
column8: that there would be a political effect. That if the Republican Party deals with immigration
column9: it would then have an opportunity to talk with Latino voters about other issues. And
column10: of course
column11: this is a voter group where Republicans have done very poorly in recent elections. Immigration hasn't been dealt with. What are the likely consequences for the Republican party in 2016?

column1: Well
column2: again
column3: every candidate has a different position on where they stand on the issue. From my perspective
column4: I continue to believe it's an issue we need to address. The only point I've made is that I think the lessons of the last couple of years
column5: for me
column6: is that we're not going to be able to deal with it in one big piece of legislation. I still think we need to do immigration reform. I just don't think you can do it in a comprehensive
column7: massive piece of legislation
column8: given the lack of trust that there is today in the federal government. I honestly believe that the key to moving forward on immigration is to first and foremost prove to the American people that we are going to bring future illegal immigration under control Ã¢ÂÂ that if we legalize 12 million people
column9: they won't be replaced by 12 million more who are here illegally. And I honestly believe
column10: given my experiences on this issue now
column11: that if we did that
column12: the American people and the majority of Republicans and conservatives will be very reasonable and
column13: and responsible about how we address the reality that we have 12 million human beings living in this country illegally.

column1: But we're in a circumstance
column2: granted there's still time
column3: but we're in a circumstance where it doesn't look like immigration legislation is going to get through Congress before 2016. What does that mean for your party?

column1: And I think
column2: I think it's nearly Ã¢ÂÂ well
column3: I just outlined to you what I think the key is to moving forward. And I think that's impossible as long as Barack Obama's president now
column4: because on two instances
column5: particularly very recently
column6: last year
column7: he issued an executive order ordering federal agencies not to enforce immigration law. So if I'm telling you that the key to moving forward is the enforcement of immigration law
column8: then that says the notion that future illegal immigration will be brought under control
column9: and you have a president that's ordering agencies not to enforce immigration law
column10: our ability to convince people
column11: no matter what we pass
column12: that future illegal immigration will be brought under control
column13: as long as Barack Obama's president
column14: is nil.

column1: How do you keep from getting hammered on that in a general election where the Hispanic vote may be very important?
Well
column2: I don't know about the others
column3: but I've done more immigration than Hillary Clinton ever did. I mean
column4: I helped pass an immigration bill in a Senate dominated by Democrats. And that's more than she's ever done. She's given speeches on it
column5: but she's never done anything on it. So I have a record of trying to do something on it. It didn't work because at the end of the day
column6: we did not sufficiently address the issue of
column7: of illegal immigration and I warned about that throughout that process
column8: as well
column9: that I didn't think we were doing enough to give that bill a chance of moving forward in the House.

column1: Does your biography help?
I think biography's part of all of our lives
column2: all of our candidacies
column3: because it certainly influences how you view the country and how you view issues. I have a personal attachment to the working class because it's where I come from
column4: it's still the neighborhood I live in
column5: it's the people my children go to school with
column6: it's the community that I'm involved in. And
column7: but I also happen to think it's the identity of our country. And every candidate
column8: you know
column9: will bring to bear their experiences in life and how it's guided them and influenced their thinking
column10: but from my perspective
column11: I think it matters simply because it informs me on my policy decisions.

column1: There's a big question here
column2: also
column3: because the Republican party
column4: as many people have noted
column5: faces a demographic challenge that gets a little worse with every election cycle. Growing groups in society
column6: such as Latinos and others
column7: are voting increasingly Democratic
column8: and Republican voter groups
column9: particularly older white voters
column10: are getting smaller. What's the Republican Party need to do about that?

column1: Well
column2: at the end
column3: I don't think people go to the ballot box and say
column4: I'm a Latino
column5: therefore I'm voting Democrat. I think they bring with them their hopes and fears about the future
column6: and they vote for whoever they think best understands them. And the challenge the Republican Party has had is unfairly
column7: but it's the reality
column8: they've been portrayed as a party that doesn't care about people who are trying to make it. A disproportionate number of people who are trying to make it
column9: who are working class
column10: who are out there working for a living at $18 an hour
column11: $15 an hour
column12: happen to also be people from minority communities. And if you think someone doesn't care or understand people like you
column13: no matter what your policies are
column14: it's going to be difficult to get them to listen to you
column15: much less vote for you. And so I hope the Republican Party can become the champion of the working class because I think our policy proposals of limited government and free enterprise are better for the people who are trying to make it than big government is. The fact is that big government helps the people who have made it. If you can afford to hire an army of lawyers
column16: lobbyists and others to help you navigate and sometimes influence the law
column17: you'll benefit. And so that's why you see big banks
column19: keep winning. And everybody else is stuck and being left behind.

column1: So you're beginning this gigantic game of Survivor with who knows how many other candidates. You're smiling as I say that. With who knows how many other candidates
column2: what will determine who survives ultimately and how will you make sure it's you?

column1: Well
column2: there are basics about any campaign. Obviously you'll have to put time into it
column3: you'll have to be able to raise sufficient funds to communicate your message. And on a daily basis
column4: you have to make sure you do the best you can to help convince people in a crowded field that you're the best person at this time for the job that you seek. But beyond it
column5: I really think the key is
column6: who can inspire our country into believing that the future doesn't have to be worse than our past
column7: that the 21st century can be better than the 20th. And then once you've inspired them to believe that
column8: showing them how we can accomplish it. And I feel very confident in our ability to do it and I think that's why we're going to win.

column1: Should I think of this as an insurgent campaign
column2: because you don't have the resources of Jeb Bush
column3: particularly?

column1: Well
column2: I think our resources will be sufficient to do the job we're trying to do. At the end of the day
column3: this is not a fundraising competition in and of itself. You also have to have a message and a messenger and a policy outline that proves to people that
column4: that your campaign is better for them than what someone else is offering. But I'm certainly not the frontrunner and Ã¢ÂÂ but that's O.K. The election isn't tomorrow.

column1: What are you doing to make sure you don't run out of money?
(Laughs) We're going to
column2: we
column3: we're trying to raise as much money as we can and that's important. As long as the media outlets keep charging us for advertising
column4: we'll have to keep raising money.

column1: Senator Rubio
column2: thanks very much.

column1: Thank you."	0

It turns out that one reason why Estonia has been the lone feel-good story amidst the Eurozone crisis is that its tax filing system is scarily efficient.
Introduced in 2000
column2: the system allows individual income taxes
column3: business taxes and excises to be filed electronically.

column1: Using a secure ID
column2: a filer simply completes pre-made forms and approves the document with a digital signature.

column1: The process takes an average of five minutes
column2: and last year 94% of tax declarations were filed electronically.

column1: Advertisement
Advertisement
The system is part of the country's impressive e-government initiative
column2: which allows Estonians to do everything from vote to fill out prescriptions to look up school grades online.

column1: Estonians begin filing their taxes on Wednesday."	0

27	"President Trump made a barely veiled threat today on Twitter to Representative Maxine Waters (D-CA) after the congresswoman called for the continued public shaming of members of his administration to hold them accountable for the presidentÃ¢ÂÂs heinous policies
column2: particularly the immigration policy debacle that led to the separation of thousands of children from their refugee parents at the border.

column1: Congresswoman Maxine Waters
column2: an extraordinarily low IQ person
column3: has become
column4: together with Nancy Pelosi
column5: the Face of the Democrat Party. She has just called for harm to supporters
column6: of which there are many
column7: of the Make America Great Again movement. Be careful what you wish for Max! Ã¢ÂÂ Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) June 25

column1: Trump
column2: of course
column3: lied about what Rep. Waters called for which was peaceful protests and public demonstrations rather than the Ã¢ÂÂharmÃ¢ÂÂ he claims. The Ã¢ÂÂBe careful what you wish for Max!Ã¢ÂÂ quote
column4: however
column5: was a dog whistle call to action for his supporters to attack Rep. Waters on par with his warning during his campaign when discussing Hillary Clinton that perhaps Ã¢ÂÂthe Second Amendment peopleÃ¢ÂÂ i.e.
column6: gun owners could solve the problem.

column1: While some people may consider TrumpÃ¢ÂÂs tweet as more cheap theatrics for his base
column2: the presidentÃ¢ÂÂs hate-mongering towards Waters has real-life consequences as the news about a San Pedro
column3: California man demonstrates.

column1: Anthony Scott Lloyd
column3: is pled guilty on April 16th to a charge of threatening to kill Rep. Maxine Waters because of her criticism of President Trump.

column1: According to the Los Angeles Times
column2: Lloyd Ã¢ÂÂfaces a single count of threatening a United States official
column3: according to a plea agreement filed March 26. It is punishable by up to 10 years in prison and a $250
column4: 000 fine.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: LloydÃ¢ÂÂs plea details the voicemail that he left at Congresswoman WatersÃ¢ÂÂ Washington DC office last October that used both a racial slur and an anti-gay epithet to refer to the representative and stated that:
Ã¢ÂÂIf you continue to make threats towards the president
column2: youÃ¢ÂÂre going to wind up dead
column3: Maxine
column4: Ã¢ÂÂcause weÃ¢ÂÂll kill you.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: The voicemail was forwarded to the FBI who investigated it and arrested Lloyd who claims that the call was a Ã¢ÂÂspur of the momentÃ¢ÂÂ decision made while listening to conservative talk radio and that he had no real intention of following through with the threat.
Unfortunately
column2: we have no such assurances from the president himself
column3: and given TrumpÃ¢ÂÂs penchant for simply ignoring the rule of law
column4: that is a frightening proposition.

column1: The contrast here is stark between Trump and Waters and the other Democrats whose calls for peaceful activism through public declarations of disgust and shaming of deplorable policies and behaviors are met by Trump and his Republican enablers with threats laden with hints of violence.
When those threats lead deranged Trump supporters to take action beyond mere threatening phone calls
column2: the responsibility for incitement to violence will be squarely at TrumpÃ¢ÂÂs feet.

column1: Correction: The original headline to this story erroneously implied that Anthony Scott Lloyd
column2: the man who threatened Rep. Waters
column3: did so on the same day as President TrumpÃ¢ÂÂs tweet about the Congresswoman on June 25th. An editing error also caused the timing of the guilty plea to be reported as happening that same day
column4: even though it actually took place over two months prior to TrumpÃ¢ÂÂs June 25th tweet. The story has been revised to reflect the actual chronology of the events. Washington Press greatly regrets the errors.

column1: President Trump has sent tweets criticizing Rep. Waters prior to the tweet on June 25th
column2: including this one from March prior to Mr. LloydÃ¢ÂÂs plea. Therefore the conclusion that TrumpÃ¢ÂÂs bullying tactics have dangerous real life consequences remains valid."	1

Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton are debating in Milwaukee tonight
column2: their second one-on-one debate. It's started at 9 p.m. The Fix team and other Washington Post reporters are using Genius annotations to explain what it all meant. Wp Get the full experience. Choose your plan ArrowRight To see an annotation
column3: click or tap the highlighted part of the transcript; if you would like to leave your own annotations
column4: make sure you have a Genius account. Post staff annotations will appear by default; others are in a menu that you can see in the upper right when you click or tap on an annotation.

column1: WOODRUFF: Good evening
column2: and thank you. We are happy to welcome you to Milwaukee for this Democratic debate.

column1: WOODRUFF: We are especially pleased to thank our partners at Facebook
column2: who have helped us set up a vibrant conversation among voters who are undecided. And tonight you're going to hear some of their questions for the candidates. And you can follow along at home on the PBS NewsHour page on Facebook.

column1: Advertisement
We also want to thank our hosts
column2: the University of Wisconsin
column3: Milwaukee
column4: on whose campus we meet
column5: here in the beautiful Helen Bader Concert Hall.

column1: IFILL: We want to also extend our warm thanks to Milwaukee Public Radio and Milwaukee Public Television
column2: as well as all of our friends at the PBS member stations across the country tuning in tonight.

column1: This is the sixth time the Democrats have met face to face. Each time
column2: we learn more about them and the presidents they say they want to be. You know you're watching -- whether you're a Democrat
column3: a Republican
column4: or neither -- because you believe the outcome of the election is important to you. And we believe that
column5: too.

column1: With that
column2: let's welcome the candidates to the stage. Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
WOODRUFF: Welcome
column2: Senator
column3: great to see you.

column1: Advertisement
And former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton.
(APPLAUSE)
Very good to be here with you.
CLINTON: Thank you.
IFILL: Welcome to you both.
WOODRUFF: Now
column2: a word about format. There will be two short breaks
column3: and the rules are simple: 90 seconds for each answer and 30 seconds for the other candidate to respond.

column1: IFILL: With Iowa and New Hampshire behind us
column2: we are now broadening the conversation to America's heartland and beyond
column3: including here in Wisconsin. Now let's turn to the candidates for their opening statements. The order was decided by coin toss. And
column4: Senator Sanders
column5: you go first.

column1: SANDERS: Well
column2: Gwen and Judy
column3: thank you very much for hosting this event. And
column4: PBS
column5: thank you.

column1: Nine months ago
column2: our campaign began. And when it began
column3: we had no political organization
column4: no money
column5: and not much name recognition outside of the state of Vermont. A lot has happened in nine months.

column1: Advertisement
And what has happened is
column2: I think
column3: the American people have responded to a series of basic truths
column4: and that is that we have today a campaign finance system which is corrupt
column5: which is undermining American democracy
column6: which allows Wall Street and billionaires to pour huge sums of money into the political process to elect the candidates of their choice.

column1: SANDERS: And aligned with a corrupt campaign finance system is a rigged economy. And that's an economy where ordinary Americans are working longer hours for low wagers. They are worried to death about the future of their kids. And yet they are seeing almost all new income and all new wealth going to the top 1 percent.
And then in addition to that
column2: the American people are looking around and they see a broken criminal justice system. They see more people in jail in the United States of America than any other country on earth
column3: 2.2 million. We're spending $80 billion a year locking up fellow Americans.

column1: Advertisement
They see kids getting arrested for marijuana
column2: getting in prison
column3: getting a criminal record
column4: while they see executives on Wall Street who pay billions of dollars in settlements and get no prosecution at all. No criminal records for them.

column1: I think what our campaign is indicating is that the American people are tired of establishment politics
column2: tired of establishment economics. They want a political revolution in which millions of Americans stand up
column3: come together
column4: not let the Trumps of the world divide us
column5: and say
column6: you know what
column7: in this great country
column8: we need a government that represents all of us
column9: not just a handful of wealthy campaign contributors.

column1: Thank you.
IFILL: Thank you
column2: Senator Sanders.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
IFILL: Thank you
column2: Senator Sanders.

column1: Secretary Clinton.
CLINTON: I'm running for president to knock down all the barriers that are holding Americans back
column2: and to rebuild the ladders of opportunity that will give every American a chance to advance
column3: especially those who have been left out and left behind.

column1: Advertisement
I know a lot of Americans are angry about the economy. And for good cause. Americans haven't had a raise in 15 years. There aren't enough good-paying jobs
column2: especially for young people. And yes
column3: the economy is rigged in favor of those at the top.

column1: We both agree that we have to get unaccountable money out of our political system and that we have to do much more to ensure that Wall Street never wrecks main street again.
But I want to go further. I want to tackle those barriers that stand in the way of too many Americans right now. African-Americans who face discrimination in the job market
column2: education
column3: housing
column4: and the criminal justice system.

column1: Hardworking immigrant families living in fear
column2: who should be brought out of the shadows so they and their children can have a better future. Guaranteeing that women's work finally gets the pay
column3: the equal pay that we deserve.

column1: Advertisement

I think America can only live up to its potential when we make sure that every American has a chance to live up to his or her potential. That will be my mission as president. And I think together we will make progress.
WOODRUFF: Thank you both.
(APPLAUSE)
WOODRUFF: Thank you both. And we'll be right back after a short break to begin questions.
WOODRUFF: And
column2: welcome back to this PBS Newshour debate
column3: Democratic debate
column4: here in Milwaukee. Let's get right to the questions.

column1: Senator Sanders
column2: to you first. Coming off the results in Iowa and New Hampshire
column3: there are many voters who are taking a closer look at you
column4: and your ideas
column5: and they're asking how big a role do you foresee for the federal government? It's already spending 21% of the entire U.S. economy. How much larger would government be in the lives of Americans under a Sanders presidency?

column1: Advertisement
SANDERS: Well
column2: to put that in a context
column3: Judy
column4: I think we have to understand that in the last 30 years in this country there has been a massive transfer of wealth going from the hands of working families into the top one-tenth of 1% whose percentage of wealth has doubled. In other words
column5: the very rich are getting richer
column6: almost everybody is going -- getting poorer.

column1: What I believe is the United States
column2: in fact
column3: should join the rest of the industrialized world and guarantee healthcare to all people. Our Medicare for all single-payer proposal will save the average middle class family $5
column4: 000 a year.

column1: I do believe that in the year 2016 we have to look in terms of public education as colleges as part of public education making public colleges and universities tuition free. I believe that when real unemployment is close to 10%
column2: and when our infrastructure
column3: our roads
column4: our bridges
column5: our water systems
column6: Flint
column7: Michigan comes to mind. Our waste water plants
column8: our rail
column9: our airports
column10: in many places are disintegrating.

column1: Advertisement
Yeah
column2: we can create 13 million jobs by rebuilding our infrastructure at a cost of a trillion dollars.

column1: WOODRUFF: But
column2: my question is how big would government be? Would there be any limit on the size of the role of government...

column1: SANDERS: ... Of course there will be a limit
column2: but when today you have massive levels of income and wealth inequality
column3: when the middle class is disappearing
column4: you have the highest rate of child poverty of almost any major country on Earth. Yes
column5: in my view
column6: the government of a democratic society has a moral responsibility to play a vital role in making sure all of our people have a decent standard of living. CLINTON: Judy
column7: I think that the best analysis that I've seen based on Senator Sanders plans is that it would probably increase the size of the federal government by about 40%
column8: but what is most concerning to me is that in looking at the plans -- let's take healthcare for example.

column1: Last week in a CNN town hall
column2: the Senator told a questioner that the questioner would spend about $500 dollars in taxes to get about $5
column3: 000 dollars in healthcare. Every progressive economist who has analyzed that says that the numbers don't add up
column4: and that's a promise that cannot be kept
column5: and it's really important now that we are getting into the rest of the country that both of us are held to account for explaining what we are proposing because
column6: especially with healthcare
column7: this is not about math. This is about people's lives
column8: and we should level with the American people about what we can do to make sure they get quality affordable healthcare.

column1: SANDERS: Well
column2: let us level with the American people. Secretary Clinton has been going around the country saying Bernie Sanders wants to dismantle the Affordable Care Act
column3: people are going to lose their MedicAid
column4: they're going to lose their CHIP program.

column1: I have fought my entire life to make sure that healthcare is a right for all people. We're not going to dismantle everything. But
column2: here is the truth.

column1: Twenty-nine million people have no health insurance today in America. We pay
column2: by far
column3: the highest prices in the world for prescription drugs. One out of five Americans can't even afford the prescriptions their doctors are writing. Millions of people have high deductibles and co-payments. What I said
column4: and let me repeat it
column5: I don't know what economists Secretary Clinton is talking to
column6: but what I have said
column7: and let me repeat it
column8: that yes
column9: the middle -- the family right in the middle of the economy would pay $500 dollars more in taxes
column10: and get a reduction in their healthcare costs of $5
column11: 000 dollars.

column1: In my view healthcare is a right of all people
column2: not a privilege
column3: and I will fight for that.

column1: CLINTON: I can only say that we both share the goal of universal health care coverage. You know
column2: before it was called Obamacare
column3: it was called Hillarycare. And I took on the drug companies and I took on the insurance companies to try to get us universal health care coverage.

column1: (APPLAUSE)

And why I am a staunch supporter of President Obama's principal accomplishment -- namely the Affordable Care Act -- is because I know how hard it was to get that done. We are at 90 percent coverage. We have to get the remaining 10. I've set forth very specific plans about how to get costs down
column2: especially prescription drug costs.

column1: And it is difficult to in any way argue with the goal that we both share. But I think the American people deserve to know specifically how this would work. If it's Medicare for all
column2: then you no longer have the Affordable Care Act
column3: because the Affordable Care Act
column4: as you know very well
column5: is based on the insurance system
column6: based on exchanges
column7: based on a subsidy system. The Children's Health Insurance Program
column8: which I helped to create
column9: which covers 8 million kids
column10: is also a different kind of program.

column1: So if you're having Medicare for all
column2: single-payer
column3: you need to level with people about what they will have at the end of the process you are proposing. And based on every analysis that I can find by people who are sympathetic to the goal
column4: the numbers don't add up
column5: and many people will actually be worse off than they are right now.

column1: IFILL: Final thought
column2: Senator.

column1: SANDERS: That is absolutely inaccurate. Look
column2: here is the reality
column3: folks. There is one major country on Earth that does not guarantee health care to all people. There is one major country -- the United States -- which ends up spending almost three times per capita what they do in the U.K. guaranteeing health care to all people
column4: 50 percent more than they do in France guaranteeing health care to all people
column5: far more than our Canadian neighbors
column6: who guarantee health care to all people.

column1: Please do not tell me that in this country
column2: if -- and here's the if -- we have the courage to take on the drug companies
column3: and have the courage to take on the insurance companies
column4: and the medical equipment suppliers
column5: if we do that
column6: yes
column7: we can guarantee health care to all people in a much more cost effective way.

column1: CLINTON: Well
column2: let me just -- let me just say
column3: once again...

column1: (APPLAUSE)
... that
column2: having been in the trenches fighting for this
column3: I believe strongly we have to guarantee health care. I believe we are on the path to doing that. The last thing we need is to throw our country into a contentious debate about health care again.

column1: And we are not England. We are not France. We inherited a system that was set up during World War II; 170 million Americans get health insurance right now through their employers. So what we have tried to do and what President Obama succeeded in doing was to build on the health care system we have
column2: get us to 90 percent coverage. We have to get the other 10 percent of the way to 100. I far prefer that and the chances we have to be successful there than trying to start all over again
column3: gridlocking our system
column4: and trying to get from zero to 100 percent.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
IFILL: I'd like to move along. I'd like to move along.
Secretary Clinton
column2: you might -- you also have proposed fairly expansive ideas about government. You may remember this pledge from a State of the Union Address at which I believe you were present
column3: in which these words were said: ""The era of big government is over."" You may remember that.

column1: When asked your feelings about the federal government this week
column2: 61 percent of New Hampshire Democrats told exit pollsters that they are angry or at least dissatisfied. Given what you and Senator Sanders are proposing
column3: an expanding government in almost every area of our lives
column4: is it fair for Americans who fear government to fear you?

column1: CLINTON: No. But it is absolutely fair and necessary for Americans to vet both of our proposals
column2: to ask the really hard questions about
column3: what is it we think we can accomplish
column4: why do we believe that
column5: and what would be the results for the average American family?

column1: In my case
column2: whether it's health care
column3: or getting us to debt-free tuition
column4: or moving us toward paid family leave
column5: I have been very specific about where I would raise the money
column6: how much it would cost
column7: and how I would move this agenda forward.

column1: I've tried to be as specific to answer questions so that my proposals can be vetted
column2: because I feel like we have to level with people for the very reason
column3: Gwen
column4: that you are mentioning. There is a great deal of skepticism about the federal government. I'm aware of that. It comes from the right
column5: from the left
column6: from people on all sides of the political spectrum.

column1: CLINTON: So we have a special obligation to make clear what we stand for
column2: which is why I think we should not make promises we can't keep
column3: because that will further
column4: I think
column5: alienate Americans from understanding and believing we can together make some real changes in people's lives.

column1: IFILL: But I haven't heard either of you put a price tag on your -- you say...
(CROSSTALK)
CLINTON: I will put a price tag. My price tag is about $100 billion a year. And again
column2: paid for. And what I have said is I will not throw us further into debt. I believe I can get the money that I need by taxing the wealthy
column3: by closing loopholes
column4: the things that we are way overdue for doing.

column1: And I think once I'm in the White House we will have enough political capital to be able to do that.
But I am conscious of the fact that we have to also be very clear
column2: especially with young people
column3: about what kind of government is going to do what for them and what it will cost.

column1: IFILL: Senator?
SANDERS: Well
column2: Secretary Clinton
column3: you're not in the White House yet. And let us be clear that every proposal that I have introduced has been paid for. For example
column4: all right
column5: who in America denies that we have an infrastructure that is crumbling? Roads
column6: bridges
column7: water systems
column8: wastewater plants
column9: who denies that?

column1: Who denies that real unemployment today
column2: including those who have given up looking for work and are working part-time is close to 10 percent? Who denies that African-American youth unemployment
column3: real
column4: is over 50 percent.

column1: We need to create jobs. So yes
column2: I will do away with the outrageous loopholes that allow profitable multinational corporations to stash billions of dollars in the Cayman Islands and Bermuda and in a given year pay zero
column3: zero in federal income tax.

column1: Yes
column2: I'm going to do away with that. We will use those proceeds
column3: a hundred billion a year
column4: to invest in rebuilding our infrastructure. Yes
column5: I believe that as a result of the illegal behavior on Wall Street
column6: that they are a Wall Street that drove this country into the worst economic downturn since the Great Recession -- Great Depression.

column1: Yes
column2: I do believe that now after the American people bailed Wall Street out
column3: yes
column4: they should pay a Wall Street speculation tax so that we can make public colleges and universities tuition-free.

column1: We bailed them out. Now it is their time to help the middle class.
(APPLAUSE)
CLINTON: You know
column2: I think
column3: again
column4: both of us share the goal of trying to make college affordable for all young Americans. And I have set forth a compact that would do just that for debt-free tuition.

column1: We differ
column2: however
column3: on a couple of key points. One of them being that if you don't have some agreement within the system from states and from families and from students
column4: it's hard to get to where we need to go.

column1: And Senator Sanders's plan really rests on making sure that governors like Scott Walker contribute $23 billion on the first day to make college free. I am a little skeptical about your governor actually caring enough about higher education to make any kind of commitment like that.
(APPLAUSE)
WOODRUFF: Next
column2: we're going to...

column1: SANDERS: A brief response.
WOODRUFF: Very brief
column2: thank you.

column1: SANDERS: Here is where we are with public education. A 100
column2: 150 years ago incredibly brave Americans said
column3: you know what
column4: working class kids
column5: low income kids should not have to work in factories or on the farms. Like rich kids
column6: they deserve to get a free education.

column1: And that free education of extraordinary accomplishment was from first grade to 12th grade. The world has changed. This is 2016. In many ways
column2: a college degree today is equivalent to what a high school degree was 50
column3: 60 years ago.

column1: So
column2: yes
column3: I do believe that when we talk about public education in America
column4: today
column5: in a rapidly changing world
column6: we should have free tuition at public colleges and universities. That should be a right of all Americans regardless of the income of their families.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
WOODRUFF: Secretary Clinton
column2: your campaign -- you and your campaign have made a clear appeal to women voters. You have talked repeatedly about the fact
column3: we know you would be
column4: if elected
column5: the first woman president.

column1: But in New Hampshire 55 percent of the women voters supported and voted for Senator Sanders. What are women missing about you?
CLINTON: Well
column2: first
column3: Judy
column4: I have spent my entire adult life working toward making sure that women are empowered to make their own choices
column5: even if that choice is not to vote for me. I believe that it's most important that we unleash the full potential of women and girls in our society.

column1: And I feel very strongly that I have an agenda
column2: I have a record that really does respond to a lot of the specific needs that the women in our country face. So I'm going to keep making that case. I'm going to keep making sure that everything I've done
column3: everything that I stand for is going to be well known.

column1: But I have no argument with anyone making up her mind about who to support. I just hope that by the end of this campaign there will be a lot more supporting me. That's what I'm working towards.
(APPLAUSE)
WOODRUFF: As you know
column2: just quickly
column3: as you know
column4: your strong supporter
column5: former Secretary of State Madeleine Albright
column6: said the other day that there's a special place in Hell for women who don't support other women. Do you agree with what she said?

column1: CLINTON: Well
column2: look
column3: I think that she's been saying that for as long as I've known her
column4: which is about 25 years. But it doesn't change my view that we need to empower everyone
column5: women and men
column6: to make the best decisions in their minds that they can make. That's what I've always stood for.

column1: And when it comes to the issues that are really on the front lines as to whether we're going to have equal pay
column2: paid family leave
column3: some opportunity for
column4: you know
column5: women to go as far as their hard work and talent take them
column6: I think that we still have some barriers to knock down
column7: which is why that's at the core of my campaign.

column1: I would note
column2: just for a historic aside
column3: somebody told me earlier today we've had like 200 presidential primary debates
column4: and this is the first time there have been a majority of women on the stage. So
column5: you know
column6: we'll take our progress wherever we can find it.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
WOODRUFF: Senator Sanders
column2: you're in the minority
column3: but we still want to hear from you.

column1: (LAUGHTER) SANDERS: Look
column2: we are fighting for every vote that we can get from women
column3: from men
column4: straight
column5: gay
column6: African-Americans
column7: Latinos
column8: Asian-Americans. We are trying to bring America together around an agenda that works for working families and the middle class.

column1: I am very proud
column2: if my memory is not correct -- I think I am -- that I have a lifetime -- and I've been in Congress a few years -- a lifetime 100 percent pro-choice voting record. I am very proud that over the years we have had the support in my state of Vermont from very significant majorities of women.

column1: I'm very proud that I support legislation that is currently in the Congress
column2: got support of almost all progressive Democrats in the House and Senate
column3: which says we will end the absurdity of women today making 79 cents on the dollar compared to men. And we will join the rest of the other -- the industrialized world in saying that paid family and medical leave should be a right of all working families.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
IFILL: Senator
column2: do you worry at all that you will be the instrument of thwarting history
column3: as Senator Clinton keeps claiming
column4: that she might be the first woman president?

column1: SANDERS: Well
column2: you know
column3: I think
column4: from a historical point of view
column5: somebody with my background
column6: somebody with my views
column7: somebody who has spent his entire life taking on the big money interests
column8: I think a Sanders victory would be of some historical accomplishment
column9: as well.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
CLINTON: You know
column2: I have said -- I have said many times
column3: you know
column4: I'm not asking people to support me because I'm a woman. I'm asking people to support me because I think I'm the most qualified
column5: experienced
column6: and ready person to be the president and the commander- in-chief.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
And I appreciate greatly Senator Sanders' voting record. And I was very proud to get the endorsement of the Planned Parenthood Action Fund
column2: because I've been a leader on these issues. I have gone time and time again to take on the vested interests who would keep women's health care decisions the province of the government instead of women ourselves.

column1: CLINTON: I'm very proud that NARAL endorsed me because when it comes to it we need a leader on women's issues. Somebody who
column2: yes
column3: votes right
column4: but much more than that
column5: leads the efforts to protect the hard-fought gains that women have made
column6: that
column7: make no mistake about it
column8: are under tremendous attack
column9: not just by the Republican presidential candidates but by a whole national effort to try to set back women's rights.

column1: So I'm asking women
column2: I'm asking men
column3: to support me because I'm ready to go into the White House on January 20th
column4: 2017 and get to work on both domestic and foreign policy challenges.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
WOODRUFF: Final comment.
SANDERS: Let me concur with the secretary
column2: no question women's rights are under fierce attack all over this country. And I will tell you something that really galls me. I will not shock anybody to suggest that in politics there is occasionally a little bit of hypocrisy. Just a little bit.

column1: All over this country we have Republican candidates for president saying we hate the government. Government is the enemy. We're going to cut Social Security to help you. We're going to cut Medicare and Medicaid
column2: federal aid to education to help you
column3: because the government is so terrible.

column1: But
column2: by the way
column3: when it comes to a woman having to make a very personal choice
column4: ah
column5: in that case
column6: my Republican colleagues love the government and want the government to make that choice for every woman in America.

column1: If that's not hypocrisy
column2: I don't know what hypocrisy is.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
IFILL: Thank you both.
IFILL: We turn now to the first of several questions from our partners at Facebook. They were selected from a curated group of people we've been following of undecided voters.
The first comes from Claudia Looze
column2: a 54-year-old woman who works as a program manager at a public affairs cable network in Madison
column3: Wisconsin. And she writes: ""Wisconsin is number one in African-American male incarceration
column4: according to a University of Wisconsin study. They found that Wisconsin's incarceration rate for black men
column5: which is at 13 percent
column6: was nearly double the country's rate. What can we do across the nation to address this?""

column1: Senator Sanders.

SANDERS: This is one of the great tragedies in our country today. And we can no longer continue to sweep it under the rug. It has to be dealt with. Today a male African-American baby born today stands a one-in-four chance of ending up in jail. That is beyond unspeakable.
So what we have to do is the radical reform of a broken criminal justice system.
(APPLAUSE)
SANDERS: What we have to do is end over-policing in African- American neighborhoods. The reality is that both the African-American community and the white community do marijuana at about equal rates.

The reality is four times as many blacks get arrested for marijuana. Truth is that far more blacks get stopped for traffic violations. The truth is that sentencing for blacks is higher than for whites.
We need fundamental police reform
column2: clearly
column3: clearly
column4: when we talk about a criminal justice system. I would hope that we could all agree that we are sick and tired of seeing videos on television of unarmed people
column5: often African-Americans
column6: shot by police officers.

column1: What we have got to do is make it clear that any police officer who breaks the law will
column2: in fact
column3: be held accountable.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
CLINTON: You know
column2: I completely agree with Senator Sanders. The first speech I gave in this campaign back in April was about criminal justice reform and ending the era of mass incarceration.

column1: The statistics from Wisconsin are particularly troubling
column2: because it is the highest rate of incarceration for African-Americans in our nation
column3: twice the national average. And we know of the tragic
column4: terrible event that lead to the death of Dontre Hamilton right here in Milwaukee
column5: a young man unarmed
column6: who should still be with us.

column1: His family certainly believes that. And so do I. So we have work to do. There have been some good recommendations about what needs to happen. President Obama's policing commission came out with some. I have fully endorsed those.
CLINTON: But we have to restore policing that will actually protect the communities that police officers are sworn to protect.
And
column2: then we have to go after sentencing
column3: and that's one of the problems here in Wisconsin because so much of what happened in the criminal justice system doesn't happen at the federal level
column4: it happens at the state and local level.

column1: But
column2: I would also add this. There are other racial discrepancies. Really systemic racism in this state
column3: as in others
column4: education
column5: in employment
column6: in the kinds of factors that too often lead from a position where young people
column7: particularly young men
column8: are pushed out of school early
column9: are denied employment opportunities. So
column10: when we talk about criminal justice reform
column11: and ending the era of mass incarceration
column12: we also have to talk about jobs
column13: education
column14: housing
column15: and other ways of helping communities.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
SANDERS: Nothing that Secretary Clinton said do I disagree with. This mandatory sentencing
column2: a very bad idea. It takes away discretion from judges. We have got to demilitarize local police departments so they do not look like occupying armies.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
We have got to make sure that local police departments look like the communities they serve in their diversity. And
column2: where we are failing abysmally is in the very high rate of recidivism we see. People are being released from jail without the education
column3: without the job training
column4: without the resources that they need to get their lives together
column5: then they end up -- we're shocked that they end up back in jail again. So
column6: we have a lot of work to do.

column1: But
column2: here is a pledge I've made throughout this campaign
column3: and it's really not a very radical pledge. When we have more people in jail
column4: disproportionately African American and Latino
column5: than China does
column6: a communist authoritarian society four times our size. Here's my promise
column7: at the end of my first term as president we will not have more people in jail than any other country.

column1: We will invest in education
column2: and jobs for our kids
column3: not incarceration and more jails.

column1: (APPLAUSE) WOODRUFF: Secretary Clinton
column2: I was talking recently with a 23 year old black woman who voted for President Obama because she said she thought relations between the races would get better under his leadership
column3: and his example. Hardly anyone believes that they have. Why do you think race relations would be better under a Clinton presidency? What would you do that the nation's first African American has not been able to?

column1: CLINTON: Well
column2: I'm just not sure I agree completely with that assessment. I think under President Obama we have seen a lot of advances
column3: the Affordable Care Act has helped more African Americans than any other group to get insurance
column4: to be taken care of
column5: but we also know a lot more than we did. We have a lot more social media
column6: we have everybody with a cellphone.

column1: So
column2: we are seeing the dark side of the remaining systemic racism that we have to root out in our society. I think President Obama has set a great example. I think he has addressed a lot of these issues that have been quite difficult
column3: but he has gone forward. Now
column4: what we have to do is to build on an honest conversation about where we go next.

column1: We now have much more information about what must be done to fix our criminal justice system. We now have some good models about how better to provide employment
column2: housing and education. I think what President Obama did was to exemplify the importance of this issue as our first African American president
column3: and to address it both from the President's office
column4: and through his advocacy
column5: such as working with young men
column6: and Mrs. Obama's work with young women.

column1: But
column2: we can't rest. We have work to do
column3: and we now know a lot more than we ever did before. So
column4: it's going to be my responsibility to make sure we move forward to solve these problems that are now out in the open. Nobody can deny them. To use the Justice Department
column5: as we just saw
column6: they have said they are going to sue Ferguson
column7: that entered into a consent agreement
column8: and then tried to back out. So
column9: we're going to enforce the law
column10: we're going to change policing practices
column11: we're going to change incarceration practices
column12: but we're also going to emphasize education
column13: jobs
column14: and housing.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
WOODRUFF: Senator Sanders?
(APPLAUSE)
SANDERS: Well
column2: I think
column3: Judy
column4: what has to be appreciated is that
column5: as a result of the disastrous and illegal behavior on Wall Street
column6: millions of lives were hurt. People lost their jobs
column7: their homes
column8: their life savings. Turns out that the African-American community and the Latino community were hit especially hard. As I understand it
column9: the African-American community lost half of their wealth as a result of the Wall Street collapse.

column1: So when you have childhood African-American poverty rates of 35 percent
column2: when you have youth unemployment at 51 percent
column3: when you have unbelievable rates of incarceration -- which
column4: by the way
column5: leaves the children back home without a dad or even a mother -- clearly
column6: we are looking at institutional racism. We are looking at an economy in which the rich get richer and the poor get poorer. And sadly
column7: in America today
column8: in our economy
column9: a whole lot of those poor people are African-American.

column1: Some sites have since realized their error. Neatorama
column2: for example
column3: has removed its story with the photo called ""Thank you
column4: Hurricane Irene: Shark in the street."" We've asked Channel 7 in Miami
column5: which broadcast the user-submitted photo

column1: This phenomenon is nothing new. After the death of Osama bin Laden

column3: photographs of a damaged church started circulating. The church was located in Christchurch
column4: New Zealand.
