Fred Thompson is laying on the southern-fried charm. ItÃ¢ÂÂs a tire-melting afternoon in June
column2: and the son of Lawrenceburg
column3: Tennessee
column4: turned two-term United States senator
column5: Law & Order star
column6: and now almost Republican presidential candidate has just arrived at the Clarion Townhouse hotel in Columbia
column7: South Carolina
column8: for a state-party fund-raiser. A crush of reporters has swarmed him
column9: one of whom has just asked if today will be the day Thompson makes things official. Thompson delivers his honey-smooth reply as if on cue. Ã¢ÂÂIÃ¢ÂÂm just testing the waters
column10: but the water is pretty warm
column11: Ã¢ÂÂ he says as he plows toward the ballroom.

column1: Inside
column2: his wife
column3: Jeri
column4: and 3-year-old daughter
column5: Hayden
column6: hug Thompson. The family settles on the dais and is consumed in a lightning storm of flash photography. The six-foot-five
column7: cigar-smoking ThompsonÃ¢ÂÂs calling card is his cozy
column8: avuncular folksiness
column9: and he seems nothing if not at home here among his people. Jeri is a formidable womanÃ¢ÂÂa former Senate staffer and spokeswoman for the Republican National Committee who is said to be the true force behind her husbandÃ¢ÂÂs decision to run and a key operative in his campaign. She also happens to be blonde
column10: gorgeous
column11: and two dozen years younger than her husband. She is dressed today in a purple skirt cut an inch or so above the knees that has definitely caught the attention of the locals. Hayden
column12: saucer-eyed and adorable in a flower-print dress
column13: smiles shyly. Thompson is only 64
column14: but the family tableau makes him look a bit old and wan.

column1: The room settles down
column2: and Thompson steps to the microphone. He goes straight to Page One of the Thompson scriptÃ¢ÂÂa bit of homey Mayberry RFD bemusement directed at those crazy city slickers in Washington. Ã¢ÂÂI was telling one of my buddies up there
column3: Ã¢ÂÂYou know
column4: itÃ¢ÂÂs kind of strange. People are always asking me the difference between show business and politics and so forth.Ã¢ÂÂ And he says
column5: Ã¢ÂÂWell
column6: donÃ¢ÂÂt you see the deal? Politics is show business for ugly people.Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ Thompson pauses for a moment and grins. Ã¢ÂÂAnd then he says
column7: Ã¢ÂÂThompson
column8: you got it all covered.Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ Everyone laughs.

column1: Today
column2: the immigration bill hangs in the balance
column3: and Thompson
column4: who sells himself as the only genuine red-meat conservative among the leading GOP contenders
column5: lays into his wussy opponents. Ã¢ÂÂWe canÃ¢ÂÂt drop another 12 million people and be able to cope with that. WeÃ¢ÂÂve already got a 24-hour rule. If you canÃ¢ÂÂt prove theyÃ¢ÂÂre terrorists within 24 hours
column6: youÃ¢ÂÂve got to pass them. You know the dog ainÃ¢ÂÂt eating the dog food when they put that one out there.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: Someone shouts Ã¢ÂÂGo
column2: Fred
column3: go.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: Now itÃ¢ÂÂs back to the outsider theme
column2: but this time Thompson is more slick. The subject is the Iraq war
column3: a conflict that Thompson has staunchly supported. Ã¢ÂÂPeople talk about the last election. They say
column4: Ã¢ÂÂThe war
column5: the war
column6: the war
column7: Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ Thompson says with a sigh. Ã¢ÂÂI think it has to do more with corruption and spending than it did the war
column8: and itÃ¢ÂÂs understandable. Sad to say some of our folks went to Washington to drain the swamp and made partnership with the alligators instead.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: A minute later
column2: Thompson offers what has now become a hallmark tease. Ã¢ÂÂMaybe I can come back a little bit later in a different capacity and we can talk a little bit more about some of these issues.Ã¢ÂÂ The applause builds to a standing ovation. Ã¢ÂÂYou know
column3: I had another comment or two
column4: Ã¢ÂÂ Thompson says
column5: Ã¢ÂÂbut I think thatÃ¢ÂÂs the perfect place to stop.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: Thompson sticks around for five minutes afterward to answer a few questions from reporters and pose for pictures with old ladies asking that a fence be built around America. I try to force him to improv a little by asking whether it was too late for him to mobilize a modern presidential campaign. But the man can hit his mark. Ã¢ÂÂYou know
column2: they said that you had to raise $100 million this year to compete
column3: Ã¢ÂÂ Thompson says as his aides try to get him to turn rightward toward the cameras. Ã¢ÂÂWithout raising a dime
column4: I was in the pack. So IÃ¢ÂÂve already saved $50 million this year.Ã¢ÂÂ Then Thompson smiles and lopes toward the exit. The former actor is done shooting for the day.

column1: Since announcing this spring that he was considering a presidential run
column2: Fred Thompson has improbably jumped to the front of the line for the GOP nomination. In two mid-July polls
column3: Thompson led Rudolph Giuliani by a point or two
column4: and while other recent surveys show the former New York mayor in the lead
column5: ThompsonÃ¢ÂÂs strength in key southern states
column6: including the aforementioned South Carolina
column7: has not gone unnoticed. This despite the fact that the famously laid-back Thompson has barely campaigned
column8: forgoing the roll-up-your-sleeves-and-make-a-thousand-trips-to-Iowa strategy in favor of the odd Leno appearance and a YouTube jab at Michael Moore
column9: in which he essentially told Moore that if he didnÃ¢ÂÂt love America
column10: he should leave it
column11: and go to Cuba.

column1: Photo: Daily News
So far
column2: the Thompson bubble has floated skyward on several favorable updrafts. HeÃ¢ÂÂs the newest man in the raceÃ¢ÂÂand one with celebrity name recognition. HeÃ¢ÂÂs a Southerner and arguably the most conservative candidate in a field devoid of hard-liners. Despite his eight years in the Senate
column3: people seem to buy the idea
column4: for the time being anyway
column5: that heÃ¢ÂÂs a Washington outsider. And all of his opponents have significant liabilities. But then again
column6: so does Thompson. Among them are his work ethic and authenticity.

column1: Thompson is often compared to Ronald Reagan
column2: not just because they are both actors
column3: but also because of each manÃ¢ÂÂs almost preternatural affability. But Reagan was an unalloyed ideologue when America was looking for one
column4: with eight years as the chief executive of what amounts to one of the worldÃ¢ÂÂs largest countries. He wasnÃ¢ÂÂt elected until his third campaign
column5: when he defeated a weak Democratic incumbent. Fred Thompson is in a different place. If heÃ¢ÂÂs going to be elected the leader of the Free World
column6: he may have to do it on the strength of his not inconsiderable personal charm.

column1: You canÃ¢ÂÂt get to Fred ThompsonÃ¢ÂÂs hometown from here. Lawrenceburg
column2: Tennessee
column3: is located 28 miles from the nearest interstate. Its rolling hills are picturesquely dotted with pigs and cattle
column4: but it remains one of the stateÃ¢ÂÂs poorest areas. Ã¢ÂÂThis town hasnÃ¢ÂÂt been the same since the Yankees came in and opened the Murray bike factory
column5: Ã¢ÂÂ says Tommy Beuerlein
column6: who owns a downtown pharmacy and was a classmate of ThompsonÃ¢ÂÂs. The bike factory arrived in 1955. Ã¢ÂÂNixon was right about there being a silent majority in America
column7: Ã¢ÂÂ Beuerlein proudly says. Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs right here.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: On a recent summer day
column2: eighteen people attended a city-council meeting dealing with the local problem of illegal dumping of couches. A few steps away
column3: 71 residents
column4: some of them as young as 9
column5: attended a shotgun-safety class. Ã¢ÂÂYou have to respect your zone of fire
column6: Ã¢ÂÂ insisted the instructor. Ã¢ÂÂVice-President Cheney didnÃ¢ÂÂt respect his zone of fire
column7: and look what happened.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: Much of ThompsonÃ¢ÂÂs down-home affability can be attributed to his roots in Lawrenceburg
column2: where as a child he pretended to be Western star Lash LaRue and courted his high-school sweetheart underneath the townÃ¢ÂÂs Davy Crockett statue (true story). But while Thompson may be a country boy
column3: heÃ¢ÂÂs a certain type of country boy: the one who plays possum while you mock his cornpone ways. Next thing you know heÃ¢ÂÂs got your girl and holds the deed to your farm.

column1: ThompsonÃ¢ÂÂs father
column2: Fletch
column3: ran a used-car lot in the center of town
column4: and would talk Republican politics at the Blue Ribbon CafÃÂ©. Neither of ThompsonÃ¢ÂÂs parents attended high school (his father eventually earned a GED)
column5: and Fred
column6: the first of two sons
column7: proved to be an indifferent but popular student. Even as a kid
column8: Fred had a flair for showmanship. One of the building blocks of the Thompson legend is the story of his concerned football coachÃ¢ÂÂs running onto the field to check on an injured Thompson. When coach Garner Ezell reached his player
column9: Thompson smiled at his fellow Church of Christ parishioner and quipped
column10: Ã¢ÂÂHowÃ¢ÂÂs the crowd takinÃ¢ÂÂ it?Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: Ã¢ÂÂFred said it
column2: Ã¢ÂÂ says Ezell. Ã¢ÂÂBut he wasnÃ¢ÂÂt ever hurt. He was just tired and wanted a rest.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: Even a blind squirrel sometimes finds a nut
column2: and Thompson has always seemed to have a way of stumbling into success. By all accounts
column3: ThompsonÃ¢ÂÂs work ethic kicked in at 17
column4: when he got his sweetheart Sarah Lindsey pregnant and immediately proposed. Ã¢ÂÂI barely got out of high school
column5: Ã¢ÂÂ Thompson told the Washington Post in 1985. Ã¢ÂÂI was interested in two thingsÃ¢ÂÂand sports was one of them.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: Because of his marriage
column2: Thompson didnÃ¢ÂÂt play sports his senior year
column3: and he put in long shifts at the bike factory to support his new family. The following fall
column4: the newlyweds headed to nearby Florence State
column5: now the University of North Alabama
column6: before transferring to Memphis State
column7: from which they both graduated. SarahÃ¢ÂÂs grandfather was an influential Lawrenceburg lawyer
column8: and her family urged Thompson to apply to Vanderbilt Law School. After graduating
column9: the couple moved back to Lawrenceburg
column10: and Thompson practiced law with SarahÃ¢ÂÂs uncle and began dabbling in local GOP politics
column11: eventually joining the countyÃ¢ÂÂs Republican Executive Committee. It was through that group that Thompson caught the eye of another accidental benefactor
column12: Tennessee senator Howard Baker. Thompson worked on BakerÃ¢ÂÂs 1972 reelection
column13: sometimes driving the senator around Tennessee
column14: and the two men struck up a friendship.

column1: By the next year
column2: Watergate was everywhere. And while Yale and Harvard up-and-comers like Hillary Clinton and Bill Weld clawed for minor legal positions
column3: Baker offered Thompson a coveted slot as minority counsel on the Senate Watergate Committee.

column1: Photo: Brett Flashnick/AP

column2: Thompson wrote about the experience in his book At That Point in Time: The Inside Story of the Senate Watergate Committee
column3: portraying himself as the picture of the awestruck country lawyer. He insists when Baker offered him the job in February of 1973
column4: Ã¢ÂÂthe only names I could recall without prompting were Howard Hunt and Gordon Liddy.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: Because it was a Republican investigator who had uncovered the fact that Nixon aide Alexander Butterfield had admitted that the White House featured an elaborate taping system
column2: Baker insisted that a Republican cross-examine Butterfield the next day so the GOP could maintain the illusion of impartialityÃ¢ÂÂand take credit. On national television
column3: Thompson asked Butterfield the now famous line
column4: Ã¢ÂÂAre you aware of the installation of any listening devices in the Oval Office of the president?Ã¢ÂÂ Butterfield famously answered yes (as everyone already knew he would). It was ThompsonÃ¢ÂÂs first star turn
column5: a role that marked him in AmericaÃ¢ÂÂs minds as a righteous heavyweight prosecutor.

column1: ThompsonÃ¢ÂÂs own book suggests he wasnÃ¢ÂÂt exactly an impartial participant in the proceedings
column2: however. He admits to leaking the news about the Butterfield discovery to NixonÃ¢ÂÂs lawyers without authorization. Transcripts from the Nixon Tapes also suggest Thompson was at least partially in NixonÃ¢ÂÂs pocket. As the Watergate Committee prepared to call Nixon aide John Dean
column3: Nixon lawyer J. Fred Buzhardt coached Thompson on how to question Dean. Buzhardt told Nixon
column4: Ã¢ÂÂI found Thompson most cooperative
column5: feeling more Republican every day.Ã¢ÂÂ The next day
column6: Nixon Chief of Staff Alexander Haig reported to the president
column7: Ã¢ÂÂHe [Thompson] thinks weÃ¢ÂÂre in good shape.Ã¢ÂÂ Of course
column8: they were not. Not long after
column9: Dean became the first Nixon aide to directly tie the president to the break-in and cover-up. But ThompsonÃ¢ÂÂs reputation as a plain-speaking crusader for truth and justice had already been made.

column1: ThompsonÃ¢ÂÂs acting career also happened by accident. After parlaying his Watergate fame into big speaking fees and the start of a lucrative lobbying career (his clients included Westinghouse and the Tennessee savings-and-loans industry)
column2: Thompson returned to private practice in Tennessee. There
column3: he wound up representing Marie Ragghianti
column4: the head of the Tennessee Parole Board who was fired by Democratic governor Ray Blanton for exposing a parole-for-sale scheme. Ragghianti sued for wrongful dismissal
column5: and Thompson won the case. Serpico author Peter Maas wrote a book about RagghiantiÃ¢ÂÂs story that was eventually optioned as a movie with Sissy Spacek slated to play the title role.

column1: According to Thompson lore
column2: director Roger Donaldson had to plead with Thompson to audition to play himself. Ã¢ÂÂThe idea of him playing himself was reached
column3: Ã¢ÂÂ Donaldson told the Nashville Tennessean in May of this year. Ã¢ÂÂAnd so I said to Fred
column4: Ã¢ÂÂWould you be interested at having a go at playing yourself?Ã¢ÂÂ He was like
column5: Ã¢ÂÂShucks
column6: do you think I could do that?Ã¢ÂÂ I said
column7: Ã¢ÂÂYou never know until you try.Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ

column1: However
column2: back in 1985
column3: when the movie was made
column4: Thompson freely admitted heÃ¢ÂÂd lobbied Donaldson hard until he scored an audition. Although the film wasnÃ¢ÂÂt especially successful
column5: Thompson received raves
column6: including one that described him as the movieÃ¢ÂÂs Ã¢ÂÂreal discovery.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: Bored with the law and in the process of getting a divorce from Lindsey

column4: Thompson had become a Hollywood go-to guy for gruff government types

column6: so Thompson kept his hand in the lobbying game. Tennessee insiders tried to persuade Thompson to run for the retiring BakerÃ¢ÂÂs seat in 1984
column7: but he declined

column1: The day after his South Carolina speech in June

column4: Sean Hannity
column5: and Fox News. This morning

column5: well

Thompson glanced around at the 4

column1: the greatest testament to the power of Fred ThompsonÃ¢ÂÂs down-home likability might be that his Senate years were widely viewed as a train wreck
column2: yet he emerged not only unscathed but also as a presidential contender.

column1: Things started auspiciously enough. Because Thompson had been elected to fill GoreÃ¢ÂÂs unexpired term

column3: 1994. Republicans didnÃ¢ÂÂt waste any time putting the actor in front of the cameras. On December 15
column4: Thompson gave the RepublicansÃ¢ÂÂ response to President ClintonÃ¢ÂÂs budget address. Thompson spoke for only five minutes
column5: but he struck a chord. A STAR IS BORN read the headline of Frank RichÃ¢ÂÂs New York Times column.

column1: But that would be the high point. Thompson spent the next two years accomplishing almost nothing of significance other than raising money for his 1996 reelection: Thompson brought back the red truck and won in a walk.
While Bill Clinton easily trounced Bob Dole in that yearÃ¢ÂÂs presidential race

column1: In the weeks leading up to the hearings that July

column3: and the conventional wisdom was that Thompson would charm the octogenarian into submission. It didnÃ¢ÂÂt happen. Thompson condescended to Glenn and alienated members of his own party. When New Hampshire Republican Bob Smith announced in his opening statement

column6: rolled his eyes

column2: Thompson donated his Senate papers to the University of Tennessee. Some of his archives are filled with notes of off-the-record interviews Thompson conducted with reporters during his Senate years. In his papers

column4: grilling your team to a point where [you have to] get them to a room
column5: woodshed them
column6: [on] how to ask questions
column7: how to proceed.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: ThompsonÃ¢ÂÂs hearings grew even more unpopular with his own party when he diverted the proceedings to the subject of campaign-finance reform (Senate Republicans opposed such reform for fear of losing hard-won fund-raising advantages). Lott was furious
column2: and Thompson suspected the majority leader was the anonymous author of quotes criticizing the hearings.

column1: The senator further angered conservatives by becoming an early supporter of the McCain-Feingold campaign-finance-reform legislation. Although Thompson has recently tried to minimize his enthusiasm for the bill
column2: his Senate papers include a handwritten note from Senator Russell Feingold after the measure passed the Senate in 2001 reading
column3: Ã¢ÂÂYou were essential to our success from the outset!Ã¢ÂÂ

column2: ThompsonÃ¢ÂÂs archives show
column3: he sent Clinton a note after the State of the Union address that partially read
column4: Ã¢ÂÂThe speech probably would not have seemed so long to some of us if you hadnÃ¢ÂÂt been putting the wood to us so effectively.Ã¢ÂÂ ThompsonÃ¢ÂÂs 1999 split vote on ClintonÃ¢ÂÂs two counts of impeachment squared with one of his off-the-record sessions in 1998
column5: when he told reporters
column6: Ã¢ÂÂIÃ¢ÂÂm prejudiced in his favor
column7: I object to the tactics used against him.Ã¢ÂÂ This didnÃ¢ÂÂt stop Thompson from sending Kenneth Starr a congratulations letter at the end of the Clinton saga.

column4: and Washington Post publisher Katharine Graham. ThereÃ¢ÂÂs a mash note from Bruce Willis (Ã¢ÂÂYou were great in Die HardÃ¢ÂÂ) and a letter from Oliver Stone thanking Thompson for brokering an interview with Martin Luther King Jr. assassin James Earl Ray.

column1: ThompsonÃ¢ÂÂs off-the-record chats with reporters also suggest that his claim that he hasnÃ¢ÂÂt given much thought to running for president might be somewhat disingenuous (his campaign has attempted to make a virtue of the fact that Thompson
column2: unlike his competitors
column3: isnÃ¢ÂÂt obsessed with power). During one 1998 off-the-record bull session
column4: Thompson boasted to a reporter
column5: Ã¢ÂÂAl Gore goes to bed at night and says
column6: Ã¢ÂÂPlease donÃ¢ÂÂt let it be Fred Dalton Thompson.Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ

column1: As a senator and movie star of a certain age

column2: romantic and otherwise
column3: have paid significant dividends. This March
column4: Carlson talked up ThompsonÃ¢ÂÂs presidential possibilities on MSNBC
column5: rhapsodizing
column6: Ã¢ÂÂHeÃ¢ÂÂs handsome
column7: heÃ¢ÂÂs charming
column8: he sounds like a president
column9: and he looks like a president.Ã¢ÂÂ She didnÃ¢ÂÂt disclose their prior personal relationship.

column2: yes
column3: Fred Thompson. Ã¢ÂÂEverybody loves Fred

column2: Thompson said
column3: Ã¢ÂÂWhen I served eight years

column4: ending a long

column1: A few months before he left office

column5: a British reinsurer responsible for paying out millions in asbestos claims. Equitas wanted Senate legislation that would limit its liability and paid Thompson $760
column6: 000 over the next three years. He also serves as a member of the Council on Foreign Relations

column2: Thompson married Jeri. The couple met in 1995 (Jeri was a Republican spokesperson at the time) on the Nashville yacht of Dale Gish
column3: on the Fourth of July. Their relationship was on and off for years
column4: with Kehn memorably complaining about other rivals to the New York Post in 2000. Ã¢ÂÂThey just wonÃ¢ÂÂt leave him alone
column5: Ã¢ÂÂ she said. Ã¢ÂÂI canÃ¢ÂÂt get up to get a cocktail at a party without coming back and finding some girl sitting in my chair.Ã¢ÂÂ Fred and Jeri have since had two children
column6: Hayden and an 8-month-old son named Samuel.

column1: Last November
column2: Thompson said he wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt run for president
column3: telling a political dinner-party gathering
column4: Ã¢ÂÂI would have had to start two years ago if I was going to run. I donÃ¢ÂÂt think IÃ¢ÂÂd ever want to jump back in.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: But with Giuliani
column2: McCain

34	"With polls showing that President Obama is losing ground
column2: The Post asked political experts what he could do to regain the initiative. Below are contributions from Scott Keeter
column3: Michael S. Berman
column4: Newt Gingrich
column5: Donna Brazile
column6: Robert J. Blendon
column7: Christine Todd Whitman
column8: Dan Schnur
column9: Ed Rogers
column10: Harold Ford Jr. and Ed Gillespie.

column1: SCOTT KEETER
Director of survey research at Pew Research Center
President Obama had a better honeymoon with the public than either Bill Clinton or George W. Bush. But it's over now. His ratings are approaching his electoral margin.
This summer slump is a product of his own actions and political forces outside his control. Obama campaigned for strong government action on the economy and health care
column2: and most of his voters agreed with this direction. But Obama's efforts to expand the role of government have alienated many of those who did not vote for him but nonetheless gave him high marks when first he took office.

column1: Pew Research's political values survey this spring showed no surge in public demand for more government. Indeed
column2: anti-government sentiment
column3: which had been building for years
column4: was heightened by the financial bailout and stimulus program. Moreover
column5: it was inevitable that Obama eventually would have to take responsibility for the economy
column6: which -- despite a few ""green shoots"" -- remains grim.

column1: The health-care debate has taken a toll on the president's popularity as well as that of his party. Americans remain ambivalent
column2: desiring most of the major elements in the reform proposals but simultaneously worrying about too much government control of health care. Obama can influence whether and how reform passes
column3: and whether it passes at all will affect his approval rating. Democrats in Congress fear that passing an unpopular health care package will be politically costly
column4: but as Clinton's 1994 experience demonstrated
column5: they have good reason to fear that failure on health care could also be costly.

column1: MICHAEL S. BERMAN
President of the Duberstein Group; former counsel and deputy chief of staff to Vice President Walter Mondale
First
column2: the president should not over-read or over-rely on polls. To get some perspective
column3: check out the Aug. 26 piece by Jeremy Rosner of Greenberg
column4: Quinlan
column5: Rosner Research entitled ""A Pollster's Advice: Don't Trust the Polls on Health Reform's Demise.""

column1: Second
column2: Obama should show that he understands that people are being asked to accept changes in the health-care system while they are in the throes of actual or potential crisis in their personal financial ""systems."" And that he has heard the concerns raised by affected Americans nationwide. While the media attention to various town halls was in the best tradition of ""if it bleeds it leads
column3: most of the people who came out did so out of a real need and interest to learn more about health-care reform proposals.

column1: Third
column2: invite House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Majority Leader Harry Reid to a meeting
column3: just the three of them
column4: and work through with them a plan for going forward. Work ""with"" the congressional leadership to come up with a single bill that represents the doable
column5: sans the wish list of every idea for changing health care that has been suggested in the past several decades. And get to that bill before the process kind of stumbles on to it.

column1: Finally
column2: choose a dramatic forum
column3: perhaps a joint session of Congress
column4: to lay out a bill that includes core changes but reflects having heard what is bothering the people he was elected to lead.

column1: NEWT GINGRICH
Former Republican speaker of the House of Representatives
When he returns from vacation
column2: the president's most important assignment should be to take a deep breath and get a long-term view of the country's reaction to his policies.

column1: Since World War II
column2: only Gerald Ford and Bill Clinton have had worse ratings after seven months than President Obama. His economic policies are not creating jobs. His energy tax is unlikely to pass the Senate. There is an overwhelming rejection of his spending policies.

column1: On the international front
column2: Afghanistan is proving much harder than expected. Iran is showing no signs of giving up its nuclear program and North Korea is still unyielding.

column1: In this setting
column2: the left's health program is bitterly dividing the country. Several polls have shown that more Americans expect their personal health-care situation to get worse than to get better under the plan being considered in Congress.

column1: Still
column2: Obama's left-wing advisers want him to undertake the revolutionary act of ramming through massive change for 17 percent of the economy under a narrow budgetary provision. This would be a statement of absolute defiance of the vast majority of Americans.

column1: Obama faces a choice: He can attempt to run a left-wing government against the American people. Or he can govern from the center with a large majority of Americans supporting him. He can have either his left angry or the American people angry. We will know in September which choice he has made.
DONNA BRAZILE
Author and political commentator; manager of Al Gore's 2000 presidential campaign
President Obama must reset the national debate and narrow his focus on passing health-insurance reform with or without Republicans. To do this
column2: the president must convince deficit-weary voters that reform will not send the national debt soaring and that higher taxes on the middle class are not just around the corner.

column1: With everything in his inbox still marked urgent
column2: the president needs to prioritize more and stop trying to do everything at once without also reminding Americans of the sacrifices involved. He should repeat: ""Remember
column3: we're all in this together.""

column1: Obama must also take a chapter from his campaign and begin to work on the ""new politics"" that would allow him to reach bipartisan consensus on a host of major challenges.
Much of the real anger we are seeing is economic anxiety that ordinary people are experiencing in this jobless recession. The economy is doing better
column2: according to statistics
column3: but nobody feels it yet. That makes for a lot of fear and worry.

column1: The administration should also keep an eye on the stimulus spending: target funds
column2: track job creation
column3: rebuild the safety net
column4: and eliminate waste and duplicity. With money so tight
column5: no one wants to see the government spending frivolously.

column1: ROBERT J. BLENDON
Professor of health policy and political analysis at Harvard's School of Public Health and its Kennedy School of Government
Most Americans do not see the president's economic policies as having been particularly successful for people like themselves
column2: and this is leading to some skepticism about health-care reform. In fact
column3: recent polls show most Americans do not anticipate any aspect of their health care improving if the president's health-reform proposals were enacted.

column1: To shift this thinking requires two things: The administration's message has to change sharply
column2: focusing on more concrete
column3: practical aspects of reform and how it will improve typical Americans' experiences with health care. Obama needs to present over and over again five specific changes in the legislation that will help the average family
column4: and how they will be paid for. For example
column5: explain why changing the system so families cannot lose their insurance coverage and enacting tough insurance reforms helps families who have coverage today.

column1: Second
column2: the president needs to make a clear decision this fall about whether he supports a public option competing with private insurance. If so
column3: he must explain how it would function in practice. Americans in the political center are turned off by ideological debates. After all these months
column4: they want him to explain if it is essential and then move on to other issues they see as important.

column1: CHRISTINE TODD WHITMAN
Chair of the Republican Leadership Council; governor of New Jersey from 1994 to 2001
If he wants to regain ground on the health-care debate
column2: climate change and the other legislative initiatives he has identified
column3: President Obama needs to start by rebuilding some bridges within his party. The squabbling among Democrats is bitter
column4: with the attacks from the more liberal end of the party on the more moderate ""Blue Dog"" Democrats reaching a fever pitch. Obama might keep in mind the legacy of Sen. Edward Kennedy and reach out to those Blue Dog Democrats as well as moderate Republicans to find common ground. Kennedy was an ardent partisan with a 90 percent liberal lifetime voting rating from the liberal watchdog group Americans for Democratic Action. No one questioned his commitment to the liberal agenda or his party. Yet few senators have ever authored more bipartisan bills and were known for so consistently reaching across the aisle. The president should refuse to push through legislation on strictly partisan votes and should seek the types of bipartisan compromise he promised to broker.

column1: DAN SCHNUR
Director of the University of Southern California's Unruh Institute of Politics; communications director for John McCain's 2000 presidential campaign

Everyone is drawing political lessons from the life and legacy of Ted Kennedy. But there is one missed opportunity in particular from Kennedy's career that Barack Obama can reflect on to get himself and his administration back on track.

Kennedy famously cited his decision to reject President Richard Nixon's health-care reform package as his greatest regret. Although Nixon's proposal was not nearly as ambitious as Kennedy would have preferred
column2: the senator realized over the years that working with Nixon would have led to significant advancements toward his larger goals.

column1: Fast-forward to today's battle over health care. It's clear that Obama deserves credit for moving the debate forward and achieving consensus on a number of previously intractable issues. Set aside
column2: for now
column3: the brawls about end-of-life counseling and a publicly funded option. If Obama signed a bill that allows individuals who change jobs to keep their insurance
column4: forbids the denial of coverage for preexisting conditions
column5: and deals with a lifetime cap on benefits
column6: people will throw rose petals at his feet.

column1: Important progress can be made now on health care; after the most significant reforms in a generation are signed into law
column2: he can still come back to the negotiating table and continue to move forward.

column1: ED ROGERS
Chairman of BGR Group; White House staffer to Ronald Reagan and George H.W. Bush
While the president's effectiveness is eroding
column2: the situation is not dire. He can regain the initiative
column3: but an eloquent speech won't do it. I assume he will not convert to conservatism and abandon his flawed plans
column4: but he should cut his losses and get back to reality.

column1: Occasionally all White Houses contort themselves into situations where they begin to say things they know are not true. The more you say such things
column2: the more you have to keep saying them to try and make them true. But the Obama administration needs to face it: The president's energy bill is not a jobs bill! His health-care plans will lead to government bureaucratic decisions about individuals' heath care and will cost a fortune. The deficit is not under control. The administration should not deny the obvious or defend the indefensible. White House officials know they are losing the public debate on these issues and must scale back to what is possible and credible given America's economic circumstances -- or use brute force in Congress to pass unpopular
column3: harmful and vast new programs.

column1: Even if he did use his congressional majorities to win these battles
column2: the president would lose the war by slowing economic growth
column3: only resulting in more political pain for himself and his party. Obama doesn't have any political problems that a couple of years of 4 percent GDP growth won't solve. But he has to want it
column4: and he needs honest policies to achieve it. Now
column5: though
column6: he is on a course that terrifies his political handlers and his party's candidates.

column1: HAROLD FORD JR.
Chairman of the Democratic Leadership Council
Every president faces a time when poll numbers slide. It's easy to advise a president to ignore the numbers and plow ahead. It's not wise for a president to heed that advice blindly. Thankfully
column2: President Obama knows that politics is about the art of the possible.

column1: Obama is battling a stubborn recession
column2: a Republican Congress hell-bent on defeating health reform and a resurgent Taliban in Afghanistan. When he returns to Washington the president should forge a consensus in Congress to pass what ""is possible"" on health reform
column3: redouble his efforts to stimulate job creation
column4: clearly articulate our mission objectives in Afghanistan
column5: and redefine and revive energy and financial services reform.

column1: First he needs to win on health reform. Obama has been patient
column2: committed and focused on leading Congress to a consensus. At his core
column3: this president is a pragmatist. In the spirit of the late Sen. Ted Kennedy
column4: Obama should work toward winning a compromise here before taking on new reform challenges.

column1: The compromise should be built around insurance reform
column2: such as prohibiting companies from denying coverage based on preexisting conditions
column3: and guaranteeing coverage for every child in America. Such substantive health reform would put us firmly on path to solving the uninsured problem in this country when our economy gets back on track.

column1: ED GILLESPIE
Counselor to President George W. Bush
Barack Obama faces a fundamental decision about the direction of his presidency: Try to muscle through with Democratic votes a much more liberal agenda than many of his voters expected of him
column2: or seek more consensus-oriented policies that attract at least a slice of the House and Senate Republicans by sacrificing core liberal elements of his policies.

column1: If he chooses the former
column2: he risks spectacular failure or a victory that eliminates the ""postpartisan"" persona that is a critical component of his personal approval ratings. This would make it much more difficult to achieve future legislative goals
column3: in the same way the rushed
column4: forced passage of the stimulus bill has made his health-care policy harder to achieve. And once that critical attribute is lost
column5: it's all but impossible to get back.

column1: To pull his young presidency back from the brink
column2: and protect his greatest asset
column3: President Obama would be wise to tack back to the center and pull his congressional leadership with him. He can then return his focus to the central issue on which voters are looking to him for leadership -- turning our economy around."	0

column1: 35	"Under attack at a recent debate from rival Hillary Clinton on health care
column2: Barack Obama shot back:

column1: Well
column2: let's talk about health care right now because the fact of the matter is that I do provide universal health care. The only difference between Sen. Clinton's health care plan and mine is that she thinks the problem for people without health care is that nobody has mandated Ã¢ÂÂ forced Ã¢ÂÂ them to get health care.""

column1: Before jumping into this fray
column2: it's important to note that when it comes to health care
column3: the two Democratic presidential candidates have a lot in common.

column1: One of the few differences is that Clinton includes a universal mandate. That means that after everything else goes according to plan
column2: individuals will be required by law to purchase insurance. Think of how people are required to buy auto insurance and you get an idea of what that might look like.

column1: Obama's plan includes a mandate to insure children
column2: but it does not include a mandate for adults
column3: as the Clinton and Edwards plans do. That likely means not as many people will be insured
column4: said Kenneth Thorpe
column5: professor of health policy and management at Emory University.

column1: Obama's decision not to include a mandate is a more cautious approach
column2: one Obama says is designed not to penalize people with modest incomes. If premiums don't drop enough after all the reforms are implemented
column3: people will still be unable to afford insurance. If a law mandates they buy it anyway
column4: they probably won't. Obama's argument is that if you then fine them
column5: you're essentially punishing the poor Ã¢ÂÂ and they will still be uninsured. Obama is betting that his plan will get costs low enough that many of the estimated 47-million uninsured will sign up without a mandate
column6: and a mandate will come later.

column1: So is it fair for Obama to call his plan ""universal""? Well
column2: not really. Even if you buy his argument that his plan will create the market conditions to make health care universally available
column3: nothing in his plan guarantees it. We rate his claim Barely True."	0

column1: 36	"Whoopi Goldberg is in hot water after comments she made Wednesday regarding the Navy SEAL widow that was honored last night during President Donald TrumpÃ¢ÂÂs historical speech.
Ã¢ÂÂShe was just looking for attention. These military widows love their 15 minutes in the spotlightÃ¢ÂÂ
column2: Goldberg said.

column1: Ã¢ÂÂIf it were me I wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt be able to leave the house. How can someone who is truly greiving go out there and be on TV. It just doesnÃ¢ÂÂt make sense to meÃ¢ÂÂ
After last nightÃ¢ÂÂs demonstration where several democrats in leadership roles refused to stand while the widow was being honored
column2: Goldberg continues to make the point that liberals lack a significant amount of class.

column1: THE PRESIDENT: Hello
column2: El Paso! (Applause.) Well
column3: it is wonderful -- wonderful to be back with all of you in the Lone Star State. (Applause.) Everything is bigger in Texas. (Applause.)

column1: AUDIENCE MEMBER: We love you!
THE PRESIDENT: I love you back! (Applause.) Even the welcomes are bigger. (Applause.) So
column2: in appreciation
column3: I wanted to give a big policy speech outside on a really hot day. (Laughter.) Those of you who are still wearing your jackets
column4: feel free to take them off. I hope everybody is wearing sunscreen.

column1: AUDIENCE MEMBER: We live here.
THE PRESIDENT: You say you live here? You donÃ¢ÂÂt need it
column2: huh? (Laughter.) Well
column3: it is a great honor to be here. And I want to express my appreciation to all of you for taking the time to come out today.

column1: AUDIENCE MEMBER: We love you!
THE PRESIDENT: Thank you. I appreciate it. Thank you. (Applause.)
You know
column2: about a week ago
column3: I delivered a commencement address at Miami Dade Community College
column4: which is one of the most diverse schools in the nation. The graduates were proud that their class could claim heritage from 181 countries around the world -- 181 countries. (Applause.)

column1: Many of the students were immigrants themselves
column2: coming to America with little more than the dream of their parents and the clothes on their back. A handful had discovered only in adolescence or adulthood that they were undocumented. But they worked hard and they gave it their all
column3: and so they earned those diplomas.

column1: And at the ceremony
column2: 181 flags -- one for every nation that was represented -- was marched across the stage. And each one was applauded by the graduates and the relatives with ties to those countries. So when the Haitian flag went by
column3: all the Haitian kids -- Haitian American kids shouted out. And when the Guatemalan flag went by
column4: all the kids of Guatemalan heritage shouted out. And when the Ukrainian flag went by
column5: I think one kid shouted out. (Laughter.) This was down in Miami. (Laughter.) If it had been in Chicago
column6: there would have been more.

column1: But then
column2: the last flag
column3: the American flag
column4: came into view. And everyone in the room erupted in applause. Everybody cheered. (Applause.) So
column5: yes
column6: their parents and grandparents -- some of the graduates themselves -- had come from every corner of the globe. But it was here that they had found opportunity. It was here that they had a chance to contribute to the nation that is their home.

column1: And it was a reminder of a simple idea
column2: as old as America itself: E pluribus unum. Out of many
column3: one. We define ourselves as a nation of immigrants -- a nation that welcomes those willing to embrace AmericaÃ¢ÂÂs ideals and AmericaÃ¢ÂÂs precepts. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs why millions of people
column4: ancestors to most of us
column5: braved hardship and great risk to come here -- so they could be free to work and worship and start a business and live their lives in peace and prosperity. The Asian immigrants who made their way to CaliforniaÃ¢ÂÂs Angel Island. The German and Scandinavians who settled across the Midwest. The waves of Irish
column6: and Italian
column7: and Polish
column8: and Russian
column9: and Jewish immigrants who leaned against the railing to catch their first glimpse of the Statue of Liberty.

column1: This flow of immigrants has helped make this country stronger and more prosperous. (Applause.) We can point to the genius of Einstein
column2: the designs of I. M. Pei
column3: the stories of Isaac Asimov
column4: the entire industries that were forged by Andrew Carnegie.

column1: And then when I think about immigration I think about the naturalization ceremonies that weÃ¢ÂÂve held at the White House for members of our military. Nothing could be more inspiring. Even though they were not yet citizens when they joined our military
column2: these men and women signed up to serve.

column1: We did one event at the White House and a young man named Granger Michael from Papua New Guinea
column2: a Marine who had been deployed to Iraq three times
column3: was there. And you know what he said about becoming an American citizen? He said
column4: Ã¢ÂÂI might as well. I love this country already.Ã¢ÂÂ ThatÃ¢ÂÂs all he said. Marines arenÃ¢ÂÂt big on speeches. (Laughter.)

column1: Another was a woman named Perla Ramos who was born and raised in Mexico and came to the United States shortly after 9/11
column2: and joined the Navy. And she said
column3: Ã¢ÂÂI take pride in our flag and the history we write day by day.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: ThatÃ¢ÂÂs the promise of this country -- that anyone can write the next chapter in our story. It doesnÃ¢ÂÂt matter where you come from -- (applause) -- it doesnÃ¢ÂÂt matter where you come from; it doesnÃ¢ÂÂt matter what you look like; it doesnÃ¢ÂÂt matter what faith you worship. What matters is that you believe in the ideals on which we were founded; that you believe that all of us are created equal
column2: endowed by our Creator with certain inalienable rights. (Applause.) All of us deserve our freedoms and our pursuit of happiness. In embracing America
column3: you can become American. That is what makes this country great. That enriches all of us.

column1: And yet
column2: at the same time
column3: weÃ¢ÂÂre here at the border today -- (applause) -- weÃ¢ÂÂre here at the border because we also recognize that being a nation of laws goes hand in hand with being a nation of immigrants. This
column4: too
column5: is our heritage. This
column6: too
column7: is important. And the truth is
column8: weÃ¢ÂÂve often wrestled with the politics of who is and who isnÃ¢ÂÂt allowed to come into this country. This debate is not new.

column1: At times
column2: there has been fear and resentment directed towards newcomers
column3: especially in hard economic times. And because these issues touch deeply on what we believe
column4: touch deeply on our convictions -- about who we are as a people
column5: about what it means to be an American -- these debates often elicit strong emotions.

column1: ThatÃ¢ÂÂs one reason itÃ¢ÂÂs been so difficult to reform our broken immigration system. When an issue is this complex
column2: when it raises such strong feelings
column3: itÃ¢ÂÂs easier for politicians to defer until the problem the next election. And thereÃ¢ÂÂs always a next election.

column1: So weÃ¢ÂÂve seen a lot of blame and a lot of politics and a lot of ugly rhetoric around immigration. And weÃ¢ÂÂve seen good faith efforts from leaders of both parties -- by the way
column2: I just noticed
column3: those of you who have chairs
column4: if you want to sit down
column5: feel free. ThereÃ¢ÂÂs no rule about having to stand when IÃ¢ÂÂm --

column1: AUDIENCE MEMBER: -- we love you! (Applause.)
THE PRESIDENT: But weÃ¢ÂÂve seen leaders of both parties who try to work on this issue
column2: but then their efforts fell prey to the usual Washington games. And all the while
column3: weÃ¢ÂÂve seen the mounting consequences of decades of inaction.

column1: Today
column2: there are an estimated 11 million undocumented immigrants here in the United States. Some crossed the border illegally. Others avoid immigration laws by overstaying their visas. Regardless of how they came
column3: the overwhelming majority of these folks are just trying to earn a living and provide for their families. (Applause.)

column1: But we have to acknowledge theyÃ¢ÂÂve broken the rules. TheyÃ¢ÂÂve cut in front of the line. And what is also true is that the presence of so many illegal immigrants makes a mockery of all those who are trying to immigrate legally.
Also
column2: because undocumented immigrants live in the shadows
column3: where theyÃ¢ÂÂre vulnerable to unscrupulous businesses that skirt taxes
column4: and pay workers less than the minimum wage
column5: or cut corners with health and safety laws
column6: this puts companies who follow the rules
column7: and Americans who rightly demand the minimum wage or overtime or just a safe place to work
column8: it puts those businesses at a disadvantage.

column1: Think about it. Over the past decade
column2: even before the recession hit
column3: middle-class families were struggling to get by as the costs went up for everything
column4: from health care
column5: to college tuition
column6: to groceries
column7: to gas. Their incomes didnÃ¢ÂÂt go up with those prices. WeÃ¢ÂÂre seeing it again right now with gas prices.

column1: So one way to strengthen the middle class in America is to reform the immigration system so that there is no longer a massive underground economy that exploits a cheap source of labor while depressing wages for everybody else. I want incomes for middle-class families to rise again. (Applause.) I want prosperity in this country to be widely shared. (Applause.) I want everybody to be able to reach that American dream. And thatÃ¢ÂÂs why immigration reform is an economic imperative. ItÃ¢ÂÂs an economic imperative. (Applause.)
And reform will also help to make America more competitive in the global economy. Today
column2: we provide students from around the world with visas to get engineering and computer science degrees at our top universities. (Applause.)

column1: But then our laws discourage them from using those skills to start a business or a new industry here in the United States. Instead of training entrepreneurs to stay here
column2: we train them to create jobs for our competition. That makes no sense. In a global marketplace
column3: we need all the talent we can attract
column4: all the talent we can get to stay here to start businesses -- not just to benefit those individuals
column5: but because their contribution will benefit all Americans.

column1: Look at Intel
column2: look at Google
column3: look at Yahoo
column4: look at eBay. All those great American companies
column5: all the jobs theyÃ¢ÂÂve created
column6: everything that has helped us take leadership in the high-tech industry
column7: every one of those was founded by
column8: guess who
column9: an immigrant. (Applause.)

column1: So we donÃ¢ÂÂt want the next Intel or the next Google to be created in China or India. We want those companies and jobs to take root here. (Applause.) Bill Gates gets this. He knows a little something about the high-tech industry. He said
column2: Ã¢ÂÂThe United States will find it far more difficult to maintain its competitive edge if it excludes those who are able and willing to help us compete.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: So immigration is not just the right thing to do. ItÃ¢ÂÂs smart for our economy. ItÃ¢ÂÂs smart for our economy. (Applause.) And itÃ¢ÂÂs for this reason that businesses all across America are demanding that Washington finally meet its responsibilities to solve the immigration problem. Everybody recognizes the system is broken. The question is
column2: will we finally summon the political will to do something about it? And thatÃ¢ÂÂs why weÃ¢ÂÂre here at the border today.

column1: And I want to say I am joined today by an outstanding Secretary of the Department of Homeland Security
column2: Janet Napolitano
column3: whoÃ¢ÂÂs been working tirelessly on this issue. (Applause.) Our commissioner whoÃ¢ÂÂs working diligently on border issues
column4: Alan Bersin
column5: is there
column6: and we appreciate him -- Bersin. (Applause.)

column1: So theyÃ¢ÂÂre doing outstanding work. And in recent years
column2: among one of the greatest impediments to reform were questions about border security. And these were legitimate concerns. What was true was a lack of manpower and a lack of resources at the border
column3: combined with the pull of jobs and ill-considered enforcement once folks were in the country.

column1: All this contributed to a growing number of undocumented people living in the United States. And these concerns helped unravel a bipartisan coalition that we had forged back when I was in the United States Senate. So in the years since
column2: Ã¢ÂÂborders first
column3: borders first
column4: Ã¢ÂÂ that's become the common refrain
column5: even among those who were previously supportive of comprehensive immigration reform.

column1: But over the last two years
column2: thanks to the outstanding work of Janet and Alan and everybody whoÃ¢ÂÂs down here working at the border
column3: weÃ¢ÂÂve answered those concerns. Under their leadership
column4: we have strengthened border security beyond what many believed was possible. They wanted more agents at the border. Well
column5: we now have more boots on the ground on the southwest border than at any time in our history. (Applause.)

column1: The Border Patrol has 20
column2: 000 agents -- more than twice as many as there were in 2004. ItÃ¢ÂÂs a build-up that began under President Bush and that weÃ¢ÂÂve continued
column3: and I had a chance to meet some of these outstanding agents
column4: and actually saw some of them on horseback who looked pretty tough. (Laughter.) So we put the agents here.

column1: Then they wanted a fence. Well
column2: the fence is --

column1: AUDIENCE: Booo!
THE PRESIDENT: The fence is now basically complete.
AUDIENCE MEMBER: Tear it down!

THE PRESIDENT: Then weÃ¢ÂÂve gone further. We tripled the number of intelligence analysts working at the border. IÃ¢ÂÂve deployed unmanned aerial vehicles to patrol the skies from Texas to California. We have forged a partnership with Mexico to fight the transnational criminal organizations that have affected both of our countries. (Applause.) And for the first time -- for the first time weÃ¢ÂÂre screening 100 percent of southbound rail shipments to seize guns and money going south even as we go after drugs that are coming north. (Applause.)
So
column2: hereÃ¢ÂÂs the point. I want everybody to listen carefully to this. We have gone above and beyond what was requested by the very Republicans who said they supported broader reform as long as we got serious about enforcement. All the stuff they asked for
column3: weÃ¢ÂÂve done. But even though weÃ¢ÂÂve answered these concerns
column4: IÃ¢ÂÂve got to say I suspect there are still going to be some who are trying to move the goal posts on us one more time.

column1: AUDIENCE MEMBER: TheyÃ¢ÂÂre racist!
THE PRESIDENT: You know
column2: they said we needed to triple the Border Patrol. Or now theyÃ¢ÂÂre going to say we need to quadruple the Border Patrol. Or theyÃ¢ÂÂll want a higher fence. Maybe theyÃ¢ÂÂll need a moat. (Laughter.) Maybe they want alligators in the moat. (Laughter.) TheyÃ¢ÂÂll never be satisfied. And I understand that. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs politics.

column1: But the truth is the measures weÃ¢ÂÂve put in place are getting results. Over the past two and a half years
column2: weÃ¢ÂÂve seized 31 percent more drugs
column3: 75 percent more currency
column4: 64 percent more weapons than ever before. (Applause.) And even as we have stepped up patrols
column5: apprehensions along the border have been cut by nearly 40 percent from two years ago. That means far fewer people are attempting to cross the border illegally.

column1: And also
column2: despite a lot of breathless reports that have tagged places like El Paso as dangerous
column3: violent crime in southwest border counties has dropped by a third. El Paso and other cities and towns along this border are consistently among the safest in the nation. (Applause.) Of course
column4: we shouldnÃ¢ÂÂt accept any violence or crime. And weÃ¢ÂÂve always got more work to do. But this progress is important and itÃ¢ÂÂs not getting reported on.

column1: And weÃ¢ÂÂre also going beyond the border. Beyond the border
column2: weÃ¢ÂÂre going after employers who knowingly exploit people and break the law. (Applause.) And we are deporting those who are here illegally. And thatÃ¢ÂÂs a tough issue. ItÃ¢ÂÂs a source of controversy.

column1: But I want to emphasize weÃ¢ÂÂre not doing it haphazardly. WeÃ¢ÂÂre focusing our limited resources and people on violent offenders and people convicted of crimes -- not just families
column2: not just folks who are just looking to scrape together an income. And as a result
column3: weÃ¢ÂÂve increased the removal of criminals by 70 percent. (Applause.)

column1: ThatÃ¢ÂÂs not to ignore the real human toll of a broken immigration system. Even as we recognize that enforcing the law is necessary
column2: we donÃ¢ÂÂt relish the pain that it causes in the lives of people who are just trying to get by and get caught up in the system.

column1: And as long as the current laws are on the books
column2: itÃ¢ÂÂs not just hardened felons who are subject to removal
column3: but sometimes families who are just trying to earn a living
column4: or bright
column5: eager students
column6: or decent people with the best of intentions. (Applause.)

column1: And sometimes when I talk to immigration advocates
column2: they wish I could just bypass Congress and change the law myself. But thatÃ¢ÂÂs not how a democracy works. What we really need to do is to keep up the fight to pass genuine
column3: comprehensive reform. That is the ultimate solution to this problem. That's what IÃ¢ÂÂm committed to doing. (Applause.)

column1: AUDIENCE MEMBER: Yes
column2: we can! Yes
column3: we can!

column1: THE PRESIDENT: Yes
column2: we can. We can do it. (Applause.)

column1: AUDIENCE: Yes
column2: we can! Yes
column3: we can! Yes
column4: we can!

column1: THE PRESIDENT: The most significant step we can now take to secure the borders is to fix the system as a whole so that fewer people have the incentive to enter illegally in search of work in the first place. This would allow agents to focus on the worst threats on both of our -- both sides of our borders
column2: from drug traffickers to those who would come here to commit acts of violence or terror. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs where our focus should be.

column1: So
column2: El Paso
column3: the question is whether those in Congress who previously walked away in the name of enforcement are now ready to come back to the table and finish the work that weÃ¢ÂÂve started. (Applause.) WeÃ¢ÂÂve got to put the politics aside. And if we do
column4: IÃ¢ÂÂm confident we can find common ground.

column1: Washington is lagging behind the country on this. There is already a growing coalition of leaders across America who donÃ¢ÂÂt always see eye-to-eye
column2: but are coming together on this issue. They see the harmful consequences of a broken immigration system for their businesses and for their communities
column3: and they understand why we need to act.

column1: There are Democrats and Republicans
column2: people like former Republican Senator Mel Martinez; former Bush administration Homeland Security Secretary Michael Chertoff; leaders like Mayor Michael Bloomberg of New York; evangelical ministers like Leith Anderson and Bill Hybels; police chiefs from across the nation; educators; advocates; labor unions; chambers of commerce; small business owners; Fortune 500 CEOs.

column1: I mean
column2: one CEO had this to say about reform: Ã¢ÂÂAmerican ingenuity is a product of the openness and diversity of this society. Immigrants have made America great as the world leader in business
column3: in science
column4: higher education and innovation.Ã¢ÂÂ You know who that leader was? Rupert Murdoch
column5: who owns FOX News
column6: and is an immigrant himself. I donÃ¢ÂÂt know if youÃ¢ÂÂre familiar with Rupert MurdochÃ¢ÂÂs views
column7: but letÃ¢ÂÂs just say he doesnÃ¢ÂÂt have an Obama sticker on his car. (Laughter.) But he agrees with me on this. (Applause.)

column1: So there is a consensus around fixing whatÃ¢ÂÂs broken. And now we need Congress to catch up. Now we need to come together around reform that reflects our values as a nation of laws and a nation of immigrants; reform that demands that everybody take responsibility. So what would comprehensive reform look like?
First
column2: we know that government has a threshold responsibility to secure our borders and enforce the law. And thatÃ¢ÂÂs what Janet and all her folks are doing. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what theyÃ¢ÂÂre doing. (Applause.)

column1: Second
column2: businesses have to be held accountable if they exploit undocumented workers. (Applause.)

column1: Third
column2: those who are here illegally
column3: they have a responsibility as well. So they broke the law
column4: and that means theyÃ¢ÂÂve got to pay their taxes
column5: theyÃ¢ÂÂve got to pay a fine
column6: theyÃ¢ÂÂve got to learn English. And theyÃ¢ÂÂve got to undergo background checks and a lengthy process before they get in line for legalization. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs not too much to ask. (Applause.)

column1: And fourth
column2: stopping illegal immigration also depends on reforming our outdated system of legal immigration. (Applause.) We should make it easier for the best and the brightest to not only stay here
column3: but also to start businesses and create jobs here. In recent years
column4: a full 25 percent of high-tech startups in the U.S. were founded by immigrants. That led to 200
column5: 000 jobs here in America. IÃ¢ÂÂm glad those jobs are here. I want to see more of them created in this country. We need to provide them the chance. (Applause.)

column1: We need to provide our farms a legal way to hire workers that they rely on
column2: and a path for those workers to earn legal status. (Applause.) And our laws should respect families following the rules -- reuniting them more quickly instead of splitting them apart. (Applause.)

column1: Today
column2: the immigration system not only tolerates those who break the rules
column3: but it punishes folks who follow the rules. While applications -- while applicants wait for approval
column4: for example
column5: theyÃ¢ÂÂre often forbidden from visiting the United States. Even husbands and wives may have to spend years apart. Parents canÃ¢ÂÂt see their children. I donÃ¢ÂÂt believe the United States of America should be in the business of separating families. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs not right. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs not who we are. We can do better than that. (Applause.)

column1: And we should stop punishing innocent young people for the actions of their parents. (Applause.) We should stop denying them the chance to earn an education or serve in the military. And thatÃ¢ÂÂs why we need to pass the DREAM Act. (Applause.) Now
column2: we passed the DREAM Act through the House last year when Democrats were in control. But even though it received a majority of votes in the Senate
column3: it was blocked when several Republicans who had previously supported the DREAM Act voted no.

column1: That was a tremendous disappointment to get so close and then see politics get in the way. And as I gave that commencement at Miami Dade
column2: it broke my heart knowing that a number of those promising
column3: bright students -- young people who worked so hard and who speak about whatÃ¢ÂÂs best in America -- are at risk of facing the agony of deportation. These are kids who grew up in this country. They love this country. They know no other place to call home. The idea that weÃ¢ÂÂd punish them is cruel. It makes no sense. WeÃ¢ÂÂre a better nation than that. (Applause.)

column1: So weÃ¢ÂÂre going to keep fighting for the DREAM Act. WeÃ¢ÂÂre going to keep up the fight for reform. (Applause.) And thatÃ¢ÂÂs where you come in. IÃ¢ÂÂm going to do my part to lead a constructive and civil debate on these issues. And weÃ¢ÂÂve already had a series of meetings about this at the White House in recent weeks. WeÃ¢ÂÂve got leaders here and around the country helping to move the debate forward.
But this change ultimately has to be driven by you
column2: the American people. YouÃ¢ÂÂve got to help push for comprehensive reform
column3: and youÃ¢ÂÂve got to identify what steps we can take right now -- like the DREAM Act
column4: like visa reform -- areas where we can find common ground among Democrats and Republicans and begin to fix whatÃ¢ÂÂs broken.

column1: So IÃ¢ÂÂm asking you to add your voices to this debate. You can sign up to help at whitehouse.gov. We need Washington to know that there is a movement for reform thatÃ¢ÂÂs gathering strength from coast to coast. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs how weÃ¢ÂÂll get this done. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs how we can ensure that in the years ahead we are welcoming the talents of all who can contribute to this country and that weÃ¢ÂÂre living up to the basic American idea that you can make it here if you try. (Applause.)

ThatÃ¢ÂÂs the idea that gave hope to JosÃÂ© HernÃÂ¡ndez. Is JosÃÂ© here? WhereÃ¢ÂÂs -- JosÃÂ© is right over there. (Applause.) I want you to hear -- I want you to think about this story. JosÃÂ©Ã¢ÂÂs parents were migrant farm workers. And so
column2: growing up
column3: he was too. He was born in California
column4: though he could have just as easily been born on the other side of the border
column5: if it had been a different time of year
column6: because his family moved around with the seasons. So two of his siblings were actually born in Mexico.

column1: So they traveled a lot
column2: and JosÃÂ© joined his parents picking cucumbers and strawberries. And he missed part of school when they returned to Mexico each winter. JosÃÂ© didnÃ¢ÂÂt learn English until he was 12 years old. But you know what
column3: JosÃÂ© was good at math and he liked math. And the nice thing is that math was the same in every school
column4: and itÃ¢ÂÂs the same in Spanish as it is in English.

column1: So JosÃÂ© studied
column2: and he studied hard. And one day
column3: heÃ¢ÂÂs standing in the fields
column4: collecting sugar beets
column5: and he heard on a transistor radio that a man named Franklin Chang-Diaz -- a man with a surname like his -- was going to be an astronaut for NASA. So JosÃÂ© decided -- right there in the field
column6: he decided -- well
column7: I could be an astronaut
column8: too.

column1: So JosÃÂ© kept on studying
column2: and he graduated high school. And he kept on studying
column3: and he earned an engineering degree. And he kept on studying
column4: and he earned a graduate degree. And he kept on working hard
column5: and he ended up at a national laboratory
column6: helping to develop a new kind of digital medical imaging system.

column1: And a few years later
column2: he found himself more than 100 miles above the surface of the Earth
column3: staring out of the window of the shuttle Discovery
column4: and he was remembering the boy in the California fields with that crazy dream that in America everything is possible. (Applause.)

column1: Think about that
column2: El Paso. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs the American Dream right there. (Applause.) That's what weÃ¢ÂÂre fighting for. We are fighting for every boy and every girl like JosÃÂ© with a dream and potential that's just waiting to be tapped. We are fighting to unlock that promise
column3: and all that holds not just for their futures
column4: but for AmericaÃ¢ÂÂs future. That's why weÃ¢ÂÂre going to get this done. And that's why IÃ¢ÂÂm going to need your help.

column1: Thank you. God bless you. And may God bless the United States of America. (Applause.)
END

41	"ItÃ¢ÂÂs not a good day for Democrats.

Democrat House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi suffered what her staff is calling a Ã¢ÂÂbreakdownÃ¢ÂÂ this morning and was transferred via ambulance to Bethesda. Rear-Admiral Thomas Phillip McCrakken
column2: head of psychiatry
column3: said Pelosi shows signs of a psychotic break from reality that a woman her age may never recover from:

column1: Ã¢ÂÂMrs. Pelosi is in an advanced stage of disengagement from reality. SheÃ¢ÂÂs under the impression that Democrats still have say in how our country is governed
column2: for example

column5: just silly. She also believes
column6: as she told me personally just yesterday
