column1: Real Patriots who love their president. No. Matter. What."	1
MR. DORSEY: Good afternoon and welcome to the White House. I am Jack Dorsey
column2: from Twitter.

column1: Through more than 200 million tweets per day
column2: people around the world use Twitter to instantly connect to what's most meaningful to them. In every country -- Egypt and Japan
column3: the UK and the United States -- much of this conversation is made up of everyday people engaging in spirited debate about the future of their countries.

column1: Our partners at Salesforce Radian6 studied more than a million tweets
column2: discussing our nation's politics over the recent weeks
column3: and they found that America's financial security to be one of the most actively talked about topics on Twitter. They further found that President Obama's name comes up in more than half of these conversations.

column1: And so today this vibrant discussion comes here to the White House and you get to ask the questions. To participate
column2: just open your web browser and go to askObama.Twitter.com. Neither the President or I know the questions that will be asked today. That decision is driven entirely by the Twitter users.

column1: And so let's get the conversation started. Ladies and gentlemen
column2: the President of the United States. (Applause.)

column1: THE PRESIDENT: Hello
column2: everybody! (Applause.) First of all
column3: everybody can sit down. (Laughter.) It's much easier to tweet from a seated position. (Laughter.)

column1: MR. DORSEY: And I understand you want to start the conversation off with a tweeter yourself.
THE PRESIDENT: I'm going to make history here as the first President to live tweet. So we've got a computer over here. (Types in tweet.)
MR. DORSEY: It's only 140 characters. (Laughter.)
THE PRESIDENT: All right
column2: I think I have done this properly. But here's the test.

column1: MR. DORSEY: And you tweeted.
THE PRESIDENT: How about that? Not bad. (Applause.) Thank you. So I think my question will be coming up at some point.
MR. DORSEY: So what was your question? Here it is.
THE PRESIDENT: Here's the question: ""In order to reduce the deficit
column2: what costs would you cut and what investments would you keep?""

column1: And the reason I thought this was an important question is
column2: as all of you know
column3: we are going through a spirited debate here in Washington
column4: but it's important to get the whole country involved
column5: in making a determination about what are the programs that can help us grow
column6: can create jobs
column7: improve our education system
column8: maintain our clean air and clean water
column9: and what are those things that are a waste that we shouldnÃ¢ÂÂt be investing in because they're not helping us grow or create jobs or creating new businesses. And that debate is going to be heating up over the next couple of weeks
column10: so I'd love to hear from the American people
column11: see what thoughts they have.

column1: MR. DORSEY: Excellent. Well
column2: first question comes from a curator in New Hampshire. And we have eight curators around the country helping us pick tweets from the crowd so that we can read them to the President.

column1: And this one comes from William Smith: ""What mistakes have you made in handling this recession and what would you do differently?""
THE PRESIDENT: That's a terrific question. When I first came into office we were facing the worst recession since the Great Depression. So
column2: looking around this room
column3: it's a pretty young room -- it's certainly the worst recession that we've faced in our lifetimes. And we had to act quickly and make some bold and sometimes difficult decisions.

column1: It was absolutely the right thing to do to put forward a Recovery Act that cut taxes for middle-class folks so they had more money in their pocket to get through the recession. It was the right thing to do to provide assistance to states to make sure that they didnÃ¢ÂÂt have to lay off teachers and cops and firefighters as quickly as they needed to. And it was the right thing to do to try to rebuild our infrastructure and put people back to work building roads and bridges and so forth.
It also was the right thing to do
column2: although a tough decision
column3: to save the auto industry
column4: which is now profitable and gaining market share -- the U.S. auto industry -- for the first time in a very long time.

column1: I think that -- probably two things that I would do differently. One would have been to explain to the American people that it was going to take a while for us to get out of this. I think even I did not realize the magnitude
column2: because most economists didnÃ¢ÂÂt realize the magnitude
column3: of the recession until fairly far into it
column4: maybe two or three months into my presidency where we started realizing that we had lost 4 million jobs before I was even sworn in.

column1: And so I think people may not have been prepared for how long this was going to take and why we were going to have to make some very difficult decisions and choices. And I take responsibility for that
column2: because setting peopleÃ¢ÂÂs expectations is part of how you end up being able to respond well.

column1: The other area is in the area of housing. I think that the continuing decline in the housing market is something that hasnÃ¢ÂÂt bottomed out as quickly as we expected. And so thatÃ¢ÂÂs continued to be a big drag on the economy.
WeÃ¢ÂÂve had to revamp our housing program several times to try to help people stay in their homes and try to start lifting home values up. But of all the things weÃ¢ÂÂve done
column2: thatÃ¢ÂÂs probably been the area thatÃ¢ÂÂs been most stubborn to us trying to solve the problem.

column1: MR. DORSEY: Mr. President
column2: 27 percent of our questions are in the jobs category
column3: as you can see from the screen over here. Our next question has to do about jobs and technology. It comes from David: ""Tech and knowledge industries are thriving
column4: yet jobs discussion always centers on manufacturing. Why not be realistic about jobs?""

column1: THE PRESIDENT: Well
column2: itÃ¢ÂÂs not an either/or question; itÃ¢ÂÂs a both/and question. We have to be successful at the cutting-edge industries of the future like Twitter. But we also have always been a country that makes stuff. And manufacturing jobs end up having both higher wages typically
column3: and they also have bigger multiplier effects. So one manufacturing job can support a range of other jobs -- suppliers and the restaurant near the plant and so forth. So they end up having a substantial impact on the overall economy.

column1: What we want to focus on is advanced manufacturing that combines new technology
column2: so research and development to figure out how are we going to create the next Twitter
column3: how are we going to create the next Google
column4: how are we going to create the next big thing -- but make sure that production is here.

column1: So itÃ¢ÂÂs great that we have an Apple thatÃ¢ÂÂs creating iPods
column2: iPads and designing them and creating the software
column3: but it would be nice if weÃ¢ÂÂre also making the iPads and the iPods here in the United States
column4: because that's some more jobs that people can work at.

column1: And there are going to be a series of decisions that weÃ¢ÂÂve got to make. Number one
column2: are we investing in research and development in order to emphasize technology? And a lot of that has to come from government. That's how the Internet got formed. That's how GPS got formed. Companies on their own canÃ¢ÂÂt always finance the basic research because they canÃ¢ÂÂt be assured that theyÃ¢ÂÂre going to get a return on it.

column1: Number two
column2: weÃ¢ÂÂve got to drastically improve how we train our workforce and our kids around math and science and technology.

column1: Number three
column2: weÃ¢ÂÂve got to have a top-notch infrastructure to support advanced manufacturing
column3: and weÃ¢ÂÂve got to look at sectors where we know this is going to be the future. Something like clean energy
column4: for example. For us not to be the leaders in investing in clean energy manufacturing so that wind turbines and solar panels are not only designed here in the United States but made here in the United States makes absolutely no sense. WeÃ¢ÂÂve got to invest in those areas for us to be successful.

column1: So you can combine high-tech with manufacturing
column2: and then you get the best of all worlds.

column1: MR. DORSEY: You mentioned education. There's a lot of questions coming about education and its impact on the economy. This one in particular is from a curator who is pulling from a student in Ohio
column2: named Dustin: ""Higher ed is necessary for a stronger economy
column3: but for some middle-class Americans itÃ¢ÂÂs becoming too expensive. What can be done?""

column1: THE PRESIDENT: Well
column2: here is some good news. WeÃ¢ÂÂve already done something that is very significant
column3: and people may not know. As part of a higher education package that we passed last year
column4: what we were able to do was to take away subsidies that were going to banks for serving as middlemen in the student loan program and funnel that to help young people
column5: through Pell Grants and lower rates on student loans. And so there are millions of students who are getting more affordable student loans and grants as a consequence of the steps that weÃ¢ÂÂve already taken. This is about tens of billions of dollars' worth of additional federal dollars that were going to banks are now going to students directly.

column1: In addition
column2: what weÃ¢ÂÂve said is that starting in 2013
column3: young people who are going to college will not have to pay more than 10 percent of their income in repayment. And that obviously helps to relieve the burden on a lot students -- because
column4: look
column5: IÃ¢ÂÂm a guy who had about $60
column6: 000 worth of debt when I graduated from law school
column7: and Michelle had $60
column8: 000. And so we were paying a bigger amount every month than our mortgage. And we did that for eight
column9: 10 years. So I know how burdensome this can be.

column1: I do think that the universities still have a role in trying to keep their costs down. And I think that itÃ¢ÂÂs important -- even if we've got better student loan programs
column2: more grants
column3: if the costs keep on going up then we'll never have enough money
column4: you'll never get enough help to avoid taking on these huge debts. And so working with university presidents to try to figure out
column5: where can you cut costs -- of course
column6: it may mean that the food in the cafeteria is a little worse and the gym is not as fancy. But I think all of us have to figure out a way to make sure that higher education is accessible for everybody.

column1: One last point -- I know
column2: Twitter
column3: IÃ¢ÂÂm supposed to be short. (Laughter.) But city -- community colleges is a huge
column4: under-utilized resource
column5: where what we want to do is set up a lifelong learning system where you may have gotten your four-year degree
column6: but five years out you decide you want to go into another field or you want to brush up on new technologies that are going to help you advance. We need to create a system where you can conveniently access community colleges that are working with businesses to train for the jobs that actually exist. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs a huge area where I think we can make a lot of progress.

column1: MR. DORSEY: You mention debt a lot. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs come up in conversation a lot recently
column2: especially in some of our recent questions
column3: specifically the debt ceiling. And this is formulated in our next question from RenegadeNerd out of Atlanta: ""Mr. President
column4: will you issue an executive order to raise the debt ceiling pursuant to Section 4 of the 14th Amendment?""

column1: THE PRESIDENT: Can I just say
column2: RenegadeNerd
column3: that picture is -- captures it all there. (Laughter.) He's got his hand over there
column4: heÃ¢ÂÂs looking kind of confused. (Laughter.)

column1: Let me
column2: as quickly as I can
column3: describe whatÃ¢ÂÂs at stake with respect to the debt ceiling. Historically
column4: the United States
column5: whenever it has a deficit
column6: it finances that deficit through the sale of treasuries. And this is a very common practice. Over our lifetimes
column7: typically the government is always running a modest deficit. And Congress is supposed to vote on the amount of debt that Treasury can essentially issue. ItÃ¢ÂÂs a pretty esoteric piece of business; typically has not been something that created a lot of controversy.

column1: WhatÃ¢ÂÂs happening now is
column2: is that Congress is suggesting we may not vote to raise the debt ceiling. If we do not
column3: then the Treasury will run out of money. It will not be able to pay the bills that are owing
column4: and potentially the entire world capital markets could decide
column5: you know what
column6: the full faith and credit of the United States doesnÃ¢ÂÂt mean anything. And so our credit could be downgraded
column7: interest rates could go drastically up
column8: and it could cause a whole new spiral into a second recession
column9: or worse.

column1: So this is something that we shouldnÃ¢ÂÂt be toying with. What DexterÃ¢ÂÂs question referred to was there are some people who say that under the Constitution
column2: itÃ¢ÂÂs unconstitutional for Congress not to allow Treasury to pay its bills and are suggesting that this should be challenged under the Constitution.

column1: I donÃ¢ÂÂt think we should even get to the constitutional issue. Congress has a responsibility to make sure we pay our bills. WeÃ¢ÂÂve always paid them in the past. The notion that the U.S. is going to default on its debt is just irresponsible. And my expectation is
column2: is that over the next week to two weeks
column3: that Congress
column4: working with the White House
column5: comes up with a deal that solves our deficit
column6: solves our debt problems
column7: and makes sure that our full faith and credit is protected.

column1: MR. DORSEY: So back to jobs. We have a question from New York City about immigrant entrepreneurs: ""Immigrant entrepreneurs can build companies and create jobs for U.S. workers. Will you support a startup visa program?""
THE PRESIDENT: What I want to do is make sure that talented people who come to this country to study
column2: to get degrees
column3: and are willing and interested in starting up businesses can do so
column4: as opposed to going back home and starting those businesses over there to compete against the United States and take away U.S. jobs.

column1: So weÃ¢ÂÂre working with the business community as well as the entrepreneurial community to figure out are there ways that we can streamline the visa system so if you are studying here
column2: youÃ¢ÂÂve got a PhD in computer science or youÃ¢ÂÂve got a PhD in engineering
column3: and you say IÃ¢ÂÂm ready to invest in the United States
column4: create jobs in the United States
column5: then we are able to say to you
column6: we want you to stay here.

column1: And I think that it is possible for us to deal with this problem. But itÃ¢ÂÂs important for us to look at it more broadly. WeÃ¢ÂÂve got an immigration system thatÃ¢ÂÂs broken right now
column2: where too many folks are breaking the law but also our laws make it too hard for talented people to contribute and be part of our society. And weÃ¢ÂÂve always been a nation of laws and a nation of immigrants. And so we need comprehensive immigration reform
column3: part of which would allow entrepreneurs and high-skilled individuals to stay here -- because we want to be attracting that talent here. We donÃ¢ÂÂt want that -- we donÃ¢ÂÂt want to pay for training them here and then having them benefit other countries.

column1: MR. DORSEY: Our next question was just -- was sent just an hour ago and touches on alternative energy and job creation: ""Will you focus on promoting alternative energy industries in oil states like Louisiana and Texas?""
THE PRESIDENT: I want to promote alternative energy everywhere
column2: including oil states like Louisiana and Texas. This is something that IÃ¢ÂÂm very proud of and doesnÃ¢ÂÂt get a lot of attention. We made the largest investment in clean energy in our history through the Recovery Act. And so we put forward a range of programs that provided credits and grants to startup companies in areas like creating wind turbines
column3: solar panels.

column1: A great example is advanced battery manufacturing. When I came into office
column2: advanced batteries
column3: which are used
column4: for example
column5: in electric cars
column6: we only accounted for 2 percent of the world market in advanced batteries. And we have quintupled our market share
column7: or even gone further
column8: just over the last two years. And weÃ¢ÂÂre projecting that we can get to 30 to 40 percent of that market. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs creating jobs all across the Midwest
column9: all across America.

column1: And whoever wins this race on advanced battery manufacturing is probably going to win the race to produce the cars of the 21st century. China is investing in it. Germany is investing in it. We need to be investing in it as well.
MR. DORSEY: I wanted to take a moment and point out the map just behind you. These are tweets coming in
column2: in real time
column3: and these are questions being asked right now. And it flips between the various categories that weÃ¢ÂÂve determined and also just general askObama questions.

column1: So our next question is coming up on the screen now
column2: from Patrick: Ã¢ÂÂMr. President
column3: in several states we have seen people lose their collective bargaining rights. Do you have a plan to rectify this?""

column1: THE PRESIDENT: The first thing I want to emphasize is that collective bargaining is the reason why the vast majority of Americans enjoy a minimum wage
column2: enjoy weekends
column3: enjoy overtime. So many things that we take for granted are because workers came together to bargain with their employers.

column1: Now
column2: we live in a very competitive society in the 21st century. And that means in the private sector
column3: labor has to take management into account. If labor is making demands that make management broke and they canÃ¢ÂÂt compete
column4: then that doesnÃ¢ÂÂt do anybody any good.

column1: In the public sector
column2: what is true is that some of the pension plans that have been in place and the health benefits that are in place are so out of proportion with whatÃ¢ÂÂs happening in the private sector that a lot of taxpayers start feeling resentful. They say
column3: well
column4: if I donÃ¢ÂÂt have health care where I only have to pay $1 for prescription drugs
column5: why is it that the person whose salary IÃ¢ÂÂm paying has a better deal?

column1: What this means is
column2: is that all of us are going to have to make some adjustments. But the principle of collective bargaining
column3: making sure that people can exercise their rights to be able to join together with other workers and to negotiate and kind of even the bargaining power on either side
column4: thatÃ¢ÂÂs something that has to be protected. And we can make these adjustments in a way that are equitable but preserve peopleÃ¢ÂÂs collective bargaining rights.

column1: So
column2: typically
column3: the challenges against bargaining rights have been taking place at the state level. I don't have direct control over that. But what I can do is to speak out forcefully for the principle that we can make these adjustments that are necessary during these difficult fiscal times
column4: but do it in a way that preserves collective bargaining rights. And certainly at the federal level where I do have influence
column5: I can make sure that we make these adjustments without affecting peopleÃ¢ÂÂs collective bargaining rights.

column1: I'll give you just one example. We froze federal pay for federal workers for two years. Now
column2: that wasnÃ¢ÂÂt real popular
column3: as you might imagine
column4: among federal workers. On the other hand
column5: we were able to do that precisely because we wanted to prevent layoffs and we wanted to make sure that we sent a signal that everybody is going to have to make some sacrifices
column6: including federal workers.

column1: By the way
column2: people who work in the White House
column3: theyÃ¢ÂÂve had their pay frozen since I came in
column4: our high-wage folks. So they havenÃ¢ÂÂt had a raise in two and a half years
column5: and that's appropriate
column6: because a lot of ordinary folks out there havenÃ¢ÂÂt
column7: either. In fact
column8: theyÃ¢ÂÂve seen their pay cut in some cases.

column1: MR. DORSEY: Mr. President
column2: 6 percent of our questions are coming in about housing
column3: which you can see in the graph behind me. And this one in particular has to do with personal debt and housing: Ã¢ÂÂHow will admin work to help underwater homeowners who arenÃ¢ÂÂt behind in payments but are trapped in homes they canÃ¢ÂÂt sell?Ã¢ÂÂ From Robin.

column1: THE PRESIDENT: This is a great question. And remember
column2: I mentioned one of our biggest challenges during the course of the last two and a half years has been dealing with a huge burst of the housing bubble.

column1: What's happened is a lot of folks are underwater
column2: meaning their home values went down so steeply and so rapidly that now their mortgage
column3: the amount they owe
column4: is a lot more than the assessed worth of their home. And that obviously burdens a lot of folks. It means if theyÃ¢ÂÂre selling
column5: theyÃ¢ÂÂve got to sell at a massive loss that they canÃ¢ÂÂt afford. It means that they donÃ¢ÂÂt feel like they have any assets because the single biggest asset of most Americans is their home.

column1: So what weÃ¢ÂÂve been trying to do is to work with the issuers of the mortgages
column2: the banks or the service companies
column3: to convince them to work with homeowners who are paying
column4: trying to do the right thing
column5: trying to stay in their homes
column6: to see if they can modify the loans so that their payments are lower
column7: and in some cases
column8: maybe even modify their principal
column9: so that they donÃ¢ÂÂt feel burdened by these huge debts and feel tempted to walk away from homes that actually they love and where theyÃ¢ÂÂre raising their families.

column1: WeÃ¢ÂÂve made some progress. We have
column2: through the programs that we set up here
column3: have probably seen several million home modifications either directly because we had control of the loan process
column4: or because the private sector followed suit. But itÃ¢ÂÂs not enough. And so weÃ¢ÂÂre going back to the drawing board
column5: talking to banks
column6: try to put some pressure on them to work with people who have mortgages to see if we can make further adjustments
column7: modify loans more quickly
column8: and also see if there may be circumstances where reducing principal is appropriate.

column1: MR. DORSEY: And our next question comes from someone you may know. This is Speaker Boehner.
THE PRESIDENT: Oh
column2: there you go. (Laughter.)

column1: MR. DORSEY: Ã¢ÂÂAfter embarking on a record spending binge that left us deeper in debt
column2: where are the jobs?Ã¢ÂÂ And I want to note that these characters are his fault. (Laughter.)

column1: THE PRESIDENT: First of all --
MR. DORSEY: Not his fault
column2: not his fault.

column1: THE PRESIDENT: -- John obviously needs to work on his typing skills. (Laughter.) Well
column2: look
column3: obviously John is the Speaker of the House
column4: heÃ¢ÂÂs a Republican
column5: and so this is a slightly skewed question. (Laughter.) But what heÃ¢ÂÂs right about is that we have not seen fast enough job growth relative to the need. I mean
column6: we lost
column7: as I said
column8: 4 million jobs before I took office
column9: before I was sworn in. About 4 million jobs were lost in the few months right after I took office before our economic policies had a chance to take any effect.

column1: And over the last 15 months
column2: weÃ¢ÂÂve actually seen two million jobs created in the private sector. And so weÃ¢ÂÂre each month seeing growth in jobs
column3: But when youÃ¢ÂÂve got a 8 million dollar -- 8-million-job hole and youÃ¢ÂÂre only filling it 100
column5: 000 jobs at a time each month
column6: obviously thatÃ¢ÂÂs way too long for a lot of folks who are still out of work.

column1: There are a couple of things that we can continue to do. I actually worked with Speaker Boehner to pass a payroll tax cut in December that put an extra $1
column2: 000 in the pockets of almost every single American. That means theyÃ¢ÂÂre spending money. That means that businesses have customers. And that has helped improve overall growth.

column1: We have provided at least 16 tax cuts to small businesses who have needed a lot of help and have been struggling
column2: including
column3: for example
column4: saying zero capital gains taxes on startups -- because our attitude is we want to encourage new companies
column5: young entrepreneurs
column6: to get out there
column7: start their business
column8: without feeling like if theyÃ¢ÂÂre successful in the first couple of years that somehow they have to pay taxes
column9: as opposed to putting that money back into their business.

column1: So weÃ¢ÂÂve been able to cooperate with Republicans on a range of these issues. There are some areas where the Republicans have been more resistant in cooperating
column2: even though I think most objective observers think itÃ¢ÂÂs the right thing to do. IÃ¢ÂÂll give you a specific example.

column1: ItÃ¢ÂÂs estimated that we have about $2 trillion worth of infrastructure that needs to be rebuilt. Roads
column2: bridges
column3: sewer lines
column4: water mains; our air traffic control system doesnÃ¢ÂÂt make sense. We donÃ¢ÂÂt have the kind of electric grid thatÃ¢ÂÂs smart
column5: meaning it doesnÃ¢ÂÂt waste a lot of energy in transmission. Our broadband system is slower than a lot of other countries.

column1: For us to move forward on a major infrastructure initiative where weÃ¢ÂÂre putting people to work right now -- including construction workers who were disproportionately unemployed when the housing bubble went bust -- to put them to work rebuilding America at a time when interest rates are very low
column2: contractors are looking for work
column3: and the need is there
column4: that is something that could make a huge
column5: positive impact on the economy overall. And itÃ¢ÂÂs an example of making an investment now that ends up having huge payoffs down the road.

column1: We havenÃ¢ÂÂt gotten the kind of cooperation that IÃ¢ÂÂd like to see on some of those ideas and initiatives. But IÃ¢ÂÂm just going to keep on trying and eventually IÃ¢ÂÂm sure the Speaker will see the light. (Laughter.)
MR. DORSEY: Speaking of startups
column2: thereÃ¢ÂÂs a ton of questions about small businesses and how they affect job creation. This one comes from Neal: Ã¢ÂÂSmall biz create jobs. What incentives are you willing to support to improve small business growth?Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: THE PRESIDENT: Well
column2: I just mentioned some of the tax breaks that weÃ¢ÂÂve provided not only to small businesses
column3: but also in some cases were provided big businesses. For example
column4: if theyÃ¢ÂÂre making investments in plants and equipment this year
column5: they can fully write down those costs
column6: take -- essentially depreciate all those costs this year and that saves them a pretty big tax bill. So weÃ¢ÂÂre already initiating a bunch of steps.

column1: The biggest challenge that I hear from small businesses right now actually has to do with financing
column2: because a lot of small businesses got their financing from community banks. Typically
column3: theyÃ¢ÂÂre not getting them from the big Wall Street banks
column4: but theyÃ¢ÂÂre getting them from their various regional banks in their communities. A lot of those banks were pretty over-extended in the commercial real estate market
column5: which has been hammered. A lot of them are still digging themselves out of bad loans that they made that were shown to be bad during the recession.

column1: And so
column2: what weÃ¢ÂÂve tried to do is get the Small Business Administration
column3: the federal agency that helps small businesses
column4: to step in and to provide more financing -- waiving fees
column5: seeing if we can lower interest rates in some cases
column6: making sure that the threshold for companies that qualify for loans are more generous. And thatÃ¢ÂÂs helped a lot of small businesses all across the country. And this is another example of where
column7: working with Congress
column8: my hope is
column9: is that we can continue to provide these tax incentives and maybe do even a little bit more.

column1: Q Our next question was tweeted less than five minutes ago and comes to us from Craig: Ã¢ÂÂMy question is
column2: can you give companies a tax break if they hire an honorable discharged veteran?Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: THE PRESIDENT: This is something that IÃ¢ÂÂve been talking a lot about internally. WeÃ¢ÂÂve got all these young people coming back from Iraq and Afghanistan; have made incredible sacrifices; have taken on incredible responsibilities. You see some 23-year-old who's leading a platoon in hugely dangerous circumstances
column2: making decisions
column3: operating complex technologies. These are folks who can perform. But
column4: unfortunately
column5: what weÃ¢ÂÂre seeing is that a lot of these young veterans have a higher unemployment rate than people who didnÃ¢ÂÂt serve. And that makes no sense.

column1: So what weÃ¢ÂÂd like to do is potentially combine a tax credit for a company that hires veterans with a campaign to have private companies step up and do the right thing and hire more veterans. And one of the things that weÃ¢ÂÂve done is internally in the federal government we have made a huge emphasis on ramping up our outreach to veterans and the hiring of veterans
column2: and this has been a top priority of mine. The notion that these guys who are sacrificing for our freedom and our security end up coming home and not being able to find a job I think is unacceptable.

column1: MR. DORSEY: Mr. President
column2: this next question comes from someone else you may recognize. And what's interesting about this question
column3: it was heavily retweeted and voted up by our userbase. This comes from NickKristof: Ã¢ÂÂWas it a mistake to fail to get Republicans to commit to raise the debt ceiling at the same time tax cuts were extended?Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: THE PRESIDENT: Nicholas is a great columnist. But I have to tell you the assumption of the question is
column2: is that I was going to be able to get them to commit to raising the debt ceiling.

column1: In December
column2: we were in what was called the lame duck session. The Republicans knew that they were going to be coming in as the majority. We only had a few short weeks to deal with a lot of complicated issues
column3: including repealing ""don't ask
column4: don't tell
column5: dealing with a START treaty to reduce nuclear weapons
column6: and come to terms with a budget. And what we were able to do was negotiate a package where we agreed to do something that we didnÃ¢ÂÂt like but that the Republicans badly wanted
column7: which is to extend the Bush tax cuts on the wealthy for another two years.

column1: In exchange
column2: we were able to get this payroll tax that put $1
column3: 000 -- tax cut that put $1
column4: 000 in the pockets of every American
column5: which would help economic growth and jobs. We were also able to get unemployment insurance extended for the millions of Americans out there who are still out of work and whose benefits were about to run out. And that was a much better deal than I think a lot of people expected.

column1: It would have been great if we were able to also settle this issue of the debt ceiling at that time. That wasnÃ¢ÂÂt the deal that was available. But hereÃ¢ÂÂs the more basic point: Never in our history has the United States defaulted on its debt. The debt ceiling should not be something that is used as a gun against the heads of the American people to extract tax breaks for corporate jet owners
column2: or oil and gas companies that are making billions of dollars because the price of gasoline has gone up so high.

column1: IÃ¢ÂÂm happy to have those debates. I think the American people are on my side on this. What we need to do is to have a balanced approach where everything is on the table. We need to reduce corporate loopholes. We need to reduce discretionary spending on programs that arenÃ¢ÂÂt working. We need to reduce defense spending. Everything has -- we need to look at entitlements
column2: and we have to say
column3: how do we protect and preserve Medicare and Social Security for not just this generation but also future generations. And thatÃ¢ÂÂs going to require some modifications
column4: even as we maintain its basic structure.

column1: So what IÃ¢ÂÂm hoping to see over the next couple of weeks is people put their dogmas aside
column2: their sacred cows aside; they come together and they say
column3: hereÃ¢ÂÂs a sensible approach that reduces our deficit
column4: makes sure that government is spending within its means
column5: but also continues to make investments in education
column6: in clean energy
column7: and basic research that are going to preserve our competitive advantage going forward.

column1: MR. DORSEY: So speaking of taxes
column2: our next question is coming from us -- from Alabama
column3: from Lane: ""What changes to the tax system do you think are necessary to help solve the deficit problem and for the system to be fair?""

column1: THE PRESIDENT: Well
column2: I think that
column3: first of all
column4: itÃ¢ÂÂs important for people to realize that since IÃ¢ÂÂve been in office IÃ¢ÂÂve cut taxes for middle-class families
column5: repeatedly. The Recovery Act cut taxes for 95 percent of working families. The payroll tax cut that we passed in December put an extra thousand dollars in the pockets of every family in America.

column1: And so we actually now have the lowest tax rates since the 1950s. Our tax rates are lower now than they were under Ronald Reagan. TheyÃ¢ÂÂre lower than they were under George Bush -- senior or George Bush
column2: junior. TheyÃ¢ÂÂre lower than they were under Bill Clinton.

column1: The question is how do we pay for the things that we all think are important and how do we make sure that the tax system is equitable? And what IÃ¢ÂÂve said is that in addition to eliminating a whole bunch of corporate loopholes that are just not fair -- the notion that corporate jets should get a bett"	0

column1: The territorial gains of the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS) in the Middle East over the past week have prompted a fresh look at what the U.S. can do to stop the militant group. But lawmakers are still divided about whether a military or political strategy provides the best shot at success.
We need to have a more robust strategy. We need more troops on the ground
column2: we need forward air controllers - we're just referring to air strikes
column3: said Senate Armed Services Committee Chairman John McCain
column4: R-Arizona
column5: on CBS' ""Face the Nation"" Sunday. ""We found in Vietnam War that if you don't have the right strategy
column6: airpower is minimal in its effect
column7: but we need to have forward air controllers
column8: we need to have special forces
column9: we need to have more of those kind of raids that were so successful into Syria. We need to have a strategy. There is no strategy. And anyone that says that there is
column10: I'd like to hear what it is because it certainly isn't apparent now and right now.""

column1: He said that there should be a few thousand more American troops on the ground to carry out that kind of mission.
But California Rep. Adam Schiff
column2: the top Democrat on the House Intelligence Committee
column3: says the U.S. will not be able to sustain any victories in Iraq unless the government is able to resolve its political differences.

column1: During the Iraq War
column2: Schiff said
column3: ""We won Ramadi but it didn't stay won because the political problems that preceded the first Iraq war haven't been solved and that is the Sunnis have not been brought into the government adequately
column4: Sunni forces haven't been adequately trained and integrated into the military.

column1: Until those changes are made
column2: until Iraq makes the political decision to fully incorporate the Sunnis we can add more forces we can win these battles but they're not going to stay won. I think that's the real lesson of the last Iraq War and what's going on now
column3: he said.

column1: He warned that sending in a lot of American troops could ""aggravate"" the threat that ISIS already poses and risk further escalation of the fight.
McCain
column2: for his part
column3: argues that President Obama never should have pulled troops out of the country entirely in 2011 because the 2007 troop surge had succeeded.

column1: George W. Bush at least had the guts to reverse and sponsor the surge which...eventually then succeeded. I wish
column2: I pray that Barack Obama would do the same thing
column3: he said.

column1: For now
column2: Schiff said there is an ""ebb and flow and a largely stalemated situation in the war against ISIS."" He said he is concerned that the administration appears to be measuring success by the number of bombing runs it is able to carry out in the region.

column1: I think the more important metrics are how are doing in stopping foreign fighters from entering the country
column2: how are we doing in drying up ISIS' resources
column3: how are we doing in working with our gulf allies in fighting the ideological fight within Islam that we're not positioned to fight ourselves
column4: and how are we doing in terms of our military support
column5: he said."	0

column1: LetÃ¢ÂÂs review the story so far.
Two weeks ago

column1: 46	"'This Week' Transcript: Former Vice President Dick Cheney
Transcript: ""This Week"" with Former Vice President Dick Cheney and George Will
column2: Peter Beinart
column3: Paul Gigot and Jane Mayer.

column1: KARL: Good morning
column2: and welcome to ""This Week.""

column1: CHENEY: There is no middle ground.
KARL: This morning
column2: a ""This Week"" exclusive
column3: former Vice President Dick Cheney
column4: the administration's harshest critic...

column1: CHENEY: The president's been largely silent. Half-measures keep you half-exposed. The White House must stop dithering.
KARL: ... with no apologies of his own.
CHENEY: I was and remain a strong proponent of our enhanced interrogation program.
KARL: National security
column2: Iran
column3: politics
column4: and...

column1: BIDEN: Iraq
column2: I mean
column3: it's going to be one of the great achievements of this administration.

column1: KARL: ... Dick Cheney takes on the current vice president
column2: only on ""This Week."" Then
column3: a Washington thaw.

column1: OBAMA: I'm going to spend some time listening.
KARL: But can bipartisanship survive the politics of the moment?
PALIN: We need a commander-in-chief
column2: not a professor of law standing at the lectern.

column1: KARL: That and the rest of the week's politics on our roundtable with George Will
column2: Peter Beinart of the Council on Foreign Relations
column3: the New Yorker's Jane Mayer
column4: and Paul Gigot of the Wall Street Journal.

column1: And as always
column2: the Sunday funnies.

column1: LETTERMAN: John McCain knew that it was Sarah Palin's birthday
column2: and he did something very nice for her. He bought her a Toyota.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
ANNOUNCER: From the heart of the nation's capital
column2: ""This Week"" with ABC's congressional correspondent
column3: Jonathan Karl
column4: live from the Newseum on Pennsylvania Avenue.

column1: KARL: Joining me now
column2: former Vice President Dick Cheney.

column1: Mr. Vice President
column2: welcome to ""This Week.""

column1: CHENEY: Good morning
column2: John.

column1: KARL: Now
column2: you have been unflinching in your criticism of this administration's handling of terrorism
column3: counterterrorism. Most recently
column4: talking about the Christmas Day bomber
column5: you said
column6: ""It is clear once again that President Obama is trying to pretend that we are not at war."" Now
column7: this morning
column8: we have heard from the current vice president
column9: Joe Biden
column10: directly in response to that. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

column1: BIDEN: We're pursuing that war with a vigor like it's never been seen before. We've eliminated 12 of their top 20 people. We have taken out 100 of their associates. We are making -- we've sent them underground. They are
column2: in fact
column3: not able to do anything remotely like they were in the past. They are on the run. I don't know where Dick Cheney has been.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
KARL: Your response?
CHENEY: Well
column2: my reference to the notion that the president was trying to avoid treating this as a war was in relation to his initial response when we heard about the Christmas underwear bomber...

column1: KARL: Right.
CHENEY: ... up in Detroit
column2: when he went out and said this was the act of an isolated extremist. No
column3: it wasn't. And we found out over time
column4: obviously -- and he eventually changed his -- his assessment -- but that
column5: in fact
column6: this was an individual who'd been trained by Al Qaida
column7: who'd been part of a larger conspiracy
column8: and it was closer to being an act of war than it was the act of an isolated extremist.

column1: It's the mindset that concerns me
column2: John. I think it's -- it's very important to go back and keep in mind the distinction between handling these events as criminal acts
column3: which was the way we did before 9/11
column4: and then looking at 9/11 and saying
column5: ""This is not a criminal act
column6: not when you destroy 16 acres of Manhattan
column7: kill 3
column8: 000 Americans
column9: blow a big hole in the Pentagon. That's an act of war.

column1: KARL: Well -- well...
CHENEY: And what the administration was slow to do was to come to that -- that recognition that we are at war
column2: not dealing with criminal acts. And as I say
column3: my response there dealt specifically to the fact the president called it an isolated extremist. It was not.

column1: KARL: Well
column2: I want to get to that notion of treating this as a law enforcement action
column3: but what the administration will say is
column4: look at what they have done
column6: 000 additional troops to Afghanistan
column7: doubling
column8: tripling
column9: and maybe even more the drone attacks on the tribal areas in Pakistan on Al Qaida targets. They say that they are actually dedicating more resources to the fight against Al Qaida than you were.

column1: CHENEY: Well
column2: I -- you know
column3: I'm a complete supporter of what they're doing in Afghanistan. I think the president made the right decision to send troops into Afghanistan. I thought it took him a while to get there.

column1: Having Stan McChrystal now in charge in Afghanistan I think is an excellent choice. General McChrystal's one of the most able officers I know. I'm glad they're doing what they're doing in Afghanistan. I'm not a critic of what they're doing
column2: in terms of how they're dealing with that situation.

column1: But I do see repeatedly examples that there are key members in the administration
column2: like Eric Holder
column3: for example
column4: the attorney general
column5: who still insists on thinking of terror attacks against the United States as criminal acts as opposed to acts of war
column6: and that's a -- that's a huge distinction.

column1: KARL: OK
column2: before we get to Eric Holder
column3: a couple more things from the vice president. He's been out responding preemptively to you. One thing he said we heard in the open
column4: that he believes Iraq may ultimately prove to be one of the greatest achievements of the Obama administration.

column1: CHENEY: Well
column2: I -- I guess I shouldn't be surprised by my friend
column3: Joe Biden. I'm glad he now believes Iraq is a success. Of course
column4: Obiden and -- Obama and Biden campaigned from one end of the country to the other for two years criticizing our Iraq policy.

column1: CHENEY: They opposed the surge that was absolutely crucial to our getting to the point we're at now with respect to Iraq. And for them to try to take credit for what's happened in Iraq strikes me as a little strange. I think if -- if they had had their way
column2: if we'd followed the policies they'd pursued from the outset or advocated from the outset
column3: Saddam Hussein would still be in power in Baghdad today.

column1: So if they're going to take credit for it
column2: fair enough
column3: for what they've done while they're there
column4: but it ought to go with a healthy dose of ""Thank you
column5: George Bush"" up front and a recognition that some of their early recommendations
column6: with respect to prosecuting that war
column7: we're just dead wrong.

column1: KARL: Well
column2: in fact
column3: Vice President Biden says that he believes that the war in Iraq was not worth it. What do you say to that? I mean
column4: given the resources that were drawn away from the -- what you could argue is the central front in Afghanistan
column5: Pakistan
column6: is he right about that?

column1: CHENEY: No. I -- I believe very deeply in the proposition that what we did in Iraq was the right thing to do. It was hard to do. It took a long time. There were significant costs involved.
But we got rid of one of the worst dictators of the 20th century. We took down his government
column2: a man who'd produced and used weapons of mass destruction
column3: a man who'd started two different wars
column4: a man who had a relationship with terror. We're going to have a democracy in Iraq today. We do today. They're going to have another free election this March.

column1: This has been an enormous achievement from the standpoint of peace and stability in the Middle East and ending a threat to the United States. Now
column2: as I say
column3: Joe Biden doesn't believe that. Joe Biden wants to take credit -- I'm not sure for what -- since he opposed that policy pretty much from the outset.

column1: KARL: I think what he wants to take credit for is taking resources out of Iraq
column2: the fact...

column1: CHENEY: That's being done in accordance with a timetable that we initiated
column2: that we -- that we negotiated with -- with the Iraqis. I mean
column3: that was our policy.

column1: KARL: Another thing from the vice president
column2: he also addressed the possibility of another 9/11-style attack.

column1: (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
BIDEN: The idea of there being a massive attack in the United States like 9/11 is unlikely
column2: in my view. But if you see what's happening
column3: particularly with Al Qaida in the Arabian Peninsula
column4: they have decided to move in a direction of much more small-bore
column5: but devastatingly frightening attacks.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
KARL: Is he right?
CHENEY: I don't think so. And I would point to a study that was released just within the last week or two up at the Kennedy School at Harvard by a gentleman -- Mowatt-Larssen's his name
column2: I believe. He was CIA for 23 years
column3: director of intelligence at the Energy Department for a long time
column4: that looks at this whole question of weapons of mass destruction and Al Qaida and comes to the conclusion that there's a very high threat that Al Qaida is trying very hard to acquire a weapon of mass destruction and
column5: if they're successful in acquiring it
column6: that they will use it.

column1: I think he's right. I think
column2: in fact
column3: the situation with respect to Al Qaida to say that
column4: you know
column5: that was a big attack we had on 9/11
column6: but it's not likely again
column7: I just think that's dead wrong. I think the biggest strategic threat the United States faces today is the possibility of another 9/11 with a nuclear weapon or a biological agent of some kind
column8: and I think Al Qaida is out there even as we meet trying to figure out how to do that.

column1: KARL: And do you think that the Obama administration is taking enough serious steps to prevent that?
CHENEY: I think they need to do everything they can to prevent it. And if the mindset is it's not likely
column2: then it's difficult to mobilize the resources and get people to give it the kind of priority that it deserves.

column1: KARL: OK
column2: let's get to -- you mentioned Eric Holder
column3: the treatment of the Christmas Day underwear bomber. How do you think that case should have been dealt with?

column1: CHENEY: I think the -- the proper way to -- to deal with it would have been to treat him as an enemy combatant. I think that was the right way to go.
The thing I learned from watching that process unfold
column2: though
column3: was that the administration really wasn't equipped to deal with the aftermath of an attempted attack against the United States in the sense that they didn't know what to do with the guy.

column1: There was talk earlier after they'd dismantled the system we'd put in place for prisoner interrogation of high-value detainees. They'd gone out supposedly to create the HIG
column2: high-value interrogation program
column3: but in reality
column4: it was not up and running at Christmastime when it should have been. It started months before that
column5: to put that in place. They need a process
column6: a set of institutions that they can fall back on. Admittedly
column7: this is hard. We had a hard time dealing with this. You've got the Supreme Court on one side that -- that is going to evaluate everything you do
column8: and you've got to be careful with that. The Congress gets involved in it.

column1: CHENEY: So I'm not saying it's an easy task
column2: but by this point
column3: when they've made all the decisions they've had
column4: closed Guantanamo
column5: end (ph) the high-value detainee program and so forth
column6: I think those are all mistakes. Those were the tools we put in place to deal with this kind of situation. They should have had something to put in lieu of those programs
column7: and it would look like they do not have -- have that kind of capability yet.

column1: KARL: If you have somebody in custody like Abdulmutallab
column2: after just trying to blow up an airliner
column3: and you think he has information on another attack
column4: I mean
column5: do you think that those enhanced interrogation techniques should have been -- should have been used? I mean
column6: would you -- do you think that he should have been
column7: for instance
column8: subject to everything
column9: including waterboarding?

column1: CHENEY: Well
column2: I think the -- the professionals need to make that judgment. We've got people in -- we had in our administration -- I'm sure they're still there -- many of them were career personnel -- who are expects in this subject. And they are the ones that you ought to turn somebody like Abdulmutallab over to
column3: let them be the judge of whether or not he's prepared to cooperate and how they can best achieve his cooperation.

column1: KARL: But you believe they should have had the option of everything up to and including waterboarding?
CHENEY: I think you ought to have all of those capabilities on the table. Now
column2: President Obama has taken them off the table. He announced when he came in last year that they would never use anything other than the U.S. Army manual
column3: which doesn't include those techniques. I think that's a mistake.

column1: KARL: OK. So -- so was it a mistake when your administration took on the Richard Reid case? This is very similar. This was somebody that was trying to blow up an airliner with a shoe bomb
column2: and he was within five minutes of getting taken off that plane read his Miranda rights
column3: four times
column4: in fact
column5: in 48 hours
column6: and tried through the civilian system. Was that a mistake?

column1: CHENEY: Well
column2: first of all
column3: I believe he was not tried. He pled guilty. They never did end up having a trial.

column1: Secondly
column2: when this came up
column3: as I recall
column4: it was December of '01
column5: just a couple of months after 9/11. We were not yet operational with the military commissions. We hadn't had all the Supreme Court decisions handed down about what we could and couldn't do with the commissions.

column1: KARL: But you still had an option to put him into military custody.
CHENEY: Well
column2: we could have put him into military custody. I don't -- I don't question that. The point is
column3: in this particular case
column4: all of that was never worked out
column5: primarily because he pled guilty.

column1: KARL: Now
column2: I'd like to read you something that the sentencing judge reading the -- giving him his life sentence read to Richard Reid at the time of that sentencing. Here it is. He said to Reid
column3: ""You are not an enemy combatant. You are a terrorist. You are not a soldier in any war. To give you that reference
column4: to call you a soldier gives you far too much stature. We do not negotiate with terrorists. We hunt them down one by one and bring them to justice.""

column1: The judge in that case was a Reagan appointee. Doesn't he make a good point?
CHENEY: Well
column2: I don't think so
column3: in a sense that it -- if it -- if you interpret that as taking you to the point where all of these people are going to be treated as though they're guilty of individual criminal acts.

column1: I want to come back again to the basic point I tried to make at the outset
column2: John. And up until 9/11
column3: all terrorist attacks were criminal acts. After 9/11
column4: we made the decision that these were acts of war
column5: these were strategic threats to the United States.

column1: Once you make that judgment
column2: then you can use a much broader range of tools
column3: in terms of going after your adversary. You go after those who provide them safe harbor and sanctuary. You go after those who finance and those who provide weapons for them and those who train them. And you treat them as unlawful enemy combatants.

column1: There's a huge distinction here in terms of the kinds of policies you put in place going forward. And what I'm most concerned about isn't so much argument about all the stuff in the past
column2: about what happened to Abdulmutallab or Richard Reid. I think the relevant point is: What are the policies going to be going forward?

column1: And if you're really serious and you believe this is a war and if you believe the greatest threat is a 9/11 with nukes or a 9/11 with a biological agent of some kind
column2: then you have to consider it as a war
column3: you have to consider it as something we may have to deal with tomorrow. You don't want the vice president of the United States running around saying
column4: ""Oh
column5: it's not likely to happen.""

column1: KARL: Now
column2: on that question of trying
column3: you know
column4: dealing as enemy combatants or through the criminal justice system
column5: I came across this. This is a document that was put out by the Bush Justice Department under Attorney General Ashcroft...

column1: CHENEY: Right.
KARL: ... covering the years 2001 to 2005. And if you go right to page one
column2: they actually tout the criminal prosecutions...

column1: CHENEY: They did.
KARL: ... of terror suspects
column2: saying
column3: ""Altogether
column4: the department has brought charges against 375 individuals in terrorism- related investigations and has convicted 195 to date."" That was 2005. Again
column5: seems to make the administration's point that they're not doing it all that differently from how you were doing it.

column1: CHENEY: Well
column2: we didn't all agree with that. We had -- I can remember a meeting in the Roosevelt Room in the West Wing of the White House where we had a major shootout over how this was going to be handled between the Justice Department
column3: that advocated that approach
column4: and many of the rest of us
column5: who wanted to treat it as an intelligence matter
column6: as an act of war with military commissions.

column1: We never clearly or totally resolved those issues. These are tough questions
column2: no doubt about it. You want my opinion
column3: my view of what ought to happen
column4: I think we have to treat it as a -- as a war. This is a strategic threat to the United States. I think that's why we were successful for seven-and-a-half years in avoiding a further major attack against the United States.

column1: And I do get very nervous and very upset when that's the dominant approach
column2: as it was sometimes in the Bush administration or certainly would appear to be at times in the new Obama administration.

column1: KARL: Did you more often win or lose those battles
column2: especially as you got to the second term?

column1: CHENEY: Well
column2: I suppose it depends on which battle you're talking about. I won some; I lost some. I can't...

column1: (CROSSTALK)
KARL: ... waterboarding
column2: clearly
column3: what was your...

column1: CHENEY: I was a big supporter of waterboarding. I was a big supporter of the enhanced interrogation techniques that...
KARL: And you opposed the administration's actions of doing away with waterboarding?
CHENEY: Yes.
KARL: I'd like to ask you about the big terror case now
column2: which is the KSM trial. The administration very much wants to see the mastermind of 9/11 tried in civilian courts here in the United States. New York has obviously objected.

column1: Do you think that's going to happen? Do you think this will be a civilian trial? Or are they not going to be able to do it?
CHENEY: It looks to me like they're going to have great difficulty doing it in New York. I mean
column2: even the mayor's come out against it now. I think trying Khalid Sheikh Mohammed in New York's a big -- big mistake. It gives him a huge platform to promulgate his -- his particular brand of propaganda around the world.

column1: I think he ought to be at Guantanamo. I think he ought to be tried at Guantanamo in front of a military commission. They've got difficulties now
column2: because my guess is they don't want to send him back to Guantanamo
column3: because that would validate
column4: if you will
column5: the value of Guantanamo. They're trying to close it
column6: clearly haven't been able to get it done.

column1: But my guess is
column2: in the end
column3: he'll end up being tried in front of a military commission on a military facility some place.

column1: KARL: So you think Guantanamo will be open when this president leaves office?

CHENEY: I wouldn't be surprised. It's a valuable facility. There's a reason why we set it up. It makes good sense. There's obviously great reluctance on Capitol Hill to appropriate the funds to close it down. I think -- I think Guantanamo is going to be there for quite a while.
KARL: And one other point -- I just want to read also from a previous interview that you gave -- one of your points about Guantanamo is
column2: if you release the hard-core Al Qaida terrorists
column3: you said
column4: that are held at Guantanamo
column5: I think they go back into the business of trying to kill more Americans and mount further mass casualty attacks. If you turn them loose and they go kill more Americans
column6: who's responsible for that?

column1: And it's a real concern. We've heard from the president's homeland security adviser
column2: John Brennan
column3: saying that at minimum 10 percent of the more than 500 that have been released from Guantanamo have gone back into the fight.

column1: But Brennan also wrote this. He said
column2: ""I want to underscore the fact that all of these cases relate to detainees released during the previous administration and under the prior detainee review process.""

column1: In other words
column2: all of those released from Guantanamo that have gone back into the fight were released by your administration. Can't you make the case that the Obama administration has actually been more responsible about releasing who they release from Guantanamo?

column1: CHENEY: I wouldn't make that -- I wouldn't make that case
column2: John. I think -- as I recall
column3: the percentage that we had of the recidivists was 12 percent. And we released prisoners back basically to their home countries
column4: partly because the State Department was under enormous pressure to do so
column5: and there was an effort to try to return them. The Saudis had a rehabilitation program for returned Saudis
column6: and...

column1: KARL: Did you oppose those releases?
CHENEY: I did. I didn't think that releasing anybody was the right thing to do
column2: unless you had evidence that
column3: you know
column4: there was a mistake of some kind or they'd been -- been before a commission and you'd reviewed their case and found that the case didn't stand up
column5: and that was usually the case. They were put through a thorough scrub before they were released.

column1: Obviously
column2: some of them got through the filter. But I think
column3: out of the ones that remain
column4: those are the real hard core
column5: and I think your recidivist rate would be far higher than it was on those that have already been released.

column1: It's a tough problem; I'll be the first to admit it. But I think you have to have a facility like Guantanamo to hold these individuals who are members of Al Qaida
column2: who've tried to kill Americans
column3: and who -- when they're released
column4: they'll go back out and try to kill Americans again.

column1: KARL: I'd like to move to Iran. Do you trust the Obama administration to do what is necessary to keep Iran from getting nuclear weapons?
CHENEY: I remain to be persuaded.
KARL: Do you think that sanctions can work? I mean
column2: that's the track they've chosen.

column1: CHENEY: Well
column2: I think -- I hope sanctions work.

column1: KARL: It's the same track you chose (ph).
CHENEY: We -- I certainly would hope sanctions would work
column2: but I think they're most likely to work if you keep the military option on the table. I don't think you want to eliminate the military -- the possibility of military action. I think that's essential to give any kind of meaning at all to negotiations over sanctions.

column1: KARL: How close did you come -- how close did the Bush administration come to taking military action against Iran?
CHENEY: Well
column2: I would -- some of that I can't talk about
column3: obviously
column4: still. I'm sure it's still classified. We clearly never made the decision -- we never crossed over that line of saying
column5: ""Now we're going to mount a military operation to deal with the problem.""

column1: The president was always hopeful -- and I think everybody else was
column2: too -- that we could find a way to deal with it within having to resort to military force. One of the problems that the Obama administration inherited was the Iranian problem
column3: and it's a tough one.

column1: KARL: David Sanger of the New York Times says that the Israelis came to you -- came to the administration in the final months and asked for certain things
column2: bunker-buster bombs
column3: air-to-air refueling capability
column4: overflight rights
column5: and that basically the administration dithered
column6: did not give the Israelis a response. Was that a mistake?

column1: CHENEY: I -- I can't get into it still. I'm sure a lot of those discussions are still very sensitive.
KARL: Let me ask you: Did you advocate a harder line
column2: including in the military area
column3: in those -- in those final months?

column1: CHENEY: Usually.
KARL: And with respect to Iran?
CHENEY: Well
column2: I -- I made public statements to the effect that I felt very strongly that we had to have the military option
column3: that it had to be on the table
column4: that it had to be a meaningful option
column5: and that we might well have to resort to military force in order to deal with the threat that Iran represented. The problem here being that a nuclear-armed Iran is a huge threat to that entire part of the world and
column6: indeed
column7: to the United States.

column1: KARL: Was it -- was it a...
CHENEY: We never got to the point where the president had to make a decision one way or the other.
KARL: Was that a mistake? Was it a mistake to leave that nuclear capability intact?
CHENEY: Well
column2: we -- we did a lot
column3: because we were very concerned about nuclear capability in the hands of rogue states or potentially shared with terrorist organizations
column4: and we were successful in taking down
column5: for example
column6: Saddam Hussein
column7: who had messed with nuclear weapons twice previously
column8: taking down the A.Q. Khan network
column9: a black-market operation that was providing technology to the North Koreans
column10: Iranians
column11: and Libyans. We successfully obtained all the Libyan materials for their nuclear program
column12: so we got a lot done.

column1: We didn't get everything done. We still -- when we finished
column2: there still was the ongoing Iranian problem and the ongoing North Korean problem. Both of them remain to be addressed.

column1: KARL: I'd like to get your response to Sarah Palin's recent comments on Iran.
(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
PALIN: Say he decided to declare war on Iran or decided really to come out and do whatever he could to support Israel
column2: which I would like him to do
column3: if he decided to toughen up and do all that he can to secure our nation and our allies
column4: I think people would perhaps shift their thinking a little bit and decide
column5: well
column6: maybe he's tougher than we think he -- than he is today.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
KARL: She's
column2: of course
column3: talking about President Obama
column4: seemed to be implying that this would be a good political move for him. What's your take?

column1: CHENEY: I don't think a president can make a judgment like that on the basis of politics. The stakes are too high
column2: the consequences too significant to be treating those as simple political calculations. When you begin to talk about war
column3: talk about crossing international borders
column4: you talk about committing American men and women to combat
column5: that takes place on a plane clear above any political consideration.

column1: KARL: So...
CHENEY: So I'd be -- I'd be very cautious about treating that kind of issue on those kinds of conditions.
KARL: We're almost out of time. We're going to get you very quickly on a few other subjects. First of all
column2: one more on Palin. Is she qualified to be president?

column1: CHENEY: I haven't made a decision yet on who I'm going to support for president the next time around. Whoever it is
column2: is going to have to prove themselves capable of being president of the United States. And those tests will -- will come during the course of campaigns
column3: obviously. I think -- well
column4: I think all the prospective candidates out there have got a lot of work to do if
column5: in fact
column6: they're going to persuade a majority of Americans that they're ready to take on the world's toughest job.

column1: KARL: OK
column2: ""don't ask/don't tell"" -- you're a former defense secretary -- should this policy be repealed?

column1: CHENEY: Twenty years ago
column2: the military were strong advocates of ""don't ask/don't tell
column3: when I was secretary of defense. I think things have changed significantly since then. I see that Don Mullen -- or Mike Mullen
column4: the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff
column5: has indicated his belief that we ought to support a change in the policy. So I think -- my guess is the policy will be changed.

column1: KARL: And do you think that's a good thing? I mean
column2: is it time to allow gays and lesbians to serve openly in the military?

column1: CHENEY: I think the society has moved on. I think it's partly a generational question. I say
column2: I'm reluctant to second-guess the military in this regard
column3: because they're the ones that have got to make the judgment about how these policies affect the military capability of our -- of our units
column4: and that first requirement that you have to look at all the time is whether or not they're still capable of achieving their mission
column5: and does the policy change
column6: i.e.
column7: putting gays in the force
column8: affect their ability to perform their mission?

column1: When the chiefs come forward and say
column2: ""We think we can do it
column3: then it strikes me that it's -- it's time to reconsider the policy. And I think Admiral Mullen said that.

column1: KARL: And
column2: finally
column3: I know that you have a reunion coming up later this month with President Bush. This'll be the first time you've seen him since leaving office
column4: face to face?

column1: CHENEY: Pretty much
column2: yes. We talk on the telephone periodically
column3: but the first time I've seen him since January 20th.

column1: KARL: What does he think of you being so outspoken in contrast to him?
CHENEY: Well
column2: I don't think he's opposed to it
column3: by any means. I'd be inclined to let him speak for himself about it. The reason I've been outspoken is because there were some things being said
column4: especially after we left office
column5: about prosecuting CIA personnel that had carried out our counterterrorism policy or disbarring lawyers in the Justice Department who had -- had helped us put those policies together
column6: and I was deeply offended by that
column7: and I thought it was important that some senior person in the administration stand up and defend those people who'd done what we asked them to do.

column1: And that's why I got started on it. I'm the vice president now -- ex-vice president. I have the great freedom and luxury of speaking out
column2: saying what I -- what I want to say
column3: what I believe. And I have not been discouraged from doing so.

column1: KARL: And that includes writing a book?
CHENEY: Writing a book
column2: that's correct.

column1: KARL: Can you give us -- before you go -- a quick nugget that's going to be in the book
column2: give us the title
column3: give us something going?

column1: CHENEY: Have me back about a year from now
column2: and I'll have a copy of the book for you
column3: John.

column1: KARL: OK
column2: it's deal.

column1: CHENEY: All right.
KARL: Mr. Vice President
column2: thanks a lot for joining us on ""This Week.""

column1: CHENEY: Good to see you. I've enjoyed it.
KARL: The roundtable is next
column2: George Will
column3: Paul Gigot
column4: Jane Mayer
column5: and Peter Beinart. And later
column6: the Sunday funnies."	0

column1: 47	"SEARCH keyword:
Writers May Have Pact. Huckabee Crosses Picket LineÃ¢ÂÂAgain
by Mike Hall
column2: Feb 8

column1: Television and movie writers who have been on strike since Nov. 5 will meet tomorrow in New York City and Los Angeles to discuss a potential tentative agreement that could end the strike. The Writers Guild of America members have been fighting to win a fair share of revenue for their work distributed online
column2: through DVDs and other new media.

column1: Also on the strike front
column2: Republican presidential candidate and former Gov. Mike Huckabee (Ark.) crossed another picket line (See below.).

column1: Officials of the Writers Guild of America
column2: East ( WGAE)
column3: Writers Guild of America
column4: West (WGAW) and the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers (AMPTP) have been meeting informally since Jan. 24
column5: the first meetings between the two sides since the producers walked out of negotiations in December.

column1: In a letter to their members posted on both unionsÃ¢ÂÂ websites today
column2: WGAE President Michael Winship and WGAW President Patric Verrone say:

column1: We are continuing to negotiate the terms of a tentative agreement with the AMPTP. We anticipate that we will be able to present the terms of that agreement to you in the next few days. In order to have a full discussion with you of the terms and how they were reached
column2: and in order to get your input before making recommendations or decisions
column3: we have scheduled membership meetings for current-active members only for this Sat.
column4: February 9
column5: in New York and Los Angeles.

column1: We urge you to attend. We have gotten to this point in our negotiation as the direct result of the power of this strike
column2: which each of you has generated. Neither the Negotiating Committee
column3: nor the East Council or the West Board
column4: will take action on any contract until after the membership meetings are held and your voices have been heard. We are all in this together.

column1: This afternoon
column2: several hundred writers rallied and marched at the Time Warner Center in New York City. Both sides have agreed to a news blackout so details of the possible tentative agreement are not available.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: Writers Guild members met Huckabee with angry resistance last night as he crossed a picket line to be a guest on Ã¢ÂÂThe Colbert Report.Ã¢ÂÂ This is how the WGAE website describes the episode:

column1: As his black SUV arrived outside the set
column2: 20 or so picketers swarmed in close
column3: shouting things such as Ã¢ÂÂDonÃ¢ÂÂt cross Governor!Ã¢ÂÂ and Ã¢ÂÂThis is a struck show!Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: As Mr. HuckabeeÃ¢ÂÂs security team led him toward the guest entrance WGA members persisted in their attempt to persuade him not to cross
column2: shouting and holding up signs that read Ã¢ÂÂHuckabee DonÃ¢ÂÂt Cross (Again)Ã¢ÂÂ & Ã¢ÂÂHuckabee Supports Scabs.Ã¢ÂÂ This strong union action was captured on film by reporters from CNN and NBC
column3: who were there on the scene to record his appearance. Mr. Huckabee gained notoriety by being the first guest for Jay Leno the night the TV host returned to work without his writers on January 3rd.

column1: On Jan. 30
column2: Republican front-runner Sen. John McCain (Ariz.) crossed a writersÃ¢ÂÂ picket line to appear on the Leno show.

48	"Following the recent resignation of Director of the Office of Government Ethics Walter Shaub Jr.
column2: the Trump Administration has unexpectedly accepted another resignation: White House Chef Lisa Mead.

column1: Mead reportedly decided to resign because President Donald Trump hasnÃ¢ÂÂt utilized her culinary talents even once the entire time he has been living in the White House.
Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs kind of crazy because Lisa is such a good chef
column2: Ã¢ÂÂ said Kurt Reno
column3: the White House aide who recommended Ms. Mead for the job. Ã¢ÂÂBut Lisa feels insulted because the President has ordered fast food for literally every single meal heÃ¢ÂÂs eaten in D.C. The only food-related duty Lisa has done for the past six months is retrieve TrumpÃ¢ÂÂs orders from drive-through windows and scoop the PresidentÃ¢ÂÂs ice cream from the carton.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: Mr. TrumpÃ¢ÂÂs favorite fast food choices are reportedly Kentucky Fried Chicken and McDonalds
column2: and he eats his fried chicken
column3: burgers
column4: and fries with a knife and fork according to a White House staffer who requested anonymity to avoid consequences from leaking about the PresidentÃ¢ÂÂs eating habits to the press.

column1: Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs borderline creepy
column2: Ã¢ÂÂ the staffer said. Ã¢ÂÂThe first thing Trump does with his fried chicken is pick off all the skin from every piece like heÃ¢ÂÂs dissecting the chickens with a scalpel or something
column3: and then he puts it all in a pile. Then he cuts off all the lean meat and throws it away
column4: leaving just the pieces of fat which he then eats individually with pieces of the crispy skin he peeled off. ItÃ¢ÂÂs gotta be a warning sign of a serial killer or something.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: Mr. TrumpÃ¢ÂÂs McDonalds habits are even weirder.
Ã¢ÂÂHe orders the same thing every time
column2: Ã¢ÂÂ said the staffer. Ã¢ÂÂHe orders two big macs
column3: a large fry
column4: a diet coke of course
column5: and an M&M McFlurry that he has Lisa dig out and remove every brown M&M
column6: and then he makes her dump out half of the ice cream and fill it back up with extra M&MÃ¢ÂÂs. Then he cuts off pieces of his big macs and dips them in the McFlurry so every bite has ice cream and chocolate on it. He dips his fries
column7: still with a fork
column8: in the diet coke as if it were a condiment. The sight of this never gets normal. When Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe saw this routine he threw up.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: No wonder Chef Lisa Mead quit. The Halfway Post wishes her good luck on her future endeavors.
(Photo courtesy of Shelby Bell.)"	1

This amount of corruption is a next level thing that we havenÃ¢ÂÂt seen portrayed this nonchalantly before. Namely
