column1: 51	"A dangerous sentiment on the left threatens to derail what could be the biggest progressive achievement in half a century. It's the view that any health-care reform that doesn't include a public option isn't ""real"" reform and thus isn't worth doing. This mantra has become an article of faith among many Democrats who haven't necessarily thought through the matter but who take their cues from leaders advancing this argument. Unless liberals rethink this premise
column2: and fast
column3: Democrats will squander their best chance in a generation to end the scandal of the uninsured
column4: bring health security to every American family and begin the long-term process of getting national health costs under control.

column1: The first fallacy of the ""public option or nothing"" mantra is the notion that we'll never cover everyone without a Medicare-style program for Americans under 65. The experiences of Switzerland and the Netherlands prove that this isn't the case. Both have pioneered market-based universal health care. Both cover all their citizens using private insurers
column2: and they do so for much less cost -- 10 percent of gross domestic product for the Dutch and 12 percent for Switzerland
column3: compared with 17 percent in the United States
column4: where nearly 50 million people are still uninsured.

column1: Those countries also boast better health outcomes than we do
column2: even when compared to states with similar demographics
column3: such as Connecticut and Massachusetts. Sick people in both countries are pursued as customers by private insurers (rather than shunned
column4: as they are in the United States) because health plans are paid more for sick enrollees via a government-designed system of ""risk adjustment."" The Swiss and Dutch achievements are important because conservative critics often act as though fully socialized systems
column5: such as those in Britain and Canada
column6: are the inevitable result of any drive for universal coverage. In fact
column7: as these two countries show
column8: it is possible to cover everyone without a ""big government takeover.""

column1: A related fallacy is that the public option is the most important issue to debate. It's not. The central progressive breakthrough in any reform should be to make it possible for every American to access group health coverage outside the employment setting -- access that does not currently exist but which the proposed insurance exchanges would enable. What's critical
column2: therefore
column3: is the structure of these exchanges and the rules about who would be eligible to use them. Such questions have received disturbingly little attention but need to be front and center. For example
column4: some legislation proposes barring people who enjoy employer-based coverage from seeking insurance from the new exchanges; this ban should be scrapped in favor of the proposal offered by Sen. Ron Wyden
column5: under which employees could use the cash their companies spend on their benefits to buy coverage they prefer at the exchange.

column1: I respect those in my party who seek the single-payer system into which the public option might eventually evolve. But I don't agree that it's the best answer for the United States. Though single payer has merits
column2: especially in administrative efficiency
column3: it is also likely to freeze in place our fragmented
column4: uncoordinated system of fee-for-service care. It would encourage providers to goose volume (to boost their incomes) rather than improve quality and would offer greater rewards for providers of acute care when we need a fresh focus on chronic disease management. Single payer also asks government to do things I don't think it is competent to do
column5: such as setting prices across a large swath of the health sector in ways that seem certain to create damaging rigidities or resource misallocations (as happens in Medicare).

column1: Finally
column2: if government is the sole payer
column3: provider payments will become even more politicized than they are today. On the eve of beneficial innovations in drug therapies
column4: devices and cost-effective ways to deliver better care
column5: it is ill-advised to make the government's hand too rigid. Private health plans have many flaws
column6: to be sure
column7: but if sensibly regulated they're likely to respond more nimbly to disperse medical innovations.

column1: Liberals should make peace with the notion that a regulated market of competing private health plans can be the vehicle for getting everyone covered. Yes
column2: it means that unlike some other advanced countries
column3: we'll have billions of ""health"" dollars siphoned off by middlemen and marketers. But if liberals think of it as a jobs program
column4: they'll learn to love it. If everyone's covered and insurer ""cherry-picking"" is dead
column5: health insurance will come to look more like a regulated utility.

column1: Those on the left still seeking incentive should consider: In 2006
column2: Sen. Ted Kennedy urged Massachusetts Democrats to support Mitt Romney's plan for universal coverage via a competing system of regulated private insurers
column3: paired with an individual mandate and subsidies for low earners. Kennedy knew this would become a model for a bipartisan fix for the country. Now
column4: a Kennedy-approved model is within reach. Liberals
column5: far from resisting it as a setback
column6: should celebrate it as a triumph.

column1: Matt Miller
column2: a former Clinton White House aide
column3: is a management consultant and the author of ""The Tyranny of Dead Ideas."" In recent years he has advised and given paid speeches to doctor groups
column4: hospitals
column5: pharmaceutical firms and insurance companies
column6: as well as to low-income advocacy groups promoting universal coverage."	0

ANNOUNCER: From the heart of the nation's capital
column2: ""This Week"" with ABC's senior White House correspondent
column3: Jake Tapper
column4: live from the Newseum on Pennsylvania Avenue.

column1: TAPPER: And joining me now is House Majority Leader Steny Hoyer and House Minority Leader John Boehner. Gentlemen
column2: thanks so much for joining me.

column1: HOYER: Thank you.
BOEHNER: Hey
column2: good morning.

column1: TAPPER: So you got a letter last night -- I actually think I got it before you guys did...
HOYER: I think you did.
TAPPER: ... but from President Obama requesting $50 billion in emergency spending for state and local governments. Leader Hoyer
column2: you have said that there is spending fatigue on Capitol Hill. Can you get this passed?

column1: HOYER: Well
column2: I think it's accurate that there's spending fatigue
column3: not only on Capitol Hill
column4: but around the country. People are concerned about the debt level
column5: and we are
column6: as well. But clearly
column7: you cannot not continue to stimulate an economy that is still struggling to get out of the deep ditch that we found it in about 18 months ago.

column1: What the president is saying is
column2: we need to expend additional dollars to make sure that we don't have significant layoffs in the next few months
column3: which will again depress the economy
column4: so that -- I understand what he's saying. I have asked the White House to look at the package that we -- the Recovery and Reinvestment Act that we passed
column5: approximately $800-plus billion. There are clearly funds in there that have not been expended to see whether or not there are some available for this more immediate priority than some that may not be quite as immediate.

column1: TAPPER: Leader Boehner
column2: the president said in his letter that if this does not pass
column3: the economy -- there's a risk that the economy will slide back into recession. Do you agree?

column1: BOEHNER: Listen
column2: I'm concerned about the plight of teachers
column3: firemen
column4: policemen who face the real possibility that they may be laid off
column5: but to send this letter up here on a Saturday night with no opportunity to cut spending elsewhere in the budget strikes me as a little different. Steny and I and other leaders were at the White House on Thursday
column6: and this subject never came up.

column1: There was no indication this was going to happen. And I'm asking myself
column2: why is this happening on Saturday night?

column1: Fact is that the spending spree in Washington is continuing to run unabated. The American people are screaming at the top of their lungs
column2: ""Stop!"" And -- and to move this without finding other offsets in spending
column3: I think
column4: is irresponsible. It's just putting more debt on the backs of our kids and our grandkids
column5: and it really begs the question is
column6: why don't we have a budget this year?

column1: You know
column2: we've not cut -- the House has failed -- not failed in the modern era to move a budget. And this appears to be the first time in the modern era that the House is not even going to consider a budget.

column1: TAPPER: Well
column2: Leader Hoyer
column3: if I could...

column1: (CROSSTALK)
TAPPER: ... if I could say
column2: one of the -- the theory is that you don't want to make vulnerable Democrats vote for another spending bill
column3: and that's why for the first time since 1974 there isn't going to be a House budget. Is that not true?

column1: HOYER: Whatever -- whatever the theory may be
column2: Jake
column3: the fact of the matter is
column4: my friend
column5: Mr. Boehner
column6: voted for $2 trillion during the Bush administration of unfunded spending. So when he says this cascade of spending
column7: he...

column1: (CROSSTALK)
TAPPER: But you agree that this should be offset with spending cuts?
HOYER: I would hope that we could do that
column2: yes. However
column3: what I said was
column4: money that has already been appropriated in the Recovery and Reinvestment Act that has not yet been spent could be spent now on these priority items. Nobody wants to see $300
column5: 000 teachers or fire and police laid off. That's not good for the economy; it's not good for our kids; it's not good for the safety of our communities.

column1: So the president's absolutely right in terms of this being critically important spending
column2: and we're going to work on getting that. I personally believe that if we have dollars that are not yet expended in the Recovery Act that we can apply to this immediate need and then look to later expenditures in the long term for investments
column3: I think we ought to do that. But we can't -- we can't stimulate and depress at the same time.

column1: TAPPER: I'd like to -- I'd...
BOEHNER: Jake
column2: every family knows that in a tough time it's more important to have a budget
column3: not less. And if you think that they're going to move a budget on Capitol Hill
column4: you must obviously believe that Elvis is still alive.

column1: TAPPER: Well
column2: I'd -- I'd like to move on to another topic...

column1: HOYER: I know you do...
TAPPER: ... other than Elvis.
HOYER: ... but as you know
column2: the Republicans didn't have a budget in '02

column1: BOEHNER: The House has never failed to pass a budget in the modern era.
HOYER: And the American public had no idea about that
column2: budgets that pass...

column1: BOEHNER: Well
column2: this is a great opportunity...

column1: HOYER: ... and spending bills that follow (ph).
BOEHNER: ... to cut spending and to get the economy going again.
HOYER: And we're doing that.
BOEHNER: That's why I gave the president...
HOYER: Let me close with this.
BOEHNER: ... a letter this week with -- 100 economists signed a letter saying that cutting spending now will
column2: in fact
column3: help get the economy moving again
column4: get jobs back...

column1: (CROSSTALK)
TAPPER: I would like -- in terms of getting things moving again
column2: I would like to move to another topic...

column1: HOYER: Look
column2: can I conclude on the deficit? Because the president -- we've adopted statutory PAYGO
column3: which they jettisoned.

column1: BOEHNER: And you've ignored it every time you've had a chance to use it.
TAPPER: All right
column2: guys...

column1: HOYER: The president sent down a freeze in spending. And he established a commission to look at long-term spending control. All of that is positive movement.
TAPPER: Let's move on to the oil spill.
BOEHNER: The American people want spending cut now.
TAPPER: Got it. Let's move on to the oil spill
column2: because I want to get your reaction. On Tuesday
column3: the BP chief operating officer
column4: Doug Suttles
column5: told the Associated Press that the flow ""should decrease to a relative trickle by Monday or Tuesday."" That's by tomorrow or the day after that
column6: Doug Suttles said that.

column1: I don't know what a relative anything means when it comes to this oil spill
column2: but there's no indication that there's going to be -- it's only going to be trickling by tomorrow or the next day. And I just want to know
column3: as the leaders of your respective parties on Capitol Hill
column4: are you finding it tough to believe anything these guys from BP have to say anymore?

column1: HOYER: Certainly BP has not been accurate in its representations. It has been misleading in its representations. What has happened is outrageous
column2: and the American public are correctly very
column3: very angry. And the administration has been marshalling every asset that we have available to work on this program.

column1: I hope he's right. The American public hopes he's right. A trickle. I don't know what a trickle is. But certainly a very
column2: very substantial reduction. BP said they could handle a 250
column3: 000-barrel spill. They have -- weren't able to handle what they said was initially a 5
column5: which was -- what then went to 20
column7: 000 and now we think is a much greater spill than that.

column1: BOEHNER: Well
column2: Steny
column3: guess what? I agree wholeheartedly with you. The American people want this oil leak stopped now. They want to know what happened. They want the gulf cleaned up. And they want it all done now.

column1: And I just think that BP ought to be held responsible for all of the costs that are involved in this. I've said that right from -- from the beginning. And I continue to believe that.
I'm sure that the federal government
column2: though
column3: was -- isn't also responsible. The laws that were in place
column4: the -- the materials that should have been in place for a spill this size were not
column5: and the reaction
column6: I think
column7: on the part of the administration has been slow. But having said that
column8: it's time to get this thing stopped now.

column1: TAPPER: All right
column2: just to...

column1: HOYER: The only thing I would say to that
column2: Jake...

column1: TAPPER: ... just to clear up what you said earlier this week
column2: on Thursday
column3: you said that -- that BP and the federal government should take full responsibility. To clarify that
column4: you think BP needs to pay?

column1: BOEHNER: I've said from the beginning
column2: BP needs to pay for the entire cost of this. But the federal government -- this is a failure of government. Government is there to protect our shores
column3: to protect our environment. And there's been a real failure here.

column1: We've been asking for 55 days
column2: where's the inspection reports from this rig? The administration won't give them to us.

column1: TAPPER: The Democrats are pushing a bill to lift the liability. Right now
column2: it's at $75 million. Democrats are pushing a bill to lift the liability cap. Do you support that?

column1: BOEHNER: I believe that lifting the liability cap on BP and for this spill is appropriate. I have concerns...
TAPPER: So lift it entirely for BP?
BOEHNER: Absolutely. They should be held responsible for every dime of this cost.
HOYER: Let me -- let me -- let me say a few words here. First of all
column2: the Republicans have been holding up lifting the cap in the Senate from the $75 million
column3: minuscule sum
column4: as we see
column5: to $10 billion.

column1: Secondly
column2: I think John Boehner is right in this respect: The psychology of neglect in terms of regulatory oversight that was pursued in the Bush administration
column3: which led to the banking failure
column4: insurance prices going way up
column5: and oil companies thinking they could do whatever they wanted because the ""drill
column6: baby
column7: drill"" crowd
column8: all they wanted them to do was to drill.

column1: So I think John's right. I think the regularly psychology of the last administration was not appropriate
column2: and there was mistakes made in this administration
column3: as well.

column1: BOEHNER: How long are you going to blame the Bush administration? Come on. What's going on over at MSS...
HOYER: As long as they're responsible
column2: whether it's the economy...

column1: BOEHNER: No
column2: that's -- listen...

column1: HOYER: ... or their lack of oversight
column2: John
column3: I'm going to do that.

column1: BOEHNER: Where -- where -- when is someone...
HOYER: As appropriate (ph).
BOEHNER: ... in Washington going to -- Washington going to take responsibility for what they are in charge of?
TAPPER: I want to move on...
HOYER: And the administration has done that.
TAPPER: I want to move on to some foreign policy questions
column2: but before I do
column3: I just -- there -- there was a poll recently this week indicating that the American people rate the federal response to this oil spill as worse than the federal response to Katrina
column4: 69 percent negative for the gulf oil spill
column5: 62 percent negative for the government's response to Katrina. Do you rate the government's response to this oil spill as negative or positive?

column1: HOYER: Absolutely not. I think that that's -- the American public are angry
column2: rightfully so. BP was on site. The folks who own the rig
column3: Halliburton
column4: who constructed the piping
column5: the concrete down there
column6: they are responsible with the federal government was (ph).

column1: Immediately upon this incident happening -- immediately...
TAPPER: So you think the government's responsible?
HOYER: ... the Coast Guard -- the Coast Guard was on site. Unfortunately
column2: tragically
column3: we lost 11 lives
column4: but saved over 100 lives on site. Thad Allen
column5: the admiral
column6: immediately put in charge
column8: 500 National Guard troops on duty right now.

column1: TAPPER: OK.
HOYER: So there's been a vast response here. A natural disaster came along in Katrina
column2: and
column3: frankly
column4: there were months before there was adequate response.

column1: TAPPER: Leader Boehner
column2: turning to Israel
column3: a member of your leadership team
column4: Congressman Mike Pence of Indiana
column5: said this on Thursday.

column1: (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
PENCE: Remarkably
column2: yesterday
column3: the president said it was time for Israel to sharply limit its effective blockade in Gaza
column4: saying
column5: quote
column6: ""The situation in Gaza is unsustainable."" The truth is
column7: Mr. President
column8: your policy in Israel is unsustainable. The American people are on the side of Israel and Israel's right to defend herself. Mr. President
column9: whose side are you on?

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
TAPPER: Leader Boehner
column2: is expressing concern about the humanitarian crisis in Gaza the same thing as being anti-Israel?

column1: BOEHNER: Well
column2: I think the Israelis have a clear right to -- to defend themselves. When you look at this flotilla that came over
column3: the first five ships that were inspected
column4: there was no -- there was no problem at all. It's pretty clear to many of us who've looked into this that this last ship was intended to be a problem
column5: intended to cause a conflict.

column1: And this is part of a much bigger problem that we see with the administration
column2: where we've -- we've coddled our enemies and -- and pushed our friends aside in the process...

column1: TAPPER: Leader Hoyer?
BOEHNER: ... raising a lot of doubts around the world
column2: including the people of Israel
column3: who are having serious doubts about our commitment to them
column4: our closest ally in the Middle East.

column1: HOYER: And I think one of the problems is
column2: when you see Mr. Pence and you hear Mr. Boehner
column3: this is not a partisan difference. Mr. Cantor and I had a colloquy on Thursday
column4: which as John knows
column5: I strongly support Israel's actions.

column1: They told these folks
column2: come here
column3: you're not going to break the blockade. Why are you not going to break the blockade? Because Hamas
column4: a terrorist organization
column5: continues to attack civilians
column6: men
column7: women and children
column8: in Israel.

column1: And it is appropriate to have a blockade to make sure they don't get the weapons or other materials to effect those kinds of attacks
column2: which are criminal
column3: which are terrorist acts. So I think they did exactly the right thing in stopping that.

column1: And in fact
column2: in my view
column3: the sixth ship
column4: as John has pointed out
column5: we agree on this
column6: five ships were stopped without incident. This sixth ship was stopped. There's some reason to believe that that's exactly what they intended to do. Al Jazeera television showed attacks on the boarding party
column7: and they responded in self-defense.

column1: Turkey knew that if these ships came
column2: it was going to be a problem. And the Israelis offered to allow the -- those ships to be offloaded at an Israeli port and all the humanitarian gear go into Gaza. That was the appropriate thing to do.

column1: TAPPER: We only have one minute left
column2: and I want to get your predictions for the midterm elections
column3: literally one minute left. So...

column1: HOYER: History says we're going to lose a few seats
column2: but we're going to retain the House.

column1: TAPPER: You're going to keep the House?
HOYER: We're going to keep the House.
TAPPER: Sir?
BOEHNER: Our goal is to take the majority in the House...
TAPPER: Not your goal. What's going to happen? Prediction. Prediction. You've said 100 seats. Can you do it?

BOEHNER: We've got -- we've got 100 seats in play. We have a real shot at winning a majority so that we can put a check on this administration and all the spending that's out of control here in Washington
column2: D.C.

column1: HOYER: Jake
column2: they said that about Mark Critz in the 12th District of Pennsylvania. He won by 8 points.

column1: TAPPER: All right.
HOYER: We're going to keep the House.
TAPPER: Leader Hoyer
column2: Leader Boehner
column3: thanks so much for joining us. I appreciate it.

column1: TAPPER: Joining me now
column2: Microsoft co-founder and chairman
column3: Bill Gates.

column1: Mr. Gates
column2: thanks so much for joining us.

column1: BILL GATES
column2: MICROSOFT CO-FOUNDER & CHAIRMAN: Great to be here.

column1: TAPPER: Obviously
column2: the oil spill in the Gulf makes your proposal for $11 billion in energy innovation all the more resonant
column3: all the more relevant. But I'm wondering
column4: some are criticizing the president's handling of the federal response to the spill by saying he doesn't have executive experience and that's why he hasn't been able to -- to really get the federal bureaucracy moving the way it needs to.

column1: As a former CEO
column2: do you think there's anything to that at all?

column1: GATES: Well
column2: I think in any crisis like this
column3: the key thing is to avoid them happening in the future. And I'm not an expert on oil recovery. BP is certainly incented to try and minimize the damage here in a very complex situation.

column1: But how did we get an ener -- energy infrastructure that is this fragile?
You know
column2: we've got a supply chain where we send a billion dollars a year overseas and you can imagine that there will be disruptions. When there have been in the past
column3: we've always said
column4: no
column5: let's put a solution in place. But
column6: in fact
column7: the only real solution is to take American ingenuity and fund R &D to get energy in different forms that we're not sending this much money away and -- and that it's stable and reliable.

column1: TAPPER: Well
column2: let -- let's talk about that. Obviously
column3: your proposal for $11 billion in additional spending for energy innovation
column4: there's not a huge appetite right now among the American people for more spending with the record deficits we have.

column1: Forgetting the merits of your proposal for a second
column2: how politically feasible is it?

column1: GATES: Well
column2: I would distinguish between spending and investment. What we're talking about is about 1 percent of what the United States spends on energy
column3: being devoted to R &D. And so if you find a way out of the energy sector to raise that 1 percent
column4: which is not some huge increase in the costs there
column5: then you can tap into the unique ability in this country
column6: through its universities
column7: the national labs and entrepreneurs
column8: to give us a form of energy that is both cheaper
column9: not dependent on foreign supply and is environmentally designed so that we're not emitting carbon and getting into the climate change problem.

column1: The only way you get those things is through the breakthroughs. And I'm optimistic they're there
column2: but we're not making the investment. Today we spend only about $4 billion on energy R &D compared to $30 billion on health
column3: $80 billion on -- on defense."	0

55	"As expected
column2: Rick Perry
column3: the governor of Texas
column4: has announced that he is running for president. And we already know what his campaign will be about: faith in miracles.

column1: Some of these miracles will involve things that youÃ¢ÂÂre liable to read in the Bible. But if he wins the Republican nomination
column2: his campaign will probably center on a more secular theme: the alleged economic miracle in Texas
column3: which
column4: itÃ¢ÂÂs often asserted
column5: sailed through the Great Recession almost unscathed thanks to conservative economic policies. And Mr. Perry will claim that he can restore prosperity to America by applying the same policies at a national level.

column1: So what you need to know is that the Texas miracle is a myth
column2: and more broadly that Texan experience offers no useful lessons on how to restore national full employment.

column1: ItÃ¢ÂÂs true that Texas entered recession a bit later than the rest of America
column2: mainly because the stateÃ¢ÂÂs still energy-heavy economy was buoyed by high oil prices through the first half of 2008. Also
column3: Texas was spared the worst of the housing crisis
column4: partly because it turns out to have surprisingly strict regulation of mortgage lending."	0

column1: 56	"UNHCR
column2: the UN Refugee Agency
column3: has welcomed news of the arrival in the United States this week of the 10
column4: 000th refugee from the conflict in Syria
column5: and calls for greater global solidarity ahead of summits next month that will look at ways to increase efforts to deal with the unprecedented refugee crisis worldwide.

column1: Ã¢ÂÂThe United States has long been a leader in welcoming people fleeing global persecution and the arrival on Monday of the 10
column2: 000th Syrian refugee is a further expression of this leadership
column3: Ã¢ÂÂ said UNHCR Regional Representative in the United States
column4: Shelly Pitterman.

column1: Ã¢ÂÂWe thank the communities in the United States that have kept their doors open and also our civil society partners for their tireless humanitarian efforts. Much more needs to be done for Syrian refugees and for the global crisis that has seen more people flee persecution than at any time ever recorded.Ã¢ÂÂ
At the end of 2015
column2: war
column3: conflict and persecution had forced 65.3 million people globally to flee for their lives
column4: an all-time high. The Syrian refugee crisis is the worldÃ¢ÂÂs largest and more than 4.8 million have fled mostly to neighbouring countries whose resources are stretched thin so that increasing numbers of refugees live below national poverty lines.

column1: To aid the most vulnerable refugees and to share the tremendous burden of these refugee-hosting countries
column2: UNHCR has called on governments to resettle those most at risk. So far resettlement countries have pledged a total of more than 220
column3: 000 places for Syrians under resettlement and other humanitarian admissions programmes. Around 478
column4: 000 Syrians are considered to be in need of resettlement Ã¢ÂÂ close to 40 per cent of the 1.19 million people who are in need of resettlement globally.

column1: UNHCR recognizes that opportunities for resettlement are extremely limited and so reserves this for persons who are most at risk
column2: such as unaccompanied children
column3: women-headed households
column4: victims of torture
column5: and persons with special medical needs. UNHCR identifies and carefully screens all refugees before they are referred to a country for resettlement. In the case of the United States
column6: all refugees who are referred then undergo extensive face-to-face interviews with Department of Homeland Security officers
column7: along with multiple layers of identity and security checks in a thorough process undertaken by US authorities.

column1: UNHCR calls for increased efforts to provide Syrian refugees with additional safe and regular pathways for admission. The United Nations General Assembly Summit for Refugees and Migrants on 19 September and the President of the United States Summit on Refugees on 20 September will provide opportunities for countries to show solidarity with refugee-hosting countries across the globe by giving Syrian and other vulnerable refugee groups legal opportunities to access safety and protection through resettlement and other pathways for admission.
Ã¢ÂÂResettling refugees
column2: along with continued humanitarian funding
column3: is a critical form of solidarity with refugee-hosting countries and it needs to be expanded worldwide
column4: Ã¢ÂÂ said Pitterman."	0

column1: 57	"Ravi Bhalla was elected HobokenÃ¢ÂÂs 39th Mayor on November 7
column2: 2017 out of a field of six candidates. Born and raised in New Jersey
column3: Mayor Bhalla is a 17 year resident of Hoboken and eight year member of the Hoboken City Council.

column1: He received his undergraduate education from the University of California at Berkeley
column2: where he received a B.A. in Political Psychology. Upon graduation
column3: he attended the London School of Economics (L.S.E.) in the United Kingdom and received a Master of Science degree in Public Administration and Public Policy
column4: and also earned a Juris Doctor Degree from Tulane Law School in New Orleans
column5: Louisiana.

column1: Ravi first set his roots in Hoboken at the age of 26
column2: a bachelor fresh out of law school starting his first job at a small law firm in Newark
column3: New Jersey. Ravi earned national recognition in the New York Times for his legal advocacy after suffering a violation of his own constitutional and civil rights during a jail visit to a client. The incident motivated Ravi to lead a successful campaign to reform the federal governmentÃ¢ÂÂs visitation policies at correctional facilities nationwide.

column1: Ravi married his wife Bindya
column2: and they had two children
column3: Arza and Shahbegh. It was during this time that HobokenÃ¢ÂÂs local government was in dire straits. He observed and witnessed mismanaged government at the local level
column4: including a government budget that was underfunded and overspent by $12 million
column5: a state takeover of Hoboken
column6: and a 70% spike in municipal taxes in a single year.

column1: Ravi ran for Council alongside Mayor Zimmer and worked tirelessly to get their message out of restoring honesty
column2: professionalism and fiscal responsibility to Hoboken. Out of twelve candidates vying for 3 council-at-large positions
column3: Ravi received the highest number of votes
column4: as a first time candidate for office.

column1: Once in office
column2: Ravi worked hard alongside Mayor Zimmer and his council colleagues to establish tangible reforms to the way government is run in Hoboken. Municipal taxes were reduced and HobokenÃ¢ÂÂs finances were put on a responsible long-term path. The CityÃ¢ÂÂs bond rating was improved from junk bond status in 2009 to AA+ in 2013
column3: the second highest rating
column4: and had a responsible cash surplus for the first time in years.

column1: Ravi was a leading voice on the council for securing the necessary funding for HobokenÃ¢ÂÂs second flood pump in Northwest Hoboken
column2: advocated with Mayor Zimmer for the addition of 9 acres of open space
column3: ensured our parks were built with detention systems to help alleviate flooding
column4: voted to add progressive transportation options including corner cars and bike share
column5: and played a large role in saving the hospital from closing in 2013
column6: preserving more than 1
column7: 200 jobs and relieving taxpayers of a $52 million bond guarantee. Ravi currently sits as a co-chair of the CityÃ¢ÂÂs Rebuild by Design project
column8: in which the City was awarded $230 million to comprehensively protect Hoboken from storm surge events like Superstorm Sandy.

column1: Ravi served as Council President from 2011-2012 and Council Vice-President from 2010-2011 & 2013-2014 and was Chairman of the Hoboken Democratic Party from 2010-2011. Prior to his service as a Councilman
column2: Mr. Bhalla served as a local Democratic Committeeman for the 2nd Ward
column3: 3rd District of Hoboken from 2007-2009.

column1: Ravi and his wife Bindya reside on Garden Street with their two children
column2: Arza Kaur
column3: age 10 and Shabegh Singh
column4: age 5."	1

Jim

column5: for a Newt Gingrich.

column1: Let's bring you right to the contributors.
The Mormons really delivered for Mitt Romney as we look through the entrance polls. We know that they were able to deliver. Is there anything that you can take from what we know about Mormon response
column2: Mormon commitment to Mitt Romney that you can say and transpose to the general election?

column1: UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I think when you get into the general election
column2: it becomes more -- they become your typical Republican voter
column3: but they're also a funding source for the Romney campaign.

column1: O'BRIEN: OK. So
column2: funding. Organization?

column1: UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Organization will be a good thing for the Mormons. In fact
column2: that was a selling point for Romney
column3: although it didn't pan out for the primaries in 2008. That was one selling point a lot of people made is the way Mormons organize around the country. Those voters
column4: young students will be able to help him. I don't know that that's true as much as hype.

column1: O'BRIEN: David Gergen talked a little about this sort of national polls
column2: you see Mitt Romney going down
column3: down
column4: down
column5: even though he's becoming more and more sort of the de facto candidate. And when you ask the question
column6: can the candidate connect with -- understand the problems of America? With President Obama
column7: the polls are like at 55 percent and Mitt Romney polling at the end of January around 39 percent. How big a problem is that?

column1: ROLAND MARTIN
column2: CNN POLITICAL ANALYST: Well
column3: first of all
column4: it's no shock his numbers will be going down because as you get deeper into a primary
column5: his negatives naturally go up
column6: because you have the attacks going back and forth
column7: you have the ads
column8: you have Newt Gingrich slinging arrows
column9: get Rick Santorum in his speech tonight condemning
column10: of course
column11: the health care plan in Massachusetts.

column1: So
column2: people begin to hear more about you. He is going to have an issue when it comes to connecting with voters. I go back to -- when he goes into Ohio and Pennsylvania and he goes into Michigan
column3: what is he going to say to those voters? How is he going to say
column4: oh
column5: before when I say it
column6: look
column7: let the market take over when it comes to foreclosures
column8: but you're under water. What did I say before when I say let GM go into bankruptcy
column9: but down to automakers. He has to deal with that. Those are real blue collar workers. If he doesn't make the arguments to them
column10: how is he going to win them over to ...

column1: UNIDENTIFIED MALE: He's already having trouble connecting to the Republican base.
MARTIN: So I'm saying.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: And this is critical for the general election. That's why I keep saying that his win tonight really doesn't have any implications for the general elections other than negative ones I think because he's shown that he can't win the Latino vote.
UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I want to say I disagree. (CROSSTALK)
UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Me thinks he lost this primary tonight listening to you guys.
(CROSSTALK)
UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: That's right. And to Roland's point
column2: when a voter goes into the voting booth to vote and many studies have been done about this
column3: they vote on their gut. And right now President Obama is winning that battle of who is going to be the candidate who is going to fight for you
column4: who understands what you're going through
column5: and who is going to put forth policies that is going to fight for you.

column1: And that really
column2: that's not just a talking point. If you look at Mitt Romney's plan
column3: his economic plan
column4: a tax cut for middle class families
column5: $167. A tax cut for millionaires
column7: 000. That's the reality that he's got to contend with.

column1: O'BRIEN: It does make it sound like he lost today
column2: when actually not only did he win
column3: he won by a lot.

column1: UNIDENTIFIED MALE: But his percentage is lower this year than in 2008.
(CROSSTALK)
WILL CAIN
column2: CNN CONTRIBUTOR: It reinforces what Gloria talked about
column3: David talked about. This word we've been batting around for months now of inevitability. When he's now winning tea party supporters
column4: when he's now winning very conservative voters
column5: it reinforces this. He is going to be the nominee. It reinforces inevitability.

column1: O'BRIEN: Wolf Blitzer's got Rick Santorum now. Wolf?
BLITZER: Let's talk to Rick Santorum
column2: Pennsylvanian senator
column3: the Republican presidential candidate. He's joining us right now.

column1: Senator
column2: thanks very much for coming in. You're in Colorado. Already didn't waste any time in Nevada. I suspect when you realized you weren't going to do all that well in Nevada
column3: that's why you got out and look ahead to Tuesday's contest in Colorado.

column1: RICK SANTORUM (R) PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: Yes
column2: absolutely. I mean
column3: you know
column4: we're playing the demographics
column5: you're playing on Mitt's home court in Nevada. He spent a lot of money
column6: a lot of time there. He's been campaigning there really for five years and organizing
column7: you know
column8: as has Ron Raul. I mean
column9: those are -- these early states
column10: these first five states
column11: you know
column12: there's an inherent advantage to the folks who have run before
column13: that have spent a lot of time and money in those states.

column1: And now we're moving out to states where they had to play sort of catch up four years ago and didn't have the organization
column2: didn't have the strength
column3: didn't run the campaign commercials and didn't have the strong identity. And so we think this is an opportunity for us for this race to begin to turn and begin to come toward our direction.

column1: BLITZER: Have you had the chance to call Mitt Romney and congratulate him yet?
SANTORUM: As a matter of fact
column2: I just got off -- I just gave a speech here in Greeley
column3: Colorado and did a couple of interviews and now I'm doing yours. So I really haven't had a moment to do so. And I understand he's going to speak here in a minute. So I'll try to reach him maybe after he gets off the platform.

column1: BLITZER: But you will call him? I ask the question only because Newt Gingrich has made a point of not calling him to congratulate him after he won in Florida. But you will call him to congratulate?
SANTORUM: Look
column2: you know
column3: one of the things I feel very strongly about is that politics is a rough enough game that it shouldn't be personal. And that when someone has an accomplishment
column4: if someone beats you fair and square
column5: you pick up the phone and you give him a call and you congratulate him for his good work. And we'll see him on the campaign trail.

column1: BLITZER: You know
column2: I can't tell you how many people
column3: so-called experts
column4: pundits
column5: analysts
column6: Senator
column7: have said to be the reason that Rick Santorum is staying in the race is that in case Newt Gingrich were to drop out
column8: he could then emerge as the non-Mitt Romney
column9: the so- called real conservative and develop a real challenge to Mitt Romney. Is that the way you're thinking?

column1: SANTORUM: I think
column2: eventually
column3: as I said before
column4: this race will come toward us. We're the candidate that provides the real best perspective of beating Barack Obama. I think that's going to become more and more evident. It's just the opposite of what people actually thought at the beginning of this race. I think it's going to become clear.

column1: Look at the latest Rasmussen Poll that has us beating Obama by a point and has Romney losing by three
column2: Gingrich losing by eighth or nine. The more that this race goes on
column3: the more people see that we present the best chance to win this and you get a twofer. Not only do you get the best chance to win
column4: but you get the candidate who actually holds the values that Republicans generally speak in this country hold.

column1: BLITZER: Tell us what's going to happen on Tuesday in Colorado
column2: Minnesota
column3: and Missouri.

column1: SANTORUM: You know
column2: I think
column3: again
column4: demographically
column5: Colorado is not the best state for us
column6: but I think we can do well here. I think we will do much better than we did in Nevada. I think we can do even better maybe in Minnesota
column7: and Missouri is an interesting one
column8: because Newt is not on the ballot and that presents an opportunity for a one- on-one match up in a state that's a pretty key swing state for Republicans
column9: actually a must-win state for Republicans in this election cycle. So
column10: we're optimistic that we're going to perform very
column11: very well in all three of those states.

column1: BLITZER: I'm going to let you go
column2: but very quickly
column3: your little daughter Bella
column4: how is she doing?

column1: SANTORUM: Well
column2: thank you so much for asking
column3: and she is doing just great. She's almost back to -- back as good as new. I just want to thank you and everybody again. It's been a -- and what a relief and thank you for your prayers and for helping us out. It's certainly given a little more hop in my steps these last few days.

column1: BLITZER: Well
column2: give her our love
column3: as you know. Thanks very much
column4: Senator. We'll talk to you on the campaign trail. Rick Santorum joining us from Colorado.

column1: Soledad?
SOLEDAD O'BRIEN
column2: CNN ANCHOR: Gloria Borger
column3: David Gergen
column4: first of all
column5: we heard from Rick Santorum just now. Ron Paul we heard from a little bit earlier. We're going to hear from Newt Gingrich. We're expecting that for long for now. Mitt Romney
column6: though
column7: will also be coming out to give his acceptance speech. What do we need to hear from him? What you expect to hear from him?

column1: GLORIA BORGER
column2: CNN POLITICAL ANALYST: I expect him to just turn to Barack Obama. I think that he's not going to be talking about Newt Gingrich. He's going to be talking about what a great win this was. But I think he's just going to pivot and talk about Barack Obama
column3: how he can take it to Barack Obama
column4: how he will be better at fixing the economy and all of the things that we've already heard we will hear repeated again.

column1: DAVID GERGEN
column2: CNN CONTRIBUTOR: I think Gloria is basically right. That's what he did after his New Hampshire win. That's what he did after his Florida win. I would suggest though that's not what he should do tonight. Yes
column3: he should take it to Barack Obama and probably is going to do some of that. But it's more important now that he begin making people understand what he would do
column4: because
column5: you know
column6: he's got this big economic plan. I haven't met a single person that can tell you three things that they could just reel off and say here's what Mitt Romney would do if he will president.

column1: BORGER: 59-point.
GERGEN: He has a 59-point plan. People don't -- you don't remember that. I can tell you when Reagan was running back in 1980
column2: he had five things he was going to do
column3: everybody knew what they were and he got a mandate out of it.

column1: O'BRIEN: He's got to work on connecting with people.
GERGEN: He's got to work on connecting emotionally but also there has to be -- they've got a great line about being a takeover person
column2: somebody who can turn things around. His son did that tonight and his wife Ann has been doing that. But he has now -- will have to sort of say
column3: I can turn things around by doing the following.

column1: O'BRIEN: Does an improving economy make that an even trickier pivot?
BORGER: It does because you have to be a little bit more nuisance to mean Republicans cannot be seen to be rooting against an economic recovery. Of course not. What Mitt Romney has said
column2: and probably continues to say
column3: is that Barack Obama hasn't made the recovery occur quickly enough and that it may not be sustained and if you do these 59 things
column4: that maybe you will sustain.

column1: But I think this is a point for all of these campaigns. We just heard from Rick Santorum. They're all now refining their message. Rick Santorum is saying
column2: if Gingrich goes
column3: I'm the anti-Romney candidate
column4: and they believe that there's a base of support out there that is anti-Romney. Romney is
column5: I can take on Obama. Newt Gingrich is
column6: I'm the conservative in this race
column7: I can beat...

column1: GERGEN: Before we leave that -- Rick Santorum
column2: we were"	0

column1: 59	"Following is a transcript of the first presidential debate between Senators John McCain and Barack Obama in Oxford
column2: Miss.
column3: as recorded by CQ Transcriptions:

column1: View the video of this debate
LEHRER: Good evening from the Ford Center for the Performing Arts at the University of Mississippi in Oxford. I'm Jim Lehrer of the NewsHour on PBS
column2: and I welcome you to the first of the 2008 presidential debates between the Republican nominee
column3: Senator John McCain of Arizona
column4: and the Democratic nominee
column5: Senator Barack Obama of Illinois. The Commission on Presidential Debates is the sponsor of this event and the three other presidential and vice presidential debates coming in October. Tonight's will primarily be about foreign policy and national security
column6: which
column7: by definition
column8: includes the global financial crisis. It will be divided roughly into nine-minute segments. Direct exchanges between the candidates and moderator follow-ups are permitted after each candidate has two minutes to answer the lead question in an order determined by a coin toss. The specific subjects and questions were chosen by me. They have not been shared or cleared with anyone. The audience here in the hall has promised to remain silent
column9: no cheers
column10: no applause
column11: no noise of any kind
column12: except right now
column13: as we welcome Senators Obama and McCain. (APPLAUSE) Let me begin with something General Eisenhower said in his 1952 presidential campaign. Quote
column14: ""We must achieve both security and solvency. In fact
column15: the foundation of military strength is economic strength
column16: end quote. With that in mind
column17: the first lead question. Gentlemen
column19: where do you stand on the financial recovery plan? First response to you
column20: Senator Obama. You have two minutes.

column1: OBAMA: Well
column2: thank you very much
column3: Jim
column4: and thanks to the commission and the University of Mississippi
column5: Ole Miss
column6: for hosting us tonight. I can't think of a more important time for us to talk about the future of the country. You know
column7: we are at a defining moment in our history. Our nation is involved in two wars
column8: and we are going through the worst financial crisis since the Great Depression. And although we've heard a lot about Wall Street
column9: those of you on Main Street I think have been struggling for a while
column10: and you recognize that this could have an impact on all sectors of the economy. And you're wondering
column11: how's it going to affect me? How's it going to affect my job? How's it going to affect my house? How's it going to affect my retirement savings or my ability to send my children to college? So we have to move swiftly
column12: and we have to move wisely. And I've put forward a series of proposals that make sure that we protect taxpayers as we engage in this important rescue effort. Number one
column13: we've got to make sure that we've got oversight over this whole process; $700 billion
column14: potentially
column15: is a lot of money. Number two
column16: we've got to make sure that taxpayers
column17: when they are putting their money at risk
column18: have the possibility of getting that money back and gains
column19: if the market -- and when the market returns. Number three
column20: we've got to make sure that none of that money is going to pad CEO bank accounts or to promote golden parachutes. And
column21: number four
column22: we've got to make sure that we're helping homeowners
column23: because the root problem here has to do with the foreclosures that are taking place all across the country. Now
column24: we also have to recognize that this is a final verdict on eight years of failed economic policies promoted by George Bush
column25: supported by Senator McCain
column26: a theory that basically says that we can shred regulations and consumer protections and give more and more to the most
column27: and somehow prosperity will trickle down. It hasn't worked. And I think that the fundamentals of the economy have to be measured by whether or not the middle class is getting a fair shake. That's why I'm running for president
column28: and that's what I hope we're going to be talking about tonight.

column1: LEHRER: Senator McCain
column2: two minutes.

column1: MCCAIN: Well
column2: thank you
column3: Jim. And thanks to everybody. And I do have a sad note tonight. Senator Kennedy is in the hospital. He's a dear and beloved friend to all of us. Our thoughts and prayers go out to the lion of the Senate. I also want to thank the University of Mississippi for hosting us tonight. And
column4: Jim
column5: I -- I've been not feeling too great about a lot of things lately. So have a lot of Americans who are facing challenges. But I'm feeling a little better tonight
column6: and I'll tell you why. Because as we're here tonight in this debate
column7: we are seeing
column8: for the first time in a long time
column9: Republicans and Democrats together
column10: sitting down
column11: trying to work out a solution to this fiscal crisis that we're in. And have no doubt about the magnitude of this crisis. And we're not talking about failure of institutions on Wall Street. We're talking about failures on Main Street
column12: and people who will lose their jobs
column13: and their credits
column14: and their homes
column15: if we don't fix the greatest fiscal crisis
column16: probably in -- certainly in our time
column17: and I've been around a little while. But the point is -- the point is
column18: we have finally seen Republicans and Democrats sitting down and negotiating together and coming up with a package. This package has transparency in it. It has to have accountability and oversight. It has to have options for loans to failing businesses
column19: rather than the government taking over those loans. We have to -- it has to have a package with a number of other essential elements to it. And
column20: yes
column21: I went back to Washington
column22: and I met with my Republicans in the House of Representatives. And they weren't part of the negotiations
column23: and I understand that. And it was the House Republicans that decided that they would be part of the solution to this problem. But I want to emphasize one point to all Americans tonight. This isn't the beginning of the end of this crisis. This is the end of the beginning
column24: if we come out with a package that will keep these institutions stable. And we've got a lot of work to do. And we've got to create jobs. And one of the areas
column25: of course
column26: is to eliminate our dependence on foreign oil.

column1: LEHRER: All right
column2: let's go back to my question. How do you all stand on the recovery plan? And talk to each other about it. We've got five minutes. We can negotiate a deal right here. But
column3: I mean
column4: are you -- do you favor this plan
column5: Senator Obama
column6: and you
column7: Senator McCain? Do you -- are you in favor of this plan?

column1: OBAMA: We haven't seen the language yet. And I do think that there's constructive work being done out there. So
column2: for the viewers who are watching
column3: I am optimistic about the capacity of us to come together with a plan. The question
column4: I think
column5: that we have to ask ourselves is
column6: how did we get into this situation in the first place? Two years ago
column7: I warned that
column8: because of the subprime lending mess
column9: because of the lax regulation
column10: that we were potentially going to have a problem and tried to stop some of the abuses in mortgages that were taking place at the time. Last year
column11: I wrote to the secretary of the Treasury to make sure that he understood the magnitude of this problem and to call on him to bring all the stakeholders together to try to deal with it. So -- so the question
column12: I think
column13: that we've got to ask ourselves is
column14: yes
column15: we've got to solve this problem short term. And we are going to have to intervene; there's no doubt about that. But we're also going to have to look at
column16: how is it that we shredded so many regulations? We did not set up a 21st-century regulatory framework to deal with these problems. And that in part has to do with an economic philosophy that says that regulation is always bad.

column1: LEHRER: Are you going to vote for the plan
column2: Senator McCain?

column1: MCCAIN: I -- I hope so. And I...
LEHRER: As a United States senator...
MCCAIN: Sure.
LEHRER: ... you're going to vote for the plan?
MCCAIN: Sure. But -- but let me -- let me point out
column2: I also warned about Fannie Mae (NYSE:FNM) and Freddie Mac (NYSE:FRE) and warned about corporate greed and excess
column3: and CEO pay
column4: and all that. A lot of us saw this train wreck coming. But there's also the issue of responsibility. You've mentioned President Dwight David Eisenhower. President Eisenhower
column5: on the night before the Normandy invasion
column6: went into his room
column7: and he wrote out two letters. One of them was a letter congratulating the great members of the military and allies that had conducted and succeeded in the greatest invasion in history
column8: still to this day
column9: and forever. And he wrote out another letter
column10: and that was a letter of resignation from the United States Army for the failure of the landings at Normandy. Somehow we've lost that accountability. I've been heavily criticized because I called for the resignation of the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission. We've got to start also holding people accountable
column11: and we've got to reward people who succeed. But somehow in Washington today -- and I'm afraid on Wall Street -- greed is rewarded
column12: excess is rewarded
column13: and corruption -- or certainly failure to carry out our responsibility is rewarded. As president of the United States
column14: people are going to be held accountable in my administration. And I promise you that that will happen.

column1: LEHRER: Do you have something directly to say
column2: Senator Obama
column3: to Senator McCain about what he just said?

column1: OBAMA: Well
column2: I think Senator McCain's absolutely right that we need more responsibility
column3: but we need it not just when there's a crisis. I mean
column4: we've had years in which the reigning economic ideology has been what's good for Wall Street
column5: but not what's good for Main Street. And there are folks out there who've been struggling before this crisis took place. And that's why it's so important
column6: as we solve this short-term problem
column7: that we look at some of the underlying issues that have led to wages and incomes for ordinary Americans to go down
column8: the -- a health care system that is broken
column9: energy policies that are not working
column10: because
column11: you know
column12: 10 days ago
column13: John said that the fundamentals of the economy are sound.

column1: LEHRER: Say it directly to him.
OBAMA: I do not think that they are.
LEHRER: Say it directly to him.
OBAMA: Well
column2: the -- John
column3: 10 days ago
column4: you said that the fundamentals of the economy are sound. And...

column1: MCCAIN: Are you afraid I couldn't hear him? (LAUGHTER)
LEHRER: I'm just determined to get you all to talk to each other. I'm going to try.
OBAMA: The -- and I just fundamentally disagree. And unless we are holding ourselves accountable day in
column2: day out
column3: not just when there's a crisis for folks who have power and influence and can hire lobbyists
column4: but for the nurse
column5: the teacher
column6: the police officer
column7: who
column8: frankly
column9: at the end of each month
column10: they've got a little financial crisis going on. They're having to take out extra debt just to make their mortgage payments. We haven't been paying attention to them. And if you look at our tax policies
column11: it's a classic example.

column1: LEHRER: So
column2: Senator McCain
column3: do you agree with what Senator Obama just said? And
column4: if you don't
column5: tell him what you disagree with.

column1: MCCAIN: No
column2: I -- look
column3: we've got to fix the system. We've got fundamental problems in the system. And Main Street is paying a penalty for the excesses and greed in Washington
column4: D.C.
column5: and in the Wall Street. So there's no doubt that we have a long way to go. And
column6: obviously
column7: stricter interpretation and consolidation of the various regulatory agencies that weren't doing their job
column8: that has brought on this crisis. But I have a fundamental belief in the goodness and strength of the American worker. And the American worker is the most productive
column9: the most innovative. America is still the greatest producer
column10: exporter and importer. But we've got to get through these times
column11: but I have a fundamental belief in the United States of America. And I still believe
column12: under the right leadership
column13: our best days are ahead of us.

column1: LEHRER: All right
column2: let's go to the next lead question
column3: which is essentially following up on this same subject. And you get two minutes to begin with
column4: Senator McCain. And using your word ""fundamental
column5: are there fundamental differences between your approach and Senator Obama's approach to what you would do as president to lead this country out of the financial crisis?

column1: MCCAIN: Well
column2: the first thing we have to do is get spending under control in Washington. It's completely out of control. It's gone -- we have now presided over the largest increase in the size of government since the Great Society. We Republicans came to power to change government
column3: and government changed us. And the -- the worst symptom on this disease is what my friend
column4: Tom Coburn
column5: calls earmarking as a gateway drug
column6: because it's a gateway. It's a gateway to out-of-control spending and corruption. And we have former members of Congress now residing in federal prison because of the evils of this earmarking and pork-barrel spending. You know
column7: we spent $3 million to study the DNA of bears in Montana. I don't know if that was a criminal issue or a paternal issue
column8: but the fact is that it was $3 million of our taxpayers' money. And it has got to be brought under control. As president of the United States
column9: I want to assure you
column10: I've got a pen. This one's kind of old. I've got a pen
column11: and I'm going to veto every single spending bill that comes across my desk. I will make them famous. You will know their names. Now
column12: Senator Obama
column13: you wanted to know one of the differences. He has asked for $932 million of earmark pork-barrel spending
column14: nearly a million dollars for every day that he's been in the United States Senate. I suggest that people go up on the Web site of Citizens Against Government Waste
column15: and they'll look at those projects. That kind of thing is not the way to rein in runaway spending in Washington
column16: D.C. That's one of the fundamental differences that Senator Obama and I have.

column1: LEHRER: Senator Obama
column2: two minutes.

column1: OBAMA: Well
column2: Senator McCain is absolutely right that the earmarks process has been abused
column3: which is why I suspended any requests for my home state
column4: whether it was for senior centers or what have you
column5: until we cleaned it up. And he's also right that oftentimes lobbyists and special interests are the ones that are introducing these kinds of requests
column6: although that wasn't the case with me. But let's be clear: Earmarks account for $18 billion in last year's budget. Senator McCain is proposing -- and this is a fundamental difference between us -- $300 billion in tax cuts to some of the wealthiest corporations and individuals in the country
column7: $300 billion. Now
column8: $18 billion is important; $300 billion is really important. And in his tax plan
column9: you would have CEOs of Fortune 500 companies getting an average of $700
column10: 000 in reduced taxes
column11: while leaving 100 million Americans out. So my attitude is
column12: we've got to grow the economy from the bottom up. What I've called for is a tax cut for 95 percent of working families
column13: 95 percent. And that means that the ordinary American out there who's collecting a paycheck every day
column14: they've got a little extra money to be able to buy a computer for their kid
column15: to fill up on this gas that is killing them. And over time
column16: that
column17: I think
column18: is going to be a better recipe for economic growth than the -- the policies of President Bush that John McCain wants to -- wants to follow.

column1: LEHRER: Senator McCain?
MCCAIN: Well
column2: again
column3: I don't mean to go back and forth
column4: but he... (CROSSTALK)

column1: LEHRER: No
column2: that's fine.

column1: MCCAIN: Senator Obama suspended those requests for pork-barrel projects after he was running for president of the United States. He didn't happen to see that light during the first three years as a member of the United States Senate
column2: $932 million in requests. Maybe to Senator Obama it's not a lot of money. But the point is that -- you see
column3: I hear this all the time. ""It's only $18 billion."" Do you know that it's tripled in the last five years? Do you know that it's gone completely out of control to the point where it corrupts people? It corrupts people. That's why we have
column4: as I said
column5: people under federal indictment and charges. It's a system that's got to be cleaned up. I have fought against it my career. I have fought against it. I was called the sheriff
column6: by the -- one of the senior members of the Appropriations Committee. I didn't win Miss Congeniality in the United States Senate. Now
column7: Senator Obama didn't mention that
column8: along with his tax cuts
column9: he is also proposing some $800 billion in new spending on new programs. Now
column10: that's a fundamental difference between myself and Senator Obama. I want to cut spending. I want to keep taxes low. The worst thing we could do in this economic climate is to raise people's taxes.

column1: OBAMA: I -- I don't know where John is getting his figures. Let's just be clear. What I do is I close corporate loopholes

column8: whatever it is it's going to cost

column1: OBAMA: Well
column2: there are a range of things that are probably going to have to be delayed. We don't yet know what our tax revenues are going to be. The economy is slowing down
column3: so it's hard to anticipate right now what the budget is going to look like next year. But there's no doubt that we're not going to be able to do everything that I think needs to be done. There are some things that I think have to be done. We have to have energy independence
column4: so I've put forward a plan to make sure that
column5: in 10 years' time
column6: we have freed ourselves from dependence on Middle Eastern oil by increasing production at home
column7: but most importantly by starting to invest in alternative energy (OOTC:AEGC)
column8: solar
column9: wind
column10: biodiesel
column11: making sure that we're developing the fuel-efficient cars of the future right here in the United States
column12: in Ohio and Michigan
column13: instead of Japan and South Korea. We have to fix our health care system
column14: which is putting an enormous burden on families. Just -- a report just came out that the average deductible went up 30 percent on American families. They are getting crushed
column15: and many of them are going bankrupt as a consequence of health care. I'm meeting folks all over the country. We have to do that now
column16: because it will actually make our businesses and our families better off. The third thing we have to do is we've got to make sure that we're competing in education. We've got to invest in science and technology. China had a space launch and a space walk. We've got to make sure that our children are keeping pace in math and in science. And one of the things I think we have to do is make sure that college is affordable for every young person in America. And I also think that we're going to have to rebuild our infrastructure
column17: which is falling behind
column19: our bridges
column20: but also broadband lines that reach into rural communities. Also
column21: making sure that we have a new electricity grid to get the alternative energy to population centers that are using them. We've got to eliminate programs that don't work
column22: and we've got to make sure that the programs that we do have are more efficient and cost less.

column12: particularly in the new challenges we face in the world
column13: but we have to get a lot of the cost overruns under control. I know how to do that.

column1: MCCAIN: I saved the taxpayers $6.8 billion by fighting a contract that was negotiated between Boeing and DOD that was completely wrong. And we fixed it and we killed it and the people ended up in federal prison so I know how to do this because I've been involved these issues for many
column2: many years. But I think that we have to examine every agency of government and find out those that are doing their job and keep them and find out those that aren't and eliminate them and we'll have to scrub every agency of government.

column1: LEHRER: But if I hear the two of you correctly neither one of you is suggesting any major changes in what you want to do as president as a result of the financial bailout? Is that what you're saying?
OBAMA: No. As I said before
column2: Jim
column3: there are going to be things that end up having to be ...

OBAMA: ... deferred and delayed. Well
column2: look
column3: I want to make sure that we are investing in energy in order to free ourselves from the dependence on foreign oil. That is a big project. That is a multi-year project.

column1: LEHRER: Not willing to give that up?

OBAMA: Not willing to give up the need to do it but there may be individual components that we can't do. But John is right we have to make cuts. We right now give $15 billion every year as subsidies to private insurers under the Medicare system. Doesn't work any better through the private insurers. They just skim off $15 billion. That was a give away and part of the reason is because lobbyists are able to shape how Medicare works. They did it on the Medicaid prescription drug bill and we have to change the culture. Tom -- or John mentioned me being wildly liberal. Mostly that's just me opposing George Bush's wrong headed policies since I've been in Congress but I think it is that it is also important to recognize I work with Tom Coburn
column2: the most conservative
