column1: 62	"Ohio Sen. Rob Portman has been busy in Washington touting the Comprehensive Addiction Recovery Act in response to a shocking number of heroin overdoses in Ohio.
The bill just passed in the Senate
column2: 94-1. (Nebraska Sen. Ben Sasse was the sole ""nay
column3: saying he believes that fighting addiction is a local issue.)

column1: Ohio ranks high on the list of states reeling from the national epidemic. In Montgomery County
column2: which encompasses Dayton
column3: Ohio
column4: heroin-related deaths increased 225 percent between 2011 and 2015.

column1: Back in the 1970s
column2: the heroin on U.S. streets was the ""black tar"" variety
column3: and much of it came from southeast Asia. In 2010
column4: 80 percent of the heroin in the world came from poppy fields in Afghanistan
column5: according to the Office of National Drug Control Policy.

column1: So when Portman said that most of the heroin in America comes from MexicoÃ¢ÂÂs border
column2: we were skeptical.

column1: Portman
column2: it turns out
column3: has done his homework. The Drug Enforcement AdministrationÃ¢ÂÂs National Drug Threat Assessment of 2015 says that Mexico is the primary supplier of heroin to the United States.

column1: Southeast Asia was once the dominant supplier of heroin in the United States
column2: but Southeast Asian heroin is now rarely detected in U.S. markets
column3: the report state. ""Mexico and
column4: to a lesser extent
column5: Colombia dominate the U.S. heroin market
column6: because of their proximity
column7: established transportation and distribution infrastructure
column8: and ability to satisfy U.S. heroin demand.""

column1: The report also says that Mexican ""transnational criminal organizations
column2: (the DEAÃ¢ÂÂs term for drug-dealing gangs) ""pose the greatest criminal drug threat to the United States; no other group is currently positioned to challenge them.""

column1: The National Drug Threat report notes that Colombian gangs were traditionally the suppliers of wholesale cocaine and heroin to Mexican and Dominican groups. But cartels in Mexico are ramping up their roles on the supply side -- opium production in Mexico increased by 50 percent in 2014.
Mexican labs also produce fentanyl
column2: a synthetic painkiller that is 80 to 100 times stronger than morphine. Fentanyl is sometimes mixed with heroin or substituted for heroin
column3: and the DEA reports more than 700 overdoses attributed to fentanyl between late 2013 and early 2015.

column1: Drugs get past the U.S. borders mostly ""by land
column2: not by sea
column3: said Homeland Security Secretary Jeh Johnson
column4: in the same March 8 hearing with Portman. And a 2015 Washington Post series on the surge of heroin puts the border detection rate at a scant 1.5 percent.

column1: SmugglersÃ¢ÂÂ creativity defies gravity: One successful bust came when agents caught two men flying a drone carrying 28 pounds of heroin from Mexico to California.
Our ruling
Portman said that heroin is coming to the United States primarily from Mexico. He hasnÃ¢ÂÂt been studying drug facts for nothing.
We rate this claim True."	0
63	"Immigration reform was a major component of President Barack Obama's campaign platform. He promised to secure the border
column2: crack down on employers who hire undocumented immigrants
column3: and provide a path to citizenship for undocumented immigrants.

column1: While watching ABC's This Week as part of our fact-checking partnership with the show
column2: we learned of a promise that we hadn't heard before. During the campaign
column3: then-candidate Obama was interviewed by Univision's Jorge Ramos
column4: a prominent voice within the Latin American community. During that interview
column5: Obama said he would pursue immigration reform aggressively. ""I cannot guarantee that it is going to be in the first 100 days
column6: Obama said. ""But what I can guarantee is that we will have in the first year an immigration bill that I strongly support and that I'm promoting. And I want to move that forward as quickly as possible.""

column1: We checked our database of promises
column2: and found that that while we did have promises from Obama on immigration reform
column3: we missed this one with its specific deadline. So we're adding it
column4: along with a rating.

column1: Obama set a timetable for this promise
column2: saying he would ""strongly support"" an immigration bill in his first year. But
column3: well into his second year
column4: no comprehensive immigration reform measure supported by Obama has been introduced in Congress.

column1: We searched his speeches on VoteSmart.org and found numerous mentions of immigration reform. In April 2009
column2: in response to a question about the one-year deadline
column3: he said that he saw the ""process moving this first year."" In June 2009
column4: he assigned Secretary of Homeland Security Janet Napolitano to begin putting together a comprehensive immigration reform framework. Finally
column5: in September 2009
column6: he said that he anticipated ""that before the year is out we will have draft legislation
column7: along with sponsors potentially in the House and the Senate who are ready to move this forward
column8: and when we come back next year
column9: that we should be in a position to start acting.""

column1: Alas
column2: the year came to an end with no Obama-endorsed bill in sight. On December 15
column4: Democratic Rep. Luis Gutierrez introduced a bill of his own
column5: but a spokesman for the Center for Immigration Studies said that Obama administration has not promoted or publicly supported Gutierrez's bill.

column1: Over the course of 2010
column2: Obama continued to push for immigration reform in his speeches. He mentioned it in his State of the Union address and announced in March that Senators Charles Schumer
column3: D-N.Y.
column4: and Lindsey Graham
column5: R-S.C.
column6: finished working on a bipartisan framework ""to fix our broken immigration system."" That was followed by a release of a 26-page immigration reform proposal in April
column7: which the President called a ""a very important step.""

column1: Finally
column2: Obama reiterated his call for bipartisan reform in a major speech at American University on July 1
column3: 2010. ""In recent days
column4: the issue of immigration has become once more a source of fresh contention in our country
column5: with the passage of a controversial law in Arizona and the heated reactions we""ve seen across America. Some have rallied behind this new policy. Others have protested and launched boycotts of the state. And everywhere
column6: people have expressed frustration with a system that seems fundamentally broken
column7: said Obama.

column1: Obama promised to strongly support a comprehensive immigration reform bill that would be introduced during his first year in office. As president
column2: he has repeatedly called for reform and several immigration-related bills are pending in Congress. But we're well into the second year of Obama's presidency
column3: and all that we've seen are proposals and frameworks
column4: no actual bills. Unless the White House has a time machine that we don't know about
column5: this is a Promise Broken."	0

column1: 64	"The government has implemented a new regulation requiring a governor to be placed on all motorcycles by mid-January 2017. The purpose of the mandatory governor would be to prevent motorcyclists from exceeding a speed of 75- miles per hour. The regulation aims to drastically reduce the amount of annual motorcycle fatalities in the United States.
Many are not surprised by the regulation as politicians have been asking for stricter safety features to be implemented on motorcycles for the past several decades. In 2014
column2: the government offered all major motorcycle manufactures including Harley-Davidson
column3: Yamaha
column4: Honda
column5: Ducati
column6: Kawasaki
column7: Suzuki
column8: and BMW a large tax-incentive to begin implementing governors on all newly manufactured motorcycles
column9: however to much surprise
column10: all relevant manufactures declined to take advantage of the additional tax-incentive
column11: requiring government officials to return to the drawing board.

column1: Members of the U.S. Department of Transportation or U.D.O.T were supportive of the regulation and heavily involved in its roll-out. According to U.S. Department of Transportation representative James Littleton
column2: the motorcycle governor regulation was long past due and made a comparison to the governors placed on traditional automobiles. Littleton told reporters during a press-conference that each year approximately 8
column3: 265 motorcycle fatalities occur throughout the United States. According to Littleton
column4: the vast majority (approximately 73%) of motorcycle fatalities are the result of motorcyclists driving at unsafe speeds.

column1: When asked why the regulation would only allow motorcyclists to maintain a speed below 75-miles per hour
column2: Littleton made the following comment to reporters
column3: Ã¢ÂÂThis is a crucial safety regulation that should have been implemented at least 20-years ago
column4: now that we are finally implementing it
column5: we want to ensure we do it right. With the exception of a few states that allow for 80-miles per mile freeway driving (Idaho
column6: Montana
column7: South Dakota
column8: Utah
column9: and Wyoming) and Texas who allows for speeds of up to 85-miles per hour on the freeway
column10: most states allow a maximum speed of 75-miles per hour. We wanted to make it easy for motorcyclists in most all states to easily obey their respective posted speed limit.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: According to Littleton
column2: motorcyclists in the few states that periodically allow for speeds exceeding 75-miles per hour
column3: governors allowing speeds up to 80-85-miles per hour may eventually be implemented
column4: however in the meantime
column5: police officials in these states have been given direction to avoid citing motorcyclists for such infractions as obstructing the flow of traffic when relevant.

column1: Officials expect all motorcyclists and motorcycle manufactures to be in compliance with the new regulation by mid to late January 2017
column2: however may file for a temporary 30
column4: or 90-day extension under select circumstances. According to Littleton
column5: citations and fines will be imposed on both motorcyclists and motorcycle manufactures who fail to remain in compliance with the regulation.

column1: According to Littleton
column2: designated motorcycle mechanic and auto-body shops in each state will be permitted to install the mandatory governors on motorcycles manufactured and sold prior to the implementation of the regulation at a subsidized rate. Littleton did not have details regarding the government subsidized repair readily available
column3: however told reporters that he expects the subsidized cost to be around $35 to the consumer.

column1: Littleton concluded the press conference by informing reporters that the U.S Department of Transportation is currently working diligently to release all relevant information pertaining to the new regulation on the U.D.O.T website.

65	Speaking in Cleveland
column2: Ohio
column3: Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton called for unity in the wake of the tragic shooting in Orlando. Here are key moments from that speech. (Video: Reuters/Associated Press)

column1: Share Add to your saved stories Save

Hillary Clinton delivered an address pledging that as president she would take on ""lone wolves"" who might carry out terrorist attacks in the United States and calling for unity in light of the massacre at a gay nightclub in Orlando on Sunday. The compete transcript of her remarks in Cleveland are posted below.
SPEAKER: FORMER SECRETARY OF STATE HILLARY RODHAM CLINTON
column2: DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE

column1: CLINTON: Thank you. (APPLAUSE)
Thank you all very much.
(APPLAUSE)
Thank you. Thank you all.
(APPLAUSE)

Thank you. Thank you. I am -- I'm absolutely -- I'm absolutely delighted to be back in Cleveland and to be here at the Industrial Innovation Center. I've had a chance to learn about the great work you do here. I especially want to applaud Team Wendy for everything you do to protect our troops
column2: first responders.

column1: Advertisement
(APPLAUSE)
And others from traumatic brain injury. It is so important that we continue to support those who protect us.
AUDIENCE: We want Hillary!
CLINTON: Thank you.
AUDIENCE: We want Hillary!
CLINTON: Thank you all.
AUDIENCE: We want Hillary!
(APPLAUSE)
CLINTON: It is good to be back in Cleveland
column2: I can tell you that.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
I want to thank -- I wan to thank your extraordinary senator
column2: Sherrod Brown
column3: for his leadership
column4: for that very kind and generous introduction. You are very fortunate to -- to have him representing you. I want to thank your congresswoman
column5: Marcia Fudge...

column1: (APPLAUSE)
Who is both indomitable and indefatigable. She is such a tenacious advocate for the people she represents. I want to acknowledge the mayor
column2: Mayor Jackson
column3: who was here
column4: County Executive Budish (ph). And I particularly want to recognize the passing of George Voinovich
column5: and he devoted his life to serving the people of Ohio as mayor of Cleveland
column6: as governor and senator. And we send our prayers and sympathy to his family.

column1: Advertisement
I also want to thank Dan Moore
column2: the owner and founder of this company and Team Wendy for his belief in Cleveland
column3: for his commitment to create jobs. I can't wait to work with him to do more of what he has accomplished here.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
You know
column2: originally
column3: I had intended to come to Cleveland under very different circumstances. We are heading into a general election that could be the most consequential of our lifetimes. But today is not a day for politics.

column1: On Sunday
column2: Americans woke up to a nightmare that's become mind numbingly familiar. Another act of terrorism in a place no one expected. A madman filled with hate
column3: with guns in his hands
column4: and just a horrible sense of vengeance and vindictiveness in his heart
column5: apparently consumed by rage against LGBT Americans
column6: and by extension
column7: the openness and diversity that defines our American way of life.

column1: Advertisement
We will learn more about the killer in the days to come. We know that he pledged allegiance to ISIS
column2: that they are now taking credit and that part of their strategy is to radicalize individuals and encourage attacks against the United States
column3: even if they are not coordinated with ISIS leadership. But there's a lot we still don't know
column4: including what other mix of motives drove him to kill.

column1: The more we learn about what happened
column2: the better we'll be able to protect our people going forward. In the days ahead
column3: we will also learn more about the many lives he viciously cut short
column4: many of them young people
column5: just starting out in their lives. They were travel agents and pharmacy techs
column6: college students and amusement park workers
column7: sons and daughters
column8: brothers and sisters
column9: and they had one thing in common. They all had a lot more to give.

column1: CLINTON: We should take a moment today amid our busy lives to think about them
column2: to pray for everyone who was killed
column3: for the wounded
column4: those who are fighting to regain their lives and futures
column5: for our first responders who walked into danger one more time. As a mother
column6: I can't imagine what those families are going through.

column1: Advertisement

But let's also remember the other scenes we saw on Sunday. We saw the faces of some of those first responders who rushed into danger and tried to save as many people as they could. We saw survivors like Chris Hansen who risked their lives to help others.
People gathering outside hospitals to comfort anxious family members
column2: waiting for news of their loved ones and waiting
column3: too
column4: to learn more about what they could do to make sure this never happened again.

column1: Religion leaders condemning hate and appealing for peace. People lining up to donate blood. Americans refusing to be intimidated or divided.

Yesterday I called Mayor Dyer of Orlando and offered my support and my appreciation for the leadership that he and the other officials have shown. This is a moment when all Americans need to stand together.
Advertisement
No matter how many times we endure attacks like this
column2: the horror never fades. The murder of innocent people breaks our hearts
column3: tears at our sense of security and makes us furious.

column1: Now we have to steal our resolve to respond. And that's what I want to talk to you about. How we respond.
The Orlando terrorist may be dead
column2: but the virus that poisoned his mind remains very much alive. And we must attack it with clear eyes
column3: steady hands
column4: unwavering determination and pride in our country and our values.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
I have no doubt -- I have no doubt we can meet this challenge if we meet it together. Whatever we learn about this killer
column2: his motives in the days ahead
column3: we know already the barbarity that we face from radical jihadists is profound.

column1: In the Middle East
column2: ISIS is attempting a genocide of religious and ethnic minorities. They are slaughtering Muslims who refuse to accept their medieval ways. They are beheading civilians
column3: including executing LGBT people. They are murdering Americans and Europeans
column4: enslaving
column5: torturing and raping women and girls.

column1: Advertisement
In speeches like this one
column2: after Paris
column3: Brussels and San Bernardino
column4: I have laid out a plan to defeat ISIS and the other radical jihadist groups in the region and beyond.

column1: The attack in Orlando makes it even more clear
column2: we cannot contain this threat. We must defeat it. And the good news is that the coalition effort in Syria and Iraq has made recent gains in the last months.

column1: So we should keep the pressure on ramping up the air campaign
column2: accelerating support for our friends fighting to take and hold ground and pushing our partners in the region to do even more.

column1: We also need continued American leadership to help resolve the political conflicts that fuel ISIS recruitment efforts.
But as ISIS loses actual ground in Iraq and Syria
column2: it will seek to stage more attacks and gain stronger footholds wherever it can
column3: from Afghanistan
column4: to Libya
column5: to Europe.

column1: Advertisement
The threat is metastasizing. We saw this in Paris. And we saw it in Brussels. We face a twisted ideology and poisoned psychology that inspires the so-called lone wolves
column2: radicalized individuals who may or may not have contact and direction from any formal organization.

column1: CLINTON: So
column2: yes
column3: efforts to defeat ISIS on the battlefield must succeed. But it will take more than that.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
Share this article Share
We have to be just as adaptable and versatile as our enemies. As president
column2: I will make identifying and stopping lone wolves a top priority.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
I will put a team together from across our government
column2: the entire government
column3: as well as the private sector and communities to get on top of this urgent challenge. And I will make sure our law enforcement and intelligence professionals have all the resources they need to get the job done.

column1: Advertisement
As we do this
column2: there are three areas that demand attention. First
column3: we and our allies must work hand-in-hand to dismantle the networks that move money
column4: and propaganda
column5: and arms and fighters around the world.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
We have to flow -- we have to stem the flow of jihadists from Europe and Iraq
column2: Syria
column3: Afghanistan and then back again. The only way to do this is by working closely with our partners
column4: strengthening our alliances
column5: not weakening them or walking away from them.

column1: Second
column2: here at home
column3: we must harden our own defenses. We have to do more to support our first responders
column4: law enforcement and intelligence officers who do incredible work every day at great personal risk to keep our country safe.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
I have seen firsthand how hard their job is
column2: and how well they do it.

column1: In Orlando
column2: at least one police officer was shot in the head. Thankfully
column3: his life was saved by a Kevlar helmet
column4: something folks here at Team Wendy know a lot about.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
It has often been said that our law enforcement
column2: our intelligence agencies
column3: our first responders have to be right 100 percent of the time
column4: but terrorists only have to be right once.

column1: What a heavy responsibility. These men and women deserve both our respect and gratitude. And they deserve the right tools
column2: and resources and training. Too often
column3: state and local officials can't get access to intelligence from the federal government that would help them do their jobs.

column1: We need to change that. We also need to work...
(APPLAUSE)
We also need to work with local law enforcement and business owners on ways to protect vulnerable
column2: so-called soft targets
column3: like nightclubs and shopping malls and hotels and movie theaters and schools and houses of worship.

column1: Now
column2: I know a lot of Americans are asking how it was possible that someone already on the FBI's radar could have still been able to commit an attack like the one in Orlando
column3: and what more we can do to stop this kind of thing from happening again.

column1: Well
column2: we have to see what the investigation uncovers. If there are things that can and should be done to improve our ability to prevent
column3: we must do them. We already know we need more resources for this fight. The professionals who keep us safe would be the first to say we need better intelligence to discover and disrupt terrorist plots before they can be carried out.

column1: That's why I have proposed an intelligence surge to bolster our capabilities across the board with appropriate safeguards here at home.
Even as we make sure our security officials get the tools they need to prevent attacks
column2: it's essential that we stop terrorists from getting the tools they need to carry out the attack.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
CLINTON: And that is especially true when it comes to assault weapons like those used in Orlando and San Bernardino.
(APPLAUSE)
I believe weapons of war have no place on our streets and we may have our disagreements about gun safety regulations
column2: but we should all be able to agree on a few essential things.

column1: If the FBI is watching you for a suspected terrorist link
column2: you shouldn't be able to just go buy a gun with no questions asked.

column1: And you shouldn't be able to exploit loopholes and evade criminal background checks by buying online or at a gun show.
And yes
column2: if you're too dangerous to get on a plane
column3: you are too dangerous to buy a gun in America.

column1: Now
column2: I know some will say that assault weapons and background checks are totally separate issues having nothing to do with terrorism. Well
column3: in Orlando and San Bernardino terrorists used assault weapons
column4: the AR-15. And they used it to kill Americans. That was the same assault weapon used to kill those little children in Sandy Hook.

column1: We have to make it harder for people who should not have those weapons of war. And that may not stop every shooting or every terrorist attack
column2: but it will stop some and it will save lives and it will protect our first responders.

column1: And I want you to know
column2: I'm not going to stop fighting for these kinds of provisions.

column1: Now
column2: the third area that demands attention is preventing radicalization and countering efforts by ISIS and other international terrorist networks to recruit in the United States and Europe.

column1: For starters
column2: it is long past time for the Saudis
column3: the Qataris and the Kuwaitis and others to stop their citizens from funding extremist organizations. And they should stop supporting radical schools and mosques around the world that have set too many young people on a path towards extremism.

column1: We also have to use all our capabilities to counter jihadist propaganda online. This is something that I spend a lot of time on at the State Department.
As president
column2: I will work with our great tech companies from Silicon Valley to Boston to step up our game. We have to a better job intercepting ISIS' communications
column3: tracking and analyzing social media posts and mapping jihadist networks
column4: as well as promoting credible voices who can provide alternatives to radicalization.

column1: And there is more to do offline as well.
CLINTON: Since 9/11
column2: law enforcement agencies have worked hard to build relationships with Muslim American communities. Millions of peace-loving Muslims live
column3: work and raise their families across America. And they are the most likely to recognize the insidious effects of radicalization before it's too late
column4: and the best positioned to help us block it. So we should be intensifying contacts in those communities
column5: not scapegoating or isolating them.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
Last year
column2: I visited a pilot program in Minneapolis that helps parents
column3: teachers
column4: imams
column5: mental health professionals and others recognize signs of radicalization in young people and work with law enforcement to intervene before it's too late.

column1: I've also met with local leaders pursuing innovative approaches in Los Angeles and other places. And we need more efforts like that in more cities across America. And as the director of the FBI has pointed out
column2: we should avoid eroding trust in that community
column3: which will only make law enforcement's job more difficult.

column1: Inflammatory anti-Muslim rhetoric and threatening to ban the families and friends of Muslim Americans as well as millions of Muslim business people and tourists from entering our country hurts the vast majority of Muslims who love freedom and hate terror.
(APPLAUSE)

So does saying that we have to start special surveillance on our fellow Americans because of their religion. It's no coincidence that hate crimes against American Muslims and mosques have tripled after Paris and San Bernardino. That's wrong. And it's also dangerous. It plays right into the terrorists' hands.
Still
column2: as I have said before
column3: none of us can close our eyes to the fact that we do face enemies who use their distorted version of Islam to justify slaughtering $ innocent people. They'd take us all back to the Stone Age if they could
column4: just as they have in parts of Iraq and Syria.

column1: The terrorist in Orlando targeted LGBT Americans out of hatred and bigotry. And an attack on any American is an attack on all Americans.
(APPLAUSE) And I want to say this to all the LGBT people grieving today in Florida and across our country. You have millions of allies who will always have your back.
(APPLAUSE)
And I am one of them.
(APPLAUSE)
From Stonewall to Laramie
column2: and now Orlando
column3: we've seen too many examples of how the struggle to live freely
column4: openly and without fear has been met by violence. We have to stand together
column5: be proud together. There is no better rebuke to the terrorists and all those who hate.

column1: Our open
column2: diverse society is an asset in the struggle against terrorism
column3: not a liability. It makes us stronger and more resistant to radicalization. And this raises a larger point about the future of our country.

column1: America is strongest when we all believe that we have a stake in our country and our future.
CLINTON: This vision has sustained us from the beginning. The belief that
column2: yes
column3: we are all created equal and the journey we have made to turn that into reality over the course of our history
column4: that we are not a land of winners and losers
column5: that we should all have the opportunity to live up to our God-given potential. And we have a responsibility to help others do so as well.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
As I look at American history
column2: I see that this has always been a country of ""we"" not ""me."" We stand together because we are stronger together. E pluribus unum. One -- out of many
column3: one -- has seen us through the darkest chapters of our history. Ever since 13 squabbling colonies put aside their disagreements and united because they realized they were going to rise together or fall separately
column4: generation after generation has fought and marched and organized to widen the circle of dignity and opportunity. Ending slavery. Securing and expanding the right to vote. Throwing open the doors of education. Building the greatest middle class the world has ever seen.

column1: And we are stronger when more people can participate in our democracy.
(APPLAUSE)
And we are stronger when everyone can share in the rewards of our economy and contribute to our communities
column2: when we bridge our divides and lift each other up instead of tearing each other down. Now we have overcome a lot together and we will overcome the threats of terror and radicalization and all of our other challenges. Here in Ohio and across America
column3: I've listened to people talk about the problems that keep you up at night.

column1: The bonds that hold us together as communities
column2: as one national community
column3: are strained by an economy with too much inequality and too little upward mobility. By social and political divisions that have diminished our trust in each other and our confidence in our shared future. I have heard that
column4: and I want you to know as your president I will work every day to break down all the barriers holding you back and keeping us apart. We're gonna get an economy that works for everyone
column5: not just those at the top
column6: we're gonna forge a new sense of connection and shared responsibility to each other and our nation.

column1: And finally
(APPLAUSE) finally let me remind us all
column2: I remember
column3: I remember how it felt
column4: on the day after 9/11
column5: and I bet many of you do as well. Americans from all walks of life rallied together with a sense of common purpose on September the 12th and in the days and weeks and months that followed. We had each others' backs. I was a senator from New York. There was a Republican president
column6: a Republican governor
column7: and a Republican mayor. We did not attack each other. We worked with each other to protect our country and to rebuild our city (ph).

column1: (APPLAUSE)

President Bush went to a Muslim community center just six days after the attacks to send a message of unity and solidarity. To anyone who wanted to take out their anger on our Muslim neighbors and fellow citizens
column2: he said
column3: ""That should not
column4: and that will not
column5: stand in America."" It is time to get back to the spirit of those days
column6: spirit of 9/12. Let's make sure we keep looking to the best of our country
column7: to the best within each of us. Democratic and Republican presidents have risen to the occasion in the face of tragedy. That is what we are called to do my friends and I am so confident and optimistic that is exactly what we will do.

column1: Thank you all so much."	0

column1: Thank you so much Charlie [Rangel]. Thanks for your friendship. Thanks for your leadership. The Congress will miss you when you leave its ranks
column2: but I have a feeling that you are going to be spending a lot of time right here in Harlem. Charlie didnÃ¢ÂÂt tell you the whole story.

column1: He was actually the person who called to encourage me to run for the Senate. He basically said that I had no choice. But it took me a long time before I realized he was right. HeÃ¢ÂÂs been a great friend and partner since then.
I want to tell you how special it is for me to be back here in Harlem to make this set of comments. I loved representing New York for eight years. And Harlem looms large in the American imagination
column2: as the birthplace of so much art and culture and such vibrant public life. ThereÃ¢ÂÂs really no place like it in the world.

column1: I appreciate being joined by the Governor [Cuomo] and Sandra

column3: by the former Attorney General
column4: Eric Holder
column5: Representative Yvette Clark
column6: and Representative Nydia VelÃÂ¡zquez

column10: Puerto Rican
column11: Hispanic and Asian caucus members and members of the New York City Council. The Black
column12: Latino
column13: and Asian Caucus: I thank you all so much for being here.

column1: I want to pick up on what I just said about Harlem
column2: because Harlem
column3: and many other communities across America
column4: remind us that any view of Black America that focuses exclusively on crime
column5: poverty
column6: or other challenges is missing so much. Missing the strength and the pride and the achievement that is evident on every street here.

column1: That narrative is missing the remarkable rise of the African American middle class
column2: the rise of African American Ã¢ÂÂ¦ leadership in all walks of life: in business
column3: law
column4: politics
column5: science
column6: the arts
column7: sports
column8: and all the professions. ItÃ¢ÂÂs missing the vibrancy of the black church
column9: the passionate advocacy of the next generation of changemakers
column10: and the service of leaders at every level
column11: who never tire of making othersÃ¢ÂÂ lives better.

column1: Earlier today
column2: I spent some time with the heads of nine of AmericaÃ¢ÂÂs historic civil rights groups
column3: hosted by Marc Morial of the National Urban League. Reverend Al Sharpton attended. And we had a great conversation
column4: because they are working to drive a 21st century agenda for jobs and freedom. I am grateful for their guidance and wisdom. I am also grateful to be speaking in this building that honors two men who represent just some of the diversity of the African American community.

column1: Arturo Schomburg
column2: who was from the Caribbean
column3: and Langston Hughes
column4: whose ashes are housed here
column5: reminded all of us that when life ainÃ¢ÂÂt no crystal stair
column6: youÃ¢ÂÂve got to keep climbing. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs a good lesson for everyone.

column1: But even as we acknowledge and even celebrate successes
column2: itÃ¢ÂÂs important to remember: There are still very real barriers holding back African Americans from fully participating in our society. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what I am here to talk about today.

column1: Last week on the debate stage in Milwaukee
column2: I said I want to tear down all the barriers that hold back Americans across racial lines
column3: because our country can only live up to its potential when every single American has the chance to live up to theirs. So I want to talk with you about how we break down the barriers that disproportionately affect African Americans and build ladders of opportunity in their place.

column1: Last week
column2: I went to Flint
column3: Michigan. By now
column4: we all know whatÃ¢ÂÂs happening there. Families
column5: children
column6: babies
column7: drinking poisoned water for nearly two years because their government wanted to save a little money. ItÃ¢ÂÂs a horrifying story
column8: but what makes it even worse is that itÃ¢ÂÂs not a coincidence that this was allowed to happen in a largely black
column9: largely poor community. Just ask yourself
column10: would this have ever occurred in a wealthy white suburb of Detroit? Absolutely not.

column1: And as we have learned more about this crisis
column2: weÃ¢ÂÂve seen other barriers holding back the people of Flint coming into clearer focus.

column1: Years of under-investment have left behind a hollowed out community without enough jobs or opportunity for the people living there. Not enough families have access to the quality education that their children deserve. And they have too little political power
column2: which left them vulnerable to a state government that ignored and dismissed their concerns.

column1: Just imagine Ã¢ÂÂ every one of you a parent
column2: a grandparent
column3: an aunt
column4: an uncle Ã¢ÂÂ going to the authorities holding a bottle of brown
column5: smelly water. Telling those in authority
column6: Ã¢ÂÂThereÃ¢ÂÂs something wrong with this water. My baby has a rash. I feel funny when I drink it or take a bath
column7: Ã¢ÂÂ and being told
column8: Ã¢ÂÂThereÃ¢ÂÂs nothing wrong with the water. Just go away.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: Flint is not alone. There are many Flints across our country: places where people of color and the poor have been left out and left behind.
Now
column2: in the contest for the Democratic nomination
column3: we have spent a lot of time debating about the big banks and the excesses of Wall Street
column4: and these are important issues. And I am absolutely committed to ensuring that no bank is too big to fail
column5: and no executive too powerful to jail.

column1: But Flint reminds us thereÃ¢ÂÂs a lot more going on in our country that we should be concerned about. The truth is we arenÃ¢ÂÂt a single-issue country. We face a complex set of economic
column2: social
column3: and political challenges.

column1: They are intersectional
column2: they are reinforcing
column3: and we have got to take them all on.

column1: So itÃ¢ÂÂs not enough for your economic plan to be
column2: Ã¢ÂÂbreak up the banks.Ã¢ÂÂ You also need a serious plan to create jobs
column3: especially in places where unemployment remains stubbornly high. You need a plan to address the generations of underinvestment and neglect.

column1: Now even if we succeed on raising taxes on every millionaire and billionaire in America Ã¢ÂÂ and believe me
column2: I do intend to succeed at that Ã¢ÂÂ we still need to face the painful reality that African Americans are nearly three times as likely as whites to be denied a mortgage. SomethingÃ¢ÂÂs wrong when the median wealth for black families is just a tiny fraction of the median wealth of white families.

column1: And when gun violence is by far the leading cause of death for young African American men
column2: outstripping the next nine causes of death combined
column3: there is something deeply wrong.

column1: Something is wrong when African American men are far more likely to be stopped and searched by police
column2: charged with crimes
column3: and sentenced to longer prison terms than white men convicted of the same offenses. And when black kids get arrested for petty crimes
column4: but white CEOÃ¢ÂÂs get away with fleecing our entire country
column5: there is something wrong.

column1: Just imagine with me
column2: for a minute
column3: if white kids were 500 percent more likely to die from asthma than black kids. Five hundred percent. Imagine if a white baby in South Carolina were twice as likely to die before her first birthday than an African American baby. Imagine the outcry. Imagine the resources that would flood in.

column1: Now
column2: these inequities are wrong Ã¢ÂÂ but theyÃ¢ÂÂre also immoral. And itÃ¢ÂÂll be the mission of my presidency to bring them to an end. We have to begin by facing up to the reality of systemic racism. Because these are not only problems of economic inequality.

column1: These are problems of racial inequality. And we have got to say that loudly and clearly.
Now
column2: I donÃ¢ÂÂt by any means intend to imply that we are not still making progress. We do have a lot to celebrate
column3: as Congressman Rangel said. The people in this room know that Ã¢ÂÂ you have helped to make it happen.

column1: And there is no better example of that progression than our president. And for all the partisan resistance President Obama has faced every day
column2: remember Ã¢ÂÂ and celebrate Ã¢ÂÂ he brought our economy back from the brink of another Great Depression. On his watch
column3: 14 million jobs have been created
column4: health care has been brought to 18 million people
column5: the auto industry was saved
column6: and so much else.

column1: Now
column2: he would be the first to say Ã¢ÂÂ as weÃ¢ÂÂve heard him say Ã¢ÂÂ that despite our best efforts and our highest hopes
column3: AmericaÃ¢ÂÂs long struggle with race is far from finished.

column1: For many white Americans
column2: itÃ¢ÂÂs tempting to believe that bigotry is largely behind us. That would leave us with a lot less work
column3: wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt it? But more than half a century after Rosa Parks sat and Dr. King marched and John Lewis bled
column4: race still plays a significant role in determining who gets ahead in America and who gets left behind.

column1: Now anyone Ã¢ÂÂ anyone Ã¢ÂÂ asking for your vote has a responsibility to grapple with this reality. To see things as they actually are
column2: not just as we want them to be.

column1: IÃ¢ÂÂd be the first to admit I donÃ¢ÂÂt have all the answers. IÃ¢ÂÂve made my own mistakes. IÃ¢ÂÂve walked my own journey. But I believe with all my heart we can and must do better. WeÃ¢ÂÂve made progress before
column2: which gives me hope we can do it again. In the 1990s
column3: economic programs like the new market tax credit
column4: the earned income tax credit
column5: and empowerment zones like the one right here in Harlem made a real difference in peopleÃ¢ÂÂs lives.

column1: They helped to create the highest increase in black incomes and the lowest black unemployment in history. We achieved record small-business lending to minority-owned businesses
column2: and record bank lending in minority communities. Right here in Harlem
column3: the unemployment rate dropped by two-thirds
column4: and we saw a drop in child poverty and an increase in employment and income for single mothers
column5: too.

column1: We also learned about what doesnÃ¢ÂÂt work. Some of what we tried didnÃ¢ÂÂt resolve problems. Some ended up creating new ones
column2: and caused disappointment
column3: frustration
column4: even anger. So as we face todayÃ¢ÂÂs challenges
column5: we have to bring all those lessons to bear.

column1: HereÃ¢ÂÂs the bottom line
column2: as I see it: When we make direct strategic investments in communities that have been left behind
column3: and when we guarantee justice and dignity to every American
column4: then we really can make progress. Lasting progress. Progress that will catapult us into the future. We can reduce poverty. We can build ladders of opportunity.

column1: So IÃ¢ÂÂm proposing a comprehensive new commitment to equity and opportunity for African American communities. That means a real plan to create jobs. If IÃ¢ÂÂm elected president
column2: we will direct hundreds of billions of dollars in new investments to places like Harlem and rural South Carolina Ã¢ÂÂ including $20 billion aimed specifically at creating jobs for young people.

column1: The unemployment rate among young African Americans is twice as high as for young white people. Now
column2: we need to get young people working
column3: developing their skills
column4: unlocking the full extent of the contributions they can make to themselves
column5: their families
column6: and our country. We need to make sure weÃ¢ÂÂre not only creating good jobs
column7: but connecting black communities to where the good jobs are.

column1: So weÃ¢ÂÂve got to be strategic about our investments in transit and infrastructure. And we need a real plan
column2: including expanding access to capital to support black entrepreneurs Ã¢ÂÂ especially black women
column3: who represent the fastest-growing segment of women-owned businesses in America. And while weÃ¢ÂÂre at it
column4: letÃ¢ÂÂs finally ensure equal pay for equal work for women.

column1: That would benefit women of color most of all
column2: and would lift up an awful lot of families. And letÃ¢ÂÂs go even further. LetÃ¢ÂÂs follow Governor CuomoÃ¢ÂÂs lead and raise the minimum wage to help people get out of poverty.

column1: Now we need to support African American homeownership
column2: which has always been one of the surest ways for black families to build wealth. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs why I have a plan that would
column3: among things
column4: help African American families save for a down payment.

column1: We need to make sure every family also has access to quality pre-school. And I applaud Mayor De Blasio for what heÃ¢ÂÂs achieved here in New York with his pre-K program.
And please
column2: help us reverse the dangerous slide towards re-segregation in our schools. Our schools are now more segregated than they were in 1968. That is appalling
column3: and weÃ¢ÂÂve got to fix it.

column1: We also have to make sure everyone who wants to go to college can afford to. And everyone with student debt can have that debt refinanced
column2: and take thousands of dollars off the burden that they are carrying!

column1: LetÃ¢ÂÂs give tax credits to businesses that actually invest in training and in apprenticeship programs to help young people who donÃ¢ÂÂt go for a two or four-year degree.
And my plan gives special support to historically black colleges and universities.
The HBCUs have produced some of the finest leaders in our country. And itÃ¢ÂÂs not just who they graduated in the past
column2: itÃ¢ÂÂs the work theyÃ¢ÂÂre still doing today Ã¢ÂÂ often against great odds.

column1: And then finally
column2: and so importantly
column3: we need end-to-end reform in our criminal justice system.

column1: Not half measures
column2: but a full commitment with real follow-through. Now
column3: this is something we can talk about for hours. In fact
column4: I gave my first speech of this campaign in April not far from here
column5: and it was about reforming criminal justice. Because the inequities that persist in our justice system undermine our shared vision of what America can Ã¢ÂÂ and should Ã¢ÂÂ be.

column1: Our legal system is still
column2: all too often
column3: stacked against those who have the least power
column4: who are the most vulnerable. And weÃ¢ÂÂve seen the toll it takes on families torn apart by excessive incarceration
column5: and children growing up in homes shattered by prison and poverty.

column1: WeÃ¢ÂÂve got to get back to that fundamental principle that everyone
column2: in every community
column3: benefits when there is respect for the law Ã¢ÂÂ and when everyone is respected by the law. That is the formula for building trust and cooperation
column4: and we need to not only acknowledge but fix the crisis of mass incarceration.

column1: LetÃ¢ÂÂs finally
column2: once and for all
column3: eliminate the remaining disparity in sentencing between crack and powder cocaine. LetÃ¢ÂÂs rebuild the bonds of trust between law enforcement and communities by creating more opportunities for people to actually interact with one another
column4: to build relationships.

column1: LetÃ¢ÂÂs the end the epidemic of African Americans being killed by police or dying in custody.
Now I think you know Ã¢ÂÂ because I sure believe Ã¢ÂÂ there are many police officers out there every day inspiring trust and confidence
column2: putting themselves on the line to save lives. So letÃ¢ÂÂs learn from those who are doing it right
column3: and apply those lessons across the country.

column1: LetÃ¢ÂÂs make sure the Justice Department has the resources to hold departments Ã¢ÂÂ like FergusonÃ¢ÂÂs Ã¢ÂÂ accountable when they do it wrong.
Again and again
column2: something terrible happens Ã¢ÂÂ and no one is held accountable; the deeply troubling pattern
column3: and weÃ¢ÂÂve got to break it. WeÃ¢ÂÂve also got to do a much better job of helping people who have paid their debt to society find jobs and support when they get out.

column1: Up to 60 percent of prisoners who re-enter society face long-term unemployment. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs a recipe for hopelessness and repeat offending. My jobs plan would make significant investments in re-entry programs for the formerly incarcerated.
In my faith
column2: we believe in second chances. In America
column3: we believe in second chances. LetÃ¢ÂÂs give those chances to people who need our help the most. LetÃ¢ÂÂs give them a fair shot Ã¢ÂÂ which is also why I will Ã¢ÂÂban the boxÃ¢ÂÂ in the federal government. And I want to thank Attorney General Holder
column4: who has been really in the forefront of making so many of these changes happen. And I also want to thank another great New Yorker
column5: Attorney General Loretta Lynch
column6: who is continuing the work for equity and justice!

column1: And letÃ¢ÂÂs roll up our sleeves and get to work to dismantle the school-to-prison pipeline. ItÃ¢ÂÂs diverting too many African-American kids into the criminal justice system
column2: instead of giving them the education they deserve.

column1: WeÃ¢ÂÂve seen a significant increase in police involvement in school discipline
column2: especially in schools with majority-black students. WeÃ¢ÂÂre seeing an over-reliance on suspensions and expulsions. IÃ¢ÂÂm sure many of us remember that horrifying video of the girl in South Carolina being thrown out of her desk and dragged across her classroom by a school police officer.

column1: A classroom should be a safe place for our children. We shouldnÃ¢ÂÂt even have to say that
column2: I donÃ¢ÂÂt think.

column1: So today IÃ¢ÂÂm announcing my plan to end the school to prison pipeline. It includes major investments in school districts that reform their discipline practices. We want districts to know
column2: if they do the right thing
column3: weÃ¢ÂÂll have their backs. And we will dramatically expand support for guidance counselors
column4: school psychologists and social workers Ã¢ÂÂ so instead of just labeling kids problem students
column5: they can actually help kids with their problems
column6: and keep them in school!

column1: And for schools that refuse to reform and states that refuse to take this issue seriously
column2: I want the Department of EducationÃ¢ÂÂs Office of Civil Rights to intervene
column3: because this Ã¢ÂÂ this is not just an education issue
column4: this is a civil rights issue and we cannot ignore it any longer.

column1: The bottom line is this: We need to be sending our kids to college. We need a cradle-to-college pipeline
column2: not sending them into court and into prison.

column1: ThereÃ¢ÂÂs much more to do. If you go to my website
column2: hillaryclinton.com
column3: you can read our full agenda.

column1: Sometimes people make fun of me because I actually tell you what I want to do as president. I actually give you plans about what I want to do. I kind of think itÃ¢ÂÂs my duty to help inform voters
column2: so that you can make a good decision!

column1: But I want to mention one more critical area: Protecting that most fundamental of rights Ã¢ÂÂ the right to vote. Across our country
column2: Republican governors and legislatures are erecting one barrier after another that make it harder for black people to vote. ItÃ¢ÂÂs a blast from the Jim Crow past
column3: and we need to call it for what it is.

column1: And in the past few days the stakes got even higher. Justice ScaliaÃ¢ÂÂs passing means the court hangs in the balance. Now the Republicans say theyÃ¢ÂÂll reject anyone President Obama nominates
column2: no matter how qualified. Some are even saying he doesnÃ¢ÂÂt have the right to nominate anyone
column3: as if somehow heÃ¢ÂÂs not the real president.

column1: ThatÃ¢ÂÂs in keeping with what weÃ¢ÂÂve heard all along
column2: isnÃ¢ÂÂt it? Many Republicans talk in coded
column3: racial language about takers and losers. They demonize President Obama and encourage the ugliest impulses of the paranoid fringe. This kind of hatred and bigotry has no place in our politics Ã¢ÂÂ or our country.

column1: The president has the right to nominate
column2: under the Constitution
column3: and the Senate has the obligation to process that nomination. And I hope the Senate will start paying more attention to statesmanship than partisanship. And I hope that they will understand that we can have our differences
column4: but letÃ¢ÂÂs not go right after fundamental rules of how we govern ourselves. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs a bridge way too far
column5: my friends.

column1: Now
column2: I will appoint Supreme Court justices who will see the Constitution as a blueprint for progress
column3: not as an excuse to try to roll back decisions going all the way back to Teddy Roosevelt Ã¢ÂÂ which is apparently what some of them would prefer to do!

column1: Now I suppose some people will hear what IÃ¢ÂÂm proposing and think
column2: Ã¢ÂÂWell
column3: sheÃ¢ÂÂs saying this because sheÃ¢ÂÂs in an election.Ã¢ÂÂ But many of you in this audience know me
column4: and you know that these issues have always been part of my North Star.

column1: In my first semester at law school
column2: a woman named Marian Wright Edelman came to speak on campus at Yale. She was the first African American woman admitted to the Mississippi bar
column3: a lawyer for the NAACP in Jackson
column4: a friend of Dr. King before he was murdered Ã¢ÂÂ altogether a remarkable person. She talked about starting a Head Start program in Mississippi and using her legal education on behalf of poor children who were invisible to the rest of the country.

column1: Something clicked in my brain that day. Until I heard Marian speak
column2: it wasnÃ¢ÂÂt clear to me how to channel my faith and commitment to social justice to try to make a real difference in the world. But she put me on the path of service.

column1: I went to work for her at the ChildrenÃ¢ÂÂs Defense Fund. She sent me to her home state of South Carolina to take on the problem of black teenagers who were being incarcerated along with adults. And when I look back
column2: everything else IÃ¢ÂÂve done Ã¢ÂÂ whether it was going undercover to Alabama to expose segregated academies and try to skip them of their tax exemptions
column3: or running a legal clinic at the University of Arkansas
column4: to represent inmates Ã¢ÂÂ thatÃ¢ÂÂs been part of my mission. Representing poor people through the Legal Services Corporation: ItÃ¢ÂÂs about making peopleÃ¢ÂÂs lives better.

column1: And it taught me that
column2: even if youÃ¢ÂÂre young and you donÃ¢ÂÂt have a powerful job
column3: if you work at it and you stick with it
column4: you can make a difference.

column1: Ã¢ÂÂ¦ You know
column2: to quote Dr. King
column3: the time is always right to do right Ã¢ÂÂ no matter who you are. And when I had the great privilege of representing New York
column4: I worked with members of our congressional delegation. We fought to bring investments and jobs to neighborhoods that needed them
column5: to improve health care
column6: to get cleaner air and water for low-income communities.

column1: One of the highlights was partnering with the organization
column2: One Hundred Black Men
column3: to create the Eagle Academy
column4: which has been so successful Ã¢ÂÂ itÃ¢ÂÂs grown to six schools now in New York Ã¢ÂÂ taking young African American and Latino men.

column1: There was always something to be done
column2: and I had so many partners here in New York. We championed reforms to probation and drug diversion programs. We promoted specialized drug courts and juvenile programs
column3: coming full circle with the work that I had done for Marion.

column1: So when I decided to run for president
column2: I knew these issues had to be at the heart of my campaign. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs where theyÃ¢ÂÂve always been
column3: thatÃ¢ÂÂs where they will always be.

column1: And I want to add something else: We Democrats have a special obligation: If weÃ¢ÂÂre serious about our commitment to the poor
column2: to those who need some help
column3: including African Americans
column4: if we continue to ask black people to vote for us
column5: we cannot minimize the realities of the lives they lead or take their concerns for granted.

column1: You know
column2: you canÃ¢ÂÂt just show up at election time and say the right things and think thatÃ¢ÂÂs enough. We canÃ¢ÂÂt start building relationships a few weeks before a vote. We have to demonstrate a sustained commitment to building opportunity
column3: creating prosperity
column4: and righting wrongs. Not just every two or four years
column5: not just when the cameras are on and people are watching
column6: but every single day.

column1: So hereÃ¢ÂÂs what I ask of you: Hold me accountable. Hold every candidate accountable. What we say matters Ã¢ÂÂ but what we do matters more. And you deserve leaders who will do whatever it takes to tear down all the barriers holding you back
column2: and then replace them with those ladders of opportunities that every American deserves to have.

column1: IÃ¢ÂÂm also asking all Americans to join in that effort. As Cornell Brooks
column2: the new head of the NAACP
column3: said in our meeting this morning: None of this is a Ã¢ÂÂtheyÃ¢ÂÂ problem. ItÃ¢ÂÂs a Ã¢ÂÂweÃ¢ÂÂ problem
column4: and all of us have to admit that. And you know what? It is not an urban problem. ItÃ¢ÂÂs an American problem.

column1: Ending systemic racism requires contributions from all of us Ã¢ÂÂ especially those of us who havenÃ¢ÂÂt experienced it ourselves. White Americans need to do a better job of listening when African Americans talk about the seen and unseen barriers that you face every day.
We need to recognize our privilege and practice humility
column2: rather than assume that our experiences are everyoneÃ¢ÂÂs experiences. All of us need to bring our skills to bare Ã¢ÂÂ and especially young people coming up today
column3: who have a passion for social justice and are helping to create new ways to solve intractable problems.

column1: And we all need to try as best we can to walk in one anotherÃ¢ÂÂs shoes. Imagine what it would be like to sit our son or daughter down and have the talk. Or if people followed us around stores or locked our car doors whenever we walked past.
That kind of empathy is critical. ItÃ¢ÂÂs what makes it possible for people from every background
column2: every race
column3: every religion to come together in this great city
column4: and to come together as one nation. ItÃ¢ÂÂs what makes a country like America endure.

column1: You know
column2: I started my remarks by talking about Flint. IÃ¢ÂÂm going to keep talking about Flint until the families there get the help they need Ã¢ÂÂ for as long as it takes.

column1: But thereÃ¢ÂÂs another side to the story of this tragedy.
ItÃ¢ÂÂs the story of hundreds of union plumbers from across the country travelling to Flint to install water filters for free.
ItÃ¢ÂÂs students at universities all over the Midwest raising funds for water deliveries and student athletes showing up in Flint to distribute supplies.
ItÃ¢ÂÂs the United Auto Workers and General Motors donating millions.
ItÃ¢ÂÂs money pouring in to organizations where people are donating
column2: if you wish
column3: to try and help the kids and the people of Flint. And IÃ¢ÂÂm grateful to everyone who has responded to our request sent out to our campaign.

column1: And itÃ¢ÂÂs the story of that kindergartner in Wilton
column2: NH who lost his first tooth just a few days ago. The tooth fairy left him five dollars. I got a dime
column3: I donÃ¢ÂÂt know about you.

column1: And he said to his mother
column2: Ã¢ÂÂI want to give it so those little kids can have water.Ã¢ÂÂ His mom sat right down and wrote me a letter about it.

column1: To me
column2: thatÃ¢ÂÂs the best of America
column3: and it keeps me going. That sense we are all in this together. We all have vital contributions to make
column4: and that when we come together Ã¢ÂÂ all of us Ã¢ÂÂ with a sense of shared purpose and shared humanity
column5: we can solve any problem we face.

column1: And we can heal any divide. We can build a future that is far
column2: far better than our past. That is my hope for our country
column3: that is my goal for this election
column4: and I promise to keep fighting right alongside all of you
column5: every day
column6: to make the United States a place where all men and all women are treated as equals Ã¢ÂÂ just as we are
column7: just as we deserve to be.

column1: That is my hope for America.
Thank you all very much."	0

column1: Aired March 21
THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.
CROWLEY: Normally
column2: on Sundays
column3: we take a reflective look at the past week and set the agenda for the coming days
column4: but today is no normal Sunday. We are four hours away from a showdown in the House of Representatives
column5: a series of votes that will determine the future of health care reform
column6: impact the economy
column7: influence this November's election and set the stage for the rest of President Obama's agenda. Today is no normal Sunday. Today is game day. I am Candy Crowley and this is State of the Union.

column1: This morning
column2: health reform from all angles. Two House leaders
column3: John Larson and Mike Pence
column4: on today's vote. Two senior senators
column5: Dianne Feinstein
column6: and Orrin Hatch
column7: on the week ahead. And analysis from Donna Brazile and Bill Bennett.

column1: We have heard the words ""end game"" so many times in this health care debate
column2: I wouldn't try it now. That said
column3: it would in fact be the end if Republicans prevailed in today's vote. For Democrats
column4: the magic number is 216. That's how many yeas needed to pass the health care bill in the House
column5: 216 votes among the 253 Democratic members. It has been a struggle all week to get there. We begin with seven days in two minutes.

column3: this bill would be long gone.

CROWLEY: Here to look ahead to today's vote and the high stakes politics surrounding it
column2: House Democratic Caucus Chairman
column3: John Larson of Connecticut
column4: and the House Republican Conference Chairman Mike Pence of Indiana. Gentlemen
column5: thank you both for joining me.

column1: PENCE: Thank you
column2: Candy.

column1: LARSON: Great to be with you
column2: Candy.

column1: CROWLEY: State of play
column2: where are you? 216
column3: do you have it locked in?

column1: LARSON: This is a historic day. And we are happy warriors. We are so proud of the Democratic caucus
column2: that we will be a part of history
column3: joining Franklin Delano Roosevelt's passage of Social Security
column4: Lyndon Johnson's passage of Medicare
column5: and now Barack Obama's passage of health care reform.

column1: CROWLEY: So you have got the 216?
LARSON: We've got the votes. And the reason for that
column2: Candy
column3: I think it started earlier this week with Natoma Canfield becoming the poster child for -- or lady for health care reform. And that struck such a cord within our caucus. And Dennis Moore standing up to give a speech in the caucus was Blackberried by a woman who works with him in Kansas. She said thank you for voting for this. I know I am losing my job at the end of this year
column4: and unfortunately
column5: I have just been diagnosed with cancer. Without this bill
column6: I'm lost. Dennis ended by saying
column7: and she is 24. You could have heard a pin drop.

column1: This is about whose side you are on. And clearly
column2: this historic moment in the people's chamber
column3: we are on the side of the American people and those that have been denied access to health care
column4: and those who have pre-existing conditions who have been denied
column5: and those who have had their policies rescinded.

column2: I think that puts you on the side not of the people
column3: if we take his calculation. What is left for Republicans to do? Congressman Larson says they have the 216. So it is all over but the shouting? You guys vote no and move on?

column1: PENCE: Well
column2: I don't know if they have the votes. House Republicans are going to use every means at our disposal.

PENCE: Well
column2: stay tuned
column3: Candy. It's going to be an interesting day.
