column1: PENCE: We are going to use every means at our disposal to oppose this government takeover of health care. Because quite frankly
column2: as thousands gather at rallies all across this country and here in the nation's capital
column3: yesterday
column4: you know
column5: the American people are sick and tired of runaway federal spending by both parties
column6: of borrowing and bailouts and takeovers. And I believe this is going to be a historic weekend.

column1: LARSON: It is.

PENCE: But I think it is going to be different from the way John thinks it is going to be. I think this is going to be a historic weekend because I think this weekend is going to be the beginning of the end of business as usual in Washington
column2: D.C. I think the American people see an administration and see a Congress that are in a headlong rush to confront the very real challenges that we have in health care with more government instead of more freedom.

column1: They know -- the Republicans have been offering solutions from the beginning. Let people purchase health insurance across state lines
column2: pass malpractice reform
column3: cover preexisting conditions. All of that can be done without a massive
column4: trillion-dollar expansion of the federal government and burdening future generations with more deficits and more debt.

column1: CROWLEY: But the reality of this day is that you don't have the votes to stop it. You may have the means to delay it. PENCE: Right. You know
column2: the Republicans
column3: it shouldn't be a news flash to anybody
column4: Republicans don't have the votes to stop anything in the House of Representatives. We are in a decisive minority.

column1: CROWLEY: (inaudible) politically.
PENCE: But what's remarkable about this one-year debate has proven my point
column2: that a minority in Congress plus the American people equals a majority. Republicans -- the reason they weren't able to do this last year -- remember all the deadlines? We had deadlines in the summer
column3: we had deadlines in the fall
column4: we had deadlines at the end of the year. The American people don't want this government takeover of health care. And I don't know if they have the votes today
column5: but I guarantee you
column6: the American people know they have the votes in America.

column1: LARSON: The American people who are already on Medicare
column2: all of our veterans who already receive Tricare
column3: understand the importance and the value of having insurance coverage. For 47 million Americans who have none
column4: 31 million will now be able to have access to insurance
column5: lowering costs
column6: lowering costs for small businesses
column7: lowering the national debt. First
column8: $138 billion
column9: and then $1.2 trillion. We can't afford not to do this. And taking care of those people--

column1: (CROSSTALK)
CROWLEY: I want to talk about the debt. Hang on one second. I have got to take a small break--
(CROSSTALK)
CROWLEY: We will come back. I do want to talk about the costs. There are some figures out there floating. I'll do that
column2: we'll be back with Congressmen Larson and Pence right after this.

column1: (COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CROWLEY: We are back with Democratic Congressman John Larson of Connecticut and Republican Congressman Mike Pence of Indiana. We were talking about the cost of this. The CBO has said over 10 years this health care bill will reduce the deficit by $143 billion.
However
column2: that doesn't include what might come and what has been promised
column3: with more than a wink and a nod to doctors
column4: which is to up their Medicare payments
column5: their reimbursements
column6: which would cost $208 million
column7: which then means it actually would be -- would add to the deficit.

column1: Is that -- is my math correct there? LARSON: Well
column2: if that were to be true. But here is the thing
column3: there is no question about the fact that we need to take care of the docs and we need to emphasize primary care. But also what never gets discussed
column4: Candy
column5: is something that Reuters came out with earlier this year
column6: $700 billion annually in inefficiencies in this system
column7: lack of interoperability in hospitals
column8: lack of a continuum of care
column9: and fraud and abuse -- $700 billion.

column1: I think that we're going to -- that's $7 trillion over a 10-year period. I think that we're more than going to be able to wring out the cost in there. I think that's why the president brought people down to Washington
column2: to the White House
column3: that's why he brought the six (ph) in to try to wring out those costs as we go forward.

column1: You know
column2: we spend 20 percent of gross domestic product. The closest country to us is Switzerland. I can't believe that we can't get that money out of there.

column1: CROWLEY: Can't we get that money out of there?
PENCE: Yes
column2: yes
column3: we do such a great job here in Washington wringing out the cost.

column1: LARSON: Now that's in the private sector.
PENCE: One-point-six trillion dollar deficit this year
column2: you know
column3: only in Washington D.C. could you say with a straight face that you are going to spend $1 trillion and save tax-payers money. Look
column4: you point out the doc fix. This is a total fraud. The Democrats are leaving out $200 billion in spending that the speaker of the house committed again this week to spend
column5: which makes this -- even using this CBO's numbers
column6: it makes it a bill that adds to the deficit in the short term and in the long term.

column1: But look
column2: even beyond that
column3: Candy
column4: the American people know that you expand the federal government's role in health care without giving the American people more health care choices by purchasing across state lines
column5: without passing any medical malpractice reform at all -- roughly a third of health care costs in this country I hear are actually defensive medicine driven by junk lawsuits.

column1: The American people know this is going to cost more and add more to the deficit
column2: add more to the debt
column3: cost higher taxes even than the rosiest scenarios that are presented...

column1: LARSON: The CBO is the bible. The CBO says...
CROWLEY: It is
column2: but it's not always accurate
column3: as you know.

column1: LARSON: We have arguments with them all of the time
column2: but...

column1: CROWLEY: Somebody once told me that predicting...
LARSON: ... that's all that we can -- that's all that we can vote on.
CROWLEY: Sure
column2: absolutely. But it still is one of those things that we might not find out...

column1: PENCE: And the president...
CROWLEY: ... except for 10 years from now.
LARSON: And the president has put in numerous reforms that are going to take effect
column2: including the inability to rescind your insurance policy
column3: pre-existing conditions. For women across this country
column4: Candy
column5: I mean
column6: there birth is a pre-existing condition
column7: domestic violence is a pre-existing condition
column8: a C-section is a pre- existing condition
column9: in-vitro fertilization
column10: come on.

column1: (CROSSTALK)
PENCE: My wife had to -- John
column2: my wife had a pre-existing condition. I lost my job about 15 years ago. My wife had a pre- existing condition. She was pregnant with our daughter Audrey. We went to the state guarantee fund
column3: a fund that would be replenished if we passed medical malpractice reform
column4: we could use the savings to strengthen those funds to cover people like my wife was covered.

column1: You don't need a government takeover of health care. You don't need to mandate that every American purchase health insurance whether they want it or need it or not
column2: and you don't need to put us on a pathway towards socialized medicine.

column1: LARSON: Where is the takeover by the government?
PENCE: And that's what this crowd is doing today.
LARSON: Where is the takeover by the government? CROWLEY: Let me ask you something
column2: just turn...

column1: LARSON: Humana runs Medicare currently. Tricare is run by them. Where is the takeover of government?
PENCE: Well
column2: I'll break it down. John
column3: if you mandate that every American purchase health insurance
column4: you mandate that every business provide it...

column1: LARSON: Do we mandate that people get car insurance?
PENCE: ... you create a...
(CROSSTALK)
PENCE: ... so that people end up in government-run insurance
column2: and you provide public funding for abortion
column3: you mandate insurance plans
column4: cover it within the exchange...

column1: LARSON: There is no funding for abortion in this bill.
PENCE: It is a government takeover of health care.
LARSON: There is no funding for abortion in this bill. It follows Hyde. That's not -- that's the case. PENCE: John
column2: you know that is not true. The Catholic Church...

column1: LARSON: I know it's absolutely true.
PENCE: ... the Catholic bishops
column2: the right to life says...

column1: LARSON: Sixty thousand nuns can't be wrong.
PENCE: ... public funding for abortions is in this bill.
LARSON: Thank God for the sisters of Notre Dame
column2: that's what I think.

column1: CROWLEY: Let me call a time here
column2: because we are out of time. But for more of this
column3: our audience can tune into the House debate starting this afternoon. And I suspect that pass or not pass
column4: this debate continues as we watch how it goes.

column1: LARSON: That's right. Very strong disagreements. But Mike Pence is an honorable man. And I look forward to this debate
column2: and as are our colleagues. I hope that we do ratchet down the conversation though
column3: because when two of our colleagues are spat on and hurled racial slurs
column4: it is time...

column1: CROWLEY: It did indeed happen.
LARSON: ... it's time to ratchet down things a little bit.
PENCE: Well
column2: I'll tell you
column3: I was in Selma with John Lewis
column4: if what is reported to have happened was reported is contemptible
column5: I denounce it in the strongest terms. But I assure you
column6: this debate will not end today.

column1: LARSON: I agree with that.
CROWLEY: Or probably on this show.
LARSON: I agree with that.
CROWLEY: Thank you very much
column2: I appreciate it.

column1: LARSON: There is going to be a lot of work to go to...
CROWLEY: If health care reform wins passage in the House today
column2: the measure heads back to the Senate. Up next
column3: a quick tutorial on what happens next. And then a conversation with Democratic Senator Dianne Feinstein and Republican Senator Orrin Hatch.

column1: (COMMERCIAL BREAK)
CROWLEY: A quick reality check for those who today's House votes will bring us to the finish line
column2: not quite
column3: not yet. If House Democrats muster the votes today
column4: two things happen. First the Senate version of health care reform will be passed by the House and will then be ready for the president to sign into law. Second
column5: House Democrats will pass a fix-it bill
column6: a companion measure of sorts to correct the things they don't like about the Senate measure. That bill has to go to the Senate. If the Senate goes the easy route
column7: they will pass the fixes without change and send it off to the president. But if the Senate changes anything
column8: if it adds or subtracts from the House measure
column9: it must go back to the House for another vote before it goes to the president.

column1: Senate Republicans have some options which could delay or change the bill
column2: including parliamentary challenges to any part of it as unrelated to the budget. Why didn't the ""Schoolhouse Rock"" teach us about this? We will do our best to get answers on what comes next from senators Orrin Hatch and Dianne Feinstein right after the break.

column1: (COMMERCIAL BREAK)
CROWLEY: As we explained
column2: even if the health care reform bill wins passage in the House later today
column3: it still has another legislative hurdle to clear
column4: back to the Senate for those changes or fixes
column5: if you will
column6: that House Democrats want.

column1: Joining us
column2: Democratic Senator Dianne Feinstein of California and Republican Senator Orrin Hatch of Utah.

column1: So the other day I noticed
column2: Senator Hatch
column3: that you said it would be nuts for anyone to believe that this is the House's last word on this. You think the Senate will change the fix-it bill that's coming over to you?

column1: HATCH: Well
column2: if the rules are followed
column3: they'd have to. Because there is a Social Security component. And you can't do that on reconciliation. There's also an appropriations component as well.

column1: So if -- if the parliamentarian upholds that and Joe Biden doesn't overrule the parliamentarian
column2: which would be a first
column3: then it seems to me that it's going to have to be sent back to the House. So anybody that thinks that this is only going to be a one-time deal today in the House
column4: I think
column5: is grossly mistaken.

column1: CROWLEY: Senator Feinstein
column2: do you think it's possible for the Senate to take that bill and just go
column3: OK
column4: fine with us?

column1: FEINSTEIN: Yes
column2: I do. And I think that's exactly what we'll do. And I really disagree with my friend and colleague. I believe there are at least 51 votes there. I think the bill has been carefully vetted with the parliamentarian. I believe he will stand for each part of it.

column1: And the bill that the House passes today goes to the president. He signs it. Then the reconciliation bill comes over to us. We'll probably begin debate on Tuesday. It will be posted -- it takes some time -- begin debate on Tuesday.
Now
column2: I'm sure what Senator Hatch's party will do is submit a whole host of amendments. We'll have a major vote-a-thon. And this will go on for several days. And I believe
column3: at the end
column4: more than 51 Democrats will hold firm and will pass the reconciliation bill and we will have health care reform. I can say
column5: for my state
column6: the reconciliation bill is very important. Because we have now 8 million people without any insurance in California. The number has gone up 1 million people a year for the last two years. So this bill is necessary.

column1: CROWLEY: Senator Hatch
column2: I want to ask you about the vote-a-thon
column3: but I first want to play something Senator Reid said recently.

column1: (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
SEN. HARRY REID
column2: D-NEV.
column3: SENATE MAJORITY LEADER: We're in the last minute of play. The shot clock is turned off. The other side knows what the outcome will be. So they're trying to foul us and foul us and foul us and foul us again
column4: just to keep the clock from reading zero. They're not just delaying the inevitable; they're delaying the imperative.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
CROWLEY: Are you going on after -- after the shot clock has...
(LAUGHTER)
I mean
column2: you know
column3: Senator Feinstein calls it a vote-a-thon. I mean
column4: is this the Republican approach to this now
column5: is just to delay the inevitable?

column1: HATCH: Well
column2: not really. I think it's to try and get amendments passed that really are valid amendments. I think
column3: if you have a Social Security component in it
column4: it has -- it has to come back to the House. And a parliamentarian has to rule the right way.

column1: But who knows? I don't know what the parliamentarian is going to do. All I can say is this. You know
column2: as I walk around this country
column3: and I've been all over the country
column4: people come up to me from everywhere
column5: Democrats
column6: Republicans
column7: saying
column8: we can't afford this; we can't do this. We do not even have solid
column9: final scoring on this.

column1: As a matter of fact
column2: the actuary at CMS said he cannot get the final scoring. They also don't include the doc fix in it
column3: which is $371 billion
column4: and that's at present worth. And that doesn't even take care of Medicaid.

column1: Of the 31 million people you're going to cover
column2: 16 million are pushed into Medicaid.

column1: I mean
column2: let me just tell you
column3: we're coming to a Europeanization of America. And the American people sense it. They feel it. They know that we can't afford this.

column1: And
column2: frankly
column3: the doc fix that they have on Medicaid...

column1: (CROSSTALK) HATCH: He's a letter -- here's a letter from my governor saying -- now
column2: for two years
column3: they say they'll hold the states free. But then you go off the clip because they cannot afford to pay for it in the federal government.

column1: And -- and Medicaid
column2: they're paying -- the doctors are getting 66 percent of what the private sector pays doctors. And they're up in arms. They're not going to take patients now. You can imagine how bad this is going to be if this bill goes through.

column1: CROWLEY: Senator Feinstein
column2: do you worry about either unintended consequences or changes in the economy that could
column3: in the end
column4: if this is made into law
column5: really ruin some aspects of health care?

column1: FEINSTEIN: Well
column2: of course. This isn't the perfect bill. We all know that.

column1: HATCH: Well
column2: that's for sure.

column1: FEINSTEIN: We all know that there are going to have to be fixes down the road
column2: just as every major program has had; Medicare has had; Social Security will likely have because of the explosion of costs.

column1: Having said that
column2: you have to look at the basics. And the basics are that we pay far more than European nations do for health care. And they have a much better performance.

column1: We're about 15 percent; France is 10 percent. And in overall performance by the World Health Organization
column2: France is ranked number one. I think we're ranked 17.

column1: We spend a lot of money
column2: but we don't necessarily spend it in the right way or the right places.

column1: Now
column2: let me just finish. This bill is really important. Because
column3: if we don't pass it now
column4: you can forget health care reform forever after
column5: I believe. So this is the opportunity. We're right at the goal line. I believe it's going to pass the House. It will be signed by the president. We should pass a reconciliation bill.

column1: And I would really appeal to my good friend
column2: Senator Hatch. Let this reconciliation bill get passed. Then
column3: you can see. If it's wrong
column4: you'll certainly say so. If it works
column5: hopefully
column6: you'll say so as well.

column1: CROWLEY: And we'll get your answer right after this
column2: because I've got to take a break. And we'll find out if you listened to her appeal
column3: right after this.

column1: (COMMERCIAL BREAK)
CROWLEY: We are back with two top senators
column2: Democrat Dianne Feinstein and Republican Orrin Hatch.

column1: When last we met
column2: she was asking if you would just let this reconciliation bill go through and see what happens. FEINSTEIN: Suggesting.

column1: (LAUGHTER)
HATCH: Well
column2: let me tell you
column3: Republicans are dedicated against this bill. We consider it an awful bill.

column1: Do you realize they're going to subsidize families that make over -- families of four that make over $80
column2: 000 a year?

column1: I mean
column2: we're getting to where 50 percent of the people in this country are going to depend on subsidies. And
column3: of course
column4: I know Dianne can't agree with that or doesn't believe in that.

column1: But -- and all I can say is -- is
column2: everywhere I go
column3: people say
column4: how do we pay for this? You know
column5: in all honesty
column6: they have jacked up the costs of Medicare. They're going to take better than $500 billion
column7: now
column8: out of Medicare. They're going to increase taxes by over $500 billion. They're going to sock it to individuals who don't -- who can't afford to buy insurance. They're going to have to pay 2.5 percent of their gross income.

column1: Businesses are now going to have to pay up to $3
column2: 000 per employee if they don't provide health insurance.

column1: You reach a point where you say
column2: who is going to pay for all of this? And it's going to come down to us taxpayers. And like I say
column3: it's the Europeanization of America
column4: and that's the worst thing that could possibly happen to our country.

column1: CROWLEY: You -- you said earlier that
column2: of course
column3: there were things that worried you about the bill. If you looked at in the totality
column4: what worries you the most?

column1: Is there anything that he says that you think
column2: you know
column3: yes
column4: that is a worry of mine?

column1: FEINSTEIN: Well
column2: there -- the bill is a combination of a number of different things designed to cover more people. The bill has very big strong points. For example
column3: right away
column4: there's a $5 billion fund for people with pre-existing conditions who can't get health insurance today.

column1: HATCH: We're both for that. We're both for that.
FEINSTEIN: That's a very positive thing.
HATCH: Sure.
FEINSTEIN: So the bill
column2: when really accumulated
column3: the Congressional Budget Office says
column4: will save
column5: over 10 years
column6: $138 billion.

column1: Now
column2: Orrin will say
column3: well
column4: it's not this; it's not that; it's not the other thing. But that's the fact that we go on when we assess a bill. CROWLEY: But isn't also true
column5: Senator...

column1: FEINSTEIN: So over 10 years
column2: this bill
column3: I'm confident
column4: will not cost more.

column1: Now
column2: as I said
column3: are there certain parts that may have to be tweaked
column4: that don't work exactly right? But he has given a litany of complaints about the bill. The thrust of the bill is to provide more people with coverage.

column1: One of the good things the bill does is it reduces the nonpremium costs for those 85 percent of people that have medical health insurance. It reduces it from 20 percent to 15 percent so that more money from insurance companies will actually go for medical care. And I think that's important.
CROWLEY: Politically
column2: isn't it going to be hard to argue
column3: should this bill pass
column4: and we think it will
column5: just given the numbers
column6: to say
column7: listen
column8: people are now going to be -- not be thrown off their insurance because they got sick. There will be no more caps.

column1: FEINSTEIN: Exactly.
CROWLEY: There will be help for people down the road
column2: to help subsidize it. How can you argue against that? Isn't that a pretty political powerful package?

column1: HATCH: Well
column2: I'm not arguing -- I'm not arguing against that. I think Republicans certainly -- we could agree on a large percentage of things together. But there was really no effort to get us involved.

column1: All I can say is this
column2: is that everywhere I go -- and I've said it over and over -- people say
column3: how are you going to pay for this? How do you pay for it?

column1: Now
column2: the CMS actuary -- that's the actuary for the administration -- says the cost curve will not be bent
column3: that premiums are going to go up. I have to say that I believe that -- that CBO -- of course they have to decide these budgetary matters based upon the papers given them by the House of Representatives and by the Senate
column4: and those papers are stacked in favor of trying to live within our means
column5: but they don't.

column1: The fact is that they double-count in this bill. They have all kinds of other gimmicks in this bill that try to get this bill down to -- everybody knows that this
column2: extrapolated over 10 years
column3: is going to be $2.5 trillion more on top of what we're already spending
column4: $2.4 trillion.

column1: You cannot tell me that this country can afford to do that and that we can't find a way
column2: by working together
column3: to really come up with a health care system that will work and work within financial means.

column1: CROWLEY: I'm going to give you the last short word. And that is
column2: are you comfortable with the cost of this bill...

column1: FEINSTEIN: Yes.
CROWLEY: ... and comfortable the country can afford it?
FEINSTEIN: Yes. I believe we can. And I believe that will be sorted out over time.
I think there's one thing that isn't in the bill
column2: that the president was good enough to take my bill
column3: which would give the secretary of health and human services some control over the rate of premiums to ensure that they are reasonable for people who have private-sector insurance. Unfortunately
column4: the parliamentarian said that could not be added to the reconciliation bill. I have introduced it as a separate bill.

column1: I believe this is a huge problem out there. You have Anthem in California and 800
column2: 000 policies just jacking up premiums up to 39 percent in California and then saying there may be another increase in the middle of the year.

column1: And so people are being pushed off of their health insurance because of the cost of premiums. And this is one thing we need to strengthen
column2: in my view
column3: and hopefully will as a separate piece of legislation.

column1: CROWLEY: Senator Dianne Feinstein
column2: Senator Orrin Hatch
column3: I can't thank you both enough for coming. I appreciate it.

column1: FEINSTEIN: Thank you.
HATCH: Thank you.
CROWLEY: More of this on the Senate floor next week...
FEINSTEIN: Oh
column2: you bet.

column1: CROWLEY: ... we promise. (LAUGHTER)
FEINSTEIN: Thank you.
CROWLEY: Up next
column2: in our ""American Dispatch
column3: why
column4: despite the claims of some politicians
column5: it's hard to say exactly how most Americans feel about the health reform bill. And then Donna Brazile and Ben Bennett on the potential fallout for both Democratic and Republican lawmakers up for re-election this fall.

column1: (COMMERCIAL BREAK)
CROWLEY: Our ""American Dispatch"" looks at a central question. What do Americans think?
House Republican Leader John Boehner answers for Republicans.
(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
BOEHNER: Because the American people are saying ""Stop
column2: and they're screaming at the top of their lungs. (END VIDEO CLIP)

column1: CROWLEY: But are they? Two polls released this week leave lots of room for debate. A Pew poll released Thursday asks
column2: ""Do you favor or oppose the current bill?""

column1: Only 38 percent said they favor it. So is Minority Leader Boehner right?
A Wall Street Journal/NBC poll asks
column2: ""Is it better to pass the Obama plan or keep the current system?""

column1: The respondents were split right down the middle.
Is it in the way the question is asked? Are more people more likely to support it when it's called the Obama plan or is it that people think some change is better than no change?
You be the judge. We will sort through the complicated politics of all this with Donna Brazile and Bill Bennett after a short break.
(COMMERCIAL BREAK)
CROWLEY: Joining me here in Washington
column2: two of my favorite people
column3: CNN political contributor and Democratic strategist Donna Brazile and CNN political contributor and host of ""Morning in America
column4: Bill Bennett
column5: who is also author of the new book ""A Century Turns."" These authors and stuff
column6: OK.

column1: The politics of all this. John Larson
column2: head of the Democratic caucus
column3: says they've got the 216
column4: done deal
column5: goes over to the Senate
column6: Dianne Feinstein all confident they're going to pass it. It's going to be law. How does this all play out politically? I want to play you something the -- two things
column7: actually
column8: the president said yesterday. First
column9: there was this.

column1: (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
OBAMA: I am actually confident -- I've talked to some of you individually -- that it will end up being the smart thing to do politically
column2: because I believe that good policy is good politics.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
CROWLEY: OK
column2: now
column3: about two minutes later
column4: he had this to say.

column1: (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
OBAMA: Now
column2: I can't guarantee that this is good politics. Every one of you know your districts better than I do.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
CROWLEY: So
column2: let's see
column3: I'm thinking we're not really sure how the politics are going to play out. What do you think? BENNETT: Yes
column4: well
column5: as a former teacher of logic
column6: he didn't contradict himself
column7: because he said I believe this will be good politics because it's good policy
column8: but I can't guarantee it. OK
column9: we've heard that before.

column1: I think it's bad politics
column2: because I think it's bad policy
column3: and not just from a partisan point of view
column4: but let me just do it analytically. You would not have so many nervous Democrats if this looked like it was really good politics. I don't think it is.

column1: And
column2: again
column3: I think
column4: when we see how this plays out
column5: one play will be in November with the midterm elections. Another play
column6: we'll see what happens with budget issues.

column1: And since misrepresentations are all over the place in this -- in this proposal
column2: and you look at a state like Massachusetts
column3: which is a state closest to what this federal program is
column4: I think they're going to regret it. Be careful what you wish for
column5: Richard Butler (ph) said
column6: because you may get it.

column1: CROWLEY: You know
column2: Donna
column3: what the White House is counting on -- what Democrats are counting on is that
column4: after this is signed into law
column5: people will go
column6: ""Oh
column7: you mean I "	0

column1: 72	"The following a transcript of Senator Barack ObamaÃ¢ÂÂs speech to supporters on the last night of voting in the primary campaign
column2: as provided by CQ Transcriptions.

column1: SENATOR BARACK OBAMA: Sixteen months have passed since we first stood together on the steps of the Old State Capitol in Springfield
column2: Illinois. Thousands of miles have been traveled; millions of voices have been heard.

column1: And because of what you said
column2: because you decided that change must come to Washington
column3: because you believed that this year must be different than all the rest
column4: because you chose to listen not to your doubts or your fears
column5: but to your greatest hopes and highest aspirations
column6: tonight we mark the end of one historic journey with the beginning of another
column7: a journey...

column1: (APPLAUSE)
... a journey that will bring a new and better day to America.
Because of you
column2: tonight I can stand here and say that I will be the Democratic nominee for the president of the United States of America."	0

To learn about the history of the Senate visit the About the Senate section of Senate.gov."	0
74	"MR. OBAMA: I said during the campaign that Iran is a country that has extraordinary people
column2: extraordinary history and traditions
column3: but that its actions over many years now have been unhelpful when it comes to promoting peace and prosperity both in the region and around the world; that their attacks or -- or their -- their financing of terrorist organizations like Hezbollah and Hamas
column4: the bellicose language that they've used towards Israel
column5: their development of a nuclear weapon or their pursuit of a nuclear weapon -- that all of those things create the possibility of destabilizing the region and are not only contrary to our interests
column6: but I think are contrary to the interests of international peace.

column1: What I've also said is that we should take an approach with Iran that employs all of the resources at the United States' disposal
column2: and that includes diplomacy. And so my national security team is currently reviewing our existing Iran policy
column3: looking at areas where we can have constructive dialogue
column4: where we can directly engage with them. And my expectation is
column5: in the coming months
column6: we will be looking for openings that can be created where we can start sitting across the table

column1: There's been a lot of mistrust built up over the years

column7: of a relationship of mutual respect and progress.

83	"Protecting Our Children from the Dangers of Smoking
Viewing this video requires Adobe Flash Player 8 or higher. Download the free player.
download .mp4 (159.8 MB) | read the transcript
The President expressed his appreciation for Senator Ted Kennedy above all today. Lamenting that the senator could not be there for the signing of Family Smoking Prevention and Tobacco Control Act
column2: he called it ""change that's been decades in the making."" By all accounts
column3: it is the strongest measure protecting children from the dangers of smoking to date -- read the fact sheet for all of the details.

column1: He recounted the all-too-familiar statistics: that more than 400
column2: 000 Americans now die of tobacco-related illnesses each year; that more than 8 million Americans suffer from at least one serious illness caused by smoking; and that almost 90% of all smokers began at or before their 18th birthday.

column1: He spoke on his personal experience:
I know -- I was one of these teenagers
column2: and so I know how difficult it can be to break this habit when it's been with you for a long time. And I also know that kids today don't just start smoking for no reason. They're aggressively targeted as customers by the tobacco industry. They're exposed to a constant and insidious barrage of advertising where they live
column3: where they learn
column4: and where they play. Most insidiously
column5: they are offered products with flavorings that mask the taste of tobacco and make it even more tempting.

column1: We've known about this for decades
column2: but despite the best efforts and good progress made by so many leaders and advocates with us today
column3: the tobacco industry and its special interest lobbying have generally won the day up on the Hill. When Henry Waxman first brought tobacco CEOs before Congress in 1994
column4: they famously denied that tobacco was deadly
column5: nicotine was addictive
column6: or that their companies marketed to children. And they spent millions upon millions in lobbying and advertising to fight back every attempt to expose these denials as lies.

column1: Fifteen years later
column2: their campaign has finally failed. Today
column3: thanks to the work of Democrats and Republicans
column4: health care and consumer advocates
column5: the decades-long effort to protect our children from the harmful effects of tobacco has emerged victorious. Today
column6: change has come to Washington.

column1: This legislation will not ban all tobacco products
column2: and it will allow adults to make their own choices. But it will also ban tobacco advertising within a thousand feet of schools and playgrounds. It will curb the ability of tobacco companies to market products to our children by using appealing flavors. It will force these companies to more clearly and publicly acknowledge the harmful and deadly effects of the products they sell. And it will allow the scientists at the FDA to take other common-sense steps to reduce the harmful effects of smoking.

column1: This legislation is a victory for bipartisanship
column2: and it was passed overwhelmingly in both Houses of Congress. It's a victory for health care reform
column3: as it will reduce some of the billions we spend on tobacco-related health care costs in this country. It's a law that will reduce the number of American children who pick up a cigarette and become adult smokers. And most importantly
column4: it is a law that will save American lives and make Americans healthier.

column1: Making clear that this legislation does not represent the end of the road on fighting back the health risks of smoking
column2: the President nonetheless described it as another very significant sign of change in Washington:

column1: Despite the influence of the credit card industry
column2: we passed a law to protect consumers from unfair rate hikes and abusive fees. Despite the influence of banks and lenders
column3: we passed a law to protect homeowners from mortgage fraud. Despite the influence of the defense industry
column4: we passed a law to protect taxpayers from waste and abuse in defense contracting. And today
column5: despite decades of lobbying and advertising by the tobacco industry
column6: we've passed a law to help protect the next generation of Americans from growing up with a deadly habit that so many of our generation have lived with."	0

90	"It's not often you see someone stand up and say
column2: ""Tax me more!""

column1: Yet that's just what famed investor Warren Buffett has done in an op-ed in the New York Times headlined
column2: ""Stop Coddling the Super-Rich."" Buffett says that very wealthy people like himself pay lower tax rates than the middle class
column3: thanks to special tax categories for investment income.

column1: While the poor and middle class fight for us in Afghanistan
column2: and while most Americans struggle to make ends meet
column3: we mega-rich continue to get our extraordinary tax breaks
column4: he writes.

column1: As an example
column2: Buffett said he paid an effective tax rate of 17.4 percent
column3: while people who worked in his office made much less but paid higher effective tax rates of between 33 percent and 41 percent
column4: averaging 36 percent.

column1: If you make money with money
column2: as some of my super-rich friends do
column3: your percentage may be a bit lower than mine. But if you earn money from a job
column4: your percentage will surely exceed mine Ã¢ÂÂ most likely by a lot
column5: Buffett wrote. ""To understand why
column6: you need to examine the sources of government revenue. Last year about 80 percent of these revenues came from personal income taxes and payroll taxes. The mega-rich pay income taxes at a rate of 15 percent on most of their earnings but pay practically nothing in payroll taxes. ItÃ¢ÂÂs a different story for the middle class: typically
column7: they fall into the 15 percent and 25 percent income tax brackets
column8: and then are hit with heavy payroll taxes to boot.""

column1: Buffett's op-ed inspired a reader to write to us and ask how Buffett's numbers could be correct. As our previous fact-checks have shown
column2: about half of all Americans pay no federal income taxes because they are low income. And when you analyze who pays the bulk of federal income taxes
column3: it's people with higher incomes. So we decided to fact-check Buffett's statement that ""the mega-rich pay income taxes at a rate of 15 percent on most of their earnings but pay practically nothing in payroll taxes. ... (The middle class) fall into the 15 percent and 25 percent income tax brackets
column4: and then are hit with heavy payroll taxes to boot.""

column1: Before we get to the heart of the fact-check
column2: it's best if we review a few basics of the tax code that Buffett's op-ed takes for granted. This review proves the point that the federal tax code is extremely complicated
column3: so bear with us.

column1: Income taxes. Federal income taxes are progressive
column2: which means your income is taxed at higher rates as you make more money. Let's take a married couple filing jointly as an example. In 2011
column3: after deductions and exemptions:

column1: Ã¢ÂÂ¢ the income between $0 and $17
column2: 000 is taxed at 10 percent;

column1: Ã¢ÂÂ¢ the income between $17
column3: 000 is taxed at 15 percent;

column1: Ã¢ÂÂ¢ the income between $69
column3: 350 is taxed at 25 percent;

column1: Ã¢ÂÂ¢ the income between $139
column3: 300 is taxed at 28 percent;

column1: Ã¢ÂÂ¢ the income between $212
column3: 150 is taxed at 33 percent;

column1: Ã¢ÂÂ¢ the income above $379
column2: 150 is taxed at 35 percent.

column1: Keep in mind that even if you're in the top bracket of 35 percent
column2: you don't pay that tax rate on all your income. You pay 10 percent on the first $17
column4: 15 percent on the money between $17
column7: and so on.

column1: Payroll taxes. Payroll taxes are separate from income taxes. If you work for a company
column2: your employer deducts the payroll taxes before you get your paycheck and sends the money on to the federal government. These taxes pay for Social Security and Medicare; it's listed as FICA on your pay stub. Typically
column3: workers pay 6.2 percent of their first $106
column4: 800 in earnings for Social Security taxes
column5: and they pay 1.45 percent on all their earnings for Medicare hospital coverage. The employer has to match those taxes
column6: bringing total contributions on behalf of an individual to 12.4 percent for Social Security and 2.9 percent for Medicare. Last year
column7: though
column8: President Barack Obama and Congress knocked 2 percentage points off Social Security taxes for workers
column9: as an economic stimulus measure. So this year
column10: most of us are paying 4.2 percent while employers pay 6.2 percent. Oh
column11: and if you're self-employed
column12: you typically have to pay your share and the employer share for totals this year of 10.4 percent on earnings up to $106
column13: 800 and 2.9 percent on all income. Payroll taxes are not progressive -- the rates don't get higher the more you earn. In the case of the Social Security taxes
column14: which disappear once your reach a certain level of earnings
column15: the percentage actually gets smaller if your income is higher than the $106
column16: 800 cap.

column1: Head hurt yet? Ours
column2: too.

column1: Taxes on investments. Okay
column2: now we're getting closer to Buffett's main point here
column3: and that's taxes on investments. The tax rates on investments tend to be lower than taxes on regular income. If you make money buying and selling stocks or receiving dividends from stock ownership
column4: those earnings are generally taxed at 15 percent
column5: the rate for long-term capital gains and qualified dividends.

column1: Some hedge fund managers and other finance-sector executives get taxed at this rate on their earnings because their compensation is classified as ""carried interest"" and taxed as a capital gain. (The Wall Street Journal breaks down how carried interest works.) In fact
column2: some economists believe that the lower rates for capital gains actually encourages tax dodges
column3: because it motivates high earners to look for ways to classify normal income as capital gains. Defenders say the lower tax rate helps the economy because it rewards investors for risk-taking and entrepreneurship. They also argue that taxing dividends amounts to double taxation because corporations pay taxes on their income before investors are paid dividends. We won't settle the argument here
column4: but there's no doubt that investors get lower tax rates on their income than workers.

column1: Getting back to Buffett's op-ed
column2: his claims rest on how these taxes interact with each other. The fact we're checking here is that ""the mega-rich pay income taxes at a rate of 15 percent on most of their earnings but pay practically nothing in payroll taxes
column3: while middle class taxpayers ""fall into the 15 percent and 25 percent income tax brackets
column4: and then are hit with heavy payroll taxes to boot.""

column1: He's right that a billionaire whose income is mostly from investments is probably taxed at a lower rate than someone who has an ordinary job. Very little of this taxpayer's income is wage income
column2: so payroll taxes don't take much of a bite. It seems likely that much of this hypothetical person's income would be taxed around the 15 percent rate. And
column3: in fact
column4: as Buffett says
column5: statistics from the Internal Revenue Service show that the 400 wealthiest taxpayers pay tax rates of less than 20 percent.

column1: On the other side of the equation
column2: people who work for a living
column3: especially those who make higher than average salaries
column4: get taxed at higher rates. It gets a little complicated
column5: given how the tax brackets work
column6: but basically
column7: people who make between $100
column9: 000 are paying around 20 percent in income taxes
column10: and it goes up from there
column11: according to an analysis from the nonpartisan Tax Policy Center.

column1: Buffett slightly glosses over the fact that if you're in the 25 percent tax bracket
column2: your overall tax rate is less than 25 percent. And
column3: the more money you make
column4: the more income taxes you pay
column5: while payroll taxes seem less and less significant as a percentage of income. We're dubious someone would pay as high as a 41 percent tax rate
column6: as Buffett claims someone in his office now pays. (The top income tax rate is 35 percent
column7: but payroll taxes as a share of income decline as income rises
column8: which makes it difficult to get above 37.9 percent
column9: according to the people we ran this by at the Tax Policy Center.) We contacted Buffett's offices as Berkshire Hathaway about this point but didn't hear back.

column1: One final note: People who don't pay any income tax at all tend to have limited incomes
column2: or they qualify for enough deductions -- think of child tax credits and mortgage interest -- that they have no income. When Buffett talks about people in the middle class who pay more taxes than he does
column3: he's thinking of people who make much higher than average salaries.

column1: So when it comes to Buffett's statement
column2: there are two categories: the rich and the really rich. And the evidence tends to point to the conclusion that the really rich pay less in taxes as a percentage of income then their merely well-to-do counterparts -- if their income comes primarily from investments. Overall
column3: we rate Buffett's statement True."	0

column3: Factcheck.org said in its analysis
column4: ""Clinton's denial came in response to a question about deleting emails 'while facing a subpoena
column5: ' and Clinton objected to Keilar's 'assumption.' ClintonÃ¢ÂÂs campaign said that the emails were deleted before she received the subpoena and that was the point Clinton was making."" Politifact added
column6: ""Suggesting that Clinton deleted emails while facing a subpoena contradicts what we know about the controversy so far.""

column1: Vox went on to further decry Rep. Gowdy's reaction
column2: saying
column3: ""[T]his one's a particularly absurd gimmick
column4: even for a committee that is selectively leaking from depositions and documents to justify its existence. If there was a more extreme category of dissembling than 'pants on fire
column5: ' now would be the time for Politifact to roll it out on the House Republicans.""

column1: Why was the State Department given printed copies?

That is the requirement. The instructions regarding electronic mail in the Foreign Affairs Manual (the Department's policy manual) require that ""until technology allowing archival capabilities for long-term electronic storage and retrieval of email messages is available and installed
column2: those messages warranting preservation as records (for periods longer than current E-mail systems routinely maintain them) must be printed out and filed with related records."" [5 FAM 443.3].

column1: Were any work items deleted in the course of producing the printed copies?
No.
How many emails were in her account? And how many of those were provided to the State Department?
Her email account contained a total of 62
column2: 320 sent and received emails from March 2009 to February 2013. Based on the review process described below
column4: 490 of these emails were provided to the Department
column5: and the remaining 31
column6: 830 were private
column7: personal records.

column1: How and who decided what should be provided to the State Department?

The Federal Records Act puts the obligation on the government official to determine what is and is not a federal record. The State Department Foreign Affairs Manual outlines guidance ""designed to help employees determine which of their e-mail messages must be preserved as federal records and which may be deleted without further authorization because they are not Federal record materials."" [5 FAM 443.1(c)].
Following conversations with State Department officials and in response to the State Department's 2014 letter to former Secretaries
column2: Clinton directed her attorneys to assist by identifying and preserving all emails that could potentially be federal records. This entailed a multi-step process to review each email and provide printed copies of Clinton's emails to the State Department
column3: erring on the side of including anything that might be even potentially work-related.

column1: A search was conducted on Clinton's email account for all emails sent and received from 2009 to her last day in office
column2: February 1

column1: After this universe was determined
column2: a search was conducted for a "".gov"" (not just state.gov) in any address field in an email. This produced over 27
column3: 500 emails
column4: representing more than 90% of the 30
column5: 490 printed copies that were provided to the State Department.

column1: To help identify any potential non-"".gov"" correspondence that should be included
column2: a search of first and last names of more than 100 State Department and other U.S. government officials was performed. This included all Deputy Secretaries
column3: Under Secretaries
column4: Assistant Secretaries
column5: Ambassadors-at-Large
column6: Special Representatives and Envoys
column7: members of the Secretary's Foreign Policy Advisory Board
column8: and other senior officials to the Secretary
column9: including close aides and staff.

column1: Next
column2: to account for non-obvious or non-recognizable email addresses or misspellings or other idiosyncrasies
column3: the emails were sorted and reviewed both by sender and recipient.

column1: Lastly
column2: a number of terms were specifically searched for
column3: including: ""Benghazi"" and ""Libya.""

column1: These additional three steps yielded just over another 2
column2: 900 emails
column3: including emails from former Administration officials and long-time friends that may not be deemed by the State Department to be federal records. And hundreds of these emails actually had already been forwarded onto the state.gov system and captured in real-time.

column1: With respect to materials that the Select Committee has requested
column2: the State Department has stated that just under 300 emails related to Libya were provided by the State Department to the Select Committee in response to a November 2014 letter
column3: which contained a broader request for materials than prior requests from the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee.

column1: Given Clinton's practice of emailing State Department officials on their state.gov addresses
column2: the State Department already had
column3: and had already provided
column4: the Select Committee with emails from Clinton in August 2014 Ã¢ÂÂ prior to requesting and receiving printed copies of her emails.

column1: The review process described above confirmed Clinton's practice of emailing State Department officials on their .gov address
column2: with the vast majority of the printed copies of work-related emails Clinton provided to the State Department simply duplicating what was already captured in the State Department's record-keeping system in real time.

column1: Did Clinton use this account to communicate with foreign officials?
During her time at State
column2: she communicated with foreign officials in person
column3: through correspondence
column4: and by telephone. The review of all of her emails revealed only one email with a foreign (UK) official.

column1: Did she withhold any work emails? What about the 15 emails that Sid Blumenthal provided to the Select Committee that she did not provide to the State Department?
She provided the State Department with all work and potentially work-related emails that she had
column2: including all of her correspondence with Sid Blumenthal. We understand that Mr. Blumenthal had some emails that Clinton did not have
column3: and Clinton had some emails that Mr. Blumenthal did not have
column4: but it is important to note that none of those emails provide any new insights on the attack on our facilities in Benghazi.

column1: Do you think a third party should have been allowed to review what was turned over to the State Department
column2: as well as the remainder that was not?

column1: The Federal Records Act puts the obligation on the government official
column2: not the agency or a third party
column3: to determine what is and is not a federal record. The State Department Foreign Affairs Manual outlines guidance ""designed to help employees determine which of their e-mail messages must be preserved as federal records and which may be deleted without further authorization because they are not Federal record materials."" [5 FAM 443.1(c)].

column1: Clinton responded to the State Department's request by providing approximately 55
column2: 000 pages of her work and potentially work-related emails. She has also taken the unprecedented step of asking that those emails be made public. In doing so
column3: she has sought to support the State Department's efforts
column4: fulfill her responsibility of record-keeping
column5: and provide the chance for the public to assess the work she and officials at the State Department did during her tenure.

column1: After her work-related emails were identified and preserved
column2: Clinton chose not to keep her private
column3: personal emails that were not federal records
column4: including emails about her daughter's wedding plans
column5: her mother's funeral service
column6: family vacations
column7: etc.

column1: Government officials are granted the privacy of their personal
column2: non-work related emails
column3: including personal emails on .gov accounts. Clinton exercised her privilege to ensure the continued privacy of her personal
column4: non-work related emails.

column1: Can't she release the emails she provided to the State Department herself?
Because the printed copies of work-related emails she provided to the State Department include federal records of the Department
column2: the Department needs to review these emails before they can be made public. She called for them to be made available as soon as possible
column3: and is glad to see the Department has begun releasing them.

column1: Some of the emails released show Clinton emailed aides at times on their personal
column2: rather than .gov accounts. Was she trying to hide these communications?

column1: As Clinton has said before
column2: it was her practice to email U.S. government officials on their .gov accounts if it was work-related. This is evidenced in the emails released so far. In reviewing her emails in 2014
column3: there was a fraction of emails with work-related information sent to U.S. government officialsÃ¢ÂÂ personal accounts
column4: and those were provided to the State Department. The overwhelming majority of her work-related emails were to .gov accounts.

column1: Where was the server for her email located?
The server for her email was physically located on her property
column2: which is protected by U.S. Secret Service.

column1: What level of encryption was employed? Who was the service provider?

The security and integrity of her family's electronic communications was taken seriously from the onset when it was first set up for President Clinton's team. While the curiosity about the specifics of this set up is understandable
column2: given what people with ill intentions can do with such information in this day and age
column3: there are concerns about broadcasting specific technical details about past and current practices. Suffice it to say
column4: robust protections were put in place and additional upgrades and techniques employed over time as they became available
column5: including consulting and employing third party experts.

column1: Was the server ever hacked?
No
column2: there is no evidence there was ever a breach.

column1: Was there ever an unauthorized intrusion into her email or did anyone else have access to it?
No.
What was done after her email was exposed in February 2013 after the hacker known as ""Guccifer"" hacked Sid BlumenthalÃ¢ÂÂs account?
While this was not a breach of Clinton's account
column2: because her email address was exposed
column3: steps were taken at that time to ensure the security and integrity of her electronic communications
column4: including changing her email address.

column1: Was the State Department able to respond to requests related to FOIA or Congressional requests before they received printed copies of her work-related emails?
Yes. As the Select Committee has said
column2: the State Department provided the Committee with relevant emails it already had on the state.gov system before the State Department requested any printed copies from former Secretaries
column3: and four months before the State Department received the printed copies.

column1: For example
column2: in the well-publicized hack of Sid Blumenthal's email account
column3: a note he sent Clinton on September 12
column5: was posted online. At first blush
column6: one might not think this exchange would be captured on the state.gov system. But in fact
column7: Clinton forwarded the email
column8: that very same day
column9: onto the state.gov system. And the email was produced by the State Department to the Select Committee
column10: and acknowledged by the Select Committee
column11: in August 2014.

column1: This example illustrates: 1) when an email from a non-"".gov"" sender had some connection to work or might add to the understanding of State Department officials
column2: it was ClintonÃ¢ÂÂs practice to forward it to officials at their ""state.gov"" address; and 2) the State Department was able to search and produce ClintonÃ¢ÂÂs emails when needed long before
column3: and unrelated to
column4: receiving the printed copies as they were already captured on state.gov accounts."	0

column1: In part five of the second democratic primary debate

column1: Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders earned laughter and applause during Saturday's Democratic debate for a line defending his progressive tax policy.
When asked how he would pay for proposals like tuition-free college for Americans
column2: Sanders said he would finance them by ""due-demanding: that the wealthiest people and the largest corporations - have gotten away with murder for years - start paying their fair share.""

column1: CBS News Congressional Correspondent Nancy Cordes pressed the White House hopeful: ""Let's get specific. How high would you go? You've said before you'd go above 50 percent. How high?""
We haven't come up with an exact number yet
column2: Sanders responded. ""But it will not be as high as the number under Dwight D. Eisenhower which was 90 percent.""

column1: As an aside
column2: he said
column3: to loud cheers in the audience: ""I'm not that much of a socialist compared to Eisenhower.""

column1: Sanders went on to say that his administration would ""end the absurdities as Warren Buffet often reminds us - that billionaires pay an effective tax rate lower than nurses
column2: or truck drivers that makes no sense at all. There has to be real tax reform and the wealthiest and the large corporations will pay when I'm president.""

column1: In fact
column2: during the first term of Republican President Eisenhower
column3: the marginal tax rate on regular income for those earning over $400
column4: 000 -- at the time
column5: the highest income bracket -- was 92 percent. The tax rate was carried over from Democratic President Harry Truman's administration. This was the second-highest tax rate during the 20th century
column6: following the 94 percent instituted by President Roosevelt during World War II for those making over $200
column7: 000 annually.

column2: under Eisenhower
column3: the rate for the highest income bracket decreased to 91 percent.

column1: Taking into account these income tax rates
column2: Sanders' assertion that he's not as ""socialist"" as Eisenhower's administration is correct: Sanders has said before that he doesn't believe his tax policy would tax the top bracket over 90 percent
column3: though he has yet to offer up an exact number.

column1: Appearing on ""CBS This Morning"" in September
column2: Sanders said ""We are going to ask the wealthiest people in this country who are doing phenomenally well
column3: and many large corporations that are making billions of dollars of profits and not paying a nickel in taxes
column4: to in fact start paying their fair share of taxes.""

column1: When asked to specify
column2: the Vermont senator said of taxing those in the highest income bracket
column3: ""I don't think you have to go up to 90 percent.""

column1: Sanders
column2: however
column3: has also called for greater increases in capital gains taxes
column4: which were capped at 25 percent during most of Eisenhower's tenure.

column1: During Saturday's debate
column2: former Maryland Gov. Martin O'Malley also defended asking the wealthy to pay a higher share of taxes.

column1: Under Ronald Reagan's first term
column2: the highest marginal rate was 70 percent
column3: he pointed out.

column1: O'Malley is also correct on this point: Under President Reagan
column2: those with annual incomes over $215
column3: 400 were taxed at a rate of 69.1 percent."	0

column3: and they are really

column3: as governor

column1: I did it to keep crony capitalism away from government.
Another big difference between Hillary Clinton and myself is that IÃ¢ÂÂm for our national tradition of peace
column2: commerce and honest friendship with all nations Ã¢ÂÂ while being extremely skeptical of committing ourselves and our armed forces to foreign conflicts.

column1: As a Senator

column4: in Egypt and in Syria. These should not be AmericaÃ¢ÂÂs wars

Section 1.
In case of the removal of the President from office or of his death or resignation
column2: the Vice President shall become President.

column1: Section 2.
Whenever there is a vacancy in the office of the Vice President
column2: the President shall nominate a Vice President who shall take office upon confirmation by a majority vote of both Houses of Congress.

column1: Section 3.

Whenever the President transmits to the President pro tempore of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives his written declaration that he is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office
column2: and until he transmits to them a written declaration to the contrary
column3: such powers and duties shall be discharged by the Vice President as Acting President.

column1: Section 4.
Whenever the Vice President and a majority of either the principal officers of the executive departments or of such other body as Congress may by law provide
column2: transmit to the President pro tempore of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives their written declaration that the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office
column3: the Vice President shall immediately assume the powers and duties of the office as Acting President.

column10: determines by two-thirds vote of both Houses that the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office

100	"Go to www.hillaryclinton.com and check out Bill Clinton's syrupy five minute ad for Hillary. He introduces the commercial by saying that he wants to share some things we may not know about Hillary's background. His version of her biography is about as reliable as if it appeared in Pravda!
So
column2: I wanted to make a few corrections:

column1: Bill says: Hillary never wanted to run for public office
column2: but she did want to work at public service.

column1: The true facts are: When Clinton was considering not running for another term as Governor of Arkansas in 1990
column2: Hillary said she would run if he didn't. She and Bill even had me take two surveys to assess her chances of winning. The conclusion was that she couldn't win because people would just see her as a seat warmer for when Bill came back licking his wounds after losing for president. So she didn't run. Bill did and won. But there is no question she had her eye on public office
column3: as opposed to service
column4: long ago.

column1: Bill says: In law school Hillary worked on legal services for the poor.
The true facts are: Hillary's main extra-curricular activity in law school was helping the Black Panthers
column2: on trial in Connecticut for torturing and killing a federal agent. She went to court every day as part of a law student monitoring committee trying to spot civil rights violations and develop grounds for appeal.

column1: Bill says: Hillary spent a year after graduation working on a children's rights project for poor kids.
The true facts are: Hillary interned with Bob Truehaft
column2: the head of the California Communist Party. She met Bob when he represented the Panthers and traveled all the way to San Francisco to take an internship with him.

column1: Bill says: Hillary could have written her own job ticket
column2: but she turned down all the lucrative job offers.

column1: The true facts are: She flunked the DC bar exam and only passed the Arkansas bar. She had no job offers in Arkansas and only got hired by the University of Arkansas Law School at Fayetteville because Bill was already teaching there. She only joined the prestigious Rose Law Firm after Bill became Attorney General and made partner only after he was elected Governor.
Bill says: President Carter appointed Hillary to the Legal Services Board of Directors and she became its Chairman.

The true facts are: The appointment was in exchange for Bill's support for Carter in his 1980 primary against Ted Kennedy. Hillary became chairman in a coup in which she won a majority away from Carter's choice to be chairman.
Bill says: She served on the board of the Arkansas Children's Hospital.
The true facts are: Yes she did. But her main board activity
column2: not mentioned by Bill
column3: was to sit on the Wal-Mart board of directors
column4: for a substantial fee. She was silent about their labor and health care practices.

column1: Bill says: Hillary didn't succeed at getting health care for all Americans in 1994 but she kept working at it and helped to create the Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP) that provides five million children with health insurance.

The true facts are: Hillary had nothing to do with creating CHIP. It was included in the budget deal between Bill Clinton and Republican Majority Leader Senator Trent Lott. I helped to negotiate the deal. The money came half from the budget deal and half from the Attorney Generals' tobacco settlement. Hillary had nothing to do with either source of funds.
Bill says: Hillary was the face of America all over the world.

The true facts are: Her visits were part of a program to get her out of town so that Bill would not appear weak by feeding stories that Hillary was running the White House. Her visits abroad were entirely touristic and symbolic
column2: and there was no substantive diplomacy on any of them.

column1: Bill says: Hillary was an excellent Senator who kept fighting for children's and women's issues.
The true facts are: Other than totally meaningless legislation like changing the names on courthouses and post offices
column2: she has passed only four substantive pieces of legislation. One set up a national park in Puerto Rico. A second provided respite care for family members helping their relatives through Alzheimer's or other conditions. And two were routine bills to aid 9-11 victims and responders which were sponsored by the entire NY delegation.

column1: Here is what bothers me more than anything else about Hillary Clinton. She has done everything possible to weaken the President and our country when it comes to the war on terror:
1. She wants to close GITMO & move the combatants to the USA where they would have access to our legal system.
2. She wants to eliminate the monitoring of suspected Al Qaeda phone calls to/from the USA.
3. She wants to grants constitutional rights to enemy combatants captured on the battlefield.
4. She wants to eliminate the monitoring of money transfers between suspected Al Qaeda cells & supporters in the USA.

5. She wants to eliminate the type of interrogation tactics used by the military & CIA where coercion might be used when questioning known terrorists even though such tactics might save American lives.I can't think of a single bill Hillary has introduced or a single comment she has made that would tend to strengthen our country in the War on Terror. But
column2: I can think of a lot of comments she has made that weakens our country and makes it a more dangerous situation for all of us........She goes hand in hand with the ACLU on far too many issues where common sense is abandoned. She is a disaster for all Americans."	0

column5: was in conversation with a number of Republicans back then. It doesn't surprise me completely because his people similarly approached me to engage in a discussion about his potentially being on the ticket as Vice President. So his people were active -- let's put it that way."" SINGER: ""Okay. And just to confirm
column6: you said it
column7: but this is something they approached you rather than..."" KERRY: ""Absolutely correct. John Weaver of his shop approached..."" (My DD Website
column8: http://www.mydd.com/images/admin/McCain.mp3
column9: Accessed 4/3/07)

column1: Sen. McCain Publicly Said He'd Entertain The Idea Of Running With Kerry:

column2: When First Questioned If He'd Run With Kerry
column3: McCain Said He ""Would Entertain It."" ABC's CHARLES GIBSON: ""But
column4: let me
column5: let me
column6: let me imagine it. If he asked you
column7: if he came across the aisle and asked you
column8: would you even entertain the idea? Or will you rule it out for good and all and ever right now?"" SEN. JOHN MCCAIN: ""John Kerry is a very close friend of mine. We've been friends for years. Obviously
column9: I would entertain it."" (ABC's ""Good Morning America
column10: 3/10/04; www.youtube.com/watch?v=LkcVXIhssCI)

column1: Sen. McCain Also Considered Leaving The Republican Party In 2001:
The Hill: Sen. McCain Considered Leaving The GOP In 2001. ""Sen. John McCain (R-Ariz.) was close to leaving the Republican Party in 2001
column2: weeks before then-Sen. Jim Jeffords (Vt.) famously announced his decision to become an Independent
column3: according to former Democratic lawmakers who say they were involved in the discussions."" (Bob Cusack
column4: ""Democrats Say McCain Nearly Abandoned GOP
column5: The Hill

column1: Sen. McCain's Top Political Strategist John Weaver Recently Acknowledged That McCain Spoke To Democrats About Leaving The Party. ""McCain consistently shot down the rumors
column2: though Weaver acknowledged this week that the senator did talk to Democrats about leaving the GOP."" (Bob Cusack
column3: ""Democrats Say McCain Nearly Abandoned GOP
column4: The Hill

column1: One McCain Loyalist Said His Chances Of Leaving The Party Were ""50-50."" ""In one article
column2: Marshall Wittman
column3: a McCain loyalist and strategist six years ago
column4: put the odds of McCain leaving the Republican Party at '50-50.'"" (Bob Cusack
column5: ""Democrats Say McCain Nearly Abandoned GOP
column6: The Hill

column1: Sen. McCain Reached Out To Democrats:

column2: McCain Aide John Weaver Approached Prominent Democrats About McCain Switching Parties. ""Democrats had contacted Jeffords and then-Sen. Lincoln Chafee (R-R.I.) in the early months of 2001 about switching parties
column3: but in McCain's case
column4: they said
column5: it was McCain's top strategist who came to them."" (Bob Cusack
column6: ""Democrats Say McCain Nearly Abandoned GOP
column7: The Hill

column1: Weaver Met With Lobbyist Tom Downey To Float The Idea Of A McCain Switch. ""At the end of their March 31
column2: 2001 lunch at a Chinese restaurant in Bethesda
column3: Md.
column4: Downey said Weaver asked why Democrats hadn't asked McCain to switch parties."" (Bob Cusack
column5: ""Democrats Say McCain Nearly Abandoned GOP
column6: The Hill

column1: - Weaver: ""Well
column2: If The Right People Asked Him."" (Bob Cusack
column3: ""Democrats Say McCain Nearly Abandoned GOP
column4: The Hill

column1: Calls Were Immediately Placed To Powerful Democrats. ""Within seconds' of arriving home from his lunch with Weaver
column2: Downey said he was on the phone to the most powerful Democrats in town. One of the first calls he made was to then-Senate Minority Leader Daschle."" (Bob Cusack
column3: ""Democrats Say McCain Nearly Abandoned GOP
column4: The Hill

column1: - Sen. Tom Daschle (D-SD) Confirmed He Spoke To Downey. ""I did take the call from Tom [Downey]
column2: ' Daschle said in an interview. 'It was Weaver's comment' to Downey that started the McCain talks
column3: he added."" (Bob Cusack
column4: ""Democrats Say McCain Nearly Abandoned GOP
column5: The Hill

column1: Downey And Weaver Spoke Weekly. ""Downey said he talked to Weaver at least once a week during McCain's discussions with Democrats
column2: asking him questions like
column3: 'What is the state of play?' and 'Where are we?'"" (Bob Cusack
column4: ""Democrats Say McCain Nearly Abandoned GOP
column5: The Hill

column1: - Downey: ""I Actually Thought During The Initial Stages Of This That [McCain Leaving The Republican Party] Was Almost A Certain Deal."" (Bob Cusack
column2: ""Democrats Say McCain Nearly Abandoned GOP
column3: The Hill

column1: - Downey: ""Weaver Was Very Active In This."" (Bob Cusack
column2: ""Democrats Say McCain Nearly Abandoned GOP
column3: The Hill

column1: - Downey: ""None Of This Happens Without Weaver."" (Bob Cusack
column2: ""Democrats Say McCain Nearly Abandoned GOP
column3: The Hill

column1: Influential Democrats Talked To McCain About Defecting:
Leading Democrats Talked With Sen. McCain For Months About Leaving The Party. ""In interviews with The Hill this month
column2: former Sen. Tom Daschle (D-S.D.) and ex-Rep. Tom Downey (D-N.Y.) said there were nearly two months of talks with the maverick lawmaker following an approach by John Weaver
column3: McCain's chief political strategist."" (Bob Cusack
column4: ""Democrats Say McCain Nearly Abandoned GOP
column5: The Hill

column1: - Sens. McCain And Daschle Met. ""Daschle said that throughout April and May of 2001
column2: he and McCain 'had meetings and conversations on the floor and in his office
column3: I think in mine as well
column4: about how we would do it
column5: what the conditions would be. We talked about committees and his seniority ... [A lot of issues] were on the table.'"" (Bob Cusack
column6: ""Democrats Say McCain Nearly Abandoned GOP
column7: The Hill

column1: Sens. John Edwards
column2: Teddy Kennedy And Harry Reid All Attempted To Recruit Sen. McCain. ""Other senators who played major roles in the intense recruiting effort
column3: according to Democrats
column4: were then-Sen. John Edwards (D-N.C.) as well as Sens. Edward Kennedy (D-Mass.) and Harry Reid (D-Nev.)."" (Bob Cusack
column5: ""Democrats Say McCain Nearly Abandoned GOP
column6: The Hill

column1: - Edwards Thought He Might Be Able To Convince McCain To Defect. '""John [Edwards] at that time was working with McCain on a couple things and there was a sense that because of his relationship that he might be a good person to talk to him
column2: ' Daschle said. 'He was clearly one of those that we thought could be helpful.''' (Bob Cusack
column3: ""Democrats Say McCain Nearly Abandoned GOP
column4: The Hill

column1: Daschle Thought Sen. McCain Was The Democrats' ""Best Opportunity."" ""Daschle
column2: however
column3: said the talks went much further
column4: claiming that there were times that he and Democratic leaders thought McCain 'might be our best opportunity.'"" (Bob Cusack
column5: ""Democrats Say McCain Nearly Abandoned GOP
column6: The Hill
