column1: 103	"Obama Demands Investigation into Subprime Loan Discrimination
Thursday
column2: October 18

column1: FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
CONTACT: Amy Brundage
Asks FTC to examine whether minority homeowners are being targeted with high-priced loans
WASHINGTON
column2: D.C. Ã¢ÂÂ U.S. Senator Barack Obama (D-IL) today sent the following letter to FTC Commissioner Deborah Platt Majoras
column3: calling on her to investigate the marketing practices of subprime lenders and the brokers of subprime loans to determine whether minority borrowers have been victims of discrimination. According to recent studies
column4: and an editorial in the New York Times
column5: there is increasing evidence that black and Hispanic borrowers were more likely to be steered to high-cost subprime loans than other borrowers. Hundreds of thousands of African American families Ã¢ÂÂ many of whom probably should have been eligible for lower cost prime loans instead of riskier subprime loans Ã¢ÂÂ could potentially lose their homes in the coming years.

column1: In the letter
column2: Obama requests that the FTC investigate whether there is evidence that lenders or brokers target poor or minority borrowers with higher cost products
column3: whether lenders are engaging in deceptive marketing practices
column4: and whether the lack of lower-cost borrowing options has disproportionately disadvantaged minority borrowers.

column1: The text of the letter is below:
October 18
The Honorable Deborah Platt Majoras
Federal Trade Commission
600 Pennsylvania Avenue
column2: N.W.

column1: Washington
Dear Commissioner Majoras:
I am writing to bring to your attention the attached editorial from yesterday's New York Times which begins: ""Evidence is mounting that during the housing boom
column2: black and Hispanic borrowers were far more likely to be steered into high-cost subprime loans than other borrowers
column3: even after controlling for factors such as income
column4: loan size and property location."" (""Subprime in Black and White
column5: The New York Times
column6: October 17

column1: In reality
column2: such evidence has been mounting since the 1990s when the Clinton Administration found that subprime loans in 1998 were over four times more prevalent in predominantly black neighborhoods in New York than in predominantly white neighborhoods. More recent studies have found similar examples of potentially discriminatory lending patterns.

column1: Last year
column2: for example
column3: the Center for Responsible Lending found that for most types of subprime home loans
column4: minority borrowers are more likely to pay higher rates than white borrowers even after accounting for differences in credit scores
column5: loan to value ratios
column6: and other underwriting criteria. And just this week another analysis confirmed that even high-income black borrowers are more likely than comparable white borrowers to have risky and costly subprime loans.

column1: Black families are paying more for home loans than similarly situated white families. Effective action to address this disparity is long overdue. I call upon the FTC to investigate the marketing practices of subprime lenders and the brokers of subprime loans to determine if minority borrowers have been the victims of discrimination.
Among other things
column2: the Federal Trade Commission is charged with protecting consumers from unfair or deceptive marketing acts or practices. Many subprime loans include sales practices or loan features that are potentially unfair and deceptive for borrowers. Some practices
column3: such as yield-spread premiums
column4: which encourage mortgage brokers to steer borrowers into the most costly products
column5: or prepayment penalties
column6: which enable lenders to offer mortgages that are unsupported by sound underwriting principles
column7: appear to be the source of significant problems faced by many subprime borrowers.

column1: With an estimated 53% of African American borrowers in 2005 receiving subprime loans
column2: and more than 60% of subprime loans containing prepayment penalties
column3: the risks particularly for African American homeowners are substantial. Indeed
column4: hundreds of thousands of African American families Ã¢ÂÂ many of whom probably should have been eligible for lower cost prime loans instead of riskier subprime loans Ã¢ÂÂ are expected to face loss of their homes in the coming years.

column1: I request that you begin a thorough investigation within five days and provide a status report to my office within 15 days on the following questions:

1) Whether there is evidence of lenders or brokers specifically targeting poor or minority borrowers with higher cost products than would otherwise be justified based on legitimate underwriting criteria.
2) Whether the marketing of lending products to poor or minority borrowers has been deceptive or unfair. Specifically
column2: whether the disclosure of yield-spread premiums and prepayment penalties has been sufficiently transparent to borrowers and whether such or similar sales and pricing practices have been disproportionately detrimental to minority borrowers.

column1: 3) Whether the lack of lower-cost borrowing options
column2: including those regulated by the Federal government
column3: in predominantly minority communities even for higher-income borrowers
column4: has disproportionately disadvantaged minority borrowers in their efforts to realize the dream of affordable home ownership and wealth building.

column1: Thank you for your assistance protecting all consumers from the pernicious affects of predatory and discriminatory lending practices which undermine the American dream.
Sincerely
Barack Obama
United States Senator

0
104	"Some of the hardest-working and most productive people in this city are undocumented aliens
column2: Mr. Giuliani said. ""If you come here and you work hard and you happen to be in an undocumented status
column3: you're one of the people who we want in this city. You're somebody that we want to protect
column4: and we want you to get out from under what is often a life of being like a fugitive
column5: which is really unfair.""

column1: The politics of immigration is different in New York. Immigration and burden are two words that do not appear often -- or without raising a furor -- in the same sentence. Whatever their legal status
column2: immigrants are considered a fact of life
column3: a point of pride and an integral part of New York City's identity. Many New Yorkers know well that their own forebears arrived without papers.

column1: So many of the Irish
column2: so many of the Italians who came when my parents came
column3: were technically illegal
column4: Mr. Cuomo said.

column1: Because of New York City's size
column2: new immigrants are absorbed without as much fuss as elsewhere. Often
column3: they are responsible for revitalizing dying neighborhoods -- like Crown Heights in Brooklyn and Flushing
column4: Queens -- and New Yorkers know it.

column1: Illegal immigrants in New York City confound the national stereotype of a young Mexican man sneaking across the border. Italians are the largest group
column2: followed by Ecuadoreans
column3: Poles
column4: Dominicans and Trinidadians. European
column5: Caribbean
column6: Latin American and Asian
column7: they blend into the city without radically altering its racial and ethnic makeup. So the racism that often compounds anti-immigrant sentiment is not as stark in New York."	0

column1: 106	"JUDY WOODRUFF: And now to the analysis of Shields and Gerson. That's syndicated columnist Mark Shields and Washington Post columnist Michael Gerson.
David Brooks is off tonight.
Gentlemen
column2: it's good to have you with us.

column1: MARK SHIELDS: Good to be with you.
JUDY WOODRUFF: So
column2: Mark
column3: the fiscal cliff
column4: it's still with us. It's still out there. The president made a last-minute statement late this afternoon. Where does everything stand?

column1: MARK SHIELDS: Nobody knows
column2: Judy.

column1: RELATED INFORMATION The very best from our political pundits
column2: NewsHour regulars Mark Shields and David Brooks.

column1: What happened last night in the Republican Caucus is precedent-shattering. I mean
column2: it really is
column3: that John Boehner could not get a majority of his own caucus to support what had become the Republican position
column4: endorsed not simply by him
column5: but by Republican Whip Kevin McCarthy and Republican Majority Leader Eric Cantor.

column1: And it's a real problem. I think it puts at risk Boehner's own leadership and his ability to deliver Republicans. It weakens the bargaining position for Republicans in the final negotiations. But I don't know how much closer we are
column2: because I think it strengthens the liberals in the Democratic Caucus
column3: which is going to make it tougher for the Republicans to accept it
column4: because a weakened Republican means a strengthened
column5: emboldened Democratic liberal group.

column1: And I just think that there's too many moving parts at this point to say
column2: this is what is going to happen.

column1: JUDY WOODRUFF: Do you -- what do you -- can it get done
column2: Michael? I mean
column3: it's. . .

column1: MICHAEL GERSON: Well
column2: I generally agree with Mark.

column1: And today was supposed to be the end of the world. I think it feels like it for Boehner. This is a case where he ended up with 40 to 50 members of his caucus that wouldn't support anything on this.
MICHAEL GERSON: And they were to the right of Grover Norquist. Norquist was open to the Plan B.
JUDY WOODRUFF: Because he had endorsed Plan B.
MICHAEL GERSON: Right
column2: exactly. So
column3: they want to go off the cliff flags flying. It marginalized Boehner and the Republicans in future negotiations
column4: and raised a question of whether anyone can get a governing majority in the House of Representatives when it comes to the budget.

column1: Those are really serious matters. Now
column2: it does go to the Senate
column3: where Harry Reid and McConnell can try to come to some
column4: you know
column5: functional surrender for Republicans on rates
column6: and kick the can on a lot of other issues
column7: and see if that can pass in the next 10 days.

column1: But that still would pass -- have to pass the House. And so I think the chances of backing off
column2: off the cliff are higher than they ever have been.

column1: JUDY WOODRUFF: You know
column2: I listened to some of these recalcitrant House Republicans today
column3: Mark. And they were saying
column4: I was not going to vote for a tax increase
column5: when my constituents would never have gone along with that.

column1: MARK SHIELDS: Well
column2: I think there's two realities
column3: here
column4: Judy.

column1: First of all
column2: there's a lot of Republicans
column3: and more than a few Democrats
column4: who are terrified of one thing. That's being primaried
column5: a primary opponent who is going to run on your right if you are a Republican
column6: on your left if you are a Democrat. But it's really become a problem for Republicans
column7: because this has been an article of faith that -- said before it is since 1990 that any Republican in the House or the Senate has voted for a tax increase on Capitol Hill
column8: any Republican.

column1: Now
column2: of the 241 Republicans now in the House
column3: 212 of them have come to the Congress since 1990. So
column4: they have never voted for a tax increase. They don't know anybody who has voted for a tax increase. And they were being asked to vote for a tax increase for a tactical advantage on a piece of legislation that they knew the president
column5: A.
column6: would veto
column7: B.
column8: wouldn't pass the Senate.

column1: JUDY WOODRUFF: Only on people earning over a million.
MARK SHIELDS: A million dollars
column2: but they were going to give up their virginity
column3: their political virginity
column4: and risk a primary challenge -- that is how they saw it -- by doing this.

column1: What they failed to address is the reality that
column2: when you are the -- part of the governing party in any institution
column3: the House
column4: the Senate
column5: anyplace else
column6: you have a responsibility to make sure that you can govern. And what they did was
column7: they robbed the Republicans
column8: that 40 to 50. They robbed the Republicans of that -- that sense of leadership
column9: of governability
column10: and robbed them
column11: I think
column12: and reduced the brand of the Republican Party even more.

column1: JUDY WOODRUFF: Is it a fundamental disagreement over what governing is?
MICHAEL GERSON: Yes
column2: I think that that is part of it.

column1: I think what they couldn't answer is how they are going to get a better result. . .
MARK SHIELDS: That's right.
MICHAEL GERSON: . . . after you -- when you go over the cliff
column2: or later on in these negotiations
column3: because they're not. This actually undermines their negotiating power and position
column4: which -- because it is a foolish position to be in.

column1: But it does -- it raises some really big issues. I mean
column2: one of them here is that we now have a president and a speaker who both wanted a deal
column3: OK? By every account
column4: they wanted a deal. They tried it twice. And they couldn't make it happen.

column1: Now
column2: they -- and I don't think they can make it happen. It's a serious kind of governing challenge right now. If you look
column3: we have got a short-term political crisis. We have a long-term fiscal crisis. And we're providing no confidence whatsoever that we can approach those things as a government in a mature way.

column1: We look increasingly like we have the dysfunction
column2: the governmental dysfunction of Europe
column3: without the excuse of being separate countries. And
column4: you know
column5: I think it's a serious challenge to America's standing in the world
column6: that -- the views of credit markets. And Washington is not taking that yet with sufficiency seriously -- seriousness.

column1: MARK SHIELDS: Yes.
I would just add
column2: and not in a partisan way
column3: but the 213 -- 215-209 vote last night in the House before the whole thing came apart
column4: which was that -- to not take the sequestration funds out of defense
column5: but to take them out of domestic spending
column6: was a party-line vote; 209 Democrats stuck on that. Not a single one broke.

column1: And I think -- I think you are seeing far more unity in the Democratic ranks than you are in the Republican ranks right now. I agree it is a governmental problem. If the whole thing comes to a grinding halt and we see it reflected in the financial markets and the stock market and elsewhere
column2: then it's a governmental problem. It's not simply a Democratic advantage
column3: a Republican advantage.

column1: But
column2: right now
column3: the real fault lines are in the Republican Caucus.

column1: JUDY WOODRUFF: Well
column2: we don't -- sounds like neither one -- none of us knows where this is headed.

column1: So let's move to another subject.
Michael
column2: the president today named John Kerry to be secretary of state. It had been widely believed he wanted to choose the U.N. ambassador
column3: Susan Rice.

column1: John Kerry -- what do you make of the choice?
MICHAEL GERSON: Well
column2: it's a -- I think
column3: a safe choice and a good choice. I mean
column4: this is a man who has had three decades on the Foreign Relations Committee
column5: former presidential candidate
column6: would have immediate standing on the global stage
column7: similar to Hillary Clinton
column8: in this kind of job.

column1: He's also been a troubleshooter for the president in some key ways
column2: under the radar screen. When South Sudan was separating from the North
column3: and it looked like those negotiations were breaking down
column4: Kerry came in and really made a difference there. So
column5: I think that
column6: I mean
column7: he looks good after the Rice nomination. He is a less controversial nominee.

column1: He has a lot of respect among his colleagues in the Senate. And so I think that the president -- you know
column2: it was not -- not particularly a hard choice.

column1: JUDY WOODRUFF: Mark?
MARK SHIELDS: I think James Mann and David Ignatius put it very well
column2: I mean
column3: that he is -- he is experienced
column4: probably unmatched in experience. He does bring considerable stature
column5: on a first-name basis with many of the people around the world with whom he will be dealing. He has done
column6: as David pointed out
column7: back-channel missions for the president
column8: whether it's dealing with Hamas
column9: Afghanistan
column10: Pakistan.

column1: And he is eminently confirmable. That's in the Senate. There is no question about it. And it opens up a possibility of a Republican seat in Massachusetts. So
column2: Republicans are cheered by that.

column1: (LAUGHTER)
JUDY WOODRUFF: And
column2: just quickly
column3: before we leave that
column4: there was a -- and this -- we heard this mentioned earlier
column5: that some -- there is still conversation about whether the president is going to name
column6: may name Chuck Hagel
column7: former Republican senator
column8: to be secretary of defense.

column1: A lot of criticism has risen up. Outside groups are saying they are going to defeat him if he's named. What is going on there?
MARK SHIELDS: Yes.
Well
column2: I mean
column3: certainly
column4: Chuck Hagel has been subjected to withering criticism for his lack of constant or at least unswerving support of every Israeli administration. That has been a central part. There are people who have personal issues with Chuck Hagel.

column1: I personally think
column2: A.
column3: he's close to the president. He was close to the president when the president was in the Senate. And I think he brings to it credentials that are sadly lacking in this administration. I mean
column4: this is somebody who has spilled blood
column5: shed blood for his own country
column6: spilled blood for his country
column7: faced combat
column8: chose to go to Vietnam.

column1: He had orders to go to Germany as an enlisted man. He insisted on going to Vietnam
column2: where he faced serious combat. I just think -- I think he brings to it the first Vietnam veteran to be secretary of defense and the only enlisted man ever to be Secretary of Defense. I think those are credentials that are needed.

column1: JUDY WOODRUFF: Any thoughts on that?
MICHAEL GERSON: I think that
column2: sometimes
column3: people say these trial balloons are a sign of presidential weakness if they don't go up.

column1: They're not really. They're actually a smart way for a president to gauge this. I think the opposition to Hagel is growing. I think it is rooted in disagreements
column2: not just about Israel
column3: but about defense cuts
column4: but about his views on Iran
column5: which are significantly to the left of president
column6: and because he has -- he doesn't have a lot of respect of former colleagues here
column7: which are already coming out
column8: and many of them in opposition.

column1: I think it's an unlikely nomination.
JUDY WOODRUFF: Let me turn you both to the gun control discussion.
We heard from the head of the NRA
column2: Mark
column3: today
column4: Wayne LaPierre
column5: who is advocating putting an armed guard in every school. The president has launched a task force this week. Where do you see this headed?

column1: MARK SHIELDS: I mean
column2: to call Wayne LaPierre and the NRA have a tin ear
column3: I think is an understatement. I mean
column4: they seem to be almost whining about criticism of their position
column5: that it somehow was rooted in the press bias or elected officials who have gun-free school zones.

column1: You know
column2: Judy
column3: the reality is -- and it's a terrible reality -- since Robert Kennedy died in the Ambassador Hotel on June 4
column5: more Americans have died from gunfire than died in all the -- all the wars
column6: all the wars of this country's history
column7: from the Revolutionary through the Civil War
column8: World War I
column9: World War II
column10: in those 43 years.

column1: We have half the guns that are in the world are in the United States. I mean
column2: guns are a problem. And I think they still have to be confronted.

column1: JUDY WOODRUFF: Something like 280 million guns.
MICHAEL GERSON: Yes. And we're not going to get rid of all those guns. That's not going to happen. The question is. . .
MARK SHIELDS: Well
column2: we could do -- we could do Daniel Patrick Moynihan
column3: and tax ammunition.

column1: MICHAEL GERSON: Well
column2: yes.

column1: I think that there -- but there are a series of reasonable measures we could take
column2: even going back to what we were doing in the 1990s
column3: when it comes to ammunition
column4: and magazine size
column5: and assault -- certain types of semiautomatic weapons.

column1: You should be able to make that case. We have swung so far in this debate in the libertarian direction
column2: that those are fairly minimal burdens on anyone's rights when it comes to this that might have a marginal positive in fact -- impact on gun violence.

column1: But any solution is also going have to deal with mental health issues. Security in schools
column2: I don't think it's practical to put armed people in tens of thousands of schools. But security in schools
column3: as well as reasonable gun controls
column4: we're going to have to do a bunch of things in this area.

column1: JUDY WOODRUFF: Sobering topic
column2: and we will be coming back to it.

column1: Michael Gerson
column2: Mark Shields
column3: thank you both.

column1: MARK SHIELDS: Thank you
column2: Judy. Thank you.

column1: JUDY WOODRUFF: And Merry Christmas.
MICHAEL GERSON: Merry Christmas.
MARK SHIELDS: Merry Christmas to you. Thank you."	0

column1: 110	"JUDY WOODRUFF: We come back now to the gun story.
And we're joined by David Keene. He's president of the National Rifle Association.
Welcome to the NewsHour.
DAVID KEENE
column2: National Rifle Association: Thank you for having me.

column1: JUDY WOODRUFF: So
column2: earlier on the program
column3: we heard from the governor of Delaware
column4: Jack Markell
column5: who said the critics who argue that what they're trying to do by limiting gun violence and say that it's an attack on the Second Amendment are not right. He said
column6: what we're simply doing are commonsense safety measures.

column1: DAVID KEENE: That's what Michael Bloomberg says.
No
column2: it is an attack on the Second Amendment. It is an attack on those Americans who purchased and legally use firearms
column3: who have never committed a criminal act
column4: who have never done anything wrong. And they can say that it doesn't infringe upon their rights
column5: but
column6: in fact
column7: it does.

column1: Now
column2: every amendment -- the First Amendment -- you can't
column3: famously
column4: yell fire in a crowded theater. The Second Amendment is also subject to reasonable limits. The Supreme Court has held that. But they're strictly looked at.

column1: And you have to demonstrate that they really impact things and that they're really necessary. And the problem that we have is that none of the things that they have suggested are going to do any good. They're asking the question
column2: Judy
column3: what do we do about guns? The question should be
column4: what do we do to prevent the kinds of things that happened in Connecticut?

column1: And we don't think that they're asking that question
column2: but they're pursuing their own agenda.

column1: JUDY WOODRUFF: Well
column2: they say that's what they're doing.

column1: DAVID KEENE: I know they do.
JUDY WOODRUFF: And let me just quickly read from something that Gabby Giffords
column2: the former congresswoman who was gravely wounded. Mark Kelly
column3: her husband.

column1: They wrote an op-ed article just a few days ago. They say
column2: people who are just -- he said: ""Special interests have cast -- have cast simple protections for our communities as existential threats to individual liberties.""

column1: And they say
column2: as a result
column3: more people are vulnerable to gun violence.

column1: DAVID KEENE: You know
column2: they're talking about what they call assault weapons. Actually
column3: an assault weapon
column4: so-called
column5: wasn't involved in the Giffords shooting.

column1: But the fact of the matter is that we have heard time and time again that these are military weapons designed for the battlefield. They're not. They're semiautomatic commercial rifles. The AR-15 is the bestselling long gun in the United States. There are over three million of them that have been purchased by people.
Most people that have them use them for sport shooting
column2: for hunting and for the like. And to take those guns away from them for no reason is an infringement on their rights.

column1: JUDY WOODRUFF: So
column2: the mother of one of the victims in Aurora
column3: Colo.
column4: was visiting Newtown just yesterday
column5: and she specifically talked about the AR-15
column6: these assault weapons.

column1: And she said
column2: they don't belong in the hands of people in the community. What do you say to what -- her name is...

column1: JUDY WOODRUFF: ... Phillips.
DAVID KEENE: It was interesting
column2: Judy
column3: because...

column1: JUDY WOODRUFF: What do you say to her?
DAVID KEENE: ... because we're talking -- anybody who dies in a tragedy
column2: whether it's an auto accident or beaten to death or knifed or killed by a gun
column3: it is tragic. And I can understand her reaction to that.

column1: But
column2: in this country
column3: last year
column4: more people were
column5: in fact
column6: beaten to death than killed by all long arms
column7: including assault
column8: so-called assault weapons. The semiautomatic rifle has been in this country and available to people since 1806.

column1: In our museum
column2: we have got one that fired 20 rounds from a magazine
column3: a magazine that would be banned by some people
column4: that Lewis and Clark took with them on their expedition.

column1: It's been that long. And we're talking -- we're talking about something that has no impact. We have tried to do that as a society before. It hasn't made any difference.
JUDY WOODRUFF: Well
column2: we can argue about the statistics. I mean
column3: what is out there...

column1: DAVID KEENE: Right. People do that.
JUDY WOODRUFF: ... 70 percent of the violent deaths last year were due -- had a gun involved.
But
column2: specifically
column3: David Keene
column4: what about what we're hearing from the president
column5: that there is going to be an attempt to ban the assault weapon
column6: that there will be a proposal for comprehensive background checks? Is there -- where -- is there any common ground between the position of the NRA and the White House?

column1: DAVID KEENE: Yes
column2: there is some common ground.

column1: It's not on banning rifles that we don't think would make any difference. And it's not on setting up a national gun registry.
But we have for 20 years been asking that those people who have been adjudicated to be mentally potentially violent be put on the lists of people who are not allowed to buy firearms.
When you go into a store to buy a gun
column2: or if you go to a gun show to buy a gun from a licensed dealer
column3: they have to check your background. The FBI keep databases of people who are not allowed to buy guns
column4: felons and the like. We have been urging that these people be put on these lists. And nothing has happened.

column1: Twenty-three states don't put any on the list. Now
column2: one of the things we have to do is keep firearms out of the hands of people who shouldn't have them. And we can do that partly in that way. The problem is
column3: you can never predict in a society who is going to do what.

column1: JUDY WOODRUFF: Right.
DAVID KEENE: So
column2: you also have to provide security. And that's what we have been proposing in terms of the schools.

column1: JUDY WOODRUFF: And that's why -- and that's -- and you mentioned mental illness. And that is something the administration is going to talk about.
Maybe there's some common ground there. When it comes to guards
column2: putting armed guards
column3: Gov. Markell said earlier on the program that -- he said
column4: how would you know where to put a guard
column5: how many to put? He said it's really an impractical thing to...

column1: DAVID KEENE: Sure.
Well
column2: I don't think that it's impractical. You know
column3: just by coincidence
column4: I was in Israel the day after the Newtown shooting. And I was touring a facility where they in fact train guards for their schools
column5: because they had a spate of shootings in the 1970s.

column1: Their crazy people are a little different from ours
column2: but the results were the same. And they first used volunteers.

column1: Now each school provides its own through private security guards. And I was a place where they train these people. It works there. It was a sensible thing for them to do.
After Columbine
column2: President Clinton proposed what he called the COPS program. And about 28
column3: 000 schools in this country now either have police through that program or police that are paid for by the state or private security guards. Those schools have them.

column1: Now
column2: and it is -- there's an argument -- the argument against it is just what you said. But the fact is
column3: if you look at the people who do this
column4: first of all
column5: they're mentally deranged. And
column6: secondly
column7: they're cowards. And the fact that there's somebody armed there will prevent them in most cases from doing anything.

column1: Can you -- do we live in a perfect world? No. But we can do what makes sense to protect our kids.
JUDY WOODRUFF: Well
column2: speaking of what's not perfect
column3: what about trying some of the solutions that the folks who are saying they're not trying to attack the Second Amendment are saying? They simply want to make -- they want to reduce gun violence.

column1: Why not try reducing high-capacity ammunition clips? Why not try a ban on assault weapons?
DAVID KEENE: Well
column2: we tried a ban on assault weapons. The only thing that is different is -- and
column3: remember
column4: Judy
column5: that an assault weapon has to be listed because there's no functional difference between a so-called assault weapon and any other semiautomatic rifle.

column1: So
column2: this time
column3: they're saying
column4: well
column5: if it has a pistol grip
column6: it's dangerous. If it doesn't have a pistol grip
column7: it isn't dangerous. Now
column8: that's absurd from a functional standpoint
column9: because it's the same gun
column10: the same rifle. And the only difference is cosmetic.

column1: So
column2: banning something for cosmetic reasons is not going to cause -- is not going to cure the problem.

column1: JUDY WOODRUFF: But you're not saying there's -- couldn't reasonable people sit down at the table and come up with a solution that would satisfy you
column2: your organization and would satisfy those who say
column3: we have got to make it safer?

column1: DAVID KEENE: That's why we went to the meeting with Vice President Biden.
But
column2: you know
column3: before that meeting
column4: the vice president himself and those speaking for him said
column5: we're open-minded. We're going to discuss this. We got to the meeting.

column1: And one of the first things he said was
column2: the president and I have strong feelings about firearms
column3: and nobody is going to change our mind on that. We're going to pursue what we want to pursue.

column1: Fine. They had the meeting
column2: so they could say
column3: oh
column4: and we talked to the NRA.

column1: JUDY WOODRUFF: Well
column2: and I happened to talk to someone in the White House
column3: because I had heard you say something similar to that in another interview. And they say that's not what was said in the meeting.

column1: DAVID KEENE: Well
column2: it is.

column1: And the other thing -- let me say one other thing. In the last year
column3: 000 people who were on the prohibited list tried to buy firearms. That
column4: in itself
column5: is a crime. You know how many have been prosecuted? Seventy.

column1: When that was raised at the meeting
column2: the attorney general said
column3: well
column4: we don't have the resources and the time to be going after those people. Those people are the potential criminals whom we're trying to keep guns out of the hands of
column5: but the government doesn't have time to do anything about them. They do have time to try and prohibit legitimate citizens from owning firearms.

column1: JUDY WOODRUFF: Very quickly
column2: David Keene
column3: the new polls show that are out that show even in gun-owning households people are saying by large percentages we need to do something about
column4: again
column5: high-capacity ammunition clips
column6: assault weapons
column7: background checks?

column1: DAVID KEENE: Well
column2: actually
column3: interestingly
column4: the Gallup poll showed no change at all on the so-called assault weapon question. I consider that evidence of the fact that people are smarter than politicians.

column1: But
column2: given the publicity and everything
column3: I'm surprised that there hasn't been more of an immediate reaction.

column1: But when we get into this
column2: when we begin to discuss it -- and remember it's sort of deja vu
column3: because we have had this discussion before. Once the discussion takes place and people think about the substance of it
column4: I'm confident that the judgment of the American people is going to be as it was before.

column1: And that is that Second Amendment rights should be protected. Criminals should be prosecuted. And we should strengthen the ways we keep guns out of the hands of people who have no business buying them.
JUDY WOODRUFF: David Keene
column2: president of the NRA
column3: we thank you for being with us tonight.

column1: DAVID KEENE: My pleasure
column2: as always. Thank you."	0

column1: 111	"Share Add to your saved stories Save
Ã¢ÂÂFACT: Donald Trump would force schools to allow guns in classrooms on his first day in office.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ Hillary Clinton campaign post on Twitter
column2: May 14
column3: 2016 Wp Get the full experience. Choose your plan ArrowRight One of the nine things the Clinton campaign says Ã¢ÂÂevery voter in America needs to know about Donald TrumpÃ¢ÂÂ is that he would get rid of gun-free zones in schools on his first day in office. Most of the nine items are TrumpÃ¢ÂÂs widely-known ideas (Muslim ban
column4: torture
column5: ISIS
column6: etc.)
column7: but his proposal to allow guns in schools is less familiar to the public.

column1: ThatÃ¢ÂÂs largely because Trump himself hasnÃ¢ÂÂt talked about it much publicly. His campaign
column2: as usual
column3: didnÃ¢ÂÂt respond to our request for more information
column4: and doesnÃ¢ÂÂt seem to have answered other media outletsÃ¢ÂÂ requests
column5: either.

column1: Perhaps Trump is saving the details until his May 20 speech at the National Rifle Association leadership event. (The NRA wants to repeal gun-free zones.) In the meantime
column2: we took a look at the few instances heÃ¢ÂÂs described his plan to see what he intends to do about school gun-free zones.

column1: The Facts
Congress enacted the Gun-Free School Zones Act in 1990
column2: under President George H. W. Bush
column3: as a part of a larger crime bill
column4: in response to school shootings in the 1980s. It was struck down by the Supreme Court because of violations under the Commerce Clause but was reenacted under President Bill Clinton with a list of exceptions supported by the NRA.

column1: Advertisement
The law makes it illegal under federal law for people to carry or discharge a firearm in a school zone
column2: but states can decide whether to allow concealed carry at K-12 schools or colleges. Most states prohibit concealed carry. There is a dispute between gun-rights and gun-control advocates as to whether the law enacted to prevent shootings on school grounds actually motivates people to target schools
column3: since the victims would be unarmed. (We plan to explore this in a future fact-check.)

column1: After the 2012 shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School
column2: states began introducing legislation to arm teachers and staff at K-12 schools. In 2013 alone
column3: at least 33 states introduced more than 80 bills to authorize school districts to allow certain teachers and staff to carry concealed firearms
column4: according to the National Conference of State Legislatures. Since 2013
column5: more states have considered laws allowing guns on college campuses.

column1: That year
column2: seven bills were signed into law allowing limited concealed carry with a permit at K-12 schools (mostly applicable to private schools). Some states have specific exemptions for guns in school zones with a concealed-carry permit
column3: such as guns carried by security or law enforcement or unloaded firearms locked in a vehicle on school property.

column1: Advertisement
Trump has argued against gun-free zones at military bases since last October
column2: but he has been less vocal about repealing gun-free zones at schools.

column1: Share this article Share
The one time he talked about it publicly was at a January 2016 rally in Vermont: Ã¢ÂÂI will get rid of gun-free zones on schools Ã¢ÂÂ you have to Ã¢ÂÂ and on military bases. My first day
column2: it gets signed
column3: okay? My first day. ThereÃ¢ÂÂs no more gun-free zones.Ã¢ÂÂ His campaign did not respond to requests by the media to clarify his proposal.

column1: Our colleague Jenna Johnson reported at the time that the proposal Ã¢ÂÂraises a number of questions
column2: such as: Would this apply to all public schools
column3: from elementary to college? How would schools deal with the likely logistical and safety concerns created by having guns on the grounds?Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: Trump was asked similar questions a few weeks later during an interview with the Outdoor Channel. This seems to be one of the only times he was ever asked directly about his proposal: How would you mandate that legislation? By executive order? Since public schools are legislated by the states
column2: how could you make such an order stick? Would this legislation apply just to public schools
column3: or private as well?

column1: Advertisement
TrumpÃ¢ÂÂs answer was still devoid of specifics:
Ã¢ÂÂIÃ¢ÂÂm going to get rid of the gun-free zones on the military bases. IÃ¢ÂÂm also going to do it in schools. You say you have a school
column2: and itÃ¢ÂÂs gun-free. The criminals are out there saying
column3: Ã¢ÂÂThis is incredible. This is perfect. ThereÃ¢ÂÂs no guns in there. IÃ¢ÂÂm the only one thatÃ¢ÂÂs going to have guns.Ã¢ÂÂ You canÃ¢ÂÂt do it. IÃ¢ÂÂm going to work with the states
column4: and if I have to
column5: IÃ¢ÂÂm going to try and perhaps override the states if I have to
column6: if IÃ¢ÂÂm allowed to do that. . . . But we canÃ¢ÂÂt have gun-free zones where
column7: I see schools advertise
column8: Ã¢ÂÂWe are a gun-free zone.Ã¢ÂÂ And then you have these crazy people out there saying
column9: Ã¢ÂÂBoy
column10: this is the most incredible thing
column11: Ã¢ÂÂ and thatÃ¢ÂÂs happening.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: The Pinocchio Test
Trump hasnÃ¢ÂÂt offered many details of his proposal
column2: but it is clear that he wants to force states to allow guns in schools. Would he propose that Congress repeal the federal ban? Would it become illegal for states to pass laws to prohibit concealed carry at schools? The specifics arenÃ¢ÂÂt clear yet.

column1: Trump said he would Ã¢ÂÂwork with the statesÃ¢ÂÂ but that he would Ã¢ÂÂoverride the states if I have to.Ã¢ÂÂ Based on what he has said publicly so far
column2: Trump indeed would force schools to allow guns. And he wants to make it happen on his first day as president.

112	"THE WHITE HOUSE
Office of the Press Secretary
FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE June 1
BACKGROUND BRIEFING
BY SENIOR ADMINISTRATION OFFICIALS
ON THE GENERAL MOTORS RESTRUCTURING
May 31
Via Conference Call
7:10 P.M. EDT
MS. PSAKI: Thank you
column2: everyone
column3: for joining the call. Just a reminder that the call this evening is on background
column4: and you can attribute quotes to a senior administration official. And the embargo is set for 10:00 p.m. this evening Eastern time. Everyone on this call should also have a fact sheet.

column1: I'm going to turn it over to Robert Gibbs now.
MR. GIBBS: Thanks
column2: everybody
column3: for joining. We're going to do this basically in two parts. The first part
column4: my colleagues will go through the GM specific parts of the call tonight. And then after that we will go through the government ownership principles
column5: which I know a number of you are interested in as part of this and other transactions.

column1: So with that
column2: I'm going to turn it over to my colleague.

column1: SENIOR ADMINISTRATION OFFICIAL: Thanks
column2: I'll just try to run through this reasonably quickly and maximize the time for questions. Everyone should have a fact sheet. I know you've only had it for a short period of time
column3: so let me run through quickly the main points that we wanted to cover.

column1: Everyone is aware that 60 days ago the President announced that he would give General Motors 60 days in order to design a plan for viability that would achieve lasting and permanent profitability and opportunity for success. And since that time the company has been working diligently in conjunction with the auto task force to implement those principles
column2: including one of the President's main principles which was the concept of shared sacrifice among all of the stakeholders.

column1: And so we are here tonight to give you a preview of the results of this
column2: including what the President will talk about tomorrow. So I'll run through that reasonably quickly.

column1: First
column2: within this concept of shared sacrifice there are several things to talk about -- first
column3: as I said
column4: the auto task force has worked with GM on an operational restructuring that is designed to reduce General Motors break-even point of about 16 million annual rate of car sales down to 10 million annual car sales environment. As many of you undoubtedly know
column5: we're running about 9.5 million car sales at the moment. And so we hope that by reducing this break-even point GM will be able to endure a period of difficult car sales before hopefully we will see a recovery
column6: and this will
column7: of course
column8: allow GM to become profitable at a much lower level of car sales than has been the case before.

column1: Secondly
column2: as you know
column3: the UAW has reached a new agreement with GM and that agreement has been ratified that involves significant concessions by the UAW -- concessions that are in virtually every respect more aggressive than what the previous administration demanded in its loan agreement. And one of the major aspects of that settlement
column4: of that renegotiation
column5: was changes in terms of the VEBA -- employee retirement health care trust in which GM had a $20 billion obligation under its existing -- and I'll talk in a second about what's going to happen with that.

column1: GM is also announcing more or less as we speak that the steering committee has reported that bondholders represent at least 54 percent of GM's unsecured bonds
column2: have agreed to tender their portion of the $27 billion of unsecured debt for a pro rata share of 10 percent of the equity of new GM for -- inaudible -- for an additional 58 percent. And so I think from the standpoint of the U.S. government we are very pleased and gratified to be going into the 363 process that will commence tomorrow with such a strong showing of support from the -- inaudible -- community.

column1: And then GM is also announcing tonight the specifics of its operational restructuring with respect to its plant operations. And we will leave the details of that to them as it is their decisions and their restructuring.
So we are going through
column2: as I think everyone here is aware
column3: a 363 process that we hope and expect will be similar to Chrysler. We do not expect it to be as speedy as Chrysler's because GM is a far larger
column4: far more complicated global company
column5: but we do expect it to proceed
column6: broadly speaking
column7: along similar lines to the Chrysler one
column8: which you all know
column9: has made very good progress and is very close to a successful outcome.

column1: So in the context of that 363
column2: a new company
column3: a new GM
column4: if you will
column5: will be formed to purchase the operating assets out of the old General Motors that will become part of this new company. And left behind in the old company will be liabilities and other miscellaneous assets that are no longer needed as part of the new General Motors that we expect to create.

column1: So as part of that several other things will happen. First
column2: the new GM will establish a new VEBA
column3: a new independent trust. And you will recall that I mentioned the $20 billion obligation that the old General Motors had to VEBA. As part of the shared sacrifice that the President has emphasize
column4: that will be replaced by a $2.5 billion note
column5: $6.5 billion of preferred stock
column6: and 17.5 percent of the equity of new GM -- thus warrants to purchase an additional 2.5 percent of the company.

column1: As was the case in Chrysler
column2: VEBA will have the right to select one independent director
column3: and as in the case with Chrysler
column4: and will be the case with both companies
column5: neither VEBA nor UAW will have any right to voter's share or any other government right. So it is with the exception of one independent director
column6: a purely passive interest.

column1: As was the case with Chrysler
column2: the qualified pension plan for both hourly and salaried employees will be carried over to the new GM and will remain intact and benefits will be paid in the normal course.

column1: Thirdly
column2: as I mentioned
column3: the U.S. Treasury is preparing to provide about $30 billion of additional financing through -- inaudible -- possession process during this Chapter 11 to meet both working capital needs during the bankruptcy process as well as to refinance certain existing obligations
column4: and as well as to be sure that the company has the means to be successful in the future. And I'll talk a little bit more about that in a second.

column1: The U.S. Treasury does not believe or anticipate that any additional assistance to GM will be required. We intend for this to be a permanent resolution of the GM situation and an ability for the company to go forward and be profitable.
In exchange for the $30.1 billion
column2: the U.S. government will receive about $9 billion of debt and preferred stock in the new GM and approximately 60 percent of the equity in the new company.

column1: Let me emphasize in anticipation of those later discussion and questions that we did not seek or solicit or desire to have this equity position. We came upon it simply as a matter of prudence and out of desire to assure that GM was able to go forward with a flexible
column2: deleverage balance sheet
column3: one that is capable of sustaining itself during -- in a very cyclical business in what is obviously a difficult environment. And so we had a choice as guardians of the taxpayer dollars
column4: which was to either take this equity as part of the consideration that we could receive on behalf of the U.S. taxpayers
column5: and hopefully have it result in the taxpayers receiving a greater recovery
column6: or we could have simply left it behind and given it to others and taxpayers would have ended up much shorter in terms of the total outcome. So the equity ownership of the U.S. government is not something we sought or desired; it was simply a necessary outcome of the restructuring process and a desire to have GM with a substantially deleveraged balance sheet and able to be competitive.

column1: We're also very pleased to say that the governments of Canada and Ontario -- similar to the situation with Chrysler
column2: will participate alongside the Treasury by lending about $9.5 billion and they will also receive both debt and preferred stock and about 12 percent of the equity in the new GM
column3: and similar to the case with Chrysler
column4: the right to pick one of the initial directors.

column1: I think at that point I will -- I think I've covered now the main points on GM
column2: so let me turn it back to Robert

column1: MR. GIBBS: Thanks. Before we take questions on that -- do you want to go through our government ownership principles now? I know it's a big part of what a lot of folks are interested in.
SENIOR ADMINISTRATION OFFICIAL: Sure
column2: let me take that on and start by saying that while this
column3: of course applies to GM right now
column4: this is part of a much broader effort to articulate principles for the U.S. government investments in a series of other companies as well. So this is more about how we can expect the government to act as a common shareholder in this and other cases.

column1: The first starting point is really to pick up on something you said
column2: which is the government really has no desire to own equity stakes in companies any longer than is absolutely necessary and will actively seek to dispose its ownership interest as soon as it is practical to do that. The goal is to promote strong
column3: viable companies that can become profitable quickly
column4: can contribute to growth and jobs without government involvement. And there is absolute clarity about that.

column1: Of course
column2: in exceptional cases where the U.S. government feels it's necessary to respond to a company's request for assistance the government has decided to reserve the right to set upfront conditions that will protect taxpayers and promote the financial stability or encourage growth. And in the sense of -- inaudible -- conditions
column3: there has been some -- as you've seen in this restructuring and in some other companies
column4: where necessary
column5: these conditions are precisely the kinds of restructuring that my colleague has talked about and would focus primarily on ensuring a strong board of directors
column6: that focuses on the right kind of management that can deliver a long-term vision
column7: that gets these companies to be profitable
column8: ends the need for government support as quickly as is practical.

column1: Now
column2: after those upfront conditions are in place
column3: the government feels that it can protect taxpayers' investment by managing its ownership stake as a hands-off in a commercial manner as possible. And so the government will not interfere with or exert control over day-to-day company operations and very much will ensure that no government employees will serve on board or be employed by the company it makes investments in.

column1: As a shareholder
column2: the government will limit what it votes on to core governance issues
column3: particularly the selection of the company's board of directors; major corporate events or transactions. And in its effort to protect taxpayers' resources as much as possible
column4: the government intends to be extremely disciplined as to how it uses even these limited rights.

column1: So those
column2: as I said
column3: are the principles that apply here in the upfront restructuring of GM and in the intention of the government going forward
column4: but are consistently being applied where the U.S. finds itself in these kinds of situations.

column1: MS. PSAKI: Thank you so much. I think we're ready to turn it over to questions at this point.
Q Good evening. Appreciating that this is obviously a bigger company than Chrysler
column2: how quickly do you expect you can get it through
column3: and do you expect that legally it will be more difficult?

column1: SENIOR ADMINISTRATION OFFICIAL: In 60 to 90 days; more complicated and many more moving pieces
column2: but we are hopeful that it will have a similar successful outcome.

column1: Q Can you speak a little bit about the input that you will have on the selection of some of the directors -- you're not naming them directly
column2: but you will have input into who some of the new board members are -- what kind of direct or indirect input
column3: and what would you be looking for in the directors?

column1: SENIOR ADMINISTRATION OFFICIAL: Let me say a couple of things about that. First
column2: you'll recall that at the time the President
column3: on March 30th -- announced that a majority of the directors of new General Motors would be new
column4: so by implication
column5: there will be a number of existing General Motors directors that will continue with the new company and there will be identified
column6: based on consultations between the current chairman and his colleagues and ourselves -- there has been a process underway since that announcement
column7: led by the General Motors board
column8: to identify additional directors
column9: again in consultation with the U.S. government.

column1: Thirdly
column2: with respect to the kinds of people that are being sought
column3: they are business leaders
column4: CEOs
column5: former CEOS
column6: people from other walks of life with relevant experience and can contribute
column7: regardless of political background
column8: affiliation
column9: or nature. And I would point you to the selection of the term at Chrysler
column10: Bob Kidder
column11: very distinguished former businessman
column12: former CEO of Borden
column13: former CEO of Duracell
column14: his politics are not known to any of us anyway
column15: who has agreed to take this on because of his belief in this industry and belief and desire that Chrysler could succeed. And I think Bob Kidder exemplifies the type of individual that will be sought to serve on the new General Motors board.

column1: Q Are we going to see the new board members named tomorrow or is that a longer process?
SENIOR ADMINISTRATION OFFICIAL: I would expect over the 60 to 90 days
column2: by the time the company comes out of bankruptcy 60 or 90 days from now
column3: I would expect you to see substantial additions to the GM board.

column1: SENIOR ADMINISTRATION OFFICIAL: As a technical matter
column2: these directors will actually join the board of New Co.
column3: which will be buying the assets out of General Motors.

column1: Q Gentlemen
column2: can you specify how the UAW negotiations altered the restructuring plan and are there still the number of plants being closed as before
column3: even though there is one new assembly plant -- also how would the process for -- inaudible -- dealer count of GM mirror or change from that used by Chrysler in its bankruptcy case?

column1: SENIOR ADMINISTRATION OFFICIAL: We were involved in helping to facilitate the discussions between the UAW and General Motors
column2: but I think those are matters that are best left to the two of them. I think the UAW has spoken about its contracts and what it believes. Obviously the vast majority of its members have ratified it. And General Motors has spoken about the contract. So I think they're both satisfied with it and we're satisfied with it
column3: but we don't see a need to get into the details.

column1: SENIOR ADMINISTRATION OFFICIAL: And with respect to your second question
column2: GM has already embarked on the beginnings of its new -- inaudible -- program. They have different management in process
column3: so inevitably it thinks about life slightly differently and so it's a slightly different process that they're going through
column4: but the goal and the end result is intended to be very similar.

column1: Q Can you talk a little bit about how long it might take to get all this money back over time and what your expectations are as to how much the taxpayer might see back on this?

SENIOR ADMINISTRATION OFFICIAL: I don't think we're here today to predict or project. We designed the restructuring to maximize the potential for taxpayer money. The company has done a great job on the operational restructuring -- in conjunction with our colleagues in order to facilitate that. And so we certainly intend to maximize taxpayer proceeds
column2: but I would also point you back to what my colleague said
column3: that we intend to also exit as soon as practical.

column1: Q My question is to expand the subsidiary of GM. Australia
column2: for instance
column3: has got a subsidiary of General Motors America. What will happen to those subsidiaries
column4: and will there be any restrictions on the new GM investing in factories overseas
column5: like for instance
column6: the factory in Australia?

column1: SENIOR ADMINISTRATION OFFICIAL: One of the principles that the President established early on that we have very much intimated as part of this is that U.S. taxpayer dollars should stay within the U.S. And that is not intended to sound protectionist -- I think it's a principle that every country follows. And so we do not intend to use U.S. taxpayer dollars to support foreign subsidiaries. Happily
column2: most of GM's foreign subsidiaries are able to sustain themselves independently or by receiving support from their local governments
column3: as I believe will be the case in Australia. We have had contacts with the Australian government on this matter and I believe they're intending to support GM Australia.

column1: You're all aware of the restructuring of Opal -- of GM Europe
column2: and that was effected under the same set of principles
column3: and those are the principles that we intend to maintain going forward. I think having a global footprint is certainly an advantage to General Motors
column4: and to the extent that it is financially prudent and within those principles
column5: we'd certainly like to see it continue.

column1: Q Good evening. Could you give us a sense whether any members on the current GM board will be remaining on the board of the new company
column2: and how that will work with the lead executives at GM
column3: as well
column4: please?

column1: SENIOR ADMINISTRATION OFFICIAL: Well
column2: I believe I already answered that question by reminding you that the President
column3: on March 30th
column4: said that the majority of the GM board will become new members
column5: which means a minority will be old members. And so we do expect to have some continuity with respect to those members. Fritz Henderson is the CEO and like all CEOs
column6: serves at the pleasure of the board
column7: and we would expect that that relationship would continue.

column1: Q As GM restructures and the government is now involved in that company
column2: how -- or will the government get involved in new jobs
column3: or should I say
column4: fuel-efficient
column5: alternative-fuel sources
column6: starting with that type of training with GM employees?

column1: SENIOR ADMINISTRATION OFFICIAL: As my colleague suggested
column2: there are a number of principles that are going to govern our behavior as a shareholder in this company and others
column3: one of which is no involvement in day-to-day business matters. And that will be a continuing principle for us. Of course the government of the United States has many relationships with the automobile industry as a whole
column4: including foreign companies and including companies that have not been the beneficiaries of financial support from the U.S. government. And those matters
column5: whether they go to regulation for fuel efficiency
column6: or regulation for safety or support
column7: or employment or what have you
column8: will continue
column9: but they will continue on a track entirely separate from and not driven by our role as shareholders.

column1: I might mention the President some time ago appointed Ed Montgomery
column2: the former deputy secretary of labor
column3: to support him in assuring that we were doing everything that we could for communities in Michigan.

column1: Q I was just wondering if you guys are disclosing which plants or factories may close as part of all this restructuring. I know there's been talk of 14
column2: or is that still up in the air right now or haven't been determined?

column1: SENIOR ADMINISTRATION OFFICIAL: As I said earlier
column2: General Motors I believe is in the process of releasing that information
column3: and I think
column4: in the context of what my colleague said about us not making plant-by-plant or any other kind of management decisions
column5: we will leave that to them.

column1: Q Thank you. I've got a couple of quick things. Are secured bondholders
column2: do they get a hundred percent back? Does the tax lump carry forward
column3: go to the new company? And can you say that there's no negative impact on Ford from these arrangements that you've described? Thank you.

column1: SENIOR ADMINISTRATION OFFICIAL: With respect to the first question
column2: there are no secured bondholders in GM; there are secured banks
column3: and they will receive a full recovery because they are amply secured
column4: as distinct from the banks in Chrysler which were not fully secured.

column1: With respect to your second question
column2: I'm going to let my colleague answer -- would you expect the transfer? And what was the third question? Oh
column3: Ford.

column1: SENIOR ADMINISTRATION OFFICIAL: Ford has ample financial resources. Ford has been very successful in maintaining and even growing its market share during this period and is a world-class company
column2: and we do believe completely -- and that has been the President's decision -- the belief that this country can support three domestic successful
column3: viable auto companies.

column1: Q Thanks
column2: guys. A number of the principles -- the governmental principles you've established -- members of Congress have asked GM and the administration to keep the company from importing cars made in Chinese plants. Is that an issue that the administration will specifically stay away from
column3: or will it take a position? Have you made a preference known to GM's management?

column1: SENIOR ADMINISTRATION OFFICIAL: GM has made a commitment in its later agreement with respect to production in North America. But as to any specific thing
column2: no
column3: that would be a kind of specific commercial thing and would not be the object of our negotiation with the company.

column1: Q -- any additional money going into GM beyond the $30.1 billion that you're extending now -- is that an expectation
column2: or are you saying
column3: or will the President say that this is it for GM
column4: this is the extent of taxpayer money and they won't get any additional funding?

column1: SENIOR ADMINISTRATION OFFICIAL: There's no plan of any kind
column2: intention
column3: contingency plan
column4: anything of any kind for further support beyond this point.

column1: Q But beyond not having as plan are you saying that there's no way they will get --
SENIOR ADMINISTRATION OFFICIAL: We believe the support being provided within a framework on a conservative economic assumption should allow the company if stakeholders do what they need to do
column2: if its managers are successful in doing what they need to do
column3: to be commercially viable going forward and not require extraordinary support going forward. One never says never with respect to any hypothetical contingency that could arise in the future
column4: but this is it for support for GM
column5: and on a go forward basis
column6: GM's position will be the same as that of any other company in the United States.

column1: SENIOR ADMINISTRATION OFFICIAL: We are reducing GM's liability by well over 50 percent and providing it with the financial flexibility that we truly believe -- and an enormous amount of work that's been done here that will allow it to be viable even under today's difficult economic circumstances.
Q I just wanted to ask what the sort of anticipated future of the whole task force operation that you all have set up is going to be? And maybe this answers that question
column2: but whether there will be
column3: six months from now or a year from now
column4: some part of the U.S. government that will look after the shares that we will have in the two car companies
column5: if only at a distance?

column1: SENIOR ADMINISTRATION OFFICIAL: There are a number of people around the table who are looking at me with interest in how I answer this. On a go forward from here
column2: moving through this bankruptcy where the government has a major role
column3: there is a great deal to be done
column4: and the staff of the task force will continue to be very active. The Cabinet members who comprise the task force will continue to play their role in providing expertise on a range of issues. On a go-forward basis
column5: the government will obviously adjust its staffing to its needs. But for now
column6: there's plenty to do.

column1: Q As it is now
column2: you guys have folks in Detroit -- I'm not sure what numbers there are. Is it anticipated that you'll continue to have representation on site going forward?

column1: SENIOR ADMINISTRATION OFFICIAL: We don't have anybody in Detroit on any kind of long-term basis. People obviously go out there in the context of diligence. I think we -- in the context of what my colleague said about the government as shareholder
column2: we are shareholders
column3: like a lot of other people who don't control companies. And in that respect
column4: we expect that the taxpayers will want us to monitor their investment and be sure that we understand what's going on
column5: but we're not going to be having people based in Detroit or anything like that.

column1: Q What will the government's position be in terms of executive compensation issues?
SENIOR ADMINISTRATION OFFICIAL: There are a series of laws and other regulations that exist
column2: and the company will comply with all of them.

column1: Q But will you -- you'll have the ability to name the compensation committee. Will you leave it to the compensation committee? Will there be any government policy -- because you have a policy with the banking bailout; I'm wondering if you're going to have any kind of a policy for this industrial company.
SENIOR ADMINISTRATION OFFICIAL: Again
column2: there are a series of policies; there's the Dodd amendment
column3: there will be regulations to implement the Dodd amendment in due course
column4: and the company will live with them. We don't intend to name the compensation committee per se. We intend to
column5: as we said
column6: to work with the company and their initial directors
column7: but the compensation committee will operate on its own. And we assume
column8: just as it has during the period of the loan agreements where there were also compensation restrictions
column9: that it will operate within them.

column1: SENIOR ADMINISTRATION OFFICIAL: And like as in any company
column2: the board will name a compensation committee.

column1: Q Thanks
column2: guys. Just a couple quick questions. Can you talk about the appointment of the chief restructuring officer and about the bad assets that GM will leave behind
column3: even if you're not going to name the plants or the dealers that might be left behind? And also
column4: is the government planning or encouraging any more management changes at GM?

column1: SENIOR ADMINISTRATION OFFICIAL: I think those are all pretty much questions for the company in terms of the naming of the chief restructuring officer is a company decision. The assets that will be left behind will be -- are being chosen
column2: have been chosen by the company
column3: and again we would direct you to them to answer those questions. And in terms of management changes
column4: we have nothing further to announce on that at this time. As I said earlier
column5: Fritz Henderson and other management key members serve at the pleasure of the board. It will be up to the existing board until emergence and then the new board to make any decisions about management.

column1: MS. PSAKI: We have time for one more question.
Q I just wanted to go back to the question of the task force. In terms of the longevity of the task force
column2: do you perceive it being needed well beyond the bankruptcy proceeding itself? I mean
column3: do you perceive the task force being in existence in fact until the company is sold?

column1: SENIOR ADMINISTRATION OFFICIAL: The company is not going to be -- I mean
column2: I'm not sure what you mean by the company being sold. The company will go through this restructuring period; new GM will emerge as part of the 363 process; and then the company will continue
column3: as we said
column4: as a private company operating in the for-profit commercial role and so forth. And the government
column5: as we indicated
column6: is a reluctant -- will be a reluctant shareholder for only as long as is necessary
column7: for as long as -- we will be out as soon as is practicable. During that period of time
column8: we imagine that the taxpayers want us to be looking after their money
column9: and so as we indicated
column10: there will be people here watching over that investment
column11: but as I indicated
column12: in the nature of passive shareholders similar to Fidelity or some other large investment firm that has a large stake in a company.

column1: MS. PSAKI: Thank you
column2: everyone
column3: for joining the call. As a reminder
column4: this is embargoed until 10:00 p.m. Eastern time.

column1: END
7:40 P.M. EDT

116	"Rising to a New Generation of Global Challenges
Mitt Romney
From Foreign Affairs
column2: July/August 2007

column1: Summary: Washington is as divided on foreign policy as it has been at any point in the last 50 years. As the ""greatest generation"" did before us
column2: we must move beyond political camps to unite around bold actions in order to build a strong America and a safer world. We must strengthen our military and economy
column3: achieve energy independence
column4: reenergize civilian and interagency capabilities
column5: and revitalize our alliances. Mitt Romney
column6: Governor of Massachusetts from 2003 to 2007
column7: is a candidate for the Republican presidential nomination.

column1: Topics:
U.S. policy and politics
National security and defense
WASHINGTON DIVIDED Less than six years after 9/11
column2: Washington is as divided and conflicted over foreign policy as it has been at any point in the last 50 years. Senator Arthur Vandenberg once famously declared that ""politics stops at the water's edge""; today
column3: the chair of the House Foreign Affairs Committee declares that our major political parties should carry out two separate foreign policies. The Senate unanimously confirmed General David Petraeus
column4: who pledged to implement a new strategy
column5: as the commander of U.S. forces in Iraq. Yet just weeks later
column6: the Senate began crafting legislation specifically designed to stop that new strategy. More broadly
column7: lines have been drawn between those labeled ""realists"" and those labeled ""neoconservatives."" Yet these terms mean little when even the most committed neoconservative recognizes that any successful policy must be grounded in reality and even the most hardened realist admits that much of the United States' power and influence stems from its values and ideals. In the midst of these divisions
column8: the American people -- and many others around the world -- have increasing doubts about the United States' direction and role in the world. Indeed
column9: it seems that concern about Washington's divisiveness and capability to meet today's challenges is the one thing that unites us all. We need new thinking on foreign policy and an overarching strategy that can unite the United States and its allies -- not around a particular political camp or foreign policy school but around a shared understanding of how to meet a new generation of challenges. A GENERATION'S LEGACY OF LEADERSHIP Today's challenges are daunting. They include the conflict in Iraq
column10: the resurgence of the Taliban
column11: and global terrorist networks made even more menacing by the threat of nuclear proliferation. While Iran's leaders relentlessly pursue nuclear weapons capabilities and spout genocidal threats against Israel
column12: the world largely stands silent
column13: unable to agree on effective sanctions even as each day the danger grows. Genocide ravages Darfur even as the world stands frozen. In Latin America
column14: leaders such as Venezuelan President Hugo ChÃÂ¡vez seek to reverse the spread of freedom and return to failed authoritarian policies. AIDS and potential new pandemics threaten us in an interconnected world. The economic rise of China and other countries across Asia poses a different type of challenge. It is easy to understand why Americans -- and many others around the world -- feel so much unease and uncertainty. Yet although we face fundamentally different issues today
column15: the United States has a history of rising to meet even greater challenges. Indeed
column16: we need not look to ancient history
column17: but only to the courage and determination of our parents and grandparents to see a stark contrast with the confusion and infighting of Washington today. Just over 60 years ago
column18: we were in the midst of a global war that would take the lives of tens of millions. The outcome was far from certain. General Dwight Eisenhower drafted a short note before the D-day landings at Normandy accepting full responsibility ""in case of failure."" The invasion did not fail. Yet no sooner had we defeated fascism than we were engaged in a 50-year struggle with communism. Those whom the journalist Tom Brokaw memorialized as ""the greatest generation"" made the tough choices that allowed us to prevail in these struggles. And it was not just our Washington leaders who were decisive. In the 1940s
column19: Americans rationed and saved
column20: and mothers and daughters enlisted to work in factories. Together with the GIs who returned home
column21: they built this country's prosperity and fueled a sense of optimism. In the 1960s
column23: and 1980s
column24: America pursued learning and innovation to lead the world in space
column25: technology
column26: and productivity -- outcompeting the Soviets and driving them to an economic bankruptcy that matched their moral bankruptcy. In the aftermath of World War II and with the coming of the Cold War
column27: members of ""the greatest generation"" united America and the free world around shared values and actions that changed history. They unified U.S. military and security efforts
column28: creating the Department of Defense and the National Security Council. They rethought U.S. approaches to the world
column29: building the U.S. Agency for International Development
column30: the Office of the U.S. Trade Representative
column31: and the Peace Corps. They forged alliances
column33: that magnified the power of freedom and created a world trading system that helped launch the greatest expansion of economic and political freedom and development in history. Our times call for equally bold leadership and for a renewed sense of service and shared sacrifice among Americans and our allies around the world. A NEW GENERATION OF CHALLENGES
