column1: 119	"Snopes Paid to Push Ã¢ÂÂPropagandaÃ¢ÂÂ by Facebook
column2: Former Editor Reveals

column1: Claims 'fact-checkers' are paid to 'appear to prevent damage' while pushing an agenda
ÃÂ© press Former managing editor at Snopes Brooke Binkowski says the 'fact-checker' is pushing 'propaganda'
Snopes is paid by Facebook to push ""propaganda
column2: according to the former managing editor of the ""fact-checker
column3: who claims the social media giant ""doesn't care"" about facts and is using journalists to promote an agenda so it can ""pass the buck.""

column1: According to a bombshell report by the Guardian
column2: several current and former Facebook fact-checkers have stepped forward and spoken out to reveal their distrust in the social network and their fact-checking employers.

column1: Facebook has fact-checking partnerships with Snopes
column2: PolitiFact
column3: Factcheck.org
column4: the Weekly Standard
column5: and Associated Press
column6: and uses the information provided by these organizations to reduce the reach of posts that are ""debunked"" in their News Feed.

column1: The partnering with these fact-checkers has come under heavy criticism
column2: mainly due to the almost-monopolized influence news on Facebook has
column3: which is then being filtered out by unregulated individuals who are often financially motivated and express political bias.

column1: Ã¢ÂÂTheyÃ¢ÂÂve essentially used us for crisis PR
column2: Ã¢ÂÂ declared former Snopes managing editor Brooke Binkowski during an interview with the Guardian.

column1: Ã¢ÂÂTheyÃ¢ÂÂre not taking anything seriously.
They are more interested in making themselves look good and passing the buckÃ¢ÂÂ¦
They clearly donÃ¢ÂÂt care.Ã¢ÂÂ
Ã¢ÂÂYouÃ¢ÂÂre not doing journalism anymore. YouÃ¢ÂÂre doing propaganda
column2: Ã¢ÂÂ she continued
column3: adding
column4: Ã¢ÂÂThey threw us under the bus at every opportunity.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: Another former Snopes employee
column2: Kim LaCapria
column3: recently left the company over its partnership with Facebook
column4: accusing it of focusing only on the Ã¢ÂÂappearance of trying to prevent damage without actually doing anything
column5: Ã¢ÂÂ and expressing distaste with the fact that Snopes was being paid by Facebook.

column1: LaCapria said she was particularly upset to learn that Facebook was paying Snopes: Ã¢ÂÂThat felt really gross Ã¢ÂÂ¦ Facebook has one mission and fact-checking websites should have a completely different mission.Ã¢ÂÂ
Aside from allegedly being paid by Facebook
column2: Snopes also generates revenue by filling its website with advertisements from Google Adsense
column3: asking for donations from readers via PayPal
column4: and has an active GoFundMe campaign to ""Save Snopes"" which has so far generated over $850
column5: 000 of its $2 million goal.

column1: Of course
column2: it's understandable that a website has overheads that need to be covered
column3: but when a company is primarily driven by profit
column4: how can they be trusted to remain non-partisan?

column1: According to a report by the Daily Mail
column2: Snopes founder David Mikkelson was accused of embezzling thousands from the company.

column1: Mikkelson's ex-wife Barbara
column2: claimed in legal documents he embezzled $98
column3: 000 of company money and spent it on ""himself and prostitutes.""

column1: During the lengthy and bitter legal dispute
column2: CEO David Mikkelson also claimed to be underpaid and was demanding the ""industry standard"" or at least $360
column3: 000 a year.

column1: Being motivated by ""facts"" is apparently very lucrative.
And in the case of Snopes
column2: their business model is a simple
column3: yet devastatingly effective one since they partnered with Facebook and Google: They debunk viral news
column4: and posts.

column1: Therefore
column2: if a post goes viral on social media
column3: and Snopes says that it's ""false
column4: then it will be flagged as so and Facebook will place a link to the ""fact-check
column5: thus driving more traffic and revenue to Snopes.

column1: Due to this arrangement
column2: it adds a clear incentive to mark a viral news story as false rather than confirming lesser-known facts as true.

column1: ÃÂ© press Snopes founder David Mikkelson was accused on embezzling company money
Over recent months this push to flag big news stories as ""false
column2: mainly from conservative websites
column3: has become more apparent.

column1: In November
column2: Breitbart accused Snopes of attempting to ""wash away"" the story of armed members of the New Black Panther Party campaigning for the Democrat gubernatorial candidate in Georgia
column3: Stacey Abrams.

column1: According to Breitbart
column2: the move was an ""openly partisan"" attempt to protect Abrams after the damaging story went viral.

column1: Earlier this month
column2: The Daily Caller also accused Snopes of left-bias after it ""botched"" its fact-check of a viral meme that was mocked within political circles for spreading false information.

column1: Snopes said that the Ã¢ÂÂgeneral ideaÃ¢ÂÂ of the meme was Ã¢ÂÂcorrect
column2: Ã¢ÂÂ yet
column3: according to the TheDCNF
column4: the fact-checker intentionally framed it that way as it portrayed President Trump in a negative light if the ""wildly misleading"" meme was true.

column1: In Snopes ""transparency"" disclaimer
column2: it states that it operates ""without any partisan considerations
column3: saying:

column1: We donÃ¢ÂÂt choose or exclude items for coverage based on whether they deal with Republican/Democratic
column2: conservative/liberal
column3: or religious/secular issues.""

column1: Despite this statement
column2: the left-leaning bias of their fact-checkers is clear.

column1: Snopes' ""science dude"" Alex Kasprak makes no secret of his political bias
column2: and one look at his Twitter account shows it is filled with anti-Trump rhetoric and retweets of Trump-bashing posts.

column1: The only way to report on that ""totally clears the president"" tweet is to highlight it as an example of our president's abject delusion
column2: not as a valid legal opinion or as ""breaking news"" Ã¢ÂÂ Alex H. Kasprak (@alexkasprak) December 8

column1: Prior to joining Snopes
column2: Kasprak wrote for left-wing news outlets Motherboard and BuzzFeed and is pegged as a ""science writer"" who mainly ""debunks"" science-related articles.

column1: It comes as no surprise then that Kasprak mainly fact-checks conservative news sites
column2: often using derogatory language when describing the outlets and their writers
column3: using terms such as ""right-wing blog"" and ""junk news.""

column1: Biting the hand that feeds
Snopes apparent bias has seen the company suffer considerably over recent months as it continues to abuse its influence over Facebook's News Feed to promote a political agenda.
Visits to snopes.com have plummeted by almost half over recent months as users are seemingly losing trust in the organization.
According to website data tool SimilarWeb
column2: visits to Snopes dropped another 20 percent in November to 19.59 million for the month.

column1: This number is a considerable drop from their July figure of 37.79 million
column2: representing a staggering 48.16 percent drop in website traffic in just four months.

column1: While it's unclear what has caused this drop
column2: when you consider that being flagged as ""fake news"" on Facebook cuts reach to the websites being debunked
column3: it's clear to see that attacking the sources of their viral ""fact-checks
column4: is hardly sustainable if it destroys the sites that it continually attacks.

column1: ÃÂ© SimilarWeb Website visits to Snopes have plummeted by almost 50 percent since July
The appearance of trying to prevent damage
Ã¢ÂÂWhy should we trust Facebook when itÃ¢ÂÂs pushing the same rumors that its own fact checkers are calling fake news?Ã¢ÂÂ an unnamed Facebook fact-checker told the Guardian.

Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs worth asking how do they treat stories about George Soros on the platform knowing they specifically pay people to try to link political enemies to him?[Ã¢ÂÂ¦] Working with Facebook makes us look bad.Ã¢ÂÂ
According to Breitbart
column2: one fact-checker who has reportedly Ã¢ÂÂlong workedÃ¢ÂÂ with Facebook even referred to the social network as a Ã¢ÂÂterrible company
column3: Ã¢ÂÂ declaring
column4: Ã¢ÂÂand
column5: on a personal level
column6: I donÃ¢ÂÂt want to have anything to do with them
column7: Ã¢ÂÂ while another fact-checker proclaimed
column8: Ã¢ÂÂMost of us feel itÃ¢ÂÂs more trouble than itÃ¢ÂÂs worth.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: Facebook started its fact-checking efforts following President TrumpÃ¢ÂÂs 2016 presidential election victory and is even expanding into fact-checking images and videos.
Left-wing biases have been found at nearly all Facebook fact-check partners in the United States
column2: including Snopes
column3: Politifact
column4: and the Weekly Standard.

column1: An investigation revealed that Snopes employs left-wing people almost exclusively
column2: with some of its most prominent fact-checkers openly describing themselves as Ã¢ÂÂprogressiveÃ¢ÂÂ and expressing anti-Trump sentiment.

column1: A satirical article from popular satire website Babylon Bee about CNN using a washing machine to Ã¢ÂÂspin the news
column2: Ã¢ÂÂ was also nearly removed by Facebook after Snopes fact-checked it as false.

column1: One of FacebookÃ¢ÂÂs other top fact-checking partners
column2: Politifact
column3: is funded by a frequent Clinton Foundation donor
column4: and gave preferential treatment to Hillary Clinton during the 2016 presidential election Ã¢ÂÂ rating 51 percent of ClintonÃ¢ÂÂs claims as true versus just over 15 percent for Trump.

column1: Even a 2013 article from one of FacebookÃ¢ÂÂs other fact-checking partners
column2: the Weekly Standard
column3: claimed Politifact Ã¢ÂÂhas it out for Republicans
column4: Ã¢ÂÂ and the Weekly Standard itself has also pushed out misleading information during its partnership with Facebook.

column1: UPDATE: Since this article was published
column2: and subsequently went viral on social media
column3: Snopes CEO David Mikkelson denied the information we presented in this article. Snopes didn't ""fact-check"" or ""debunk"" any of the information
column4: nor did they present any evidence to refute the claims. Mikkelson
column5: however
column6: saw fit to abuse his position as Facebook approved ""fact-checker"" and flagged our story as a ""hoax"" with Facebook
column7: pulling it from users' News Feed
column8: immediately squashing the story as a result. Make of that what you will."	1

column1: 120	"NASHVILLE
column2: Tennessee (CNN) -- Presidential candidates John McCain and Barack Obama debated in Nashville
column3: Tennessee
column4: on Tuesday night. NBC's Tom Brokaw moderated the debate. Here is a transcript of that debate.

column1: Sen. Barack Obama and Sen. John McCain meet in Nashville for their second debate.
Brokaw: Good evening from Belmont University in Nashville
column2: Tennessee. I'm Tom Brokaw of NBC News. And welcome to this second presidential debate
column3: sponsored by the Commission on Presidential Debates.

column1: Tonight's debate is the only one with a town hall format. The Gallup Organization chose 80 uncommitted voters from the Nashville area to be here with us tonight. And earlier today
column2: each of them gave me a copy of their question for the candidates.

column1: From all of these questions -- and from tens of thousands submitted online -- I have selected a long list of excellent questions on domestic and foreign policy.
Neither the commission nor the candidates have seen the questions. And although we won't be able to get to all of them tonight
column2: we should have a wide-ranging discussion one month before the election.

column1: Each candidate will have two minutes to respond to a common question
column2: and there will be a one-minute follow-up. The audience here in the hall has agreed to be polite
column3: and attentive
column4: no cheering or outbursts. Those of you at home
column5: of course
column6: are not so constrained.

column1: The only exception in the hall is right now
column2: as it is my privilege to introduce the candidates
column3: Sen. Barack Obama of Illinois and Sen. John McCain of Arizona.

column1: Gentlemen?
Gentlemen
column2: we want to get under way immediately
column3: if we can. Since you last met at Ole Miss 12 days ago
column4: the world has changed a great deal
column5: and not for the better. We still don't know where the bottom is at this time.

column1: As you might expect
column2: many of the questions that we have from here in the hall tonight and from online have to do with the American economy and
column3: in fact
column4: with global economic conditions.

column1: I understand that you flipped a coin.
And
column2: Sen. Obama
column3: you will begin tonight. And we're going to have our first question from over here in Section A from Allen Shaffer.

column1: Allen?
Shaffer: With the economy on the downturn and retired and older citizens and workers losing their incomes
column2: what's the fastest
column3: most positive solution to bail these people out of the economic ruin?

column1: Obama: Well
column2: Alan (ph)
column3: thank you very much for the question. I want to first
column4: obviously
column5: thank Belmont University
column6: Tom
column7: thank you
column8: and to all of you who are participating tonight and those of you who sent e-mail questions in.

column1: I think everybody knows now we are in the worst financial crisis since the Great Depression. And a lot of you I think are worried about your jobs
column2: your pensions
column3: your retirement accounts
column4: your ability to send your child or your grandchild to college.

column1: And I believe this is a final verdict on the failed economic policies of the last eight years
column2: strongly promoted by President Bush and supported by Sen. McCain
column3: that essentially said that we should strip away regulations
column4: consumer protections
column5: let the market run wild
column6: and prosperity would rain down on all of us.

column1: It hasn't worked out that way. And so now we've got to take some decisive action.
Now
column2: step one was a rescue package that was passed last week. We've got to make sure that works properly. And that means strong oversight
column3: making sure that investors
column4: taxpayers are getting their money back and treated as investors.

column1: It means that we are cracking down on CEOs and making sure that they're not getting bonuses or golden parachutes as a consequence of this package. And
column2: in fact
column3: we just found out that AIG
column4: a company that got a bailout
column5: just a week after they got help went on a $400
column6: 000 junket.

column1: And I'll tell you what
column2: the Treasury should demand that money back and those executives should be fired. But that's only step one. The middle-class need a rescue package. And that means tax cuts for the middle-class.

column1: It means help for homeowners so that they can stay in their homes. It means that we are helping state and local governments set up road projects and bridge projects that keep people in their jobs.
And then long-term we've got to fix our health care system
column2: we've got to fix our energy system that is putting such an enormous burden on families. You need somebody working for you and you've got to have somebody in Washington who is thinking about the middle class and not just those who can afford to hire lobbyists.

column1: Brokaw: Sen. McCain?
McCain: Well
column2: thank you
column3: Tom. Thank you
column4: Belmont University. And Sen. Obama
column5: it's good to be with you at a town hall meeting.

column1: And
column2: Alan (ph)
column3: thank you for your question. You go to the heart of America's worries tonight. Americans are angry
column4: they're upset
column5: and they're a little fearful. It's our job to fix the problem.

column1: Now
column2: I have a plan to fix this problem and it has got to do with energy independence. We've got to stop sending $700 billion a year to countries that don't want us very -- like us very much. We have to keep Americans' taxes low. All Americans' taxes low. Let's not raise taxes on anybody today.

column1: We obviously have to stop this spending spree that's going on in Washington. Do you know that we've laid a $10 trillion debt on these young Americans who are here with us tonight
column2: $500 billion of it we owe to China?

column1: We've got to have a package of reforms and it has got to lead to reform prosperity and peace in the world. And I think that this problem has become so severe
column2: as you know
column3: that we're going to have to do something about home values.

column1: You know that home values of retirees continues to decline and people are no longer able to afford their mortgage payments. As president of the United States
column2: Alan
column3: I would order the secretary of the treasury to immediately buy up the bad home loan mortgages in America and renegotiate at the new value of those homes -- at the diminished value of those homes and let people be able to make those -- be able to make those payments and stay in their homes.

column1: Is it expensive? Yes. But we all know
column2: my friends
column3: until we stabilize home values in America
column4: we're never going to start turning around and creating jobs and fixing our economy. And we've got to give some trust and confidence back to America.

column1: I know how the do that
column2: my friends. And it's my proposal
column3: it's not Sen. Obama's proposal
column4: it's not President Bush's proposal. But I know how to get America working again
column5: restore our economy and take care of working Americans. Thank you.

column1: Brokaw: Senator
column2: we have one minute for a discussion here. Obviously the powers of the treasury secretary have been greatly expanded. The most powerful officer in the cabinet now. Hank Paulson says he won't stay on. Who do you have in mind to appoint to that very important post?

column1: Sen. McCain?
McCain: Not you
column2: Tom.

column1: Brokaw: No
column2: with good reason.

column1: McCain: You know
column2: that's a tough question and there's a lot of qualified Americans. But I think the first criteria
column3: Tom
column4: would have to be somebody who immediately Americans identify with
column5: immediately say
column6: we can trust that individual.

column1: A supporter of Sen. Obama's is Warren Buffett [chairman of Berkshire Hathaway]. He has already weighed in and helped stabilize some of the difficulties in the markets and with companies and corporations
column2: institutions today.

column1: I like Meg Whitman [former CEO of eBay and current McCain campaign adviser]
column2: she knows what it's like to be out there in the marketplace. She knows how to create jobs. Meg Whitman was CEO of a company that started with 12 people and is now 1.3 million people in America make their living off eBay. Maybe somebody here has done a little business with them.

column1: But the point is it's going to have to be somebody who inspires trust and confidence. Because the problem in America today to a large extent
column2: Tom
column3: is that we don't have trust and confidence in our institutions because of the corruption on Wall Street and the greed and excess and the cronyism in Washington
column4: D.C.

column1: Brokaw: All right. Sen. McCain -- Sen. Obama
column2: who do you have in mind for treasury secretary?

column1: Obama: Well
column2: Warren would be a pretty good choice -- Warren Buffett
column3: and I'm pleased to have his support. But there are other folks out there. The key is making sure that the next treasury secretary understands that it's not enough just to help those at the top.

column1: Prosperity is not just going to trickle down. We've got to help the middle class.
And we've -- you know
column2: Sen. McCain and I have some fundamental disagreements on the economy
column3: starting with Sen. McCain's statement earlier that he thought the fundamentals of the economy were sound.

column1: Part of the problem here is that for many of you
column2: wages and incomes have flat-lined. For many of you
column3: it is getting harder and harder to save
column4: harder and harder to retire.

column1: And that's why
column2: for example
column3: on tax policy
column4: what I want to do is provide a middle class tax cut to 95 percent of working Americans
column5: those who are working two jobs
column6: people who are not spending enough time with their kids
column7: because they are struggling to make ends meet.

column1: Sen. McCain is right that we've got to stabilize housing prices. But underlying that is loss of jobs and loss of income. That's something that the next treasury secretary is going to have to work on.
Brokaw: Sen. Obama
column2: thank you very much.

column1: May I remind both of you
column2: if I can
column3: that we're operating under rules that you signed off on and when we have a discussion
column4: it really is to be confined within about a minute or so.

column1: We're going to go now
column2: Sen. McCain
column3: to the next question from you from the hall here
column4: and it comes from Oliver Clark
column5: who is over here in section F.

column1: Oliver?
Clark: Well
column2: Senators
column3: through this economic crisis
column4: most of the people that I know have had a difficult time. And through this bailout package
column5: I was wondering what it is that's going to actually help those people out.

column1: McCain: Well
column2: thank you
column3: Oliver
column4: and that's an excellent question
column5: because as you just described it
column6: bailout
column7: when I believe that it's rescue
column8: because -- because of the greed and excess in Washington and Wall Street
column9: Main Street was paying a very heavy price
column10: and we know that.

column1: I left my campaign and suspended it to go back to Washington to make sure that there were additional protections for the taxpayer in the form of good oversight
column2: in the form of taxpayers being the first to be paid back when our economy recovers -- and it will recover -- and a number of other measures.

column1: But you know
column2: one of the real catalysts
column3: really the match that lit this fire was Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. I'll bet you
column4: you may never even have heard of them before this crisis.

column1: But you know
column2: they're the ones that
column3: with the encouragement of Sen. Obama and his cronies and his friends in Washington
column4: that went out and made all these risky loans
column5: gave them to people that could never afford to pay back.

column1: And you know
column2: there were some of us that stood up two years ago and said we've got to enact legislation to fix this. We've got to stop this greed and excess.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: the Democrats in the Senate and some -- and some members of Congress defended what Fannie and Freddie were doing. They resisted any change.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: they were getting all kinds of money in campaign contributions. Sen. Obama was the second highest recipient of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac money in history -- in history.

column1: So this rescue package means that we will stabilize markets
column2: we will shore up these institutions. But it's not enough. That's why we're going to have to go out into the housing market and we're going to have to buy up these bad loans and we're going to have to stabilize home values
column3: and that way
column4: Americans
column5: like Alan
column6: can realize the American dream and stay in their home.

column1: But Fannie and Freddie were the catalysts
column2: the match that started this forest fire. There were some of us -- there were some of us that stood up against it. There were others who took a hike.

column1: Brokaw: Sen. Obama?
Obama: Well
column2: Oliver
column3: first
column4: let me tell you what's in the rescue package for you. Right now
column5: the credit markets are frozen up and what that means
column6: as a practical matter
column7: is that small businesses and some large businesses just can't get loans.

column1: If they can't get a loan
column2: that means that they can't make payroll. If they can't make payroll
column3: then they may end up having to shut their doors and lay people off.

column1: And if you imagine just one company trying to deal with that
column2: now imagine a million companies all across the country.

column1: So it could end up having an adverse effect on everybody
column2: and that's why we had to take action. But we shouldn't have been there in the first place.

column1: Now
column2: I've got to correct a little bit of Sen. McCain's history
column3: not surprisingly. Let's
column4: first of all
column5: understand that the biggest problem in this whole process was the deregulation of the financial system.

column1: Sen. McCain
column2: as recently as March
column3: bragged about the fact that he is a deregulator. On the other hand
column4: two years ago
column5: I said that we've got a sub-prime lending crisis that has to be dealt with.

column1: I wrote to Secretary Paulson
column2: I wrote to Federal Reserve Chairman [Ben] Bernanke
column3: and told them this is something we have to deal with
column4: and nobody did anything about it.

column1: A year ago
column2: I went to Wall Street and said we've got to reregulate
column3: and nothing happened.

column1: And Sen. McCain during that period said that we should keep on deregulating because that's how the free enterprise system works.
Now
column2: with respect to Fannie Mae
column3: what Sen. McCain didn't mention is the fact that this bill that he talked about wasn't his own bill. He jumped on it a year after it had been introduced and it never got passed.

column1: And I never promoted Fannie Mae. In fact
column2: Sen. McCain's campaign chairman's firm was a lobbyist on behalf of Fannie Mae
column3: not me.

column1: So -- but
column2: look
column3: you're not interested in hearing politicians pointing fingers. What you're interested in is trying to figure out
column4: how is this going to impact you?

column1: This is not the end of the process; this is the beginning of the process. And that's why it's going to be so important for us to work with homeowners to make sure that they can stay in their homes.
The secretary already has the power to do that in the rescue package
column2: but it hasn't been exercised yet. And the next president has to make sure that the next Treasury secretary is thinking about how to strengthen you as a home buyer
column3: you as a homeowner
column4: and not simply think about bailing out banks on Wall Street.

column1: Brokaw: Sen. Obama
column2: time for a discussion. I'm going to begin with you. Are you saying to Mr. Clark (ph) and to the other members of the American television audience that the American economy is going to get much worse before it gets better and they ought to be prepared for that?

column1: Obama: No
column2: I am confident about the American economy. But we are going to have to have some leadership from Washington that not only sets out much better regulations for the financial system.

column1: The problem is we still have a archaic
column2: 20th-century regulatory system for 21st-century financial markets. We're going to have to coordinate with other countries to make sure that whatever actions we take work.

column1: But most importantly
column2: we're going to have to help ordinary families be able to stay in their homes
column3: make sure that they can pay their bills
column4: deal with critical issues like health care and energy
column5: and we're going to have to change the culture in Washington so that lobbyists and special interests aren't driving the process and your voices aren't being drowned out.

column1: Brokaw: Sen. McCain
column2: in all candor
column3: do you think the economy is going to get worse before it gets better?

column1: McCain: I think it depends on what we do. I think if we act effectively
column2: if we stabilize the housing market -- which I believe we can
column3: if we go out and buy up these bad loans
column4: so that people can have a new mortgage at the new value of their home -- I think if we get rid of the cronyism and special interest influence in Washington so we can act more effectively.

column1: My friend
column2: I'd like you to see the letter that a group of senators and I wrote warning exactly of this crisis. Sen. Obama's name was not on that letter.

column1: The point is -- the point is that we can fix our economy. Americans' workers are the best in the world. They're the fundamental aspect of America's economy.
They're the most innovative. They're the best -- they're most -- have best -- we're the best exporters. We're the best importers. They're most effective. They are the best workers in the world.

And we've got to give them a chance. They've got -- we've got to give them a chance to do their best again. And they are the innocent bystanders here in what is the biggest financial crisis and challenge of our time. We can do it.
Brokaw: Thank you
column2: Sen. McCain.

column1: We're going to continue over in Section F
column2: as it turns out.

column1: Sen. Obama
column2: this is a question from you from Teresa Finch.

column1: Teresa?
Finch: How can we trust either of you with our money when both parties got -- got us into this global economic crisis?
Obama: Well
column2: look
column3: I understand your frustration and your cynicism
column4: because while you've been carrying out your responsibilities -- most of the people here
column5: you've got a family budget. If less money is coming in
column6: you end up making cuts. Maybe you don't go out to dinner as much. Maybe you put off buying a new car.

column1: That's not what happens in Washington. And you're right. There is a lot of blame to go around.
But I think it's important just to remember a little bit of history. When George Bush came into office
column2: we had surpluses. And now we have half-a-trillion-dollar deficit annually.

column1: When George Bush came into office
column2: our debt -- national debt was around $5 trillion. It's now over $10 trillion. We've almost doubled it.

column1: And so while it's true that nobody's completely innocent here
column2: we have had over the last eight years the biggest increases in deficit spending and national debt in our history. And Sen. McCain voted for four out of five of those George Bush budgets.

column1: So here's what I would do. I'm going to spend some money on the key issues that we've got to work on.
You know
column2: you may have seen your health care premiums go up. We've got to reform health care to help you and your budget.

column1: We are going to have to deal with energy because we can't keep on borrowing from the Chinese and sending money to Saudi Arabia. We are mortgaging our children's future. We've got to have a different energy plan.
We've got to invest in college affordability. So we're going to have to make some investments
column2: but we've also got to make spending cuts. And what I've proposed
column3: you'll hear Sen. McCain say
column4: well
column5: he's proposing a whole bunch of new spending
column6: but actually I'm cutting more than I'm spending so that it will be a net spending cut.

column1: The key is whether or not we've got priorities that are working for you as opposed to those who have been dictating the policy in Washington lately
column2: and that's mostly lobbyists and special interests. We've got to put an end to that.

column1: Brokaw: Sen. McCain?
McCain: Well
column2: Theresa (ph)
column3: thank you. And I can see why you feel that cynicism and mistrust
column4: because the system in Washington is broken. And I have been a consistent reformer.

column1: I have advocated and taken on the special interests
column2: whether they be the big money people by reaching across the aisle and working with Sen. [Russ] Feingold [D-Wisconsin] on campaign finance reform
column3: whether it being a variety of other issues
column4: working with Sen. Lieberman on trying to address climate change.

column1: I have a clear record of bipartisanship. The situation today cries out for bipartisanship. Sen. Obama has never taken on his leaders of his party on a single issue. And we need to reform.

And so let's look at our records as well as our rhetoric. That's really part of your mistrust here. And now I suggest that maybe you go to some of these organizations that are the watchdogs of what we do
column2: like the Citizens Against Government Waste or the National Taxpayers Union or these other organizations that watch us all the time.

column1: I don't expect you to watch every vote. And you know what you'll find? This is the most liberal big-spending record in the United States Senate. I have fought against excessive spending and outrages. I have fought to reduce the earmarks and eliminate them.

Do you know that Sen. Obama has voted for -- is proposing $860 billion of new spending now? New spending. Do you know that he voted for every increase in spending that I saw come across the floor of the United States Senate while we were working to eliminate these pork barrel earmarks?
He voted for nearly a billion dollars in pork barrel earmark projects
column2: including
column3: by the way
column4: $3 million for an overhead projector at a planetarium in Chicago
column5: Illinois. My friends
column6: do we need to spend that kind of money?

column1: I think you have to look at my record and you have to look at his. Then you have to look at our proposals for our economy
column2: not $860 billion in new spending
column3: but for the kinds of reforms that keep people in their jobs
column4: get middle-income Americans working again
column5: and getting our economy moving again.

column1: You're going to be examining our proposals tonight and in the future
column2: and energy independence is a way to do that
column3: is one of them. And drilling offshore and nuclear power are two vital elements of that. And I've been supporting those and I know how to fix this economy
column4: and eliminate our dependence on foreign oil
column5: and stop sending $700 billion a year overseas.

column1: Brokaw: We've run out of time. We have this one-minute discussion period going on here.
There are new economic realities out there that everyone in this hall and across this country understands that there are going to have to be some choices made. Health policies
column2: energy policies
column3: and entitlement reform
column4: what are going to be your priorities in what order? Which of those will be your highest priority your first year in office and which will follow in sequence?

column1: Sen. McCain?
McCain: The three priorities were health...
Brokaw: The three -- health care
column2: energy
column3: and entitlement reform: Social Security and Medicare. In what order would you put them in terms of priorities?

column1: McCain: I think you can work on all three at once
column2: Tom. I think it's very important that reform our entitlement programs.

column1: My friends
column2: we are not going to be able to provide the same benefit for present-day workers that we are going -- that present-day retirees have today. We're going to have to sit down across the table
column3: Republican and Democrat
column4: as we did in 1983 between Ronald Reagan and Tip O'Neill.

column1: I know how to do that. I have a clear record of reaching across the aisle
column2: whether it be Joe Lieberman or Russ Feingold or Ted Kennedy or others. That's my clear record.

column1: We can work on nuclear power plants. Build a whole bunch of them
column2: create millions of new jobs. We have to have all of the above
column3: alternative fuels
column4: wind
column5: tide
column6: solar
column7: natural gas
column8: clean coal technology. All of these things we can do as Americans and we can take on this mission and we can overcome it.

column1: My friends
column2: some of this $700 billion ends up in the hands of terrorist organizations.

column1: As far as health care is concerned
column2: obviously
column3: everyone is struggling to make sure that they can afford their premiums and that they can have affordable and available health care. That's the next issue.

column1: But we can do them all at once. There's no -- and we have to do them all at once. All three you mentioned are compelling national security requirements.
Brokaw: I'm trying to play by the rules that you all established. One minute for discussion.
Sen. Obama
column2: if you would give us your list of priorities
column3: there are some real questions about whether everything can be done at once.

column1: Obama: We're going to have to prioritize
column2: just like a family has to prioritize. Now
column3: I've listed the things that I think have to be at the top of the list.

column1: Energy we have to deal with today
column2: because you're paying $3.80 here in Nashville for gasoline
column3: and it could go up. And it's a strain on your family budget
column4: but it's also bad for our national security
column5: because countries like Russia and Venezuela and
column6: you know
column7: in some cases
column8: countries like Iran
column9: are benefiting from higher oil prices.

column1: So we've got to deal with that right away. That's why I've called for an investment of $15 billion a year over 10 years. Our goal should be
column2: in 10 year's time
column3: we are free of dependence on Middle Eastern oil.

column1: And we can do it. Now
column2: when JFK said we're going to the Moon in 10 years
column3: nobody was sure how to do it
column4: but we understood that
column5: if the American people make a decision to do something
column6: it gets done. So that would be priority number one.

column1: Health care is priority number two
column2: because that broken health care system is bad not only for families
column3: but it's making our businesses less competitive.

column1: And
column2: number three
column3: we've got to deal with education so that our young people are competitive in a global economy.

column1: But just one point I want to make
column2: Tom. Sen. McCain mentioned looking at our records. We do need to look at our records.

column1: Sen. McCain likes to talk about earmarks a lot. And that's important. I want to go line by line through every item in the federal budget and eliminate programs that don't work and make sure that those that do work
column2: work better and cheaper.

column1: But understand this: We also have to look at where some of our tax revenues are going. So when Sen. McCain proposes a $300 billion tax cut
column2: a continuation not only of the Bush tax cuts
column3: but an additional $200 billion that he's going to give to big corporations
column4: including big oil companies
column5: $4 billion worth
column6: that's money out of the system.

column1: And so we've got to prioritize both our spending side and our tax policies to make sure that they're working for you. That's what I'm going to do as president of the United States.
Brokaw: All right
column2: gentlemen
column3: I want to just remind you one more time about time. We're going to have a larger deficit than the federal government does if we don't get this under control here before too long.

column1: Sen. McCain
column2: for you
column3: we have our first question from the Internet tonight. A child of the Depression
column4: 78-year-old Fiorra from Chicago.

column1: Since World War II
column2: we have never been asked to sacrifice anything to help our country
column3: except the blood of our heroic men and women. As president
column4: what sacrifices -- sacrifices will you ask every American to make to help restore the American dream and to get out of the economic morass that we're now in?

column1: McCain: Well
column2: Fiorra
column3: I'm going to ask the American people to understand that there are some programs that we may have to eliminate.

column1: I first proposed a long time ago that we would have to examine every agency and every bureaucracy of government. And we're going to have to eliminate those that aren't working.
I know a lot of them that aren't working. One of them is in defense spending
column2: because I've taken on some of the defense contractors. I saved the taxpayers $6.8 billion in a deal for an Air Force tanker that was done in a corrupt fashion.

column1: I believe that we have to eliminate the earmarks. And sometimes those projects
column2: not -- not the overhead projector that Sen. Obama asked for
column3: but some of them that are really good projects
column4: will have -- will have to be eliminated
column5: as well.

column1: And they'll have to undergo the same scrutiny that all projects should in competition with others.
So we're going to have to tell the American people that spending is going to have to be cut in America. And I recommend a spending freeze that -- except for defense
column2: Veterans Affairs
column3: and some other vital programs
column4: we'll just have to have across-the-board freeze.

column1: And some of those programs may not grow as much as we would like for them to
column2: but we can establish priorities with full transparency
column3: with full knowledge of the American people
column4: and full consultation
column5: not done behind closed doors and shoving earmarks in the middle of the night into programs that we don't even -- sometimes we don't even know about until months later.

column1: And
column2: by the way
column3: I want to go back a second.

column1: Look
column2: we can attack health care and energy at the same time. We're not -- we're not -- we're not rifle shots here. We are Americans. We can
column3: with the participation of all Americans
column4: work together and solve these problems together.

column1: Frankly
column2: I'm not going to tell that person without health insurance that
column3: ""I'm sorry
column4: you'll have to wait."" I'm going to tell you Americans we'll get to work right away and we'll get to work together
column5: and we can get them all done
column6: because that's what America has been doing.

column1: Brokaw: Sen. McCain
column2: thank you very much.

column1: Sen. Obama?
Obama: You know
column2: a lot of you remember the tragedy of 9/11 and where you were on that day and
column3: you know
column4: how all of the country was ready to come together and make enormous changes to make us not only safer
column5: but to make us a better country and a more unified country.

column1: And President Bush did some smart things at the outset
column2: but one of the opportunities that was missed was
column3: when he spoke to the American people
column4: he said
column5: ""Go out and shop.""

column1: That wasn't the kind of call to service that I think the American people were looking for.
And so it's important to understand that the -- I think the American people are hungry for the kind of leadership that is going to tackle these problems not just in government
column2: but outside of government.

column1: And let's take the example of energy
column2: which we already spoke about. There is going to be the need for each and every one of us to start thinking about how we use energy.

column1: I believe in the need for increased oil production. We're going to have to explore new ways to get more oil
column2: and that includes offshore drilling. It includes telling the oil companies
column3: that currently have 68 million acres that they're not using
column4: that either you use them or you lose them.

column1: We're going to have to develop clean coal technology and safe ways to store nuclear energy.
But each and every one of us can start thinking about how can we save energy in our homes
column2: in our buildings. And one of the things I want to do is make sure that we're providing incentives so that you can buy a fuel efficient car that's made right here in the United States of America
column3: not in Japan or South Korea
column4: making sure that you are able to weatherize your home or make your business more fuel efficient.

column1: And that's going to require effort from each and every one of us.
And the last point I just want to make. I think the young people of America are especially interested in how they can serve
column2: and that's one of the reasons why I'm interested in doubling the Peace Corps
column3: making sure that we are creating a volunteer corps all across this country that can be involved in their community
column4: involved in military service
column5: so that military families and our troops are not the only ones bearing the burden of renewing America.

column1: That's something that all of us have to be involved with and that requires some leadership from Washington.
Brokaw: Sen. Obama
column2: as we begin
column3: very quickly
column4: our discussion period
column5: President Bush
column6: you'll remember
column7: last summer
column8: said that ""Wall Street got drunk.""

column1: A lot of people now look back and think the federal government got drunk and
column2: in fact
column3: the American consumers got drunk.

column1: How would you
column2: as president
column3: try to break those bad habits of too much debt and too much easy credit
column4: specifically
column5: across the board
column6: for this country
column7: not just at the federal level
column8: but as a model for the rest of the country
column9: as well?

column1: Obama: Well
column2: I think it starts with Washington. We've got to show that we've got good habits
column3: because if we're running up trillion dollar debts that we're passing on to the next generation
column4: then a lot of people are going to think
column5: ""Well
column6: you know what? There's easy money out there.""

column1: It means -- and I have to
column2: again
column3: repeat this. It means looking (ph) at the spending side
column4: but also at the revenue side. I mean
column5: Sen. McCain has been talking tough about earmarks
column6: and that's good
column7: but earmarks account for about $18 billion of our budget.

column1: Now
column2: when Sen. McCain is proposing tax cuts that would give the average Fortune 500 CEO an additional $700
column3: 000 in tax cuts
column4: that's not sharing a burden.

column1: And so part of the problem
column2: I think
column3: for a lot of people who are listening here tonight is they don't feel as if they are sharing the burden with other folks.

column1: I mean
column2: you know
column3: it's tough to ask a teacher who's making $30
column5: 000 a year to tighten her belt when people who are making much more than her are living pretty high on the hog.

column1: And that's why I think it's important for the president to set a tone that says all of us are going to contribute
column2: all of us are going to make sacrifices
column3: and it means that
column4: yes
column5: we may have to cut some spending
column6: although I disagree with Sen. McCain about an across-the- board freeze.

column1: That's an example of an unfair burden sharing. Tha"	0

column1: By PolitiFact staff

PolitiFact is annotating the second presidential debate at Washington University. We will be posting the transcript and our annotations through the night. Follow us on Medium and check back regularly to see our commentary.
RADDATZ: Ladies and gentlemen the Republican nominee for president
column2: Donald J. Trump
column3: and the Democratic nominee for president
column4: Hillary Clinton.

column1: COOPER: Thank you very much for being here. WeÃ¢ÂÂre going to begin with a question from one of the members in our town hall. Each of you will have two minutes to respond to this question. Secretary Clinton
column2: you won the coin toss
column3: so youÃ¢ÂÂll go first. Our first question comes from Patrice Brock. Patrice?

column1: QUESTION: Thank you
column2: and good evening. The last debate could have been rated as MA

column1: CLINTON: Well

column4: as well as every adult

column2: Ã¢ÂÂ because I think if we work together
column3: if we overcome the divisiveness that sometimes sets Americans against one another
column4: and instead we make some big goals Ã¢ÂÂ and IÃ¢ÂÂve set forth some big goals
column5: getting the economy to work for everyone
column6: not just those at the top
column7: making sure that we have the best education system from preschool through college and making it affordable
column8: and so much else.

column1: If we set those goals and we go together to try to achieve them
column2: thereÃ¢ÂÂs nothing in my opinion that America canÃ¢ÂÂt do. So thatÃ¢ÂÂs why I hope that we will come together in this campaign. Obviously
column3: IÃ¢ÂÂm hoping to earn your vote
column4: IÃ¢ÂÂm hoping to be elected in November
column5: and I can promise you
column6: I will work with every American.

column1: I want to be the president for all Americans
column2: regardless of your political beliefs
column3: where you come from
column4: what you look like
column5: your religion. I want us to heal our country and bring it together because thatÃ¢ÂÂs
column6: I think
column7: the best way for us to get the future that our children and our grandchildren deserve.

column1: COOPER: Secretary Clinton
column2: thank you. Mr. Trump
column3: you have two minutes.

column1: TRUMP: Well
column2: I actually agree with that. I agree with everything she said. I began this campaign because I was so tired of seeing such foolish things happen to our country. This is a great country. This is a great land. IÃ¢ÂÂve gotten to know the people of the country over the last year-and-a-half that IÃ¢ÂÂve been doing this as a politician. I cannot believe IÃ¢ÂÂm saying that about myself
column3: but I guess I have been a politician.

column1: TRUMP: And my whole concept was to make America great again. When I watch the deals being made
column2: when I watch whatÃ¢ÂÂs happening with some horrible things like Obamacare
column3: where your health insurance and health care is going up by numbers that are astronomical
column4: 68 percent
column5: 59 percent
column6: 71 percent
column7: when I look at the Iran deal and how bad a deal it is for us
column8: itÃ¢ÂÂs a one-sided transaction where weÃ¢ÂÂre giving back $150 billion to a terrorist state
column9: really
column10: the number one terror state
column11: weÃ¢ÂÂve made them a strong country from really a very weak country just three years ago.

column1: When I look at all of the things that I see and all of the potential that our country has
column2: we have such tremendous potential
column3: whether itÃ¢ÂÂs in business and trade
column4: where weÃ¢ÂÂre doing so badly. Last year
column5: we had almost $800 billion trade deficit. In other words
column6: trading with other countries. We had an $800 billion deficit. ItÃ¢ÂÂs hard to believe. Inconceivable.

column1: You say whoÃ¢ÂÂs making these deals? WeÃ¢ÂÂre going the make great deals. WeÃ¢ÂÂre going to have a strong border. WeÃ¢ÂÂre going to bring back law and order. Just today
column2: policemen was shot
column3: two killed. And this is happening on a weekly basis. We have to bring back respect to law enforcement. At the same time
column4: we have to take care of people on all sides. We need justice.

column1: But I want to do things that havenÃ¢ÂÂt been done
column2: including fixing and making our inner cities better for the African-American citizens that are so great
column3: and for the Latinos
column4: Hispanics
column5: and I look forward to doing it. ItÃ¢ÂÂs called make America great again.

column1: COOPER: Thank you
column2: Mr. Trump. The question from Patrice was about are you both modeling positive and appropriate behavior for todayÃ¢ÂÂs youth? We received a lot of questions online
column3: Mr. Trump
column4: about the tape that was released on Friday
column5: as you can imagine. You called what you said locker room banter. You described kissing women without consent
column6: grabbing their genitals. That is sexual assault. You bragged that you have sexually assaulted women. Do you understand that?

column1: TRUMP: No
column2: I didnÃ¢ÂÂt say that at all. I donÃ¢ÂÂt think you understood what was Ã¢ÂÂ this was locker room talk. IÃ¢ÂÂm not proud of it. I apologize to my family. I apologize to the American people. Certainly IÃ¢ÂÂm not proud of it. But this is locker room talk.

column1: You know
column2: when we have a world where you have ISIS chopping off heads
column3: where you have Ã¢ÂÂ and
column4: frankly
column5: drowning people in steel cages
column6: where you have wars and horrible
column7: horrible sights all over
column8: where you have so many bad things happening
column9: this is like medieval times. We havenÃ¢ÂÂt seen anything like this
column10: the carnage all over the world.

column1: And they look and they see. Can you imagine the people that are
column2: frankly
column3: doing so well against us with ISIS? And they look at our country and they see whatÃ¢ÂÂs going on.

column1: 123	"Fox News' Shepard Smith: 'Why is it lie after lie after lie?' on Russia meeting

Fox News host Shepard Smith slammed what he called ""lies"" and ""deception"" pushed by Donald Trump Jr. in a fiery Friday rant over emerging details of Trump Jr.'s meeting with a Russian lawyer last summer.
On Friday's Shepard Smith Reporting
column2: the host launched into a tirade over Trump Jr.'s stance the meeting equated to nothing even as new details showed it included eight people. Several congressional committees and a special counsel are investigating whether Trump associates colluded with the Russians during the presidential campaign.

column1: We're still not clean on this
column2: Chris
column3: Smith told fellow Fox anchor Chris Wallace. ""Why all these lies? Why is it lie after lie after lie? If you clean
column4: come on clean.""

column1: Smith
column2: who has chided President Trump for his treatment of the media
column3: continued.

column1: The deception
column2: Chris
column3: is mind-boggling
column4: he said. ""And there are still people out there who believe we're making it up and one day they're going to realize we're not.""

column1: The diatribe left Wallace speechless.
I don't know what to say
column2: he said. ""I think there's a lot of truth to everything you've said.""

column1: Smith's statements quickly spread across the Internet
column2: where some called for his firing.

column1: Smith went on the offensive against Trump and his administration earlier this year. In February
column2: Smith defended CNN as ""not fake news
column3: an accusation often lobbed by the president and his supporters.
