column1: 127	"Share Add to your saved stories Save
Three Democratic candidates participated in tonight's ABC presidential primary debate at St. Anselm College in New Hampshire: Hillary Clinton
column2: Bernie Sanders and Martin O'Malley. We posted the complete transcript below
column3: with insight from the crew here at The Fix as well as the Fact Checker's Michelle Lee. Wp Get the full experience. Choose your plan ArrowRight Click or tap the highlighted part of the transcript to see an annotation; if you would like to leave your own annotations
column4: make sure you have a Genius account. Post staff annotations will appear by default; others are in a menu that you can see in the upper right when you click or tap on an annotation.

column1: The debate began after ABC's Martha Raddatz and David Muir introduced the candidates.

Raddatz: Good evening to you all. The rules for tonight are very basic and have been agreed to by all three campaigns in advance. Candidates can take up to a minute-and-a-half to respond directly to a question. For a rebuttal
column2: for a follow-up
column3: 45 seconds will be allowed. There are green
column4: yellow
column5: and red lights that each candidate will see to signal when time is running out and when they're supposed to be finished with their answers.

column1: Advertisement
MUIR: We will be tackling many critical issues right here tonight
column2: and we begin with opening statements
column3: in alphabetical order
column4: and Secretary Clinton.

column1: CLINTON: Well
column2: thank you. And I'm delighted to be here in New Hampshire for this debate.

column1: You know
column2: the American president has to both keep our families safe and make the economy grow in a way that helps everyone
column3: not just those at the top. That's the job. I have a strategy to combat and defeat ISIS without getting us involved in another ground war
column4: and I have plans to raise incomes and deal with a lot of the problems that keep families up at night.

column1: I'm very clear that we have a distinct difference between those of us on this stage tonight and all of our Republican counterparts. From my perspective
column2: we have to prevent the Republicans from rolling back the progress that we've made. They would repeal the Affordable Care Act
column3: not improve it. They would give more tax breaks to the super-wealthy and corporations
column4: not to the middle class. And they would
column5: despite all their tough talk about terrorism
column6: continue to let people who are on the no-fly list buy guns.

column1: Advertisement
So we have a lot of work to do in this campaign to make it clear where we stand in the Democratic Party
column2: what we will do for our country
column3: and I look forward to this evening's discussion of real issues that face the American people.

column1: Thank you.
RADDATZ: Thank you
column2: Secretary Clinton.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
Governor O'Malley?
O'MALLEY: Martha
column2: thank you. Tonight we have a different debate than the debates that we have been allowed to have so far
column3: because tonight is different because of this reason
column4: that in the course of this presidential campaign America has again been attacked by jihadi terrorists
column5: American lives taken from us. So
column6: yes
column7: we must talk about our ideas to move our economy forward
column8: but the first job of the president of the United States is to protect the people of the United States.

column1: I visited with a number of our neighbors in Northern Virginia at a mosque last Friday. And as I looked out there at the eyes of our neighbors
column2: I also looked in the eyes of veterans. I looked into the eyes of Boy Scouts. I looked into the eyes of moms and dads who would do anything in their power to protect our country's values and our freedoms.

column1: Advertisement
What our nation needs right now is to realize that
column2: while we face a terrible danger
column3: we also face a different sort of political danger. And that is the danger that democracies find themselves susceptible to when unscrupulous leaders try to turn us upon each other. What our country needs right now is new leadership that will bring us together around the values that unite us and the freedoms that we share as Americans.

column1: We will rise to challenge of ISIL and we will rise together to the challenges that we face in our economy. But we will only do so if we hold true to the values and the freedoms that unite us
column2: which means we must never surrender them to terrorists
column3: must never surrender our Americans values to racist
column4: must never surrender to the fascist pleas of billionaires with big mouths.

column1: We are a better country than this. Our enduring symbol is not the barbed wire fence
column2: it is the Statue of Liberty. And America's best days are in front of us if we move forward together.

column1: Advertisement
(APPLAUSE)
MUIR: Senator Sanders.
SANDERS: Good evening.

I am running for president of the United States because it is too late for establishment politics and establishment economics. I'm running for president because our economy is rigged because working people are working longer hours for lower wages and almost all of new wealth and income being created is going to the top one percent. I'm running for president because I'm going to create an economy that works for working families not just billionaires.
I'm running for president because we have a campaign finance system which is corrupt
column2: where billionaires are spending hundreds of millionaires of dollars to buy candidates who will represent their interests rather than the middle class and working families. I'm running because we need to address the planetary crisis of climate change and take on the fossil fuel industry and transform our energy system away from fossil fuel to energy efficiency and sustainable energy.

column1: Advertisement
I'm running for president because I want a new foreign policy; one that takes on Isis
column2: one that destroys ISIS
column3: but one that does not get us involved in perpetual warfare in the quagmire of the Middle East but rather works around a major coalition of wealthy and powerful nations supporting Muslim troops on the ground. That's the kind of coalition we need and that's the kind of coalition I will put together.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
MUIR: Senator Sanders thank you and thank you all.

We do have a lot of important issues to get here tonight and we want to address the controversy of the last 24 hours right off the top because we heard some of the most heated rhetoric of the campaign so far between two of the campaigns on this stage tonight.
Senator Sanders
column2: you fired a campaign staffer you have sued the Democratic National Committee; all of this after your campaign acknowledge that some of your staffers quote
column3: ""irresponsibly accessed data from another campaign."" The Clinton campaign called this a very egregious breech of data of ethics and said
column4: quote
column5: ""our data was stolen.""

column1: Advertisement
Did they overstate this or were your staffers essentially stealing part of the Clinton playbook?
SANDERS: David
column2: let me give you a little bit of background here.

column1: The DNC has hired vendors. On two occasions
column2: there were breeches in information two months ago. Our staff found information on our computers from the Clinton campaign. And when our staffers said
column3: ""whoa
column4: what's going here?"" They went to the DNC quietly.

column1: They went to the vendor and said
column2: ""hey
column3: something is wrong
column4: and that was quietly dealt with. None of that information was looked at. Our staffer at that point did exactly the right thing.

column1: A few days ago a similar incident happened. There was a breach because the DNC vendor screwed up
column2: information came to our campaign. In this case
column3: our staff did the wrong thing -- they looked a that information. As soon as we learned that they looked at that information - we fired that person. We are now doing an independent internal investigation to see who else was involved.

column1: Advertisement
Thirdly
column2: what I have a really problem
column3: and as you mentioned - this is a problem
column4: I recognize it as a problem. But what the DNC did arbitrarily without discussing it with us is shut off our access to our information crippling our campaign. That is an egregious act. I'm glad that late last night
column5: that was resolved.

column1: SANDERS: Fourthly
column2: I work -- look forward to working with Secretary Clinton for an investigation
column3: an independent investigation
column4: about all of the breaches that have occurred from day one in this campaign
column5: because I am not convinced that information from our campaign may not have ended up in her campaign. Don't know that.

column1: But we need an independent investigation
column2: and I hope Secretary Clinton will agree with me for the need of that.

column1: Last point. When we saw the breach two months
column2: we didn't go running to the media and make a big deal about it. And it bothers me very much that
column3: rather than working on this issue to resolve it
column4: it has become many press releases from the Clinton campaign later.

column1: Advertisement
MUIR: But Senator
column2: you do mention the DNC -- the vender. But you said of your staff that they did the wrong thing.

column1: SANDERS: Absolutely.
At ABC's Democratic presidential debate
column2: candidate Bernie Sanders apologizes to rival Hillary Clinton for a scandal involving key voter data. (Video: ABC News)

column1: MUIR: So
column2: does Secretary Clinton deserve an apology tonight?

column1: SANDERS: Yes
column2: I apologize.

column1: MUIR: Secretary Clinton...
(APPLAUSE)

SANDERS: Not only -- not only do I apologize to Secretary Clinton -- and I hope we can work together on an independent investigation from day one -- I want to apologize to my supporters. This is not the type of campaign that we run.
And if I find anybody else involved in this
column2: they will also be fired.

column1: MUIR: Secretary Clinton
column2: he has apologized. How do your react?

column1: CLINTON: I very much appreciate that comment
column2: Bernie. It really is important that we go forward on this.

column1: I know that you now have your data back
column2: and that there has been an agreement for an independent inquiry into what did happen.

column1: Obviously
column2: we were distressed when we learned of it
column3: because we have worked very hard -- I said in the beginning of this campaign
column4: we want to reach as many voters as possible
column5: and we have tens of thousands of volunteers doing that
column6: and entering data all the time to keep up with what people are telling us.

column1: And so
column2: now that
column3: I think
column4: you know
column5: we have resolved your data
column6: we have agreed on an independent inquiry
column7: we should move on. Because I don't think the American people are all that interested in this.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
I think they're more interested in what we have to say about all the big issues facing us.
O'MALLEY: Yeah
column2: David
column3: look
column4: for crying out loud
column5: our country has been attacked
column6: we have pressing issues involving how we're going to adapt to this changing era of warfare.

column1: Our economy -- people are working harder and being left behind. You want to know why things don't get done in Washington? Because for the last 24 hours
column2: with those issues being so urgent to people as they tune in tonight
column3: wondering how they're even be able to buy presents for their kids.

column1: Instead
column2: we're listening to the bickering back and forth. Maybe that is normal politics in Washington
column3: but that is not the politics of higher purpose that people expect from our party.

column1: We need to address our security issues
column2: we need to address the economic issues around the kitchen table. And if people want a more high-minded politics and want to move our country forward
column3: go on to martinomalley.com and help my campaign move our country forward.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
MUIR (?): All three candidates are weighing in.
SANDERS: Let me agree with Governor O'Malley and let me agree with Secretary Clinton. You know
column2: we had this incident before
column3: Secretary
column4: with your famous e-mails. Right?

column1: And what I said and I think what Governor O'Malley is saying
column2: and I hope you say
column3: is when the middle class of this country is disappearing
column4: when we have massive income and wealth inequality
column5: when we're the only major country on earth not guaranteeing health care to all people
column6: all the issues that the governor talked about
column7: the secretary talked about
column8: those are the issues. Media notwithstanding.

column1: Those are the issues that the American people want discussed. I hope those are the issues we'll discuss.
MUIR: Good let's move on -- Senator Sanders
column2: let's move on right to some of those issues.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
It is just six days before Christmas
column2: as we all know in this country. It's typically a joyful time
column3: as it is this year
column4: as well. But it's also an anxious time. President Obama has acknowledged that what we saw in San Bernardino was an act of terrorism. But we remember the president said
column5: right before Thanksgiving
column6: there is no known specific and credible intelligence indicating a plot on the homeland.

column1: We now know that this couple had assembled an arsenal. They were not on law enforcement's radar. They were completely undetected. So as we approach another holiday
column2: with the president again saying
column3: late this week
column4: no credible threat
column5: Secretary Clinton
column6: how confident should the American people be
column7: that there aren't others like that couple right now in the U.S. going undetected?

column1: And what would you do as president to find them?
CLINTON: Well
column2: first
column3: the most important job of being president is obviously to keep our country safe and to keep the families of America safe.

column1: I have a plan that I've put forward to go after ISIS. Not to contain them
column2: but to defeat them. And it has three parts. First
column3: to go after them and deprive them of the territory they occupy now in both Syria and Iraq.

column1: CLINTON: Secondly
column2: to go after and dismantle their global network of terrorism. And thirdly
column3: to do more to keep us safe. Under each of those three parts of my plan
column4: I have very specific recommendations about what to do.

column1: Obviously
column2: in the first
column3: we do have to have a -- an American-led air campaign
column4: we have to have Arab and Kurdish troops on the ground. Secondly
column5: we've got to go after everything from North Africa to South Asia and beyond.

column1: And then
column2: most importantly
column3: here at home
column4: I think there are three things that we have to get right. We have to do the best possible job of sharing intelligence and information. That now includes the internet
column5: because we have seen that ISIS is a very effective recruiter
column6: propagandist and inciter and celebrator of violence.

column1: That means we have to work more closely with our great tech companies. They can't see the government as an adversary
column2: we can't see them as obstructionists. We've got to figure out how we can do more to understand who is saying what and what they're planning.

column1: And we must work more closely with Muslim-American communities. Just like Martin
column2: I met with a group of Muslim-Americans this past week to hear from them about what they're doing to try to stop radicalization. They will be our early warning signal. That's why we need to work with them
column3: not demonize them
column4: as the Republicans have been doing.

column1: O'MALLEY: David
column2: I am the very first...

column1: MUIR: (inaudible) thank you.
(APPLAUSE)
I am the very first post-9/11 mayor and the very first post-9/11 governor. I understand
column2: from the ground up
column3: that when attacks like San Bernardino happen
column4: when attacks like the attacks of 9/11 happen
column5: that when people call 911
column6: the first people to show up are the local first responders.

column1: Many of the things Secretary Clinton said are absolutely true
column2: but they underscore a lack of investment that we have
column3: as a nation
column4: failed to make over these last 15 years in intelligence gathering
column5: intelligence analysis
column6: intelligence sharing. Not only in theater
column7: in Syria and Iraq and other places where we embalk (ph) ourselves in toppling dictators without having any idea what comes next
column8: but here in the homeland
column9: as we protect people from this threat of the lone wolves and these changing tactics and strategies.

column1: I believe that what's happened here is that the president had us on the right course
column2: but it's a lack of battle tempo. We have to increase the battle tempo
column3: we have to bring a modern way of getting things done and forcing the sharing of information and do a much better job of acting on it in order to prevent these sorts of attacks in the future.

column1: MUIR: And we're going to break down these issues tonight
column2: but I do want to go to Senator Sanders because the concern going into Christmas is significant
column3: as you know. A new ABC News poll shows 77 percent of Americans have little or no confidence in the government's ability to prevent a lone wolf attack. How would you specifically find would-be terrorist who are going undetected?

column1: SANDERS: I'm one of the 77 percent. I think this is a very difficult issue. Let me agree with much of what the secretary and the governor have said. Let me tell you what I think we have got to do. I think it's a two-pronged issue.
Number one
column2: our goal is to crush and destroy ISIS. What is the best way to do it? Well
column3: I think there are some differences of opinion here
column4: perhaps between the secretary and myself. I voted against the war in Iraq because I thought unilateral military action would not produce the results that were necessary and would lead to the kind of unraveling and instability that we saw in the Middle East.

column1: I do not believe in unilateral American action. I believe in action in which we put together a strong coalition of forces
column2: major powers and the Muslim nations. I think one of the heroes in a real quagmire out there
column3: in a dangerous and difficult world
column4: one of the heroes who we should recognize in the Middle East is King Abdullah II of Jordan. This small country has welcomed in many refugees.

column1: And Abdullah said something recently
column2: very important. He said
column3: ""Yes
column4: international terrorism is by definition an international issue
column5: but it is primarily an issue of the Muslim nations who are fighting for the soul of Islam. We the Muslims should lead the effort on the ground."" And I believe he is absolutely right.

column1: MUIR: Senator
column2: thank you.

column1: RADDATZ: Secretary Clinton
column2: in the wake of the San Bernardino attack
column3: you all emphasized gun control. But our latest poll shows that more Americans believe arming people
column4: not stricter gun laws
column5: is the best defense against terrorism. Are they wrong?

column1: CLINTON: Well
column2: I think you have to look at both the terrorism challenge that we face abroad and certainly at home and the role that guns play in delivering the violence that stalks us. Clearly
column3: we have to have a very specific set of actions to take. You know
column4: when Senator Sanders talks about a coalition
column5: I agree with him about that. We've got to build a coalition abroad. We also have to build a coalition at home. Abroad
column6: we need a coalition that is going to take on ISIS. I know how hard that is. I know it isn't something you just hope people will do and I've worked on that...

column1: RADDATZ: Secretary Clinton
column2: can we stick to gun control?

column1: CLINTON: Yes
column2: I'm getting...

column1: RADDATZ: Are they wrong?
CLINTON: ... I'm getting to that. Because I think if you only think about the coalition abroad you're missing the main point
column2: which is we need a coalition here at home. Guns
column3: in and of themselves
column4: in my opinion
column5: will not make Americans safer. We lose 33
column6: 000 people a year already to gun violence
column7: arming more people to do what I think is not the appropriate response to terrorism.

column1: I think what is...
(APPLAUSE)
Is creating much deeper
column2: closer relations and
column3: yes
column4: coalitions within our own country. The first line of defense against radicalization is in Muslim-American community. People who we should be welcoming and working with.

column1: I worry greatly that the rhetoric coming from the Republicans
column2: particularly Donald Trump
column3: is sending a message to Muslims here in the United States and literally around the world that there is a ""clash of civilizations
column4: that there is some kind of Western plot or even ""war against Islam
column5: which then I believe fans the flames of radicalization.

column1: So guns have to be looked at as its own problem
column2: but we also have to figure out how we're going to deal with the radicalization here in the United States.

column1: (CROSSTALK)
RADDATZ: Senator Sanders -- wait just a moment
column2: please
column3: Governor O'Malley.

column1: Senator Sanders
column2: we've seen those long lines of people buying guns in record numbers after the Paris attacks. Would you discourage people from buying a gun?

column1: SANDERS: It's a country in which people choose to buy guns. I think half of the -- more than half of the people in my own state of Vermont
column2: my guess here in New Hampshire
column3: are gun owners. That's the right of people.

column1: But this is what I do believe. I believe that when we have some 300 million guns in this country
column2: I believe that when we have seen these horrific mass killings
column3: not only in San Bernardino
column4: but in Colorado and movie theaters in Colorado
column5: I think we have got to bring together the vast majority of the people who do in fact believe in sensible gun safety regulations.

column1: For example
column2: talking about polls
column3: a poll recently came out
column4: overwhelming majority of the American people say we should strengthen the instant background check. Who denies that it is crazy...

column1: (APPLAUSE)
Who denies that it is crazy to allow people to own guns who are criminals or are mentally unstable? We've got to eliminate the gun show loophole. In my view
column2: we have got to see that weapons designed by the military to kill people are not in the hands of civilians.

column1: I think there is a consensus.
(APPLAUSE)
I think -- I'm not going to say that everybody is in agreement. It's a divided country on guns. But there is a broad consensus on sensible gun safety regulations that I
column2: coming from a state that has virtually no gun control
column3: will do my best to bring together.

column1: O'MALLEY: Martha
column2: if I may...

column1: RADDATZ: Thank you
column2: Senator Sanders.

column1: (CROSSTALK)
RADDATZ: I think we're going to go on...
O'MALLEY: Excuse me
column2: no.

column1: MUIR: Governor
column2: we have to abide the rules here
column3: we'll call on you here shortly
column4: but...

column1: O'MALLEY: I am the only person on this stage who has actually...
MUIR: But I do want pick up on something...
O'MALLEY: ... passed comprehensive gun safety legislation with a ban on combat assault weapons
column2: David.

column1: And
column2: look
column3: there are profound differences...

column1: (APPLAUSE)

O'MALLEY: Senator Sanders voted against the Brady Bill. Senator Sanders voted to give immunity to gun dealers. And Senator Sanders voted against even research dollars to look into this public health issue.
Secretary Clinton changes her position on this every election year
column2: it seems
column3: having one position in 2000 and then campaigning against President Obama and saying we don't need federal standards.

column1: Look
column2: what we need on this issue is not more polls. We need more principle. When ISIL does training videos that say the easiest way to get a combat assault weapon in the United States of America is at a gun show
column3: then we should all be waking up. We need comprehensive gun safety legislation and a ban on assault weapons.

column1: RADDATZ: Governor
column2: now -- and let me stay with gun control for a minute
column3: then. You talk about assault weapons. Even if you were able to ban the purchase of assault weapons tomorrow
column4: Americans already own an estimated 7 to 10 million semi-automatic rifles.

column1: Would you make it illegal to own those weapons
column2: force people to turn them in? And if not
column3: how would banning the sales really make a difference?

column1: O'MALLEY: Because
column2: Martha
column3: it would prevent people like the guy that just got charged yesterday perhaps from being able to buy combat assault weapons. You know
column4: we are the only nation
column5: only developed nation on the planet...

column1: RADDATZ: But
column2: again
column3: I'm not talking about buying. Would you have them confiscated? The ones that are already here?

column1: O'MALLEY: No
column2: Martha
column3: I would not. And that's not what we did in Maryland. But you know what we did in Maryland? We overcame the NRA's objections. We overcame all of the crowds that were coming down there.

column1: We did our own rallies. And at least if we enact these laws in a prospective way
column2: we can address a major vulnerability in our country. ISIL videos
column3: ISIL training videos are telling lone wolves the easiest way to buy a combat assault weapon in America is at a gun show.

column1: And it's because of the flip-flopping
column2: political approach of Washington that both of my two colleagues on this stage have represented there for the last forty years.

column1: SANDERS: Whoa
column2: whoa
column3: whoa. Let's calm down a little bit
column4: Martin.

column1: CLINTON: Yes
column2: let's tell the truth
column3: Martin.

column1: O'MALLEY: I am telling the truth.
SANDERS: First of all
column2: let's have some rules here
column3: commentators.

column1: MUIR: We will.
(LAUGHTER)
SANDERS: All right.
MUIR: But let me just establish that for you
column2: senator. Really quickly governor
column3: we are going to call on you tonight and it's very clear you have a lot to say but please wait until you're called upon. And senator
column4: he invoked your record and I'll let you respond.

column1: SANDERS: He sure did.
MUIR: I'll let you respond.
CLINTON: He invoked mine as well.
MUIR: And you will get some to as well.
SANDERS: Sure did. All right. First off
column2: we can do all the great speeches we want but you're not going to succeed unless there is a consensus. In 1988
column3: just to set the record straight governor
column4: I ran for the U.S. House. We have one House member from Vermont
column5: three candidates in the race. One candidate said
column6: you know what
column7: I don't think it's a great idea that we sell automatic weapons in this country that are used by the military to kill people very rapidly.

column1: Gun people said
column2: there were three candidates in the race
column3: you vote for one of the others
column4: but not Bernie Sanders. I lost that election by three percentage points. Quite likely
column5: for that reason. So please
column6: do not explain to me
column7: coming from a state where democratic governors and republican governors have supported virtually no gun control.

column1: (CROSSTALK)
Excuse me. Do not tell me that I have not shown courage in standing up to the gun people
column2: in voting to ban assault weapons
column3: voting for instant background checks
column4: voting to end the gun show loop hole and now we're in a position to create a consensus in America on gun safety.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
MUIR: Senator
column2: thank you. I want to move on here. Secretary Clinton
column3: you brought up Donald Trump a short time ago.

column1: CLINTON: I do and this is an important issue and I know we'll get to a lot of other critical ones as well. I actually agree with Governor O'Malley about the need for common sense gun safety measures. And I applaud his record in Maryland. I just wish he wouldn't misrepresent mine. I have been for the Brady bill
column2: I have been against assault weapons.

column1: I have voted not to give gun makers and sellers immunity. And I also know that -- and I'm glad to see this -- Senator Sanders has really moved in face of the facts about what we're confronting in our country. I know that he has said in the two previous that he wants to take on this immunity issue because we need to send a strong message to the gun manufacturers
column2: to the sellers
column3: to the gun lobby.

column1: And I would hope
column2: Senator Sanders
column3: that you would join the Democrats who are trying to close the Charleston loophole
column4: that you would sponsor or co-sponsor legislation to remove the absolute immunity. We need to move on this consensus that exists in the country. It's no longer enough just to say the vast majority of Americans want common sense gun safety measures including gun owners.

column1: We need
column2: and only the three of us will do this
column3: nobody on the Republican side will even admit there's a problem. And in whatever way the three of us can we need to move this agenda forward and begin to deal with the gun lobby and the intimidation that they present.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
MUIR: Secretary Clinton
column2: thank you. We're going to move on from guns here and go back to something you mentioned a short time ago. You brought up Donald Trump first here this evening. We've now seen the polling done well after his proposed ban on Muslims coming to America. Thirty-six percent of Americans
column3: more than a third
column4: agree with him.

column1: You have weighed in already on Donald Trump. You've weighed in on the proposed ban. But what would you say to the millions of Americans watching tonight who agree with him? Are they wrong?
CLINTON: Well I think a lot of people are understandably reacting out of fear and anxiety about what they're seeing. First what they saw in Paris
column2: now what they have seen in San Bernardino. And Mr. Trump has a great capacity to use bluster and bigotry to inflame people and to make think there are easy answers to very complex questions.

column1: So what I would say is
column2: number one
column3: we need to be united against the threats that we face. We need to have everybody in our country focused on watching what happens and reporting it if it's suspicious
column4: reporting what you hear. Making sure that Muslim Americans don't feel left out or marginalized at the very moment when we need their help.

column1: CLINTON: You know
column2: I was a senator from New York after 9/11
column3: and we spent countless hours trying to figure out how to protect the city and the state from perhaps additional attacks. One of the best things that was done
column4: and George W. Bush did this and I give him credit
column5: was to reach out to Muslim Americans and say
column6: we're in this together. You are not our adversary
column7: you are our partner.

column1: And we also need to make sure that the really discriminatory messages that Trump is sending around the world don't fall on receptive ears. He is becoming ISIS's best recruiter. They are going to people showing videos of Donald Trump insulting Islam and Muslims in order to recruit more radical jihadists. So I want to explain why this is not in America's interest to react with this kind of fear and respond to this sort of bigotry.
MUIR: Secretary
column2: thank you.

column1: Senator Sanders
column2: I did want to ask you about a neighbor in San Bernardino who reportedly witnessed packages being delivered to that couple's home
column3: that it set off red flags
column4: but they didn't report it because they were afraid to profile. What would you say to Americans afraid to profile? Is it ever acceptable?

column1: SANDERS: Well
column2: the answer is
column3: obviously
column4: if you see suspicious activity
column5: you report it. That's kind of a no-brainer. You know
column6: somebody is loading guns and ammunition into a house
column7: I think it's a good idea to call 911. Do it.

column1: (LAUGHTER)
MUIR: But I'm asking about -- I'm asking about profiling. Because a lot of people are afraid of that.
SANDERS: But I want to talk -- I want to talk about something else
column2: because Secretary Clinton I think made some interesting and good points. What you have now is a very dangerous moment in American history.

column1: The secretary is right: Our people are fearful. They are anxious on a number of levels. They are anxious about international terrorism and the possibility of another attack on America. We all understand that.
But you know what else they're anxious about? They're anxious about the fact that they are working incredibly long hours
column2: they're worried about their kids
column3: and they're seeing all the new income and wealth -- virtually all of it -- going to the top 1 percent. And they're looking around them
column4: and they're looking at Washington
column5: and they're saying the rich are getting much richer
column6: I'm getting poorer
column7: what are you going to do about it? What are you going to do for my kids?

column1: And somebody like a Trump comes along and says
column2: ""I know the answers. The answer is that all of the Mexicans
column3: they're criminals and rapists
column4: we've got to hate the Mexicans. Those are your enemies. We hate all the Muslims
column5: because all of the Muslims are terrorists. We've got to hate the Muslims."" Meanwhile
column6: the rich get richer.

column1: So what I say to those people who go to Donald Trump's rallies
column2: understand: He thinks a low minimum wage in America is a good idea. He thinks low wages are a good idea.

column1: I believe we stand together to address the real issues facing this country
column2: not allow them to divide us by race or where we come from. Let's create an America that works for all of us
column3: not the handful on top.

column1: (APPLAUSE)

column2: thank you.

column1: The defense teamÃ¢ÂÂs April 8 motion to compel immediate production of all exculpatory evidence reports the following exchange.
When the defense counsel asked K.S.
column2: Ã¢ÂÂDid you ever see [Greitens] in possession of a camera or phone?Ã¢ÂÂ she answered: Ã¢ÂÂNot to my knowledge. I didnÃ¢ÂÂt see him with it.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: K.S. remembered the photo incident Ã¢ÂÂthrough a dreamÃ¢ÂÂ? Memories recovered through dreams have led to some of the great injustices in recent jurisprudence. To her credit

Announces His Candidacy Washington DC - April 17
column2: 2006 We have a great country. We can do better. We must embrace our Founders intentions that we evolve our democracy to remain true to its founding principles. Lincoln
column3: 140 years ago
column4: defined our government: Ã¢ÂÂof the People
column5: by the People
column6: and for the People.Ã¢ÂÂ It falls to us to now give full meaning to a Government Ã¢ÂÂby the PeopleÃ¢ÂÂ so our common wisdom is reflected in our national policies. TodayÃ¢ÂÂs advances in information and communication technology provide us unprecedented ability to communicate as citizens
column7: and all that is lacking is a political process
column8: a mechanism
column9: that permits the citizens to play a direct role in the operations of government. Our country needs a renewalÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂrenewal not just of particular policies
column10: or of particular people
column11: but of democracy itself. I believe that the remedy for the state of our political alienation is the civic renewal embodied in the Ã¢ÂÂNational Initiative for Democracy.Ã¢ÂÂ The National Initiative is proposed legislation that colleagues and I have developed over the last fifteen years. The National InitiativeÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂwhen enacted into lawÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂwill bring all American citizens into the operations of government as lawmakers. Our three branches of government have become like an unstable chair with only three legs. The Founders could not have envisioned how much money and special interests would corrupt our political process. Giving usÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂAmerican citizensÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂlegislative power will put the fourth leg on our chair
column12: giving birth to a new foundation of American governanceÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂadding a new check to our system of Checks and Balances. I believe the internet adage: Ã¢ÂÂall of us together are smarter than any one of us alone. I say: Ã¢ÂÂLet the People Decide.Ã¢ÂÂ Lawmaking is the central power of government not Election Day voting. Politicians have purposely made the electoral process uncompetitive and jealously guard their monopoly on lawmaking. Whoever makes the laws determines who we vote for
column13: when we vote and how we voteÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂFlorida and Ohio are recent examples. Representative government is mired in a culture of lies and corruption. The corrupting influence of money has created a class of professional politicians raising huge sums to maintain power. Then politicians legislate in the interests of corporations and interest groups. Are todayÃ¢ÂÂs political leaders more corrupt than earlier generations? I do not think so. Most men and women in public service begin with a dedication to the public good. ItÃ¢ÂÂs the power that corrupts them. Throwing the rascals out Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂRepublicans or Democrats or any party for that matterÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂmay make us feel good but reshuffling the deck wonÃ¢ÂÂt make any difference. We hope against hope that our representatives will correct and reform government. But itÃ¢ÂÂs like asking the foxes to redesign the chicken-coop. The flaws of representative government arenÃ¢ÂÂt in either in the structure of representative government or with those who manage it. ItÃ¢ÂÂs both. ItÃ¢ÂÂs the structure of representative government that makes its managers susceptible to corruption
column14: greed
column15: injustice and self serving interests. Continued on page 2 Stay up to date
column16: enter your email and zip code: Email : Zip : A 21st Century Government We are a great nationÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂblessed with ideal geography and abundant resources developed by the sacrifices of immigrant peoples who came to our shores from all over the world
column17: melding foreign cultures and political and religious beliefs into a national community of diversity
column19: laws and free markets. Our political and economic achievements inspired respect and admiration worldwide. That respect and admiration has been squandered by our current partisan
column20: political leadership. Today
column21: the United States government and the president are reviled in many parts of the world. Not only have we failed as a world leader but our domestic stewardship has presided over a crumbling national infrastructure and unmet social needs while undermining the soundness of our economy with government profligacy. Unfortunately
column23: political rhetoric we hear as we approach the 2006 election ineffectively nibbles at the margins of domestic issues and defers submissively to an imperial presidency on global matters. Unfortunately
column24: the monopoly power representatives have thwarts any possibly of reforming government. Representative government
column25: by its very structure
column29: injustice and self-serving special interests. There are only two venues in human governance within which change is possible: the people or the government (that the people set up in the Constitution). Since the government venue is responsible for our current predicament
column30: we have no choice but to look to the venue of the people to reform the government. We need to change the direction of the United States if we are to meet the social
column32: environmental and global challenges of the 21st Century."	0

column1: 12:03 P.M. EDT
MR. HARWOOD: Good afternoon from Washington
column2: D.C. I'm John Harwood. It is noon on the East Coast. The Dow Jones average stands around 10
column3: 700 points; 15 million Americans are out of work. And we're spending the next hour talking about how to fix the troubled American economy.

column1: Please welcome the President of the United States. (Applause.)
THE PRESIDENT: Thank you very much.
MR. HARWOOD: Mr. President
column2: thanks for being here.

column1: THE PRESIDENT: That was quite a lead-in
column2: by the way. (Laughter.)

column1: MR. HARWOOD: Yes
column2: wasnÃ¢ÂÂt it? You like that dramatic pause? (Laughter.) We have got a cross-section of people from around the country -- CEOs
column3: union workers
column4: teachers and students --

column1: THE PRESIDENT: ItÃ¢ÂÂs a good-looking group
column2: I have to say. (Laughter and applause.)

column1: MR. HARWOOD: -- small business owners
column2: people who don't have a job. Every one of them has a stake in the American Dream. And they got some good news over the weekend. The National Bureau of Economic Research
column3: as you know
column4: has said that the recession ended in June 2009 -- a few months after you took office. And yet hereÃ¢ÂÂs the problem you find yourself with. Many leaders in business think you and your policies are hostile to them. And many ordinary Americans think your policies are helping Wall Street and big business. How did that happen?

column1: THE PRESIDENT: Well
column2: first of all
column3: even though economists may say that the recession officially ended last year
column4: obviously for the millions of people who are still out of work
column5: people who have seen their home values decline
column6: people who are struggling to pay the bills day to day
column7: itÃ¢ÂÂs still very real for them.

column1: And I think we have to go back to what was happening when I was first sworn in as the 44th President of the United States. We went through the worst recession since the Great Depression. Nothing has come close. In fact
column2: if you look at the consequences of the recession in the Ã¢ÂÂ80s
column3: the recession in the Ã¢ÂÂ90s
column4: and the recession in 2001
column5: and you combine all three of those
column6: it still wasnÃ¢ÂÂt as bad as this recession that we went through.

column1: So the month I was sworn in we lost 750
column2: 000 jobs; the month after that 600
column3: 000; the month after that 600
column4: 000. This is before any of our plans had a chance to take effect. The financial markets were on the verge of meltdown and the economy was contracting about 6 percent -- by far
column5: the largest contraction we've seen since the Ã¢ÂÂ30s.

column1: You combine all that and what that meant was that we had to take some steps very quickly just to make sure that the financial system was not collapsing -- that people could get auto loans
column2: could get student loans
column3: that businesses large and small could get some financing to keep their doors open and to keep their payrolls on track. And in addition
column4: we had to make sure that we didnÃ¢ÂÂt slip into a Great Depression.

column1: Now
column2: we've done that. Those programs that we put in place worked. So now youÃ¢ÂÂve got a financial system that is stable. ItÃ¢ÂÂs still not as strong as it was back in 2006
column4: but it is stabilized. YouÃ¢ÂÂve got now eight consecutive months of private sector job growth. Businesses are able to borrow again; theyÃ¢ÂÂre investing again; theyÃ¢ÂÂre making profits again.

column1: That's all the good news. The challenge is
column2: is that the hole was so deep that a lot of people out there are still hurting -- and probably some folks here in the audience are still having a tough time. (Applause.) And so the question then becomes what can we now put in place to make sure that the trend lines continue in a positive direction
column3: as opposed to going back in the negative direction.

column1: Last week we got some good news. After fighting for several months
column2: we finally got a small business tax cut bill in place so that weÃ¢ÂÂre eliminating capital gains for small businesses and startups
column3: making sure that they can get loans -- because small businesses are the ones that have been hardest hit in terms of not being able to get capital. We have put forward proposals
column4: for example
column5: to accelerate investment here in the United States instead of overseas in research and development and plants and equipment that could put people back to work.

column1: So there are a lot of plans in place that can make improvement
column2: but itÃ¢ÂÂs slow and steady
column3: as opposed to the kind of quick fix that I think a lot of people would like to see. But the thing IÃ¢ÂÂve just got to remind people of is the fact that it took us a decade to get into the problem that weÃ¢ÂÂre in right now.

column1: The Wall Street Journal came out with a report based on Census information that the years from 2001 to 2009
column2: the middle class actually saw their wages decline by 5 percent. This was before the financial crisis. So these have been some long-term trends of the middle class having a lot of problems out there. And what weÃ¢ÂÂve got to do now it to reverse it
column3: but something that took 10 years to create is going to take a little more time to solve.

column1: MR. HARWOOD: IÃ¢ÂÂve heard you give that turnaround message you just gave many times.
THE PRESIDENT: Right
column2: right.

column1: MR. HARWOOD: Let me ask about your assessment of the challenge and the problem in communicating that to the American people. We all identify with people like ourselves. Do you think itÃ¢ÂÂs possible that because of your style
column2: or the unusual things about your background -- your racial heritage
column3: where you grew up
column4: Ivy League education -- that the fearful voters who are about to go to the polls in November think
column5: yes
column6: I hear him
column7: he may get it intellectually
column8: but he doesnÃ¢ÂÂt feel what IÃ¢ÂÂm feeling?

column1: THE PRESIDENT: Well
column2: hereÃ¢ÂÂs my suspicion. I think that when the unemployment rate is still high and people are having a tough time
column3: it doesnÃ¢ÂÂt matter if I was green -- (laughter) -- it doesnÃ¢ÂÂt matter if I was purple. I think people would still be frustrated
column4: and understandably so.

column1: Look
column2: I can describe whatÃ¢ÂÂs happening to the economy overall
column3: but if youÃ¢ÂÂre out of work right now
column4: the only thing that youÃ¢ÂÂre going to be hearing is
column5: when do I get a job? (Applause.) If youÃ¢ÂÂre about to lose your home
column6: all youÃ¢ÂÂre thinking about is
column7: when can I get my home?

column1: So I donÃ¢ÂÂt think that those are the issues. And by the way
column2: I think most people understand -- because I spent two years running around the country talking about my life and why I was running for President -- they understand that I was the kid of a single mom
column3: and I got my education through scholarships
column4: and I lived in a small apartment with my grandparents
column5: and they were helped by the G.I. Bill and FHA in terms of being able to climb into the middle class.

column1: The whole reason I ran was because my life is a testimony to the American Dream. And everything that weÃ¢ÂÂve been doing since I came into office is designed to make sure that that American Dream continues for future generations.

I think the challenge right now is that IÃ¢ÂÂm thinking about the next generation and there are a lot of folks out there who are thinking about the next election. If I were making decisions based on November
column2: then I wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt have done some of the things that I did because I knew they werenÃ¢ÂÂt popular. But they were the right thing to do. And that's got to be my top priority. (Applause.)

column1: MR. HARWOOD: LetÃ¢ÂÂs go to the real jury who will decide whether they were the right things to do with an audience question right here.
Q Thank you very much and
column2: quite frankly
column3: good afternoon
column4: President Obama. I am deeply honored to finally be in this forum
column5: and so grateful for CNBC making the forum available so that you can speak to American citizens just like myself.

column1: THE PRESIDENT: Well
column2: thank you.

column1: Q I am a chief financial officer for a veterans service organization
column2: AmVets here in Washington. IÃ¢ÂÂm also a mother
column3: IÃ¢ÂÂm a wife
column4: IÃ¢ÂÂm an American veteran
column5: and IÃ¢ÂÂm one of your middle-class Americans. And quite frankly
column6: IÃ¢ÂÂm exhausted. IÃ¢ÂÂm exhausted of defending you
column7: defending your administration

Q -- and deeply disappointed with where we are right now.
I have been told that I voted for a man who said he was going to change things in a meaningful way for the middle class. IÃ¢ÂÂm one of those people
column2: and IÃ¢ÂÂm waiting
column3: sir. IÃ¢ÂÂm waiting. I don't feel it yet. And I thought

column5: have made good decisions.

column2: as I said before
column3: times are tough for everybody right now
column4: so I understand your frustration. But I would just -- when you say there are things that youÃ¢ÂÂd like to see happen or youÃ¢ÂÂre hoping to see happen that havenÃ¢ÂÂt happened yet
column5: let me just give you a couple of examples.

column2: as well.

THE PRESIDENT: Okay. Now part of what we did over the last year and a half is to make sure that billions of dollars that were going to subsidize financial service industries under the federal student loan programs are now going to be going directly to students so that millions more students are going to be able to get loans and grants and scholarships to go to college. Now
column2: that's going to have an impact on a whole bunch of kids out there

THE PRESIDENT: Well
column2: see
column3: now youÃ¢ÂÂre really -- now youÃ¢ÂÂve shown how responsible you are. (Laughter.) But if you have a mortgage or a credit card or any kind of financial dealings out there

column5: the credit card companies canÃ¢ÂÂt increase your interest rate without notifying you

column3: gosh

column1: MR. HARWOOD: Mr. President
column2: let me go at this from a different direction

MR. LANGONE: What should they stop doing? Well
column2: I think the one thing to do is to not make people in business feel like weÃ¢ÂÂre villains or criminals or doing something wrong. I think anytime we can create a job that puts somebody to work

column5: is based on a strong

column3: businesses
column4: some of the same commentators who are on CNBC
column5: were crying
column6: Ã¢ÂÂDo something
column7: Ã¢ÂÂ -- because as a consequence of reckless decisions that had been made

column9: we have instituted about 50 tax cuts
column10: many of them going to businesses large and small.

column1: And so the only thing that weÃ¢ÂÂve said is that weÃ¢ÂÂve got to make sure that weÃ¢ÂÂre not doing some of the same things that we were doing in the past that got us into this mess in the first place.
So when I mentioned
column2: for example
column3: changes in the financial services industry
column4: it is very important for us not to find ourselves in a position in which banks get too big to fail
column5: and if they make bad decisions taxpayers have to bail them out or we let the entire economy collapse. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs not a choice that I want any future President to have to make. And we instituted those changes.

column1: And the fact is that when FDR put in place deposit insurance in banks
column2: banks said at the time
column3: this is going to destroy capitalism. When Medicare was instituted
column4: there were a whole bunch of people who said
column5: this is socialized medicine. Now we take it for granted. But oftentimes thereÃ¢ÂÂs this response that somehow these modest reforms that make the free market work better for consumers and for workers as well as for businesses
column6: on the front end are resisted.

column1: MR. HARWOOD: Let me take it
column2: though
column3: to a level that's beyond policy and it goes to what you value and you don't value.

column1: THE PRESIDENT: Sure.

MR. HARWOOD: I think some of those in business may think that deep down you think that working for profit is morally inferior to the kind of work you used to do as a community organizer. Is that how you feel?
THE PRESIDENT: No
column2: it isnÃ¢ÂÂt. Look
column3: in every speech
column4: every interview that I've made
column5: I've constantly said that what sets America apart
column6: what has made us successful over the long term
column7: is we've got the most dynamic free market economy in the world. And that has to be preserved. That has to be preserved. We benefit from entrepreneurs and innovators who are going out there and creating jobs
column8: creating businesses.

column1: Government can't create the majority of jobs. And in fact
column2: we want to get out of the way of folks whoÃ¢ÂÂve got a great idea and want to run with it and are going to be putting people to work.

column1: MR. HARWOOD: Maybe we've got one of those people right here.
THE PRESIDENT: I'd love to hear from him.
Q Thank you
column2: Mr. President. I'm 30 years old. I recently graduated from law school. And I went back to law school in order to pursue a life of public service
column3: like you have. And what I found was that I simply -- there aren't jobs out there right now. I took advantage of the loans that you were just speaking about
column4: but I can't make the interest payments on those loans today
column5: let alone think about getting a mortgage
column6: having a family
column7: having even a marriage -- itÃ¢ÂÂs awfully expensive. (Laughter.)

column1: THE PRESIDENT: I'm not going to comment on that. (Laughter and applause.) Let me just say that whatever the expense
column2: itÃ¢ÂÂs worth it. (Laughter.) I want that on record. (Applause.)

column1: Q Like a lot of people in my generation
column2: I was really inspired by you and by your campaign and message that you brought
column3: and that inspiration is dying away. It feels like the American Dream is not attainable to a lot of us. And what I'm really hoping to hear from you is several concrete steps that youÃ¢ÂÂre going to take moving forward that will be able to re-ignite my generation
column4: re-ignite the youth who are beset by student loans. And I really want to know
column5: is the American Dream dead for me?

column1: THE PRESIDENT: Absolutely not. Look
column2: we still have the best universities in the world. WeÃ¢ÂÂve got the most dynamic private sector in the world. WeÃ¢ÂÂve got the most productive workers in the world. There is not a country in the world that would not want to change places with us. For all the problems that weÃ¢ÂÂve got
column3: as tough as things are right now
column4: we are still the country that billions of people around the world look to and aspire to. And I want everybody to always remember that.

column1: Now
column2: as I said before
column3: what we saw happening during 2001 to the time I took office was wages actually declining for middle-class families
column4: people treading water
column5: young people having more trouble getting their foot in the door in terms of businesses. And so we are now having to go back to the fundamentals that made America great.

column1: And that means weÃ¢ÂÂve got to improve our education system. That means that we have to make sure that our markets are working in a way that is good for a broad base of people and not just a narrow base of people. It means that
column2: letÃ¢ÂÂs say -- you used the example of student loans -- one of the things that I just mentioned was
column3: is that we put billions of dollars more into student loans. This was paid for
column4: now. We took this out of financial service industries that were getting essentially unjustified subsidies -- theyÃ¢ÂÂre now going to students so that your debt would be lower. And by the way
column5: part of that law also capped your debt at 10 percent of your income so that you knew that you could actually afford to take out this debt and pay for it even if you had a modest salary.

column1: So we are taking these steps. But the most important thing we can do right now is to grow our economy. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs the single most important thing that we can do. And some of the measures that weÃ¢ÂÂve put forward and IÃ¢ÂÂm going to be fighting for are designed to exactly do that.
For example
column2: weÃ¢ÂÂve said letÃ¢ÂÂs accelerate business investment in the year 2011 to give a further jumpstart to the economy. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs something that
column3: by the way
column4: doesnÃ¢ÂÂt add to the deficit necessarily long term because this is depreciation that could be taken in the out-years. WeÃ¢ÂÂre just saying you invest now
column5: you can take it now. And that gives businesses incentives to do it.

column1: We want to give tax breaks to companies that are investing in research and development here in the United States because the key to our long-term growth is technology and innovation. And if we can get more of those investments here
column2: that's going to improve. The reforms weÃ¢ÂÂve made on education -- which
column3: by the way
column4: have received bipartisan support -- are designed to make sure weÃ¢ÂÂve got the best engineers and the best scientists in the world right here in the United States.

column1: So if weÃ¢ÂÂre doing all those things
column2: I am confident that the American Dream will continue for the next generation. What we canÃ¢ÂÂt do
column3: though
column4: is go back to the same old things that we were doing
column5: because weÃ¢ÂÂve been putting off these problems for decades. And that is something that I refuse to do.

column1: MR. HARWOOD: Mr. President
column2: let me ask you a question about course correction. Sometimes a leader
column3: even if you think youÃ¢ÂÂve done the right things
column4: but if the people youÃ¢ÂÂre trying to lead don't think so
column5: youÃ¢ÂÂve got to somehow accommodate that
column6: just like you would in a relationship. He was talking about marriage. (Laughter.)

column1: As you go forward
column2: is there any way in which you want to signal to the American people that youÃ¢ÂÂre going to change your approach? And specifically -- weÃ¢ÂÂre coming up to the midterm election -- have you asked your Treasury Secretary Tim Geithner and your top economic advisor Larry Summers to stay with you through the end of your term
column3: or might you make some changes?

column1: THE PRESIDENT: Well
column2: look
column3: I have not made any determinations about personnel. I think Larry Summers and Tim Geithner have done an outstanding job
column4: as have my whole economic team. This is tough
column5: the work that they do. TheyÃ¢ÂÂve been at it for two years
column6: and theyÃ¢ÂÂre going to have a whole range of decisions about family that will factor into this
column7: as well. But the bottom line is
column8: is that weÃ¢ÂÂre constantly thinking
column9: is what weÃ¢ÂÂre doing working as well as it could? Do we have other options and other alternatives that we can explore?

column1: I think one of the things that's on a lot of peopleÃ¢ÂÂs minds right now
column2: obviously
column3: for example
column4: is the issue of deficits and debt. That has fanned a lot of peopleÃ¢ÂÂs concerns because we had to take a lot of emergency decisions last year that cost money. Now
column5: they were the right things to do. Had we not taken them
column6: the economy would be in a much worse position. Even John McCainÃ¢ÂÂs former economist during the campaign has said that if we hadnÃ¢ÂÂt taken these steps
column7: that we might have lost another 8 million jobs
column8: and we would be in an even deeper hole.

column1: MR. HARWOOD: And we know you have that commission that reports in December
column2: but I think a lot of Americans may wonder how serious you are about what that commission is going to do.

column1: THE PRESIDENT: Well
column2: let me tell you. WeÃ¢ÂÂve already identified $250 billion in cuts on the discretionary side of our budget. WeÃ¢ÂÂve identified $300 billion worth of loopholes in our tax code that are not helping economic growth. If we just did those two things
column3: as IÃ¢ÂÂve already proposed
column4: that would make a huge difference. WeÃ¢ÂÂve proposed to freeze discretionary spending for three years
column5: to start whittling down some of the debt that I inherited.

column1: MR. HARWOOD: Peter Orszag
column2: as you know
column3: your former budget director
column4: says that we canÃ¢ÂÂt afford to extend the Bush tax cuts for anyone after a year or two. Is he right?

column1: THE PRESIDENT: Well
column2: I want to make sure I get this gentlemanÃ¢ÂÂs question in
column3: but I will say this. The debate that weÃ¢ÂÂre having about tax cuts right now I think really speaks to the choices that everybody here is going to be facing as we go forward. I think all of us are concerned about the deficit; all of us are concerned about the debt. Now
column4: what weÃ¢ÂÂve said is that we should extend tax cuts
column5: tax relief
column6: for middle-class Americans -- like most of the audience here -- because
column7: first of all
column8: youÃ¢ÂÂre the ones who didn't see your wages or income rise. Second of all
column9: youÃ¢ÂÂre the folks who are most likely to spend it on a new computer for your kids
column10: or in some other fashion that would boost demand in the economy.

column1: Everybody agrees that this should be done. All weÃ¢ÂÂve said is that you get those tax breaks up to $250
column2: 000 a year. After that
column3: if you make more than $250
column4: 000 a year
column5: you still get a tax break; itÃ¢ÂÂs just you only get it up to $250

column1: MR. HARWOOD: House Speak Pelosi said last week --
THE PRESIDENT: And let me say this
column2: John
column3: because I just think itÃ¢ÂÂs very important that everybody understands this. What the Republicans are proposing is that we
column4: in addition to that
column5: provide tax relief to primarily millionaires and billionaires. It would cost us $700 billion to do it. On average
column6: millionaires would get a check of $100

column1: And by the way
column2: I would be helped by this
column3: so I just want to be clear. IÃ¢ÂÂm speaking against my own financial interests. This is a -- it is a irresponsible thing for us to do. Those folks are the least likely to spend it and -- (applause.)

column1: MR. HARWOOD: Well
column2: let me ask you from this angle. House Speaker Pelosi last week said you can get 80 percent of the revenue if you simply take away the tax cuts for people over a million dollars. Are you open to any sort of compromise that would capture most of that revenue
column3: but those people between $250
column4: 000 and a million would get to keep that tax cut?

column1: THE PRESIDENT: HereÃ¢ÂÂs the basic principle. HereÃ¢ÂÂs what I canÃ¢ÂÂt do as President. I think IÃ¢ÂÂve worked pretty hard and I have a pretty big grasp of the challenges that weÃ¢ÂÂre facing. (Applause.) But hereÃ¢ÂÂs what I canÃ¢ÂÂt do. I canÃ¢ÂÂt give tax cuts to the top 2 percent of Americans
column2: 86 percent of that money going to people making a million dollars or more
column3: and lower the deficit at the same time. I donÃ¢ÂÂt have the math.

column1: I would love to do it. Every -- anybody in elected office would love nothing more than to give everybody tax cuts
column2: not cut services
column3: make sure that IÃ¢ÂÂm providing help to student loans
column4: make sure that weÃ¢ÂÂre keeping our roads safe and our bridges safe
column5: and make sure that weÃ¢ÂÂre paying for our veterans who are coming back from Iraq and Afghanistan. At some point
column6: the numbers just donÃ¢ÂÂt work.

column1: So what IÃ¢ÂÂve said is very simple. LetÃ¢ÂÂs go ahead and move forward on what we agree to
column2: which is tax relief for 95 -- 97 percent of Americans. In fact
column3: actually everybody would get tax relief
column4: but just up to $250
column5: 000 a year more. And letÃ¢ÂÂs get the economy moving faster
column6: letÃ¢ÂÂs get it growing faster. At some point in the future
column7: if we want to have discussions about further lowering tax rates
column8: letÃ¢ÂÂs do so at a time when we can actually afford it.

column1: MR. HARWOOD: All right
column2: weÃ¢ÂÂve kept this gentleman waiting long enough.

column1: THE PRESIDENT: Thank you very much.
Q Mr. President
column2: it is an honor to be in front of you. I am a small business owner. I'm a third-generation business owner in Pennsylvania. We are actually celebrating our 100th-year anniversary because we were founded in 1910.

column1: THE PRESIDENT: Congratulations. (Applause.) WhatÃ¢ÂÂs your business?
Q Something called Susquehanna Glass
column2: and we do monogrammed glasswork.

column1: THE PRESIDENT: Outstanding.
Q If you ever pick up a Williams-Sonoma catalog and buy a monogrammed glass
column2: youÃ¢ÂÂre getting the stuff from me. (Laughter.)

column1: THE PRESIDENT: Congratulations -- and your grandfather started this?
Q My grandfather and his brother started the business
column2: yes
column3: three generations.

column1: THE PRESIDENT: ThatÃ¢ÂÂs outstanding. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs great.
Q Two world wars
column2: one Great Depression
column3: and a lot of economic recession
column4: so weÃ¢ÂÂve been through a lot. What I have learned in running a small business over that period of time is that to succeed
column5: to survive
column6: you have to reinvest in your business. It simply is imperative. The single greatest economic challenge that I face today is a public that is fearful and negative.

column1: You
column2: when you first came into office
column3: your stimulus package actually funded a very ailing financial system
column4: which was essential for small businesspeople. You turned around and invested in the auto industry
column5: and I believe saved millions of jobs
column6: and I think youÃ¢ÂÂre actually going to make a profit on them. (Applause.)

column1: THE PRESIDENT: We are. That's true.
Q And yet your critics continue to paint you as a dramatically anti-business President. I believe you are investing in this country
column2: as small businesses invest. And yet for some reason the public just doesnÃ¢ÂÂt get it. I need you to help us understand how you can regain the political center
column3: because youÃ¢ÂÂre losing the war of sound bites
column4: youÃ¢ÂÂre losing the media cycles.

column1: I have a son that just graduated from college. He was just commissioned as a second lieutenant in the Army. He wants to make a career of the Army. I want to have a business for him to come back to when he gets out of the Army.
THE PRESIDENT: Well
column2: first of all
column3: let me say to your son thank you for your service to our country
column4: and we want to make sure weÃ¢ÂÂve got a strong economy for him to come back to. (Applause.)

column1: As I said before
column2: I think that if you look at what weÃ¢ÂÂve done over the last two years
column3: itÃ¢ÂÂs very hard to find evidence of anything that weÃ¢ÂÂve done that is designed to squash business as opposed to promote business.

column1: You mentioned the auto industry. This is a great example of something that we did -- we knew it wasnÃ¢ÂÂt popular. I mean
column2: people just -- the last thing folks wanted to see was us helping the auto industry. Now
column3: keep in mind
column4: the previous administration had been helping them
column5: giving them billions of dollars and just asking nothing in return. But we were at a point where two of the big three automakers were about to liquidate
column6: in the midst of this huge recession
column7: and we would have lost an additional million jobs as a consequence
column8: but also lost what is a signature manufacturing industry in this country. I mean
column9: we built the world auto industry.

column1: And so what we did was we said to the auto companies
column2: we are going to help you
column3: but youÃ¢ÂÂve got to make some changes. YouÃ¢ÂÂve got to make sure that we see a restructuring of how you do business. And by the way
column4: some of the folks who made the biggest concessions were actually the workers there. It wasnÃ¢ÂÂt -- they took huge cuts in terms of pay and benefits because they understood that there wage structures could no longer support the auto industry in a competitive era.

column1: We are now seeing the top -- the three U.S. automakers making a profit for the first time in a long time. They are hiring for the first time in a long time. And that has huge ramifications
column2: because there are suppliers
column3: and the restaurant next to the plant that's open -- and so it has provided a lot of confidence in a lot of these communities. But it wasnÃ¢ÂÂt popular at the time.

column1: Now
column2: there were some folks in -- on CNBC who were unhappy with our decision
column3: partly because they had made bets
column4: essentially
column5: against the auto industry
column6: or they had senior debt. And we said
column7: you know what
column8: if the workers are giving up something
column9: if management is giving up something
column10: if the federal government is giving up something
column11: and taxpayers are giving something
column12: youÃ¢ÂÂre not going to get a hundred percent of what you bargained for in terms of some of the investments that you made here. YouÃ¢ÂÂre going to have to take a haircut
column13: too. And they got very mad about it. I still remember some of the fulminating that was taking place on CNBC about it. (Laughter.)

column1: We didnÃ¢ÂÂt do that because we were anti-business. We were doing it because we wanted to make sure that these businesses would continue. And by the way
column2: some of the same folks who complained were some of the same folks who
column3: if we hadnÃ¢ÂÂt taken some of those actions on Wall Street
column4: would have lost everything they had. And they didnÃ¢ÂÂt mind us intervening when it was helping them. But they did mind it when we were helping some other folks.

column1: So the point
column2: I guess
column3: IÃ¢ÂÂm making is this. I think that American businesses like yours are what make this country go. We have passed eight tax cuts for small businesses so far. We have made it easier for you to invest in plants and equipment. We have already taken down your capital gains and we want to reduce capital gains for small businesses down to zero. All of these things are what historically have been considered pro-business agendas.

column1: Even on health care
column2: a lot of small businesses couldnÃ¢ÂÂt provide health care. We are now saying weÃ¢ÂÂve giving you a tax break if you provide health care to your workers. And 4 mil"	0
