column1: AMANPOUR (voice-over): Welcome to our viewers here and around the world. I'm Christiane Amanpour. And at the top of the news this week
column2: the Gang of 20. At the big summit in Seoul
column3: U.S. economic policies come under fire from China and Germany. Are America's woes putting its global leadership in question?

column1: OBAMA: A whole host of other countries are doing very well. Naturally
column2: they are going to be more assertive.

column1: AMANPOUR: Former Secretary of State Madeleine Albright and Republican Senator Lindsey Graham debate America's role in the world.
Then
column2: American austerity.

column1: BOWLES: The path we're on today is not sustainable. We are headed for disaster.
AMANPOUR: Two members of the president's deficit commission
column2: Democratic Senator Kent Conrad and Honeywell International Chairman and CEO David Cote share some sobering views on tough economic choices the United States faces.

column1: And the coming showdown over tax cuts.
BOEHNER: Making these permanent will be the most important thing we could do to help create jobs in the country.
AMANPOUR: That and all the week's politics on our roundtable with George Will
column2: New York Times columnist Paul Krugman
column3: Ruth Marcus of the Washington Post
column4: and Robert Kagan of the Brookings Institution.

column1: And the Sunday funnies.
FALLON: China is expected to overtake the U.S. as the world's biggest economy in the next two years. Americans couldn't believe it. They were like
column2: ""That hasn't happened already?""

column1: (LAUGHTER)
ANNOUNCER: From all across our world to the heart of our nation's capital
column2: ABC ""This Week"" with Christiane Amanpour starts now.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
AMANPOUR: And hello again.
By the time Air Force One lands in Washington this evening
column2: it will have flown around the world
column3: a world that is fast changing
column4: as the president found out during his 10-day trip to Asia. ABC's senior White House correspondent Jake Tapper has been with the president and brings us this report.

column1: (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)
TAPPER (voice-over): Rebuked by American voters and reminded to focus more on the economy
column2: President Obama began his Asian trip talking it up as a sort of international stimulus to open markets to American goods and bolster American jobs.

column1: OBAMA: We're actually doing some business while we're here. With every $1 billion we sell in exports
column3: 000 jobs are supported at home. For America
column4: this is a job strategy.

column1: TAPPER: In Mumbai
column2: India
column3: flanked by American CEOs
column4: the president announced deals between U.S. and Indian companies totaling nearly $10 billion in U.S. exports and maintaining more than 50
column5: 000 American jobs.

column1: A cause for celebration
column2: as he and the first lady joined in on the festivities marking the Hindu holiday of Diwali.

column1: (on-screen): By the end of the week here in South Korea
column2: there was no cause for dancing. Some of the world's fastest-growing economies refused President Obama's entreaties to alter their economic policies
column3: policies the president needs changed to fully implement his export strategy
column4: his job strategy.

column1: OBAMA: Instead of hitting home runs
column2: sometimes we're going to hit singles.

column1: TAPPER (voice-over): And sometimes he struck out
column2: failing to convince South Korea to open their markets to American beef and cars. At stake: $10 billion in exports and 70
column3: 000 American jobs.

column1: Failing to convince Chinese President Hu Jintao to stop artificially building up the dollar and holding down Chinese currency.
And failing to convince his fellow G-20 leaders to use stronger language in the joint declaration on China's currency manipulation.
OBAMA: That is an irritant not just to the United States
column2: but is an irritant to a lot of China's trading partners and those who are competing with China to sell goods around the world.

column1: TAPPER: The president was even forced to push back on attacks that the U.S. was engaging in its own currency manipulation
column2: defending a move by the independent Federal Reserve to inject $600 billion into the U.S. economy.

column1: OBAMA: From everything I can see
column2: this decision was not one designed to have an impact on the currency
column3: on the dollar. It was designed to grow the economy.

column1: TAPPER: Criticisms from G-20 leaders who questioned President Obama's spending habits were made all the more relevant when the co-chairs of the president's own debt commission put forth controversial proposals to reduce the deficit.
BOWLES: This debt is like a cancer that will truly destroy this country from within.
TAPPER: Ones attacked by liberals and conservative
column2: showing how difficult reducing the deficit will be. Modesty was forced upon the president in this trip full of complications.

column1: For ""This Week
column2: Jake Tapper
column3: ABC News
column4: traveling with the president."	0

column1: 146	"April 18
column2: 2010 Ã¢ÂÂ -- Bill Clinton made mistakes as president on financial regulation
column3: he admitted in an exclusive ""This Week"" interview
column4: but Clinton stood his ground regarding the dangers of overheated political rhetoric
column5: saying Rush Limbaugh's accusation Clinton ""set the stage for violence"" with a recent speech on the subject ""doesn't make any sense.""

column1: In his first ""This Week"" interview since the passage of health care reform
column2: Clinton reflected on how the bill's success made him feel like Teddy Roosevelt to Obama's FDR. And Clinton offered advice and thoughts on some of Obama's next issues -- a Supreme Court nomination
column3: the Middle East peace process and the midterm elections.

column1: Anchor Jake Tapper asked Clinton about Limbaugh's criticism of his speech marking the upcoming 15th anniversary of the Oklahoma City bombing. In that speech
column2: Clinton warned that ""the words we use really do matter
column3: because there's this vast echo chamber
column4: and they go across space and they fall on the serious and delirious alike. They fall on the connected and the unhinged alike.""

column1: On ""This Week
column2: Clinton said
column3: ""The only point I tried to make was that we ought to have a lot of political dissent -- a lot of political argument. Nobody is right all the time. But we also have to take responsibility for the possible consequences of what we say.""

column1: Clinton said he worries about threats against President Obama and the Congress. And
column2: he worries ""about more careless language ... some of which we've seen against the Republican governor in New Jersey
column3: Gov. Christie.""

column1: A recently leaked memo from a New Jersey teacher joked about Christie dying.
I think we all have to be careful
column2: Clinton said. ""We ought to remember [that] after Oklahoma City we learned something about the difference in disagreement and demonization.""

column1: Clinton acknowledged that he was wrong to take what he now views as bad advice from his Treasury secretaries
column2: Robert Rubin and Larry Summers
column3: who told him the market for complex financial instruments known as derivatives ought to remain unregulated.

column1: On derivatives
column2: yeah
column3: I think they were wrong and I think I was wrong to take [their advice]
column4: Clinton said
column5: ""because the argument on derivatives was that these things are expensive and sophisticated and only a handful of investors will buy them
column6: and they don't need any extra protection and any extra transparency. The money they're putting up guarantees them transparency.

column1: The flaw in that argument
column2: Clinton added
column3: ""was that first of all sometimes people with a lot of money make stupid decisions and make it without transparency.""

column1: The former president said he also was wrong in his understanding of what a collapse in the derivative market could do to the economy.
The most important flaw
column2: he said
column3: ""was even if less than 1 percent of the total investment community is involved in derivative exchanges
column4: so much money was involved that if they went bad
column5: they could affect 100 percent of the investments
column6: and indeed 100 percent of the citizens in countries
column7: not investors. And I was wrong about that.""

column1: He now wishes he had tried to regulate derivatives while in office
column2: but he doesn't think he would have been successful.

column1: Now
column2: I think if I had tried to regulate them
column3: because the Republicans were the majority in the Congress
column4: they would have stopped it
column5: he said. ""But I wish I should have been caught trying. I mean
column6: that was a mistake I made."""	0

TRUMP: Many people

Crossfire
Should U.S. Trust Russia on Syria?
Aired September 10
THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.
ANNOUNCER: Tonight on CROSSFIRE
column2: as President Obama prepares to address the nation
column3: he hits the pause button on attacking Syria. Should he follow Russia's lead or keep threatening a military strike?

column1: JOHN KERRY
column2: SECRETARY OF STATE: Nothing focuses the mind like the prospect of a hanging.

column1: ANNOUNCER: On the left
column2: Van Jones. On the right
column3: S.E. Cupp. In the CROSSFIRE
column4: Joe Lieberman
column5: who supports the strike on Syria
column6: and Rick Santorum
column7: who's opposed. Is Russia's diplomacy real? Or should the U.S. strike Assad now? Tonight on CROSSFIRE.

column1: VAN JONES
column2: CO-HOST: Welcome to CROSSFIRE. I'm Van Jones on the left.

column1: S.E. CUPP
column2: CO-HOST: I'm S.E. Cupp on the right.

column1: Tonight
column2: the world is giddy at the prospect of getting out of a U.S. military strike on Syria. It's all thanks to Russia's offer of a diplomatic solution
column3: even though it's a phony one. Nevertheless
column4: the president's team is more than happy to take credit for it.

column1: (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
KERRY: Well
column2: it's the credible threat of force that has been on the table for these last weeks that has
column3: for the first time
column4: brought this regime to even acknowledge that they have a chemical weapons arsenal.

column1: REP. NANCY PELOSI (D-CA)
column2: MINORITY LEADER: This is a victory for President Obama
column3: if it is real.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
CUPP: Van
column2: it seems like Nancy Pelosi is ready to order the ""mission accomplished"" banner. Look
column3: everyone wants to parachute out of this conflict. I get that. But the Russians have offered us not a parachute but a knapsack. A knapsack that will never open. This is nothing more than a delay tactic.

column1: JONES: Well
column2: I disagree. First of all
column3: I think the world is rightfully happy that we are off the path to war
column4: possibly. The diplomatic option is a good thing. And frankly
column5: everybody is giving John Kerry a hard time. I would rather for us to blunder on the path to peace than to stumble onto the path of war.

column1: CUPP: If this were proposal -- if this proposal were real and offered up by legitimate
column2: good actors
column3: I would be happy to consider it.

column1: JONES: Well
column2: welcome to the real world
column3: where you don't get the chance to pick who offers you a solution to this thing.

column1: Look
column2: we've got two former presidential candidates and two former senators -- both the same person -- tonight on CROSSFIRE to help us with this thing.

column1: RICK SANTORUM (R)
column2: FORMER PENNSYLVANIA SENATOR: Two friends
column3: I might add. And two friends.

column1: JONES: And two friends. Republican Rick Santorum is against attacking Syria. Democratic former senator
column2: now independent
column3: Joe Lieberman
column4: he supports the strike.

column1: The first question to you. You've got to be happy now. We've got a big diplomatic opening. You've got to be on President Obama's team now. You're happy
column2: right?

column1: CUPP: Leading question.
SANTORUM: If there's not going to be a military attack
column2: that's a good thing. So if the president is willing to step down for whatever reason
column3: look
column4: he -- he went to the Congress because he didn't want to do this. If he wanted to do it
column5: he'd said he had the power to do it. And he just decided not to.

column1: When you consider the fact that
column2: whether it's on immigration or health care or on DOMA or on a whole variety of things --

column1: JONES: But are you --
SANTORUM: -- he's done things that he doesn't have the power to do. Now he has the power to do something
column2: and he went to Congress. So it's clear he didn't want to do this.

column1: JONES: You're on team Obama now.

SANTORUM: I'm on team ""let's not broaden this war and put a much more complicated diplomatic situation and military situation in the hands of someone who's proved incapable of handling the situation.""
JONES: We'll argue about that later.
CUPP: Senator Lieberman
column2: why after two years and 100
column3: 000 people dead
column4: two chemical attacks
column5: two million refugees
column6: why is pausing yet again to dither on this conflict the smart or moral decision?

column1: JOE LIEBERMAN (I)
column2: FORMER CONNECTICUT SENATOR: Well
column3: I wish we were not pausing. I mean
column4: I think President Obama made the right moral decision when he drew the red line --

column1: CUPP: Right.
LIEBERMAN: -- and then when he said
column2: after we had proof that chemical weapons were used to kill almost 1
column3: 500 innocents
column4: including 426 children by Assad in Syria
column5: that he was going to take military action.

column1: I was really surprised and disappointed when he decided to toss it to Congress. He was right. He had the legal authority to do it himself. I wish he had done it. If he had
column2: I think the American people would have been happy now that he had done it.

column1: CUPP: Should he attack now? Should he attack now without Congress?
LIEBERMAN: I -- well
column2: I think
column3: now that Russia has made this offer
column4: even though it's hard to take it seriously coming from Russia which hasn't been our friend -- just look at the Snowden matter.

column1: CUPP: Right.
LIEBERMAN: Look at Syria
column2: where Assad -- John Kerry said correctly last week that he tried very hard to reach an agreement with Assad years ago as a senator and decided he was a liar.

column1: JONES: But you're not saying we should through this peace offering in the garbage can and then -- and then attack now. Is that what you're saying?
LIEBERMAN: No
column2: I'm saying that it's hard to take the proposal by Russia seriously
column3: but it's important enough that we've got to challenge them to be serious about it and see if Syria really will
column4: with international supervision and penalties
column5: get rid of all their chemical weapons. If they did that
column6: it would be a tremendous accomplishment.

column1: But I think the president still has to face the fact
column2: if nothing happens
column3: that there was a chemical attack --

column1: SANTORUM: The bottom line is here we have no national security interests.
JONES: We don't have any national security interests when children are being chemically --
SANTORUM: Then we should be in Darfur. Then we should be in 50 other countries around the world.
JONES: Hold on.
SANTORUM: That is not --
CUPP: What about --
SANTORUM: That is not a reason.
CUPP: What about al Qaeda?
SANTORUM: I wish -- I wish -- that is the point. The point is we have no set national security interest
column2: because the two sides of this conflict are both enemies of the United States. We have al Qaeda
column3: who is basically the dominant rebel force right now
column4: on one side and we have on the other side Hezbollah
column5: Iran
column6: Russia and Assad. JONES: I don't understand what you want to do
column7: though. Here's my problem. You are a leader on Syria. You are a big supporter and
column8: frankly
column9: the author of the Syrian Accountability Act.

column1: SANTORUM: I was.

JONES: And now you seem to have completely disappeared. What is it that you think that should happen? I want to show you -- show you these images that have shocked the world. Can we show these images?
Look at these children. They're twitching. They're dying. What if one of the mothers of one of those children called this station right now and said to you
column2: ""Why won't you help me? Why won't you help my children?"" You're saying there's no interest in doing that.

column1: SANTORUM: The reason the United States -- and I think Joe will agree with me on this. We may disagree on where we come out
column2: but the reason the United States uses military forces for one reason and one reason only. It's in our national security interests.

column1: JONES: We have no moral obligation?
SANTORUM: We have no moral obligation to use military force when it comes to a humanitarian situation. We have other obligations.
JONES: Look
column2: what -- but what can we do?

column1: SANTORUM: We need to get involved. We need to -- the Syrian Accountability Act was about political sanctions. It was about economic sanctions. It was no trip wire for military force. And when the president used the Syrian Accountability Act as reasons for Congress to support him
column2: he misled the American public on that.

column1: CUPP: Senator Santorum --
SANTORUM: As the author
column2: I know that.

column1: CUPP: Senator Santorum
column2: I know you. We go back a little ways. We've had some conservations about faith and morality and values
column3: social conservatism. I don't understand -- help me understand -- how you square your conscience with not going in and ending a conflict where hundreds of thousands have died? How -- how are you not concerned that this will become another Rwanda?

column1: LIEBERMAN: They're fighting for their freedom
column2: incidentally
column3: which is what America's supposed to be all about.

column1: CUPP: Yes. And how -- aren't you worried this will be another Rwanda?
LIEBERMAN: This didn't start out as al Qaeda.
SANTORUM: I agree. And I called for military force 18 months ago.
CUPP: Right. As did I. As did I.
LIEBERMAN: I met with the opposition. And there -- these were patriots
column2: Syrian patriots
column3: freedom fighters --

column1: SANTORUM: Agreed.
LIEBERMAN: -- who were sick of the dictator.
SANTORUM: Agreed.

LIEBERMAN: We held back and al Qaeda came in. I don't think al Qaeda is the dominant force in the opposition. I think from all I know it's the Syrian people who want to change from Assad. And they deserve --
(CROSSTALK)
JONES: I want to give him a chance to say something
column2: because listen
column3: I want to double down on peace. I don't want to double down on war. I think that we have diplomatic options we haven't exhausted. My quarrel with the president all week long has been we're rushing to war.

column1: But my problem is
column2: I want to double down on peace; some people want to double down on war. It seems like you're doubling down on nothing. What do you want us to do?

column1: SANTORUM: Let's -- let's --
JONES: If you were the president
column2: what would you do?

column1: SANTORUM: Well
column2: first off
column3: go back and look at the debates that occurred about 18 months ago. And I
column4: in those debates
column5: called for the president to intervene
column6: to side with exactly the people that Joe Lieberman was talking about
column7: and get involved
column8: give them --

column1: JONES: So we had an interest then
column2: but we don't have an interest now?

column1: Hold on a second. How do we have an interest then and not now?
CUPP: Everything has changed.
SANTORUM: Everything has changed. Everything has changed. The people who are the rebels in Syria right now are not the same people that we --
CUPP: That's right.
SANTORUM: That we could have been partners with 18 months ago.
LIEBERMAN: But it's not going to get better if we hang back. I mean
column2: if we get involved in one level and support the moderates there -- and there are moderates there who are our friends -- then they'll have a better opportunity to control the country when Assad goes.

column1: Right now
column2: I think we've got to hang tough. And tonight
column3: the president's got a real challenge
column4: but -- because of all of the twists and turns of the story -- but he's got a great opportunity to tell people why he thinks it's worth us carrying out limited but decisive attacks. CUPP: What does he need to say tonight? What does he need to say tonight?

column1: LIEBERMAN: Well
column2: I think he needs to say
column3: one
column4: we can't -- we can't handle every problem in the world. But Americans
column5: you know
column6: we have a Declaration of Independence that talks about the self-evident truth that everybody -- not just Americans but in the world -- got from our creator the rights to life and liberty. And these people in Syria have been deprived of both of those rights.

column1: CUPP: Right.
LIEBERMAN: But here's the point. If you let a dictator mass murder his people and you turn away from it
column2: he's going to keep going. And every other madman is going to keep going.

column1: CUPP: Sure. And haven't we learned this lesson?
SANTORUM: Two different -- two different lessons. First off
column2: there are lot -- there are lots of dictators
column3: unfortunately
column4: in this world who are mass murdering their people. We've seen it. We've seen it under President Obama. We saw it under President Bush. It's under presidents for decades now. The United States has not stepped in unless there's a national security interest military. We've stepped in in other ways
column5: but we have not stepped in militarily.

column1: But the president is going to change that and say that humanitarian reasons and the reason we're going to step in and -- and engage in military conflict. We are broadening -- you want to talk about not being a cop on the beat. You want to talk about something you and folks that -- that have been advocating for us to have -- make peace not war. We've now opened up Pandora's box as to military use. It's a bad idea. It's not in the security interests.
JONES: I want -- I want you to respond to this. My quarrel with the president is I think he did two things right and one thing wrong. I think he was right to say this is an outrage
column2: and we're not going to let babies get gassed.

column1: CUPP: And then do nothing about it?
JONES: I think that was right. I think he was wrong to rush into a war posture without talking to Congress
column2: without bringing in the U.N.
column3: without bringing a global coalition
column4: without exhausting --

column1: SANTORUM: He did that when he set the red line
column2: with Russia. And he set the red line --

column1: CUPP: Months ago.
JONES: And he did -- and I think he did. Because he waited -- and I'm surprised you say you wish we'd gone in -- because he waited
column2: we now have a new opening.

column1: Do you disagree that the president
column2: by putting those warships out there and waiting
column3: don't you agree he created an opening now for peace? You're saying that the president has done nothing right this whole crisis?

column1: SANTORUM: If we believe Putin and Assad are legitimate actors in the diplomatic stage. Well
column2: but that's who's come forward
column3: and it's not --

column1: CUPP: It's who we got.
SANTORUM: It's who we got. And so
column2: look
column3: I'm perfectly willing to let this play out. I want us to not strike Syria --

column1: JONES: You and me both.
SANTORUM: -- because I think streaking Syria
column2: at this point in time
column3: will create a real problem for us militarily with Russia
column4: with potentially others in the region.

column1: We are taking -- and I think Joe will agree with me on this one. The whole Syria conflict at this point
column2: has taken our eye off the ball. And the ball is Iran. Syria is a puppet state of Iran.

column1: LIEBERMAN: That's exactly the reason why we can't let Assad get away.
CUPP: That's right. Iran is watching.
LIEBERMAN: It's the biggest body blow we could land to Iran. He's their only ally in the Arab world. And this -- even this proposal
column2: which if it works for Russia
column3: will be a good thing. The price of it will be that Assad will stay there
column4: and Iran will still have its No. 1 ally in the Arab world.

column1: CUPP: All right. Well
column2: let's -- let's continue this over in the next -- in the next segment. There are a lot of creative solutions that don't involve bombing and killing people apparently.

column1: Yes
column2: there are and we'll talk about it when we get back. Thank you very much.

column1: (COMMERCIAL BREAK)
JONES: Welcome back.

Tonight President Obama addresses the nation about Syria. He's hitting the pause button on the military strikes. That gives us time for some creative solutions. And we should keep the warships parked off of there. But what about helping refugees? What about an arms embargo? What about cyber-attacks
column2: what about anything? It's all either war or nothing.

column1: I'm going to ask you: If there were a dome over Syria
column2: so it was not about bomb or don't bomb
column3: what are some of the creative things we could do that don't involve war? How do we win without war?

column1: LIEBERMAN: Unfortunately
column2: if there were a dome over Syria
column3: there was nothing we could do to stop the bloodshed. Because you've got a basically unfair fight here. The government has most of the fire power. Finally
column4: the patriots
column5: the freedom fighter Syrians
column6: have gotten help from outside. But they're still getting decimated. So --

column1: JONES: This is America. You're saying there's nothing we can do? It's either Tomahawk missiles or nothing? We're the most creative --
CUPP: But the dome doesn't exist
column2: Van. The dome is fantasy land. Let's deal with reality.

column1: JONES: The fact -- let's get with reality. We have someone here --
LIEBERMAN: Let me say something about the dome. Because the other reason it's gone --
CUPP: Van Jones Dome.
LIEBERMAN: The dome is unreal
column2: but what that really reminds us of is that their neighbors there -- Israel
column3: Iraq
column4: Jordan -- they're all being -- Lebanon -- they're all being badly affected by what's going on in Syria. Our allies are.

column1: JONES: This is a crisis in our country
column2: of imagination. How can we get out of this without bombs. You tell us.

column1: SANTORUM: That's why -- that's why Rick Santorum
column2: 18 months ago
column3: during the presidential campaign --

column1: JONES: Today.
SANTORUM: -- said we should be arming the rebels.
CUPP: That's right.
SANTORUM: We should be supporting them militarily. We should be supporting them economically. We should be doing everything --
JONES: That's all in the past.
SANTORUM: We agree --
JONES: And now we give up. Because we didn't do what you wanted so we just give up.
SANTORUM: Because a lot of folks -- hello?
JONES: Hello?
SANTORUM: A lot of folks said no
column2: we had no interest in this.

column1: JONES: Hey
column2: listen.

column1: SANTORUM: Do you admit you were wrong?
JONES: I'll tell you what: I'm going to shock you. I think the Democrats were wrong for not taking Syria more seriously earlier. But I think it's wrong
column2: and I'm giving you an opportunity. I don't want to go to war. I think there are a lot of things we could do that would get us out of the situation without war. You are somebody who's got some ideas about it
column3: but I don't hear anybody talking about what can we do.

column1: CUPP: Senator
column2: you've said Assad -- Assad has to go. You've said Assad has to go. How do you do it without military intervention?

column1: JONES: What can we do?
(CROSSTALK)
SANTORUM: This is very difficult right now. When you look at the rebels and the composition of the rebel forces
column2: you see -- you're seeing on YouTube how rebel forces are
column3: you know -- these radical al- Qaeda folks are killing off other rebel leaders and are doing atrocities to the public also.

column1: JONES: But if you were president --
SANTORUM: You are going to say we are going to come on the side of them and help them.
JONES: That's terrible. Help us.
SANTORUM: But we can't. No
column2: what we have to do is do what we should have done from the very beginning
column3: which is let's identify
column4: as we can
column5: and support and protect and defend the legitimate elements within the rebel forces. Begin the process of arming them
column6: protecting them
column7: et cetera.

column1: JONES: You agree with this?

LIEBERMAN: I totally agree. I just want to say something. You've been using the word ""war."" Nobody's talking about war. President Obama's not talking about war. He's not talking about any American boots on the ground. He's talking about limited
column2: decisive attacks.

column1: CUPP: Whoa
column2: whoa
column3: whoa
column4: whoa. Because you are not that naive
column5: Senator Lieberman. You know that
column6: even though President Obama is saying no boots on the ground
column7: if one of our planes goes down
column8: we're sending boots on the ground.

column1: LIEBERMAN: Yes
column2: but that -- everybody's --

column1: CUPP: This is a lot bigger conflict than he thinks.
LIEBERMAN: I don't believe so. It's not going to be a massive land invasion.
Incidentally
column2: what the president could have done when he decided to send it to Congress in taking the military action limited that he has in mind
column3: is not a precedent. President Reagan did it in Grenada and struck at Libya when he thought the Libyans blew up a disco in Germany.

column1: You know
column2: President Clinton went into Bosnia
column3: and people could argue we had no national security interests there
column4: but a lot of people were getting slaughtered --

column1: CUPP: Right.
LIEBERMAN: -- by the Serbs at that point. And it goes on and on. So --
JONES: I'm glad the president went to Congress. I think the president going to Congress is the best thing that happened
column2: because it gave us time. You don't agree with me.

column1: LIEBERMAN: No. Here's my concern when he did it. I don't think he had to do it. He himself said
column2: and I think he was right
column3: that he had the legal authority to take action himself as commander in chief under the War Powers Resolution
column4: everything else. He took an enormous risk
column5: and unfortunately
column6: he's in a quagmire now
column7: because the risk was that Congress would say no.

column1: JONES: Well
column2: now they're both being delayed
column3: and the U.N. is -- the U.N. is now a forum where -- I don't understand why you can say it's a bad thing. The delay gave us time.

column1: CUPP: Don't worry. The U.N.'s on it.

SANTORUM: You may have not seen the polls. I'm not a great poll- watcher. But the American public is overwhelmingly against the president. The president's been making this case now for several weeks. They are against military action. They do not see any positive benefit for the United States in getting involved in a war between two radical elements of which neither are our friends.
LIEBERMAN: Now I want to -- I want to quote you -- I'm quoting from the New Testament
column2: Corinthians: ""When the sound of the trumpet is uncertain
column3: who will follow into battle?"" So I think people are so confused about what's going on here. If --

column1: SANTORUM: The president says he has to do it
column2: but then he goes to Congress.

column1: LIEBERMAN: If you looked at the polls earlier
column2: there was authority for a limited strike without American boots on the ground
column3: particularly if we had some support from other --

column1: CUPP: Let me ask you
column2: Senator -- go ahead.

column1: SANTORUM: Here's the president says we need to do it
column2: but I'm going to ask Congress. We need to strike
column3: but it's not going to be decisive. Of course
column4: the American people is going to say what the heck are we doing here?

column1: Because here's the problem: If we actually do act
column2: and if the Russians or the Iranians or somebody else say
column3: ""You know what? You've drawn a line in the sand for us and we're going to -- we're going to act back
column4: now we've put the United States in a much broader war with a president who is clearly over his head.

column1: JONES: Listen
column2: I don't -- I do not agree the president is in over his head. First of all
column3: let's be clear. This is a president who built a -- he built a coalition to --

column1: SANTORUM: Really?
JONES: Let me finish. He isolated Iran.
SANTORUM: A coalition?
JONES: Let's walk through the list before we take him down too hard. He got -- he got Russia and China to be with us against Iran.
SANTORUM: Stop right there. Stop. Whoa!
LIEBERMAN: Forget Libya.
JONES: Libya.
SANTORUM: Stop at Iran. Is Iran pursuing the nuclear weapons program? They have not drawn down.
JONES: The answer is -- Do you want a war? Do you want a war?
SANTORUM: We have drawn a red line.
JONES: Yes. We're doing cyber-attacks. We're doing an embargo.
SANTORUM: We have drawn a red line with Iran
column2: and we have done nothing publicly.

column1: CUPP: Let me ask you. This is a very good opportunity --
(CROSSTALK)
CUPP: This is a very good opportunity -- very good opportunity to talk about the U.N. The U.N. -- no one
column2: maybe except Van
column3: trusts the Russians in this new plan to seize chemical weapons from Assad. But I fear that a lot of people trust the U.N. to do that.

column1: The U.N. does not have a terribly impressive track record when it comes to ending conflicts. Are you worried? Should the American people trust U.N. to oversee this new Russian plan?
LIEBERMAN: The U.N. works sometimes. Other times it doesn't. The record is mixed. The question is what passes in the U.N.? If
column2: as France --

column1: CUPP: Well
column2: nothing if you're Russia and China.

column1: LIEBERMAN: France tabled a resolution in the Security Council today that basically embraced the Russian proposal that the Syrians get rid of their chemical weapons with international supervision and said that
column2: if they didn't
column3: then force was authorized by the U.N. Security Council. I thought that was great
column4: because it called -- called Russia's bluff.

column1: And what do you think Russia did? They said that was unacceptable. They don't want a mandatory resolution with teeth in it. They want it to be a presidential statement of kind of appealing to Syria.
CUPP: Senator Santorum
column2: do you trust the U.N.?

column1: SANTORUM: It calls into question Russia's credibility with this entire proposal.
CUPP: Do you trust -- wait
column2: let me ask. Do you trust the U.N.?

column1: JONES: Hold on.
SANTORUM: Pick an issue. The answer is no.
CUPP: Exactly right.
JONES: A hundred and seventy-two successful peacekeeping missions and negotiations for some. Listen
column2: we always focus -- 172 --

column1: CUPP: Cambodia
column2: Sri Lanka
column3: Rwanda
column4: Bosnia --

column1: JONES: The world is a tough
column2: nasty place
column3: and we focus on the places the U.N. has not been able to change human nature. But we are in a much safer world because of the U.N. than we would be without it.

column1: CUPP: That is not -- that is a total inaccuracy.
JONES: Look right here: 172 peacekeeping --
CUPP: I have a list
column2: too
column3: of atrocities that they have taken responsibility for and not changed. The world feels very good about itself when it allows the U.N. to take over
column4: because it feels like it's doing something. It's false security.

column1: JONES: Well
column2: listen -- Here's what I don't understand. When George W. Bush brought in the United Nations
column3: people thought that was a good thing. He was trying to bring in the global community. I thought that you wanted us to build a big global coalition. I think we have a moment now to do so.

column1: And why do we have it? We have it for two reasons. One
column2: he went to Congress
column3: which you don't like. And two
column4: because as much as we do not trust the Russians for their own interests
column5: they are moving. Why are you mad at Congress and the U.N.?

column1: (CROSSTALK)
SANTORUM: Name -- name the countries that are for the United States getting involved militarily in Syria.
JONES: Well
column2: apparently
column3: there's France. Militarily?

column1: LIEBERMAN: The people that want us to --
(CROSSTALK)
JONES: You can answer that.
LIEBERMAN: There's about 15 that signed that statement calling for action.
SANTORUM: Action but not military action.
LIEBERMAN: But you know what? The president has --

SANTORUM: There's a big difference between action and military action. I'm for action. I'm just not for -- I'm not for a military strike. Particularly one that's not decisive and is not going to accomplish anything.
LIEBERMAN: But here's the problem. I think a military strike today will hurt Assad. I think that's the reason why
column2: at least in words
column3: he's accepted this Russian proposal.

column1: I don't believe him for a minute. I'll believe it when I see it
column2: when he gives us his chemical weapons.

column1: SANTORUM: Let's play it out.
LIEBERMAN: But I think he's scared of a strike. We're going to hit his command and control.
SANTORUM: Let's play it out. We strike Assad. We -- we knock out a few command and control operations. Then where do we go?
LIEBERMAN: Then we give more support to the Syrian opposition. Because they will have a tremendous boost in morale.
SANTORUM: Why can't we do that without striking?
LIEBERMAN: We can
column2: but we've got to strike him because he used chemical weapons. And if we don't
column3: then he'll use them again.

column1: SANTORUM: And you don't have any -- you don't have any fear or concern that any other country will
column2: as a result of us striking Syria
column3: do something to -- to insert themselves even in that conflict or potentially against the United States?

column1: LIEBERMAN: They might but you know
column2: when you're -- we can't -- we can't act out of fear of what might happen. We're strong. We're still the strongest country in the world.

column1: SANTORUM: We're not. We're not acting like -- we're not acting like a leader. We're not acting strong. We're acting like someone who said
column2: don't knock this off my shoulder and you do. And so I -- OK
column3: so I've got a fight back. We have to have --

column1: (CROSSTALK)
LIEBERMAN: The shoulder was the high moral ground about --
SANTORUM: It wasn't a high moral ground.
LIEBERMAN: Hitler
column2: Saddam Hussein
column3: Assad have used chemical weapons.

column1: SANTORUM: Chemical weapons -- LIEBERMAN: You've got to say no.
SANTORUM: Chemical weapons is very different than WMD that Iran is working on. That's where we should focus our attention.
CUPP: OK. Thanks to Joe Lieberman and Rick Santorum. It was a great debate. We appreciate it.
Next
column2: we ""Cease Fire."" There's something important here we need to agree on. Not just the two of us but the whole country.

column1: (COMMERCIAL BREAK)
JONES: Tonight on CROSSFIRE
column2: we've been debating and fighting about what to do about Syria. But now we're going to call a ""Cease Fire.""

column1: Now I think
column2: and I want to come back to a point I made. I think that I have to admit that you guys have been right about something. You guys have been out
column3: you in particular
column4: out there for two years saying we've got to do something about Syria
column5: something about Syria.

column1: I hate your solution.
CUPP: Yes.
JONES: I don't like the war. But you are pointing to the right problem. And I think a lot of people on the left were ducking it
column2: and we weren't dealing with it. And I think that what my lesson out of this is
column3: even when we don't agree
column4: we've got to listen to each other more than we did.

column1: CUPP: Well
column2: and I appreciate that. And I will return a favor and say
column3: look
column4: I don't agree with your solutions either
column5: but at least you've been consistent. I think a lot of Democrats and liberals have talked about President Obama's foreign policy as somehow morally superior to President Bush's. And you hold Obama to the same standard as you hold President Bush
column6: and that -- that says a lot about your credibility.

column1: JONES: Here we go. The two of us
column2: we agreed
column3: and the world didn't come to an end.

column1: CUPP: Here's another thing we agree on: Your opinion matters. You can weigh in on our ""Fire Back"" question via Facebook or Twitter. ""Should the U.S. trust Russia's offer to rid Syria of chemical weapons?"" Right now 41 percent of you say yes; 59 percent say no.
JONES: The debate continues online at CNN.com/crossfire. You can also go to Facebook and Twitter.
From the left
column2: I'm Van Jones.

column1: CUPP: and from the right
column2: I'm S.C. Cupp. Join us tomorrow for another edition of CROSSFIRE.

column1: A special edition of ""ERIN BURNETT OUTFRONT"" starts right now.

column1: 1:00 P.M. MST
THE PRESIDENT: Hey! Hello
column2: Phoenix! (Applause.) Hello
column3: Arizona! (Applause.) It is --

column1: AUDIENCE MEMBER: We love you
column2: Obama!

column1: THE PRESIDENT: I love you back. It is good to be here. (Applause.)
I want to say thank you to the Thunder for hosting us here today. (Applause.) Well
column2: we are so glad to be here. I want you to give it up for somebody whoÃ¢ÂÂs been fighting for homeowners and working families every single day
column3: whoÃ¢ÂÂs with me today -- Secretary Shaun Donovan
column4: Secretary of HUD. There he is right there. Give him a big round of applause. (Applause.) WeÃ¢ÂÂve got Congressman Ed Pastor whoÃ¢ÂÂs here as well. (Applause.) WeÃ¢ÂÂve got your Mayor
column5: Greg Stanton
column6: here. (Applause.) Doing an outstanding job. And to all the mayors and state legislators and tribal leaders who are here today
column7: thank you. (Applause.)

column1: Give Jorge a big round of applause for his introduction. (Applause.) To your superintendent
column2: Dr. Kenneth Baca. (Applause.) Your principal
column3: Dr. Anna Battle. (Applause.) And I appreciate everybody at Desert Vista for having me here today. (Applause.) It is good to see the students are pretty enthusiastic about being back in school. (Laughter.) IÃ¢ÂÂm not sure I would have been that enthusiastic starting on the 6th. (Laughter.)

column1: And I know this isnÃ¢ÂÂt your typical school -- second day of school. So I want to give a special shout-out to the new seniors
column2: class of 2014. (Applause.) You are aware that youÃ¢ÂÂre not finished yet. (Laughter.) Senior year
column3: thatÃ¢ÂÂs sometimes tempting. I want you all to stay focused.

column1: Over the past couple weeks
column2: I have been --

column1: AUDIENCE MEMBER: Happy birthday
column2: Mr. President!

column1: THE PRESIDENT: Thank you very much. Thank you. (Applause.) It was my birthday two days ago. (Laughter.) Got some singers here.
AUDIENCE: Happy birthday to you
column2: happy birthday to you
column3: happy birthday
column4: Mr. President. (Applause.)

column1: THE PRESIDENT: Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. (Applause.) I am now 52
column2: and Michelle says that I donÃ¢ÂÂt look a day over 51. (Laughter.)

column1: So over the last few weeks
column2: IÃ¢ÂÂve been visiting towns all across the country
column3: talking about what we need to do to secure a better bargain for the middle class -- a national strategy to make sure that everybody who works hard has a chance to succeed in the 21st century economy.

column1: And I think people in Arizona especially understand the challenges that are out there
column2: because for the past four and a half years
column3: together
column4: we fought our way back from a devastating recession that cost millions of jobs for Americans. A lot of folks lost their homes; a lot of folks lost their savings. And what the recession showed was the long erosion of middle-class security that had been taking place for decades.

column1: But we fought back. We took on a broken health care system. We took on a housing market that was in free fall. We invested in new technologies to reverse our addiction to foreign oil. We changed a tax code that had become tilted a little bit too much in favor of the wealthiest Americans at the expense of working families. (Applause.) We saved the auto industry. WeÃ¢ÂÂve now got GM that plans to hire a thousand new workers right next door in Chandler to make sure weÃ¢ÂÂre building some of the best cars in the world right here in the United States of America. (Applause.)

Our businesses have created 7.3 million new jobs over the past 41 months. We now sell more products made in America to the rest of the world than ever before. Our exports are way up. We produce more renewable energy than ever before
column2: more natural gas than anybody else. Health care costs have been growing at the slowest rate in 50 years. And our deficits are coming down at the fastest rate in 60 years. So weÃ¢ÂÂre making progress. (Applause.)

column1: So thanks to the efforts of a lot of people like you
column2: weÃ¢ÂÂve cleared away the rubble of the financial crisis. WeÃ¢ÂÂre starting to lay the foundation for more stable
column3: more durable economic growth. But as any middle-class family will tell you
column4: weÃ¢ÂÂre not yet where we need to be. Because even before the crisis hit
column5: we had lived through a decade where a few at the top were doing better and better
column6: but most families were working harder and harder just to get by.

column1: And reversing this trend should be -- must be -- WashingtonÃ¢ÂÂs highest priority. ItÃ¢ÂÂs my highest priority. (Applause.) I want to make sure that in America
column2: it doesnÃ¢ÂÂt matter what you look like
column3: where you come from
column4: who you love -- you should be able to make it when you try. You should be able to make it. (Applause.)

column1: Now
column2: unfortunately
column3: for the last year or so
column4: weÃ¢ÂÂve had an endless parade of distractions and political posturing and phony scandals that shift focus away from what do we need to do to shore up middle-class families and create ladders of opportunity for folks to get into the middle class. And as Washington heads towards another budget debate
column5: the stakes could not be higher.

column1: And thatÃ¢ÂÂs why IÃ¢ÂÂm traveling around
column2: laying out my ideas for how we have to build the cornerstones of what it means to be middle class: a good job with good wages; a home to call your own; a good education; affordable health care thatÃ¢ÂÂs there for you when you get sick; a secure retirement even if youÃ¢ÂÂre not rich; the opportunity -- the ladders of opportunity for people to earn their way into the middle class
column3: to work their way out of poverty. Those are the elements that I think all of us believe in
column4: but right now we're not delivering as much as we should on those promises.

column1: Now
column2: last Tuesday
column3: I went to Tennessee to talk about the first cornerstone
column4: which is how do we make sure that we're creating good middle-class jobs here in the United States of America. Today I've come to Phoenix to talk about the second component
column5: which is the most tangible cornerstone that lies at the heart of the American Dream
column6: at the heart of middle-class life -- and that's the chance to own your own home. (Applause.) The chance to own your own home.

column1: We've got a lot of young people here who are thinking about college
column2: they're going to get a higher education
column3: they're going to find a job
column4: they're going to find somebody they love
column5: they're going to want to own a home. And the reason they will is because a home is the ultimate evidence that here in America
column6: hard work pays off
column7: that responsibility is rewarded.

column1: I think about my grandparentsÃ¢ÂÂ generation. When my grandfather served in World War II
column2: he fought in Patton's Army -- when he got back
column3: this country gave him a chance to go to college on the G.I. Bill
column4: but it also gave him the chance to buy his first home with a loan from the FHA. To him
column5: and to generations of Americans before and since
column6: a home was more than just a house. It was a source of pride and a source of security. It was a place to raise kids
column7: to put down roots; a place where you could build up savings for college
column8: or to start a business
column9: or to retire with some security.

column1: And buying a home required responsibility on everybodyÃ¢ÂÂs part. You had to save up to buy a home. And then banks were supposed to give you a fair deal
column2: with terms you could understand
column3: and buyers were supposed to live within their means and make sure that they could make their payments. So in that earlier generation
column4: houses werenÃ¢ÂÂt for flipping around
column5: they werenÃ¢ÂÂt for speculation -- houses were to live in
column6: and to build a life with.

column1: And unfortunately
column2: over time
column3: responsibility too often gave way to recklessness. You had reckless lenders who sold loans to people they knew couldnÃ¢ÂÂt afford them. And let's face it
column4: we also had some reckless buyers who knew they couldnÃ¢ÂÂt afford them and still took out loans. And all this created a housing bubble. And especially in some places like Arizona
column5: it was devastating when that bubble finally burst -- triggered a recession. Millions of Americans who had done everything right were hurt badly by the actions of other people. Housing prices plummeted.

column1: By the time I took office
column2: home values had fallen almost 20 percent from the year before. New housing starts had fallen nearly 80 percent from their peak. Hundreds of thousands of construction workers had lost their jobs. A record number of people were behind on their mortgage payments. And a lot of people here in Phoenix
column3: they saw that devastation. This was part of Ground Zero for the housing bubble bursting.

column1: So less than a month after I took office
column2: I came here to Arizona and I laid out steps to stabilize the housing market and help responsible homeowners get back on their feet. And the truth is it's been a long
column3: slow process. The housing market is so big that it was going to take some time to heal when it got hurt that badly. It's taken longer than any of us would like. But during that time
column4: we helped millions of Americans save an average of $3
column5: 000 each year by refinancing at lower rates. We helped millions of responsible homeowners stay in their homes
column6: which was good for their neighbors because you don't want a bunch of foreclosure signs in your neighborhood.

column1: Where Congress wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt act
column2: we went ahead and acted
column3: so over the past few years
column4: we had the Department of Justice stand up for buyers who had been discriminated against or conned by predatory lending. And we won a settlement that gave more money to victims of discrimination in one year than in the previous 23 years combined. (Applause.)

column1: We worked with states to force big banks to repay more than $50 billion to more than 1.5 million families -- largest lending settlement in history. (Applause.) We extended the time that folks who had lost their jobs could delay their payment on their mortgages while they kept looking for work. We cracked down on the bad practices that led to the crisis in the first place. I mean
column2: you had some loans back there in the bubble that were called Ã¢ÂÂliarÃ¢ÂÂs loan.Ã¢ÂÂ Now
column3: something that's called a liar's loan is probably a bad idea. (Laughter.)

column1: So because of all these actions we've been taking
column2: our housing market is beginning to heal. Home prices are rising at the fastest pace in seven years. Sales are up nearly 50 percent. Construction is up nearly 75 percent. New foreclosures are down by nearly two-thirds. Millions of families have been able to come up for air -- theyÃ¢ÂÂre no longer underwater on their mortgages. (Applause.)

column1: And just like the crisis hit Phoenix very hard
column2: thanks to some great leadership here locally
column3: Phoenix has also led one of the biggest comebacks in the country. (Applause.) So you should be proud of what you've done here. Home prices in Phoenix have risen by nearly 20 percent over the last year. New home sales are up by more than 25 percent.

column1: This morning
column2: right before I came here
column3: I visited Erickson Construction -- (applause.) We've got some Erickson folks here. And they were explaining how right when the bubble hit
column4: Erickson shrank to less than a hundred workers. Today they're employing 580 people -- and theyÃ¢ÂÂre hiring even more people -- (applause) -- because the housing market is bouncing back.

column1: So that's one of the things about housing. It's not just important for the person who owns the house; our economy is so impacted by everything that happens in housing. Consumers feel better when their home values are in a better place
column2: so they're more willing to spend. A lot of people who want to start a business
column3: their savings may be locked up in their house. Construction workers
column4: contractors
column5: suppliers
column6: carpet makers
column7: all these folks are impacted by the housing industry.

column1: So we've made progress
column2: and that's helped to move the economy forward. But we've got to build on this progress. We're not where we need to be yet. We've got to give more hardworking Americans the chance to buy their first home. (Applause.) We have to help more responsible homeowners refinance their mortgages
column3: because a lot of them still have a spread between the rates they're paying right now on their mortgage and what they could be getting if they were able to refinance.

column1: And weÃ¢ÂÂve got to turn the page on this kind of bubble-and-bust mentality that helped to create this mess in the first place. (Applause.) We got to build a housing system that is durable and fair and rewards responsibility for generations to come. That's what weÃ¢ÂÂve got to do. (Applause.)
So IÃ¢ÂÂve already put forward a bunch of ideas that will help accomplish that. And
column2: look
column3: the fact of the matter is Congress hasnÃ¢ÂÂt enacted all of them
column4: so IÃ¢ÂÂd like you to encourage members of Congress to take some of these actions. (Applause.)

column1: But like the other actions that weÃ¢ÂÂve taken
column2: these will not help the neighbors down the street who bought a house that they couldnÃ¢ÂÂt afford
column3: and then walked away from it and left a foreclosed home behind. We don't want to help speculators who bought multiple homes just to make a quick buck.

column1: What we want to do is put forward ideas that will help millions of responsible
column2: middle-class homeowners who still need relief. And we want to help hardworking Americans who dream of owning their own home fair and square
column3: have a down payment
column4: are willing to make those payments
column5: understand that owning a home requires responsibility. And there are some immediate actions we could take right now that would help on that front
column6: that would make a difference. So let me just list a couple of them.

column1: Number one: Congress should pass a good
column2: bipartisan idea to allow every homeowner the chance to save thousands of dollars a year by refinancing their mortgage at todayÃ¢ÂÂs rates. (Applause.) We need to get that done. WeÃ¢ÂÂve been talking about it for a year and a half
column3: two years
column4: three years. ThereÃ¢ÂÂs no reason not to do it. (Applause.)

column1: Step number two: Now that weÃ¢ÂÂve made it harder for reckless buyers to buy homes that they canÃ¢ÂÂt afford
column2: letÃ¢ÂÂs make it a little bit easier for qualified buyers to buy the homes that they can afford. (Applause.) So Shaun Donovan has been working with the finance industry to make sure weÃ¢ÂÂre simplifying overlapping regulations; weÃ¢ÂÂre cutting red tape for responsible families who want to get a mortgage but keep getting rejected by the banks. We need to give well-qualified Americans who lost their jobs during the crisis a fair chance to get a loan if theyÃ¢ÂÂve worked hard to repair their credit.

column1: And step three is something that you donÃ¢ÂÂt always hear about when it comes to the housing market
column2: and that is fixing our broken immigration system. It would actually help our housing market. (Applause.)

column1: ItÃ¢ÂÂs pretty simple: When more people buy homes and play by the rules
column2: home values go up for everybody. And according to one recent study
column3: the average homeowner has already seen the value of their home boosted by thousands of dollars just because of immigration. And the good news is
column4: with the help of your Senators
column5: John McCain and Jeff Flake
column6: the Senate has already passed a bipartisan immigration bill. ItÃ¢ÂÂs got the support of CEOs and labor and law enforcement. (Applause.) This could help homeownership here.

column1: So I want you to encourage Republicans in the House of Representatives to stop dragging their feet. LetÃ¢ÂÂs go ahead and get this done.
Step number four: We should address the uneven recovery by rebuilding the communities hit the hardest by the housing crisis
column2: including many right here in Arizona. LetÃ¢ÂÂs put construction back -- construction workers back to work repairing rundown homes
column3: tearing down vacant properties so that the value of homes in those surrounding areas start picking up. We can put people to work right now and improve the remaining housing stock that's out there. (Applause.) Places that are facing a longer road back from the crisis should have their countryÃ¢ÂÂs help to get back on their feet.

column1: Step five: We should make sure families that donÃ¢ÂÂt want to buy a home or canÃ¢ÂÂt yet afford to buy one still have a decent place to rent. (Applause.) ItÃ¢ÂÂs important for us to encourage homeownership
column2: but a lot of people rent and thereÃ¢ÂÂs nothing wrong with renting. And we got to make sure that we are creating affordable opportunities when it comes to rental properties.

column1: In the run-up to the crisis
column2: banks and governments too often made everybody feel like they had to own a home
column3: even if they werenÃ¢ÂÂt ready and didn't have the payments. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs a mistake we should not repeat. Instead
column4: letÃ¢ÂÂs invest in affordable rental housing. LetÃ¢ÂÂs bring together cities and states to address local barriers that drive up rents for working families. (Applause.)

column1: So if we help more Americans refinance their homes
column2: if we help qualified families get a mortgage
column3: we reform our immigration system
column4: we rebuild the hardest-hit communities
column5: we make sure that folks have a decent place to rent if they're not yet able to buy -- all these steps will give more middle-class families the chance to either buy their own home now or eventually buy their own home. It's going to give more relief to responsible homeowners. It gives more options to families who arenÃ¢ÂÂt yet ready to buy. All that is going to improve the housing market and will improve the economy.

column1: But -- and this is the last key point I want to make -- as home prices rise
column2: we canÃ¢ÂÂt just re-inflate another housing bubble. I hope everybody here in Arizona learned some hard lessons from what happened. Housing prices generally don't just keep on going up forever at the kind of pace it was going up. It was crazy. So what we want to do is something stable and steady. And that's why I want to lay a rock-solid foundation to make sure the kind of crisis we went through never happens again. We've got to make sure it doesn't happen again. (Applause.)

column1: And one of the key things to make sure it doesn't happen again is to wind down these companies that are not really government
column2: but not really private sector -- they're known as Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae. For too long
column3: these companies were allowed to make huge profits buying mortgages
column4: knowing that if their bets went bad
column5: taxpayers would be left holding the bag. It was Ã¢ÂÂheads we win
column6: tails you lose.Ã¢ÂÂ And it was wrong. And along with what happened on Wall Street
column7: it helped to inflate this bubble in a way that ultimately killed Main Street.

column1: So the good news is
column2: right now thereÃ¢ÂÂs a bipartisan group of senators working to end Fannie and Freddie as we know them. And I support these kinds of reform efforts. And they're following four core principles for what I believe this reform should look like.

column1: First
column2: private capital should take a bigger role in the mortgage market. I know that sounds confusing to folks who call me a socialist -- I think I saw some posters there on the way in. (Laughter.) But I actually believe in the free market. And just like the health care law that we put in place
column3: Obamacare -- (applause) -- which
column4: by the way

column1: So I want to be honest with you. No program or policy is going to solve all the problems in a multi-trillion dollar housing market. The housing bubble went up so high

column1: The Washington Post
Battling for Iraq
BYLINE: David H. Petraeus
SECTION: Editorial; B07
LENGTH: 1239 words
DATELINE: BAGHDAD
Helping organize
column2: train and equip nearly a quarter-million of Iraq's security forces is a daunting task. Doing so in the middle of a tough insurgency increases the challenge enormously
column3: making the mission akin to repairing an aircraft while in flight -- and while being shot at. Now
column4: however
column5: 18 months after entering Iraq
column6: I see tangible progress. Iraqi security elements are being rebuilt from the ground up.

column1: The institutions that oversee them are being reestablished from the top down. And Iraqi leaders are stepping forward
column2: leading their country and their security forces courageously in the face of an enemy that has shown a willingness to do anything to disrupt the establishment of the new Iraq.

column1: In recent months
column2: I have observed thousands of Iraqis in training and then watched as they have conducted numerous operations. Although there have been reverses -- not to mention horrific terrorist attacks -- there has been progress in the effort to enable Iraqis to shoulder more of the load for their own security
column3: something they are keen to do. The future undoubtedly will be full of difficulties
column4: especially in places such as Fallujah. We must expect setbacks and recognize that not every soldier or policeman we help train will be equal to the challenges ahead.

column1: Nonetheless
column2: there are reasons for optimism. Today approximately 164
column3: 000 Iraqi police and soldiers (of which about 100
column4: 000 are trained and equipped) and an additional 74
column5: 000 facility protection forces are performing a wide variety of security missions. Equipment is being delivered. Training is on track and increasing in capacity. Infrastructure is being repaired. Command and control structures and institutions are being reestablished.

column1: Most important
column2: Iraqi security forces are in the fight -- so much so that they are suffering substantial casualties as they take on more and more of the burdens to achieve security in their country. Since Jan. 1 more than 700 Iraqi security force members have been killed
column3: and hundreds of Iraqis seeking to volunteer for the police and military have been killed as well.

column1: Six battalions of the Iraqi regular army and the Iraqi Intervention Force are now conducting operations. Two of these battalions
column2: along with the Iraqi commando battalion
column3: the counterterrorist force
column4: two Iraqi National Guard battalions and thousands of policemen recently contributed to successful operations in Najaf. Their readiness to enter and clear the Imam Ali shrine was undoubtedly a key factor in enabling Grand Ayatollah Ali Sistani to persuade members of the Mahdi militia to lay down their arms and leave the shrine.

column1: In another highly successful operation several days ago
column2: the Iraqi counterterrorist force conducted early-morning raids in Najaf that resulted in the capture of several senior lieutenants and 40 other members of that militia
column3: and the seizure of enough weapons to fill nearly four 71/2-ton dump trucks.

column1: Within the next 60 days
column2: six more regular army and six additional Intervention Force battalions will become operational. Nine more regular army battalions will complete training in January
column3: in time to help with security missions during the Iraqi elections at the end of that month.

column1: Iraqi National Guard battalions have also been active in recent months. Some 40 of the 45 existing battalions -- generally all except those in the Fallujah-Ramadi area -- are conducting operations on a daily basis
column2: most alongside coalition forces
column3: but many independently. Progress has also been made in police training. In the past week alone
column4: some 1
column5: 100 graduated from the basic policing course and five specialty courses. By early spring
column6: nine academies in Iraq and one in Jordan will be graduating a total of 5
column7: 000 police each month from the eight-week course
column8: which stresses patrolling and investigative skills
column9: substantive and procedural legal knowledge
column10: and proper use of force and weaponry
column11: as well as pride in the profession and adherence to the police code of conduct.

column1: Iraq's borders are long
column2: stretching more than 2
column3: 200 miles. Reducing the flow of extremists and their resources across the borders is critical to success in the counterinsurgency. As a result
column4: with support from the Department of Homeland Security
column5: specialized training for Iraq's border enforcement elements began earlier this month in Jordan.

column1: Regional academies in Iraq have begun training as well
column2: and more will come online soon. In the months ahead
column3: the 16
column4: 000-strong border force will expand to 24
column5: 000 and then 32
column6: 000. In addition
column7: these forces will be provided with modern technology
column8: including vehicle X-ray machines
column9: explosive-detection devices and ground sensors.

column1: Outfitting hundreds of thousands of new Iraqi security forces is difficult and complex
column2: and many of the units are not yet fully equipped. But equipment has begun flowing. Since July 1
column3: for example
column4: more than 39
column5: 000 weapons and 22 million rounds of ammunition have been delivered to Iraqi forces
column6: in addition to 42
column7: 000 sets of body armor
column9: 400 vehicles
column11: 000 radios and more than 235
column12: 000 uniforms.

column1: Considerable progress is also being made in the reconstruction and refurbishing of infrastructure for Iraq's security forces. Some $1 billion in construction to support this effort has been completed or is underway
column2: and five Iraqi bases are already occupied by entire infantry brigades.

column1: Numbers alone cannot convey the full story. The human dimension of this effort is crucial. The enemies of Iraq recognize how much is at stake as Iraq reestablishes its security forces. Insurgents and foreign fighters continue to mount barbaric attacks against police stations
column2: recruiting centers and military installations
column3: even though the vast majority of the population deplores such attacks. Yet despite the sensational attacks
column4: there is no shortage of qualified recruits volunteering to join Iraqi security forces. In the past couple of months
column5: more than 7
column6: 500 Iraqi men have signed up for the army and are preparing to report for basic training to fill out the final nine battalions of the Iraqi regular army. Some 3
column7: 500 new police recruits just reported for training in various locations. And two days after the recent bombing on a street outside a police recruiting location in Baghdad
column8: hundreds of Iraqis were once again lined up inside the force protection walls at another location -- where they were greeted by interim Prime Minister Ayad Allawi.

column1: I meet with Iraqi security force leaders every day. Though some have given in to acts of intimidation
column2: many are displaying courage and resilience in the face of repeated threats and attacks on them
column3: their families and their comrades. I have seen their determination and their desire to assume the full burden of security tasks for Iraq.

column1: There will be more tough times
column2: frustration and disappointment along the way. It is likely that insurgent attacks will escalate as Iraq's elections approach. Iraq's security forces are
column3: however
column4: developing steadily and they are in the fight. Momentum has gathered in recent months. With strong Iraqi leaders out front and with continued coalition -- and now NATO -- support
column5: this trend will continue. It will not be easy
column6: but few worthwhile things are.

column1: The writer
column2: an Army lieutenant general
column3: commands the Multinational Security Transition Command in Iraq. He previously commanded the 101st Airborne Division
column4: which was deployed in Iraq from March 2003 until February 2004."	0

Encouraging the Democratic PartyÃ¢ÂÂs efforts from Harry Truman on to socialize the healthcare system of the United States is likely to have dire consequences for Catholic and other religious-based social service providers. 158	"Gun control advocates often cite the statistic that 90 percent of Americans support expanding background checks for gun purchases.
President Barack Obama just did it in his Jan. 1
column3: weekly address.

column1: But conservative radio talk show host Laura Ingraham says that statistic is not accurate.
The 90 percent statistic of supporting background checks
column2: that's been debunked
column3: Ingraham said on Fox News Sunday on Jan. 3. ""Lots of the myths about gun ownership are perpetrated by people who never much liked the Second Amendment in the first place and who have a vested interest in amassing more power in Washington

column1: PolitiFact has rated this 90 percent statistic True as recently as October. So we decided to try and figure out what Ingraham was talking about when she said this is a myth that has been debunked.
Go to the polls
Under current law
column2: background checks are required in sales by federally licensed gun dealers
column3: but the checks are not required for gun sales by private sellers.

column1: National polls conducted in 2015 consistently show that around 90 percent of Americans support some sort of expanded background checks for gun purchases. Here are a few examples:
Quinnipiac University poll
column2: conducted Dec. 16-20: ""Would you support or oppose a law requiring background checks on people buying guns at gun shows or online?"" Support: 89 percent. Oppose: 9 percent. Unsure/No answer: 1 percent.

column1: CBS/New York Times poll
column2: conducted Oct. 21-25: ""Do you favor or oppose a federal law requiring background checks on all potential gun buyers?"" Favor: 92 percent. Oppose: 7 percent. Unsure/No answer: 1 percent.

column1: Gallup poll
column2: conducted Oct. 7-11: ""Would you favor or oppose a law which would require universal background checks for all gun purchases in the U.S. using a centralized database across all 50 states?"" Favor: 86 percent. Oppose: 12 percent. Unsure: 2 percent.

column1: Quinnipiac University poll
column2: conducted Sept. 17-21: ""Do you support or oppose requiring background checks for all gun buyers?"" Support: 93 percent. Oppose: 6 percent. Unsure/No answer: 1 percent.

column1: Pew Research Center poll
column2: conducted July 14-20: Do you favor or oppose ""making private gun sales and sales at gun shows subject to background checks""? Favor: 85 percent. Oppose: 13 percent. Unsure/Refused: 2 percent.

column1: Pew found that support for background checks spans all partisan and demographic groups
column2: and it is also favored by a majority of households that own guns and those that do not.

column1: So are all of these polls wrong? We reached out to IngrahamÃ¢ÂÂs producers and didnÃ¢ÂÂt hear back.
We couldnÃ¢ÂÂt find any sort of definitive debunking of this stat
column2: but we did find that some gun rights advocates have taken issue with this statistic for reasons such as the survey questions referring to the general idea of background checks rather than specific legislation.

column1: For example
column3: polls found that 90 percent of Americans supported expanded background checks. However
column4: when Congress failed to pass a popular bill that would have increased background checks
column5: 47 percent were disappointed or angry that it failed
column6: while some 39 percent were relieved or very happy
column7: according to a Washington Post/Pew Research Center poll.

column1: Some gun rights activists took this as proof that the 90 percent figure was phooey.
This highlights an odd discrepancy: While people overwhelmingly support specific gun policy ideas
column2: like universal background checks and banning suspected terrorists from buying guns
column3: the support is not as robust when it comes to actually expanding gun control.

column1: The same October CBS/New York Times poll that found 92 percent support for expanded background checks also shows 46 percent of Americans think laws covering gun sales should be either made less strict or stay the same. Just 51 percent said the laws should be made more strict.
People don't seem to like the idea of Ã¢ÂÂgun control
column2: Ã¢ÂÂ but they still want the government to do more to keep guns out of the hands of criminals and the mentally ill
column3: said Adam Winkler
column4: a law professor at the University of California Los Angeles and author of Gunfight: The Battle over the Right to Bear Arms in America.

column1: Our ruling
Ingraham said
column2: ""The 90 percent statistic of supporting background checks
column3: that's been debunked.""

column1: Numerous respected polls from 2015 show around 90 percent support for some sort of expanded background checks for gun purchases.

While there are some questions as to what inferences can be made from these findings Ã¢ÂÂ such as whether that 90-percent support translates into support for specific legislation Ã¢ÂÂ there hasnÃ¢ÂÂt been a definitive debunking of the statistic.
We rate IngrahamÃ¢ÂÂs claim False."	0
