column1: 184	"July 25
column2: 2010 Ã¢ÂÂ -- TAPPER: Secretary Geithner thanks for joining us. Good to see you.

column1: So
column2: the administration has had a number of successes after big battles
column3: stimulus
column4: health care legislation
column5: new rules for Wall Street
column6: but you have a big battle coming when it comes to the Bush tax cuts.

column1: If they remain in place
column2: as Republicans want
column3: it will cost three trillion dollars every ten years. The administration has said it wants to keep the ones for people who make under $200
column4: 000 a year
column5: individuals and $250
column6: 000 for couples.

column1: That will cost $2.5 trillion over 10 years.
Ben Bernanke the chairman of the Federal Reserve said that with the economic outlook unusually uncertain
column2: extending the Bush tax cuts would have a stimulative effect on the economy. Is he right?

column1: GEITHNER: I don't think it should be a battle
column2: Jake. You know
column3: what the President's proposing to do is to leave in place
column4: to extend tax cuts that go to more than 95 percent of working Americans and to leave in place tax cuts that are very important to incent businesses to hire new pe -- new employees and to invest in expanding output.

column1: We think that's a -- the -- it's a very strong package. We think it's the right package. We think it's fair. We think it's responsible.
Now
column2: we also think it's responsible to let the tax cuts expire that just go to 2 percent to 3 percent of Americans
column3: the highest earning Americans. We think that's the responsible thing to do because we need to make sure we can show the world that they're willing as a country now to start to make some progress bringing down our long -- our long-term deficits.

column1: TAPPER: Don't you think it will slow economic growth?
GEITHNER: No. Just letting those tax cuts that only go to 2 percent to 3 percent of Americans
column2: the highest earning Americans in the country expire. I do not believe it will have a negative effect on growth.

column1: TAPPER: This package that you're talking about pushing in Congress to -- to save the Bush tax cuts for people under $200
column2: 000 individuals and 250 for couples --

column1: GEITHNER: And in fact
column2: we go beyond that. Because you know
column3: we're proposing to extend the make or pay tax cut which also goes to 95 percent of working Americans. And a set of very important business tax cuts targeted for small businesses themselves
column4: expensing
column5: zero capital gains rate for investment in small businesses. These things
column6: we think
column7: are very helpful
column8: very powerful.

column1: TAPPER: And when are you talking about pushing that into Congress?
GEITHNER: Congress is on the verge of what we hope will be enactment of a very strong package of tax measures for small businesses and ways to help them get credit so they can expand.
TAPPER: So
column2: before the election?

column1: GEITHNER: Oh
column2: absolutely.

column1: TAPPER: A number of Senate democrats
column2: moderate Senate democrats have said that they oppose repealing or allowing to expire the Bush tax cuts on the wealthiest Americans that they think that would be harmful to growth.

column1: Are you guys going to have the votes to get through the package you want which is focused more on middle and lower income America?
GEITHNER: Oh absolutely. I believe we will.
TAPPER: Some in the administration and internal discussions are talking about maybe just keeping all the Bush tax cuts for a year or two. Those aren't -- that's not going to happen?
GEITHNER: I don't believe it should and I don't believe it will. Again
column2: because what the president's proposed is to make sure we're leaving them in place for the people that need the most and can make the most difference in helping make sure this economy comes back. That we heal the damage caused by this crisis.

column1: TAPPER: Job creation has not gone as well as you hoped. What more can you do? I know there's this small business lending initiative. What more can you do given the lack of appetite on Capitol Hill for any spending programs? Any more stimulus?
GEITHNER: Well you know
column2: the President's proposed a very strong package of help for small businesses which you just referred to. He'd support giving more support to states so they can keep teachers in the classroom.

column1: TAPPER: Fifty billion dollars in emergency spending but the Congress has not acted on that.
GEITHNER: They haven't yet
column2: but we can (inaudible) case for doing it. They're going to
column3: we're going to keep at that. But right now
column4: the best thing the government can do in addition to those things
column5: is help create the conditions for the private sector to start to invest in hiring again.

column1: Now
column2: we've seen six months of positive job growth by the private sector. That's pretty good.

column1: TAPPER: By the private sector.
GEITHNER: Pretty good this early in a recession.
TAPPER: Although you count in the public sector with the layoffs and the census jobs.
GEITHNER: But only because of census. But you know
column2: what matters is -- is the private sector starting to hire people
column3: add back hours and that's what's critical.

column1: And you're seeing that happen now. Now we want it -- we want to see it happen at a faster pace. But I think most people understand that you know
column2: this was a deep crisis. The scars ran very deep. Devastating damage. It's going to take time to repair that damage
column3: take time to grow out of this. But we're making progress.

column1: TAPPER: In 2009 when President Obama talked about unemployment insurance extensions he talked about how it was paid for. This time
column2: it was not paid for
column3: the $34 billion in unemployment insurance extensions became added to the national debt.

column1: Republicans on Capitol Hill argued that they wanted to pay for it and they supported it but they just wanted it offset by spending cuts.
Given the fact that we're going to be -- we're going to have unemployment for the foreseeable future
column2: high unemployment. Isn't it the fiscally responsible thing to do to not treat this as emergency spending but treat this as something we know is coming down the pike so we're not just laying this burden on our future generations?

column1: GEITHNER: I don't think so. In a crisis that was this bad and a recession that was that deep. With this amount of lasting damage
column2: scars from recovery
column3: it's appropriate to treat these things as emergencies."	0

186	"WASHINGTON (Reuters) - Defense Secretary Robert Gates will consider sending some 3
column2: 000 Marines to Afghanistan to thwart any spring offensive by Taliban militants
column3: the Pentagon said on Wednesday.

column1: U.S and Dutch soldiers drive along a dusty road in a village in Baluchi pass in Uruzgan province
column2: Afghanistan November 1
column3: 2007. REUTERS/Goran Tomasevic

column1: Ã¢ÂÂThis proposal is coming before the secretary this week
column2: Ã¢ÂÂ Pentagon press secretary Geoff Morrell said. Ã¢ÂÂHe will take it and consider it thoroughly before approving it.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: Violence has surged in Afghanistan over the past two years
column2: with the hardline Islamist Taliban fighting a guerrilla war in the south and east and carrying out high-profile suicide and car bombings across the country.

column1: For months
column2: Gates has pressed NATO allies to provide more troops for Afghanistan. But if the Pentagon chief backs the proposal
column3: it will show Washington has concluded it will have to provide a large share of any extra combat forces.

column1: Gates ordered a boost in U.S. forces early last year in response to the violence and the United States currently has some 27
column2: 000 troops in Afghanistan -- a record high.

column1: Around half the U.S. troops serve in a 40
column2: 000-strong NATO-led security assistance force while the rest conduct missions ranging from counter-terrorism to training Afghan troops.

column1: While NATO says it thwarted last yearÃ¢ÂÂs attempted Taliban spring offensive
column2: overall violence is up 27 percent over a year ago and it has risen by 60 percent in the southern province of Helmand
column3: the U.S. military said last month.

column1: IN PLACE BY APRIL
Morrell said most of the Marines would go to southern Afghanistan
column2: where British
column3: Canadian and Dutch troops have done much of the fighting.

column1: Ã¢ÂÂThe idea is to get this in place to prevent
column2: as we did last spring
column3: another attempt by the Taliban to come back
column4: Ã¢ÂÂ he told reporters. Ã¢ÂÂThe timing is that they would be in place by April. This is a one-time seven-month deployment.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: After meeting allies in Scotland last month
column2: Gates signaled a shift away from pressing NATO nations to make politically difficult decisions to provide combat troops.

column1: He suggested the allies could help with other areas of the mission of rebuilding Afghanistan. But that shift means the United States must shoulder more of the combat burden.
Ã¢ÂÂThe commander needs additional forces there. Our allies are not in a position to provide them so we are now looking at perhaps carrying a bit of that additional load
column2: Ã¢ÂÂ Morrell said.

column1: U.S.-led forces ousted the Taliban government in late 2001 in response to the September 11 attacks on the United States.
Morrell said the plan to send the Marines would be contained in a schedule of deployment proposals presented to Gates on Friday.
The plan would involve the deployment of a unit called a Marine Air Ground Task Force to fight in southern Afghanistan
column2: and a Marine battalion to train Afghan forces.

column1: The PentagonÃ¢ÂÂs Joint Staff developed the plan after a request from Adm. William Fallon
column2: the top U.S. commander for the Middle East
column3: and it has the support of Adm. Mike Mullen
column4: chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff
column5: a U.S. military official said."	0

column1: 187	"DENVER
column2: COLORADO Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: With the new laws in effect in Colorado
column2: major sports organizations are looking for ways to cash in on the newest legal cash crop in the state.

column1: Sources are reporting that Major League BaseballÃ¢ÂÂs Colorado Rockies plan to sell food items which contain marijuana at concession stands during games next season.
The first item on the list? Pot Brownies.
An official within the Rockies organization stated that the Rockies organization has given the green light to concession stands selling marijuana brownies.
High ranking officials in the Rockies organization say they are thrilled at the new menu item since they note that it will bring in tens of thousands of dollars per month.

The Rockies head office is hoping that the sale of marijuana brownies will also boost sales of other concession items. What better way to sell concessions that to give everyone in the stadium the munchies?

SIDENOTE: An inside source with the organization said that it appears that the strain of marijuana that will be used in the making of the marijuana brownies will be Durango Bango which is considered to be the very best weed in the Rocky Mountain State."	1
188	"Obama delivers speech on the national debt
Speech Transcript

OBAMA: It is wonderful to be back at G.W. I want you to know that one of the reasons that I worked so hard with Democrats and Republicans to keep the government open was so that I could show up here today.
(LAUGHTER)
I want to make sure that all of you had one more excuse to skip class.
(LAUGHTER)
You're welcome.
(LAUGHTER)
I want to give a special thanks to Steven Knapp
column2: the president of G.W. I just saw him. Where is he?

column1: There he is
column2: right here.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
I want to -- we've got a lot of distinguished guests here. A couple of people I want to acknowledge.
First of all
column2: my outstanding vice president
column3: Joe Biden
column4: is here.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
Our secretary of the treasury
column2: Tim Geithner
column3: is in the house.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
Jack Lew
column2: the director of the Office of Management and Budget.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
Gene Sperling
column2: chair of the National Economic Council
column3: is here.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
Members of our bipartisan fiscal commission are here
column2: including the two outstanding chairs -- Erskine Bowles and Alan Simpson are here.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
And we have a umber of members of Congress here today. I'm grateful for all of you taking the time to attend.
What we've been debating here in Washington over the last few weeks will affect the lives of the students here and families all across America in potentially profound ways.
This debate over budgets and deficits is about more than just numbers on a page
column2: it's about more than just cutting and spending. It's about the kind of future that we want.

column1: OBAMA: It's about the kind of country that we believe in. And that's what I want to spend some time talking about today.
From our first days as a nation
column2: we have put our faith in free markets and free enterprise as the engine of America's wealth and prosperity. And more than citizens of any other country
column3: we are rugged individualists
column4: a self-reliant people with a healthy skepticism of too much government.

column1: But there has always been another thread running through our history: a belief that we're all connected and that there are some things we can only do together
column2: as a nation.

column1: We believe
column2: in the words of the first Republican president
column3: Abraham Lincoln
column4: that through government
column5: we should do together what we cannot do as well for ourselves.

column1: And so we've built a strong military to keep us secure
column2: and public schools and universities to educate our citizens. We've laid down railroads and highways to facilitate travel and commerce.

column1: OBAMA: We've supported the work of scientists and researchers whose discoveries have saved lives
column2: unleashed repeated technological revolutions
column3: and led to countless new jobs and entire new industries.

column1: Each of us has benefited from these investments
column2: and we're a more prosperous country as a result.

column1: Now
column2: part of this American belief that we're all connected also expresses itself in a conviction that each one of us deserves some basic measure of security and dignity.

column1: We recognize that
column2: no matter how responsibly we live our lives
column3: hard times or bad luck
column4: a crippling illness or a layoff may strike any one of us. ""There but for the grace of God go I
column5: we say to ourselves.

column1: And so we contribute to programs like Medicare and Social Security
column2: which guarantee us health care and a measure of basic income after a lifetime of hard work; unemployment insurance
column3: which protects us against unexpected job loss; and Medicaid
column4: which provides care for millions of seniors in nursing homes
column5: poor children
column6: those with disabilities.

column1: OBAMA: We're a better country because of these commitments.
I'll go further: We would not be a great country without those commitments.
And for much of the last century
column2: our nation found a way to afford these investments and priorities with the taxes paid by its citizens. As a country that values fairness
column3: wealthier individuals have traditionally borne a greater share of this burden than the middle class or those less fortunate; everybody pays
column4: but the wealthier have borne a little more.

column1: This is not because we begrudge those who've done well. We rightly celebrate their success.
Instead
column2: it's a basic reflection of our belief that those who benefited most from our way of life can afford to give back a little -- a little bit more.

column1: OBAMA: Moreover
column2: this belief hasn't hindered the success of those at the top of the income scale. They continue to do better and better with each passing year.

column1: Now
column2: at certain times -- particularly during war or recession -- our nation has had to borrow money to pay for some of our priorities. And as most families understand
column3: a little credit card debt isn't going to hurt
column4: if it's temporary.

column1: But as far back as the 1980s
column2: America started amassing debt at more alarming levels
column3: and our leaders began to realize that a larger challenge was on the horizon.

column1: They knew that eventually
column2: the baby boom generation would retire
column3: which meant a much bigger portion of our citizens would be relying on programs like Medicare
column4: Social Security and possibly Medicaid.

column1: Like parents with young children who know they have to start saving for the college years
column2: America had to start borrowing less and saving more to prepare for the retirement of an entire generation.

column1: To meet this challenge
column2: our leaders came together three times during the 1990s to reduce our nation's deficit -- three times. They forged historic agreements that required tough decisions made by the first President Bush
column3: then made by President Clinton
column4: by Democratic Congresses and by a Republican Congress.

column1: All three agreements asked for shared responsibility and shared sacrifice
column2: but they largely protected the middle class
column3: they largely protected our commitments to seniors
column4: they protected our key investments in our future.

column1: As a result of these bipartisan efforts
column2: America's finances were in great shape by the year 2000. We went from deficit to surplus. America was actually on track to becoming completely debt-free
column3: and we were prepared for the retirement of the baby boomers.

column1: But after Democrats and Republicans committed to fiscal discipline during the 1990s
column2: we lost our way in the decade that followed. We increased spending dramatically for two wars and an expensive prescription drug program
column3: but we didn't pay for any of this new spending.

column1: OBAMA: Instead we made the problem worse with trillions of dollars in unpaid-for tax cuts; tax cuts that went to every millionaire and billionaire in the country; tax cuts that will force us to borrow an average of $500 billion every year over the next decade.
To give you an idea of how much damage this caused to our nation's checkbook
column2: consider this.

column1: In the last decade
column2: if we had simply found a way to pay for the tax cuts and the prescription drug benefit
column3: our deficit would currently be at low historical levels in the coming years.

column1: But that's not what happened. And so
column2: by the time I took office
column3: we once again found ourselves deeply in debt and unprepared for a baby boom retirement that is now starting to take place.

column1: When I took office
column2: our projected deficit annually was more than $1 trillion. On top of that
column3: we faced a terrible financial crisis and a recession that
column4: like most recessions
column5: led us to temporarily borrow even more.

column1: In this case
column2: we took a series of emergency steps that saved millions of jobs
column3: kept credit flowing
column4: and provided working families extra money in their pocket. It was absolutely the right thing to do
column5: but these steps were expensive and added to our deficits in the short term.

column1: So that's how our fiscal challenge was created. That's how we got here. And now that our economic recovery is gaining strength
column2: Democrats and Republicans must come together and restore the fiscal responsibility that served us so well in the 1990s.

column1: We have to live within our means. We have to reduce our deficit. And we have to get back on a path that will allow us to pay down our debt.
OBAMA: And we have to do it in a way that protects the recovery
column2: protects the investments we need to grow
column3: creates jobs
column4: and helps us win the future.

column1: Now
column2: before I get into how we can achieve this goal
column3: some of you
column4: particularly the younger people here -- you don't qualify
column5: Joe...

column1: (LAUGHTER)
... some of you might be wondering
column2: ""Why is this so important? Why does this matter to me?""

column1: Well
column2: here's why.

column1: Even after our economy recovers
column2: our government will still be on track to spend more money than it takes in throughout this decade and beyond. That means we'll have to keep borrowing more from countries like China.

column1: That means more of your tax dollars each year will go towards paying off the interest on all of the loans that we keep taking out. By the end of this decade
column2: the interest that we owe on our debt could rise to nearly $1 trillion. Think about that. That's the interest
column3: just the interest payments.

column1: Then
column2: as the baby boomers start to retire in greater numbers and health care costs continue to rise
column3: the situation will get even worse.

column2: the amount of taxes we currently pay will only be enough to finance our health care programs
column3: Medicare and Medicaid
column4: Social Security
column5: and the interest we owe on our debt. That's it. Every other national priority -- education
column6: transportation
column7: even our national security -- will have to be paid for with borrowed money.

column1: Now
column2: ultimately all this rising debt will cost us jobs and damage our economy. It will prevent us from making the investments we need to win the future.

column1: OBAMA: We won't be able to afford good schools
column2: new research
column3: or the repair of roads; all the things that create new jobs and businesses here in America.

column1: Businesses will be less likely to invest and open shop in a country that seems unwilling or unable to balance its books. And if our creditors start worrying that we may be unable to pay back our debts
column2: that could drive up interest rates for everybody who borrows money
column3: making it harder for businesses to expand and hire or families to take out a mortgage.

column1: Here's the good news: That doesn't have to be our future; that doesn't have to be the country that we leave our children.
We can solve this problem. We came together as Democrats and Republicans to meet this challenge before; we can do it again. But that starts by being honest about what's causing our deficit.
You see
column2: most Americans tend to dislike government spending in the abstract
column3: but like the stuff that it buys.

column1: Most of us
column2: regardless of party affiliation
column3: believe that we should have a strong military and a strong defense. Most Americans believe we should invest in education and medical research. Most Americans think we should protect commitments like Social Security and Medicare.

column1: And without even looking at a poll
column2: my finely honed political instincts tell me that almost nobody believes they should be paying higher taxes.

column1: (LAUGHTER)
So because all this spending is popular with both Republicans and Democrats alike
column2: and because nobody wants to pay higher taxes
column3: politicians are often eager to feed the impression that solving the problem is just a matter of eliminating waste and abuse.

column1: OBAMA: You'll hear that phrase a lot: ""We just need to eliminate waste and abuse.""
The implication is that tackling the deficit issue won't require tough choices.
Or politicians suggest that we can somehow close our entire deficit by eliminating things like foreign aid
column2: even though foreign aid makes up about 1 percent of our entire federal budget.

column1: So here's the truth.
Around two-thirds of our budget -- two-thirds -- is spent on Medicare
column2: Medicaid
column3: Social Security and national security -- two- thirds.

column1: Programs like unemployment insurance
column2: student loans
column3: veterans' benefits and tax credits for working families take up another 20 percent.

column1: What's left
column2: after interest on the debt
column3: is just 12 percent for everything else. That's 12 percent for all of our national priorities: education
column4: clean energy
column5: medical research
column6: transportation
column7: our national parks
column8: food safety
column9: keeping our air and water clean. You name it
column10: all of that accounts for 12 percent of our budget.

column1: Now
column2: up 'til now
column3: the debate here in Washington -- the cuts proposed by a lot of folks in Washington have focused almost exclusively on that 12 percent.

column1: OBAMA: But cuts to that 12 percent alone won't solve the problem. So any serious plan to tackle our deficit will require us to put everything on the table and take on excess spending wherever it exists in the budget.
A serious plan doesn't require us to balance our budget overnight. In fact
column2: economists think that with the economy just starting to grow again we need a phased-in approach. But it does require tough decisions and support from our leaders in both parties now. Above all
column3: it will require us to choose a vision of the America we want to see five years
column4: 10 years
column5: 20 years down the road.

column1: Now
column2: to their credit
column3: one vision has been presented and championed by Republicans in the House of Representatives and embraced by several of their party's presidential candidates. It's a plan that aims to reduce our deficit by $4 trillion over the next 10 years
column4: and one that addresses the challenge of Medicare and Medicaid in the years after that.

column1: Those are both worthy goals. They're worthy goals for us to achieve.
But the way this plan achieves those goals would lead to a fundamentally different America than the one we've known
column2: certainly in my lifetime. In fact
column3: I think it would be fundamentally different than what we've known throughout our history.

column1: A 70 percent cut in clean energy
column2: a 25 percent cut in education
column3: a 30 percent cut in transportation
column4: cuts in college Pell Grants that will grow to more than $1
column5: 000 per year.

column1: OBAMA: That's the proposal.
These aren't the kind of cuts you make when you're trying to get rid of some waste or find extra savings in the budget. These aren't the kind of cuts that the fiscal commission proposed.
These are the kind of cuts that tell us we can't afford the America that I believe in and I think you believe in.
I believe it paints a vision of our future that is deeply pessimistic. It's a vision that says if our roads crumble and our bridges collapse
column2: we can't afford to fix them; if there are bright young Americans who have the drive and the will but not the money to go to college
column3: we can't afford to send them.

column1: Go to China and you'll see businesses opening research labs and solar facilities.
South Korean children are outpacing our kids in math and science. They're scrambling to figure out how they put more money into education.
Brazil is investing billions in new infrastructure and can run half their cars not on high-priced gasoline
column2: but on biofuels.

column1: And yet
column2: we are presented with a vision that says the American people
column3: the United States of America
column4: the greatest nation on Earth
column5: can't afford any of this.

column1: It's a vision that says America can't afford to keep the promise we've made to care for our seniors. It says that 10 years from now
column2: if you're a 65-year-old who's eligible for Medicare
column3: you should have to pay nearly $6
column4: 400 more than you would today.

column1: It says
column2: instead of guaranteed health care
column3: you will get a voucher. And if that voucher isn't worth enough to buy the insurance that's available in the open marketplace
column4: well
column5: tough luck; you're on your own.

column1: Put simply
column2: it ends Medicare as we know it.

column1: It's a vision that says up to 50 million Americans have to lose their health insurance in order for us to reduce the deficit.
OBAMA: Who are these 50 million Americans?
Many are somebody's grandparents
column2: maybe one of yours
column3: who wouldn't be able afford nursing home care without Medicaid.

column1: Many are poor children. Some are middle-class families who have children with autism or Down's syndrome. Some are these kids with disabilities are -- the disabilities are so severe that they require 24-hour care.
These are the Americans we'd be telling to fend for themselves.
And
column2: worst of all
column3: this is a vision that says even though Americans can't afford to invest in education at current levels or clean energy
column4: even though we can't afford to maintain our commitment on Medicare and Medicaid
column5: we can somehow afford more than $1 trillion in new tax breaks for the wealthy.

column1: Think about that.
In the last decade
column2: the average income of the bottom 90 percent of all working Americans actually declined. Meanwhile
column3: the top 1 percent saw their income rise by an average of more than a quarter of a million dollars each. That's who needs to pay less taxes?

column1: They want to give people like me a $200
column2: 000 tax cut that's paid for by asking 33 seniors to each pay $6
column3: 000 more in health costs.

column1: That's not right
column2: and that's not going to happen as long as I'm president.

column1: (APPLAUSE)

This vision is less about reducing the deficit than it is about changing the basic social compact in America. Ronald Reagan's own budget director said there's nothing serious or courageous about this plan.

OBAMA: There's nothing serious about a plan that claims to reduce the deficit by spending a trillion dollars on tax cuts for millionaires and billionaires. And I don't think there's anything courageous about asking for sacrifice from those who can least afford it and don't have any clout on Capitol Hill. That's not a vision of the America I know.
The America I know is generous and compassionate. It's a land of opportunity and optimism. Yes
column2: we take responsibility for ourselves
column3: but we also take responsibility for each other
column4: for the country we want and the future that we share.

column1: We're a nation that built a railroad across a continent and brought light to communities shrouded in darkness. We sent a generation to college on the G.I. Bill and we saved millions of seniors from poverty with Social Security and Medicare.
We have led the world in scientific research and technological breakthroughs that have transformed millions of lives.
That's who we are. This is the America that I know.
We don't have to choose between a future of spiraling debt and one where we forfeit our investment in our people and our country.
To meet our fiscal challenge
column2: we will need to make reforms
column3: we will all need to make sacrifices. But we do not have to sacrifice the America we believe in. And as long as I'm president
column4: we won't.

column1: So today I'm proposing a more balanced approach to achieve $4 trillion in deficit reduction over 12 years. It's an approach that borrows from the recommendations of the bipartisan fiscal commission that I appointed last year
column2: and it builds on the roughly $1 trillion in deficit reduction I already proposed in my 2012 budget.

column1: OBAMA: It's an approach that puts every kind of spending on the table
column2: but one that protects the middle class
column3: our promise to seniors and our investments in the future.

column1: The first step in our approach is to keep annual domestic spending low by building on the savings that both parties agreed to last week. That step alone will save us about $750 billion over 12 years.
We will make the tough cuts necessary to achieve these savings
column2: including in programs that I deeply care about. But I will not sacrifice the core investments that we need to grow and create jobs. We will invest in medical research. We will invest in clean energy technology. We will invest in new roads and airports and broadband access. We will invest in education. We will invest in job training. We will do what we need to do to compete
column3: and we will win the future.

column1: The second step in our approach is to find additional savings in our defense budget.
Now
column2: as commander in chief
column3: I have no greater responsibility than protecting our national security
column4: and I will never accept cuts that compromise our ability to defend our homeland or America's interests around the world.

column1: But as the chairman of the Joint Chiefs
column2: Admiral Mullen
column3: has said
column4: the greatest long-term threat to America's national security is America's debt.

column1: OBAMA: So just as we must find more savings in domestic programs
column2: we must do the same in defense. And we can do that while still keeping ourselves safe.

column1: Over the last two years
column2: Secretary Bob Gates has courageously taken on wasteful spending
column3: saving $400 billion in current and future spending. I believe we can do that again.

column1: We need to not only eliminate waste and improve efficiency and effectiveness
column2: but we're going to have to conduct a fundamental review of America's missions
column3: capabilities
column4: and our role in a changing world.

column1: I intend to work with Secretary Gates and the Joint Chiefs on this review
column2: and I will make specific decisions about spending after it's complete.

column1: The third step in our approach is to further reduce health care spending in our budget. Now
column2: here the difference with the House Republican plan could not be clearer.

column1: Their plan essentially lowers the government's health care bills by asking seniors and poor families to pay them instead. Our approach lowers the government's health care bills by reducing the cost of health care itself.
Already
column2: the reforms we passed in the health care law will reduce our deficit by $1 trillion. My approach would build on those -- these reforms.

column1: We will reduce wasteful subsidies and erroneous payments. We will cut spending on prescription drugs by using Medicare's purchasing power to drive greater efficiency and speed generic brands of medicine onto the market. We will work with governors of both parties to demand more efficiency and accountability from Medicaid.
We will change the way we pay for health care: not by the procedure or the number of days spent in a hospital
column2: but with new incentives for doctors and hospitals to prevent injuries and improve results.

column1: And we will slow the growth of Medicare costs by strengthening an independent commission of doctors
column2: nurses
column3: medical experts and consumers who will look at all the evidence and recommend the best ways to reduce unnecessary spending while protecting access to the services that seniors need.

column1: Now
column2: we believe the reforms we've proposed to strengthen Medicare and Medicaid will enable us to keep these commitments to our citizens while saving us $500 billion by 2023
column3: and an additional $1 trillion in the decade after that.

column1: OBAMA: But if we're wrong
column2: and Medicare costs rise faster than we expect
column3: then this approach will give the independent commission the authority to make additional savings by further improving Medicare.

column1: But let me be absolutely clear: I will preserve these health care programs as a promise we make to each other in this society. I will not allow Medicare to become a voucher program that leaves seniors at the mercy of the insurance industry
column2: with a shrinking benefit to pay for rising costs. I will not tell families with children who have disabilities that they have to fend for themselves.

column1: We will reform these programs
column2: but we will not abandon the fundamental commitment this country has kept for generations.

column1: That includes
column2: by the way
column3: our commitment to Social Security. While Social Security is not the cause of our deficit
column4: it faces real long-term challenges in a country that's growing older.

column1: As I said in the State of the Union
column2: both parties should work together now to strengthen Social Security for future generations. But we have to do it without putting at risk current retirees or the most vulnerable or people with disabilities
column3: without slashing benefits for future generations and without subjecting Americans' guaranteed retirement income to the whims of the stock market. And it can be done.

column1: The fourth step in our approach is to reduce spending in the tax code
column2: so-called tax expenditures.

column1: In December
column2: I agreed to extend the tax cuts for the wealthiest Americans because it was the only way I could prevent a tax hike on middle-class Americans.

column1: OBAMA: But we cannot afford $1 trillion worth of tax cuts for every millionaire and billionaire in our society. We can't afford it. And I refuse to renew them again.
Beyond that
column2: the tax code is also loaded up with spending on things like itemized deductions. And while I agree with the goals of many of these deductions
column3: from homeownership to charitable giving
column4: we can't ignore the fact that they provide millionaires an average tax break of $75
column5: 000 but do nothing for the typical middle-class family that doesn't itemize.

column1: So my budget calls for limiting itemized deductions for the wealthiest 2 percent of Americans
column2: a reform that would reduce the deficit by $320 billion over 10 years.

column1: But to reduce the deficit
column2: I believe we should go further. And that's why I'm calling on Congress to reform our individual tax code so that it is fair and simple
column3: so that the amount of taxes you pay isn't determined by what kind of accountant you can afford.

column1: I believe reform should protect the middle class
column2: promote economic growth
column3: and build on the fiscal commission's model of reducing tax expenditures so that there is enough savings to both lower rates and lower the deficit. And as I called for in the State of the Union
column4: we should reform our corporate tax code as well
column5: to make our businesses and our economy more competitive.

column1: So this is my approach to reduce the deficit by $4 trillion over the next 12 years.

OBAMA: It's an approach that achieves about $2 trillion in spending cuts across the budget. It will lower our interest payments on the debt by $1 trillion. It calls for tax reform to cut about $1 trillion in tax expenditures -- spending in the tax code. And it achieves these goals while protecting the middle class
column2: protecting our commitment to seniors and protecting our investments in the future.

column1: Now
column2: in the coming years
column3: if the recovery speeds up and our economy grows faster than our current projections
column4: we can make even greater progress than I've pledged here.

column1: But just to hold Washington and to hold me accountable and make sure that the debt burden continues to decline
column2: my plan includes a debt failsafe.

column1: If
column3: our debt is not projected to fall as a share of the economy
column4: if we haven't hit our targets
column5: if Congress has failed to act
column6: then my plan will require us to come together and make up the additional savings with more spending cuts and more spending reductions in the tax code.

column1: And that should be an incentive for us to act boldly now
column2: instead of kicking our problems further down the road.

column1: So this is our vision for America
column2: this is my vision for America
column3: a vision where we live within our means while still investing in our future
column4: where everyone makes sacrifices but no one bears all the burden
column5: where we provide a basic measure of security for our citizens and we provide rising opportunity for our children.

column1: There will be those who vigorously disagree with my approach. I can guarantee that as well.
(LAUGHTER)
Some will argue we should not even consider -- ever
column2: ever -- raising taxes
column3: even if only on the wealthiest Americans.

column1: OBAMA: It's just an article of faith to them.
I say that at a time when the tax burden on the wealthy is at its lowest level in half a century
column2: the most fortunate among us can afford to pay a little more.

column1: I don't need another tax cut. Warren Buffett doesn't need another tax cut. Not if we have to pay for it by making seniors pay more for Medicare or by cutting kids from Head Start or by taking away college scholarships that I wouldn't be here without
column2: and that some of you wouldn't be here without.

column1: And here's the thing: I believe that most wealthy Americans would agree with me. They want to give back to their country
column2: a country that's done so much for them. It's just Washington hasn't asked them to.

column1: Others will say that we shouldn't even talk about cutting spending until the economy is fully recovered. These are mostly folks in my party.
I'm sympathetic to this view
column2: which is one of the reasons I supported the payroll tax cuts we passed in December. It's also why we have to use a scalpel and not a machete to reduce the deficit
column3: so that we can keep making the investments that create jobs.

column1: But doing nothing on the deficit is just not an option. Our debt has grown so large that we could do real damage to the economy if we don't begin a process now to get our fiscal house in order.
Finally
column2: there are those who believe we shouldn't make any reforms to Medicare
column3: Medicaid or Social Security out of fear that any talk of change to these programs will immediately usher in the sort of radical steps that House Republicans have proposed. And I understand those fears.

column1: OBAMA: But I guarantee that if we don't make any changes at all
column2: we won't be able to keep our commitment to a retiring generation that will live longer and will face higher health care costs than those who came before.

column1: Indeed
column2: to those in my own party
column3: I say that if we truly believe in a progressive vision of our society
column4: we have an obligation to prove that we can afford our commitments.

column1: If we believe that government can make a difference in people's lives
column2: we have the obligation to prove that it works
column3: by making government smarter and leaner and more effective.

column1: Of course
column2: there are those who simply say there's no way we can come together at all and agree on a solution to this challenge. They'll say the politics of this city are just too broken
column3: the choices are just too hard
column4: the parties are just too far apart.

column1: And after a few years on this job I have some sympathy for this view.
(LAUGHTER)
But I also know that we've come together before and met big challenges.
Ronald Reagan and Tip O'Neill came together to save Social Security for future generations.
The first President Bush and a Democratic Congress came together to reduce the deficit.
President Clinton and a Republican Congress battled each other ferociously -- disagreed on just about everything -- but they still found a way to balance the budget.
OBAMA: And in the last few months
column2: both parties have come together to pass historic tax relief and spending cuts. And I know there are Republicans and Democrats in Congress who want to see a balanced approach to deficit reduction.

column1: And even those Republicans I disagree with most strongly I believe are sincere about wanting to do right by their country. We may disagree on our visions
column2: but I -- I -- I truly believe they want to do the right thing.

column1: So I believe we can and must come together again.
This morning
column2: I met with Democratic and Republican leaders in Congress to discuss the approach that I laid out today. And in early May
column3: the vice president will begin regular meetings with leaders in both parties with the aim of reaching a final agreement on a plan to reduce the deficit and get it done by the end of June.

column1: I don't expect the details in any final agreement to look exactly like the approach I laid out today. This is a democracy; that's not how things work. I'm eager to hear other ideas from all ends of the political spectrum.
And though I'm sure the criticism of what I've said here today will be fierce in some quarters and my critique of the House Republican approach has been strong
column2: Americans deserve and will demand that we all make an effort to bridge our differences and find common ground.

column1: This larger debate that we're having -- this larger debate about the size and the role of government -- it has been with us since our founding days. And during moments of great challenge and change
column2: like the one that we're living through now
column3: the debate gets sharper and it gets more vigorous. That's not a bad thing. In fact
column4: it's a good thing.

column1: OBAMA: As a country that prizes both our individual freedom and our obligations to one another
column2: this is one of the most important debates that we can have.

column1: But no matter what we argue
column2: no matter where we stand
column3: we've always held certain beliefs as Americans.

column1: We believe that in order to preserve our own freedoms and pursue our own happiness
column2: we can't just think about ourselves. We have to think about the country that made these liberties possible. We have to think about our fellow citizens with whom we share a community. And we have to think about what's required to preserve the American dream for future generations.

column1: This sense of responsibility -- to each other and to our country -- this isn't a partisan feeling. This isn't a Democratic or a Republican idea. It's patriotism.

The other day I received a letter from a man in Florida. He started off by telling me he didn't vote for me and he hasn't always agreed with me. But even though he's worried about our economy and the state of our politics
column2: here's what he said.

column1: He said
column2: ""I still believe. I believe in that great country that my grandfather told me about. I believe that somewhere lost in this quagmire of petty bickering on every news station
column3: the American dream is still alive.""

column1: We need to use our dollars here rebuilding
column2: refurbishing and restoring all that our ancestors struggled to create and maintain. We as a people must do this together
column3: no matter the color of the "	0

Ã¢ÂÂThatÃ¢ÂÂs what Republicans are offering with our Pledge to America

column1: Ã¢ÂÂA generation of fiscal recklessness in Washington has pushed us to the brink. Just to stay afloat

column1: Ã¢ÂÂThis spending spree threatens our childrenÃ¢ÂÂs future. ItÃ¢ÂÂs also hurting our economy. Americans know it has to stop

column1: Ã¢ÂÂWe need to stop the coming tax hike. We canÃ¢ÂÂt balance the budget without cutting spending and achieving real economic growth Ã¢ÂÂ and we wonÃ¢ÂÂt have real economic growth if we raise taxes on small businesses and families.
Ã¢ÂÂThereÃ¢ÂÂs a third thing we need to do to help our economy

Americans should have three days to read all bills before Congress votes on them Ã¢ÂÂ something they didnÃ¢ÂÂt get when the Ã¢ÂÂstimulusÃ¢ÂÂ was rushed into law. We should put an end to so-called Ã¢ÂÂcomprehensiveÃ¢ÂÂ bills that make it easy to hide wasteful spending projects and job-killing policies. Bills should be written by legislators in committee in plain public view Ã¢ÂÂ not written in the SpeakerÃ¢ÂÂs office
column4: behind closed doors.

column1: Ã¢ÂÂAcross our nation
column2: Americans are looking at President ObamaÃ¢ÂÂs policies and asking Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂwhere are the jobs?Ã¢ÂÂ To help our economy get back on track
column3: we have to stop all of the coming tax hikes and cut spending Ã¢ÂÂ and to cut spending
column4: we need to change Congress itself.

column1: Ã¢ÂÂThis is a new way forward that hasnÃ¢ÂÂt been tried in Washington yet. ItÃ¢ÂÂs a break from the direction in which President Obama has taken our country. And frankly
column2: itÃ¢ÂÂs also a break from the direction in which Republicans were headed when Americans last entrusted us with the reins of government. The American people are in charge
column3: and they deserve nothing less.

column1: Ã¢ÂÂTogether

Ã¢ÂÂWeÃ¢ÂÂve tried it President ObamaÃ¢ÂÂs way. WeÃ¢ÂÂve tried it WashingtonÃ¢ÂÂs way. It hasnÃ¢ÂÂt worked. ItÃ¢ÂÂs time to put the people back in charge.

AMANPOUR: Then

column3: killing his son and three grandchildren. Howwill the strongman strike back? And how does it all end?

column1: (UNKNOWN): This was a direct operation to assassinate the leaderof this country.
AMANPOUR: What's the way out for the U.S.? A formeradministration insider weighs in.
Plus
column2: we're live from the Vatican
column3: as Pope John Paul II gets onestep closer to sainthood. Is the fast track too fast?

column1: ANNOUNCER: Live from the Newseum in Washington
column2: ""This Week"" withChristiane Amanpour starts right now.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
AMANPOUR: Welcome to our viewers here and around the world.There is a lot happening this Sunday

column5: ""a direct operation to assassinate MoammarGadhafi
column6: this after a NATO bomb hit Gadhafi's compound. It sparedhim

column8: which has dragged into astalemate in recent weeks?

column1: We go live now to Libya for the very latest on the ground. ABC'sMiguel Marquez is in Benghazi

column3: where the attack took place.

column1: Christian
column2: let's start with you. Is there a feeling now that thewar is entering a new phase around Tripoli?

column1: FRASER: I think that's a very real possibility
column2: Christiane. Theway that the press visit to this bomb site was orchestrated lastnight
column3: it was very deliberately held back for two hours
column4: and then wewere taken there and then given a press conference here at the hotel
column5: in which Moussa Ibrahim spelled out what he thought the attack meantdoes suggest that they will try and make as much political capitalfrom this as they can.

column1: Certainly
column2: it puts pressure on NATO and its allies. And we'veseen already a very angry reaction from his supporters in Tripoli

column1: The unknowns

column3: are what Colonel Gadhafi's response willbe. We've not heard from him yet. We don't know what the response ofhis supporters will be in the days ahead
column4: and we don't know
column5: really
column6: what the sort of international reaction will be to what has unfoldedhere last night.

column1: AMANPOUR: A lot of questions there
column2: Christian
column3: and we'llcontinue to monitor it.

column1: Of course
column2: the U.S. embassy is empty

column4: who's in the east there in rebel-held Benghazi.

column1: 198	"Pledge of Allegiance E-mail
The following is the text of a chain e-mail that features Sen. John McCain's remarks about the Pledge of Allegiance
column2: and an anecdote from his time as a prisoner of war in Vietnam.

column1: John McCain's remarks about the Pledge of Allegiance
In light of the recent appeals court ruling in California
column2: with respect to the Pledge of Allegiance
column3: the following recollection from Senator John McCain is very appropriate:

column1: 'The Pledge of Allegiance' - by Senator John McCain
'As you may know
column2: I spent five and one half years as a prisoner of war during the Vietnam War. In the early years of our imprisonme nt
column3: the NVA kept us in solitary confinement or two or three to a cell. In 1971 the NVA moved us from these conditions of isolation into large rooms with as many as 30 to 40 men to a room.

column1: This was
column2: as you can imagine
column3: a wonderful change and was a direct result of the efforts of millions of Americans on behalf of a few hundred POWs 10
column4: 000 miles from home.

column1: One of the men who moved into my room was a young man named Mike Christian.
Mike came from a small town near Selma
column2: Alabama . He didn't wear a pair of shoes until he was 13 years old. At 17
column3: he enlisted in the US Navy. He later earned a commission by going to Officer Training School Then h e became a Naval Flight Officer and was shot down and captured in 1967. Mike had a keen and deep appreciation of the opportunities this country and our military provide for people who want to work and want to succeed.

column1: As part of the change in treatment
column2: the Vietnamese allowed some prisoners to receive packages from home. In some of these packages were handkerchiefs
column3: scarves and other items of clothing.

column1: Mike got himself a bamboo needle. Over a period of a couple of months
column2: he created an American flag and sewed on the inside of his shirt.

column1: Every afternoon
column2: before we had a bowl of soup
column3: we would hang Mike's shirt on the wall of t he cell and say the Pledge of Allegiance.

column1: I know the Pledge of Allegiance may not seem the most important part of our day now
column2: but I can assure you that in that stark cell it was indeed the most important and meaningful event.

column1: One day the Vietnamese searched our cell
column2: as they did periodically
column3: and discovered Mike's shirt with the flag sewn inside
column4: and removed it.

column1: That evening they returned
column2: opened the door of the cell
column3: and for the benefit of all of us
column4: beat Mike Christian severely for the next couple of hours. Then
column5: they opened the door of the cell and threw him in. We cleaned him up as well as we could.

column1: The cell in which we lived had a concrete slab in the middle on which we slept Four naked light bulbs hung in each corner of the room.
As I said
column2: we tried to clean up Mike as well as we could. After the excitement died down
column3: I looked in the corner of the room
column4: and sitting there beneath that dim light bulb with a piece of red cloth
column5: another shirt and his bamboo needle
column6: was my friend
column7: Mike Christian. He was sitting there with his eyes almost shut from the beating he had received
column8: making another American flag. He was not making the flag because it made Mike Christian feel better. He was making that flag because he knew how important it was to us to be able to Pledge our allegiance to our flag and country.

column1: So the next time you say the Pledge of Allegiance
column2: you must never forget the sacrifice and courage that thousands of Americans have made to build our nation and promote freedom around the world. You must remember our duty
column3: our honor
column4: and our country.'

column1: 'I pledge allegiance to the flag of the United States of America and to the republic for which it stands
column2: one nation under God
column3: indivisible
column4: with liberty and justice for all.'

column1: PASS THIS ON... And on... And on! You can even send it back to me
column2: I don't mind
column3: because its worth reading again.

column2: who refuses to place his hand on his heart and say the pledge...... Subject: Remember this picture on election day!

column3: but at least she shows respect for the country she lives in! I had heard about this but a picture is definitely worth 1000 words! God save us!!!

200	"It was June 2014 when the Washington Post reported that illegal immigrants
column2: Ã¢ÂÂincluding thousands of women and children
column3: stream into south Texas. It was nine months late when the same paper reported that ObamaÃ¢ÂÂs border agents were tossing some of those kids into internment camps as an experiment.

column1: It was called the Juvenile Referral Process
column2: and it worried human rights groups Mexican officials who feared that it put the kids at risk. The program was the creation of Robert Harris who at the time U.S. Customs and Border Protection commander of the Laredo sector. Harris believed holding certain young Mexicans
column3: believed to be working for cartels in detention serves to get these kids out of the smuggling enterprise. Believed is the operative word
column4: There were no judges
column5: no chargesÃ¢ÂÂ no trialÃ¢ÂÂjust belief.

column1: His intelligence analysts estimated that 78 percent of the guides smuggling other migrants were Mexicans younger than 18 Ã¢ÂÂ teenagers often hired or conscripted by drug cartels that knew they would not be prosecuted if caught Ã¢ÂÂ and he wanted to attack this loophole. Ã¢ÂÂWhy donÃ¢ÂÂt we remove these juveniles from the smuggling cycle?Ã¢ÂÂ Harris
column2: the outgoing commander of the Laredo sector of U.S. Customs and Border Protection
column3: recalled thinking. Now
column4: as a result of that decision
column5: young Mexicans are being held for months without charge in shelters across the United States
column6: sometimes without their parentsÃ¢ÂÂ knowledge. Since the program began in May
column7: 536 juveniles have been held Ã¢ÂÂ 248 of whom have been deported to Mexico after an average stay of 75 days
column8: according to Border Patrol statistics. Mexican authorities say some of these repeat border-crossers have spent as much as six months in U.S. custody while they await an appearance before an immigration judge. During their detention
column9: they are questioned by U.S. authorities and then transferred to a network of facilities run by the Office of Refugee Resettlement
column10: part of the Department of Health and Human Services
column11: across 15 states.

column1: Lets put this in perspective
column2: under Trump children are separated from their parents because they donÃ¢ÂÂt want the kids going to jail with their parents. Under Obama
column3: young illegal immigrants were put in Ã¢ÂÂfacilitiesÃ¢ÂÂ so they could be squeezed for any information they may or may not have about drug cartels.

column1: Ã¢ÂÂOur concern is that the programÃ¢ÂÂs real intent is to interrogate the kids

column3: an expert on Mexico and migrants at the Washington Office on Latin America (WOLA). The kids are Ã¢ÂÂoften questioned about the criminal groups they are working for and then subsequently returned to Mexico with no apparent concern about the implications for them.Ã¢ÂÂ While in custody last year [2014]
column4: one Mexican boy who worked as a guide shared information with U.S. authorities about the location of stash houses used by migrants as they move through the United States

column4: Ã¢ÂÂ said Reyna Torres MendÃÂ­vil
column5: director general of the Mexican Foreign MinistryÃ¢ÂÂs office for protection of Mexicans abroad. Ã¢ÂÂWhere were they taking these children?Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: Regarding preventing kids from becoming repeat offenders
column2: the Juvenile Referral Process worked
column3: But why is it okay to incarcerate kids based on a belief without a judge or knowledge of their parents? The only reason I can think of is that a program to detain kids is okay under a Democratic Party president
column4: but preventing kids from going to jail with their parents is considered unAmerican when the president is a Republican.
