CNN Live Event/Special
Republican Presidential Debate
Aired June 05
THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.
WOLF BLITZER
column2: HOST: Let's begin our questioning.

column1: Right now Tom Fahey of the New Hampshire Union Leader with the first question.
TOM FAHEY
column2: NEW HAMPSHIRE UNION LEADER: Thanks
column3: Wolf.

column1: Governor Romney
column2: I wanted to start by asking you a question on which every American has formed an opinion.

column1: We have lost 3
column2: 400 troops
column3: civilian casualties are even higher
column4: and the Iraqi government does not appear ready to provide for the security of its own country. Knowing everything you know right now
column5: was it a mistake for us to invade Iraq?

column1: MITT ROMNEY
column2: FORMER GOVERNOR OF MASSACHUSETTS: Well
column3: the question is
column4: kind of
column5: a non sequitur
column6: if you will. What I mean by that -- or a null set -- that is that if you're saying let's turn back the clock and Saddam Hussein had opening up his country to IAEA inspectors and they'd come in and they'd found that there were no weapons of mass destruction
column7: had Saddam Hussein therefore not violated United Nations resolutions
column8: we wouldn't be in the conflict we're in.

column1: But he didn't do those things
column2: and we knew what we knew at the point we made the decision to get in.

column1: I supported the president's decision based on what we knew at that time.
I think we were underprepared and underplanned for what came after we knocked down Saddam Hussein.
By the way
column2: Harry Reid was wrong. We did not lose the war in Iraq. And that's not the sort of thing you say when you have men and women in harm's way.

column1: We did
column2: however
column3: not do a great job after we knocked down Saddam Hussein and won the war to take him down and his military.

column1: And at this stage
column2: the right thing for us to do is to see if we could possibly stabilize the central government in Iraq so that they can have stability
column3: and so we can bring our troops home as soon as possible.

column1: Not to do that adds an enormous potential risk that the whole region could be embroiled in a regional conflict. BLITZER: Governor
column2: thank you
column3: but the question was
column4: knowing what you know right now -- not what you knew then
column5: what you know right now -- was it a mistake for the United States to invade Iraq?

column1: ROMNEY: Well
column2: I answered the question by saying it's a non- sequitur. It's a non -- null set kind of question
column3: because you can go back and say
column4: ""If we knew then what we know now
column5: by virtue of inspectors having been let in and giving us that information
column6: by virtue of if Saddam Hussein had followed the U.N. resolutions
column7: we wouldn't be having this discussion.""

column1: So it's a hypothetical that I think is an unreasonable hypothetical.
And the answer is: We did what we did. We did the right thing based on what we knew at that time. I think we made mistakes following the conduct or the collapse of Saddam's government.
FAHEY: Mayor Giuliani
column2: same question to you. Knowing what you know right now
column3: was it a good decision?

column1: RUDY GIULIANI
column2: FORMER MAYOR OF NEW YORK CITY: Absolutely the right thing to do. It's unthinkable that you would leave Saddam Hussein in charge of Iraq and be able to fight the war on terror.

column1: And the problem is that we see Iraq in a vacuum. Iraq should not be seen in a vacuum. Iraq is part of the overall terrorist war against the United States.
The problem the Democrats make is they're in denial. That's why you hear things like you heard in the debate the other night
column2: that
column3: you know
column4: Iran really isn't dangerous; it's 10 years away from nuclear weapons.

column1: Iran is not 10 years away from nuclear weapons. And the danger to us is not just missiles. The danger to us is a state like Iran handing nuclear weapons over to terrorists.
So it has to be seen in that light. And we have to be successful in Iraq.
BLITZER: Senator McCain
column2: arguably going to war is the most important decision a member of the Senate can make.

column1: Did you read the national intelligence estimate
column2: which included all the caveats on whether or not there were weapons of mass destruction in Iraq?

column1: SEN. JOHN MCCAIN (R)
column2: ARIZONA: I did not read that particular document. I received hundreds of briefing
column3: tens and hundreds of hours of study and background and information on it. And the fact is that the sanctions were breaking down. The sanctions were not going to hold. We had a multi-billion dollar scandal in the form of oil for food.

column1: The fact is that Saddam Hussein had used weapons of mass destruction before on his own people and on his enemies. And if he'd gotten them again
column2: he'd have used them again. That was his commitment and his belief
column3: that he was going to. And we did the right thing.

column1: The problem was the mismanagement of the conflict.
BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Senator.

column1: Senator Brownback
column2: you're also a member of the United States Senate. Did you read that classified national intelligence estimate?

column1: SEN. SAM BROWNBACK (R)
column2: KANSAS: I don't remember that report. I had a number of briefings and I held a number of committee hearings. At that time
column3: I was chairing the Middle East Subcommittee on Foreign Relations. And we held hearings on this topic and what was taking place and what Saddam was doing.

column1: But the issue is that we've got to put forward
column2: now
column3: a political plan. And that's something I'm going to introduce tomorrow
column4: a political plan to create a three-state solution in Iraq: a Kurdish state
column5: a Sunni state
column6: a Shia state. Because Iraq is more three groups held together by exterior forces. And that's what we've lacked is a political plan to get us moving forward in success.

column1: BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Senator.

column1: Governor Gilmore
column2: let me go to you. You chaired this commission. Do you think it was appropriate that members of Congress would authorize the president to go to war without reading that national intelligence estimate?

column1: JIM GILMORE
column2: FORMER GOVERNOR OF VIRGINIA: You know
column3: I think the people who are in Congress who are responsible for sending this country to war
column4: with the enormous dangers that it has geopolitically and strategically
column5: ought to read at least that kind of material. I know they get a lot of stuff and they can't read everything.

column1: But you know what
column2: Wolf? I think the true business is this: The interests of the United States is in creating as much stability as possible in the Middle East. There is a very great danger to this country: our interests in Israel
column3: our interests in energy and in other ways. There is a giant danger of the Middle East becoming an unstable place.

column1: Saddam Hussein was unstable
column2: and so taking him out was good there. But we certainly didn't anticipate the further instability that was to come after.

column1: BLITZER: We're going to bring all of you in
column2: but I want to go to Scott Spradling of WMUR for the next question.

column1: SCOTT SPRADLING
column2: WMUR-TV: Thanks
column3: Wolf.

column1: Senator McCain
column2: we've just spent a few minutes looking back. I'd ask you to look forward now
column3: if you will.

column1: Since June 1st there have been at least 17 confirmed deaths of American soldiers in Iraq. Approximately 100 U.S. troops are dying there every month. If our top military commander in Iraq
column2: General Petraeus
column3: reports back to Congress this September that the surge hasn't significantly improved the situation on the ground
column4: what then?

column1: MCCAIN: Well
column2: let me say
column3: first of all
column4: I know how frustrated and saddened all Americans are. This morning I was with the family of Matthew Stanley of Wolfeboro
column5: who sacrificed his life. And our hearts and our sympathy goes out to all those who have sacrificed their lives in this conflict.

column1: I (inaudible) think this strategy needs to be given a chance to succeed. We haven't barely gotten the fifth brigade over there
column2: which is part of this strategy.

column1: I am convinced that if we fail and we have to withdraw
column2: they will follow us home. It will be a base for Al Qaida. And we will be facing greater challenges and greater sacrifices than that already made by Matthew Stanley and his family.

column1: There is no doubt in my mind that this will become a base for terrorism
column2: there will be chaos in the region. And when Senator Clinton says this is Mr. Bush's war
column3: that this is President Bush's war -- when President Clinton was in power
column4: I didn't say that Bosnia
column5: our intervention there was President Clinton's war. When we intervened in Kosovo
column6: I didn't say it was President Clinton's war.

column1: What Senator Clinton doesn't understand that presidents don't lose wars. Political parties don't lose wars.
Nations lose wars
column2: and nations lose the -- have the consequences of failure.

column1: BLITZER: Senator...
MCCAIN: We must succeed in this conflict.
BLITZER: ... the question was
column2: if General Petraeus says...

column1: (APPLAUSE)
... it's not working so far in September
column2: what do you do then?

column1: MCCAIN: Then you have to examine the options.

And I'll tell you the options: One is the division that Sam described. You would have to divide bedrooms in Baghdad because Sunni and Shia are married to each other. You have 2 million Sunni and 4 million Shia living in Baghdad together.

You would have to -- you withdraw to the borders and watch genocide take place inside Baghdad. You watch the destabilization of Jordan. You see further jeopardy of Israel because of the threats of Hezbollah and Iranian hegemony in the region.
All of the options I could run through with you. My friend
column2: none of them are good. That's why we must succeed and give it a chance to succeed.

column1: BLITZER: All right.
Now
column2: let me bring in Governor Thompson.

column1: Go ahead
column2: same question to you: If General Petraeus says it's not working in September
column3: what should the U.S. do then?

column1: TOMMY THOMPSON
column2: FORMER HHS SECRETARY: The first thing the president should do is demand the al-Maliki government to vote as to whether or not they want the United States to stay in Iraq. We've been there four years. Give the government the responsibility of voting.

column1: If they vote ""yes
column2: how are they going to help us win this war? If they vote ""no
column3: we should redeploy our forces outside.

column1: Secondly
column2: there are 18 territories in Iraq
column3: geographically defined. Those 18 territories
column4: just like 50 states in America
column5: should elect their state leaders. And if they do so
column6: the Shiites will elect Shiites
column7: Sunnis will elect Sunnis
column8: Kurds will elect Kurds. And you know something? People will go to those particular territories
column9: and you get rid of this civil war internecine.

column1: Number three...
BLITZER: All right...
THOMPSON: ... I would like to have the oil revenue proceeds -- very quickly -- oil revenue proceeds split: one-third to the federal government
column2: one-third to the states
column3: and one-third to every man
column4: woman and child. And that will get everybody a stake in their country.

column1: BLITZER: Let me bring in Congressman Duncan Hunter.
Congressman
column2: if it's not working at that point
column3: how much longer should the United States stay?

column1: REP. DUNCAN HUNTER (R)
column2: CALIFORNIA: Well
column3: Wolf
column4: you know
column5: I read that NIE report
column6: and I held briefings before we made the vote to go in and invited everybody
column7: Democrat and Republican
column8: to get the classified information.

column1: And this depends -- the turnover of the security apparatus depends on one thing: reliable Iraqi forces.
You've got 129 Iraqi battalions. We've trained them up. We've got a lot of them in the fight. Over the next three to four months
column2: we need to get them all in the fight
column3: get them that combat capability. When they're combat-hardened
column4: we rotate them in
column5: we displace American heavy combat forces off that battlefield
column6: and Americans come home. And
column7: Wolf...

column1: BLITZER: Thank you.
HUNTER: ... I can tell you
column2: as the chairman of the Armed Services Committee for the last four years
column3: I have the credentials to leave Iraq the right way.

column1: BLITZER: Congressman Ron Paul
column2: how much longer should the United States stay in Iraq?

column1: REP. RON PAUL (R)
column2: TEXAS: The sooner we come home
column3: the better. If they declare there's no progress in September
column4: we should come home. It was a mistake to go
column5: so it's a mistake to stay.

column1: If we made the wrong diagnosis
column2: we should change the treatment. So we're not making progress there and we should come home.

column1: The weapons weren't there and we went in under U.N. resolutions. And our national security was not threatened. We're more threatened now by staying.
BLITZER: Governor Huckabee
column2: do you have confidence in the government of Iraq...

column1: (APPLAUSE)
... the government of Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki
column2: that he's going to do what needs to be done?

column1: MIKE HUCKABEE
column2: FORMER GOVERNOR OF ARKANSAS: I think there's some real doubt about that
column3: Wolf.

column1: But I want to remind all of us on this stage and the people in the audience that there's a reason that this is such a struggle. And I think we miss it over here in the West.
Today's the birthday of Ronald Reagan. We all would believe that Ronald Reagan is the one who ended the Cold War and Ronald Reagan is the one who helped bring about the collapse of the Soviet Union.
But there's a group of people who don't believe that
column2: and that's the Taliban. They believe they brought about the demise of the Soviet Union because of the way they fought in Afghanistan.

column1: And what I want to just mention is that it is not the size of the dog in the fight
column2: it is the size of the fight in the dog. And we underestimate -- grossly underestimate how fierce this dog is and how determined they are to destroy every last one of us.

column1: BLITZER: All right.
Congressman Tom Tancredo
column2: what do you say?

column1: REP. TOM TANCREDO (R)
column2: COLORADO: I'll tell you this
column3: that if it comes to that point in that time that you described
column4: that the surge is apparent that it is not working
column5: I did support it. I hope to God it does work. I hope I'm wrong. I hope we pacify Iraq.

column1: However
column2: if it is apparent that we cannot
column3: then we have to do and tell the Iraqis the exact same thing that Benjamin Franklin said when he came out of the convention in 1787 and somebody said to him
column4: ""Dr. Franklin
column5: what have you given us?"" And he said
column6: ""A republic
column7: if you can keep it.""

column1: It is exactly that time and it is exactly that thing that we have to say to the Iraqi government: ""We have given you this. We bought it with our blood and sweat. It is now up to you to keep it.""
And I want the Iraqis to be in fact patrolling Baghdad. If they need vehicles
column2: you let them have the vehicles. But I want them patrolling their city and putting their lives at risk.

column1: Then we move out.
BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Congressman.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
I want to go to the next question. I want to go back to Tom.
Tom
column2: go ahead.

column1: FAHEY: Senator Brownback
column2: President Bush has stated that states that sponsor terrorism are no different than terrorists themselves. Yet Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice recently met with Iranian officials to discuss security in Iraq. Iran is a known support of Hezbollah
column3: Hamas.

column1: Did President Bush make the right call in opening a dialogue with Iran?
BROWNBACK: I think he made a right call on saying that about terrorist states
column2: particularly Iran. But I think we have to at times talk with them in different situations.

column1: Like
column2: before we went into Afghanistan
column3: we talked with Iran. It wasn't we were negotiating. We didn't open up formal diplomatic relations and we shouldn't.

column1: Iran is the lead sponsor of terrorism. Ahmadinejad just this past week called for the destruction of Israel
column2: continues to call for attacking of the United States.

column1: On Iraq
column2: I think we need to talk with them. I think we have to confront them aggressively for what they are
column3: which is the lead sponsor of terrorism in the world. I think we need to push the sanctions forward more aggressively. I think we need to work with the labor union movement that's developing inside of Iran. You had a bus driver strike that recently took place.

column1: And I think we have to show that purpose and resolve
column2: that we're going to confront these guys and we're going to stand with our allies like Israel
column3: we're going to stand against them oppressing and pushing us
column4: and trying to fund terrorists against us.

column1: BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Congressman.

column1: Congressman Hunter
column2: let me bring...

column1: BROWNBACK: Senator
column2: if you don't mind.

column1: BLITZER: Excuse me
column2: Senator.

column1: BROWNBACK: That's OK.
BLITZER: Congressman Hunter
column2: let me bring you back in. Do you agree with Senator Brownback that President Bush made the right decision in opening a direct dialogue with Iran?

column1: HUNTER: With two conditions. And I think that you do have a dialogue with everybody
column2: whether they're adversaries or friends.

column1: The two conditions are: Number one
column2: they are moving deadly equipment across the border that is killing Americans in Iraq.

column1: We have license to utilize anything that we want to use: special operations
column2: intelligence
column3: whatever it takes to stop that deadly equipment from moving across the border and hitting Americans in Iraq. And we don't give that up with these talks.

column1: Secondly
column2: they've got about 1
column3: 000 centrifuges now working
column4: enriching the material that can make
column5: at some point
column6: a nuclear device. The United States reserves the right to preempt
column7: and we may have to preempt that nuclear weapons program. We cannot allow them to have a nuclear device.

column1: With those two caveats
column2: talk to your enemies.

column1: BLITZER: If it came down to a preemptive U.S. strike against Iran's nuclear facility if necessary
column2: would you authorize as president the use of tactical nuclear weapons?

column1: HUNTER: I would authorize the use of tactical nuclear weapons if there was no other way to preempt those particular centrifuges.
When the Osirak reactor was hit in '86
column2: when the six F-18s came over the horizon and knocked that out
column3: they didn't need anything but conventional weapons.

column1: Probably it's going to take a little more than that. I don't think it's going to take tactical nukes.
BLITZER: What do you think
column2: Mayor? Do you think
column3: if you were president of the United States and it came down to Iran having a nuclear bomb
column4: which you say is unacceptable
column5: you would authorize the use of tactical nuclear weapons?

column1: GIULIANI: Part of the premise of talking to Iran has to be that they have to know very clearly that it is unacceptable to the United States that they have nuclear power. I think it could be done with conventional weapons
column2: but you can't rule out anything and you shouldn't take any option off the table.

column1: And during the debate the other night
column2: the Democrats seemed to be back in the 1990s. They don't seem to have gotten beyond the Cold War. Iran is a threat
column3: a nuclear threat
column4: not just because they can deliver a nuclear warhead with missiles. They're a nuclear threat because they are the biggest state sponsor of terrorism and they can hand nuclear materials to terrorists.

column1: And we just saw it just last week in New York
column2: an attempt by Islamist terrorists to attack JFK airport; three weeks ago
column3: an attempt to attack Fort Dix.

column1: These are real problems. This war is not a bumper sticker. This war is a real war.
BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Mayor.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BLITZER: Let me bring Governor Gilmore in.
What do you say about the potential use of tactical nuclear weapons if that's what it takes to go deep underground and destroy those Iraqi facilities?
GILMORE: One of the central problems of the Middle East is the desire for Iran to dominate that portion of the world
column2: because of what they are doing. And that is why I believe that they are seeking this kind of nuclear capacity. That is one of the reasons why we are
column3: in fact
column4: in Iraq.

column1: And that's why our soldiers
column2: when they fight and die there
column3: are in fact serving the interests of the United States. Nobody ought to have any doubt about that.

column1: With respect to Iran
column2: the policy I would follow would be dual.

column1: Number one
column2: we need to work with our European allies in order to put in appropriate sanctions. We need to communicate directly with the Iranians that we are going to offer them an opportunity to work with us.

column1: But we are also going to say that having a nuclear weapon is unacceptable; they need to understand it. And all options are on the table by the United States in that instance.
BLITZER: All right. Thank you
column2: Governor.

column1: Governor Romney
column2: I want to get you on the record. Do you agree with the mayor
column3: the governor
column4: others here
column5: that the use of tactical nuclear weapons
column6: potentially
column7: would be possible if that were the only way to stop Iran from developing a nuclear bomb?

column1: ROMNEY: You don't take options off the table
column2: but what you do is stand back and say
column3: ""What's going on here?"" You see what's happening in Sudan and Afghanistan
column4: in Iraq and Iran. All over the world
column5: we're seeing the same thing happening
column6: and that is people are testing the United States of America. And we have to make sure they understand that we're not arrogant; we have resolve. And we have the strength to protect our interests and to protect people who love liberty.

column1: For that to happen
column2: we're going to have to not just attack each one of these problems one by one
column3: but say
column4: how do we help move the world of Islam so that the moderate Muslims can reject the extreme?

column1: And for that to happen
column2: we're going to have to have a strong military and an effort to combine with our allies in such a way
column3: we combine for an effort to help move Islam toward modernity.

column1: That's what we're going to have to do
column2: instead of looking at each theater one by one and saying
column3: ""We'll bomb here
column4: we'll attack here
column5: we'll go to Sudan.""

column1: I watched the Democrats...
BLITZER: Thank you.
ROMNEY: ... they don't think there's a war on terror.
BLITZER: Thank you.
ROMNEY: There's a war going on
column2: and we need a broad response to make sure that these people have a different vision.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Governor.

column1: All of you are going to have an opportunity to weigh on all of these questions as well.
If you're hearing some sounds out there
column2: it's lightning here in Manchester
column3: New Hampshire. Those are the crackling sounds that you're hearing.

column1: Let's go back to Scott.
SPRADLING: Thanks
column2: Wolf.

column1: Congressman Tancredo
column2: let's talk immigration.

column1: TANCREDO: OK.
SPRADLING: You oppose the immigration reform compromise
column2: calling it
column3: quote
column4: ""the worst piece of legislation to come down the pike in a long time."" Just this morning in Manchester
column5: you vowed to oust any senator who supports the bill
column6: including possibly New Hampshire's senior Senator Judd Gregg
column7: who's undecided
column8: and says to your comments that you are part of the know-nothing wing of the political spectrum.

column1: In the meantime
column2: the president says his plan is the last best chance for serious immigration reform.

column1: He's criticized conservatives for being obstructionists.
With that tension at stake
column2: if this becomes law
column3: what are the consequences for the country?

column1: TANCREDO: They are incredible
column2: and they are disastrous.

column1: And that is exactly why I have said what I've said
column2: and that is why I have consistently tried to impress upon the American public the seriousness of this issue.

column1: We're not just talking about the number of jobs that we may be losing or the number of kids that are in our schools and impacting our school system or the number of people that are abusing our hospital system and taking advantage of the welfare system in this country. We're not just talking about that.
We're talking about something that goes to the very heart of this nation: whether or not we will actually survive as a nation.
And here's what I mean by that.
What we're doing here in this immigration battle is testing our willingness to actually hold together as a nation or split apart into a lot of balkanized pieces.
We are testing our willingness to actually hold on to something called the English language
column2: something that is the glue that is supposed to hold us together as a nation.

column1: We are becoming a bilingual nation. And that is not good.
And that is the fearful part of this. The ramifications are much
column2: much more significant than any that we've been discussing so far.

column1: And so
column2: yes
column3: I have said dramatic things. And
column4: yes
column5: I am willing to do whatever is necessary to try to stop this piece of legislation. And that includes go after any Republican that votes for it
column6: because the Republicans can stop this.

column1: BLITZER: Thank you. Thank you
column2: Congressman.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
Mayor Giuliani
column2: what do you think the consequences for the nation are if this immigration plan proposed by President Bush goes through?

column1: GIULIANI: The problem with this immigration plan is it has no real unifying purpose. It's a typical Washington mess. It's everybody compromises -- four or five compromises.
And the compromises leave you with the following conclusion: The litmus test you should have for legislation is
column2: is it going to make things better? And when you look at these compromises
column3: it is quite possible it will make things worse. The organizing purpose should be that our immigration laws should allow us to identify everyone who is in this country that comes here from a foreign country.

column1: They should have a tamper-proof I.D. card. It should be in a database that allows you to figure out who they are
column2: why they're here
column3: make sure they're not illegal immigrants coming here for a bad purpose
column4: and then to be able to throw out the ones who are not in that database.

column1: We can do that. Credit card companies...
BLITZER: Thank you.
GIULIANI: ... take care of data that is greater than that.
BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Mayor.

column1: I want to get to Senator McCain in a moment
column2: but first
column3: Governor Romney
column4: Senator McCain has accused you of flip-flopping on this issue
column5: in effect.

column1: Yesterday in Miami
column2: he said the following: ""Pandering for votes on this issue while offering no solution to the problem amounts to doing nothing. And doing nothing is silent amnesty.""

column1: What do you say to Senator McCain?
ROMNEY: Well
column2: he's my friend. He campaigned for me two times. I consider him a friend. I'm not going to make this a matter of personal politics. It's an issue that's way too important for that.

column1: My view is that we should enforce our immigration laws.
And this bill
column2: unfortunately
column3: has at least one provision that's a real problem. It's the Z visa.

column1: And what it allows is people who have come here illegally to stay here for the rest of their lives -- not necessarily as citizens; they have to wait 13 years to become citizens. That's not the point.
The point is: Every illegal alien
column2: almost every one
column3: under this bill
column4: gets to stay here. That's not fair to the millions and millions of people around the world that would love to come here
column5: join with family members
column6: bring skill and education that we need.

column1: It's simply not fair to say those people get put ahead in the line of all the people who've been waiting legally to come to this country.
(APPLAUSE)
BLITZER: All right
column2: Senator McCain
column3: this is your chance. I'd like you to respond as someone who is the co-author of this legislation.

column1: MCCAIN: Well
column2: first of all
column3: I agree with Judd Gregg. He's a great senator.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
Second of all
column2: Rudy
column3: you just described our legislation
column4: so I'd be glad to have further conversation with you
column5: because it does account for people who are here illegally.

column1: It does have an employment verification system. And it weeds out those who shouldn't be here
column2: and it gives others a chance to remain in this country.

column1: Look
column2: this is a national security issue
column3: first and foremost. Ever since 9/11
column4: it's a national security issue.

column1: People came to Fort Dix
column2: New Jersey
column3: from across our southern border and tried to kill our soldiers.

column1: For us to do nothing is silent and de facto amnesty.
What we have done is what you expect us to do
column2: my friends
column3: and that's come together with the president of the United States
column4: the leader of our party
column5: Democrat and Republican
column6: conservative Republicans like Jon Kyl
column7: Johnny Isakson
column8: Saxby Chambliss and Trent Lott
column9: and sit down and figure out an approach to this problem.

column1: And it is a serious national security problem.
We need to act
column2: my friends. And if someone else has a better idea
column3: I'd love to have them pursue -- give it to us.

column1: BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Senator.

column1: (LAUGHTER)
(APPLAUSE)
Hold on.
MCCAIN: That can get...
BLITZER: Senator...
(CROSSTALK)
AUDIENCE MEMBER: ... a better idea!
MCCAIN: That will get the support of enough people so that we can pass legislation.
This isn't the bill that I would have written
column2: but it does...

column1: BLITZER: All right. Thank you.
MCCAIN: ... it does satisfy our national security challenges
column2: which are severe and intense. And we cannot 12 million people washing around America illegally
column3: my friends. (CROSSTALK)

column1: MCCAIN: And I hope you'll examine the legislation.
BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Senator.

column1: MCCAIN: And I hope we can move forward with it. And we can make it better.
BLITZER: All right.
MCCAIN: But it's our job to do the hard things...
BLITZER: Mayor
column2: go ahead.

column1: MCCAIN: ... not the easy things.
(APPLAUSE)
GIULIANI: I've read the 400 pages. And this is part of the problem in Washington: They say things and then it's not in the legislation.
There are four or five different methods of identification
column2: not one.

column1: It does not provide information about who exited the United States. Now
column2: tell me how you're going to figure out who's in the United States if you can't figure out who's left the United States.

column1: And finally
column2: it doesn't provide for a uniform database. Many countries have this. The United States doesn't have it.

column1: On September 11th
column2: when we tried to figure out who was in this country
column3: it took weeks to figure out who were the right people and who weren't
column4: because there isn't such a database. And that is a fatal flaw in this legislation. And wishing it away doesn't make it possible.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BLITZER: Governor Romney
column2: what would you do with the 12 million or so illegal immigrants who are
column3: right now
column4: in this country?

column1: ROMNEY: Well
column2: one is to enforce the law as it exists. The law that was passed in 1986...

column1: (APPLAUSE)
The law passed in 1986 asked for us to secure the border and said also to put in place an employment verification system.
Neither one of those was done. So let's make sure that we enforce the law as it exists.
And if you want to improve this bill
column2: well
column3: one thing you could do to make it better is to take that Z visa and make it temporary instead of a permanent right to stay in America. That's simply just not fair.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BLITZER: I want to stay on immigration. Everybody's going to have a chance to weigh in. But let's go back to Tom for another question on immigration.
FAHEY: Congressman Hunter
column2: whether we like it or not
column3: in cities across America
column4: counties across America
column5: including your district in San Diego
column6: illegal immigrants are doing jobs that American citizens don't want
column7: working on farms
column8: in hotels
column9: restaurants.

column1: If you have your way and they all leave this country
column2: who's going to fill those jobs?

column1: HUNTER: Well
column2: first
column3: I disagree with that premise
column4: because when they made the sweep on the Swift plants -- those were the meat- packaging plants in Iowa; took out some 850 people who were working there illegally several months ago -- there were American citizens lined up the next day to get their jobs back at 18 bucks an hour.

column1: And let me tell you
column2: this is a disastrous bill. And John McCain is right in saying that this is a national security issue. And it is: border enforcement.

column1: Then the Hunter bill
column2: which was signed by the president on the 26th of October
column3: mandating 854 miles of double fence -- not that scraggly
column4: little fence you show on CNN all the time
column5: Wolf
column6: that people get across so easily.

column1: If they get across my fence
column2: we sign them up for the Olympics immediately.

column1: (LAUGHTER)
We've got a big fence.
But 854 miles of double border fence was mandated to be constructed. Homeland Security has a billion bucks
column2: cash on hand. It's been six months
column3: and they've done 11 miles.

column1: So this administration has a case of the slows. And I think they slowed the fence down so that they could come out with the amnesty at the same time
column2: put the two together
column3: and the Bush-McCain-Kennedy bill would then be accepted by conservatives and liberals alike.

column1: It's a bad bill.
BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Congressman.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
Senator Brownback
column2: what do you say about this notion of a pathway toward citizenship for these 12 million illegal immigrants who are in the country right now? Under what circumstances would you let them begin that path?

column1: BROWNBACK: I don't think you create any new paths to citizenship. But I also think you allow them to be able to use paths that they would currently qualify for
column2: and to be able to get in the back of "	0

column1: 203	"Puerto Rican born and raised
column2: Colonel Michael A. Valle (Ã¢ÂÂTorchÃ¢ÂÂ)
column3: Commander
column4: 101st Air and Space Operations Group
column5: and Director of the Joint Air Component Coordination Element
column6: 1st Air Force
column7: responsible for Hurricane Maria relief efforts
column8: has the following comment:

column1: Ã¢ÂÂ¦They have the generators
column2: water
column3: food
column4: medicine
column5: and fuel on the ground
column6: yet the supplies are not moving across the island as quickly as theyÃ¢ÂÂre needed.

column1: Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs a lack of drivers for the transport trucks
column2: the 18 wheelers. Supplies we have. Trucks we have. There are ships full of supplies
column3: backed up in the ports
column4: waiting to have a vehicle to unload into. However
column5: only 20% of the truck drivers show up to work. These are private citizens in Puerto Rico
column6: paid by companies that are contracted by the governmentÃ¢ÂÂ.. (link)"	1

column1: 204	"Editor's note: This is part one of the transcript for the Democratic presidential debate sponsored by CNN and the Congressional Black Caucus Institute on January 21
column2: 2008. Click here to connect to part two or part three.

column1: Sen. Hillary Clinton
column2: Sen. Barack Obama and former Sen. John Edwards answered questions from CNN's Wolf Blitzer
column3: Joe Johns and Suzanne Malveaux in a debate sponsored by CNN and the Congressional Black Caucus Institute
column4: Monday night.

column1: Hillary Clinton
column2: left
column3: Barack Obama
column4: center
column5: and John Edwards answer questions on Monday night.

column1: JOE JOHNS
column2: CNN: Senator Clinton
column3: good evening.

column1: The number-one issue for Americans of both parties is the economy
column2: and today the news is simply not good. Markets around the world are in a tailspin because of fears of a U.S. recession. So far this year
column3: the Dow has lost nearly 9 percent.

column1: How much money would your stimulus plan put in the pockets of the average South Carolinian?
SEN. HILLARY CLINTON: Well
column2: Joe
column3: I'm glad you started with the economy
column4: because that is the number-one issue. What's been happening in the markets
column5: what's been happening with the home mortgage crisis
column6: $100-a- barrel oil
column7: so many of the issues that are really at the kitchen tables of Americans today and what they're talking to me about.

column1: We have to stimulate the economy. I began calling for some kind of economic action plan back at the beginning of December. I have a package of $110 billion; $70 billion of that would go towards dealing with the mortgage crisis
column2: which
column3: unfortunately
column4: I don't think that President Bush has really taken seriously enough.

column1: I would have a moratorium on home foreclosures for 90 days to try to help families work it out so that they don't lose their homes. We're in danger of seeing millions of Americans become basically
column2: you know
column3: homeless and losing the American dream.

column1: I want to have an interest rate freeze for five years
column2: because these adjustable-rate mortgages
column3: if they keep going up
column4: the problem will just get compounded. And we need more transparency in the market.

column1: Then
column2: I think we need to give people about $650
column3: if they qualify -- which will be millions of people -- to help pay their energy bills this winter. You know
column4: there are so many people on fixed incomes and working people who are not going to be able to afford the spike in energy costs.

column1: We need to make sure that we start jumpstarting the jobs in this country again. That's why I want to put money into clean energy jobs
column2: green-collar jobs
column3: and also make sure we have a fund that will help communities deal with the consequences of the home foreclosure crisis and make sure the unemployment system is up to the task.

column1: And then we will have money for rebates
column2: but let's make them the right rebates. Everything we know about President Bush's plans would leave 50 million to 70 million Americans out
column3: because a lot of our seniors on fixed incomes don't pay income taxes. But that doesn't mean they're immune from the energy costs and the health care costs and everything else that's going up around them.

column1: And we have a huge number of working people who thankfully don't pay income tax. They pay payroll tax. They pay a lot of other taxes. President Bush's plan would do nothing to help them.
But thankfully we've got leaders of the Congressional Black Caucus here who are going to make sure that we get the right kind of stimulus. And that's what the Democrats are going to support.
It's imperative we do it. It's a part of economic justice
column2: which on Dr. King's holiday is part of his unfinished legacy.

column1: WOLF BLITZER
column2: CNN: All right.

column1: Senator Obama?
(APPLAUSE)
SEN. BARACK OBAMA: Well
column2: we do meet on the King holiday. And I think it's important to remember that
column3: in the march on Washington
column4: where Dr. King always talks about -- or it's always repeated
column5: the dream speech that is so famous -- that march was for jobs
column6: as well as justice.

column1: And
column2: unfortunately
column3: we have not made the kind of progress that we need in having a balanced economy
column4: and George Bush has made it worse.

column1: George Bush has consistently skewed our tax code to the wealthy. He has squandered billions of dollars in a war that I believe should never have been authorized and should have never been waged.
(APPLAUSE)
We have not made the investments that are needed in our school system. You travel around South Carolina along the corridor of shame
column2: and you've got children who are going to schools that were built in the 1800s. And they are not able to compete in an international economy.

column1: So it is absolutely critical right now to give a stimulus to the economy. And Senator Clinton mentioned tax rebates. That wasn't the original focus of her plan. I think recently she has caught up with what I had originally said
column2: which is we've got to get taxes into the -- tax cuts into the pockets of hard-working Americans right away.

column1: And it is important for us to make sure that they are not just going to the wealthy. They should be going to folks who are making $75
column2: 000 a year or less
column3: and they should be going to folks who only pay payroll tax
column4: but typically are not paying income tax.

column1: If we do that
column2: then not only can we stimulate the economy
column3: those are the folks who are most likely to spend money right away.

column1: BLITZER: Do you agree with her
column2: $650 is a good number for a tax rebate?

column1: OBAMA: Well
column2: I think that we are going to have to get some immediate money. What I do is I say
column3: for a typical family
column4: $500 for a tax rebate per family.

column1: But also
column2: for senior citizens
column3: get a supplement to their Social Security check
column4: because they get that every month. We know exactly how to do it. And that would provide seniors all across the country right away some money to help pay for their heating bills and other expenses that they've got right now.

column1: BLITZER: Correct me if I'm wrong
column2: Senator Edwards. Your plan does not call for a tax rebate
column3: does it?

column1: FORMER SEN. JOHN EDWARDS: No
column2: that's exactly right. Can I start by saying how proud I am to be here tonight
column3: a debate sponsored by the Congressional Black Caucus on Dr. King's holiday?

column1: And particularly on this night
column2: when we're honoring the legacy of Dr. King
column3: central to his work was the idea of fighting for real equality between the races
column4: fighting to end poverty in America
column5: his famous Poor People's Campaign
column6: which he was engaged in at the time of his death
column7: fighting for garbage workers
column8: actually
column9: in Memphis.

column1: And the chasm between the rich and the poor in America is wide. It is getting worse. The rich are get richer. And we've added five million people to the poverty rolls in just over the course of the last seven years
column2: which is...

column1: BLITZER: But what about the stimulus package?

EDWARDS: Here's what we should do. That's why I'm getting to this. What Bush does is he leaves 50 million -- as Hillary pointed out -- 50 million Americans. They're low-income Americans and moderate-income Americans. They are completely left out of the stimulus package.
If we're actually going to deal with the legacy of Dr. King
column2: if we're going to deal with this issue of poverty -- and I have a comprehensive plan to do that
column3: it is the cause of my life
column4: to end poverty in this country -- we also have to include all Americans in this stimulus plan.

column1: Now
column2: one difference between what I have proposed and what my two colleagues have proposed is I have done something that not only stimulates the economy
column3: but creates long-term benefits
column4: investment in green infrastructure
column5: which creates jobs.

column1: Instead of just getting money out in the short term
column2: this will actually create jobs over the long term
column3: create green infrastructure.

column1: Yes
column2: we need to do something about the mortgage crisis. I want to mention one last thing.

column1: There is one other issue that was mentioned in passing by the two of them
column2: which is the issue of jobs. And there is a difference between myself and my colleagues on this issue of jobs
column3: because they both supported the Peru trade deal.

column1: My view is the Peru trade deal was similar to NAFTA. And this is crucial to the state of South Carolina...
BLITZER: But...
EDWARDS: ... no
column2: no -- and crucial to the state of the South Carolina and jobs in South Carolina. South Carolina has been devastated by NAFTA and trade deals like NAFTA.

column1: BLITZER: I just want to be precise. What you're proposing are really long-term objectives. In terms of a short-term stimulus package
column2: you disagree with them on an immediate tax rebate.

column1: EDWARDS: No
column2: no. What I'm saying is if we do what we should do to green the economy
column3: if we change our unemployment insurance laws
column4: modernize them to make them available to more people
column5: to more Americans
column6: if we in fact give help to the states
column7: which gets money straight into the economy and we deal with the mortgage crisis in a serious way with a home rescue fund to provide transitional financing for those people who are about to lose their homes
column8: all those things will stimulate the economy.

column1: BLITZER: I'll let both of you respond
column2: but let me let Senator Obama respond first.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
OBAMA: Let me just respond to a couple of things. I think the idea of bringing jobs is important
column2: which is why that's central to my energy plan. But
column3: Wolf
column4: you're exactly right
column5: that is a long-term agenda. That is not going to deal with the immediate crisis we have right now.

column1: You've got the European markets dropped 5 percent. The expectation is that the Dow Jones tomorrow may do the same. We could be sliding into an extraordinary recession unless we stimulate the economy immediately. That's point number one.
Point number two
column2: on trade
column3: John is exactly right that you travel around South Carolina and you see the textile mills that John's father worked in closed
column4: all over the region. And it is absolutely true that NAFTA was a mistake.

column1: I know that Hillary on occasion has said -- just last year said this was a boon to the economy. I think it has been devastating
column2: because our trade agreements did not have labor standards and environmental standards that would assure that workers in the U.S. were getting a square deal.

column1: But the only thing I want to differ on John is this whole notion of Peru. The Peru trade deal had labor and environmental agreements in it. Peru is an economy the size of New Hampshire. Over 90 percent of the goods coming from Peru already come in under various free trade agreements.
And
column2: John
column3: you voted for permanent trade relations with China
column4: which I think anybody who looks at how we structure trade in this country would tell you has been the biggest beneficiary and the biggest problem that we have with respect to trade
column5: particularly because they're still manipulating the currency.

column1: BLITZER: I'll let you respond
column2: but
column3: Senator Clinton
column4: I want to get back to the issue of an immediate stimulus for the economy.

column1: CLINTON: That's what I want to get back to.
BLITZER: Because who knows what the markets are going to be like tomorrow and there are a lot of people out there who are suffering already. But go ahead and respond.
CLINTON: Well
column2: I want to just clarify a couple of points. My original plan was $70 billion in spending with a $40 billion contingency that was part of the original plan
column3: in order to have that money available for tax rebates.

column1: I hope that we could do it through spending
column2: and here's why: I don't want to necessarily open up the tax code while we've got Republicans in the Senate who are going to try to come back and open up making Bush's tax cuts permanent.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
I understand that that's a real risk. So I was hoping to be able to do it through spending
column2: but the crisis has gotten too deep
column3: and what happened in the markets globally today is a huge wakeup call.

column1: The president should convene the working group on financial markets. He should ask the secretary of treasury to do this immediately. I know that there's been talking going on
column2: but the president's proposed stimulus package is not adequate. It is too little too late and it doesn't give enough money to the people who are hardest hit by the increased costs in energy and everything else.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
As a further point
column2: I do believe that the green-collar job piece of this is important. That's why I have $5 billion to do it. There are programs already. Oakland
column3: California
column4: Mayor Dellums is working to have a green-collar job program. We could put hundreds and hundreds of young people to work right now
column5: putting solar panels in
column6: insulating homes.

column1: That would give them jobs and it would move us more quickly to a green economy. And I think that if you look at this from a jobs and justice
column2: a stimulation and long-term planning effort
column3: we need to lay down the markers now. And that's why the Congress
column4: under the leadership of a lot of the people who are chairs of committees and subcommittees who are here today are going to play a major role in this. And we've got to hold the line against President Bush with his ill-advised approach to stimulating the economy.

column1: BLITZER: All right. We're staying on topic. We're staying on this subject
column2: but I want to ask Suzanne Malveaux to ask a question and then all of you will be able to weigh...

column1: EDWARDS: You have to give me a chance to respond to Senator Obama.
BLITZER: All right
column2: go ahead
column3: respond quickly and then Suzanne.

column1: EDWARDS: Thank you.
Well
column2: first of all
column3: what I have proposed for green-collar jobs will create jobs within 30 or so days
column4: so we will have an immediate impact on the economy and stimulate the economy. Second
column5: no one has to explain to me what these trade deals have done to South Carolina
column6: to North Carolina. My father
column7: who's sitting right out there in the audience
column8: worked in the mills for 36 years and we have seen what these trade deals have done to people who have worked hard all their lives.

column1: EDWARDS: And the problem with Peru
column2: Barack
column3: is you are leaving the enforcement of environmental and labor regulations in the hands of George Bush.

column1: I wouldn't trust George Bush to enforce anything
column2: certainly no trade obligations.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BLITZER: All right. Ten seconds
column2: go ahead.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
OBAMA: Well
column2: the only point I would make is that in a year's time
column3: it'll be me who's enforcing them.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
And so we're going to make sure that the right thing is being done. And
column2: John
column3: you tell an extraordinarily powerful story. I mean
column4: you understand what's happened with respect to trade here and I think it is powerful when you talk about it.

column1: But keep in mind
column2: I first moved to Chicago to be a community organizer with churches who were trying to deal with the devastation of steel plants that had closed in that region. And so I spent 3.5 years working alongside folks who had lost their jobs.

column1: And I know what it's like for families to have put their life and their heart and soul into a company
column2: building profits for shareholders
column3: and then suddenly they had the rug pulled out from under them. Not only have they lost their job
column4: they've lost their health care
column5: they've lost their pension benefits.

column1: And it is absolutely critical for us to understand that NAFTA was an enormous problem. The permanent trade relations with China
column2: without some of the enforcement mechanisms that were in there
column3: that you voted for
column4: was also a significant problem.

column1: And we've got to all move forward as Democrats to make sure that we've got trade deals that work for working people and not just for corporate profits.
BLITZER: All right. Suzanne Malveaux
column2: go ahead.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
SUZANNE MALVEAUX
column2: CNN: I'd like to follow-up with Senator Obama. It was just a few days ago that Senator Clinton asserted that she was the strongest candidate when it comes to fiscal responsibility.

column1: She says that the new programs that she proposes she essentially can pay for. She says that you have failed in that regard in the tune of some $50 billion worth of new programs that you cannot account for.
How do you respond to that charge?
OBAMA: What she said wasn't true. We account for every single dollar that we propose.
Now
column2: this
column3: I think
column4: is one of the things that's happened during the course of this campaign
column5: that there's a set of assertions made by Senator Clinton
column6: as well as her husband
column7: that are not factually accurate.

column1: And I think that part of what the people are looking for right now is somebody who's going to solve problems and not resort to the same typical politics that we've seen in Washington.
(APPLAUSE)

That is something that I hear all across the country. So when Senator Clinton says -- or President Clinton says that I wasn't opposed to the war from the start or says it's a fairytale that I opposed the war
column2: that is simply not true.

column1: When Senator Clinton or President Clinton asserts that I said that the Republicans had had better economic policies since 1980
column2: that is not the case.

column1: Now
column2: the viewers aren't concerned with this kind of back-and- forth. What they're concerned about is who's actually going to help the get health care
column3: how are they going to get their kids...

column1: (APPLAUSE)
... going to college
column2: and that's the kind of campaign I've tried to run. I think that's the kind of campaign we should all try to run.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
CLINTON: Well
column2: I couldn't agree more. But I do think that your record and what you say does matter. And when it comes to...

column1: (APPLAUSE)
... a lot of the issues that are important in this race
column2: it is sometimes difficult to understand what Senator Obama has said
column3: because as soon as he is confronted on it
column4: he says that's not what he meant.

column1: The facts are that he has said in the last week that he really liked the ideas of the Republicans over the last 10 to 15 years
column2: and we can give you the exact quote.

column1: Now
column2: I personally think they had ideas
column3: but they were bad ideas. They were bad ideas for America.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
They were ideas like privatizing Social Security
column2: like moving back from a balanced budget and a surplus to deficit and debt.

column1: And with respect to putting forth how one would pay for all of the programs that we're proposing in this campaign
column2: I will be more than happy
column3: Barack
column4: to get the information
column5: because we have searched for it.

column1: You have a lot of money that you want to put into foreign aid
column2: a very worthy program. There is no evidence from your Web site
column3: from your speeches
column4: as to how you would pay for it.

column1: Now
column2: why is this important? It's important because I think elections are about the future. But how do you determine what will happen in the future? Well
column3: you have to look to the record
column4: you have to look to what we say in campaigns
column5: and what we have done during our careers.

column1: And I want to be just very explicit about this. We are not
column2: neither my campaign nor anyone associated with it
column3: are in any way saying you did not oppose the war in Iraq.

column1: CLINTON: You did. You gave a great speech in 2002 opposing the war in Iraq. That was not what the point of our criticism was.
It was after having given that speech
column2: by the next year the speech was off your Web site. By the next year
column3: you were telling reporters that you agreed with President Bush in his conduct of the war. And by the next year
column4: when you were in the Senate
column5: you were voting to fund the war time after time after time.

column1: BLITZER: All right.
CLINTON: So it was more about the distinction between words and action. And I think that is a fair assessment for voters to make.
(APPLAUSE)
BLITZER: OK. Thank you
column2: Senator. Senator
column3: we're a little off topic. I have to let Senator Obama respond
column4: then Senator Edwards
column5: who's going to come...

column1: OBAMA: We're off topic
column2: but...

column1: BLITZER: But go ahead and respond
column2: and then I want to get back to this issue that we're talking about
column3: fiscal responsibility. But go ahead.

column1: OBAMA: Let's talk about it.
Hillary
column2: I will be happy to provide you with the information about all -- all the spending that we do. Now
column3: let's talk about Ronald Reagan. What you just repeated here today is...

column1: CLINTON: Barack...
OBAMA: Wait. No. Hillary
column2: you just spoke.

column1: CLINTON: I did not say anything about Ronald Reagan.
OBAMA: You just spoke for two minutes.
CLINTON: You said two things.
OBAMA: You just...
CLINTON: You talked about admiring Ronald Reagan and you talked about the ideas...
OBAMA: Hillary
column2: I'm sorry. You just...

column1: BLITZER: Senator...
CLINTON: I didn't talk about Reagan.
OBAMA: Hillary
column2: we just had the tape. You just said that I complimented the Republican ideas. That is not true.

column1: What I said -- and I will provide you with a quote -- what I said was is that Ronald Reagan was a transformative political figure because he was able to get Democrats to vote against their economic interests to form a majority to push through their agenda
column2: an agenda that I objected to. Because while I was working on those streets watching those folks see their jobs shift overseas
column3: you were a corporate lawyer sitting on the board at Wal-Mart.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
OBAMA: I was fighting these fights. I was fighting these fights. So -- but I want to be clear.

So I want to be clear. What I said had nothing to do with their policies. I spent a lifetime fighting a lifetime against Ronald Reagan's policies. But what I did say is that we have to be thinking in the same transformative way about our Democratic agenda.
We've got to appeal to Independents and Republicans in order to build a working majority to move an agenda forward. That is what I said.
(APPLAUSE)
OBAMA: Now
column2: you can dispute that
column3: but let me finish.

column1: Hillary
column2: you went on for two minutes. Let me finish.

column1: The irony of this is that you provided much more fulsome praise of Ronald Reagan in a book by Tom Brokaw that's being published right now
column2: as did -- as did Bill Clinton in the past. So these are the kinds of political games that we are accustomed to.

column1: CLINTON: Now
column2: wait a minute.

column1: Wolf
column2: wait a minute. Wait a minute. Just a minute.

column1: BLITZER: Senator Edwards
column2: let them wrap up. Then I'm going to come to you.

column1: Yes?
CLINTON: I just want -- I just to clarify -- I want to clarify the record. Wait a minute.
EDWARDS: There's a third person in this debate.
BLITZER: Wait a minute
column2: Senator Edwards. Hold on.

column1: There has been a specific charge leveled against Hillary Clinton
column2: so she can respond. Then I'll bring in Senator Edwards.

column1: CLINTON: I just want to be sure...
OBAMA: Go ahead and address what you said about...
BLITZER: We have got a long time to. You'll have a good opportunity.
CLINTON: We're just getting warmed up.
(APPLAUSE)
CLINTON: Now
column2: I just -- I just want to be clear about this. In an editorial board with the Reno newspaper
column3: you said two different things
column4: because I have read the transcript. You talked about Ronald Reagan being a transformative political leader. I did not mention his name.

column1: OBAMA: Your husband did.
CLINTON: Well
column2: I'm here. He's not. And...

column1: OBAMA: OK. Well
column2: I can't tell who I'm running against sometimes.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
CLINTON: Well
column2: you know
column3: I think we both have very passionate and committed spouses who stand up for us. And I'm proud of that.

column1: But you also talked about the Republicans having ideas over the last 10 to 15 years.
OBAMA: I didn't say they were good ones.
CLINTON: Well
column2: you can read the context of it.

column1: OBAMA: Well
column2: I didn't say they were good ones.

column1: CLINTON: Well
column2: it certainly...

column1: OBAMA: All right
column2: Wolf.

column1: CLINTON: It certainly came across in the way that it was presented
column2: as though the Republicans had been standing up against the conventional wisdom with their ideas. I'm just reacting to the fact
column3: yes
column4: they did have ideas
column5: and they were bad ideas.

column1: OBAMA: I agree.
CLINTON: Bad for America
column2: and I was fighting against those ideas when you were practicing law and representing your contributor
column3: Resco
column4: in his slum landlord business in inner city Chicago.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
OBAMA: No
column2: no
column3: no.

column1: BLITZER: Hold on one second. Hold on.
Senator Edwards -- Senator Edwards has been remarkably patient during this exchange. And I want him -- I don't know if you want to get involved in this
column2: Senator Edwards.

column1: EDWARDS: What I want to say first is
column2: are there three people in this debate
column3: not two?

column1: (APPLAUSE)
EDWARDS: And I also want to know -- I also want to know on behalf of voters here in South Carolina
column2: this kind of squabbling
column3: how many children is this going to get health care? How many people are going to get an education from this? How many kids are going to be able to go to college because of this?

column1: EDWARDS: We have got to understand -- you know
column2: and I respect both of my fellow candidates -- but we have got to understand this is not about us personally. It is about...

column1: (APPLAUSE)
... what we are trying to do for this country and what we believe in.
Now
column2: fiscal responsibility
column3: which I think was the question. It was a little hard to tell there at the end of that. But I think the question was about fiscal responsibility.

column1: I have proposed
column2: I think
column3: the most aggressive
column4: most progressive agenda of the three of us up here. And I was the first to come out with a universal health care plan
column5: first to come out with a global warming plan
column6: first -- and
column7: to the best of my knowledge
column8: only at this point -- to come out with a comprehensive
column9: detailed plan to end poverty in America
column10: since we are on Dr. King's day.

column1: This is the cause of my life. Everything I have proposed
column2: I have come up with a way to pay for it. And I've been very explicit about how it should be paid for
column3: not abstract
column4: not rhetoric
column5: very
column6: very explicit.

column1: But I do have to say
column2: in response to something Senator Clinton said just a minute ago
column3: both Senator Obama and I have said Social Security needs a solution. And we have said we won't privatize
column4: we won't cut benefits
column5: we won't raise the retirement age. Same thing that Hillary has said.

column1: But she has proposed nothing about how we're going to create revenue to keep Social Security alive and talked about fiscal responsibility. Here's the problem: If you don't have -- this is not complicated. The American people understand it. If you've got more money going out than is coming in
column2: you're going to eventually run out of money.

column1: And you've got to have a way to pay for it
column2: which is why -- now
column3: let me finish this. Lord knows you let them go on forever.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
What I'm saying is we have to be consistent in what we're saying. I have said I think Hillary doesn't want to talk about raising taxes. Let's just be honest about that.
Barack and I have both said that you've got to do something about the cap on Social Security taxes
column2: which is now capped at $97
column3: 000. It means if somebody is making $80
column4: 000 a year
column5: every dime of their income is taxed for Social Security. But if you are making $50 million a year
column6: only the first $97
column7: 000 is taxed.

column1: That's not right. And people ought to be paying their Social Security taxes. But the American people deserve to know what we're going to do.
We can disagree. There's nothing wrong with that
column2: so they can make an informed choice
column3: but they at least deserve to know where they stand and what we'd do.

column1: BLITZER: We're staying on the economy
column2: but I want Joe Johns to ask another question so we can continue this dialogue.

column1: JOHNS: All right. Well
column2: Senator Edwards
column3: let's dig a little deeper on the economic mess we're in currently.

column2: a study from the Center for Responsible Lending found that African-Americans are something like 30 percent more likely to be sold a subprime loan than white borrowers with similar credit histories and income.

column1: The South Carolina NAACP said last month that the American dream for too many Americans
column2: too many African-Americans is a national nightmare. The national NAACP has even filed a class-action lawsuit against 12 nationwide lenders.

column1: So the bottom-line question really is: Do you believe that lenders have specifically targeted African-Americans? Is this subprime mess really also an issue of race?
EDWARDS: Yes
column2: is the answer. I think they have targeted -- if they haven't been racially motivated
column3: I don't know. There's no way for me to know what's inside their head.

column1: But what they have done is they have targeted the lowest income
column2: most vulnerable families. And anybody who's paying any attention to what's going on in America today understands
column3: if you are African- American in this country today
column4: you are likely to have a net worth of about 10 percent of what white families have.

column1: This is not an accident. I mean
column2: we can go put our heads against the wall and pretend that the past never happened
column3: pretend that we didn't live through decades of slavery
column4: followed by decades of segregation
column5: followed by decades of discrimination
column6: which is still going on today.

column1: (APPLAUSE)

That history and that legacy has consequences. And the consequence has been that African-American families are more vulnerable. They're more vulnerable to payday lenders. They're more vulnerable to predatory lenders
column2: which is why we desperately need a national law
column3: which I have proposed
column4: which would crack down on these predatory payday lenders.

column1: It's not enough to do it state-by-state
column2: because these predators just move from place to place to place.

column1: I was in a neighborhood in Cleveland a few months ago
column2: one-block radius
column3: 38 houses under foreclosure
column4: middle-class
column5: African-American neighborhood. These people work. They put everything they had into their homes. And they were about to lose them because these predators have come into the neighborhood and taken everything they have.

column1: So here are the solutions. Number one
column2: we need a national predatory lending law. Number two
column3: we've got to help low-income families save.

column1: EDWARDS: They have nothing to fall back on. Many have no bank account. They don't deal with financial institutions. We need to teach financial literacy
column2: we need to match what they're able to save so that they actually have something that they can fall back on in case they get in a place where they need more money.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BLITZER: All right. I want both Senator Clinton and Senator Obama to respond.
But
column2: briefly
column3: Senator Clinton
column4: your proposal calls for a five- year moratorium on interest rates
column5: 90-day moratorium on foreclosure
column6: five year keeping those interest rates the same. Alan Greenspan suggested that we simply have to let this housing crisis exhaust itself. Trying to prevent the housing markets from going down merely prolongs the agony.

column1: Does your plan
column2: as he would seem to be suggesting
column3: prolong the agony?

column1: CLINTON: No. I think it helps to mitigate the agony. I mean
column2: what I hear as I go in and out of people's homes and talk to so many who have already lost their homes
column3: they're in foreclosure
column4: they see these interest rates that are about to go up and they know they can't pay them
column5: is that we take action now.

column1: I've been calling for action since last March. When I first started calling for it
column2: a lot of the same economists who now say don't do anything about it said
column3: well
column4: it won't be that bad. We'll be able to weather the crisis.

column1: Well
column2: the fact is
column3: the mortgage crisis is not only destroying the dreams of Americans for home ownership
column4: it is having a ripple effect across the world. So my moratorium for 90 days is a work-out. It's not a bailout. I want people to be able to see whether they can stay in their homes paying a rate that is affordable for them.

column1: And the interest rate freeze is I think merited
column2: because look at what's happening -- if you're a big bank that helped get us into this mess
column3: you go borrow money from Abu Dhabi or somewhere. If you're a homeowner who has been at the bottom of this incredible scheme that was established
column4: you're left holding the bag and you don't have the house anymore.

column1: BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Senator.

column1: CLINTON: So I just disagree with those who say don't try to do anything to help the people who need the help right now.
BLITZER: Senator Obama.
OBAMA: I think that we need to help them. I think it is important to make sure that we're not helping out the speculators
column2: but instead are helping out the homeowners who are actually living in their homes
column3: who have the capacity to make the payments if they're not seeing a huge increase in their mortgage payments.

column1: But understand this
column2: this is not new. We have a history in this country of preying on low-income peoples because they don't have access to banks. The Community Reinvestment Act is oftentimes not enforced as it should be.

column1: We've got to open up bank branches. We've got to give people access to financing so that they're not going to a payday loan operation.
I two years ago introduced a provision that would eliminate predatory lending
column2: something that I had already helped to get passed at the state level. But it is important for us to understand that we've got to give ordinary working people access to financing. And it's important to understand that part of the reason that they are borrowing on their homes
column3: they're borrowing on credit cards
column4: is that the banks and financial institutions have dominated policy in Washington.

column1: And this is an area where I've got a policy disagreement with Senator Clinton. Wh"	0
205	"Barton: Medicare Drug Program Drawing Participants by the Thousands WASHINGTON - U.S. Rep. Joe Barton
column2: R-Texas
column3: chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee
column4: made the following statement today during the full committee hearing on the Administration's FY '07 Health Care Priorities: ""Good afternoon. Let me begin by welcoming Secretary Michael Leavitt today to the Energy and Commerce Committee. We look forward to hearing him testify about the Administration's Fiscal Year 2007 Health Care Priorities. ""First
column5: Mr. Secretary
column6: I want to thank you for your assistance in developing the important reforms we put into place for the Medicaid program starting this year. As a former governor yourself
column7: you understood and appreciated the need to improve this program. Through passage of the Deficit Reduction Act
column8: we will sustain Medicaid for those people who most often need health care and to get good get their health care through good jobs in a thriving economy instead of from a government welfare program. The reforms we adopted recently are beginning to rescue the program from the threat of financial collapse. I look forward to working with you to see that the governors get the tools they need to better manage the program and deliver its benefits to the poor of their states. ""I want to briefly highlight at least some of the changes in the law that have not recently received the public attention that they deserve. According to the Congressional Budget Office
column10: 000 disabled children covered by the Family Opportunity Act will receive improved health care services as a result of the recently passed Deficit Reduction Act. The new law will provide access to new home and community based care to 120
column11: 000 individuals; and it will facilitate 100
column12: 000 nursing home residents to return to their communities through the Administration's Money Follows the Person Demonstration. These are the true results of Medicaid reform - better access to better care for those who most need our assistance. ""There is still much to be done to improve long-term care service delivery and financing as well as to promote Medicaid managed care. I have received the administration's proposals regarding additional improvement to the Medicaid program and I look forward to working with you this year on them. ""This year the secretary and the administration also are required to administer the new Medicare prescription drug benefit. Making this program succeed is a high priority of yours
column13: and it is a high priority of this committee that I chair. ""Since it began
column14: critics have tried to make patients believe that they are not smart enough to understand the new Medicare drug benefit
column15: that it provides inadequate coverage
column16: and that signing up isn't worth their time because it cannot save them any money. The critics are simply wrong. They were wrong when they complained about the Medicare prescription drug card. They were wrong when they said nobody would offer any insurance plans. And they are wrong now. ""Some sense political advantage in condemning the program and others can't bring themselves to admit that free markets actually work. Transparency and competition will drive down prices and provide lower costs to consumers. Even if the critics don't get it
column17: Medicare beneficiaries certainly do. That is why over 3.6 million Medicare beneficiaries have already signed up for the new benefit. You told me earlier today that there are close to 24 million Americans that have been enrolled in the program
column19: and enrollment is increasing at approximately 250
column20: 000 people per week. That sounds like a success story to me. If you add that to the fact that the premiums which we estimated at $37 a month is now down to an average $27 per month
column21: that appears to me to be a successful program. ""This is a huge undertaking and there are going to be glitches. My goal is the same as yours: Get rid of the glitches. The committee will work closely with yourself and Dr. Mark McClellan at CMS to get problems noticed and solved. We will have the first of what will likely be several hearings on this topic on March 1
column22: when Dr. McClellan will testify before the Health subcommittee. I expect that we ask him very direct questions about where the problems are and what CMS is doing to fix them. ""Another high priority for the committee will be the reauthorization of the National Institutes of Health (NIH) and related programs. I want to restate my deep commitment to reauthorizing the NIH and would ask for the secretary's assistance in working out the technical details so that we can enact this long overdue legislation. In addition
column23: the authorization for the Ryan White CARE Act has now lapsed. I believe that funding unauthorized programs is not a responsible practice
