209	"McCain renews attacks on Obama links to radical
MIAMI
column2: Florida (AFP) Ã¢ÂÂ Republican John McCain renewed his attacks on Barack Obama's ties to a 1960s radical here Wednesday as he targeted voters in the key battleground state of Florida.

column1: McCain
column2: who has refrained from linking Obama to Bill Ayers during recent campaign speeches
column3: went back on the offensive six days before the November 4 polls in an interview with a Spanish-language radio station in Miami.

column1: I think this whole issue of the relationship with Bill Ayers needs to be known by the American people
column2: he told Radio Mambi. ""Senator Obama said it was just a guy in the neighborhood. We know much more than that.""

column1: Ayers was a member of the ""Weathermen"" movement
column2: classified by the FBI as a ""domestic terrorist organization
column3: which carried out a series of attacks to protest the Vietnam War
column4: including on the Pentagon and US Capitol.

column1: Obama met Ayers early in his political career in 1995 but his campaign has said he has not spoken by phone or exchanged e-mail messages with him since Obama became US senator in 2005.
McCain went on to accuse the Los Angeles Times of refusing to publish a video it had obtained of Ayers attending an event with a member of the Palestine Liberation Organization (PLO).
I don't care much about an old
column2: washed-up unrepentant terrorist
column3: and his wife who was on an FBI top 10 wanted list
column4: McCain said.

column1: But we should know about their relationship
column2: including apparently information that is held by the Los Angeles Times concerning an event that Mr Ayers attended with a PLO spokesman.""

column1: McCain appeared to be referring to a Los Angeles Times article from April which said Obama knew and attended a farewell party for Rashid Khalidi
column2: a former PLO spokesman
column3: during his academic career in Chicago. The article makes no mention of Ayers's presence at the event.

column1: The Los Angeles Times refuses to make that videotape public. I'm not in the business of talking about media bias but what if there was a tape with John McCain with a neo-Nazi outfit being held by some media outlet?
I think the treatment of the issue would be slightly different
column2: he said
column3: saying Ayers had a ""long relationship"" with Obama
column4: who was eight years old when the Weathermen were waging their radical campaign.

column1: It's not that Barack Obama was eight years old when Mr Ayers was committing acts of terror
column2: it's all about the long relationship on foundations
column3: for his book and launching his political career in Mr Ayers living room
column4: McCain said.

column1: The interview was one of several given by the 72-year-old senator to local radio in Miami as he attempts to woo the influential Hispanic vote in Florida
column2: a state he almost certainly must win in order to take the White House.

column1: Later McCain took aim at recent comments by former Cuba president Fidel Castro
column2: who had ridiculed the former pilot's low grades at naval academy.

column1: I notice in the past couple of days that Fidel has made his preferences known in the campaign and had some very unkind things to say about me
column2: McCain said. ""My feelings are hurt.""

column1: More than one million Cuban-Americans live in Florida
column2: and McCain said he was acutely aware of the group's possible influence in the election race.

column1: He attempted to tap into anti-Castro sentiment by vowing to ""restore freedom and democracy"" on the island
column2: criticizing Obama for advocating a policy of diplomatic engagement.

column1: I think we all know that the Cuban-American vote can be vital to whether I win Florida or not
column2: McCain said. ""So I do want to say again that we will never waver in our mission to restore freedom and democracy."	0

column1: 210	"David Hogg
column2: a senior at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School
column3: knows what gunshots sound like: His father worked in law enforcement
column4: and taught him about weapons and how to handle them. So when Hogg heard a Ã¢ÂÂpopÃ¢ÂÂ while sitting in an AP environmental science class around 2:30 p.m. Wednesday
column5: he told his teacher it sounded strangely like a gunshot. But there had been a fire drill that very morning and talk of a Ã¢ÂÂCode RedÃ¢ÂÂ exercise to prepare for an active shooter. This must just be a surprise drill

column1: And then the fire alarm sounded. Dutifully acting on it
column2: Hogg and other students tried to exit the building. A janitorÃ¢ÂÂHogg doesnÃ¢ÂÂt know his name but calls him an angelÃ¢ÂÂknew where the shots were coming from and sent the students back. Then a culinary arts teacher
column3: Ashley Kurth
column4: pulled Hogg and others inside
column5: locked the door
column6: and made them hide in a closet. Checking Twitter and Instagram
column7: HoggÃ¢ÂÂwhoÃ¢ÂÂs an editor at the schoolÃ¢ÂÂs TV stationÃ¢ÂÂfound the news that the shooting was real and ongoing.

Ã¢ÂÂWhile I was in there
column2: I thought
column3: Ã¢ÂÂWhat impact have I had? What will my story be if I die here?Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ Hogg told TIME in the hours following the ordeal. Ã¢ÂÂAnd the only thing I could think of was
column4: pull out my camera and try telling others. As a student journalist

column6: thatÃ¢ÂÂs all I could think: Get other peopleÃ¢ÂÂs stories on tape. If we all die
column7: the camera survives
column8: and thatÃ¢ÂÂs how we get the message out there
column9: about how we want change to be brought about.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: In the wake of WednesdayÃ¢ÂÂs mass shooting

column3: that cry for change is echoing across this normally quiet
column4: almost bucolic Florida community of 30
column5: 000 on the edge of the Everglades

column7: whose sheriff
column8: Scott Israel

column11: if anything
column12: changes from one mass shooting to the next.

column1: Ã¢ÂÂWhen do we say
column2: thatÃ¢ÂÂs not acceptable
column3: something has to change?Ã¢ÂÂ asked Hogg
column5: his voice breaking.

column1: HoggÃ¢ÂÂs sister Lauren
column2: a freshman at the high school
column3: is fearing the worst: one of her friends had still not been located late Thursday. Nikolas Cruz
column4: the suspect who has been charged with 17 counts of murder
column5: had been expelled from the school a year ago and appears to have targeted a building full of ninth-graders.

column1: RELATED VIDEO: Florida Shooting Survivor Calls for Action
Will Gilroy is one of the freshmen who escaped the gunmanÃ¢ÂÂs wrath. He is still waiting for word about classmates that havenÃ¢ÂÂt been located. Like Hogg
column2: Gilroy thought the shooting wasnÃ¢ÂÂt real at first. But then he heard the sirens. He listened to his teacherÃ¢ÂÂs orders and crowded into a closet with about 20 others. He was in there
column3: he says
column4: for about an hour.

column1: Ã¢ÂÂIt was hot in there. We were packed in tight
column2: Ã¢ÂÂ he told TIME. Ã¢ÂÂSome students were crying. The teacher had paper plates and we used them to fan ourselves.Ã¢ÂÂ Inside the closet Gilroy began texting with his mother
column3: Kristi Gilroy
column4: who teaches second and third grade in at Country Hills Elementary just down the road. She too was on lockdown
column5: with kids who stayed for after-school ccare. She was relieved to know her only son was alive. But the shooter was still at large. Cruz was eventually caught just down the road from their house
column6: trying to escape with the rest of the crowd.

column1: Ã¢ÂÂMy husband is ex-military
column2: so itÃ¢ÂÂs not like weÃ¢ÂÂre anti-gun. But an AR-15?Ã¢ÂÂ Kristi Gilroy said. Ã¢ÂÂYou tell me
column3: how big of a gun does a person need?Ã¢ÂÂ Douglas is closed for the rest of the week as teens and teachers struggle to make sense of the carnage. But Kristi Gilroy faces the difficult job of going back to school Thursday
column4: waiting for news of the dead and injured
column5: which might
column6: she feared
column7: include children sheÃ¢ÂÂd taught when they were younger.

column1: The usual questions arose Thursday about whether it was too soon to talk about gun control. Some local officials seemed ready to toss out the oft-heard script
column2: the prayers for families and praise for first responders. Ã¢ÂÂNow
column3: now is the time for this country to have a conversation about sensible gun control laws in this country
column4: Ã¢ÂÂ Broward County School Superintendent Robert W. Runcie told reporters. Ã¢ÂÂOur students are asking for that.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: President Trump spoke Thursday morning
column2: taking on the grim task of comforter-in-chief
column3: but offering no specific proposals.

column1: Ã¢ÂÂTo every parent
column2: teacher
column3: and child who is hurting so badly
column4: we are here for you
column5: whatever you need
column6: whatever we can do
column7: to ease your pain
column8: Ã¢ÂÂ Trump said. Ã¢ÂÂWe are all joined together as one American family
column9: and your suffering is our burden also.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: Attorney General Pam Bondi
column2: speaking to reporters on Thursday
column3: said that sheÃ¢ÂÂd been sitting with parents until 3:30 a.m. Ã¢ÂÂHaving to tell parents that a child
column4: 14 years old
column5: is dead
column6: is the hardest thing you have to do in your career
column7: Ã¢ÂÂ she said
column8: her eyes full of tears.

column1: To some
column2: however
column3: words of comfort wonÃ¢ÂÂt be enough. Ã¢ÂÂWhen do we actually stand up? I think itÃ¢ÂÂs the time that we all stand up
column4: Ã¢ÂÂ Hogg demanded. Ã¢ÂÂIf you donÃ¢ÂÂt call your Congressman and do it again and again and not give up
column5: itÃ¢ÂÂs going to be your child thatÃ¢ÂÂs next. And thatÃ¢ÂÂs horrifying.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: Meanwhile
column2: Parkland waits. Waits for the names of the innocent who were gunned down before they could graduate
column3: or in some cases
column4: finish the ninth grade. Waits for news of funeral arrangements for a beloved football coach and security guard. Waits to hear if the children still in the hospital pull will through. Waits for someone to convince their teenagers that itÃ¢ÂÂs okay to go back to school
column5: that theyÃ¢ÂÂre safe
column6: and that nothing like this will happen again.

column2: asJake said
column3: to step back to a support role after the initial phase.Martha
column4: you're there. You're covering the military. Is thathappening? Do you think it's realistic to go into a support role?It's obviously very unusual in these kinds of military interventions. RADDATZ: It's certainly unusual for the U.S. And right now
column5: aU.S. general is in charge of the operation
column6: General Carter Ham. Andyou have an admiral
column7: Admiral Scott -- or Sam Locklear
column8: who is on aship. And he is the tactical commander
column9: meaning he is coordinatingall of these air strikes.

column1: But in a few days
column2: the hope is
column3: the U.S. hopes that GeneralCarter Ham can turn over his responsibility to one of the coalitionmembers. That is the plan right now. I don't think they know whothat will be.

column1: But in this initial phase
column2: the U.S. does have uniquecapabilities
column3: as the president keeps saying. You had stealth bombersgoing in there. You had the B-2 bombers going in there. You hadthese Tomahawk missiles on the ships. So the U.S. felt it had to takethe lead role in this phase.

column1: And this phase is
column2: of course
column3: to wipe out Gadhafi's air defenses.The next phase will be the no-fly zone. I do think the U.S. will beinvolved in that somewhat and will have fighters involved in that
column4: butthe bulk of the no-fly zone will be flown by British pilots
column5: Frenchpilots
column6: and other allies.

column1: AMANPOUR: Martha
column2: thank you so much.

column1: And joining me next
column2: Admiral Mike Mullen
column3: chairman of the JointChiefs of Staff. And we'll put that to him. I'll ask him how themissions will work
column4: when it will end
column5: and whether it can succeed atall if Moammar Gadhafi remains in power.

column1: (COMMERCIAL BREAK)
AMANPOUR: Welcome back.
Though his son sounded subdued
column2: Moammar Gadhafi himself wassounding undaunted this morning. He says his supporters are armed andprepared to fight
column3: and he's pledging that this will be
column4: quote
column5: ""a longwar.""

column1: Joining me now
column2: chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff
column3: AdmiralMike Mullen.

column1: Thank you for joining us.
MULLEN: Good morning.
AMANPOUR: Is the United States leading this? Or is it in asupporting role?
MULLEN: Well
column2: actually
column3: the French were the first ones inyesterday
column4: in terms of starting to establish the no-fly zone. TheUnited States is taking the lead in terms of the coalition. GeneralCarter Ham
column5: U.S. commander of U.S. AFRICOM
column6: is actually the commanderright now. And we look to
column7: in the next few days
column8: transition that to acoalition leadership."	0

column1: Return to Transcripts main page
State of the Union
Interview with Mitch McConnell; Interview with Robert Gibbs
Aired July 08
THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.
CANDY CROWLEY
column2: CNN ANCHOR: June disappoints with weak job numbers. Today
column3: unemployment and the presidential race.

column1: (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)
BARACK OBAMA
column2: PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: But it is still tough out there.

column1: FORMER GOV. MITT ROMNEY
column2: R-MASS.
column3: PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: This kick in the gut has got to end.

column1: CROWLEY: Exclusive interviews with Senate Republican leader Mitch McConnell and Obama campaign senior adviser Robert Gibbs. Then the numbers and the politics of a sputtering economy with economist Douglas Holtz-Eakin
column2: Mark Zandi
column3: and CNN senior congressional correspondent
column4: Dana Bash.

column1: BILL BRADLEY
column2: FORMER DEMOCRATIC SENATOR: If we are going to succeed
column3: we have to face our problems squarely.

column1: Former Democratic senator Bill Bradley on how to fix a broken Washington and what we can all do better. I'm Candy Crowley and this is STATE OF THE UNION.
(END VIDEOTAPE)
CROWLEY: Not the best of weeks for the Romney campaign. It was already under fire from friendly sources as not ready for prime time when a senior adviser said that ObamaCare is fine
column2: for not buying insurance is not a penalty
column3: not a tax. A big oops in political world because Republicans have used the Supreme Court decision to argue that ObamaCare is a tax hike on the middle class. Reset.

column1: (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
ROMNEY: The Supreme Court has the final word
column2: right? Is it the highest court in the land? They said it was a tax
column3: didn't they?

column1: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: So what do you --
ROMNEY: It's a tax. Of course
column2: you --

column1: CROWLEY: Too late for the conservative ""Wall Street Journal
column2: which blistered the Romney campaign for looking confused and politically dumb. ""Mr. Romney
column3: it read
column4: ""promised Republicans he was the best man to make the case against President Obama
column5: whom they desperately want to defeat. So far
column6: Mr. Romney is letting them down.""

column1: Joining me is Senate Republican leader Mitch McConnell. There are few people in Washington with a larger stake in seeing that Mitt Romney does well than you do
column2: because you would like to go from minority leader in the Senate to majority. How do you think he has been doing? MCCONNELL: Well
column3: the race is very
column4: very close. I mean I think the best evidence of that is a Gallup tracking poll that has had it consistently very close. People are unhappy with the economy. They know that Mitt Romney is a job creator and I think he has got a great chance of being elected.

column1: CROWLEY: But his campaign
column2: as you know
column3: has come under fire from Republicans
column4: first as being not ready for prime time
column5: as we said
column6: that he needs a steady
column7: sort of more national hand in this.

column1: Do you have any complaints
column2: first of all
column3: about how they handled this whole Supreme Court tax issue
column4: which is a major issue for you all?

column1: MCCONNELL: Well
column2: I think a better use of my time is to criticize the guys we are running against. I'm not here to critique the Romney campaign. I do think that we've got plenty to run against. The president has got a very
column3: very poor record. That is why he does not want to talk about it.

column1: I mean
column2: take Friday's job figure
column3: for example. You can go back two years ago and the job figure was better and the president said we are turning the -- we are turning it around. You know
column4: clearly what they are doing is not working. And I think that is what this campaign needs to be about.

column1: CROWLEY: And yet
column2: we did look at the figures for this year
column3: and you know that there were great advances in job creation in the first quarter. It's been minimal in the second quarter.

column1: Nonetheless
column2: still job creation. When you average out the first six months
column3: it is something like 125
column5: 000 jobs have been created on average. That's not too bad considering where we came from
column6: is it?

column1: MCCONNELL: It is terrible. We have got 41 straight months now of unemployment above 8 percent
column2: 41 straight months. Candy
column3: this is the most tepid recovery -- if it is a recovery -- from a deep recession in American history.

column1: The economy is just sputtering along and the reason for that
column2: in my judgment
column3: is because of what the administration chose to do: spend
column4: borrow
column5: pass this new ObamaCare law with its penalty tax in it
column6: its mandate tax. All of this is slowing the economy down.

column1: CROWLEY: Let me ask you about the president's jobs plan that was introduced last September
column2: I think. And something -- this is what he is saying on the campaign trail. This was in Columbus
column3: Ohio
column4: in an interview with WBNS.

column1: (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
OBAMA: -- making sure that we're rebuilding the infrastructure
column2: our roads
column3: our bridges
column4: our runways
column5: all those things that could put construction workers back to work right now and would lift the entire economy and then
column6: as I said
column7: refocusing on manufacturing. That's the recipe for growth over the long term.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
CROWLEY: So what's wrong with any of that? Shouldn't Congress
column2: at this point
column3: be saying the American people want this economy to be better? Isn't it incumbent on you all to find something you can agree on in the long list of things the president put in that jobs package and move it forward?

column1: MCCONNELL: Well
column2: we just passed a transportation bill
column3: so we were addressing an issue that we had broad agreement on
column4: that transportation is important to our economy.

column1: But look
column2: the way we're going to get the private sector going again is to change the way the government is treating the private sector. Things like ObamaCare
column3: things like overregulation are causing companies not to hire. And we have got the fiscal cliff coming at the end of the year.

column1: You know
column2: what we ought to be doing is extend the current tax rates for another year with a hard requirement to get through comprehensive tax reform one more time. I negotiated with Vice President Biden the two-year extension of the current tax rates that we're in right now.

column1: The president signed it because he argued that to let taxes going up would make the economy worse. We have a slower growth rate today than we had then. That would settle at least part of the problem.
CROWLEY: Let me ask you though
column2: because they are doing nothing because you all are at odds over what you should do
column3: is in fact
column4: a lot of people argue
column5: slowing the growth of the economy here in the U.S. and adding to the jobless rate
column6: which is pretty tepid.

column1: I want to play you something from the managing director of the IMF.
(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
CHRISTINE LAGARDE
column2: MANAGING DIRECTOR
column3: IMF: The threat
column4: only the threat of the delay in raising the debt ceiling and of the fiscal cliff could weaken growth already later this year
column5: and should they materialize because no agreement can be reached
column6: the domestic effects would be severe with negative spillovers to the rest of the world.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
CROWLEY: So basically IMF is saying if you don't come off this fiscal cliff -- and by you
column2: I mean Congress -- it is going to add to the uncertainty. There are certain things -- ObamaCare
column3: you've mentioned it; regulations
column4: that's fine.

column1: You're not going to the Democrats to agree on it
column2: but something that Congress could do is something about this oncoming train
column3: which everyone sees coming
column4: and yet there's no action. MCCONNELL: Well
column5: what we could do and is what the House is going to do this week
column6: I believe
column7: is go ahead and extend the current tax rates for another year. That deals with part of the fiscal cliff.

column1: (CROSSTALK)
CROWLEY: The president said he would veto that
column2: so --

column1: MCCONNELL: The president shouldn't veto that. This is the same president who signed the very same thing two years ago with the argument --
CROWLEY: I understand.
MCCONNELL: -- to do otherwise would make the economy worse.
CROWLEY: Yes.
MCCONNELL: I mean
column2: look
column3: the principal reason that we're having this economic trough is what the government is doing to the private sector. Now the president keeps talking about public sector employees.

column1: Unemployment in the public sector is 4.2 percent. We've got to get the private sector going. That is only the way you have job growth
column2: which creates revenue for the government. Everything this administration has done
column3: Candy
column4: has taken us in the wrong direction.

column1: CROWLEY: But they would argue that the stimulus plan and other things they've done since and investing in infrastructure
column2: getting construction jobs going
column3: hiring the teachers
column4: policemen
column5: that that has kept this economy from being even worse over a longer period of time.

column1: And I think
column2: you know
column3: again
column4: we are seeing the same arguments we have seen now --

column1: MCCONNELL: Yes
column2: I know.

column1: CROWLEY: -- for a year and a half. And I sense out there in the country -- and now we're seeing from the IMF -- that what is really worrying people is that you do nothing. It is almost not the something that you do
column2: it is that you look up to Capitol Hill for some sort of guidance. When was the last time that you sat down with the Senate majority leader and said. how can we do this?

column1: MCCONNELL: We have passed 11 different things the president has asked us to pass in the last six months. That is not the point.
The point is this: for two years the administration was able to do everything they wanted to. They borrowed. They spent. They had the government take over American health care. That's all in place
column2: and the question the American people should be asking is how is that working?

column1: Now the president would like to do more of the same. We don't think that makes sense. Why don't we try doing things that get the private sector -- which is the only way we're going to ever (inaudible) going again.
CROWLEY: We don't try
column2: because you are in the minority and not a majority in the Senate
column3: and yet the minority in the Senate can stop things
column4: so
column5: you know
column6: the fact of the matter is don't you and Senator Reid need to sit down and say
column7: here is how we can help the economy? Here's what we can agree on? Have you all done that?

column1: MCCONNELL: We have
column2: as I just indicated
column3: passed a number of things the president's asked for.

column1: CROWLEY: Have you sat down with senator Reid looking forward?
(CROSSTALK)

MCCONNELL: Sure. We -- every day we talk about the way forward and we have passed a number of pieces of legislation that are important and are helpful. But the primary problem is the president would like for us to keep doing more of what he was able to do the first two years when he had total control of Congress.
The American people have looked at the results of that. It clearly has not worked.
CROWLEY: Let me turn you to the Senate race races that are out there. Sitting here today and looking at the landscape
column2: do you believe you will be the majority leader next year?

column1: MCCONNELL: 50-50. I think it is going to be a very close
column2: competitive election. There are a number of places where we have opportunities for pickups
column3: not many places where we have much chance of losing a seat. I think at the end of the day
column4: we will have a very narrow Senate one way or the other.

column1: CROWLEY: And looking at the Virginia race and the Massachusetts race?
MCCONNELL: Two close races. Good candidates --
(CROSSTALK)
CROWLEY: You could lose as easily as you could win?
MCCONNELL: I'm sorry?
CROWLEY: You could lose as easily as you could win?
MCCONNELL: Well
column2: they are close races. We expect to win them both
column3: but they are close races. CROWLEY: And as you look at the Supreme Court decision over the past week and the reaction to it
column4: and you read
column5: I'm assuming Justice Roberts'
column6: Chief Justice Roberts' opinion on that -- are you sorry you voted for him?

column1: MCCONNELL: No
column2: I'm not
column3: but I was extremely disappointed. The chief justice
column4: however
column5: did make it clear that the mandate is a tax
column6: and if I may make an observation about that
column7: Candy
column8: you know
column9: the mandate tax
column10: 77 percent of it will be levied on people making $120
column11: 000 and less. And interestingly enough
column12: that produces more tax revenue for the government than the so-called Buffett tax which the president tried to get us to pass to raise taxes on high income people.

column1: CROWLEY: And yet there is 330 million-plus population in the U.S. or around in there
column2: we are talking about maybe about 3 million people
column3: at least according to the CBO
column4: how this would -- I mean the congressional folks
column5: according to them
column6: this would affect maybe 3 million people. That is not that much to get 30 million people covered
column7: is it?

column1: MCCONNELL: Well
column2: look
column3: the question is the law in its entirety. The president said it would not raise taxes. It is raising taxes.

column1: CROWLEY: On very few people
column2: though
column3: you would concede that.

column1: MCCONNELL: Well
column2: it is important to those people
column3: and they are middle-income people. More tax revenue raised from middle-income people than the Buffett tax would raise from high-income people from a president who promised not to raise taxes on anyone. It is also driving premiums up. The cost of health care is going up. It cut Medicare by half a trillion dollars over the next ten years. Nothing that was said in connection with passing this health care bill is working out.

column1: CROWLEY: Senator
column2: I want you thank you for joining us this morning. I hope you will come back.

column1: MCCONNELL: I will.
CROWLEY: Jobs and the president's plan for winning the battleground states with Obama campaign senior adviser Robert Gibbs when we come back.
(COMMERCIAL BREAK)
CROWLEY: I'm joined by Obama campaign senior adviser Robert Gibbs. Good to see you
column2: Robert.

column1: I want to run you through a series of economic figures and polls
column2: and then get your comment at the end. First of all
column3: when you ask folks what are economic conditions like today -- good
column4: 27 percent. Poor
column5: 73 percent. When you say
column6: how important is the economy to your vote? 92 percent say it is either very or extremely important to their vote.

column1: GIBBS: Who are the other 8 percent? CROWLEY: Exactly. To their vote. And then finally
column2: who would better handle the economy. Romney 48 percent
column3: Obama 47 percent. If the economy is doing better
column4: as the president argues
column5: not as good as you want but better
column6: why are those numbers like that?

column1: GIBBS: Well
column2: look
column3: I think we are coming out of the hardest economic time in our country's history. CROWLEY: Which we have been doing for four years.

column1: GIBBS: We have been
column2: and typically when you come out of the recession
column3: the depths that we were in
column4: that's caused by a financial crisis
column5: which is what happened
column6: it takes a while to dig out of that hole. We saw on Friday that our economy is growing and we are adding jobs. The president believes that --

column1: CROWLEY: Not enough jobs.
GIBBS: We are not growing fast enough and we're not adding enough jobs.
CROWLEY: So what is the argument to
column2: like
column3: after four years
column4: what is then the argument that re-elect me?

column1: GIBBS: Well
column2: Candy
column3: we have made progress
column4: but we have got a long way to go
column5: and this is going to be an election about two different visions. You heard part of it here just a minute ago with Senator McConnell and you hear it with Mitt Romney every day. The best way to create jobs is to provide millionaires and billionaires with greater tax cuts
column6: take financial regulations off of things like banks and Wall Street
column7: and somehow we will see jobs flourish for years and years to come. The problem with that is that it is not a theory. We tried it for eight years
column8: and it ended in this huge economic calamity and this financial mess.

column1: CROWLEY: But the jobs are not flourishing now
column2: and folks don't actually seem to think that the president would handle it better than Mitt Romney
column3: so I'm just trying to figure out what the sales pitch is here.

column1: GIBBS: Well
column2: the other vision is that we have to grow this economy like we did for years and years and decades from the middle- class out. Let's continue to add opportunity
column3: let's bring this American dream back
column4: let's guarantee that if you work hard and play by the rules
column5: you will have a chance to get ahead
column6: that your children will have a chance to get ahead. And again
column7: we have tried these different philosophies before. We know what tax breaks and tax cuts for the wealthy and financial regulations off of Wall Street mean. They mean economic calamity
column8: they mean what we are dealing with now
column9: versus a vision where we add jobs and build out of the middle-class. People take responsibility
column10: they work hard
column11: but they get ahead. And that is what we need to do.

column1: CROWLEY: I think
column2: you know
column3: even the Republicans would
column4: you know
column5: that you think have this different version
column6: would say
column7: we want to grow the middle-class
column8: that is where our aim is.

column1: GIBBS: That is not their primary aim. Their primary aim is to give tax breaks to the very wealthy.
CROWLEY: That is what you think their primary aim is
column2: but --

column1: GIBBS: Let's look at the central plank in Mitt Romney's so- called economic plan. And granted
column2: this is -- most of his economic plans and most of his plans are secret
column3: but the one thing that he has fleshed out is to take the Bush tax cuts
column4: which disproportionately impact millionaires and billionaires
column5: and add to them. Candy
column6: do you think we are a Bush tax away for a millionaire away from a flourishing economy? Or should we protect and keep taxes low for middle-class families and give them a chance?

column1: CROWLEY: Do you think the president will do anything other than veto a bill that would keep those Bush tax cuts for everyone intact?
GIBBS: We should protect the tax cuts for the middle-class
column2: and we should let tax cuts for millionaires and billionaires expire.

column1: CROWLEY: Even though recovery is not that great
column2: and people say don't take money out of this economy
column3: it is not the time for a tax hike
column4: you would go ahead and do it for those making $250
column5: 000 and above.

column1: GIBBS: We ought to do something about this deficit
column2: and we ought to protect middle class tax cuts
column3: and the best way to do that is to let the upper-end tax cuts expire
column4: let the wealthy in this country that had been doing fine for years and years and years begin to pay their fair share
column5: and make sure that we protect the tax rate that middle-class families have had for the past many years.

column1: CROWLEY: So the president is totally committed to getting rid of the tax cut for those making $250
column2: 000 and above.

column1: GIBBS: Let's make some progress on our spending by doing away with tax cuts for people who quite frankly don't need them
column2: tax cuts that have not worked
column3: and have them pay their fair share.

column1: CROWLEY: So is that a yes or a no? The president is completely committed to this
column2: he won't allow it to happen?

column1: GIBBS: He is 100 percent committed to it.
CROWLEY: OK. I want to play an ad that you all have been running
column2: and then ask you about it.

column1: Or not.
(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Mitt Romney campaigned as a job creator.
ROMNEY: I know how jobs are created.
UNIDENTIFIED MALE: But as a corporate raider
column2: he shipped jobs to China and Mexico. As a governor
column3: he did the same thing
column4: outsourcing state jobs to India. Now he is making the exact same pitch. ROMNEY: I know why the jobs come and why they go.

column1: UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Outsourcing jobs
column2: Romney economics
column3: it didn't work then and it won't work now.

column1: (END VIDEOTAPE)
CROWLEY: You all have invested very heavily in the Bain Capital element of trying to convince people of what Mitt Romney is about. And yet
column2: this particular ad got four pinocchios from the Washington Post
column3: which is not true. And this is what Factcheck.org had to say. ""We found no evidence to support the claim that Romney
column4: while he was still running Bain Capital
column5: shipped American jobs overseas."" You now have a similar ad out. Why do you keep with that?

column1: GIBBS: Well
column2: I've got to say factcheck.org ought to read the Washington Post
column3: which is the one that came up with a report that said looking at SEC filings that Mitt Romney and Bain Capital were pioneers in outsourcing. They shipped jobs all over the world that could and should have been--

column1: CROWLEY: You say that Romney was
column2: but the point
column3: their point is that in fact
column4: Mitt Romney was not running Bain. He had cut ties and gone off.

column1: GIBBS: That also is not true
column2: because Mitt Romney was the head and sole owner of Bain longer than Mitt Romney has admitted to being the sole owner of Bain.

column1: But let's understand this
column2: because we saw this a little bit again this week. We have got a guy who believes and has been a pioneer in outsourcing jobs
column3: and quite frankly
column4: he offshores most of his own personal investments
column5: presumably to shield them from taxes.

column1: Candy
column2: I don't know about you
column3: I pick a bank because there is an ATM near my home
column4: right? Mitt Romney has a bank account in Switzerland. He's got a shell company--

column1: CROWLEY: Nothing illegal
column2: right? You are not charging that he has done anything illegal with any of this? GIBBS: Candy
column3: nobody knows why he has a corporation in Bermuda
column4: why he failed to disclose that on seven different financial disclosures
column5: why he transferred it to somebody else's purview the day before he became governor of Massachusetts. The one thing he can do
column6: Candy
column7: to clear up whether or not he's done anything illegal
column8: whether he's shielding his income from taxes in Bermuda or Switzerland
column9: is to do what every other presidential candidate has done
column10: and that is release a series of years of their own tax returns. Mitt Romney's father was the pioneer for releasing a series of tax returns. The best way to figure out if Mitt Romney is complying with American tax law is to have him release more of his tax returns.

column1: This is a guy whose slogan is believe in America
column2: and it should be business in Bermuda
column3: that is what Mitt Romney is all about.

column1: CROWLEY: Which is a great line
column2: but again
column3: there is no evidence here that any of the fact check organizations have found that A
column4: he outsourced jobs
column5: or was president of Bain when it happened
column6: and B
column7: that he has done anything illegal. You have had a lot of advice from folks
column8: Democrats saying get off of this particular Bain thing. There is obviously some polling that shows in fact it's having some effect in some of the battleground states
column9: but why--

column1: GIBBS: Again
column2: this is an ad that's based on a report that the Washington Post did. OK? So I would encourage everyone go to Washingtonpost.com and read that report. The reason that we'll keep talking about this is
column3: this is important. Are we going to create jobs here in America
column4: we're going to bring them back from overseas
column5: we're going to do away with tax breaks for companies that ship jobs overseas
column6: or are we going to invest in manufacturing here in this country? You know
column7: we have created half a million manufacturing jobs. More manufacturing jobs have been created in the last few years than since the mid-90s. Mitt Romney famously said we ought to let Detroit and the auto industry go bankrupt. Again
column8: I go back to two very different visions about this economy.

column1: CROWLEY: Right. I have to end it there
column2: I'm sorry
column3: I hope you come back. Robert Gibbs
column4: senior adviser to the Obama campaign. Thanks.

column1: GIBBS: Thank you.
CROWLEY: Four more jobs reports before the election
column2: the problems and the solutions when we come back.

column1: (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
ROMNEY: The president's policies have not gotten America working again.
OBAMA: Businesses have created 4.4 million new jobs over the past 28 months.
(END VIDEO CLIP)
(COMMERCIAL BREAK) CROWLEY: With me now
column2: Mark Zandi
column3: chief economist of Moody's Analytics
column4: former Congressional Budget Office Director Douglas Holtz- Eakin
column5: and CNN senior congressional correspondent Dana Bash. So let's just straighten out this economy thing. And have you all tell me
column6: A
column7: what was the most worrisome thing in the economic report we got
column8: the jobless report
column9: and what makes you think
column10: OK
column11: we can still survive this. Let's start with you.

column1: ZANDI: Well
column3: 000 jobs is pretty disappointing. If we stick at 80
column5: if that is the reality of what is going on
column6: then unemployment is going to rise
column7: and we have an 8.2 percent unemployment rate
column8: and that is a problem. So that is the most worrisome aspect of the report.

column1: But there were some positives -- hours worked increased. That's a good leading indicator. Businesses will ask workers to work longer hours before they hire. And we did see--
CROWLEY: So that is a precursor to new jobs.
ZANDI: It is.
CROWLEY: Sometimes.
ZANDI: Generally is. And hours worked were actually at a pretty high level
column2: so any pickup of activity will probably translate into more jobs
column3: and we got a big increase in wages
column4: which was encouraging. I had been nervous that wage growth had been slowing
column5: but that does not appear to be the case. It is pretty solid.

column1: CROWLEY: Douglas
column2: what do you think?

column1: HOLTZ-EAKIN: Well
column2: those points are right. One of the real disappointing characteristics of this recovery has been not just the jobs
column3: but the lack of income growth
column4: and that has hurt the ability of households to spend
column5: and to see some strength in wages was a very important part of this report.

column1: I think the really troubling issue is that this report came on the heels of some other reports that showed manufacturing slowing
column2: the service sector slowing
column3: and to the extent that employment is a lagging sort of indicator
column4: that we could have further trouble down the road. And I'm worried about the outlook for that reason.

column1: CROWLEY: I tried to get Robert Gibbs to tell us how the president plays this at this point
column2: because I think people look and think
column3: we just thought we'd be so much further along. How do the Romney folks play this
column4: and is there any sign that it is working
column5: and what can the president do?

column1: BASH: Well
column2: the Romney folks
column3: what they think their message is going to be going forward isn't so much the Reagan
column4: are you better off now than you were four years ago? It's what we all witnessed four years ago
column5: the high expectations
column6: the soaring rhetoric
column7: the -- you know
column8: as Sarah Palin would say
column9: the ""hopey-changey"" thing. Do you feel that? Or do you feel like -- ?

column1: CROWLEY: Consumer confidence?
BASH: What happened? What happened?
CROWLEY: Yes.
BASH: So it's not -- it's that the expectations were set so high
column2: and that is what the Romney campaign wants to hit big time going forward.

column1: Having said that
column2: there was some criticism
column3: sort of friendly fire
column4: from Republican editorial boards -- you showed some of the quotes to Mitch McConnell. That's a concern because Mitt Romney should be doing very well against somebody with 8.2 percent unemployment. And the concern is
column5: especially given the fact that his calling card is business acumen
column6: why isn't he doing better?

column1: CROWLEY: Let me read you something from Brian Cropp (ph) -- I don't know if either one of you know him -- he is on the corporate executive board
column2: a managing director here
column3: and here is what he had to say about a two-tiered job market.

column1: We continue to hear from companies that it's a two-tiered labor market. For people who have been employed with professional and technical skills
column2: it's a decent job market. But for the rest of the workforce
column3: it's still very difficult.""

column1: Is that accurate that we're getting a sort of a two Americas when you look at the jobless rate?
HOLTZ-EAKIN: I think there's an element or two to it. But to say that there is two Americas is too strong. I mean
column2: it is always the case that during expansions
column3: some skills and some sectors do better than others
column4: and we are seeing that right now. There's no question. High school people have done better
column5: and that is not unusual
column6: especially in tough economic times.

column1: So the challenge is to have enough economic growth that the people who have -- at the moment have sort of a relatively low-skilled job can get in
column2: get the kind of experience that allows them to turn into the other part of America
column3: and we're just not seeing that right now.

column1: ZANDI: I am sympathetic to that description. I mean
column2: I think if you have education
column3: if you've gone to college
column4: if you have the skills
column5: you are doing OK. You're doing pretty well. If you look at the unemployment rates for people with college degrees and lots of skills
column6: very -- it is really quite low.

column1: CROWLEY: (Inaudible).
ZANDI: (Inaudible). And those folks that don't have skills and education
column2: they are getting creamed in this economy.

column1: CROWLEY: And that --
HOLTZ-EAKIN: I think the key here is the income. I think -- they might have jobs
column2: but they're not getting college and skilled level incomes out of this recovery
column3: and the other guys are getting creamed.

column1: BASH: And that does feed into the political divide of the two Americas
column2: Candy
column3: no question
column4: that President Obama historically has struggled with the sort of uneducated voter or the voter who doesn't have the high education
column5: and he struggles with the lunch bucket voter
column6: and this feeds right into that.

column1: ZANDI: I want to push back on your point about people expecting this to be better than it is. The reality is that
column2: after financial crises
column3: like the one we went through -- and it was a devastating crisis -- you just look at the string of financial institutions that just are no longer with us
column4: you always have very weak economic recovery. This is the history of economics
column5: all the way back to the 1400s.

column1: So it's not atypical that an economy would struggle like it is
column2: and we have made improvements. I mean --

column1: (CROSSTALK)
CROWLEY: You would know that because you know stuff like that
column2: but --

column1: HOLTZ-EAKIN: And the president and his advisers pooh-poohed that research early on
column2: said no
column3: no
column4: no
column5: that's not true. We can do this and get out quicker and they sold it politically that they would get out quicker
column6: and they were probably wrong.

column1: ZANDI: And
column2: Doug
column3: I think we are going to get out quicker than what has happened typically in history
column4: but in history
column5: it has been a decade before economies get out. And we're going to get out a lot faster than that
column6: but
column7: you know
column8: we're only three years
column9: four years after the nadir of all of this.

column1: And to say we have created 4 million jobs in the last couple of years
column2: I think that's actually quite an improvement.

column1: But you are right
column2: Candy
column3: I'm talking as an economist. I'm not talking as a person on the street who has been nailed by this.

column1: BASH: And we are in a fast food nation right now. We're in the Twitter nation
column2: where three years is six lifetimes
column3: where everything happens very
column4: very fast. And that's the problem (inaudible).

column1: CROWLEY: I want you all to stick with me. We've talked about the problems. After the break
column2: we want to talk about some solutions.

column1: And later
column2: solving Washington's problems may be easier than you might think.

column1: BILL BRADLEY
column2: FORMER DEMOCRATIC SENATOR: It is not a quick fix
column3: but it begins essentially by people telling you the truth.

column1: (COMMERCIAL BREAK)
CROWLEY: With me now
column2: Mark Zandi
column3: chief economist of Moody Analytics
column4: former Congressional Budget Office director Douglas Holtz- Eakin
column5: and CNN senior congressional correspondent Dana Bash.

column1: I have talked to folks
column2: like you all
column3: that have said
column4: you know
column5: the truth is
column6: there is not a whole lot the president or even the Fed can do to make a major change in the state of the economy
column7: that we are now looking at a kind of a new normal with above 6 percent unemployment for the out years
column8: as they say
column9: maybe a decade or so to come. Do you go with that?

column1: ZANDI: Not me. No
column2: I disagree totally with that. I think our economy is on the precipice of very strong economic growth. I think that American companies have restructured
column3: they've gotten their cost structures down
column4: they've reduced debt
column5: they have lots of cash. It's a matter of confidence. It's not a matter of ability to go out and expand. And I think they will. And I think there's a lot that the Federal Reserve and the administration and Congress can do
column6: most importantly -- you were talking about this with senator McConnell -- is we have got to nail down this fiscal cliff because this is making business people nervous and it's the reason why they are not taking that step to hire more workers.

column1: So I don't think we're in a new normal.
CROWLEY: Are you bullish about the future?
HOLTZ-EAKIN: We get to dictate the normal. In the '60s and '70s
column2: we took a series of policy steps that left us with chronic high inflation
column3: chronic high unemployment. And then we changed course in the '80s and '90s
column4: and we got a much better performance.

column1: So I'm with Mark. We can do much better than we're doing now. I don't think that if you round up the usual cast of characters -- this is a lot like ""Casablanca"" -- that you look at the Fed
column2: I actually don't think there's much they can do right now.

Technical Notes
Nature and sources of data

Preliminary data for 2005 are based on a substantial proportion of births for that year (99.2 percent). The data for 2005 are based on a continuous receipt and processing of statistical records through May 31
column3: by the Centers for Disease Control and PreventionÃ¢ÂÂs National Center for Health Statistics (NCHS). NCHS receives the data from the statesÃ¢ÂÂ vital registration systems through the Vital Statistics Cooperative Program. In this report
column4: U.S. totals include only events occurring within the 50 states and the District of Columbia. Detailed information on reporting completeness and imputation procedures may be found in the Ã¢ÂÂTechnical AppendixÃ¢ÂÂ of Vital Statistics of the United States
column6: Natality (8).

column1: To produce the preliminary estimates shown in this report
column2: records in the file were weighted using independent control counts of all 2005 births by state of occurrence. Detailed information on weighting is available elsewhere (8). Detailed information on the reliability of estimates also may be found elsewhere (1).

column1: Marital status
National estimates of births to unmarried women are based on two methods of determining marital status. For 2004 and 2005
column2: birth certificates in 48 states and the District of Columbia included a direct question about motherÃ¢ÂÂs marital status; in two of these states
column3: California and Nevada
column4: a direct question is part of the electronic birth registration process but does not appear on certified or paper copies of the birth certificate. The question in most states is: Ã¢ÂÂMother married? (At birth
column5: conception
column6: or any time between) (Yes or no)Ã¢ÂÂ. Marital status is inferred in Michigan and New York. A birth is inferred as nonmarital if a paternity acknowledgment was filed or if the fatherÃ¢ÂÂs name is missing from the birth certificate (listed in respective priority-of-use order).

column1: Population denominators
Birth and fertility rates for 2005 shown in this report are based on population estimates based on the 2000 census
column2: as of July 1
column3: 2005. These population estimates are available on the NCHS Web- page (14). The production of these population estimates is described in detail in a recent report (2).

column1: Information on the national estimates of births to unmarried women (i.e.
column2: methods of determining marital status) and the computation of the preliminary birth rates for unmarried women is presented elsewhere (1). The birth rate for unmarried women for 2005 is estimated on the basis of population distributions by marital status provided by the U.S. Census Bureau as of March 2005 applied to the national population estimates as of July 1 (4
column4: 15). Both population files are 2000 census based. The nonmarital birth rate shown here for 2005 thus differs from those published by NCHS in the annual final reports
column5: which are based on populations estimated from 3-year averages of the marital status distributions
column6: rather than a single year as shown here (4). Population estimates for a single year are not an adequate basis for computing age-specific birth rates for unmarried womenÃ¢ÂÂthese rates are available only in reports based on final data.

column1: 221	"Frequently Asked Questions
What is a Presidential Library and Museum?
Presidential Libraries and Museums promote understanding of the presidency and the American experience. We preserve and provide access to historical materials
column2: support research
column3: and create interactive programs and exhibits that educate and inspire. Presidential Libraries and Museums hold vast archives of documents
column4: feature museums full of important Presidential artifacts
column5: present compelling educational and public programs
column6: and host informative websites. Presidential Libraries and Museums are not traditional lending libraries
column7: but instead are repositories for the papers
column8: records and historical materials of each Presidential administration. We work to ensure that these irreplaceable items are preserved and made available for the widest possible use.

column1: Presidential Libraries and Museums give you the chance to see
column2: hear
column3: and participate in the events that changed our lives and shaped our national story.

column1: History
How did the Presidential Library System begin?
It all began with President Franklin D. Roosevelt in the late 1930s.
A dramatic increase in the volume of Presidential papers led Roosevelt to seek the advice of prominent historians and public figures on how and where to keep not only his White House files
column2: but also his earlier papers
column3: book collection
column4: and memorabilia.

column1: Roosevelt announced plans for a new type of facility
column2: a Presidential Library
column3: on December 10
column4: 1938. An organization was chartered to raise private funds for the construction of the building on RooseveltÃ¢ÂÂs Hyde Park estate.

column1: On July 18
column3: Congress passed a joint resolution accepting the new facility and agreeing to operate it as part of the National Archives. The Roosevelt Library was turned over to the Federal government on July 4
column5: and dedicated on June 30

column1: The Roosevelt Library became the model for subsequent Presidential Libraries. Succeeding Libraries have been constructed with private and other non-Federal funds. A private
column2: non-profit organization is formed to coordinate these efforts and provide support for Library and museum programs.

column1: Once each Library was constructed
column2: NARA assumed responsibility for its operation and maintenance in accordance with the Presidential Libraries Acts of 1955 and 1986. In 2017
column3: President Barack Obama and NARA announced plans for the first digital presidential library
column4: without a dedicated federal facility.

column1: Learn more about the history of the Presidential Libraries.
What is the role of the Office of Presidential Libraries within the National Archives?
The Office of Presidential Libraries is the office responsible for the overall administration of the Presidential Library System. The office and the Libraries are within the Legislative Archives
column2: Presidential Libraries
column3: and Museum Services division of the National Archives.

column1: This office provides budgetary and administrative oversight for the system
column2: organizes multi-Library and system-wide initiatives
column3: coordinates the development and implementation of NARA policies and procedures
column4: and represents the Presidential Library System within the National Archives. The Office of Presidential Libraries also oversees new Presidential Library development
column5: major construction and renovation projects at the libraries and national programs aligning the work of the Presidential Libraries.

column1: View the National Archives organizational chart for more information.
What institutions comprise the Presidential Library System administered by NARA?
The Presidential Library System comprises 15 Presidential Libraries documenting Presidents Herbert Hoover through Donald J. Trump.
The building dedication dates are included:
Herbert Hoover Presidential Library and Museum

column1: * Read more information about the establishment of the Nixon Presidential Library and Museum in Ã¢ÂÂNixonÃ¢ÂÂs Library Now a Part of NARA.Ã¢ÂÂ
Does the Obama Library follow the same model as earlier Presidential Libraries?
No. The Obama Foundation
column2: a private entity
column3: made the decision in 2017 not to construct a Presidential Library for NARA to house the records (textual
column4: audiovisual
column5: and artifacts). Instead
column6: the Obama Foundation plans to build and operate a private museum and presidential center in Chicago. NARA will digitize and then store and preserve all original presidential records and artifacts in an existing NARA facility that meets NARAÃ¢ÂÂs standards for archival storage. NARA retains legal and physical custody of the records and artifacts. NARA will maintain
column7: preserve
column8: and provide access to the Presidential records of the Obama administration
column9: in accordance with the Presidential Records Act
column10: employing a digital model for access to opened records and loans of materials for display around the world
column11: including at the private Obama Presidential Center. Educational and public programs
column12: both live and virtual
column13: will also be a critical component of the Obama Presidential Library.

column1: Are there any plans to extend the Obama Library model to existing Presidential Libraries and Museums?
NARA has no plans to apply this change retroactively.
Will this be the new model for all presidential libraries going forward?
Decisions about future library models will be made in consultation between NARA and each outgoing presidential administration. Considering the increasing volume of born-digital records
column2: digital libraries will support the expectations of the public that our holdings be available free and online. We welcome exploring new approaches to presidential libraries
column3: which open up more options for future former presidents beyond traditional brick-and-mortar facilities and ultimately improve public access to records and collections.

column1: When are the records of a former President open for research?
For older Presidential Libraries (Hoover through Carter
column2: with the exception of Nixon)
column3: access to the holdings are governed by deeds of gift
column4: and the papers are processed according to prioritized plans developed by each Library. Major areas of current research interest and the timeliness of topics in the national arena are also considered. Nixon Presidential materials are governed by the Presidential Recordings and Materials Preservation Act (PRMPA)
column5: and material is reviewed in accordance with established regulations.

column1: For newer Libraries (from Reagan forward)
column2: the holdings are governed by the Presidential Records Act (PRA) of 1978. Under the PRA
column3: the records are exempt from public release for five years after the end of a Presidential administration. During this five-year period
column4: archivists begin processing and preparing materials for release to researchers.

column1: After the end of the five-year period
column2: all Presidential records become subject to Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) requests. These requests must be made in writing and cite the Freedom of Information Act and then be submitted to the appropriate Library by mail
column3: e-mail
column4: fax
column5: or in person.

column1: The Libraries whose Presidential holdings are governed by the PRA work to respond to FOIA requests from the general public. They process records and make them publicly available not only to requestors but also to anyone interested in conducting research on the particular topics covered by FOIA requests.
Learn more available about requesting access to records.
How can a researcher find out what records are open at a Presidential Library?
Each Presidential Library has digitized a portion of their textual and audiovisual collections and made them available on their websites.
The Presidential Daily Diary is the official record of the presidentsÃ¢ÂÂ travel
column2: meetings
column3: and telephone calls. View all of the digitized Presidential Daily Diaries from Roosevelt onward.

column1: Researchers can search archival records through the National Archives Catalog.
In addition
column2: each Library also has a website that contains information regarding their holdings including finding aids and collection guides. If finding aids are not available online
column3: researchers can contact the Library
column4: for more information on the materials available for research.

column1: Museum Information
Are the museums of the Presidential Libraries open to the general public?
Presidential Libraries and Museums with permanent facilities are open to the general public of all ages. NARA's Presidential Museums document the life and times of its respective President.
Each Presidential Museum charges an admission fee
column2: with revenues going to support museum operations and programs.

column1: The museums also host changing exhibits about particular topics relating to American history and the American experience and are open to the public year-round.
Many Libraries also have an active education component
column2: providing programs geared specifically to students and teachers and often tied to local curricula.

Passport to Presidential Libraries Program
What is the Passport Program?
Through the Passport to Presidential Libraries program
column2: visitors can purchase a special keepsake booklet to take with them on their travels to Presidential Libraries across the nation. Visitors receive a commemorative stamp from the Library at the time of the purchase and can collect stamps from every Presidential Library visited in the future. Once they collect stamps from all Presidential Libraries
column3: they may visit any of the Presidential Libraries for a special gift.

column1: How do I get my Passport stamped?
Stamps are available at each Library's admissions desk and/or museum store. We unfortunately cannot retroactively stamp Passports or accept Passports via mail for stamping purposes.
Who can I call with questions about the Passport?
Please direct all inquiries and feedback regarding the Passport to Presidential Libraries to the Office of Presidential Libraries at (301) 837-3250.
Funding
How is a Presidential Library funded?

A Presidential Library is constructed with private or non-Federal funds donated to non-profit organizations typically established for the express purpose of building a Presidential Library and supporting its programs.
Some Libraries have also received construction and development funding from state and/or local governments or university partners.
The Library is then transferred to the Federal Government and operated and maintained by NARA through its congressionally appropriated operating budget.

Some staff and programs at Presidential Libraries are paid for with funds from associated private presidential foundations. These private foundations also provide continuing support for Library programs and special events
column2: such as conferences and exhibitions.

column1: What is the role of a Presidential Library foundation?
Presidential Libraries carry out a mandated program to preserve
column2: process
column3: and make available their archival holdings. As part of providing access
column4: the Libraries and Museums provide outreach and educational programs.

column1: Presidential foundations also provide financial support to ensure the broadest spectrum of innovative and insightful public
column2: education
column3: and information programs at each Library.

column1: Presidential Libraries and Museums
column2: their websites
column3: and the scholarship they promote benefit in significant ways from private organizations established to support such programs.

column1: In several cases
column2: these organizations evolved from bodies chartered to raise money and construct the original Library building. In other instances
column3: these organizations were formed after the dedication of the Library by friends of the President.

column1: Also
column2: it should be noted that
column3: starting with the George Bush Library
column4: all Presidential Library foundations funding a NARA facility must provide an endowment to NARA to help offset facility operating expenses. This endowment is presented to NARA and is used by the government to support facility maintenance needs.

column1: Why should taxpayers support Presidential Libraries?
NARAÃ¢ÂÂs mission is to serve American democracy by safeguarding and preserving the records of our Government
column2: ensuring that everyone can discover
column3: use
column4: and learn from this documentary heritage. We ensure continuing access to the essential documentation of the rights of American citizens and the actions of their government. We support democracy
column5: promote civic education
column6: and facilitate historical understanding of our national experience.

column1: Presidential Libraries support NARAÃ¢ÂÂs mission by preserving and providing access to materials from a crucial part of our government as well as materials from individuals who have played key roles in our government. The papers and records created by
column2: for
column3: or about Presidents
column4: Vice Presidents
column5: and their administrations document the key decisions
column6: policy and activities of the institution of the Presidency - the highest policy level of government. The documents and artifacts held by the Presidential Libraries not only inform society about the President as an individual and about his term in office
column7: but also provide insights into the American experience.

column1: We provide access to these holdings through our research rooms
column2: our exhibits
column3: and online in order to reach the broadest audience possible. We also draw on the many partnerships formed between NARA and the Presidential Library foundations. As a result
column4: many aspects of museum and public programs are
column5: in fact
column6: supported by private funds
column7: although they are overseen by government professionals including curators
column8: educators
column9: and archivists.

column1: Building Details
Who decides where a Presidential Library and Museum should be located?
The President
column2: with advice from the Archivist of the United States
column3: makes the decision about the location of his Presidential Library. In consultation with his family
column4: friends
column5: and associates
column6: the President usually selects from a series of proposals submitted by interested communities or universities.

column1: Presidents have often acknowledged their origins by placing their Libraries in their hometowns. However
column2: in some cases Presidents place their Libraries on or near a university campus. For example
column3: the Lyndon Baines Johnson Library and Museum is located on the campus of the University of Texas in Austin.

column1: Does NARA have any input into the decision on location or the kind of building the Presidential Library will be?
The former President or his representatives choose the architects
column2: or an architectural firm/design team for the building of a Presidential Library and for the development and fabrication of museum exhibits. The President or his representatives are solely responsible for choice of the final location for the Library building and for the construction costs.

column1: The Presidential Libraries Act (44 U.S.C. Section 2112 (a) (2)) requires the Archivist of the United States to establish architectural and design standards that apply to new and existing libraries Ã¢ÂÂin order to ensure that such depositories (A) preserve Presidential records subject to Chapter 22 of 44 U.S.C. and papers and other historical materials accepted for deposit under section 2111 of 44 U.S.C. (B) contain adequate research facilities.Ã¢ÂÂ
The Architectural and Design Standards for Presidential Libraries are a supplement to NARA directive 1571
column2: Archival Storage Standards
column3: and NARA provides the standards for Presidential Libraries to the architects and design team selected by the former President or his representatives.

column1: View the current Architecture and Design Standards for Presidential Libraries.
Are there any limits to the size of Presidential Library buildings?
Though not specifically limiting the size of Presidential Libraries
column2: the Presidential Libraries Act of 1986 mandates that Library foundations must provide an endowment to NARA upon acceptance of the Library facility by the Archivist of the United States. The size of this endowment is based in part on the size of the facility.

column1: The requirement of a significant increase in the endowment for facilities over 70
column2: 000 square feet has had the practical effect of limiting the size of newer Libraries to less than 70
column3: 000 square feet.

The Presidential Libraries are most often buildings or series of buildings managed by the National Archives and Records Administration and a presidential library foundation.

column1: Holdings
What is housed in a Presidential Library?
A Presidential Library is a rich resource for a particular President and his administration
column2: as well as for the times in which he lived.

column1: The papers and records created by a President and his administration
column2: as well as the materials created by a President during his life and career comprise the core holdings of all Presidential Libraries.

column1: The papers and records document the personal and professional lives of a President
column2: his family
column3: close friends
column4: and business and political associates
column5: revealing the details about White House activities
column6: a PresidentÃ¢ÂÂ s career
column7: and a PresidentÃ¢ÂÂ s personal life.

column1: Along with the papers and records
column2: a Presidential Library contains thousands of films and video as well as millions of still pictures revealing all aspects of a President's life before
column3: during
column4: and after the White House. This rich resource of audiovisual materials may include home movies
column5: official White House photographs
column6: and audiotapes of Presidential conversations.

column1: Modern Presidential Libraries are also the custodians of the electronic records generated by a Presidential administration in its carrying out of the constitutional
column2: statutory
column3: and ceremonial duties of the Presidency.

column1: Additionally
column2: a Presidential Library contains thousands of artifacts
column3: the objects that document a life and career. Whether a gift from a foreign head of state or a cherished childhood memento
column4: the artifacts provide a unique record of a President's life
column5: in and out of the public eye.

column1: NARA has a statutory obligation to care for and provide access to legally defined Presidential records as a result of the Presidential Records Act of 1978. This law vested the ownership and administration of Presidential records with the United States Government through NARA. This law applies to the core holdings of Presidential Libraries starting with the records from the administration of Ronald Reagan.
The holdings of the Presidential Libraries differ from the materials created by all executive branch agencies
column2: the United States District and Circuit Courts
column3: and Legislative branch agencies. The Federal Records Act provides the statutory framework NARA uses to determine what records from these agencies should be accessioned into the holdings of the National Archives.

column1: Where are the materials of Presidents before Herbert Hoover?
Although Franklin D. Roosevelt established the first Presidential Library
column2: his predecessor
column3: Herbert Hoover
column4: later established a Presidential Library in West Branch
column5: Iowa.

column1: The materials of Presidents prior to Herbert Hoover are dispersed throughout the nation. Some are held by universities and historical societies
column2: but a large quantity are held by the Library of Congress. The Other Places to Research Presidential Materials page is an excellent starting point to finding information on other presidents.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: the extent of Presidential materials in archival and historical institutions across the country varies considerably depending on the attitudes of the former Presidents
column3: their families
column4: and friends to the preservation of their documentary materials. Many materials were lost
column5: purposefully destroyed
column6: or dispersed to family
column7: friends
column8: and supporters.

column2: such as the Obama Presidential Center?

column1: The Obama Presidential Center is not part of the Presidential Library system. NARA's requirements apply only to the extent the privately owned and operated museum intends to borrow records and artifacts from NARA for display. Those requirements support the preservation and security of loaned items and apply to any museum or other facility that borrows items from NARA.
What are the key statutes governing the establishment and operation of a Presidential Library?
Though Congress approved the acceptance of the Franklin D. Roosevelt Presidential Library and Museum by the National Archives in 1939
column2: the nation's legislative branch did not formally authorize the Presidential Library System until 1955 with the passage of the Presidential Libraries Act.

column1: The Presidential Libraries Act of 1955 codified the acceptance
column2: in the name of the United States
column3: of land
column4: buildings
column5: and equipment for the purposes of creating a Presidential archival depository
column6: as well as the role of the National Archives in maintaining
column7: operating
column8: and protecting them as a Presidential archival depository.

column1: The act was amended in 1986
column2: establishing a limit of 70
column3: 000 square feet for the Presidential Library facility that will be provided to the government and a requirement for an endowment to offset the maintenance costs of the facility. The most recent update to the act set the endowment requirement for future Presidential Libraries at 60 percent of the overall initial cost of the facility.

column1: What is a deed of gift?
A deed of gift is a legal document between a donor and an archival repository.
Prior to the passage of the Presidential Records Act in 1978
column2: the documentary materials created by a President and his staff during an administration were considered the President's personal property to be disposed of as he desired.

column1: Presidents Herbert Hoover through Jimmy Carter (with the exception of Richard Nixon) donated their Presidential papers to NARA through deed of gift agreements.
Deeds of gift include restrictions of materials for national security and invasion of privacy reasons.
What is the Presidential Recordings and Materials Preservation Act?
As a result of the abuses of governmental power commonly known as ""Watergate"" and the controversy that occurred over the disposition of the Nixon tapes and papers documenting these abuses
column2: Congress passed the Presidential Recordings and Materials Preservation Act (PRMPA) in 1974. PRMPA transferred ownership of the Presidential historical materials of Richard Nixon to the Federal government
column3: deposited them with the National Archives and Records Administration (NARA)
column4: and specified access restrictions to these materials.

column1: The act also called for a commission to study and make recommendations regarding the status of the papers of all Federal officials
column2: including those of the President. The findings of this study led to the Presidential Records Act of 1978
column3: vesting ownership of the official records of the President and Vice President with the Federal government after January 20
