column1: 12:35 P.M. EDT
THE PRESIDENT: Thank you very much. (Applause.) Please have a seat. Well
column2: good afternoon
column3: and thank you to Dean Singleton and the board of the Associated Press for inviting me here today. It is a pleasure to speak to all of you -- and to have a microphone that I can see. (Laughter.) Feel free to transmit any of this to Vladimir if you see him. (Laughter.)

column1: Clearly
column2: weÃ¢ÂÂre already in the beginning months of another long
column3: lively election year. There will be gaffes and minor controversies
column4: be hot mics and Etch-a-Sketch moments. You will cover every word that we say
column5: and we will complain vociferously about the unflattering words that you write -- unless
column6: of course
column7: you're writing about the other guy -- in which case
column8: good job. (Laughter.)

column1: But there are also big
column2: fundamental issues at stake right now -- issues that deserve serious debate among every candidate
column3: and serious coverage among every reporter. Whoever he may be
column4: the next President will inherit an economy that is recovering
column5: but not yet recovered
column6: from the worst economic calamity since the Great Depression. Too many Americans will still be looking for a job that pays enough to cover their bills or their mortgage. Too many citizens will still lack the sort of financial security that started slipping away years before this recession hit. A debt that has grown over the last decade
column7: primarily as a result of two wars
column8: two massive tax cuts
column9: and an unprecedented financial crisis
column10: will have to be paid down.

column1: In the face of all these challenges
column2: we're going to have to answer a central question as a nation: What
column3: if anything
column4: can we do to restore a sense of security for people who are willing to work hard and act responsibly in this country? Can we succeed as a country where a shrinking number of people do exceedingly well
column5: while a growing number struggle to get by? Or are we better off when everyone gets a fair shot
column6: and everyone does their fair share
column7: and everyone plays by the same rules?

column1: This is not just another run-of-the-mill political debate. IÃ¢ÂÂve said itÃ¢ÂÂs the defining issue of our time
column2: and I believe it. ItÃ¢ÂÂs why I ran in 2008. ItÃ¢ÂÂs what my presidency has been about. ItÃ¢ÂÂs why IÃ¢ÂÂm running again. I believe this is a make-or-break moment for the middle class
column3: and I canÃ¢ÂÂt remember a time when the choice between competing visions of our future has been so unambiguously clear.

column1: Keep in mind
column2: I have never been somebody who believes that government can or should try to solve every problem. Some of you know my first job in Chicago was working with a group of Catholic churches that often did more good for the people in their communities than any government program could. In those same communities I saw that no education policy
column3: however well crafted
column4: can take the place of a parentÃ¢ÂÂs love and attention.

column1: As President
column2: IÃ¢ÂÂve eliminated dozens of programs that werenÃ¢ÂÂt working
column3: and announced over 500 regulatory reforms that will save businesses and taxpayers billions
column4: and put annual domestic spending on a path to become the smallest share of the economy since Dwight Eisenhower held this office -- since before I was born. I know that the true engine of job creation in this country is the private sector
column5: not Washington
column6: which is why IÃ¢ÂÂve cut taxes for small business owners 17 times over the last three years.

column1: So I believe deeply that the free market is the greatest force for economic progress in human history. My mother and the grandparents who raised me instilled the values of self-reliance and personal responsibility that remain the cornerstone of the American idea. But I also share the belief of our first Republican President
column2: Abraham Lincoln -- a belief that
column3: through government
column4: we should do together what we cannot do as well for ourselves.

column1: That belief is the reason this country has been able to build a strong military to keep us safe
column2: and public schools to educate our children. That belief is why weÃ¢ÂÂve been able to lay down railroads and highways to facilitate travel and commerce. That belief is why weÃ¢ÂÂve been able to support the work of scientists and researchers whose discoveries have saved lives
column3: and unleashed repeated technological revolutions
column4: and led to countless new jobs and entire industries.

column1: That belief is also why weÃ¢ÂÂve sought to ensure that every citizen can count on some basic measure of security. We do this because we recognize that no matter how responsibly we live our lives
column2: any one of us
column3: at any moment
column4: might face hard times
column5: might face bad luck
column6: might face a crippling illness or a layoff. And so we contribute to programs like Medicare and Social Security
column7: which guarantee health care and a source of income after a lifetime of hard work. We provide unemployment insurance
column8: which protects us against unexpected job loss and facilitates the labor mobility that makes our economy so dynamic. We provide for Medicaid
column9: which makes sure that millions of seniors in nursing homes and children with disabilities are getting the care that they need.

column1: For generations
column2: nearly all of these investments -- from transportation to education to retirement programs -- have been supported by people in both parties. As much as we might associate the G.I. Bill with Franklin Roosevelt
column3: or Medicare with Lyndon Johnson
column4: it was a Republican
column5: Lincoln
column6: who launched the Transcontinental Railroad
column7: the National Academy of Sciences
column8: land grant colleges. It was Eisenhower who launched the Interstate Highway System and new investment in scientific research. It was Richard Nixon who created the Environmental Protection Agency
column9: Ronald Reagan who worked with Democrats to save Social Security. It was George W. Bush who added prescription drug coverage to Medicare.

column1: What leaders in both parties have traditionally understood is that these investments arenÃ¢ÂÂt part of some scheme to redistribute wealth from one group to another. They are expressions of the fact that we are one nation. These investments benefit us all. They contribute to genuine
column2: durable economic growth.

column1: Show me a business leader who wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt profit if more Americans could afford to get the skills and education that todayÃ¢ÂÂs jobs require. Ask any company where theyÃ¢ÂÂd rather locate and hire workers Ã¢ÂÂ- a country with crumbling roads and bridges
column2: or one thatÃ¢ÂÂs committed to high-speed Internet and high-speed railroads and high-tech research and development?

column1: It doesnÃ¢ÂÂt make us weaker when we guarantee basic security for the elderly or the sick or those who are actively looking for work. What makes us weaker is when fewer and fewer people can afford to buy the goods and services our businesses sell
column2: or when entrepreneurs donÃ¢ÂÂt have the financial security to take a chance and start a new business. What drags down our entire economy is when thereÃ¢ÂÂs an ever-widening chasm between the ultra-rich and everybody else.

column1: In this country
column2: broad-based prosperity has never trickled down from the success of a wealthy few. It has always come from the success of a strong and growing middle class. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs how a generation who went to college on the G.I. Bill
column3: including my grandfather
column4: helped build the most prosperous economy the world has ever known. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs why a CEO like Henry Ford made it his mission to pay his workers enough so they could buy the cars that they made. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs why research has shown that countries with less inequality tend to have stronger and steadier economic growth over the long run.

column1: And yet
column2: for much of the last century
column3: we have been having the same argument with folks who keep peddling some version of trickle-down economics. They keep telling us that if weÃ¢ÂÂd convert more of our investments in education and research and health care into tax cuts -- especially for the wealthy -- our economy will grow stronger. They keep telling us that if weÃ¢ÂÂd just strip away more regulations
column4: and let businesses pollute more and treat workers and consumers with impunity
column5: that somehow weÃ¢ÂÂd all be better off. WeÃ¢ÂÂre told that when the wealthy become even wealthier
column6: and corporations are allowed to maximize their profits by whatever means necessary
column7: itÃ¢ÂÂs good for America
column8: and that their success will automatically translate into more jobs and prosperity for everybody else. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs the theory.

column1: Now
column2: the problem for advocates of this theory is that weÃ¢ÂÂve tried their approach -- on a massive scale. The results of their experiment are there for all to see. At the beginning of the last decade
column3: the wealthiest Americans received a huge tax cut in 2001 and another huge tax cut in 2003. We were promised that these tax cuts would lead to faster job growth. They did not. The wealthy got wealthier -- we would expect that. The income of the top 1 percent has grown by more than 275 percent over the last few decades
column4: to an average of $1.3 million a year. But prosperity sure didn't trickle down.

column1: Instead
column2: during the last decade
column3: we had the slowest job growth in half a century. And the typical American family actually saw their incomes fall by about 6 percent
column4: even as the economy was growing.

column1: It was a period when insurance companies and mortgage lenders and financial institutions didnÃ¢ÂÂt have to abide by strong enough regulations
column2: or they found their ways around them. And what was the result? Profits for many of these companies soared. But so did peopleÃ¢ÂÂs health insurance premiums. Patients were routinely denied care
column3: often when they needed it most. Families were enticed
column4: and sometimes just plain tricked
column5: into buying homes they couldnÃ¢ÂÂt afford. Huge
column6: reckless bets were made with other peopleÃ¢ÂÂs money on the line. And our entire financial system was nearly destroyed.

column1: So we tried this theory out. And you would think that after the results of this experiment in trickle-down economics
column2: after the results were made painfully clear
column3: that the proponents of this theory might show some humility
column4: might moderate their views a bit. You'd think theyÃ¢ÂÂd say
column5: you know what
column6: maybe some rules and regulations are necessary to protect the economy and prevent people from being taken advantage of by insurance companies or credit card companies or mortgage lenders. Maybe
column7: just maybe
column8: at a time of growing debt and widening inequality
column9: we should hold off on giving the wealthiest Americans another round of big tax cuts. Maybe when we know that most of todayÃ¢ÂÂs middle-class jobs require more than a high school degree
column10: we shouldnÃ¢ÂÂt gut education
column11: or lay off thousands of teachers
column12: or raise interest rates on college loans
column13: or take away peopleÃ¢ÂÂs financial aid.

column1: But thatÃ¢ÂÂs exactly the opposite of what theyÃ¢ÂÂve done. Instead of moderating their views even slightly
column2: the Republicans running Congress right now have doubled down
column3: and proposed a budget so far to the right it makes the Contract with America look like the New Deal. (Laughter.) In fact
column4: that renowned liberal
column5: Newt Gingrich
column6: first called the original version of the budget ""radical"" and said it would contribute to ""right-wing social engineering."" This is coming from Newt Gingrich.

column1: And yet
column2: this isnÃ¢ÂÂt a budget supported by some small rump group in the Republican Party. This is now the partyÃ¢ÂÂs governing platform. This is what theyÃ¢ÂÂre running on. One of my potential opponents
column3: Governor Romney
column4: has said that he hoped a similar version of this plan from last year would be introduced as a bill on day one of his presidency. He said that heÃ¢ÂÂs Ã¢ÂÂvery supportiveÃ¢ÂÂ of this new budget
column5: and he even called it ""marvelous"" -- which is a word you donÃ¢ÂÂt often hear when it comes to describing a budget. (Laughter.) ItÃ¢ÂÂs a word you donÃ¢ÂÂt often hear generally. (Laughter.)

column1: So hereÃ¢ÂÂs what this ""marvelous"" budget does. Back in the summer
column2: I came to an agreement with Republicans in Congress to cut roughly $1 trillion in annual spending. Some of these cuts were about getting rid of waste; others were about programs that we support but just canÃ¢ÂÂt afford given our deficits and our debt. And part of the agreement was a guarantee of another trillion in savings
column3: for a total of about $2 trillion in deficit reduction.

column1: This new House Republican budget
column2: however
column3: breaks our bipartisan agreement and proposes massive new cuts in annual domestic spending Ã¢ÂÂ- exactly the area where weÃ¢ÂÂve already cut the most. And I want to actually go through what it would mean for our country if these cuts were to be spread out evenly. So bear with me. I want to go through this -- because I donÃ¢ÂÂt think people fully appreciate the nature of this budget.

column1: The year after next
column2: nearly 10 million college students would see their financial aid cut by an average of more than $1
column3: 000 each. There would be 1
column4: 600 fewer medical grants
column5: research grants for things like AlzheimerÃ¢ÂÂs and cancer and AIDS. There would be 4
column6: 000 fewer scientific research grants
column7: eliminating support for 48
column8: 000 researchers
column9: students
column10: and teachers. Investments in clean energy technologies that are helping us reduce our dependence on foreign oil would be cut by nearly a fifth.

column1: If this budget becomes law and the cuts were applied evenly
column2: starting in 2014
column3: over 200
column4: 000 children would lose their chance to get an early education in the Head Start program. Two million mothers and young children would be cut from a program that gives them access to healthy food. There would be 4
column5: 500 fewer federal grants at the Department of Justice and the FBI to combat violent crime
column6: financial crime
column7: and help secure our borders. Hundreds of national parks would be forced to close for part or all of the year. We wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt have the capacity to enforce the laws that protect the air we breathe
column8: the water we drink
column9: or the food that we eat.

column1: Cuts to the FAA would likely result in more flight cancellations
column2: delays
column3: and the complete elimination of air traffic control services in parts of the country. Over time
column4: our weather forecasts would become less accurate because we wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt be able to afford to launch new satellites. And that means governors and mayors would have to wait longer to order evacuations in the event of a hurricane.

column1: ThatÃ¢ÂÂs just a partial sampling of the consequences of this budget. Now
column2: you can anticipate Republicans may say
column3: well
column4: weÃ¢ÂÂll avoid some of these cuts -- since they donÃ¢ÂÂt specify exactly the cuts that they would make. But they can only avoid some of these cuts if they cut even deeper in other areas. This is math. If they want to make smaller cuts to medical research that means theyÃ¢ÂÂve got to cut even deeper in funding for things like teaching and law enforcement. The converse is true as well. If they want to protect early childhood education
column5: it will mean further reducing things like financial aid for young people trying to afford college.

column1: Perhaps they will never tell us where the knife will fall -- but you can be sure that with cuts this deep
column2: there is no secret plan or formula that will be able to protect the investments we need to help our economy grow.

column1: This is not conjecture. I am not exaggerating. These are facts. And these are just the cuts that would happen the year after next.
If this budget became law
column2: by the middle of the century
column3: funding for the kinds of things I just mentioned would have to be cut by about 95 percent. Let me repeat that. Those categories I just mentioned we would have to cut by 95 percent. As a practical matter
column4: the federal budget would basically amount to whatever is left in entitlements
column5: defense spending
column6: and interest on the national debt -- period. Money for these investments that have traditionally been supported on a bipartisan basis would be practically eliminated.

column1: And the same is true for other priorities like transportation
column2: and homeland security
column3: and veterans programs for the men and women who have risked their lives for this country. This is not an exaggeration. Check it out yourself.

column1: And this is to say nothing about what the budget does to health care. WeÃ¢ÂÂre told that Medicaid would simply be handed over to the states -- that's the pitch: Let's get it out of the central bureaucracy. The states can experiment. They'll be able to run the programs a lot better. But here's the deal the states would be getting. They would have to be running these programs in the face of the largest cut to Medicaid that has ever been proposed -- a cut that
column2: according to one nonpartisan group
column3: would take away health care for about 19 million Americans -- 19 million.

column1: Who are these Americans? Many are someoneÃ¢ÂÂs grandparents who
column2: without Medicaid
column3: won't be able to afford nursing home care without Medicaid. Many are poor children. Some are middle-class families who have children with autism or DownÃ¢ÂÂs Syndrome. Some are kids with disabilities so severe that they require 24-hour care. These are the people who count on Medicaid.

column1: Then thereÃ¢ÂÂs Medicare. Because health care costs keep rising and the Baby Boom generation is retiring
column2: Medicare
column3: we all know
column4: is one of the biggest drivers of our long-term deficit. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs a challenge we have to meet by bringing down the cost of health care overall so that seniors and taxpayers can share in the savings.

column1: But hereÃ¢ÂÂs the solution proposed by the Republicans in Washington
column2: and embraced by most of their candidates for president: Instead of being enrolled in Medicare when they turn 65
column3: seniors who retire a decade from now would get a voucher that equals the cost of the second cheapest health care plan in their area. If Medicare is more expensive than that private plan
column4: theyÃ¢ÂÂll have to pay more if they want to enroll in traditional Medicare. If health care costs rise faster than the amount of the voucher -- as
column5: by the way
column6: theyÃ¢ÂÂve been doing for decades -- thatÃ¢ÂÂs too bad. Seniors bear the risk. If the voucher isnÃ¢ÂÂt enough to buy a private plan with the specific doctors and care that you need
column7: that's too bad.

column1: So most experts will tell you the way this voucher plan encourages savings is not through better care at cheaper cost. The way these private insurance companies save money is by designing and marketing plans to attract the youngest and healthiest seniors -- cherry-picking -- leaving the older and sicker seniors in traditional Medicare
column2: where they have access to a wide range of doctors and guaranteed care. But that
column3: of course
column4: makes the traditional Medicare program even more expensive
column5: and raise premiums even further.

column1: The net result is that our country will end up spending more on health care
column2: and the only reason the government will save any money -- it wonÃ¢ÂÂt be on our books -- is because weÃ¢ÂÂve shifted it to seniors. TheyÃ¢ÂÂll bear more of the costs themselves. ItÃ¢ÂÂs a bad idea
column3: and it will ultimately end Medicare as we know it.

column1: Now
column2: the proponents of this budget will tell us we have to make all these draconian cuts because our deficit is so large; this is an existential crisis
column3: we have to think about future generations
column4: so on and so on. And that argument might have a shred of credibility were it not for their proposal to also spend $4.6 trillion over the next decade on lower tax rates.

column1: WeÃ¢ÂÂre told that these tax cuts will supposedly be paid for by closing loopholes and eliminating wasteful deductions. But the Republicans in Congress refuse to list a single tax loophole they are willing to close. Not one. And by the way
column2: there is no way to get even close to $4.6 trillion in savings without dramatically reducing all kinds of tax breaks that go to middle-class families -- tax breaks for health care
column3: tax breaks for retirement
column4: tax breaks for homeownership.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: these proposed tax breaks would come on top of more than a trillion dollars in tax giveaways for people making more than $250
column3: 000 a year. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs an average of at least $150
column4: 000 for every millionaire in this country -- $150

column1: LetÃ¢ÂÂs just step back for a second and look at what $150
column2: 000 pays for: A yearÃ¢ÂÂs worth of prescription drug coverage for a senior citizen. Plus a new school computer lab. Plus a year of medical care for a returning veteran. Plus a medical research grant for a chronic disease. Plus a yearÃ¢ÂÂs salary for a firefighter or police officer. Plus a tax credit to make a year of college more affordable. Plus a yearÃ¢ÂÂs worth of financial aid. One hundred fifty thousand dollars could pay for all of these things combined -- investments in education and research that are essential to economic growth that benefits all of us. For $150
column4: that would be going to each millionaire and billionaire in this country. This budget says weÃ¢ÂÂd be better off as a country if thatÃ¢ÂÂs how we spend it.

column1: This is supposed to be about paying down our deficit? ItÃ¢ÂÂs laughable.

The bipartisan Simpson-Bowles commission that I created -- which the Republicans originally were for until I was for it -- that was about paying down the deficit. And I didnÃ¢ÂÂt agree with all the details. I proposed about $600 billion more in revenue and $600 billion -- I'm sorry -- it proposed about $600 billion more in revenue and about $600 billion more in defense cuts than I proposed in my own budget. But Bowles-Simpson was a serious
column2: honest
column3: balanced effort between Democrats and Republicans to bring down the deficit. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs why
column4: although it differs in some ways
column5: my budget takes a similarly balanced approach: Cuts in discretionary spending
column6: cuts in mandatory spending
column7: increased revenue.

column1: This congressional Republican budget is something different altogether. It is a Trojan Horse. Disguised as deficit reduction plans
column2: it is really an attempt to impose a radical vision on our country. It is thinly veiled social Darwinism. It is antithetical to our entire history as a land of opportunity and upward mobility for everybody whoÃ¢ÂÂs willing to work for it; a place where prosperity doesnÃ¢ÂÂt trickle down from the top
column3: but grows outward from the heart of the middle class. And by gutting the very things we need to grow an economy thatÃ¢ÂÂs built to last -- education and training
column4: research and development
column5: our infrastructure -- it is a prescription for decline.

column1: And everybody here should understand that because there's very few people here who haven't benefitted at some point from those investments that were made in the '50s and the '60s and the '70s and the '80s. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs part of how we got ahead. And now
column2: we're going to be pulling up those ladders up for the next generation?

column1: So in the months ahead
column2: I will be fighting as hard as I know how for this truer vision of what the United States of America is all about. Absolutely
column3: we have to get serious about the deficit. And that will require tough choices and sacrifice. And IÃ¢ÂÂve already shown myself willing to make these tough choices when I signed into law the biggest spending cut of any President in recent memory. In fact
column4: if you adjust for the economy
column5: the Congressional Budget Office says the overall spending next year will be lower than any year under Ronald Reagan.

column1: And IÃ¢ÂÂm willing to make more of those difficult spending decisions in the months ahead. But IÃ¢ÂÂve said it before and IÃ¢ÂÂll say it again -- there has to be some balance. All of us have to do our fair share.
IÃ¢ÂÂve also put forward a detailed plan that would reform and strengthen Medicare and Medicaid. By the beginning of the next decade
column2: it achieves the same amount of annual health savings as the plan proposed by Simpson-Bowles -- the Simpson-Bowles commission
column3: and it does so by making changes that people in my party havenÃ¢ÂÂt always been comfortable with. But instead of saving money by shifting costs to seniors
column4: like the congressional Republican plan proposes
column5: our approach would lower the cost of health care throughout the entire system. It goes after excessive subsidies to prescription drug companies. It gets more efficiency out of Medicaid without gutting the program. It asks the very wealthiest seniors to pay a little bit more. It changes the way we pay for health care -- not by procedure or the number of days spent in a hospital
column6: but with new incentives for doctors and hospitals to improve their results.

column1: And it slows the growth of Medicare costs by strengthening an independent commission -- a commission not made up of bureaucrats from government or insurance companies
column2: but doctors and nurses and medical experts and consumers
column3: who will look at all the evidence and recommend the best way to reduce unnecessary health care spending while protecting access to the care that the seniors need.

column1: We also have a much different approach when it comes to taxes -- an approach that says if weÃ¢ÂÂre serious about paying down our debt
column2: we canÃ¢ÂÂt afford to spend trillions more on tax cuts for folks like me
column3: for wealthy Americans who donÃ¢ÂÂt need them and werenÃ¢ÂÂt even asking for them
column4: and that the country cannot afford. At a time when the share of national income flowing to the top 1 percent of people in this country has climbed to levels last seen in the 1920s
column5: those same folks are paying taxes at one of the lowest rates in 50 years. As both I and Warren Buffett have pointed out many times now
column6: heÃ¢ÂÂs paying a lower tax rate than his secretary. That is not fair. It is not right.

column1: And the choice is really very simple. If you want to keep these tax rates and deductions in place -- or give even more tax breaks to the wealthy
column2: as the Republicans in Congress propose -- then one of two things happen: Either it means higher deficits
column3: or it means more sacrifice from the middle class. Seniors will have to pay more for Medicare. College students will lose some of their financial aid. Working families who are scraping by will have to do more because the richest Americans are doing less. I repeat what IÃ¢ÂÂve said before: That is not class warfare
column4: that is not class envy
column5: that is math.

column1: If thatÃ¢ÂÂs the choice that members of Congress want to make
column2: then weÃ¢ÂÂre going to make sure every American knows about it. In a few weeks
column3: there will be a vote on what weÃ¢ÂÂve called the Buffett Rule. Simple concept: If you make more than a million dollars a year -- not that you have a million dollars -- if you make more than a million dollars annually
column4: then you should pay at least the same percentage of your income in taxes as middle-class families do. On the other hand
column5: if you make under $250
column6: 000 a year -- like 98 percent of American families do -- then your taxes shouldnÃ¢ÂÂt go up. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs the proposal.

column1: Now
column2: youÃ¢ÂÂll hear some people point out that the Buffett Rule alone wonÃ¢ÂÂt raise enough revenue to solve our deficit problems. Maybe not
column3: but itÃ¢ÂÂs definitely a step in the right direction. And I intend to keep fighting for this kind of balance and fairness until the other side starts listening
column4: because I believe this is what the American people want. I believe this is the best way to pay for the investments we need to grow our economy and strengthen the middle class. And by the way
column5: I believe itÃ¢ÂÂs the right thing to do.

column1: This larger debate that we will be having and that you will be covering in the coming year about the size and role of government
column2: this debate has been with us since our founding days. And during moments of great challenge and change
column3: like the ones that weÃ¢ÂÂre living through now
column4: the debate gets sharper; it gets more vigorous. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs a good thing. As a country that prizes both our individual freedom and our obligations to one another
column5: this is one of the most important debates that we can have.

column1: But no matter what we argue or where we stand
column2: we have always held certain beliefs as Americans. We believe that in order to preserve our own freedoms and pursue our own happiness
column3: we canÃ¢ÂÂt just think about ourselves. We have to think about the country that made those liberties possible. We have to think about our fellow citizens with whom we share a community. We have to think about whatÃ¢ÂÂs required to preserve the American Dream for future generations.

column1: And this sense of responsibility -- to each other and our country -- this isnÃ¢ÂÂt a partisan feeling. This isnÃ¢ÂÂt a Democratic or Republican idea. ItÃ¢ÂÂs patriotism. And if we keep that in mind
column2: and uphold our obligations to one another and to this larger enterprise that is America
column3: then I have no doubt that we will continue our long and prosperous journey as the greatest nation on Earth.

column1: Thank you. God bless you. God bless the United States of America. (Applause.) Thank you.
MR. SINGLETON: Thank you
column2: Mr. President. We appreciate so much you being with us today. I have some questions from the audience
column3: which I will ask -- and I'll be more careful than I was last time I did this.

column1: Republicans have been sharply critical of your budget ideas as well. What can you say to the Americans who just want both sides to stop fighting and get some work done on their behalf?
THE PRESIDENT: Well
column2: I completely understand the American peopleÃ¢ÂÂs frustrations
column3: because the truth is that these are eminently solvable problems. I know that Christine Lagarde is here from the IMF
column4: and sheÃ¢ÂÂs looking at the books of a lot of other countries around the world. The kinds of challenges they face fiscally are so much more severe than anything that we confront -- if we make some sensible decisions.

column1: So the American peopleÃ¢ÂÂs impulses are absolutely right. These are solvable problems if people of good faith came together and were willing to compromise. The challenge we have right now is that we have on one side
column2: a party that will brook no compromise. And this is not just my assertion. We had presidential candidates who stood on a stage and were asked
column3: Ã¢ÂÂWould you accept a budget package
column4: a deficit reduction plan
column5: that involved $10 of cuts for every dollar in revenue increases?Ã¢ÂÂ Ten-to-one ratio of spending cuts to revenue. Not one of them raised their hand.

column1: Think about that. Ronald Reagan
column2: who
column3: as I recall
column4: is not accused of being a tax-and-spend socialist
column5: understood repeatedly that when the deficit started to get out of control
column6: that for him to make a deal he would have to propose both spending cuts and tax increases. Did it multiple times. He could not get through a Republican primary today.

column1: So let's look at Bowles-Simpson. Essentially
column2: my differences with Bowles-Simpson were I actually proposed less revenue and slightly lower defense spending cuts. The Republicans want to increase defense spending and take in no revenue
column3: which makes it impossible to balance the deficit under the terms that Bowles-Simpson laid out -- unless you essentially eliminate discretionary spending. You don't just cut discretionary spending. Everything we think of as being pretty important -- from education to basic science and research to transportation spending to national parks to environmental protection -- we'd essentially have to eliminate.

column1: I guess another way of thinking about this is -- and this bears on your reporting. I think that there is oftentimes the impulse to suggest that if the two parties are disagreeing
column2: then they're equally at fault and the truth lies somewhere in the middle
column3: and an equivalence is presented -- which reinforces I think people's cynicism about Washington generally. This is not one of those situations where there's an equivalence. I've got some of the most liberal Democrats in Congress who were prepared to make significant changes to entitlements that go against their political interests
column4: and who said they were willing to do it. And we couldn't get a Republican to stand up and say
column5: we'll raise some revenue
column6: or even to suggest that we won't give more tax cuts to people who don't need them.

column1: And so I think it's important to put the current debate in some historical context. It's not just true
column2: by the way
column3: of the budget. It's true of a lot of the debates that we're having out here.

column1: Cap and trade was originally proposed by conservatives and Republicans as a market-based solution to solving environmental problems. The first President to talk about cap and trade was George H.W. Bush. Now you've got the other party essentially saying we shouldnÃ¢ÂÂt even be thinking about environmental protection; let's gut the EPA.
Health care
column2: which is in the news right now -- there's a reason why there's a little bit of confusion in the Republican primary about health care and the individual mandate since it originated as a conservative idea to preserve the private marketplace in health care while still assuring that everybody got covered
column3: in contrast to a single-payer p"	0

column1: Return to Transcripts main page
CNN Live Event/Special
Democratic Candidates Compassion Forum
Aired April 13
THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.
BROWN: Good evening
column2: everybody
column3: to our viewers in the United States and around the world. Welcome to Messiah College in Grantham
column4: Pennsylvania. I'm Campbell Brown.

column1: Tonight
column2: we bring you something different in this already extraordinary campaign year. We are calling it the Compassion Forum
column3: an evening with the Democratic presidential candidates to focus on the issues of faith and compassion and how a president's faith can affect us all.

column1: The focus tonight is to take the conversation beyond the candidate's standard policy points. And some of these questions tonight will be deeply personal.
We are here before a distinguished
column2: bipartisan audience of faith leaders from around the country
column3: from the head of the Southern Baptist Convention to the head of Catholic charities to rabbis and lay leaders.

column1: Before we get started
column2: on behalf of CNN and the candidates
column3: I'd like to thank the people behind tonight's event
column4: Faith in Public Life
column5: the ONE Campaign
column6: Oxfam America
column7: and
column8: of course
column9: our hosts
column10: Messiah College.

column1: And I'd like now to introduce my co-host. Please welcome Jon Meacham. He is the editor of Newsweek and one of America's best-known writers of religion and matters of faith.
Welcome
column2: Jon.

column1: MEACHAM: Thank you.
BROWN: Tonight
column2: we're going to spend about half of our time with Senator Clinton
column3: about half of our time with Senator Obama. The order tonight was decided by coin toss. Senator Clinton won and has elected to go first. Questions will come from Jon and me and from some of the faith leaders assembled here in our audience
column4: so let's get started.

column1: Without further ado
column2: please welcome the senator from New York
column3: Hillary Clinton.

column1: BROWN: Nice to see you. Welcome.
(APPLAUSE)
CLINTON: Thank you. Thank you very much.
BROWN: Senator Clinton
column2: welcome to you.

column1: CLINTON: Thank you.
BROWN: Jon has got the first question.
CLINTON: Great. Well
column2: it's wonderful to be here. I want to thank Messiah College for hosting this. Very good of you to do this.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
MEACHAM: Senator
column2: we'll start with the news. You have been extremely critical of Senator Obama's recent comments in San Francisco in which he argued that some hard-pressed Americans have -- economically hard-pressed Americans have
column3: and I quote
column4: ""gotten bitter and cling to guns or religion or antipathy to people who aren't like them or anti-immigrant sentiment or antitrade sentiment as a way to explain their frustrations.""

column1: Senator
column2: you have written of how faith sustained you in bitter times. Many of us have been sustained by our faith in bitter times. What exactly is wrong with what Senator Obama had to say?

column1: CLINTON: Well
column2: I'm going to let Senator Obama speak for himself. But from my perspective
column3: the characterization of people in a way that really seemed to be elitist and out of touch is something that we have to overcome.

column1: You know
column2: the Democratic Party
column3: to be very blunt about it
column4: has been viewed as a party that didn't understand and respect the values and the way of life of so many of our fellow Americans.

column1: And I think it's important that we make clear that we believe people are people of faith because it is part of their whole being; it is what gives them meaning in life
column2: through good times and bad times. It is there as a spur
column3: an anchor
column4: to center one in the storms
column5: but also to guide one forward in the day-to-day living that is part of everyone's journey.

column1: And
column2: you know
column3: when we think about the legitimate concerns that people have about trade or immigration
column4: those are problems to be solved. And that's what I think we should be focused on.

column1: But I am very confident that
column2: as we move forward tonight and beyond
column3: people will get a chance to get to know each of us a little better
column4: and that's really what I want to talk about. I will leave it to Senator Obama to speak for himself; he does an excellent job of that.

column1: And I will speak for myself on what my faith journey is and what
column2: you know
column3: leads me to this chair here tonight.

column1: BROWN: But
column2: Senator
column3: you've been out there on the stump attacking him pretty aggressively over this. And his response has been -- and he said it pretty bluntly tonight -- shame on you. You know that he is a man of faith. This is what he's saying. And to suggest that he is demeaning religion is you playing politics. CLINTON: Well
column4: he will have to speak for himself and provide his own explanation. But I do think it raises a lot of concerns and we've seen that exhibited in the last several days by people here in Pennsylvania
column5: in Indiana where I was yesterday
column6: and elsewhere
column7: because it did seem so much in-line with what often we are charged with.

column1: Someone goes to a closed-door fund-raiser in San Francisco and makes comments that do seem elitist
column2: out of touch and
column3: frankly
column4: patronizing. That has nothing to do with him being a good man or a man of faith.

column1: We had two very good men and men of faith run for president in 2000 and 2004. But large segments of the electorate concluded that they did not really understand or relate to or frankly respect their ways of life.
And I think that is an issue for voters
column2: as I've heard today from people I visited in Scranton and elsewhere. So this is a legitimate political issue. And there are some issues that are not. But this one is.

column1: And I do believe that Senator Obama will have a chance to explain himself tonight. And I'm sure he will take that opportunity.
BROWN: Let's talk about your faith. And we warned people the questions tonight would be pretty personal. So I want to ask you. You said in an interview last year that you believe in the Father
column2: Son and the Holy Spirit. And you have actually felt the presence of the Holy Spirit on many occasions.

column1: Share some of those occasions with us.
CLINTON: You know
column2: I have
column3: ever since I've been a little girl
column4: felt the presence of God in my life. And it has been a gift of grace that has
column5: for me
column6: been incredibly sustaining. But
column7: really
column8: ever since I was a child
column9: I have felt the enveloping support and love of God and I have had the experiences on many
column10: many occasions where I felt like the holy spirit was there with me as I made a journey.

column1: It didn't have to be a hard time. You know
column2: it could be taking a walk in the woods. It could be watching a sunset.

column1: You know
column2: I am someone who has talked a lot about my life. You know more about my life than you know about nearly anybody else's
column3: about 60 books worth...

column1: (LAUGHTER)
CLINTON: ... some of which are
column2: you know
column3: frankly
column4: a little bit off-base. But I don't think that I could have made my life's journey without being anchored in God's grace and without having that
column5: you know
column6: sense of forgiveness and unconditional love. And I am not going to point to one or another matter. I mean
column7: some of my struggles and challenges have been extremely public. And I have talked about how I have been both guided and supported through those
column8: trying to find my own way through
column9: because
column10: for me
column11: my faith has given me the confidence to make decisions that were right for me
column12: whether anybody else agreed with me or not.

column1: And it is just such a part of who I am and what I have lived through for so many years that trying to pull out and say
column2: oh
column3: I remember
column4: I was sitting right there when I felt
column5: you know
column6: God's love embrace me
column7: would be
column8: I think
column9: trivializing what has been an extraordinary sense of support and possibility that I have had with me my entire life.

column1: MEACHAM: Senator
column2: you -- right after New Hampshire
column3: you and I had a conversation a couple of days after that in which you described your moment in the setting where you said that you worked very hard and it was seen as a turning point by many people. You described that as a moment of grace.

column1: CLINTON: Yes.
MEACHAM: So that is a specific in...
CLINTON: Right
column2: right. Well
column3: you know
column4: Jon
column5: it is -- it is perhaps a reluctance on my part that is rooted in my personal reserve
column6: rooted in the way I was raised
column7: that I worry and I -- you know
column8: I understand you want to ask a lot of personal questions
column9: and I appreciate that.

column1: But I also worry
column2: as I suggested to you in that same interview
column3: that you have to walk the walk of faith. And talking about it is important because it's important to share that experience. But I also believe that
column4: you know
column5: faith is just -- it's grace. It's love. It's mystery. It's provocation.

column1: It is everything that makes life and its purpose meaningful as a human being.
CLINTON: And those moments of grace are ones that I cherish and
column2: you know
column3: in asked a specific question about how I felt when I shared my belief that politics is not a game
column4: it is not a who's up
column5: who's down.

column1: I mean
column2: it is a serious search and we are so fortunate because we have taken the gifts that God gave us and we have created this democracy where we choose our leaders and we have to be more mindful of how important and serious a business this is.

column1: And
column2: therefore
column3: when I say politics is not a game
column4: it is really coming from deep within me because I know that we have the opportunity to really give other people a chance to live up to their own God-given potential. And that
column5: to me
column6: is the kind of grace note that makes politics worthwhile. Because
column7: believe me
column8: there's a lot about it that is not particularly welcoming or easy.

column1: But every day as I travel around the country
column2: I meet people whose faith just knocks me over. I mean
column3: I was with a woman in Philadelphia Friday morning whose son was murdered on the streets in Philadelphia
column4: whose grandson was murdered. And she and I just sat together and she told me about how strong her faith is and how it has sustained her and how she believes
column5: you know
column6: God is with her and she doesn't understand why this happened to her son and her grandson.

column1: But every day she's grateful
column2: and she is determined to be the person that she believes God meant her to be. And so when I sit there and I listen to that woman tell me about how it felt and how today she is still
column3: you know
column4: getting up every morning
column5: has a smile on her face
column6: looking to go to her daycare business and take care of all of these children who have been entrusted to her
column7: that's a moment of grace.

column1: But it's not about me. I mean
column2: not every moment of grace is about you. More often it is about the interaction and the relationship. You know
column3: grace is that relationship with God. But it's also the relationships with our fellow human beings in which we know grace is present. And so I just feel very fortunate that
column4: you know
column5: I have been able to experience that and I wish it for everyone.

column1: BROWN: Let's bring a question in from one of the religious leaders joining us tonight. Dr. Joel Hunter
column2: who is senior pastor of the 12
column3: 000-member Northland Church in Longwood
column4: Florida. Dr. Hunter?

column1: CLINTON: How are you
column2: Dr. Hunter? Good to see you.

column1: PASTOR JOEL HUNTER
column2: NORTHLAND CHURCH: I'm fine
column3: Senator. Good to see you. Senator
column4: many of the issues we're going to be talking about tonight
column5: Darfur
column6: AIDS
column7: abortion
column8: torture
column9: could present you with choices that will have life and death consequences for countless people around the world. What are the first principles you fall back on to make such decisions? Are there certain activities or references or people with whom you consult in order to do what is morally right?

column1: CLINTON: You know
column2: Dr. Hunter
column3: I think this is one of the challenges that face any of us who are in public life where literally you do have the authority to make these decisions that could very well be life and death decisions and they are daunting and I do not pretend to know how I will deal with every single one of them.

column1: But I do have a sense of the process by which I will try to approach them. And it really is rooted in
column2: you know
column3: my prayer
column4: my contemplation
column5: my study. I think you have to immerse yourself in advice
column6: information
column7: criticism from others. I don't pretend to even believe that I know the answers to a lot of these questions. I don't.

column1: But I do believe that you have to be willing to expose yourself to many different points of view and then you have to make that decision. I think that for a lot of us
column2: decisions are ones that you don't just make and put on a shelf. To be fair to be constantly struggling and challenging yourself
column3: you have to keep opening up that decision and asking.

column1: CLINTON: And very often
column2: as you know
column3: some decisions look like they're 100-to-nothing until you actually examine them. And some decisions truly are right down the middle
column4: and you're not sure which side of the line you will decide upon.

column1: You mentioned some of the very difficult decisions that we are going to face
column2: and there are countless more. How do we get out of Iraq the right way? Everyone knows there is no easy
column3: comfortable decision.

column1: I believe we've got to begin taking our troops out of Iraq based on my analysis of what I think is the best path forward for us and for the Iraqis. But I am deeply aware that there will be predictable and unpredictable consequences. And part of making a decision is having to live with the consequences.
And I have been very fortunate in my life to have people whom I feel very comfortable talking to openly
column2: with total frankness
column3: seeking their guidance. They don't all agree with me; they don't all share my view
column4: when I start the conversation
column5: perhaps.

column1: But I don't think you can surround yourself only with people with whom you think you will agree. And
column2: for me
column3: being amongst people who challenge me
column4: who make me uncomfortable
column5: to be very blunt
column6: is an important part of my decisionmaking process.

column1: I want to push back; I want to argue; I want to raise other hypotheticals and throw them back to see what the outcome is.
But at the end of the day
column2: since we are running to be the president of the United States
column3: you have to be comfortable making a decision
column4: because you cannot say
column5: ""Well
column6: let's put it on the back burner and then get back to it some time when it's clearer
column7: for many of these decisions. And then you have to live with the consequences.

column1: But I hope I will never
column2: ever find myself being defensive or abrupt and dismissive of people who disagree with me. I regret that that often happens in politics
column3: and maybe it's because oftentimes the decisionmaking process is so exhausting.

column1: You know
column2: if you're a person of faith
column3: after you've prayed
column4: if you're a person willing to subject yourself to criticism
column5: after you've done it
column6: you're just so relieved to make the decision you don't want to revisit it. But I don't think that a president can afford to do that.

column1: MEACHAM: Senator
column2: do you believe personally that life begins at conception?

column1: CLINTON: I believe that the potential for life begins at conception. I am a Methodist
column2: as you know. My church has struggled with this issue. In fact
column3: you can look at the Methodist Book of Discipline and see the contradiction and the challenge of trying to sort that very profound question out.

column1: But for me
column2: it is also not only about a potential life; it is about the other lives involved. And
column3: therefore
column4: I have concluded
column5: after great
column6: you know
column7: concern and searching my own mind and heart over many years
column8: that our task should be in this pluralistic
column9: diverse life of ours in this nation that individuals must be entrusted to make this profound decision
column10: because the alternative would be such an intrusion of government authority that it would be very difficult to sustain in our kind of open society.

column1: And as some of you've heard me discuss before
column2: I think abortion should remain legal
column3: but it needs to be safe and rare.

column1: And I have spent many years now
column2: as a private citizen
column3: as first lady
column4: and now as senator
column5: trying to make it rare
column6: trying to create the conditions where women had other choices.

column1: I have supported adoption
column2: foster care. I helped to create the campaign against teenage pregnancy
column3: which fulfilled our original goal 10 years ago of reducing teenage pregnancies by about a third.

column1: And I think we have to do even more.
CLINTON: And I am committed to doing that. And I guess I would just add from my own personal experience
column2: I have been in countries that have taken very different views about this profoundly challenging question.

column1: Some of you know
column2: I went to China in 1995 and spoke out against the Chinese government's one child policy
column3: which led to forced abortions and forced sterilization because I believed that we needed to bear witness against what was an intrusive
column4: abusive
column5: dehumanizing effort to dictate how women and men would proceed with respect to the children they wished to have.

column1: And then shortly after that
column2: I was in Romania and there I met women who had been subjected to the Communist regime of the 1970s and '80s where they were essentially forced to bear as many children as possible for the good of the state. And where abortion was criminalized and women were literally forced to have physical exams and followed by the secret police and so many children were abandoned and left to the orphanages that
column3: unfortunately
column4: led to an AIDS epidemic.

column1: So
column2: you know
column3: when I think about this issue
column4: I think about the whole range of concerns and challenges associated with it and I will continue to do what I can to reduce the number and to improve and increase the care for women and particularly the adoption system and the other opportunities that women would have to make different choices.

column1: BROWN: Senator
column2: I want to go to the other end of the spectrum and the end of life and ask you
column3: do you believe it is compassionate
column4: that it is appropriate to let someone who is really suffering choose to end their life?

column1: CLINTON: Again
column2: this is one of those incredibly challenging issues. You know
column3: the Terry Schiavo case in Florida posed that for many people. And it was one of those decisions to go back to Dr. Hunter's point
column4: where there were people of good faith and people of strong feelings on both sides about what should happen to that woman's life.

column1: And I don't know that any of us is in a position to make that choice for families or for individuals
column2: but I don't want us also to condone government action that would legitimize or encourage end of life decisions. Somehow there has to be a framework for us to determine how can people who are either able to make these decisions on their own do so? Or if they are not
column3: how best do we create a decision process for their families to try to decide?

column1: And now we are being faced with a lot of these difficult decisions because of what the world we live in today with modern technology and so much else. And we're going to have to come to grips with them one way or another.
BROWN: We've got to take a quick break
column2: a commercial break. We'll be back. Much more with Senator Clinton
column3: right after this.

column1: (COMMERCIAL BREAK)
BROWN: Welcome back to ""The Compassion Forum""
column2: everyone. We're here with Senator Hillary Clinton.

column1: And
column2: Senator
column3: there are a lot of Americans who are uncomfortable with the conversation that we're having here tonight. That they believe religion already has way too much influence in political life and public life. How do you reassure them?

column1: CLINTON: Well
column2: I understand that concern because part of our obligation as leaders in America is to make sure that any conversation about religion is inclusive and respectful. And that has not always happened
column3: as we know. And it is so personal. The spiritual journey that each of us takes or doesn't take.

column1: And I think it's important that we recognize that for good cause
column2: I mean
column3: we have been such a vibrant nation when it comes to religious experience in large measure because we've always protected ourselves against
column4: you know
column5: religion going too far
column6: being too intrusive. So it is a balance. And we want religion to be in the public square. If you are a person of faith
column7: you have a right and even an obligation to speak from that wellspring of your faith. But to do so in a respectful and inclusive way.

column1: So I understand why some people
column2: even religious people
column3: even people of faith might say
column4: why are you having this forum? And why are you exploring these issues from two people who are vying to be president of the United States?

column1: And I think that's a fair question to ask. I am here because I think it's also fair for us to have this conversation. But I'm very conscious of how thoughtful we must proceed.
BROWN: Another question from the audience. Rabbi Steve Gutow
column2: who is director of the Jewish Council for Public Affairs is with us.

column1: Rabbi?
RABBI STEVE GUTOW
column2: JEWISH COUNCIL FOR PUBLIC AFFAIRS: Senator Clinton?

column1: CLINTON: Yes
column2: Rabbi.

column1: GUTOW: Back to China. China has continued to persecute and subject to oppression
column2: the people of Tibet. It continues to be the largest supplier of weapons to Sudan and the largest purchaser of its oil. Let's just say China is not doing all it can to stop the genocide in Darfur. You have said that America needs to return to being a moral voice of the world.

column1: Is our participation in the Beijing Olympics harmful to that moral voice?
CLINTON: Well
column2: Rabbi
column3: I appreciate your asking this question because I think it's a question of both political and moral significance. And that's why last week I called on our president to decide he would not attend the opening ceremonies of the Olympics because that is a public and very obvious ratification of our government's approval of the Beijing government's actions.

column1: CLINTON: Unless the Chinese began to take very visible steps to begin to end the suppression of the Tibetans and undermining their culture and religious beliefs
column2: and if we could get more cooperation out of the Chinese government with respect to Sudan.

column1: And
column2: of course
column3: I would welcome even more action on behalf of human rights. But the challenge is
column4: how do we try to influence the Chinese government? And I believe we have missed many opportunities during the Bush administration to do so.

column1: In fact
column2: I think it's fair to say our policy toward China is incoherent and that has not been in the best interest of our values or our strategic interest. So I would urge the president at least to consider and
column3: therefore
column4: publicly say that he will not be attending the opening ceremonies.

column1: And let's see whether the Chinese government begins to respond because that for them would be a great loss of face and perhaps we would get more cooperation. We would get the process going that the Dalai Lama has asked for over many years.
There could be a lot of ways that the Chinese government demonstrated it heard our concerns.
BROWN: A question from Reverend William Shaw. He is the president of the National Baptist Convention.
Reverend Shaw?
CLINTON: He is. Hello
column2: Reverend Shaw. Good to see you again.

column1: REV. WILLIAM J. SHAW
column2: NATIONAL BAPTIST CONVENTION: Senator. Current U.S. policies toward developing countries -- trade policies
column3: make it sometimes extremely difficult for poor people to access inexpensive
column4: generic drugs for the treatment of AIDS and other sicknesses.

column1: How would you shape the policies of your administration to ensure that the poor would have access to and could secure the drugs that they need to improve the quality of their lives
column2: of their families and even the future of their country?

column1: CLINTON: Well
column2: Reverend Shaw
column3: I agree with your description of this problem
column4: and I believe that our government must do so much more to get generic drugs and low-cost drugs to people suffering.

column1: Not only from HIV/AIDS
column2: but the range of diseases that affect disproportionately the poor. It's one of the reasons why I voted against the free trade agreement with Central America
column3: because there was a provision that would give even more power to our pharmaceutical companies to prevent exactly doing what you are discussing.

column1: I have been an outspoken advocate in urging that both our great pharmaceutical companies -- which do a lot of good. Because
column2: after all
column3: they invent the compounds and put them together that the generics then are able to copy.

column1: But we need to do much more to get our pharmaceutical companies to work with us to get the drug costs down and to open the pathway for generic drugs. And that's going to take presidential leadership.
I commend President Bush for his PEPFAR initiative. It was a very bold and important commitment
column2: but it didn't go far enough in opening up the door to generics and getting the costs down.

column1: And as president
column2: I will do that.

column1: MEACHAM: Senator
column2: we've heard about HIV/AIDS. Many people here are concerned about Darfur and a number of other humanitarian issues. Why do you think it is that a loving God allows innocent people to suffer?

column1: CLINTON: Well...
(LAUGHTER)
MEACHAM: And we just have 30 seconds.
CLINTON: Yes. You know
column2: that is the subject of generations of commentary and debate. And I don't know. I can't wait to ask him. Because I have...

column1: (LAUGHTER)
CLINTON: I have just pondered it endless endlessly.
(APPLAUSE)
CLINTON: But I do want to just add that what that means to me is that in the face of suffering
column2: there is no doubt in my mind that God calls us to respond. You know
column3: that's part of what we are expected to do.

column1: For whatever reason it exists
column2: it's very existence is a call to action. Certainly in
column3: you know
column4: our...

column1: (APPLAUSE)
CLINTON: You know
column2: in my Judeo-Christian faith tradition
column3: in both the Old and the New Testament
column4: the incredible demands that God places on us and that the prophets ask of us
column5: and that Christ called us to respond to on behalf of the poor are unavoidable.

column1: CLINTON: And it's always been curious to me how our debate about religion in America too often misses that. You know
column2: his holiness
column3: the pope
column4: is going to be coming to America next week
column5: and he's been a strong voice on behalf of what we must do to deal with poverty
column6: and deal with injustice
column7: and deal with what is truly our obligations toward those who are the least among us.

column1: So maybe
column2: you know
column3: the lord is just waiting for us to respond to his call
column4: because this despair
column5: this impoverishment of body and soul is what we are expected to be spending our time responding to
column6: and so few of us do.

column1: Even those who are doing wonderful work with organizations represented in this audience
column2: we are just not doing enough. And it's a personal call; it's a family community
column3: religious call; and it's a governmental call. And we've got to do more to respond to that call.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BROWN: Quickly
column2: just you brought up the Bible. We were talking theology. Do you have a favorite Bible story?

column1: CLINTON: Oh
column2: I have so many of them. You know
column3: I was fortunate as a child growing up to be read Bible stories
column4: to go to Sunday school
column5: to go to Bible school. And Bill and I read
column6: you know
column7: Bible stories to Chelsea.

column1: And
column2: you know
column3: I have talked about Bible stories and parables a lot in my life with friends. And
column4: you know
column5: it depends upon what's going on in my life at the time.

column1: But clearly
column2: for me
column3: the recent Purim holiday for Jews raised the question of Esther. And I have been -- ever since I was a little girl -- a great admirer of Esther. And I used to ask that that be read to me over and over again
column4: because there weren't too many models of women who had the opportunity to make a decision
column5: to take a chance
column6: a risk that
column7: you know
column8: was very courageous.

column1: And so that's the one that's most recently on my mind
column2: because I have some rabbi friends who send me readings that go with the scripture of the week. And certainly
column3: Esther is someone who I wish I knew even more about than what we know from the Bible.

column1: BROWN: A question from Eboo Patel
column2: who is a Muslim
column3: is the founder and executive director of the Interfaith Youth Core.

column1: Welcome.
CLINTON: Hello.
QUESTION: As-Salamu Alaykum
column2: Senator Clinton.

column1: CLINTON: Thank you.
QUESTION: My name is Eboo Patel. I'm an American Muslim
column2: and I lead an organization called the Interfaith Youth Core. And it's my privilege to watch a range of faith communities come together around the common value of compassion.

column1: Americans of all faiths and no faith at all genuinely believe in compassion and want to apply that in addressing global poverty and climate change. Can we do that without changing our standard of living?
CLINTON: Well
column2: I believe there is so much we can do that we're not doing that would not change our standard of living as an imposition from the outside
column3: but which would inspire us to take action that would impact how we live.

column1: And I don't think we would notice it demonstrably undermining our standard of living
column2: but it would give us the opportunity to set an example and to be a model.

column1: When I think about the simple steps any one of us can take -- you know
column2: turning off lights when one leaves a room
column3: unplugging appliances
column4: changing to compact florescent bulbs -- you know
column5: my husband and I have done that -- I don't think it's impacted our standard of living
column6: but we feel like we're making a small contribution to limiting the amount of greenhouse gas emissions
column7: you know
column8: being more mindful of our purchases.

column1: I hope that
column2: as president
column3: I can model that and lead that effort so that people don't feel so threatened by the changes we're talking about when it comes to dealing with global warming.

column1: In preparation for the pope's visit
column2: I was reading that the Vatican is the first carbon-neutral state in the world now. Well
column3: that shows leadership. And I don't think it has impacted the work or the living. You know
column4: Ambassador Flynn
column5: who was our ambassador to the Vatican
column6: might know. But it was a great statement.

column1: And we can do more.
CLINTON: And I think that
column2: with leadership
column3: people will find ways to take those first steps. And then we can take even more.

column1: Now there's so much that I have to do as president with the cap in trade system
column2: with moving away from our dependence on foreign oil
column3: but I'm going to look for ways that will cushion the costs on middle class and working and poor people. Because I don't believe that they should have to bear more than what they are bearing right now as we make this transition. And I believe we can accomplish that.

column1: BROWN: Let's go to Lisa Sharon Harper. She is the executive director of New York Faith and Justice. Welcome to you.
LISA SHARON HARPER
column2: N.Y. FAITH AND JUSTICE: Thank you. Senator Clinton
column3: underdeveloped nations and regions that lack widespread access to education and basic resources like water
column4: and they tend to be some of the most unstable and dangerous regions of the world. Places like Pakistan
column5: Somalia
column6: Sudan. Our national security is at stake
column7: but our military is stretched. As president
column8: would you consider committing U.S. troops to a purely humanitarian mission under the leadership of a foreign flag?

column1: CLINTON: Well
column2: let me start by saying
column3: No. 1
column4: I believe strongly that we have to get back to leading on issues like health care and education and women's rights around the world. I have introduced legislation called The Education for All Act. And it's bipartisan. I introduced it first in '04 and then we reintroduced it on a bipartisan basis in '07.

column1: And the work that I would want to do to have the United States lead the world in putting the 77 million kids who aren't in school into school
column2: having us lead when it comes to health care
column3: particularly in malaria
column4: T.B.
column5: HIV/AIDS
column6: but also women's health which has been woefully neglected.

column1: I believe we should demonstrate our commitment to people who are poor
column2: disenfranchised
column3: disempowered before we talk about putting troops anywhere. The United States has to be seen again as a peacekeeper
column4: and we have lost that standing in these last seven years.

column1: Therefore
column2: I want us to have a partnership
column3: government to government
column4: government with the private sector
column5: government with our NGOS and our faith community to show the best of what America has to offer. You know
column6: I really appreciated President Bush after the tsunami struck
column7: asking his father and my husband to represent the United States and our concern for the people who have been devastated.

column1: And
column2: yes
column3: the military was there delivering supplies. That sent a loud message and it was resonating throughout South Asia -- in Indonesia
column4: the largest Muslim country in the world. America's favorability rose dramatically because we were seen as caring and compassionate toward those with whom we had very little contact or
column5: in fact
column6: some
column7: you know
column8: level of distrust previously.

column1: So I think we have to concentrate first and foremost on restoring our moral authority in the world and our standing in the world. And there are lots of ways that the United State"	0
