229	"It is for that reason that I rise today
column2: to talk about the truth
column3: and its relationship to democracy. For without truth
column4: and a principled fidelity to truth and to shared facts
column5: Mr. President
column6: our democracy will not last.

column1: 2017 was a year which saw the truth Ã¢ÂÂ objective
column2: empirical
column3: evidence-based truth -- more battered and abused than any other in the history of our country
column4: at the hands of the most powerful figure in our government. It was a year which saw the White House enshrine Ã¢ÂÂalternative factsÃ¢ÂÂ into the American lexicon
column5: as justification for what used to be known simply as good old-fashioned falsehoods. It was the year in which an unrelenting daily assault on the constitutionally-protected free press was launched by that same White House
column6: an assault that is as unprecedented as it is unwarranted. Ã¢ÂÂThe enemy of the people
column7: Ã¢ÂÂ was what the president of the United States called the free press in 2017.

column1: Mr. President
column2: it is a testament to the condition of our democracy that our own president uses words infamously spoken by Josef Stalin to describe his enemies. It bears noting that so fraught with malice was the phrase Ã¢ÂÂenemy of the people
column3: Ã¢ÂÂ that even Nikita Khrushchev forbade its use
column4: telling the Soviet Communist Party that the phrase had been introduced by Stalin for the purpose of Ã¢ÂÂannihilating such individualsÃ¢ÂÂ who disagreed with the supreme leader.

column1: This alone should be a source of great shame for us in this body
column2: especially for those of us in the presidentÃ¢ÂÂs party. For they are shameful
column3: repulsive statements. And
column4: of course
column5: the president has it precisely backward Ã¢ÂÂ despotism is the enemy of the people. The free press is the despotÃ¢ÂÂs enemy
column6: which makes the free press the guardian of democracy. When a figure in power reflexively calls any press that doesnÃ¢ÂÂt suit him Ã¢ÂÂfake news
column7: Ã¢ÂÂ it is that person who should be the figure of suspicion
column8: not the press.

column1: I dare say that anyone who has the privilege and awesome responsibility to serve in this chamber knows that these reflexive slurs of Ã¢ÂÂfake newsÃ¢ÂÂ are dubious
column2: at best. Those of us who travel overseas
column3: especially to war zones and other troubled areas around the globe
column4: encounter members of U.S. based media who risk their lives
column5: and sometimes lose their lives
column6: reporting on the truth. To dismiss their work as fake news is an affront to their commitment and their sacrifice.

column1: According to the International Federation of Journalists
column2: 80 journalists were killed in 2017
column3: and a new report from the Committee to Protect Journalists documents that the number of journalists imprisoned around the world has reached 262
column4: which is a new record. This total includes 21 reporters who are being held on Ã¢ÂÂfalse newsÃ¢ÂÂ charges.

column1: Mr. President
column2: so powerful is the presidency that the damage done by the sustained attack on the truth will not be confined to the presidentÃ¢ÂÂs time in office. Here in America
column3: we do not pay obeisance to the powerful Ã¢ÂÂ in fact
column4: we question the powerful most ardently Ã¢ÂÂ to do so is our birthright and a requirement of our citizenship -- and so
column5: we know well that no matter how powerful
column6: no president will ever have dominion over objective reality.

column1: No politician will ever get to tell us what the truth is and is not. And anyone who presumes to try to attack or manipulate the truth to his own purposes should be made to realize the mistake and be held to account. That is our job here. And that is just as Madison
column2: Hamilton
column3: and Jay would have it.

column1: Of course
column2: a major difference between politicians and the free press is that the press usually corrects itself when it gets something wrong. Politicians donÃ¢ÂÂt.

column1: No longer can we compound attacks on truth with our silent acquiescence. No longer can we turn a blind eye or a deaf ear to these assaults on our institutions. And Mr. President
column2: an American president who cannot take criticism Ã¢ÂÂ who must constantly deflect and distort and distract Ã¢ÂÂ who must find someone else to blame -- is charting a very dangerous path. And a Congress that fails to act as a check on the president adds to the danger.

column1: Now
column2: we are told via twitter that today the president intends to announce his choice for the Ã¢ÂÂmost corrupt and dishonestÃ¢ÂÂ media awards. It beggars belief that an American president would engage in such a spectacle. But here we are.

column1: And so
column2: 2018 must be the year in which the truth takes a stand against power that would weaken it. In this effort
column3: the choice is quite simple. And in this effort
column4: the truth needs as many allies as possible. Together
column5: my colleagues
column6: we are powerful. Together
column7: we have it within us to turn back these attacks
column8: right these wrongs
column9: repair this damage
column10: restore reverence for our institutions
column11: and prevent further moral vandalism.

column1: Together
column2: united in the purpose to do our jobs under the Constitution
column3: without regard to party or party loyalty
column4: let us resolve to be allies of the truth -- and not partners in its destruction.

column1: It is not my purpose here to inventory all of the official untruths of the past year. But a brief survey is in order. Some untruths are trivial Ã¢ÂÂ such as the bizarre contention regarding the crowd size at last yearÃ¢ÂÂs inaugural.

But many untruths are not at all trivial Ã¢ÂÂ such as the seminal untruth of the presidentÃ¢ÂÂs political career - the oft-repeated conspiracy about the birthplace of President Obama. Also not trivial are the equally pernicious fantasies about rigged elections and massive voter fraud
column2: which are as destructive as they are inaccurate Ã¢ÂÂ to the effort to undermine confidence in the federal courts
column3: federal law enforcement
column4: the intelligence community and the free press
column5: to perhaps the most vexing untruth of all Ã¢ÂÂ the supposed Ã¢ÂÂhoaxÃ¢ÂÂ at the heart of special counsel Robert MuellerÃ¢ÂÂs Russia investigation.

column1: To be very clear
column2: to call the Russia matter a Ã¢ÂÂhoaxÃ¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ as the president has many times Ã¢ÂÂ is a falsehood. We know that the attacks orchestrated by the Russian government during the election were real and constitute a grave threat to both American sovereignty and to our national security. It is in the interest of every American to get to the bottom of this matter
column3: wherever the investigation leads.

column1: Ignoring or denying the truth about hostile Russian intentions toward the United States leaves us vulnerable to further attacks. We are told by our intelligence agencies that those attacks are ongoing
column2: yet it has recently been reported that there has not been a single cabinet-level meeting regarding Russian interference and how to defend America against these attacks. Not one. What might seem like a casual and routine untruth Ã¢ÂÂ so casual and routine that it has by now become the white noise of Washington - is in fact a serious lapse in the defense of our country.

column1: Mr. President
column2: let us be clear. The impulses underlying the dissemination of such untruths are not benign. They have the effect of eroding trust in our vital institutions and conditioning the public to no longer trust them. The destructive effect of this kind of behavior on our democracy cannot be overstated.

column1: Mr. President
column2: every word that a president utters projects American values around the world. The values of free expression and a reverence for the free press have been our global hallmark
column3: for it is our ability to freely air the truth that keeps our government honest and keeps a people free. Between the mighty and the modest
column4: truth is the great leveler. And so
column5: respect for freedom of the press has always been one of our most important exports.

column1: But a recent report published in our free press should raise an alarm. Reading from the story:
Ã¢ÂÂIn FebruaryÃ¢ÂÂ¦Syrian President Bashar Assad brushed off an Amnesty International report that some 13
column2: 000 people had been killed at one of his military prisons by saying
column3: Ã¢ÂÂYou can forge anything these days
column4: we are living in a fake news era.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: In the Philippines
column2: President Rodrigo Duterte has complained of being Ã¢ÂÂdemonizedÃ¢ÂÂ by Ã¢ÂÂfake news.Ã¢ÂÂ Last month
column3: the report continues
column4: with our President
column5: quote Ã¢ÂÂlaughing by his sideÃ¢ÂÂ Duterte called reporters Ã¢ÂÂspies.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: In July
column2: Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro complained to the Russian propaganda outlet
column3: that the world media had Ã¢ÂÂspread lots of false versions
column4: lots of liesÃ¢ÂÂ about his country
column5: adding
column6: Ã¢ÂÂThis is what we call Ã¢ÂÂfake newsÃ¢ÂÂ today
column7: isnÃ¢ÂÂt it?Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: There are more:
Ã¢ÂÂA state official in Myanmar recently said
column2: Ã¢ÂÂThere is no such thing as Rohingya. It is fake news
column3: Ã¢ÂÂ referring to the persecuted ethnic group.

column1: Leaders in Singapore
column2: a country known for restricting free speech
column3: have promised Ã¢ÂÂfake newsÃ¢ÂÂ legislation in the new year.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: And on and on. This feedback loop is disgraceful
column2: Mr. President. Not only has the past year seen an American president borrow despotic language to refer to the free press
column3: but it seems he has in turn inspired dictators and authoritarians with his own language. This is reprehensible.

column1: We are not in a Ã¢ÂÂfake newsÃ¢ÂÂ era
column2: as Bashar Assad says. We are
column3: rather
column4: in an era in which the authoritarian impulse is reasserting itself
column5: to challenge free people and free societies
column6: everywhere.

column1: In our own country
column2: from the trivial to the truly dangerous
column3: it is the range and regularity of the untruths we see that should be cause for profound alarm
column4: and spur to action. Add to that the by-now predictable habit of calling true things false
column5: and false things true
column6: and we have a recipe for disaster. As George Orwell warned
column7: Ã¢ÂÂThe further a society drifts from the truth
column8: the more it will hate those who speak it.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: Any of us who have spent time in public life have endured news coverage we felt was jaded or unfair. But in our positions
column2: to employ even idle threats to use laws or regulations to stifle criticism is corrosive to our democratic institutions. Simply put: it is the pressÃ¢ÂÂs obligation to uncover the truth about power. It is the peopleÃ¢ÂÂs right to criticize their government. And it is our job to take it.

column1: What is the goal of laying siege to the truth? President John F. Kennedy
column2: in a stirring speech on the 20th anniversary of the Voice of America
column3: was eloquent in answer to that question:

column1: Ã¢ÂÂWe are not afraid to entrust the American people with unpleasant facts
column2: foreign ideas
column3: alien philosophies
column4: and competitive values. For a nation that is afraid to let its people judge the truth and falsehood in an open market is a nation that is afraid of its people.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: Mr. President
column2: the question of why the truth is now under such assault may well be for historians to determine. But for those who cherish American constitutional democracy
column3: what matters is the effect on America and her people and her standing in an increasingly unstable world -- made all the more unstable by these very fabrications. What matters is the daily disassembling of our democratic institutions.

column1: We are a mature democracy Ã¢ÂÂ it is well past time that we stop excusing or ignoring Ã¢ÂÂ or worse
column2: endorsing -- these attacks on the truth. For if we compromise the truth for the sake of our politics
column3: we are lost.

column1: I sincerely thank my colleagues for their indulgence today. I will close by borrowing the words of an early adherent to my faith that I find has special resonance at this moment. His name was John Jacques
column2: and as a young missionary in England he contemplated the question: Ã¢ÂÂWhat is truth?Ã¢ÂÂ His search was expressed in poetry and ultimately in a hymn that I grew up with
column3: titled Ã¢ÂÂOh Say
column4: What is Truth.Ã¢ÂÂ It ends as follows:

column1: Ã¢ÂÂThen say
column2: what is truth? Ã¢ÂÂTis the last and the first

column1: For the limits of time it steps oÃ¢ÂÂer.
Tho the heavens depart and the earthÃ¢ÂÂs fountains burst.
Truth
column2: the sum of existence
column3: will weather the worst

column1: EternalÃ¢ÂÂ¦ unchangedÃ¢ÂÂ¦ evermore.Ã¢ÂÂ
Thank you
column2: Mr. President. I yield the floor.

233	"WASHINGTON

SENATORS say they fear the N.R.A. and the gun lobby. But I think that fear must be nothing compared to the fear the first graders in Sandy Hook Elementary School felt as their lives ended in a hail of bullets. The fear that those children who survived the massacre must feel every time they remember their teachers stacking them into closets and bathrooms
column2: whispering that they loved them
column3: so that love would be the last thing the students heard if the gunman found them.

column1: On Wednesday
column2: a minority of senators gave into fear and blocked common-sense legislation that would have made it harder for criminals and people with dangerous mental illnesses to get hold of deadly firearms Ã¢ÂÂ a bill that could prevent future tragedies like those in Newtown
column3: Conn.
column4: Aurora
column5: Colo.
column6: Blacksburg
column7: Va.
column8: and too many communities to count.

column1: Some of the senators who voted against the background-check amendments have met with grieving parents whose children were murdered at Sandy Hook
column2: in Newtown. Some of the senators who voted no have also looked into my eyes as I talked about my experience being shot in the head at point-blank range in suburban Tucson two years ago
column3: and expressed sympathy for the 18 other people shot besides me
column4: 6 of whom died. These senators have heard from their constituents Ã¢ÂÂ who polls show overwhelmingly favored expanding background checks. And still these senators decided to do nothing. Shame on them.

column1: I watch TV and read the papers like everyone else. We know what weÃ¢ÂÂre going to hear: vague platitudes like Ã¢ÂÂtough voteÃ¢ÂÂ and Ã¢ÂÂcomplicated issue.Ã¢ÂÂ I was elected six times to represent southern Arizona
column2: in the State Legislature and then in Congress. I know what a complicated issue is; I know what it feels like to take a tough vote. This was neither. These senators made their decision based on political fear and on cold calculations about the money of special interests like the National Rifle Association
column3: which in the last election cycle spent around $25 million on contributions
column4: lobbying and outside spending."	0

column1: 234	"Here are the key moments from the first 2016 presidential debate between Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump. (Video: Sarah Parnass/The Washington Post)
Share Add to your saved stories Save
Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump went head-to-head for the first time Monday night in a debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead
column2: N.Y. The debate was moderated by Lester Holt of NBC News and came as polls both nationally and in swing states are increasingly tight. Wp Get the full experience. Choose your plan ArrowRight The complete transcript of the debate is posted below. The Fix team has annotated it with context
column3: analysis and other thoughts
column4: using Genius.

column1: To see an annotation
column2: click or tap the highlighted words. If you would like to leave your own annotations
column3: make sure you have a Genius account. Post staff annotations will appear by default; others are in a menu that you can see in the upper right when you click or tap on an annotation.

column1: LESTER HOLT: Good evening from Hofstra University in Hempstead
column2: New York. I'm Lester Holt
column3: anchor of ""NBC Nightly News."" I want to welcome you to the first presidential debate.

column1: Advertisement
The participants tonight are Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton. This debate is sponsored by the Commission on Presidential Debates
column2: a nonpartisan
column3: nonprofit organization. The commission drafted tonight's format
column4: and the rules have been agreed to by the campaigns.

column1: The 90-minute debate is divided into six segments
column2: each 15 minutes long. We'll explore three topic areas tonight: Achieving prosperity; America's direction; and securing America. At the start of each segment
column3: I will ask the same lead-off question to both candidates
column4: and they will each have up to two minutes to respond. From that point until the end of the segment
column5: we'll have an open discussion.

column1: The questions are mine and have not been shared with the commission or the campaigns. The audience here in the room has agreed to remain silent so that we can focus on what the candidates are saying.
Advertisement
I will invite you to applaud
column2: however
column3: at this moment
column4: as we welcome the candidates: Democratic nominee for president of the United States
column5: Hillary Clinton
column6: and Republican nominee for president of the United States
column7: Donald J. Trump.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
CLINTON: How are you
column2: Donald?

column1: (APPLAUSE)
HOLT: Good luck to you.
(APPLAUSE)
Well
column2: I don't expect us to cover all the issues of this campaign tonight
column3: but I remind everyone
column4: there are two more presidential debates scheduled. We are going to focus on many of the issues that voters tell us are most important
column5: and we're going to press for specifics. I am honored to have this role
column6: but this evening belongs to the candidates and
column7: just as important
column8: to the American people.

column1: Candidates
column2: we look forward to hearing you articulate your policies and your positions
column3: as well as your visions and your values. So
column4: let's begin.

column1: Advertisement
We're calling this opening segment ""Achieving Prosperity."" And central to that is jobs. There are two economic realities in America today. There's been a record six straight years of job growth
column2: and new census numbers show incomes have increased at a record rate after years of stagnation. However
column3: income inequality remains significant
column4: and nearly half of Americans are living paycheck to paycheck.

column1: Beginning with you
column2: Secretary Clinton
column3: why are you a better choice than your opponent to create the kinds of jobs that will put more money into the pockets of American works?

column1: CLINTON: Well
column2: thank you
column3: Lester
column4: and thanks to Hofstra for hosting us.

column1: The central question in this election is really what kind of country we want to be and what kind of future we'll build together. Today is my granddaughter's second birthday
column2: so I think about this a lot. First
column3: we have to build an economy that works for everyone
column4: not just those at the top. That means we need new jobs
column5: good jobs
column6: with rising incomes.

column1: Advertisement
I want us to invest in you. I want us to invest in your future. That means jobs in infrastructure
column2: in advanced manufacturing
column3: innovation and technology
column4: clean
column5: renewable energy
column6: and small business
column7: because most of the new jobs will come from small business. We also have to make the economy fairer. That starts with raising the national minimum wage and also guarantee
column8: finally
column9: equal pay for women's work.

column1: CLINTON: I also want to see more companies do profit-sharing. If you help create the profits
column2: you should be able to share in them
column3: not just the executives at the top.

column1: And I want us to do more to support people who are struggling to balance family and work. I've heard from so many of you about the difficult choices you face and the stresses that you're under. So let's have paid family leave
column2: earned sick days. Let's be sure we have affordable child care and debt-free college.

column1: Advertisement
How are we going to do it? We're going to do it by having the wealthy pay their fair share and close the corporate loopholes.
Finally
column2: we tonight are on the stage together
column3: Donald Trump and I. Donald
column4: it's good to be with you. We're going to have a debate where we are talking about the important issues facing our country. You have to judge us
column5: who can shoulder the immense
column6: awesome responsibilities of the presidency
column7: who can put into action the plans that will make your life better. I hope that I will be able to earn your vote on November 8th.

column1: HOLT: Secretary Clinton
column2: thank you.

column1: Mr. Trump
column2: the same question to you. It's about putting money -- more money into the pockets of American workers. You have up to two minutes.

column1: TRUMP: Thank you
column2: Lester. Our jobs are fleeing the country. They're going to Mexico. They're going to many other countries. You look at what China is doing to our country in terms of making our product. They're devaluing their currency
column3: and there's nobody in our government to fight them. And we have a very good fight. And we have a winning fight. Because they're using our country as a piggy bank to rebuild China
column4: and many other countries are doing the same thing.

column1: Advertisement
So we're losing our good jobs
column2: so many of them. When you look at what's happening in Mexico
column3: a friend of mine who builds plants said it's the eighth wonder of the world. They're building some of the biggest plants anywhere in the world
column4: some of the most sophisticated
column5: some of the best plants. With the United States
column6: as he said
column7: not so much.

column1: So Ford is leaving. You see that
column2: their small car division leaving. Thousands of jobs leaving Michigan
column3: leaving Ohio. They're all leaving. And we can't allow it to happen anymore. As far as child care is concerned and so many other things
column4: I think Hillary and I agree on that. We probably disagree a little bit as to numbers and amounts and what we're going to do
column5: but perhaps we'll be talking about that later.

column1: But we have to stop our jobs from being stolen from us. We have to stop our companies from leaving the United States and
column2: with it
column3: firing all of their people. All you have to do is take a look at Carrier air conditioning in Indianapolis. They left -- fired 1
column4: 400 people. They're going to Mexico. So many hundreds and hundreds of companies are doing this.

column1: Advertisement
TRUMP: We cannot let it happen. Under my plan
column2: I'll be reducing taxes tremendously
column3: from 35 percent to 15 percent for companies
column4: small and big businesses. That's going to be a job creator like we haven't seen since Ronald Reagan. It's going to be a beautiful thing to watch.

column1: Companies will come. They will build. They will expand. New companies will start. And I look very
column2: very much forward to doing it. We have to renegotiate our trade deals
column3: and we have to stop these countries from stealing our companies and our jobs.

column1: HOLT: Secretary Clinton
column2: would you like to respond?

column1: CLINTON: Well
column2: I think that trade is an important issue. Of course
column3: we are 5 percent of the world's population; we have to trade with the other 95 percent. And we need to have smart
column4: fair trade deals.

column1: We also
column2: though
column3: need to have a tax system that rewards work and not just financial transactions. And the kind of plan that Donald has put forth would be trickle-down economics all over again. In fact
column4: it would be the most extreme version
column5: the biggest tax cuts for the top percent of the people in this country than we've ever had.

column1: Advertisement
I call it trumped-up trickle-down
column2: because that's exactly what it would be. That is not how we grow the economy.

column1: We just have a different view about what's best for growing the economy
column2: how we make investments that will actually produce jobs and rising incomes.

column1: I think we come at it from somewhat different perspectives. I understand that. You know
column2: Donald was very fortunate in his life
column3: and that's all to his benefit. He started his business with $14 million
column4: borrowed from his father
column5: and he really believes that the more you help wealthy people
column6: the better off we'll be and that everything will work out from there.

column1: I don't buy that. I have a different experience. My father was a small-businessman. He worked really hard. He printed drapery fabrics on long tables
column2: where he pulled out those fabrics and he went down with a silkscreen and dumped the paint in and took the squeegee and kept going.

column1: And so what I believe is the more we can do for the middle class
column2: the more we can invest in you
column3: your education
column4: your skills
column5: your future
column6: the better we will be off and the better we'll grow. That's the kind of economy I want us to see again.

column1: HOLT: Let me follow up with Mr. Trump
column2: if you can. You've talked about creating 25 million jobs
column3: and you've promised to bring back millions of jobs for Americans. How are you going to bring back the industries that have left this country for cheaper labor overseas? How
column4: specifically
column5: are you going to tell American manufacturers that you have to come back?

column1: TRUMP: Well
column2: for one thing -- and before we start on that -- my father gave me a very small loan in 1975
column3: and I built it into a company that's worth many
column4: many billions of dollars
column5: with some of the greatest assets in the world
column6: and I say that only because that's the kind of thinking that our country needs.

column1: Our country's in deep trouble. We don't know what we're doing when it comes to devaluations and all of these countries all over the world
column2: especially China. They're the best
column3: the best ever at it. What they're doing to us is a very
column4: very sad thing.

column1: So we have to do that. We have to renegotiate our trade deals. And
column2: Lester
column3: they're taking our jobs
column4: they're giving incentives
column5: they're doing things that
column6: frankly
column7: we don't do.

column1: Let me give you the example of Mexico. They have a VAT tax. We're on a different system. When we sell into Mexico
column2: there's a tax. When they sell in -- automatic
column3: 16 percent
column4: approximately. When they sell into us
column5: there's no tax. It's a defective agreement. It's been defective for a long time
column6: many years
column7: but the politicians haven't done anything about it.

column1: Now
column2: in all fairness to Secretary Clinton -- yes
column3: is that OK? Good. I want you to be very happy. It's very important to me.

column1: But in all fairness to Secretary Clinton
column2: when she started talking about this
column3: it was really very recently. She's been doing this for 30 years. And why hasn't she made the agreements better? The NAFTA agreement is defective. Just because of the tax and many other reasons
column4: but just because of the fact...

column1: HOLT: Let me interrupt just a moment
column2: but...

column1: TRUMP: Secretary Clinton and others
column2: politicians
column3: should have been doing this for years
column4: not right now
column5: because of the fact that we've created a movement. They should have been doing this for years. What's happened to our jobs and our country and our economy generally is -- look
column6: we owe $20 trillion. We cannot do it any longer
column7: Lester. HOLT: Back to the question
column8: though. How do you bring back -- specifically bring back jobs
column9: American manufacturers? How do you make them bring the jobs back?

column1: TRUMP: Well
column2: the first thing you do is don't let the jobs leave. The companies are leaving. I could name
column3: I mean
column4: there are thousands of them. They're leaving
column5: and they're leaving in bigger numbers than ever.

column1: And what you do is you say
column2: fine
column3: you want to go to Mexico or some other country
column4: good luck. We wish you a lot of luck. But if you think you're going to make your air conditioners or your cars or your cookies or whatever you make and bring them into our country without a tax
column5: you're wrong.

column1: And once you say you're going to have to tax them coming in
column2: and our politicians never do this
column3: because they have special interests and the special interests want those companies to leave
column4: because in many cases
column5: they own the companies. So what I'm saying is
column6: we can stop them from leaving. We have to stop them from leaving. And that's a big
column7: big factor.

column1: HOLT: Let me let Secretary Clinton get in here.
CLINTON: Well
column2: let's stop for a second and remember where we were eight years ago. We had the worst financial crisis
column3: the Great Recession
column4: the worst since the 1930s. That was in large part because of tax policies that slashed taxes on the wealthy
column5: failed to invest in the middle class
column6: took their eyes off of Wall Street
column7: and created a perfect storm.

column1: In fact
column2: Donald was one of the people who rooted for the housing crisis. He said
column3: back in 2006
column4: ""Gee
column5: I hope it does collapse
column6: because then I can go in and buy some and make some money."" Well
column7: it did collapse.

column1: TRUMP: That's called business
column2: by the way.

column1: CLINTON: Nine million people -- nine million people lost their jobs. Five million people lost their homes. And $13 trillion in family wealth was wiped out.
Now
column2: we have come back from that abyss. And it has not been easy. So we're now on the precipice of having a potentially much better economy
column3: but the last thing we need to do is to go back to the policies that failed us in the first place.

column1: Independent experts have looked at what I've proposed and looked at what Donald's proposed
column2: and basically they've said this
column3: that if his tax plan
column4: which would blow up the debt by over $5 trillion and would in some instances disadvantage middle-class families compared to the wealthy
column5: were to go into effect
column6: we would lose 3.5 million jobs and maybe have another recession.

column1: They've looked at my plans and they've said
column2: OK
column3: if we can do this
column4: and I intend to get it done
column5: we will have 10 million more new jobs
column6: because we will be making investments where we can grow the economy. Take clean energy. Some country is going to be the clean- energy superpower of the 21st century. Donald thinks that climate change is a hoax perpetrated by the Chinese. I think it's real.

column1: TRUMP: I did not. I did not. I do not say that.
CLINTON: I think science is real.
TRUMP: I do not say that.
CLINTON: And I think it's important that we grip this and deal with it
column2: both at home and abroad. And here's what we can do. We can deploy a half a billion more solar panels. We can have enough clean energy to power every home. We can build a new modern electric grid. That's a lot of jobs; that's a lot of new economic activity.

column1: So I've tried to be very specific about what we can and should do
column2: and I am determined that we're going to get the economy really moving again
column3: building on the progress we've made over the last eight years
column4: but never going back to what got us in trouble in the first place.

column1: HOLT: Mr. Trump?
TRUMP: She talks about solar panels. We invested in a solar company
column2: our country. That was a disaster. They lost plenty of money on that one.

column1: Now
column2: look
column3: I'm a great believer in all forms of energy
column4: but we're putting a lot of people out of work. Our energy policies are a disaster. Our country is losing so much in terms of energy
column5: in terms of paying off our debt. You can't do what you're looking to do with $20 trillion in debt.

column1: The Obama administration
column2: from the time they've come in
column3: is over 230 years' worth of debt
column4: and he's topped it. He's doubled it in a course of almost eight years
column5: seven-and-a-half years
column6: to be semi- exact.

column1: So I will tell you this. We have to do a much better job at keeping our jobs. And we have to do a much better job at giving companies incentives to build new companies or to expand
column2: because they're not doing it.

column1: And all you have to do is look at Michigan and look at Ohio and look at all of these places where so many of their jobs and their companies are just leaving
column2: they're gone.

column1: And
column2: Hillary
column3: I'd just ask you this. You've been doing this for 30 years. Why are you just thinking about these solutions right now? For 30 years
column4: you've been doing it
column5: and now you're just starting to think of solutions.

column1: CLINTON: Well
column2: actually...

column1: TRUMP: I will bring -- excuse me. I will bring back jobs. You can't bring back jobs.
CLINTON: Well
column2: actually
column3: I have thought about this quite a bit.

column1: TRUMP: Yeah
column2: for 30 years.

column1: CLINTON: And I have -- well
column2: not quite that long. I think my husband did a pretty good job in the 1990s. I think a lot about what worked and how we can make it work again...

column1: TRUMP: Well
column2: he approved NAFTA...

column1: (CROSSTALK)
CLINTON: ... million new jobs
column2: a balanced budget...

column1: TRUMP: He approved NAFTA
column2: which is the single worst trade deal ever approved in this country.

column1: CLINTON: Incomes went up for everybody. Manufacturing jobs went up also in the 1990s
column2: if we're actually going to look at the facts.

column1: When I was in the Senate
column2: I had a number of trade deals that came before me
column3: and I held them all to the same test. Will they create jobs in America? Will they raise incomes in America? And are they good for our national security? Some of them I voted for. The biggest one
column4: a multinational one known as CAFTA
column5: I voted against. And because I hold the same standards as I look at all of these trade deals.

column1: But let's not assume that trade is the only challenge we have in the economy. I think it is a part of it
column2: and I've said what I'm going to do. I'm going to have a special prosecutor. We're going to enforce the trade deals we have
column3: and we're going to hold people accountable.

column1: When I was secretary of state
column2: we actually increased American exports globally 30 percent. We increased them to China 50 percent. So I know how to really work to get new jobs and to get exports that helped to create more new jobs.

column1: HOLT: Very quickly...
TRUMP: But you haven't done it in 30 years or 26 years or any number you want to...
CLINTON: Well
column2: I've been a senator
column3: Donald...

column1: TRUMP: You haven't done it. You haven't done it.
CLINTON: And I have been a secretary of state...
TRUMP: Excuse me.
CLINTON: And I have done a lot...
TRUMP: Your husband signed NAFTA
column2: which was one of the worst things that ever happened to the manufacturing industry.

column1: CLINTON: Well
column2: that's your opinion. That is your opinion.

column1: TRUMP: You go to New England
column2: you go to Ohio
column3: Pennsylvania
column4: you go anywhere you want
column5: Secretary Clinton
column6: and you will see devastation where manufacture is down 30
column8: sometimes 50 percent. NAFTA is the worst trade deal maybe ever signed anywhere
column9: but certainly ever signed in this country.

column1: And now you want to approve Trans-Pacific Partnership. You were totally in favor of it. Then you heard what I was saying
column2: how bad it is
column3: and you said
column4: I can't win that debate. But you know that if you did win
column5: you would approve that
column6: and that will be almost as bad as NAFTA. Nothing will ever top NAFTA.

column1: CLINTON: Well

column1: 235	"During the presidential race
column2: Republican candidate Donald Trump has often criticized China
column3: most often on economic grounds. But in the Republican presidential debate in North Charleston
column4: S.C.
column5: on Jan. 14
column7: Trump also took a shot at China over foreign policy -- specifically for not doing enough to rein in its neighbor
column8: North Korea.

column1: Trump said
column2: ""China
column3: they don't like to tell us but they have total control -- just about
column4: of North Korea. They can solve the problem of North Korea if they wanted to
column5: but they taunt us.""

column1: With the secretive nation back in the news for its claimed (but unverified) hydrogen bomb test earlier this month
column2: we wondered whether Trump was right that China has ""total control
column3: just about
column4: of North Korea.""

column1: When we took a closer look at this question
column2: we found that experts on the region offered a nuanced answer. China
column3: they said
column4: does have notable influence over North Korea because it provides or enables transit for much of North KoreaÃ¢ÂÂs supply of goods from the outside world. But that influence
column5: they added
column6: falls well short of ""total control.""

column1: China does not Ã¢ÂÂcontrolÃ¢ÂÂ North Korea in any real sense of the word
column2: but it has influence over North Korea -- perhaps not as much as we think
column3: but more than Beijing is willing to acknowledge
column4: said Evans J.R. Revere
column5: a senior fellow at the Brookings InstitutionÃ¢ÂÂs Center for East Asia Policy Studies.

column1: Robert Ross
column2: a China expert at Boston College and Harvard University
column3: compared the relationship between China and North Korea to that between a parent and a teenager.

column1: ItÃ¢ÂÂs similar to dealing with a rebellious adolescent
column2: Ross said. ""Do the parents have total control? Perhaps Ã¢ÂÂ they provide food and shelter. But the cost to the parents of using such leverage can be prohibitive Ã¢ÂÂ driving a child out of the house and away from the family. China has much at stake in its strategic and economic relationship with North Korea. But is there total control? That is debatable.""

column1: ChinaÃ¢ÂÂs leverage over North Korea
The strongest argument for China having significant control over North Korea stems from its role in trade
column2: particularly food and fuel.

column1: North Korea has a lengthy land border with China -- its longest with any neighbor -- and while North Korea also has seaports
column2: the rest of the world can more easily monitor shipments into those ports
column3: making it preferable from North KoreaÃ¢ÂÂs perspective to move goods over land. Research by Stephan Haggard of the University of California-San Diego and Marcus Noland of the Peterson Institute for International Economics estimates that China may account for as much as 80 percent of North KoreaÃ¢ÂÂs trade
column4: and a similar percentage of its investment flows.

column1: North Korea would face daunting economic problems if China were to fully exercise its leverage
column2: for example by cutting off oil supplies or threatening to do so
column3: Haggard told PolitiFact.

column1: Why Ã¢ÂÂtotal controlÃ¢ÂÂ is an exaggeration
Yet while ChinaÃ¢ÂÂs economic lifeline gives it leverage
column2: that doesnÃ¢ÂÂt mean it can simply wave a wand and make things happen in Pyongyang -- something one might reasonably assume when hearing TrumpÃ¢ÂÂs quote. (The Trump campaign did not respond to an inquiry.)

column1: For starters
column2: China has worried -- with reason
column3: experts say -- that pushing so hard that the current North Korean regime collapses would lead to a humanitarian disaster on its border.

column1: China is reluctant to exercise its leverage
column2: fearing possible effects of an economic breakdown on its border and an outflow of refugees
column3: Haggard said.

column1: It also has become painfully obvious over the years that North Korea doesnÃ¢ÂÂt exactly listen to outsiders.
Mr. Trump is correct that the Chinese have leverage
column2: but it is leverage they would have to use with the North Korean regime resisting them with everything they had
column3: said Joseph de Thomas
column4: a professor of international affairs at Penn State University. ""This is hardly control.""

column1: Not only has North Korea thumbed its nose at the United Nations and world powers
column2: but its government has taken extreme measures to keep its citizens ignorant of the outside world. In fact
column3: the countryÃ¢ÂÂs national ideology -- juche -- is undergirded by the concept of self-reliance.

column1: North Korea is a country that prides itself on answering to no one and following no one's lead
column2: Revere said. ""This has been a consistent element of North Korean behavior for decades
column3: and is of course the reason why the regime is such a danger for the United States
column4: for South Korea
column5: the East Asia region
column6: and the international community at large.""

column1: Indeed
column2: despite North KoreaÃ¢ÂÂs heavy reliance on China for food
column3: fuel and virtually all other goods
column4: ""it is not clear that the leadership cares
column5: said Ross of Boston College and Harvard. ""For decades the population has lived in extreme poverty
column6: while the elite has fared very well.""

column1: Meanwhile
column2: North KoreaÃ¢ÂÂs development of its nuclear program has given it a measure of strategic independence from China -- which only further complicates ChinaÃ¢ÂÂs situation.

column1: This was on display with the recent test of the purported hydrogen bomb.
China publicly and privately exhorted North Korea not to test nukes and missiles over the past few months
column2: to no avail
column3: said Scott A. Snyder
column4: director of the program on U.S.-Korea policy at the Council on Foreign Relations. ""As a result
column5: relations between China and North Korea are strained. Chinese President Xi has not met with North KoreaÃ¢ÂÂs Kim Jong-un
column6: while meeting six times with the South Korean leader.""

column1: That does not sound like a country in ""total control"" of another.
TrumpÃ¢ÂÂs claim ""suggests a fundamental lack of understanding of both China and North Korea
column2: both today and over the decades
column3: Revere said. ""It is virtually certain that the Chinese were given no advance warning of the test
column4: and Chinese anger was quite evident in the public statements the government made after the test. In the view of virtually every North Korea and China expert I know
column5: the nuclear test was a slap in China's face
column6: in addition to being a major challenge and threat to the international community.""

column1: Our ruling
Trump said China has ""total control
column2: just about
column3: of North Korea.""

column1: He has a point that China holds significant leverage over North Korea if it wishes to exercise it
column2: since China provides the vast majority of North KoreaÃ¢ÂÂs international trade
column3: including food and fuel imports. But TrumpÃ¢ÂÂs assertion
column4: even slightly hedged as it is
column5: overlooks some significant limits to that leverage
column6: notably the North Korean governmentÃ¢ÂÂs willingness to follow its own drummer even if that means its people suffer. The fact that North Korea recently conducted a nuclear test over the strenuous objections of China suggests that Beijing lacks anything approaching ""total control"" over North Korea.

column1: The statement contains some element of truth but ignores critical facts that would give a different impression
column2: so we rate it Mostly False."	0

THE PRESIDENT: Thank you

column3: hello

I want to thank all the outstanding leaders that weÃ¢ÂÂve got here today. I want to introduce some of them. WeÃ¢ÂÂve got Secretary of Labor Tom Perez here. (Applause.) column7: a little more flavor. (Laughter and applause.)

column1: Bill Ford is in the house. (Applause.) Surprisingly enough

column3: listen
column4: IÃ¢ÂÂm a Bears fan. You beat us twice. But even a Bears fan has to admit --

THE PRESIDENT: -- that that was a little suspect. (Applause.) I have never seen anything like that before. I would have been pretty irritated. Were you irritated? Oh
column2: yes. (Laughter.) But all I can say -- because IÃ¢ÂÂm used to saying this
column3: IÃ¢ÂÂm a Bears fan -- thereÃ¢ÂÂs always next year. (Laughter.) And look
column4: youÃ¢ÂÂve got a lot to be hopeful for. First of all
column5: youÃ¢ÂÂve got one of the best defenses in the league. (Applause.) A fine young quarterback
column6: Megatron. And if thereÃ¢ÂÂs one thing that you can take to the bank when talking about Detroit is that Detroit always comes back. (Applause.) Detroit always comes back. (Applause.)

column1: And thatÃ¢ÂÂs why IÃ¢ÂÂm here today. One of my New YearÃ¢ÂÂs resolutions is to make sure that more Americans in Wayne
column2: more Americans in Michigan
column3: more Americans all across this great country -- that everybody feels like theyÃ¢ÂÂre coming back. And there is no doubt
column4: thanks to the steps that we took early on to rescue our economy and to rebuild it on a new foundation
column5: we are entering into the New Year with new confidence that America is coming back. (Applause.)

column1: Now
column2: you donÃ¢ÂÂt have to take my word for it. The facts are the facts. And letÃ¢ÂÂs face it
column3: a lot of times the media doesnÃ¢ÂÂt like reporting on good news
column4: but every once in a while
column5: itÃ¢ÂÂs important for us to hear some good news
column6: not to make us complacent
column7: but to give us confidence that if we work harder
column8: we can make even more good news.

column1: So hereÃ¢ÂÂs how we begin this year. Last year
column3: was the strongest year for job growth since the 1990s. (Applause.) Since the 1990s. (Applause.) WeÃ¢ÂÂve now had a 57-month streak of private sector job creation. WeÃ¢ÂÂve created nearly 11 million new jobs. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs the longest stretch in our history of private sector
column4: uninterrupted job creation. (Applause.)

column1: HereÃ¢ÂÂs another way of thinking about it. Since 2010
column2: we
column3: America
column4: have put more people back to work than Europe
column5: Japan
column6: and every other advanced economy combined. (Applause.) Combined. (Applause.) And let me tell you whatÃ¢ÂÂs leading the way: American manufacturing. After a decade of decline
column7: American manufacturing is in its best stretch of job growth since the 1990s. Here in Michigan
column8: manufacturers have created more than 100
column9: 000 jobs
column10: helping to cut your unemployment rate in half.

column1: So weÃ¢ÂÂre making more stuff. WeÃ¢ÂÂre selling it around the world. America is the number-one producer of oil
column2: the number-one producer of gas. ItÃ¢ÂÂs helping to save drivers about a buck-ten a gallon at the pump over this time last year. (Applause.) And the cars that you make help everybody go a little further on that gallon of gas. (Applause.)

column1: Thanks to the Affordable Care Act -- also known as Obamacare -- (applause) -- about 10 million Americans gained health insurance just over this last year. WeÃ¢ÂÂve cut our deficits by about two-thirds. IÃ¢ÂÂd like people to think about that
column2: because when they do surveys of
column3: like
column4: ordinary folks on the street and they ask them
column5: are the deficits going up or are they coming down
column6: everybody automatically assumes
column7: well
column8: government spending and deficits must be going up. Deficits have come down by two-thirds since I took office -- by two-thirds. TheyÃ¢ÂÂre going down. (Applause.) And after 13 long years
column9: our war in Afghanistan has come to a responsible end
column10: which means more of our brave troops have come home and spent time with their families during the holidays. (Applause.)

column1: So the point is weÃ¢ÂÂre moving. These six years have been tough
column2: demanded hard work
column3: demanded sacrifice on everybodyÃ¢ÂÂs part. You guys know that more than most. Which means that as a country
column4: we have every right to be proud of what weÃ¢ÂÂve got to show for all that hard work.

column1: AmericaÃ¢ÂÂs resurgence is real. DonÃ¢ÂÂt let anybody tell you otherwise. WeÃ¢ÂÂve got the best cards and we are doing better than just about anybody else on Earth. And now that weÃ¢ÂÂve got some calmer waters
column2: now that the worst of the crisis is behind us
column3: if we all do our part
column4: if we all pitch in
column5: then we can make sure that this rising tide is actually lifting all the boats
column6: not just some. We can make sure that the middle class is the engine that powers American prosperity for decades to come.

column1: And thatÃ¢ÂÂs going to be the focus of my State of the Union address in a couple of weeks -- building on the progress that weÃ¢ÂÂve already made. But IÃ¢ÂÂve got to admit IÃ¢ÂÂve only got two years left in office -- I didnÃ¢ÂÂt want to wait for the State of the Union to talk about all the things that make this country great and how we can make it better. So I thought IÃ¢ÂÂd get started this week. (Applause.) I figured
column2: why wait? ItÃ¢ÂÂs like opening your Christmas presents a little early.

column1: So today IÃ¢ÂÂm here in Detroit
column2: going to talk about the incredible things that have happened in the auto industry and what more we can do with manufacturing. Tomorrow
column3: IÃ¢ÂÂm going to visit Arizona
column4: a state that was hit about as hard as anybody by the housing crisis
column5: because we want to talk about how we're making homeownership a reality for more middle-class families.

column1: On Friday
column2: IÃ¢ÂÂm going to go to Tennessee
column3: a state that's making big strides in education
column4: to show how we can help every American get the education they need to get ahead in this new economy.

column1: But today
column2: I wanted to come here to Michigan because this state proves no matter how tough times get Americans are tougher. (Applause.) Plus I wanted to see the new Mustang. (Laughter.)

column1: Now
column2: letÃ¢ÂÂs just take a minute and think about what you've had to fight through. A few years ago
column3: nearly one in five autoworkers got a punch in the gut with a pink slip. The year before I took office
column5: 000 jobs vanished in this industry -- 400
column6: 000. Sales plunged 40 percent. And then as the financial crisis built
column7: we faced what once seemed unimaginable when just two of the Big Three -- GM and Chrysler -- were on the brink of failure.

column1: Now
column2: this is the heartbeat of American manufacturing right here. And it was flat-lining. And we had a choice to make. We could have kept giving billions of taxpayer dollars to the auto industry without asking for accountability or change in return. But that would have just kicked the problem down the road. We could have done nothing
column3: which some people said we should do
column4: and let those companies fail. But think about what that would have meant for this country. The suppliers
column5: the distributors
column6: the communities that depend on the workers who patronize the restaurants and shop at the stores
column7: all those companies would have gone under also.

column1: And
column2: look
column3: the fact is nobody was in a stronger position than Ford. Bill and the team had done a great job steering Ford through tough times
column4: but Bill and others are the first to admit that you could have had a cascading effect if the whole supply chain in the U.S. auto industry starts declining. Then Ford could have gone under
column5: too. Plants would have shuttered. We would have lost this iconic industry
column6: sold for scraps. And folks like you -- the men and women who built these companies with your hands -- would have been hung out to dry. And the communities you depended on -- the schoolteachers
column7: the small business owners
column8: the servers in the diner and
column9: letÃ¢ÂÂs face it
column10: the barkeep -- (laughter and applause.) IÃ¢ÂÂm just saying. (Laughter.) Are you a barkeep
column11: or youÃ¢ÂÂre just waving at me? (Laughter.) But everybody would have been affected. Their jobs were at stake
column12: too.

column1: And itÃ¢ÂÂs more than that. The jobs in the auto industry have always been about more than a paycheck. They're a source of pride for generations. It was representative of what it meant to get into the middle class. You work hard in this job
column2: you could afford to raise a family
column3: buy a house
column4: go on vacation
column5: retire with some dignity. You knew you were making something that people could count on. It meant something. Every car you sent off the line brought you that step closer to doing the right thing by your family and giving something to your kids
column6: and having a sense of security in your life. So plants like this one built more than just cars -- they built the middle class in this country. And that was worth fighting for. (Applause.)

column1: So in exchange for the help
column2: we demanded responsibility. We said to the auto industry
column3: youÃ¢ÂÂve got to change with the times. Plants retooled. Plants restructured. Labor and management worked together
column4: settled their differences. Everybody put some skin in the game. Everybody made some sacrifices. It wasnÃ¢ÂÂt just some
column5: it wasnÃ¢ÂÂt just the workers who gave something up -- everybody.

column1: And that's how things work best
column2: by the way
column3: when everybody is in it -- when workers and businesses work together; when whoever is in the board room and folks on the floor
column4: they both understand theyÃ¢ÂÂre in it together. And we believe America is best when everybody is in it together. And we rejected the false choice that either unions or businesses could succeed but not both. We said
column5: you know what
column6: whatÃ¢ÂÂs going to work for the company is also going to work for that worker
column7: and vice versa
column8: which means when the company is doing better
column9: then the workers have got to get their share as well. (Applause.)

column1: And Ford rejected the false choice that they could either take care of their shareholder or take care of their worker -- they did both. And the company benefited and America benefited. We believed in shared sacrifice and that shared sacrifice leads to shared prosperity.
Now
column2: IÃ¢ÂÂve got to tell you
column3: I was talking to the Detroit News -- they were asking
column4: what was it like when you were making this decision? I just want everybody to be clear. It was not popular. Even in Michigan
column5: it wasnÃ¢ÂÂt popular. I remember they did a poll and
column6: like
column7: in Michigan
column8: it was like only 10 percent were in favor. (Laughter.) And you donÃ¢ÂÂt have to be a genius political analyst to say
column9: 10 percent is not very high. (Laughter.)

column1: And
column2: look -- and it wasnÃ¢ÂÂt on my to-do list when I ran for President. I wasnÃ¢ÂÂt expecting to have to do this. But I ran not to be just doing the popular things
column3: I ran not just to do the easy things
column4: I ran to do the right thing. And saving the American auto industry was the right thing to do. (Applause.) Betting on you was the right thing to do. (Applause.) It was the right thing to do. And that bet has paid off for America
column5: because the American auto industry is back. (Applause.)

column1: Now
column2: part of the reason that we wanted to start this trip here is not just because I wanted to see the new Mustang
column3: not just because the American auto industry is back
column4: but because last month we actually marked a milestone. Last month
column5: the rescue of the auto industry officially came to an end. The auto companies have now repaid taxpayers every dime and more of what my administration invested in you. (Applause.) You paid the taxpayers back with your hard work
column6: with your dedication. (Applause.)

column1: And over the past five years
column2: this industry created about 500
column3: 000 new jobs. Last year
column4: American autoworkers churned out cars faster than any year since 2005. Ford has brought jobs back from Mexico
column5: created nearly 24
column6: 000 new jobs across this country
column7: including 1
column8: 800 new jobs right here in this plant. (Applause.) And after more than a century since Henry Ford introduced the moving assembly line
column9: youÃ¢ÂÂre reinventing it -- one production line for gas
column10: electric
column11: hybrid
column12: plug-in vehicles. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs the first in the world
column13: right here in Wayne
column14: Michigan. (Applause.) First in the world. (Applause.) ThatÃ¢ÂÂs always cool when you do something first.

column1: And youÃ¢ÂÂre helping rebuild the middle class for the 21st century. Just down the road in Lincoln Park
column2: UAW-Ford Joint Apprenticeship Program is providing workers with hands-on training in the skills that employers need for the jobs of tomorrow. And nationally
column3: by the way
column4: 87 percent of all apprentices are employed after they complete their apprenticeship program
column5: with an average starting wage of $50
column6: 000. So the more folks we get into apprenticeships
column7: the more folks are getting middle-class jobs.

column1: And thatÃ¢ÂÂs why I called on last year for businesses across the country to create more and expand more apprenticeship programs. And since then
column2: weÃ¢ÂÂve seen the largest increase in apprenticeships in nearly a decade. And now my administration is investing $100 million in an American Apprenticeship Grant competition. WeÃ¢ÂÂre going to build on this momentum. WeÃ¢ÂÂre going to expand successful programs. We want young people to see that they have opportunities. They donÃ¢ÂÂt all have to go to a four-year college. They can get an apprenticeship
column3: save some money
column4: start working -- (applause) -- build a family
column5: buy a home
column6: get some Lions tickets. (Laughter and applause.)

column1: Because everybody came together here and worked together
column2: folks are better off. And some of the most high-tech
column3: fuel-efficient
column4: high-powered
column5: heart-pounding
column6: good-looking
column7: well-designed
column8: fuel-efficient cars in the world are once again designed
column9: engineered
column10: forged and built not in Europe
column11: not in Asia
column12: right here in the United States of America. (Applause.) Right here in America. (Applause.)

column1: So because of you -- because of you
column2: manufacturing has a future in this country. Management has actually grown faster than other parts of the economy. And companies are now saying
column3: you know what
column4: we got to get back to America. We got to relocate. We were offshore
column5: and now they're saying
column6: oh
column7: oh
column8: America is back. We better get back in there. And that means because of you
column9: the middle class has a future in this country.

column1: And the auto industry has proved that any comeback is possible -- and by the way
column2: so has Motor City. (Applause.) So has a Motor City. (Applause.) A year and a half ago
column3: Detroit became the largest city ever to file for bankruptcy. Today
column4: under the leadership of Mayor Duggan
column5: Detroit is charting a new course. Businesses and private investors are making big investments
column6: including Ford
column7: which is helping to launch a tech startup incubator downtown. New restaurants and stores are popping up. Residents are fighting blight
column8: securing abandoned homes
column9: cleaning up neglected neighborhoods.

column1: WeÃ¢ÂÂre seeing stories of young people who left town for other opportunities
column2: didn't think they could make it here
column3: and suddenly they're saying
column4: you know what
column5: maybe I want to get back to Detroit -- hoping to be part of the rebirth of this city.

column1: Now
column2: this city still faces big challenges
column3: but youÃ¢ÂÂre coming back. Just like the auto industry is going to have to continue to come up with new ideas and new designs and address competition. It never stops. We got to stay hungry. We can't be complacent. Just like America has got to still keep on working. Just like the Lions got to still come up with a little more work. (Applause.) But we're coming back.

column1: And one thing is for sure -- we may not all root for the Lions
column2: but America is rooting for Detroit. (Applause.) America is rooting for Detroit. (Applause.) We want the Motor City strong. And behind the stories of plants and cities and economic data
column3: itÃ¢ÂÂs people. ItÃ¢ÂÂs all of you.

column1: So IÃ¢ÂÂll just close with a story of a guy named Ramone -- because weÃ¢ÂÂre rooting for guys like Ramone. Ramone spent eight years in the military
column2: served in Afghanistan
column3: served in Iraq. Ramone here? Raise your hand
column4: Ramone. (Applause.)

column1: So Ramone is somebody who fought for our freedom
column2: fought for our security. But sometimes we give lip service to supporting our troops
column3: and then when they come home they get lost. So when Ramone came home
column4: he had a hard time finding a job because it was a tough economy. He didnÃ¢ÂÂt want to be a burden on his family
column5: so he moved into a homeless shelter
column6: took whatever work he could get. And then
column7: one day in 2012
column8: a VA counselor that heÃ¢ÂÂd been working with handed him an application from Ford. Ford was hiring for new shifts.

column1: Imagine what Ramone felt the day he knocked on his grandpaÃ¢ÂÂs door -- his grandfather who had spent 25 years building Mustangs in Dearborn -- and Ramone was able to tell his grandfather he got a job at Ford. (Applause.) And now Ramone has got his own place. And now Ramone has got a good job right on the line here in Wayne. And every day
column2: heÃ¢ÂÂs doing just what his grandfather did. And heÃ¢ÂÂs proud. HeÃ¢ÂÂs punching in and building some of the best cars in the world. (Applause.)

column1: If you want to know what America is about
column2: about grit and determination and hard work and sacrifice and looking out for one another and not giving up
column3: think about Ramone. Think about Detroit. Think about the auto industry. Think about the Midwest. Think about Michigan. Think about America.

column1: When our assembly lines grind to a halt
column2: we work together
column3: we get them going again. We donÃ¢ÂÂt give up. We get up
column4: we fight back. We come back stronger than before. Thanks to the hard work of people like you
column5: America is coming back. And IÃ¢ÂÂm going to be on your side every step of the way. (Applause.)

column1: Thank you
column2: Michigan. God bless you. God bless America. (Applause.)

column1: END

column1: Nearly everyone who knows him seems to agree that Rod Rosenstein

column3: not a persecutor

column1: But Trump could not fire Mueller directly
column2: according to the law that authorizes MuellerÃ¢ÂÂs probe
column3: so the only possible way is to throw the Justice Department into upheaval by firing Deputy Attorney General Rosenstein who only holds the key MuellerÃ¢ÂÂs expulsion.

column2: and Rod Rosenstein who was on matters related to the probe

column1: UNDER the best of circumstancesÃ¢ÂÂwhen America has a president who is disciplined

column6: a political giant who held that post for Barack Obama said

column1: Rosenstein

column3: 2017 lasted a smidgeon over few days. After days of increasingly public concerns over the likelihood of MuellerÃ¢ÂÂs dismissal by Trump and amidst TrumpÃ¢ÂÂs former national-security adviser

column2: who already fill several top jobs in his government. It ends the fear of Trump administration being damaged by FlynnÃ¢ÂÂs plea to MuellerÃ¢ÂÂs investigation team.

column1: These are not anything like ideal circumstances for Mr Neil Gorsuch. New holder of the toughest job in government
column2: the ex-clerk for Judge David B. Sentelle on the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit from 1991 to 1992
column3: and then for U.S. Supreme Court Justices Byron White and Anthony Kennedy
column4: from 1993 to 1994. He currently was serving as an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States. How long Mr Neil Gorsuch lasts is anyoneÃ¢ÂÂs guess. If he only emerges with his dignity intact and adhere to the orders and principles of TrumpÃ¢ÂÂs administration
column5: he will have done better than his predecessor.

column1: President Donald TrumpÃ¢ÂÂs interview with the New York Times on Wednesday stirred speculation he might consider firing Special Counsel Robert Mueller for investigating TrumpÃ¢ÂÂs business dealings as part of the Russia probe.
But Trump could not fire Mueller directly
column2: according to the law that authorizes MuellerÃ¢ÂÂs probe. Firing the Deputy Attorney General simply means setting off a chain-reaction that would throw the Justice Department into upheaval and consequently reaching his target to fire Robert Mueller under his dictatorship.

column1: HeÃ¢ÂÂd certainly begun by dismissing Rosenstein
column2: whose political loyalties Trump questioned in the Times interview on Wednesday in which he also warned Mueller against broadening his investigation. Such a scenario would parallel President Richard NixonÃ¢ÂÂs 1973 Ã¢ÂÂSaturday Night Massacre
column3: Ã¢ÂÂ when Nixon forced out the top two officials in the Justice Department in order to oust the Watergate special counsel.

column1: Ã¢ÂÂI donÃ¢ÂÂt think thatÃ¢ÂÂs politically survivable
column2: and itÃ¢ÂÂs not clear how much collateral damage he will do
column3: putting himself into a position to have somebody fire Mueller
column4: Ã¢ÂÂ said Senator Sheldon Whitehouse
column5: a Democrat from Rhode Island.

column1: Expanding Investigation
MuellerÃ¢ÂÂs investigation has expanded to examine a broad range of transactions involving the presidentÃ¢ÂÂs businesses

column3: Jared Kushner
column4: and Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross
column5: a person familiar with the probe told Bloomberg News. Trump told the Times that if Mueller examined his familyÃ¢ÂÂs finances beyond any relationship with Russia heÃ¢ÂÂd consider it Ã¢ÂÂa violation.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: Ã¢ÂÂThere is no possible way anybody at the White House could be seriously thinking about firing Mueller
column2: Ã¢ÂÂ said Senate Bob Corker of Tennessee
column3: a Republican. Ã¢ÂÂI donÃ¢ÂÂt even want to comment on that because thatÃ¢ÂÂs so far out of bounds it couldnÃ¢ÂÂt possibly be a serious discussion.Ã¢ÂÂ

246	"By Sen. Rand Paul
Videos by Rare
Rumors are that Donald Trump might pick John Bolton for Secretary of State. Heaven forbid.
One of the things I occasionally liked about the President-elect was his opposition to the Iraq war and regime change. He not only grasped the mistake of that war early
column2: but also seemed to fully understand how it disrupted the balance of power in the Middle East and even emboldened Iran.

column1: We liberated Iraq
column2: but today their best friend is Iran
column3: their second greatest ally is Russia
column4: and their third strongest alliance is with Syria. Trump really seems to get the lesson. Hillary Clinton never did.

column1: RELATED: Rand Paul: The president cannot use out-of-date authorities to send our troops to war
Most importantly right now
column2: John Bolton never learned and never will.

column1: Bolton is a longtime member of the failed Washington elite that Trump vowed to oppose
column2: hell-bent on repeating virtually every foreign policy mistake the U.S. has made in the last 15 years Ã¢ÂÂ particularly those Trump promised to avoid as president.

column1: John Bolton more often stood with Hillary Clinton and against what Donald Trump has advised.
None of this is secret. ItÃ¢ÂÂs all out there. Perhaps the incoming administration should take a closer look.

Bolton was one of the loudest advocates of overthrowing Saddam Hussein and still stupefyingly insists it was the right call 13 years later. Ã¢ÂÂI still think the decision to overthrow Saddam was correct
column2: Ã¢ÂÂ Bolton said just last year.

column1: Trump
column2: rightly

column4: Ã¢ÂÂ Trump said in 2015. Ã¢ÂÂ(N)ow itÃ¢ÂÂs the Harvard of terrorism.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: Ã¢ÂÂIf you look at Iraq from years ago
column2: IÃ¢ÂÂm not saying he was a nice guy
column3: he was a horrible guy
column4: Ã¢ÂÂ Trump said of Saddam Hussein
column5: Ã¢ÂÂbut it was a lot better than it is right now.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: Trump has said U.S. intervention in Iraq in 2003 Ã¢ÂÂhelped to throw the region into chaos and gave ISIS the space it needs to grow and prosper.Ã¢ÂÂ In contrast
column2: Bolton has said explicitly that he wants to repeat Iraq-style regime change in Syrian and Iran.

column1: You canÃ¢ÂÂt learn from mistakes if you donÃ¢ÂÂt see mistakes.
Trump has blamed George W. Bush
column2: Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton for helping to create ISIS Ã¢ÂÂ but should add John Bolton to that list
column3: who essentially agreed with all three on our regime change debacles.

column2: Bolton bashed Obama Ã¢ÂÂfor his refusal to directly target GaddafiÃ¢ÂÂ and declared
column3: Ã¢ÂÂthere is a strategic interest in toppling GaddafiÃ¢ÂÂ¦ But Obama missed it.Ã¢ÂÂ In fact
column4: Obama actually took BoltonÃ¢ÂÂs advice and bombed the Libyan dictator into the next world. Secretary of State Clinton bragged
column5: Ã¢ÂÂWe came
column6: we saw
column7: he died.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: When Trump was asked last year if Libya and the region would be more stable today with Gaddafi in power
column2: he replied Ã¢ÂÂ100 percent.Ã¢ÂÂ Mr. Trump is 100 percent right.

column1: No man is more out of touch with the situation in the Middle East or more dangerous to our national security than Bolton.
All nuance is lost on the man. The fact that Russia has had a base in Syria for 50 years doesnÃ¢ÂÂt deter Bolton from calling for all out
column2: no holds barred war in Syria. Bolton criticized the current administration for offering only a tepid war. For Bolton
column3: only a hot-blooded war to create democracy across the globe is demanded.

column1: Woodrow Wilson would be proud
column2: but the parents of our soldiers should be mortified. War should be the last resort
column3: never the first. War should be understood to be a hell no one wishes for. Dwight Eisenhower understood this when he wrote
column4: Ã¢ÂÂI hate war like only a soldier can
column5: the stupidity
column6: the banality
column7: the futility.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: Bolton would not understand this because
column2: like many of his generation
column3: he used every privilege to avoid serving himself. Bolton said
column4: with the threat of the Vietnam draft over his head
column5: that Ã¢ÂÂhe had no desire to die in a Southeast Asian rice paddy.Ã¢ÂÂ But heÃ¢ÂÂs seems to be okay with your son or daughter dying wherever his neoconservative impulse leads us: Ã¢ÂÂEven before the Iraq War
column6: John Bolton was a leading brain behind the neoconservativesÃ¢ÂÂ war-and-conquest agenda
column7: Ã¢ÂÂ notes The American ConservativeÃ¢ÂÂs Jon Utley.

column1: At a time when Americans thirst for change and new thinking

column1: The man is a menace.

Our Constitution and our founding fathers were explicit war was not to be fought without the permission of Congress. No matter which party occupies the White House

column1: The true statesmen realizes
