column1: 248	"Rose Garden
5:35 P.M. EDT
MR. BARDEN: Hello. My name is Mark Barden. Just four months ago
column2: my wife Jackie and I lost our son
column3: and our children
column4: James and Natalie
column5: they lost their little brother Daniel. Daniel was a first-grader at Sandy Hook Elementary School. Our sweet
column6: 7-year-old Daniel was one of 20 children
column7: six adults lost on December 14th. I have to say it feels like it was just yesterday.

column1: In our deepest grief
column2: we were supported by the love of our families and comforted by the love and prayers we received from millions of America
column3: from every corner of the country.

column1: What happened in Newtown can happen anywhere. In any instant
column2: any dad in America could be in my shoes. No one should feel the pain. No one should feel our pain or the pain felt by the tens of thousands of people whoÃ¢ÂÂve lost loved ones to senseless gun violence.

column1: And that's why we're here. Two weeks ago
column2: 12 of us from Newtown came to meet with U.S. senators and have a conversation about how to bring common-sense solutions to the issues of gun violence. We came with a sense of hope
column3: optimistic that real conversation could begin that would ultimately save the lives of so many Americans. We met with dozens of Democrats and Republicans and shared with them pictures of our children
column4: our spouses
column5: our parents who lost their lives on December 14th.

column1: Expanded background checks wouldn't have saved our loved ones
column2: but still we came to support the bipartisan proposal from two senators
column3: both with Ã¢ÂÂAÃ¢ÂÂ ratings from the NRA -- a common-sense proposal supported by 90 percent of Americans. ItÃ¢ÂÂs a proposal that will save lives without interfering with the rights of responsible
column4: law-abiding gun owners.

column1: We'll return home now
column2: disappointed but not defeated. We return home with the determination that change will happen -- maybe not today
column3: but it will happen. It will happen soon. We've always known this would be a long road
column4: and we don't have the luxury of turning back. We will keep moving forward and build public support for common-sense solutions in the areas of mental health
column5: school safety
column6: and gun safety.

column1: We take strength from the children and loved ones that we lost
column2: and we carry a great faith in the American people.

column1: On behalf of the Sandy Hook Promise
column2: I would like to thank President Obama
column3: Vice President Biden for their leadership and for standing strong and continuing to fight for a safer America. I would like to thank Senators Toomey
column4: Manchin
column5: Schumer and Kirk on coming together to seek common ground on legislation that would keep guns out of the hands of criminals and save lives.

column1: And I would like to thank ConnecticutÃ¢ÂÂs Senators Blumenthal and Murphy. TheyÃ¢ÂÂve been right with us. They stood by us right from the very beginning. From the first few hours after this tragedy they were with us.
We will not be defeated. We are not defeated
column2: and we will not be defeated. We are here now; we will always be here because we have no other choice. We are not going away. And every day
column3: as more people are killed in this country because of gun violence
column4: our determination grows stronger.

column1: We leave Washington hoping that others
column2: both here and across the country
column3: will join us in making the Sandy Hook Promise
column4: a pledge that we'd had great hope that more U.S. senators would take literally. I'd like to end by repeating the words with which the Sandy Hook Promise begins: Our hearts are broken. Our spirit is not.

column1: Thank you. It is now my great pleasure to introduce the President of the United States of America
column2: Barack Obama.

column1: THE PRESIDENT: A few months ago
column2: in response to too many tragedies -- including the shootings of a United States Congresswoman
column3: Gabby Giffords
column4: whoÃ¢ÂÂs here today
column5: and the murder of 20 innocent schoolchildren and their teachers Ã¢ÂÂ- this country took up the cause of protecting more of our people from gun violence.

column1: Families that know unspeakable grief summoned the courage to petition their elected leaders Ã¢ÂÂ- not just to honor the memory of their children
column2: but to protect the lives of all our children. And a few minutes ago
column3: a minority in the United States Senate decided it wasnÃ¢ÂÂt worth it. They blocked common-sense gun reforms even while these families looked on from the Senate gallery.

column1: By now
column2: itÃ¢ÂÂs well known that 90 percent of the American people support universal background checks that make it harder for a dangerous person to buy a gun. WeÃ¢ÂÂre talking about convicted felons
column3: people convicted of domestic violence
column4: people with a severe mental illness. Ninety percent of Americans support that idea. Most Americans think that's already the law.

column1: And a few minutes ago
column2: 90 percent of Democrats in the Senate just voted for that idea. But itÃ¢ÂÂs not going to happen because 90 percent of Republicans in the Senate just voted against that idea.

column1: A majority of senators voted Ã¢ÂÂyesÃ¢ÂÂ to protecting more of our citizens with smarter background checks. But by this continuing distortion of Senate rules
column2: a minority was able to block it from moving forward.

column1: IÃ¢ÂÂm going to speak plainly and honestly about whatÃ¢ÂÂs happened here because the American people are trying to figure out how can something have 90 percent support and yet not happen. We had a Democrat and a Republican -Ã¢ÂÂ both gun owners
column2: both fierce defenders of our Second Amendment
column3: with Ã¢ÂÂAÃ¢ÂÂ grades from the NRA -- come together and worked together to write a common-sense compromise on background checks. And I want to thank Joe Manchin and Pat Toomey for their courage in doing that. That was not easy given their traditional strong support for Second Amendment rights.

column1: As they said
column2: nobody could honestly claim that the package they put together infringed on our Second Amendment rights. All it did was extend the same background check rules that already apply to guns purchased from a dealer to guns purchased at gun shows or over the Internet. So 60 percent of guns are already purchased through a background check system; this would have covered a lot of the guns that are currently outside that system.

column1: Their legislation showed respect for gun owners
column2: and it showed respect for the victims of gun violence. And Gabby Giffords
column3: by the way
column4: is both -- sheÃ¢ÂÂs a gun owner and a victim of gun violence. She is a Westerner and a moderate. And she supports these background checks.

column1: In fact
column2: even the NRA used to support expanded background checks. The current leader of the NRA used to support these background checks. So while this compromise didnÃ¢ÂÂt contain everything I wanted or everything that these families wanted
column3: it did represent progress. It represented moderation and common sense. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs why 90 percent of the American people supported it.

column1: But instead of supporting this compromise
column2: the gun lobby and its allies willfully lied about the bill. They claimed that it would create some sort of Ã¢ÂÂbig brotherÃ¢ÂÂ gun registry
column3: even though the bill did the opposite. This legislation
column4: in fact
column5: outlawed any registry. Plain and simple
column6: right there in the text. But that didnÃ¢ÂÂt matter.

column1: And unfortunately
column2: this pattern of spreading untruths about this legislation served a purpose
column3: because those lies upset an intense minority of gun owners
column4: and that in turn intimidated a lot of senators. And I talked to several of these senators over the past few weeks
column5: and theyÃ¢ÂÂre all good people. I know all of them were shocked by tragedies like Newtown. And I also understand that they come from states that are strongly pro-gun. And I have consistently said that there are regional differences when it comes to guns
column6: and that both sides have to listen to each other.

column1: But the fact is most of these senators could not offer any good reason why we wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt want to make it harder for criminals and those with severe mental illnesses to buy a gun. There were no coherent arguments as to why we wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt do this. It came down to politics -- the worry that that vocal minority of gun owners would come after them in future elections. They worried that the gun lobby would spend a lot of money and paint them as anti-Second Amendment.
And obviously
column2: a lot of Republicans had that fear
column3: but Democrats had that fear
column4: too. And so they caved to the pressure
column5: and they started looking for an excuse -- any excuse -- to vote Ã¢ÂÂno.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: One common argument I heard was that this legislation wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt prevent all future massacres. And thatÃ¢ÂÂs true. As I said from the start
column2: no single piece of legislation can stop every act of violence and evil. We learned that tragically just two days ago. But if action by Congress could have saved one person
column3: one child
column4: a few hundred
column5: a few thousand -- if it could have prevented those people from losing their lives to gun violence in the future while preserving our Second Amendment rights
column6: we had an obligation to try.

column1: And this legislation met that test. And too many senators failed theirs.
I've heard some say that blocking this step would be a victory. And my question is
column2: a victory for who? A victory for what? All that happened today was the preservation of the loophole that lets dangerous criminals buy guns without a background check. That didnÃ¢ÂÂt make our kids safer. Victory for not doing something that 90 percent of Americans
column3: 80 percent of Republicans
column4: the vast majority of your constituents wanted to get done? It begs the question
column5: who are we here to represent?

column1: I've heard folks say that having the families of victims lobby for this legislation was somehow misplaced. ""A prop
column2: somebody called them. Ã¢ÂÂEmotional blackmail
column3: Ã¢ÂÂ some outlet said. Are they serious? Do we really think that thousands of families whose lives have been shattered by gun violence donÃ¢ÂÂt have a right to weigh in on this issue? Do we think their emotions
column4: their loss is not relevant to this debate?

column1: So all in all
column2: this was a pretty shameful day for Washington.

column1: But this effort is not over. I want to make it clear to the American people we can still bring about meaningful changes that reduce gun violence
column2: so long as the American people donÃ¢ÂÂt give up on it. Even without Congress
column3: my administration will keep doing everything it can to protect more of our communities. WeÃ¢ÂÂre going to address the barriers that prevent states from participating in the existing background check system. WeÃ¢ÂÂre going to give law enforcement more information about lost and stolen guns so it can do its job. WeÃ¢ÂÂre going to help to put in place emergency plans to protect our children in their schools.

column1: But we can do more if Congress gets its act together. And if this Congress refuses to listen to the American people and pass common-sense gun legislation
column2: then the real impact is going to have to come from the voters.

column1: To all the people who supported this legislation -- law enforcement and responsible gun owners
column2: Democrats and Republicans
column3: urban moms
column4: rural hunters
column5: whoever you are -- you need to let your representatives in Congress know that you are disappointed
column6: and that if they donÃ¢ÂÂt act this time
column7: you will remember come election time.

column1: To the wide majority of NRA households who supported this legislation
column2: you need to let your leadership and lobbyists in Washington know they didnÃ¢ÂÂt represent your views on this one.

column1: The point is those who care deeply about preventing more and more gun violence will have to be as passionate
column2: and as organized
column3: and as vocal as those who blocked these common-sense steps to help keep our kids safe. Ultimately
column4: you outnumber those who argued the other way. But they're better organized. They're better financed. TheyÃ¢ÂÂve been at it longer. And they make sure to stay focused on this one issue during election time. And that's the reason why you can have something that 90 percent of Americans support and you can't get it through the Senate or the House of Representatives.

column1: So to change Washington
column2: you
column3: the American people
column4: are going to have to sustain some passion about this. And when necessary
column5: youÃ¢ÂÂve got to send the right people to Washington. And that requires strength
column6: and it requires persistence.

column1: And that's the one thing that these families should have inspired in all of us. I still don't know how they have been able to muster up the strength to do what theyÃ¢ÂÂve doing over the last several weeks
column2: last several months.

column1: And I see this as just round one. When Newtown happened
column2: I met with these families and I spoke to the community
column3: and I said
column4: something must be different right now. WeÃ¢ÂÂre going to have to change. That's what the whole country said. Everybody talked about how we were going to change something to make sure this didn't happen again
column5: just like everybody talked about how we needed to do something after Aurora. Everybody talked about we needed change something after Tucson.

column1: And IÃ¢ÂÂm assuming that the emotions that weÃ¢ÂÂve all felt since Newtown
column2: the emotions that weÃ¢ÂÂve all felt since Tucson and Aurora and Chicago -- the pain we share with these families and families all across the country whoÃ¢ÂÂve lost a loved one to gun violence -- IÃ¢ÂÂm assuming that's not a temporary thing. IÃ¢ÂÂm assuming our expressions of grief and our commitment to do something different to prevent these things from happening are not empty words.

column1: I believe weÃ¢ÂÂre going to be able to get this done. Sooner or later
column2: we are going to get this right. The memories of these children demand it. And so do the American people.

column1: Thank you very much
column2: everybody.

column1: 257	"At 5:28 PM EST on Jan. 11
column3: a satellite arced over southern China. It was smallÃ¢ÂÂjust 6 ft. longÃ¢ÂÂa tiny object in the heavens
column4: steadily bleeping its location to ground stations below
column5: just as it had every day for the past seven years. And then it was gone
column6: transformed into a cloud of debris hurtling at nearly 16
column7: 000 mph along the main thoroughfare used by orbiting spacecraft.

column1: It was not the start of the world's first war in space
column2: but it could have been. It was just a test: The satellite was a defunct Chinese weather spacecraft. And the country that destroyed it was China. According to reports
column3: a mobile launcher at the Songlin test facility near Xichang
column4: in Sichuan province
column5: lofted a multistage solid-fuel missile topped with a kinetic kill vehicle. Traveling nearly 18
column6: 000 mph
column7: the kill vehicle intercepted the sat andÃ¢ÂÂboomÃ¢ÂÂobliterated it. ""It was almost just a dead-reckoning flight with little control over the intercept path
column8: says Phillip S. Clark
column9: an independent British authority who has written widely on the Chinese and Russian space programs.

column1: For China
column2: a nation that has already sent humans into space and developed intercontinental ballistic missiles (ICBMs)
column3: the technology involved in the test was hardly remarkable. But as a demonstration of a rising military posture
column4: it was a surprisingly aggressive act
column5: especially since China has long pushed for an international treaty banning space weapons. ""The move was a dangerous step toward the abyss of weaponizing space
column6: says Theresa Hitchens
column7: director of the Center for Defense Information
column8: an independent defense research group in Washington
column9: D.C. ""China held the moral high ground about space
column10: and that test re-energized the China hawks in Congress. If we're not careful
column11: space could become the new Wild West. You don't just go and blow things up there."" In fact
column12: after the Chinese test
column13: India publicly stepped up its development of antiÃÂÃÂ­satellite technology. And some Israeli officials have argued that
column14: given China's record of selling missile technology to Iran
column15: Israel should develop its own program.

column1: INTERNATIONAL THREAT
For many countries
column2: the most disturbing aspect of the test was not the potentially destabilizing sat kill
column3: but the resulting debris
column4: which poses a serious threat to every satellite in orbit
column5: as well as to the International Space Station. ""Space debris is a huge problem
column6: says Laura Grego
column7: staff scientist in the Global Security Program at the Union of Concerned Scientists. ""A 1-centimeter object is very hard to track but can do considerable damage if it collides with any spacecraft at a high rate of speed."" Think of a shotgun pellet traveling at 10 times the speed of a bullet
column8: smashing into a device built to be as light as possible. And then consider that China's antisatellite (ASAT) test produced as many as 35
column9: 000 of these pellets
column10: or pieces of debris
column11: in the 1-cm range. Nearly 1500 pieces were 10 cm and larger.

column1: Although the United States knew that China was planning to test ASAT technology
column2: administration officialsÃ¢ÂÂreluctant to disclose the level of U.S. surveillanceÃ¢ÂÂchose to say nothing. China failed two or three times before successfully launching the missile in January. All the attempts were observed by the U.S. Air Force satellite system known as the Defense Support Program. Infrared telescopes on these 33-ft.-high defense satellites can spot the plumes from rockets launched anywhere on Earth.

column1: Battlefield: Space Media Platforms Design Team
1] Songlin test facility
column2: near Xichang
column3: Sichuan province
column4: China. Publicly available satellite images of the facility were censored by China prior to the test; immediately following
column5: they were declassified.

column1: 2] Experts believe a four-stage
column2: solidÃÂÃÂ­-fuel launch vehicleÃ¢ÂÂthought by American officials to be based on China's KT-2Ã¢ÂÂboosted the kill vehicle into orbit.

column1: 3] The Feng-Yun 1C target vehicle was launched May 10
column3: with a two-year active life span. The 1650-pound polar-orbiting weather satellite was equipped with two 10-band scanning radiometers for Earth observation.

column1: 4] The kinetic-energy kill vehicle was traveling nearly 18
column2: 000 mph when it struck the satellite.

column1: 5] The collision blasted debris throughout low Earth orbit. Within 7 hours
column2: a band of debris had spread halfway around the globe.

column1: Some details of China's ASAT test are classified. Our artist relied on published reports
column2: declassified information and comparable technology to create this graphic. The Chinese kinetic kill vehicle is based on Raytheon's Exoatmospheric Kill Vehicle. (Diagram by Golden Section Graphics. Inset satellite photograph by Digital Globe.)

column1: Media Platforms Design Team
AMERICA'S OWN SAT KILLS
Every industrialized country relies on satellites every day
column2: for everything from computer networking technology to telecommunications
column3: navigation
column4: weather prediction
column5: television and radio. This makes satellites especially vulnerable targets. Imagine the U.S. military suddenly without guidance for its soldiers and weapons systems
column6: and its civilians without storm warnings or telephones.

column1: Some satellites
column2: however
column3: are at greater risk than others. Most spacecraft -- including spy sats -- are in low Earth orbit
column4: which stretches 1240 miles into space. As the Chinese test proved
column5: such targets could be hit with medium-range missiles tipped with crude kill devices. GPS satellites are far higher
column6: orbiting at about 12
column7: 600 miles. Many communications sats are in the 22
column8: 000-mile range. Destroying them requires a much more powerful and sophisticated long-range ballistic missile -- yet it can be done. ""You'd need a sky-sweeping capability to comprehensively negate a space support system that is scattered all over
column9: says John Pike
column10: a space analyst at GlobalSecurity.org. ""You'd need ICBM-size boosters -- hundreds of them.""

column1: Such an all-out satellite war would render space useless for decades to come. ""There'd be so much debris up there
column2: Clark says
column3: ""that it wouldn't be safe to put anything up in space.""

column1: The United States and Russia
column2: the two countries with proven ASAT capabilities
column3: have long steered clear of satellites as military targets. Even during the Cold War spy sats were hands-off; the consequences of destroying them were greater than those of unwelcome surveillance. ""The consensus
column4: Clark says
column5: ""was that anybody could look at anybody else.""

column1: Media Platforms Design Team
Diagram: China's antisatellite strike took place at an altitude of 537 miles
column2: which places the international spacecraft depicted below well within range of China's space arsenal.

column1: Nevertheless
column2: the U.S. military has spent decades designing weapons capable of killing other countries' satellites. The crudest American ASAT test
column3: code-named Starfish Prime
column4: took place in 1962
column5: when the U.S. Air Force detonated a 1.4-megaton nuclear weapon at an altitude of 250 miles. The explosion
column6: which occurred about 800 miles west of Hawaii
column7: disabled at least six U.S. and foreign satellites -- roughly a third of the world's low Earth orbit total. The resulting electromagnetic pulse knocked out 300 streetlights in Oahu. Clearly
column8: nukes worked as ASAT weapons
column9: but far too indiscriminately.

column1: To develop a more surgical capability
column2: the Air Force launched Project Mudflap
column3: which was designed to destroy individual Soviet satellites with missiles. But inaccurate space-guidance systems plagued early tests. Then
column4: on May 23
column6: the Air Force pulled off a successful intercept with a modified Nike-Zeus ballistic missile launched from Kwajalein Atoll in the Marshall Islands. It took out a rendezvous and docking target for NASA's Gemini missions at an altitude of 150 miles.

column1: Over the next several decades the Air Force graduated to more sophisticated air-launched missiles that could hit targets with far better accuracy. In 1985 the United States destroyed an American solar observation satellite using a three-stage
column2: heat-seeking miniature vehicle fired from an F-15 fighter jet. That test
column3: like the Chinese one earlier this year
column4: used a kinetic kill vehicle that spewed debris into space. Funding for the program was cancelled before the air-launched system could be perfected.

column1: That same year
column2: at the White Sands Missile Range in New Mexico
column3: the Air Force began operating the powerful Mid-Infrared Chemical Laser. In 1997
column4: it was used to temporarily blind sensors on an Air Force missile-launch and tracking satellite. The sat remained intact; no debris was created. And no laser tests have been conducted since. However
column5: the current federal budget includes funding for a laser to be fired at a low Earth orbit sat from the Starfire Optical Range at Kirtland Air Force Base
column6: in New Mexico
column7: later this year.

column1: Some $400 million has been spent in recent years to develop another sophisticated kill vehicle -- a three-stage missile that smacks an enemy's craft with a sheet of Mylar plastic
column2: disabling it without producing any debris. It has yet to be fully tested
column3: and would only work on satellites in low Earth orbit; communication and GPS sats are too high.

column1: Destroying an adversary's satellites has far-reaching implications. Do you take out only military sats or so-called civilian ones
column2: too? Nearly every satellite has dual uses: A civilian weather satellite used for tracking hurricanes also could watch military movements. Many satellites are used by multiple nations. And once a nation disables an adversary's satellites
column3: it puts its own in peril. As Charles Vick
column4: a senior analyst at GlobalÃÂÃÂ­Security says
column5: ""It's an act of war.""

column1: U.S. Sat Kill Arsenal
--Davin Coburn
1] Perhaps the most spectacular test -- known as Starfish Prime -- occurred on July 9
column3: when a 1.4-megaton nuclear warhead was detonated 250 miles above the Pacific. Radiation and electromagnetic pulses disabled at least six satellites and created an eerie
column4: artificial glow for 20 minutes.

column1: 2] The U.S. conducted its only direct antisat test in 1985
column2: when an F-15 climbed to 80
column4: then fired a three-stage missile. It caught up to a 17
column5: 500-mph Solwind solar observation satellite at an altitude of nearly 300 miles over Vandenberg Air Force Base in California.

column1: 3] In 1997 the U.S. Army hover-tested a kinetic energy weapon that could act like a space-age fly swatter. The kill vehicle extends a Mylar sheet to disable satellites without destroying them. The military found the technology too messy
column2: and eventually canceled the program.

column1: 4] The XSS-11 microsatellite isn't an antisat -- but it could be. First launched in April 2005
column2: the spacecraft is designed to circumnavigate targets and relay diagnostic data. Some experts note that it wouldn't be difficult to reprogram the craft to ram into enemy targets.

column1: Media Platforms Design Team
SENDING A MESSAGE
So why did China risk provoking international hostility? The country's government has been opaque. ""The experiment is not targeted at any other country
column2: said a foreign ministry spokeswoman in Beijing.

column1: Some experts think at least part of China's motivation lies in an unclassified 2006 U.S. report on the future of military activities in space. The document reaffirms that ""The United States considers space capabilities ... vital to its national interests. Consistent with this policy
column2: the United States will: preserve its rights
column3: capabilities
column4: and freedom of action in space; dissuade or deter others from either impeding those rights or developing capabilities intended to do so ... and deny
column5: if necessary
column6: adversaries the use of space capabilities hostile to U.S. national interests.""

column1: The United States ""basically said it has the right to restrict the use of space to only its allies
column2: Clark says. Adds Jeffrey G. Lewis
column3: an arms control expert at the New America Foundation: ""Much of the world was appalled at the tone of the policy. One British newspaper columnist basically said it made space the 51st state.""

column1: In that context
column2: some experts say
column3: the Chinese test was an effort to force the issue
column4: to show the United States the potential consequences of refusing to negotiate a favorable treaty on the military use of space. ""The U.S. was restricting all these arms treaties
column5: says Michael O'Hanlon
column6: a senior fellow in security studies at the Brookings Institution
column7: a Washington
column8: D.C.
column9: think tank. ""For the Chinese
column10: [the test] was an effort to deal from a position of strength.""

column1: Pike believes China may have another rationale for flexing its space muscle: Taiwan. China has long yearned to reabsorb the breakaway island state
column2: which the United States has pledged to defend. In the short term
column3: Pike says
column4: China has only two strategies that could lead to a Taiwan takeover. It could bluff the U.S. in a nuclear confrontation
column5: or it could try something altogether different: Fire medium-range missiles from mobile launchers
column6: just as it did in the January test
column7: and take out America's low-flying imaging satellites. Doing so might blind U.S. military planners long enough for Chinese military forces to gain a foothold on the island.

column1: The Chinese stage these big amphibious exercises off Taiwan all the time. One day
column2: maybe it'll be real
column3: Pike says. ""Either the U.S. will get there quickly enough to stop them or the Chinese will win the race and there won't be the American political resolve to kick them out. All the Chinese would need is time."" A half-dozen sats
column4: Pike says -- that's all it would take. ""Those satellites are low-hanging fruit. It's a no-brainer.""

column1: In that scenario
column2: the ASAT test was not really about China showing the United States its capability. It was about China confirming that its own war plan is feasible.

column1: AMERICA'S TRUMP CARD
The long-term ramifications of the test will take years to play out
column2: but
column3: for now
column4: few observers think China scored any gains. ""It was a mistake
column5: O'Hanlon says. It fueled American hard-liners who want to restrict American technological cooperation with China. And
column6: ""It doesn't help China's case saying it isn't a threatening military power
column7: Vick says. ""It is a threat
column8: and the test showed that."" Whether the United States suddenly accelerates its ASAT capability beyond the testing phase remains to be seen. The country is in the midst of a war; budgets are already tight. Russia is not perceived as a threat and China has only 60 satellites -- few of these are worth shooting down.

column1: America's most robust ASAT weapons were not designed for destroying satellites at all -- they are missiles developed and operated by the Missile Defense Agency (MDA)
column2: formerly known as the Strategic Defense Initiative. All U.S. ballistic missiles are actually dual-use
column3: and while their ability to shoot down incoming rockets has been proven only in tests
column4: it would be easy to direct them against any low Earth orbit satellite. Twenty-four MDA missiles are operational in Alaska and California
column5: far more than would be needed
column6: Pike says
column7: to handle any immediate ASAT needs. There is
column8: he says
column9: ""just nothing to shoot at.""

column1: For now
column2: that is. The militarization of space has long been debated. With one blown-up old weather satellite
column3: China has made the prospect of a new arms race far more likely. It showed the world that it is willing to go toe-to-toe up in the final frontier.

column1: Waste Mismanagement IMPACT + ONE DAY It takes only 24 hours for debris to spread along the destroyed satellite's sun-synchronous polar orbit. The force of the impact drives debris into higher and lower orbits
column2: but most of the wreckage remains at the satellite's original altitude.

column1: JULY 2007 The debris ring broadens and begins to mix with satellites and the abundant trash in low Earth orbit
column2: which extends to an altitude of about 1240 miles.

column1: JANUARY 2008 A year after the test
column2: the debris field continues to spread
column3: joining the cloud of general space junk
column4: which includes everything from 10-ton rocket boosters to radioactive droplets of sodium potassium coolant from the nuclear cores of Soviet satellites.

column1: It's called the Kessler Syndrome -- the point at which low Earth orbit becomes so crowded with debris that collisions render space unusable. ""Debris accumulates over time and takes decades to decay
column2: says Dr. T.S. Kelso of the Center for Space Standards and Innovation. ""We can't track the smaller pieces
column3: so there is even more out there than we know."" The graphic at left illustrates the density of junk in orbit up to an altitude of 22
column4: 000 miles -- and Kessler's looming threat. -- Erin McCarthy

column1: Source: Analysis courtesy of the Center for Space Standards and Innovation/Analytical Graphics
column2: Inc. Data as of April 26
column3: 2007. Objects greatly magnified for visibility.

column1: Litter Kings Sad to say

column3: such as the bags of garbage Soviet cosmonauts jettisoned from the MIR space station for 15 years. Here's how the three busiest space players stack up.

column1: United States: Topping the list

column1: Russia: The relatively low ratio of debris to satellites will soon change: The explosion of a Russian rocket over Australia in February appears to have produced approximately 1200 pieces of fresh debris.
China: Its January sat kill made it the top space polluter per satellite. ""Almost 85 percent of that debris will be in orbit in 100 years
column2: says Kelso of the Center for Space Standards and Innovation. ""It shows how badly they messed things up with one event."" -- E.M."	0

column1: Social Security: Promised Benefits Outpacing Resources
Social Security was designed as a pay-as-you-go
column2: self-financing program whereby current workers pay taxes directly and indirectly
column3: through their employers

column5: disabled persons
column6: and survivors (collectively
column7: beneficiaries). Such a system can only be sustained if the number of workers and the taxes they pay align with the number of beneficiaries and the benefits they receive. In 1950
column8: when there were 16 workers for every program beneficiary

column11: and will fall to 2.2 workers per beneficiary in 2030.

column1: Even after the baby boom generation is fully retired

column1: The growth in retirees resulting from the retirement of the baby boom generation and increases in life expectancy will create a large and rapidly growing mismatch between scheduled Social Security benefits and the resources available to the program under current law. Through 2016
column2: Social Security is projected to collect more in cash receipts than it pays in benefits. Beginning in 2017
column3: however
column4: Social Security benefit payments are projected to exceed the cash income dedicated to the trust funds. From this point forward
column5: the Federal Government must borrow
column6: tax
column7: or cut other spending to pay excess Social Security benefits. Receipts are projected to continue falling to 70 percent of promised benefits by 2080.

column1: There are many ways to summarize the extent of the mismatch between expected Social Security receipts and benefits. One such summary is the discounted present value of all future scheduled benefits net of receipts
column2: or unfunded obligations under Social Security. The concept is to compare scheduled benefits and receipts under current law into the indefinite future
column3: and to recognize through discounting that a dollar tomorrow is worth less than a dollar today. Based on the 2006 Social Security TrusteesÃ¢ÂÂ Report
column4: the unfunded obligation of Social Security totals $15.3 trillion over the indefinite future. To put this figure into perspective
column5: this is about three times the amount of Federal debt currently held by the public.

column1: The President is committed to strengthening Social Security through a bipartisan reform process in which participants are encouraged to bring different options for strengthening Social Security to the table. The President has identified three goals for reform: to strengthen permanently the safety net for future generations without raising payroll tax rates; to protect those who depend on Social Security the most; and to offer every American a chance to experience ownership through voluntary personal retirement accounts.

The 2008 Budget again reflects the PresidentÃ¢ÂÂs proposal to allow workers to use a portion of the Social Security payroll tax to fund voluntary personal retirement accounts. These accounts will permit Americans to have greater control over their retirement planning
column2: giving them an opportunity to obtain a higher return on their payroll taxes than is possible in the current Social Security system. The result will be to shift Social Security from an entirely pay-as-you-go system of financing toward a system that is less dependent on current workers. Beginning in 2012
column3: workers will be allowed to use up to four percent of their Social Security taxable earnings
column4: up to a $1
column5: 300 annual limit
column6: to fund their personal retirement accounts; the $1
column7: 300 cap will be increased by $100 each year through 2017.

column1: As one component of reforms to make the system sustainable

column3: wages tend to rise faster than prices

column6: changes in the indexation of wages

Medicare: Slowing Cost Growth through Reforms

The single largest fiscal challenge we face is the unsustainable growth in the Medicare program. The Medicare Part A Hospital Insurance program receives designated payroll taxes from employees and their employers
column2: which are deposited in the Medicare trust fund held by the Government. Medicare Part A is therefore similar to Social Security in that it is an inter-generational transfer program with current workers paying benefits for current beneficiaries. In contrast
column3: under Medicare Part B
column4: the Supplementary Medical Insurance program
column5: and Part D
column6: the new drug benefit
column7: beneficiaries pay premiums to cover some of the costs and the balance is paid out of general revenues.

column3: Medicare is projected to have much higher cost-per-beneficiary growth than Social Security in the coming decades.

column1: MedicareÃ¢ÂÂs dedicated revenues from designated payroll taxes and from premium payments cover only 57 percent of current benefits. The remaining 43 percent is financed from general tax revenues. By 2030
column2: the pressure from Medicare on general revenues will be substantially greater as dedicated revenues are projected to finance only 38 percent of total benefits
column3: leaving 62 percent of program costs relying on general tax revenues. This projected rate of growth in Medicare benefits is not sustainable over time.

column1: The 2006 Medicare TrusteesÃ¢ÂÂ report shows that future dedicated payroll taxes and premiums are sufficient to cover only a portion of MedicareÃ¢ÂÂs projected costs. This results in an unfunded obligation (the gap between dedicated receipts and projected costs) of $71 trillion over the infinite horizon. This is more than four times as large as the gap between receipts and projected costs for Social Security and 14 times as large the total amount of Government debt that is held by the public. Within Medicare
column2: the Hospital Insurance trust fund
column3: which is mostly funded by the Medicare payroll tax
column4: has unfunded obligations
column5: or a gap between dedicated receipts and projected costs
column6: of $28 trillion. Meeting these obligations would require tripling the Medicare payroll tax. If the Medicare payroll tax were used to pay for MedicareÃ¢ÂÂs entire $71 trillion unfunded obligation
column7: the Medicare payroll tax would have to be increased by 500 percent. This would be a huge tax increase on workers and companies that would cripple the NationÃ¢ÂÂs economy. The only realistic solution is to reduce program growth to a sustainable level.

column1: In the long run
column2: part of the solution to Medicare and MedicaidÃ¢ÂÂs unsustainable growth must lie with slowing health care inflation. column3: Improvement
column4: and Modernization Act of 2003 (MMA) with respect to Medicare financing. Under current law

Medicaid is the Federal entitlement program that provides medical assistance

column1: BUDGET REFORMS
During the 1990s
column2: budget decisions were governed by the now-expired Budget Enforcement Act (BEA). Under the BEA
column3: discretionary spending (including both budget authority and actual outlays) was limited each fiscal year to a maximum amount specified in law. In addition
column4: under the BEA
column5: pay-as-you-go rules required all legislation involving new mandatory spending or tax cuts was required to be deficit neutral. Violations of the discretionary spending caps or the pay-as-you-go provisions triggered across-the-board spending reductions. The BEA generally succeeded in preventing the GovernmentÃ¢ÂÂs budgetary outlook from deteriorating.

column1: Based in part on the spending controls in the BEA
column2: the President has proposed a number of budget process reforms
column3: including new caps on discretionary spending
column4: a pay-as-you-go requirement for mandatory spending
column5: a line-item veto
column6: and earmark reform. In addition
column7: the Administration implemented its own pay-as-you-go controls to limit mandatory spending resulting from agency administrative action. Specifically
column8: on May 23
column10: the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) began requiring that proposed agency administrative action that increases mandatory spending be offset by administrative actions that reduce mandatory spending by the same amount.

column1: Federal spending is generally divided into three major categories: discretionary spending (approximately 38 percent of the Budget)
column2: mandatory spending (53 percent)
column3: and interest on the debt (9 percent).

column1: Discretionary Spending Caps: Restraining Annual Appropriations

Discretionary spending is generally thought of as funding the day-to-day operations of Government and is the only spending subject to annual review and appropriations by the Congress and the President. As distinct from mandatory spending
column2: discretionary spending must be enacted into law every year before Government agencies may obligate and spend money. Hence
column3: discretionary spending is not subject to the same automatic
column4: uncontrolled growth characteristic of some mandatory spending. Nevertheless
column5: without active restraint reinforced by effective rules governing the legislative process
column6: discretionary spending will tend to increase steadily over time. The 2008 Budget proposes to reinstate BEA controls on discretionary spending. Specifically
column7: the Budget proposes placing statutory limits or Ã¢ÂÂcapsÃ¢ÂÂ on discretionary spending each year through 2012. Any appropriations bill that causes the caps to be exceeded would be subject to a point of order
column8: requiring a three-fifths vote
column9: in the Senate. If
column10: in the aggregate
column11: appropriations actions exceed the spending caps
column12: then OMB would be required to make across-the-board cuts to reduce total discretionary spending to the statutory caps.

column1: Within these proposed spending caps
column2: the Budget proposes to devote resources for program integrity efforts. Program integrity efforts are designed to eliminate spending to those not eligible for benefit payments and to collect unpaid taxes due to the Government. Since program integrity efforts can generate as high as a ten-to-one return to the Government
column3: the Administration proposes an adjustment to the statutory discretionary spending limits for amounts dedicated to program integrity.

column1: Mandatory Spending Controls: Restraining Automatic Spending

The vast majority of spending for mandatory programs takes place automatically every year without any action on the part of the Congress or the President. It is made up of Ã¢ÂÂentitlementÃ¢ÂÂ programs
column2: for which the amount of spending is based on the number of qualifying beneficiaries and benefit formulas specified in law. This spending provides income security and health care to individuals who are elderly
column3: disabled
column4: widowed
column5: or orphaned. These programs are effectively exempt from the annual review and approval in the budget process because the benefit qualifications and benefit formulas are specified in law
column6: resulting in an automatic appropriation of benefit payments.

column2: mandatory spending accounted for just over one-quarter of total Government outlays and discretionary spending accounted for slightly more than two-thirds of Government outlays; the remainder of outlays was for interest. Today
column3: the picture is dramatically different
column4: with mandatory spending having doubled as a share of total outlays
column5: now accounting for 53 percent of all Government spending. Without intervention
column6: entitlement spending over the next four decades will become unsustainable. With the baby boom population beginning to become eligible for Social Security in 2008 and Medicare in 2011
column7: the time to address this problem is now.

column1: STEPHANOPOULOS: Good morning and welcome to ""This Week."" Watching everything.

STEPHANOPOULOS: This morning
column2: we cover the controversy from all angles. The reporter who broke the story

column5: and the Committee Chairs who approved the program

column1: ANNOUNCER: From ABC News
column2: This Week with George Stephanopoulos. Reporting from ABC News Headquarters
column3: George Stephanopoulos.

column1: STEPHANOPOULOS: Hello again. The secret struggle to balance national security and individual liberty broke out into open this week
column2: after a series of blockbuster revelations
column3: starting in The Guardian newspaper. We learned that the government has the capacity to track virtually every American phone call
column4: and to scoop up impossibly vast quantities of data across the Internet.

column1: And our first guest is The Guardian columnist getting these scoops
column2: Glenn Greenwald. Thank you for joining us today
column3: Mr. Greenwald. You are really on a roll. You broke another story yesterday showing the scale of the data collection programs. In March 2013
column4: you report the government collected 97 billion pieces of data
column5: almost all of it from outside the U.S. What's the key finding here?

column1: GREENWALD: There are two key findings. One is that there are members of the Congress who have responsibility for oversight
column2: for checking the people who run this vast secret apparatus of spying to make sure they are not abusing their power. These people in Congress have continuously asked for the NSA to provide basic information about how many Americans they are spying on
column3: how many conversations and telephone and chats of -- of Americans they are intercepting
column4: and the NSA continuously tells them
column5: we don't have the capability to tell you that
column6: to even give you a rough estimate.

column1: So what these documents that we published show
column2: that were marked top-secret to prevent the American people from learning about them
column3: was that the NSA keeps extremely precise statistics
column4: all the data that the senators amassed where that the NSA has falsely claimed does not exist. And the other thing that it does
column5: as you said
column6: is it indicates just how vast and massive the NSA is in terms of sweeping up all forms of communication around the globe
column7: including domestically.

column1: STEPHANOPOULOS: You also drew new criticism yesterday from the Director of National Intelligence
column2: James Clapper. He called the disclosures reckless
column3: said the rush to publish has created significant misimpressions and added that the articles are filled with inaccuracies. Your response to that?"	0

And they all look like John -- the brothers do -- so he doesnÃ¢ÂÂt have to go to every event. He can just send one of his brothers out. (Laughter.) It is good to see him.
