column3: good job. (Laughter.)

column1: So
column2: eight years ago
column3: I came here to deliver the commencement address for the class of 2005. Things were a little different back then. For example
column4: I had no gray hair -- (laughter) -- or a motorcade. DidnÃ¢ÂÂt even have a prompter. In fact
column5: there was a problem in terms of printing out the speech because the printer didnÃ¢ÂÂt work here and we had to drive it in from somewhere. (Laughter.) But it was my first big speech as your newest senator.

column1: And on the way here I was telling Cheri and Claire about how important this area was
column2: one of the areas that I spent the most time in outside of Chicago
column3: and how much it represented whatÃ¢ÂÂs best in America and folks who were willing to work hard and do right by their families. And I came here to talk about what a changing economy was doing to the middle class -- and what we
column4: as a country
column5: needed to do to give every American a chance to get ahead in the 21st century.

column1: See
column2: I had just spent a year traveling the state and listening to your stories -- of proud Maytag workers losing their jobs when the plant moved down to Mexico. (Applause.) A lot of folks here remember that. Of teachers whose salaries werenÃ¢ÂÂt keeping up with the rising cost of groceries. (Applause.) Of young people who had the drive and the energy
column3: but not the money to afford a college education. (Applause.)

column1: So these were stories of families who had worked hard
column2: believed in the American Dream
column3: but they felt like the odds were increasingly stacked against them. And they were right. Things had changed.

column1: In the period after World War II
column2: a growing middle class was the engine of our prosperity. Whether you owned a company
column3: or swept its floors
column4: or worked anywhere in between
column5: this country offered you a basic bargain -- a sense that your hard work would be rewarded with fair wages and decent benefits
column6: the chance to buy a home
column7: to save for retirement
column8: and most of all
column9: a chance to hand down a better life for your kids.

column1: But over time
column2: that engine began to stall -- and a lot of folks here saw it -- that bargain began to fray. Technology made some jobs obsolete. Global competition sent a lot of jobs overseas. It became harder for unions to fight for the middle class. Washington doled out bigger tax cuts to the very wealthy and smaller minimum wage increases for the working poor.

column1: And so what happened was that the link between higher productivity and peopleÃ¢ÂÂs wages and salaries was broken. It used to be that
column2: as companies did better
column3: as profits went higher
column4: workers also got a better deal. And that started changing. So the income of the top 1 percent nearly quadrupled from 1979 to 2007
column5: but the typical familyÃ¢ÂÂs incomes barely budged.

column1: And towards the end of those three decades
column2: a housing bubble
column3: credit cards
column4: a churning financial sector was keeping the economy artificially juiced up
column5: so sometimes it papered over some of these long-term trends. But by the time I took office in 2009 as your President
column6: we all know the bubble had burst
column7: and it cost millions of Americans their jobs
column8: and their homes
column9: and their savings. And I know a lot of folks in this area were hurt pretty bad. And the decades-long erosion that had been taking place -- the erosion of middle-class security -- was suddenly laid bare for everybody to see.

column1: Now
column2: today
column3: five years after the start of that Great Recession
column4: America has fought its way back. (Applause.) We fought our way back. Together
column5: we saved the auto industry; took on a broken health care system. (Applause.) We invested in new American technologies to reverse our addiction to foreign oil. We doubled wind and solar power. (Applause.) Together
column6: we put in place tough new rules on the big banks
column7: and protections to crack down on the worst practices of mortgage lenders and credit card companies. (Applause.) We changed a tax code too skewed in favor of the wealthiest at the expense of working families -- so we changed that
column8: and we locked in tax cuts for 98 percent of Americans
column9: and we asked those at the top to pay a little bit more. (Applause.)

column1: So you add it all up
column2: and over the past 40 months
column3: our businesses have created 7.2 million new jobs. This year
column4: weÃ¢ÂÂre off to our strongest private sector job growth since 1999.

column1: And because we bet on this country
column2: suddenly foreign companies are
column3: too. Right now
column4: more of HondaÃ¢ÂÂs cars are made in America than anyplace else on Earth. (Applause.) Airbus
column5: the European aircraft company
column6: theyÃ¢ÂÂre building new planes in Alabama. (Applause.) And American companies like Ford are replacing outsourcing with insourcing -- theyÃ¢ÂÂre bringing jobs back home. (Applause.)

column1: We sell more products made in America to the rest of the world than ever before. We produce more natural gas than any country on Earth. WeÃ¢ÂÂre about to produce more of our own oil than we buy from abroad for the first time in nearly 20 years. (Applause.) The cost of health care is growing at its slowest rate in 50 years. (Applause.) And our deficits are falling at the fastest rate in 60 years. (Applause.)

So thanks to the grit and resilience and determination of the American people -- of folks like you -- weÃ¢ÂÂve been able to clear away the rubble from the financial crisis. We started to lay a new foundation for stronger
column2: more durable economic growth. And it's happening in our own personal lives as well
column3: right? A lot of us tightened our belts
column4: shed debt
column5: maybe cut up a couple of credit cards
column6: refocused on those things that really matter.

column1: As a country
column2: weÃ¢ÂÂve recovered faster and gone further than most other advanced nations in the world. With new American revolutions in energy and technology and manufacturing and health care
column3: we're actually poised to reverse the forces that battered the middle class for so long
column4: and start building an economy where everyone who works hard can get ahead.

column1: But -- and here's the big Ã¢ÂÂbutÃ¢ÂÂ -- IÃ¢ÂÂm here to tell you today that we're not there yet. We all know that. We're not there yet. We've got more work to do. Even though our businesses are creating new jobs and have broken record profits
column2: nearly all the income gains of the past 10 years have continued to flow to the top 1 percent. The average CEO has gotten a raise of nearly 40 percent since 2009. The average American earns less than he or she did in 1999. And companies continue to hold back on hiring those whoÃ¢ÂÂve been out of work for some time.

column1: Today
column2: more students are earning their degree
column3: but soaring costs saddle them with unsustainable debt. Health care costs are slowing down
column4: but a lot of working families havenÃ¢ÂÂt seen any of those savings yet. The stock market rebound helped a lot of families get back much of what they had lost in their 401(k)s
column5: but millions of Americans still have no idea how theyÃ¢ÂÂre going to be able to retire.

column1: So in many ways
column2: the trends that I spoke about here in 2005 -- eight years ago -- the trend of a winner-take-all economy where a few are doing better and better and better
column3: while everybody else just treads water -- those trends have been made worse by the recession. And that's a problem.

column1: This growing inequality not just of result
column2: inequality of opportunity -- this growing inequality is not just morally wrong
column3: itÃ¢ÂÂs bad economics. Because when middle-class families have less to spend
column4: guess what
column5: businesses have fewer consumers. When wealth concentrates at the very top
column6: it can inflate unstable bubbles that threaten the economy. When the rungs on the ladder of opportunity grow farther and farther apart
column7: it undermines the very essence of America -- that idea that if you work hard you can make it here.

column1: And thatÃ¢ÂÂs why reversing these trends has to be WashingtonÃ¢ÂÂs highest priority. (Applause.) It has to be Washington's highest priority. (Applause.) ItÃ¢ÂÂs certainly my highest priority. (Applause.)
Unfortunately
column2: over the past couple of years
column3: in particular
column4: Washington hasnÃ¢ÂÂt just ignored this problem; too often
column5: Washington has made things worse. (Applause.)

column1: And I have to say that -- because I'm looking around the room -- I've got some friends here not just who are Democrats
column2: I've got some friends here who are Republicans -- (applause) -- and I worked with in the state legislature and they did great work. But right now
column3: what weÃ¢ÂÂve got in Washington
column4: we've seen a sizable group of Republican lawmakers suggest that they wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt vote to pay the very bills that Congress rang up. And that fiasco harmed a fragile recovery in 2011 and we can't afford to repeat that.

column1: Then
column2: rather than reduce our deficits with a scalpel -- by cutting out programs we donÃ¢ÂÂt need
column3: fixing ones that we do need that maybe are in need of reform
column4: making government more efficient -- instead of doing that
column5: we've got folks whoÃ¢ÂÂve insisted on leaving in place a meat cleaver called the sequester that's cost jobs. It's harmed growth. It's hurt our military. It's gutted investments in education and science and medical research. (Applause.)

column1: Almost every credible economist will tell you it's been a huge drag on this recovery. And it means that we're underinvesting in the things that this country needs to make it a magnet for good jobs.
Then
column2: over the last six months
column3: this gridlock has gotten worse. I didn't think that was possible. (Laughter.) The good news is a growing number of Republican senators are looking to join their Democratic counterparts and try to get things done in the Senate. So that's good news. (Applause.) For example
column4: they worked together on an immigration bill that economists say will boost our economy by more than a trillion dollars
column5: strengthen border security
column6: make the system work.

column1: But you've got a faction of Republicans in the House who wonÃ¢ÂÂt even give that bill a vote. And that same group gutted a farm bill that AmericaÃ¢ÂÂs farmers depend on
column2: but also America's most vulnerable children depend on.

column1: AUDIENCE MEMBER: Booo --
THE PRESIDENT: And if you ask some of these folks
column2: some of these folks mostly in the House
column3: about their economic agenda how it is that they'll strengthen the middle class
column4: theyÃ¢ÂÂll shift the topic to Ã¢ÂÂout-of-control government spendingÃ¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ- despite the fact that we've cut the deficit by nearly half as a share of the economy since I took office. (Applause.)

column1: Or theyÃ¢ÂÂll talk about government assistance for the poor
column2: despite the fact that theyÃ¢ÂÂve already cut early education for vulnerable kids. They've already cut insurance for people whoÃ¢ÂÂve lost their jobs through no fault of their own. Or theyÃ¢ÂÂll bring up Obamacare -- this is tried and true -- despite the fact that our businesses have created nearly twice as many jobs in this recovery as businesses had at the same point in the last recovery when there was no Obamacare. (Applause.)

column1: AUDIENCE MEMBER: My daughter has insurance now!
THE PRESIDENT: I appreciate that. (Applause.) ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what this is about. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what this is about. (Applause.) ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what we've been fighting for.
But with this endless parade of distractions and political posturing and phony scandals
column2: Washington has taken its eye off the ball. And I am here to say this needs to stop. (Applause.) This needs to stop.

column1: This moment does not require short-term thinking. It does not require having the same old stale debates. Our focus has to be on the basic economic issues that matter most to you
column2: the people we represent. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what we have to spend our time on and our energy on and our focus on. (Applause.)

column1: And as Washington prepares to enter another budget debate
column2: the stakes for our middle class and everybody who is fighting to get into the middle class could not be higher. The countries that are passive in the face of a global economy
column3: those countries will lose the competition for good jobs. They will lose the competition for high living standards. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs why America has to make the investments necessary to promote long-term growth and shared prosperity -- rebuilding our manufacturing base
column4: educating our workforce
column5: upgrading our transportation systems
column6: upgrading our information networks. (Applause.) ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what we need to be talking about. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what Washington needs to be focused on.

column1: And thatÃ¢ÂÂs why
column2: over the next several weeks
column3: in towns across this country
column4: I will be engaging the American people in this debate. (Applause.) I'll lay out my ideas for how we build on the cornerstones of what it means to be middle class in America
column5: and what it takes to work your way into the middle class in America: Job security
column6: with good wages and durable industries. A good education. A home to call your own. Affordable health care when you get sick. (Applause.) A secure retirement even if youÃ¢ÂÂre not rich. Reducing poverty. Reducing inequality. Growing opportunity. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what we need. (Applause.) ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what we need. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what we need right now. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what we need to be focused on. (Applause.)

column1: Now
column2: some of these ideas IÃ¢ÂÂve talked about before. Some of the ideas I offer will be new. Some will require Congress. Some I will pursue on my own. (Applause.) Some ideas will benefit folks right away. Some will take years to fully implement. But the key is to break through the tendency in Washington to just bounce from crisis to crisis. What we need is not a three-month plan
column3: or even a three-year plan; we need a long-term American strategy
column4: based on steady
column5: persistent effort
column6: to reverse the forces that have conspired against the middle class for decades. That has to be our project. (Applause.)

column1: Now
column2: of course
column3: weÃ¢ÂÂll keep pressing on other key priorities. I want to get this immigration bill done. We still need to work on reducing gun violence. (Applause.) WeÃ¢ÂÂve got to continue to end the war in Afghanistan
column4: rebalance our fight against al Qaeda. (Applause.) We need to combat climate change. WeÃ¢ÂÂve got to standing up for civil rights. WeÃ¢ÂÂve got to stand up for womenÃ¢ÂÂs rights. (Applause.)

column1: So all those issues are important
column2: and weÃ¢ÂÂll be fighting on every one of those issues. But if we donÃ¢ÂÂt have a growing
column3: thriving middle class then we wonÃ¢ÂÂt have the resources to solve a lot of these problems. We wonÃ¢ÂÂt have the resolve
column4: the optimism
column5: the sense of unity that we need to solve many of these other issues.

column1: Now
column2: in this effort
column3: I will look to work with Republicans as well as Democrats wherever I can. And I sincerely believe that there are members of both parties who understand this moment
column4: understand whatÃ¢ÂÂs at stake
column5: and I will welcome ideas from anybody across the political spectrum. But I will not allow gridlock
column6: or inaction
column7: or willful indifference to get in our way. (Applause.)

column1: That means whatever executive authority I have to help the middle class
column2: IÃ¢ÂÂll use it. (Applause.) Where I canÃ¢ÂÂt act on my own and Congress isnÃ¢ÂÂt cooperating
column3: IÃ¢ÂÂll pick up the phone -- IÃ¢ÂÂll call CEOs; IÃ¢ÂÂll call philanthropists; IÃ¢ÂÂll call college presidents; IÃ¢ÂÂll call labor leaders. IÃ¢ÂÂll call anybody who can help -- and enlist them in our efforts. (Applause.)

column1: Because the choices that we
column2: the people
column3: make right now will determine whether or not every American has a fighting chance in the 21st century. And it will lay the foundation for our childrenÃ¢ÂÂs future
column4: our grandchildrenÃ¢ÂÂs future
column5: for all Americans.

column1: So let me give you a quick preview of what IÃ¢ÂÂll be fighting for and why. The first cornerstone of a strong
column2: growing middle class has to be
column3: as I said before
column4: an economy that generates more good jobs in durable
column5: growing industries. That's how this area was built. That's how America prospered. Because anybody who was willing to work
column6: they could go out there and they could find themselves a job
column7: and they could build a life for themselves and their family.

column1: Now
column2: over the past four years
column3: for the first time since the 1990s
column4: the number of American manufacturing jobs has actually gone up instead of down. That's the good news. (Applause.) But we can do more. So IÃ¢ÂÂm going to push new initiatives to help more manufacturers bring more jobs back to the United States. (Applause.) WeÃ¢ÂÂre going to continue to focus on strategies to make sure our tax code rewards companies that are not shipping jobs overseas
column5: but creating jobs right here in the United States of America. (Applause.)

column1: We want to make sure that -- weÃ¢ÂÂre going to create strategies to make sure that good jobs in wind and solar and natural gas that are lowering costs and
column2: at the same time
column3: reducing dangerous carbon pollution happen right here in the United States. (Applause.)

column1: And something that Cheri and I were talking about on the way over here -- IÃ¢ÂÂm going to be pushing to open more manufacturing innovation institutes that turn regions left behind by global competition into global centers of cutting-edge jobs. So letÃ¢ÂÂs tell the world that America is open for business. (Applause.) I know thereÃ¢ÂÂs an old site right here in Galesburg
column2: over on Monmouth Boulevard -- letÃ¢ÂÂs put some folks to work. (Applause.)

column1: Tomorrow
column2: IÃ¢ÂÂll also visit the Port of Jacksonville
column3: Florida to offer new ideas for doing what America has always done best
column4: which is building things. Pat and I were talking before I came -- backstage -- Pat Quinn -- he was talking about how I came over the Don Moffitt Bridge. (Applause.) But weÃ¢ÂÂve got work to do all across the country. WeÃ¢ÂÂve got ports that arenÃ¢ÂÂt ready for the new supertankers that are going to begin passing through the new Panama Canal in two yearsÃ¢ÂÂ time. If we donÃ¢ÂÂt get that done
column5: those tankers are going to go someplace else. WeÃ¢ÂÂve got more than 100
column6: 000 bridges that are old enough to qualify for Medicare. (Laughter and applause.)

column1: Businesses depend on our transportation systems
column2: on our power grids
column3: on our communications networks. And rebuilding them creates good-paying jobs right now that canÃ¢ÂÂt be outsourced. (Applause.)

column1: And by the way
column2: this isnÃ¢ÂÂt a Democratic idea. Republicans built a lot of stuff. This is the Land of Lincoln. Lincoln was all about building stuff -- first Republican President. (Applause.) And yet
column3: as a share of our economy
column4: we invest less in our infrastructure than we did two decades ago. And thatÃ¢ÂÂs inefficient at a time when itÃ¢ÂÂs as cheap as itÃ¢ÂÂs been since the 1950s to build things. ItÃ¢ÂÂs inexcusable at a time when so many of the workers who build stuff for a living are sitting at home waiting for a call.

column1: The longer we put this off
column2: the more expensive it will be and the less competitive we will be. Businesses of tomorrow will not locate near old roads and outdated ports. TheyÃ¢ÂÂll relocate to places with high-speed Internet
column3: and high-tech schools
column4: and systems that move air and auto traffic faster
column5: and not to mention will get parents home quicker from work because weÃ¢ÂÂll be eliminating some of these traffic jams. And we can watch all of that happen in other countries
column6: and start falling behind
column7: or we can choose to make it happen right here
column8: in the United States. (Applause.)

column1: In an age when jobs know no borders
column2: companies are also going to seek out the countries that boast the most talented citizens
column3: and theyÃ¢ÂÂll reward folks who have the skills and the talents they need -- theyÃ¢ÂÂll reward those folks with good pay.

column1: The days when the wages for a worker with a high school degree could keep pace with the earnings of somebody who got some sort of higher education -- those days are over. Everybody here knows that. There are a whole bunch of folks here whose dads or grandpas worked at a plant
column2: didnÃ¢ÂÂt need a high school education. You could just go there. If you were willing to work hard
column3: you might be able to get two jobs. And you could support your family
column4: have a vacation
column5: own your home. But technology and global competition
column6: theyÃ¢ÂÂre not going away. Those old days arenÃ¢ÂÂt coming back.

column1: So we can either throw up our hands and resign ourselves to diminishing living standards
column2: or we can do what America has always done
column3: which is adapt
column4: and pull together
column5: and fight back
column6: and win. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what we have to do. (Applause.)

column1: And that brings me to the second cornerstone of a strong middle class -- and everybody here knows it -- an education that prepares our children and our workers for the global competition that theyÃ¢ÂÂre going to face. (Applause.) And if you think education is expensive
column2: wait until you see how much ignorance costs in the 21st century. (Laughter and applause.)

column1: If we donÃ¢ÂÂt make this investment
column2: weÃ¢ÂÂre going to put our kids
column3: our workers
column4: and our country at a competitive disadvantage for decades. So we have to begin in the earliest years. And thatÃ¢ÂÂs why IÃ¢ÂÂm going to keep pushing to make high-quality preschool available for every 4-year-old in America. (Applause.) Not just because we know it works for our kids
column5: but because it provides a vital support system for working parents.

column1: And IÃ¢ÂÂm going to take action in the education area to spur innovation that donÃ¢ÂÂt require Congress. (Applause.) So
column2: today
column3: for example
column4: as we speak
column5: federal agencies are moving on my plan to connect 99 percent of AmericaÃ¢ÂÂs students to high-speed Internet over the next five years. WeÃ¢ÂÂre making that happen right now. (Applause.) WeÃ¢ÂÂve already begun meeting with business leaders and tech entrepreneurs and innovative educators to identify the best ideas for redesigning our high schools so that they teach the skills required for a high-tech economy.

column1: And weÃ¢ÂÂre also going to keep pushing new efforts to train workers for changing jobs. So here in Galesburg
column2: for example
column3: a lot of the workers that were laid off at Maytag chose to enroll in retraining programs like the one at Carl Sandburg College. (Applause.) And while it didnÃ¢ÂÂt pay off for everyone
column4: a lot of the folks who were retrained found jobs that suited them even better and paid even more than the ones they had lost.

column1: And thatÃ¢ÂÂs why IÃ¢ÂÂve asked Congress to start a Community College to Career initiative
column2: so that workers can earn the skills that high-tech jobs demand without leaving their hometown. (Applause.) And IÃ¢ÂÂm going to challenge CEOs from some of AmericaÃ¢ÂÂs best companies to hire more Americans whoÃ¢ÂÂve got what it takes to fill that job opening but have been laid off for so long that nobody is giving their rÃÂ©sumÃÂ© an honest look.

column1: AUDIENCE MEMBER: More talent!
THE PRESIDENT: That
column2: too.

column1: IÃ¢ÂÂm also going to use the power of my office over the next few months to highlight a topic thatÃ¢ÂÂs straining the budgets of just about every American family -- and thatÃ¢ÂÂs the soaring cost of higher education. (Applause.) Everybody is touched by this
column2: including your President
column3: who had a whole bunch of loans he had to pay off. (Laughter.)

column1: Three years ago
column2: I worked with Democrats to reform the student loan system so that taxpayer dollars stopped padding the pockets of big banks
column3: and instead helped more kids afford college. (Applause.) Then
column4: I capped loan repayments at 10 percent of monthly incomes for responsible borrowers
column5: so that if somebody graduated and they decided to take a teaching job
column6: for example
column7: that didnÃ¢ÂÂt pay a lot of money
column8: they knew that they were never going to have to pay more than 10 percent of their income and they could afford to go into a profession that they loved. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs in place right now. (Applause.) And this week
column9: weÃ¢ÂÂre working with both parties to reverse the doubling of student loan rates that happened a few weeks ago because of congressional inaction. (Applause.)

column1: So this is all a good start -- but it isnÃ¢ÂÂt enough. Families and taxpayers canÃ¢ÂÂt just keep paying more and more and more into an undisciplined system where costs just keep on going up and up and up. WeÃ¢ÂÂll never have enough loan money
column2: weÃ¢ÂÂll never have enough grant money
column3: to keep up with costs that are going up 5
column5: 7 percent a year. WeÃ¢ÂÂve got to get more out of what we pay for.

column1: Now
column2: some colleges are testing new approaches to shorten the path to a degree
column3: or blending teaching with online learning to help students master material and earn credits in less time. In some states
column4: theyÃ¢ÂÂre testing new ways to fund college based not just on how many students enroll
column5: but how many of them graduate
column6: how well did they do.

column1: So this afternoon
column2: IÃ¢ÂÂll visit the University of Central Missouri to highlight their efforts to deliver more bang for the buck to their students. And in the coming months
column3: I will lay out an aggressive strategy to shake up the system
column4: tackle rising costs
column5: and improve value for middle-class students and their families. It is critical that we make sure that college is affordable for every single American whoÃ¢ÂÂs willing to work for it. (Applause.)

column1: Now
column2: so youÃ¢ÂÂve got a good job; you get a good education -- those have always been the key stepping stones into the middle class. But a home of your own has always been the clearest expression of middle-class security. For most families
column3: thatÃ¢ÂÂs your biggest asset. For most families
column4: thatÃ¢ÂÂs where your lifeÃ¢ÂÂs work has been invested. And that changed during the crisis
column5: when we saw millions of middle-class families experience their home values plummeting. The good news is over the past four years
column6: weÃ¢ÂÂve helped more responsible homeowners stay in their homes. And today
column7: sales are up and prices are up
column8: and fewer Americans see their homes underwater.

column1: But weÃ¢ÂÂre not done yet. The key now is to encourage homeownership that isnÃ¢ÂÂt based on unrealistic bubbles
column2: but instead is based on a solid foundation
column3: where buyers and lenders play by the same set of rules
column4: rules that are clear and transparent and fair.

column1: So already
column2: IÃ¢ÂÂve asked Congress to pass a really good
column3: bipartisan idea -- one that was championed
column4: by the way
column5: by Mitt RomneyÃ¢ÂÂs economic advisor -- and this is the idea to give every homeowner the chance to refinance their mortgage while rates are still low so they can save thousands of dollars a year. (Applause.) It will be like a tax cut for families who can refinance.

column1: IÃ¢ÂÂm also acting on my own to cut red tape for responsible families who want to get a mortgage but the bank is saying no. WeÃ¢ÂÂll work with both parties to turn the page on Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac
column2: and build a housing finance system thatÃ¢ÂÂs rock-solid for future generations.

column1: So weÃ¢ÂÂve got more work to do to strengthen homeownership in this country. But along with homeownership
column2: the fourth cornerstone of what it means to be middle class in this country is a secure retirement. (Applause.) I hear from too many people across the country
column3: face to face or in letters that they send me
column4: that they feel as if retirement is just receding from their grasp. ItÃ¢ÂÂs getting farther and farther away. They can't see it.

column1: Now
column2: today
column3: a rising stock market has millions of retirement balances going up
column4: and some of the losses that had taken place during the financial crisis have been recovered. But we still live with an upside-down system where those at the top
column5: folks like me
column6: get generous tax incentives to save
column7: while tens of millions of hardworking Americans who are struggling
column8: they get none of those breaks at all. So as we work to reform our tax code
column9: we should find new ways to make it easier for workers to put away money
column10: and free middle-class families from the fear that they won't be able to retire. (Applause.)

column1: And if Congress is looking for a bipartisan place to get started
column2: I should just say they donÃ¢ÂÂt have to look far. We mentioned immigration reform before. Economists show that immigration reform makes undocumented workers pay their full share of taxes
column3: and that actually shores up the Social Security system for years. So we should get that done. (Applause.)

column1: Good job; good education for your kids; home of your own; secure retirement.
Fifth
column2: I'm going to keep focusing on health care -- (applause) -- because middle-class families and small business owners deserve the security of knowing that neither an accident or an illness is going to threaten the dreams that youÃ¢ÂÂve worked a lifetime to build.

column1: As we speak
column2: we're well on our way to fully implementing the Affordable Care Act. (Applause.) We're going to implement it. Now
column3: if youÃ¢ÂÂre one of the 85 percent of Americans who already have health insurance either through the job or Medicare or Medicaid
column4: you donÃ¢ÂÂt have to do anything
column5: but you do have new benefits and better protections than you did before. You may not know it
column6: but you do. Free checkups
column7: mammograms
column8: discounted medicines if you're on Medicare -- thatÃ¢ÂÂs what the Affordable Care Act means. You're already getting a better deal. No lifetime limits.

column1: If you donÃ¢ÂÂt have health insurance
column2: then starting on October 1st
column3: private plans will actually compete for your business
column4: and you'll be able to comparison-shop online. There will be a marketplace online
column5: just like youÃ¢ÂÂd buy a flat-screen TV or plane tickets or anything else you're doing online
column6: and you'll be able to buy an insurance package that fits your budget and is right for you.

column1: And if you're one of the up to half of all Americans whoÃ¢ÂÂve been sick or have a preexisting condition -- if you look at this auditorium
column2: about half of you probably have a preexisting condition that insurance companies could use to not give you insurance if you lost your job or lost your insurance -- well
column3: this law means that beginning January 1st
column4: insurance companies will finally have to cover you and charge you the same rates as everybody else
column5: even if you have a preexisting condition. (Applause.) ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what the Affordable Care Act does. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what it does. (Applause.)

column1: Now
column2: look
column3: I know because I've been living it that there are folks out there who are actively working to make this law fail. And I donÃ¢ÂÂt always understand exactly what their logic is here
column4: why they think giving insurance to folks who donÃ¢ÂÂt have it and making folks with insurance a little more secure
column5: why they think thatÃ¢ÂÂs a bad thing. But despite the politically motivated misinformation campaign
column6: the states that have committed themselves to making this law work are finding that competition and choice are actually pushing costs down.

column1: So just last week
column2: New York announced that premiums for consumers who buy their insurance in these online marketplaces will be at least 50 percent lower than what they're "	0

column1: 275	"A new ad from an independent group claims President Barack Obama apologized and showed weakness on Iran.
The ad comes from Secure America Now
column2: which calls itself a ""broad-based grassroots coalition of 2 million national security activists."" A reader in Florida asked us to check it out. It uses clips from an interview Obama gave in the White House during his first days in office with the Arab network Al Arabiya.

column1: A female voiceover says
column2: ""For his first interview as president
column3: Barack Obama chose Arab TV for an apology."" (The words ""an apology"" flash across the screen.)

column1: Then it cuts to Obama telling the interviewer
column2: ""Start by listening
column3: because all too often the United States starts by dictating.""

column1: The voiceover says
column2: ""He reached out.""

column1: Obama: ""It is important for us to be willing to talk to Iran.""
Voiceover: ""Iran answered with terror
column2: attacks on our troops and nuclear weapons development. Ã¢ÂÂ¦Tell President Obama: no apologies
column3: no weakness. ItÃ¢ÂÂs time to stop Iran.""

column1: The claim that Obama has apologized for America has been used and reused countless times -- always falsely -- and we found that this incarnation is only a hair closer to the truth.
His first interview
Obama sat down with Hisham Melhem
column2: Al ArabiyaÃ¢ÂÂs Washington bureau chief
column3: on Jan. 27
column4: 2009. The network
column5: based in Dubai
column6: is regarded as a less-radical format than Al Jazeera and has been criticized for having a pro-Saudi Arabia bias.

column1: News coverage at the time billed the interview as ObamaÃ¢ÂÂs ""first television interview in the White House
column2: according to the New York Times
column3: and ""his first formal television interview as president
column4: per the Washington Post. A spokesman for Secure America Now also pointed us to an MSNBC story characterizing the interview as the new presidentÃ¢ÂÂs first.

column1: The Al Arabiya interview was part of a coordinated unveiling of ObamaÃ¢ÂÂs diplomatic initiatives. He had just named former Maine Sen. George Mitchell as special envoy to the Middle East
column2: and before he sent Mitchell off on a tour of the region
column3: he called Arab and Israeli leaders on his first full day in office.

column1: So itÃ¢ÂÂs fair to say this was ObamaÃ¢ÂÂs first interview as president.
No apology
The interview begins with Melhem asking Obama about Mitchell's appointment and how the administration plans to pursue peacemaking between Israelis and Palestinians.
Obama responds:
Well
column2: I think the most important thing is for the United States to get engaged right away. And George Mitchell is somebody of enormous stature. He is one of the few people who have international experience brokering peace deals.

column1: And so what I told him is start by listening
column2: because all too often the United States starts by dictating -- in the past on some of these issues --and we don't always know all the factors that are involved. So let's listen. He's going to be speaking to all the major parties involved. And he will then report back to me. From there we will formulate a specific response.

column1: Ultimately
column2: we cannot tell either the Israelis or the Palestinians what's best for them. They're going to have to make some decisions. But I do believe that the moment is ripe for both sides to realize that the path that they are on is one that is not going to result in prosperity and security for their people. And that instead
column3: it's time to return to the negotiating table.

column1: And it's going to be difficult
column2: it's going to take time. I don't want to prejudge many of these issues
column3: and I want to make sure that expectations are not raised so that we think that this is going to be resolved in a few months. But if we start the steady progress on these issues
column4: I'm absolutely confident that the United States -- working in tandem with the European Union
column5: with Russia
column6: with all the Arab states in the region -- I'm absolutely certain that we can make significant progress.

column1: The ad uses only his comments
column2: ""Start by listening
column3: because all too often the United States starts by dictating."" But Obama was discussing how to begin brokering a peace deal between Israelis and Palestinians. He was not referring to Iran
column4: as the ad implies.

column1: In addition
column2: we donÃ¢ÂÂt agree that those words equate to an apology. In that statement

column1: Later
column2: speaking about the wider Arab world
column3: Obama said
column4: ""My job to the Muslim world is to communicate that the Americans are not your enemy. We sometimes make mistakes. We have not been perfect. But if you look at the track record

column1: Nowhere in the interview did Obama use the word ""apology
column2: ""apologize"" or ""sorry.""

column1: PolitiFact has examined the apology claim numerous times. Mitt Romney
column2: the likely Republican presidential nominee
column3: wrote in his book and repeated many times that Obama has apologized for America around the world.

column1: But again
column2: there isnÃ¢ÂÂt an ""IÃ¢ÂÂm sorry"" anywhere to be found in ObamaÃ¢ÂÂs speeches or remarks. One expert weÃ¢ÂÂve talked to before says Obama is using conciliatory language for diplomatic purposes

column1: It's much more a sense of establishing of reciprocity
column2: John Murphy
column3: a communications professor at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign
column4: told PolitiFact in 2010. ""Each side says
column5: okay
column6: we haven't done great
column7: but we have a new president and we're going to make a fresh start and move forward. I don't think that's an apology.""

column1: Our ruling
Secure America NowÃ¢ÂÂs ad says

column3: Barack Obama chose Arab TV for an apology."" The ad particularly emphasizes that Obama apologized.

column1: ObamaÃ¢ÂÂs first television interview after taking office was with the Al Arabiya network at the White House. But the ad gets nothing right beyond that.
By saying ""all too often the United States starts by dictating

column3: the ad criticizes ObamaÃ¢ÂÂs approach to Iran

column1: The statement contains an element of truth but ignores critical facts and gives an inaccurate impression. We rate it Mostly False."	0

column1: 285	"Mitt RomneyÃ¢ÂÂs pick of U.S. Rep. Paul Ryan as his running mate has rekindled a heated debate over Medicare.
Ryan
column2: R-Wis.
column3: is the head of the Budget Committee in the U.S. House of Representatives and the architect of a plan to dramatically restructure Medicare.

column1: Today
column2: Medicare operates as a government-run health insurance plan for Americans over age 65.

column1: RyanÃ¢ÂÂs idea is to eventually move Medicare toward private insurance companies by giving people a set amount to buy their own health insurance plans. The new system would be for people who are under age 55 now
column2: and it would give them voucher-like credits to buy traditional fee-for-service Medicare or competing private insurance plans. (The credits are sometimes called ""premium support."")

column1: Though House Republicans voted overwhelmingly for RyanÃ¢ÂÂs plan
column2: polling shows public opinion is mixed
column3: with older voters the most wary of the plan.

column1: The Republican response to attacks on the Ryan plan has been to attack back
column2: saying President Barack Obama has cut ""$700 billion"" out of Medicare. And the Democratic response to that: Well
column3: Paul Ryan cuts that amount
column4: too!

column1: For this check
column2: weÃ¢ÂÂre looking specifically at what Obama campaign spokeswoman Stephanie Cutter said on Face the Nation when debating Romney spokesman Eric Fehrnstrom.

column1: You know
column2: I heard Mitt Romney deride the $700 billion cuts in Medicare that the president achieved through health care reform
column3: Cutter said. ""You know what those cuts are? ItÃ¢ÂÂs taking subsidies away from insurance companies
column4: taking rebates away from prescription drug company. Is that what Mitt Romney wants to protect? And interestingly enough Paul Ryan protected those cuts in his budget.""

column1: ItÃ¢ÂÂs a lot to digest if youÃ¢ÂÂre not already a Medicare policy wonk
column2: so let us sort it out for you. For now
column3: we are going to put aside the question of whether it is accurate to call them ""cuts"" -- a claim we're checking in another item -- and focus on the question of whether Cutter is correct that Ryan relies on those same reductions in his budget.

column1: $700 billion in Medicare cuts?
Because weÃ¢ÂÂre wonks ourselves at PolitiFact
column2: our ears pricked up at the claim in recent days that Obama cut $700 billion out of Medicare. Just a few weeks ago
column3: the oft-cited number was $500 billion. How did he manage to cut another $200 billion when no one was looking?

column1: Well
column2: there are cuts and then there are CUTS. Neither Obama nor his health care law literally ""cut"" a dollar from the Medicare programÃ¢ÂÂs budget.

column1: Rather
column2: the health care law instituted a number of changes to reduce the growth of Medicare costs. At the time the law was passed
column3: those reductions amounted to $500 billion over the next 10 years.

column1: What kind of spending reductions are we talking about? They were mainly aimed at insurance companies and hospitals
column2: not beneficiaries. The law makes significant reductions to Medicare Advantage
column3: a subset of Medicare plans run by private insurers. Medicare Advantage was started under President George W. Bush
column4: and the idea was that competition among the private insurers would reduce costs. But in recent years the plans have actually cost more than traditional Medicare. So the health care law scales back the payments to private insurers.

column1: Hospitals
column2: too
column3: will be paid less if they have too many re-admissions
column4: or if they fail to meet other new benchmarks for patient care.

column1: Still
column2: the overall Medicare budget is projected to go up for the foreseeable future. The health care law tries to limit that growth
column3: making it less than it would have been without the law
column4: but not reducing its overall budget. So claims that Obama would ""cut"" Medicare need more explanation to be fully accurate. In the past
column5: weÃ¢ÂÂve rated similar statements Half True or Mostly False
column6: depending on the wording and context.

column1: Because Medicare spending gets bigger every year
column2: the cost-saving mechanisms in the health care law also get bigger. Also
column3: it takes a few years for the health care lawÃ¢ÂÂs savings mechanisms to kick in. In fact
column4: the effects of time are the main reason the $500 billion number has turned into $700 billion.

column1: The CBO determined in 2011 that the federal health care law would reduce Medicare outlays by $507 billion between 2012 and 2021. In a more recent estimate released this year
column2: the CBO looked at the years 2013 to 2022 and determined the health care law affected Medicare outlays by $716 billion.

column1: So itÃ¢ÂÂs timing thatÃ¢ÂÂs making the ""cuts"" bigger
column2: not changes to Medicare.

column1: Does the Ryan budget Ã¢ÂÂprotect those cutsÃ¢ÂÂ?
Now onto our second question: Does RyanÃ¢ÂÂs budget keep the reductions in Medicare spending? The short answer is yes.
HereÃ¢ÂÂs what Ryan said in an interview with George Stephanopolous of ABC News in June
column2: before his selection as RomneyÃ¢ÂÂs running mate:

column1: Stephanopoulos: ""You know
column2: several independent fact-checkers have taken a look at that claim
column3: the $500 billion in Medicare cuts
column4: and said that it's misleading. And in fact
column5: by that accounting
column6: your budget
column7: your own budget
column8: which Gov. Romney has endorsed
column9: would also have $500 billion in Medicare cuts.

column1: Ryan: ""Well
column2: our budget keeps that money for Medicare to extend its solvency. What Obamacare does is it takes that money from Medicare to spend on Obamacare. ..."" (Read the full exchange.)

column1: So Ryan has confirmed his budget includes the Medicare savings.
The Romney campaign got questions on this point the day after CutterÃ¢ÂÂs remarks
column2: and issued a statement saying that Romney intended to fully repeal the federal law
column3: including the savings for Medicare.

column1: Mitt Romney and Paul Ryan have always been fully committed to repealing Obamacare
column2: ending President ObamaÃ¢ÂÂs $716 billion raid on Medicare
column3: and tackling the serious fiscal challenges our country faces
column4: said Lanhee Chen
column5: RomneyÃ¢ÂÂs policy director
column6: in a statement reported by NBC News. ""A Romney-Ryan administration will restore the funding to Medicare
column7: ensure that no changes are made to the program for those 55 or older
column8: and implement the reforms that they have proposed to strengthen it for future generations.""

column1: Cutter
column2: though
column3: was talking about the Ryan budget. We should point out that the Ryan budget is a congressional resolution that doesnÃ¢ÂÂt have the force of law. And its plan for Medicare hasnÃ¢ÂÂt been turned into legislation that could be analyzed in detail by the Congressional Budget Office.

column1: Still
column2: Ryan himself said his plan did include the reductions in future spending that were part of the federal health care law.

column1: ThatÃ¢ÂÂs because both sides agree on one point: Medicare spending is growing too rapidly
column2: and it needs to reined in.

column1: Our ruling
Cutter said that Romney attacked Obama for cutting $700 billion out of Medicare
column2: but ""Paul Ryan protected those cuts in his budget."" Again
column3: with this item we are not addressing whether they are cuts
column4: but simply whether she is correctly characterizing Ryan's plan.

column1: Cutter is correct that the Ryan budget plan included cost savings that were part of the future health care law. Just recently
column2: the Romney campaign backed away from that play
column3: saying RomneyÃ¢ÂÂs plan would restore the spending that the health law is set to curtail
column4: such as extra funding for private insurers under the Medicare Advantage plan.

column1: Still
column2: Cutter was right about the Ryan plan. We rate her statement True."	0

STATE OF THE UNION
Interview With Speaker of the House Paul Ryan; Interview With Former New York Mayor Rudy Giuliani; Donald Trump Ignored Muslim Ban Question; Interview With Michael Moore. Aired 9-10a ET
Aired November 13
THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.
(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)
JAKE TAPPER
column2: CNN ANCHOR (voice-over): President-elect Trump heads to the White House after an earthquake election few expected.

column1: DONALD TRUMP (R)
column2: PRESIDENT-ELECT: Now it's time for America to bind the wounds of division.

column1: TAPPER: Some say
column2: not so fast
column3: as protesters take to the streets in uproar.

column1: UNIDENTIFIED PROTESTERS: Not my president!
TAPPER: What will Donald Trump's America and his White House look like? Top adviser and potential Cabinet pick Rudy Giuliani will be here.
Plus
column2: Trump made big campaign promises
column3: from Obamacare.

column1: TRUMP: Repealing and replacing Obamacare.
TAPPER: To immigration.
TRUMP: There will be no amnesty.
TAPPER: And
column2: of course:

column1: TRUMP: We will build a great wall.
TAPPER: But he seems to be already backing off some of his signature lines. What will really get done? And can he work with Congress? An exclusive interview with House Speaker Paul Ryan.
Plus
column2: Clinton concedes.

column1: HILLARY CLINTON (D)
column2: FMR. PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: This is not the outcome we wanted or we worked so hard for.

column1: TAPPER: As Democrats lick their wounds.
CLINTON: I'm not going to sugarcoat it. These have been very
column2: very tough days. TAPPER: Should they have seen it coming? Michael Moore did -- what he says liberals must do now.

column1: Plus
column2: the best political minds will be here with insights on this historic election.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
TAPPER: Hello. I'm Jake Tapper in Washington
column2: where the state of our union is in transition.

column1: Donald Trump is now president-elect Trump. And the world is watching with bated breath to see just what he has in store for America. Protests against his election
column2: of course
column3: continue this weekend across the country
column4: most of them peaceful
column5: although the mayor of Portland
column6: Oregon
column7: is asking protesters to stand down in the wake of violence against police in that city.

column1: There are some reports of violence against Trump supporters. In Connecticut
column2: two men were arrested for allegedly beating a man holding a Trump sign. Meanwhile
column3: civil rights groups in school districts across the country report an uptick in incidents of intimidation and harassment of minority groups and girls and women.

column1: Graffiti in North Carolina reads: ""Black lives doesn't matter and neither does your votes.""
Go back to Africa. Make America great again"" was written in a high school bathroom in Minnesota.
Tensions are high and tempers are flaring across the country. The country
column2: of course
column3: may be divided
column4: but the government in Washington
column5: D.C.
column6: is not. Republicans now control the U.S. House
column7: the U.S. Senate
column8: and
column9: soon
column10: the White House.

column1: So what is on the Trump agenda and how quickly can it get done?
(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)
TAPPER: Joining me now from Janesville
column2: Wisconsin
column3: is House Speaker Paul Ryan.

column1: Mr. Speaker
column2: thanks so much for joining us.

column1: Before we begin talking about legislation and moving forward
column2: I'm just wondering
column3: there are millions of Americans out there
column4: as I'm sure you know
column5: who are frankly terrified about what this America under President Trump will mean for them.

column1: Is there anything that you
column2: as speaker of the House
column3: one of the leaders of the nation
column4: want to say to them?

column1: REP. PAUL RYAN (R-WI)
column2: SPEAKER OF THE HOUSE: Sure.

column1: First of all
column2: I hate it that people feel this way. And
column3: second of all
column4: they should not. I think people should be rest assured. America is a pluralistic
column5: inclusive country. It has
column6: it has been
column7: and it will continue to be.

column1: So
column2: I really think that people should put their minds at ease. We're going to get to work on solving the big country's problems
column3: getting this economy growing
column4: fixing our national security
column5: you know
column6: fixing our health care problems
column7: getting our budget put together
column8: the things that we have been talking about.

column1: So
column2: I think people should just really put their minds at ease. We are pluralistic. We're inclusive. That's the kind of country we want. That's the country we are. And that's the country we're still going to have.

column1: TAPPER: But just to accept and acknowledge that there are these incidents taking place all over the country...
RYAN: Well
column2: first
column3: yes
column4: I heard your lead-in there. That's terrible. That's awful.

column1: By the way
column2: that's not Republicans. We are the party of Lincoln. People who espouse those views
column3: they're not Republicans. And we don't want them in our party
column4: even if they're thinking about it. And I'm confident Donald Trump feels the same way.

column1: So
column2: there's no place for that. And protests
column3: as long as protests are peaceful
column4: if people want to express themselves that way
column5: that's what we can do in this country. That's what the First Amendment is all about.

column1: TAPPER: Let's move forward to some of the action items.
Obviously
column2: repealing and replacing Obamacare is one of the big items that president-elect Trump and you want to tackle. President-elect Trump recently said there are elements of Obamacare he wants to keep. This is what he to say to ""60 Minutes."" Take a listen.

column1: (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
QUESTION: Let me does you about Obamacare
column2: which you say you're going to repeal and replace. When you replace it
column3: are you going to make sure that people with preconditions are still covered?

column1: TRUMP: Yes
column2: because it happens to be one of the -- strongest asset.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
TAPPER: Now
column2: your Better Way agenda talks about spending $25 billion on high-risk pools that would help those with preexisting conditions afford insurance. Where would that $25 billion come from?

column1: RYAN: Well
column2: we actually have it paid for in our bill. You really want me to give you a technical answer to this? It gets a little technical.

column1: The point is
column2: we have in our plan pay for doing that. Here's the bigger point
column3: Jake. We agree. It's in our plan. Donald Trump agrees with this. We need to have a solution for people with preexisting conditions.

column1: In our plan is allowing younger people up to the age of 26 to stay on their parents' plan. So
column2: there are aspects that we have all along agreed to.

column1: TAPPER: Under Obamacare
column2: as you know
column3: millions of people were able to get health insurance for the first time through the expansion of Medicaid.

column1: What is going happen to those people? Will they lose coverage under your plan?
RYAN: Well
column2: if you go -- what I encourage people to do is go to Better.GOP. It's number five on our plan. We put the most detail out of anybody that has put out an Obamacare replacement plan.

column1: And it is to have an answer for everyone with preexisting conditions
column2: people who are the uninsured. The point I would say is this
column3: Jake. We can have a health care system in America where everyone
column4: regardless of income or health condition
column5: can get affordable health insurance
column6: get affordable health care.

column1: This is what we propose. We think a patient-centered system is the right way to do that. And you can have the system without a costly government takeover
column2: like Obamacare
column3: that is cranking up premiums
column4: that is making deductibles so high. Doesn't even feel like you have health insurance. Obamacare is failing. It must replaced.

column1: We're going to do that. We're excited about it. And the point I would put people's minds at ease is
column2: we can fix these problems. We can fix what was broken in health care without breaking what was working in health care. And that's exactly what we're proposing.

column1: And if you want to get any level of detail on this
column2: just go to Better.GOP and see what we have already offered.

column1: TAPPER: Well
column2: as you know
column3: the Medicaid expansion is providing government-paid health insurance to individuals. I mean
column4: that's what it does. So
column5: if you repeal Obamacare
column6: does it repeal also the Medicaid expansion
column7: or would that part of it stay?

column1: RYAN: For example
column2: we propose to replace that with refundable tax credits for people to buy affordable health care insurance.

column1: So
column2: the kinds of reforms that we're talking about will lower the cost of insurance itself. And then a person would have
column3: such as our proposal calls for
column4: a refundable tax credit
column5: like a voucher
column6: to go buy health insurance.

column1: That's much cheaper
column2: much more affordable. And
column3: more importantly
column4: you get to buy what you want to buy
column5: not what the government is making you buy.

column1: TAPPER: Obamacare also provides birth control to women at no cost. Is that going to end or will that remain?
RYAN: Look
column2: I'm not going to get into all the nitty-gritty details of these things.

column1: TAPPER: With all do respect
column2: I don't know that the average woman of child-bearing years out there who relies upon contraception provided by health insurance mandated by the Affordable Care Act
column3: I don't know that she would think that that's just a nitty-gritty detail. That's...

column1: RYAN: You're asking me detail...
TAPPER: Well
column2: what do you think? Is it important to you?

column1: RYAN: Jake
column2: you're asking me details about legislation -- you're asking me details about legislation that hasn't been written yet.

column1: (CROSSTALK)
TAPPER: Right. But is it important to you? Would that be a principle? Would that be a principle of whatever replaces it
column2: because...

column1: RYAN: I'm not going to get into -- I'm not going to get into hypotheticals about legislation that hasn't even been drafted yet.

TAPPER: Let me ask you a question about improving security at the border. You and Donald Trump both agree you want to improve security at the border. You obviously have different views when it comes to the 10 to 11 million undocumented immigrants currently living in the United States.
This is what you said to say back in April during a town hall at Georgetown University:
(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
RYAN: I'm a person who believes that
column2: for the undocumented
column3: we have to come up with a solution that doesn't involve mass deportation
column4: that involves giving people the ability to get right with the law to come and earn a legal status while we fix the rest of legal immigration.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
TAPPER: Now take a listen to what president-elect Trump said on ""Morning Joe"" last year.
(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP
column2: ""MORNING JOE"")

column1: TRUMP: We're going to have a deportation force. And you're going to do it humanely
QUESTION: How are you going to pay for this?
TRUMP: It's very inexpensive.
QUESTION: Are they going to be ripped out of their homes? How?
TRUMP: Can I tell you
column2: they're going back where they came. If they came from a certain country
column3: they're going to be brought back to that country. That's the way it's supposed to be.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
TAPPER: So
column2: Congress writes the laws and controls the purse strings

column1: Is there going to be mass deportation or not? And this isn't just a nitty-gritty detail. There are millions of people who are very worried about this.
RYAN: Sure. Sure.
And I think we should put people's minds at ease. That is not what our focus is. That is not what we're focused on. We're focused on securing the border.
We think that's first and foremost. Before we get into any other immigration issue
column2: we have got to know who's coming and going in the country. We have got to secure the border. So
column3: we believe an enforcement bill
column4: a border security enforcement bill
column5: is really the first priority. And that's what we're focused on.

column1: TAPPER: OK
column2: so it's not a top priority
column3: mass deportation. But
column4: obviously
column5: president-elect Trump thinks it is.

column1: RYAN: No
column2: securing the border is our...

column1: TAPPER: Right.
RYAN: Securing the border is our top priority.
TAPPER: Right
column2: but about what in year two
column3: year three
column4: year four?

column1: RYAN: That's why I'm saying we're not focused on -- we are not planning on erecting a deportation force. Donald Trump's not planning on that.
TAPPER: Well
column2: let me ask you
column3: and does the fact that Hillary Clinton won the popular vote
column4: does that impact in any way your sense of mandate or how far you should be willing to go
column5: considering that the woman who lost actually got more votes?

column1: RYAN: I'd say two things.
Look at the expectations going into this. Look at what all the public polling said. Look at what all the prognosticators were saying like the day of the election. He beat all the odds.
Look
column2: what I think people need to stop doing is stop underestimating Donald Trump. A lot of us did that. I think he's very much of the mind-set that there is a need to unify this country
column3: to heal the division in this country
column4: but also there's a mandate and a desire and a commitment to fix the problems as we have laid the solutions out.

column1: So
column2: we all laid out very concrete solutions for why we need to get this country back on track. We're now going to implement the solutions. And we think this is good. We think this is going to help people get out of poverty. We think this is going to grow the economy
column3: make our country more secure
column4: make our border secure
column5: help the military go on offense against ISIS
column6: clean up the red tape that is strangling small businesses
column7: so they can hire people again.

column1: These are good things that we have in store that we're really excited about getting to work on doing for the American people.

TAPPER: One of the things that you don't mention -- and I can certainly understand why -- when you talk about the path forward with president-elect Trump is one of the biggest differences between yourself and Donald Trump policy-wise
column2: having to do with the issue of trade.

column1: In his contract with the American voter
column2: he promised in his 100 days to establish tariffs to discourage companies from laying off workers. Will you pass those tariffs in your first 100 days?

column1: RYAN: Well
column2: I think there's a better way of dealing with that particular issue.

column1: And if you go to number six on our Better Way agenda and you look at the tax reform
column2: this is something that Donald also talked about during the campaign
column3: which is to fix our taxes on border adjustments
column4: which we believe is a smarter way
column5: which is what all the other countries
column6: which is not tariffs
column7: not trade wars.

column1: So
column2: we think there are better ways of dealing with making American products and workers more competitive
column3: and really it's fixing our tax code.

column1: TAPPER: Throughout the campaign
column2: as you know
column3: president-elect Trump talked about tariffs. It could be as high as 35 percent
column4: 45 percent.

column1: RYAN: Yes.
TAPPER: If he comes to you and says
column2: this is what we're doing
column3: what are you going say?

column1: RYAN: The point I'm trying to make is
column2: I think we can achieve what he's trying -- he's trying to make America more competitive. He's trying to make the American worker more competitive. He's trying to make it so that American businesses stay in America.

column1: And we believe the smartest and best way to do that is comprehensive tax reform
column2: which actually makes America much more competitive without any adverse effects
column3: without any collateral damage to the economy.

column1: TAPPER: A minute ago
column2: you were talking about how Donald Trump
column3: the president-elect
column4: expressed concerned to you he wanted to -- or expressed a desire to you that he wanted to unify the country. On that note
column5: I want to turn to staffing at the Trump White House. A

column1: lot of people
column2: including many conservatives
column3: are concerned that Steve Bannon
column4: who is the CEO of the Trump campaign and the chief executive of Breitbart News
column5: that he used Breitbart News to
column6: in their view
column7: the view of conservatives
column8: the view of Republicans
column9: to mainstream white supremacist views
column10: anti-Semitic views
column11: racist views.

column1: Do you have any concerns about Steve Bannon being in the White House?
RYAN: No
column2: I don't have concerns. I have never met the guy. I don't know Steve Bannon
column3: so I have no concerns.

column1: I believe -- I trust Donald's judgment. I think he's going to pick who he thinks will best serve him. And I'm sure we will work well with whoever his chief of staff is
column2: whoever his staff is.

column1: So
column2: I believe that Donald is going to have a great set of choices to make for staffing. I'm also very own encouraged by the fact that my friend
column3: a great conservative from -- a man whose shown he's a true leader
column4: Mike Pence
column5: is going to be running the transition team.

column1: So
column2: I think between Pence running the transition team -- look
column3: Donald is a multibillionaire who has had lots of companies
column4: who has run extremely successful businesses. So
column5: he's done things like this before. He's staffed up. He's run major organizations. He's a successful person. He surrounds himself with successful people.

column1: So
column2: I'm confident he's going to do the same here.

column1: TAPPER: You sound very optimistic and positive about him
column2: but during the campaign
column3: you said that one of the things he said about Judge Curiel fit the textbook definition of racism.

column1: RYAN: Look
column2: I'm not going to relitigate the past. I'm looking for the future.

column1: And I want I mean when I say unifying
column2: getting people back to work
column3: fixing welfare so people -- fixing welfare so people can go from welfare to work
column4: replacing this horrible health care law that is really hurting families
column5: putting health care providers out of business
column6: and replacing it with patient-centered health care
column7: rebuilding our national security so we're safe again
column8: cleaning up the regulatory state
column9: following the Constitution.

column1: I mean
column2: these are all good things for our country that we are now working on putting in place the plan to do just that. That's transformational. That's positive. That's good.

column1: TAPPER: The pride of Janesville
column2: House Speaker Paul Ryan
column3: thank you so much for joining us. We appreciate it.

column1: RYAN: All right
column2: thank you Jake. Take care.

column1: (END VIDEOTAPE) TAPPER: The Trump transition team has been huddled inside Trump Tower all weekend as they work to create an administration
column2: Cabinet nominees
column3: White House staff.

column1: Kellyanne Conway telling reports yesterday that Trump's choice for chief of staff is imminent. That and other picks could tell us a lot about how president-elect Trump plans to govern.
Let's talk about the new Trump administration with top adviser Rudy Giuliani
column2: who is himself rumored to be a contender for several top jobs.

column1: Mr. Mayor
column2: thanks for joining us. And congratulations.

column1: RUDY GIULIANI (R)
column2: FORMER MAYOR OF NEW YORK: Thank you
column3: Jake.

column1: TAPPER: So
column2: I know you're not going to answer...

column1: GIULIANI: Thank you very
column2: very much
column3: Jake.

column1: TAPPER: I know you're not going to answer any questions I have about what jobs you're being considered for.
(LAUGHTER)
TAPPER: So
column2: let me just set that aside.

column1: There's a big issue...
GIULIANI: Thank you.
(LAUGHTER)
TAPPER: There's a big issue at play here as you prepare for the Trump administration.
I know you're more than cognizant of the fact that Donald Trump has hundreds of millions
column2: if not billions of dollars in businesses and business interests around the nation and throughout the world. During the campaign
column3: he was asked what he would do with his businesses if he won.

column1: Take a listen.
(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
TRUMP: If I become president
column2: I couldn't care less about my company. It's peanuts. I have Ivanka and Eric and Don sitting there.

column1: Run the company
column2: kids. Have a good time. I'm going to do it for America
column3: OK?

column1: (CHEERING AND APPLAUSE)
TRUMP: So
column2: I would be willing to...

column1: QUESTION: So
column2: you will put your assets in a blind trust?

column1: TRUMP: I would put it in a blind trust.
Well
column2: I don't know if it's a blind trust if Ivanka
column3: Don
column4: and Eric run it
column5: but -- is that a blind trust? I don't know.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
TAPPER: I will answer that question. That's not a blind trust. If your kids run your businesses
column2: it's not a blind trust.

column1: In a blind trust
column2: there is an independent trustee who takes over your portfolio and directs it without your input or any input from anyone around you.

column1: Do you think that to avoid any conflicts of interest
column2: not to many questions by the public as to whether he's making decisions at least in part for his own financial reasons
column3: do you think it would be best for Mr. Trump to set up a true blind trust with no involvement from him or his kids?

column1: GIULIANI: Well
column2: first of all
column3: you realize that those laws don't apply to the president
column4: right? So
column5: the president doesn't have to have a blind trust. For some reason
column6: when the law was written
column7: the president was exempt.

column1: I think he's in a very unusual situation. He would basically put his children out of work if -- and they'd have to go start a whole new business
column2: and that would set up the whole -- set up new problems.

column1: So
column2: it would seem to me that if he set up a situation in which the children were running it
column3: there was a legal or clear document that meant that he would not be involved
column4: he would have no interest in it
column5: he would have no input into it
column6: he would just have a passive interest
column7: that would be the kind of thing that would work here.

column1: It's kind of unrealistic to say
column2: you're going to take the business away from the three people who are running it
column3: and give it to some independent person. And
column4: remember
column5: they can't work in the government because of the government rule against nepotism.

column1: So
column2: you would be putting them out of work. So
column3: I think you're going to have to fashion something that is very comfortable
column4: something that's fair
column5: something that assures the American people
column6: as he said
column7: he has no interest in what's going on in the business
column8: and that his children get to run the business they know how to run.

column1: TAPPER: Right.
GIULIANI: And stay out of all government matters.
TAPPER: Well
column2: but
column3: Mr. Mayor
column4: I mean
column5: his children are -- as I don't need to tell you
column6: they are a huge part of his advisory committee. They are advising the transition
column7: Ivanka
column8: Don Jr.
column9: and Eric.

column1: Jared Kushner
column2: Ivanka's husband
column3: is being talked about as coming on board and working at the White House
column4: even if he's not paid for it.

column1: If he does not set up a truly blind trust
column2: how can the American people have confidence that
column3: when he makes a decision
column4: that he isn't at least partly making it to enrich himself?

column1: GIULIANI: Well
column2: even if he turned it over to an independent trustee and it was the Trump Corporation
column3: you can't -- I mean
column4: there's no perfect way to do this.

column1: You have to have some confidence in the integrity of the president. The man is an enormously wealthy man. I don't think there's any real fear of suspicion that he's seeking to enrich himself by being president. If he wanted to enrich himself
column2: he wouldn't have run for president.

column1: So
column2: I think there can be a way to do this. And
column3: by the way
column4: Jared Kushner has his own company
column5: completely independent of Trump
column6: that is a very
column7: very successful real estate company. He's maybe
column8: you know
column9: one of the biggest in New York. He -- so
column10: Jared is a kind of different
column11: different situation.

column1: TAPPER: Well
column2: I will just say this. And then you can dismiss it as you want. But I'm putting a flag in it right now.

column1: If a blind trust is not set up
column2: this is going to be Donald Trump for the duration of his presidency
column3: because every decision he makes
column4: whether it's the pipeline in North Dakota
column5: or business relationships in Turkey
column6: everything is going to be under the lens of
column7: well
column8: what is the effect of this on his wealth and his family's wealth?

column1: I get that you think that that's not a consideration or not as serious a consideration as...
GIULIANI: No
column2: no
column3: no.

column1: What I'm telling you is
column2: the blind trust solution isn't much better
column3: meaning an independent trustee would run it. And any decision that he made
column4: even if he didn't know it
column5: that helped him
column6: somebody would run it down and say
column7: oh
column8: my goodness
column9: he may have made it for that reason.

column1: So
column2: blind trusts aren't perfect either. This is a very special kind of situation.

column1: TAPPER: I think it's far better than -- it's far better than people in his family advising him and then also working on his business. I think...
GIULIANI: But they're not -- once he gets into government
column2: they will not be -- they will not be -- they will not be advising him.

column1: There will be -- there will have to be a wall -- there will have to be a wall between them with regard to government matters and something I'm very familiar with from my days in the Justice Department
column2: which is recusing yourself from decisions that involve you or any financial matter involving you.

column1: TAPPER: All right.
Well
column2: if you thought the issues between the Clinton Foundation and Hillary Clinton's State Department were big
