column1: Mr. Trump shook up the Republican primary by...
GIULIANI: Oh
column2: I think
column3: I think
column4: Jake
column5: Jake
column6: Jake
column7: I think that's a very unfair suggestion.

column1: There
column2: you were talking about enormous amounts of cash. I'm counting up to about $230 million that went for specific actions like talking to the IRS. And I don't -- I don't see that happening in a Trump administration.

column1: This man didn't run for president because he wants to get rich. He's rich already.
TAPPER: All right.
GIULIANI: So
column2: I don't think you're going to have that happen unless you try to make it happen.

column1: TAPPER: All right.
Mr. Trump shook up the Republican primary back in December when he made this promise. Take a listen.
(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
TRUMP: Donald J. Trump is calling all and complete shutdown of Muslims entering the United States until our country's representatives can figure out what the hell is doing on.
(CHEERING AND APPLAUSE)
(END VIDEO CLIP)
TAPPER: So
column2: just a simple question. Is that policy still operative?

column1: GIULIANI: Well
column2: you know
column3: twice
column4: you used things that he changed during the campaign. He did say that. That is correct.

column1: Actually
column2: within a day or two of his saying that
column3: he called me and asked me to put a little group together that included Congressman McCaul
column4: General Flynn -- I can't remember who else
column5: a few other people. We wrote a paper for him. And he amended it to the ban would be restricted to particular countries
column6: and it would not be a ban.

column1: It would involve extreme vetting. The one -- the one place in which he would not let anyone in
column2: unless it was an extraordinary circumstance
column3: would be Syrian refugees. All the rest from countries that contain dangerous populations of radical Islamic extremists
column4: he will subject them to extreme vetting
column5: but not a ban. So
column6: he said that about 100 times during the campaign from the time

column1: that he made that -- from the time that he made that statement.
TAPPER: Yes
column2: he said that was an expansion.

column1: GIULIANI: So
column2: you can go back.

column1: TAPPER: He said it was an expansion of his original proposal.
But let's talk about what you're talking about
column2: specifically
column3: Mr. Trump wanting to suspend immigration from terror-prone regions where vetting cannot safely occur and also extreme vetting.

column1: Back in June
column2: when Senator Jeff Sessions
column3: a strong supporter and adviser of president-elect Trump
column4: when Senator Sessions was on the program
column5: he identified six countries that might fall into that category
column6: Pakistan
column7: Egypt
column8: Syria
column9: Iraq
column10: Afghanistan
column11: and Yemen.

column1: So
column2: now that Mr. Trump has been elected president
column3: can you tell us if those are the six countries that will see a suspension of immigration?

column1: GIULIANI: Well
column2: I would say that those countries are certainly countries where we would have to be very careful.

column1: Now
column2: let's take Egypt
column3: for example. Egypt
column4: we could probably do some pretty good vetting. The Sisi government is a strong ally. It has a pretty good hold on the Muslim Brotherhood. I'm not saying perfect
column5: but they have done a lot of work in reducing the power of the Muslim Brotherhood. They have a very
column6: very mature and really strong army. You could do vetting in Egypt.

column1: Yemen
column2: a lot more volatile
column3: a lot more difficult to do vetting. So
column4: I think this is going to be a country-by-country decision. Pakistan
column5: you can do pretty good vetting. So
column6: a lot of this is going to depend on
column7: you know
column8: how cooperative is the country we're talking about? How many records can we get?

column1: The reason the Syrian problem was so bad
column2: the Syrian refugees
column3: it's not just that you can't vet them
column4: which actually Director Comey and I think about five members of the Obama administration have made clear
column5: that you can't vet these people
column6: these refugees from Syria.

column1: The problem also is that Baghdadi has said he is going to put terrorist operatives in with the refugee population. He's told us he's going to do this.
TAPPER: Right.
GIULIANI: So
column2: we would be foolish -- we would be foolish to allow these people to come into the United States.

column1: We're sort of being warned that he's bringing more people into attack us. We already have 1
column2: 000 investigations of radical Islamic terrorists in the United States. We can't add another whole group to that.

column1: TAPPER: I want to ask you. Russia's deputy foreign minister
column2: Sergei Ryabkov
column3: was quoted as saying that the Russian government maintained contacts with members of Trump's -- quote -- ""immediate entourage"" during the presidential campaign.

column1: What can you tell us about those contacts?
GIULIANI: I know of no such contacts with the Russian government.
I was pretty deeply involved in the campaign. I was with Donald Trump
column2: you know
column3: day and night for about 100 days actually at one period. So
column4: if that's going on
column5: it's going on somewhere where I didn't see it.

column1: It is true that I think Donald Trump wants to engage Russia in areas where we can work together in a way that Hillary Clinton and John Kerry and Barack Obama failed to do. But
column2: remember
column3: he's going to do it from a different point of view.

column1: You're forgetting his campaign promise of increasing dramatically the size of the military and doing away with the sequester. We're going to go up to 550
column2: 000 troops
column3: where we're going down to 420

column1: TAPPER: Well
column2: let me ask you a quick question about troops.

column1: GIULIANI: We're going to go up to 350 ships.
TAPPER: Putin...
GIULIANI: We're going to go up to 350 troops (sic). Let me finish.
TAPPER: Yes.
GIULIANI: We're going to go up to 1
column2: 200 modern aircraft. And we're going to increase the size of the Marines from about 27 battalions to 36.

column1: So
column2: he's going to be facing
column3: Putin
column4: with a country that is not diminishing its military
column5: but a country that is dramatically increasing it to Reagan-like levels
column6: so that he can negotiate -- and he talked about this a lot during the campaign -- he's going to negotiate for peace
column7: but with strength
column8: not with a diminishing army.

column1: TAPPER: A spokesman for Putin said that one of the first things that Trump can do as president is to convince NATO to pull back troops from near the Russian border.
Do you have any idea if any decision has been made along those lines?
GIULIANI: No. No decision like that has been made
column2: thought about.

column1: In fact
column2: during the campaign
column3: Donald Trump talked about forward positioning of some troops in NATO as kind of a bargaining chip with some of the NATO countries that are not putting in their fair share
column4: their 2 percent. TAPPER: OK.

column1: GIULIANI: And I think you're going see something more like that.
I think a President Trump would want to increase the impact of NATO
column2: but make sure that these countries are participating. You know
column3: when we were fighting in Iraq and we had some of these countries participating
column4: their armies weren't fighting. They were watching us
column5: the U.K.
column6: and Canada fight
column7: and they were just observing.

column1: Well
column2: it can't work that way.

column1: TAPPER: All right.
GIULIANI: They have got to be full participants. And we have to be full participants.
TAPPER: Mr. Mayor
column2: thank you so much. And congratulations again.

column1: GIULIANI: Thank you.

column1: 288	"As Americans Save Money
column2: their Government Spends with Reckless Abandon

column1: Posted by Kevin Boland on January 5th
Last month
column2: the New York Times wrote a story about the rise in the personal savings rate - an encouraging sign that American families are living within their means. The Times reported that Ã¢ÂÂ[t]his was the year of the return to financial sobriety.Ã¢ÂÂ Unfortunately
column3: the same canÃ¢ÂÂt be said for out-of-touch Washington Democrats.

column1: Michael Mandel
column2: the chief economist at Business Week
column3: noted that Ã¢ÂÂMost other journalists and economists have take [sic] the same position-that Americans have reacted to the recession by saving more. But for the U.S. economy as a whole
column4: the savings rate has not gone up-itÃ¢ÂÂs actually fallen.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: How can that be? The answer is simple: government spending has exploded over the past year
column2: which explains the discrepancies in the following chart:

column1: Mandel explained:
What we see here is that the net national savings-the sum of personal
column2: corporate
column3: and government savings
column4: net of depreciation-has been plunging rather than rising. The net national savings rate fell to -2.5% in the third quarter of 2009
column5: its lowest level since the Great Depression. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs astounding lowÃ¢ÂÂ¦ the government is running such big deficits that they swamp the savings gains in the private sectors . HereÃ¢ÂÂs another way of putting it: The government is borrowing a lot of money and transferring it to the private sector
column6: through fiscal and monetary stimulus. The private sector is using some of those transfers to boost savings. But on net
column7: the countryÃ¢ÂÂs savings rate as a whole is falling.

column1: In other words
column2: the federal government is overwhelming the private sector with deficit spending.

column1: The House Budget Committee Republican Staff complied a lengthy list of all the DemocratsÃ¢ÂÂ spending in last year:
Democrats need to abandon their job-killing agenda thatÃ¢ÂÂs burdening families and small businesses with tax hikes and burying our kids and grandkids under a mountain of debt. All year long
column2: House Republicans have been offering better solutions on the budget
column3: energy
column4: and health care - solutions that recognize that we need to empower the American people
column5: not bureaucrats in Washington
column6: D.C. Until Democrats understand that fundamental truth
column7: weÃ¢ÂÂll never get our fiscal house in order.

column1: | No Comments ÃÂ»"	0
289	"Marco Rubio portrayed fellow GOP senator and presidential hopeful Ted Cruz as all talk and no action on defense in an interview on Meet the Press.
He talks tough on some of these issues
column2: Rubio said Dec. 13. ""For example
column3: he was going to Ã¢ÂÂcarpet bombÃ¢ÂÂ ISIS. But the only budget he's ever voted for in his time in the Senate is a budget that cut defense spending by more than Barack Obama proposes we cut it.""

column1: Rubio has tried to portray himself as a strong supporter of the military
column2: while Cruz has tried to appeal to hawks as well as libertarians
column3: who typically favor less defense spending.

column1: We decided to fact-check RubioÃ¢ÂÂs claim that Cruz voted for a budget that cut defense spending by more than the Democratic president.
CruzÃ¢ÂÂs vote on Rand PaulÃ¢ÂÂs budget proposal
RubioÃ¢ÂÂs campaign pointed to CruzÃ¢ÂÂs 2013 vote in favor of a budget proposal by U.S. Sen. Rand Paul
column2: R-Ky.
column3: who is also running for president. Cruz was one of just 18 senators
column4: all Republican
column5: to vote in favor of PaulÃ¢ÂÂs amendment. Rubio voted against it. The measure failed.

column1: PaulÃ¢ÂÂs 2013 proposal emerged after the widespread budget cuts
column2: known as the sequester
column3: went into effect. The sequester dramatically reduced non-war defense spending during the next decade.

column1: RubioÃ¢ÂÂs campaign pointed to PaulÃ¢ÂÂs statement in his budget proposal about cutting military spending:
This budget proposal does not simply reduce military spending
column2: but provides directives to realign the military for the 21st century
column3: Paul wrote. ""It seeks to reduce the size and scope of the military complex
column4: including its global footprint to one that is more in line with a policy of containment.""

column1: Under PaulÃ¢ÂÂs proposal
column2: defense appropriations would have gone from $521 billion in 2014 to $634 billion in 2023. The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office
column3: meanwhile
column4: projected $588 billion in defense appropriations in 2014 to $731 billion in 2023. That means that Paul actually increased year-over-year defense spending
column5: though it did not keep pace with estimated projections to sustain current defense levels.

column1: Was PaulÃ¢ÂÂs proposal a Ã¢ÂÂcutÃ¢ÂÂ for defense?
So why did Rubio refer to PaulÃ¢ÂÂs budget as a ""cut"" if defense spending would rise?
We take the budget document at its word that it cuts defense spending and seeks to reduce the size and scope of the military
column2: Rubio senior adviser Joe Pounder said.

column1: But experts questioned whether Rubio can call PaulÃ¢ÂÂs proposal a ""cut.""
PaulÃ¢ÂÂs defense budget was above the budget caps set in the Budget Control Act
column2: so in that respect it was an increase (and the presidentÃ¢ÂÂs budget was an even larger increase)
column3: said Todd Harrison
column4: a defense budget expert at the Center for Strategic and International Studies. ""But PaulÃ¢ÂÂs defense budget was less than what other Republicans were proposing and what the president was proposing
column5: so in that sense it was a cut.""

column1: PaulÃ¢ÂÂs 2013 proposal for defense was well below ObamaÃ¢ÂÂs request both at the time and now
column2: Harrison said.

column1: Christopher Preble
column2: at the libertarian Cato Institute
column3: said he would not call PaulÃ¢ÂÂs budget a ""cut.""

column1: As is typical in Washington-speak
column2: a less-than-expected increase is often cast as a cut
column3: he said. ""This is misleading.""

column1: Cruz spokesman Brian Phillips made a similar argument.

So it sounds like Rubio is engaging in the time-honored Washington cartel tactic of budget gimmickry and is suggesting that a reduction in the rate of increase is equal to a Ã¢ÂÂcutÃ¢ÂÂ when in fact the Obama and Paul budgets spend more on defense every year
column2: Phillips said. ""The fact is
column3: in supporting the Paul budget
column4: Cruz did not support a cut in defense spending
column5: but a more responsible rate of increase.""

column1: Benjamin Friedman
column2: a defense expert at Cato
column3: pointed to CruzÃ¢ÂÂs vote in March in favor of a Rubio amendment to boost defense spending over two years rather than PaulÃ¢ÂÂs amendment which would have boosted it with offsets.

column1: This was a budget
column2: so it doesnÃ¢ÂÂt make Rubio wrong
column3: but it undermines his larger point
column4: Friedman said.

column1: Our ruling
Rubio said that the only budget Cruz ""ever voted for in his time in the Senate is a budget that cut defense spending by more than Barack Obama proposes we cut it.""

Rubio was referring to CruzÃ¢ÂÂs vote in favor of PaulÃ¢ÂÂs budget proposal in 2013. But Rubio mischaracterized PaulÃ¢ÂÂs plan when he called it a ""cut."" That proposal included an increase in defense spending each year from 2014 going forward a decade
column2: although it did not keep pace with estimated projections in growth.

column1: However
column2: there is a kernel of truth here in that PaulÃ¢ÂÂs proposal for defense was below ObamaÃ¢ÂÂs request.

column1: We rate this statement Mostly False."	0
290	"The recent Massachusetts Senate election captivated Americans far beyond the Bay State. In that contest
column2: Republican Scott Brown picked up a seat formerly held by the late Democratic giant Edward Kennedy. Brown's upset victory was aided by a wave of frustration over how Congress and President Barack Obama have been handling health care reform legislation.

column1: During the campaign
column2: Brown said that if he was elected
column3: he would become the 41st Republican senator
column4: enabling the GOP to block the Democratic majority from reaching the 60-vote threshold required to pass key legislation
column5: including a health care bill. The Senate has already passed a version of health care
column6: but it needs to be reconciled with a different bill passed by the House and then signed by the president before it becomes law.

column1: As it happened
column2: Massachusetts passed its own health care reform plan in 2006
column3: with the help of both Republican Gov. Mitt Romney and a heavily Democratic legislature. Brown
column4: then serving in the state Senate
column5: voted for the plan.

column1: On the Jan. 31
column3: edition of ABC's This Week
column4: host Barbara Walters asked Brown about his vote on the Massachusetts plan. ""Why isn't what's good for Massachusetts good for the whole country?"" she asked.

column1: Brown responded
column2: ""In Massachusetts
column3: the free market
column4: the free enterprise has taken control
column5: and they're offering a wide range of plans. I've never ever said that people should not get health insurance. It's just a question of if we're going to take a one-size-fits-all government plan or we're going to do something where the individual states can tailor their plans as we've done.""

column1: When Walters asked him
column2: ""Do you think the whole plan should be scrapped?"" Brown said

column1: The whole plan?"" Walters continued.
Yes
column2: Brown said.

column1: Later
column2: during the show's round-table segment
column3: liberal New York Times columnist Paul Krugman expressed disbelief at Brown's response.

column1: That was the most evasive answer
column2: Krugman said. ""If you think this is a straightforward guy
column3: that was an incredibly evasive answer on health care
column4: because the Senate bill
column5: which has now stalled
column6: is identical to the Massachusetts health care plan -- the same thing. Only in the finest of fine print is there any difference. He voted for the Massachusetts plan. A majority of voters in Massachusetts who voted for him approve of the Massachusetts health care plan. Nonetheless
column7: their plan is dead.""

column1: We wanted to see whether the Massachusetts plan was indeed ""the same thing"" as the bill passed by the U.S. Senate. So we looked at the details of both plans and consulted with an ideologically diverse group of health policy experts.
The consensus among our experts was that Krugman is basically right on the overall structure
column2: although some of the details differ. As Elizabeth A. McGlynn
column3: associate director of RAND Health
column4: put it
column5: ""Same recipe
column6: different amounts on the ingredients.""

column1: Here are elements of the two plans that are broadly the same
column2: along with some of the differences in details:

column1: Ã¢ÂÂ¢ Individual mandate to buy health insurance. Everyone in Massachusetts must purchase health insurance or else pay a penalty; the same goes for the Senate plan
column2: though the penalty structures vary between the two.

column1: Ã¢ÂÂ¢ Employer responsibilities for offering health insurance. Companies with more than 10 employees in Massachusetts need to offer health insurance or else pay a penalty. The Senate bill sets the bar for companies at 50 employees
column2: though technically the bill falls short of a mandate.

column1: Ã¢ÂÂ¢ Health insurance exchanges. Both the Massachusetts and U.S. Senate plans involve the use of voluntary ""exchanges"" that individuals and small businesses can use to purchase private-sector health insurance. These exchanges are designed to offer a range of plans with different benefits and premium levels.
Ã¢ÂÂ¢ Affordability subsidies. Under both plans
column2: lower-income individuals and families can receive government subsidies to help them pay their health insurance premiums. In the Massachusetts plan
column3: subsidies are allotted on a sliding scale up to 300 percent of the federal poverty level. Under the U.S. Senate plan
column4: the sliding-scale subsidies go up to 400 percent of the federal poverty level.

column1: Ã¢ÂÂ¢ Expansion of Medicaid. The Massachusetts plan expands Medicaid to all children up to 300 percent of the federal poverty level. The U.S. Senate plan also expands Medicaid
column2: but in a different fashion
column3: offering it to all individuals (not just children) up to 133 percent of the federal poverty level.

column1: Ã¢ÂÂ¢ Insurance market regulation. Both plans restructure the insurance market
column2: in similar but slightly different ways. In Massachusetts
column3: the reform bill merged the individual and small-group markets (that is
column4: it merged the market serving individuals not covered by their employer's plan with the market serving smaller employers). The U.S. Senate bill placed new regulations on those two markets but kept them separate. In Massachusetts
column5: dependents up to age 25 can be covered on their parents' plan
column6: while the U.S. Senate bill allows such dependent coverage up to age 26. And young adults in Massachusetts from age 19 to 26 can purchase a special lower-cost
column7: lower-benefit plan through the exchange; the U.S. Senate bill creates a category of lower-cost
column8: lower-benefit plan in the exchange for those up to age 30 who cannot find affordable coverage.

column1: Ã¢ÂÂ¢ Limits on the ratio between the highest and lowest premiums. In Massachusetts
column2: the highest premiums can generally only be twice as high as the lowest premiums. The only factors that can be used to vary premiums are age
column3: tobacco use
column4: geographic area
column5: the nature of the employee's industry
column6: an unusually low participation rate (for group plans) and participation in a wellness plan. The U.S. Senate bill allows premiums in the individual and small-group market and on the exchange to vary based only on age (limited to a 3-to-1 ratio)
column7: geographic area
column8: family composition and tobacco use (limited to 1.5 -to-1 ratio). Wellness programs do not factor into ratings variations under the Senate bill
column9: but the bill does provide other incentives for such plans.

column1: The bills differ more noticeably in several other areas.

Ã¢ÂÂ¢ Cost containment. Critics of the Massachusetts plan have taken it to task for its lack of cost-containment provisions. The U.S. Senate bill makes changes to Medicare that are intended to lower program costs
column2: such as restructuring how payments are made to Medicare Advantage plans -- the HMO option under Medicare. Since Medicare is a federal program
column3: the Massachusetts plan does not address this issue. The U.S. Senate bill also authorizes the Food and Drug Administration to approve generic versions of certain drugs. This
column4: too
column5: is a federal rather than a state responsibility.

column1: Ã¢ÂÂ¢ Financing. Both the Massachusetts plan and the Senate bill are financed in part by revenue generated from the individual and employer mandates. But the Massachusetts plan's financing is heavily dependent on leveraging federal matching funds
column2: while the Senate bill
column3: in addition to cost savings from Medicare
column4: imposes taxes on drugmakers
column5: device manufacturers
column6: health insurers and indoor tanning services. It also taxes high-cost (""Cadillac"") health care plans. The Massachusetts plan does not do any of these things.

column1: The Senate probably has more cost containment
column2: said John Holahan
column3: a health expert at the Urban Institute who has studied the Massachusetts plan extensively. ""And the financing is different. But the structure is the same.""

column1: So it seems that there's broad agreement that
column2: despite some operational differences
column3: the broad structure of the Massachusetts health care plan is quite similar to that in the U.S. Senate bill -- certainly more similar than either one is to
column4: say
column5: a single-payer health care plan or even to the current system. Krugman's comparison of the two plans is Mostly True."	0

column1: 292	"More information about the United Kingdom is available on the United Kingdom Page and from other Department of State publications and other sources listed at the end of this fact sheet.
U.S.-UNITED KINGDOM RELATIONS
The United States has no closer Ally than the United Kingdom. Following the end of the American Revolution in 1783
column2: the United Kingdom officially recognized American independence
column3: and in 1785 our two countries established diplomatic relations. Other than a brief break in relations during the War of 1812
column4: the United States and the United Kingdom have remained durable partners and Allies. Our partnership is a foundation of our mutual prosperity and security.

column6: stop the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction

column9: cyberattacks

column16: and United States (AUKUS) security partnership agreement

column11: close to 17

column1: U.S. Assistance to the United Kingdom
The International Fund for Ireland (IFI)
column2: established by the British and Irish governments in 1986
column3: provides funding for projects to sustain the peace process and to generate cross-community engagement and economic opportunity in Northern Ireland (the United Kingdom) and the border counties of Ireland. The U.S. government has contributed more than $549 million to the IFI since its establishment.

column1: Bilateral Economic Relations
Mutual trade and investment are at the heart of our prosperity
column2: and our commitment to free market values enables our economies to thrive. Following the United KingdomÃ¢ÂÂs 2020 departure from the European Union
column3: the United States continues to be a strong partner to the United Kingdom and looks forward to advancing mutual international trade priorities rooted in our shared values
column4: while promoting innovation and inclusive economic growth for workers and businesses on both sides of the Atlantic.

column1: The United States and the United Kingdom are the worldÃ¢ÂÂs first and fifth largest economies in the world by GDP. We traded over $273 billion worth of goods and services in 2019. Two-way direct investment totals over $1.3 trillion.
Every U.S. state has jobs that are connected to an investment by a UK company. Nearly 1.3 million Americans work for UK companies in the United States
column2: and over 1.5 million Britons are directly employed by U.S. firms. The top U.S. exports to the United Kingdom include precious metal and stone
column3: aircraft
column4: machinery
column5: financial and travel services
column6: and agricultural products
column7: such as wine and beer.

column1: Leading on Climate

The United States and the United Kingdom are leaders in the global fight against climate change and are committed to taking decisive action to reach our shared goal of achieving net-zero emissions no later than 2050 and keeping the goal of limiting warming to 1.5 degree Celsius within reach.
The United States is committed to reducing emissions by 50-52 percent in 2030 compared to 2005 levels
column2: while the UKÃ¢ÂÂs new 2035 target to slash emissions by 78 percent has also set a high bar for other major economies. The UK hosted the 26th UN Climate Change Conference of the Parties (COP26) in Glasgow
column3: Scotland in 2021
column4: and we will continue to work closely with the UK to secure international commitments that raise ambition on climate action and protect the world from climate change.

column1: The United KingdomÃ¢ÂÂs Membership in International Organizations
Along with France
column2: both the United States and the United Kingdom are among the five permanent members of the UN Security Council (P5) and are founding members of NATO. In addition
column3: the United Kingdom and the United States belong to the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE)
column6: Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD)
column7: International Monetary Fund (IMF)
column8: World Bank
column9: and World Trade Organization. As our Ally
column10: and a top contributor at NATO
column11: the UK strengthens the AllianceÃ¢ÂÂs ability to deter modern security and defense threats. The UK leads on key NATO efforts
column12: such as cyber and emerging and disruptive technologies
column13: and is a Framework Nation for the Enhanced Forward Presence in Estonia. The United Kingdom also is an observer to the Organization of American States and a Dialogue Partner of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations.

column1: Bilateral Representation
Principal embassy officials are listed in the DepartmentÃ¢ÂÂs Key Officers List.
The United Kingdom maintains an embassy in the United States at 3100 Massachusetts Ave. NW
column2: Washington

column1: BIDEN: Yeah.
TAPPER: But -- but he said that enough seats are in the play in the House for the Democrats to possibly lose the House. Empirically true.
How bad are the losses going to be for Democrats?

BIDEN: I don't think the losses are going to be bad at all. I think we're going to shock the heck out of everybody. I really -- and I've been saying this now. I think even when you and I went down to North Carolina and you followed be on the recovery trip
column2: I was saying it then. I am absolutely confidence -- confident when people take a look at the what has happened since we've taken office in November and comparing it to the alternative
column3: we're going to be very -- we're going to be in great shape.

column1: Here's the deal. What Robert Gibbs also said was what he believes
column2: what I believe
column3: what the president believes
column4: we're going to win the House and we're going to win the Senate. We're not going to lose either one of those bodies.

column1: And so
column2: again
column3: this is July. November and at the time
column4: the most vulnerable time any public official finds himself in is when they have no opponent.

column1: Look at Harry Reid. You know
column2: I got -- I got kind of banged around for saying I think there was a 55 percent chance Harry Reid is going to win. Well
column3: Harry Reid
column4: when he was the -- you know
column5: on the other side of the barrage of how bad Harry Reid was
column6: was in trouble. Now Harry Reid
column7: in the last poll
column8: was up 7 points. I -- he I think he -- I -- I'd bet anything -- I'm not allowed to bet
column9: but I'll bet Harry Reid wins. You're going to see that repeated.

column1: So
column2: that old -- to paraphrase Mark Twain
column3: I think the -- the reports of our demise are premature.

299	"Rep. Joe Kennedy III (D-MA) claimed the host-city of his response to President Donald TrumpÃ¢ÂÂs State of the Union address
column2: Fall River
column3: Massachusetts was Ã¢ÂÂbuilt by immigrants.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: Fact-Check: MOSTLY FALSE
What is now Fall River was first established in the 1600s by English settlers who were not Ã¢ÂÂimmigrantsÃ¢ÂÂ but colonists. A native-born family
column2: the Bordens ran a mill in what became the town for generations before and after the American revolution. Industrialization began when Col. Joseph Durfee
column3: a native-born Revolutionary War hero built the first factory in 1811. Later
column4: at the end of the 19th Century a wave of immigrants swelled the townÃ¢ÂÂs population. Immigrants
column5: however
column6: never made up a majority of the population of Bristol County
column7: where Fall River lies
column8: even at their early 20th Century peak."	1

column1: 300	"There he is in the photos
column2: aflame with conviction and heady with success: class president
column3: editor on the law review
column4: bold young prosecutor
column5: No. 3 man at the Justice Department
column6: crime-fighting United States Attorney
column7: archenemy of the Mafia
column8: the 107th Mayor of the City of New York. Quite a run!

column1: And now
column2: working from City Hall
column3: Rudolph William Giuliani
column5: has become New York's one ubiquitous figure
column6: hurrying from a burned-out building to a subway derailment to the bedside of a wounded police officer. He is Gotham's action hero
column7: self-cast as the take-charge guy who is reliably among the first at every scene.

column1: By most reckonings
column2: including those of many adversaries
column3: Mr. Giuliani has coupled this celebrity with effective leadership. A seemingly ungovernable city now seems responsive to discipline
column4: its crime rate in a plunge
column5: its tourist-stocked streets palpably safer.

column1: Still
column2: however many his accomplishments
column3: there is something else striking about the Mayor: his temperament. He seems to believe in mayoral infallibility
column4: at least so long as he is the Mayor. To question his righteousness is to risk his wrath. A devil's advocate often seems regarded as the devil himself."	0

column1: 301	"One in Four Congressman Joe Pitts ÃÂ· Follow 3 min read ÃÂ· Mar 10
column2: 2016 -- 3 Listen Share

column1: One out of every four Pennsylvania households is affected by addiction. More than 2
column2: 400 Pennsylvanians died from overdoses last year
column3: making it the leading cause of accidental death in our Commonwealth.

column1: According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)
column2: about 120 Americans on average die from a drug overdose every day. Overall
column3: drug overdose deaths now outnumber deaths from firearms. More than 4 million Americans abuse prescription drugs or painkillers; another 435
column4: 000 use heroin.

column1: These facts are shocking
column2: but they reflect the reality right here in our neighborhoods
column3: in Reading
column4: in Lancaster City
column5: and across Pennsylvania. It is happening to Democrats and Republicans
column6: to people of every race and religion. It happens to our friends
column7: family members
column8: and neighbors. We all know them. And we share their pain.

column1: No one suffers alone. We donÃ¢ÂÂt have the option to think of this as merely a private or personal issue. Every addict comes from a family
column2: and has people who love them and suffer with them. It can be almost unbearable to watch someone you love endure the physical and mental effects of drug abuse. Every addiction hurts not only an addict
column3: but an entire community.

column1: All of us pay the price of addiction
column2: too
column3: because it keeps people from fulfilling their potential and contributing more fully to our society. Drug abuse contributes to unemployment
column4: homelessness
column5: and sex trafficking. It puts pressure on government programs and budgets.

column1: Ninety percent of addicts who need treatment donÃ¢ÂÂt get it. Our health care system is failing not only them
column2: but it is failing all of us. Addiction is treatable. We need to treat it
column3: and we need to educate our young people properly in order to prevent the spread of addiction.

column1: At a time when political acrimony is reaching a record level
column2: leaders in both parties are coming together to find solutions. At the state level
column3: Governor Wolf has ordered every state police vehicle to carry naloxone
column4: an anti-overdose drug that has already saved hundreds of lives.

column1: Congress likewise is working on a bipartisan basis
column2: with the support of the Obama Administration
column3: to make the system work better.

column1: This week
column2: the Senate passed comprehensive legislation to address the addiction crisis. The bill was the result of bipartisan effort
column3: and passed with bipartisan support from both of PennsylvaniaÃ¢ÂÂs Senators.

column1: In November
column2: Congress passed and the President signed into law a bipartisan bill
column3: the Protecting Our Infants Act
column4: to review federal programs to help the newborns of heroin and opiate addicts. Tragically
column5: thousands of babies are exposed to and addicted to drugs like codeine
column6: morphine
column7: or heroin before they are even born. Doctors are able to take these babies through the withdrawal process
column8: however. Our new law will require the federal government to develop a strategy to address any gaps in current research or programs.

column2: the Energy and Commerce CommitteeÃ¢ÂÂs Oversight and Investigations Subcommittee held five hearings on the drug abuse crisis. In October
column3: as Chairman of the Health Subcommittee
column4: I chaired a two-part hearing at which we heard from experts like the Obama AdministrationÃ¢ÂÂs drug czar Michael Botticelli and Dr. Kenneth Katz of the Lehigh Valley Health Network.

column1: Their testimony was as chilling as it was informative. Director Botticelli testified that over the past decade
column2: the number of people treated for overdoses each year
column3: and the number of babies born with neo-natal abstinence syndrome have both tripled. Dr. Katz told us about a number of adolescents in Allentown whom he has seen hospitalized and even killed after trying a new synthetic strand of cannabis.

column1: At the hearing
column2: we discussed seven bipartisan proposals that would improve federal public health policies and help addicts get treatment. Each of these seven bills deals with a different aspect of the epidemic
column3: because we need a comprehensive plan: not just adequate funding
column4: but targeted funding; not just emergency response
column5: but education and prevention.

column1: These bills would make a number of changes to existing law. They would expand the number of physicians who can prescribe the drug buprenorphine to addicts
column2: develop best practices and a national awareness campaign
column3: ban certain synthetic drugs
column4: help pregnant women who are addicted
column5: and create a patient tracking pilot program.

column1: We arenÃ¢ÂÂt finished. Congress will continue to take action on behalf of the families and communities across Pennsylvania and across the country being shattered by this public health crisis. We will work until the system works.

AgainÃ¢ÂÂ¦. That is with 90% extremely negative coverage for President Trump!"	1

303	"Oct. 11: The debate over the best way forward intensifies in Washington. Two key voices on the Hill and two experienced military leaders weigh in on the direction a new war strategy should take: Sen. Carl Levin (D-MI); Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-SC); Gen. Barry McCaffrey (Ret.); and Gen. Richard Myers (Ret.). Plus a roundtable: Ron Brownstein
column2: Paul Gigot
column3: Katty Kay
column4: Bob Woodward.

column1: GREGORY: Realistically
column2: from both of you generals
column3: what is victory in Afghanistan?

column1: GEN. MYERS: Some sort--in my view
column2: it's some sort of stable government. And back to Senator Levin's point...

column1: GREGORY: So we can't leave. We can't pull troops out of Afghanistan until there's a stable government?
GEN. MYERS: I think it has to be a viable
column2: stable government that the people believe in. And if you're going to have Afghan security forces that are effective
column3: they have to be connected to the central government and feel that there's some connection and some direction coming from their central government. Otherwise it doesn't work; they're just in the field doing what they do but there's no connection to the overall mission of that country. So I think clearly that's
column4: that's part of it. And I think there has to be some economic development to give people there hope that there's something beyond...

column1: GREGORY: Yeah.
GEN. MYERS: ...what they're doing today.
GREGORY: Can we beat the Taliban?
GEN. McCAFFREY: Well
column2: I
column3: I think in 10 years of $5 billion a month and with a significant front-end security component
column4: we can leave a Afghan national army and police force and a viable government and roads and universities. But it's a time constraint that we can't change things in 18 to 24 months. So I think we got to lower expectations. Senator Levin talked about our political resolve; is it there or not? You know
column5: sort of a simplistic lesson I learned as an infantry company commander in combat
column6: you only got three choices. When you're under fire you can hunker down and take casualties--it's bad--you can break contact and withdraw or you can reinforce and attack. That's really the
column7: the challenge facing the Obama administration right now. And the
column8: the politics of it are really tough. The American people do not appear to support large-scale continued intervention in this conflict.

column1: GREGORY: Just with
column2: with very little time left
column3: I want to get to two other issues. The president spoke last night at the Human Rights Campaign dinner and spoke about ""Don't Ask
column4: Don't Tell.""

column1: (Videotape)
PRES. OBAMA: I'm working with the Pentagon
column2: its leadership and the members of the House and Senate on ending this policy. Legislation has been introduced in the House to make this happen. I will end ""Don't Ask
column3: Don't Tell."" That's my commitment to you.

column1: (End videotape)
GREGORY: That
column2: of course
column3: the position of the military to expel gays and lesbians from service.

column1: Senator Levin
column2: will the president live up to this pledge? Can he?

column1: SEN. LEVIN: I think he
column2: he will and he can. I think it has to be done in the
column3: in the right way
column4: which is to get a buy-in from the military
column5: which I think is now possible. Other militaries in the West
column6: the British and other Western armies
column7: have ended this discriminatory policy. We can do it successfully. But it ought to be done with thoughtfulness and with care
column8: and with a buy-in from the military.

column1: GREGORY: General Myers
column2: is it time?

column1: GEN. MYERS: I can't talk about whether it's time or not. I think the process that Senator Levin outlined is exactly right
column2: that the senior military leadership needs to be part of this.

column1: GREGORY: Mm-hmm.
GEN. MYERS: The Pentagon needs to be part of it.
GREGORY: Do you have an opinion about whether it's time?
GEN. MYERS: Well
column2: I
column3: I take some exception to what Senator Levin said
column4: because gays can serve in the military
column5: just can't serve openly. And they
column6: they do and there's lot of them. And we are
column7: and we are
column8: and we're the beneficiary of all that.

column1: GREGORY: OK.
GEN. MYERS: So I'll leave it to the current folks to
column2: to decide whether it's time or not.

column1: GEN. McCAFFREY: Well
column2: there's no question it's time to change the policy. The key to it isn't buy-in from the military
column3: it's for Congress to change the law. They ought to do so. And we would--I'm confident the military will move ahead on it.

column1: SEN. LEVIN: And we
column2: I think
column3: will do that
column4: but we'll need the support at least of some of the military to do it.

column1: GEN. MYERS: I think that's right. You can't...
GREGORY: Does the
column2: does the president have the political resolve to make good on his promise?

column1: SEN. LEVIN: Oh
column2: he does
column3: and I think many of us do.

column1: GREGORY: Yeah.
SEN. LEVIN: I thought it was a mistake to begin with.
GREGORY: Right. Congress has the resolve as well to change it?
SEN. LEVIN: I think we will gain that resolve. The way we've made other changes in this country
column2: the military are the ones that ended a discriminatory policy against African-Americans. They can end it here and it will be great progress.

column1: GREGORY: And finally
column2: Senator Graham
column3: on that question
column4: do you think the military should end the policy?

column1: SEN. GRAHAM: Well
column2: it's my belief that if the policy--you don't have buy-in by the military
column3: that's a disservice to the people in the military. They should be included in this. I'm open-minded to what the military may suggest. But I can tell you
column4: I'm not going to make policy based on a campaign rally.

column1: And when it comes to time
column2: the one thing I would say again about Afghanistan
column3: history will judge not when we left but by what we left behind. And our national security interests will be determined by what we left behind and not when we left. And if this policy about ""Don't Ask
column4: Don't Tell"" changes
column5: it should be done based not on politics
column6: but on reason.

column1: GREGORY: And
column2: and
column3: finally
column4: Senator Graham
column5: do you think the president deserved the Nobel Peace Prize?

column1: SEN. GRAHAM: If he can successfully turn around Afghanistan
column2: deter Iran from getting a nuclear weapon
column3: I will build a bookcase for him to put it in. It depends on what he does.

column1: GREGORY: Senator Levin?
SEN. LEVIN: I think it was a
column2: a positive statement about hope for America
column3: as well as a recognition of the new direction that he's setting for us.

column1: GREGORY: All right
column2: we are going to leave it there. This debate will continue. Thanks to all of you.

column1: And coming next
column2: Afghanistan
column3: health care and jobs; the politics behind it all. Insights and analysis from our roundtable. Plus
column4: our MEET THE PRESS Minute highlighting some eerie similarities between Afghanistan and Vietnam
column5: only on MEET THE PRESS.

column1: (Announcements)
GREGORY: Our roundtable weighs in--Afghanistan
column2: health care and the economy--after this brief commercial break.

column1: (Announcements)
GREGORY: We are back and joined now by BBC America's Katty Kay
column2: The Washington Post's Bob Woodward
column3: National Journal's Ron Brownstein and Paul Gigot of The Wall Street Journal.

column1: Welcome to all of you. So much to get to this week; war and peace
column2: as I said at the outset. But let's talk about the politics of war
column3: and I think it's striking. Here we are in October of 2009
column4: and it was October of 2001 when President Bush made the decision to go to war. In October of 2009
column5: another president has to make another big decision about troops in Afghanistan
column6: and look how the politics have changed. This was a USA Today/Gallup poll about views of sending more troops
column7: and what you see here is a huge political divide: Democrats
column8: 36 percent for it; Republicans
column9: 73 percent for it. Opponents on the Democratic side
column10: 59 percent to 23 percent.

column1: Bob Woodward
column2: what's different? What are the politics here for this president?

column1: MR. BOB WOODWARD: Well
column2: I
column3: I think what's interesting
column4: instead of trying to figure out the future
column5: what's going on in the White House now? It's extraordinary series of very long meetings. One of the big criticisms of Lyndon Johnson during Vietnam was he wouldn't listen
column6: and Obama is listening. He's on a listening tour
column7: and everyone is getting their say. And he's got to
column8: he's got to make a giant decision not about troop numbers
column9: but what's the strategy? And I think
column10: you know
column11: this is
column12: this is the test for him. Can he come up with some consensus so the military doesn't feel wounded
column13: so his own party doesn't feel wounded? And if he does that
column14: you know
column15: a lot of people
column16: even if they don't agree with the final decision
column17: will say he did something--again
column19: in deciding to go into Iraq
column20: the model there was he decided...

column1: GREGORY: Right.
MR. WOODWARD: ...""We're going to do it."" All the meetings were about how to do it
column2: never considering other options.

column1: GREGORY: But
column2: but there
column3: there is a real debate about this policy that has broken into the public
column4: and you broke this story with McChrystal's assessment. The vice president is on the cover of Newsweek magazine with his perspective as a
column5: as a counselor to the president on important matters
column6: including this question of Afghanistan. This is played out--we spent a lot of time talking about this in the Bush administration over Iraq. This has really played out publicly.

column1: MR. WOODWARD: But
column2: but--and I think to everyone's benefit
column3: including the president's
column4: including the military and certainly the
column5: the public. Look
column6: if we had had the secret report on WMD in Iraq before the war and published that
column7: history might have been different. It's very important to know
column8: if you can
column9: what these classified memos say. And in the
column10: in this case we have it
column11: and people are talking about something very concrete.

column1: GREGORY: Paul Gigot
column2: the
column3: the question is the president had a strategy. He announced it in March.

column1: MR. PAUL GIGOT: I thought--yeah.

GREGORY: It was clear. This is what Charles Krauthammer wrote on Friday in his column: ""So what does [the] commander-in-chief do now with the war he once declared had to be won but had been almost criminally underresourced by Bush? Perhaps provide the resources to win it? You would think so. ... Obama agonizes publicly and the world watches. Why?"""	0

column5: a well-known news anchor was rammed in what looked like an act of violence and not an accident.

column1: EMTÃ¢ÂÂs on the scene were heard on their radios describing the man as Fox News anchor Tucker Carlson after retrieving his wallet. He was transported to Saint MaryÃ¢ÂÂs where he is said to be in critical condition and awaiting surgery. No other information is available from the hospital
column2: which also refuses to release anything until they get the OK from police.

column1: The car that crossed the median and struck Carlson had a reinforced bumper and the steering wheel was covered with foam to provide the driver extra protection from a crash. ItÃ¢ÂÂs obvious that someone wanted to do harm to another human being on purpose. Whether or not Carlson was specifically targeted or just in the wrong place at the wrong time remains unknown. The perpetrator fled the scene. The Ford Explorer he was driving had no plates or VIN numbers. Police have impounded it as evidence.
Our thoughts and prayers are with TuckerÃ¢ÂÂs family tonight. This is a developing story that will be updated."	1

311	"A ship owned and operated by the Clinton Foundation was raided as it arrived from Africa this morning at the Port of Baltimore. The ship
column2: which was supposed to be carrying Ã¢ÂÂemergency supplies
column3: Ã¢ÂÂ was actually carrying a cargo that had authorities stunned. BPA Harbormaster Jake Cummings explained to CNN:

column1: Ã¢ÂÂWe received a tip that the Clinton Foundation flagship
column2: The Chelsea
column3: was carrying illegal contraband into the United States. We honestly didnÃ¢ÂÂt know what to expect
column4: but what we found was simplyÃ¢ÂÂ¦surreal. In the middle of the shipÃ¢ÂÂs large manifest of containers
column5: most of which were empty
column6: we found 14 containingÃ¢ÂÂ¦people. Yes
column7: people. They were all Refugees from places like Yemen and Syria and not a single one had any kind of documentation. We interviewed those who spoke English and were told that for $40K
column8: anyone can catch a ride to the United States on a ship nobody would ever suspect.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: Immigration was immediately called and found that of the 460 people on board illegally
column2: not one had been through any kind of vetting process. After running the men through facial recognition
column3: they found more than a dozen suspected terrorists who are on the US no-fly list. Those men were about to be unleashed on the public for $40K each."	1

column1: 312	"Share Comment on this story Comment Add to your saved stories Save
For weeks
column2: dozens of construction workers from Latin America have streamed onto the site of the Old Post Office Pavilion in downtown Washington and taken pride in their work building one of the cityÃ¢ÂÂs newest luxury hotels. Fast
column3: informative and written just for locals. Get The 7 DMV newsletter in your inbox every weekday morning. ArrowRight But that job site is now laden with tension after the man behind the project Ã¢ÂÂ billionaire developer Donald Trump Ã¢ÂÂ put himself at the center of the nationÃ¢ÂÂs debate over illegal immigration.

column1: Trump garnered headlines Ã¢ÂÂ and prompted several business associates to sever relations with him Ã¢ÂÂ when he launched his bid for the Republican presidential nomination last month with a controversial description of drug dealers and Ã¢ÂÂrapistsÃ¢ÂÂ crossing the border each day into the United States from Mexico.
But a Trump company may be relying on some undocumented workers to finish the $200 million hotel
column2: which will sit five blocks from the White House on Pennsylvania Avenue
column3: according to several who work there. A Trump spokeswoman said the company and its contractors follow all applicable laws. But in light of TrumpÃ¢ÂÂs comments
column4: some of the workers at the site said they are now worried about their jobs Ã¢ÂÂ while others simply expressed disgust over the opinions of the man ultimately responsible for the creation of those jobs.

column1: Since Donald Trump announced his presidential bid
column2: he's drawn plenty of controversy and outrage for his comments. Here are some of the key moments. (Video: The Washington Post)

column1: All of them said they have been talking about Trump ever since his inflammatory remarks dominated coverage of his presidential announcement on June 16.
Advertisement
Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs something ironic
column2: Ã¢ÂÂ said Ivan Arellano
column4: who is from Mexico and obtained legal status through marriage. He now works as a mason laying the stonework for the lobby floor and walls of what will become the Trump International Hotel.

column1: Ã¢ÂÂThe majority of us are Hispanics
column2: many who came illegally
column3: Ã¢ÂÂ Arellano said in Spanish. Ã¢ÂÂAnd weÃ¢ÂÂre all here working very hard to build a better life for our families.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: Interviews with about 15 laborers helping renovate the Old Post Office Pavilion revealed that many of them had crossed the U.S-Mexico border illegally before they eventually settled in the Washington region to build new lives.
Several of the men
column2: who hail mostly from El Salvador
column3: Honduras and Guatemala
column4: have earned U.S. citizenship or legal status through immigration programs targeting Central Americans fleeing civil wars or natural disasters. Others quietly acknowledged that they remain in the country illegally.

column1: Advertisement
Ã¢ÂÂMost of the concern is that this escalates into a bigger problem
column2: Ã¢ÂÂ said Daniel Gonzalez
column4: a sheet metal worker from El Salvador who crossed the border in the 1980s to escape his countryÃ¢ÂÂs civil war. He became a U.S. citizen after a federal immigration judge granted him asylum
column5: he said.

column1: Ã¢ÂÂHe might come one day and pretty much tell us to get the heck out of here
column2: Ã¢ÂÂ Gonzalez said of Trump.

column1: Donald Trump announces presidential run + 23 The real estate mogul and reality TV celebrity
column2: announced he would seek the GOP presidential nomination.

column1: Several of the laborers Ã¢ÂÂ who travel to work from as far away as Baltimore or Manassas
column2: Va.
column3: every day Ã¢ÂÂ fumed at TrumpÃ¢ÂÂs comments
column4: saying that they have led honest lives that have allowed them to buy homes and raise U.S.-born children.

The obligation to check all workers on site is exclusive to Lend Lease. This of course assumes that the assertion regarding the employeesÃ¢ÂÂ status is accurate.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: TrumpÃ¢ÂÂs comments about illegal immigration Ã¢ÂÂ which included a promise to Ã¢ÂÂbuild a great
column2: great wall on our southern borderÃ¢ÂÂ and bill Mexico for the cost Ã¢ÂÂ reflect deep-rooted concerns among conservative voters over the effect of illegal immigration in the United States. Yet
column3: concerns raised by workers at one of his companyÃ¢ÂÂs real estate ventures reveal the complexities of an issue that has long polarized the country.

The rapid rejection of TrumpÃ¢ÂÂs comments by some of his business partners may also reflect how perilous a topic immigration is

column1: TrumpÃ¢ÂÂs comments were popular with conservative activists across the country Ã¢ÂÂ and may even have helped elevate his status

But they were less popular among an increasingly diverse general electorate that serves as a consumer base for the influential corporate entities that were quick to distance themselves from the mogulÃ¢ÂÂs remarks.

column1: At the mammoth construction site in Washington that bears TrumpÃ¢ÂÂs name

column1: The site is a bustling microcosm of blue-collar work life in Washington Ã¢ÂÂ with soaring turrets and a majestic clock tower that evoke the buildingÃ¢ÂÂs heyday as the DistrictÃ¢ÂÂs main post office in the early 20th century.
Trucks roll in and out of the construction site carrying heavy loads of cement or carting off piles of debris. Over the din of surrounding traffic

column1: 313	"Crime in Arizona Reports
An Annual Report compiled by Access Integrity Unit of the Arizona Department of Public Safety.
The Arizona Department of Public Safety is pleased to participate in and serve as the coordinating agency for the Arizona Uniform Crime Reporting Program.

The purpose of the Crime in Arizona Report is to provide data regarding the nature and extent of crime throughout the State. This report does not draw conclusions as to the causes of crime. The report does provide the vital information necessary to assist law enforcement agencies
column2: government
column3: and the public in their approach to crime in our state.

column1: This report is the culmination of a joint effort by our state's law enforcement agencies to collect and organize crime data. The information contained in this report should provide a valuable overview of the crime problem.

315	"Such a reaction would be understandable if Saeed Jalili
column2: the most anti-Western ultraconservative candidate
column3: had won. But why has the Israeli government greeted Rouhani with hostility? The common refrain in Israel is that Rouhani's moderate image Ã¢ÂÂ in contrast to his predecessor Mahmoud Ahmadinejad's Ã¢ÂÂ will hamper Israel's efforts to keep Iran isolated. Furthermore
column4: Rouhani's moderate tone could fool the United States and Europe into a false sense of security
column5: resulting in the lifting of sanctions against Iran and even passivity toward the threat of Iran's nuclear program. Such concern likely peaked after Rouhani's recent visit to the United Nations General Assembly
column6: which led to a number of milestones in Iran's troubled relationship with the U.S. The meeting between Iran's foreign minister Mohammad Javad Zarif and U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry Ã¢ÂÂ the first such formal talks between the two countries since the 1978 Iranian Revolution Ã¢ÂÂ was followed by another major unprecedented milestone: a phone call between Rouhani and President Barack Obama. To be sure
column7: when it comes to Rouhani's ability to usher real change to Iran's nuclear program
column8: a healthy dose of skepticism is called for. However
column9: his election victory is not the threat that Netanyahu and his cabinet have alleged. In fact
column10: there are good reasons for Israelis to welcome Rouhani's rise to power. Rouhani was elected on a platform of moderation. Among the presidential candidates
column11: he was the most critical of Iran's nuclear-negotiation strategy. His criticism focused on Iran's intransigent posture at the talks
column12: which forced it to pay a disproportionate price for its nuclear program. As Rouhani stated in a campaign video on June 5
column13: 10 days before the election: ""If centrifuges are turning
column14: but the country is dormant
column15: then we don't choose this. If the arrangement is for Natanz [Iran's nuclear enrichment site] to work but 100 other factories close because of sanctions and shortage of primary material or they only work at 20 percent of their capacity
column16: then this is unacceptable.""

column1: Iranian President Hassan Rouhani was the most moderate candidate among those allowed to run in the country's June election. Yet within one month of Rouhani's victory
column2: Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu publicly called him a ""wolf in sheepÃ¢ÂÂs clothing.""

column1: In what should be good news for Israel
column2: Rouhani could usher in change to Iran's nuclear stance. He enjoys very good relations with Iran's Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei and seems to be highly trusted by him. For 25 years Rouhani was Khamenei's representative on the Supreme National Security Council (SNSC)
column3: which shapes Iran's national security and defense policies.

column1: In fact
column2: Rouhani's relations with Khamenei are far better so far than that of his predecessors
column3: Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani
column4: Mohammad Khatami and Ahmadinejad. Khamenei may not have allowed Ahmadinejad to shift Iran's nuclear strategy
column5: despite the latter's calls for Iran to halt enrichment at 20 percent
column6: because of bad relations between the two leaders after a public falling out in April 2011.

column1: Rouhani's rapprochement with the U.S. could also be good news for Israeli worries over Iran's nuclear ambitions. Improved relations with Iran
column2: along with the leverage of sanctions
column3: could give the U.S. what it needs to extract concessions from Tehran over its nuclear program.

column1: At the same time
column2: Rouhani's rise to power and the strengthening of his position will come at a cost to Iran's hard-liners
column3: Israel's most ardent enemies. In fact
column4: this is already happening: In less than two months since coming to power
column5: Rouhani is already changing parts of Iran's stance on the Holocaust
column6: much to the fury of Iran's ultraconservatives.

column1: Last but not least
column2: Rouhani's election represented a victory for the tough sanctions imposed against Iran
column3: such as the restrictions against Iran's Central Bank that Israel had demanded for many years. A military attack by Israel or the U.S.
column4: by contrast
column5: would most probably have stiffened Iran's stance against negotiations. So now that the goal of softening Iran's stance has been achieved
column6: it is time to reap its benefits.

column1: Netanyahu appears to believe that Rouhani cannot be trusted and must be pressured incessantly
column2: even if he offers compromises. Netanyahu insists that Iran's entire nuclear program must be dismantled and
column3: if Iran does not comply
column4: military action should be taken.

column1: The irony in Netanyahu's harsh line is that it helps Rouhani politically. In Iran praise from any Israeli leaders could be detrimental.
For now
column2: Netanyahu appears to be attacking Rouhani because he genuinely doubts his sincerity and views his overtures as a threat to Israel. Let us hope that instead of hurting Rouhani
column3: Netanyahu ends up helping him. Rouhani's diplomatic outreach could be the best opportunity Israel has seen in the last decade to find a negotiated settlement to Iran's nuclear program."	0

column1: 316	"This is part one of the transcript for the CNN/YouTube presidential debates. To see the transcript of part two click here.
CHARLESTON
column2: South Carolina (CNN) -- The eight candidates vying to be the Democrat nominee for president in the 2008 elections answered questions submitted by CNN and YouTube users in a debate Tuesday night. Here is a full transcript of the event:

column1: Eight candidates gathered in South Carolina for a new type of questioning.
ANDERSON COOPER
column2: CNN host: Our first question tonight is Zach Kempf in Provo
column3: Utah.

column1: QUESTION: What's up? I'm running out of tape; I have to hurry.
So my question is: We have a bunch of leaders who can't seem to do their job. And we pick people based on the issues they that they represent
column2: but then they get in power and they don't do anything about it anyway.

column1: You're going to spend this whole night talking about your views on issues
column2: but the issues don't matter if when you get in power nothing's going to get done.

column1: We have a Congress and a president with
column2: like
column3: a 30 percent approval rating
column4: so clearly we don't think they're doing a good job. What's going to make you any more effectual
column5: beyond all the platitudes and the stuff we're used to hearing? I mean
column6: be honest with us. How are you going to be any different?

column1: COOPER: Senator Dodd
column2: you've been in Congress more than 30 years. Can you honestly say you're any different?

column1: SEN. CHRISTOPHER DODD: Well
column2: I think so.

column1: First of all
column2: thank you for inviting us here in The Citadel. It's great to be here at this wonderful college
column3: university.

column1: Certainly
column2: I think it's a very important question one ought to be asking because
column3: while hope and confidence and optimism are clearly very important
column4: I think experience matters a great deal -- the experience people bring to their candidacy
column5: the ideas
column6: the bold ideas that they've championed over the years
column7: whether or not they were successful in advancing those ideas and able to bring people together.

column1: I'm very proud of the fact that
column2: over my 26 years in the Senate
column3: I've authored landmark legislation
column4: the Family and Medical Leave Act
column5: child care legislation
column6: reform of financial institutions.

column1: In every case
column2: those are new ideas
column3: bold ideas
column4: that I campaigned on and then were able to achieve in the United States Senate by bringing Republicans as well as Democrats together around those issues.

column1: That's what's missing
column2: more than anything else
column3: I think
column4: right now
column5: is the ability to bring people together to get the job done.

column1: COOPER: But if someone really wants a change
column2: are you the guy to give it to them?

column1: DODD: Well
column2: I think they ought to look back. Speeches are easy to make and rhetoric is easy to expose here. But I think the idea of looking back and saying
column3: ""What have you done?"" --if you want to get a good idea of where someone is going to lead or how they're going to lead
column4: I think it's very appropriate to say
column5: ""What have you done? Show me. Demonstrate to me the ability to get these things done that you've championed in the past.""

column1: COOPER: Senator Obama
column2: your supporters say you are different. Your critics say you're inexperienced. You're a first-term senator.

column1: SEN. BARACK OBAMA: Well
column2: I think the questioner hit the nail on the head. As I travel around the country
column3: people have an urgent desire for change in Washington. And we are not going to fix health care
column4: we're not going to fix energy
column5: we are not going to do anything about our education system unless we change how business is done in Washington.

column1: Now
column2: part of that is bringing people together
column3: as Chris said. But part of it is also overcoming special interests and lobbyists who are writing legislation that's critical to the American people.

column1: And one of the things I bring is a perspective as a community organizer
column2: as a state legislator
column3: as well as a U.S. senator
column4: that says: Washington has to change.

column1: COOPER: A lot of people say -- Congressman Kucinich
column2: your supporters certainly say you are different. Even your critics would certainly say you are different. Here's a direct question for you.

column1: QUESTION: Hello. My name is Davis Fleetwood. I'm from Groton
column2: Massachusetts. My question is for Dennis Kucinich.

column1: After watching the first several debates
column2: which seemed more like conversations than actually debates
column3: we're all clear out here that you Democrats are united. We get it.

column1: But we have a very important decision to make coming up very soon
column2: and Americans desperate for a change need to know: Congressman Kucinich
column3: how would America be better off with you as president than we would be if either Hillary Clinton or Barack Obama became president?

column1: COOPER: What do you have that Senator Clinton and Senator Obama do not have?
REP. DENNIS KUCINICH: Well
column2: first of all
column3: a clear record as having not only opposed the war from the very beginning -- the only one of the stage that actually voted against the war
column4: and also the only one on the stage who voted against funding the war 100 percent of the time.

column1: You know
column2: we're here at The Citadel. I want the people of The Citadel to know that I mourn the passing of those people who gave their lives
column3: but I also would not hesitate to call upon you to defend this country
column4: but I'll never send you in pursuit of a political agenda or a lie.

column1: Just like my father before me
column2: who served in the Marines
column3: and my brother who served in the Marines in Vietnam
column4: and my nephew who served in Iraq
column5: I believed in duty and honor and I think it's important to have those commitments to this country.

column1: And so I say we achieve strength through peace. That's the new doctrine that I'm going to promote throughout this campaign; that we'll use the science of human relations and diplomacy; that we pursue an approach which says that you can use international agreements and treaties; and that you can work to settle your differences without committing the young men and women to war
column2: unless it's absolutely necessary.

column1: COOPER: Senator Clinton
column2: you were involved in that question. I want to give you a chance to respond
column3: 30 seconds.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
SEN. HILLARY CLINTON: Well
column2: I think the Democrats are united
column3: as Davis said
column4: and we are united for change. We cannot take another four or eight years of Republican leadership that has been so disastrous for our country.

column1: The issue is: Which of us is ready to lead on day one? I have 35 years of being an instrument and agent of change
column2: before I was ever a public official. And during the time that I've been privileged to serve as first lady and now as senator
column3: I've worked to bring people together
column4: to find common ground where we can
column5: and then to stand our ground where we can't.

column1: COOPER: Senator Obama
column2: you were involved in that question as well.

column1: OBAMA: Look
column2: I don't think this is just a Republican problem. I think this is a problem that spans the parties. And we don't just need a change in political parties in Washington. We've got to have a change in attitudes of those who are representing the people
column3: America. And part of the reason I don't take PAC money
column4: I don't take federal lobbyists' money is because we've got to get the national interests up front as opposed to the special interests.

column1: And that is something that I've got a track record doing
column2: and I think that is what the American people are looking for in this election -- people of both parties as well as independents.

column1: COOPER: Our next question is for Senator Clinton.
(APPLAUSE)
QUESTION: Hi. My name is Rob Porter
column2: and I'm from Irvine
column3: California.

column1: I have a question for Hillary Clinton.
Mrs. Clinton
column2: how would you define the word ""liberal?""

column1: And would you use this word to describe yourself?
Thank you.
(LAUGHTER)
CLINTON: You know
column2: it is a word that originally meant that you were for freedom
column3: that you were for the freedom to achieve
column4: that you were willing to stand against big power and on behalf of the individual.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: in the last 30
column3: 40 years
column4: it has been turned up on its head and it's been made to seem as though it is a word that describes big government
column5: totally contrary to what its meaning was in the 19th and early 20th century.

column1: I prefer the word ""progressive
column2: which has a real American meaning
column3: going back to the progressive era at the beginning of the 20th century.

column1: I consider myself a modern progressive
column2: someone who believes strongly in individual rights and freedoms
column3: who believes that we are better as a society when we're working together and when we find ways to help those who may not have all the advantages in life get the tools they need to lead a more productive life for themselves and their family.

column1: So I consider myself a proud modern American progressive
column2: and I think that's the kind of philosophy and practice that we need to bring back to American politics.

column1: COOPER: So you wouldn't use the word ""liberal
column2: you'd say ""progressive.""

column1: (APPLAUSE)
Senator Gravel
column2: are you a liberal?

column1: FORMER SEN. MIKE GRAVEL: I wouldn't use either word (OFF-MIKE) Zach asked about change. You're not going to see any change when these people get elected.
We were asked about -- that we're united.
We're not united. I'm not united on many of their views. And I want to take on Barack Obama for a minute
column2: who said he doesn't take money from lobbyists. Well
column3: he has 134 bundlers. Now
column4: what does he think that is?

column1: And
column2: besides that
column3: he has received money from a Robert Wolf
column4: the head of the USB (sic) bank in the United States
column5: who raised $195
column6: 000 -- from this bank -- wait a second -- who has lobbyists in Washington...

column1: COOPER: Your time is up.
GRAVEL: ... and it's a foreign-owned bank.
COOPER: Senator Obama
column2: I'm going to have to let you respond.

column1: OBAMA: Absolutely.
Well
column2: the fact is I don't take PAC money and I don't take lobbyists' money.

column1: And the bundlers -- the reason you know who is raising money for me
column2: Mike
column3: is because I have pushed through a law this past session to disclose that.

column1: And that's the kind of leadership that I've shown in the Senate. That's the kind of leadership that I showed when I was a state legislator. And that's the kind of leadership that I'll show as president of the United States.
GRAVEL: Wait a minute...
(APPLAUSE)
COOPER: Our next question is for Senator Biden.

QUESTION: Hello. This question is for all of the candidates. Partisanship played a major role in why nothing can be done in Washington today. All of you say you will be able to work with Republicans. Well
column2: here's a test. If you had to pick any Republican member of Congress or Republican governor to be your running mate
column3: who would it be?

column1: SEN. JOE BIDEN: At the risk of hurting his reputation -- and it will hurt him -- but I would pick Chuck Hagel
column2: and I'd consider asking Dick Lugar to be secretary of state.

column1: And I do have -- I do have a record of significant accomplishment. The crime bill
column2: which became known as the Clinton crime bill
column3: was written by Joe Biden
column4: the Biden crime bill. That required me to cross over
column5: get everyone together
column6: not -- no one's civil liberties were in any way jeopardized.

column1: We put 100
column2: 000 cops on the street. Violent crime came down.

column1: The Violence against Women Act
column2: what we did in Bosnia
column3: and so on. So I have a track record of being able to cross over and get things done.

column1: And by the way
column2: if you want to end all this money
column3: support my effort to pass public financing of all elections.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
COOPER: All right. Stay on the topic.
Senator Edwards? Any Republicans?
FORMER SEN. JOHN EDWARDS: Actually
column2: I think Chuck Hagel is a good choice. But I -- if you listen to these questions
column3: they all have exactly the same thing
column4: which is how do we bring about big change?

column1: And I think that's a fundamental threshold question. And the question is: Do you believe that compromise
column2: triangulation will bring about big change? I don't.

column1: I think the people who are powerful in Washington -- big insurance companies
column2: big drug companies
column3: big oil companies -- they are not going to negotiate. They are not going to give away their power. The only way that they are going to give away their power is if we take it away from them.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
And I have been standing up to these people my entire life. I have been fighting them my entire life in court rooms -- and beating them.
If you want real change
column2: you need somebody who's taking these people on and beating them...

column1: COOPER: Time.
EDWARDS: ... over and over and over.
COOPER: The other thing you're going to see tonight are candidate videos. We've asked each campaign to put together a 30- second YouTube-style video. The first one is from Senator Chris Dodd.
(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
QUESTION: Senator
column2: I have to ask
column3: what's with the white hair?

column1: DODD: I don't know why you bring that up. Bill Richardson
column2: Hillary
column3: Joe Biden and I
column4: we're all about the same age. I don't think the white hair is an issue.

column1: QUESTION: Well
column2: how did you get the white hair?

column1: DODD: Hard work
column2: I suppose. For example
column3: it took me seven years to pass the Family and Medical Leave Act
column4: and I helped to end wars in Central America and bring peace to Northern Ireland. I'm ready to be president.

column1: QUESTION: Well
column2: how many white hairs do you have?

column1: DODD: Hundreds
column2: thousands
column3: I presume.

column1: QUESTION: Really?
DODD: I'm Chris Dodd
column2: and we approved this message.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
(APPLAUSE)
COOPER: There you go. Nothing wrong with white hair.
DODD: A young person with white hair
column2: too?

column1: COOPER: Yes
column2: sadly
column3: my age is catching up to my hair.

column1: (LAUGHTER)
Almost 50 percent of South Carolina's Democrats are African- Americans. It's among the highest percentage of the nation. So we're giving a lot of questions from YouTube viewers on race tonight.
This first one is for Senator Edwards. Let's listen.
QUESTION: Hello
column2: America. Hello
column3: presidential candidates. This is Will from Boston
column4: Massachusetts. And I hope
column5: you know
column6: they put this question on. It's a question in the back of everybody's head. You know
column7: in some people
column8: it's further back than others
column9: collecting cobwebs.

column1: But is African-Americans ever going to get reparations for slavery?
I know you all are going to run around this question
column2: dipping and dodging
column3: so let's see how far you all can get.

column1: COOPER: Senator Edwards
