column2: no dipping and dodging. Should African-Americans get reparations?

column1: EDWARDS: I'm not for reparations. I can answer that questions. But I think there are other things we can do to create some equality that doesn't exist in this country today.
Today there was a report that
column2: right here in Charleston
column3: African Americans are paying more than their white counterparts for mortgages than any other place in America
column4: any other place in the United States of America.

column1: And here's an example. What is the conceivable explanation for this
column2: that black people are paying more for their mortgage?

column1: And
column2: by the way
column3: it's not just low-income African Americans; it's high-income African-Americans. There's absolutely no explanation for this. It goes to the basic question that I raised just a few minutes ago.

column1: To have a president that's going to -- is going to fight for equality
column2: fight for real change
column3: big change
column4: bold change
column5: we're going to have to somebody -- we can't trade our insiders for their insiders. That doesn't work.

column1: What we need is somebody who will take these people on
column2: these big banks
column3: these mortgage companies
column4: big insurance companies
column5: big drug companies. That's the only way we're going to bring about change. And I will do that as president.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
COOPER: Senator Obama
column2: your position on reparations?

column1: OBAMA: I think the reparations we need right here in South Carolina is investment
column2: for example
column3: in our schools. I did a...

column1: (APPLAUSE)
I did a town hall meeting in Florence
column2: South Carolina
column3: in an area called the corridor of shame. They've got buildings that students are trying to learn in that were built right after the Civil War. And we've got teachers who are not trained to teach the subjects they're teaching and high dropout rates.

column1: We've got to understand that there are corridors of shame all across the country. And if we make the investments and understand that those are our children
column2: that's the kind of reparations that are really going to make a difference in America right now.

column1: COOPER: Is anyone on the stage for reparations for slavery for African-Americans?
Are you?
KUCINICH: I am.
The Bible says we shall be and must be repairers of the breach. And a breach has occurred.
We have to acknowledge that. It's a breach that has resulted in inequality in opportunities for education
column2: for health care
column3: for housing
column4: for employment. And so
column5: we must be mindful of that.

column1: But it's also a breach that has affected a lot of poor whites as well.

We need to have a country which recognizes that there is an inequality of opportunity and a president who's ready to challenge the interest groups -- be they insurance companies or mortgage companies or defense contractors who are taking the money away from the people who need it.
COOPER: Time.
KUCINICH: Yes
column2: I am for repairing the breach. Yes
column3: I am for reparations.

column1: COOPER: Our next question is for Senator Dodd.
QUESTION: Do you believe the response in the wake of Hurricane Katrina would have been different if the storm hit an affluent
column2: predominantly white city? What roles do you believe race and class played in the storm's aftermath? And if you acknowledge that race and class affected the response efforts
column3: what can you do to ensure that this won't happen in the future? And what can you do to ensure this nation's most needy people
column4: in times of crisis and always
column5: something will be done to help them too?

column1: DODD: Well
column2: it's a great question
column3: Morgan
column4: to raise here. It
column5: obviously
column6: points to one of the most dark and shameful moments in recent past history in our country -- the fact that a major American city went through a natural disaster
column7: and we found almost (ph) little to do. The American president had almost no response whatsoever to the people of that city
column8: New Orleans.

column1: In fact
column2: today still
column3: the problem persists where people who had to move out of their city
column4: move elsewhere
column5: and little or no efforts to make sure they can get back in their homes. They have literally thousands of people whose homes were destroyed
column6: their economic opportunities destroyed.

column1: I believe that had this occurred in a place with mainly a white population
column2: we would have seen a much more rapid response and a consistent response to that issue.

column1: As an American president
column2: we can never
column3: ever allow again a major city
column4: a major population center in our country go through what New Orleans
column5: what the Gulf states did as a result of the kind of neglect from an American president.

column1: As president
column2: I would commit to do everything possible we bring to bear the talents
column3: the resources.

column1: In fact
column2: it should have been done ahead of time
column3: to have a FEMA operation that was prepared to respond to these predictable disasters. So it's a mark of shame on our country. It ought to be reversed. It will in the Dodd administration.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
COOPER: Governor Richardson
column2: the Democrats talk a lot about the failure of the president with Hurricane Katrina. The governor of that state was a Democrat; the mayor of that city is a Democrat as well.

column1: GOV. BILL RICHARDSON: Well
column2: there was politics. All of a sudden
column3: other states that had the similar devastation got better treatment
column4: like Mississippi.

column1: This is what I would do. The response of our government to Katrina
column2: before
column3: during and after
column4: was inexcusable. We have got to eliminate in the future any red tape that helps families -- that helps the devastation.

column1: Secondly
column2: we have to let those that live there to come back first
column3: instead of big moneyed interests. We have to stop the predatory lending of insurance companies
column4: housing and many others that are ripping off the people.

column1: And then
column2: finally
column3: we have to make sure that a president cares -- and doesn't just pose for photo ops
column4: but makes a difference and a commitment to rebuild that city and that region.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
COOPER: Our next question comes from Jordan Williams.
QUESTION: Hello. My name is Jordan Williams
column2: and I am a student at K.U.
column3: from Coffeyville
column4: Kansas.

column1: This question is meant for Senator Obama and Senator Clinton.
Whenever I read an editorial about one of you
column2: the author never fails to mention the issue of race or gender
column3: respectively. Either one is not authentically black enough
column4: or the other is not satisfactorily feminine.

column1: How will you address these critics and their charges if one or both of you should end up on the Democratic ticket in '08?
COOPER: Senator Obama
column2: how do you address those who say you're not authentically black enough?

column1: (LAUGHTER)
OBAMA: Well...
COOPER: Not my question; Jordan's question.
OBAMA: You know
column2: when I'm catching a cab in Manhattan -- in the past
column3: I think I've given my credentials.

column1: (LAUGHTER)
(APPLAUSE)
But let me go to the broader issue here. And that is that race permeates our society. It is still a critical problem.
But I do believe in the core decency of the American people
column2: and I think they want to get beyond some of our racial divisions.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: we've had a White House that hasn't invested in the kinds of steps that have to be done to overcome the legacy of slavery and Jim Crow in this country.

column1: And as president of the United States
column2: my commitment on issues like education
column3: my commitment on issues like health care is to close the disparities and the gaps
column4: because that's what's really going to solve the race problem in this country.

column1: If people feel like they've got a fair shake
column2: if children feel as if the fact that they have a different surname or they've got a different skin color is not going to impede their dreams
column3: then I am absolutely confident that we're going to be able to move forward on the challenges that we face as a country.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
COOPER: Senator Clinton
column2: you have a minute as well since this question is to you.

column1: CLINTON: Well
column2: I couldn't run as anything other than a woman.

column1: (LAUGHTER)
I am proud to be running as a woman.
And I'm excited that I may...
(APPLAUSE)
... you know
column2: may be able
column3: finally
column4: to break that hardest of all glass ceilings.

column1: But
column2: obviously
column3: I'm not running because I'm a woman. I'm running because I think I'm the most qualified and experienced person to hit the ground running in January 2009.

column1: And I trust the American people to make a decision that is not about me or my gender
column2: or about Barack or his race or about Bill and his ethnicity
column3: but about what is best for you and your family.

column1: We have big challenges...
(APPLAUSE)
... and big needs in our country. And I think we're going to need experienced and strong leadership in order to start handling all of the problems that we have here at home and around the world.
And when I'm inaugurated
column2: I think it's going to send a great message to a lot of little girls and boys around the world.

column1: COOPER: Senator Edwards...
(APPLAUSE)
Senator Edwards
column2: earlier this week
column3: your wife said that you would be a better advocate for women than Senator Clinton. Was she right?

column1: EDWARDS: Well
column2: let me say first that on the question that was just asked to Senator Obama...

column1: COOPER: We prefer you stay on the question...
EDWARDS: I'm going to stay on your question. I promise I'll answer that question. But the first thing I want to say -- and I want to speak for everybody
column2: I believe
column3: on this stage -- anybody who's considering not voting for Senator Obama because he's black or for Senator Clinton because she's a woman
column4: I don't want their vote. I don't want them voting for me.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
I think what Elizabeth was saying was -- to answer your question
column2: what Elizabeth was saying was there are very important issues facing women in this country. More women are affected by the minimum wage than men are affected by the minimum wage. I have been the most aggressive -- in fact
column3: I would challenge every Democrat on this stage today to commit to raising the minimum wage to $9.50 an hour by the year 2012.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
Second
column2: there are more women in poverty than men in poverty.

column1: And I have made this a central cause in my life and a central cause in my campaign. More women have difficulty getting the health care that they need than men do. And I was the first person to come out with a comprehensive
column2: truly universal health care plan.

column1: COOPER: So do you think you're a better advocate for women than Senator Clinton?
EDWARDS: Those are issues -- listen
column2: Senator Clinton has a long history of speaking out on behalf of women. She deserves to be commended for that. But I believe that on the issues that directly affect women's lives
column3: I have the strongest
column4: boldest ideas and can bring about the change that needs to be brought.

column1: COOPER: Senator Clinton
column2: is he a better advocate for women?

column1: (APPLAUSE)
CLINTON: Anderson
column2: I have a great deal of admiration for Elizabeth Edwards. And I appreciate greatly John's comments. You know
column3: I have spent my entire life advocating for women. I went to Beijing in 1995 and said that women's rights are human rights
column4: and I've done everything I can to make that principle come true.

column1: And
column2: specifically on issues
column3: I got to vote to raise the minimum wage.

column1: I put in legislation which said that Congress should not get a salary increase until they did raise the minimum wage
column2: and I am putting that back in
column3: because I agree that by the time we got it raised after 10 years
column4: it was already out of date.

column1: And as to women in poverty and women with health care needs
column2: I have been on the forefront of both advocating and creating change in my public service
column3: in my time in Arkansas
column4: the White House
column5: and now in the Senate.

column1: But I think it is terrific. We're up here arguing about who's going to be better for women
column2: because isn't that a nice change for everybody to hear.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
COOPER: Our next question is on a topic that got a lot of response from YouTube viewers. Let's watch.
QUESTION: Hi. My name is Mary.
QUESTION: And my name is Jen.
QUESTION: And we're from Brooklyn
column2: New York.

column1: If you were elected president of the United States
column2: would you allow us to be married to each other?

column1: COOPER: Congressman Kucinich?
KUCINICH: Mary and Jen
column2: the answer to your question is yes. And let me tell you why.

column1: Because if our Constitution really means what it says
column2: that all are created equal
column3: if it really means what it says
column4: that there should be equality of opportunity before the law
column5: then our brothers and sisters who happen to be gay
column6: lesbian
column7: bisexual or transgender should have the same rights accorded to them as anyone else
column8: and that includes the ability to have a civil marriage ceremony.

column1: Yes
column2: I support you. And welcome to a better and a new America under a President Kucinich administration.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
COOPER: Senator Dodd
column2: you supported the Defense of Marriage Act. What's your position?

column1: DODD: I've made the case
column2: Anderson
column3: that -- my wife and I have two young daughters
column4: age 5 and 2.

column1: I'd simply ask the audience to ask themselves the question that Jackie and I have asked: How would I want my two daughters treated if they grew up and had a different sexual orientation than their parents?
Good jobs
column2: equal opportunity
column3: to be able to retire
column4: to visit each other
column5: to be with each other
column6: as other people do.

column1: So I feel very strongly
column2: if you ask yourself the question
column3: ""How would you like your children treated if they had a different sexual orientation than their parents?
column4: the answer is yes. They ought to have that ability in civil unions.

column1: I don't go so far as to call for marriage. I believe marriage is between a man and a woman.
But my state of Connecticut
column2: the state of New Hampshire
column3: have endorsed civil unions. I strongly support that. But I don't go so far as marriage.

column1: COOPER: Governor Richardson?
RICHARDSON: Well
column2: I would say to the two young women
column3: I would level with you -- I would do what is achievable.

column1: What I think is achievable is full civil unions with full marriage rights. I would also press for you a hate crimes act in the Congress. I would eliminate ""don't ask/don't tell"" in the military.
(APPLAUSE)
If we're going to have in our military men and women that die for this country
column2: we shouldn't give them a lecture on their sexual orientation

column1: I would push for domestic partnership laws
column2: nondiscrimination in insurance and housing.

column1: I would also send a very strong message that
column2: in my administration
column3: I will not tolerate any discrimination on the basis of race
column4: gender
column5: or sexual orientation.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
COOPER: This next question is for Senator Edwards.
QUESTION: I'm Reverend Reggie Longcrier. I'm the pastor of Exodus Mission and Outreach Church in Hickory
column2: North Carolina.

column1: Senator Edwards said his opposition to gay marriage is influenced by his Southern Baptist background. Most Americans agree it was wrong and unconstitutional to use religion to justify slavery
column2: segregation
column3: and denying women the right to vote.

column1: So why is it still acceptable to use religion to deny gay American their full and equal rights?
(APPLAUSE)
EDWARDS: I think Reverend Longcrier asks a very important question
column2: which is whether fundamentally -- whether it's right for any of our faith beliefs to be imposed on the American people when we're president of the United States. I do not believe that's right.

column1: I feel enormous personal conflict about this issue. I want to end discrimination. I want to do some of the things that I just heard Bill Richardson talking about -- standing up for equal rights
column2: substantive rights
column3: civil unions
column4: the thing that Chris Dodd just talked about. But I think that's something everybody on this stage will commit themselves to as president of the United States.

column1: But I personally have been on a journey on this issue. I feel enormous conflict about it. As I think a lot of people know
column2: Elizabeth spoke -- my wife Elizabeth spoke out a few weeks ago
column3: and she actually supports gay marriage. I do not. But this is a very
column4: very difficult issue for me. And I recognize and have enormous respect for people who have a different view of it.

column1: COOPER: I should also point out that the reverend is actually in the audience tonight. Where is he? Right over here.
Reverend
column2: do you feel he answered your question?

column1: (APPLAUSE)
QUESTION: This question was just a catalyst that promoted some other things that wrapped around that particular question
column2: especially when it comes to fair housing practices. Also...

column1: COOPER: Do you think he answered the question
column2: though?

column1: QUESTION: Not like I would like to have heard it...
(LAUGHTER)
COOPER: What did you not hear?
QUESTION: I didn't quite get -- some people were moving around
column2: and I didn't quite get all of his answer. I just heard...

column1: COOPER: All right
column2: there's 30 seconds more. Why is it OK to quite religious beliefs when talking about why you don't support something? That's essentially what's his question.

column1: EDWARDS: It's not. I mean
column2: I've been asked a personal question which is
column3: I think
column4: what Reverend Longcrier is raising
column5: and that personal question is
column6: do I believe and do I personally support gay marriage?

column1: The honest answer to that is I don't. But I think it is absolutely wrong
column2: as president of the United States
column3: for me to have used that faith basis as a basis for denying anybody their rights
column4: and I will not do that when I'm president of the United States.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
COOPER: Senator Obama
column2: the laws banning interracial marriage in the United States were ruled unconstitutional in 1967. What is the difference between a ban on interracial marriage and a ban on gay marriage?

column1: OBAMA: Well
column2: I think that it is important to pick up on something that was said earlier by both Dennis and by Bill
column3: and that is that we've got to make sure that everybody is equal under the law. And the civil unions that I proposed would be equivalent in terms of making sure that all the rights that are conferred by the state are equal for same-sex couples as well as for heterosexual couples.

column1: Now
column2: with respect to marriage
column3: it's my belief that it's up to the individual denominations to make a decision as to whether they want to recognize marriage or not. But in terms of
column4: you know
column5: the rights of people to transfer property
column6: to have hospital visitation
column7: all those critical civil rights that are conferred by our government
column8: those should be equal.

column1: COOPER: We're going to take a quick break
column2: but before we go we're going to show another candidate video. This one is from the Clinton campaign. And then when we come back from the break
column3: we'll see one from the -- from Senator Edwards' campaign.

column1: (MUSIC PLAYED FROM CLINTON CAMPAIGN VIDEO)
(COMMERCIAL BREAK)
(MUSIC PLAYED FROM EDWARDS CAMPAIGN VIDEO)
COOPER: That was just one of the candidates' videos. If you're just joining us
column2: that's one of the candidate videos you're going to be seeing throughout the evening as we go to commercial breaks.

column1: Let's turn international now. We've got a lot of international questions. Let's listen.
QUESTION:"	0
317	"In his press conference on March 11
column3: President Barack Obama talked up U.S. oil production against a backdrop of rising prices at the pump.

column1: We need to continue to boost domestic production of oil and gas
column2: he said. ""Last year
column3: American oil production reached its highest level since 2003. Let me repeat that. Our oil production reached its highest level in seven years. Oil production from federal waters in the Gulf of Mexico reached an all-time high. For the first time in more than a decade
column4: imports accounted for less than half of what we consumed. So any notion that my administration has shut down oil production might make for a good political sound bite
column5: but it doesnÃ¢ÂÂt match up with reality

column1: In this item
column2: weÃ¢ÂÂll check the first piece of evidence to support his contention that his administration hasnÃ¢ÂÂt ""shut down"" oil production -- that ""last year
column3: American oil production reached its highest level since 2003.""

column1: We turned to the Energy Information Administration
column2: the federal governmentÃ¢ÂÂs official office for energy statistics. Since Obama said ""oil production
column3: we will only look at oil removed from U.S. territory
column4: rather than natural gas or other petroleum products.

column1: Here are the annual totals
column2: in barrels produced
column3: going back to 2003:

column1: So
column2: 2010 is definitely the highest since 2003. But weÃ¢ÂÂll note a couple of caveats.

column1: First
column2: production levels actually have been quite stable over the eight-year period. Comparing 2009 and 2010 statistics
column3: petroleum production only rose about 3 percent. And the level for 2010 is only 11 percent higher than for the lowest year in that eight-year period. So the increase the president is referring to is not particularly dramatic.

column1: The second caveat is that the Energy Information Administration projects that production totals are poised to fall from their current levels over the next two years.
Domestic crude oil production
column2: the agency says
column3: is projected to decline by 110
column4: 000 barrels a day in 2011 and by an additional 130
column5: 000 barrels per day in 2012. The agency makes that projection based on expected production declines in Alaska due to maturing oil fields. Production in the Gulf of Mexico is also projected to decline. Both are partially offset by projected increases in the Lower 48 states
column6: but on balance
column7: EIA sees the numbers falling.

column1: So Obama is right that American oil production is at its highest level since 2003
column2: but weÃ¢ÂÂre taking the statement down a notch on our rating scale because the amount is projected to fall during each of the next two years
column3: making it somewhat problematic to use the number as evidence that domestic oil production is on a healthy trendline. On balance
column4: we rate the statement Mostly True."	0

column1: 318	"Congressional Quarterly has studied the voting behavior of members of Congress since 1953 to assess how often lawmakers stick with members of their own caucus on votes when the two parties divide and how often they back the president on votes where he has a clear position. With Congress out of town until after the national conventions
column2: CQ's editors are digging into their votes database to compile expanded vote analysis packages for CQ.com.

column1: New! Partisanship and Presidential Support in the Bush Era

CQ has completed a study of all roll-call votes during the seven-and-a-half years of President Bush's two terms Ã¢ÂÂ up to Congress' August recess. It is a first-ever look at the way lawmakers voted over an entire presidency. It underscores the high level of Capitol Hill partisanship that has been a hallmark of the period
column2: and shows that while Republican support for President Bush was quite high
column3: Democratic support was almost nonexistent in the House and very limited in the Senate.

column1: The searchable table shows both party unity and presidential support scores over the entire Bush presidency for individual lawmakers who are currently serving in the 110th Congress. It also flags the races CQ Politics has determined will be competitive on Election Day.
How CQ Calculated the Bush Administration Scores | Previous CQ Weekly Coverage: Moderates Come Front and Center (July 28)"	0
319	"'This Week' Transcript: McKay
column2: Napolitano
column3: Salazar and Allen

column1: Transcript: ""This Week"" with Lamar McKay McKay
column2: Janet Napolitano
column3: Ken Salazar and Thad Allen

column1: TAPPER: Good morning. We'll get to our main story on the oil spill in a moment
column2: but first a breaking news from overnight. A car bomb discovered in New York's Times Square. Police cleared thousands of people from the streets after finding an SUV loaded with propane tanks
column3: gasoline
column4: black powder and a timing device
column5: the makings of what appeared to be a crude car bomb. The situation is now safe
column6: but joining me this morning is Secretary of Homeland Security Janet Napolitano. And Secretary Napolitano
column7: I just wanted to ask you a couple of questions about this.

column1: First of all
column2: I know that the federal government is treating this as a potential terrorist attack and that you have some evidence
column3: you're dusting for fingerprints. But this attempted attack resembles car bomb attempts in London and Scotland in 2007. How concerned are you that this is not an isolated incident?

column1: NAPOLITANO: Well
column2: right now
column3: we have no evidence that it is anything other than a one-off
column4: but we are alerting state
column5: local officials around the country
column6: letting them know what is going on. The forensics are being done. As leads evolve or develop
column7: they will all be tracked down. This is getting attention. FBI
column8: Department of Homeland Security
column9: New York City police
column10: everybody is on it.

column1: TAPPER: I got to think that Times Square is one of the most surveilled areas in the entire world. How close are we to finding a suspect?
NAPOLITANO: Well
column2: right now
column3: it is heavily surveilled
column4: and as you know
column5: there are cameras all over
column6: and so tape is being reviewed. But traditional forensics are being done in addition to that. Looking for fingerprints
column7: tracking down the vehicle
column8: the license plate number
column9: looking at the timer -- the (inaudible) of the explosive device. Right now it doesn't look like it's all a very sophisticated one
column10: quite frankly
column11: but looking into that. So there is a lot of work that's being done
column12: and then of course other intel being developed
column13: and that will evolve as the day goes on.

column1: TAPPER: How concerned should the American people be?
NAPOLITANO: Well
column2: Times Square I think is now safe
column3: and I believe that right now
column4: we have no information other than it is a one-off. But nonetheless
column5: we are alerting state and local law enforcement
column6: everybody to be on their toes.

column1: TAPPER: OK
column2: great. We'll come back to you and other Obama administration officials in a second. Right now
column3: we're going to turn to our main interview
column4: and that is the President Obama is heading down to the Gulf Coast this morning for his own assessment of the oil spill
column5: a massive slick almost the size of Connecticut. It's making its way to the Louisiana coast
column6: threatening wild life
column7: the environment and the economic livelihood of residents there. Meanwhile
column8: efforts to plug the gush almost a mile below the surface have failed.

column1: Joining me now for an exclusive interview is Lamar McKay
column2: chairman and president of BP America
column3: which owned the well and was leasing the rig that blew up. He joins us from company headquarters in Houston. Mr. McKay
column4: thanks for joining us
column5: and first of all
column6: our condolences to the families of the workers who lost their lives.

column1: MCKAY: Thank you
column2: Jake
column3: and thank you for the opportunity to be here today. This has been a tragic event. As you mentioned
column4: we had 11 people lose their lives. We've had people seriously injured
column5: and we've got an event of enormous proportion that we're dealing with.

column1: TAPPER: OK
column2: BP's plans to stop this leak include an underwater dome that you're trying to build to contain the leak
column3: and a whole other rig to drill a relief well
column4: what is the latest on the situation? The relief well could take up to three months to drill. Where are we in this process?

column1: MCKAY: Jake
column2: let me explain for your viewers exactly what's going on. We've got effectively three fronts of attack that we are aggressively pursuing in partnership with the government. One is effectively stopping the source
column3: stopping the well from flowing. The second one is as -- and these are in parallel -- is to work a containment system
column4: a collection system sub-sea to be able to effectively channel the flow up a pipe and into a processing system that we can control at the surface. Then the third is dealing aggressively
column5: aggressively with the spill offshore and trying to fight that spill offshore
column6: and the fourth is to deal with the -- deal with the
column7: if the oil touches the shore
column8: to deal with the cleanup and deal with the impacts on shore. Those are sorts of the fronts that are under way.

column1: You mentioned the containment system. We call it the containment dome. That has been fabricated. The engineering is being finalized to get that mobilized and deployed. That will probably be in six to eight days
column2: we'll have that deployed.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: just so you know
column3: we're still working hard
column4: still working hard on the blowout preventer and see if we can actuate this piece of evidently failed equipment. And as you can imagine
column5: this is like doing open-heart surgery at 5
column6: 000 feet
column7: with -- in the dark
column8: with robot-controlled submarines.

column1: TAPPER: The government says currently 5
column2: 000 barrels of oil a day are spilling into the gulf. Some experts say it might be five times that
column4: 000 barrels of oil a day. How much oil do you think is spilling into the gulf?

column1: MCKAY: Well
column2: the estimates of how much oil is coming out are very difficult because you can't measure in any way accurately
column3: so effectively what we're doing with the help of NOAA and the rest of the government agencies is understand that volume that is inferred essentially by surface expression on the top of the water. So I don't know the volume. The volume uncertainty -- there is a large uncertainty range around the 5
column4: 000 barrels.

column1: Our spill response is designed to take that uncertainty into account
column2: and we're responding for that full range of uncertainty with all the resources that we can
column3: in conjunction with the government.

column1: TAPPER: Obama administration officials have expressed in recent days concerns that BP is not doing enough. Other officials have said that you don't have the resources. Should the government take over this operation?
MCKAY: I think we're
column2: as we said from day one
column3: we're throwing every resource that we've got at this
column4: and this is now an industry effort. It's not just a BP effort. It's an effort in conjunction with the government. And I think the partnership that we've got between industry and the government has rallied an effort that is unprecedented in size
column5: and I think that that effort is actually working pretty well. It will continue to be flexed and expanded where it needs to
column6: and I think
column7: you know
column8: the point here is we are doing everything possible that we know of -- and I believe I'm talking about the collective we here -- to control the source first. That's our first priority. While in parallel
column9: fighting the thing offshore as far as -- as far as possible and as effectively as possible
column10: and then dealing with the cleanup and issues and impacts on shore should they occur.

column1: TAPPER: Your company
column2: BP
column3: has a spotty safety record
column4: most horrifically in 2005
column5: an explosion at a refinery in Texas that killed 15 workers; other incidents involving leaks have been blamed on cutting corners on financial reasons. How confident are you that this accident had nothing to do with cutting back on safety to save a buck?

column1: MCKAY: Well
column2: the investigations are going to show the cause of this accident
column3: and we want those investigations to be done. My belief that is that that does not have anything to do with it. I believe we've got a failed piece of equipment. We don't know why it failed yet in this contracted rig
column4: and BOP system will figure that out.

column1: But let me just tell you
column2: our focus
column3: our focus right now is dealing with the source of the oil
column4: dealing with it on the surface
column5: and dealing with it on the beach or the marsh if it occurs.

column1: TAPPER: Your initial filing to the government
column2: to the Mineral Management Service for 2009 before you drilled on this spot made this assessment
column3: quote
column4: ""An accidental oil spill could cause impact to the beaches. However
column5: due to the distance to shore
column6: 48 miles
column7: and the response capabilities that would be implemented
column8: no significant adverse impacts are expected. BP Exploration and Production Incorporated has the capability to respond to the maximum extent practicable to a worst-case discharge
column9: which you estimated at 300
column10: 000 gallons. It's less than that
column11: it's estimated to be 210
column13: and yet BP does not seem to have the capability to respond. How can the public trust BP's assessments of risk and how can the public trust anything you guys say?

column1: MCKAY: Well
column2: I think we are responding very
column3: very aggressively. As you may know
column4: we had a response planned
column5: filed for the drilling of this well that incorporates various capability around the Gulf Coast. That spill response plan was activated as soon as this event occurred. It has been extremely aggressive. It will continue to be extremely aggressive
column6: and I believe the response -- this is
column7: you know
column8: we must understand
column9: this is -- this is a very low likelihood but very high impact response -- sorry
column10: incident -- and the response is matching that incident.

column1: TAPPER: I just have a couple more questions. Just a few months ago
column2: a BP executive protested proposed new safety regulations for oil rigs
column3: writing to the government that quote
column4: ""while BP is supportive of companies having a system in place to reduce risks
column5: accidents
column6: injuries and spills
column7: we are not supportive of extensive proscriptive regulations."" Will BP continue to fight and lobby against safety regulations?

column1: MCKAY: Well
column2: I would characterize the letter you're talking about slightly differently. That letter was in response to the government's request for input on safety regulations that the MMS was looking at. The rest of the letter actually recommends improvements and specific recommendations around safety regulations should they choose to change them. So we're not fighting anything about safety. Safety is the number one priority. We're going to figure out what happened here
column3: and that is going to help the MMS and help ourselves and help the industry get safer
column4: so we're not fighting anything about safety.

column1: TAPPER: All right
column2: last question
column3: Mr. McKay. You had several fail/safe mechanisms on this rig
column4: and they all failed. Since you don't yet know what caused this accident
column5: will you stop all operations until you know? How can the American people trust that there won't be another explosion at another BP facility?

column1: MCKAY: Well
column2: we're working in conjunction with the government on understanding everything we can understand as quickly as we can. We're not going to do anything that we think is unsafe. We're doing extra tests on various pieces of equipment to make absolutely sure they will work in the condition they're intended to work in.

column1: We won't do any work if we don't think it can be carried out safely and without impact. But we are working very closely with the government in trying to understand this and see if there should be any changes quickly.
TAPPER: All right. Lamar McKay
column2: thank you so much for joining us. We really appreciate your time.

column1: MCKAY: Thank you.
TAPPER: And we're now joined by a powerhouse roundtable. As always
column2: George Will
column3: from the National Action Network
column4: the Reverend Al Sharpton
column5: from HBO's ""Real Time with Bill Maher
column6: Bill Maher
column7: former Bush adviser Matthew Dowd
column8: and Katrina vanden Heuvel from The Nation.

column1: Thanks
column2: one and all.

column1: George
column2: I've heard some conservative critics say that this oil slick is President Obama's Katrina. Is it?

column1: WILL: No. It might come as a news bulletin to the president himself
column2: but he's not responsible for everything
column3: and bad things happen. This is a reality check for a nation that's ravenous for energy and has to be and always has been. Getting our sources of energy has risks.

column1: The Exxon Valdez called our attention to the fact that it's very dangerous shipping oil across the surface of the ocean. Since the Exxon Valdez
column2: there have been seven larger tanker spills. You can go up to West Virginia
column3: where 29 miners are being mourned today
column4: and they will tell you about the risks of mining coal. No one says stop mining coal because of this.

column1: TAPPER: Reverend
column2: some critics -- not just from the right -- are saying that the Obama administration was slow. The New York Times editorial board faulted the Obama administration. Is that unfair criticism?

column1: SHARPTON: Well
column2: I think so. I think that when you look at the fact that
column3: first of all
column4: this has been an evolving crisis -- this did not happen -- unlike Katrina
column5: where you had a natural disaster that immediately blanketed the whole area and we were watching it live on television
column6: this got worse over time.

column1: And I think that there's evidence that the White House has put out -- I've not talked to them
column2: but I've read this on their Web site -- of how they met each rising crisis with personnel there
column3: cabinet members there
column4: now the president going
column5: unlike George Bush
column6: that said he didn't see the crisis
column7: and we sat there four or five days and watched it live on television. So I think any analogy is absolutely ridiculous.

column1: TAPPER: Bill
column2: I was watching your show Friday night...

column1: MAHER: Morning.
TAPPER: ... and you said
column2: in language more suitable for premium cable...

column1: MAHER: I promise I won't here. They're so nervous about that.
TAPPER: ... that you're surprised President Obama isn't getting more
column2: shall we say
column3: guff for...

column1: MAHER: Exactly.
TAPPER: ... for this crisis.
MAHER: Yes
column2: I think he should. You know
column3: he owns this issue now
column4: because it was only a few weeks ago that he came out for offshore drilling. And I would say philosophically this is -- you know
column5: the problem
column6: I think
column7: a lot of people on the left have with this country and have for many years
column8: is that there's no one who really represents our point of view.

column1: There's two parties who want to fight the war on terror with an army in Afghanistan. There's two parties who want to drill offshore. Where is the other side on this?
So
column2: you know
column3: I could certainly criticize oil companies
column4: and I could criticize America in general for not attacking this problem in the '70s. I mean
column5: Brazil got off oil in the last 30 years. We certainly could have.

column1: But it is very disappointing
column2: I think
column3: for this president to be taking a position
column4: as he had -- and I guess he's backpedaling now on it
column5: I hope. I mean
column6: I hope there's a flip-flop I can believe in there. But...

column1: TAPPER: There's a slogan for you
column2: flip-flops I can believe in.

column1: MAHER: I could believe in that one
column2: and I hope he does.

column1: TAPPER: Matt
column2: where's the public on this issue?

column1: DOWD: Well
column2: I think the public -- I mean
column3: first of all
column4: the public doesn't think there's any equal nature to Katrina and this. I mean
column5: Katrina
column6: obviously
column7: evacuated -- having to evacuate an entire area and what that issue was
column8: was such a different issue than this.

column1: But I think where the public is on this
column2: if you put this in the context of what happened in West Virginia and the mine disaster and this in context of Katrina
column3: even though it was different
column4: and this in context in many things
column5: I think the public sits there and says
column6: ""Who's in charge? Who is accountable
column7: and who can -- what governmental entity can actually be effective in doing anything?""

column1: And I think that ultimately is where the public is. It's just another example of a fact that we cannot trust the government to do anything that we need them to do
column2: from mines to even a belief (ph) on health care to -- to the oil spill. It's a loss of faith
column3: I think
column4: again
column5: in the government.

column1: VANDEN HEUVEL: What we've seen are the risks are too great. Offshore drilling is the problem
column2: not the solution. This is not Katrina
column4: 500 dead
column5: hundreds of thousands homeless.

column1: I think more important is to understand that we now need a government that is going to regulate a company
column2: BP
column3: which was a serial abuser of workers and of safety regulations. Just like Massey
column4: we need regulations...

column1: TAPPER: Massey
column2: with the -- with the West Virginia mine.

column1: VANDEN HEUVEL: ... tough enforcement -- the mines -- we need a government that understands that. I would also point out that this was the week that for the first time an offshore wind farm was approved. And George Will may not see a future in that
column2: but I believe we need a Manhattan Project
column3: an Apollo Alliance to ramp up public and private investment.

column1: At the moment
column2: energy companies spend 0.25 percent on R&D. We can do better. We are a nation which should do better
column3: George
column4: and not rely on dirty energy
column5: which just compounds the problem affecting this country and the planet.

column1: TAPPER: Mr. Will
column2: your name has been invoked.

column1: WILL: Well
column2: one in five steps of an approval process has now been taken for the wind farm
column3: vigorously opposed by people who are all in favor of renewable energy elsewhere
column4: because they think it'll spoil their view.

column1: TAPPER: This is the wind farm off the coast of Massachusetts that a lot of people...
WILL: The wind farm on Cape Cod
column2: yes.

column1: TAPPER: ... including the Kennedy family
column2: were fighting tooth and nail.

column1: WILL: Right. And -- and
column2: by the way
column3: wind farms kill a lot more birds daily than are probably going to be killed in this oil spill.

column1: And so -- but I'd like to go back to Bill. Could you just explain to me in what sense Brazil got off oil?
MAHER: I believe they did. I believe they
column2: in the '70s
column3: they had a program to use sugarcane ethanol. And I believe that is what fuels their country.

column1: WILL: I think they still burn a lot of oil and have a lot of it offshore.
VANDEN HEUVEL: But
column2: George
column3: you're a man who understands there are always alternatives in politics and in science. We can -- you know
column4: why should we be relying on what we are now seeing the risks of?

column1: And
column2: by the way
column3: we can do better with existing oil fields. We can get as much from existing oil fields
column4: which the oil companies for profit reasons aren't doing much with. So I just think we have seen the risks and we need to take action. It is just too much to look at what is going on in the gulf and what will happen if it moves into the Arctic.

column1: And I agree with Bill. I think President Obama was pandering when he moved to this offshore drilling stance. But I think this White House has the ability
column2: unlike previous White Houses
column3: to understand and see the light and take a different step.

column1: MAHER: And could we have judges fact-check this on Brazil? I don't know...
(CROSSTALK)
MAHER: ... dreamed that about Brazil.
(CROSSTALK)
MAHER: ... and Brazil
column2: let's get back to the United States. I think that Katrina's right. I think that there's a challenge here. And I think that the president and the country has to deal with the reality that we're facing.

column1: And I think that the reality is that usually it's not about who's going to speak for the left or right. It's
column2: who's going to be right on these issues? We see what can happen here. Now what do we do about it? And I think that
column3: clearly
column4: a failure to stand up and lead at this point is something that all of us would criticize.

column1: But I'm not convinced that this president won't. I think he's going down there
column2: he's going to reassess. And I think that we've got to see where that goes and if he goes
column3: right
column4: support him
column5: and I think he will.

column1: But I think to act like this is Katrina
column2: I think this is the step without -- beyond the realm of a sane discussion.

column1: TAPPER: OK. We're going to take a quick break and come back
column2: and the roundtable will discuss the far less controversial issue -- that's sarcastic -- about immigration law and Florida Governor Charlie Crist's declaration of independence. And later
column3: of course
column4: the Sunday funnies.

column1: (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
COLBERT: There is an impending environmental disaster looming right off our nation's fragile coastline. I'm speaking
column2: of course
column3: about the new wind farm off of Cape Cod. What if it breaks and we have a catastrophic wind spill?

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
(COMMERCIAL BREAK)
(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
(UNKNOWN): And if the feds won't come in and protect us
column2: then we will come forward and protect ourselves. We -- we have no other choice. We have -- we have a right
column3: Greta
column4: to feel free in our state and to feel safe. And with what's going on
column5: we have many
column6: many people that feel that they are not safe.

column1: (UNKNOWN): Si se puede! Si se puede! Si se puede!
OBAMA: If you are a Hispanic American in Arizona
column2: if you don't have your papers and you took your kid out to get ice cream
column3: you're going to be harassed
column4: that's something that could potentially happen
column5: that's not the right way to go.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
TAPPER: And we're back with our roundtable. As always
column2: George Will
column3: the Reverend Al Sharpton from the National Action Network
column4: the host of HBO's ""Real Time with Bill Maher
column5: Bill Maher
column6: Matthew Dowd
column7: former Bush adviser
column8: and Katrina vanden Heuvel of The Nation.

column1: Reverend Sharpton
column2: I want to start with you. You're going to be participating in leading a march and a rally and a vigil in Arizona on Wednesday to protest this immigration reform law. What do you think the citizens of Arizona should do with the fact that there is this big illegal immigration problem?

column1: SHARPTON: Well
column2: first of all
column3: I think we need to have real immigration reform from a federal level. The federal government is supposed to set immigration policy
column4: and I think that all of our forces ought to really try to put the pressure there
column5: which is something all of us advocated doing the last two general elections.

column1: To try and now say that because that has not happened -- and all of us agree it should -- that we're now going to have state law and open the door to racial profiling is what we're objecting to and protesting on Wednesday and have said since the law was signed Friday before last.
And this
column2: unlike many of the critics of those of us that protest this
column3: this is not about protecting illegal immigrants. This is about protecting legal citizens. If you are Hispanic or thought to be Hispanic in the state of Arizona
column4: you can be faced (ph) and subjected to an harassment that other citizens should not. That's a violation of equal protection under the law.

column1: We would not tolerate that to people that look like George if this was a law saying we're looking for people that look Canadian in the state of Vermont. That would be racial profiling.
Citizens that are here
column2: that have -- that have not broken any laws should not be subjected to anything different than any other citizens. It's not about illegal immigrants. It's about legal Latino citizens that should not be targeted
column3: and this law does that.

column1: TAPPER: Matthew?
DOWD: To me
column2: Arizona is a sideshow
column3: and it's symptomatic of a bigger problem. And I don't think this is about the Arizona law. This is about people in a state -- and it's out going on all over the country -- that they see a federal government that's unwilling to enforce a law that's already on the books.

column1: There is an immigration law on the books. It is illegal to come into this country. Arizona for years and years and years
column2: including under the previous guest
column3: Governor Napolitano
column4: has asked the federal government to enforce the law
column5: which they refuse to do in this -- in this context.

column1: So it's not about a new law passed. It's about a state says that we think the federal government should enforce the law. They're not enforcing the law
column2: so we're going to enforce the law.

column1: I don't think it's the right response. I think we need the federal government to step up and actually perform an immigration policy. But it's not about Arizona.
(CROSSTALK)
SHARPTON: The federal law...
TAPPER: Reverend Sharpton...
(CROSSTALK)
SHARPTON: ... does not say that
column2: based on reasonable suspicion of the police
column3: they can go after someone which targets people that are Latino
column4: since you're dealing with a problem with Mexicans coming across the border. The federal law does not say that
column5: does not target that. We agree the federal laws should be looked at
column6: reformed
column7: and enforced
column8: but to say that you're going to sacrifice the civil rights of Latinos and people of color because the federal government has not moved forward
column9: I think
column10: is very irresponsible.

column1: TAPPER: George?
WILL: The Arizona law does not say that there should be racial profiling. And let me tell you what the...
(CROSSTALK)
SHARPTON: Well
column2: then why did they just reform it over the weekend...

column1: (CROSSTALK)

WILL: Let me tell you what the federal law says. ""Every alien 18 years of age and older shall at all times carry with him and have in his personal possession a certificate of alien registration or alien registration receipt card issued to him."" That's been federal law for 58 years.
All that Arizona has done is say we at the state level are going to reinforce the federal law. This is legal. In 2008
column2: the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals
column3: the most liberal circuit court in this country
column4: affirmed the constitutionality of an Arizona law that made it a state crime for employers to hire illegal immigrants. This is not bizarre behavior on Arizona's part.

column1: SHARPTON: The state law does not say -- the state law says that a policeman
column2: under reasonable suspicion -- it did not -- it does not say that in the federal law -- can go and make someone produce and document their citizenship. It does not say what you just read...

column1: (CROSSTALK)
SHARPTON: With all due respect
column2: Mr. Will
column3: that is not what that federal law says. And the recognition of that is the state of Arizona's legislature just refined what they said over the weekend. They conceited that we were right and they had to refine it.

column1: (CROSSTALK)
WILL: ... 50 years of case law refining the concept of reasonable suspicion. This is not a blank slate
column2: Reverend.

column1: VANDEN HEUVEL: Mr. Will
column2: why is the law enforcement community in Arizona so deeply divided? I find that an interesting problem.

column1: SHARPTON: Absolutely.
VANDEN HEUVEL: You have police chiefs who believe that this will endanger the public safety and security of the state and its citizens. You also have -- these are pragmatic
column2: not moral reasons
column3: even though this bill is state-sanctioned racial profiling and draconian
column4: ugly
column5: mean-spirited -- but you have a $3 billion budget deficit in Arizona. This may well loot that state's treasury as they fight this bill.

column1: You're going to have economic boycotts
column2: which you disagree with
column3: but you're going to have them
column4: as you had them to push that state to respect Martin Luther King holiday.

column1: And finally
column2: you have a situation where the crime rates in Arizona have declined over this last decade
column3: and you have a border guard which has tripled since 2004. The budget has increased money for security. I personally think the security piece is overstated. You want to ensure an orderly flow of people and goods. But you need a humane pathway to citizenship.

column1: TAPPER: Bill
column2: what do you say to Arizona's citizens who are frustrated with the federal government
column3: the law is not being enforced
column4: there is an influx of illegal immigrants -- some of them
column5: obviously not all of them
column6: but some of them are involved in crimes -- what are they supposed to do?

column1: MAHER: Well
column2: I would hope the Constitution of the country is a little more important to them. I know that's asking a lot.

column1: WILL: What constitutional provision does this violate?
MAHER: Well
column2: I mean
column3: nobody's been able to articulate a scenario where the police are stopping people for any other reason than they look Mexican and poor. You know
column4: it kind of reminds me of -- what
column5: was it Potter Stewart on the Supreme Court said about pornography
column6: ""I know it when I see it""? That seems to be the standard the police are now using with immigration.

column1: TAPPER: I think what...
SHARPTON: There's something called equal protection under the law.
(CROSSTALK)
TAPPER: The law has -- the law has -- to be fair to Governor Jan Brewer of Arizona
column2: she signed an executive order the same day that she signed a law that said that a person's race alone cannot be enough to be reasonable suspicion. There needs to be more than...

column1: SHARPTON: And now she's come back this weekend with something else. So are we going to keep redoing it? I think you'd have to concede that had this not been raised and these protests had not -- they would not themselves be now doing the moonwalk against their own bill.
DOWD: Jake
column2: I think the situation is -- we keep falling back into an Arizona problem. The majority of the country...

column1: (CROSSTALK)
SHARPTON: People in Arizona have an Arizona problem.
DOWD: No
column2: the people of this country have an immigration problem.

column1: SHARPTON: I agree.
DOWD: The majority of this country supports what Arizona did
column2: the majority of the country. And two-thirds of people in Arizona support this. Do I think that the Arizona response is the right thing? No. But do I think that it represents a frustration with the federal government
column3: just like what's going on in Wall Street -- the people of this country see Washington -- Democrats and Republicans -- complicit in what we do.

column1: We don't enforce the laws on Wall Street
column2: so we have a huge problem there. We don't enforce the immigration laws
column3: so states like Arizona react in this way
column4: which I don't think is actually reasonable. But I -- it's reasonable for them to be frustrated with the problem.

column1: TAPPER: Bill?
MAHER: The government intrusion
column2: you know
column3: government power is something that really bothers conservatives
column4: unless it's directed toward people who aren't white. You know
column5: I mean
column6: it does seem like there's some of that going on there. I mean...

column1: (CROSSTALK)
TAPPER: Let me just interject. To be fair to conservatives
column2: Virginia Governor Bob McDonnell
column3: a conservative Republican
column4: and Florida Congressman Connie Mack have had some tough words about parts of this law. Here's McDonnell on Tuesday.

column1: (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MCDONNELL: I'm concerned about the whole idea of carrying papers and always have to be able to prove your citizenship. That brings up shades of some other regimes that were not particularly helpful to democracy and civil rights.
(END VIDEO CLIP)
TAPPER: And Florida Congressman Connie Mack said in a press release
column2: ""This law of frontier justice
column3: where law enforcement officials are required to stop anyone based on reasonable suspicion that they may be in the country illegally
column4: is reminiscent of a time during World War II when the Gestapo in Germany stopped people on the street and asked for their papers without probable cause.""

column1: George
column2: these are conservative Republicans
column3: very -- I mean
column4: nobody would question Bob McDonnell's bona fides as a conservative. And they are voicing serious concern about this law.

column1: WILL: Yes. To enter Mr. McDonnell's Capitol building or to enter the House office building where Connie Mack works
column2: you have to show a government-issued ID. I mean
column3: this is -- this is synthetic hysteria by a herd of independent minds called our political class right now that has decided to stand up and worry about the Constitution being shredded by measures that have ample history of being sustained against constitutional challenges.

column1: Now
column2: Mr. Maher just said
column3: if I heard him right
column4: that conservatives basically are racists and they like government intrusion only against people who aren't white. I mean
column5: that's the level...

column1: (CROSSTALK)
TAPPER: We'll come to you in one second...
(CROSSTALK)
MAHER: Can you -- can you imagine if some of the -- what's going on with the Tea Party rallies
column2: if they were a group of black people
column3: you know
column4: waving guns
column5: coming up armed
column6: talking about how you might -- you know
column7: hinting about how you might have to take matters into your own hands if the government doesn't do what you want? Do you think the reaction in this country would be...

column1: (CROSSTALK)
SHARPTON: ... very important point that needs to be addressed. When you say
column2: Mr. Will
column3: that if you go to Mr. McDonnell's building or Congressman Mack's building
column4: you have to show ID
column5: that is the point. Everyone has to show ID. They do not have guards stand there and say
column6: ""Only you that I deem to be reasonably suspect because I think you come from a particular group that may be entering the building to do harm
column7: we're going to search you."" Everyone is searched.

column1: This is not the case in the Arizona law. This is not the case of what's going on in the raids with Sheriff Arpaio there. And this is not what we're protesting. If everyone was subjected to that
column2: like the buildings you referred to
column3: there would be no cause for concern.

column1: VANDEN HEUVEL: And for George to talk about synthetic hysteria
column2: I mean
column3: your colleague at the Washington Post
column4: Michael Gerson
column5: took serious issue with the column you wrote underneath
column6: saying that this issue is going to sort Republicans and conservatives politically
column7: morally.

column1: I think Latino-bashing

322	HOUSTON
column2: TEXAS Ã¢ÂÂ Anti-apartheid and human rights activist Archbishop Desmond Tutu has died in Texas at the age of 86.

column1: His wife Leah Tutu told reporters that the couple were in Texas for holiday and had plans of greeting George H.W Bush who lost his wife few days ago.
According to Leah Tutu
column2: Desmond Tutu was rushed to hospital in the wee hours of Saturday morning where he passed on. The cause of his death is not immediately known.

column1: In August 2016
column2: TutuÃ¢ÂÂs daughter Thandeka Tutu-Gxashe he was in the hospital for treatment of a recurring infection.

column1: Zimbabwean leader Robert Mugabe may have described him as Ã¢ÂÂevilÃ¢ÂÂ
column2: but Archbishop Desmond Tutu remained a much-loved figure across the world Ã¢ÂÂ principally for his role in South AfricaÃ¢ÂÂs struggle against apartheid.

column1: During the long years that Nelson Mandela was in prison
column2: Archbishop Tutu spoke out against the regime Ã¢ÂÂ and won the Nobel peace prize in 1984 for his efforts.

column1: He was chosen by President Mandela to chair South AfricaÃ¢ÂÂs Truth and Reconciliation Commission and investigate the crimes committed by all sides during the apartheid regime.
Before his demise
column2: Ã¢ÂÂthe ArchÃ¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ as he was known Ã¢ÂÂ had remained irrepressible and influential both in his native South Africa and on the global political stage.

column1: He was chairman of a group of former world leaders called The Elders
column2: launched on Nelson MandelaÃ¢ÂÂs 89th birthday in 2007 with the aim of tackling some of the worldÃ¢ÂÂs most pressing problems.

column1: 324	"The full text of the op-ed by President Barack Obama is printed below. The piece was published today in Newsweek.
President Obama Reflects on the Impact of Title IX
By President Obama
Coaching my daughter SashaÃ¢ÂÂs basketball team is one of those times when I just get to be Ã¢ÂÂDad.Ã¢ÂÂ I snag rebounds
column2: run drills
column3: and have a little fun. More importantly
column4: I get to watch Sasha and her teammates improve together
column5: start thinking like a team
column6: and develop self-confidence.

column1: Any parent knows there are few things more fulfilling than watching your child discover a passion for something. And as a parent
column2: youÃ¢ÂÂll do anything to make sure he or she grows up believing she can take that ambition as far as she wants; that your child will embrace that quintessentially American idea that she can go as far as her talents will take her.

column1: But it wasnÃ¢ÂÂt so long ago that something like pursuing varsity sports was an unlikely dream for young women in America. Their teams often made do with second-rate facilities
column2: hand-me-down uniforms
column3: and next to no funding.

column1: What changed? Well
column2: 40 years ago
column3: committed women from around the country
column4: driven by everyone who said they couldnÃ¢ÂÂt do something
column5: worked with Congress to ban gender discrimination in our public schools. Title IX was the result of their efforts
column6: and this week
column7: we celebrated its 40th anniversaryÃ¢ÂÂ40 years of ensuring equal education
column8: in and out of the classroom
column9: regardless of gender.

column1: I was reminded of this milestone last month
column2: when I awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom to Pat Summitt. When she started out as a basketball coach
column3: Pat drove the team van to away games. She washed the uniforms in her own washing machine. One night she and her team even camped out in an opponentÃ¢ÂÂs gym because they had no funding for a hotel. But she and her players kept their chins up and their heads in the game. And in 38 years at the University of Tennessee
column4: Pat won eight national championships and tallied more than 1
column5: 000 winsÃ¢ÂÂthe most by any college coach
column6: man or woman. More important
column7: every single woman who ever played for Pat has either graduated or is on her way to a degree.

column1: Today
column2: thanks in no small part to the confidence and determination they developed through competitive sports and the work ethic they learned with their teammates
column3: girls who play sports are more likely to excel in school. In fact
column4: more women as a whole now graduate from college than men. This is a great accomplishmentÃ¢ÂÂnot just for one sport or one college or even just for women but for America. And this is what Title IX is all about.

column1: LetÃ¢ÂÂs not forget
column2: Title IX isnÃ¢ÂÂt just about sports. From addressing inequality in math and science education to preventing sexual assault on campus to fairly funding athletic programs
column3: Title IX ensures equality for our young people in every aspect of their education. ItÃ¢ÂÂs a springboard for success: itÃ¢ÂÂs thanks in part to legislation like Title IX that more women graduate from college prepared to work in a much broader range of fields
column4: including engineering and technology. IÃ¢ÂÂve said that women will shape the destiny of this country
column5: and I mean it. The more confident
column6: empowered women who enter our boardrooms and courtrooms
column7: legislatures
column8: and hospitals
column9: the stronger we become as a country.

column1: And that is what we are seeing today. Women are not just taking a seat at the table or sitting at the head of it
column2: they are creating success on their own terms. The women who grew up with Title IX now pioneer scientific breakthroughs
column3: run thriving businesses
column4: govern states
column5: and
column6: yes
column7: coach varsity teams. Because they do
column8: todayÃ¢ÂÂs young women grow up hearing fewer voices that tell them Ã¢ÂÂYou canÃ¢ÂÂt
column9: Ã¢ÂÂ and more voices that tell them Ã¢ÂÂYou can.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: We have come so far. But thereÃ¢ÂÂs so much farther we can go. There are always more barriers we can break and more progress we can make. As president
column2: IÃ¢ÂÂll do my part to keep Title IX strong and vibrant
column3: and maintain our schools as doorways of opportunity so every child has a fair shot at success. And as a dad
column4: IÃ¢ÂÂll do whatever it takes to make sure that this country remains the place where
column5: no matter who you are or what you look like
column6: you can make it if you try."	0

column1: 325	"CBO and the staff of the Joint Committee on Taxation (JCT) have estimated the direct spending and revenue effects of H.R. 6079
column2: the Repeal of Obamacare Act
column3: as passed by the House of Representatives on July 11
column4: 2012. H.R. 6079 would repeal the Affordable Care Act (ACA)
column5: with the exception of one subsection that has no budgetary effect. This estimate reflects the spending and revenue projections in CBOÃ¢ÂÂs March 2012 baseline as adjusted to take into account the effects of the recent Supreme Court decision regarding the ACA.

column1: For various reasons discussed in the report
column2: the estimated budgetary effects of repealing the ACA by enacting H.R. 6079 are close to
column3: but not equivalent to
column4: an estimate of the budgetary effects of the ACA with the signs reversed.

column1: What Is the Impact of Repealing the ACA on the Federal Budget?
Assuming that H.R. 6079 is enacted near the beginning of fiscal year 2013
column2: CBO and JCT estimate that
column3: on balance
column4: the direct spending and revenue effects of enacting that legislation would cause a net increase in federal budget deficits of $109 billion over the 2013Ã¢ÂÂ2022 period. Specifically
column5: we estimate that H.R. 6079 would reduce direct spending by $890 billion and reduce revenues by $1 trillion between 2013 and 2022
column6: thus adding $109 billion to federal budget deficits over that period.

column1: What Major Components Result in the Net Increase in Deficits?

Deficits would be increased under H.R. 6079 because the net savings from eliminating the insurance coverage provisions would be more than offset by the combination of other spending increases and revenue reductions:
The ACA contains a set of provisions designed to expand health insurance coverage
column2: which
column3: on net
column4: are projected to cost the government money. The costs of those coverage expansionsÃ¢ÂÂwhich include the cost of the subsidies to be provided through the exchanges
column5: increased outlays for Medicaid and the ChildrenÃ¢ÂÂs Health Insurance Program (CHIP)
column6: and tax credits for certain small employersÃ¢ÂÂwill be partially offset by penalty payments from employers and uninsured individuals
column7: revenues from the excise tax on high-premium insurance plans
column8: and net savings from other coverage-related effects. By repealing those coverage provisions of the ACA
column9: over the 2013Ã¢ÂÂ2022 period
column10: H.R. 6079 would yield gross savings of an estimated $1
column11: 677 billion and net savings (after accounting for the offsets just mentioned) of $1
column12: 171 billion.

column1: The ACA also includes a number of other provisions related to health care that are estimated to reduce net federal outlays (primarily for Medicare). By repealing those provisions
column2: H.R. 6079 would increase other direct spending in the next decade by an estimated $711 billion.

column1: The ACA includes a number of provisions that are estimated to increase federal revenues (apart from the effect of provisions related to insurance coverage)
column2: mostly by increasing the Hospital Insurance (HI) payroll tax and extending it to net investment income for high- income taxpayers
column3: and imposing fees or excise taxes on certain manufacturers and insurers. Repealing those provisions would reduce revenues by an estimated $569 billion over the 2013Ã¢ÂÂ2022 period.

column1: What Would be the Effect of Repealing the ACA on Discretionary Spending?
In addition to those effects on direct spending and revenues
column2: by CBOÃ¢ÂÂs estimates
column3: repeal of the ACA would reduce the need for appropriations to the Internal Revenue Service by between $5 billion and $10 billion over 10 years. Repealing the ACA would also reduce the need for appropriations to the Department of Health and Human Services by between $5 billion and $10 billion over 10 years
column4: CBO estimates. Such savings might be reflected in reductions in total discretionary spending
column5: or they might free up room for additional spending for other purposes under the caps on discretionary appropriations that were established by the Budget Control Act of 2011. H.R. 6079 would also repeal a number of authorizations for appropriations
column6: which
column7: if left in place
column8: might or might not result in additional appropriations.

column1: Why Are These Estimates Uncertain?
Projections of the budgetary impact of H.R. 6079 are quite uncertain because they are based
column2: in large part
column3: on projections of the effects of the ACA
column4: which are themselves highly uncertain. Assessing the effects of making broad changes in the nationÃ¢ÂÂs health care and health insurance systems requires estimates of a broad array of technical
column5: behavioral
column6: and economic factors. Separating the incremental effects of the provisions in the ACA that affect spending for ongoing programs and revenue streams becomes more uncertain as the time since enactment grows. The recent Supreme Court decision that essentially made the expansion of the Medicaid program a state option has also increased the uncertainty of the estimates. However
column7: CBO and JCT
column8: in consultation with outside experts
column9: have devoted a great deal of care and effort to the analysis of health care legislation in the past few years
column10: and the agencies have strived to develop estimates that are in the middle of the distribution of possible outcomes."	0

column1: 326	"Supreme Court Case: Flemming vs. Nestor
Background to the Case:

The fact that workers contribute to the Social Security program's funding through a dedicated payroll tax establishes a unique connection between those tax payments and future benefits. More so than general federal income taxes can be said to establish ""rights"" to certain government services. This is often expressed in the idea that Social Security benefits are ""an earned right."" This is true enough in a moral and political sense. But like all federal entitlement programs
column2: Congress can change the rules regarding eligibility--and it has done so many times over the years. The rules can be made more generous
column3: or they can be made more restrictive. Benefits which are granted at one time can be withdrawn
column4: as for example with student benefits
column5: which were substantially scaled-back in the 1983 Amendments.

column1: There has been a temptation throughout the program's history for some people to suppose that their FICA payroll taxes entitle them to a benefit in a legal
column2: contractual sense. That is to say
column3: if a person makes FICA contributions over a number of years
column4: Congress cannot
column5: according to this reasoning
column6: change the rules in such a way that deprives a contributor of a promised future benefit. Under this reasoning
column7: benefits under Social Security could probably only be increased
column8: never decreased
column9: if the Act could be amended at all. Congress clearly had no such limitation in mind when crafting the law. Section 1104 of the 1935 Act
column10: entitled ""RESERVATION OF POWER
column11: specifically said: ""The right to alter
column12: amend
column13: or repeal any provision of this Act is hereby reserved to the Congress."" Even so
column14: some have thought that this reservation was in some way unconstitutional. This is the issue finally settled by Flemming v. Nestor.

column1: In this 1960 Supreme Court decision Nestor's denial of benefits was upheld even though he had contributed to the program for 19 years and was already receiving benefits. Under a 1954 law
column2: Social Security benefits were denied to persons deported for
column3: among other things
column4: having been a member of the Communist party. Accordingly
column5: Mr. Nestor's benefits were terminated. He appealed the termination arguing
column6: among other claims
column7: that promised Social Security benefits were a contract and that Congress could not renege on that contract. In its ruling
column8: the Court rejected this argument and established the principle that entitlement to Social Security benefits is not contractual right. Flemming V. Nestor Case Name: FLEMMING V. NESTOR 363 U.S. 603 NO. 54. ARGUED FEBRUARY 24
column9: 1960. - DECIDED JUNE 20
column11: REVERSED . THE TERMINATION OF OLD-AGE BENEFITS PAYABLE TO AN ALIEN WHO
column12: AFTER THE DATE OF ITS ENACTMENT (SEPTEMBER 1
column14: IS DEPORTED UNDER SEC. 241(A) OF THE IMMIGRATION AND NATIONALITY ACT ON ANY ONE OF CERTAIN GROUNDS SPECIFIED IN SEC. 202(N). APPELLEE
column15: AN ALIEN WHO HAD BECOME ELIGIBLE FOR OLD-AGE BENEFITS IN 1955
column16: WAS DEPORTED IN 1956
column17: PURSUANT TO SEC. 241(A) OF THE IMMIGRATION AND NATIONALITY ACT
