column326: IT DOES SAY THAT THE TERMINATION OF BENEFITS WOULD APPLY TO THOSE PERSONS WHO WERE ""DEPORTED FROM THE UNITED STATES BECAUSE OF ILLEGAL ENTRY
column329: AT 25. IT WAS EVIDENTLY THE THOUGHT THAT SUCH WAS THE SCOPE OF THE STATUTE RESULTING FROM ITS APPLICATION TO DEPORTATION UNDER THE 14 NAMED PARAGRAPHS OF SEC. 241(A) OF THE IMMIGRATION AND NATIONALITY ACT. ID.
column330: AT 77. (FN10) THE SENATE COMMITTEE REJECTED THE PROPOSAL FOR THE STATED REASON THAT IT HAD ""NOT HAD AN OPPORTUNITY TO GIVE SUFFICIENT STUDY TO ALL THE POSSIBLE IMPLICATIONS OF THIS PROVISION
column331: WHICH INVOLVES TERMINATION OF BENEFIT RIGHTS UNDER THE CONTRIBUTORY PROGRAM OF OLD-AGE AND SURVIVORS INSURANCE ... ."" S. REP. NO. 1987
column337: THE PROPOSAL WAS RESTORED IN MODIFIED FORM
column338: (FN11) AND AS MODIFIED WAS ENACTED AS SEC. 202(N). SEE H.R. CONF. REP. NO. 2679
column341: P. 18. APPELLEE ARGUES THAT THIS HISTORY DEMONSTRATES THAT CONGRESS WAS NOT CONCERNED WITH THE FACT OF A BENEFICIARY'S DEPORTATION - WHICH IT IS CLAIMED ALONE WOULD JUSTIFY THIS LEGISLATION AS BEING PURSUANT TO A POLICY RELEVANT TO REGULATION OF THE SOCIAL SECURITY SYSTEM - BUT THAT IT SOUGHT TO REACH CERTAIN GROUNDS FOR DEPORTATION
column342: THUS EVIDENCING A PUNITIVE INTENT. (FN12) IT IS IMPOSSIBLE TO FIND IN THE MEAGRE HISTORY THE UNMISTAKABLE EVIDENCE OF PUNITIVE INTENT WHICH
column344: IS REQUIRED BEFORE A CONGRESSIONAL ENACTMENT OF THIS KIND MAY BE STRUCK DOWN. EVEN WERE THAT HISTORY TO BE TAKEN AS EVIDENCING CONGRESS' CONCERN WITH THE GROUNDS
column347: WE DO NOT THINK THAT THIS
column349: WOULD SUFFICE TO ESTABLISH A PUNITIVE PURPOSE. THIS WOULD STILL BE A FAR CRY FROM THE SITUATIONS INVOLVED IN SUCH CASES AS CUMMINGS
column355: WHERE THE LEGISLATION WAS ON ITS FACE AIMED AT PARTICULAR INDIVIDUALS. THE LEGISLATIVE RECORD
column357: FALLS SHORT OF ANY PERSUASIVE SHOWING THAT CONGRESS WAS IN FACT CONCERNED ALONE WITH THE GROUNDS OF DEPORTATION. TO BE SURE CONGRESS DID NOT APPLY THE TERMINATION PROVISION TO ALL DEPORTEES. HOWEVER
column358: IT IS EVIDENT THAT NEITHER DID IT REST THE OPERATION OF THE STATUTE ON THE OCCURRENCE OF THE UNDERLYING ACT. THE FACT OF DEPORTATION ITSELF REMAINED AN ESSENTIAL CONDITION FOR LOSS OF BENEFITS
column359: AND EVEN IF A BENEFICIARY WERE SAVED FROM DEPORTATION ONLY THROUGH DISCRETIONARY SUSPENSION BY THE ATTORNEY GENERAL UNDER SEC. 244 OF THE IMMIGRATION AND NATIONALITY ACT (66 STAT. 214
column361: SEC. 202(N) WOULD NOT REACH HIM. MOREOVER
column362: THE GROUNDS FOR DEPORTATION REFERRED TO IN THE COMMITTEE REPORT EMBRACE THE GREAT MAJORITY OF THOSE DEPORTED
column363: AS IS EVIDENT FROM AN EXAMINATION OF THE FOUR OMITTED GROUNDS
column364: SUMMARIZED IN THE MARGIN. (FN13) INFERENCES DRAWN FROM THE OMISSION OF THOSE GROUNDS CANNOT ESTABLISH
column365: TO THE DEGREE OF CERTAINTY REQUIRED
column366: THAT CONGRESSIONAL CONCERN WAS WHOLLY WITH THE ACTS LEADING TO DEPORTATION
column367: AND NOT WITH THE FACT OF DEPORTATION. (FN14) TO HOLD OTHERWISE WOULD BE TO REST ON THE ""SLIGHT IMPLICATION AND VAGUE CONJECTURE"" AGAINST WHICH CHIEF JUSTICE MARSHALL WARNED. FLETCHER V. PECK
column369: AT 128. THE SAME ANSWER MUST BE MADE TO ARGUMENTS DRAWN FROM THE FAILURE OF CONGRESS TO APPLY SEC. 202(N) TO BENEFICIARIES VOLUNTARILY RESIDING ABROAD. BUT CF. SEC. 202(T)
column371: NOTE 5. CONGRESS MAY HAVE FAILED TO CONSIDER SUCH PERSONS; OR IT MAY HAVE THOUGHT THEIR NUMBER TOO SLIGHT
column372: OR THE PERMANENCE OF THEIR VOLUNTARY RESIDENCE ABROAD TOO UNCERTAIN
column373: TO WARRANT APPLICATION OF THE STATUTE TO THEM
column374: WITH ITS ATTENDANT ADMINISTRATIVE PROBLEMS OF SUPERVISION AND ENFORCEMENT. AGAIN
column375: WE CANNOT WITH CONFIDENCE REJECT ALL THOSE ALTERNATIVES WHICH IMAGINATIVENESS CAN BRING TO MIND
column376: SAVE THAT ONE WHICH MIGHT REQUIRE THE INVALIDATION OF THE STATUTE. REVERSED. FOOTNOTES Footnote 1- SECTION 202(N) PROVIDES AS FOLLOWS: ""(N)(1) IF ANY INDIVIDUAL IS (AFTER THE DATE OF ENACTMENT OF THIS SUBSECTION) DEPORTED UNDER PARAGRAPH (1)
column389: OR (18) OF SECTION 241(A) OF THE IMMIGRATION AND NATIONALITY ACT
column391: NOTWITHSTANDING ANY OTHER PROVISIONS OF THIS TITLE: ""(A) NO MONTHLY BENEFIT UNDER THIS SECTION OR SECTION 223 (42 U.S.C. SEC. 423
column392: RELATING TO ""DISABILITY INSURANCE BENEFITS"") SHALL BE PAID TO SUCH INDIVIDUAL
column393: ON THE BASIS OF HIS WAGES AND SELF-EMPLOYMENT INCOME
column394: FOR ANY MONTH OCCURRING (I) AFTER THE MONTH IN WHICH THE SECRETARY IS NOTIFIED BY THE ATTORNEY GENERAL THAT SUCH INDIVIDUAL HAS BEEN SO DEPORTED
column395: AND (II) BEFORE THE MONTH IN WHICH SUCH INDIVIDUAL IS THEREAFTER LAWFULLY ADMITTED TO THE UNITED STATES FOR PERMANENT RESIDENCE: ""(B) IF NO BENEFIT COULD BE PAID TO SUCH INDIVIDUAL (OR IF NO BENEFIT COULD BE PAID TO HIM IF HE WERE ALIVE) FOR ANY MONTH BY REASON OF SUBPARAGRAPH (A)
column396: NO MONTHLY BENEFIT UNDER THIS SECTION SHALL BE PAID
column397: ON THE BASIS OF HIS WAGES AND SELF-EMPLOYMENT INCOME
column398: FOR SUCH MONTH TO ANY OTHER PERSON WHO IS NOT A CITIZEN OF THE UNITED STATES AND IS OUTSIDE THE UNITED STATES FOR ANY PART OF SUCH MONTH
column399: AND: ""(C) NO LUMP-SUM DEATH PAYMENT SHALL BE MADE ON THE BASIS OF SUCH INDIVIDUAL'S WAGES AND SELF-EMPLOYMENT INCOME IF HE DIES (I) IN OR AFTER THE MONTH IN WHICH SUCH NOTICE IS RECEIVED
column400: AND (II) BEFORE THE MONTH IN WHICH HE IS THEREAFTER LAWFULLY ADMITTED TO THE UNITED STATES FOR PERMANENT RESIDENCE. ""SECTION 203(B) AND (C) OF THIS ACT SHALL NOT APPLY WITH RESPECT TO ANY SUCH INDIVIDUAL FOR ANY MONTH FOR WHICH NO MONTHLY BENEFIT MAY BE PAID TO HIM BY REASON OF THIS PARAGRAPH. ""(2) AS SOON AS PRACTICABLE AFTER THE DEPORTATION OF ANY INDIVIDUAL UNDER ANY OF THE PARAGRAPHS OF SECTION 241(A) OF THE IMMIGRATION AND NATIONALITY ACT ENUMERATED IN PARAGRAPH (1) IN THIS SUBSECTION
column401: THE ATTORNEY GENERAL SHALL NOTIFY THE SECRETARY OF SUCH DEPORTATION."" THE PROVISIONS OF SEC. 241(A) OF THE IMMIGRATION AND NATIONALITY ACT ARE SUMMARIZED IN NOTES "	0

330	"It's amazing but true: we can prevent terror suspects from boarding an airplane
column2: but the FBI doesn't have the power to block them from buying dynamite or an AK-47.

column1: I believe strongly that they should. And so do the 500 mayors who are members of our bi-partisan coalition of Mayor Against Illegal Guns.
Advertisement
It is time to close the ""Terror Gap"" in our gun laws.

This morning I will be testifying at a hearing of the Senate Homeland Security Committee about the easy access that terror suspects have to guns and explosives. I wanted to share with lawmakers the hard-earned perspective New Yorkers have on this national security risk.
The car bomb the New York City Police Department found in Times Square on Saturday night was not the only attempted terrorist attack on our city since 9/11 -- far from it. And sadly
column2: it won't be the last.

column1: Since 1990
column2: there have been more than 20 terrorists plots -- or actual attacks -- against our city.

column1: In the last year alone
column2: the NYPD -- working closely with federal authorities -- prevented two major planned attacks on our City. The first was last May
column3: when the terrorists purchased guns and explosives as part of a planned attack on a Temple and Jewish Center in the Bronx.

column1: The second was in September
column2: when the City and federal authorities broke up a plot to detonate explosives in the New York City subway system.

column1: Advertisement
And
column2: of course
column3: attacks and planned attacks have not been limited to New York.

column1: Last June in Little Rock
column2: Arkansas
column3: a man opened fire at a military recruiting station
column4: killing one private and wounding another. At the time of the shooting
column5: the FBI was already investigating the man after his arrest in Yemen with a fake Somali passport. He was charged with murder and 16 counts of terrorist acts.

column1: And on November 5
column3: Major Nidal Hasan shot 43 people at Fort Hood -- killing 13. We know Hasan was able to buy a handgun despite having been under investigation by the FBI for links to terrorism.

column1: The Bush Administration first proposed closing the Terror Gap in 2007. But because Congress has failed to act on that proposal
column2: people who may want to do our country harm have been able to buy guns and explosives.

column1: Today
column2: the Government Accountability Office has released new data showing that suspects on the terrorism watch lists were able to buy guns and explosives from licensed US dealers 1
column3: 119 times between 2004 and 2010.

column1: That is a serious and dangerous breach of national security.
That's why the more than 500 mayors in Mayors Against Illegal Guns
column2: a coalition that I co-chair with Mayor Tom Menino of Boston
column3: support legislation to close the Terror Gap. This issue is a centerpiece of the coalition's fight to strengthen the federal background check system. Today
column4: we have launched a new website -- www.TerrorGap.org -- to help educate Congress and the public about the Terror Gap and its consequences.

column1: Advertisement

This legislation would give FBI agents the authority to block terror suspects from buying guns and explosives. It would also give them the ability to make exceptions when they determine that blocking a sale might tip off a suspect who is under investigation.
And the bill also allows those on the list to appeal their status to the Justice Department -- and challenge the determination in court.
Attorney General Eric Holder supported closing the Terror Gap in testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee last year. And so does the vast majority of Americans.
A December poll by Republican pollster Frank Luntz found that 82% of NRA members
column2: and 86% of other gun owners
column3: support closing the Terror Gap.

column1: To learn more and take action
column2: please visit: www.TerrorGap.org.

column1: In New York City
column2: we are doing everything humanly possible to prevent another terrorist attack. Under Commissioner Kelly's leadership
column3: the NYPD has developed one of the world's most advanced counter-terrorism programs. One thousand of our best officers work on counter-terrorism and intelligence efforts every day.

column1: Advertisement
A key element of any smart counter-terrorism strategy is to make it harder for terrorists to strike.
That's why air passengers walk through metal detectors.
That's why our police officers randomly check bags in the subway.
That's why our police officers patrol sensitive locations.
And that's why it's just common sense to give the FBI the authority to keep terror suspects from buying guns and explosives."	0

First lady Melania Trump underwent kidney surgery Monday at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center near Washington
column2: DC
column3: according to a statement from her office.

column1: Trump had been experiencing an issue with her kidney that her office described as benign but requiring medical attention.
Ã¢ÂÂThis morning
column2: first lady Melania Trump underwent an embolization procedure to treat a benign kidney condition. The procedure was successful
column3: and there were no complications
column4: Ã¢ÂÂ the first ladyÃ¢ÂÂs communications director
column5: Stephanie Grisham
column6: said in a statement.

column1: Ã¢ÂÂMrs. Trump is at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center and will likely remain there for the duration of the week. The first lady looks forward to a full recovery so she can continue her work on behalf of children everywhere
column2: Ã¢ÂÂ Grisham wrote.

column1: President Donald Trump remained in the White House during Melania TrumpÃ¢ÂÂs surgery. He tweeted just after 5 p.m. Monday that he was heading to hospital to visit his wife in Marine One.
Ã¢ÂÂHeading over to Walter Reed Medical Center to see our great First Lady
column2: Melania. Successful procedure
column3: she is in good spirits. Thank you to all of the well-wishers!Ã¢ÂÂ Trump tweeted.

column1: Heading over to Walter Reed Medical Center to see our great First Lady
column2: Melania. Successful procedure
column3: she is in good spirits. Thank you to all of the well-wishers! Ã¢ÂÂ Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) May 14

column1: Trump
column2: who turned 48 last month
column3: had surgery at Walter Reed in nearby Bethesda
column4: Maryland
column5: on Monday morning.

column1: She is the first US first lady to undergo such a serious medical procedure while in the White House since Nancy Reagan had a mastectomy in October 1987. Rosalynn Carter underwent surgery to remove a benign lump from her breast in April 1977. Weeks after Betty Ford became first lady
column2: she was diagnosed with breast cancer and underwent a mastectomy in September 1974.

column1: The first lady did not move to Washington until six months into the administration
column2: choosing to let their son
column3: Barron
column4: finish the 2017 school year in New York. More recently
column5: Melania Trump has had a more public profile. On April 24
column6: she and the President hosted the first official state dinner of the Trump administration
column7: an event that was planned and executed primarily by the first lady.

column1: Trump was responsible for every aspect of the formal dinner in honor of French President Emmanuel Macron and his wife
column2: Brigitte Macron
column3: from the hand-selected ivory tablecloths to the menu
column4: which the first lady designed to meld American food with French influence. During the welcome ceremony leading up to the dinner
column5: Melania Trump stole headlines
column6: wearing a crisp white Michael Kors Collection suit with a matching white hat
column7: custom-made by her personal couturier. The hat set the internet ablaze
column8: with references and comparisons to BeyoncÃÂ©
column9: the suffragette movement and even television character Olivia Pope of Ã¢ÂÂScandal.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: On May 7
column2: Trump
column3: a relatively private first lady by comparison to her most recent predecessors
column4: was once again front and center
column5: this time to unveil her formal platform
column6: Be Best. She kicked off the initiative with a Rose Garden speech lasting 11 minutes
column7: the longest public speaking engagement during her 16-month tenure as first lady.

column1: Be Best is a three-pronged platform with a focus on opioid addiction and families
column2: general physical and emotional well-being of children
column3: and kindness and safety for kids using social media. The latter caused a firestorm of controversy because it encompasses cyberbullying
column4: a tactic that Melania TrumpÃ¢ÂÂs husband
column5: the President
column6: has often been accused of fueling. In March
column7: the first lady addressed the criticism she has faced by taking up the issue during opening remarks to a meeting she convened at the White House for tech industry leaders from Google
column8: Snap
column9: Twitter
column10: Facebook
column11: Amazon and others.

column1: Ã¢ÂÂI am well-aware that people are skeptical of me discussing this topic
column2: Ã¢ÂÂ she said. Ã¢ÂÂI have been criticized for my commitment to tackling this issue
column3: and I know that will continue. But it will not stop me from doing what I know is right.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: Melania Trump has also appeared with her husband several times in recent weeks. He was seated in the front row during her Be Best speech
column2: after which he made remarks praising her commitment to helping children
column3: and he was again second to speak
column4: after his wife
column5: during the Military Mothers and Spouses Ceremony on Friday in the White House East Room.

column1: Ã¢ÂÂSheÃ¢ÂÂs become a very
column2: very popular first lady. IÃ¢ÂÂm reading that Ã¢ÂÂ¦ They love Melania
column3: Ã¢ÂÂ the President said. A new CNN poll released May 7 had the first ladyÃ¢ÂÂs favorable rating up 10 points since January to 57%.

CNN Live Event/Special
Republican Presidential Debate
Aired June 05
THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.
WOLF BLITZER
column2: HOST: Let's begin our questioning.

column1: Right now Tom Fahey of the New Hampshire Union Leader with the first question.
TOM FAHEY
column2: NEW HAMPSHIRE UNION LEADER: Thanks
column3: Wolf.

column1: Governor Romney
column2: I wanted to start by asking you a question on which every American has formed an opinion.

column1: We have lost 3
column2: 400 troops
column3: civilian casualties are even higher
column4: and the Iraqi government does not appear ready to provide for the security of its own country. Knowing everything you know right now
column5: was it a mistake for us to invade Iraq?

column1: MITT ROMNEY
column2: FORMER GOVERNOR OF MASSACHUSETTS: Well
column3: the question is
column4: kind of
column5: a non sequitur
column6: if you will. What I mean by that -- or a null set -- that is that if you're saying let's turn back the clock and Saddam Hussein had opening up his country to IAEA inspectors and they'd come in and they'd found that there were no weapons of mass destruction
column7: had Saddam Hussein therefore not violated United Nations resolutions
column8: we wouldn't be in the conflict we're in.

column1: But he didn't do those things
column2: and we knew what we knew at the point we made the decision to get in.

column1: I supported the president's decision based on what we knew at that time.
I think we were underprepared and underplanned for what came after we knocked down Saddam Hussein.
By the way
column2: Harry Reid was wrong. We did not lose the war in Iraq. And that's not the sort of thing you say when you have men and women in harm's way.

column1: We did
column2: however
column3: not do a great job after we knocked down Saddam Hussein and won the war to take him down and his military.

column1: And at this stage
column2: the right thing for us to do is to see if we could possibly stabilize the central government in Iraq so that they can have stability
column3: and so we can bring our troops home as soon as possible.

column1: Not to do that adds an enormous potential risk that the whole region could be embroiled in a regional conflict. BLITZER: Governor
column2: thank you
column3: but the question was
column4: knowing what you know right now -- not what you knew then
column5: what you know right now -- was it a mistake for the United States to invade Iraq?

column1: ROMNEY: Well
column2: I answered the question by saying it's a non- sequitur. It's a non -- null set kind of question
column3: because you can go back and say
column4: ""If we knew then what we know now
column5: by virtue of inspectors having been let in and giving us that information
column6: by virtue of if Saddam Hussein had followed the U.N. resolutions
column7: we wouldn't be having this discussion.""

column1: So it's a hypothetical that I think is an unreasonable hypothetical.
And the answer is: We did what we did. We did the right thing based on what we knew at that time. I think we made mistakes following the conduct or the collapse of Saddam's government.
FAHEY: Mayor Giuliani
column2: same question to you. Knowing what you know right now
column3: was it a good decision?

column1: RUDY GIULIANI
column2: FORMER MAYOR OF NEW YORK CITY: Absolutely the right thing to do. It's unthinkable that you would leave Saddam Hussein in charge of Iraq and be able to fight the war on terror.

column1: And the problem is that we see Iraq in a vacuum. Iraq should not be seen in a vacuum. Iraq is part of the overall terrorist war against the United States.
The problem the Democrats make is they're in denial. That's why you hear things like you heard in the debate the other night
column2: that
column3: you know
column4: Iran really isn't dangerous; it's 10 years away from nuclear weapons.

column1: Iran is not 10 years away from nuclear weapons. And the danger to us is not just missiles. The danger to us is a state like Iran handing nuclear weapons over to terrorists.
So it has to be seen in that light. And we have to be successful in Iraq.
BLITZER: Senator McCain
column2: arguably going to war is the most important decision a member of the Senate can make.

column1: Did you read the national intelligence estimate
column2: which included all the caveats on whether or not there were weapons of mass destruction in Iraq?

column1: SEN. JOHN MCCAIN (R)
column2: ARIZONA: I did not read that particular document. I received hundreds of briefing
column3: tens and hundreds of hours of study and background and information on it. And the fact is that the sanctions were breaking down. The sanctions were not going to hold. We had a multi-billion dollar scandal in the form of oil for food.

column1: The fact is that Saddam Hussein had used weapons of mass destruction before on his own people and on his enemies. And if he'd gotten them again
column2: he'd have used them again. That was his commitment and his belief
column3: that he was going to. And we did the right thing.

column1: The problem was the mismanagement of the conflict.
BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Senator.

column1: Senator Brownback
column2: you're also a member of the United States Senate. Did you read that classified national intelligence estimate?

column1: SEN. SAM BROWNBACK (R)
column2: KANSAS: I don't remember that report. I had a number of briefings and I held a number of committee hearings. At that time
column3: I was chairing the Middle East Subcommittee on Foreign Relations. And we held hearings on this topic and what was taking place and what Saddam was doing.

column1: But the issue is that we've got to put forward
column2: now
column3: a political plan. And that's something I'm going to introduce tomorrow
column4: a political plan to create a three-state solution in Iraq: a Kurdish state
column5: a Sunni state
column6: a Shia state. Because Iraq is more three groups held together by exterior forces. And that's what we've lacked is a political plan to get us moving forward in success.

column1: BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Senator.

column1: Governor Gilmore
column2: let me go to you. You chaired this commission. Do you think it was appropriate that members of Congress would authorize the president to go to war without reading that national intelligence estimate?

column1: JIM GILMORE
column2: FORMER GOVERNOR OF VIRGINIA: You know
column3: I think the people who are in Congress who are responsible for sending this country to war
column4: with the enormous dangers that it has geopolitically and strategically
column5: ought to read at least that kind of material. I know they get a lot of stuff and they can't read everything.

column1: But you know what
column2: Wolf? I think the true business is this: The interests of the United States is in creating as much stability as possible in the Middle East. There is a very great danger to this country: our interests in Israel
column3: our interests in energy and in other ways. There is a giant danger of the Middle East becoming an unstable place.

column1: Saddam Hussein was unstable
column2: and so taking him out was good there. But we certainly didn't anticipate the further instability that was to come after.

column1: BLITZER: We're going to bring all of you in
column2: but I want to go to Scott Spradling of WMUR for the next question.

column1: SCOTT SPRADLING
column2: WMUR-TV: Thanks
column3: Wolf.

column1: Senator McCain
column2: we've just spent a few minutes looking back. I'd ask you to look forward now
column3: if you will.

column1: Since June 1st there have been at least 17 confirmed deaths of American soldiers in Iraq. Approximately 100 U.S. troops are dying there every month. If our top military commander in Iraq
column2: General Petraeus
column3: reports back to Congress this September that the surge hasn't significantly improved the situation on the ground
column4: what then?

column1: MCCAIN: Well
column2: let me say
column3: first of all
column4: I know how frustrated and saddened all Americans are. This morning I was with the family of Matthew Stanley of Wolfeboro
column5: who sacrificed his life. And our hearts and our sympathy goes out to all those who have sacrificed their lives in this conflict.

column1: I (inaudible) think this strategy needs to be given a chance to succeed. We haven't barely gotten the fifth brigade over there
column2: which is part of this strategy.

column1: I am convinced that if we fail and we have to withdraw
column2: they will follow us home. It will be a base for Al Qaida. And we will be facing greater challenges and greater sacrifices than that already made by Matthew Stanley and his family.

column1: There is no doubt in my mind that this will become a base for terrorism
column2: there will be chaos in the region. And when Senator Clinton says this is Mr. Bush's war
column3: that this is President Bush's war -- when President Clinton was in power
column4: I didn't say that Bosnia
column5: our intervention there was President Clinton's war. When we intervened in Kosovo
column6: I didn't say it was President Clinton's war.

column1: What Senator Clinton doesn't understand that presidents don't lose wars. Political parties don't lose wars.
Nations lose wars
column2: and nations lose the -- have the consequences of failure.

column1: BLITZER: Senator...
MCCAIN: We must succeed in this conflict.
BLITZER: ... the question was
column2: if General Petraeus says...

column1: (APPLAUSE)
... it's not working so far in September
column2: what do you do then?

column1: MCCAIN: Then you have to examine the options.

And I'll tell you the options: One is the division that Sam described. You would have to divide bedrooms in Baghdad because Sunni and Shia are married to each other. You have 2 million Sunni and 4 million Shia living in Baghdad together.

You would have to -- you withdraw to the borders and watch genocide take place inside Baghdad. You watch the destabilization of Jordan. You see further jeopardy of Israel because of the threats of Hezbollah and Iranian hegemony in the region.
All of the options I could run through with you. My friend
column2: none of them are good. That's why we must succeed and give it a chance to succeed.

column1: BLITZER: All right.
Now
column2: let me bring in Governor Thompson.

column1: Go ahead
column2: same question to you: If General Petraeus says it's not working in September
column3: what should the U.S. do then?

column1: TOMMY THOMPSON
column2: FORMER HHS SECRETARY: The first thing the president should do is demand the al-Maliki government to vote as to whether or not they want the United States to stay in Iraq. We've been there four years. Give the government the responsibility of voting.

column1: If they vote ""yes
column2: how are they going to help us win this war? If they vote ""no
column3: we should redeploy our forces outside.

column1: Secondly
column2: there are 18 territories in Iraq
column3: geographically defined. Those 18 territories
column4: just like 50 states in America
column5: should elect their state leaders. And if they do so
column6: the Shiites will elect Shiites
column7: Sunnis will elect Sunnis
column8: Kurds will elect Kurds. And you know something? People will go to those particular territories
column9: and you get rid of this civil war internecine.

column1: Number three...
BLITZER: All right...
THOMPSON: ... I would like to have the oil revenue proceeds -- very quickly -- oil revenue proceeds split: one-third to the federal government
column2: one-third to the states
column3: and one-third to every man
column4: woman and child. And that will get everybody a stake in their country.

column1: BLITZER: Let me bring in Congressman Duncan Hunter.
Congressman
column2: if it's not working at that point
column3: how much longer should the United States stay?

column1: REP. DUNCAN HUNTER (R)
column2: CALIFORNIA: Well
column3: Wolf
column4: you know
column5: I read that NIE report
column6: and I held briefings before we made the vote to go in and invited everybody
column7: Democrat and Republican
column8: to get the classified information.

column1: And this depends -- the turnover of the security apparatus depends on one thing: reliable Iraqi forces.
You've got 129 Iraqi battalions. We've trained them up. We've got a lot of them in the fight. Over the next three to four months
column2: we need to get them all in the fight
column3: get them that combat capability. When they're combat-hardened
column4: we rotate them in
column5: we displace American heavy combat forces off that battlefield
column6: and Americans come home. And
column7: Wolf...

column1: BLITZER: Thank you.
HUNTER: ... I can tell you
column2: as the chairman of the Armed Services Committee for the last four years
column3: I have the credentials to leave Iraq the right way.

column1: BLITZER: Congressman Ron Paul
column2: how much longer should the United States stay in Iraq?

column1: REP. RON PAUL (R)
column2: TEXAS: The sooner we come home
column3: the better. If they declare there's no progress in September
column4: we should come home. It was a mistake to go
column5: so it's a mistake to stay.

column1: If we made the wrong diagnosis
column2: we should change the treatment. So we're not making progress there and we should come home.

column1: The weapons weren't there and we went in under U.N. resolutions. And our national security was not threatened. We're more threatened now by staying.
BLITZER: Governor Huckabee
column2: do you have confidence in the government of Iraq...

column1: (APPLAUSE)
... the government of Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki
column2: that he's going to do what needs to be done?

column1: MIKE HUCKABEE
column2: FORMER GOVERNOR OF ARKANSAS: I think there's some real doubt about that
column3: Wolf.

column1: But I want to remind all of us on this stage and the people in the audience that there's a reason that this is such a struggle. And I think we miss it over here in the West.
Today's the birthday of Ronald Reagan. We all would believe that Ronald Reagan is the one who ended the Cold War and Ronald Reagan is the one who helped bring about the collapse of the Soviet Union.
But there's a group of people who don't believe that
column2: and that's the Taliban. They believe they brought about the demise of the Soviet Union because of the way they fought in Afghanistan.

column1: And what I want to just mention is that it is not the size of the dog in the fight
column2: it is the size of the fight in the dog. And we underestimate -- grossly underestimate how fierce this dog is and how determined they are to destroy every last one of us.

column1: BLITZER: All right.
Congressman Tom Tancredo
column2: what do you say?

column1: REP. TOM TANCREDO (R)
column2: COLORADO: I'll tell you this
column3: that if it comes to that point in that time that you described
column4: that the surge is apparent that it is not working
column5: I did support it. I hope to God it does work. I hope I'm wrong. I hope we pacify Iraq.

column1: However
column2: if it is apparent that we cannot
column3: then we have to do and tell the Iraqis the exact same thing that Benjamin Franklin said when he came out of the convention in 1787 and somebody said to him
column4: ""Dr. Franklin
column5: what have you given us?"" And he said
column6: ""A republic
column7: if you can keep it.""

column1: It is exactly that time and it is exactly that thing that we have to say to the Iraqi government: ""We have given you this. We bought it with our blood and sweat. It is now up to you to keep it.""
And I want the Iraqis to be in fact patrolling Baghdad. If they need vehicles
column2: you let them have the vehicles. But I want them patrolling their city and putting their lives at risk.

column1: Then we move out.
BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Congressman.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
I want to go to the next question. I want to go back to Tom.
Tom
column2: go ahead.

column1: FAHEY: Senator Brownback
column2: President Bush has stated that states that sponsor terrorism are no different than terrorists themselves. Yet Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice recently met with Iranian officials to discuss security in Iraq. Iran is a known support of Hezbollah
column3: Hamas.

column1: Did President Bush make the right call in opening a dialogue with Iran?
BROWNBACK: I think he made a right call on saying that about terrorist states
column2: particularly Iran. But I think we have to at times talk with them in different situations.

column1: Like
column2: before we went into Afghanistan
column3: we talked with Iran. It wasn't we were negotiating. We didn't open up formal diplomatic relations and we shouldn't.

column1: Iran is the lead sponsor of terrorism. Ahmadinejad just this past week called for the destruction of Israel
column2: continues to call for attacking of the United States.

column1: On Iraq
column2: I think we need to talk with them. I think we have to confront them aggressively for what they are
column3: which is the lead sponsor of terrorism in the world. I think we need to push the sanctions forward more aggressively. I think we need to work with the labor union movement that's developing inside of Iran. You had a bus driver strike that recently took place.

column1: And I think we have to show that purpose and resolve
column2: that we're going to confront these guys and we're going to stand with our allies like Israel
column3: we're going to stand against them oppressing and pushing us
column4: and trying to fund terrorists against us.

column1: BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Congressman.

column1: Congressman Hunter
column2: let me bring...

column1: BROWNBACK: Senator
column2: if you don't mind.

column1: BLITZER: Excuse me
column2: Senator.

column1: BROWNBACK: That's OK.
BLITZER: Congressman Hunter
column2: let me bring you back in. Do you agree with Senator Brownback that President Bush made the right decision in opening a direct dialogue with Iran?

column1: HUNTER: With two conditions. And I think that you do have a dialogue with everybody
column2: whether they're adversaries or friends.

column1: The two conditions are: Number one
column2: they are moving deadly equipment across the border that is killing Americans in Iraq.

column1: We have license to utilize anything that we want to use: special operations
column2: intelligence
column3: whatever it takes to stop that deadly equipment from moving across the border and hitting Americans in Iraq. And we don't give that up with these talks.

column1: Secondly
column2: they've got about 1
column3: 000 centrifuges now working
column4: enriching the material that can make
column5: at some point
column6: a nuclear device. The United States reserves the right to preempt
column7: and we may have to preempt that nuclear weapons program. We cannot allow them to have a nuclear device.

column1: With those two caveats
column2: talk to your enemies.

column1: BLITZER: If it came down to a preemptive U.S. strike against Iran's nuclear facility if necessary
column2: would you authorize as president the use of tactical nuclear weapons?

column1: HUNTER: I would authorize the use of tactical nuclear weapons if there was no other way to preempt those particular centrifuges.
When the Osirak reactor was hit in '86
column2: when the six F-18s came over the horizon and knocked that out
column3: they didn't need anything but conventional weapons.

column1: Probably it's going to take a little more than that. I don't think it's going to take tactical nukes.
BLITZER: What do you think
column2: Mayor? Do you think
column3: if you were president of the United States and it came down to Iran having a nuclear bomb
column4: which you say is unacceptable
column5: you would authorize the use of tactical nuclear weapons?

column1: GIULIANI: Part of the premise of talking to Iran has to be that they have to know very clearly that it is unacceptable to the United States that they have nuclear power. I think it could be done with conventional weapons
column2: but you can't rule out anything and you shouldn't take any option off the table.

column1: And during the debate the other night
column2: the Democrats seemed to be back in the 1990s. They don't seem to have gotten beyond the Cold War. Iran is a threat
column3: a nuclear threat
column4: not just because they can deliver a nuclear warhead with missiles. They're a nuclear threat because they are the biggest state sponsor of terrorism and they can hand nuclear materials to terrorists.

column1: And we just saw it just last week in New York
column2: an attempt by Islamist terrorists to attack JFK airport; three weeks ago
column3: an attempt to attack Fort Dix.

column1: These are real problems. This war is not a bumper sticker. This war is a real war.
BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Mayor.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BLITZER: Let me bring Governor Gilmore in.
What do you say about the potential use of tactical nuclear weapons if that's what it takes to go deep underground and destroy those Iraqi facilities?
GILMORE: One of the central problems of the Middle East is the desire for Iran to dominate that portion of the world
column2: because of what they are doing. And that is why I believe that they are seeking this kind of nuclear capacity. That is one of the reasons why we are
column3: in fact
column4: in Iraq.

column1: And that's why our soldiers
column2: when they fight and die there
column3: are in fact serving the interests of the United States. Nobody ought to have any doubt about that.

column1: With respect to Iran
column2: the policy I would follow would be dual.

column1: Number one
column2: we need to work with our European allies in order to put in appropriate sanctions. We need to communicate directly with the Iranians that we are going to offer them an opportunity to work with us.

column1: But we are also going to say that having a nuclear weapon is unacceptable; they need to understand it. And all options are on the table by the United States in that instance.
BLITZER: All right. Thank you
column2: Governor.

column1: Governor Romney
column2: I want to get you on the record. Do you agree with the mayor
column3: the governor
column4: others here
column5: that the use of tactical nuclear weapons
column6: potentially
column7: would be possible if that were the only way to stop Iran from developing a nuclear bomb?

column1: ROMNEY: You don't take options off the table
column2: but what you do is stand back and say
column3: ""What's going on here?"" You see what's happening in Sudan and Afghanistan
column4: in Iraq and Iran. All over the world
column5: we're seeing the same thing happening
column6: and that is people are testing the United States of America. And we have to make sure they understand that we're not arrogant; we have resolve. And we have the strength to protect our interests and to protect people who love liberty.

column1: For that to happen
column2: we're going to have to not just attack each one of these problems one by one
column3: but say
column4: how do we help move the world of Islam so that the moderate Muslims can reject the extreme?

column1: And for that to happen
column2: we're going to have to have a strong military and an effort to combine with our allies in such a way
column3: we combine for an effort to help move Islam toward modernity.

column1: That's what we're going to have to do
column2: instead of looking at each theater one by one and saying
column3: ""We'll bomb here
column4: we'll attack here
column5: we'll go to Sudan.""

column1: I watched the Democrats...
BLITZER: Thank you.
ROMNEY: ... they don't think there's a war on terror.
BLITZER: Thank you.
ROMNEY: There's a war going on
column2: and we need a broad response to make sure that these people have a different vision.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Governor.

column1: All of you are going to have an opportunity to weigh on all of these questions as well.
If you're hearing some sounds out there
column2: it's lightning here in Manchester
column3: New Hampshire. Those are the crackling sounds that you're hearing.

column1: Let's go back to Scott.
SPRADLING: Thanks
column2: Wolf.

column1: Congressman Tancredo
column2: let's talk immigration.

column1: TANCREDO: OK.
SPRADLING: You oppose the immigration reform compromise
column2: calling it
column3: quote
column4: ""the worst piece of legislation to come down the pike in a long time."" Just this morning in Manchester
column5: you vowed to oust any senator who supports the bill
column6: including possibly New Hampshire's senior Senator Judd Gregg
column7: who's undecided
column8: and says to your comments that you are part of the know-nothing wing of the political spectrum.

column1: In the meantime
column2: the president says his plan is the last best chance for serious immigration reform.

column1: He's criticized conservatives for being obstructionists.
With that tension at stake
column2: if this becomes law
column3: what are the consequences for the country?

column1: TANCREDO: They are incredible
column2: and they are disastrous.

column1: And that is exactly why I have said what I've said
column2: and that is why I have consistently tried to impress upon the American public the seriousness of this issue.

column1: We're not just talking about the number of jobs that we may be losing or the number of kids that are in our schools and impacting our school system or the number of people that are abusing our hospital system and taking advantage of the welfare system in this country. We're not just talking about that.
We're talking about something that goes to the very heart of this nation: whether or not we will actually survive as a nation.
And here's what I mean by that.
What we're doing here in this immigration battle is testing our willingness to actually hold together as a nation or split apart into a lot of balkanized pieces.
We are testing our willingness to actually hold on to something called the English language
column2: something that is the glue that is supposed to hold us together as a nation.

column1: We are becoming a bilingual nation. And that is not good.
And that is the fearful part of this. The ramifications are much
column2: much more significant than any that we've been discussing so far.

column1: And so
column2: yes
column3: I have said dramatic things. And
column4: yes
column5: I am willing to do whatever is necessary to try to stop this piece of legislation. And that includes go after any Republican that votes for it
column6: because the Republicans can stop this.

column1: BLITZER: Thank you. Thank you
column2: Congressman.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
Mayor Giuliani
column2: what do you think the consequences for the nation are if this immigration plan proposed by President Bush goes through?

column1: GIULIANI: The problem with this immigration plan is it has no real unifying purpose. It's a typical Washington mess. It's everybody compromises -- four or five compromises.
And the compromises leave you with the following conclusion: The litmus test you should have for legislation is
column2: is it going to make things better? And when you look at these compromises
column3: it is quite possible it will make things worse. The organizing purpose should be that our immigration laws should allow us to identify everyone who is in this country that comes here from a foreign country.

column1: They should have a tamper-proof I.D. card. It should be in a database that allows you to figure out who they are
column2: why they're here
column3: make sure they're not illegal immigrants coming here for a bad purpose
column4: and then to be able to throw out the ones who are not in that database.

column1: We can do that. Credit card companies...
BLITZER: Thank you.
GIULIANI: ... take care of data that is greater than that.
BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Mayor.

column1: I want to get to Senator McCain in a moment
column2: but first
column3: Governor Romney
column4: Senator McCain has accused you of flip-flopping on this issue
column5: in effect.

column1: Yesterday in Miami
column2: he said the following: ""Pandering for votes on this issue while offering no solution to the problem amounts to doing nothing. And doing nothing is silent amnesty.""

column1: What do you say to Senator McCain?
ROMNEY: Well
column2: he's my friend. He campaigned for me two times. I consider him a friend. I'm not going to make this a matter of personal politics. It's an issue that's way too important for that.

column1: My view is that we should enforce our immigration laws.
And this bill
column2: unfortunately
column3: has at least one provision that's a real problem. It's the Z visa.

column1: And what it allows is people who have come here illegally to stay here for the rest of their lives -- not necessarily as citizens; they have to wait 13 years to become citizens. That's not the point.
The point is: Every illegal alien
column2: almost every one
column3: under this bill
column4: gets to stay here. That's not fair to the millions and millions of people around the world that would love to come here
column5: join with family members
column6: bring skill and education that we need.

column1: It's simply not fair to say those people get put ahead in the line of all the people who've been waiting legally to come to this country.
(APPLAUSE)
BLITZER: All right
column2: Senator McCain
column3: this is your chance. I'd like you to respond as someone who is the co-author of this legislation.

column1: MCCAIN: Well
column2: first of all
column3: I agree with Judd Gregg. He's a great senator.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
Second of all
column2: Rudy
column3: you just described our legislation
column4: so I'd be glad to have further conversation with you
column5: because it does account for people who are here illegally.

column1: It does have an employment verification system. And it weeds out those who shouldn't be here
column2: and it gives others a chance to remain in this country.

column1: Look
column2: this is a national security issue
column3: first and foremost. Ever since 9/11
column4: it's a national security issue.

column1: People came to Fort Dix
column2: New Jersey
column3: from across our southern border and tried to kill our soldiers.

column1: For us to do nothing is silent and de facto amnesty.
What we have done is what you expect us to do
column2: my friends
column3: and that's come together with the president of the United States
column4: the leader of our party
column5: Democrat and Republican
column6: conservative Republicans like Jon Kyl
column7: Johnny Isakson
column8: Saxby Chambliss and Trent Lott
column9: and sit down and figure out an approach to this problem.

column1: And it is a serious national security problem.
We need to act
column2: my friends. And if someone else has a better idea
column3: I'd love to have them pursue -- give it to us.

column1: BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Senator.

column1: (LAUGHTER)
(APPLAUSE)
Hold on.
MCCAIN: That can get...
BLITZER: Senator...
(CROSSTALK)
AUDIENCE MEMBER: ... a better idea!
MCCAIN: That will get the support of enough people so that we can pass legislation.
This isn't the bill that I would have written
column2: but it does...

column1: BLITZER: All right. Thank you.
MCCAIN: ... it does satisfy our national security challenges
column2: which are severe and intense. And we cannot 12 million people washing around America illegally
column3: my friends. (CROSSTALK)

column1: MCCAIN: And I hope you'll examine the legislation.
BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Senator.

column1: MCCAIN: And I hope we can move forward with it. And we can make it better.
BLITZER: All right.
MCCAIN: But it's our job to do the hard things...
BLITZER: Mayor
column2: go ahead.

column1: MCCAIN: ... not the easy things.
(APPLAUSE)
GIULIANI: I've read the 400 pages. And this is part of the problem in Washington: They say things and then it's not in the legislation.
There are four or five different methods of identification
column2: not one.

column1: It does not provide information about who exited the United States. Now
column2: tell me how you're going to figure out who's in the United States if you can't figure out who's left the United States.

column1: And finally
column2: it doesn't provide for a uniform database. Many countries have this. The United States doesn't have it.

column1: On September 11th
column2: when we tried to figure out who was in this country
column3: it took weeks to figure out who were the right people and who weren't
column4: because there isn't such a database. And that is a fatal flaw in this legislation. And wishing it away doesn't make it possible.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BLITZER: Governor Romney
column2: what would you do with the 12 million or so illegal immigrants who are
column3: right now
column4: in this country?

column1: ROMNEY: Well
column2: one is to enforce the law as it exists. The law that was passed in 1986...

column1: (APPLAUSE)
The law passed in 1986 asked for us to secure the border and said also to put in place an employment verification system.
Neither one of those was done. So let's make sure that we enforce the law as it exists.
And if you want to improve this bill
column2: well
column3: one thing you could do to make it better is to take that Z visa and make it temporary instead of a permanent right to stay in America. That's simply just not fair.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BLITZER: I want to stay on immigration. Everybody's going to have a chance to weigh in. But let's go back to Tom for another question on immigration.
FAHEY: Congressman Hunter
column2: whether we like it or not
column3: in cities across America
column4: counties across America
column5: including your district in San Diego
column6: illegal immigrants are doing jobs that American citizens don't want
column7: working on farms
column8: in hotels
column9: restaurants.

column1: If you have your way and they all leave this country
column2: who's going to fill those jobs?

column1: HUNTER: Well
column2: first
column3: I disagree with that premise
column4: because when they made the sweep on the Swift plants -- those were the meat- packaging plants in Iowa; took out some 850 people who were working there illegally several months ago -- there were American citizens lined up the next day to get their jobs back at 18 bucks an hour.

column1: And let me tell you
column2: this is a disastrous bill. And John McCain is right in saying that this is a national security issue. And it is: border enforcement.

column1: Then the Hunter bill
column2: which was signed by the president on the 26th of October
column3: mandating 854 miles of double fence -- not that scraggly
column4: little fence you show on CNN all the time
column5: Wolf
column6: that people get across so easily.

column1: If they get across my fence
column2: we sign them up for the Olympics immediately.

column1: (LAUGHTER)
We've got a big fence.
But 854 miles of double border fence was mandated to be constructed. Homeland Security has a billion bucks
column2: cash on hand. It's been six months
column3: and they've done 11 miles.

column1: So this administration has a case of the slows. And I think they slowed the fence down so that they could come out with the amnesty at the same time
column2: put the two together
column3: and the Bush-McCain-Kennedy bill would then be accepted by conservatives and liberals alike.

column1: It's a bad bill.
BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Congressman.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
Senator Brownback
column2: what do you say about this notion of a pathway toward citizenship for these 12 million illegal immigrants who are in the country right now? Under what circumstances would you let them begin that path?

column1: BROWNBACK: I don't think you create any new paths to citizenship. But I also think you allow them to be able to use paths that they would currently qualify for
column2: and to be able to get in the back of "	0

column1: 334	"Scranton High School
Scranton
column2: Pennsylvania

column1: 2:37 P.M. EST
THE PRESIDENT: Hello
column2: Scranton! Thank you. (Applause.) It is good to be back in Scranton. Go
column3: Knights! (Applause.) It is good to be here. Thank you
column4: Principal Schaeffer
column5: for letting us hold this little assembly here at the high school. (Laughter.) The principal was bragging about both the basketball team and the football team. I understand theyÃ¢ÂÂre -- (applause) -- right up there? All right.

column1: Thank you
column2: Donna
column3: for the wonderful invitation. We had a chance to visit in the FestasÃ¢ÂÂ living room
column4: and just a wonderful family
column5: and their kids are doing great. So IÃ¢ÂÂm really
column6: really proud to be with all of you.

column1: AUDIENCE MEMBER: Can you come to my house? (Laughter.)
THE PRESIDENT: What did she say? You want -- next time
column2: your house. (Laughter.) All right? (Applause.)

column1: Now
column2: I will say
column3: Donna put out some really good cookies. So -- (laughter) -- IÃ¢ÂÂm just saying. (Laughter.) All right.

column1: Now
column2: I also want to bring greetings from somebody you guys know pretty well -Ã¢ÂÂ a guy named Joe Biden. (Applause.) Joe is in Iraq as we speak
column3: and heÃ¢ÂÂs visiting with our brave men and women in uniform
column4: thanking them for their service. (Applause.) And part of the reason heÃ¢ÂÂs going now is because
column5: pretty soon
column6: weÃ¢ÂÂll all get a chance to say thank you. This holiday season is going to be a season of homecomings
column7: because by the end of December
column8: all of our troops are going to be out of Iraq. TheyÃ¢ÂÂre going to be back home. (Applause.)

column1: Now
column2: I mention Joe
column3: first of all
column4: because he loves Scranton. (Applause.) He was born here in Scranton. He spent his early years here in Scranton. This town helped make him who he is. This is a town where he and so many of you grew up with a faith in an America where hard work matters. Where responsibility matters. Where if you stay true to those things
column5: you can get ahead. Where no matter who you are
column6: no matter what you look like -Ã¢ÂÂ whether you own a factory or you work on the factory floor Ã¢ÂÂ- America is a place where you can make it if you try. (Applause.)

column1: ThatÃ¢ÂÂs why Joe and I ran for this office. You are why we spent so much time in this state a few years ago. Because even then
column2: those ideas -Ã¢ÂÂ the idea thatÃ¢ÂÂs at the very heart of the American Dream Ã¢ÂÂ- felt like it was slipping away for a lot of people. It was wonderful visiting with Patrick and Donna
column3: and we were talking about the fact that Patrick has been -- Patrick Festa has been teaching in the school system for 25 years now; Donna has been a graphic artist. But theyÃ¢ÂÂre still worried about if the washer/dryer goes out
column4: or if they have to do a car repair. Things are tight. And theyÃ¢ÂÂre pretty lucky that theyÃ¢ÂÂve got a good job
column5: steady jobs. For a lot of folks
column6: itÃ¢ÂÂs a lot tougher.

column1: And weÃ¢ÂÂve gone through a difficult decade for middle-class Americans. More good jobs in manufacturing left our shores over the last decade. More of our prosperity was built on risky financial deals and homes that a lot of folks couldnÃ¢ÂÂt afford. And a lot of you watched your incomes fall or your wages flatline. Meanwhile
column2: the costs of everything from college to health care were all going up. And then
column3: after all that
column4: the financial crisis hit because of the irresponsibility of some on Wall Street. (Applause.) And that made things a whole lot tougher.

column1: Today
column2: we all know folks whoÃ¢ÂÂve spent months looking for work. We all know families making deep sacrifices just to get by. We all know young people who have gone to college
column3: theyÃ¢ÂÂve taken on a bunch of debt. Now theyÃ¢ÂÂre finding that the opportunity that they worked so hard to find is getting harder and harder to come by. So thereÃ¢ÂÂs a sense of deep frustration among people whoÃ¢ÂÂve done the right thing
column4: but donÃ¢ÂÂt see that hard work and that responsibility pay off. And thatÃ¢ÂÂs not the way things are supposed to be
column5: not here in America.

column1: But here today with all of you
column2: IÃ¢ÂÂm thinking about something that is probably JoeÃ¢ÂÂs favorite expression. And some of you know JoeÃ¢ÂÂs story. He went through some tough times when he was a kid. And his father used to tell him
column3: Champ
column4: when you get knocked down
column5: you get up. You get up.

column1: And Scranton
column2: weÃ¢ÂÂve taken some punches these last few years. But thereÃ¢ÂÂs one thing I know about people here in Scranton
column3: people in Pennsylvania
column4: and people all across America: We are tougher than the times. We are America. We get back up. We fight back. We move forward. (Applause.) We donÃ¢ÂÂt give up. We get back up. (Applause.)

column1: And even though our economic problems werenÃ¢ÂÂt caused overnight and so theyÃ¢ÂÂre not going to be solved overnight -- even though itÃ¢ÂÂs going to take a few more years to meet all the challenges that were decades in the making -- weÃ¢ÂÂre fighting to make things right again. WeÃ¢ÂÂre fighting to make sure that if you are working hard and you are carrying out your responsibilities and youÃ¢ÂÂre looking out for your family
column2: that you can live a good
column3: solid
column4: middle-class life. That is what America is all about. And we are going to be fighting for that every day
column5: every week
column6: every month and every year that weÃ¢ÂÂre in office. (Applause.)

column1: We want an America where hard work is valued and responsibility is rewarded. WeÃ¢ÂÂre fighting to rebuild an economy that restores security for the middle class and renews opportunity for folks that are trying to get into the middle class. WeÃ¢ÂÂre fighting to build an economy thatÃ¢ÂÂs not based on outsourcing and tax loopholes and risky financial schemes
column2: but one thatÃ¢ÂÂs built to last -- one where we invest in things like education and small businesses -- (applause) -- an economy thatÃ¢ÂÂs built on manufacturing and building things again and selling them all around the world. (Applause.)

column1: And weÃ¢ÂÂre going to keep fighting to make our economy stronger and put our friends and neighbors back to work
column2: to give our young people opportunities greater than the opportunities that we had. (Applause.) ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what weÃ¢ÂÂve been doing for the last three years.

column1: But two months ago
column2: I sent a particular piece of legislation to Congress called the American Jobs Act. (Applause.) This is a jobs bill that will put more Americans to work
column3: put more money back in the pockets of working families. ItÃ¢ÂÂs contains ideas that historically have been supported by Democrats and Republicans. ItÃ¢ÂÂs paid for by asking our wealthiest citizens to pay their fair share. (Applause.) And independent economists said that it would create up to 2 million jobs
column4: and grow the economy by as much as 2 percent. And thatÃ¢ÂÂs what we need right now.

column1: Now
column2: hereÃ¢ÂÂs the problem -- there is a problem. Folks in Washington donÃ¢ÂÂt seem to be getting the message. When this jobs bill came to a vote
column3: Republicans in the Senate got together and they blocked it. They refused to even debate it. Even though polls showed that two-thirds of Americans of all political stripes supported the ideas in this bill
column4: not one single Republican stepped up to say
column5: this is the right thing to do.

column1: AUDIENCE: Booo!
THE PRESIDENT: Not one. But hereÃ¢ÂÂs the good news
column2: Scranton. Just like you donÃ¢ÂÂt quit
column3: I donÃ¢ÂÂt quit. (Applause.) I donÃ¢ÂÂt quit. So I said
column4: look
column5: IÃ¢ÂÂm going to do everything that I can do without Congress to get things done. (Applause.)

column1: So letÃ¢ÂÂs just take a look over the past several weeks. We said
column2: we canÃ¢ÂÂt wait. We just went ahead and started taking some steps on our own to give working Americans a leg up in a tough economy. For homeowners
column3: I announced a new policy that will help families refinance their mortgages and save thousands of dollars. (Applause.) For all the young people out here -- (applause) -- we reformed our student loan process to make it easier for more students to pay off their debts earlier. (Applause.) For our veterans out here -- and I see some veterans in the crowd -- (applause) -- we ordered several new initiatives to help our returning heroes find new jobs and get trained for those jobs. (Applause.) Because you shouldnÃ¢ÂÂt have to fight for a job when you come home after fighting for America -- you shouldnÃ¢ÂÂt have to do that. (Applause.)

column1: And in fact
column2: last week I was able to sign into law two new tax breaks for businesses that hire veterans
column3: because nobody out here who is a veteran should -- we have to make sure that they are getting the help that they need.

column1: AUDIENCE MEMBER: Thank you
column2: Mr. President!

column1: THE PRESIDENT: And by the way
column2: I think weÃ¢ÂÂre starting to get
column3: maybe
column4: to the Republicans a little bit
column5: because they actually voted for this veterans bill. I was glad to see that. (Applause.) I was glad that Democrats and Republicans got together with this bipartisan legislation.

column1: Now
column2: thereÃ¢ÂÂs a lot more to do
column3: though
column4: if weÃ¢ÂÂre going to get every American back to work who wants to work
column5: and to rebuild an economy that works for every American
column6: which is why weÃ¢ÂÂre going to give Congress another chance to do the right thing with the American Job Act. WeÃ¢ÂÂre going to give them another chance to help working families like yours. (Applause.)

column1: Last year
column2: both parties came together to cut payroll taxes for the typical household by $1
column3: 000. Now
column4: thatÃ¢ÂÂs been showing up in your paychecks each week. You may not be aware of it
column5: because times are tight. But you actually got a tax cut of $1
column6: 000 this year. Now
column7: I know you hear a lot of folks on cable TV claiming that IÃ¢ÂÂm this big tax-and-spend liberal. Next time you hear that
column8: you just remind the people who are saying it that since IÃ¢ÂÂve taken office
column9: IÃ¢ÂÂve cut your taxes. (Applause.)

column1: Your taxes today -- the average middle-class family
column2: your taxes today are lower than when I took office
column3: just remember that. (Applause.) We have cut taxes for small businesses not once
column4: not twice
column5: but 17 times. The average familyÃ¢ÂÂs tax burden is among the lowest itÃ¢ÂÂs been in the last 60 years.

column1: So the problem is not that weÃ¢ÂÂve been raising taxes. WeÃ¢ÂÂve actually been trying to give families a break during these tough times. But hereÃ¢ÂÂs the thing: That payroll tax cut that we passed in December of last year
column2: itÃ¢ÂÂs set to expire at the end of this year
column3: one month from now. If that happens -- if Congress doesnÃ¢ÂÂt act to extend this tax cut -- then most of you
column4: the typical middle-class family
column5: is going to see your taxes go up by $1
column6: 000 at the worst possible time. A young lady just said she canÃ¢ÂÂt afford that. It would be tough for you. It would also be a massive blow for the economy
column7: because weÃ¢ÂÂre not fully out of the recession yet. DonÃ¢ÂÂt take my word for it; this is what every independent economist says. We canÃ¢ÂÂt let this tax cut lapse right now.

column1: And thatÃ¢ÂÂs why my jobs bill -- part of the American Jobs Act was to extend this tax cut for another year. In fact
column2: it does one better. It says
column3: letÃ¢ÂÂs expand that tax cut. Instead of a $1

column10: 000 each

column12: 000. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs money that you can then use to hire some more workers and get this economy moving again. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs a good thing. (Applause.)

column1: Now
column2: this really should not be controversial. A lot of Republicans have agreed with this tax cut in the past. The Republican leader in the Senate said it would -- IÃ¢ÂÂm quoting here -- it would Ã¢ÂÂput a lot of money back in the hands of business and in the hands of individuals.Ã¢ÂÂ ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what he said. Another Republican leader said it would help small business owners create jobs and help their employees spend more money
column3: creating even more jobs. One Republican even called it a Ã¢ÂÂconservative approach to help put our economy back on track.Ã¢ÂÂ So whatÃ¢ÂÂs the problem?

column1: The bad news is some of those same Republicans voted Ã¢ÂÂnoÃ¢ÂÂ on my jobs bill and those tax cuts. I donÃ¢ÂÂt know whether itÃ¢ÂÂs just because I proposed it. I donÃ¢ÂÂt know. They said Ã¢ÂÂnoÃ¢ÂÂ to cutting taxes for small business owners and working families. One of them said just two years ago that this kind of tax cut would boost job creation

column3: he said we should let it expire. I mean
column4: what happened?

column1: Republicans say theyÃ¢ÂÂre the party of tax cuts. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what they say. A lot of them have sworn an oath to never raise taxes on anybody as long as they live. That doesnÃ¢ÂÂt square with their vote against these tax cuts. I mean
column2: how is it that they can break their oath when it comes to raising your taxes
column3: but not break their oath when it comes to raising taxes for wealthy people? That doesnÃ¢ÂÂt make any sense. (Applause.) I mean
column4: I hope that they donÃ¢ÂÂt want to just score political points. I hope that they want to help the economy.

column1: This cannot be about who wins and loses in Washington. This is about delivering a win for the American people. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what this is about. (Applause.) You know
column3: 500 -- thatÃ¢ÂÂs not a Band-Aid for middle-class families
column4: thatÃ¢ÂÂs a big deal. How many people here could use an extra $1
column5: 500? (Applause.) Yes
column6: I thought so.

column1: So IÃ¢ÂÂll tell you what
column2: Scranton. They may have voted Ã¢ÂÂnoÃ¢ÂÂ on these tax cuts once. But IÃ¢ÂÂm already filled with the Christmas spirit. ThereÃ¢ÂÂs kind of some chill in the air. I saw some Christmas decorations at the Festas. So IÃ¢ÂÂm in a Christmas spirit. I want to give them another chance. I want to give them a chance to redeem themselves. WeÃ¢ÂÂre going to give them another chance.

column1: So as early as Friday
column2: this Friday
column3: in a couple of days
column4: weÃ¢ÂÂre going to give them a chance to take a simple vote on these tax cuts. If they vote Ã¢ÂÂno
column5: Ã¢ÂÂ then the typical familyÃ¢ÂÂs taxes will go up by $1
column6: 000 next year. If they vote Ã¢ÂÂyes
column7: Ã¢ÂÂ then the typical family will have an extra $1
column8: 500 in their pocket. (Applause.) So letÃ¢ÂÂs just be clear: If they vote Ã¢ÂÂno
column9: Ã¢ÂÂ your taxes go up; vote Ã¢ÂÂyes
column10: Ã¢ÂÂ you get a tax cut. Which way do you think Congress should vote? They should vote Ã¢ÂÂyes
column11: Ã¢ÂÂ itÃ¢ÂÂs pretty simple.

column1: Now
column2: if you want to see what this vote will mean for your bottom line

column4: WhiteHouse.gov. So you can go on there and you can punch in your numbers and figure out what it would mean to your family. But this is real money that would go into the economy at a time it needs it.

column1: Now
column2: I really do think your voices are already getting

column1: through
column2: because some of the folks in Congress are starting to say
column3: well
column4: maybe weÃ¢ÂÂre open to this thing. Maybe weÃ¢ÂÂll be open to these tax cuts. And thatÃ¢ÂÂs good news. But I want to make sure that we do this responsibly. So what IÃ¢ÂÂve said is
column5: to pay for this tax cut
column6: we need to ask wealthy Americans to pay their fair share. (Applause.)

column1: WeÃ¢ÂÂre asking -- what weÃ¢ÂÂve said is letÃ¢ÂÂs ask the folks whoÃ¢ÂÂve seen their incomes rise fastest
column2: whoÃ¢ÂÂve gotten bigger tax breaks under Bush
column3: letÃ¢ÂÂs ask them to help out a little bit
column4: because they made it better through the recession than most of us. LetÃ¢ÂÂs ask them to contribute a little bit more to get the economy going again.

column1: And I just want to point out IÃ¢ÂÂve done pretty well over these last few years. So IÃ¢ÂÂve said
column2: let me pay a little bit more. I promise you
column3: I can afford it. (Laughter.) I really can. WeÃ¢ÂÂre asking people like me to sacrifice just a little bit so that you guys have a little bit of a leg up.

column1: And by the way
column2: let me say this: When you talk to most folks who are making a million dollars a year
column3: they are willing to do more if theyÃ¢ÂÂre asked. Warren Buffett is a good example. TheyÃ¢ÂÂre willing to do more if theyÃ¢ÂÂre asked. (Applause.)

column1: Now
column2: I mean
column3: I donÃ¢ÂÂt want to exaggerate. ItÃ¢ÂÂs not like theyÃ¢ÂÂre volunteering. (Laughter.) But if theyÃ¢ÂÂre asked
column4: if they feel like itÃ¢ÂÂs going to help middle-class families
column5: help grow the economy
column6: help to reduce the deficit
column7: theyÃ¢ÂÂre willing to help. I canÃ¢ÂÂt tell you how many well-to-do folks I meet who say
column8: look
column9: America gave me a chance to succeed. Somewhere along the line
column10: somebody gave me a good education. Somewhere along the line
column11: somebody gave me a college scholarship. Somewhere along the line
column12: somebody built the information and transportation networks that have helped my business grow. Somewhere along the line
column13: somebody gave me a shot. And so now itÃ¢ÂÂs my turn to do the next generation that same good thing. IÃ¢ÂÂve got to give something back to them as well. (Applause.)

column1: Because
column2: Scranton
column3: this is something everybody in this audience understands. When you think about the history of Scranton and the immigrants who came here and worked hard
column4: each successive generation doing a little bit better -- you guys know that what America is about is that weÃ¢ÂÂre all in this together; that each of us has to do our own individual part
column5: but we also have to be looking out for one another.

column1: And thatÃ¢ÂÂs the very simple choice thatÃ¢ÂÂs facing Congress right now: Are you going to cut taxes for the middle class and those who are trying to get into the middle class? Or are you going to protect massive tax breaks for millionaires and billionaires
column2: many of whom donÃ¢ÂÂt even want those tax breaks? Are you going to ask a few hundred thousand people who have done very
column3: very well to do their fair share? Or are you going to raise taxes for hundreds of millions of people across the country -- 160 million Americans? Are you willing to fight as hard for middle-class families as you do for those who are most fortunate? WhatÃ¢ÂÂs it going to be?

column1: ThatÃ¢ÂÂs the choice in front of Congress. And I hope members of Congress think hard about this
column2: because their actions lately donÃ¢ÂÂt reflect who we are as a people. What does it say about our priorities when weÃ¢ÂÂd rather protect a few really well-to-do people than fight for the jobs of teachers and firefighters? (Applause.) What does it say when we -- about our values when weÃ¢ÂÂd rather fight for corporate tax breaks than put construction workers back on the job rebuilding our roads and our bridges and our schools? (Applause.) What does it say about us if weÃ¢ÂÂre willing to cut taxes for the people who donÃ¢ÂÂt need them
column3: and raise them on folks who do need a tax break?

column1: We are better than that. America is better than that. We celebrate individual achievement
column2: we expect everybody to work hard
column3: but we donÃ¢ÂÂt believe in every person for themselves; we believe that out of many
column4: we come together as one. (Applause.) WeÃ¢ÂÂre a people who reach for our own success
column5: but we also reach back for the people -- to bring somebody up. Reach back to help others earn their own success as well. (Applause.) And we believe that if the folks at the bottom and the folks in the middle succeed
column6: then American succeeds
column7: and the folks at the top succeed as well. (Applause.)

column1: The decisions we make today are going to determine whether or not our kids grow up in a country where those values still thrive. And Scranton
column2: I donÃ¢ÂÂt know about you
column3: but I want our kids to grow up -- I want Malia and Sasha and all your kids
column4: I want them to come into a country that is built on those big
column5: generous values -- (applause) -- an America that reflects the values that we inherited from our parents and our grandparents.

column1: So if you agree with me
column2: I need you to tell Congress where your priorities lie. Members of Congress
column3: they work for you. Scranton
column4: youÃ¢ÂÂve got a great senator in Senator Casey. I love Senator Casey. (Applause.)

column1: So I want you to know
column2: Casey is already on the program. (Applause.) But to everybody who is here
column3: everybody who is watching
column4: send your Senate a message -- send your senators a message. Tell them
column5: Ã¢ÂÂDonÃ¢ÂÂt be a Grinch.Ã¢ÂÂ (Laughter.) Ã¢ÂÂDonÃ¢ÂÂt be a Grinch.Ã¢ÂÂ DonÃ¢ÂÂt vote to raise taxes on working Americans during the holidays. Make sure to renew unemployment insurance during the holidays. (Applause.) Stop saying Ã¢ÂÂnoÃ¢ÂÂ to steps that would make our economy stronger. Put our country before party. Put money back into the pockets of working Americans. Do your job. Pass this bill. (Applause.)

column1: Scranton
column2: the American people are with us on this. It is time for folks to stop running around spending all their time talking about whatÃ¢ÂÂs wrong with America. Spend some time
column3: roll up your sleeves
column4: and help us rebuild America. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what we need to do. (Applause.)

column1: There is nothing wrong with this country that we canÃ¢ÂÂt fix. WeÃ¢ÂÂre Americans
column2: and our story has never been about things coming easy to us. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs not what Scranton has been about. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs not what Pennsylvania
column3: thatÃ¢ÂÂs not what America is about. ItÃ¢ÂÂs been about rising to the moment
column4: and meeting the moment when things are hard. ItÃ¢ÂÂs about doing whatÃ¢ÂÂs right.

column1: So letÃ¢ÂÂs do whatÃ¢ÂÂs right. LetÃ¢ÂÂs prove that the best days of America are still ahead of us.
God bless you
column2: and God bless the United States of America. (Applause.)
