column1: 12:13 P.M. CDT
THE PRESIDENT: Hello
column2: Galesburg! (Applause.) Well
column3: itÃ¢ÂÂs good to be home in Illinois! (Applause.) It is good to be back. ItÃ¢ÂÂs good to be back. Thank you. Thank you so much
column4: everybody. (Applause.) Thank you. Everybody
column5: have a seat
column6: have a seat. Well
column7: it is good to be back.

column1: I want to
column2: first of all
column3: thank Knox College -- (applause) -- I want to thank Knox College and your president
column4: Teresa Amott
column5: for having me here today. Give Teresa a big round of applause. (Applause.) I want to thank your Congresswoman
column6: Cheri Bustos
column7: whoÃ¢ÂÂs here. (Applause.) We've got Governor Quinn here. (Applause.) I'm told we've got your Lieutenant Governor
column8: Sheila Simon
column9: is here. (Applause.) There she is. Attorney General Lisa Madigan is here. (Applause.)

column1: I see a bunch of my former colleagues
column2: some folks who I haven't seen in years and I'm looking forward to saying hi to. One in particular I've got to mention
column3: one of my favorites from the Illinois Senate -- John Sullivan is in the house. (Applause.) John was one of my earliest supporters when I was running for the U.S. Senate
column4: and it came in really handy because heÃ¢ÂÂs got
column5: like
column6: 10 brothers and sisters
column7: and his wife has got 10 brothers and sisters -- (laughter) -- so theyÃ¢ÂÂve got this entire precinct just in their family. (Laughter.) And they all look like John -- the brothers do -- so he doesnÃ¢ÂÂt have to go to every event. He can just send one of his brothers out. (Laughter.) It is good to see him.

column1: Dick Durbin couldnÃ¢ÂÂt make it today
column2: but he sends his best. And we love Dick. (Applause.) HeÃ¢ÂÂs doing a great job. And weÃ¢ÂÂve got one of my favorite neighbors
column3: the Senator from Missouri
column4: Claire McCaskill
column5: in the house
column6: because weÃ¢ÂÂre going to Missouri later this afternoon. (Applause.)

column1: And all of you are here
column2: and itÃ¢ÂÂs great to see you. (Applause.) And I hope everybody is having a wonderful summer. The weather is perfect. Whoever was in charge of that
column3: good job. (Laughter.)

column1: So
column2: eight years ago
column3: I came here to deliver the commencement address for the class of 2005. Things were a little different back then. For example
column4: I had no gray hair -- (laughter) -- or a motorcade. DidnÃ¢ÂÂt even have a prompter. In fact
column5: there was a problem in terms of printing out the speech because the printer didnÃ¢ÂÂt work here and we had to drive it in from somewhere. (Laughter.) But it was my first big speech as your newest senator.

column1: And on the way here I was telling Cheri and Claire about how important this area was
column2: one of the areas that I spent the most time in outside of Chicago
column3: and how much it represented whatÃ¢ÂÂs best in America and folks who were willing to work hard and do right by their families. And I came here to talk about what a changing economy was doing to the middle class -- and what we
column4: as a country
column5: needed to do to give every American a chance to get ahead in the 21st century.

column1: See
column2: I had just spent a year traveling the state and listening to your stories -- of proud Maytag workers losing their jobs when the plant moved down to Mexico. (Applause.) A lot of folks here remember that. Of teachers whose salaries werenÃ¢ÂÂt keeping up with the rising cost of groceries. (Applause.) Of young people who had the drive and the energy
column3: but not the money to afford a college education. (Applause.)

column1: So these were stories of families who had worked hard
column2: believed in the American Dream
column3: but they felt like the odds were increasingly stacked against them. And they were right. Things had changed.

column1: In the period after World War II
column2: a growing middle class was the engine of our prosperity. Whether you owned a company
column3: or swept its floors
column4: or worked anywhere in between
column5: this country offered you a basic bargain -- a sense that your hard work would be rewarded with fair wages and decent benefits
column6: the chance to buy a home
column7: to save for retirement
column8: and most of all
column9: a chance to hand down a better life for your kids.

column1: But over time
column2: that engine began to stall -- and a lot of folks here saw it -- that bargain began to fray. Technology made some jobs obsolete. Global competition sent a lot of jobs overseas. It became harder for unions to fight for the middle class. Washington doled out bigger tax cuts to the very wealthy and smaller minimum wage increases for the working poor.

column1: And so what happened was that the link between higher productivity and peopleÃ¢ÂÂs wages and salaries was broken. It used to be that
column2: as companies did better
column3: as profits went higher
column4: workers also got a better deal. And that started changing. So the income of the top 1 percent nearly quadrupled from 1979 to 2007
column5: but the typical familyÃ¢ÂÂs incomes barely budged.

column1: And towards the end of those three decades
column2: a housing bubble
column3: credit cards
column4: a churning financial sector was keeping the economy artificially juiced up
column5: so sometimes it papered over some of these long-term trends. But by the time I took office in 2009 as your President
column6: we all know the bubble had burst
column7: and it cost millions of Americans their jobs
column8: and their homes
column9: and their savings. And I know a lot of folks in this area were hurt pretty bad. And the decades-long erosion that had been taking place -- the erosion of middle-class security -- was suddenly laid bare for everybody to see.

column1: Now
column2: today
column3: five years after the start of that Great Recession
column4: America has fought its way back. (Applause.) We fought our way back. Together
column5: we saved the auto industry; took on a broken health care system. (Applause.) We invested in new American technologies to reverse our addiction to foreign oil. We doubled wind and solar power. (Applause.) Together
column6: we put in place tough new rules on the big banks
column7: and protections to crack down on the worst practices of mortgage lenders and credit card companies. (Applause.) We changed a tax code too skewed in favor of the wealthiest at the expense of working families -- so we changed that
column8: and we locked in tax cuts for 98 percent of Americans
column9: and we asked those at the top to pay a little bit more. (Applause.)

column1: So you add it all up
column2: and over the past 40 months
column3: our businesses have created 7.2 million new jobs. This year
column4: weÃ¢ÂÂre off to our strongest private sector job growth since 1999.

column1: And because we bet on this country
column2: suddenly foreign companies are
column3: too. Right now
column4: more of HondaÃ¢ÂÂs cars are made in America than anyplace else on Earth. (Applause.) Airbus
column5: the European aircraft company
column6: theyÃ¢ÂÂre building new planes in Alabama. (Applause.) And American companies like Ford are replacing outsourcing with insourcing -- theyÃ¢ÂÂre bringing jobs back home. (Applause.)

column1: We sell more products made in America to the rest of the world than ever before. We produce more natural gas than any country on Earth. WeÃ¢ÂÂre about to produce more of our own oil than we buy from abroad for the first time in nearly 20 years. (Applause.) The cost of health care is growing at its slowest rate in 50 years. (Applause.) And our deficits are falling at the fastest rate in 60 years. (Applause.)

So thanks to the grit and resilience and determination of the American people -- of folks like you -- weÃ¢ÂÂve been able to clear away the rubble from the financial crisis. We started to lay a new foundation for stronger
column2: more durable economic growth. And it's happening in our own personal lives as well
column3: right? A lot of us tightened our belts
column4: shed debt
column5: maybe cut up a couple of credit cards
column6: refocused on those things that really matter.

column1: As a country
column2: weÃ¢ÂÂve recovered faster and gone further than most other advanced nations in the world. With new American revolutions in energy and technology and manufacturing and health care
column3: we're actually poised to reverse the forces that battered the middle class for so long
column4: and start building an economy where everyone who works hard can get ahead.

column1: But -- and here's the big Ã¢ÂÂbutÃ¢ÂÂ -- IÃ¢ÂÂm here to tell you today that we're not there yet. We all know that. We're not there yet. We've got more work to do. Even though our businesses are creating new jobs and have broken record profits
column2: nearly all the income gains of the past 10 years have continued to flow to the top 1 percent. The average CEO has gotten a raise of nearly 40 percent since 2009. The average American earns less than he or she did in 1999. And companies continue to hold back on hiring those whoÃ¢ÂÂve been out of work for some time.

column1: Today
column2: more students are earning their degree
column3: but soaring costs saddle them with unsustainable debt. Health care costs are slowing down
column4: but a lot of working families havenÃ¢ÂÂt seen any of those savings yet. The stock market rebound helped a lot of families get back much of what they had lost in their 401(k)s
column5: but millions of Americans still have no idea how theyÃ¢ÂÂre going to be able to retire.

column1: So in many ways
column2: the trends that I spoke about here in 2005 -- eight years ago -- the trend of a winner-take-all economy where a few are doing better and better and better
column3: while everybody else just treads water -- those trends have been made worse by the recession. And that's a problem.

column1: This growing inequality not just of result
column2: inequality of opportunity -- this growing inequality is not just morally wrong
column3: itÃ¢ÂÂs bad economics. Because when middle-class families have less to spend
column4: guess what
column5: businesses have fewer consumers. When wealth concentrates at the very top
column6: it can inflate unstable bubbles that threaten the economy. When the rungs on the ladder of opportunity grow farther and farther apart
column7: it undermines the very essence of America -- that idea that if you work hard you can make it here.

column1: And thatÃ¢ÂÂs why reversing these trends has to be WashingtonÃ¢ÂÂs highest priority. (Applause.) It has to be Washington's highest priority. (Applause.) ItÃ¢ÂÂs certainly my highest priority. (Applause.)
Unfortunately
column2: over the past couple of years
column3: in particular
column4: Washington hasnÃ¢ÂÂt just ignored this problem; too often
column5: Washington has made things worse. (Applause.)

column1: And I have to say that -- because I'm looking around the room -- I've got some friends here not just who are Democrats
column2: I've got some friends here who are Republicans -- (applause) -- and I worked with in the state legislature and they did great work. But right now
column3: what weÃ¢ÂÂve got in Washington
column4: we've seen a sizable group of Republican lawmakers suggest that they wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt vote to pay the very bills that Congress rang up. And that fiasco harmed a fragile recovery in 2011 and we can't afford to repeat that.

column1: Then
column2: rather than reduce our deficits with a scalpel -- by cutting out programs we donÃ¢ÂÂt need
column3: fixing ones that we do need that maybe are in need of reform
column4: making government more efficient -- instead of doing that
column5: we've got folks whoÃ¢ÂÂve insisted on leaving in place a meat cleaver called the sequester that's cost jobs. It's harmed growth. It's hurt our military. It's gutted investments in education and science and medical research. (Applause.)

column1: Almost every credible economist will tell you it's been a huge drag on this recovery. And it means that we're underinvesting in the things that this country needs to make it a magnet for good jobs.
Then
column2: over the last six months
column3: this gridlock has gotten worse. I didn't think that was possible. (Laughter.) The good news is a growing number of Republican senators are looking to join their Democratic counterparts and try to get things done in the Senate. So that's good news. (Applause.) For example
column4: they worked together on an immigration bill that economists say will boost our economy by more than a trillion dollars
column5: strengthen border security
column6: make the system work.

column1: But you've got a faction of Republicans in the House who wonÃ¢ÂÂt even give that bill a vote. And that same group gutted a farm bill that AmericaÃ¢ÂÂs farmers depend on
column2: but also America's most vulnerable children depend on.

column1: AUDIENCE MEMBER: Booo --
THE PRESIDENT: And if you ask some of these folks
column2: some of these folks mostly in the House
column3: about their economic agenda how it is that they'll strengthen the middle class
column4: theyÃ¢ÂÂll shift the topic to Ã¢ÂÂout-of-control government spendingÃ¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ- despite the fact that we've cut the deficit by nearly half as a share of the economy since I took office. (Applause.)

column1: Or theyÃ¢ÂÂll talk about government assistance for the poor
column2: despite the fact that theyÃ¢ÂÂve already cut early education for vulnerable kids. They've already cut insurance for people whoÃ¢ÂÂve lost their jobs through no fault of their own. Or theyÃ¢ÂÂll bring up Obamacare -- this is tried and true -- despite the fact that our businesses have created nearly twice as many jobs in this recovery as businesses had at the same point in the last recovery when there was no Obamacare. (Applause.)

column1: AUDIENCE MEMBER: My daughter has insurance now!
THE PRESIDENT: I appreciate that. (Applause.) ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what this is about. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what this is about. (Applause.) ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what we've been fighting for.
But with this endless parade of distractions and political posturing and phony scandals
column2: Washington has taken its eye off the ball. And I am here to say this needs to stop. (Applause.) This needs to stop.

column1: This moment does not require short-term thinking. It does not require having the same old stale debates. Our focus has to be on the basic economic issues that matter most to you
column2: the people we represent. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what we have to spend our time on and our energy on and our focus on. (Applause.)

column1: And as Washington prepares to enter another budget debate
column2: the stakes for our middle class and everybody who is fighting to get into the middle class could not be higher. The countries that are passive in the face of a global economy
column3: those countries will lose the competition for good jobs. They will lose the competition for high living standards. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs why America has to make the investments necessary to promote long-term growth and shared prosperity -- rebuilding our manufacturing base
column4: educating our workforce
column5: upgrading our transportation systems
column6: upgrading our information networks. (Applause.) ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what we need to be talking about. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what Washington needs to be focused on.

column1: And thatÃ¢ÂÂs why
column2: over the next several weeks
column3: in towns across this country
column4: I will be engaging the American people in this debate. (Applause.) I'll lay out my ideas for how we build on the cornerstones of what it means to be middle class in America
column5: and what it takes to work your way into the middle class in America: Job security
column6: with good wages and durable industries. A good education. A home to call your own. Affordable health care when you get sick. (Applause.) A secure retirement even if youÃ¢ÂÂre not rich. Reducing poverty. Reducing inequality. Growing opportunity. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what we need. (Applause.) ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what we need. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what we need right now. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what we need to be focused on. (Applause.)

column1: Now
column2: some of these ideas IÃ¢ÂÂve talked about before. Some of the ideas I offer will be new. Some will require Congress. Some I will pursue on my own. (Applause.) Some ideas will benefit folks right away. Some will take years to fully implement. But the key is to break through the tendency in Washington to just bounce from crisis to crisis. What we need is not a three-month plan
column3: or even a three-year plan; we need a long-term American strategy
column4: based on steady
column5: persistent effort
column6: to reverse the forces that have conspired against the middle class for decades. That has to be our project. (Applause.)

column1: Now
column2: of course
column3: weÃ¢ÂÂll keep pressing on other key priorities. I want to get this immigration bill done. We still need to work on reducing gun violence. (Applause.) WeÃ¢ÂÂve got to continue to end the war in Afghanistan
column4: rebalance our fight against al Qaeda. (Applause.) We need to combat climate change. WeÃ¢ÂÂve got to standing up for civil rights. WeÃ¢ÂÂve got to stand up for womenÃ¢ÂÂs rights. (Applause.)

column1: So all those issues are important
column2: and weÃ¢ÂÂll be fighting on every one of those issues. But if we donÃ¢ÂÂt have a growing
column3: thriving middle class then we wonÃ¢ÂÂt have the resources to solve a lot of these problems. We wonÃ¢ÂÂt have the resolve
column4: the optimism
column5: the sense of unity that we need to solve many of these other issues.

column1: Now
column2: in this effort
column3: I will look to work with Republicans as well as Democrats wherever I can. And I sincerely believe that there are members of both parties who understand this moment
column4: understand whatÃ¢ÂÂs at stake
column5: and I will welcome ideas from anybody across the political spectrum. But I will not allow gridlock
column6: or inaction
column7: or willful indifference to get in our way. (Applause.)

column1: That means whatever executive authority I have to help the middle class
column2: IÃ¢ÂÂll use it. (Applause.) Where I canÃ¢ÂÂt act on my own and Congress isnÃ¢ÂÂt cooperating
column3: IÃ¢ÂÂll pick up the phone -- IÃ¢ÂÂll call CEOs; IÃ¢ÂÂll call philanthropists; IÃ¢ÂÂll call college presidents; IÃ¢ÂÂll call labor leaders. IÃ¢ÂÂll call anybody who can help -- and enlist them in our efforts. (Applause.)

column1: Because the choices that we
column2: the people
column3: make right now will determine whether or not every American has a fighting chance in the 21st century. And it will lay the foundation for our childrenÃ¢ÂÂs future
column4: our grandchildrenÃ¢ÂÂs future
column5: for all Americans.

column1: So let me give you a quick preview of what IÃ¢ÂÂll be fighting for and why. The first cornerstone of a strong
column2: growing middle class has to be
column3: as I said before
column4: an economy that generates more good jobs in durable
column5: growing industries. That's how this area was built. That's how America prospered. Because anybody who was willing to work
column6: they could go out there and they could find themselves a job
column7: and they could build a life for themselves and their family.

column1: Now
column2: over the past four years
column3: for the first time since the 1990s
column4: the number of American manufacturing jobs has actually gone up instead of down. That's the good news. (Applause.) But we can do more. So IÃ¢ÂÂm going to push new initiatives to help more manufacturers bring more jobs back to the United States. (Applause.) WeÃ¢ÂÂre going to continue to focus on strategies to make sure our tax code rewards companies that are not shipping jobs overseas
column5: but creating jobs right here in the United States of America. (Applause.)

column1: We want to make sure that -- weÃ¢ÂÂre going to create strategies to make sure that good jobs in wind and solar and natural gas that are lowering costs and
column2: at the same time
column3: reducing dangerous carbon pollution happen right here in the United States. (Applause.)

column1: And something that Cheri and I were talking about on the way over here -- IÃ¢ÂÂm going to be pushing to open more manufacturing innovation institutes that turn regions left behind by global competition into global centers of cutting-edge jobs. So letÃ¢ÂÂs tell the world that America is open for business. (Applause.) I know thereÃ¢ÂÂs an old site right here in Galesburg
column2: over on Monmouth Boulevard -- letÃ¢ÂÂs put some folks to work. (Applause.)

column1: Tomorrow
column2: IÃ¢ÂÂll also visit the Port of Jacksonville
column3: Florida to offer new ideas for doing what America has always done best
column4: which is building things. Pat and I were talking before I came -- backstage -- Pat Quinn -- he was talking about how I came over the Don Moffitt Bridge. (Applause.) But weÃ¢ÂÂve got work to do all across the country. WeÃ¢ÂÂve got ports that arenÃ¢ÂÂt ready for the new supertankers that are going to begin passing through the new Panama Canal in two yearsÃ¢ÂÂ time. If we donÃ¢ÂÂt get that done
column5: those tankers are going to go someplace else. WeÃ¢ÂÂve got more than 100
column6: 000 bridges that are old enough to qualify for Medicare. (Laughter and applause.)

column1: Businesses depend on our transportation systems
column2: on our power grids
column3: on our communications networks. And rebuilding them creates good-paying jobs right now that canÃ¢ÂÂt be outsourced. (Applause.)

column1: And by the way
column2: this isnÃ¢ÂÂt a Democratic idea. Republicans built a lot of stuff. This is the Land of Lincoln. Lincoln was all about building stuff -- first Republican President. (Applause.) And yet
column3: as a share of our economy
column4: we invest less in our infrastructure than we did two decades ago. And thatÃ¢ÂÂs inefficient at a time when itÃ¢ÂÂs as cheap as itÃ¢ÂÂs been since the 1950s to build things. ItÃ¢ÂÂs inexcusable at a time when so many of the workers who build stuff for a living are sitting at home waiting for a call.

column1: The longer we put this off
column2: the more expensive it will be and the less competitive we will be. Businesses of tomorrow will not locate near old roads and outdated ports. TheyÃ¢ÂÂll relocate to places with high-speed Internet
column3: and high-tech schools
column4: and systems that move air and auto traffic faster
column5: and not to mention will get parents home quicker from work because weÃ¢ÂÂll be eliminating some of these traffic jams. And we can watch all of that happen in other countries
column6: and start falling behind
column7: or we can choose to make it happen right here
column8: in the United States. (Applause.)

column1: In an age when jobs know no borders
column2: companies are also going to seek out the countries that boast the most talented citizens
column3: and theyÃ¢ÂÂll reward folks who have the skills and the talents they need -- theyÃ¢ÂÂll reward those folks with good pay.

column1: The days when the wages for a worker with a high school degree could keep pace with the earnings of somebody who got some sort of higher education -- those days are over. Everybody here knows that. There are a whole bunch of folks here whose dads or grandpas worked at a plant
column2: didnÃ¢ÂÂt need a high school education. You could just go there. If you were willing to work hard
column3: you might be able to get two jobs. And you could support your family
column4: have a vacation
column5: own your home. But technology and global competition
column6: theyÃ¢ÂÂre not going away. Those old days arenÃ¢ÂÂt coming back.

column1: So we can either throw up our hands and resign ourselves to diminishing living standards
column2: or we can do what America has always done
column3: which is adapt
column4: and pull together
column5: and fight back
column6: and win. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what we have to do. (Applause.)

column1: And that brings me to the second cornerstone of a strong middle class -- and everybody here knows it -- an education that prepares our children and our workers for the global competition that theyÃ¢ÂÂre going to face. (Applause.) And if you think education is expensive
column2: wait until you see how much ignorance costs in the 21st century. (Laughter and applause.)

column1: If we donÃ¢ÂÂt make this investment
column2: weÃ¢ÂÂre going to put our kids
column3: our workers
column4: and our country at a competitive disadvantage for decades. So we have to begin in the earliest years. And thatÃ¢ÂÂs why IÃ¢ÂÂm going to keep pushing to make high-quality preschool available for every 4-year-old in America. (Applause.) Not just because we know it works for our kids
column5: but because it provides a vital support system for working parents.

column1: And IÃ¢ÂÂm going to take action in the education area to spur innovation that donÃ¢ÂÂt require Congress. (Applause.) So
column2: today
column3: for example
column4: as we speak
column5: federal agencies are moving on my plan to connect 99 percent of AmericaÃ¢ÂÂs students to high-speed Internet over the next five years. WeÃ¢ÂÂre making that happen right now. (Applause.) WeÃ¢ÂÂve already begun meeting with business leaders and tech entrepreneurs and innovative educators to identify the best ideas for redesigning our high schools so that they teach the skills required for a high-tech economy.

column1: And weÃ¢ÂÂre also going to keep pushing new efforts to train workers for changing jobs. So here in Galesburg
column2: for example
column3: a lot of the workers that were laid off at Maytag chose to enroll in retraining programs like the one at Carl Sandburg College. (Applause.) And while it didnÃ¢ÂÂt pay off for everyone
column4: a lot of the folks who were retrained found jobs that suited them even better and paid even more than the ones they had lost.

column1: And thatÃ¢ÂÂs why IÃ¢ÂÂve asked Congress to start a Community College to Career initiative
column2: so that workers can earn the skills that high-tech jobs demand without leaving their hometown. (Applause.) And IÃ¢ÂÂm going to challenge CEOs from some of AmericaÃ¢ÂÂs best companies to hire more Americans whoÃ¢ÂÂve got what it takes to fill that job opening but have been laid off for so long that nobody is giving their rÃÂ©sumÃÂ© an honest look.

column1: AUDIENCE MEMBER: More talent!
THE PRESIDENT: That
column2: too.

column1: IÃ¢ÂÂm also going to use the power of my office over the next few months to highlight a topic thatÃ¢ÂÂs straining the budgets of just about every American family -- and thatÃ¢ÂÂs the soaring cost of higher education. (Applause.) Everybody is touched by this
column2: including your President
column3: who had a whole bunch of loans he had to pay off. (Laughter.)

column1: Three years ago
column2: I worked with Democrats to reform the student loan system so that taxpayer dollars stopped padding the pockets of big banks
column3: and instead helped more kids afford college. (Applause.) Then
column4: I capped loan repayments at 10 percent of monthly incomes for responsible borrowers
column5: so that if somebody graduated and they decided to take a teaching job
column6: for example
column7: that didnÃ¢ÂÂt pay a lot of money
column8: they knew that they were never going to have to pay more than 10 percent of their income and they could afford to go into a profession that they loved. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs in place right now. (Applause.) And this week
column9: weÃ¢ÂÂre working with both parties to reverse the doubling of student loan rates that happened a few weeks ago because of congressional inaction. (Applause.)

column1: So this is all a good start -- but it isnÃ¢ÂÂt enough. Families and taxpayers canÃ¢ÂÂt just keep paying more and more and more into an undisciplined system where costs just keep on going up and up and up. WeÃ¢ÂÂll never have enough loan money
column2: weÃ¢ÂÂll never have enough grant money
column3: to keep up with costs that are going up 5
column5: 7 percent a year. WeÃ¢ÂÂve got to get more out of what we pay for.

column1: Now
column2: some colleges are testing new approaches to shorten the path to a degree
column3: or blending teaching with online learning to help students master material and earn credits in less time. In some states
column4: theyÃ¢ÂÂre testing new ways to fund college based not just on how many students enroll
column5: but how many of them graduate
column6: how well did they do.

column1: So this afternoon
column2: IÃ¢ÂÂll visit the University of Central Missouri to highlight their efforts to deliver more bang for the buck to their students. And in the coming months
column3: I will lay out an aggressive strategy to shake up the system
column4: tackle rising costs
column5: and improve value for middle-class students and their families. It is critical that we make sure that college is affordable for every single American whoÃ¢ÂÂs willing to work for it. (Applause.)

column1: Now
column2: so youÃ¢ÂÂve got a good job; you get a good education -- those have always been the key stepping stones into the middle class. But a home of your own has always been the clearest expression of middle-class security. For most families
column3: thatÃ¢ÂÂs your biggest asset. For most families
column4: thatÃ¢ÂÂs where your lifeÃ¢ÂÂs work has been invested. And that changed during the crisis
column5: when we saw millions of middle-class families experience their home values plummeting. The good news is over the past four years
column6: weÃ¢ÂÂve helped more responsible homeowners stay in their homes. And today
column7: sales are up and prices are up
column8: and fewer Americans see their homes underwater.

column1: But weÃ¢ÂÂre not done yet. The key now is to encourage homeownership that isnÃ¢ÂÂt based on unrealistic bubbles
column2: but instead is based on a solid foundation
column3: where buyers and lenders play by the same set of rules
column4: rules that are clear and transparent and fair.

column1: So already
column2: IÃ¢ÂÂve asked Congress to pass a really good
column3: bipartisan idea -- one that was championed
column4: by the way
column5: by Mitt RomneyÃ¢ÂÂs economic advisor -- and this is the idea to give every homeowner the chance to refinance their mortgage while rates are still low so they can save thousands of dollars a year. (Applause.) It will be like a tax cut for families who can refinance.

column1: IÃ¢ÂÂm also acting on my own to cut red tape for responsible families who want to get a mortgage but the bank is saying no. WeÃ¢ÂÂll work with both parties to turn the page on Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac
column2: and build a housing finance system thatÃ¢ÂÂs rock-solid for future generations.

column1: So weÃ¢ÂÂve got more work to do to strengthen homeownership in this country. But along with homeownership
column2: the fourth cornerstone of what it means to be middle class in this country is a secure retirement. (Applause.) I hear from too many people across the country
column3: face to face or in letters that they send me
column4: that they feel as if retirement is just receding from their grasp. ItÃ¢ÂÂs getting farther and farther away. They can't see it.

column1: Now
column2: today
column3: a rising stock market has millions of retirement balances going up
column4: and some of the losses that had taken place during the financial crisis have been recovered. But we still live with an upside-down system where those at the top
column5: folks like me
column6: get generous tax incentives to save
column7: while tens of millions of hardworking Americans who are struggling
column8: they get none of those breaks at all. So as we work to reform our tax code
column9: we should find new ways to make it easier for workers to put away money
column10: and free middle-class families from the fear that they won't be able to retire. (Applause.)

column1: And if Congress is looking for a bipartisan place to get started
column2: I should just say they donÃ¢ÂÂt have to look far. We mentioned immigration reform before. Economists show that immigration reform makes undocumented workers pay their full share of taxes
column3: and that actually shores up the Social Security system for years. So we should get that done. (Applause.)

column1: Good job; good education for your kids; home of your own; secure retirement.
Fifth
column2: I'm going to keep focusing on health care -- (applause) -- because middle-class families and small business owners deserve the security of knowing that neither an accident or an illness is going to threaten the dreams that youÃ¢ÂÂve worked a lifetime to build.

column1: As we speak
column2: we're well on our way to fully implementing the Affordable Care Act. (Applause.) We're going to implement it. Now
column3: if youÃ¢ÂÂre one of the 85 percent of Americans who already have health insurance either through the job or Medicare or Medicaid
column4: you donÃ¢ÂÂt have to do anything
column5: but you do have new benefits and better protections than you did before. You may not know it
column6: but you do. Free checkups
column7: mammograms
column8: discounted medicines if you're on Medicare -- thatÃ¢ÂÂs what the Affordable Care Act means. You're already getting a better deal. No lifetime limits.

column1: If you donÃ¢ÂÂt have health insurance
column2: then starting on October 1st
column3: private plans will actually compete for your business
column4: and you'll be able to comparison-shop online. There will be a marketplace online
column5: just like youÃ¢ÂÂd buy a flat-screen TV or plane tickets or anything else you're doing online
column6: and you'll be able to buy an insurance package that fits your budget and is right for you.

column1: And if you're one of the up to half of all Americans whoÃ¢ÂÂve been sick or have a preexisting condition -- if you look at this auditorium
column2: about half of you probably have a preexisting condition that insurance companies could use to not give you insurance if you lost your job or lost your insurance -- well
column3: this law means that beginning January 1st
column4: insurance companies will finally have to cover you and charge you the same rates as everybody else
column5: even if you have a preexisting condition. (Applause.) ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what the Affordable Care Act does. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what it does. (Applause.)

column1: Now
column2: look
column3: I know because I've been living it that there are folks out there who are actively working to make this law fail. And I donÃ¢ÂÂt always understand exactly what their logic is here
column4: why they think giving insurance to folks who donÃ¢ÂÂt have it and making folks with insurance a little more secure
column5: why they think thatÃ¢ÂÂs a bad thing. But despite the politically motivated misinformation campaign
column6: the states that have committed themselves to making this law work are finding that competition and choice are actually pushing costs down.

column2: New York announced that premiums for consumers who buy their insurance in these online marketplaces will be at least 50 percent lower than what they're "	0

Layoffs and discharges are involuntary separations initiated by the employer. Other separations include separations due to retirement
column30: and transfers to other locations of the same firm. The number and rate of total separations in September changed little at 5.5 million and 3.5 percent
column32: the number of total separations decreased in state and local government education (-42
column36: the number of quits changed little at 3.7 million
column37: and the rate was 2.3 percent for the 3rd consecutive month. The number of quits increased in information (+24
column38: 000) but decreased in state and local government
column41: the number and rate of layoffs and discharges changed little at 1.5 million and 1.0 percent
column42: respectively. The number of layoffs and discharges decreased in state and local government education (-22
column43: 000). (See table 5.) The number of other separations changed little in September at 352
column44: 000. (See table 6.) Establishment Size Class In September
column47: and total separations rates changed little for establishments with 1 to 9 employees. The job openings rate decreased for establishments with 5
column48: 000 or more employees. (See table 7.) ____________ The Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey estimates for October 2023 are scheduled to be released on Tuesday

column1: Technical Note This news release presents statistics from the Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey (JOLTS). The JOLTS program provides information on labor demand and turnover. Additional information about the JOLTS program can be found at www.bls.gov/jlt/. Estimates are published for job openings
column2: hires
column3: quits
column4: layoffs and discharges
column5: other separations
column6: and total separations. The JOLTS program covers all private nonfarm establishments
column7: as well as civilian federal
column8: state
column9: and local government entities in the 50 states and the District of Columbia. Starting with data for January 2023
column10: industries are classified in accordance with the 2022 North American Industry Classification System. Definitions Employment. Employment includes persons on the payroll who worked or received pay for the pay period that includes the 12th day of the reference month. Full-time
column11: part-time
column12: permanent
column13: short-term
column14: seasonal
column15: salaried
column16: and hourly employees are included
column17: as are employees on paid vacation or other paid leave. Proprietors or partners of unincorporated businesses
column19: employees on strike for the entire pay period
column20: and employees on leave without pay for the entire pay period are not counted as employed. Employees of temporary help agencies
column21: employee leasing companies
column23: and consultants are counted by their employer of record
column24: not by the establishment where they are working. JOLTS does not publish employment estimates but uses the reported employment for validation of the other reported data elements. Job Openings. Job openings include all positions that are open on the last business day of the reference month. A job is open only if it meets all three of these conditions: * A specific position exists
column25: and there is work available for that position. The position can be full-time or part-time
column28: or seasonal. * The job could start within 30 days
column29: whether or not the employer can find a suitable candidate during that time. * The employer is actively recruiting workers from outside the establishment to fill the position. Active recruiting means that the establishment is taking steps to fill a position. It may include advertising in newspapers
column31: or on the radio; posting internet notices
column33: networking or making Ã¢ÂÂword-of-mouthÃ¢ÂÂ announcements; accepting applications; interviewing candidates; contacting employment agencies; or soliciting employees at job fairs
column35: or similar sources. Excluded are positions open only to internal transfers
column37: or recall from layoffs. Also excluded are openings for positions with start dates more than 30 days in the future; positions for which employees have been hired but have not yet reported for work; and positions to be filled by employees of temporary help agencies
column40: or consultants. The job openings rate is computed by dividing the number of job openings by the sum of employment and job openingsÃ¢ÂÂthat is
column41: all filled and unfilled jobsÃ¢ÂÂand multiplying that quotient by 100. Hires. Hires include all additions to the payroll during the entire reference month
column42: including newly hired and rehired employees; full-time and part-time employees; permanent
column44: and seasonal employees; employees who were recalled to a job at the location following a layoff (formal suspension from pay status) lasting more than 7 days; on-call or intermittent employees who returned to work after having been formally separated; workers who were hired and separated during the month
column45: and transfers from other locations. Excluded are transfers or promotions within the reporting location
column50: or consultants. The hires rate is computed by dividing the number of hires by employment and multiplying that quotient by 100. Separations. Separations include all separations from the payroll during the entire reference month and is reported by type of separation: quits
column52: and other separations. Quits include employees who left voluntarily
column53: with the exception of retirements or transfers to other locations. Layoffs and discharges includes involuntary separations initiated by the employer
column54: including layoffs with no intent to rehire; layoffs (formal suspensions from pay status) lasting or expected to last more than 7 days; discharges resulting from mergers
column56: or closings; firings or other discharges for cause; terminations of permanent or short-term employees; and terminations of seasonal employees (whether or not they are expected to return the next season). Other separations include retirements
column59: and deaths. Excluded from separations measures are transfers within the same location; employees on strike; and employees of temporary help agencies
column62: or consultants. The separations rate is computed by dividing the number of separations by employment and multiplying that quotient by 100. The quits
column64: and other separations rates are computed similarly. Estimation Method The JOLTS survey design is a stratified random sample of approximately 21
column65: 000 nonfarm business and government establishments. The sample is stratified by ownership
column68: and establishment size class. The sampling frame is made up of establishments from two sources: the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) Quarterly Census of Employment and Wages program (QCEW) and the Federal Railroad Administration (FRA). The QCEW database contains establishments that cover approximately 95 percent of nonfarm payroll jobs in the United States. This database is a compilation of administrative data from state unemployment insurance (UI) programs and federal government establishments covered by the Unemployment Compensation for Federal Employees (UCFE) program. A frame of railroad establishments is provided by the FRA. This is added to the QCEW database to complete the JOLTS sampling frame. The JOLTS estimation method involves the following processes: unit nonresponse adjustment
column76: and variance estimates. Establishment size class levels are also produced. Detailed information about the estimation method can be found in the Handbook of Methods at https://www.bls.gov/opub/hom/jlt/home.htm. Monthly benchmarking is the process through which the JOLTS weighted employment for each estimation cell is adjusted. JOLTS estimation cells are benchmarked monthly to the current employment level from the BLS Current Employment Statistics (CES) program. The sampled weight is benchmarked to ensure that JOLTS weighted employment is equal to CES employment. Birth/death model. The time lag from the start up
column78: of an establishment until its appearance on the sampling frame is approximately one year. In addition
column79: many new establishments fail within the first year
column80: referred to as a death. Because new and short-lived universe establishments cannot be reflected in the sampling frame immediately
column81: the JOLTS sample cannot capture job openings
column83: and separations from these establishments during their early existence. BLS has developed a birth/death model that uses establishment birth and death activity from previous years as collected by the QCEW and projects forward to the present using over-the-year change in the CES. The birth/death model also uses historical JOLTS data to calculate the amount of churn (meaning the rates of hires and separations) that exists in establishments of various sizes. The model then combines the calculated churn with the projected employment change to estimate the number of hires and separations that take place in these establishments that cannot be measured through sampling. The estimates of job openings
column85: and separations produced by the birth/death model are added to the sample-based estimates produced from the survey to arrive at the estimates for job openings
column87: and separations. Alignment. The JOLTS figure for hires minus separations can be used to derive a measure of net employment change. This change should be comparable to the net employment change from the much larger CES survey. However
column88: definitional differences between the two surveys
column89: as well as sampling and nonsampling errors
column90: historically caused JOLTS to diverge from CES over time. To limit the divergence and improve the quality of the JOLTS hires and separations series
column91: BLS implemented the monthly alignment method. There are four steps to this method: seasonally adjust
column93: back out the seasonal adjustment factors
column94: and seasonally adjust again. Seasonal adjustment. After alignment
column95: the seasonal adjustment program (X-13ARIMA-SEATS) is used to seasonally adjust the JOLTS series. Each month
column96: a concurrent seasonal adjustment methodology uses all relevant data
column97: up to and including the current month
column98: to calculate new seasonal adjustment factors. Moving averages are used as seasonal filters in seasonal adjustment. JOLTS seasonal adjustment includes both additive and multiplicative models
column99: as well as regression with autocorrelated errors (REGARIMA) modeling
column100: to improve the seasonal adjustment factors at the beginning and end of the series and to detect and adjust for outliers in the series. Annual estimates and benchmarking. The JOLTS estimates are revised annually with the issuance of data for January. Five years of data are subject to revision. The revised estimates incorporate: 1) benchmarks based on CES employment estimates newly benchmarked to QCEW
column102: and 3) any needed special adjustments. The JOLTS employment levels are ratio-adjusted to the CES employment levels
column103: and the resulting ratios are applied to all JOLTS data elements. The seasonally adjusted estimates are recalculated for the most recent 5 years to reflect updated seasonal adjustment factors. These annual updates result in revisions to both the seasonally adjusted and not seasonally adjusted JOLTS data series for the period since the last benchmark was established. Annual levels for hires
column107: and total separations are the sum of the 12 published monthly levels. Annual average levels for job openings are calculated by dividing the sum of the 12 published monthly levels by 12. Annual average rates for hires
column111: and total separations are calculated by dividing the sum of the 12 monthly JOLTS published levels for each data element by the sum of the 12 monthly CES published employment levels
column112: and multiplying that quotient by 100. Annual average rates for job openings are calculated by dividing the sum of the 12 monthly JOLTS published levels by the sum of the 12 monthly CES published employment levels plus the sum of the 12 monthly job openings levels
column113: and multiplying that quotient by 100. Reliability of the estimates JOLTS estimates are subject to two types of error: sampling error and nonsampling error. Sampling error can result when a sample
column115: is surveyed. There is a chance that the sample estimates may differ from the true population values they represent. The exact difference
column118: and this variability is measured by the standard error of the estimate. BLS analyses are generally conducted at the 90-percent level of confidence. This means that there is a 90-percent chance that the true population mean will fall into the interval created by the sample mean plus or minus 1.65 standard errors. Estimates of median standard errors are released monthly as part of the significant change tables on the JOLTS webpage. Standard errors are updated annually with the most recent 5 years of data. Sampling error estimates are available at www.bls.gov/jlt/jolts_median_standard_errors.htm. Nonsampling error can occur for many reasons
column119: including the failure to include a segment of the population
column120: the inability to obtain data from all units in the sample
column121: the inability or unwillingness of respondents to provide data on a timely basis
column123: errors made in the collection or processing of the data
column124: and errors from the employment benchmark data used in estimation. The JOLTS program uses quality control procedures to reduce nonsampling error in the surveyÃ¢ÂÂs design. Other information If you are deaf
column127: please dial 7-1-1 to access telecommunications relay services.

column1: 343	"A fake news article said actress Sandra Bullock praised President Donald Trump while telling Hillary Clinton she could leave the United States if she isnÃ¢ÂÂt happy with how things are going.
Actress Sandra Bullock to Hillary Clinton: Ã¢ÂÂif you donÃ¢ÂÂt like our president you can leave and never come back again
column2: you are one jealous woman who is nothing to compare with Trump
column3: I hope he will arrest you soon
column4: Ã¢ÂÂ"" said a Dec. 25 headline on Flash 24 Daily.

column1: Facebook users flagged the post as being potentially fabricated
column2: as part of the social networkÃ¢ÂÂs efforts to combat fake news. We found no evidence that Bullock made the statement about Clinton. The same story has circulated on various websites on Facebook at least since October.

column1: While the headline showed Bullock bashing Clinton
column2: the article itself didnÃ¢ÂÂt include any quotes by Bullock in which she mentioned Clinton or Trump by name.

column1: The article said that the quotes by Bullock came from her press conference for her ""new film
column2: Our Brand Is Crisis. One big hint that this is fake news: that movie was released in 2015. In the movie
column3: Bullock played a political consultant drafted to help the president of Bolivia win re-election as she competed with her rival working for another candidate.

column1: At a press conference in October 2015 for her movie
column2: Bullock said she disagreed with Trump when asked about his comments about Mexican-Americans.

column1: I donÃ¢ÂÂt agree with that at all
column2: Bullock said. ""That was not a statement that I can get behind. I donÃ¢ÂÂt agree with that statement.""

column1: The Flash 24 Daily article included some actual quotes by Bullock from that press conference about how her views are influenced by her son. Bullock has adopted two African-American children -- a boy and a girl.
I would like my rights represented and those of my son Ã¢ÂÂ very selfish views
column2: and I think everyone else has them
column3: she says. ""When this film came along
column4: it came along at a time that I was having that internal discussion with myself about who in our country would step out of their comfort zone to help others for the greater good.""

column1: We found no evidence that Bullock said to Clinton ""if you donÃ¢ÂÂt like our president you can leave and never come back again."" We rate this headline Pants on Fire."	1
344	"For Immediate Release: February 26
column2: 2018 Statement From: Scott Gottlieb
column3: M.D.

column1: EspaÃÂ±ol
The current influenza season has been especially difficult
column2: causing widespread illness that has affected all fifty states and resulted in a record number of hospitalizations. While healthcare professionals continue to combat this yearÃ¢ÂÂs flu Ã¢ÂÂ which may continue to affect Americans into April Ã¢ÂÂ weÃ¢ÂÂre already partnering with other public health agencies to conduct essential work to produce next seasonÃ¢ÂÂs influenza vaccines.

column1: As part of this process
column2: weÃ¢ÂÂre striving to better understand why we saw reduced effectiveness of this yearÃ¢ÂÂs influenza vaccines against one strain of influenza A
column3: called H3N2. It was this strain that caused much of the influenza-related illness this flu season. Moreover
column4: this year is not the first time we have seen vaccines be less effective against this particular strain of influenza
column5: H3N2.

column1: As such
column2: we are taking a number of actions to better understand why effectiveness tends to be lower against the H3N2 strain and what we can do about it. By looking closely at the available data and applying the lessons we learn each flu season to the vaccine development process
column3: we offer the greatest chance of developing vaccines that even more effectively prevent the flu in the future.

column1: These lessons may be applied not only to enhancing the most prevalent process for developing influenza vaccine in eggs
column2: but to considering whether greater investment in alternative processes such as cell-based or recombinant approaches to vaccine development are required. With this statement
column3: I want to outline what weÃ¢ÂÂve learned so far about this seasonÃ¢ÂÂs vaccines and the steps weÃ¢ÂÂre taking and plan to take to determine the root cause of this yearÃ¢ÂÂs findings and better prepare for future flu seasons.

column1: Reduced effectiveness of 2017-2018 seasonal vaccines against H3N2
There are a number of theories on why this seasonÃ¢ÂÂs vaccines produced reduced effectiveness against H3N2. WeÃ¢ÂÂre taking steps to investigate each of these potential causes
column2: rule out possible reasons for the variation in effectiveness and improve vaccine efficacy against H3N2. Overall
column3: preliminary vaccine effectiveness reported by Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) for H3N2 influenza was 25 percent
column4: which means that people who received the vaccine were 25 percent less likely to be sick and need to see a doctor.

column1: While that finding isnÃ¢ÂÂt too far off from the vaccine effectiveness seen against H3N2 in previous years
column2: we need to take new steps to improve vaccine efficacy against H3N2. Of note
column3: the effectiveness of the vaccine against H3N2 in children 6 months to 8 years of age was 51 percent this season
column4: yet the effectiveness in those 65 years and older was only 17 percent
column5: and the effectiveness in older children and adults under 65 years of age was even lower. The vaccines did do much better for other viruses that are also causing the flu this season. The data show that overall vaccine effectiveness for H1N1 and influenza B was 67 percent and 42 percent
column6: respectively
column7: for all age groups combined.

column1: So why did this seasonÃ¢ÂÂs vaccines not deliver higher protection against H3N2? And why have vaccines in prior seasons when H3N2 circulated
column2: also delivered reduced protection against this particular flu strain?

column1: We donÃ¢ÂÂt think it was a question of getting the particular H3N2 strain wrong when we set out to produce this seasonÃ¢ÂÂs flu vaccines. Although adapting circulating virus strains for manufacture can lead to differences between the circulating strain and the one used for manufacturing that could affect effectiveness
column2: so far the data we have suggests that the viruses provided by reference laboratories to manufacturers to make this yearÃ¢ÂÂs vaccines do reasonably match the circulating flu strains that are causing most of the illnesses
column3: including H3N2.

column1: However
column2: weÃ¢ÂÂre working with our colleagues at CDC and other federal agencies to examine and address other factors that might be contributing to the less than optimal overall protection provided by this seasonÃ¢ÂÂs vaccines against influenza. We would particularly like to understand why vaccine effectiveness against H3N2 influenza year-to-year tends to be lower than effectiveness against other influenza viruses.

column1: Working to determine the root causes
Toward these ends
column2: scientists at FDA are collaborating with colleagues at Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) to use a large database that includes details of the flu vaccines administered to four million individuals along with whether they were hospitalized for influenza or treated with antiviral medications for influenza-like illness. This work
column3: which is still underway
column4: will try to better understand why overall effectiveness with both the cell-based and egg-based vaccines was less than optimal. WeÃ¢ÂÂre also looking at the difference in effectiveness in people 65 years and older who were vaccinated with high-dose influenza vaccine and adjuvanted influenza vaccine to see if effectiveness was better than in those vaccinated with standard dose vaccines. The adjuvanted influenza vaccine contains an ingredient meant to boost the immune systemÃ¢ÂÂs response to the vaccine while high dose vaccines contain four times as much of the influenza material or antigen as standard vaccines. What we learn about the differences in efficacy between these different vaccines might reveal information that can inform why overall effectiveness against H3N2 was lagging.

column1: What might this information reveal? One theory is that people might require a higher amount of H3N2 antigen to elicit a proper immune response to that particular strain of influenza. As I noted previously
column2: the work conducted with CMS shows a preliminary finding that suggests the cell-based influenza vaccine might be somewhat more effective than the egg-based vaccine. We are working to follow up on that finding. WeÃ¢ÂÂre also combing through the data to see if there are other reasons for why this seasonÃ¢ÂÂs vaccines were less effective against H3N2. Our scientists are currently working internally and collaborating with others inside and outside of the federal government to understand all of these findings.

column1: The knowledge we gain through such scientific research will allow us to determine if we need to change recommendations to vaccine manufacturers for how future seasonÃ¢ÂÂs vaccines should be produced.
Looking ahead to the 2018-2019 flu season
While this scientific work is underway
column2: the composition of next seasonÃ¢ÂÂs flu vaccines will be the subject of an FDA advisory committee meeting March 1
column3: 2018. As is done every year
column4: the FDA convenes this panel to consider the recommendations made by the World Health Organization (WHO) regarding the composition of influenza vaccines for the Northern Hemisphere
column5: and to help the FDA select strains for next seasonÃ¢ÂÂs flu vaccines in the U.S. WHO has recommended changing two of the strains currently contained in this yearÃ¢ÂÂs influenza vaccines for the Northern Hemisphere. The upcoming FDA advisory committee meeting will determine if these recommendations should also apply for the U.S. Following that meeting
column6: the FDA will also work to apply all the knowledge that we gain from this yearÃ¢ÂÂs flu season to ensure that the best possible vaccines are available next season to protect against the flu.

column1: In the meantime
column2: this flu season isnÃ¢ÂÂt over yet
column3: though CDC data shows a decline in visits to doctorÃ¢ÂÂs offices and outpatient clinics. We must continue to be diligent in doing our part to prevent the spread of flu however possible
column4: including remembering to wash your hands frequently and staying home when you are sick. ItÃ¢ÂÂs also not too late get vaccinated if you have not yet done so
column5: given that we are starting to see a larger proportion of illnesses caused by H1N1 and B influenza for which vaccines offer better protection. Vaccinations have also been shown to reduce the severity of the flu in people who get sick. People who are very sick with flu-like symptoms and those who are at high risk of serious flu complications should see a healthcare professional as soon as possible to see if they should be treated with antiviral drugs.

column1: The FDA remains committed to determining the root cause for the shortcomings observed in the effectiveness of this seasonÃ¢ÂÂs flu vaccine against H3N2
column2: notifying the public of our work as we gain new insights
column3: and applying what we learn to future vaccine development. Our aim is to make sure we continue to improve the effectiveness of future flu vaccines
column4: and encourage more people to seek vaccination.

column4: effectiveness
column5: and security of human and veterinary drugs
column6: vaccines and other biological products for human use
column7: and medical devices. The agency also is responsible for the safety and security of our nationÃ¢ÂÂs food supply
column8: cosmetics
column9: dietary supplements
column10: products that give off electronic radiation
column11: and for regulating tobacco products.

column2: Hannity said.

column1: Now
column2: this is a terrorist act
column3: Hannity said. ""What does that say about Barack Obama and our government?""

column1: Here's the point
column2: Hannity said
column3: ""Barack Obama won't even use the term 'war on terrorism
column4: ' because he's apologizing to America in every Muslim country he can.""

column1: We've heard a number of conservative radio and talk show hosts criticize President Obama for not using the ""global war on terrorism"" phrase adopted by his predecessor
column2: George W. Bush. And so we decided to check it out.

column1: We did a word search of Obama's public statements and could not find that Obama has used the phrase ""war on terrorism"" as president
column2: though he said it numerous times as a candidate. And early in his presidency
column3: Obama used the phrase ""war on terror
column4: but only a couple of times.

column1: So what gives? We found two instances where Obama directly addressed the question.
The first was during a Jan. 27
column3: interview by Hisham Melhem with al-Aribiya
column4: an Arabic-language television news station. Melhem noted that Obama seemed to eschew Bush's phrase ""war on terror"" and ""frame it in a different way
column5: specifically against one group called al-Qaida and their collaborators.""

column1: Obama: ""I think that you're making a very important point. And that is that the language we use matters. And what we need to understand is
column2: is that there are extremist organizations -- whether Muslim or any other faith in the past -- that will use faith as a justification for violence. We cannot paint with a broad brush a faith as a consequence of the violence that is done in that faith's name.

column1: And so you will
column2: I think
column3: see our administration be very clear in distinguishing between organizations like al-Qaida -- that espouse violence
column4: espouse terror and act on it -- and people who may disagree with my administration and certain actions
column5: or may have a particular viewpoint in terms of how their countries should develop. We can have legitimate disagreements but still be respectful. I cannot respect terrorist organizations that would kill innocent civilians
column6: and we will hunt them down.

column1: But to the broader Muslim world what we are going to be offering is a hand of friendship.""
The issue was again raised in a Feb. 3
column3: interview with CNN's Anderson Cooper:

column1: Cooper: ""I've noticed you don't use the term 'war on terror.' I think I read an article that you've only used it once since inauguration. Is that conscious? Is there something about that term you find objectionable or not useful?""
Obama: ""Well
column2: you know
column3: I think it is very important for us to recognize that we have a battle or a war against some terrorist organizations. But that those organizations aren't representative of a broader Arab community
column4: Muslim community. ... You know
column5: words matter in this situation because one of the ways we're going to win this struggle is through the battle of hearts and minds.""

column1: Cooper: ""So that's not a term you're going to be using much in the future?""
Obama: ""You know
column2: what I want to do is make sure that I'm constantly talking about al-Qaida and other affiliated organizations because we
column3: I believe
column4: can win over moderate Muslims to recognize that that kind of destruction and nihilism ultimately leads to a dead end
column5: and that we should be working together to make sure that everybody has got a better life.""

column1: So Obama isn't fond of the phrase ""war on terror."" But did that ever become blanket White House policy?
According to a Washington Post story in March
column2: a memo e-mailed to Pentagon staff members from the Defense Department's office of security review said ""this administration prefers to avoid using the term 'Long War' or ""Global War on Terror.' Please use 'Overseas Contingency Operation.' "" According to the memo
column3: the direction came from the White House Office of Management and Budget
column4: which reviews speeches given by administration officials.

column1: Kenneth Baer
column2: an OMB spokesman
column3: told the Washington Post there was no such guidance
column4: that it was only the opinion of ""a career civil servant.""

column1: Still
column2: you don't hear administration officials using the term ""war on terror
column3: or the like
column4: very often.

column1: Obama was criticized in some circles when he failed to even utter the words ""terror"" or ""terrorism"" in a June 4
column3: speech in Cairo
column4: Egypt
column5: directed to Muslims around the world.

column1: The absence of those words ""goes to the heart"" of Obama's new approach
column2: said John O. Brennan
column3: assistant to the president for homeland security and counterterrorism
column4: who provided perhaps the clearest and most in-depth explanation of the White House lexicon in a speech at the Center for Strategic and International Studies on Aug. 6

column1: As many have noted
column2: the president does not describe this as a 'war on terrorism.' ... Instead
column3: as the president has made clear
column4: we are at war with al-Qaida
column5: which attacked us on 9/11 and killed 3
column6: 000 people. We are at war with its violent extremist allies who seek to carry on al-QaidaÃ¢ÂÂs murderous agenda. These are the terrorists we will destroy. These are the extremists we will defeat.""

column1: Brennan warned that it would be wrong for people to conclude that Obama is not committed to fighting terrorism. ""President Obama has articulated a clear policy Ã¢ÂÂ to disrupt
column2: dismantle
column3: and defeat al-Qaida and its allies
column4: Brennan said. ""That is our mission
column5: and the president described it in no uncertain terms in his inaugural when he said
column6: 'Our nation is at war against a far-reaching network of violence and hatred.' And to win this war against al-Qaida
column7: the administration continues to be unrelenting
column8: using every tool in our toolbox and every arrow in our quiver.""

column1: Our aim here is not to wade into the war of words over the ""war on terror."" Rather
column2: we just wanted to see if Hannity was right that Obama won't use the term ""war on terrorism."" And except in a couple of instances where he used the phrase ""war on terror
column3: Obama has generally employed different words. And it's deliberate
column4: as he has explained on several occasions. Obama provides nuanced explanations for his word choices
column5: and you may agree or disagree with them
column6: but the bottom line is that Obama has chosen not to use the phrase ""war on terrorism."" And so we rate Hannity's statement True."	0

358	"(Jim Lo Scalzo for USN&WR)
1. One of six children (and the only daughter)
column2: Nancy (Patricia D'Alesandro) Pelosi was born on March 26
column4: and grew up in Baltimore's Little Italy.

column1: 2. Pelosi's father
column2: Tommy D'Alesandro
column3: was a legendary Democratic congressman and Baltimore mayor. Her brother Thomas would also go on to become mayor of Baltimore.

column1: 3. Seemingly
column2: Pelosi was a Democrat from birthÃ¢ÂÂas a young girl
column3: she was offered a toy elephant by a Republican poll worker but recoiled
column4: refusing the toy.

column1: 4. A devout Catholic
column2: Pelosi attended a Roman Catholic women's college
column3: Trinity College
column4: in Washington
column5: D.C.
column6: where she met her future husband
column7: Paul Pelosi
column8: who was attending Georgetown. They eventually relocated to his hometown
column9: San Francisco.

column1: 5. Pelosi is mother to fiveÃ¢ÂÂNancy Corinne
column2: Christine
column3: Jacqueline
column4: Paul
column5: and Alexandra
column6: all born within six yearsÃ¢ÂÂand grandmother to five.

column1: 6. Although active in politics her whole lifeÃ¢ÂÂincluding stints as a leading Democratic fundraiser and chairwoman of the party in CaliforniaÃ¢ÂÂPelosi didn't run for office until she was 47
column2: preferring to wait until the youngest of her five children was a high school senior before running for Congress in 1987.

column1: 7. Republican National Committee Chairman Ken Mehlman said that she was neither a ""new Democrat"" nor an ""old Democrat"" but a ""prehistoric Democrat."" Other Republicans call her a ""latte Democrat"" for her politically progressive views on the environment
column2: women's reproductive rights
column3: labor unions
column4: and other issues.

column1: 8. Pelosi has been a formidable force within the Democratic Party
column2: raising more money than any other congressional DemocratÃ¢ÂÂaround $100 million since taking the reins of party leadership. And she has managed to keep the House Dems toeing the party line: According to Congressional Quarterly
column3: House Democrats voted with the majority of their party 88 percent of the time in 2005
column4: the highest total since CQ started keeping track in 1956.

column1: 9. Pelosi learned the art of politics from her father
column2: a practitioner of old-school politics. To practice her penmanship
column3: ""Little Nancy"" was in charge of the book in which her New Deal father kept track of favors done and owed.

column1: 10. A true San Franciscan
column2: Pelosi makes sure that her office is stocked with Ghirardelli chocolates. Her diet typically consists of mostly chocolate and chocolate ice cream. Completing the notoriously challenging New York Times crossword puzzle is one of her favorite hobbies.
