359	"U.S. Rep. H. Morgan Griffith is milking his opposition to the Environmental Protection Agency for every last drop.
The Republican stressed his contempt for the agency throughout a heated campaign last fall in which Griffith unseated Democrat Rick Boucher
column2: a 14-term congressman from coal-rich Southwest Virginia. In his victory speech
column3: Griffith vowed to go to Washington and ""fight to rein in the EPA."" Since taking office
column4: he has fired out a barrage of anti-EPA statements.

column1: In a February newsletter to constituents
column2: Griffith claimed that new EPA rules treat milk spills the same way they treat oil spills. He titled the newsletter ""Crying over spilt milk.""

column1: What do spilt milk and oil have in common?"" he wrote. ""Quite a bit
column2: according to the EPA. In fact
column3: a new ruling by the EPA would force dairy farmers to comply with the Spill Prevention
column4: Control and Countermeasure Program when dealing with spilt milk -- the same regulations oil and natural gas producers must follow. The EPAÃ¢ÂÂs reasoning is that milk contains Ã¢ÂÂa percentage of animal fats
column5: which is a non-petroleum oil.Ã¢ÂÂ It appears spilt milk is just as threatening as an oil spill.""

column1: With visions of dairy farmers delicately dabbing milk off the wings of ducks
column2: we looked into the claim.

column1: Beth Breeding
column2: GriffithÃ¢ÂÂs press secretary
column3: said her bossÃ¢ÂÂs information came from the EPAÃ¢ÂÂs website. So we went there.

column1: Right away
column2: we found problems with GriffithÃ¢ÂÂs claim. The website says milk has been regulated under the Spill Prevention Control and Countermeasure program since 1973
column3: when the Clean Water Act took effect. The law was passed by Congress the preceding year over the veto of Republican President Richard Nixon. So this is hardly a ""new ruling
column4: as Griffith says. It has been in effect for 38 years.

column1: The EPA site says ""since the SPCC rule became law in 1973
column2: all kinds of oils including petroleum and edible oils (such as animal fats and vegetable oils) have been considered oils. This is because the SPCC rule gets its definition of Ã¢ÂÂoilÃ¢ÂÂ from the Clean Water Act
column3: which was authored by Congress.""

column1: The website also notes the rule only applies to farms storing more than 1
column2: 320 gallons of oil or milk.

column1: So whatÃ¢ÂÂs new? According to the EPA
column2: the only thing that comes close is a rule change it announced on Jan. 15
column3: 2009. It goes in effect at the end of this month.

column1: The simple purpose of the change is to exclude milk and dairy farms from the spill rules governing oil products. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs the exact opposite of what Griffith claims. HereÃ¢ÂÂs what the regulation says:
EPA proposes to exempt milk containers and associated piping and appurtenances from the SPCC requirements provided they are constructed according to the current applicable 3-A Sanitary Standards
column2: and are subject to the current applicable Grade ""A"" Pasteurized Milk Ordinance
column3: or similar state laws.

column1: Translated into plain English
column2: the rule means milk storage will no longer have to meet the EPAÃ¢ÂÂs oil spill rules
column3: provided storage tanks meet pasteurization laws. In Virginia it is illegal to sell ""raw
column4: or unpasteurized
column5: milk
column6: so the stateÃ¢ÂÂs dairy farmers should already be in compliance with the new standards.

column1: Raw milk is now legal for sale in 25 states
column2: although 15 of those states only allow sales directly from a farm. So conceivably raw milk producers -- which are almost exclusively small operations
column3: according to a group that advocates for raw milk -- might still need to comply with the SPCC rules. But this would affect only a very small fraction of total U.S. milk.

column1: Baffled by how Griffith could have this claim so mixed up
column2: we went back to his office for additional information. The second time around his press secretary pointed us to a Jan. 27 editorial in The Wall Street Journal that makes virtually the same claim. The editorial wrongly said new EPA rules will apply to dairy farms and cover milk storage. The amended rule only applies to petroleum products -- gasoline
column3: fuel oil and the like -- that are stored in large quantities on dairy farms.

column1: LetÃ¢ÂÂs review our findings.

Griffith claimed a ""new ruling by the EPA would force dairy farmers to comply"" with strict regulations for spills and leaks. He said the rules were the same as those enforced on oil and natural gas companies.
In fact
column2: these regulations have been in place for 38 years and are not new at all. The ""new ruling"" from the EPA
column3: announced in 2009 and taking effect in a few weeks
column4: actually excludes milk from the spill standards
column5: giving dairy farmers fewer regulations to meet. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs the exact opposite of what Griffith claims.

column1: Sure
column2: Griffith got some of his information from an inaccurate editorial in The Wall Street Journal. But a congressman who is railing against a federal agency has the means to get his facts right.

column1: Griffith is dishing udder cow chips. We rate his statement False."	0
360	"Remarks by the President on a New Strategy for Afghanistan and Pakistan
THE WHITE HOUSE
Office of the Press Secretary
For Immediate Release March 27
REMARKS BY THE PRESIDENT
ON A NEW STRATEGY FOR AFGHANISTAN AND PAKISTAN
Room 450
Dwight D. Eisenhower Executive Office Building
9:40 A.M. EDT
THE PRESIDENT: Good morning. Please be seated.
Before I begin today
column2: let me acknowledge
column3: first of all
column4: Your Excellencies
column5: all the ambassadors who are in attendance. I also want to acknowledge both the civilians and our military personnel that are about to be deployed to the region. And I am very grateful to all of you for your extraordinary work.

column1: I want to acknowledge General David Petraeus
column2: who's here
column3: and has been doing an outstanding job at CENTCOM
column4: and we appreciate him. I want to thank Bruce Reidel -- Bruce is down at the end here -- who has worked extensively on our strategic review. I want to acknowledge Karl Eikenberry
column5: who's here
column6: and is our Ambassador-designate to Afghanistan. And to my national security team
column7: thanks for their outstanding work.

column1: Today
column2: I'm announcing a comprehensive
column3: new strategy for Afghanistan and Pakistan. And this marks the conclusion of a careful policy review
column4: led by Bruce
column5: that I ordered as soon as I took office. My administration has heard from our military commanders
column6: as well as our diplomats. We've consulted with the Afghan and Pakistani governments
column7: with our partners and our NATO allies
column8: and with other donors and international organizations. We've also worked closely with members of Congress here at home. And now IÃ¢ÂÂd like to speak clearly and candidly to the American people.

column1: The situation is increasingly perilous. It's been more than seven years since the Taliban was removed from power
column2: yet war rages on
column3: and insurgents control parts of Afghanistan and Pakistan. Attacks against our troops
column4: our NATO allies
column5: and the Afghan government have risen steadily. And most painfully
column6: 2008 was the deadliest year of the war for American forces.

column1: Many people in the United States -- and many in partner countries that have sacrificed so much -- have a simple question: What is our purpose in Afghanistan? After so many years
column2: they ask
column3: why do our men and women still fight and die there? And they deserve a straightforward answer.

column1: So let me be clear: Al Qaeda and its allies -- the terrorists who planned and supported the 9/11 attacks -- are in Pakistan and Afghanistan. Multiple intelligence estimates have warned that al Qaeda is actively planning attacks on the United States homeland from its safe haven in Pakistan. And if the Afghan government falls to the Taliban -- or allows al Qaeda to go unchallenged -- that country will again be a base for terrorists who want to kill as many of our people as they possibly can.
The future of Afghanistan is inextricably linked to the future of its neighbor
column2: Pakistan. In the nearly eight years since 9/11
column3: al Qaeda and its extremist allies have moved across the border to the remote areas of the Pakistani frontier. This almost certainly includes al Qaeda's leadership: Osama bin Laden and Ayman al-Zawahiri. They have used this mountainous terrain as a safe haven to hide
column4: to train terrorists
column5: to communicate with followers
column6: to plot attacks
column7: and to send fighters to support the insurgency in Afghanistan. For the American people
column8: this border region has become the most dangerous place in the world.

column1: But this is not simply an American problem -- far from it. It is
column2: instead
column3: an international security challenge of the highest order. Terrorist attacks in London and Bali were tied to al Qaeda and its allies in Pakistan
column4: as were attacks in North Africa and the Middle East
column5: in Islamabad and in Kabul. If there is a major attack on an Asian
column6: European
column7: or African city
column8: it
column9: too
column10: is likely to have ties to al Qaeda's leadership in Pakistan. The safety of people around the world is at stake.

column1: For the Afghan people
column2: a return to Taliban rule would condemn their country to brutal governance
column3: international isolation
column4: a paralyzed economy
column5: and the denial of basic human rights to the Afghan people -- especially women and girls. The return in force of al Qaeda terrorists who would accompany the core Taliban leadership would cast Afghanistan under the shadow of perpetual violence.

column1: As President
column2: my greatest responsibility is to protect the American people. We are not in Afghanistan to control that country or to dictate its future. We are in Afghanistan to confront a common enemy that threatens the United States
column3: our friends and our allies
column4: and the people of Afghanistan and Pakistan who have suffered the most at the hands of violent extremists.

column1: So I want the American people to understand that we have a clear and focused goal: to disrupt
column2: dismantle and defeat al Qaeda in Pakistan and Afghanistan
column3: and to prevent their return to either country in the future. That's the goal that must be achieved. That is a cause that could not be more just. And to the terrorists who oppose us
column4: my message is the same: We will defeat you.

column1: To achieve our goals
column2: we need a stronger
column3: smarter and comprehensive strategy. To focus on the greatest threat to our people
column4: America must no longer deny resources to Afghanistan because of the war in Iraq. To enhance the military
column5: governance and economic capacity of Afghanistan and Pakistan
column6: we have to marshal international support. And to defeat an enemy that heeds no borders or laws of war
column7: we must recognize the fundamental connection between the future of Afghanistan and Pakistan -- which is why I've appointed Ambassador Richard Holbrooke
column8: who is here
column9: to serve as Special Representative for both countries
column10: and to work closely with General Petraeus to integrate our civilian and military efforts.

column1: Let me start by addressing the way forward in Pakistan.

The United States has great respect for the Pakistani people. They have a rich history and have struggled against long odds to sustain their democracy. The people of Pakistan want the same things that we want: an end to terror
column2: access to basic services
column3: the opportunity to live their dreams
column4: and the security that can only come with the rule of law. The single greatest threat to that future comes from al Qaeda and their extremist allies
column5: and that is why we must stand together.

column1: The terrorists within Pakistan's borders are not simply enemies of America or Afghanistan -- they are a grave and urgent danger to the people of Pakistan. Al Qaeda and other violent extremists have killed several thousand Pakistanis since 9/11. They've killed many Pakistani soldiers and police. They assassinated Benazir Bhutto. They've blown up buildings
column2: derailed foreign investment
column3: and threatened the stability of the state. So make no mistake: al Qaeda and its extremist allies are a cancer that risks killing Pakistan from within.

column1: It's important for the American people to understand that Pakistan needs our help in going after al Qaeda. This is no simple task. The tribal regions are vast
column2: they are rugged
column3: and they are often ungoverned. And that's why we must focus our military assistance on the tools
column4: training and support that Pakistan needs to root out the terrorists. And after years of mixed results
column5: we will not
column6: and cannot
column7: provide a blank check.

column1: Pakistan must demonstrate its commitment to rooting out al Qaeda and the violent extremists within its borders. And we will insist that action be taken -- one way or another -- when we have intelligence about high-level terrorist targets.
The government's ability to destroy these safe havens is tied to its own strength and security. To help Pakistan weather the economic crisis
column2: we must continue to work with the IMF
column3: the World Bank and other international partners. To lessen tensions between two nuclear-armed nations that too often teeter on the edge of escalation and confrontation
column4: we must pursue constructive diplomacy with both India and Pakistan. To avoid the mistakes of the past
column5: we must make clear that our relationship with Pakistan is grounded in support for Pakistan's democratic institutions and the Pakistani people. And to demonstrate through deeds as well as words a commitment that is enduring
column6: we must stand for lasting opportunity.

column1: A campaign against extremism will not succeed with bullets or bombs alone. Al Qaeda's offers the people of Pakistan nothing but destruction. We stand for something different. So today
column2: I am calling upon Congress to pass a bipartisan bill co-sponsored by John Kerry and Richard Lugar that authorizes $1.5 billion in direct support to the Pakistani people every year over the next five years -- resources that will build schools and roads and hospitals
column3: and strengthen Pakistan's democracy. I'm also calling on Congress to pass a bipartisan bill co-sponsored by Maria Cantwell
column4: Chris Van Hollen and Peter Hoekstra that creates opportunity zones in the border regions to develop the economy and bring hope to places plagued with violence. And we will ask our friends and allies to do their part -- including at the donors conference in Tokyo next month.

column1: I don't ask for this support lightly. These are challenging times. Resources are stretched. But the American people must understand that this is a down payment on our own future -- because the security of America and Pakistan is shared. Pakistan's government must be a stronger partner in destroying these safe havens
column2: and we must isolate al Qaeda from the Pakistani people. And these steps in Pakistan are also indispensable to our efforts in Afghanistan
column3: which will see no end to violence if insurgents move freely back and forth across the border.

column1: Security demands a new sense of shared responsibility. And that's why we will launch a standing
column2: trilateral dialogue among the United States
column3: Afghanistan and Pakistan. Our nations will meet regularly
column4: with Secretaries Clinton and Secretary Gates leading our effort. Together
column5: we must enhance intelligence sharing and military cooperation along the border
column6: while addressing issues of common concern like trade
column7: energy
column8: and economic development.

column1: This is just one part of a comprehensive strategy to prevent Afghanistan from becoming the al Qaeda safe haven that it was before 9/11. To succeed
column2: we and our friends and allies must reverse the Taliban's gains
column3: and promote a more capable and accountable Afghan government.

column1: Our troops have fought bravely against a ruthless enemy. Our civilians have made great sacrifices. Our allies have borne a heavy burden. Afghans have suffered and sacrificed for their future. But for six years
column2: Afghanistan has been denied the resources that it demands because of the war in Iraq. Now
column3: we must make a commitment that can accomplish our goals.

column1: I've already ordered the deployment of 17
column2: 000 troops that had been requested by General McKiernan for many months. These soldiers and Marines will take the fight to the Taliban in the south and the east
column3: and give us a greater capacity to partner with Afghan security forces and to go after insurgents along the border. This push will also help provide security in advance of the important presidential elections in Afghanistan in August.

column1: At the same time
column2: we will shift the emphasis of our mission to training and increasing the size of Afghan security forces
column3: so that they can eventually take the lead in securing their country. That's how we will prepare Afghans to take responsibility for their security
column4: and how we will ultimately be able to bring our own troops home.

column1: For three years
column2: our commanders have been clear about the resources they need for training. And those resources have been denied because of the war in Iraq. Now
column3: that will change. The additional troops that we deployed have already increased our training capacity. And later this spring we will deploy approximately 4
column4: 000 U.S. troops to train Afghan security forces. For the first time
column5: this will truly resource our effort to train and support the Afghan army and police. Every American unit in Afghanistan will be partnered with an Afghan unit
column6: and we will seek additional trainers from our NATO allies to ensure that every Afghan unit has a coalition partner. We will accelerate our efforts to build an Afghan army of 134
column7: 000 and a police force of 82
column8: 000 so that we can meet these goals by 2011 -- and increases in Afghan forces may very well be needed as our plans to turn over security responsibility to the Afghans go forward.

column1: This push must be joined by a dramatic increase in our civilian effort. Afghanistan has an elected government
column2: but it is undermined by corruption and has difficulty delivering basic services to its people. The economy is undercut by a booming narcotics trade that encourages criminality and funds the insurgency. The people of Afghanistan seek the promise of a better future. Yet once again
column3: we've seen the hope of a new day darkened by violence and uncertainty.

column1: So to advance security
column2: opportunity and justice -- not just in Kabul
column3: but from the bottom up in the provinces -- we need agricultural specialists and educators
column4: engineers and lawyers. That's how we can help the Afghan government serve its people and develop an economy that isn't dominated by illicit drugs. And that's why I'm ordering a substantial increase in our civilians on the ground. That's also why we must seek civilian support from our partners and allies
column5: from the United Nations and international aid organizations -- an effort that Secretary Clinton will carry forward next week in The Hague.

column1: At a time of economic crisis
column2: it's tempting to believe that we can shortchange this civilian effort. But make no mistake: Our efforts will fail in Afghanistan and Pakistan if we don't invest in their future. And that's why my budget includes indispensable investments in our State Department and foreign assistance programs. These investments relieve the burden on our troops. They contribute directly to security. They make the American people safer. And they save us an enormous amount of money in the long run -- because it's far cheaper to train a policeman to secure his or her own village than to help a farmer seed a crop -- or to help a farmer seed a crop than it is to send our troops to fight tour after tour of duty with no transition to Afghan responsibility.

column1: As we provide these resources
column2: the days of unaccountable spending
column3: no-bid contracts
column4: and wasteful reconstruction must end. So my budget will increase funding for a strong Inspector General at both the State Department and USAID
column5: and include robust funding for the special inspector generals for Afghan Reconstruction.

column1: And I want to be clear: We cannot turn a blind eye to the corruption that causes Afghans to lose faith in their own leaders. Instead
column2: we will seek a new compact with the Afghan government that cracks down on corrupt behavior
column3: and sets clear benchmarks
column4: clear metrics for international assistance so that it is used to provide for the needs of the Afghan people.

column1: In a country with extreme poverty that's been at war for decades
column2: there will also be no peace without reconciliation among former enemies. Now
column3: I have no illusion that this will be easy. In Iraq
column4: we had success in reaching out to former adversaries to isolate and target al Qaeda in Iraq. We must pursue a similar process in Afghanistan
column5: while understanding that it is a very different country.

column1: There is an uncompromising core of the Taliban. They must be met with force
column2: and they must be defeated. But there are also those who've taken up arms because of coercion
column3: or simply for a price. These Afghans must have the option to choose a different course. And that's why we will work with local leaders
column4: the Afghan government
column5: and international partners to have a reconciliation process in every province. As their ranks dwindle
column6: an enemy that has nothing to offer the Afghan people but terror and repression must be further isolated. And we will continue to support the basic human rights of all Afghans -- including women and girls.

column1: Going forward
column2: we will not blindly stay the course. Instead
column3: we will set clear metrics to measure progress and hold ourselves accountable. WeÃ¢ÂÂll consistently assess our efforts to train Afghan security forces and our progress in combating insurgents. We will measure the growth of AfghanistanÃ¢ÂÂs economy
column4: and its illicit narcotics production. And we will review whether we are using the right tools and tactics to make progress towards accomplishing our goals.

column1: None of the steps that I've outlined will be easy; none should be taken by America alone. The world cannot afford the price that will come due if Afghanistan slides back into chaos or al Qaeda operates unchecked. We have a shared responsibility to act -- not because we seek to project power for its own sake
column2: but because our own peace and security depends on it. And whatÃ¢ÂÂs at stake at this time is not just our own security -- it's the very idea that free nations can come together on behalf of our common security. That was the founding cause of NATO six decades ago
column3: and that must be our common purpose today.

column1: My administration is committed to strengthening international organizations and collective action
column2: and that will be my message next week in Europe. As America does more
column3: we will ask others to join us in doing their part. From our partners and NATO allies
column4: we will seek not simply troops
column5: but rather clearly defined capabilities: supporting the Afghan elections
column6: training Afghan security forces
column7: a greater civilian commitment to the Afghan people. For the United Nations
column8: we seek greater progress for its mandate to coordinate international action and assistance
column9: and to strengthen Afghan institutions.

column1: And finally
column2: together with the United Nations
column3: we will forge a new Contact Group for Afghanistan and Pakistan that brings together all who should have a stake in the security of the region -- our NATO allies and other partners
column4: but also the Central Asian states
column5: the Gulf nations and Iran; Russia
column6: India and China. None of these nations benefit from a base for al Qaeda terrorists
column7: and a region that descends into chaos. All have a stake in the promise of lasting peace and security and development.

column1: That is true
column2: above all
column3: for the coalition that has fought together in Afghanistan
column4: side by side with Afghans. The sacrifices have been enormous. Nearly 700 Americans have lost their lives. Troops from over 20 countries have also paid the ultimate price. All Americans honor the service and cherish the friendship of those who have fought
column5: and worked
column6: and bled by our side. And all Americans are awed by the service of our own men and women in uniform
column7: who've borne a burden as great as any other generationÃ¢ÂÂs. They and their families embody the example of selfless sacrifice.

column1: I remind everybody
column2: the United States of America did not choose to fight a war in Afghanistan. Nearly 3
column3: 000 of our people were killed on September 11
column5: for doing nothing more than going about their daily lives. Al Qaeda and its allies have since killed thousands of people in many countries. Most of the blood on their hands is the blood of Muslims
column6: who al Qaeda has killed and maimed in far greater number than any other people. That is the future that al Qaeda is offering to the people of Pakistan and Afghanistan -- a future without hope or opportunity; a future without justice or peace.

column1: So understand
column2: the road ahead will be long and there will be difficult days ahead. But we will seek lasting partnerships with Afghanistan and Pakistan that promise a new day for their people. And we will use all elements of our national power to defeat al Qaeda
column3: and to defend America
column4: our allies
column5: and all who seek a better future. Because the United States of America stands for peace and security
column6: justice and opportunity. That is who we are
column7: and that is what history calls on us to do once more.

column1: Thank you. God bless you
column2: and God bless the United States of America. (Applause.)

column1: END
10:02 A.M. EDT

362	News reports have confirmed that actor Kirk Douglas died of natural causes late this afternoon
column2: Los Angeles coroners office reported. This was just 4 days before he would have turned 101 years old.

column1: Family released a statement saying he Ã¢ÂÂwent comfortably and was in no painÃ¢ÂÂ and Ã¢ÂÂlived a long and prosperous life that people only dream of.Ã¢ÂÂ
Kirk Douglas was an American actor
column2: producer
column3: director
column4: and author. He was one of the last living people of the film industryÃ¢ÂÂs Golden Age. After an impoverished childhood with immigrant parents and six sisters
column5: he had his film debut in The Strange Love of Martha Ivers (1946) with Barbara Stanwyck. Douglas soon developed into a leading box-office star throughout the 1950s and 1960s
column6: known for serious dramas
column7: including westerns and war movies. During his career he appeared in more than 90 movies. Douglas was well known for his explosive acting style.

column1: As an actor and philanthropist
column2: Douglas had received three Academy Award nominations
column3: an Oscar for Lifetime Achievement
column4: and the Presidential Medal of Freedom. As an author
column5: he had written ten novels and memoirs. He was No. 17 on the American Film InstituteÃ¢ÂÂs list of the greatest male screen legends of classic Hollywood cinema
column6: and the highest-ranked living person on the list. After barely surviving a helicopter crash in 1991 and then suffering a stroke in 1996
column7: he had focused on renewing his spiritual and religious life. He lived with his second wife (of 63 years)
column8: Anne Buydens
column9: a producer. He was to turn 101 on December 9

column1: 363	"August 8
column2: 2010 Ã¢ÂÂ -- AMANPOUR: Good morning. I'm Christiane Amanpour
column3: and at the top of the news this week
column4: ending the war in Iraq.

column1: (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
PRESIDENT BARACK OBAMA: Tens of thousands of our troops in Iraq are coming home.
(END VIDEO CLIP)
AMANPOUR: As America stands down
column2: is Iraq ready to stand up? This morning from Baghdad
column3: the commanding general of U.S. forces
column4: General Ray Odierno
column5: a ""This Week"" exclusive.

column1: Then
column2: hidden wounds. After a decade of war
column3: why is the military still so unprepared to deal with its emotional scars?

column1: (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
(UNKNOWN): They didn't care about my family. The only thing I thought was my role was (inaudible).
(END VIDEO CLIP)
AMANPOUR: This morning
column2: the general in charge of healing those wounds
column3: an exclusive interview with the vice chief of staff of the army
column4: General Peter Chiarelli.

column1: Then...
(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
(UNKNOWN): We are losing everything we have.
(END VIDEO CLIP)
AMANPOUR: Jobs
column2: immigration
column3: and gay marriage. All the week's politics on our roundtable with Politico's John Harris; Gillian Tett of the Financial Times; George Packer of the New Yorker
column4: and former Bush White House official Michael Gerson.

column1: And the Sunday Funnies.
(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
(UNKNOWN): According to the Bureau of Labor statistics
column2: like half of American workers hold on to a job for four years or more. Bad news for President Obama.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
AMANPOUR: This weekend marks a major milestone in the seven-year war in Iraq. U.S. forces have now handed over control of all combat duties to Iraqi forces
column2: and by the end of this month
column3: all U.S. combat forces will be out. A transitional force of about 50
column4: 000 troops will remain
column5: though.

column1: Earlier this week
column2: President Obama spelled out their mission.

column1: (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
OBAMA: Our forces will have a focused mission -- supporting and training Iraqi forces; partnering with Iraqis in counter-terrorism missions
column2: and protecting our civilian and military efforts. But make no mistake: Our commitment in Iraq is changing from a military effort led by our troops to a civilian effort led by our diplomats.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
AMANPOUR: But five months after elections
column2: Iraqi politicians have not yet formed a government
column3: and violence continues. Last night
column4: three explosions at a market in southern Iraq killed dozens of people. And today
column5: two car bombs went off west of Baghdad.

column1: Joining me this morning from Baghdad
column2: the commander of U.S. forces in Iraq
column3: General Ray Odierno. General Odierno
column4: thank you very much for joining us on ""This Week.""

column1: And I want to start by asking you about the handover. You have just handed over all combat operations to Iraqi forces. Are they really ready to stand up once you draw down by the end of this month?
ODIERNO: Well
column2: this is something that we've been working for a very long time with the Iraqi security forces. For the last 20 months
column3: we've been slowly and deliberately turning over more and more responsibility to them
column4: and they have stepped up. They continue to do broad-scoped operations across all of Iraq. We continue to help them as they do these
column5: and that will continue after 1 September
column6: our assistance. But we do believe they are ready to assume full operations in Iraq.

column1: AMANPOUR: Well
column2: let me ask you about the violence. This weekend alone in Basra in the south
column3: there has been a big explosion that's caused dozens of deaths. What is it? Do you know what it is
column4: in fact
column5: was it a terrorist attack?

column1: ODIERNO: Well
column2: I think it probably was. We're still sorting through that
column3: because there was conflicting reports
column4: but my guess is it was probably some sort of an improvised explosive device that went off.

column1: I would just say
column2: this is a reflection -- we have ups and downs here. As I step back
column3: having been here since the dark days of 2006 and '7
column4: to where we are today
column5: what I see is a broad change in the security environment here in Iraq.

column1: However
column2: there are still groups out there who are conducting terrorist acts against the people of Iraq
column3: and they are doing this to stop the political way forward
column4: to stop the political process moving forward
column5: to stop democracy moving forward
column6: and to cause the government of Iraq not to continue its progress. And that's what we're seeing that's playing out on the ground now.

column1: AMANPOUR: Well
column2: General Odierno
column3: in fact
column4: it seems that the political parties in Iraq are not moving forward with the democracy as you describe it. Five months or more after the election
column5: there is still no government. How much does that worry you
column6: and what kind of vacuum is that creating there?

column1: ODIERNO: Well
column2: again
column3: first off
column4: we've seen during this time
column5: this governmental formation timeframe
column6: the Iraqi security forces have acted neutral; they've continued to conduct operations across the broad spectrum of operations that are necessary. In fact
column7: I have found them to be very professional in continuing to execute the security profile. So we have seen no degradation in their ability to execute the security profile. And I think that's actually an extremely positive step forward for them
column8: that they've continued to operate
column9: even though -- or during this time of governmental formation.

column1: AMANPOUR: So
column2: how concerned are you and at what point will you be concerned if there is no government
column3: and do you think that that is providing space for insurgents to reorganize
column4: as many suggest?

column1: ODIERNO: Well
column2: I will just tell you
column3: is what we -- again
column4: what we can't do is overreact to incidents. There are going to be incidents that occur here. There is a level of violence and a level of terrorism here that's going to occur. But I will tell you
column5: over the last six to seven months
column6: the success that we've had against Al Qaida in Iraq specifically in decapitating the leadership has in fact affected them. The kind of operations that they now conduct are very different than what they did just six months ago or eight months ago. And the kind of their ability to surge and do this over a sustained period of time is limited
column7: and that's due to a lot of the work of the Iraqi security forces
column8: working with us to conduct these operations."	0

column1: 364	"Early voting began in North Carolina in October
column2: and soon after almost 900 voters aged 112 reportedly cast ballots. In fact in 2008
column3: almost 10
column4: 000 108-year olds cast ballots and just over 9
column5: 000 110-year olds voted in 2010.

column1: Have this many centenarians actually been voting in North Carolina
column2: or is this a sign of voter fraud as some have asked? Neither
column3: according to the State Board of Elections.

column1: The true explanation is much less exciting.
Prior to passage of the National Voter Registration Act (NVRA) in 1993
column2: the state did not require those registering to provide their birth date. While most voters who registered before NVRA did provide birth dates
column3: some did not. These voters were automatically assigned a default birth date of 01/01/1900 in the stateÃ¢ÂÂs voter rolls. So while these voters are still diligently voting
column4: it is very doubtful they are 112 years old."	1

column1: 365	"April 25
column2: 2010 Ã¢ÂÂ -- TAPPER: Good morning
column3: everyone. Tomorrow
column4: the Senate is scheduled to hold its first vote on the biggest overhaul in decades of the nation's financial system
column5: changes that could impact your savings
column6: your pension
column7: maybe even your job. This as a big Wall Street investment bank comes under attack on Tuesday. Executives from Goldman Sachs
column8: which is already facing government accusations of fraud
column9: will testify before a Senate committee investigating whether the firm profited from the massive housing crash at the expense of its clients.

column1: Joining me this morning
column2: three key players in the middle of this storm. With me here
column3: is Austan Goolsbee from the President Obama's Council of Economic Advisers. In Chattanooga
column4: we have Tennessee Republican Senator Bob Corker
column5: and in Cincinnati
column6: Democratic Senator Sherrod Brown
column7: both key members of the Senate Banking Committee. Gentlemen
column8: welcome.

column1: GOOLSBEE: Thanks for having us.
CORKER: Good morning. Good to be with you.
TAPPER: Before we start with Wall Street reform
column2: I do want to talk about these Goldman Sachs memos
column3: these emails that the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations has released
column4: emails that seem to show executives rejoicing as the housing market crashed
column5: and in fact
column6: they seem to contradict the impression given by Goldman Sachs that they lost money as the mortgage related investment crash happened. In a private email
column7: Goldman CEO Lloyd Blankfein wrote in November of 2007
column8: ""Of course we didn't dodge the mortgage mess. We lost money
column9: then made more than we lost because of shorts.""

column1: Senator Brown
column2: I want to ask you. What do these emails signify to you?

column1: BROWN: Well
column2: these emails signify that there are all kinds of conflicts of interest on Wall Street
column3: that there are -- that Wall Street
column4: while working for its clients and working against its clients in the same sort of bundled toxic securities
column5: and that's why we need the Volcker rule. That's why we need really strong reform that will separate the proprietary trading from banking functions. I think that says it more articulately and more forcefully
column6: that example
column7: than anything we've seen so far.

column1: TAPPER: Senator Corker
column2: doesn't Senator Brown have a point? This is exactly why people think that proprietary trading
column3: that is when a bank uses its own money to invest
column4: should not be the same
column5: it should not be in the same firm as trading for commercial banking
column6: for clients? That there is an inbred conflict of interest there.

column1: CORKER: Well
column2: I can understand the sentiment. I know that certainly the emails do not read well. I look forward to seeing what the SEC investigation brings forth
column3: and the Senate investigation through this subcommittee brings forth. At the end of the day
column4: though
column5: some of that has to do with making markets. I am in no way defending sort of the attitude expressed in the emails
column6: but I think we're better off waiting to see exactly what has taken place.

column1: I think
column2: you know
column3: at the end of the day
column4: instruments are set up on Wall Street. People take either side of it. There are some conflicts of interest that can exist and do need to be looked at
column5: but I'd rather wait and see how this investigation unfolds before making any judgments.

column1: TAPPER: Austan
column2: is there anything in the legislation that Democrats are pushing that President Obama wants to pass
column3: is there anything that would have prevented what Goldman Sachs is accused of having committed?

column1: GOOLSBEE: You know
column2: I don't know the exact details
column3: but there are a number of things that would go directly at the heart of some of these issues that are raised in these cases
column4: like with securitizations
column5: that the people who originate the securities have to maintain some ownership so that if they pack it full of things that are going to fail
column6: they themselves are going to lose money when they do it. I'm certainly not going to comment on independent
column7: you know
column8: regulatory investigations
column9: but these emails that are released
column10: the CEO of Goldman is not going to win any popularity contests when over a period that ordinary Americans' pensions
column11: houses et cetera were collapsing in value
column12: they were actually making significant money off of it. If that's true
column13: I think Senator Brown's point
column14: that we've got to end the conflicts of interest and that the Volcker rule is really on point on that I think is also highly relevant.

column1: TAPPER: Senator Corker
column2: the status of the Wall Street reform bill. Right now
column3: the members of the Senate Banking Committee are negotiating. Tomorrow
column4: the majority leader
column5: Harry Reid
column6: is scheduled to bring it up for a vote. Do you think there will be a bipartisan compromise before that vote happens
column7: and if not
column8: are all 41 Republicans going to stand against proceeding to a debate?

column1: CORKER: Look
column2: first of all
column3: I think everybody knows
column4: Sherrod sure knows I want to see a bill. I think we do need to address regulation in our financial markets. You know
column5: it's in play right now. The fact is
column6: I know that Shelby and Dodd are actually on another program this morning. After that program
column7: I know they're going to continue meeting
column8: hopefully getting to a compromise before tomorrow evening.

column1: And I think what we need to do is have a template. We don't need to address every issue in this compromise
column2: but one that deals with derivatives
column3: one that deals with consumer protection
column4: and one that deals with this orderly liquidation. If we can get that template agreed to in a bipartisan way
column5: then we can debate some of the amendments that Sherrod Brown wants to bring forth
column6: some of the amendments I want to bring forth. But I think it's very
column7: very important that we reach that bipartisan agreement first
column8: because in the Senate
column9: as you know
column10: it takes 60 votes to change anything."	0

column2: 2010 Ã¢ÂÂ -- TAPPER: Good morning
column3: and a happy Mother's Day to all the moms watching. We'll begin with a Sunday first
column4: Attorney General Eric Holder. Welcome to ""This Week.""

column1: HOLDER: It's good to be here.
TAPPER: Well
column2: let's start with the latest on the investigation into the failed Times Square bomber
column3: Faisal Shahzad. What's the latest?

column1: HOLDER: Well
column2: we've now developed evidence that shows that the Pakistani Taliban was behind the attack. We know that they helped facilitate it. We know that they probably helped finance it and that he was working at their direction.

column1: TAPPER: Is there any evidence that there's a cell that Shahzad was working with in the United States? Or was it just him operating from directions from Pakistan?
HOLDER: All I can really say is that the investigation is ongoing and we are examining overseas connections that he might have
column2: as well as any people he might have worked with here in the United States. But the investigation's ongoing in both those spheres.

column1: TAPPER: In the last few days
column2: U.S. officials have met with Pakistani officials
column3: and the message
column4: as conveyed by Secretary of State Hillary Clinton on ""60 Minutes"" is this.

column1: (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
CLINTON: We want more. We expect more. We've made it very clear that if
column2: heaven forbid
column3: an attack like this that we can trace back to Pakistan were to have been successful
column4: there would be very severe consequences.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
TAPPER: What would those consequences be? And what more do you need the Pakistanis to be doing
column2: the Pakistani government
column3: beyond increased military action in North Waziristan
column4: where the Pakistani Taliban is primarily located?

column1: HOLDER: Well
column2: in connection with the Shahzad investigation
column3: they had been
column4: I think
column5: extremely aggressive
column6: they've been cooperative with us
column7: and I think we have been satisfied with the work that they have done. We want to make sure that kind of cooperation continues. To the extent that it does not
column8: we will
column9: as Secretary Clinton indicated
column10: take the appropriate steps. But as of now
column11: with regard to Shahzad
column12: I think we're satisfied with the level of cooperation we've received.

column1: TAPPER: Did the Pakistani government know about Shahzad before this happened? And did they tell the U.S. government at all anything about that?
HOLDER: We don't have any indication that the Pakistani government was aware of his plans or the attack that was planned by the Pakistani Taliban. We don't have any indication of that.
TAPPER: OK
column2: Pakistani Taliban leader Hakimullah Mehsud of the Pakistani -- Pakistani Taliban appeared in a video last month saying the time is very near when a Fedayeen
column3: or soldiers
column4: will attack the American states in the major cities. At the time that he issued that warning
column5: U.S. policymakers didn't think the Pakistani Taliban had the ability to reach into the United States. They were
column6: obviously
column7: wrong?

column1: HOLDER: Well
column2: I'm not sure that we didn't think they had that ability. We didn't think that necessarily was their aim. We certainly have seen with the Shahzad incident that they have not only the aim
column3: but the capability of doing that. And that's why they have taken on
column4: I think
column5: a new significance in our anti-terror fight.

column1: TAPPER: Shahzad was on a Treasury Department watch list since the late 1990s for bringing large sums of cash into this country. He was taken off that watch list. Did the U.S. government drop the ball?
HOLDER: No
column2: I don't think so. I think we have done a good job in monitoring those people who we need to identify as potential threats to the
column3: you know
column4: government
column5: and I think one has to understand that in connection with the -- the resolution of this plot
column6: American law enforcement I think was very successful.

column1: TAPPER: More than 200
column2: 000 people from the U.S. traveled to Pakistan last year. How on Earth do you keep track of which ones intend to do us harm?

column1: HOLDER: It is a difficult job. We have to try to use the various intelligence sources that we have
column2: try to look for telltale signs for who we should be concerned about.

column1: The vast majority of people who go to Pakistan and come from Pakistan to the United States are well intentioned. They have relatives. They have cultural ties to both countries. So we have to really try to focus and make sure that our attention is directed at those people who would do our nation harm.
TAPPER: There have been reports that others arrested this year in terrorist plots in the United States had traveled to Pakistan. Are there any ties with Shahzad?
HOLDER: Well
column2: the investigation's ongoing. And we're looking at a variety of things to try to make sure that we hold everybody accountable who was responsible for this attempted attack. I think the investigation is proceeding at a good pace. We have developed
column3: I think
column4: a good amount of information in a relatively short period of time
column5: but we will be continuing to work on it.

column1: TAPPER: There was a time when the FBI and law enforcement lost track of Shahzad after the attempted incident
column2: before he got on the plane. What happened?

column1: HOLDER: Well
column2: we lost contact with him for just a bit of time
column3: but I think what people have to understand is that we had a layered approach so that at the end of the day I think we were always confident that he would be picked up
column4: and the question was only where he would be picked up and when he would be picked up.

column1: A surveillance was conducted
column2: but we wanted to have him at a fairly good distance so that we could observe him and see if he would make contact with other people who were connected to the plot. Contact was lost for a relatively short period of time.

column1: TAPPER: How long? An hour?
HOLDER: Oh
column2: I don't know
column3: about an hour
column4: so maybe something along those lines. But what was key and what ultimately proved to be successful was this layered approach. He was caught before he was able to leave the country.

column1: TAPPER: But he almost got out
column2: right? I mean
column3: we got lucky in a few ways. First of all
column4: let's be honest: The reason that we avoided a horrible incident is because he was apparently an incompetent bomb- maker
column5: right?

column1: HOLDER: Well
column2: there certainly was a bit of that
column3: but I think also one has to look at the overall operation. He was stopped before he was able to leave the country because of a notification that the FBI made to put him on the no-fly list. We also had vigilant citizens who looked at that vehicle that he left and saw the smoke coming out and notified the appropriate authorities.

column1: This was
column2: in some ways
column3: I think
column4: a good example of what an aroused American populace
column5: coupled with a vigilant law enforcement community
column6: can actually do.

column1: TAPPER: Critics say that he should not have been -- some critics say he should not have been his Miranda rights
column2: the right to remain silent
column3: et cetera. Now
column4: I know that the public safety exception was invoked
column5: so before he was read his rights
column6: he was interrogated. But does the current Miranda system
column7: which was created before I was born and was updated
column8: this public safety exception
column9: in 1984 -- so none of the crafters were really aware of this plot
column10: this threat that we face today."	0

column1: The debate over coal involves calculations of costs

column1: 371	"Of all the major Republicans
column2: the one who comes closest to my worldview is Newt Gingrich. Despite his erratically shifting views and odd phases
column3: he continually returns to this core political refrain: He talks about using government in energetic but limited ways to increase growth
column4: dynamism and social mobility.

column1: As he said in 2007
column2: Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs not a point of view libertarians would embrace
column3: but I am more in the Alexander Hamilton-Teddy Roosevelt tradition of conservatism. I recognize that there are times when you need government to help spur private enterprise and economic development.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: Look at American history
column2: Gingrich continued
column3: Ã¢ÂÂThe government provided railroad land grants to encourage widespread adoption of what was then the most modern form of transportation to develop our country. The Homestead Act essentially gave away land to those willing to live on it and develop it. We used what were in effect public-private partnerships to bring telephone service and electricity to every community in our nation. All of these are examples of government bringing about public purposes without creating massive taxpayer-funded bureaucracies.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: This was not one of GingrichÃ¢ÂÂs passing fads. It is one of the most consistent themes of his career. His 1984 book
column2: Ã¢ÂÂWindow of Opportunity
column3: Ã¢ÂÂ is a broadside against what he calls the Ã¢ÂÂlaissez-faireÃ¢ÂÂ conservatism Ã¢ÂÂ the idea that government should just get out of the way so the market can flourish. As he wrote
column4: Ã¢ÂÂThe opportunity society calls not for a laissez-faire society in which the economic world is a neutral jungle of purely random individual behavior
column5: but for forceful government intervention on behalf of growth and opportunity.Ã¢ÂÂ"	0

column1: 372	"A new TV ad from the McCain campaign portrays the Arizona senator as a leader in the fight against global warming.
The ad begins with fast-paced music and horns honking. It shows black-and-white scenes of crowded freeways
column2: smokestacks belching and a glacier collapsing.

column1: John McCain stood up to the president and sounded the alarm on global warming . . . five years ago
column2: the narrator says.

column1: The stark black-and-white scenes are replaced by more pleasant color footage of a wind turbine against a bright blue sky and water flowing through a dam.
Today
column2: he has a realistic plan that will curb greenhouse gas emissions. A plan that will help grow our economy and protect our environment.""

column1: With images such as a newspaper headline that says ""McCain climate views clash with GOP
column2: the ad portrays McCain as an independent voice on climate change.

column1: Indeed
column2: the Congressional Record shows that McCain spoke up about global warming in January 2003. And as chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee
column3: he held hearings on the issue several years before that.

column1: On Jan. 9
column3: McCain and Sen. Joe Liberman introduced the Lieberman-McCain Climate Stewardship Act
column4: which sought to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by capping them and allowing companies and utilities to sell or trade their emission rights.

column1: When he introduced the bill
column2: McCain called it ""the first comprehensive piece of legislation"" in capping emissions.

column1: The U.S. is responsible for 25 percent of the worldwide greenhouse gas emissions
column2: he said. ""It is time for the U.S. government to do its part to address this global problem
column3: and legislation on mandatory reductions is the form of leadership that is required to address this global problem.""

column1: By contrast
column2: the Bush administration has opposed cap-and-trade programs and preferred voluntary efforts on climate change.

column1: Manik Roy
column2: director of congressional affairs for the Pew Center on Global Climate Change
column3: said McCain had actually been working on the climate change bill in 2001
column4: but it got delayed after the 9/11 attacks. The Lieberman-McCain bill ultimately failed in October 2003 by a 43-55 vote
column5: but Roy said it was a key step in ""educating the Senate"" about how government could respond to global warming.

column1: It is absolutely correct that McCain stood up on this issue
column2: forced the Senate to focus on this issue when nobody else thought it made sense and did it with strong opposition from the White House
column3: Roy said.

column1: He called McCain ""a huge leader on this issue in the Senate.""
And so we find McCain's statement to be True."	0

377	"Remarks of Senator Barack Obama: The Past Versus the Future
Denver
column2: CO | January 30

column1: Thank you Caroline - for your introduction
column2: your support
column3: and your lifetime of service to a grateful nation. You continue to inspire Americans of all ages and walks of life.

column1: Let me also say a few words about another American who has called us to a common purpose. John Edwards has spent a lifetime fighting to give voice to the voiceless and hope to the struggling. At a time when our politics is too focused on who's up and who's down
column2: he made us focus on who matters - the New Orleans child without a home
column3: the West Virginia miner without a job
column4: the families who live in that other America that is not seen or heard or talked about in Washington. John and Elizabeth Edwards believe deeply that two Americans can become one. Their campaign may have ended
column5: but this cause lives on for all of us who believe that we can achieve one America.

column1: Seven months from now
column2: the Democratic Party will gather here in Denver to nominate our candidate for President of the United States.

column1: We will come together after a long and hard fought primary campaign - and that's a good thing. Because it is through campaigns that we hear directly from the American people
column2: set our common goals
column3: and debate our differences. It is through campaigns that we bring new people into the process; build new coalitions; and renew who we are and what we stand for as a Party.

column1: It is fitting that the journey leads to Denver - a city that is younger than the Democratic Party itself
column2: but filled with the promise that our Party has always fought for. This city
column3: built at the base of the Rocky Mountains
column4: stands as a monument to a uniquely American belief in things unseen. Here
column5: in Denver
column6: fur trappers and traders; gold rushers and ranchers; came in search of opportunity
column7: and made the future their own.

column1: The story of America leads west. It is a story of ideals that know no boundaries. It is a story of immigrants who set out from distant shores; pioneers who persevered; and people of all races
column2: religions
column3: and ethnic groups who put aside their doubts to seek a new frontier.

column1: My own family's journey moved west - from Kansas
column2: where my grandparents met and married
column3: and my mother was born; to the Pacific Coast after World War II; and then across an ocean to Hawaii. Their journey - like so many others - speaks to a simple truth written into the story of America. It's a truth at the foundation of the Democratic Party's purpose
column4: Denver's progress
column5: and our nation's promise: in America
column6: the future is what we decide it's going to be.

column1: As candidates
column2: we must give new meaning to that promise. And seven months from now
column3: one of us will stand before that convention hall
column4: and give voice to the hopes
column5: and dreams
column6: and determination of Americans all across our country. In six days
column7: you get to choose who will be that voice. You get to choose who will be able to build a new majority of not just Democrats - but Independents and Republicans - to win in November
column8: and transform our country. And if you put your trust in me
column9: I will stand up at that convention and say that our divisions are past
column10: our hope is the future
column11: and our time for change has come.

column1: Now there is one thing we know for certain about the election in November: the name George Bush will not be on the ballot. The name of my cousin - Dick Cheney - will not be on the ballot. But the choice before you is about what comes next. Because we need to do more than turn the page on the failed Bush-Cheney policies; we have to turn the page on the politics that helped make those policies possible.
Lobbyists setting an agenda in Washington that feeds the inequality
column2: insecurity
column3: and instability in our economy.

column1: Division and distraction that keeps us from coming together to deal with challenges like health care
column2: and clean energy
column3: and crumbling schools year after year after year.

column1: Cronyism that gave us Katrina instead of competent government. And secrecy that made torture permissible and illegal wiretaps possible.
It's a politics that uses 9/11 to scare up votes; and fear and falsehoods to lead us into a war in Iraq that should've never been authorized and should've never been waged.

Each candidate running for the Democratic nomination shares an abiding desire to end the disastrous policies of the current administration. But we must decide - in the debate that leads to Denver - just what kind of Party we want to be
column2: and what lessons we've learned from the bitter partisanship of the last two decades. We can be a Party that tries to beat the other side by practicing the same do-anything
column3: say-anything
column4: divisive politics that has stood in the way of progress; or we can be a Party that puts an end to it.

column1: I am running for President because I believe that we need fundamental change in America. Not just a change of Party in the White House
column2: but change in Washington that the American people can believe in - unity instead of division; hope instead of fear; a politics that leaves behind the fights of the past so that we can finally take hold of our future.

column1: We began this campaign one year ago on the steps of the old statehouse in Springfield. At the time
column2: we made a bet on the American people. That bet was simple - we weren't going to change anything by relying on the same Washington games; instead
column3: we were betting on the American people's hunger for change
column4: and your ability to make change happen from the bottom-up.

column1: And we are showing America what change looks like. From the snows of Iowa to the sunshine of South Carolina
column2: we have built a movement of young and old; rich and poor; black and white; Latino
column3: Asian and Native American. We've reached Americans of all political stripes who are more interested in turning the page than turning up the heat on our opponents. That's how Democrats will win in November and build a majority in Congress. Not by nominating a candidate who will unite the other party against us
column4: but by choosing one who can unite this country around a movement for change.

column1: If you choose change
column2: you will have a nominee who doesn't take a dime from Washington lobbyists and PACs. We don't need a candidate who agrees with Republicans that lobbyists are part of the system in Washington. They're part of the problem. And when I'm President
column3: their days of setting the agenda in Washington will be over.

column1: If you choose change
column2: you will have a nominee who doesn't just tell people what they want to hear. Poll-tested positions and calculated answers might be how Washington confronts challenges
column3: but it's not how you overcome them; it's not how you inspire our nation to come together behind a common purpose; and it's not what America needs right now.

column1: If you choose change
column2: you will have a nominee who isn't just playing on the same electoral map where half the country starts out against us
column3: because you will have a nominee who has already brought in more Independents and Republicans; young people and new voters; than we have seen in a generation.

column1: I know it is tempting - after another presidency by a man named George Bush - to simply turn back the clock
column2: and to build a bridge back to the 20th Century. There are those will tell us that our Party should nominate someone who is more practiced in the art of pursuing power; that's it's not yet our turn or our time. There was also a time when Caroline Kennedy's father was counseled by a former President to Ã¢ÂÂbe patient
column3: Ã¢ÂÂ and to step aside for Ã¢ÂÂsomeone with greater experience.Ã¢ÂÂ But John F. Kennedy responded by saying
column4: Ã¢ÂÂThe world is changing. The old ways will not doÃ¢ÂÂ¦It is time for a new generation of leadership.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: It is time for a new generation of leadership
column2: because the old politics just won't do. I am running for President - right now - because I have met Americans all across this country who cannot afford to wait another day for change. That is why the real choice in this campaign is not between regions or religions or genders. It's not about rich versus poor; young versus old; and it is not about black versus white.

column1: It is about the past versus the future. And when I am the nominee
column2: the Republicans won't be able to make this election about the past because you will have already chosen the future.

column1: It's time for new leadership for an economy where families are being forced to foreclose on their dreams
column2: and workers have seen their pensions disappear.

column1: In the short-term
column2: we need what I have consistently called for - a stimulus plan that gives the American people a tax rebate
column3: and that also extends relief to seniors and expands unemployment insurance. And in the long-term
column4: we need to put the American Dream on a firmer foundation. We're not going to offer the American people the choice they need by nominating a candidate who voted to put the banks and big business ahead of hard-working Americans. I've been fighting for working people my entire public life. And when I am President
column5: I'll make sure that CEOs can't dump your pension with one hand while they collect a bonus with the other. I'll pass bankruptcy laws that protect workers instead of banks. And I'll crack down on fraudulent mortgage lenders
column6: and credit card companies that change your rates to push you further into debt.

column1: It's time for new leadership for the Maytag worker who is now competing with his own teenage son for a $7 an-hour job at Walmart because the factory he gave his life to shut its doors.
We're not going to offer the American people the choice they need by nominating a candidate who argues year after year for trade that isn't fair
column2: but calls for a time-out on trade when they run for President. I will stop giving tax breaks to companies that ship our jobs overseas and start putting them in the pockets of working Americans. I will stop giving the wealthiest Americans tax cuts that they don't need and didn't ask for
column3: and restore fairness to our economy. I'll give a tax cut to working people; provide relief to homeowners; and eliminate the income tax for seniors making under $50
column4: 000 so they can retire with the dignity and security they have earned.

column1: It's time for new leadership for the woman I met who can't get Medicaid to cover the needs of her sick child.

She can't afford to wait another four years or another fifteen years to get health care because we've put forward a nominee who can't bring Democrats and Republicans together to get things done. I know that the reason Americans don't have health care isn't because no one is forcing them to buy it - it's because they can't afford it. That's why my plan cuts costs by up to $2500 for a typical family
column2: and makes health care available and affordable for every single American. That's the plan that I'll pass in my first term as President.

column1: It is time for new leadership for children going to overcrowded schools in East L.A.; for the teacher I met who is working at Dunkin Donuts to make ends meet; for the young people who are ready to go to college but can't afford it.
When I'm President
column2: we'll rally this country to the cause of world-class education. That means putting our kids on a pathway to success with universal
column3: quality
column4: affordable early childhood education. That means paying our teachers more
column5: and making sure they're not just teaching to the test - but teaching art and music and literature. That means giving our young people an annual $4
column6: 000 tax credit for college tuition if they serve their community; and that means expanding AmeriCorps to 250
column7: 000 slots
column8: and issuing a call to service for a new generation. But that also means calling on parents to do their part - to get off the couch
column9: turn off the television
column10: and read to our children. Because responsibility for education starts at home.

column1: It's time for new leadership so that my daughters and your children don't grow up in a century where our economy is weighed down by our addiction to oil; our foreign policy is held hostage to the whims of dictators; and our planet passes a moment of no return.
When I'm President
column2: we won't wait any longer to reduce emissions. When I called for higher fuel efficiency standards
column3: I didn't do it in front of an environmental group in California or in Boulder - that would have been the easy thing to do. I did it in front of the automakers in Detroit. Now it was pretty quiet - I didn't get a lot of applause. But we need leadership that tells the American people not just what they want to hear
column4: but what we need to know. That's what I'll do. We cannot wait to invest in the next generation of biofuels
column5: and wind and solar. If President Kennedy could send us to the moon in less than a decade - then we can meet this great challenge our generation. We can set the goal of an 80% reduction in global emissions by 2050
column6: and we can lead the world to confront the climate crisis.

column1: And it's time for new leadership for the woman who told me that she hasn't been able to breathe since the day her nephew left for Iraq
column2: and the soldier who doesn't know his own child because he's on his third or fourth tour of duty.

column1: I will end the mentality that says the only way for Democrats to look tough on national security is by talking
column2: acting and voting like George Bush Republicans. It's time to reject the counsel that says the American people would rather have someone who is strong and wrong than someone who is weak and right - it's time to say that we are the Party that is going to be strong and right.

column1: It's time for new leadership that understands that the way to win a debate with John McCain is not by nominating someone who agreed with him on voting for the war in Iraq; who agreed with him by voting to give George Bush the benefit of the doubt on Iran; who agrees with him in embracing the Bush-Cheney policy of not talking to leaders we don't like; and who actually differed with him by arguing for exceptions for torture before changing positions when the politics of the moment changed.
We need to offer the American people a clear contrast on national security
column2: and when I am the nominee of the Democratic Party
column3: that's exactly what I will do. Talking tough and tallying up your years in Washington is no substitute for judgment
column4: and courage
column5: and clear plans. It's not enough to say you'll be ready from Day One - you have to be right from Day One.

column1: I opposed this war in Iraq from the start
column2: and I have never
column3: ever wavered in that opposition. I warned about taking our eye off of Osama bin Laden
column4: and overstretching our troops and their families as we have seen in communities across this country like Fort Carson. And when I am President
column5: I will immediately begin to remove our troops
column6: I will finally put meaningful pressure on Iraq's leaders to reconcile
column7: and I will end this war. And I will do what we should have done back in 2002: increase our commitment to Afghanistan
column8: press Pakistan to take action against terror
column9: and finish the fight with al Qaeda.

column1: I will challenge the conventional thinking that says we can't conduct diplomacy with leaders we don't like. Strong countries and strong Presidents talk to their adversaries as well as their friends
column2: and that's what I'll do. And when I am President
column3: we will keep nuclear weapons from terrorists by securing all loose nuclear materials around the world during my first term in office. We will set a goal of a world without nuclear weapons
column4: and we will pursue it.

column1: It's time for new leadership that reaches out
column2: as President Kennedy did to my own father
column3: to people Ã¢ÂÂin the huts and villages across the globe struggling to break the bonds of mass misery.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: It's time to restore our moral leadership by rejecting torture without equivocation; by closing Guantanamo; by restoring habeas corpus; and by again being that light of justice to dissidents in prison camps around the globe. It's time for America to lead the world against the common threats of the 21st century - terrorism and nuclear weapons
column2: but also climate change and poverty; genocide and disease. I will send once more a message to those yearning faces beyond our shores that says
column3: Ã¢ÂÂYou matter to us. Your future is our future. And our moment is now.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: This is what the moment demands of us - to cast off our doubts; to reach once more for what America can be if we have the courage to make the future our own.
We've been warned
column2: in these last few weeks
column3: that this kind of change isn't possible. That we're peddling false hopes. That we need a reality check.

column1: And we've faced forces that are not the fault of any one campaign - forces that open American wounds. The politics that uses religion as a wedge
column2: and patriotism as a bludgeon. A politics that tells us what we have to think and even vote within the confines of the categories that supposedly define us. The assumption that young people are apathetic. The assumption that Republicans won't cross over. The assumption that the wealthy care nothing for the poor
column3: and that the poor don't vote. The assumption that African-Americans can't support the white candidate; whites can't support the African-American candidate; and blacks and Latinos can't come together.

column1: But our Party - the Democratic Party - has always been at its best when we rose above these divisions; when we called all Americans to a common purpose
column2: a higher purpose; when we stood up and said that we will write our own future
column3: and the future will be what we want it to be.

column1: We followed a King to the mountaintop
column2: and a Kennedy who called on us to reject the mindless menace of violence.

column1: We're the party of a young President who asked what we could do for our country
column2: and who put us on a path to the moon.

column1: We're the party of a man who overcame his own disability; who told us that the only thing we had to fear was fear itself; and who faced down fascism and liberated a continent from tyranny.
We're the party of Jackson
column2: who took back the White House for the people of this country.

column1: And we're the party of Jefferson
column2: who wrote the words that we are still trying to heed - that all of us are created equal - and who sent us West to blaze new trails
column3: to make new discoveries
column4: and to realize the promise of our highest ideals.

column1: That is who we are. That is the Party that we need to be
column2: and can be
column3: if we cast off our doubts
column4: and leave behind our fears
column5: and choose the America that we know is possible. Because there is a moment in the life of every generation
column6: if it is to make its mark on history
column7: when its spirit has to come through
column8: when it must choose the future over the past
column9: when it must make its own change from the bottom up.

column1: This is our moment. This is our message - the same message we had when we were up
column2: and when we were down. The same message that we will carry all the way to the convention. And in seven months time - right here in Denver - we can realize this promise; we can claim this legacy; we can choose new leadership for America. Because there is nothing we cannot do if the American people decide it is time."	0

column1: 378	"Alabama Senate candidate Roy Moore is denying that he romantically pursued teenagers as young as 14 while he was in his 30s after a bombshell report.
The women accusing Moore told the Washington Post that when they were between the ages of 14 and 18
column2: he romantically pursued them.

column1: One woman

column1: 381	"This is a rush transcript from ""Fox News Sunday

column1: CHRIS WALLACE

column1: Keeping America safe after the terror attack in England. What steps is the government taking this Memorial Day weekend?
(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)
JOHN KELLY
column2: HOMELAND SECURITY SECRETARY: It's a constant threat and we always have to be vigilant.

column1: WALLACE: WeÃ¢ÂÂll discuss the investigation into the bombing and the response here in the U.S. with the secretary of homeland security
column2: General John Kelly
column3: live
column4: only on ""Fox News Sunday.""

column1: Then
