column1: Plus
column2: President Trump returns from his first trip overseas to a domestic agenda in trouble
column3: from ObamaCare repeal and replace to the budget
column4: some on Capitol Hill wonder whether Congress will pass anything.

column1: SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM
column2: R-SOUTH CAROLINA: Yes
column3: definitely dead on arrival.

column1: SEN. DICK DURBIN
column2: D-ILLINOIS: This is step backwards. YouÃ¢ÂÂre not going to make America great again with this budget.

column1: WALLACE: WeÃ¢ÂÂll break down the president's priorities and prospects with a number two Democrat in the Senate
column2: Dick Durbin
column3: and Republican senator
column4: Dr. Bill Cassidy.

column1: And our power player of the week flying high for the Blue Angels.
UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Boy
column2: is it sweet when we put all that together and get that synergy and you feel that fuzz.

column1: WALLACE: All
column2: right now
column3: on ""Fox News Sunday.""

column1: (END VIDEOTAPE)
WALLACE: And hello again on this Memorial Day weekend from Fox News in Washington.

President Trump is back at the White House arriving late last night after a largely successful nine-day trip to the Middle East and Europe. But he returns to a spreading scandal about links between the Kremlin and some of his current and former advisors
column2: and to a domestic agenda that stalled in Congress.

column1: WeÃ¢ÂÂll get to all of that this hour
column2: but we begin with terror
column3: that suicide bombing at a concert in Manchester
column4: England
column5: that killed 22
column6: just the first of four savage attacks this week around the world.

column1: Joining us now
column2: the man in charge of keeping America safe
column3: the secretary of homeland security
column4: General John Kelly.

column1: Mr. Secretary
column2: welcome to ""Fox News Sunday.""

column1: Before we get to terror
column2: let me ask you about the hot story in Washington now. These revelations about Jared Kushner trying to set up a back channel to the Kremlin
column3: through the Soviet and -- the Russian ambassador. Your reaction to that? Is there anything improper with that?

column1: KELLY: Well
column2: I don't know if it's true or not. I know itÃ¢ÂÂs being -- it's being reported in the press.

column1: WALLACE: It has been confirmed to me the conversation took place.
KELLY: OK. Then I would just tell you
column2: Chris
column3: that I think any channel of communications back or otherwise with a country like Russia is a good thing. I mean
column4: multiple ways to communicate back and forth is a good thing with a country I think
column5: and particularly a country thatÃ¢ÂÂs like Russia. So
column6: it doesnÃ¢ÂÂt -- it doesn't bother me.

column1: I mean
column2: you just have to assume
column3: obviously
column4: that what youÃ¢ÂÂre getting is -- may or may not be true
column5: they may be working you. But that's the whole point. I mean
column6: that communication goes into the White House as a data point in terms of discussion. So
column7: I don't see the big deal.

column1: WALLACE: Let me -- you say you don't see a big deal?
KELLY: No
column2: I think any time you have channels of communication with a country
column3: particularly one like Russia
column4: I wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt criticize it.

column1: WALLACE: But you talked about a data point into the White House. This is during the transition.
KELLY: Right.
WALLACE: These were private officials.
KELLY: Right.
WALLACE: We have one president at a time. Does that make a difference?
KELLY: You know
column2: I mean
column3: obviously
column4: during the transition period
column5: the people in transition
column6: the incoming Trump administration is not in a position to do anything to inhibit with the Obama administration literally days before they transitioned out. So
column7: again
column8: as they begin to build relationships
column9: there's nothing wrong with that. As they begin to build their own situational awareness with Russia in this case
column10: I don't see an issue here.

column1: WALLACE: OK. Let's turn to your day job. What's the latest on the Manchester bombing? Have they rolled up the network that was supporting the bombers
column2: and what have you learned from this plot that will help you better protect the U.S. homeland?

column1: KELLY: I mean
column2: I don't know what the -- actually the better way to put it
column3: I can't comment on whether they finish their investigations
column4: or roll -- you know
column5: completed rolling up on the network that weÃ¢ÂÂre dealing with. But I would just say that this is -- yes
column6: IÃ¢ÂÂve said it many times
column7: it really is a generational struggle. This is one tragedy in line with dozens of other tragedies in the world.

column1: I mean
column2: last week
column3: you had Manchester
column4: you had Egypt
column5: you had Indonesia
column6: you had the Philippines
column7: all ISIS-inspired or ISIS-controlled terrorist attack.

column1: WALLACE: Was there something different about this network and the way this was pulled off that says to you
column2: gee
column3: we've got to up our game?

column1: KELLY: Well
column2: itÃ¢ÂÂs this kind of -- in my view
column3: there's kind of three types of terrorist attacks. The most sophisticated that we look at
column4: that is against aviation
column5: that's the hardest to do but it's the biggest payoff for these people.

column1: Then you have kind of the middle of the road one
column2: which I think this one was. ItÃ¢ÂÂs a network. It's hard to do. You have to construct a bomb and all
column3: and then you have kind of the low-end where -- I mean
column4: just as tragic but you have people running people over in trucks
column5: that kind of thing.

column1: But this is just the way terrorism is today and I think it will be around for many
column2: many years to come. You know
column3: the good news is those officials in the United Kingdom
column4: Europe
column5: around the world are relentless. They are just as relentless in terms of trying to prevent these things as the terrorists aren't trying to create them.

column1: The good news is
column2: for our country
column3: we have not had an outside the United States terrorist attacks since 9/11. And that goes to the issue of those that fight our away game
column4: thatÃ¢ÂÂs DOD
column5: NSA
column6: CIA
column7: and those that fight the home game. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs DHS
column8: FBI
column9: local law enforcement.

column1: WALLACE: Let me pick up on this
column2: because part of the story this week was the leak of information about the bomber and the bombing that made its way into the U.S. media
column3: and that set off this exchange.

column1: (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
THERESA MAY
column2: BRITISH PRIME MINISTER: I made clear to President Trump that the intelligence that is shared between our law enforcement agencies must remain secure.

column1: REX TILLERSON
column2: SECRETARY OF STATE: We take full responsibility for that. And we
column3: obviously
column4: regret that that happened.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
WALLACE: How was this kind of sensitive information leaked to ""The New York Times""? And
column2: General
column3: why is it that whether it's politics or terror
column4: our intelligence agencies
column5: our law enforcement agencies
column6: can't keep a secret?

column1: KELLY: It's outrageous. When I call -- immediately after the attack
column2: I called my counterpart in U.K.
column3: offered my condolences. By the way
column4: the third time IÃ¢ÂÂve offered her
column5: Amber Rudd
column6: my condolences in 120 days. That's how frequent this kind of -- these terrorist attacks are happening.

column1: Anyways
column2: she rightfully and very graciously accepted the condolences and leaned into me on this leak. It's outrageous. I don't know why people do it. It jeopardizes not only investigations
column3: it puts people's lives in jeopardy.

column1: I don't why people do it
column2: but they do. And that's the world we live in.

column1: WALLACE: Let's get to what you're going to try to do to protect the homeland. There are a lot of crowded events in the summer
column2: concerts
column3: sporting events. How do you harden these soft targets like this concert? And do you have new thoughts because this person didn't get into the event
column4: he was outside the event
column5: what do you do about parameters?

column1: KELLY: We -- one of the great things about America
column2: there's many great things but we are a free and open society. And in many -- and I wouldn't change that at all. But that's also one of our vulnerabilities. People can live their lives day in and day out
column3: privacy issues
column4: all of that
column5: it's a good thing. ItÃ¢ÂÂs what America is all about. But as I say
column6: that is a vulnerability.

column1: The good news is to all Americans
column2: I mean
column3: the good news is that local state law enforcement today -- not to even go down the issue of the FBI
column4: DHS -- it's in their DNA now to harden. We are just about as hard as we can be. I don't know if there's a way to prevent these kinds of things in the kind of society we live in.

column1: WALLACE: Let me pick up on that
column2: because I want to play a clip of your testimony before Congress this week. Here it is.

column1: (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
KELLY: It's everywhere
column2: and thatÃ¢ÂÂs -- you know
column3: that's the nature of this threat that we are dealing with. As horrible as Manchester was
column4: my expectation is weÃ¢ÂÂre going to see a lot more of that kind of attack.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
WALLACE: A lot more of that kind of attack
column2: here in the U.S.?

column1: KELLY: I think weÃ¢ÂÂre relatively -- we have no specific -- we have threats all the time
column2: but no
column3: right now
column4: specific threat. But that goes to the fact that we are over here and not over there.

column1: The fact is that it's the caliphate is being destroyed
column2: that is Syria and Iraq
column3: there are large numbers of returning fighters
column4: Western Europe
column5: and
column6: you know
column7: in many cases like this guy that did this thing in Manchester
column8: heÃ¢ÂÂs a citizen of the U.K. In this case
column9: heÃ¢ÂÂs a passport holder. I don't if the U.K. had any idea that he was outside -- that he was in Libya
column10: but I think heÃ¢ÂÂs also traveled to other points.

column1: The point is
column2: they have a real threat and it's growing
column3: itÃ¢ÂÂs metastasized
column4: as fighters come back from the caliphate to be I believe to be more of this kind of thing.

column1: The good news is
column2: all decent people
column3: all decent governments
column4: and it doesn't matter whether we are politically close to them or not
column5: all governments for the most part are sharing tremendous amounts of information
column6: passport-type information
column7: aviation
column8: travel information. But
column9: you know
column10: people like this are below the radar.

column1: WALLACE: I want to pick up on aviation because you are in the process of making some big decisions on aviation. And I want to do a lightning round
column2: quick questions
column3: quick answers.

column1: Are you going to ban laptops from the cabin on all international flights both into and out of the U.S.?
KELLY: I might. That's a quick answer.
WALLACE: Yes
column2: well
column3: expand a little bit.

column1: KELLY: Well
column2: thereÃ¢ÂÂs a real threat. Numerous threats against aviation
column3: that's really the thing that they are obsessed with
column4: the terrorists
column5: the idea of knocking down an airplane in flight
column6: particularly if itÃ¢ÂÂs a U.S. carrier
column7: particularly if it's full of mostly U.S. folks
column8: people. It's real. You know that I implemented I think on the 21st of March a restriction on large electronic devices in the cabins from ten points of origin.

column1: WALLACE: Right.
But there was talk
column2: as you say
column3: about all international flights both into and out of the U.S. When you say you might
column4: when are you going to make that decision and whatÃ¢ÂÂs going to determine it?

column1: KELLY: (INAUDIBLE) follow the intelligence. The very
column2: very good news is that we are working incredibly close with friends and partners around the world. We're going to
column3: and in the process of defining this
column4: but we are going to raise the bar for generally speaking aviation security much higher than it is now.

column1: So -- and thereÃ¢ÂÂs new technologies down the road
column2: not too far down the road that we will rely on. But it is a real sophisticated threat and I will reserve that decision until we see where it's going.

column1: WALLACE: Another lightning round question
column2: I do need a quick answer here because weÃ¢ÂÂre running of time. The TSA is testing tighter screening of carry-ons
column3: and the idea that people who bring their carry-ons are going to have to unpack them and put food in one bin
column4: and electronics in the another bin
column5: and paper in another bin.

column1: Are you going to spread that nationwide and whatÃ¢ÂÂs that going to do to the screening lines?
KELLY: Yes
column2: I mean
column3: the reason weÃ¢ÂÂve done
column4: TSA
column5: of course
column6: works for me. The reason we've done that is because of -- people trying to avoid the $25 or $50 or whatever it is to check a bag are now stuffing your carry-on bags to the point of
column7: you know -- well
column8: they can't get any more in there. So
column9: the more you stuff in there
column10: the less the TSA professionals that are looking at what's in those bags through the monitors
column11: they can't tell what's in the bags anymore. So
column12: if you put --

column1: WALLACE: So
column2: are you going to do that nationwide?

column1: KELLY: We might
column2: and likely will.

column1: WALLACE: Soon?
KELLY: Well
column2: what weÃ¢ÂÂre doing now is working out the tactics
column3: techniques and procedures
column4: if you will
column5: in a few airports to find out exactly how to do that with the least amount of inconvenience to the traveler.

column1: WALLACE: A couple final questions I want to ask about the travel ban. The Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals issued a ruling this week continuing the stay on President Trump's revised travel ban -- and I want to put up -- the chief judge called it
column2: the revised travel ban: an executive order that in text speaks with vague words of national security
column3: but in context drips with religious intolerance
column4: animus and discrimination.

column1: Mr. Secretary
column2: judge after judge has said that this is a Muslim man that violates the Constitution.

column1: KELLY: They are dead wrong.
WALLACE: Well
column2: I mean
column3: you say that
column4: but they are the ones who were --

column1: KELLY: They are wrong. Remember the seven
column2: now six countries? These were the same countries identified by the Obama administration that we should be extra cautious about and backed up
column3: you know
column4: by the United States Congress. That's where those seven countries came from.

column1: The fact is that in those countries
column2: we have very little ability to actually verify
column3: vet the people that are coming out of those countries. So
column4: what the president and it's not a travel ban
column5: remember. ItÃ¢ÂÂs the travel pause. What the president said
column6: for 90 days
column7: we were going to pause in terms of people from those countries coming to the United States that would give me time to look at additional vetting to see --

column1: WALLACE: OK. I want to pick up on that and why youÃ¢ÂÂre even talking about the travel ban
column2: because I want to put some numbers on. Take a look at this.

column1: The first executive order that was issued on January 27th banned citizens from seven nations from entering the U.S. for 90 days
column2: suspended the refugee program for 120 days
column3: as you say
column4: a pause
column5: while you set up an extreme vetting program. It's now been 121 days since that first order. So
column6: why don't you have the program in place?

column1: KELLY: We are actually implementing it. The irony here is
column2: had it stood
column3: we would have had the 90 days to study. WeÃ¢ÂÂre not even studying what would be procedures
column4: because we are enjoined and can't do that. In the meantime --

column1: WALLACE: You can't study extreme vetting?
KELLY: No. WeÃ¢ÂÂre -- the irony again is we can't study it
column2: but IÃ¢ÂÂm just guessing
column3: and implementing.

column1: But we are going to find implement ways to determine who this -- an individual is
column2: and remember
column3: most of these countries have no passports. They have no police. They have no intelligence. Many of the countries in question don't even have a U.S. embassy there to help us vet. The U.N. will tell you it's almost impossible to vet these people from these countries because there are no passports and all the rest of it.

column1: We have to figure out a way to determine who they are and why they come into the United States. Otherwise
column2: weÃ¢ÂÂre guessing. And this president and John Kelly doesn't want to guess when it comes to national security and protection of the U.S. population.

column1: WALLACE: Secretary Kelly
column2: thank you. Thanks for sharing part of your holiday weekend with us.

column1: KELLY: Absolutely. Thanks.
WALLACE: Up next
column2: new reports that Jared Kushner attempted to set up a back channel between Russia and the Trump transition. WeÃ¢ÂÂll bring in our Sunday group to discuss the expanding Russia probe.

column1: Plus
column2: what would you like to ask the panel about the continuous leaks in Washington? Just go to Facebook or Twitter @FoxNewsSunday
column3: and we may use your question on the air.

column1: (COMMERCIAL BREAK)
(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
HILLARY CLINTON
column2: D-FORMER PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: We were furious about the past presidential election of a man whose presidency would eventually end in disgrace with his impeachment for obstruction of justice.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
WALLACE: Hillary Clinton talking about Richard Nixon in her commencement speech at Wellesley College
column2: but clearly taking a shot at President Trump. By the way
column3: Nixon resigned before he was actually impeached.

column1: And it's time now for our Sunday group: the head of Heritage Action for America
column2: Michael Needham
column3: Charles Lane of The Washington Post
column4: Gerald Seib from The Wall Street Journal
column5: and National Security Council staffer
column6: Gillian Turner.

column1: And just to catch you up
column2: President Trump returns home to reports that his son-in-law
column3: Jared Kushner
column4: met with the Russian ambassador to the U.S.
column5: Sergey Kislyak
column6: in December
column7: and that they discussed setting up a secret secure channel between the Trump transition and the Kremlin. That communications link reportedly to be based in a Russian diplomatic facility in Russia.

column1: A source close to the Trump administration tells me the conversation did take place but he says it was the ambassador who proposed the back channel
column2: not Kushner
column3: so the Russian military could talk with Trump advisors about the situation in Syria and the source points out that the secure link was never set up.

column1: So
column2: with that as a preface
column3: Gerry
column4: your reaction to the Kushner story
column5: and how does this complicate the already complicated investigation of links between the Kremlin and the Trump transition?

column1: GERALD F. SEIB
column2: THE WALL STREET JOURNAL: Well
column3: look
column4: I mean
column5: back channels are not unusual
column6: they are not unprecedented. This one might have seemed perfectly innocent. Two problems though with it. One is
column7: this happened during the transition
column8: it seems to violate as you suggested earlier in the show the only one president at a time rule. And the second one is itÃ¢ÂÂs Russia
column9: after a campaign in which the Russian connection to the campaign
column10: the Russian interference in the campaign was a big issue.

column1: And I think the fact that it was at a time when people were looking for whether there were going to be signs of special favors for Russia as a result of help they might have given President Trump
column2: then-President-elect Trump during the campaign
column3: that's what makes this a big story
column4: is the context of the conversation as much as the actual content.

column1: WALLACE: Michael
column2: I want to ask you
column3: one
column4: whether it's a big story
column5: and
column6: secondly
column7: about the talk we are hearing
column8: that is just rampant in Washington today about major changes in the White House that theyÃ¢ÂÂre going to set up a rapid response operation to deal with all the incoming leaks
column9: that the president has hired at least one criminal defense lawyer and may be process of hiring a team and the staff is urging the president to let the lawyers vet his tweets. I mean
column10: it really does sound like theyÃ¢ÂÂre going on a war footing on this.

column1: MICHAEL NEEDHAM
column2: CEO
column3: HERITAGE ACTION FOR AMERICA: Yes
column4: I don't know if it's a major story
column5: there are several investigations going on. They probably should be allowed to work their course. It's kind of exhausting reading some of these new stories and trying to figure out what did you read three weeks ago thatÃ¢ÂÂs just being recycled
column6: versus what new?

column1: I think it's smart for the administration to try to put this stuff to the side
column2: have
column3: you know
column4: a team that looks at these issues
column5: and another team that looks at a lot of real policy issues
column6: which are closer to the American people. You have the most conservative
column7: exciting budget that's come out in a decade.

column1: WALLACE: WeÃ¢ÂÂre going to get to the agenda in the next segment.
(CROSSTALK)
WALLACE: I mean
column2: at the very least
column3: it seems dumb.

column1: NEEDHAM: Clearly
column2: the optics of these are awful
column3: and I think that especially when you have people who are new to the political system coming in and getting advice from a guy in Mike Flynn who probably didn't show the best judgment through a lot of this
column4: you know
column5: dumb might be a good word for it. I donÃ¢ÂÂt know. You know
column6: I think Kushner said a couple of weeks ago that he was happy to participate with the Senate investigation. He said heÃ¢ÂÂs happy to participate with this investigation.

column1: You are at a disadvantage when you are the focus of an investigation and your lawyers are saying
column2: don't participate
column3: don't comment
column4: and everyone else in the country seems more than eager to talk about it. So
column5: I think a little prudence in keeping our mouth shut while we let the investigations play out is probably fair and weÃ¢ÂÂll see what comes up in them.

column1: WALLACE: You talk about the fact that they're all the stories and sometimes it's hard to remember what you've heard this week and what you heard last week. And this gets to the question of leaks. I asked our staff to put together
column2: let's put it up on the screen
column3: a list of the headlines from just the last two weeks. This is just Sunday two weeks ago until today. And as you can see
column4: there's been a torrent of disclosures from intelligence and law enforcement officials.

column1: Gillian
column2: as somebody who worked in the government
column3: have you ever seen anything like this? And
column4: you know
column5: the conservatives talk about a deep state
column6: that there are people embedded in law enforcement and embedded in the intelligence community that are trying to bring this president down. It sure seems like it's true.

column1: GILLIAN TURNER
column2: FORMER WHITE HOUSE NATIONAL SECURITY COUNCIL: So
column3: to me on the question of leaks
column4: it seems that without a doubt leaks of information today are the number one threat to U.S. national security interest across the globe. And I think for evidence of that
column5: we need look no further than the very public reprimand
column6: we the United States had to endure from Britain earlier this week
column7: in the wake of the Manchester attacks. A reminder that the British-U.S. intelligence cooperation
column8: relationship
column9: is one of the closest that has ever existed. And in my lifetime
column10: in government and policy
column11: I have not seen something so public
column12: so public a risk (ph)

column1: (CROSSTALK)

column2: Fox did accidentally put up the wrong poll graphic

column7: MSNBC or Trump

column1: During a Fox news segment in which Republican strategist Frank Luntz thought the media should give Trump more credit for the nation's economic ""clear recovery

column1: When host Howard Kurtz asked for a poll to be put up on the screen that asks if the media reports fake news

column2: New York (CNN) -- Republican presidential candidate Sen. John McCain and Democrat Sen. Barack Obama faced off at Hofstra University Wednesday night in their last debate before Election Day. Bob Schieffer of CBS was the moderator. Here is a transcript of the debate.

column1: Sens. Barack Obama and John McCain debate face to face Wednesday night.
Schieffer: Good evening. And welcome to the third and last presidential debate of 2008
column2: sponsored by the Commission on Presidential Debates. I'm Bob Schieffer of CBS News.

column1: The rules tonight are simple. The subject is domestic policy. I will divide the next hour-and-a-half into nine-minute segments.
I will ask a question at the beginning of each segment. Each candidate will then have two minutes to respond
column2: and then we'll have a discussion.

column1: I'll encourage them to ask follow-up questions of each other. If they do not
column2: I will.

column1: The audience behind me has promised to be quiet
column2: except at this moment
column3: when we welcome Barack Obama and John McCain.

column1: Gentlemen
column2: welcome.

column1: By now
column2: we've heard all the talking points
column3: so let's try to tell the people tonight some things that they -- they haven't heard. Let's get to it.

column1: Another very bad day on Wall Street
column2: as both of you know. Both of you proposed new plans this week to address the economic crisis.

column1: Sen. McCain
column2: you proposed a $52 billion plan that includes new tax cuts on capital gains
column3: tax breaks for seniors
column4: write-offs for stock losses
column5: among other things.

column1: Sen. Obama
column2: you proposed $60 billion in tax cuts for middle- income and lower-income people
column3: more tax breaks to create jobs
column4: new spending for public works projects to create jobs.

column1: I will ask both of you: Why is your plan better than his?
Sen. McCain
column2: you go first.

column1: McCain: Well
column2: let -- let me say
column3: Bob
column4: thank you.

column1: And thanks to Hofstra.
And
column2: by the way
column3: our beloved Nancy Reagan is in the hospital tonight
column4: so our thoughts and prayers are going with you.

column1: It's good to see you again
column2: Sen. Obama.

column1: Americans are hurting right now
column2: and they're angry. They're hurting
column3: and they're angry. They're innocent victims of greed and excess on Wall Street and as well as Washington
column4: D.C. And they're angry
column5: and they have every reason to be angry.

column1: And they want this country to go in a new direction. And there are elements of my proposal that you just outlined which I won't repeat.
But we also have to have a short-term fix
column2: in my view
column3: and long- term fixes.

column1: Let me just talk to you about one of the short-term fixes.
The catalyst for this housing crisis was the Fannie and Freddie Mae that caused subprime lending situation that now caused the housing market in America to collapse.
I am convinced that
column2: until we reverse this continued decline in home ownership and put a floor under it
column3: and so that people have not only the hope and belief they can stay in their homes and realize the American dream
column4: but that value will come up.

column1: Now
column2: we have allocated $750 billion. Let's take 300 of that billion and go in and buy those home loan mortgages and negotiate with those people in their homes
column3: 11 million homes or more
column4: so that they can afford to pay the mortgage
column5: stay in their home.

column1: Now
column2: I know the criticism of this.

column1: Well
column2: what about the citizen that stayed in their homes? That paid their mortgage payments? It doesn't help that person in their home if the next door neighbor's house is abandoned. And so we've got to reverse this. We ought to put the homeowners first. And I am disappointed that Secretary Paulson and others have not made that their first priority.

column1: Schieffer: All right. Sen. Obama?
Obama: Well
column2: first of all
column3: I want to thank Hofstra University and the people of New York for hosting us tonight and it's wonderful to join Sen. McCain again
column4: and thank you
column5: Bob.

column1: I think everybody understands at this point that we are experiencing the worst financial crisis since the Great Depression. And the financial rescue plan that Sen. McCain and I supported is an important first step. And I pushed for some core principles: making sure that taxpayer can get their money back if they're putting money up. Making sure that CEOs are not enriching themselves through this process.

And I think that it's going to take some time to work itself out. But what we haven't yet seen is a rescue package for the middle class. Because the fundamentals of the economy were weak even before this latest crisis. So I've proposed four specific things that I think can help.
Number one
column2: let's focus on jobs. I want to end the tax breaks for companies that are shipping jobs overseas and provide a tax credit for every company that's creating a job right here in America.

column1: Number two
column2: let's help families right away by providing them a tax cut -- a middle-class tax cut for people making less than $200
column4: and let's allow them to access their IRA accounts without penalty if they're experiencing a crisis.

column1: Now Sen. McCain and I agree with your idea that we've got to help homeowners. That's why we included in the financial package a proposal to get homeowners in a position where they can renegotiate their mortgages.
I disagree with Sen. McCain in how to do it
column2: because the way Sen. McCain has designed his plan
column3: it could be a giveaway to banks if we're buying full price for mortgages that now are worth a lot less. And we don't want to waste taxpayer money. And we've got to get the financial package working much quicker than it has been working.

column1: Last point I want to make
column2: though. We've got some long-term challenges in this economy that have to be dealt with. We've got to fix our energy policy that's giving our wealth away. We've got to fix our health care system and we've got to invest in our education system for every young person to be able to learn.

column1: Schieffer: All right. Would you like to ask him a question?
McCain: No. I would like to mention that a couple days ago Sen. Obama was out in Ohio and he had an encounter with a guy who's a plumber
column2: his name is Joe Wurzelbacher.

column1: Joe wants to buy the business that he has been in for all of these years
column2: worked 10
column3: 12 hours a day. And he wanted to buy the business but he looked at your tax plan and he saw that he was going to pay much higher taxes.

column1: You were going to put him in a higher tax bracket which was going to increase his taxes
column2: which was going to cause him not to be able to employ people
column3: which Joe was trying to realize the American dream.

column1: Now Sen. Obama talks about the very
column2: very rich. Joe
column3: I want to tell you
column4: I'll not only help you buy that business that you worked your whole life for and be able -- and I'll keep your taxes low and I'll provide available and affordable health care for you and your employees.

column1: And I will not have -- I will not stand for a tax increase on small business income. Fifty percent of small business income taxes are paid by small businesses. That's 16 million jobs in America. And what you want to do to Joe the plumber and millions more like him is have their taxes increased and not be able to realize the American dream of owning their own business.
Schieffer: Is that what you want to do?
McCain: That's what Joe believes.
Obama: He has been watching ads of Sen. McCain's. Let me tell you what I'm actually going to do. I think tax policy is a major difference between Sen. McCain and myself. And we both want to cut taxes
column2: the difference is who we want to cut taxes for.

column1: Now
column2: Sen. McCain
column3: the centerpiece of his economic proposal is to provide $200 billion in additional tax breaks to some of the wealthiest corporations in America. Exxon Mobil
column4: and other oil companies
column5: for example
column6: would get an additional $4 billion in tax breaks.

column1: What I've said is I want to provide a tax cut for 95 percent of working Americans
column2: 95 percent. If you make more -- if you make less than a quarter million dollars a year
column3: then you will not see your income tax go up
column4: your capital gains tax go up
column5: your payroll tax. Not one dime.

column1: And 95 percent of working families
column2: 95 percent of you out there
column3: will get a tax cut. In fact
column4: independent studies have looked at our respective plans and have concluded that I provide three times the amount of tax relief to middle-class families than Sen. McCain does.

column1: Now
column2: the conversation I had with Joe the plumber
column3: what I essentially said to him was
column4: ""Five years ago
column5: when you were in a position to buy your business
column6: you needed a tax cut then.""

column1: And what I want to do is to make sure that the plumber
column2: the nurse
column3: the firefighter
column4: the teacher
column5: the young entrepreneur who doesn't yet have money
column6: I want to give them a tax break now. And that requires us to make some important choices.

column1: The last point I'll make about small businesses. Not only do 98 percent of small businesses make less than $250
column3: but I also want to give them additional tax breaks
column4: because they are the drivers of the economy. They produce the most jobs.

column1: McCain: You know
column2: when Sen. Obama ended up his conversation with Joe the plumber -- we need to spread the wealth around. In other words
column3: we're going to take Joe's money
column4: give it to Sen. Obama
column5: and let him spread the wealth around.

column1: I want Joe the plumber to spread that wealth around. You told him you wanted to spread the wealth around.
The whole premise behind Sen. Obama's plans are class warfare
column2: let's spread the wealth around. I want small businesses -- and by the way
column3: the small businesses that we're talking about would receive an increase in their taxes right now.

column1: Who -- why would you want to increase anybody's taxes right now? Why would you want to do that
column2: anyone
column3: anyone in America
column4: when we have such a tough time
column5: when these small business people
column6: like Joe the plumber
column7: are going to create jobs
column8: unless you take that money from him and spread the wealth around.

column1: I'm not going to...
Obama: OK. Can I...
McCain: We're not going to do that in my administration.
Obama: If I can answer the question. Number one
column2: I want to cut taxes for 95 percent of Americans. Now
column3: it is true that my friend and supporter
column4: Warren Buffett
column5: for example
column6: could afford to pay a little more in taxes in order...

column1: McCain: We're talking about Joe the plumber.
Obama: ... in order to give -- in order to give additional tax cuts to Joe the plumber before he was at the point where he could make $250
Then Exxon Mobil
column2: which made $12 billion
column3: record profits
column4: over the last several quarters
column5: they can afford to pay a little more so that ordinary families who are hurting out there -- they're trying to figure out how they're going to afford food
column6: how they're going to save for their kids' college education
column7: they need a break.

column1: So
column2: look
column3: nobody likes taxes. I would prefer that none of us had to pay taxes
column4: including myself. But ultimately
column5: we've got to pay for the core investments that make this economy strong and somebody's got to do it.

column1: McCain: Nobody likes taxes. Let's not raise anybody's taxes. OK?
Obama: Well
column2: I don't mind paying a little more.

column1: McCain: The fact is that businesses in America today are paying the second highest tax rate of anywhere in the world. Our tax rate for business in America is 35 percent. Ireland
column2: it's 11 percent.

column1: Where are companies going to go where they can create jobs and where they can do best in business?
We need to cut the business tax rate in America. We need to encourage business.
Now
column2: of all times in America
column3: we need to cut people's taxes. We need to encourage business
column4: create jobs
column5: not spread the wealth around.

column1: Schieffer: All right. Let's go to another topic. It's related. So if you have other things you want to say
column2: you can get back to that.

column1: This question goes to you first
column2: Sen. Obama.

column1: We found out yesterday that this year's deficit will reach an astounding record high $455 billion. Some experts say it could go to $1 trillion next year.
Both of you have said you want to reduce the deficit
column2: but the nonpartisan Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget ran the numbers on both of your proposals and they say the cost of your proposals
column3: even with the savings you claim can be made
column4: each will add more than $200 billion to the deficit.

column1: Aren't you both ignoring reality? Won't some of the programs you are proposing have to be trimmed
column2: postponed
column3: even eliminated?

column1: Give us some specifics on what you're going to cut back.
Sen. Obama?
Obama: Well
column2: first of all
column3: I think it's important for the American public to understand that the $750 billion rescue package
column4: if it's structured properly
column5: and
column6: as president
column7: I will make sure it's structured properly
column8: means that ultimately taxpayers get their money back
column9: and that's important to understand.

column1: But there is no doubt that we've been living beyond our means and we're going to have to make some adjustments.
Now
column2: what I've done throughout this campaign is to propose a net spending cut. I haven't made a promise about...

column1: Schieffer: But you're going to have to cut some of these programs
column2: certainly.

column1: Obama: Absolutely. So let me get to that. What I want to emphasize
column2: though
column3: is that I have been a strong proponent of pay-as- you-go. Every dollar that I've proposed
column4: I've proposed an additional cut so that it matches.

column1: And some of the cuts
column2: just to give you an example
column3: we spend $15 billion a year on subsidies to insurance companies. It doesn't -- under the Medicare plan -- it doesn't help seniors get any better. It's not improving our health care system. It's just a giveaway.

column1: We need to eliminate a whole host of programs that don't work. And I want to go through the federal budget line by line
column2: page by page
column3: programs that don't work
column4: we should cut. Programs that we need
column5: we should make them work better.

column1: Now
column2: what is true is that Sen. McCain and I have a difference in terms of the need to invest in America and the American people. I mentioned health care earlier.

column1: If we make investments now so that people have coverage
column2: that we are preventing diseases
column3: that will save on Medicare and Medicaid in the future.

column1: If we invest in a serious energy policy
column2: that will save in the amount of money we're borrowing from China to send to Saudi Arabia.

column1: If we invest now in our young people and their ability to go to college
column2: that will allow them to drive this economy into the 21st century.

column1: But what is absolutely true is that
column2: once we get through this economic crisis and some of the specific proposals to get us out of this slump
column3: that we're not going to be able to go back to our profligate ways.

column1: And we're going to have to embrace a culture and an ethic of responsibility
column2: all of us
column3: corporations
column4: the federal government
column5: and individuals out there who may be living beyond their means.

column1: Schieffer: Time's up.
Senator?
McCain: Well
column2: thank you
column3: Bob. I just want to get back to this home ownership. During the Depression era
column4: we had a thing called the home ownership loan corporation.

column1: And they went out and bought up these mortgages. And people were able to stay in their homes
column2: and eventually the values of those homes went up
column3: and they actually made money.

column1: And
column2: by the way
column3: this was a proposal made by Sen. Clinton not too long ago.

column1: So
column2: obviously
column3: if we can start increasing home values
column4: then there will be creation of wealth.

column1: Schieffer: But what...
McCain: But -- OK. All right.
Schieffer: The question was
column2: what are you going to cut?

column1: McCain: Energy -- well
column2: first -- second of all
column3: energy independence. We have to have nuclear power. We have to stop sending $700 billion a year to countries that don't like us very much. It's wind
column4: tide
column5: solar
column6: natural gas
column7: nuclear
column8: off-shore drilling
column9: which Sen. Obama has opposed.

column1: And the point is that we become energy independent and we will create millions of jobs -- millions of jobs in America.
OK
column2: what -- what would I cut? I would have
column3: first of all
column4: across-the-board spending freeze
column5: OK? Some people say that's a hatchet. That's a hatchet
column6: and then I would get out a scalpel
column7: OK?

column1: Because we've got -- we have presided over the largest increase -- we've got to have a new direction for this country. We have presided over the largest increase in government since the Great Society.
Government spending has gone completely out of control; $10 trillion dollar debt we're giving to our kids
column2: a half-a-trillion dollars we owe China.

column1: I know how to save billions of dollars in defense spending. I know how to eliminate programs.
Schieffer: Which ones?
McCain: I have fought against -- well
column2: one of them would be the marketing assistance program. Another one would be a number of subsidies for ethanol.

column1: I oppose subsidies for ethanol because I thought it distorted the market and created inflation; Sen. Obama supported those subsidies.
I would eliminate the tariff on imported sugarcane-based ethanol from Brazil.
I know how to save billions. I saved the taxpayer $6.8 billion by fighting a deal for a couple of years
column2: as you might recall
column3: that was a sweetheart deal between an aircraft manufacturer
column4: DOD
column5: and people ended up in jail.

column1: But I would fight for a line-item veto
column2: and I would certainly veto every earmark pork-barrel bill. Sen. Obama has asked for nearly $1 billion in pork-barrel earmark projects...

column1: Schieffer: Time's up.
McCain: ... including $3 million for an overhead projector in a planetarium in his hometown. That's not the way we cut -- we'll cut out all the pork.
Schieffer: Time's up.
Obama: Well
column2: look
column3: I think that we do have a disagreement about an across-the-board spending freeze. It sounds good. It's proposed periodically. It doesn't happen.

column1: And
column2: in fact
column3: an across-the-board spending freeze is a hatchet
column4: and we do need a scalpel
column5: because there are some programs that don't work at all. There are some programs that are underfunded. And I want to make sure that we are focused on those programs that work.

column1: Now
column2: Sen. McCain talks a lot about earmarks. That's one of the centerpieces of his campaign.

column1: Earmarks account for 0.5 percent of the total federal budget. There's no doubt that the system needs reform and there are a lot of screwy things that we end up spending money on
column2: and they need to be eliminated. But it's not going to solve the problem.

column1: Now
column2: the last thing I think we have to focus on is a little bit of history
column3: just so that we understand what we're doing going forward.

column1: When President Bush came into office
column2: we had a budget surplus and the national debt was a little over $5 trillion. It has doubled over the last eight years.

column1: Obama: And we are now looking at a deficit of well over half a trillion dollars.
So one of the things that I think we have to recognize is pursuing the same kinds of policies that we pursued over the last eight years is not going to bring down the deficit. And
column2: frankly
column3: Sen. McCain voted for four out of five of President Bush's budgets.

column1: We've got to take this in a new direction
column2: that's what I propose as president.

column1: Schieffer: Do either of you think you can balance the budget in four years? You have said previously you thought you could
column2: Sen. McCain.

column1: McCain: Sure I do. And let me tell you...
Schieffer: You can still do that?
McCain: Yes. Sen. Obama
column2: I am not President Bush. If you wanted to run against President Bush
column3: you should have run four years ago. I'm going to give a new direction to this economy in this country.

column1: Sen. Obama talks about voting for budgets. He voted twice for a budget resolution that increases the taxes on individuals making $42
column2: 000 a year. Of course
column3: we can take a hatchet and a scalpel to this budget. It's completely out of control.

column1: The mayor of New York
column2: Mayor Bloomberg
column3: just imposed an across- the-board spending freeze on New York City. They're doing it all over America because they have to. Because they have to balance their budgets. I will balance our budgets and I will get them and I will...

column1: Schieffer: In four years?
McCain: ... reduce this -- I can -- we can do it with this kind of job creation of energy independence.
Now
column2: look
column3: Americans are hurting tonight and they're angry and I understand that
column4: and they want a new direction. I can bring them in that direction by eliminating spending.

column1: Sen. Obama talks about the budgets I voted for. He voted for the last two budgets that had that $24 billion more in spending than the budget that the Bush administration proposed.
He voted for the energy bill that was full of goodies for the oil companies that I opposed. So the fact is
column2: let's look at our records
column3: Sen. Obama. Let's look at it as graded by the National Taxpayers Union and the Citizens Against Government Waste and the other watchdog organizations.

column1: I have fought against spending. I have fought against special interests. I have fought for reform. You have to tell me one time when you have stood up with the leaders of your party on one single major issue.
Schieffer: Barack.
Obama: Well
column2: there's a lot of stuff that was put out there
column3: so let me try to address it. First of all
column4: in terms of standing up to the leaders of my party
column5: the first major bill that I voted on in the Senate was in support of tort reform
column6: which wasn't very popular with trial lawyers
column7: a major constituency in the Democratic Party. I support...

column1: McCain: An overwhelming vote.

Obama: I support charter schools and pay for performance for teachers. Doesn't make me popular with the teachers union. I support clean coal technology. Doesn't make me popular with environmentalists. So I've got a history of reaching across the aisle.
Now with respect to a couple of things Sen. McCain said
column2: the notion that I voted for a tax increase for people making $42
column3: 000 a year has been disputed by everybody who has looked at this claim that Sen. McCain keeps on making.

column1: Even FOX News disputes it
column2: and that doesn't happen very often when it comes to accusations about me. So the fact of the matter is that if I occasionally have mistaken your policies for George Bush's policies
column3: it's because on the core economic issues that matter to the American people
column4: on tax policy
column5: on energy policy
column6: on spending priorities
column7: you have been a vigorous supporter of President Bush.

column1: Now
column2: you've shown independence -- commendable independence
column3: on some key issues like torture
column4: for example
column5: and I give you enormous credit for that. But when it comes to economic policies
column6: essentially what you're proposing is eight more years of the same thing. And it hasn't worked.

column1: And I think the American people understand it hasn't worked. We need to move in a new direction.
Schieffer: All right...
McCain: Let me just say
column2: Bob.

column1: Schieffer: OK. About 30 seconds.
McCain: OK. But it's very clear that I have disagreed with the Bush administration. I have disagreed with leaders of my own party. I've got the scars to prove it.
Whether it be bringing climate change to the floor of the Senate for the first time. Whether it be opposition to spending and earmarks
column2: whether it be the issue of torture
column3: whether it be the conduct of the war in Iraq
column4: which I vigorously opposed. Whether it be on fighting the pharmaceutical companies on Medicare prescription drugs
column5: importation. Whether it be fighting for an HMO patient's bill of rights. Whether it be the establishment of the 9/11 Commission.

column1: I have a long record of reform and fighting through on the floor of the United States Senate.
Schieffer: All right.
McCain: Sen. Obama
column2: your argument for standing up to the leadership of your party isn't very convincing.

column1: Schieffer: All right. We're going to move to another question and the topic is leadership in this campaign. Both of you pledged to take the high road in this campaign yet it has turned very nasty.
Schieffer: Sen. Obama
column2: your campaign has used words like ""erratic
column3: ""out of touch
column4: ""lie
column5: ""angry
column6: ""losing his bearings"" to describe Sen. McCain.

column1: Sen. McCain
column2: your commercials have included words like ""disrespectful
column3: ""dangerous
column4: ""dishonorable
column5: ""he lied."" Your running mate said he ""palled around with terrorists.""

column1: Are each of you tonight willing to sit at this table and say to each other's face what your campaigns and the people in your campaigns have said about each other?
And
column2: Sen. McCain
column3: you're first.

column1: McCain: Well
column2: this has been a tough campaign. It's been a very tough campaign. And I know from my experience in many campaigns that
column3: if Sen. Obama had asked -- responded to my urgent request to sit down
column4: and do town hall meetings
column5: and come before the American people
column6: we could have done at least 10 of them by now.

column1: When Sen. Obama was first asked
column2: he said
column3: ""Any place
column4: any time
column5: the way Barry Goldwater and Jack Kennedy agreed to do
column6: before the intervention of the tragedy at Dallas. So I think the tone of this campaign could have been very different.

column1: And the fact is
column2: it's gotten pretty tough. And I regret some of the negative aspects of both campaigns. But the fact is that it has taken many turns which I think are unacceptable.

column1: One of them happened just the other day
column2: when a man I admire and respect -- I've written about him -- Congressman John Lewis
column3: an American hero
column4: made allegations that Sarah Palin and I were somehow associated with the worst chapter in American history
column5: segregation
column6: deaths of children in church bombings
column7: George Wallace. That
column8: to me
column9: was so hurtful.

column1: And
column2: Sen. Obama
column3: you didn't repudiate those remarks. Every time there's been an out-of-bounds remark made by a Republican
column4: no matter where they are
column5: I have repudiated them. I hope that Sen. Obama will repudiate those remarks that were made by Congressman John Lewis
column6: very unfair and totally inappropriate.

column1: So I want to tell you
column2: we will run a truthful campaign. This is a tough campaign. And it's a matter of fact that Sen. Obama has spent more money on negative ads than any political campaign in history. And I can prove it.

column1: And
column2: Sen. Obama
column3: when he said -- and he signed a piece of paper that said he would take public financing for his campaign if I did -- that was back when he was a long-shot candidate -- you didn't keep your word.

column1: And when you looked into the camera in a debate with Sen. Clinton and said
column2: ""I will sit down and negotiate with John McCain about public financing before I make a decision
column3: you didn't tell the American people the truth because you didn't.

column1: And that's -- that's -- that's an unfortunate part. Now we have the highest spending by Sen. Obama's campaign than any time since Watergate.
Schieffer: Time's up. All right.
Obama: Well
column2: look
column3: you know
column4: I think that we expect presidential campaigns to be tough. I think that
column5: if you look at the record and the impressions of the American people -- Bob
column6: your network just did a poll
column7: showing that two-thirds of the American people think that Sen. McCain is running a negative campaign versus one-third of mine.

column1: And 100 percent
column2: John
column3: of your ads -- 100 percent of them have been negative.

column1: McCain: It's not true.
Obama: It absolutely is true. And
column2: now
column3: I think the American people are less interested in our hurt feelings during the course of the campaign than addressing the issues that matter to them so deeply.

column1: And there is nothing wrong with us having a vigorous debate like we're having tonight about health care
column2: about energy policy
column3: about tax policy. That's the stuff that campaigns should be made of.

column1: The notion
column2: though
column3: that because we're not doing town hall meetings that justifies some of the ads that have been going up
column4: not just from your own campaign directly
column5: John
column6: but 527s and other organizations that make some pretty tough accusations
column7: well
column8: I don't mind being attacked for the next three weeks.

column1: What the American people can't afford
column2: though
column3: is four more years of failed economic policies. And what they deserve over the next four weeks is that we talk about what's most pressing to them: the economic crisis.

column1: Sen. McCain's own campaign said publicly last week that
column2: if we keep on talking about the economic crisis
column3: we lose
column4: so we need to change the subject.

column1: And I would love to see the next three weeks devoted to talking about the economy
column2: devoted to talking about health care
column3: devoted to talking about energy
column4: and figuring out how the American people can send their kids to college.

column1: And that is something that I would welcome. But it requires
column2: I think
column3: a recognition that politics as usual
column4: as been practiced over the last several years
column5: is not solving the big problems here in America.

column1: McCain: Well
column2: if you'll turn on the television
column3: as I -- I watched the Arizona Cardinals defeat the Dallas Cowboys on Sunday.

column1: Obama: Congratulations.

McCain: Every other ad -- ever other ad was an attack ad on my health care plan. And any objective observer has said it's not true. You're running ads right now that say that I oppose federal funding for stem cell research. I don't.
You're running ads that misportray completely my position on immigration. So the fact is that Sen. Obama is spending unprecedented -- unprecedented in the history of American politics
column2: going back to the beginning
column3: amounts of money in negative attack ads on me.

column1: And of course
column2: I've been talking about the economy. Of course
column3: I've talked to people like Joe the plumber and tell him that I'm not going to spread his wealth around. I'm going to let him keep his wealth. And of course
column4: we're talking about positive plan of action to restore this economy and restore jobs in America.

column1: That's what my campaign is all about and that's what it'll continue to be all about.
But again
column2: I did not hear a repudiation of Congressman...

column1: Obama: I mean
column2: look
column3: if we want to talk about Congressman Lewis
column4: who is an American hero
column5: he
column6: unprompted by my campaign
column7: without my campaign's awareness
column8: made a statement that he was troubled with what he was hearing at some of the rallies that your running mate was holding
column9: in which all the Republican reports indicated were shouting
column10: when my name came up
column11: things like ""terrorist"" and ""kill him
column12: and that you're running mate didn't mention
column13: didn't stop
column14: didn't say ""Hold on a second
column15: that's kind of out of line.""

column1: And I think Congressman Lewis' point was that we have to be careful about how we deal with our supporters.
Now...
McCain: You've got to read what he said...
(CROSSTALK)
Obama: Let -- let -- let...
McCain: You've got to read what he said.
Obama: Let me -- let me complete...
Schieffer: Go ahead.
Obama: ... my response. I do think that he inappropriately drew a comparison between what was happening there and what had happened during the civil rights movement
column2: and we immediately put out a statement saying that we don't think that comparison is appropriate.

column1: And
column2: in fact
column3: afterwards
column4: Congressman Lewis put out a similar statement
column5: saying that he had probably gone over the line.

column1: The important point here is
column2: though
column3: the American people have become so cynical about our politics
column4: because all they see is a tit- for-tat and back-and-forth. And what they want is the ability to just focus on some really big challenges that we face right now
column5: and that's what I have been trying to focus on this entire campaign.

column1: McCain: I cannot...
Obama: We can have serious differences about our health care policy
column2: for example
column3: John
column4: because we do have a difference on health care policy
column5: but we...

column1: McCain: We do and I hope...
Obama: ... talking about it this evening.
McCain: Sure.
Obama: But when people suggest that I pal around with terrorists
column2: then we're not talking about issues. What we're talking about...

column1: McCain: Well
column2: let me just say I would...

column1: Schieffer: (inaudible)
McCain: Let me just say categorically I'm proud of the people that come to our rallies. Whenever you get a large rally of 10
column6: 000 people
column7: you're going to have some fringe peoples. You know that. And I've -- and we've always said that that's not appropriate.

column1: But to somehow say that group of young women who said ""Military wives for McCain"" are somehow saying anything derogatory about you
column2: but anything -- and those veterans that wear those hats that say ""World War II
column3: Vietnam
column4: Korea
column5: Iraq
column6: I'm not going to stand for people saying that the people that come to my rallies are anything but the most dedicated
column7: patriotic men and women that are in this nation and they're great citizens.

column1: And I'm not going to stand for somebody saying that because someone yelled something at a rally -- there's a lot of things that have been yelled at your rallies
column2: Sen. Obama
column3: that I'm not happy about either.

column1: In fact
column2: some T-shirts that are very...

column1: Obama: John
McCain: ... unacceptable. So the point is -- the point is that I have repudiated every time someone's been out of line
column2: whether they've been part of my campaign or not
column3: and I will continue to do that.

column1: But the fact is that we need to absolutely not stand for the kind of things that have been going on. I haven't.
Obama: Well
column2: look
column3: Bob
column4: as I said...

column1: Schieffer: I mean
column2: do you take issue with that?

column1: Obama: You know
column2: here's what I would say. I mean
column3: we can have a debate back and forth about the merits of each other's campaigns. I su"	0

column1: 385	"''I don't regret setting bombs
column2: '' Bill Ayers said. ''I feel we didn't do enough.'' Mr. Ayers
column3: who spent the 1970's as a fugitive in the Weather Underground
column4: was sitting in the kitchen of his big turn-of-the-19th-century stone house in the Hyde Park district of Chicago. The long curly locks in his Wanted poster are shorn
column5: though he wears earrings. He still has tattooed on his neck the rainbow-and-lightning Weathermen logo that appeared on letters taking responsibility for bombings. And he still has the ebullient
column6: ingratiating manner
column7: the apparently intense interest in other people
column8: that made him a charismatic figure in the radical student movement.

column1: Now he has written a book
column2: ''Fugitive Days'' (Beacon Press
column3: September). Mr. Ayers
column4: who is 56
column5: calls it a memoir
column6: somewhat coyly perhaps
column7: since he also says some of it is fiction. He writes that he participated in the bombings of New York City Police Headquarters in 1970
column8: of the Capitol building in 1971
column9: the Pentagon in 1972. But Mr. Ayers also seems to want to have it both ways
column10: taking responsibility for daring acts in his youth
column11: then deflecting it.

column1: ''Is this
column2: then
column3: the truth?
column4: '' he writes. ''Not exactly. Although it feels entirely honest to me.''

column1: But why would someone want to read a memoir parts of which are admittedly not true? Mr. Ayers was asked.
''Obviously
column2: the point is it's a reflection on memory
column3: '' he answered. ''It's true as I remember it.''"	0

With only a month to go before the big day
column2: Donald Trump and his team's attempts to find artists to perform at his inauguration ceremony are looking increasingly desperate.

column1: As with several other aspects of his presidential campaign process
column2: the lead-up to the ceremony has been filled with embarrassing gaffes and miscommunication.

column1: It is currently unclear as to whether Trump will succeed in securing any high profile singers to perform on the day.
So far the very short list of confirmed acts is comprised of America's Got Talent runner-up Jackie Evancho
column2: The Rockettes (the announcement of which has prompted considerable controversy)
column3: and the Mormon Tabernacle Choir.

column1: What we do know for sure is that there is a fairly big (and still growing) list of major artists who definitely won't be performing on the day.
Here is who has declined so far:
Elton John
(AFP/Getty Images) (Getty)
This rumour was started by Anthony Scaramucci of the Trump transition team
column2: who claimed that Trump would be ""the first American president in US history that enters the White House with a pro-gay-rights stance. Elton John is going to be doing our concert on the mall for the inauguration.""

column1: That sounded pretty definite. Unfortunately John's publicist Fran Curtis came straight back with a statement to the New York Times: ""Incorrect. He will NOT be performing.""
John added his own thoughts in an interview with the Guardian
column2: where he said: ""I don't really want my music to be involved in anything to do with an American election campaign.

column1: I'm British. I've met Donald Trump
column2: he was very nice to me
column3: it's nothing personal
column4: his political views are his own
column5: mine are very different
column6: I'm not a Republican in a million years. Why not ask Ted f***ing Nugent? Or one of those f***ing country stars? They'll do it for you.""

column1: Enjoy unlimited access to 70 million ad-free songs and podcasts with Amazon Music Sign up now for a 30-day free trial Sign up
Enjoy unlimited access to 70 million ad-free songs and podcasts with Amazon Music Sign up now for a 30-day free trial Sign up
Andrea Bocelli
(Getty)
In early December it looked very likely that Bocelli would duet with America's Got Talent runner-up Jackie Evancho. Due to a serious backlash from his fans
column2: however
column3: Bocelli has reportedly pulled out of any potential performance.

column1: Ice T

An odd one considering everything that Donald Trump's campaign said about Black Lives Matter and hip hop - more so when you consider the fact that Ice T penned a song called 'Cop Killer' which was written as a protest against police brutality.
But Ice T claims that the team did reach out to him
column2: or at least joked about what would happen if they did.

column1: He wrote on Twitter: ""I just got [called] to perform at the inauguration. I didn't pick up and blocked the number.""
Celine Dion
According to reports
column2: Celine Dion didn't decline Trump because she didn't want to perform
column3: but more because she was just too busy.

column1: Dion is scheduled to perform at the Colosseum at Caesar's Palace in Las Vegas on the day of the inauguration ceremony (20 January) and is unlikely to cancel due to fierce loyalty to her fans.
John Legend has been vocal about the US election from the start. Asked for his opinion on why Trump was having so much difficulty in finding talent for the ceremony
column2: he told the BBC: ""Creative people tend to reject bigotry and hate.

column1: We tend to be more liberal-minded. When we see somebody that's preaching division and hate and bigotry
column2: it's unlikely that he'll get a lot of creative people that want to be associated with him.""

column1: Adam Lambert
Adam Lambert was fairly diplomatic when asked about whether he would perform at the inauguration for Trump
column2: considering his active campaigning for LGBTQ rights and the appalling record Trump's current campaign team has on the same issues.

column1: I don't think I would take money on that one
column2: he told the BBC. ""I don't think I'd be endorsing that. They might struggle.""

column1: The Dixie Chicks
Opposition to the Iraq War derailed the career of Texan threesome Dixie Chicks (Getty)
Speaking to The Wrap
column2: Dixie Chicks manager Simon Renshaw not only denied that the band would perform
column3: but also gave an answer on the wider industry's reluctance to participate. ""No one is prepared to normalise what is going on in the country right now
column4: he said.

column1: If anyone does do it
column2: I hope that the cheque they get is in the nine figures. Because it's probably the last cheque they're ever going to get."""	1

column1: 388	"Emma GonzÃÂ¡lez is a survivor of the Parkland shooting and a leader of the movement against gun violence. She has also become a target in far-right circles. (Video: Elyse Samuels/The Washington Post
column2: Photo: Andrew Harnik/The Washington Post)

column1: Share Add to your saved stories Save
Having teenagers act as figureheads for a movement has a certain quality that has not gone unnoticed in the wake of the March for Our Lives rally on Saturday. Judge too harshly
column2: and you are attacking a kid who has balanced trauma with homework. Amplifying students such as Emma GonzÃÂ¡lez has injected optimism among liberal activists in the grinding debate about the role of guns in society.

column1: GonzÃÂ¡lez
column3: has been at the flash point of this dynamic
column4: appearing in newspapers
column5: on magazine covers and in a prominent spot at the anchor rally in Washington
column6: where her speech
column7: which included a prolonged silence
column8: lasted as long as the six minutes it took a gunman at her high school in Parkland
column9: Fla.

column3: urged the crowd at his rally to ""look at the facts."" PolitiFact Georgia is all to happy to oblige him.

column1: Food stamps
column2: officially known as the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program
column3: or SNAP
column4: give certain low-income Americans vouchers to buy groceries.

column1: The most recent data show roughly 44.2 million people received SNAP benefits in February
column2: the most recent data available.

column1: CainÃ¢ÂÂs numbers arenÃ¢ÂÂt quite accurate
column2: but heÃ¢ÂÂs close. The number of recipients has topped 44 million since December
column3: which means his estimate is about 7 percent too high.

column1: The number of beneficiaries has climbed every single month since Obama took office
column2: despite signs of an improving economy. According to historical data
column3: FebruaryÃ¢ÂÂs count appears to be the highest in any month since the program was established in 1969.

column1: Obama took office in January 2009. That month
column2: nearly 32 million people received SNAP benefits. That means the number of food stamp recipients has increased by about 12.2 million since the start of his administration.

column1: Cain placed the increase at 14 million
column2: which is about 15 percent too high. Again
column3: heÃ¢ÂÂs close
column4: but not quite right.

column1: Whether Obama deserves the blame for the increase is far less clear.
The rise in food stamps is a direct consequence of the Great Recession
column2: which started more than a year before Obama took office. Conservatives and liberals agree that Obama inherited a troubled economy. Whether SNAP usage would have been lower if Republicans won the presidency is impossible to tell.

column1: The number of food stamp beneficiaries ticked upward under President George W. Bush because of policies that broadened eligibility for the program and more aggressive efforts to get eligible Americans to apply for benefits. These policies remained in place under Obama.

Another reason assigning blame is tough is that there is typically a lag between when the broader economy begins to recover and when SNAP usage declines. The monthly growth has slowed for the past three months
column2: and it could start declining in a month or two.

column1: CainÃ¢ÂÂs accusation against Obama was not as barbed as GingrichÃ¢ÂÂs
column2: but he did lay the blame for food stamp usage at the presidentÃ¢ÂÂs feet. We therefore give the presidential candidate a Mostly True."	0

column1: 395	"Obama Urges Bernanke
column2: Paulson to Fight Foreclosures
column3: Hold Homeownership Summit

column1: Thursday
column2: March 22

column1: FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
Contact: Ben LaBolt
WASHINGTON
column2: DC -- U.S. Senator Barack Obama today sent a letter to Federal Reserve Chairman Bernanke and Treasury Secretary Paulson urging them to immediately convene a homeownership preservation summit with key stakeholders to fight foreclosures driven by growth in the subprime mortgage market.

column1: The text of the letter is below:
Dear Chairman Bernanke and Secretary Paulson

There is grave concern in low-income communities about a potential coming wave of foreclosures. Because regulators are partly responsible for creating the environment that is leading to rising rates of home foreclosure in the subprime mortgage market
column2: I urge you immediately to convene a homeownership preservation summit with leading mortgage lenders
column3: investors
column4: loan servicing organizations
column5: consumer advocates
column6: federal regulators and housing-related agencies to assess options for private sector responses to the challenge.

column1: We cannot sit on the sidelines while increasing numbers of American families face the risk of losing their homes. And while neither the government nor the private sector acting alone is capable of quickly balancing the important interests in widespread access to credit and responsible lending
column2: both must act and act quickly.

column1: Working together
column2: the relevant private sector entities and regulators may be best positioned for quick and targeted responses to mitigate the danger. Rampant foreclosures are in nobodyÃ¢ÂÂs interest
column3: and I believe this is a case where all responsible industry players can share the objective of eliminating deceptive or abusive practices
column4: preserving homeownership
column5: and stabilizing housing markets.

column1: The summit should consider best practice loan marketing
column2: underwriting
column3: and origination practices consistent with the recent (and overdue) regulatorsÃ¢ÂÂ Proposed Statement on Subprime Mortgage Lending. The summit participants should also evaluate options for independent loan counseling
column4: voluntary loan restructuring
column5: limited forbearance
column6: and other possible workout strategies. I would also urge you to facilitate a serious conversation about the following:

column1: What standards investors should require of lenders
column2: particularly with regard to verification of income and assets and the underwriting of borrowers based on fully indexed and fully amortized rates.

column1: How to facilitate and encourage appropriate intervention by loan servicing companies at the earliest signs of borrower difficulty.
How to support independent community-based-organizations to provide counseling and work-out services to prevent foreclosure and preserve homeownership where practical.
How to provide more effective information disclosure and financial education to ensure that borrowers are treated fairly and that deception is never a source of competitive advantage.
How to adopt principles of fair competition that promote affordability
column2: transparency
column3: non-discrimination
column4: genuine consumer value
column5: and competitive returns.

column1: How to ensure adequate liquidity across all mortgage markets without exacerbating consumer and housing market vulnerability.
Of course
column2: the adoption of voluntary industry reforms will not preempt government action to crack down on predatory lending practices
column3: or to style new restrictions on subprime lending or short-term post-purchase interventions in certain cases. My colleagues on the Senate Committee on Banking
column4: Housing and Urban Affairs have held important hearings on mortgage market turmoil and I expect the Committee will develop legislation.

column1: Nevertheless
column2: a consortium of industry-related service providers and public interest advocates may be able to bring quick and efficient relief to millions of at-risk homeowners and neighborhoods
column3: even before Congress has had an opportunity to act. There is an opportunity here to bring different interests together in the best interests of American homeowners and the American economy. Please donÃ¢ÂÂt let this opportunity pass us by.

column1: Sincerely
U.S. Senator Barack Obama"	0

column1: With the latest VTsIOM poll

column1: While VTsIOM is a respected pollster

The latest figures come amid a prolonged economic slump. Official data released earlier this week shows Russian household income has been decreasing for the past 11 months.
