column1: 403	"Rose Garden
11:00 A.M. EDT
THE PRESIDENT: Thank you very much. (Applause.) Everybody
column2: please have a seat. Sorry weÃ¢ÂÂre running just a little bit behind
column3: but I figured itÃ¢ÂÂs a great day to enjoy the Rose Garden.

column1: Today
column2: members of Congress have a simple choice to make: They can stand with the big oil companies
column3: or they can stand with the American people.

column1: Right now
column2: the biggest oil companies are raking in record profits Ã¢ÂÂ- profits that go up every time folks pull up into a gas station. But on top of these record profits
column3: oil companies are also getting billions a year -- billions a year in taxpayer subsidies -Ã¢ÂÂ a subsidy that theyÃ¢ÂÂve enjoyed year after year for the last century.

column1: Think about that. ItÃ¢ÂÂs like hitting the American people twice. YouÃ¢ÂÂre already paying a premium at the pump right now. And on top of that
column2: Congress
column3: up until this point
column4: has thought it was a good idea to send billions of dollars more in tax dollars to the oil industry.

column1: ItÃ¢ÂÂs not as if these companies canÃ¢ÂÂt stand on their own. Last year
column2: the three biggest U.S. oil companies took home more than $80 billion in profits. Exxon pocketed nearly $4.7 million every hour. And when the price of oil goes up
column3: prices at the pump go up
column4: and so do these companiesÃ¢ÂÂ profits. In fact
column5: one analysis shows that every time gas goes up by a penny
column6: these companies usually pocket another $200 million in quarterly profits. Meanwhile
column7: these companies pay a lower tax rate than most other companies on their investments
column8: partly because weÃ¢ÂÂre giving them billions in tax giveaways every year.

column1: Now
column2: I want to make clear
column3: we all know that drilling for oil has to be a key part of our overall energy strategy. We want U.S. oil companies to be doing well. We want them to succeed. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs why under my administration
column4: weÃ¢ÂÂve opened up millions of acres of federal lands and waters to oil and gas production. WeÃ¢ÂÂve quadrupled the number of operating oil rigs to a record high. WeÃ¢ÂÂve added enough oil and gas pipeline to circle the Earth and then some. And just yesterday
column5: we announced the next step for potential new oil and gas exploration in the Atlantic.

column1: So the fact is
column2: weÃ¢ÂÂre producing more oil right now than we have in eight years
column3: and weÃ¢ÂÂre importing less of it as well. For two years in a row
column4: America has bought less oil from other countries than we produce here at home -Ã¢ÂÂ for the first time in over a decade.

column1: So American oil is booming. The oil industry is doing just fine. With record profits and rising production
column2: IÃ¢ÂÂm not worried about the big oil companies. With high oil prices around the world
column3: theyÃ¢ÂÂve got more than enough incentive to produce even more oil. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs why I think itÃ¢ÂÂs time they got by without more help from taxpayers who are already having a tough enough time paying the bills and filling up their gas tank. And I think itÃ¢ÂÂs curious that some folks in Congress
column4: who are the first to belittle investments in new sources of energy
column5: are the ones that are fighting the hardest to maintain these giveaways for the oil companies.

column1: Instead of taxpayer giveaways to an industry thatÃ¢ÂÂs never been more profitable
column2: we should be using that money to double-down on investments in clean energy technologies that have never been more promising -- investments in wind power and solar power and biofuels; investments in fuel-efficient cars and trucks
column3: and energy-efficient homes and buildings. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs the future. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs the only way we're going to break this cycle of high gas prices that happen year after year after year. As the economy is growing
column4: the only time you start seeing lower gas prices is when the economy is doing badly. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs not the kind of pattern that we want to be in. We want the economy doing well
column5: and people to be able to afford their energy costs.

column1: And keep in mind
column2: we canÃ¢ÂÂt just drill our way out of this problem. As I said
column3: oil production here in the United States is doing very well
column4: and it's been doing well even as gas prices are going up. Well
column5: the reason is because we use more than 20 percent of the worldÃ¢ÂÂs oil but we only have 2 percent of the worldÃ¢ÂÂs known oil reserves. And that means we could drill every drop of American oil tomorrow but weÃ¢ÂÂd still have to buy oil from other countries to make up the difference. WeÃ¢ÂÂd still have to depend on other countries to meet our energy needs. And because itÃ¢ÂÂs a world market
column6: the fact that weÃ¢ÂÂre doing more here in the United States doesnÃ¢ÂÂt necessarily help us because even U.S. oil companies theyÃ¢ÂÂre selling that oil on a worldwide market. TheyÃ¢ÂÂre not keeping it just for us. And that means that if thereÃ¢ÂÂs rising demand around the world then the prices are going to up.

column1: ThatÃ¢ÂÂs not the future that I want for America. I donÃ¢ÂÂt want folks like these back here and the folks in front of me to have to pay more at the pump every time that thereÃ¢ÂÂs some unrest in the Middle East and oil speculators get nervous about whether thereÃ¢ÂÂs going to be enough supply. I donÃ¢ÂÂt want our kids to be held hostage to events on the other side of the world.
I want us to control our own destiny. I want us to forge our own future. And thatÃ¢ÂÂs why
column2: as long as IÃ¢ÂÂm President
column3: America is going to pursue an all-of-the-above energy strategy
column4: which means we will continue developing our oil and gas resources in a robust and responsible way. But it also means that weÃ¢ÂÂre going to keep developing more advanced homegrown biofuels
column5: the kinds that are already powering truck fleets across America.

column1: WeÃ¢ÂÂre going to keep investing in clean energy like the wind power and solar power thatÃ¢ÂÂs already lighting thousands of homes and creating thousands of jobs. WeÃ¢ÂÂre going to keep manufacturing more cars and trucks to get more miles to the gallon so that you can fill up once every two weeks instead of every week. WeÃ¢ÂÂre going to keep building more homes and businesses that waste less energy so that youÃ¢ÂÂre in charge of your own energy bills.

WeÃ¢ÂÂre going to do all of this by harnessing our most inexhaustible resource: American ingenuity and American imagination. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what we need to keep going. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs whatÃ¢ÂÂs at stake right now. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs the choice that we face. And thatÃ¢ÂÂs the choice thatÃ¢ÂÂs facing Congress today. They can either vote to spend billions of dollars more in oil subsidies that keep us trapped in the past
column2: or they can vote to end these taxpayer subsidies that arenÃ¢ÂÂt needed to boost oil production so that we can invest in the future. ItÃ¢ÂÂs that simple.

column1: And as long as IÃ¢ÂÂm President
column2: IÃ¢ÂÂm betting on the future. And as the people IÃ¢ÂÂve talked to around the country
column3: including the people who are behind me here today
column4: they put their faith in the future as well. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what we do as Americans. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs who we are. We innovate. We discover. We seek new solutions to some of our biggest challenges. And
column5: ultimately
column6: because we stick with it
column7: we succeed. And I believe that weÃ¢ÂÂre going to do that again. Today
column8: the American people are going to be watching Congress to see if they have that same faith.

column1: Thank you very much
column2: everybody. (Applause.)

column1: END

column1: 406	"Debt Day: A Symbol of WashingtonÃ¢ÂÂs Arrogant Culture of Borrowing and Spending (Boehner Op-Ed on Townhall.com)
Washington
column2: Apr 22 - Next week
column3: the Obama Administration will mark its 100th day in power. The first three-plus months of this Administration have been turbulent
column4: to say the least. Confronted with the most severe economic crisis in generations
column5: President Obama and congressional Democrats have set out on a spending spree the likes of which our nation has never seen. In fact
column6: the Administration has spent more in its first 100 days than all previous presidents have combined Ã¢ÂÂ hardly a distinction of which to be proud.

column1: Feeling the heat
column2: the President has asked his Cabinet to begin identifying wasteful programs to cut from the federal budget. While this sort of talk sounds good
column3: the inescapable fact is that the Administration and Congress have spent the last three months piling mountains of wasteful debt on the backs of our children and grandchildren. Just take a look at how some of the so-called Ã¢ÂÂstimulusÃ¢ÂÂ dollars are being spent. In spite of promises of transparency and accountability from the Administration
column4: hundreds of millions of taxpayer dollars are being spent on wasteful projects: a skateboard park in Rhode Island
column5: bike racks in the District of Columbia
column6: highway studies instead of construction projects in my native Ohio
column7: and programs led by housing agencies that have repeatedly failed audits Ã¢ÂÂ all in the name of economic Ã¢ÂÂstimulus.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: This Sunday marks a day that is symbolic not only of our governmentÃ¢ÂÂs arrogant culture of spending Ã¢ÂÂ but of this AdministrationÃ¢ÂÂs borrowing binge as well. ItÃ¢ÂÂs called Ã¢ÂÂDebt Day.Ã¢ÂÂ Many workers have become familiar with a concept known as Ã¢ÂÂTax Freedom Day
column2: Ã¢ÂÂ which is the day on which Americans begin working for themselves each year
column3: after having covered Uncle SamÃ¢ÂÂs tax bill for the year. Debt Day is very similar. It is the day of the Fiscal Year Ã¢ÂÂ beginning on October 1 of the previous calendar year Ã¢ÂÂ on which total government spending exceeds total federal revenues. And in our current Fiscal Year
column4: that falls on April 26 Ã¢ÂÂ this Sunday
column5: just days before the AdministrationÃ¢ÂÂs 100th day milestone. In short
column6: about halfway through Fiscal Year 2009
column7: Washington has run out of money.

column1: I often like to highlight the folly of politicians spending money we donÃ¢ÂÂt have. Well
column2: Debt Day illustrates exactly what IÃ¢ÂÂm talking about. Starting this Sunday
column3: every day between now and September 30
column5: when the federal governmentÃ¢ÂÂs budget year ends
column6: weÃ¢ÂÂll be deficit spending and piling more massive debt onto the backs of our children and grandchildren.

column1: Think about it from your familyÃ¢ÂÂs perspective. If your entire income for the year was paid out in the first six months of the year
column2: would you spend it all during that first half of the year and charge the rest of the yearÃ¢ÂÂs spending on a credit card Ã¢ÂÂ plunging your family deeper and deeper into debt? Almost certainly not. A responsible family would show some discipline by drawing up and following a budget so its annual spending was spread out throughout the entire year.

column1: This is a concept House Republicans had in mind when we offered a better solution during the budget debate several weeks ago. Our plan would curb spending
column2: create jobs by cutting taxes
column3: and control the debt Ã¢ÂÂ all with an eye toward restoring some fiscal sanity on both ends of Pennsylvania Avenue. But the Democrats in charge of our government would have none of it.

column1: WashingtonÃ¢ÂÂs attitude gives new meaning to the common sales phrase Ã¢ÂÂbuy now
column2: pay later.Ã¢ÂÂ Congress and the White House have burned through our governmentÃ¢ÂÂs Ã¢ÂÂincomeÃ¢ÂÂ for the current Fiscal Year Ã¢ÂÂ a practice that shows no signs of stopping after Debt Day comes and goes on Sunday. So
column3: Washington will continue to Ã¢ÂÂbuy now
column4: Ã¢ÂÂ while taxpayers 10
column6: and 30 years from now will be forced to Ã¢ÂÂpay later.Ã¢ÂÂ And pay dearly
column7: they will."	0

408	"Across the United States
column2: billions of dollars are spent each year on lottery tickets. For many people
column3: these tickets are a part of their daily lives and a source of fun
column4: but for others they represent an all-out attempt to win big. It is a gamble that can lead to financial ruin and even mental illness. And while it is legal
column5: itÃ¢ÂÂs not something you should take lightly.

column1: ItÃ¢ÂÂs hard to find anyone who doesnÃ¢ÂÂt know that the lottery is a gambling game in which players pay a small amount of money for a chance to win a larger sum of money. But what most people donÃ¢ÂÂt realize is that lotteries arenÃ¢ÂÂt just about winning the jackpot; they also encourage reckless spending and can have a detrimental effect on society.
The history of lotteries goes back centuries. Moses was instructed by the Lord to use a lottery to divide land among the Israelites
column2: and Roman emperors used it as an entertainment at Saturnalian feasts. The practice eventually spread to America
column3: where it was adopted by New Hampshire in 1964
column4: followed by 13 other states.

column1: When state governments decide to adopt a lottery
column2: they often argue that the proceeds will benefit some specific public good
column3: such as education. This argument is effective at gaining and maintaining popular support
column4: especially during times of economic stress. But studies have shown that lottery popularity has little correlation with the actual fiscal health of a state.

column1: Once a lottery is established
column2: it inevitably expands in size and complexity. It is a classic example of public policy made piecemeal and incrementally
column3: with authority divided among multiple agencies and with the general welfare only intermittently taken into account. The growth of lottery games is usually driven by market forces
column4: and the number of available games often exceeds the number of people who can afford to play them.

column1: While rich people do buy lottery tickets (one of the largest jackpots was won by three asset managers from Greenwich
column2: Connecticut)
column3: they purchase far fewer than the poor do. The result is that the lottery is a regressive enterprise. On average
column4: those making more than fifty thousand dollars spend one percent of their income on tickets; those making less than thirty-seven thousand spend thirteen percent.

column1: As a business
column2: a lottery is all about maximizing revenues. That means that advertising necessarily focuses on persuading people to spend their money on tickets
column3: and the tactics are not that dissimilar to those used by tobacco companies and video-game producers. But should a government be in the business of promoting gambling? And if it is

column2: a member of the audience accused Mr. McCain of having moved away from his Ã¢ÂÂmaverickÃ¢ÂÂ stances and challenged him on his recent statement that Mr. Obama would rather lose a war if it meant winning an election. Did he mean to say that Mr. Obama was a traitor?

column1: In a heated back and forth
column2: Mr. McCain challenged the man
column3: who said he was from Arizona and had voted for him
column4: to specify the positions he had changed positions on. The man cited tax cuts and his fealty to the Ã¢ÂÂChristian right.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: Mr. McCain said he had not supported President BushÃ¢ÂÂs tax cuts because they were not balanced by cuts in spending but that he had supported different tax cuts. And he said he was someone who sought reconciliation
column2: both with the likes of the late Rev. Jerry Falwell and the Vietnamese
column3: who had held him captive during the war.

column1: As for whether he thought Mr. Obama was a Ã¢ÂÂtraitor
column2: Ã¢ÂÂ Mr. McCain did not repeat the word and avoided a yes-or-no answer but gave an intense response.

column1: He said he himself had been called Ã¢ÂÂdisloyalÃ¢ÂÂ by Republicans when he said the United States was losing the war in Iraq and that its strategy wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt work. He said he had been Ã¢ÂÂdeclared dead
column2: Ã¢ÂÂ but he was reminded of Chairman MaoÃ¢ÂÂs saying that Ã¢ÂÂitÃ¢ÂÂs always darkest before itÃ¢ÂÂs totally black.Ã¢ÂÂ But
column3: he added
column4: Mr. Obama said the surge would fail
column5: Ã¢ÂÂhe voted to cut off funding for the men and women who are serving in Iraq
column6: he refuses to acknowledge that the surge succeeded.Ã¢ÂÂ He added: Ã¢ÂÂI think heÃ¢ÂÂs wrong and I think he used the issue of Iraq for political reasons to get the nomination of his party
column7: Ã¢ÂÂ he said
column8: to sustained applause.

column1: He also implicitly criticized President Bush for not asking more of the nation after the 9/11 attacks. He said that by urging people to go shopping
column2: Ã¢ÂÂwe passed up an opportunityÃ¢ÂÂ to ask them to join the Peace Corps or perform some sort of national service.

column1: He also said he opposed a military draft because it wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt work. Ã¢ÂÂThe kind of war theyÃ¢ÂÂre fighting requires long-term commitment
column2: Ã¢ÂÂ he said. And a draft now would probably be as unjust as it was during Vietnam
column3: he said
column4: when people of privilege could avoid it.

column1: On the lighter side
column2: he joked about having once said that ABBAÃ¢ÂÂs Ã¢ÂÂDancing QueenÃ¢ÂÂ was his favorite singing group
column3: correcting the record to say his favorite song was Frank SinatraÃ¢ÂÂs Ã¢ÂÂIÃ¢ÂÂve Got You Under My Skin.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: He said that if heÃ¢ÂÂs Ã¢ÂÂlacking in anything
column2: Ã¢ÂÂ it is an appreciation for music and art and Ã¢ÂÂthe other great things in life
column3: Ã¢ÂÂ partly because he missed out on popular music while he was a POW. Then he began defending ABBA adamantly.

column1: Ã¢ÂÂEverybody says
column2: Ã¢ÂÂI hate ABBA
column3: Oh
column4: ABBA
column5: how terrible
column6: blah
column7: blah
column8: blah.Ã¢ÂÂHow come everybody goes to Ã¢ÂÂMamma Mia!?Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ he said. Ã¢ÂÂEverybody goes! TheyÃ¢ÂÂve been selling out for years.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: After another question about Iraq

column1: Ã¢ÂÂI appreciate art
column2: Ã¢ÂÂ he declared. Ã¢ÂÂIf thereÃ¢ÂÂs one thing IÃ¢ÂÂm going to do and I have the opportunity
column3: itÃ¢ÂÂs to take a class in art.Ã¢ÂÂ He said he had seen a lot of art in the homes of supporters recently and that his daughter had graduated from Columbia with a degree in art history. He said he loved his education at the Naval Academy

column1: 423	"MINNEAPOLIS (AP) Ã¢ÂÂ When Philando Castile saw the flashing lights in his rearview mirror the night he got shot
column2: it wasn't unusual. He had been pulled over at least 52 times in recent years in and around the Twin Cities and given citations for minor offenses including speeding
column3: driving without a muffler and not wearing a seat belt.

column1: He was assessed at least $6
column2: 588 in fines and fees
column3: although more than half of the total 86 violations were dismissed
column4: court records show.

column1: Was Castile an especially bad driver or just unlucky? Or was he targeted by officers who single out black motorists like him for such stops
column2: as several of his family members have alleged?

column1: The answer may never be known
column2: but Castile's stop for a broken tail light Wednesday ended with him fatally shot by a suburban St. Paul police officer
column3: and Castile's girlfriend livestreaming the chilling aftermath.

column1: The shooting has added a new impetus to a national debate on racial profiling; a day after Castile died
column2: a black Army veteran killed five officers in Dallas at a demonstration over Castile's killing and another fatal police shooting
column3: in Louisiana.

column1: The Castile video ""is pretty horrific
column2: said Gavin Kearney
column3: who in 2003 co-authored a report to the Minnesota Legislature on racial profiling in the state. ""There are things we don't know about it. But we know there are certain assumptions and biases Ã¢ÂÂ whether explicit or implicit Ã¢ÂÂ about black men that affect how police officers interpret their actions. And we know white drivers are less likely to be pulled over.""

column1: Court records dating to 2002 show Castile
column2: a 32-year-old school cafeteria supervisor
column3: averaged more than three traffic stops per year and received citations for misdemeanors or petty misdemeanors.

column1: Many charges were dismissed
column2: but Castile pleaded guilty to some
column3: mostly for driving after his license was revoked and driving with no proof of insurance. However
column4: those two charges also were the most frequently dismissed
column5: along with failing to wear a seat belt.

column1: The records show no convictions for more serious crimes.
No recent information is available on the racial breakdown of drivers stopped or ticketed by police in Falcon Heights
column2: the mostly white suburb where the shooting occurred
column3: or in other Minnesota towns. Minnesota is not among the handful of states that require police to keep such data.

column1: But in 2001
column2: the Legislature asked for a racial profiling study and it fell to Kearney
column3: then at the Institute on Race & Poverty at the University of Minnesota Law School
column4: to conduct it. His study
column5: using information supplied voluntarily by 65 law enforcement jurisdictions in the state
column6: found a strong likelihood that racial and ethnic bias played a role in traffic stop policies and practices. Overall
column7: officers stopped minority drivers at greater rates than whites and searched them at greater rates
column8: but found contraband in those searches at lower rates than whites.

column1: The analysis found the pattern was more pronounced in suburban areas. In Fridley
column2: New Hope
column3: Plymouth
column4: Sauk Rapids and Savage combined
column5: blacks were stopped about 310 percent more often than expected.

column1: The St. Anthony Police Department
column2: which employs the officer who shot Castile
column3: did not participate in the study. St. Anthony officials have not commented on Castile's stop since shortly after the shooting.

column1: It was not immediately clear how much money governments in the Minneapolis-St. Paul area generate from traffic violations. A U.S. Department of Justice investigation following the 2014 police shooting death of Michael Brown
column2: a black
column3: unarmed 18-year-old
column4: in Ferguson
column5: Missouri
column6: found law enforcement efforts were focused on generating revenue for that city. Most of the tickets and fines were going to blacks.

column1: Castile's girlfriend
column2: Diamond Reynolds
column3: a passenger in the car
column4: said the two officers who stopped them said the vehicle had a broken tail light. She said one of the officers shot him ""for no apparent reason"" after he reached for his ID.

column1: Valerie Castile said she thinks her son ""was just black in the wrong place."" Minnesota Gov. Mark Dayton said he did not believe it would have happened to a white motorist.
The officer who shot Castile
column2: Jeronimo Yanez
column3: is Latino. His lawyer
column4: Thomas Kelly
column5: said Saturday that his client reacted to the fact that Castile had a gun
column6: not his race
column7: though Kelly would not discuss what led Yanez to initiate the traffic stop.

column1: Police understand the concerns about choices made about who gets stopped and what happens when they get stopped
column2: said Darrel Stephens
column3: executive director of the Major Cities Chiefs Association.

column1: But the statistics can't simply be attributed to racial bias among police.
When people call the police
column2: they provide a description of somebody engaged in a crime. The police respond to those descriptions
column3: said Stephens
column4: a former Charlotte
column5: North Carolina
column6: police chief. ""That counts for part of the disproportionality that we see in those numbers.""

column1: Last year
column2: the President's Task Force on 21st Century Policing recommended police departments collect and analyze demographic data on all stops
column3: searches and seizures.

column1: Nationally
column2: 13 percent of black drivers were pulled over at least once in 2011
column3: compared with 10 percent of the white drivers
column4: according to a survey by the U.S. Justice Department's Bureau of Justice Statistics.

column1: The survey shows 68 percent of black drivers considered the stops legitimate compared with 84 percent of white drivers.
The precise reasons why certain motorists are pulled over more than others are difficult to identify
column2: said Lorie Fridell
column3: an associate professor of criminology at the University of South Florida
column4: who trains police departments through a program called Fair and Impartial Policing.

column1: Our implicit biases are most likely to impact us when we're facing ambiguous situations
column2: Fridell said. ""A person reaching into a pocket is ambiguous. If I
column3: as a white
column4: middle-aged woman
column5: reach into my pocket most people aren't going to experience fear. For a black male with dreadlocks
column6: that ambiguous action would produce fear in many people.""

column1: 428	"During a flight from New York City to Chicago
column2: violence erupted after a flight attendant assaulted a 7 month-old baby boy. This comes just hours after a man was dragged off of an overbooked United Airlines flight when he refused to get off the plane. He was pulled out of his seat and thrown into the aisle as seen on a video released on Monday.

column1: The baby
column2: whose name has not been released
column3: was left with a welt mark across his face due to the assault. Eyewitnesses say the little boy was screaming for about 38 minutes straight and the parents were asked by the flight attendant several times to Ã¢ÂÂquiet that annoying ass baby down.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: After the 4th attempt to get the parents to comply
column2: the flight attendant erupted into a rage grabbing the baby from the motherÃ¢ÂÂs arms and slapping him in the face. It took several passengers to subdue the United Airlines employee.

column1: The flight attendant was restrained in the back of the plane until the Pilot could make an emergency landing in Missouri. United Airlines released a statement saying the employee acted in a way that does not represent their company and has been fired.
The little boy is said to be in stable condition with no life-threatening injuries. The parents say they are reaching out to an attorney
column2: refusing to give any further statements."	1
the I.R.S. has compiled data from the returns of the 400 Americans reporting the largest income. In 1992
column3: the top 400 had aggregate taxable income of $16.9 billion and paid federal taxes of 29.2 percent on that sum. In 2008
column4: the aggregate income of the highest 400 had soared to $90.9 billion Ã¢ÂÂ a staggering $227.4 million on average Ã¢ÂÂ but the rate paid had fallen to 21.5 percent.

column1: The taxes I refer to here include only federal income tax
column2: but you can be sure that any payroll tax for the 400 was inconsequential compared to income. In fact
column3: 88 of the 400 in 2008 reported no wages at all
column4: though every one of them reported capital gains. Some of my brethren may shun work but they all like to invest. (I can relate to that.)

column1: I know well many of the mega-rich and
column2: by and large
column3: they are very decent people. They love America and appreciate the opportunity this country has given them. Many have joined the Giving Pledge
column4: promising to give most of their wealth to philanthropy. Most wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt mind being told to pay more in taxes as well
column5: particularly when so many of their fellow citizens are truly suffering.

column1: Twelve members of Congress will soon take on the crucial job of rearranging our countryÃ¢ÂÂs finances. TheyÃ¢ÂÂve been instructed to devise a plan that reduces the 10-year deficit by at least $1.5 trillion. ItÃ¢ÂÂs vital
column2: however
column3: that they achieve far more than that. Americans are rapidly losing faith in the ability of Congress to deal with our countryÃ¢ÂÂs fiscal problems. Only action that is immediate
column4: real and very substantial will prevent that doubt from morphing into hopelessness. That feeling can create its own reality.

column1: Job one for the 12 is to pare down some future promises that even a rich America canÃ¢ÂÂt fulfill. Big money must be saved here. The 12 should then turn to the issue of revenues. I would leave rates for 99.7 percent of taxpayers unchanged and continue the current 2-percentage-point reduction in the employee contribution to the payroll tax. This cut helps the poor and the middle class
column2: who need every break they can get."	0

column1: before the
House Judiciary Committee Subcommittee on Crime
U. S. House of Representatives May 27
Our freedoms are already endangered enough by those who oppose them. But I 've learned that a freedom is most at risk when it 's in the hands of honest people who think
column2: for some perceived common good
column3: they ought to give it up.

column1: Today we are a country in shock
column2: still bewildered by what confluence of forces could possibly lead young people to hurt each other.

column1: In that tender state
column2: good people are vulnerable. They want to do something
column3: anything
column4: for the common good. Indeed
column5: some are so perplexed about what to do that legislators admit from the outset that their legislation could not have prevented the very crimes that provoked drafting it.

column1: That's the very definition of a perceived
column2: but fictitious
column3: common good.

column1: As this made-for-TV lawmaking gets played out
column2: it needs a villain. So good Americans have been exposed daily to a well-coordinated systematic bashing of the National Rifle Association 's membership as somehow a reckless societal pathogen
column3: a mighty extremist empire opposed to safety
column4: caution
column5: and reason.

column1: That is a cruel and dangerous lie.

Because nobody --nor any combination of entities you care to add up --has invested even a measurable fraction of what we have invested toward keeping safety and sanity central to the lawful exercise of the Second Amendment.

And nobody is more committed than we are to keeping guns out of criminals 'hands. That's obviously in our best interest. It's just whether you believe you 're more likely to keep guns and criminals apart with new laws you write and ignore
column2: or with existing laws you enforce.

column1: Some think our insistence on enforcement is unreasonable. Others say we oppose reasonable restrictions on gun ownership. So let's talk about what's reasonable and what's not.

We think it 's reasonable to provide mandatory instant criminal background checks for every sale at every gun show. No loopholes anywhere for anyone. That means closing the Hinckley loophole so the records of those adjudicated mental ill are in the system.
This isn 't new
column2: or a change of position
column3: or a concession. I've been on record on this point consistently
column4: from our national meeting in Denver
column5: to paid national ads and position papers
column6: to

column1: news interviews and press appearances. But I 've repeatedly emphasized that this Administration must stop illegally keeping records of lawful gun buyers.
In fact
column2: it 's the media 's well-kept secret that the NRA was an early architect and supporter of the National Instant Check System now in place. Congressman McCollum knows we worked with him on instant checks more than a decade ago.

column1: We think it 's reasonable to provide for instant checks at gun shows just like at gun stores and
pawn shops. But what 's unreasonable is how the proposed Lautenberg legislation ignores the 250
column2: 000 prohibited people like felons who 've walked away from gun stores --instead of being prosecuted for a federal felony for trying to buy a gun.

column1: We think it 's reasonable to prevent all juveniles convicted of violent felonies from owning guns
for life. What's unreasonable is how Lautenberg can prevent your law-abiding son from
inheriting his grandpa 's shotgun collection because Lautenberg classifies him as a gun show dealer who must be federally regulated.

We think it 's reasonable to prosecute more than just two dozen thugs last year for putting illegal guns in criminals 'hands. What 's unreasonable is that Lautenberg considers legal guns in private hands subject to intrusive federal regulation
column2: even in the privacy of your home.

column1: For a century we 've taught it 's not just reasonable but essential to use safety locks
column2: trigger locks
column3: gun safes or any voluntary means appropriate to keep firearms out of the wrong hands. What's unreasonable is that Lautenberg can put you in prison just for failing to keep records on how many guns you own.

column1: We think it 's reasonable to make gun show instant checks just like gun store instant checks.
What's unreasonable is how Lautenberg could define your Walmart
column2: or your uncle 's skeetshooting range
column3: or your next-door firearms collector
column4: or your local sporting clays competition
column5: or

column1: any person or place with 50 or more firearms as a ""gun show "" subject to mtrusive government regulation. That 's crazy!
We think it 's reasonable to demand strict prosecution of criminal activity
column2: whether it takes place in

column1: a big-city alleyway or small town gun show. What 's unreasonable is that Lautenberg instead demands strict registration of law-abiding gun buyers
column2: b oiving the federal government the name and address
column3: type of gun and serial number ---not of criminals but of Americans deemed NOT to be criminals by the instant check!

column1: We think it 's reasonable to provide full funding for the National Instant Check System so it
operates efficiently and instantly. What 's unreasonable is how Lautenberg authorizes an unlimited gun tax on purchases by law-abiding citizens.
We think it 's reasonable to expect our government to prosecute more than 24 hoods last year for providing guns to criminals. What 's unreasonable is how Lautenberg makes everyone
prosecutable if you just talk about buying or selling a gun at a gun show --even if you have no gun in your possession!
We think it 's reasonable to support the federal Gun-Free School Zones Act. What 's unreasonable is letting 6
column2: 000 students caught with illegal guns at school go
column3: prosecuting only 13 of them the past

column1: two years.
We think it 's reasonable to demand that when a lawful gun buyer passes the criminal background check and purchases a firearm
column2: records of that transaction be destroyed immediately. What 's unreasonable is Lautenberg 's decree that we trust government bureaucrats to compile and keep

column1: We think it 's reasonable is to expect full enforcement of federal firearms laws by the federal government. What 's unreasonable is when the Justice Department claims that federal gun laws are
for the states to enforce! Reasonable people know that a case made in state court means plea bargains
column2: judge shopping and no mandatory minimum sentencing. Even Mayor Ed Rendell of Philadelphia knows this
column3: even if the Justice Department does not. He said
column4: quote: ""In state court
column5: we average for these types of gun violations a 4-month prison sentence. The federal guidelines are

column1: 59 months in prison. That 's a 5 l/2 year difference. Incarcerating convicted felons in possession
of firearms for that length of time will save lives. It will save carnage. It will save people from being maimed. ""
That's why we support Project Exile --the fierce prosecution of federal gun laws that has cut crime rates overnight the few places it 's been tried. Even though this Administration resists it
column2: we think

column1: it's reasonable because it works.
We only support what works
column2: and our proud list is long. From Project Exile to three-strikesyou're out
column3: to truth in sentencin g
column4: to ten-twenty-life
column5: to mandatory minimums --what 's reasonable is what works; what 's unreasonable is what doesn 't work.

column1: What's unreasonable is further erosion of privacy
column2: further intrusion into private transactions
column3: and further government penalizing of the law-abiding many instead of the lawbreaking few. America will not tolerate further surrender of precious freedoms in return for nothing but perceived but

column1: fictitious promises that make none of us safer.
The Lautenberg legislation is not only unreasonable
column2: it is unworkable . . . unacceptable . . . and to

column1: our Founders who gave us the Second Amendment
column2: unthinkable.

column1: And finally --somebody's got to say this out loud: It 's reasonable for well-meaning people to convene hearings like this to find and fashion solutions. What 's unreasonable is when a new level of hate rhetoric becomes acceptable because it 's aimed at honest gun owners
column2: as in the violent language of influential film-maker Spike Lee who last week reportedly said about NRA President Charlton Heston
column3: quote
column4: ""Shoot him --with a .44 caliber Bulldog. "" By his defiant silence
column5: instead

column1: of the quick apology most American role models would offer
column2: he sanctions hate and bears his share

column1: of culpability for the kind of violence this body seeks to stop.
On behalf of millions of gun owners who are NRA members
column2: and tens of millions who are not yet
column3: I am asking you to practice yourselves what is so readily preached to us: Be reasonable.

column2: thatÃ¢ÂÂs what one former congressman says.

column1: After Obama told The New Yorker that marijuana is no more dangerous than alcohol Ã¢ÂÂ which opened the door to a broader conversation about legalizing or decriminalizing a drug thatÃ¢ÂÂs on the federal governmentÃ¢ÂÂs most restrictive list
column2: Schedule I Ã¢ÂÂ former Rep. Patrick Kennedy
column3: D-R.I.
column4: said the president needs to brush up on his pot knowledge.

column1: I think the president needs to speak to his (National Institute of Health) director in charge of drug abuse
column2: said Kennedy
column3: who chairs Smart Approaches to Marijuana
column4: a group that opposes legalization. The NIH director ""would tell the president that
column5: in fact
column6: todayÃ¢ÂÂs modern
column7: genetically modified marijuana (has) much higher THC levels
column8: far surpass(ing) the marijuana that the president acknowledges smoking when he was a young person.""

column1: ObamaÃ¢ÂÂs exploits as a pot-smoking adolescent are well documented in his own memoir
column2: Dreams from My Father. More recently
column3: in journalist David MaranissÃ¢ÂÂ biography Barack Obama: The Story
column4: readers learned that Obama as a high schooler in the late 1970s rolled with a group called the Choom Gang Ã¢ÂÂ friends from Hawaii who frequently got high.

column1: But has marijuana changed that much? We decided to investigate.
What is THC?
Cannabis contains roughly 500 compounds
column2: 70 of which are psychoactive. THC
column3: or delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol
column4: is the main psychoactive ingredient in the marijuana plant.

column1: The level of THC in a plant varies based on the strain. When researchers discuss the potency of marijuana
column2: they typically are measuring the concentration of THC.

column1: THC levels also differ depending on the part of the plant used
column2: and how it is processed for consumption. In addition to marijuana
column3: there are materials such as sinsemilla (the flowering tops of unfertilized female plants)
column4: hashish or cannabis resin
column5: and hash oil (a concentrated extract from cannabis plants). Hashish oil tends to have much higher concentrations of THC than marijuana or even sinsemilla. Both of these have become more popular in recent years.

column1: But what about marijuana itself? Has weed as we once knew it become more potent?
The answer is: yes. THC levels are on the rise
column2: and they have been for quite some time.

column1: The University of Mississippi Potency Monitoring project analyzed tens of thousands of marijuana samples confiscated by state and federal law enforcement agencies since 1972. The average potency of all seized cannabis has increased from a concentration of 3.4 percent in 1993 to about 8.8 percent in 2008. Potency in sinsemilla in particular has jumped from 5.8 percent to 13.4 percent during that same time period.
Back in the late 1970s when Obama was in high school (he graduated in 1979)
column2: the mean potency for marijuana was about 3 percent
column3: said Mahmoud ElSohly
column4: director of marijuana research at Ole Miss.

column1: Further
column2: the number of samples confiscated with a THC concentration greater than 9 percent has increased significantly
column3: from 3.2 percent in 1993 to 21.5 percent of the 1
column4: 635 marijuana samples collected in 2007.

column1: But while the average is up due to the availability of marijuana with a higher THC count
column2: the high mark in potency (somewhere around 25-27 percent) remains relatively unchanged in the last couple decades and isnÃ¢ÂÂt likely to increase
column3: ElSohly said.

column1: How did it get so strong?
The former congressman said the reason for the increasing levels of THC is genetic modification. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs not quite right.

Genetic modification or genetic engineering involves altering a substanceÃ¢ÂÂs DNA at the molecular level. Producers of marijuana on the illicit market donÃ¢ÂÂt have the ability to pull off those kinds of lab-based modifications.
However
column2: genetic selection involves breeding marijuana plants with the highest concentration of THC. Genetic selection
column3: unlike genetic modification
column4: has been practiced for centuries. Think about how we got different breeds of dogs or varieties of tomatoes.

column1: Genetic selection is quite prevalent in marijuana
column2: ElSohly said. Drug dealers have steered toward these methods in hopes of creating a product that enables them to sell smaller volume at a higher cost.

column1: Cultivation methods that allow growers to control climate
column2: water and soil levels have dramatically improved production as well
column3: he said
column4: and they have a better idea what parts of the plant produce the highest concentration of THC.

column1: There is some genetic engineering of marijuana in labs
column2: but itÃ¢ÂÂs not widespread yet and itÃ¢ÂÂs not the cause for the increase
column3: ElSohly said.

column1: What does it mean?
What does this rise in potency mean in a practical sense? LetÃ¢ÂÂs start with what the National Institutes of Health says
column2: since Kennedy singled out the government agency.

column1: Noting that the psychoactive ingredient in marijuana has increased in recent decades
column2: the NIH warns that ""daily use can have stronger effects on a developing teen brain than it did 10 or 20 years ago.""

column1: Researchers have warned against marijuana use by teens and even young adults
column2: noting that developing brains have an increased risk of dependency. That was an issue even before potency factored in
column3: though the growing strength of the drug does have health officials more concerned.

column1: Those concerns are also directed at populations who had already been advised against smoking marijuana when THC levels were lower
column2: such as individuals with cardiovascular diseases or those with certain mental illness
column3: such as schizophrenia.

column1: But for the average adult recreational or habitual user
column2: thereÃ¢ÂÂs a lot less certainty about what rising THC levels mean.

column1: Only a handful of studies have looked at how users smoke marijuana with varying THC levels. Several of these studies noted that when test subjects were using more highly concentrated marijuana
column2: they often smoked less than they did when consuming product with a lower THC level.

column1: In that regard
column2: THC would seem to mimic how people consume beverages with different alcohol content: People tend to drink whiskey in shots
column3: wine by the glass and beer by the mug. Marijuana may work the same way
column4: said Carl Hart
column5: a psychology professor at Columbia University who studies the effects of psychoactive drugs.

column1: Roger Roffman
column2: a social work professor at the University of Washington and author of the upcoming book Marijuana Nation
column3: noted that there has been little research on the impact of potency in cannabis at the levels seen today
column4: especially in products like hash oil
column5: meaning we donÃ¢ÂÂt know everything about its potential impact.

column1: Beyond dependency
column2: health officials also warn that smoking marijuana can cause paranoia and in some cases anxiety attacks.

column1: Hospital visits caused by marijuana are on the rise over the last decade
column2: from 359
column4: 340 in 2011. However
column5: it is unclear if that is caused by higher potency levels
column6: greater usage of marijuana or other factors.

column1: This is all important food for thought
column2: because the debate is ongoing and more research is needed. However
column3: this didn't affect our ruling.

column1: Our ruling
Kennedy said that marijuana today is ""genetically modified
column2: with THC levels that ""far surpass the marijuana"" of the 1970s.

column1: Generally speaking
column2: the potency of marijuana has been on the rise since ObamaÃ¢ÂÂs youth
column3: though experts disagree about what impact that rise could have on marijuanaÃ¢ÂÂs negative health effects
column4: in part because the research so far has been incomplete. The most off-base part of KennedyÃ¢ÂÂs claim is that the rise in THC levels comes from ""genetic modification."" ItÃ¢ÂÂs actually from genetic selection
column5: a very old process of producing desired traits from crops. On balance
column6: we rate his statement Mostly True."	0

Also

column2: recession. Some people argue we're already in one. Others say we need to pass some sort of stimulus plan and quickly to avoid one if that's the case. Right now

column4: there is talk that perhaps the longer this takes
column5: the less effective it is. What would you do right now to try to stem the economic troubles we seem to be getting into?

column1: CLINTON: Well
column2: I would have a very aggressive policy toward trying to stop home foreclosures. Again
column3: I'm the only candidate left in this race on either side who has been talking about the mortgage crisis for nearly a year. We need to put a moratorium on foreclosures to help people stay in their homes and we need to freeze these interest rates that continue to escalate
column4: driving more and more people into foreclosure. A lot of people were misled. They were the victim of predatory lending practices
column5: and we need to stabilize the housing market.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
CHETRY: Senator Clinton also said she thinks the country is on the brink of a recession. And the Senate must get a stimulus plan through as a first step. John.
ROBERTS: Coming up on 34 minutes after the hour
column2: Kiran
column3: Senator Barack Obama is heading back to his hometown of Chicago for a rally tonight. We had a chance to speak with him in the last hour of AMERICAN MORNING
column4: talk about issues like Iraq and the difference between his health care plan and Senator Clinton's.

ROBERTS: She suggests you are falling short here by mandating coverage for children but not mandating it for their parents. What do you say?
SEN. BARACK OBAMA (D)
column2: PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: Let's break down what she really means by a mandate. What's meant by a mandate is that the government is forcing people to buy health insurance and so she's suggesting a parent is not going to buy health insurance for themselves if they can afford it. Now
column3: my belief is that most parents will choose to get health care for themselves and we make it affordable.

column1: ROBERTS: In an Obama White House
column2: what would that strategic relationship with Iraq look like?

column1: OBAMA: I think
column2: first of all
column3: it will not have us setting up permanent bases and a permanent occupation in Iraq for decades which is what George Bush's suggested but also John McCain. I think it is important for us to say to the Iraqis that we are willing to help them. We want to be partners with them
column4: but we are not going to be there in perpetuity. And I have been very clear. I will end this war. We will get combat troops out. I hope to do it by the end of 2009.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
ROBERTS: Senator Obama also refused to say whether he'd join a combined ticket with Hillary Clinton. He said his focus now is winning the nomination and then trying to unite the country.
Well
column2: California is a big piece of the puzzle today. Polls opened at 7:00 Pacific
column3: 10 a.m. Eastern and the republicans going after 170 delegates for the democrats' 370 are at stake. And there is no winner take all. Delegates will be awarded by congressional district making it a lot more -- making it more like a lot of mini elections instead of just one big one. So what issues are driving the voters? Our Chris Lawrence hit the road to find out. He is live for us this morning in San Francisco. Chris
column4: good morning.

column1: CHRIS LAWRENCE
column2: CNN
column3: CORRESPONDENT: Good morning
column4: John. You know
column5: 1 out of every 8 Americans lives in California. That gives you an idea of the sheer size of this primary. And the voters here are making their decisions based on immigration
column6: health care and most of all
column7: the economy.

LAWRENCE (voice-over): 80 miles east of L.A.
column2: Betty Larkins is packing up. After the bank foreclosed on her home.

column1: BETTY LARKINS: People are saying something about a recession might come. To me

column2: but she's losing her home because she went broke paying hospital bills.

column2: she's narrowed it down to Obama and Clinton.

LAWRENCE: Betty is just one member of the country's most diverse electorate. And California is super Tuesday's biggest prize. There are more people living in Los Angeles county than the entire state of Michigan. We wanted to hear from even more of California's nearly 16 million registered voters

column1: Driving hundreds of miles to the more agricultural area around Fresno
column2: we found problems for one front-runner.

column1: JOE MENDOZA
column2: UNDECIDED VOTER: McCain is wishy washy.

MENDOZA: Immigration is a big factor with me right now. To see what they are going to do. This country can't keep sending all our jobs off.
LAWRENCE: The next day
column2: we're back on the road to the Bay Area where all that Clinton-Obama advertising has some new company.

column2: the GOP is awarding delegates to the winner in each congressional district. So republican candidates are campaigning in heavily democratic areas like San Francisco because even a small number there could deliver a win.

LAWRENCE: This registered republican is voting for Mitt Romney.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I think Iraq is going to take care of itself with the surge. It's working. But I care about people who are going to actually create jobs. Keep taxes down so that companies can grow.
(END VIDEOTAPE)
LAWRENCE: Yes
column2: one thing about California
column3: a lot of the voters
column4: in fact perhaps half of the voters will vote by absentee ballots. A lot of us who live here
column5: our friends and our family
column6: have already voted. With that in mind
column7: two things to keep in mind today. Barack Obama's late surge and Mitt Romney's conservative challenge to John McCa"	0

column1: 433	"Remarks of Senator Barack Obama: The Past Versus the Future
Denver
column2: CO | January 30

column1: Thank you Caroline - for your introduction
column2: your support
column3: and your lifetime of service to a grateful nation. You continue to inspire Americans of all ages and walks of life.

column1: Let me also say a few words about another American who has called us to a common purpose. John Edwards has spent a lifetime fighting to give voice to the voiceless and hope to the struggling. At a time when our politics is too focused on who's up and who's down
column2: he made us focus on who matters - the New Orleans child without a home
column3: the West Virginia miner without a job
column4: the families who live in that other America that is not seen or heard or talked about in Washington. John and Elizabeth Edwards believe deeply that two Americans can become one. Their campaign may have ended
column5: but this cause lives on for all of us who believe that we can achieve one America.

column1: Seven months from now
column2: the Democratic Party will gather here in Denver to nominate our candidate for President of the United States.

column1: We will come together after a long and hard fought primary campaign - and that's a good thing. Because it is through campaigns that we hear directly from the American people
column2: set our common goals
column3: and debate our differences. It is through campaigns that we bring new people into the process; build new coalitions; and renew who we are and what we stand for as a Party.

column1: It is fitting that the journey leads to Denver - a city that is younger than the Democratic Party itself
column2: but filled with the promise that our Party has always fought for. This city
column3: built at the base of the Rocky Mountains
column4: stands as a monument to a uniquely American belief in things unseen. Here
column5: in Denver
column6: fur trappers and traders; gold rushers and ranchers; came in search of opportunity
column7: and made the future their own.

column1: The story of America leads west. It is a story of ideals that know no boundaries. It is a story of immigrants who set out from distant shores; pioneers who persevered; and people of all races
column2: religions
column3: and ethnic groups who put aside their doubts to seek a new frontier.

column1: My own family's journey moved west - from Kansas
column2: where my grandparents met and married
column3: and my mother was born; to the Pacific Coast after World War II; and then across an ocean to Hawaii. Their journey - like so many others - speaks to a simple truth written into the story of America. It's a truth at the foundation of the Democratic Party's purpose
column4: Denver's progress
column5: and our nation's promise: in America
column6: the future is what we decide it's going to be.

column1: As candidates
column2: we must give new meaning to that promise. And seven months from now
column3: one of us will stand before that convention hall
column4: and give voice to the hopes
column5: and dreams
column6: and determination of Americans all across our country. In six days
column7: you get to choose who will be that voice. You get to choose who will be able to build a new majority of not just Democrats - but Independents and Republicans - to win in November
column8: and transform our country. And if you put your trust in me
column9: I will stand up at that convention and say that our divisions are past
column10: our hope is the future
column11: and our time for change has come.

column1: Now there is one thing we know for certain about the election in November: the name George Bush will not be on the ballot. The name of my cousin - Dick Cheney - will not be on the ballot. But the choice before you is about what comes next. Because we need to do more than turn the page on the failed Bush-Cheney policies; we have to turn the page on the politics that helped make those policies possible.
Lobbyists setting an agenda in Washington that feeds the inequality
column2: insecurity
column3: and instability in our economy.

column1: Division and distraction that keeps us from coming together to deal with challenges like health care
column2: and clean energy
column3: and crumbling schools year after year after year.

column1: Cronyism that gave us Katrina instead of competent government. And secrecy that made torture permissible and illegal wiretaps possible.
It's a politics that uses 9/11 to scare up votes; and fear and falsehoods to lead us into a war in Iraq that should've never been authorized and should've never been waged.

Each candidate running for the Democratic nomination shares an abiding desire to end the disastrous policies of the current administration. But we must decide - in the debate that leads to Denver - just what kind of Party we want to be
column2: and what lessons we've learned from the bitter partisanship of the last two decades. We can be a Party that tries to beat the other side by practicing the same do-anything
column3: say-anything
column4: divisive politics that has stood in the way of progress; or we can be a Party that puts an end to it.

column1: I am running for President because I believe that we need fundamental change in America. Not just a change of Party in the White House
column2: but change in Washington that the American people can believe in - unity instead of division; hope instead of fear; a politics that leaves behind the fights of the past so that we can finally take hold of our future.

column1: We began this campaign one year ago on the steps of the old statehouse in Springfield. At the time
column2: we made a bet on the American people. That bet was simple - we weren't going to change anything by relying on the same Washington games; instead
column3: we were betting on the American people's hunger for change
column4: and your ability to make change happen from the bottom-up.

column1: And we are showing America what change looks like. From the snows of Iowa to the sunshine of South Carolina
column2: we have built a movement of young and old; rich and poor; black and white; Latino
column3: Asian and Native American. We've reached Americans of all political stripes who are more interested in turning the page than turning up the heat on our opponents. That's how Democrats will win in November and build a majority in Congress. Not by nominating a candidate who will unite the other party against us
column4: but by choosing one who can unite this country around a movement for change.

column1: If you choose change
column2: you will have a nominee who doesn't take a dime from Washington lobbyists and PACs. We don't need a candidate who agrees with Republicans that lobbyists are part of the system in Washington. They're part of the problem. And when I'm President
column3: their days of setting the agenda in Washington will be over.

column1: If you choose change
column2: you will have a nominee who doesn't just tell people what they want to hear. Poll-tested positions and calculated answers might be how Washington confronts challenges
column3: but it's not how you overcome them; it's not how you inspire our nation to come together behind a common purpose; and it's not what America needs right now.

column1: If you choose change
column2: you will have a nominee who isn't just playing on the same electoral map where half the country starts out against us
column3: because you will have a nominee who has already brought in more Independents and Republicans; young people and new voters; than we have seen in a generation.

column1: I know it is tempting - after another presidency by a man named George Bush - to simply turn back the clock
column2: and to build a bridge back to the 20th Century. There are those will tell us that our Party should nominate someone who is more practiced in the art of pursuing power; that's it's not yet our turn or our time. There was also a time when Caroline Kennedy's father was counseled by a former President to Ã¢ÂÂbe patient
column3: Ã¢ÂÂ and to step aside for Ã¢ÂÂsomeone with greater experience.Ã¢ÂÂ But John F. Kennedy responded by saying
column4: Ã¢ÂÂThe world is changing. The old ways will not doÃ¢ÂÂ¦It is time for a new generation of leadership.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: It is time for a new generation of leadership
column2: because the old politics just won't do. I am running for President - right now - because I have met Americans all across this country who cannot afford to wait another day for change. That is why the real choice in this campaign is not between regions or religions or genders. It's not about rich versus poor; young versus old; and it is not about black versus white.

column1: It is about the past versus the future. And when I am the nominee
column2: the Republicans won't be able to make this election about the past because you will have already chosen the future.

column1: It's time for new leadership for an economy where families are being forced to foreclose on their dreams
column2: and workers have seen their pensions disappear.

column1: In the short-term
column2: we need what I have consistently called for - a stimulus plan that gives the American people a tax rebate
column3: and that also extends relief to seniors and expands unemployment insurance. And in the long-term
column4: we need to put the American Dream on a firmer foundation. We're not going to offer the American people the choice they need by nominating a candidate who voted to put the banks and big business ahead of hard-working Americans. I've been fighting for working people my entire public life. And when I am President
column5: I'll make sure that CEOs can't dump your pension with one hand while they collect a bonus with the other. I'll pass bankruptcy laws that protect workers instead of banks. And I'll crack down on fraudulent mortgage lenders
column6: and credit card companies that change your rates to push you further into debt.

column1: It's time for new leadership for the Maytag worker who is now competing with his own teenage son for a $7 an-hour job at Walmart because the factory he gave his life to shut its doors.
We're not going to offer the American people the choice they need by nominating a candidate who argues year after year for trade that isn't fair
column2: but calls for a time-out on trade when they run for President. I will stop giving tax breaks to companies that ship our jobs overseas and start putting them in the pockets of working Americans. I will stop giving the wealthiest Americans tax cuts that they don't need and didn't ask for
column3: and restore fairness to our economy. I'll give a tax cut to working people; provide relief to homeowners; and eliminate the income tax for seniors making under $50
column4: 000 so they can retire with the dignity and security they have earned.

column1: It's time for new leadership for the woman I met who can't get Medicaid to cover the needs of her sick child.

She can't afford to wait another four years or another fifteen years to get health care because we've put forward a nominee who can't bring Democrats and Republicans together to get things done. I know that the reason Americans don't have health care isn't because no one is forcing them to buy it - it's because they can't afford it. That's why my plan cuts costs by up to $2500 for a typical family
column2: and makes health care available and affordable for every single American. That's the plan that I'll pass in my first term as President.

column1: It is time for new leadership for children going to overcrowded schools in East L.A.; for the teacher I met who is working at Dunkin Donuts to make ends meet; for the young people who are ready to go to college but can't afford it.
When I'm President
column2: we'll rally this country to the cause of world-class education. That means putting our kids on a pathway to success with universal
column3: quality
column4: affordable early childhood education. That means paying our teachers more
column5: and making sure they're not just teaching to the test - but teaching art and music and literature. That means giving our young people an annual $4
column6: 000 tax credit for college tuition if they serve their community; and that means expanding AmeriCorps to 250
column7: 000 slots
column8: and issuing a call to service for a new generation. But that also means calling on parents to do their part - to get off the couch
column9: turn off the television
column10: and read to our children. Because responsibility for education starts at home.

column1: It's time for new leadership so that my daughters and your children don't grow up in a century where our economy is weighed down by our addiction to oil; our foreign policy is held hostage to the whims of dictators; and our planet passes a moment of no return.
When I'm President
column2: we won't wait any longer to reduce emissions. When I called for higher fuel efficiency standards
column3: I didn't do it in front of an environmental group in California or in Boulder - that would have been the easy thing to do. I did it in front of the automakers in Detroit. Now it was pretty quiet - I didn't get a lot of applause. But we need leadership that tells the American people not just what they want to hear
column4: but what we need to know. That's what I'll do. We cannot wait to invest in the next generation of biofuels
column5: and wind and solar. If President Kennedy could send us to the moon in less than a decade - then we can meet this great challenge our generation. We can set the goal of an 80% reduction in global emissions by 2050
column6: and we can lead the world to confront the climate crisis.

column1: And it's time for new leadership for the woman who told me that she hasn't been able to breathe since the day her nephew left for Iraq
column2: and the soldier who doesn't know his own child because he's on his third or fourth tour of duty.

column1: I will end the mentality that says the only way for Democrats to look tough on national security is by talking
column2: acting and voting like George Bush Republicans. It's time to reject the counsel that says the American people would rather have someone who is strong and wrong than someone who is weak and right - it's time to say that we are the Party that is going to be strong and right.

column1: It's time for new leadership that understands that the way to win a debate with John McCain is not by nominating someone who agreed with him on voting for the war in Iraq; who agreed with him by voting to give George Bush the benefit of the doubt on Iran; who agrees with him in embracing the Bush-Cheney policy of not talking to leaders we don't like; and who actually differed with him by arguing for exceptions for torture before changing positions when the politics of the moment changed.
We need to offer the American people a clear contrast on national security
column2: and when I am the nominee of the Democratic Party
column3: that's exactly what I will do. Talking tough and tallying up your years in Washington is no substitute for judgment
column4: and courage
column5: and clear plans. It's not enough to say you'll be ready from Day One - you have to be right from Day One.

column1: I opposed this war in Iraq from the start
column2: and I have never
column3: ever wavered in that opposition. I warned about taking our eye off of Osama bin Laden
column4: and overstretching our troops and their families as we have seen in communities across this country like Fort Carson. And when I am President
column5: I will immediately begin to remove our troops
column6: I will finally put meaningful pressure on Iraq's leaders to reconcile
column7: and I will end this war. And I will do what we should have done back in 2002: increase our commitment to Afghanistan
column8: press Pakistan to take action against terror
column9: and finish the fight with al Qaeda.

column1: I will challenge the conventional thinking that says we can't conduct diplomacy with leaders we don't like. Strong countries and strong Presidents talk to their adversaries as well as their friends
column2: and that's what I'll do. And when I am President
column3: we will keep nuclear weapons from terrorists by securing all loose nuclear materials around the world during my first term in office. We will set a goal of a world without nuclear weapons
column4: and we will pursue it.

column1: It's time for new leadership that reaches out
column2: as President Kennedy did to my own father
column3: to people Ã¢ÂÂin the huts and villages across the globe struggling to break the bonds of mass misery.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: It's time to restore our moral leadership by rejecting torture without equivocation; by closing Guantanamo; by restoring habeas corpus; and by again being that light of justice to dissidents in prison camps around the globe. It's time for America to lead the world against the common threats of the 21st century - terrorism and nuclear weapons
column2: but also climate change and poverty; genocide and disease. I will send once more a message to those yearning faces beyond our shores that says
column3: Ã¢ÂÂYou matter to us. Your future is our future. And our moment is now.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: This is what the moment demands of us - to cast off our doubts; to reach once more for what America can be if we have the courage to make the future our own.
We've been warned
column2: in these last few weeks
column3: that this kind of change isn't possible. That we're peddling false hopes. That we need a reality check.

column1: And we've faced forces that are not the fault of any one campaign - forces that open American wounds. The politics that uses religion as a wedge
column2: and patriotism as a bludgeon. A politics that tells us what we have to think and even vote within the confines of the categories that supposedly define us. The assumption that young people are apathetic. The assumption that Republicans won't cross over. The assumption that the wealthy care nothing for the poor
column3: and that the poor don't vote. The assumption that African-Americans can't support the white candidate; whites can't support the African-American candidate; and blacks and Latinos can't come together.

column1: But our Party - the Democratic Party - has always been at its best when we rose above these divisions; when we called all Americans to a common purpose
column2: a higher purpose; when we stood up and said that we will write our own future
column3: and the future will be what we want it to be.

column1: We followed a King to the mountaintop
column2: and a Kennedy who called on us to reject the mindless menace of violence.

column1: We're the party of a young President who asked what we could do for our country
column2: and who put us on a path to the moon.

column1: We're the party of a man who overcame his own disability; who told us that the only thing we had to fear was fear itself; and who faced down fascism and liberated a continent from tyranny.
We're the party of Jackson
column2: who took back the White House for the people of this country.

column1: And we're the party of Jefferson
column2: who wrote the words that we are still trying to heed - that all of us are created equal - and who sent us West to blaze new trails
column3: to make new discoveries
column4: and to realize the promise of our highest ideals.

column1: That is who we are. That is the Party that we need to be
column2: and can be
column3: if we cast off our doubts
column4: and leave behind our fears
column5: and choose the America that we know is possible. Because there is a moment in the life of every generation
column6: if it is to make its mark on history
column7: when its spirit has to come through
column8: when it must choose the future over the past
column9: when it must make its own change from the bottom up.

column1: This is our moment. This is our message - the same message we had when we were up
column2: and when we were down. The same message that we will carry all the way to the convention. And in seven months time - right here in Denver - we can realize this promise; we can claim this legacy; we can choose new leadership for America. Because there is nothing we cannot do if the American people decide it is time."	0

column1: 434	"BREAKING: Malia Obama SUSPENDED After Racist Anti-White Attack Goes Viral
A few days ago
column2: a student at Harvard leaked the contents of Malia ObamaÃ¢ÂÂs speech final. The topic? A World Without Whites. And now it may get Malia Obama suspended.

column1: Ã¢ÂÂWhite people are so 1960Ã¢ÂÂs. Sometimes the only thing that keeps me going is the fact that they will be blended out by the time I am 30
column2: Ã¢ÂÂ a recording of ObamaÃ¢ÂÂs speech shared on Snapchat said. Ã¢ÂÂImagine a world without white people.Ã¢ÂÂ Obama was of course referring to the scientific belief that if whites continue to breed at low rates in America while others races continue to breed at current rates
column3: white babies will be virtually nonexistent in our country by 2038.

column1: Ã¢ÂÂThis sort of attack against any race is uncalled for
column2: Ã¢ÂÂ Harvard Dean Cain Markholder said in a statement Sunday. Ã¢ÂÂMs. Obama has been informed she is suspended pending an investigation into her statement.Ã¢ÂÂ But it gets worse for Obama Ã¢ÂÂ Markholder says that if a disciplinary board finds her guilty
column3: she will Ã¢ÂÂforfeit her grade for the examÃ¢ÂÂ which is worth 47% of her grade according to one of the students who shared video of her racist hate speech-filled attack on whites.

column1: The dean notes that punishment for racist attacks like this can lead to Ã¢ÂÂexpulsion

column1: 435	"Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (P.L. 111-148)

Overall approach to expanding access to coverage Require most U.S. citizens and legal residents to have health insurance. Create state-based American Health Benefit Exchanges through which individuals can purchase coverage
column2: with premium and cost-sharing credits available to individuals/families with income between 133-400% of the federal poverty level (the poverty level is $19
column3: 530 for a family of three in 2013) and create separate Exchanges through which small businesses can purchase coverage. Require employers to pay penalties for employees who receive tax credits for health insurance through an Exchange
column4: with exceptions for small employers. Impose new regulations on health plans in the Exchanges and in the individual and small group markets. Expand Medicaid to 133% of the federal poverty level.

column1: INDIVIDUAL MANDATE

Requirement to have coverage Require U.S. citizens and legal residents to have qualifying health coverage. Those without coverage pay a tax penalty of the greater of $695 per year up to a maximum of three times that amount ($2
column2: 085) per family or 2.5% of household income. The penalty will be phased-in according to the following schedule: $95 in 2014
column4: and $695 in 2016 for the flat fee or 1.0% of taxable income in 2014
column5: 2.0% of taxable income in 2015
column6: and 2.5% of taxable income in 2016. Beginning after 2016
column7: the penalty will be increased annually by the cost-of-living adjustment. Exemptions will be granted for financial hardship
column8: religious objections
column9: American Indians
column10: those without coverage for less than three months
column11: undocumented immigrants
column12: incarcerated individuals
column13: those for whom the lowest cost plan option exceeds 8% of an individualÃ¢ÂÂs income
column14: and those with incomes below the tax filing threshold (in 2009 the threshold for taxpayers under age 65 was $9
column15: 350 for singles and $18
column16: 700 for couples).

column5: 000 for each employee receiving a premium credit or $2
column6: 000 for each full-time employee
column7: excluding the first 30 employees from the assessment. (Effective January 1
column8: 2014) Ã¢ÂÂ¢ Exempt employers with up to 50 full-time employees from any of the above penalties.

column1: Other requirements Require employers with more than 200 employees to automatically enroll employees into health insurance plans offered by the employer. Employees may opt out of coverage.
EXPANSION OF PUBLIC PROGRAMS
Treatment of Medicaid Expand Medicaid to all non-Medicare eligible individuals under age 65 (children

All newly eligible adults will be guaranteed a benchmark benefit package that meets the essential health benefits available through the Exchanges. The Supreme Court ruling on the constitutionality of the ACA upheld the Medicaid expansion
column5: but limited the ability of HHS to enforce it
column6: thereby making the decision to expand Medicaid optional for states. To finance the coverage for the newly eligible (those who were not previously eligible for at least benchmark equivalent coverage
column7: those who were eligible for a capped program but were not enrolled
column8: or those who were enrolled in state-funded programs)

column10: 95% federal financing in 2017
column11: 94% federal financing in 2018
column12: 93% federal financing in 2019
column13: and 90% federal financing for 2020 and subsequent years. States that have already expanded eligibility to adults with incomes up to 100% FPL will receive a phased-in increase in the federal medical assistance percentage (FMAP) for non-pregnant childless adults so that by 2019 they receive the same federal financing as other states (93% in 2019 and 90% in 2020 and later). States have the option to expand Medicaid eligibility to childless adults beginning on April 1
