column1: Treatment of CHIP Require states to maintain current income eligibility levels for children in Medicaid and the ChildrenÃ¢ÂÂs Health Insurance Program (CHIP) until 2019 and extend funding for CHIP through 2015. CHIP benefit package and cost-sharing rules will continue as under current law. Provide states with the option to provide CHIP coverage to children of state employees who are eligible for health benefits if certain conditions are met. Beginning in 2015
column2: states will receive a 23 percentage point increase in the CHIP match rate up to a cap of 100%. CHIP-eligible children who are unable to enroll in the program due to enrollment caps will be eligible for tax credits in the state Exchanges.

column1: PREMIUM AND COST-SHARING SUBSIDIES TO INDIVIDUALS

Eligibility Limit availability of premium credits and cost-sharing subsidies through the Exchanges to U.S. citizens and legal immigrants who meet income limits. Employees who are offered coverage by an employer are not eligible for premium credits unless the employer plan does not have an actuarial value of at least 60% or if the employee share of the premium exceeds 9.5% of income. Legal immigrants who are barred from enrolling in Medicaid during their first five years in the U.S. will be eligible for premium credits.

Premium credits Provide refundable and advanceable premium credits to eligible individuals and families with incomes between 100-400% FPL to purchase insurance through the Exchanges. The premium credits will be tied to the second lowest cost silver plan in the area and will be set on a sliding scale such that the premium contributions are limited to the following percentages of income for specified income levels: Up to 133% FPL: 2% of income 133-150% FPL: 3 Ã¢ÂÂ 4% of income 150-200% FPL: 4 Ã¢ÂÂ 6.3% of income 200-250% FPL: 6.3 Ã¢ÂÂ 8.05% of income 250-300% FPL: 8.05 Ã¢ÂÂ 9.5% of income 300-400% FPL: 9.5% of income Increase the premium contributions for those receiving subsidies annually to reflect the excess of the premium growth over the rate of income growth for 2014-2018. Beginning in 2019
column2: further adjust the premium contributions to reflect the excess of premium growth over CPI if aggregate premiums and cost sharing subsidies exceed .504% of GDP.

column1: Provisions related to the premium and cost-sharing subsidies are effective January 1

Cost-sharing subsidies Provide cost-sharing subsidies to eligible individuals and families. The cost-sharing credits reduce the cost-sharing amounts and annual cost-sharing limits and have the effect of increasing the actuarial value of the basic benefit plan to the following percentages of the full value of the plan for the specified income level:
Verification Require verification of both income and citizenship status in determining eligibility for the federal premium credits.

Subsidies and abortion coverage Ensure that federal premium or cost-sharing subsidies are not used to purchase coverage for abortion if coverage extends beyond saving the life of the woman or cases of rape or incest (Hyde amendment). If an individual who receives federal assistance purchases coverage in a plan that chooses to cover abortion services beyond those for which federal funds are permitted
column2: those federal subsidy funds (for premiums or cost-sharing) must not be used for the purchase of the abortion coverage and must be segregated from private premium payments or state funds.

column1: Require Exchanges to submit financial reports to the Secretary and comply with oversight investigations including a GAO study on the operation and administration of Exchanges.

Basic health plan Permit states the option to create a Basic Health Plan for uninsured individuals with incomes between 133-200% FPL who would otherwise be eligible to receive premium subsidies in the Exchange. States opting to provide this coverage will contract with one or more standard plans to provide at least the essential health benefits and must ensure that eligible individuals do not pay more in premiums than they would have paid in the Exchange and that the cost-sharing requirements do not exceed those of the platinum plan for enrollees with income less than 150% FPL or the gold plan for all other enrollees. States will receive 95% of the funds that would have been paid as federal premium and cost-sharing subsidies for eligible individuals to establish the Basic Health Plan. Individuals with incomes between 133-200% FPL in states creating Basic Health Plans will not be eligible for subsidies in the Exchanges.
Abortion coverage Permit states to prohibit plans participating in the Exchange from providing coverage for abortions.

Require plans that choose to offer coverage for abortions beyond those for which federal funds are permitted (to save the life of the woman and in cases of rape or incest) in states that allow such coverage to create allocation accounts for segregating premium payments for coverage of abortion services from premium payments for coverage for all other services to ensure that no federal premium or cost-sharing subsidies are used to pay for the abortion coverage. Plans must also estimate the actuarial value of covering abortions by taking into account the cost of the abortion benefit (valued at no less than $1 per enrollee per month) and cannot take into account any savings that might be reaped as a result of the abortions. column1: The Brady Act mandated that everyone who wanted to buy a handgun had to wait five days while local law enforcement ran criminal background checks. (After 1998

column1: Ã¢ÂÂ¢ After some back and forth

column6: you probably also noticed thereÃ¢ÂÂs this pretty intense campaign going on right now. And the reason it is an intense campaign is because the choice that we face in November could not be bigger. ItÃ¢ÂÂs not just a choice between two candidates or two political parties. It is a choice between two fundamentally different visions about how we move this country forward. And the direction that we choose -- the direction you choose when you walk into that voting booth -- is going to have a direct impact not just on us
column7: it will have an impact on our kids and our grandkids for decades to come.

column1: Now
column2: four years ago
column3: we came together -- and it wasnÃ¢ÂÂt just Democrats
column4: we had independents and even some Republicans come together because we wanted to restore the basic bargain that made this country great
column5: that built the greatest middle class and the most prosperous economy in the history of the world. And itÃ¢ÂÂs a bargain that says very simply
column6: if you work hard
column7: your work will be rewarded. If you work hard
column8: you can get ahead. ItÃ¢ÂÂs a deal that says if you put in enough effort
column9: if you act responsibly
column10: you can find a job that pays the bills
column11: have a home you call your own. You can count on health care when you get sick. You can retire with dignity and respect. (Applause.) And most importantly
column12: you can provide your kids with the education and opportunity so that they can dream bigger than you ever dreamed and they can achieve things you couldn't even imagine.

column1: That's the American promise. That's the core of who we are as a people. And unfortunately
column2: we had gone through a decade where that dream felt like it was slipping away. Jobs had gotten shifted overseas. Incomes had gone down
column3: when you account inflation
column4: even though the cost of everything from health care to college had gone up. And it all culminated in the worst financial crisis since the Great Depression.

column1: So we knew restoring this dream
column2: reinstating this basic bargain was not going to be easy. And we understood it would take more than one year
column3: or one term
column4: or maybe even one President. And that was before the middle class got clobbered by this financial crisis. And a lot of our friends and neighbors lost their jobs
column5: lost their homes
column6: lost their savings -- and it made that dream seem even further out of reach.

column1: But here's the good news. The American people are tougher than tough times. (Applause.) Not only is there a fundamental goodness and decency to the American people
column2: but thereÃ¢ÂÂs also grit and resilience. And when we get knocked down
column3: we get back up. (Applause.)

column1: And so
column2: for the last three and a half years
column3: we've worked to make sure that we didnÃ¢ÂÂt slip into a Great Depression. And we created 4.5 million new jobs. (Applause.) We saved an auto industry on the brink of collapse. And although we are far away from where we need to be -- okay
column4: we'll be okay. I hear you. What will happen is that the medical services -- we've just got somebody who fainted. Which reminds me

column1: Now

column3: you know
column4: what hasnÃ¢ÂÂt changed as a result of this crisis is our character. (Applause.) What's made us great in the past is going to make us great in the future. (Applause.)

column1: We came together in 2008

column4: and everybody plays by the same set of rules. (Applause.) We're here to build an economy where hard work pays off
column5: so that no matter who you are or where you come from
column6: you can make it if you try. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what this campaign is about
column7: Colorado. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what the choice is in November. And that's why IÃ¢ÂÂm running for a second term as President of the United States of America. (Applause.)

column3: it was
column4: you know
column5: courteous. But we kind of tried to educateeach other

column1: WOODRUFF (on-screen): Still going to have a peaceful Christmasdinner together?
STROBEL (ph): As long as there's beer there

column1: WOODRUFF (voice-over): Late Saturday
column2: the governor issued astatement
column3: turning down a compromise offer from the unions. And sohere in Wisconsin

column5: for now.

column3: Wisconsin.

column1: 450	"We can all agree that if we want to bring down skyrocketing costs
column2: we'll need to modernize our system and invest in prevention. We can agree that if we want greater accountability and responsibility
column3: we have to ensure that people aren't overcharged for prescription drugs
column4: or discriminated against for pre-existing conditions -- and we need to eliminate fraud
column5: waste and abuse in government programs. I think most of us would agree that if we want to cover all Americans
column6: we can't make the mistake of trying to fix what isn't broken. So if somebody has insurance they like
column7: they should be able to keep that insurance. If they have a doctor that they like
column8: they should be able to keep their doctor. They should just pay less for the care that they receive.

column1: And finally
column2: we can all agree that if we want to translate these goals into policies
column3: we need a process that is as transparent and inclusive as possible. And that's why I've asked all of you -- representatives of organizations
column4: interests
column5: and parties from across the spectrum -- to join us here today. In fact
column6: this was the hottest ticket in town. (Laughter.) That's why we asked concerned citizens like the folks on this stage to organize open meetings across America where people could air their views. As Travis said
column7: more than 3
column8: 000 meetings were held in all 50 states and D.C.; more than 30
column9: 000 people attended. I thank them for their input and their ideas
column10: and look forward to reading the report that Travis has presented to me.

column1: In this effort
column2: every voice has to be heard. Every idea must be considered. Every option must be on the table. There should be no sacred cows. Each of us must accept that none of us will get everything that we want
column3: and that no proposal for reform will be perfect. If that's the measure
column4: we will never get anything done. But when it comes to addressing our health care challenge
column5: we can no longer let the perfect be the enemy of the essential. And I don't think anybody would argue that we are on a sustainable path when it comes to health care.

column1: Finally
column2: I want to be very clear at the outset that while everyone has a right to take part in this discussion
column3: nobody has the right to take it over and dominate. The status quo is the one option that's not on the table
column4: and those who seek to block any reform at all -- any reform at any costs will not prevail this time around.

column1: I didn't come here to Washington to work for those interests. I came here to work for the American people -- the folks I met on the campaign trail
column2: the people I hear from every single day in the White House. Folks who are working hard
column3: making all the right decisions
column4: but still face choices that no one in this country should have to make: how long to put off that doctor's appointment; whether to fill that prescription; when to give up and head to the emergency room because there are no other options."	0

column8: and initiative. Yet Romney explained to his patrons that he could not speak such harsh words about Obama in public
column9: lest he insult those independent voters who sided with Obama in 2008 and whom he desperately needs in this election. These were sentiments not to be shared with the voters; it was inside information
column10: available only to the select few who had paid for the privilege of experiencing the real Romney.

column3: Ã¢ÂÂ and that he would merely Ã¢ÂÂkick the ball down the field.Ã¢ÂÂ)

column1: 457	"On Sept. 28
column2: pastors from 20 states will give politically based sermons from the pulpit as part of a protest organized by the Alliance Defense Fund
column3: a conservative legal-advocacy group. The protest will challenge an Internal Revenue Code restriction that limits the political activities of charitable organizations Ã¢ÂÂ including churches and other religious groups Ã¢ÂÂ that are exempt from taxation. According to the Internal Revenue Code
column4: religious groups may lose their tax-exempt status if they officially endorse a political candidate. The ADF says that if its protest leads the Internal Revenue Service to penalize houses of worship for their pastorsÃ¢ÂÂ political advocacy
column5: ADF will bring a lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of these penalties.

column1: To discuss the ADF protest and IRS restrictions on the political activities of religious organizations
column2: the Pew Forum turns to church-state scholar Robert W. Tuttle.

column1: Featuring:
Robert W. Tuttle
column2: David R. and Sherry Kirschner Berz Research Professor of Law and Religion
column3: The George Washington University Law School

column1: Interviewer:
Jesse Merriam
column2: Research Associate
column3: Pew Forum on Religion & Public Life

column1: Question & Answer
Before 1954
column2: section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code permitted nonprofit organizations to endorse political candidates while remaining exempt from federal income tax. But in 1954
column3: the U.S. Congress amended this part of the code to say that a charitable organization loses its tax-exempt status if it intervenes in a political campaign. Why did Congress add this restriction?

column1: Many members of Congress
column2: including Lyndon B. Johnson
column3: a senator at the time
column4: voted for the amendment because they were concerned about nonprofit organizations funding their opponentsÃ¢ÂÂ political campaigns. But because there was little debate over the amendment or how it would influence churches
column5: we donÃ¢ÂÂt know precisely why Congress enacted the amendment.

column1: Notably
column2: the 1954 amendment is often misunderstood as limiting political advocacy
column3: but the ruleÃ¢ÂÂs actual purpose has to do with political contributions. Under the Internal Revenue Code
column4: there are many different kinds of tax-exempt organizations. For example
column5: section 527 of the code exempts all sorts of political organizations from federal income tax. But organizations that qualify as charitable groups under section 501(c)(3) are special because donors to these organizations may deduct their contributions from their own federal income taxes. So a primary purpose of the 1954 amendment was to prevent donors from deducting political contributions from their taxes.

column1: Why is the Alliance Defense Fund so interested in eliminating this restriction?
The ADF opposes the restriction because the rule requires churches to choose between actively participating in political campaigns
column2: on the one hand
column3: and accepting tax-deductible donations
column4: on the other hand. As a result
column5: if a church wanted to promote or oppose a particular political candidate
column6: the church would be required to create a separate organization to do so. Although this separate organization would be exempt from taxes
column7: contributors could not take a tax deduction for their donations to this organization.

column1: The ADF believes that this restriction takes political activity out of the heart of a congregationÃ¢ÂÂs life. For example
column2: a congregation that wanted to retain its tax exemption under section 501(c)(3) could not include political activity in its worship service unless the worship service was financed by a separate organization. Moreover
column3: ADF believes that because IRS officials must examine the content of sermons or other religious messages to determine whether a church has improperly engaged in political advocacy
column4: IRS enforcement of the rule entangles the government in the operation of religious organizations.

column1: If ADFÃ¢ÂÂs protest leads to a constitutional challenge in court
column2: what arguments might ADF make?

column1: The ADF would almost certainly argue that the 1954 amendment violates the First AmendmentÃ¢ÂÂs Free Exercise Clause
column2: which prohibits the government from regulating religious organizations more strictly than their secular counterparts. Similarly
column3: ADF will likely argue that the amendment violates the Religious Freedom Restoration Act
column4: a 1993 federal statute that prohibits the federal government from imposing a Ã¢ÂÂsubstantial burdenÃ¢ÂÂ on a religious organization unless the government demonstrates that it must impose that burden to achieve a Ã¢ÂÂcompelling government interest.Ã¢ÂÂ The ADF will also likely argue that the restriction violates the First AmendmentÃ¢ÂÂs Free Speech Clause
column5: which prohibits the government from regulating speech on the basis of its content. Finally
column6: ADF might also claim that IRS enforcement of the 1954 amendment violates the First AmendmentÃ¢ÂÂs Establishment Clause by requiring the IRS to scrutinize sermons or other religious messages
column7: thus excessively entangling government and religion.

column1: How might the government defend the 1954 amendment?

The government will likely defend the 1954 amendment by arguing that the rule does not violate congregationsÃ¢ÂÂ rights under the Free Exercise Clause or RFRA because the restriction treats religious organizations just like other charitable and educational organizations. Moreover
column2: the government would say
column3: the restriction does not bar congregations from participating in campaigns; it only prohibits donors from making tax-deductible political contributions. Likewise
column4: the government will likely argue
column5: the restriction does not violate the Free Speech Clause because the restriction does not prohibit the congregations from making political statements; it only bars them from using tax-deductible donations to do so. Finally
column6: in response to ADFÃ¢ÂÂs Establishment Clause argument
column7: the government will likely argue that there is no excessive entanglement of government and religion because the IRS does not need to evaluate a sermonÃ¢ÂÂs theological merit to determine whether the sermon promotes a politician.

column1: How do you think a court might evaluate these arguments?

ItÃ¢ÂÂs always difficult to predict how a court might decide a hypothetical case because a courtÃ¢ÂÂs decision often turns on a caseÃ¢ÂÂs particular facts. But past decisions give us a pretty good basis for guessing that a court would uphold the constitutionality of the 1954 amendmentÃ¢ÂÂs application to religious organizations.
The most relevant case on this issue is Branch Ministries v. Rossotti (2000)
column2: a case in which the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit upheld the 1954 amendmentÃ¢ÂÂs constitutionality. That case arose after a congregation advocated for a presidential candidate
column3: prompting the IRS to revoke the congregationÃ¢ÂÂs 501(c)(3) status. The congregation claimed that this revocation violated the Free Exercise and Free Speech clauses. But the D.C. Circuit Court rejected both of these arguments on the ground that the congregation was still free to engage in political speech and activities.

column1: The D.C. Circuit CourtÃ¢ÂÂs reasoning in this case relied heavily on two U.S. Supreme Court decisions
column2: Regan v. Taxation with Representation (1983) and Jimmy Swaggart Ministries v. Board of Equalization (1990). In Regan
column3: the high court held that 501(c)(3) status provides a monetary benefit to certain tax-exempt organizations because it allows their donors to take a tax deduction for contributions. Therefore
column4: the court concluded
column5: the 1954 amendment does not violate the Free Speech Clause because the amendment merely withholds a speech subsidy rather than restricts speech.

column1: Similarly
column2: in the Jimmy Swaggart Ministries case
column3: the Supreme Court held that a tax imposed equally on all organizations does not violate the Free Exercise Clause. The court held that although the tax may increase the cost of religious activity
column4: the tax does not impose a Ã¢ÂÂsubstantial burdenÃ¢ÂÂ on religious exercise because it does not prevent religious organizations from engaging in religious activity.

column1: If ADF challenged the 1954 amendmentÃ¢ÂÂs application to religious organizations
column2: I think it is very likely that a court would agree with the Branch Ministries decision and reject the challenge. In the years since the Regan and Jimmy Swaggart Ministries cases
column3: there have been a number of important changes in free exercise and free speech law
column4: but those changes have only reinforced these decisions.

column1: If the 1954 amendment was lifted for religious organizations but not for other charitable organizations
column2: would that raise a problem under the First AmendmentÃ¢ÂÂs Establishment Clause
column3: which generally prohibits the government from favoring religion over nonreligion?

column1: This is an even more difficult and complicated question than the previous one
column2: and I could see a court going either way. On the one hand
column3: courts usually uphold legislative efforts to relieve burdens on religious activity
column4: even if those burdens are not so Ã¢ÂÂsubstantialÃ¢ÂÂ as to require an exemption under RFRA. So if Congress lifted the 1954 amendment
column5: courts might be inclined to defer to the legislative judgment that the amendment should not apply to religious organizations.

column1: On the other hand
column2: courts might be more skeptical of such a religion-specific exemption from the 1954 amendment because this exemption would potentially provide religious organizations with a very significant benefit not extended to other charitable organizations. Indeed
column3: if the 1954 amendment applied to all 501(c)(3) organizations except religious ones
column4: those who contribute to congregations engaged in political activity would be allowed to take an income tax deduction for their contributions Ã¢ÂÂ thus offsetting some of the actual cost of the donation Ã¢ÂÂ while contributors to other political organizations would not be allowed to deduct their contributions. In other words
column5: the government would effectively subsidize the political activities of congregations.

column1: Such a subsidy raises serious questions under the Establishment Clause. In Texas Monthly v. Bullock (1989)
column2: the Supreme Court held that a Texas law that exempted religious publications but not other publications from sales taxes violated the Establishment Clause because the exemption effectively subsidized religious publications. The court explained that although the government may alleviate special burdens on religious activity
column3: the sales tax did not present such a special burden because it applied equally to both religious and nonreligious publications.

column1: So the Texas Monthly decision strongly suggests that lifting the 1954 amendment only for religious organizations would violate the Establishment Clause. But that doesnÃ¢ÂÂt mean that the present Supreme Court would definitely find a constitutional violation if Congress lifted the restriction only for religious organizations. Indeed
column2: because the present court has a much narrower view of the Establishment Clause than the court that decided Texas Monthly
column3: the present court might be willing to overrule the Texas Monthly decision. The ADF is no doubt hoping that this will be the case. As I said
column4: itÃ¢ÂÂs very difficult to guess how a court would decide this issue."	0

column1: 458	"The research section of the USDA studies everything from nutrition to climate change
column2: and according to the 2008 Farm Bill the Ã¢ÂÂchief scientistÃ¢ÂÂ is supposed to be the leader Ã¢ÂÂamong distinguished scientists with specialized or significant experience in agricultural research
column3: education and economics.Ã¢ÂÂ President Donald TrumpÃ¢ÂÂs pick
column4: Sam Clovis

column6: he barely published any academic work. Clovis had made a reputation for himself as a conservative talk radio show in Iowa and an avid Trump supporter.

column6: he said that he was Ã¢ÂÂgladÃ¢ÂÂ to be working in the Trump administration
column7: but that he was
column8: at the same time
column9: Ã¢ÂÂdisappointedÃ¢ÂÂ as to where he was assigned. Ã¢ÂÂWhile I can certainly appreciate President TrumpÃ¢ÂÂs reasons for placing me at my current position

column13: theyÃ¢ÂÂre just wasting their time.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: Ã¢ÂÂWhen I get back home from work Ã¢ÂÂ believe me Ã¢ÂÂ I thank God every single day that he had the mercy not to make me a scientist as well
column2: Ã¢ÂÂ Clovis continued. Ã¢ÂÂIÃ¢ÂÂm proud IÃ¢ÂÂm not one of them because they believe in things like evolution and the like. They have no fear from God

column4: taste
column5: smell
column6: touch or hear. If you ask me
column7: thatÃ¢ÂÂs a pretty limited way for one to live their life. And you want to know what the irony is? TheyÃ¢ÂÂre the ones who keep calling us traditional and conservative. They
column8: who refuse to believe God made man because they found some sort of so-called evidence that man derived from monkeys or whatever. TheyÃ¢ÂÂre so narrow-minded that they canÃ¢ÂÂt except that weÃ¢ÂÂre different and then they go around calling us the conservatives. ItÃ¢ÂÂs funny when you really think about it.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: Ã¢ÂÂThatÃ¢ÂÂs why IÃ¢ÂÂm happy IÃ¢ÂÂm not one of them. At the end of the day
column2: scientists are nothing more than a bunch of dumb
column3: regular people with limited vision who think dinosaurs actually existed and the earth is somehow getting warmer. They donÃ¢ÂÂt even consider the fact that thereÃ¢ÂÂs more to us
column4: to our species than just the physical and the tangible. ItÃ¢ÂÂs as funny as it is pitiful
column5: Ã¢ÂÂ he said. When asked why he continues to work as president TrumpÃ¢ÂÂs pick for top scientist if thatÃ¢ÂÂs how he feels about it
column6: he replied
column7: Ã¢ÂÂWell
column8: just because youÃ¢ÂÂre a member of the Trump administration doesnÃ¢ÂÂt mean you donÃ¢ÂÂt have to pay the bills. That used to work for members of the Obama administration
column9: if I remember correctly. Not now
column10: Ã¢ÂÂ Clovis concluded.

column1: 460	"It is for that reason that I rise today
column2: to talk about the truth
column3: and its relationship to democracy. For without truth
column4: and a principled fidelity to truth and to shared facts
column5: Mr. President
column6: our democracy will not last.

column1: 2017 was a year which saw the truth Ã¢ÂÂ objective
column2: empirical
column3: evidence-based truth -- more battered and abused than any other in the history of our country
column4: at the hands of the most powerful figure in our government. It was a year which saw the White House enshrine Ã¢ÂÂalternative factsÃ¢ÂÂ into the American lexicon
column5: as justification for what used to be known simply as good old-fashioned falsehoods. It was the year in which an unrelenting daily assault on the constitutionally-protected free press was launched by that same White House
column6: an assault that is as unprecedented as it is unwarranted. Ã¢ÂÂThe enemy of the people
column7: Ã¢ÂÂ was what the president of the United States called the free press in 2017.

column1: Mr. President
column2: it is a testament to the condition of our democracy that our own president uses words infamously spoken by Josef Stalin to describe his enemies. It bears noting that so fraught with malice was the phrase Ã¢ÂÂenemy of the people
column3: Ã¢ÂÂ that even Nikita Khrushchev forbade its use
column4: telling the Soviet Communist Party that the phrase had been introduced by Stalin for the purpose of Ã¢ÂÂannihilating such individualsÃ¢ÂÂ who disagreed with the supreme leader.

column1: This alone should be a source of great shame for us in this body
column2: especially for those of us in the presidentÃ¢ÂÂs party. For they are shameful
column3: repulsive statements. And
column4: of course
column5: the president has it precisely backward Ã¢ÂÂ despotism is the enemy of the people. The free press is the despotÃ¢ÂÂs enemy
column6: which makes the free press the guardian of democracy. When a figure in power reflexively calls any press that doesnÃ¢ÂÂt suit him Ã¢ÂÂfake news
column7: Ã¢ÂÂ it is that person who should be the figure of suspicion
column8: not the press.

column1: I dare say that anyone who has the privilege and awesome responsibility to serve in this chamber knows that these reflexive slurs of Ã¢ÂÂfake newsÃ¢ÂÂ are dubious
column2: at best. Those of us who travel overseas
column3: especially to war zones and other troubled areas around the globe
column4: encounter members of U.S. based media who risk their lives
column5: and sometimes lose their lives
column6: reporting on the truth. To dismiss their work as fake news is an affront to their commitment and their sacrifice.

column1: According to the International Federation of Journalists
column2: 80 journalists were killed in 2017
column3: and a new report from the Committee to Protect Journalists documents that the number of journalists imprisoned around the world has reached 262
column4: which is a new record. This total includes 21 reporters who are being held on Ã¢ÂÂfalse newsÃ¢ÂÂ charges.

column1: Mr. President
column2: so powerful is the presidency that the damage done by the sustained attack on the truth will not be confined to the presidentÃ¢ÂÂs time in office. Here in America
column3: we do not pay obeisance to the powerful Ã¢ÂÂ in fact
column4: we question the powerful most ardently Ã¢ÂÂ to do so is our birthright and a requirement of our citizenship -- and so
column5: we know well that no matter how powerful
column6: no president will ever have dominion over objective reality.

column1: No politician will ever get to tell us what the truth is and is not. And anyone who presumes to try to attack or manipulate the truth to his own purposes should be made to realize the mistake and be held to account. That is our job here. And that is just as Madison
column2: Hamilton
column3: and Jay would have it.

column1: Of course
column2: a major difference between politicians and the free press is that the press usually corrects itself when it gets something wrong. Politicians donÃ¢ÂÂt.

column1: No longer can we compound attacks on truth with our silent acquiescence. No longer can we turn a blind eye or a deaf ear to these assaults on our institutions. And Mr. President
column2: an American president who cannot take criticism Ã¢ÂÂ who must constantly deflect and distort and distract Ã¢ÂÂ who must find someone else to blame -- is charting a very dangerous path. And a Congress that fails to act as a check on the president adds to the danger.

column1: Now
column2: we are told via twitter that today the president intends to announce his choice for the Ã¢ÂÂmost corrupt and dishonestÃ¢ÂÂ media awards. It beggars belief that an American president would engage in such a spectacle. But here we are.

column1: And so
column2: 2018 must be the year in which the truth takes a stand against power that would weaken it. In this effort
column3: the choice is quite simple. And in this effort
column4: the truth needs as many allies as possible. Together
column5: my colleagues
column6: we are powerful. Together
column7: we have it within us to turn back these attacks
column8: right these wrongs
column9: repair this damage
column10: restore reverence for our institutions
column11: and prevent further moral vandalism.

column1: Together
column2: united in the purpose to do our jobs under the Constitution
column3: without regard to party or party loyalty
column4: let us resolve to be allies of the truth -- and not partners in its destruction.

column1: It is not my purpose here to inventory all of the official untruths of the past year. But a brief survey is in order. Some untruths are trivial Ã¢ÂÂ such as the bizarre contention regarding the crowd size at last yearÃ¢ÂÂs inaugural.

But many untruths are not at all trivial Ã¢ÂÂ such as the seminal untruth of the presidentÃ¢ÂÂs political career - the oft-repeated conspiracy about the birthplace of President Obama. Also not trivial are the equally pernicious fantasies about rigged elections and massive voter fraud
column2: which are as destructive as they are inaccurate Ã¢ÂÂ to the effort to undermine confidence in the federal courts
column3: federal law enforcement
column4: the intelligence community and the free press
column5: to perhaps the most vexing untruth of all Ã¢ÂÂ the supposed Ã¢ÂÂhoaxÃ¢ÂÂ at the heart of special counsel Robert MuellerÃ¢ÂÂs Russia investigation.

column1: To be very clear
column2: to call the Russia matter a Ã¢ÂÂhoaxÃ¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ as the president has many times Ã¢ÂÂ is a falsehood. We know that the attacks orchestrated by the Russian government during the election were real and constitute a grave threat to both American sovereignty and to our national security. It is in the interest of every American to get to the bottom of this matter
column3: wherever the investigation leads.

column1: Ignoring or denying the truth about hostile Russian intentions toward the United States leaves us vulnerable to further attacks. We are told by our intelligence agencies that those attacks are ongoing
column2: yet it has recently been reported that there has not been a single cabinet-level meeting regarding Russian interference and how to defend America against these attacks. Not one. What might seem like a casual and routine untruth Ã¢ÂÂ so casual and routine that it has by now become the white noise of Washington - is in fact a serious lapse in the defense of our country.

column1: Mr. President
column2: let us be clear. The impulses underlying the dissemination of such untruths are not benign. They have the effect of eroding trust in our vital institutions and conditioning the public to no longer trust them. The destructive effect of this kind of behavior on our democracy cannot be overstated.

column1: Mr. President
column2: every word that a president utters projects American values around the world. The values of free expression and a reverence for the free press have been our global hallmark
column3: for it is our ability to freely air the truth that keeps our government honest and keeps a people free. Between the mighty and the modest
column4: truth is the great leveler. And so
column5: respect for freedom of the press has always been one of our most important exports.

column1: But a recent report published in our free press should raise an alarm. Reading from the story:
Ã¢ÂÂIn FebruaryÃ¢ÂÂ¦Syrian President Bashar Assad brushed off an Amnesty International report that some 13
column2: 000 people had been killed at one of his military prisons by saying
column3: Ã¢ÂÂYou can forge anything these days
column4: we are living in a fake news era.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: In the Philippines
column2: President Rodrigo Duterte has complained of being Ã¢ÂÂdemonizedÃ¢ÂÂ by Ã¢ÂÂfake news.Ã¢ÂÂ Last month
column3: the report continues
column4: with our President
column5: quote Ã¢ÂÂlaughing by his sideÃ¢ÂÂ Duterte called reporters Ã¢ÂÂspies.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: In July
column2: Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro complained to the Russian propaganda outlet
column3: that the world media had Ã¢ÂÂspread lots of false versions
column4: lots of liesÃ¢ÂÂ about his country
column5: adding
column6: Ã¢ÂÂThis is what we call Ã¢ÂÂfake newsÃ¢ÂÂ today
column7: isnÃ¢ÂÂt it?Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: There are more:
Ã¢ÂÂA state official in Myanmar recently said
column2: Ã¢ÂÂThere is no such thing as Rohingya. It is fake news
column3: Ã¢ÂÂ referring to the persecuted ethnic group.

column1: Leaders in Singapore
column2: a country known for restricting free speech
column3: have promised Ã¢ÂÂfake newsÃ¢ÂÂ legislation in the new year.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: And on and on. This feedback loop is disgraceful
column2: Mr. President. Not only has the past year seen an American president borrow despotic language to refer to the free press
column3: but it seems he has in turn inspired dictators and authoritarians with his own language. This is reprehensible.

column1: We are not in a Ã¢ÂÂfake newsÃ¢ÂÂ era
column2: as Bashar Assad says. We are
column3: rather
column4: in an era in which the authoritarian impulse is reasserting itself
column5: to challenge free people and free societies
column6: everywhere.

column1: In our own country
column2: from the trivial to the truly dangerous
column3: it is the range and regularity of the untruths we see that should be cause for profound alarm
column4: and spur to action. Add to that the by-now predictable habit of calling true things false
column5: and false things true
column6: and we have a recipe for disaster. As George Orwell warned
column7: Ã¢ÂÂThe further a society drifts from the truth
column8: the more it will hate those who speak it.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: Any of us who have spent time in public life have endured news coverage we felt was jaded or unfair. But in our positions
column2: to employ even idle threats to use laws or regulations to stifle criticism is corrosive to our democratic institutions. Simply put: it is the pressÃ¢ÂÂs obligation to uncover the truth about power. It is the peopleÃ¢ÂÂs right to criticize their government. And it is our job to take it.

column1: What is the goal of laying siege to the truth? President John F. Kennedy
column2: in a stirring speech on the 20th anniversary of the Voice of America
column3: was eloquent in answer to that question:

column1: Ã¢ÂÂWe are not afraid to entrust the American people with unpleasant facts
column2: foreign ideas
column3: alien philosophies
column4: and competitive values. For a nation that is afraid to let its people judge the truth and falsehood in an open market is a nation that is afraid of its people.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: Mr. President
column2: the question of why the truth is now under such assault may well be for historians to determine. But for those who cherish American constitutional democracy
column3: what matters is the effect on America and her people and her standing in an increasingly unstable world -- made all the more unstable by these very fabrications. What matters is the daily disassembling of our democratic institutions.

column1: We are a mature democracy Ã¢ÂÂ it is well past time that we stop excusing or ignoring Ã¢ÂÂ or worse
column2: endorsing -- these attacks on the truth. For if we compromise the truth for the sake of our politics
column3: we are lost.

column1: I sincerely thank my colleagues for their indulgence today. I will close by borrowing the words of an early adherent to my faith that I find has special resonance at this moment. His name was John Jacques
column2: and as a young missionary in England he contemplated the question: Ã¢ÂÂWhat is truth?Ã¢ÂÂ His search was expressed in poetry and ultimately in a hymn that I grew up with
column3: titled Ã¢ÂÂOh Say
column4: What is Truth.Ã¢ÂÂ It ends as follows:

column1: Ã¢ÂÂThen say
column2: what is truth? Ã¢ÂÂTis the last and the first

column1: For the limits of time it steps oÃ¢ÂÂer.
Tho the heavens depart and the earthÃ¢ÂÂs fountains burst.
Truth
column2: the sum of existence
column3: will weather the worst

column1: EternalÃ¢ÂÂ¦ unchangedÃ¢ÂÂ¦ evermore.Ã¢ÂÂ
Thank you
column2: Mr. President. I yield the floor.

461	Congressional Quarterly has studied the voting behavior of members of Congress since 1953 to assess how often lawmakers stick with members of their own caucus on votes when the two parties divide and how often they back the president on votes where he has a clear position. With Congress out of town until after the national conventions
column2: CQ's editors are digging into their votes database to compile expanded vote analysis packages for CQ.com.

column1: New! Partisanship and Presidential Support in the Bush Era

CQ has completed a study of all roll-call votes during the seven-and-a-half years of President Bush's two terms Ã¢ÂÂ up to Congress' August recess. It is a first-ever look at the way lawmakers voted over an entire presidency. It underscores the high level of Capitol Hill partisanship that has been a hallmark of the period
column2: and shows that while Republican support for President Bush was quite high
column3: Democratic support was almost nonexistent in the House and very limited in the Senate.

column1: The searchable table shows both party unity and presidential support scores over the entire Bush presidency for individual lawmakers who are currently serving in the 110th Congress. It also flags the races CQ Politics has determined will be competitive on Election Day.
How CQ Calculated the Bush Administration Scores | Previous CQ Weekly Coverage: Moderates Come Front and Center (July 28)"	0

74-year-old Sir Christopher Meyer has been hospitalized with his injuries after he was set upon by a mob of thugs in London at around 3 pm local time.
Sir Meyer
column2: who is the former UK Ambassador to the United States
column3: was targetted after he publically expressed his support for Donald Trump's visit.

column2: a burst lip and a possible broken nose.

column2: she continues.

He doesnÃ¢ÂÂt remember anything.

Ã¢ÂÂHe is opinionated

column1: Daily Mail reports: Cambridge-educated Sir Christopher worked as press secretary for former chancellor Geoffrey Howe and John Major before being appointed US ambassador.
He spent six years in Washington
column2: from 1997 to 2003
column3: becoming the longest-serving holder of his office since 1945.

column1: As ambassador
column2: he welcomed around 35
column3: 000 guests to his home a year and was made Knight Commander of the Order of St Michael and St George.

column1: After retiring
column2: he became chairman of the Press Complaints Commission
column3: the former newspaper regulatory body.

column1: He is a prolific tweeter
column2: who regularly comments on politics and foreign affairs.

column1: The former diplomat has called for Britain to engage with President Trump ahead of his visit today.
He has been married to Catherine for more than 20 years.
Sir Christopher's attack comes as London's crime rate has soared.
Since the start of the year
column2: more than 80 murder investigations have been launched in the capital.

column1: Forces in England and Wales logged 5.3million crimes in the year to September 2017
column2: 14 percent up on the previous 12 months.

column1: A statement from the British Transport Police (BTP) said:
Officers were called to Victoria London Underground Station at 2.45pm yesterday (11 July)

column1: A 16-year-old boy from Hillingdon and a 15-year-old girl from Croydon were both arrested on suspicion of assault occasioning grievous bodily harm.
They have been released under investigation while inquiries into the incident continue.
A man in his seventies was taken to hospital
column2: though his injuries are not believed to be life-threatening or changing.""

Our message is simple: if you wish to protest peacefully

column1: 464	"The shooting of 18-year-old Michael Brown is an awful tragedy that continues to send shockwaves through the community of Ferguson
column2: Missouri and across the nation.

column1: If I had been told to get out of the street as a teenager
column2: there would have been a distinct possibility that I might have smarted off. But
column3: I wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt have expected to be shot.

column1: The outrage in Ferguson is understandableÃ¢ÂÂthough there is never an excuse for rioting or looting. There is a legitimate role for the police to keep the peace
column2: but there should be a difference between a police response and a military response.

column1: The images and scenes we continue to see in Ferguson resemble war more than traditional police action.
Glenn Reynolds
column2: in Popular Mechanics
column3: recognized the increasing militarization of the police five years ago. In 2009 he wrote:

column1: Soldiers and police are supposed to be different. Ã¢ÂÂ¦ Police look inward. TheyÃ¢ÂÂre supposed to protect their fellow citizens from criminals
column2: and to maintain order with a minimum of force. ItÃ¢ÂÂs the difference between Audie Murphy and Andy Griffith. But nowadays
column3: police are looking
column4: and acting
column5: more like soldiers than cops
column6: with bad consequences. And those who suffer the consequences are usually innocent civilians.

column1: The Cato InstituteÃ¢ÂÂs Walter Olson observed this week how the rising militarization of law enforcement is currently playing out in Ferguson:
Why armored vehicles in a Midwestern inner suburb? Why would cops wear camouflage gear against a terrain patterned by convenience stores and beauty parlors? Why are the authorities in Ferguson
column2: Mo. so given to quasi-martial crowd control methods (such as bans on walking on the street) and
column3: per the reporting of Riverfront Times
column4: the firing of tear gas at people in their own yards? (Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂThis my property!Ã¢ÂÂ he shouted
column5: prompting police to fire a tear gas canister directly at his face.Ã¢ÂÂ) Why would someone identifying himself as an 82nd Airborne Army veteran
column6: observing the Ferguson police scene
column7: comment that Ã¢ÂÂWe rolled lighter than that in an actual warzoneÃ¢ÂÂ?

column1: Olson added
column2: Ã¢ÂÂthe dominant visual aspect of the story
column3: however
column4: has been the sight of overpowering police forces confronting unarmed protesters who are seen waving signs or just their hands.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: How did this happen?
Most police officers are good cops and good people. It is an unquestionably difficult job
column2: especially in the current circumstances.

column1: There is a systemic problem with todayÃ¢ÂÂs law enforcement.
Not surprisingly
column2: big government has been at the heart of the problem. Washington has incentivized the militarization of local police precincts by using federal dollars to help municipal governments build what are essentially small armiesÃ¢ÂÂwhere police departments compete to acquire military gear that goes far beyond what most of Americans think of as law enforcement.

column1: This is usually done in the name of fighting the war on drugs or terrorism. The Heritage FoundationÃ¢ÂÂs Evan Bernick wrote in 2013 that
column2: Ã¢ÂÂthe Department of Homeland Security has handed out anti-terrorism grants to cities and towns across the country
column3: enabling them to buy armored vehicles
column4: guns
column5: armor
column6: aircraft
column7: and other equipment.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: Bernick continued
column2: Ã¢ÂÂfederal agencies of all stripes
column3: as well as local police departments in towns with populations less than 14
column5: come equipped with SWAT teams and heavy artillery.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: Bernick noted the cartoonish imbalance between the equipment some police departments possess and the constituents they serve
column2: Ã¢ÂÂtoday
column3: Bossier Parish
column4: Louisiana
column5: has a .50 caliber gun mounted on an armored vehicle. The Pentagon gives away millions of pieces of military equipment to police departments across the countryÃ¢ÂÂtanks included.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: When you couple this militarization of law enforcement with an erosion of civil liberties and due process that allows the police to become judge and juryÃ¢ÂÂnational security letters
column2: no-knock searches
column3: broad general warrants
column4: pre-conviction forfeitureÃ¢ÂÂwe begin to have a very serious problem on our hands.

column1: Given these developments
column2: it is almost impossible for many Americans not to feel like their government is targeting them. Given the racial disparities in our criminal justice system
column3: it is impossible for African-Americans not to feel like their government is particularly targeting them.

column1: This is part of the anguish we are seeing in the tragic events outside of St. Louis
column2: Missouri. It is what the citizens of Ferguson feel when there is an unfortunate and heartbreaking shooting like the incident with Michael Brown.

column1: Anyone who thinks that race does not still
column2: even if inadvertently
column3: skew the application of criminal justice in this country is just not paying close enough attention. Our prisons are full of black and brown men and women who are serving inappropriately long and harsh sentences for non-violent mistakes in their youth.

column1: The militarization of our law enforcement is due to an unprecedented expansion of government power in this realm. It is one thing for federal officials to work in conjunction with local authorities to reduce or solve crime. It is quite another for them to subsidize it.
Americans must never sacrifice their liberty for an illusive and dangerous
column2: or false
column3: security. This has been a cause I have championed for years
column4: and one that is at a near-crisis point in our country.

column1: Let us continue to pray for Michael BrownÃ¢ÂÂs family
column2: the people of Ferguson
column3: police
column4: and citizens alike.

column1: Paul is the junior U.S. Senator for Kentucky.
Contact us at letters@time.com."	0

column1: 469	"Good afternoon
column2: Phoenix! IÃ¢ÂÂm so glad to be here with you all.

column1: One of the core values of our campaign is that weÃ¢ÂÂre Ã¢ÂÂstronger together.Ã¢ÂÂ That means we know that the only way to change this country for the better is by working with each other. So itÃ¢ÂÂs important to us to communicate with as many people as possible Ã¢ÂÂ and to listen to as many people as possible Ã¢ÂÂ and share our positive vision for America.
This country has a foundation that spreads out all across the planet. It has roots in Africa and Asia
column2: many of whose people were brought here against their will
column3: but became part of the fabric of our society. ItÃ¢ÂÂs rooted in Native Americans
column4: who have always been here. And itÃ¢ÂÂs enriched by immigrants from all corners Ã¢ÂÂ places like Ireland
column5: where my family first came from.

column1: And people sometimes forget Ã¢ÂÂ and some may not even know Ã¢ÂÂ that the Hispanic community has been part of our country since the Spanish arrived in St. Augustine in 1565. That was well before the British landed in North America.
Spanish was the first European language spoken in this country. A few years ago
column2: I gave the first speech ever delivered in Spanish on the Senate floor. Since we were debating a bill about immigration
column3: explaining it in Spanish just made sense Ã¢ÂÂ especially since itÃ¢ÂÂs the language of more than 40 million people in this country who are most affected by this issue.

column2: it just makes sense to make the case for our campaign in a language thatÃ¢ÂÂs spoken by so many families across the country.

column1: I donÃ¢ÂÂt speak Spanish perfectly. But I picked up what I could while working with Jesuit missionaries in Honduras. I took the skills I learned as a boy
column2: working in my fatherÃ¢ÂÂs ironworking shop

column4: city councilman

column1: What I learned in Honduras comes down to three things: Fe
column2: familia y trabajo duro. Those were also the values I learned in my Irish-Catholic family in Kansas City. ThereÃ¢ÂÂs one other basic belief that Hillary and I share: Do all the good you can and serve one another. ItÃ¢ÂÂs pretty simple.

column1: And today
column2: I recognize those same values in every state in our nation
column3: by people of all skin colors
column4: religions and backgrounds. And in this campaign
column5: itÃ¢ÂÂs been inspiring to see people from across our country coming together to address the challenges we face.

column1: I believe that God has created a beautiful and rich tapestry in our country
column2: an incredible cultural diversity that succeeds when we embrace everybody in love and battle back against the dark forces of division.

column1: Presidential elections are always a choice between two visions for our countryÃ¢ÂÂ¦ a choice between two candidates.
But this year itÃ¢ÂÂs a little bit different. ItÃ¢ÂÂs about America looking in the mirror and deciding what we see there.
This isnÃ¢ÂÂt just a question of a presidentÃ¢ÂÂs temperament and experience
column2: although those are very important qualities. WhatÃ¢ÂÂs really on the ballot is Hillary ClintonÃ¢ÂÂs Ã¢ÂÂstronger togetherÃ¢ÂÂ vision versus Donald TrumpÃ¢ÂÂs frightening and divisive vision for our country.

column1: So today
column2: I wanted you to hear directly from me
column3: that under a Clinton-Kaine Administration
column4: everyone will have a place in America.

column1: Latinos have always shaped this countryÃ¢ÂÂ¦ From your service in the military
column2: to your spirit of entrepreneurshipÃ¢ÂÂ¦ to your presence

column1: on the Supreme Court.
And by 2050
column2: communities of color will represent the majority of our population. So of course Latinos will help shape the future of America because you are the future of America.

column1: Todos somos americanos.
We need all Americans
column2: from all backgrounds
column3: to help write the next chapters in our nationÃ¢ÂÂs story Ã¢ÂÂ just as you have always done. This community has been part of a long struggle that has shown your resilience and your power.

column1: In recent years
column2: many of those battles have been waged right here in Arizona. In many ways
column3: Phoenix was one of the birthplaces of the modern immigrant rights movement
column4: when people from all over the country came to organize against SB1070 Ã¢ÂÂ a bill that went against so many of our shared values.

column1: That battle isnÃ¢ÂÂt overÃ¢ÂÂ¦ Right now
column2: in this election
column3: you are all leading the way in the next phase of progress. But weÃ¢ÂÂre up against some pretty tough opponents.

column1: One of TrumpÃ¢ÂÂs biggest supporters
column2: Sheriff Joe Arpaio
column3: whoÃ¢ÂÂs facing criminal charges for profiling Latinos and has persecuted undocumented immigrants. He says he thinks Trump will get Ã¢ÂÂa lot of Hispanic votes.Ã¢ÂÂ

Just the other day
column2: your former governor
column3: Jan Brewer
column4: who signed into law the discriminatory SB1070 that promoted racial profiling
column5: said that she wasnÃ¢ÂÂt worried about her candidate
column6: Donald Trump
column7: winning this state
column8: because
column9: as she said

I think Jan Brewer must not be paying very close attention. Because
millions of Americans are coming together Ã¢ÂÂ Democrats and Republicans and Independents Ã¢ÂÂ to support Hillary Clinton and reject Donald Trump and everything he stands for.
Here in Arizona
column2: our campaign is surging. More than a million people have already voted early
column3: and the rate of Hispanic voters has nearly doubled compared to four years ago. We are also seeing the same energy from the Latino community in early vote in states like Florida
column4: Nevada
column5: North Carolina and other states.

column1: So I hate to break it to the Trump campaign
column2: but Latinos are going to have a really big voice in this electionÃ¢ÂÂ¦ And the choice is really clear.

column1: On the one hand
column2: you have Hillary Clinton. Someone whoÃ¢ÂÂs spent her entire life working on behalf of kids and families. She started her career at an organization that fights for children and their families
column3: at the ChildrenÃ¢ÂÂs Defense Fund. Registering Latino voters in South Texas and fought; fighting for universal healthcare and equal rights. In other words
column4: sheÃ¢ÂÂs lista. Hillary Clinton is lista.

column1: On the other hand
column2: you have Donald Trump. Someone who thinks Ã¢ÂÂLatino outreachÃ¢ÂÂ means tweeting out a picture of a taco bowl.

column1: In the first weeks of his campaign
column2: Donald Trump said that immigrants from Mexico are drug dealers
column3: rapists
column4: murderers. In the last debate
column5: Trump referred to them as Ã¢ÂÂbad hombres.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: He insists that Ã¢ÂÂthis is a country where we speak English
column2: not Spanish.Ã¢ÂÂ He doesnÃ¢ÂÂt understand that multilingual and bilingual families contribute to the diversity that makes our nation strong.

column1: He once called Alicia Machado
column2: the winner of his Miss Universe pageant
column3: Ã¢ÂÂMiss HousekeepingÃ¢ÂÂ¦Ã¢ÂÂ And a month ago
column4: he decided to pick a fight with her on Twitter and in interviews for days.

column1: And he attacked Gonzalo Curiel Ã¢ÂÂ the distinguished judge in the fraud lawsuit against Trump University. Now
column2: Judge Curiel was born in Indiana. His parents were born in Mexico. But Donald actually said Judge Curiel canÃ¢ÂÂt be trusted to do his job because of his Ã¢ÂÂMexican heritage.Ã¢ÂÂ

column2: Paul Ryan
column3: who has endorsed Trump

column1: Judge Curiel is as American as I am. And heÃ¢ÂÂs as American as Donald Trump.
Whether your family just arrived or has been here since before the United States even existedÃ¢ÂÂ¦ Hillary Clinton and I believe we are brothers and my sisters

column1: YouÃ¢ÂÂre our neighbors

column4: smarter
column5: and more creative. And I want all of you to know that we see you
column6: and we are with you.

column1: America is a better country because of you.
Hillary and I have a positive vision for what we want to accomplish.
You know
column2: when Hillary first called me up and told me she had chosen me to be her running mate
column3: hereÃ¢ÂÂs what she saidÃ¢ÂÂ¦

column1: The definition of success in a Clinton-Kaine Administration wonÃ¢ÂÂt be the number of laws we pass
column2: but whether we can make life a little easier for a working mother
column3: or help a child learn better in a classroom
column4: or help a person whoÃ¢ÂÂs made a mistake get a second chance. At that moment
column5: I knew we were going to be soul mates in this journey.

column1: Hillary and I are making two major promises for the first 100 days of our administration.
First
column2: weÃ¢ÂÂll make the biggest investment in new
column3: good-paying jobs since World War II. We need to create an economy that works for everyone
column4: not just those at the top. And I donÃ¢ÂÂt need to tell anyone here that we still have some work to do to get there.

column1: Latinos are 17 percent of our countryÃ¢ÂÂs population
column2: but they hold only 2 percent of its wealth. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs just not right. WeÃ¢ÂÂve got to connect more Latinos with good jobs that pay good wagesÃ¢ÂÂ¦ with more opportunities to go to college
column3: launch new ventures
column4: and build wealth that you can pass on to your kids.

column1: One of the keys to that is small business. Hillary and I are two kids of two fathers who built small businesses
column2: and we know need to do much more to support the Latino-owned small businesses that create so many jobs across America. Our plan will make it easier to start one
column3: increase access to capital
column4: and invest $25 billion in the communities that need it most.

column1: And at a time when education is more important than ever for the jobs of the future
column2: weÃ¢ÂÂll fight for universal pre-school
column3: good schools in every ZIP code
column4: and make sure no one has to give up on their dreams of college because they canÃ¢ÂÂt afford to pay.

column1: Over the last 20 years
column2: the number of Latinos going to college has tripled. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs great news. And yet
column3: Latinos are still less likely than their white peers to graduate Ã¢ÂÂ often because they canÃ¢ÂÂt afford to.

column1: Our plan will help change that. WeÃ¢ÂÂre going to make community college
free. WeÃ¢ÂÂre going to make in-state public universities debt-free. And for families making less than $125
column2: 000 a year

column1: Second
column2: Hillary and I will introduce legislation for comprehensive immigration reform that includes a path to citizenship.

column1: Too many children in America say goodbye to their parents every morning
column2: not knowing if their mom or dad will be there when they get home.

column1: Donald Trump wants to create a deportation nation. Trump wants to deport almost 16 million people. He wants to deport 11.5 million
undocumented people. And he wants to eliminate citizenship for 4.5 million people who were born in the United States to parents without documents undocumented parents and deport them as well.

This goes against one of the most important values in our Constitution Ã¢ÂÂ a person born here in the United States is a citizen. Hillary and I will fight against TrumpÃ¢ÂÂs divisive plan with all of our efforts.
One of my favorite things to do is go to the naturalization services where people become U.S. citizens.
Usually
column2: after the oath is taken

column4: and people get to walk up and explain why they decided to become a citizen. Their stories just bring tears to your eyes and a smile to your face when you hear what they think about the greatness of the United States of America.

column1: You canÃ¢ÂÂt help but think: Cualquier persona que ama tanto a los Estados Unidos merece estar aquÃÂ­.
ThatÃ¢ÂÂs why weÃ¢ÂÂre going to fight so hard for comprehensive immigration reform
column2: and in the meantime

column1: A few months ago

column3: and we will keep fighting for it.

column2: 2010 Ã¢ÂÂ -- AMANPOUR: Madam Speaker

column1: PELOSI: My pleasure.

column1: Last year
column2: 32 Democrats voted against the funding of the war in Afghanistan. This year

column1: PELOSI: Well

column1: Our president came in. He was president maybe two months
column2: three months
column3: by the time we took the vote last year. And the Republicans said they weren't going to vote for the funding. And so it took all Democratic votes.

column1: I persuaded my members to give this president a chance
column2: to give him room in order to have time to implement his plan. And in -- and in the course of time -- now the Republicans said they would vote for it

column2: you didn't vote.

column1: PELOSI: No.

column2: we brought the bill to the floor. And that was a statement that said that we knew that our troops needed to have what was -- what they needed to have would be provided for them. So we will never abandon our men and women in uniform. On the other hand

column1: AMANPOUR: How long do you think you can keep your skeptical members
column2: as you call them
column3: on side?

column1: PELOSI: Well
column2: again
column3: we have a -- varying degrees of expression here. We are there

column1: Is it worth it?
AMANPOUR: Well
column2: is it worth it?

column1: PELOSI: Yes.
AMANPOUR: Is it worth it?
PELOSI: That's the question.
AMANPOUR: But that's my question to you.
PELOSI: Well
column2: we will -- as I said
column3: we will see the metrics as they unfold in the next few months and certainly by the end of this year.

column1: AMANPOUR: But what does your gut tell you?
PELOSI: in my visits to afghanistan
column2: the last time i was there was over mother's day weekend to visit the troops///and the four metrics that we have always used year in and year out on these visits have been about security. And the military tells us this cannot be won militarily solely.

column1: Secondly
column2: governance and ending corruption.....

column1: AMANPOUR: I'm just trying to figure out
column2: for instance
column3: you know
column4: what you think is the right thing to do in Afghanistan at the moment. Look

column6: this week
column7: has this as its cover -- a girl whose had her nose and ears cut off by the Taliban.

column1: You know
column2: to put it right down to its basics
column3: is America going to abandon the women of Afghanistan
column4: the people of Afghanistan again?

column1: PELOSI: Well
column2: first of all
column3: we're in Afghanistan because it's in our strategic national interests to be so for our own national security
column4: to stop terrorism
column5: to increase global security. The women of Afghanistan have been a priority for many of the women in Congress -- and men
column6: too
column7: but the women have taken a special interest.

column1: When I was there in -- around Mother's Day
column2: I went to a province in Southern Afghanistan and visited with women.

column1: And we talked about the education of their children
column2: the health of women and the rest. And they -- especially their daughters.- they said we want that
column3: but that can't happen without security. And these women in this remote province told us and that can't happen without the end of corruption.

column1: So what we would like to see is for President Karzai be a more reliable
column2: a stronger partner
column3: ending the corruption
column4: increasing -- improving the governance

column1: AMANPOUR: Vice President Biden
column2: talking about the dead line for the transition

Does that square with -- with what you think
column2: that it could just be a couple of thousand troops?

column1: PELOSI: Well
column2: I hope it is more than that. I know it's not going to be turn out the lights and let's all go home on one day. But I do think the American people expect it to be somewhere between that and a -- a few thousand troops.

column1: AMANPOUR: Let's go to something much closer to home right now at the moment and that is the ethics conundrum with Representative Rangel.
How does your affection and your respect for him as a colleague square with what's going on right now and what you said and declared
column2: that this is going to be the -- the -- the most ethical Congress ---- that you're going to drain the swamp of any kind of wrongdoing and corruption
column3: etc.?

column1: PELOSI: When I came in

column3: but we have to pull the high ethical standard and none of our personalities is more important than that.

column1: AMANPOUR: Can you see Congressman Rangel ever returning as chairman of the Ways and Means or in any position of leadership in -- in the House?
PELOSI: Well
column2: the -- the Ethics Committee is working its will and

column1: AMANPOUR: No matter what happens?
PELOSI: it's an elementary discussion
column2: because what we have done is to wait and see what the Committee decides. I respect what they do. I'm totally out of the loop. It is independent. It is confidential
column3: classified
column4: secret
column5: whatever. We don't know what it is. But we do respect the work that the members of the Committee do.

column2: that's one version of the story. And --

After nearly half a decade working on Late Night With Seth Meyers and The Daily Show With Trevor Noah
column2: Wolf is set to host her own weekly show on Netflix. The streaming giant
column3: which is making a considerable push in the talk-show space with entries from David Letterman and Joel McHale
column4: is billing WolfÃ¢ÂÂs show as a break from the seriousness of late-night comedy. The planned star vehicle will launch later this year.

column1: The 32-year-old rising star

column4: with no preaching or political agenda Ã¢ÂÂ unless
column5: of course

column7: Ã¢ÂÂ Wolf joked in a statement
column8: with NetflixÃ¢ÂÂs vp content Bela Bajaria

483	"Rose Garden
11:27 A.M. EDT
THE PRESIDENT: Good morning
column2: everybody. Lately
column3: IÃ¢ÂÂve been speaking a lot about our need for an all-of-the-above strategy for American energy -- a strategy that produces more oil and gas here at home
column4: but also produces more biofuels and fuel-efficient cars
column5: more solar power and wind power and other sources of clean
column6: renewable energy.

column1: This strategy is not just the right thing to do for our long-term economic growth; itÃ¢ÂÂs also the right way for us to reduce our dependence on foreign oil right now. ItÃ¢ÂÂs the right way for us to put people to work right now. And ultimately
column2: itÃ¢ÂÂs the right way to stop spikes in gas prices that weÃ¢ÂÂve put up [with] every single year -- the same kind of increase that weÃ¢ÂÂve seen over the past couple of months.

column1: Obviously rising gas prices means a rough ride for a lot of families. Whether youÃ¢ÂÂre trying to get to school
column2: trying to get to work
column3: do some grocery shopping
column4: you have to be able to fill up that gas tank. And there are families in certain parts of the country that have no choice but to drive 50 or 60 miles to get to the job. So when gas prices go up
column5: itÃ¢ÂÂs like an additional tax that comes right out of your pocket.

column1: ThatÃ¢ÂÂs one of the reasons we passed a payroll tax cut at the beginning of this year and made sure it extended all the way through this year
column2: so that the average American is getting that extra $40 in every paycheck right now.

column1: But I think everybody understands that there are no quick fixes to this problem. There are politicians who say that if we just drilled more then gas prices would come down right away. What they donÃ¢ÂÂt say is that we have been drilling more. Under my administration
column2: America is producing more oil than at any time in the last eight years. WeÃ¢ÂÂve opened up new areas for exploration. We've quadrupled the number of operating rigs to a record high. We've added enough new oil and gas pipeline to circle the Earth and then some.

column1: But as I've said repeatedly
column2: the problem is we use more than 20 percent of the worldÃ¢ÂÂs oil and we only have 2 percent of the worldÃ¢ÂÂs proven oil reserves. Even if we drilled every square inch of this country right now
column3: weÃ¢ÂÂd still have to rely disproportionately on other countries for their oil. That means we pay more at the pump every time thereÃ¢ÂÂs instability in the Middle East
column4: or growing demand in countries like China and India.

column1: ThatÃ¢ÂÂs whatÃ¢ÂÂs happening right now. ItÃ¢ÂÂs those global trends that are affecting gas prices. So even as we're tackling issues of supply and demand
column2: even as we're looking at the long-term in terms of how we can structurally make ourselves less reliant on foreign oil
column3: we still need to work extra hard to protect consumers from factors that should not affect the price of a barrel of oil.

column1: That includes doing everything we can to ensure that an irresponsible few arenÃ¢ÂÂt able to hurt consumers by illegally manipulating or rigging the energy markets for their own gain. We can't afford a situation where speculators artificially manipulate markets by buying up oil
column2: creating the perception of a shortage
column3: and driving prices higher -- only to flip the oil for a quick profit. We canÃ¢ÂÂt afford a situation where some speculators can reap millions
column4: while millions of American families get the short end of the stick. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs not the way the market should work. And for anyone who thinks this cannot happen
column5: just think back to how Enron traders manipulated the price of electricity to reap huge profits at everybody elseÃ¢ÂÂs expense.

column1: Now
column2: the good news is my administration has already taken several actions to step up oversight of oil markets and close dangerous loopholes that were allowing some traders to operate in the shadows.

column1: We closed the so-called Enron loophole that let traders evade oversight by using electronic or overseas trading platforms. In the Wall Street reform law
column2: we said for the first time that federal regulators will make sure no single trader can buy such a large position in oil that they could easily manipulate the market on their own. So IÃ¢ÂÂd point out that anybody whoÃ¢ÂÂs pledging to roll back Wall Street reform -- Dodd-Frank -- would also roll back this vital consumer protection along with it.

column1: IÃ¢ÂÂve asked Attorney General Holder to work with Chairman Leibowitz of the Federal Trade Commission
column2: Chairman Gensler of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission
column3: and other enforcement agencies to make sure that acts of manipulation
column4: fraud or other illegal activity are not behind increases in the price that consumers pay at the pump.

column1: So today
column2: weÃ¢ÂÂre announcing new steps to strengthen oversight of energy markets. Things that we can do administratively
column3: we are doing. And I call on Congress to pass a package of measures to crack down on illegal activity and hold accountable those who manipulate the market for private gain at the expense of millions of working families. And be specific.

column1: First
column2: Congress should provide immediate funding to put more cops on the beat to monitor activity in energy markets. This funding would also upgrade technology so that our surveillance and enforcement officers arenÃ¢ÂÂt hamstrung by older and less sophisticated tools than the ones that traders are using. We should strengthen protections for American consumers
column3: not gut them. And these markets have expanded significantly.

column1: Chairman Gensler actually had a good analogy. He said
column2: imagine if the NFL quadrupled the number of teams but didnÃ¢ÂÂt increase the number of refs. YouÃ¢ÂÂd end up having havoc on the field
column3: and it would diminish the game. It wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt be fair. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs part of whatÃ¢ÂÂs going on in a lot of these markets. So we have to properly resource enforcement.

column1: Second
column2: Congress should increase the civil and criminal penalties for illegal energy market manipulation and other illegal activities. So my plan would toughen key financial penalties tenfold
column3: and impose these penalties not just per violation
column4: but for every day a violation occurs.

column1: Third
column2: Congress should give the agency responsible for overseeing oil markets new authority to protect against volatility and excess speculation by making sure that traders can post appropriate margins
column3: which simply means that they actually have the money to make good on their trades.

column1: Congress should do all of this right away. A few weeks ago
column2: Congress had a chance to stand up for families already paying an extra premium at the pump; congressional Republicans voted to keep spending billions of Americans' hard-earned tax dollars on more unnecessary subsidies for big oil companies. So here's a chance to make amends
column3: a chance to actually do something that will protect consumers by increasing oversight of energy markets. That should be something that everybody
column4: no matter their party
column5: should agree with. And I hope Americans will ask their members of Congress to step up.

column1: In the meantime
column2: my administration will take new executive actions to better analyze and investigate trading activities in energy markets and more quickly implement the tough consumer protections under Wall Street reform.

column1: Let me close by saying none of these steps by themselves will bring gas prices down overnight. But it will prevent market manipulation and make sure we're looking out for American consumers. And in the meantime we're going to keep pursuing an all-of-the-above strategy for American energy to break the cycle of price spikes year after year. We are going to keep producing more biofuels; we're going to keep producing more fuel-efficient cars; we are going to keep tapping into every source of American-made energy.

And these steps have already helped put America on a path to greater energy independence. Our foreign -- our dependence on foreign oil has actually decreased each year I've been in office -- even as the economy has grown. America now imports less than half of the oil we use for the first time in more than a decade. So we are less vulnerable than we were
column2: but we're still too vulnerable.

column1: We've got to continue the hard
column2: sustained work on this issue. And as long as I'm President we're going to keep placing our bets on America's future -- America's workers
column3: America's technology
column4: America's ingenuity
column5: and American-made energy. That's how we're going to solve this problem once and for all.

column1: Thank you very much
column2: everybody.

column1: END
