485	"This is well outside WonkblogÃ¢ÂÂs normal bailiwick
column2: but if nothing else
column3: Sen. Rand PaulÃ¢ÂÂs (R-Ky.) filibuster against CIA director nominee John Brennan Ã¢ÂÂ launched as a protest against the administrationÃ¢ÂÂs drone policy
column4: which Brennan has steered for the past four years Ã¢ÂÂ uncovered a hunger for a broader conversation on the topic. So what does the drone program actually entail
column5: and why are Paul and others criticizing it?

column1: What is a drone?
Technically called Ã¢ÂÂunmanned aerial vehiclesÃ¢ÂÂ (UAVs)
column2: drones are just aircraft without human pilots onboard
column3: encompassing everything from reconnaissance vehicles to unmanned crop dusters. In common parlance
column4: though
column5: Ã¢ÂÂdroneÃ¢ÂÂ has come to refer to unmanned combat aerial vehicles (UCAVs)
column6: which are UAVs equipped with combat capabilities
column7: most commonly the ability to launch missiles.

column1: How long has the U.S. government been using them?
The General Atomics MQ-1 Predator
column2: the most famous UCAV in the U.S. arsenal
column3: first saw combat in 1995 as part of the NATO intervention in Bosnia
column4: but at that time was solely a reconnaissance tool and carried no payload. On Feb. 16
column6: the Predator #3034 became the first to be successfully fitted with a Hellfire missile
column7: and to fire it in a trial flight. Predators were deployed to Afghanistan almost immediately after the Sept. 11
column8: 2001 terrorist attacks
column9: and on Oct. 7
column10: 2001 they conducted their first armed mission there.

column1: In addition to the Predator
column2: the General Atomics MQ-9 Reaper
column3: a larger UCAV capable of carrying a higher payload
column4: has seen service starting in 2007. The current program is jointly administered by the CIA and the Joint Special Operation Command (JSOC).

column1: Where do we send them?
Primarily Pakistan
column2: Yemen and Somalia. According to a Washington Post database
column3: compiled with the help of the New America Foundation and Long War Journal
column4: strikes in Pakistan have been occurring since 2004 and picked up in pace starting in summer 2008. Apart from a November 2002 strike in Yemen
column5: the Somalia and Yemen campaigns began in 2011. There have been reports of strikes in the Philippines
column6: though information there is sketchy.

column1: Additionally
column2: drones have seen service in Libya
column3: Afghanistan and Iraq as part of the Unites StatesÃ¢ÂÂs more traditional military campaigns in those countries.

column1: How powerful is a drone attack?
Predator drones can carry up to two Hellfire missiles. Those have warheads of about 20 pounds
column2: which are designed to pierce tank armor; their damage outside of the vehicle targeted is limited. An alternative warhead
column3: which manufacturer Lockheed Martin touts as featuring Ã¢ÂÂhigh lethality and minimum collateral damage
column4: Ã¢ÂÂ also is in service.

column1: Reapers are another story. They feature a maximum payload of 3
column2: 000 pounds
column3: or 1.5 tons. That means they can carry a combination of Hellfires and larger 500 pound bombs like the GBU-12 Paveway II and GBD-38 JDAM. Those have an Ã¢ÂÂeffective casualty radiusÃ¢ÂÂ of about 200 feet. That means that about 50 percent of people within 200 feet of the blast site will die. Those odds improve Ã¢ÂÂ or worsen
column4: depending on how you look at it Ã¢ÂÂ the closer you get
column5: obviously.

column1: So imagine if you took a football field and shrunk it by a third. A Reaper attacks one endzone with a GBU-12. If youÃ¢ÂÂre on the field
column2: you have a 50 percent chance of dying. Update: I apparently forgot the distinction between yards and feet since middle school. Corrected.

column1: How many drone attacks have we launched to date?
According to the Post database
column2: there have been 347 in Pakistan
column3: 53 in Yemen and 2 in Somalia. From 2008 through October 2012
column4: there were 1
column5: 015 strikes in Afghanistan
column6: 48 in Iraq
column7: and at least 105 in Libya according to the Bureau for Investigative Journalism. That does not include strikes in Libya past September 2011
column8: strikes from 2001 to 2007 in Iraq and Afghanistan
column9: and those since October 2012. The New York TimesÃ¢ÂÂ Mark Mazzetti reported that at least one strike has happened in the Philippines.

column1: What sort of people have we targeted?
Primarily al-Qaeda and its affiliates. That includes al-Shaabab in Somalia
column2: al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (which works in Yemen)
column3: and the Haqqani Network in Afghanistan and Pakistan. The Philippines strike was intended to kill Umar Patek
column4: a leader of the Indonesian terrorist group Jemaah Islamiyah who helped orchestrate the 2002 attacks in Bali that killed 95 people. Patek is now serving a 20-year sentence in Indonesia.

column1: Have we killed U.S. citizens this way?
WeÃ¢ÂÂve killed four
column2: at least. Anwar al-Awlaki
column3: an American-born al-Qaeda operative in Yemen
column4: was killed in a drone strike in 2011
column5: as was his American-born 17-year-old son (in a subsequent strike) and Samir Khan
column6: a North Carolina native who died in the same strike as the elder al-Alaki. Ahmed Hijazi
column7: also an American citizen based in Yemen
column8: was killed in 2002. Note: paragraph updated to correct spelling of al-AwlakiÃ¢ÂÂs name and include Hijazi.

column1: To clarify the Obama administrationÃ¢ÂÂs exact policy on killing Americans without a trial
column2: Eric Holder wrote the following letter to Sen. Rand Paul: Ã¢ÂÂDear Senator Paul: It has come to my attention that you have now asked an additional question: Ã¢ÂÂDoes the President have the authority to use a weaponized drone to kill an American not engaged in combat on American soil?Ã¢ÂÂ The answer to that question is no.Ã¢ÂÂ The dispatch followed an earlier
column3: more equivocal note from Holder on the subject
column4: which seemed to indicate Holder believes the president has the authority to kill U.S. citizens on U.S. soil if he judges them a threat.

column1: How many people have died in drone attacks?
Sen. Lindsey Graham estimated the death toll of the Pakistan/Somalia/Yemen program at 4
column2: 700. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs higher than most estimates; Micah Zenko of the Council on Foreign Relations puts the number at closer to 3

column1: How many of those were civilians?
Cora Currier at ProPublica helpfully compiled a number of estimates in January. New America puts the civilian death total in Pakistan and Yemen between 276 and 368
column2: of which 118-135 were under the Bush administration. The Bureau of Investigative Journalism puts the number between 446 and 978
column3: increasing to 993 if you include Somalia. Of those
column4: 179 to 209 were children
column5: BIJ estimates. A Stanford/NYU study suggests that the strikes have inflicted considerable psychological trauma on residents of Pakistan
column6: and deterred relief workers from serving areas targeted. Funerals and rescue workers have been targeted in past strikes.

column1: WhatÃ¢ÂÂs the process for deciding when and where to launch them?
As my colleague Greg Miller has reported
column2: the administration uses something called the Ã¢ÂÂdisposition matrixÃ¢ÂÂ to determine targets for drone strikes. Miller describes it as a Ã¢ÂÂsingle
column3: continually evolving database in which biographies
column4: locations
column5: known associates and affiliated organizations are all cataloged. So are strategies for taking targets down
column6: including extradition requests
column7: capture operations and drone patrolsÃ¢ÂÂ¦The database is meant to map out contingencies
column8: creating an operational menu that spells out each agencyÃ¢ÂÂs role in case a suspect surfaces in an unexpected spot.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: The National Counterterrorism Center (NCTC) will prepare lists of potential targets
column2: which will be reviewed every three months by a panel of intelligence analysts and military officials. They are then passed along to a panel at the National Security Council
column3: currently helmed by CIA director nominee Brennan
column4: and then to Obama for final approval. The criteria for addition to the list are determined personally by Obama
column5: who also must personally approve all strikes outside Pakistan. Pakistan strikes are approved by the CIA director.

column1: WhatÃ¢ÂÂs the case for using drones?
ThereÃ¢ÂÂs some political science to suggest that Ã¢ÂÂdecapitation strikes
column2: Ã¢ÂÂ like these drone attacks
column3: are actually quite effective at reducing the ability of terrorist groups to operate effectively. The RAND CorporationÃ¢ÂÂs Patrick Johnston and UCLAÃ¢ÂÂs Anoop Sarbahi have found preliminary evidence that the drone program specifically is effective at degrading the operations of targeted groups. Zack Beauchamp has a good overview of this literature here.

column1: But thatÃ¢ÂÂs a case for strikes
column2: not for drone strikes specifically. There is
column3: however
column4: substantial evidence that the percentage of casualties borne by civilians is much lower with drone strikes than with just about any other kind of military intervention
column5: even if one accepts high estimates of the percent of killed who are civilians.

column1: Is Congress kept in the loop?
To some degree. As part of BrennanÃ¢ÂÂs confirmation process
column2: Senate Intelligence Committee members were granted access to Justice Department memos justifying the use of drones
column3: and a similar white paper was shared last year. The Committee and its House counterpart are also allowed to review individual strikes
column4: including the intelligence behind them and video obtained during their commission. But they have not tried to limit the program in any way. Ã¢ÂÂI donÃ¢ÂÂt know that weÃ¢ÂÂve ever seen anything that we thought was inappropriate
column5: Ã¢ÂÂ one Congressional aide told the Los Angeles Times.

column1: How about the courts?
Nope. Sen. Angus King (I-Maine) has proposed establishing a specialized court to approve drone strikes based on FISA courts that approve surveillance of suspected foreign intelligence in the U.S.
column2: but that is
column3: for now
column4: just an idea. Neal Katyal
column5: a former acting solicitor general under Obama
column6: has called for an oversight board placed within the executive branch.

column1: Is this legal?
The Justice Department certainly thinks so
column2: though the reasons why are classified
column3: and lawsuits to expose them have proven unsuccessful. The clearest window weÃ¢ÂÂve gotten into their reasoning as relates to the killing of U.S. citizenscomes from a white paper leaked to NBC News last month. It derives the authority for the strikes from the Authorization for the Use of Military Force (AUMF) passed in the wake of 9/11
column4: which grants the government broad powers against al-Qaeda. WhatÃ¢ÂÂs more
column5: the white paper argues that drone strikes somehow donÃ¢ÂÂt run afoul of Executive Order 12333
column6: the ban on assassinations as a tool of policy that has existed since the Ford administration
column7: as they are used for Ã¢ÂÂself-defense.Ã¢ÂÂ See also BrennanÃ¢ÂÂs speech here defending the program more broadly.

column1: Administration critics arenÃ¢ÂÂt impressed
column2: with the ACLUÃ¢ÂÂs Jameel Jaffeer noting the white paper
column3: Ã¢ÂÂargues that the government has the right to carry out the extrajudicial killing of an American citizen.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: Does it violate international law?
The Justice Department memo cites the UN Charter
column2: which allows states to make war in the interest of self-defense
column3: an interest also invoked by Brennan. Critics
column4: like UN special rapporteur on extrajudicial killings
column5: summary or arbitrary executions Christof Heyns
column6: say that this defense is a stretch
column7: and the killings plainly run afoul of the laws of war and international human rights treaties.

column1: Are other countries using drones this way?
Only the United States and the United Kingdom (which assists in the Pakistan drone effort) currently use drones in combat
column2: but many other countries have acquired drone technology
column3: including China
column4: Russia
column5: India
column6: Iran and Israel. The U.K. uses Reapers and Predators while most other countries use the Israeli Aerospace Industries Heron or similar Israeli models. Drones saw combat use in Israel during the Gaza war of late 2008. Even Hezbollah has acquired reconnaissance drones. All told
column7: the GAO estimates that 76 countries
column8: at least
column9: have drone technology.

column1: What do our allies think about it?
European allies other than Britain generally refrain from using drones to attack al-Qaeda
column2: but frequently share intelligence that assists the drone program in selecting targets.

column1: What about the countries where we send drones? What do they think?
TheyÃ¢ÂÂre very mad. The Pakistani government has condemned the drone strikes as a violation of sovereignty
column2: though thereÃ¢ÂÂs evidence theyÃ¢ÂÂre tacitly allowing the strikes to happen. The Yemeni government quietly agreed to the strikes
column3: though murmurs of opposition have emerged of late. Citizens in both countries deplore the campaigns.

column1: Is it actually weakening al-Qaeda?
New America estimates that 1
column3: 236 militants were killed in Pakistan and Yemen
column4: meaning the overwhelming majority of casualties were intended targets. That said
column5: the share of deaths who were Ã¢ÂÂhigh-profile targetsÃ¢ÂÂ was 11 percent under Obama and 33 percent under Bush according to New America. And there are deeper doubts as to whether the strategy is recruiting more militants than it kills
column6: by turning local populations against the United States. The attempted Times Square bomber
column7: for instance
column8: cited drones as a motivating force.

column1: It could also be a bad idea even if it is weakening al-Qaeda. Many have noted that the money spent on anti-terrorism efforts might save more lives if devoted to tackling more mundane threats
column2: like auto accidents.

column1: Thanks to Zack Beauchamp for research help throughout."	0
486	"Expanding Opportunity Ã¢ÂÂ #KempForum16 Paul Ryan ÃÂ· Follow 5 min read ÃÂ· Jan 9
column2: 2016 -- 8 Listen Share

column1: LetÃ¢ÂÂs get the conversation going on how we can fight poverty and expand opportunity in America. Join Senator Tim Scott and I as we moderate a forum on fighting poverty with Republican presidential candidates in Columbia
column2: S.C.
column3: hosted by the Jack Kemp Foundation. Follow along here and on Twitter with #KempForum16.

column1: I just wanted to say a few words about why weÃ¢ÂÂre here today. And one reason why IÃ¢ÂÂm here is that my mentor was Jack Kemp. There was no issue he was more passionate about than poverty.
So I couldnÃ¢ÂÂt think of a better host than the foundation that bears his name. Jack was the greatest champion of the American Idea
column2: and he knew the fight against poverty is vital to renewing that idea in the 21st century.

column1: WeÃ¢ÂÂve been fighting the War on Poverty for 50 years now. And I donÃ¢ÂÂt think you can call it anything but a stalemate. The federal government has spent trillions of dollars. And yet today
column2: if you were raised poor
column3: youÃ¢ÂÂre just as likely to stay poor as you were 50 years ago.

column1: IÃ¢ÂÂm not saying we havenÃ¢ÂÂt made progress. We have. But today we have a safety net that catches people falling into poverty. What we need is a safety net that lifts people out of poverty Ã¢ÂÂ that helps them earn a good paycheck so they can support themselves. So
column2: what is the problem?

column1: It is our strategy. Most of us think poverty is about deprivation Ã¢ÂÂ or not having enough money.
We treat empty wallets like potholes. Fill them up and move on. So for the past 50 years
column2: weÃ¢ÂÂve created over 80 different programs to fill over 80 different holes in peopleÃ¢ÂÂs budgets: health care
column3: child care
column4: energy
column5: education Ã¢ÂÂ with almost no coordination among them.

column1: HereÃ¢ÂÂs the catch: You qualify for these programs based how much you make. So if you donÃ¢ÂÂt make much
column2: you get a lot of benefits. But as you work and make more
column3: you start to lose benefits.

column1: And because weÃ¢ÂÂve piled these programs right on top of each other
column2: the falloff is steep. Make a little more
column3: and youÃ¢ÂÂll lose a ton. So we think weÃ¢ÂÂve been filling holes. But weÃ¢ÂÂve actually been building a trap. And thatÃ¢ÂÂs because poverty is about more than deprivation; itÃ¢ÂÂs about isolation.

column1: There are many different kinds of poverty. But what a lot of them share in common is
column2: people are cut off from the community. They donÃ¢ÂÂt have the support they need to grow
column3: whether itÃ¢ÂÂs a counselor
column4: or a teacher
column5: or a boss.

column1: What they need is someone they can trust
column2: someone who can help them learn new skills. And by discouraging work
column3: the federal government is isolating the poor.

column1: ThatÃ¢ÂÂs why we are here today. We as a country are not winning this war
column2: and we conservatives have something to offer. I believe if we apply our principles to this challenge
column3: we can come up with real solutions. DonÃ¢ÂÂt just treat the symptoms of poverty. Get at the root causes of poverty.

column1: DonÃ¢ÂÂt measure success based on inputs. Measure the results.
And this
column2: to me
column3: is the biggest conservative insight: The answer is not the money in Washington.

column1: It is the people in our communities Ã¢ÂÂ the people with credibility. TheyÃ¢ÂÂre the ones who can break through. And IÃ¢ÂÂm not saying just cut money for the safety net. IÃ¢ÂÂd say spend the same amount of money we do now Ã¢ÂÂ because this isnÃ¢ÂÂt about saving money; itÃ¢ÂÂs about saving lives.
What IÃ¢ÂÂm saying is
column2: donÃ¢ÂÂt minimize; customize. Take the money weÃ¢ÂÂre spending now and direct it to homegrown solutions. Design aid to fit each personÃ¢ÂÂs needs. And whatever you do
column3: encourage work Ã¢ÂÂ because thatÃ¢ÂÂs how people reconnect with their community. Once they find their niche and put down roots
column4: they draw strength from the people around them
column5: and they grow.

column1: TheyÃ¢ÂÂll not only have enough money; theyÃ¢ÂÂll be able to make enough money to get off assistance.
The way I see it
column2: the federal government is the rearguard; it should direct the supply lines. But the people in our communities Ã¢ÂÂ theyÃ¢ÂÂre the vanguard; they should fight poverty on the front lines.

column1: Now
column2: I know a lot of people are wondering
column3: Ã¢ÂÂWhy do you care about this? YouÃ¢ÂÂre Republicans.Ã¢ÂÂ

column1: I remind them
column2: Ã¢ÂÂWell
column3: weÃ¢ÂÂre Americans too.Ã¢ÂÂ We all believe in the American Idea: The condition of your birth doesnÃ¢ÂÂt determine the outcome of your life.

column1: If you work hard and play by the rules
column2: you can get ahead. If you made a mistake
column3: you can redeem yourself.

column1: But a lot of people donÃ¢ÂÂt think thatÃ¢ÂÂs true anymore. And we have to be honest with ourselves: If the American Idea is not true for everybody
column2: then it is not true at all. So we all should care about poverty because it is a direct challenge to who we are.

column1: And itÃ¢ÂÂs not enough to pay your taxes and think
column2: Ã¢ÂÂGovernment is going to take care of this.Ã¢ÂÂ We all have to get involved.

column1: And I know itÃ¢ÂÂs easy to get discouraged. But what IÃ¢ÂÂve learned is
column2: there are thousands of people beating poverty every day. The solutions are out there; theyÃ¢ÂÂre already working. We just have to support them. We just have to find them. And more often than not theyÃ¢ÂÂre right under our noses . . . in our communities . . . all over America.

column1: So I look forward to hearing from all our candidates and learning more about how we can build a more prosperous
column2: a more secure
column3: and a more confident America."	0

column1: 487	"Krispy Kreme will give out free donut dozens on Nov. 13 as an act of kindness
Krispy Kreme will celebrate World Kindness Day on Monday
column2: Nov. 13 by giving out free donut dozens to the first 500 people to walk into a participating U.S. store. No purchase necessary."	0
2010 Ã¢ÂÂ -- TAPPER: Hello again. Joining me now
column3: the chairman of the Democratic National Committee
column4: Tim Kaine
column5: and the chairman of the Republican National Committee
column6: Michael Steele. Gentlemen
column7: welcome.

column1: KAINE: Hey
column2: Jake
column3: good to be with you.

column1: STEELE: Jake
column2: good to see you.

column1: TAPPER: I want to get to the general election results in a second
column2: but first
column3: I want to bear in on a couple of controversies we have
column4: and I'm going to start with you
column5: Mr. Steele.

column1: STEELE: OK.
TAPPER: I don't know if you were expecting (ph) that or not--
STEELE: Kind of.
(LAUGHTER)
TAPPER: The Kentucky Senate candidate
column2: Rand Paul
column3: has expressed his objections philosophically to the federal government being able to tell businesses that they cannot discriminate. Here's Rand Paul.

column1: (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
RAND PAUL
column2: SENATORIAL CANDIDATE
column3: R-KY.: I like the Civil Rights Act in a sense that it ended discrimination in all public domains. I abhor racism. I think it's a bad business decision to ever exclude anybody from your restaurant. But at the same time
column4: I do believe in private ownership.

column1: There's ten different titles
column2: you know
column3: to the Civil Rights Act. One deals with private institutions
column4: and had I been around
column5: I would have tried to modify that.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
TAPPER: Chairman Steele
column2: you have worked so hard to bring minorities into the Republican Party. Here is a Senate candidate saying that he doesn't think the government
column3: philosophically
column4: should be able to tell a business that they can't -- that they have to serve you.

column1: STEELE: Right
column2: right.

column1: TAPPER: Do you have an issue with that?
STEELE: Well
column2: I do
column3: and I think it's important to understand that Rand Paul has clarified his statement and has reiterated his support for and
column4: you know
column5: movement towards pushing civil rights forward as opposed to going backwards
column6: number one.

column1: Number two
column2: our party has always had a strong view on this issue. We fought very hard in the '60s to get the civil rights bill passed as well as the voting rights bill. So I think that
column3: you know
column4: any -- any
column5: you know
column6: attempted look backwards
column7: it's not in the best interests of our country
column8: certainly
column9: and certainly not in the best interests of the party.

column1: So
column2: you know
column3: I've talked to Rand. He and I are on the same page. Our party stands four-square about moving forward on civil rights. Looking at the civil rights issues of the day -- education
column4: for example -- there are many other fights that loom ahead for us in this area
column5: so Rand Paul as United States senator will be four-square with the Republican Party
column6: in lockstep with moving forward on civil rights
column7: not looking backwards.

column1: TAPPER: Chairman Kaine
column2: this is traditionally a Republican seat. Do these views of Rand Paul make this seat more competitive in your mind?

column1: KAINE: Absolutely
column2: they do
column3: Jake. Of course
column4: it starts with our candidate
column5: Jack Conway
column6: who's the attorney general
column7: I think he's going to run a great race. But Rand Paul's views on this
column8: his statement this week that he thinks it's un-American for President Obama to try to hold British Petroleum accountable for the spill in the Gulf--

column1: TAPPER: Let's talk about that. What do you think about that?
STEELE: Well
column2: I mean
column3: our own speaker of the House referred to American citizens as un-American
column4: so I think referring to a policy which he did not say it was un-American per se. He said going in that direction could be an un-American--

column1: TAPPER: We have -- we actually have the video clip. Let's watch that.
(CROSSTALK)
(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
PAUL: What I don't like from the president's administration is this sort of
column2: you know
column3: I'll put my boot heel on the throat of BP
column4: and I think it's part of this sort of blame game society in the sense that it's always got to be someone's fault
column5: instead of the fact that maybe sometimes accidents happen.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
TAPPER: Certainly
column2: accidents happen is not what you want the Republican response about the BP oil spill--

column1: STEELE: Well
column2: you know
column3: well
column4: look
column5: I mean
column6: it's not -- people shouldn't worry about the Republican response to the BP oil spill. They should worry about the Democrat president's response to the BP oil spill. It is one thing to actually get on the ground and get in front of this thing. It's another thing to sit back and hold BP accountable without helping them
column7: and that's what's happening here. I mean
column8: the federal government should have stepped into this thing immediately
column9: to help make sure that the appropriate steps are being taken by BP
column10: all federal agencies in support of the state government to try to get this thing cleaned up. And here we are
column11: almost a month and a half later
column12: and it's still spilling oil.

column1: TAPPER: How about that
column2: Chairman Kaine? A lot of Democrats are criticizing the Obama administration for not doing enough to hold BP accountable.

column1: KAINE: The administration is doing two things. It starts with BP's accountability
column2: and Rand Paul is wrong. It isn't un-American to hold somebody accountable for a massive environmental disaster of this kind. This isn't just a mistake that we can wash away. BP has got to be accountable for stopping the spill and then cleaning up and paying for the consequences. The administration has had a team working with BP from the very beginning trying to look at ways to help them do it
column3: but it is BP's job. They have to be held accountable
column4: and saying that it's just a mistake that needs to be washed away
column5: or saying
column6: as Rand Paul did
column7: for example
column8: that
column9: you know
column10: we needn't be so worried about things like mining regulations -- I mean
column11: this is a very important role that the government has
column12: to protect the safety of the environment and the health of its citizens. And so
column13: Rand Paul's statements along these lines are very
column14: very troubling
column15: and it's important for Republican leaders to say whether they back this kind of an attitude or not."	0

column1: 489	"Republican Senator Mitch McConnell and Democratic challenger Alison Lundergan Grimes sit on opposite sides of the debate about the role of money in U.S. elections.A deluge of campaign cash is playing a significant role in Kentucky's Senate race thus far.The money raised by the campaigns and outside groups is expected to top the $100 million mark and go down as the most expensive in U.S. history.More than any lawmaker
column2: McConnell is the face of looseningÃ¢ÂÂif not
column3: eliminatingÃ¢ÂÂcampaign finance regulations.For over a decade the GOP leader has espoused that money and free speech are synonymous. He has filed legal briefs urging the Supreme Court to reaffirm its Citizens United decision and supports a controversial case to further deregulate contribution limits placed on individuals.In a March 17 e-mail to supporters
column4: Grimes took a strong stance against the influence wealthy donors are having and calls out McConnell as the chief architect and beneficiary of that system.""Special interest money has already flooded into Mitch McConnellÃ¢ÂÂs campaign
column5: Grimes said. ""HeÃ¢ÂÂs the number one recipient of contributions from lobbyists this cycle and his Karl Rove-affiliated Super PACs are clogging the Commonwealth's airwaves with negative attack ads. Enough is enoughÃ¢ÂÂour democracy is too important to be auctioned off to the highest bidder.""Grimes has played it safe on the campaign trail when faced with thornier issues outside of core Democratic principles
column6: such as raising the minimum wage. But given the left's apoplectic reaction to the Roberts Court's dismantling limitations and the rise of super PACs
column7: her position is receiving applause from watchdog groups.""It's very good that Alison Grimes has come out in support of a policy that puts regular people in charge of government again
column8: says David Donnelly
column9: who is executive director of Public Campaign Action Fund. ""She understands that money in politics drowns out the voices of every day Kentuckians. This is a sharp difference between her and McConnell
column10: someone who is advocating the make the problem worse.""The Grimes campaign message also directs voters to sign a petition calling on Congress to ""stop special interest billionaires
column11: that has the support of red state Democratic senators such as Joe Donnelly of Indiana and Joe Manchin of West Virginia.In the 2014 election cycle
column12: there are almost 1
column13: 000 registered super PACs that have generated over $141 million and spent more than $24.8 million on races.According to the non-partisan Center for Responsive Politics
column14: the pro-McConnell super PAC Kentuckians for Strong Leadership is among the ranks among the top ten groups in this year's races.Democrats and liberal activists decrying the influence of money in politics have themselves pointed out its limitations in Kentucky's Senate race.McConnell has spent over half of the $20 million he's raised this cycle and he has a number of outside groups spending millions in advertisements supporting his re-election. Yet McConnell's approval ratings remain terribly low and Grimes either leads or ties the GOP leader in most polling.Former FEC Chairman Michael Toner says despite arguments that the wealthy are purchasing American elections
column15: those independent expenditure committees haven't always worked out for candidates.""One reason the federal courts over the years have not found a corruption threat at the independent spending is that sometimes it's not that effective in directly advancing a candidate's interest
column16: he says.""A lot of candidates who spend more money than their opponents whether out of their own pocket or let's say supported by major outside groups
column17: their track record in winning elections is not that good to be honest. We've seen a lot of multi-millionaire candidates who are defeated in various races. Now to be sure some are also elected
column18: but by now means is the candidate with the most money spent on their behalf assured of being elected.""Grimes has raised $4.5 million since entering the race last year and been all over the country at fundraisers with big name Democratic donors. She outpaced McConnell's money machine during the third quarter and Democratic-affiliated groups have also spent money attacking McConnell in television ads.The McConnell campaign was quick to point out that while Grimes is criticizing Citizens United
column19: she is also benefiting from attack ads against the senator from outside liberal groups who praise her position.""Like Barack Obama
column20: Alison Lundergan Grimes is obviously much more concerned with political convenience than Constitutional protections
column21: McConnell campaign spokeswoman Allison Moore told WFPL. ""The sad part is that she apparently sees no irony in the fact the special interest group who successfully persuaded her to embrace trampling on our First Amendment rights in the name of money in politics is the same one running hundreds of thousands of dollars of advertising on her behalf.""The top expenditures in 2014 have been super PACs with liberal viewpoints such as Senate Majority PAC
column22: which has slammed McConnell in TV ads.Asked about Grimes' wealthy donors
column23: Donnelly says all elected officials and candidates are implicated but that what lawmakers do in Washington matters.""The real distinction is what are you going to do to clean it up and propose pro-actively to make the system better
column24: he says. ""And on that score voters know in Alison Grimes they have someone who is going to champion the issue and that in Mitch McConnell who is going to make the problem worse."""	0

491	"June 9

TG-162 Treasury Announces $68 Billion in Expected CPP Repayments WASHINGTON Ã¢ÂÂ The U.S. Department of the Treasury announced today that 10 of the largest U.S. financial institutions participating in the Capital Purchase Program (CPP) have met the requirements for repayment established by the primary federal banking supervisors. Following consultation with the primary banking supervisor of each institution
column2: Treasury has notified the institutions that they are now eligible to complete the repayment process. If these firms choose to do so
column3: Treasury will receive $68 billion in repayment proceeds. Combined with repayments received to date from other institutions
column4: Treasury will have received approximately $70 billion in repayments from CPP participants. More than 600 banks across the country have participated in the CPP
column5: representing $199 billion in investments. ""These repayments are an encouraging sign of financial repair
column6: but we still have work to do
column7: said Secretary Tim Geithner. These repayments follow a period in which many banks have successfully raised equity capital from private investors. Also
column8: for the first time in many months
column9: these banks have issued long-term debt that is not guaranteed by the government. Under the CPP investment agreements
column10: firms that repay their preferred stock have the right to repurchase the warrants Treasury holds in their firms at fair market value. In addition to Treasury's potential income from sale of the warrants
column11: these 10 institutions have already paid dividends on the preferred stock totaling approximately $1.8 billion over the last seven months. Dividend payments received for all CPP participants are approximately $4.5 billion to date. Under the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act
column12: proceeds from repayment will be applied to Treasury's general account. These repayments help to reduce Treasury's borrowing and national debt. The repayments also increase Treasury's cushion to respond to any future financial instability that might otherwise jeopardize economic recovery.

492	This is the transcript of the debate between Democratic presidential candidates Sens. Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama on February 21
column2: 2008 at the University of Texas in Austin.

column1: Sens. Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton face off in a high-stakes debate
column2: Thursday night. more photos ÃÂ»

column1: CNN's CAMPBELL BROWN: And the candidates have taken their seats. We are ready to get started. On behalf of CNN
column2: Univision and the candidates
column3: we want to thank our hosts
column4: the University of Texas and the LBJ School and Library.

column1: And now I want to give you an idea of what to expect over the next 90 minutes or so. We want to have a real conversation between these two candidates on the issues important to Texas and the entire nation
column2: so we won't have any hard and fast rules for them to follow. We simply ask the candidates to keep their answers to a reasonable length and to stay on point.

column1: And we have given the candidates the opportunity to make opening statements. The order was determined by a draw. Senator Obama won the draw and elected to go second.
So please go ahead
column2: Senator Clinton.

column1: SEN. HILLARY CLINTON: Well
column2: thank you.

column1: And I am just delighted to be back here in Austin. You know
column2: nearly 36 years ago I came to Austin for my very first political job
column3: and that was registering voters in south Texas. And I had the great privilege of living for a while in Austin and in San Antonio
column4: and meeting people and making friends that have stayed with me for a lifetime.

column1: And I found that we had a lot in common
column2: a lot of shared values
column3: a belief that hard work is important
column4: that self-reliance and individual responsibility count for a lot.

column1: CLINTON: And among the people whom I got to know
column2: who became not only friends
column3: but heroes
column4: were Barbara Jordan
column5: who taught me a lot about courage
column6: and today...

column1: (APPLAUSE)
...would actually be her birthday. I remember all the time about how she got up every single morning
column2: facing almost insurmountable odds
column3: to do what she did.

column1: And another was my great friend Ann Richards
column2: who taught me so much...

column1: (APPLAUSE)
... about determination. Ann was a great champion for the people of Texas. She also reminded us that every so often it is good to have a laugh about what it is we're engaged in.
And as I think back on those years and the work that I've done ever since
column2: you know
column3: for me politics is about making real differences in people's lives. I am very
column4: very proud that over these years I have been able to make a difference in the lives of people in Texas
column5: Ohio and elsewhere.

column1: CLINTON: You know
column3: 000 children in Texas get health care every month because I helped to start the Children's Health Insurance Program.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
And 21
column2: 000 National Guard and Reserve members get access to health care because I went across the party line and joined up with a Republican senator to make that happen.

column1: So there's a lot that we've already done. But there's so much more to do.
I want to take on the tough issues that face us now. I want to stop the health insurance companies from discriminating against people because they're sick. You know
column2: it's unconstitutional to discriminate on the basis of race or gender or ethnic origin or religion
column3: but it's OK to discriminate against sick people.

column1: And we're going to end that
column2: because it's time we said no more.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
And I want to continue the work that I've done in the Senate to take care of our veterans.
CLINTON: It was shocking and shameful
column2: what happened
column3: that we discovered about a year ago at Walter Reed. We can do so much better
column4: to take care of the people who've taken care of us.

column1: And there is a lot of work ahead. I offer a lifetime of experience and proven results. And I know that
column2: if we work together
column3: we can take on the special interests
column4: transfer $55 billion of all those giveaways and subsidies that President Bush has given them
column5: back to the middle class
column6: to create jobs and provide health care and make college affordable.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
And I ask you -- I ask you to join in my campaign. It's now up to the people of Texas
column2: Ohio
column3: and the other states ahead.

column1: So
column2: if you'll be part of this campaign
column3: which is your really your campaign
column4: about your futures
column5: your families
column6: your jobs and your health care
column7: we'll continue to make a difference for America.

column1: Thank you all very much.
(APPLAUSE)
BROWN: Senator Clinton
column2: thank you.

column1: BROWN: Senator Obama?
(APPLAUSE)
SEN. BARACK OBAMA: First of all
column2: thank you so much to the University of Texas for hosting us
column3: and it's a great honor to share the stage once again with Senator Clinton. I've said before that we've been friends before this campaign started; we'll be friends afterwards
column4: unified to bring about changes in this country.

column1: You know
column2: we are at a defining moment in our history. Our nation is at war
column3: and our economy is increasingly in shambles. And the families of Texas and all across America are feeling the brunt of that failing economy.

column1: This week
column2: I met a couple in San Antonio
column3: who -- as a consequence of entering into a predatory loan -- are on the brink of foreclosure and are actually seeing them having to cut back on their medical expenses
column4: because their mortgage doubled in two weeks.

column1: OBAMA: I've met a young woman who gets three hours of sleep a night because she has to work the night shift even as she's going to school full time
column2: and still can't afford to provide the health care for her sister who's ill.

column1: In Youngstown
column2: Ohio
column3: talked to workers who have seen their plants shipped overseas as a consequence of bad trade deals like NAFTA
column4: literally seeing equipment unbolted from the floors of factories and shipped to China
column5: resulting in devastating job losses and communities completely falling apart.

column1: And all across America I'm meeting not just veterans
column2: but also the parents of those who have fallen.

column1: One mother in Green Bay gave me this bracelet in memory of a 20- year-old son who had been killed in a roadside bomb
column2: as a consequence of a war that I believe should have never been authorized and should have never been waged and has cost us billions of dollars that could have been invested here in the United States in roads and bridges and infrastructure and making sure that young people can go to college and that those who need health care actually get it.

column1: OBAMA: Now
column2: Senator Clinton...

column1: (APPLAUSE)

... Senator Clinton and I have been talking about these issues for the last 13 months. We both offer detailed proposals to try to deal with them. Some of them are the same. Some we have differences of opinion.

But I think we both recognize that these problems have to be dealt with and that we have seen an administration over the last seven years that has failed to address them and -- in many ways -- has made them worse.
But understand that what is lacking right now is not good ideas.
OBAMA: The problem we have is that Washington has become a place where good ideas go to die. They go to die because the lobbyists...
(APPLAUSE)

They go to die because lobbyists and special interests have a strangle-hold on the agenda in Washington. They go to die in Washington because too many politicians are interested in scoring political points rather than bridging differences in order to get things done.
And so the central premise of this campaign is that we can bring this country together
column2: that we can push against the special interests that have come to dominate the agenda in Washington
column3: that we can be straight with the American people about how we're going to solve these problems and enlist them in taking back their government.

column1: You know
column2: Senator Clinton mentioned Barbara Jordan
column3: somebody who was an inspiration to me and so many people throughout the country. And she said that what the American people want is very simple: They want an America that is as good as its promise.

column1: OBAMA: I'm running for president because I want to help America be as good as its promise.
Thank you very much.
(APPLAUSE)
BROWN: All right
column2: Senator Obama
column3: thank you
column4: and let's begin with questions.

column1: Jorge Ramos?
UNIVISION's JORGE RAMOS: Thank you very much (SPEAKING IN SPANISH).
Thank you so much for being with us
column2: and let me start with a little news. After nearly half a century in office
column3: Fidel Castro resigned as the head of the Cuban government. Ninety miles off the coast of the United States
column4: we might have a new opportunity.

column1: The question for you
column2: Senator Clinton: Would you be willing to sit down with Raul Castro
column3: or whoever leads the Cuban dictatorship when you take office at least just once
column4: to get a measure of the man?

column1: CLINTON: Well
column2: Jorge
column3: I hope we have an opportunity. The people of Cuba deserve to have a democracy. And this gives the Cuban government
column4: under Raul Castro
column5: a chance to change direction from the one that was set for 50 years by his brother.

column1: I'm going to be looking for some of those changes: releasing political prisoner
column2: ending some of the oppressive practices on the press
column3: opening up the economy.

column1: Of course the United States stands ready. And
column2: as president
column3: I would be ready to reach out and work with a new Cuban government
column4: once it demonstrated that it truly was going to change that direction.

column1: I want to bring the region together
column2: our European allies who have influence with Cuba
column3: to try to push for some of those changes
column4: and to make it very clear that
column5: if Cuba moves toward democracy and freedom for its people
column6: the United States will welcome that.

column1: CLINTON: And as president
column2: I would look for opportunities to try to make that happen and to create the momentum that might eventually lead to a presidential visit.

column1: But there has to be evidence that indeed the changes are real; that they are taking place; and that the Cuban people will finally be given an opportunity to have their future determined by themselves.
RAMOS: Very simply
column2: would you meet with him or not
column3: with Raul Castro?

column1: CLINTON: I would not meet with him until there was evidence that change was happening
column2: because I think it's important that they demonstrate clearly that they are committed to change the direction. Then I think
column3: you know
column4: something like diplomatic encounters and negotiations over specifics could take place.

column1: But we've had this conversation before
column2: Senator Obama and myself
column3: and I believe that we should have full diplomatic engagement where appropriate. But a presidential visit should not be offered and given without some evidence that it will demonstrate the kind of progress that is in our interest
column4: and in this case
column5: in the interests of the Cuban people.

column1: BROWN: Senator Obama
column2: just to follow up
column3: you had said in a previous CNN debate that you would meet with the leaders of Cuban
column4: Iran
column5: North Korea
column6: among others
column7: so presumably you would be willing to meet with the new leader of Cuba.

column1: OBAMA: That's correct. Now
column2: keep in mind that the starting point for our policy in Cuba should be the liberty of the Cuban people. And I think we recognize that that liberty has not existed throughout the Castro regime. And we now have an opportunity to potentially change the relationship between the United States and Cuba after over half a century.

column1: I would meet without preconditions
column2: although Senator Clinton is right that there has to be preparation. It is very important for us to make sure that there was an agenda
column3: and on that agenda was human rights
column4: releasing of political prisoners
column5: opening up the press. And that preparation might take some time.

column1: But I do think that it's important for the United States not just to talk to its friends
column2: but also to talk to its enemies. In fact
column3: that's where diplomacy makes the biggest difference.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
OBAMA: One other thing that I've said
column2: as a show of good faith that we're interested in pursuing potentially a new relationship
column3: what I've called for is a loosening of the restrictions on remittances from family members to the people of Cuba
column4: as well as travel restrictions for family members who want to visit their family members in Cuba.

column1: And I think that initiating that change in policy as a start and then suggesting that an agenda get set up is something that could be useful
column2: but I would not normalize relations until we started seeing some of the progress that Senator Clinton was talking about.

column1: BROWN: But that's different from your position back in 2003. You called U.S. policy toward Cuba a miserable failure
column2: and you supported normalizing relations.

column1: BROWN: So you've backtracked now...
OBAMA: I support the eventual normalization. And it's absolutely true that I think our policy has been a failure. I mean
column2: the fact is
column3: is that during my entire lifetime
column4: and Senator Clinton's entire lifetime
column5: you essentially have seen a Cuba that has been isolated
column6: but has not made progress when it comes to the issues of political rights and personal freedoms that are so important to the people of Cuba.

column1: So I think that we have to shift policy. I think our goal has to be ultimately normalization. But that's going to happen in steps. And the first step
column2: as I said
column3: is changing our rules with respect to remittances and with respect to travel.

column1: And then I think it is important for us to have the direct contact
column2: not just in Cuba
column3: but I think this principle applies generally. I recall what John F. Kennedy once said
column4: that we should never negotiate out of fear
column5: but we should never fear to negotiate. And this moment
column6: this opportunity when Fidel Castro has finally stepped down
column7: I think
column8: is one that we should try to take advantage of.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BROWN: Senator Clinton
column2: do you want a quick response?

column1: CLINTON: Well
column2: I agree
column3: absolutely
column4: that we should be willing to have diplomatic negotiations and processes with anyone. I've been a strong advocate of opening up such a diplomatic process with Iran
column5: for a number of years.

column1: Because I think we should look for ways that we can possibly move countries that are adversarial to us
column2: you know
column3: toward the world community. It's in our interests. It's in the interests of the people in countries that
column4: frankly
column5: are oppressed
column6: like Cuba
column7: like Iran.

column1: But there has been this difference between us over when and whether the president should offer a meeting
column2: without preconditions
column3: with those with whom we do not have diplomatic relations. And it should be part of a process
column4: but I don't think it should be offered in the beginning. Because I think that undermines the capacity for us to actually take the measure of somebody like Raul Castro or Ahmadinejad and others.

column1: CLINTON: And
column2: as President Kennedy said
column3: he wouldn't be afraid to negotiate
column4: but he would expect there to be a lot of preparatory work done
column5: to find out exactly what we would get out of it.

column1: And therefore
column2: I do think we should be eliminating the policy of the Bush administration
column3: which has been very narrowly defined
column4: and frankly against our interests
column5: because we have failed to reach out to countries
column6: we have alienated our friends
column7: and we have emboldened our enemies.

column1: So I would get back to very vigorous diplomacy
column2: and I would use bipartisan diplomacy. I would ask emissaries from both political parties to represent me and our country
column3: because I want to send a very clear message to the rest of the world that the era of unilateralism
column4: preemption and arrogance of the Bush administration is over and we're going to...

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BROWN: Very briefly and then we're going to move on.
(APPLAUSE)
OBAMA: I think
column2: as I said before
column3: preparation is actually absolutely critical in any meeting. And I think it is absolutely true that either of us would step back from some of the Bush unilateralism that's caused so much damage.

column1: But I do think it is important precisely because the Bush administration has done so much damage to American foreign relations that the president take a more active role in diplomacy than might have been true 20 or 30 years ago.
Because the problem is
column2: if we think that meeting with the president is a privilege that has to be earned
column3: I think that reinforces the sense that we stand above the rest of the world at this point in time. And I think that it's important for us in undoing the damage that has been done over the last seven years
column4: for the president to be willing to take that extra step.

column1: OBAMA: That is the kind of step that I would like to take as president of the United States.
(APPLAUSE)
BROWN: A question now on the economy.
John King?
CNN's JOHN KING: Campbell
column2: Senators
column3: good evening
column4: first.

column1: I want to bring the conversation back home. You know from your travels -- you don't need to look at the polls or anything else -- that the economy is by far now the dominant issue that voters want to hear about from the candidates.
For some
column2: that is a question about: What should we do about an economy that is at the edge or perhaps in the early stages of a recession? For some
column3: it is more focused. Maybe it is: Will you raise the minimum wage? Maybe it's about trade deals that they think leave them on the raw end
column4: as you mentioned in your opening statement
column5: Senator Obama.

column1: But when we ask Democrats
column2: ""How are these two candidates different?
column3: they even think they don't know.

column1: Senator Obama
column2: beginning with you
column3: tell us as specifically as you can
column4: how would a President Obama be different than a President Clinton in managing the nation's economy?

column1: OBAMA: Well
column2: first of all
column3: let me emphasize the point that you just made
column4: which is: You don't need an economist or the Federal Reserve to tell the American people that the economy's in trouble
column5: because they've been experiencing it for years now.

column1: Everywhere you go
column2: you meet people who are working harder for less
column3: wages and incomes have flatlined
column4: people are seeing escalating costs of everything from health care to gas at the pump.

column1: And so people have been struggling for a long time. In some communities
column2: they have been struggling for decades now. So this has to be a priority of the next president.

column1: Now
column2: what I've said is that we have to restore a sense of fairness and balance to our economy
column3: and that means a couple of things.

column1: Number one
column2: with our tax code: We've got to stop giving tax breaks to companies that are shipping jobs overseas and invest those tax breaks in companies that are investing here in the United States of America.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
We have to end the Bush tax cuts to the wealthy...
(APPLAUSE)
... and to provide tax breaks to middle-class Americans and working Americans who need them.
OBAMA: So I've said that if you are making $75
column2: 000 a year or less
column3: I want to give an offset to your payroll tax that will mean $1
column4: 000 extra in the pockets of ordinary Americans. Senior citizens making less than $50
column6: you shouldn't have to pay income tax on your Social Security.

column1: We pay for these by closing tax loopholes and tax havens that are being manipulated.
(APPLAUSE)
On our trade deals
column2: I think it is absolutely critical that we engaged in trade
column3: but it has to be viewed not just through the lens of Wall Street
column4: but also Main Street
column5: which means we've got strong labor standards and strong environmental standards and safety standards
column6: so we don't have toys being shipped in the United States with lead paint on them.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
So these are all issues that I've talked about repeatedly
column2: and I think there are also opportunities in our economy around creating a green economy. We send $1 billion to foreign countries every day because of our addiction to foreign oil.

column1: OBAMA: And for us to move rapidly to cap greenhouse gases
column2: generate billions of dollars that we can reinvest in solar and wind and biodiesel -- that can put people back to work. So...

column1: (APPLAUSE)
Now
column2: I don't want to take too much time. And I'm sure we'll be spend more time discussing this.

column1: Senator Clinton and I
column2: I think
column3: both agree on many of these issues. And I think it's a credit to the Democratic Party as a whole that the other candidates who were involved earlier on agreed with us on many of these issues.

column1: I think that there is a real
column2: solid agenda for moving change forward in the next presidency.

column1: The question people are going to have to ask is: How do we get it done?

And it is my strong belief that the changes are only going to come about if we're able to form a working coalition for change. Because people who were benefiting from the current tax code are going to resist. The special interests and lobbyists are going to resist.
And I think it has to be a priority for whoever the next president is to be able to overcome the dominance of the special interests in Washington
column2: to bring about the kinds of economic changes that I'm talking about.

column1: OBAMA: And that's an area where Senator Clinton and I may have a slight difference. But I'm happy to let her speak first and then can pick up on anything that's been left out.
KING: Let's give Senator Clinton that opportunity then.
(APPLAUSE)
As you have campaigned
column2: Senator
column3: on this issue and others
column4: but specifically on this issue
column5: you have said
column6: ""I am ready on day one to take charge of the economy.""

column1: The clear implication
column2: since you have one opponent at the moment
column3: is that you're ready; he's not.

column1: What would you do differently on day one than a President Obama would when it comes to managing the nation's economy?
CLINTON: Well
column2: I would agree with a lot that Senator Obama just said
column3: because it is the Democratic agenda.

column1: CLINTON: We are going to rid the tax code of these loopholes and giveaways.
We're going to stop giving a penny of your money to anybody who ships a job out of Texas
column2: Ohio or anywhere else to another country.

column1: We're certainly going to begin to get the tax code to reflect what the needs of middle class families are so we can rebuild a strong and prosperous middle class.
You know
column2: the wealthy and the well-connected have had a president the last seven years
column3: and I think it's time that the rest of America had a president to work for you every single day.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
We will also have a different approach toward trade.
We're going to start having trade agreements that not only have strong environmental and labor standards
column2: but I want to have a trade time-out. We're going to look and see what's working and what's not working
column3: and I'd like to have a trade prosecutor to actually enforce the trade agreements that we have before we enter into any others.

column1: We're also going to put much tougher standards in place so that people cannot import toys with lead paint
column2: contaminated pet food
column3: contaminated drugs into our market. We're going to have much more vigorous enforcement of safety standards.

column1: CLINTON: Now
column2: in addition
column3: there are steps I would take immediately. One is on this foreclosure crisis. I have been saying for nearly a year we had to crack down on the abusive practices of the lenders. But we also need a moratorium on home foreclosures.

column1: Everywhere I go
column2: I meet people who either have been or about to lose their home. 85
column3: 000 homes in foreclosure in Texas; 90
column4: 000 in Ohio. I've met the families: the hairdresser
column5: the single mom who's going to lose her home
column6: the postal worker who got really hoodwinked into an agreement that wasn't fair to him.

column1: So I would put a moratorium for 90 days
column2: to give us time to work out a way for people to stay in their homes
column3: and I would freeze interest rates for five years. Because these adjustable-rate mortgages
column4: if they keep going up
column5: millions of Americans are going to be homeless. And vacant homes will be across the neighborhoods of Texas and America.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
CLINTON: Now
column2: in addition
column3: there are three ways we need to jump start the economy.

column1: Clean green jobs; I've been promoting this. I wanted it to be part of the stimulus package. I thought a $5 billion investment in clean green jobs would put hundreds of thousands of Americans to work helping to create our future.
We also need to invest in our infrastructure. We don't have enough roads to take care of the congestion
column2: we have crumbling bridges and tunnels. We need to rebuild America
column3: and that will also put people to work.

column1: And
column2: finally
column3: we need to end George Bush's war on science
column4: which has been waged against scientists and researchers...

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BROWN: Thank you
column2: Senator. And we've got a lot of ground to cover...

column1: CLINTON: This is about how we fund the future. We've got to get back to being the innovation nation. Think of everything that goes on at this great university to create the new economy...
(APPLAUSE)
BROWN: All right. Senator Clinton
column2: thank you very much.

column1: BROWN: And
column2: as I was saying
column3: we've got a lot to get through. So I do want to shift gears and go on to another topic especially important here in Texas
column4: which is immigration.

column1: And
column2: Jorge
column3: you have a question.

column1: RAMOS: (SPEAKING IN SPANISH) Federal raids by immigration enforcement officials on homes and businesses have generated a great deal of fear and anxiety in the Hispanic community and have divided the family of some of the 3 million U.S.-born children who have at least one undocumented parent.
Would you consider stopping these raids once you take office until comprehensive immigration reform can be passed?
CLINTON: I would consider that
column2: except in egregious situations where it would be appropriate to take the actions you're referring to.

column1: But when we see what's been happening
column2: with literally babies being left with no one to take care of them
column3: children coming home from school
column4: no responsible adult left
column5: that is not the America that I know.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
CLINTON: That is against American values. And it is...
(APPLAUSE)

And it is a stark admission of failure by the federal government. We need comprehensive immigration reform. I have been for this. I signed onto the first comprehensive bill back in 2004. I've been advocating for it: tougher
column2: more secure borders
column3: of course
column4: but let's do it the right way
column5: cracking down on employers
column6: especially once we get to comprehensive immigration reform
column7: who exploit undocumented workers and drive down wages for everyone else.

column1: I'd like to see more federal help for communities like Austin and others like Laredo
column2: where I was this morning
column3: that absorb the health care
column4: education
column5: and law enforcement costs.

column1: And I personally
column2: as president
column3: would work with our neighbors to the south
column4: to help them create more jobs for their own people.

column1: Finally
column2: we need a path to legalization
column3: to bring the immigrants out of the shadows
column4: give them the conditions that we expect them to meet
column5: paying a fine for coming here illegally
column6: trying to pay back taxes
column7: over time
column8: and learning English.

column1: If they had a committed a crime in our country or the country they came from
column2: then they should be deported. But for everyone else
column3: there must be a path to legalization. I would introduce that in the first 100 days of my presidency.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BROWN: Senator Obama
column2: is your position the same as Hillary Clinton's?

column1: OBAMA: There are a couple of things I would add. Comprehensive immigration reform is something that I have worked on extensively.
Two years ago
column2: we were able to get a bill out of the Senate. I was one of the group of senators that helped to move it through
column3: but it died in the House this year. Because it was used as a political football instead of a way of solving a problem
column4: nothing happened.

column1: And so there are a couple of things that I would just add to what Senator Clinton said.
Number one
column2: it is absolutely critical that we tone down the rhetoric when it comes to the immigration debate
column3: because there has been an undertone that has been ugly.

column1: Oftentimes
column2: it has been directed at the Hispanic community. We have seen hate crimes skyrocket in the wake of the immigration debate as it has been conducted in Washington
column3: and that is unacceptable.

column1: We are a nation of laws and we are a nation of immigrants
column2: and we can reconcile those two things. So we need comprehensive reform...

column1: (APPLAUSE)
... we need comprehensive reform
column2: and that means stronger border security. It means that we are cracking down on employers that are taking advantage of undocumented workers because they can't complain if they're not paid a minimum wage.

column1: OBAMA: They can't complain if they're not getting overtime. Worker safety laws are not being observed.
We have to crack down on those employers
column2: although we also have to make sure that we do it in a way that doesn't lead to people with Spanish surnames being discriminated against
column3: so there's got to be a safeguard there.

column1: We have to require that undocumented workers
column2: who are provided a pathway to citizenship
column3: not only learn English
column4: pay back taxes and pay a significant fine
column5: but also that they're going to the back of the line
column6: so that they are not getting citizenship before those who have applied legally
column7: which raises two last points.

column1: Number one
column2: it is important that we fix the legal immigration system
column3: because right now we've got a backlog that means years for people to apply legally.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
And what's worse is
column2: we keep on increasing the fees
column3: so that if you've got a hard working immigrant family
column4: they've got to hire a lawyer; they've got to pay thousands of dollars in fees. They just can't afford it. And it's discriminatory against people who have good character
column5: we should want in this country
column6: but don't have the money. So we've got to fix that.

column1: OBAMA: So we've got to fix that.
The second thing is
column2: we have to improve our relationship with Mexico and work with the Mexican government so that their economy is producing jobs on that side of the border.

column1: And the problem that we have...
(APPLAUSE)
The problem that we have is that we have had an administration that came in promising all sorts of leadership on creating a U.S.- Mexican relationship. And
column2: frankly
column3: President Bush dropped the ball. He has been so obsessed with Iraq that we have not seen the kinds of outreach and cooperative work that would ensure that the Mexican economy is working not just for the very wealthy in Mexico
column4: but for all people. And that's as policy that I'm going to change when I'm president of the United States.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BROWN: All right
column2: Senator Obama.

column1: We're going to stay with this topic. I want to have John King ask another question.
Go ahead
column2: John.

column1: KING: I want to stay on the issue
column2: but move to a controversial item that was not held up when the immigration debate collapsed in Washington
column3: and that is the border fence.

column1: KING: To many Americans
column2: it is a simple question of sovereignty and security. America should be able to keep people out that it doesn't want in.

column1: But
column2: as you know in this state
column3: especially if you go to the south of here
column4: along the border
column5: and in other border states
column6: to many people it's a much more personal question. It could be a question of their livelihood. It could be a question of cross-border trade. It might be an issue to a rancher of property rights. It might be a simple question of whether someone can take a walk or a short drive to see their family members.

column1: Senator
column2: back in 2006
column3: you voted for the construction of that fence. As you know
column4: progress has been slow.

column1: As president of the United States
column2: would you commit tonight that you would finish the fence and speed up the construction
column3: or do you think it's time for a president of the United States to raise his or her hand and say
column4: ""You know what? Wait a minute. Let's think about this again. Do we really want to do this?""

column1: CLINTON: Well
column2: I think both Senator Obama and I voted for that as part of the immigration debate.

column1: CLINTON: And having been along the border for the last week or so -- in fact
column2: last night I was at the University of Texas at Brownsville -- and this is how absurd this has become under the Bush administration. Because
column3: you know
column4: there is a smart way to protect our borders
column5: and there is a dumb way to protect our borders.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
And what I learned last night when I was there with Congressman Ortiz is that the University of Texas at Brownsville would have part of its campus cut off.

This is the kind of absurdity that we're getting from this administration. I know it because I've been fighting with them about the northern border. Their imposition of passports and other kinds of burdens are separating people from families
column2: interfering with business and commerce
column3: the movement of goods and people.

column1: So what I've said is that I would say
column2: wait a minute
column3: we need to review this. There may be places where a physical barrier is appropriate.

column1: I think when both of us voted for this
column2: we were voting for the possibility that where it was appropriate and made sense
column3: it would be considered. But as with so much
column4: the Bush administration has gone off the deep end
column5: and they are unfortunately coming up with a plan that I think is counterproductive.

column1: CLINTON: So I would have a review. I would listen to the people who live along the border
column2: who understand...

column1: (APPLAUSE)
... what it is we need to be doing to protect our country.
(APPLAUSE)
BROWN: Let me go on
column2: again -- John?

column1: KING: Does that mean that you"	0
