MRS. OBAMA: Oh
column2: wow. (Applause.) Wow. It sounds like you all are already fired up and ready to go. (Applause.) This is amazing. It is truly amazing. And you know what
column3: being here with all of you today
column4: let me tell you
column5: I'm feeling pretty fired up and ready to go myself. I really am. (Applause.)

column1: But thereÃ¢ÂÂs a reason why we're here today --
AUDIENCE: I love you! (Applause.)
MRS. OBAMA: And we love you
column2: too. And it's not just because we support one extraordinary man -- although
column3: I'll admit
column4: I'm a little biased because I think our President is awesome. (Laughter and applause.)

column1: And it's not just because we want to win an election. We are here because of the values we believe in. We're here because of the vision for this country that we all share. We're here because we want all our children to have a good education
column2: right? (Applause.) Schools that push them and inspire them
column3: prepare them for good jobs. We want our parents and our grandparents to retire with dignity -- (applause) -- because we believe that after a lifetime of hard work
column4: they should enjoy their golden years.

column1: We want to restore that basic middle-class security for our families because we believe that folks shouldn't go bankrupt because they get sick. (Applause.) They shouldn't lose their home because someone loses a job. We believe that responsibility should be rewarded and hard work should pay off.
And truly
column2: these are basic American values. They're the same values that so many of us were raised with
column3: including myself. You see
column4: my father was a blue-collar city worker at the city water plant. And my family lived in a little bitty apartment on the South Side of Chicago. And neither of my parents had the chance to go to college. But let me tell you what my parents did do: They saved. They sacrificed. I mean
column5: they poured everything they had into me and my brother. They wanted us to have the kind of education they could only dream of. And while pretty much all of my college tuition came from student loans and grants
column6: my dad still paid a little bitty portion of that tuition himself. And let me tell you
column7: every semester
column8: my dad was determined to pay that bill right on time because he was so proud to be sending his kids to college. (Applause.)

column1: And he couldn't bear the thought of me or my brother missing that registration deadline because his check was late. Like so many people in this country
column2: my father took great pride in being able to earn a living that allowed him to handle his responsibility to his family
column3: to pay all of his bills and to pay them on time.

column1: And truly
column2: more than anything else
column3: that is what's at stake. It's that fundamental promise that no matter who you are or how you started out
column4: if you work hard
column5: you can build a decent life for yourself and yes
column6: an even better life for your kids. (Applause.)

column1: And it is that promise that binds us together as Americans. It's what makes us who we are. And whether it's equal pay for women
column2: or health care for our kids; whether it's tax cuts for middle-class families or student loans for our young people -- (applause) -- that is what my husband has been fighting for every single day as President. Every single day. (Applause.)

column1: And let me tell you something -- as First Lady
column2: I have had the chance to see up close and personal what being President looks like
column3: right? I have seen how the issues that come across the PresidentÃ¢ÂÂs desk are always the hard ones.

column1: AUDIENCE MEMBER: YouÃ¢ÂÂre beautiful
column2: Michelle! (Applause.)

column1: MRS. OBAMA: But in all seriousness -- (laughter) -- these problems
column2: theyÃ¢ÂÂre always the hard ones -- the problems with no clear solutions
column3: the judgment calls where the stakes are so high and there is no margin for error. And as President
column4: you can get all kinds of advice from all kinds of people. But at the end of the day
column5: when it comes time to make that decision
column6: all you have to guide you are your life experiences
column7: your values
column8: and your vision for this country. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs all you have. In the end
column9: when youÃ¢ÂÂre making those impossible choices
column10: it all boils down to who you are and what you stand for.

column1: And we all know what Barack Obama is -- who he is. (Applause.) We all know what our President stands for
column2: right? (Applause.) He is the son of a single mother who struggled to put herself through school and pay the bills. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs who he is. HeÃ¢ÂÂs the grandson of a woman who woke up before dawn every day to catch a bus to her job at the bank. And even though BarackÃ¢ÂÂs grandmother worked hard to help support his family
column3: she was good at her job. Like so many women
column4: she hit that glass ceiling. And men no more qualified than she was were promoted up the ladder ahead of her.

column1: So believe me
column2: Barack knows what it means when a family struggles. He knows what it means when someone doesnÃ¢ÂÂt have a chance to fulfill their potential. And what you need to know
column3: America -- those are the experiences that have made him the man and the President he is today. (Applause.)

column1: But I have said this before and will say it again and again: Barack cannot do this alone. And fortunately
column2: he never has. We have always moved this country forward together. And today
column3: more than ever before
column4: Barack needs your help. He needs your help. He needs your help. (Applause.) He needs every single one of you -- every single one of you to give just a little part of your life each week to this campaign.

column1: He needs you to register those voters. (Applause.) And to all of the college students out there
column2: all of you -- if you're going to be moving over the summer
column3: remember to register at your new address in the fall. You got that? Get that done. (Applause.)

column1: Barack needs you to join one of our neighborhood teams and start organizing in your community. And just let me say
column2: if there have ever been any doubt about the difference that you can make
column3: I just want you to remember that in the end
column4: this all could come down to those few thousand people who register to vote. Think about it. It could all come down to those last few thousand folks who get out to the polls on November the 6th.

column1: And when you average that out over this entire state
column2: it might mean registering just one more person in your town. It might mean helping just one more person in your community get out and vote on Election Day. So know this: With every door you knock on
column3: with every call you make
column4: with every conversation you have
column5: I want you to remember that this could be the one that makes the difference. This could be the one. (Applause.) Remember that. That is exactly the kind of impact that each of you can have.

column1: Now
column2: I am not going to kid you. This journey is going to be long. And it is going to be hard. But know that that is how change always happens in this country. And if we keep showing up
column3: if we keep fighting the good fight
column4: then eventually we get there. We always do. Maybe not in our lifetimes
column5: but maybe in our children's lifetimes
column6: maybe in our grandchildren's lifetimes -- because in the end
column7: that's what this is all about.

column1: That is what I think about when I tuck my girls in at night. I think about the world I want to leave for them and for all of our sons and our daughters. I think about how I want to do for them what my dad did for me. I want to give them a foundation for their dreams. (Applause.) I want to give them opportunities worthy of their promise. I want to give them that sense of limitless possibility
column2: that belief that here in America
column3: there is always something better out there if you're willing to work for it. So we just cannot turn back now
column4: right?

column1: AUDIENCE: No!
MRS. OBAMA: We have come so far
column2: but we have so much more to do. And if we want to keep on moving forward then we need to work our hearts out for the man that I have the pleasure of introducing here today. (Applause.) Are you ready?

column1: It is my privilege to introduce my husband and our President
column2: President Barack Obama!

column1: THE PRESIDENT: Hello
column2: Ohio! (Applause.) It is good to be back in Ohio! (Applause.) Right before I came out
column3: somebody happened to give me a buckeye for good luck. (Applause.)

column1: AUDIENCE MEMBER: I love you!
THE PRESIDENT: I love you back! Now
column2: before I begin
column3: I want to say thank you to a few people who are joining us here today. Your mayor
column4: Michael Coleman is here. (Applause.) Former Governor Ted Strickland is here. (Applause.) Senator Sherrod Brown is in the house. (Applause.) An American hero
column5: John Glenn is with us. (Applause.)

column1: And I want to thank so many of our Neighborhood Team Leaders for being here today. You guys will be the backbone of this campaign. (Applause.) And I want the rest of you to join a team or become a leader yourself
column2: because we are going to win this thing the old-fashioned way -- door by door
column3: block by block
column4: neighborhood by neighborhood. (Applause.)

column1: Ohio
column2: four years ago
column3: you and I began a journey together.

column1: I didnÃ¢ÂÂt run
column2: and you didnÃ¢ÂÂt work your hearts out
column3: just to win an election. We came together to reclaim the basic bargain that built the largest middle class and the most prosperous nation on Earth.

column1: We came together because we believe that in America
column2: your success shouldnÃ¢ÂÂt be determined by the circumstances of your birth. If youÃ¢ÂÂre willing to work hard
column3: you should be able to find a good job. If youÃ¢ÂÂre willing to meet your responsibilities
column4: you should be able to own a home
column5: maybe start a business
column6: give your children the chance to do even better -- no matter who you are
column7: or where you come from
column8: or what you look like
column9: or what your last name is. (Applause.)

column1: We believe the free market is one of the greatest forces for progress in human history; that businesses are the engine of growth; that risk-takers and innovators should be rewarded. But we also believe that at its best
column2: the free market has never been a license to take whatever you want
column3: however you can get it; that alongside our entrepreneurial spirit and our rugged individualism
column4: America only prospers when we meet our obligations to one another and to future generations. (Applause.)

column1: We came together in 2008 because our country had strayed from these basic values. A record surplus was squandered on tax cuts for people who didnÃ¢ÂÂt need them and werenÃ¢ÂÂt even asking for them. Two wars were being waged on a credit card. Wall Street speculators reaped huge profits by making bets with other peopleÃ¢ÂÂs money. Manufacturing left our shores. A shrinking number of Americans did fantastically well
column2: while most people struggled with falling incomes
column3: rising costs
column4: the slowest job growth in half a century.

column1: It was ahouse of cards that collapsed in the most destructive crisis since the Great Depression. In the last six months of 2008
column2: even as we were campaigning
column3: nearly three million of our neighbors lost their jobs. Over 800
column4: 000 more were lost in the month I took office alone.

column1: It was tough. But I tell you what
column2: Ohio -- the American people are tougher. (Applause.) All across this country
column3: people like you dug in. Some of you retrained. Some of you went back to school. Small business owners cut back on expenses
column4: but did everything they could to keep their employees. Yes
column5: there were setbacks. Yes
column6: there were disappointments. But we didnÃ¢ÂÂt quit. We donÃ¢ÂÂt quit. Together
column7: weÃ¢ÂÂre fighting our way back. (Applause.)

column1: When some wanted to let Detroit go bankrupt
column2: we made a bet on American workers
column3: on the ingenuity of American companies. And today
column4: our auto industry is back on top of the world. (Applause.) Manufacturers started investing again
column5: adding jobs for the first time since the 1990s. Businesses got back to the basics
column6: exports surged. And over four million jobs were created in the last two years -- more than one million of those in the last six months alone. (Applause.) Are we satisfied?

column1: AUDIENCE: No!
THE PRESIDENT: Of course not. Too many of our friends and family are still out there looking for work. The housing market is still weak
column2: deficits are still too high
column3: and states are still laying off teachers
column4: first responders. This crisis took years to develop
column5: and the economy is still facing headwinds. And it will take sustained
column6: persistent effort -- yours and mine -- for America to fully recover. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs the truth. We all know it.

column1: But we are making progress. And now we face a choice. (Applause.) Now we face a choice
column2: Ohio.

column1: CHILD: We love you
column2: Barack Obama!

column1: AUDIENCE: Awww --
THE PRESIDENT: (Laughter.) Thank you. Now we face a choice. For the last few years
column2: the Republicans who run this Congress have insisted that we go right back to the policies that created this mess.

column1: AUDIENCE: Booo --
THE PRESIDENT: But to borrow a line from my friend Bill Clinton
column2: now their agenda is on steroids. (Applause.) This time
column3: they want even bigger tax cuts for the wealthiest Americans. This time
column4: they want even deeper cuts to things like education and Medicare
column5: and research and technology.

column1: AUDIENCE: Booo --
THE PRESIDENT: This time
column2: they want to give banks and insurance companies even more power to do as they please. And now
column3: after a long and spirited primary
column4: Republicans in Congress have found a nominee for President who has promised to rubber-stamp this agenda if he gets the chance.

column1: AUDIENCE: Booo --
THE PRESIDENT: Ohio
column2: I tell you what: We cannot give him that chance. (Applause.) Not now. Not with so much at stake. This is not just another election. This is a make-or-break moment for the middle class
column3: and weÃ¢ÂÂve been through too much to turn back now. (Applause.)

column1: AUDIENCE: Four more years! Four more years!
THE PRESIDENT: We have come too far to abandon the change we fought for these past few years. We have to move forward
column2: to the future we imagined in 2008
column3: where everyone gets a fair shot
column4: and everyone does their fair share
column5: and everyone plays by the same rules. (Applause.) ThatÃ¢ÂÂs the choice in this election
column6: and thatÃ¢ÂÂs why IÃ¢ÂÂm running for a second term as President of the United States. (Applause.)

column1: Governor Romney is a patriotic American who has raised a wonderful family
column2: and he has much to be proud of. HeÃ¢ÂÂs run a large financial firm
column3: and heÃ¢ÂÂs run a state. But I think he has drawn the wrong lessons from those experiences. He sincerely believes that if CEOs and wealthy investors like him make money
column4: the rest of us will automatically prosper as well.

column1: AUDIENCE: Booo --
THE PRESIDENT: When a woman in Iowa shared the story of her financial struggles
column2: he responded with economic theory. He told her
column3: Ã¢ÂÂour productivity equals our income.Ã¢ÂÂ Well
column4: let me tell you something. The problem with our economy isnÃ¢ÂÂt that the American people arenÃ¢ÂÂt productive enough -- youÃ¢ÂÂve been working harder than ever. (Applause.) The challenge we face right now -- the challenge we faced for over a decade is that harder work hasnÃ¢ÂÂt led to higher incomes. ItÃ¢ÂÂs that bigger profits havenÃ¢ÂÂt led to better jobs. (Applause.)

column1: Governor Romney doesnÃ¢ÂÂt seem to get that. He doesnÃ¢ÂÂt seem to understand that maximizing profits by whatever means necessary -- whether through layoffs or outsourcing or tax avoidance or union-busting -- might not always be good for the average American or for the American economy.

Why else would he want to spend trillions more on tax cuts for the wealthiest Americans? Why else would he propose cutting his own taxes while raising them on 18 million working families? Why else would he want to slash the investments that have always helped the economy grow
column2: but at the same time
column3: stop regulating the reckless behavior on Wall Street that helped the economy crash?

column1: Somehow
column2: he and his friends in Congress think that the same bad ideas will lead to a different result. Or theyÃ¢ÂÂre just hoping you wonÃ¢ÂÂt remember what happened the last time we tried it their way.

column1: Well
column2: Ohio
column3: IÃ¢ÂÂm here to say that we were there
column4: we remember
column5: and we are not going back. We are moving this country forward. (Applause.)

column1: Look
column2: we want businesses to succeed. We want entrepreneurs and investors rewarded when they take risks
column3: when they create jobs and grow our economy. But the true measure of our prosperity is more than just a running tally of every balance sheet and quarterly profit report. I donÃ¢ÂÂt care how many ways you try to explain it: Corporations arenÃ¢ÂÂt people. People are people. (Applause.)

column1: We measure prosperity not just by our total GDP; not just by how many billionaires we produce
column2: but how well the typical family is doing -- whether they can go as far as their dreams and hard work will take them.

column1: And we understand that in this country
column2: people succeed when they have a chance to get a decent education and learn new skills -- and
column3: by the way
column4: so do the businesses that hire them or the companies that they start. (Applause.)

column1: We know that our economy grows when we support research into medical breakthroughs and new technologies that lead to the next Internet app or life-saving drug.

We know that our country is stronger when we can count on affordable health insurance and Medicare and Social Security. (Applause.) When we protect our kids from toxic dumping and mercury pollution. When there are rules to make sure we arenÃ¢ÂÂt taken advantage of by credit card companies and mortgage lenders and financial institutions. And we know these rules arenÃ¢ÂÂt just good for seniors
column2: or kids
column3: or consumers -- they're good for business
column4: too. They're part of what makes the market work.

column1: Look
column2: we donÃ¢ÂÂt expect government to solve all our problems
column3: and it shouldnÃ¢ÂÂt try. I learned from my mom that no education policy can take the place of a parentÃ¢ÂÂs love and affection. (Applause.) As a young man
column4: I worked with a group of Catholic churches who taught me that no poverty program can make as much of a difference as the kindness and commitment of a caring soul. (Applause.) Not every regulation is smart. Not every tax dollar is spent wisely. Not every person can be helped who refuses to help themselves.

column1: But thatÃ¢ÂÂs not an excuse to tell the vast majority of responsible
column2: hardworking Americans
column3: Ã¢ÂÂYouÃ¢ÂÂre on your own.Ã¢ÂÂ That unless youÃ¢ÂÂre lucky enough to have parents who can lend you money
column4: you may not be able to go to college. That even if you pay your premiums every month
column5: youÃ¢ÂÂre out of luck if an insurance company decides to drop your coverage when you need it most.

column1: ThatÃ¢ÂÂs not how we built America. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs not who we are. We built this country together. (Applause.) We built this country together.
We built railroads and highways; the Hoover Dam
column2: the Golden Gate Bridge -- together. We sent my grandfatherÃ¢ÂÂs generation to college on the GI Bill -- together. We instituted a minimum wage and worker safety laws -- together. Together
column3: we touched the surface of the moon
column4: unlocked the mystery of the atom
column5: connected the world through our own science and imagination. We did these things together -- not because they benefited any particular individual or group
column6: but because they made us all richer. Because they gave us all opportunity. Because they moved us forward together -- as one people
column7: as one nation. (Applause.)

column1: ThatÃ¢ÂÂs the true lesson of our past
column2: Ohio. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs the right vision for our future. And thatÃ¢ÂÂs why IÃ¢ÂÂm running for President. (Applause.)

column1: IÃ¢ÂÂm running to make sure that by the end of the decade
column2: more of our citizens hold a college degree than any other nation on Earth. (Applause.) I want to help our schools hire and reward the best teachers
column3: especially in math and science. (Applause.) I want to give two million more Americans the chance to go to community colleges and learn the skills that local businesses are looking for right now. In the 21st century
column4: higher education canÃ¢ÂÂt be a luxury -- it is an economic imperative that every American should be able to afford. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs the choice in this election. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs why IÃ¢ÂÂm running for President. (Applause.)

column1: IÃ¢ÂÂm running to make sure the next generation of high-tech manufacturing takes root in places like Columbus and Cleveland and Pittsburgh and Richmond. I want to stop rewarding businesses that ship jobs and profits overseas
column2: and start rewarding companies that create jobs right here in the United States of America. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs the choice in this election. (Applause.)

column1: IÃ¢ÂÂm running so that we can keep moving towards a future where we control our own energy. Our dependence on foreign oil is at its lowest point in 16 years. (Applause.) By the middle of the next decade
column2: our cars will average nearly 55 miles per gallon. Thousands of Americans have jobs
column3: right now
column4: because the production of renewal energy in this country has nearly doubled in just three years. (Applause.)

column1: So now is not the time to cut these investments to pay for another $4 billion giveaway to the oil companies. Now is the time to end the subsidies for an industry thatÃ¢ÂÂs rarely been more profitable. (Applause.) LetÃ¢ÂÂs double down on a clean energy future thatÃ¢ÂÂs never been more promising -- for our economy
column2: and for our security
column3: and for the safety of our planet. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs why IÃ¢ÂÂm running for President. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs the choice in this election
column4: Ohio. (Applause.)

column1: AUDIENCE: Four more years! Four more years!
THE PRESIDENT: For the first time in nine years
column2: there are no Americans fighting in Iraq. (Applause.) Osama bin Laden is no longer a threat to this country. (Applause.) Al Qaeda is on the path to defeat. And by 2014
column3: the war in Afghanistan will be over. (Applause.)

column1: America is safer and more respected because of the courage and selflessness of the United States Armed Forces. (Applause.) And as long as IÃ¢ÂÂm Commander-in-Chief
column2: this country will care for our veterans and serve our veterans as well as theyÃ¢ÂÂve served us -- (applause) -- because nobody who fights for this country should have to fight for a job or a roof over their heads when they come home. (Applause.)

column1: My opponent said it was Ã¢ÂÂtragicÃ¢ÂÂ to end the war in Iraq. He said he wonÃ¢ÂÂt set a timeline for ending the war in Afghanistan.
AUDIENCE: Booo --
THE PRESIDENT: I have
column2: and I intend to keep it. (Applause.) After a decade of war thatÃ¢ÂÂs cost us thousands of lives and over a trillion dollars
column3: the nation we need to build is our own. (Applause.) I will use half of what weÃ¢ÂÂre no longer spending on war to pay down the deficit
column4: and the other half to repair our roads and our bridges
column5: our runways and our wireless networks. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs the choice in this election -- to rebuild America. (Applause.)

column1: IÃ¢ÂÂm running to pay down our debt in a way thatÃ¢ÂÂs balanced and responsible. After inheriting a $1 trillion deficit
column2: I signed $2 trillion of spending cuts into law. And now I want to finish the job by streamlining government and cutting more waste
column3: and reforming our tax code so that it is simpler and fairer
column4: and asks the wealthiest Americans to pay a little bit more. (Applause.)

column1: My opponent wonÃ¢ÂÂt tell us how heÃ¢ÂÂd pay for his new
$5 trillion tax cut -- a tax cut that gives an average of $250
column2: 000 to every millionaire in this country.

column1: AUDIENCE: Booo --
THE PRESIDENT: But we know the bill for that tax cut will either be passed on to our children
column2: or it will be paid for by a whole lot of ordinary Americans. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what we know. And I refuse to let that happen again. (Applause.)

column1: I refuse to pay for another millionaireÃ¢ÂÂs tax cut by eliminating medical research projects into things like cancer and AlzheimerÃ¢ÂÂs disease. I refuse to pay for another tax cut by kicking children off of Head Start programs; or asking students to pay more for college; or eliminating health insurance for millions of poor and elderly and disabled Americans on Medicaid. (Applause.)
And as long as IÃ¢ÂÂm President of the United States
column2: I will never allow Medicare to be turned into a voucher that would end the program as we know it. (Applause.) We will not go back to the days when our citizens spent their golden years at the mercy of private insurance companies. We will reform Medicare -- not by shifting the cost of care to seniors
column3: but by reducing the spending that isnÃ¢ÂÂt making people healthier. (Applause.) ThatÃ¢ÂÂs whatÃ¢ÂÂs at stake in this election. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs whatÃ¢ÂÂs at stake
column4: Ohio.

column1: On issue after issue
column2: we canÃ¢ÂÂt afford to spend the next four years going backward. America doesnÃ¢ÂÂt need to refight the battles we just had over Wall Street reform and health care reform. On health care reform
column3: here is what I know: Allowing 2.5 million young people to stay on their parentsÃ¢ÂÂ health insurance plan -- that was the right thing to do. (Applause.) Cutting prescription drug costs for seniors -- that was the right thing to do. (Applause.) I will not go back to the days when insurance companies had unchecked power to cancel your policy
column4: or deny you coverage
column5: or charge women differently from men. WeÃ¢ÂÂre not going back there. WeÃ¢ÂÂre going forward. (Applause.)

column1: We donÃ¢ÂÂt need another political fight about ending a womanÃ¢ÂÂs right to choose
column2: or getting rid of Planned Parenthood -- (applause) -- or taking away access to affordable birth control. I want women to control their own health choices
column3: just like I want my daughters to have the same opportunities as your sons. (Applause.) We are not turning back the clock. We are moving forward. (Applause.)

column1: WeÃ¢ÂÂre not returning to the days when you could be kicked out of the United States military just because of who you are or who you love. (Applause.) That would be wrong for our national security
column2: and it would be a betrayal of our values.

column1: This should be the last election where multimillion-dollar donations speak louder than the voices of ordinary citizens. (Applause.) We need more checks on lobbyists and special interests
column2: not less.

column1: WeÃ¢ÂÂre not going to eliminate the EPA. WeÃ¢ÂÂre not going to roll back the bargaining rights that generations of workers fought for. (Applause.) ItÃ¢ÂÂs time to stop denying citizenship to responsible young people just because theyÃ¢ÂÂre the children of undocumented immigrants. (Applause.) This country is at its best when we harness the God-given talents of every individual; when we hear every voice; when we come together as one American family
column2: striving for the same dream.

column1: ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what weÃ¢ÂÂre fighting for. That's what we're fighting for
column2: Ohio. A bold America. A competitive America. A generous America. A forward-looking America
column3: where everybody has a chance to make of their life what they will. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what made us the envy of the world. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what makes us great. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs why IÃ¢ÂÂm running again for President of the United States. (Applause.)

column1: AUDIENCE: Four more years! Four more years!
THE PRESIDENT: And that is why I need your help. Ohio
column2: this election will be even closer than the last. Too many of our friends
column3: too many of our neighbors are still hurting because of this crisis. I've heard from too many people wondering why they haven't been able to get one of the jobs that have been created; why their home is still under water; why their family hasn't yet been touched by the recovery.

column1: The other side won't be offering these Americans a real answer to these questions. They won't offer a better vision or a new set of ideas. But they will be spending more money than we've ever seen before on negative ads
column2: on TV
column3: on radio
column4: in the mail
column5: on the Internet -- ads that exploit people's frustrations for my opponent's political gain. Over and over again
column6: they will tell you that America is down and out
column7: and they'll tell you who to blame
column8: and ask if youÃ¢ÂÂre better off than you were before the worst crisis in our lifetime.

column1: WeÃ¢ÂÂve seen that play before. But you know what? The real question -- the question that will actually make a difference in your life and in the lives of your children -- is not just about how weÃ¢ÂÂre doing today. ItÃ¢ÂÂs about how weÃ¢ÂÂll be doing tomorrow.

Will we better off if more Americans get a better education? ThatÃ¢ÂÂs the question. Will we better off if we depend less on foreign oil and more on our own ingenuity? That's the question. (Applause.) Will we better off if we start doing some nation-building right here at home? That's the question. Will we be better off if we bring down our deficit without gutting the very things we need to grow? When we look back four years from now
column2: or ten years from now
column3: or twenty years from now
column4: wonÃ¢ÂÂt we be better off if we have the courage to keep moving forward? (Applause.)

column1: ThatÃ¢ÂÂs the question in this election. That's the question in this election. And the outcome is entirely up to you. Now
column2: sure
column3: weÃ¢ÂÂll have to contend with even more negative ads
column4: with even more cynicism and nastiness
column5: and sometimes just plain foolishness. There will be more of that than we saw in the last campaign.

column1: But if there is one thing that we learned in 2008
column2: itÃ¢ÂÂs that nothing is more powerful than millions of voices calling for change. (Applause.) When enough of you knock on doors
column3: when you pick up phones
column4: when you talk to your friends
column5: when you decide that itÃ¢ÂÂs time for change to happen
column6: guess what? Change happens. Change comes to America. (Applause.)

column1: And thatÃ¢ÂÂs the spirit we need again. If people ask you what this campaign is about
column2: you tell them itÃ¢ÂÂs still about hope. You tell them itÃ¢ÂÂs still about change. You tell them itÃ¢ÂÂs still about ordinary people who believe that in the face of great odds
column3: we can make a difference in the life of this country. (Applause.)

column1: Because I still believe
column2: Ohio. I still believe that we are not as divided as our politics suggest. I still believe that we have more in common than the pundits tell us; that we're not Democrats or Republicans
column3: but Americans first and foremost. (Applause.) I still believe in you
column4: and IÃ¢ÂÂm asking you to keep believing in me. (Applause.) I told you in 2008 that I wasnÃ¢ÂÂt a perfect man
column5: and I would never be a perfect President. But I promised that I would always tell you what I thought. I would always tell you where I stood. And I would wake up every single day fighting for you as hard as I know how. (Applause.)

column1: And I have that kept that promise. I have kept that promise
column2: Ohio. And I will keep it so long as I have the honor of being your President. So if youÃ¢ÂÂre willing to stick with me
column3: if you're willing to fight with me
column4: and press on with me; if youÃ¢ÂÂre willing to work even harder in this election than you did in the last election
column5: I guarantee you -- we will move this country forward. (Applause.)

column1: We will finish what we started. We are still fired up. We are still ready to go. And we are going to remind the world once more just why it is that the United States of America is the greatest nation on Earth. (Applause.)
Thank you
column2: God bless you. God bless the United States of America.

column1: 499	"July 25
column2: 2010 Ã¢ÂÂ -- TAPPER: Secretary Geithner thanks for joining us. Good to see you.

column1: So
column2: the administration has had a number of successes after big battles
column3: stimulus
column4: health care legislation
column5: new rules for Wall Street
column6: but you have a big battle coming when it comes to the Bush tax cuts.

column1: If they remain in place
column2: as Republicans want
column3: it will cost three trillion dollars every ten years. The administration has said it wants to keep the ones for people who make under $200
column4: 000 a year
column5: individuals and $250
column6: 000 for couples.

column1: That will cost $2.5 trillion over 10 years.
Ben Bernanke the chairman of the Federal Reserve said that with the economic outlook unusually uncertain
column2: extending the Bush tax cuts would have a stimulative effect on the economy. Is he right?

column1: GEITHNER: I don't think it should be a battle
column2: Jake. You know
column3: what the President's proposing to do is to leave in place
column4: to extend tax cuts that go to more than 95 percent of working Americans and to leave in place tax cuts that are very important to incent businesses to hire new pe -- new employees and to invest in expanding output.

column1: We think that's a -- the -- it's a very strong package. We think it's the right package. We think it's fair. We think it's responsible.
Now
column2: we also think it's responsible to let the tax cuts expire that just go to 2 percent to 3 percent of Americans
column3: the highest earning Americans. We think that's the responsible thing to do because we need to make sure we can show the world that they're willing as a country now to start to make some progress bringing down our long -- our long-term deficits.

column1: TAPPER: Don't you think it will slow economic growth?
GEITHNER: No. Just letting those tax cuts that only go to 2 percent to 3 percent of Americans
column2: the highest earning Americans in the country expire. I do not believe it will have a negative effect on growth.

column1: TAPPER: This package that you're talking about pushing in Congress to -- to save the Bush tax cuts for people under $200
column2: 000 individuals and 250 for couples --

column1: GEITHNER: And in fact
column2: we go beyond that. Because you know
column3: we're proposing to extend the make or pay tax cut which also goes to 95 percent of working Americans. And a set of very important business tax cuts targeted for small businesses themselves
column4: expensing
column5: zero capital gains rate for investment in small businesses. These things
column6: we think
column7: are very helpful
column8: very powerful.

column1: TAPPER: And when are you talking about pushing that into Congress?
GEITHNER: Congress is on the verge of what we hope will be enactment of a very strong package of tax measures for small businesses and ways to help them get credit so they can expand.
TAPPER: So
column2: before the election?

column1: GEITHNER: Oh
column2: absolutely.

column1: TAPPER: A number of Senate democrats
column2: moderate Senate democrats have said that they oppose repealing or allowing to expire the Bush tax cuts on the wealthiest Americans that they think that would be harmful to growth.

column1: Are you guys going to have the votes to get through the package you want which is focused more on middle and lower income America?
GEITHNER: Oh absolutely. I believe we will.
TAPPER: Some in the administration and internal discussions are talking about maybe just keeping all the Bush tax cuts for a year or two. Those aren't -- that's not going to happen?
GEITHNER: I don't believe it should and I don't believe it will. Again
column2: because what the president's proposed is to make sure we're leaving them in place for the people that need the most and can make the most difference in helping make sure this economy comes back. That we heal the damage caused by this crisis.

column1: TAPPER: Job creation has not gone as well as you hoped. What more can you do? I know there's this small business lending initiative. What more can you do given the lack of appetite on Capitol Hill for any spending programs? Any more stimulus?
GEITHNER: Well you know
column2: the President's proposed a very strong package of help for small businesses which you just referred to. He'd support giving more support to states so they can keep teachers in the classroom.

column1: TAPPER: Fifty billion dollars in emergency spending but the Congress has not acted on that.
GEITHNER: They haven't yet
column2: but we can (inaudible) case for doing it. They're going to
column3: we're going to keep at that. But right now
column4: the best thing the government can do in addition to those things
column5: is help create the conditions for the private sector to start to invest in hiring again.

column1: Now
column2: we've seen six months of positive job growth by the private sector. That's pretty good.

column1: TAPPER: By the private sector.
GEITHNER: Pretty good this early in a recession.
TAPPER: Although you count in the public sector with the layoffs and the census jobs.
GEITHNER: But only because of census. But you know
column2: what matters is -- is the private sector starting to hire people
column3: add back hours and that's what's critical.

column1: And you're seeing that happen now. Now we want it -- we want to see it happen at a faster pace. But I think most people understand that you know
column2: this was a deep crisis. The scars ran very deep. Devastating damage. It's going to take time to repair that damage
column3: take time to grow out of this. But we're making progress.

column1: TAPPER: In 2009 when President Obama talked about unemployment insurance extensions he talked about how it was paid for. This time
column2: it was not paid for
column3: the $34 billion in unemployment insurance extensions became added to the national debt.

column1: Republicans on Capitol Hill argued that they wanted to pay for it and they supported it but they just wanted it offset by spending cuts.
Given the fact that we're going to be -- we're going to have unemployment for the foreseeable future
column2: high unemployment. Isn't it the fiscally responsible thing to do to not treat this as emergency spending but treat this as something we know is coming down the pike so we're not just laying this burden on our future generations?

column1: GEITHNER: I don't think so. In a crisis that was this bad and a recession that was that deep. With this amount of lasting damage
column2: scars from recovery
column3: it's appropriate to treat these things as emergencies."	0

column1: 501	"March 27
column2: 2011 Ã¢ÂÂ -- AMANPOUR: This week -- furious mobs kill more western civiliansin Afghanistan. And as the death toll mounts
column3: the Florida pastor whostarted it by burning a Koran says that he has no regrets.

column1: (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
TERRY JONES: We do not feel responsible
column2: no.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
AMANPOUR: Our correspondent is with American soldiers in thedeadliest firefight against the Taliban in months.
Then in Libya
column2: despite U.S. and NATO bombing runs meant to savethem
column3: rebels are in retreat from Gadhafi's forces. Is America in abattle it can't win? Three wars and billions of dollars later
column4: we'lldiscuss all of this with the president's former national securityadviser in his first interview since leaving the White House.

column1: Also
column2: who will pay for it all?

column1: The jobs picture is getting brighter. But could rising prices
column2: revolution
column3: and a nuclear disaster kill the recovery? And as partisanbickering meets the bloated budget
column4: will the government shut downlater this week?

column1: (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
REP. MIKE PENCE R-IND.: I say
column2: shut it down.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
AMANPOUR: Two top senators join us for a This Week debate.
ANNOUNCER: Live from the Newseum in Washington
column2: This Week startsright now.

column1: AMANPOUR: Welcome to the program. Right now
column2: the Middle East isfalling further into chaos
column3: violence and uncertainty as the UnitedStates grapples with fresh challenges in two of its three wars.President Obama
column4: who ran as the anti-war candidate
column5: now finds himselfstruggling to defend new American military action overseas
column6: while therapidly changing situations in Libya
column7: Afghanistan
column8: and across theMiddle East pose new threats to U.S. security and credibility.

column1: I'll be talking to my colleagues Mike Boettcher and Nick Schifrinin Afghanistan
column2: and Jeffrey Kaufman and Alex Marquardt on the frontlines in Libya.

column1: Let's turn first to Afghanistan
column2: where a firefight along thePakistan border brought one of the deadliest days for American troopsin months
column3: and where the battle for hearts and minds may have beenvirtually erased overnight at the hands of a fringe pastor in Florida.

column1: After months of threatening to burn a copy of the Koran
column2: PastorTerry Jones and his handful of followers finally did just that. Thisdeliberately provocative act received little media attention here inthe United States
column3: but it did spread like wildfire online. And withindays
column4: protests in Afghanistan turned deadly.

column1: ABC's Mike Boettcher is embedded with the 101st AirborneDivision. Mike was the lone reporter on that bloody six-day offensivealong the border.
Mike
column2: how bad was that?

column1: MIKE BOETTCHER
column2: ABC CORRESPONDENT: In 30 years of covering war
column3: I have never seen such withering fire. And soldiers who have beendeployed four or five times will tell you the same thing.

column1: A high price was paid. Six U.S. soldiers were killed. Six werewounded. Two Afghan national army were killed. And seven Afghanswere wounded in this battle
column2: and the battle continues as we speak
column3: right now.

column1: This is a significant engagement because it marks a turning pointor a change in strategy along the Pakistan border where bases havebeen closed in recent months
column2: small combat outposts. The U.S. nowsays that they're taking a more mobile strategy
column3: going to areas theyhaven't been before
column4: and going after the Taliban. They're going tocarry this through
column5: through the spring and summer and expect to seevery heavy fighting in the east part of the country in the comingyear. Christiane?

column1: AMANPOUR: Meantime
column2: in cities across Afghanistan today
column3: morescenes of rage and violence in response to that Florida pastor'sdecision to burn a Koran. The situation does present a grave newproblem for the United States. And ABC's Nick Schifrin joins me nowfrom Kabul.

column1: Nick
column2: today
column3: General Petraeus had to come out and specificallycondemn the burning of that Koran. How bad is it there?

column1: NICK SCHIFRIN
column2: ABC CORRESPONDENT: Well
column3: we've seen threeprotests three days in a row now
column4: massive protests
column6: 000 miles awayfrom that Koran-burning. Today thousands of Afghans in the streets ofsouthern Afghanistan and eastern Afghanistan
column7: they were burning U.S.flags and chanting ""death to President Obama.""

column1: Now David Petraeus came out with that statement today
column2: but thereis one good piece of news. The Afghan police did not shoot into thecrowds like they did yesterday. On Friday
column3: they were supposed to bethe first line of defense around a U.N. building where seven U.N.workers were killed. They were not able to keep those workers -- keepthose protesters out of that U.N. building.

column1: And U.S. officials are deeply concerned about that
column2: because theplace where that happened
column3: Mazar-i-Sharif
column4: is the first city that issupposed to transfer to Afghan control
column5: to transfer to Afghan policecontrol in three months.

column1: And U.S. and U.N. officials are worried that this incident is asign that the police aren't ready to take control -- Christiane. AMANPOUR: Nick
column2: thank you. And obviously we'll keep monitoringthat situation.

column1: And now we turn to Libya. America's newest war is entering itsthird week of bombing
column2: and still there is no sign that Colonel Gadhafiis stepping down. And now more bad news for the makeshift rebelforces. NATO warplanes seem to have mistakenly bombed one of theirconvoys. Another blow in a week where they've seen most of theirgains against Gadhafi wiped out.

column1: Just Monday
column2: the rebels were within striking distance ofcapturing Gadhafi's home town of Sirt. And they had the capitalTripoli in their sites. But by week's end
column3: they were beating a hastyretreat with Gadhafi forces once again in control of the long stretchof coastline.

column1: Our reporters in Libya have been tracking all of this. JeffreyKaufman just arrived in Tripoli
column2: and Alex Marquardt joins us from therebel bastion of Benghazi. Let's start with Jeffrey.

column1: Jeffrey
column2: in Tripoli
column3: any signs of the tension or that maybeGadhafi is on his last few days?

column1: JEFFREY KAUFMAN
column2: ABC CORRESPONDENT: Well
column3: actually
column4: just momentsago we heard a NATO warplane flying above us. We didn't hear anybombs dropping. But
column5: you know
column6: it's actually remarkably normal here.You can see the traffic behind me on the highway.

column1: As we came in
column2: we saw a lot of military checkpoints
column3: long linesfor gasoline
column4: a lot of shops closed. But the tension is not palpableat this point. The rebels are clearly on the retreat. Really
column5: whatwe're seeing now in Libya is a divided country
column6: almost two countries:the rebel-held east and the Gadhafi-held west.

column1: And neither one seems to have the strength right now to unseatthe other. Certainly the rebels aren't organized enough
column2: mannedenough
column3: or skilled enough to come to Tripoli. And Gadhafi
column4: it seems
column5: the coalition will not let him go further east and retake thosevaluable oil fields in those areas.

column1: So right now the word to describe this revolution
column2: weeks into it
column3: is stalemate -- Christiane.

column1: AMANPOUR: Jeffrey
column2: thank you. You mentioned stalemate and alsodivided country. And joining me now from the rebel-held city ofBenghazi is ABC's Alex Marquardt.

column1: Alex
column2: how are these rebels dealing with being unable to reallycapitalize on all of the help the no-fly zone is giving them?

column1: ALEX MARQUARDT
column2: ABC CORRESPONDENT: Christiane
column3: they're not ableto capitalize because they are outmanned
column4: they are outgunned
column5: and theyare not able to organize. They don't have the weapons to faceGadhafi's superior firepower. So they're forced to beat a retreat.

column1: They don't have any sort of leadership. So when they retreat
column2: they do so in a disorganized fashion
column3: very quickly
column4: no one showingthem how to hold the line
column5: how to retreat.

column1: So we're seeing now glimmers of hope that they'll be able toorganize. Experienced officers on the frontlines trying to corralthese groups into units
column2: keeping people back without any sort oftraining.

column1: And for the first time on the frontlines on Friday we saw thegeneral who is technically in charge of these forces
column2: General AbdelFattah Yunis
column3: welcomed with a hero's welcome. So signs that there issome leadership coming to the frontlines that is so desperately neededby these rebels.

column1: AMANPOUR: Alex
column2: thank you so much.

column1: Rarely has a president faced a foreign policy puzzle thiscomplex. President Obama
column2: of course
column3: came into office pledging torepair America's relationship with the Muslim world. Now thatrelationship is tested like never before. Joining me to discuss thepath forward
column4: the president's former national security adviser
column5: General Jim Jones. He's now a senior fellow at the Bipartisan PolicyCenter.

column1: Thank you for joining us.
JONES: Thank you
column2: Christiane. Good to be here.

column1: AMANPOUR: Let's first talk about Afghanistan
column2: since that seemsto be a real crisis again at the moment. This pastor who burned theKoran
column3: is unrepentant. Do you think despite the freedoms envisionedand expressed specifically in the American Constitution
column4: he should nothave burned that Koran?

column1: JONES: Oh
column2: I don't think he should have done that at all. Ithink it's extremely irresponsible
column3: and look at what it has led to.

column1: AMANPOUR: You also heard Mike Boettcher's report
column2: a fiercefirefight along the Pakistani border
column3: one of the worst that theAmericans had been involved in. Right now
column4: do you think the UnitedStates forces can pull down significantly in July?

column1: JONES: Well
column2: I think that there can be and there will be somereduction of force in keeping with the agreement made at Portugal atthe NATO summit in December to target 2014 as
column3: in President Karzai'sown words at the London Conference
column4: ""This is when I want to be able tocontrol my entire country.""

column1: AMANPOUR: But can it be done responsibly
column2: if you'd like?

column1: JONES: Yes
column2: I think so. I think it can be done responsibly.And we'll have to see what it looks like. A lot of it hinges on whathappens on the other side of the border with our friends
column3: the -- ourneighbors the Pakistanis.

column1: If Pakistan turns to what some of us think they should have donemore effectively for a long period of time now
column2: attacking and removingthose safe havens that cause us so much difficulties
column3: and if we canget some sort of coordination with their forces
column4: then I think you canin fact...

column1: (CROSSTALK)
AMANPOUR: You say if. You don't seem convinced that they'replaying their part.
JONES: Well
column2: I don't -- I'm not convinced. I think there wassome good progress made in the Swat Valley and in North Waziristan ayear or so ago. But it hasn't been sustained. There still seems tobe that reluctance to engage comprehensively and buy into an overallplan that would
column3: I think
column4: really help Pakistan in the long term.

column1: AMANPOUR: All right. General Jones
column2: stay with us because upnext we will talk about Libya. Will Libya become Obama's Iraq
column3: assome are now suggesting? And it's a question you'll hear more andmore in the coming days. I will ask General Jones if he sees an endin sight.

column1: (COMMERCIAL BREAK)
(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
ROBERT GATES
column2: DEFENSE SECRETARY: There will be no American bootson the ground in Libya. Deposing the Gadhafi regime
column3: as welcome asthat eventuality would be
column4: is not part of the military mission.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)

AMANPOUR: Defense Secretary Robert Gates testifying on CapitolHill Thursday. He is on the record saying that stopping the violencein Libya is not a vital national interest of the United States. ButAmerica is in the game now. And the big questions
column2: for how long? Andto what end? Let's bring back retired General Jim Jones
column3: who wasPresident Obama's first national security adviser.

column1: Welcome back again. On Libya
column2: Secretary Gates has said on thisprogram and on several last week
column3: that it was not in the vitalinterest of the United States. Do you agree?

column1: JONES: I agree with that.
AMANPOUR: You agree that it's not in the vital interest?
JONES: I agree that it's not a vital interest in the sense thatit affects the security -- the vital security of the nation. But weare part of an alliance. We are one of the global leaders
column2: if not theglobal leader. And we have to do -- it is in the vital interest --more in the vital interest of Europeans
column3: when you consider the effectsof massive immigration
column4: the effects of terror
column5: the effects of the oilmarket.

column1: AMANPOUR: So the United States is now in it. You can call itwhat you want. But it's a third armed conflict.
JONES: We're a part of it. We are transitioning to a supportingpart
column2: only the United States could have gotten there as quickly as itdid.

column1: AMANPOUR: The United States is making a great fanfare about nowgiving over to NATO. But you were a former SACEUR
column2: a former NATOcommander. NATO
column3: to all intents and purposes
column4: is an Americanorganization. It's run by an American commander. The chain ofcommand is American. The biggest command and control and resourcesare American. This is still an American-led operation

column1: 502	"Updated Thursday
column2: October 25th

column1: Asked about fair pay for women during the second presidential debate
column2: President Barack Obama was quick to bring up the first piece of legislation he signed into law -- the Lilly Ledbetter Fair Pay Act.

column1: Audience member Katherine Fenton asked Obama
column2: ""In what new ways to you intend to rectify the inequalities in the workplace
column3: specifically regarding females making only 72 percent of what their male counterparts earn?""

column1: Obama talked about being raised by a single mom who put herself through school and of his grandmother
column2: who worked her way up from a bank secretary to a vice president but ""hit the glass ceiling.""

column1: She trained people who would end up becoming her bosses during the course of her career. She didn't complain. That's not what you did in that generation
column2: he said at the debate at Hofstra University on Oct. 16
column3: 2012. ""And this is one of the reasons why one of the first -- the first bill I signed was something called the Lilly Ledbetter bill.""

column1: Romney responded by saying at one point he had more women in senior leadership positions than any other governor and that he wanted to help more women find jobs.
Obama jumped in
column2: saying
column3: ""Katherine
column4: I just want to point out that when Gov. Romney's campaign was asked about the Lilly Ledbetter bill
column5: whether he supported it
column6: he said
column7: Ã¢ÂÂI'll get back to you.Ã¢ÂÂ And that's not the kind of advocacy that women need in any economy.""

column1: Did Romney and his campaign really refuse to say whether he supported the law? Sort of.
The law
column2: which Obama signed on Jan. 29
column4: made it easier for workers to pursue wage discrimination claims but received little Republican support in Congress. It updated 1960s civil rights and age discrimination laws to reset the statute of limitations on such claims with each new paycheck. In 2007
column5: the Supreme Court had ruled in Ledbetter vs. Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co. that the 180-day statute of limitations started from the day an employer made the decision to discriminate Ã¢ÂÂ making it harder for employees who claimed such discrimination later to get relief
column6: such as back pay.

column1: What did Romney have to say about it? For a previous fact-check in May
column2: the Obama campaign directed us to a couple media reports.

column1: In an April 2012 conference call covered by a Washington Post blogger
column2: a Huffington Post reporter asked an unnamed Romney adviser whether Romney supported the Lilly Ledbetter Act. The adviser responded
column3: ""Sam (Stein)
column4: weÃ¢ÂÂll get back to you on that.""

column1: Later
column2: Romney spokeswoman Andrea Saul clarified in an email
column3: ""He supports pay equity and is not looking to change current law.""

column1: The second piece the Obama campaign showed us was a Romney interview by Diane Sawyer of ABC News. Sawyer asked Romney
column2: "" If you were president Ã¢ÂÂ you had been president Ã¢ÂÂ would you have signed the Lilly Ledbetter Law?""

column1: RomneyÃ¢ÂÂs response:
Romney: ""It's certainly a piece of legislation I have no intention of changing. I wasn't there three years ago Ã¢ÂÂ""
Sawyer: ""But would you have signed it?""
Romney: ""... I'm not going to go back and look at all the prior laws and say had I been there which ones would I have supported and signed
column2: but I certainly support equal pay for women and Ã¢ÂÂ and have no intention of changing that law
column3: don't think there's a reason to.""

column1: Here
column2: Romney did refuse to say whether he would have signed the bill into law. But he also said he has ""no intention of changing that law.""

column1: Our ruling
Obama said that when asked whether he would have signed the Lilly Ledbetter Act into law
column2: Romney's campaign said
column3: ""I'll get back to you."" His point was that the campaign was dodging the question.

column1: Indeed
column2: a Romney adviser did say earlier this year that he would ""get back"" to a reporter about whether he supported the Lilly Ledbetter Act. A spokeswoman then said he would not change it
column3: and Romney later said he ""certainly support(s) equal pay for women
column4: and has ""no intention of changing that law.""

column1: So Obama is correct about the initial statement
column2: but Romney later clarified by saying he wouldn't change the law. We rate Obama's claim Mostly True.

column1: CORRECTION: A previous version of this item said the Supreme Court's Ledbetter decision made it ""impossible for employees who learned of such discrimination later to get relief
column2: such as back pay."" In fact
column3: the court declined to address the question of whether employees who learned of discrimination after the statute of limitations expired would be protected under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964."	0
